title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: I'LL TAKE MANHATTAN. By Judith Krantz. 437 pages. Crown. $18.95. THE thing to do is to be positive, to look for the good in Judith Krantz's new novel, ''I'll Take Manhattan.'' Don't go searching for blemishes. Never mind that on page 3 beautiful Maxime Emma Amberville is described as moving ''with the tadpole agility of the born New Yorker'' as ''she slapped her shoulder bag down on a customs table and looked around impatiently for an inspector.'' It makes perfectly good sense if you don't stop to think about it.

Byrd of West Virginia, both spoke from portable lecterns sitting atop their desks.

Gene Orza, the associate general counsel of the players' union, said another hearing would be held today and a decision was expected ''within a month.''

title: HERS
description: ALLOW me to be unfashionable for a few minutes. You see, I can't help liking Freud. This may have something to do with a certain afternoon in the late 60's, in the psychology library of the Hebrew University of Jerusalem. I've forgotten which essay of Freud's I was reading (which may in itself be a Freudian event). I'm pretty sure it was not the one on sexual symbolism, which is where swords and towers are neatly pigeonholed as penises, and purses and boxes as wombs. But whichever essay it was, I do remember that it was both fascinating and funny. I became completely absorbed in it, my purse and notebooks forgotten on the table in front of me. So absorbed, in fact, that it came as something of a shock when I raised my head at the end of the essay to discover that while I'd been reading Freud, someone had stolen my purse.

With the first buds of spring, the impression is reinforced.

title: JAZZ: ROACH PLUS STRINGS
description: MAX ROACH'S Double Quartet, which is making its first club appearance at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street, through Sunday, is a combination of Mr. Roach's regular quartet (trumpet, tenor saxaphone, bass and drums) and a string quartet using the standard classical instrumentation (two violins, viola and cello). Mr. Roach is attempting to remove the strings from their customary role in a jazz context as a background cushion and, although they are not yet always placed on an equal footing with Mr. Roach's two-man horn section, the possibilities are already evident in the new repertory of arrangements written for the combined groups.

description: Twenty-six of the 55 college players who tested positive for cocaine or marijuana at a scouting camp in January were picked Tuesday in the National Football League draft. Two were taken on the first round, four others went on the second round and two more in the third.

title: Striking Out

Now the citizens of Nashua, N.H., home of a Pirate farm club, have taken a cue from their big league cousins in Pittsburgh. Though hometown exhibitions against major-leaguers are usually big money-makers for the farms, the Nashua team has been forced to cancel its May 12 game against the Bucs, having sold only 150 tickets to it.

title: Mayday! and May Day
description: Those who live by secrecy can also perish by it. The Chernobyl nuclear disaster may have begun as early as last Friday, but the Soviet Union suppressed all news of it until Sweden reported radiation on Monday. That delay in warning neighboring countries of the impending catastrophe alarmed and misled people from the Elbe to the Urals. Mikhail Gorbachev cannot win confidence in his pledges to reduce nuclear weapons if he forfeits his neighbors' trust over the peaceful uses of nuclear energy.

title: Q&A
description: Q. The paint on my inside windowsills has chipped off, exposing rusty metal under the paint. I want to repaint, but will enamel adhere to this rusty metal? A. Not if you paint right over the rust. The first thing you should do is use sandpaper, steel wool or a wire brush to get off all of the rust. Then apply a coat of metal primer, preferably the type made for applying over rust. Allow this to dry hard, then paint with two coats of enamel. Q. The cedar shingles on our house, which was built in 1947, will not hold paint, at least on one side which faces the bay that is nearby. We have been considering putting up aluminum siding, but a friend suggested that as a less-expensive alternative we should take all the paint off the shingles and then apply a regular shingle stain. How can all the old paint be removed, and is this a viable alternative to re-siding? A. Getting all the old paint off is quite a job but it can be done. You can take it off yourself with a water-wash, semipaste chemical paint remover, but it will be a great deal of work and you will need many gallons of remover. You would be better off hiring a professional contractor who has one of those high-pressure washers used with a chemical remover to get the old paint off. Removing the paint and then applying a stain is a viable alternative to re-siding, and with stain you will never again have a peeling problem (that is, if you use a true stain; not one of the ''heavy bodied'' types that are really paint).

title: A CHAMBER CELEBRATION OF CONCERT NO. 1,000
description: A milestone in New York's musical life was passed last night at Alice Tully Hall, where the 17-year-old Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center put on its 1,000th concert. It was not the completely solemn occasion that one might expect from an organization in the serious middle-teen years, but something more on the order of a musicians' house party. Naturally, the goings on cannot be discussed in any critical sense and yet the history of music in our time would be the loser should these proceedings be left unchronicled.

title: DEBATE ON HALFWAY HOUSES FOR THE MENTALLY ILL, ON 13

PREMATURE APPLAUSE, DESTROYER OF MUSICAL MOOD
description: EARLIER this season, I sat with a rapt audience at Carnegie Hall, listening to Mahler's Symphony No. 9. Written during the composer's final illness, the symphony provides one of the most difficult, haunting yet ultimately rewarding musical experiences in the repertory. When the final notes of the closing Adagio dissipate into air, the silence should be as eloquent as the sounds have been - a charged residue, if you like; a silence that is a musical statement in itself, transfigured by what has gone before. At Carnegie, Mahler's silence, so hard won, lasted barely a second. Somebody shouted ''Bravo!,'' the audience responded reflexively, and one left the hall frustrated, rudely shaken from an engrossing dream.

title: STRAWBERRY LEADS METS TO 11TH IN ROW
description: The Mets won another game tonight, almost routinely beating the Atlanta Braves, 8-1. They had the necessary elements in proper order: Dwight Gooden pitched typically well, Darryl Strawberry had a career-high five hits and drove in three runs, the offense rapped the sagging Braves for 13 hits. And the streak continues. Now, it is 11 consecutive victories, matching the club record set in 1969 and tied in 1972. The Mets finished April with a 13-3 record, the best start in their history. Perhaps the time for comparisons is here.

title: ESI INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
THEATER: 'THE BOYS IN AUTUMN'
description: WITH the arrival of ''The Boys in Autumn,'' Bernard Sabath's new play at the Circle in the Square, the 1985-86 Broadway season has reached its official close. While this season never did produce any cutthroat competition for the honor of best play, the worst play sweepstakes is being bitterly contested right up to the final hour. ''The Boys in Autumn,'' a terminally innocuous speculation about Huckleberry Finn and Tom Sawyer in middle age, almost makes one long for ''The Boys of Winter,'' a Vietnam war drama that had been the prize 1985-86 turkey until this point. Let's be grateful that the season has ended before anyone could write ''The Boys of Spring'' or turn Roger Kahn's good book ''The Boys of Summer'' into a flop musical.

title: CONCERT: DA CAMERA
description: A CHAMBER ensemble called Da Camera introduced itself at Town Hall Monday evening with a striking new piece for solo clarinet and tape, ''Crossroads,'' by Gregory Levin. James Campbell, alone on stage, played tentative, then piercing or songful calls and cries on the A clarinet; the sounds were taped as they emerged, and played back in a mix with a prerecorded tape of the same lines played on a B flat instrument.

title: Tyson Bout Moved
description: The Rangers' surprisingly strong showing in the Stanley Cup playoffs has knocked the scheduled heavyweight bout between Mike Tyson and Mitch Green out of Madison Square Garden May 20, forcing the promoters to search for a new site. If the Rangers get past the Montreal Canadiens, they will be playing a game in the Stanley Cup final May 20, and although there is a chance the team will be eliminated in the semifinal round, the promoter, Don King, and H.B.O., which will telecast the fight, were unwilling to risk having to find a new site at the last minute. Although no new site was announced, it was considered likely that the fight would be moved to Albany, where Tyson, who has a big following in the area, has fought before.

title: MUSIC: STONE'S ''MAE YAO'
description: CARL STONE, an electronic-music composer from Los Angeles, has been known -to this writer, at least - as one committed to the kind of ''process piece'' whose exposition falls uneasily between the inexorable and the predictable. In other words, like the early Steve Reich, Mr. Stone would set a sequence in motion and the piece would then be made up of the sometimes-too-obvious working out of the procedures inherent in the initial idea.

title: CORRECTION
description: A diagram of graphite-moderated nuclear reactors yesterday with articles on the accident in the Soviet Union misstated the function of graphite. As a moderator, graphite slows neutrons so they will split uranium nuclei. It is the control rods that reduce fission to a controllable rate by absorbing neutrons.

title: Energy II
description: Those who complain about the inefficiency of Government workers might like to know that Washington's fastest typist is Cristina Valentine, personal assistant to Deputy Secretary of State John C. Whitehead.

title: Energy I
description: Supporters of alternative technologies say the Soviet reactor accident underscores the need for continuing development of safer means of generating electric power, among them wind power, which has been given short shrift by the Reagan Administration.

title: TYSON FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-l stock split effected April 15.

title: A BIG EARTHQUAKE JOLTS MEXICO
description: A major earthquake shook the capital and four coastal states today, creating panic reminiscent of that caused by a catastrophic tremor last September.

Time of Gloom
description: The Snowden case is far from the only headache for Leslie Combs these days. Derby Week has usually been a time of pride and hope for Spendthrift Farm, which has bred and stood at stud several Derby winners, but the last year has been the unhappiest in its history.

title: CALAMITY HIGHLIGHTS OLD REACTOR-DESIGN DEBATE
description: The Soviet nuclear disaster has brought to the fore a debate regarding reactor design that began almost a half century ago during the development of the University of Chicago ''pile'' that produced the world's first chain reaction.

ARX INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

title: CABARET: JACKEE HARRY
description: JACKEE HARRY, a star of the television comedy series ''227,'' jokingly describes her cabaret act as ''New York girl makes good, goes to Hollywood, and goes crazy.'' The remark is typical of the blunt, sassy humor that runs through her show, which plays at Sweetwater's (170 Amsterdam Avenue, at 67th Street) through May 3.

title: BSD BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DROP BIGGEST IN 2 YEARS
description: Orders to factories for manufactured goods fell 2.3 percent in March, with civilian demand declining at its steepest rate in almost six years, the Commerce Department said today.

title: EXCERPTS FROM DECISION ON RACE AND JURY PANELS
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision today making it easier for black criminal defendants to keep prosecutors from excluding blacks from their juries. Associate Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. wrote the opinion. Chief Justice Warren E. Burger and Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist wrote dissents.

title: THE SOVIET SECRECY
description: To the world outside, almost as striking as the nuclear accident that sent radioactive debris over hundreds of miles, was the extraordinary Soviet effort to restrict information about it. It was a reflexive retreat into secrecy that again seemed to show the Kremlin loath to concede any failing before its people and a hostile world.

title: CHIEF OF MISSILE DEFENSE PROJECT SEEKS TO RESHAPE POLICY ON COSTS
description: The director of the program to explore a defense against ballistic missiles suggested today that a policy limiting the cost of such defenses be replaced by a more subjective standard: that they be simply ''affordable.''

title: REAGAN VIEW AWAITED
description: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d encouraged Republican senators today to continue to work on tax-revision legislation, but Mr. Baker said he could not provide President Reagan's endorsement of the new approach being considered by the Senate Finance Committee.

title: TRACOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

title: CITY IN CONFLICT WITH U.S. UNIT OVER APARTHEID
description: A new Federal policy has cast doubt on New York City's ability to require bidders for some city contracts to abide by a local anti-apartheid law, Mayor Koch said yesterday.

title: CCX INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

title: Restructuring At RCA/Ariola
description: RCA/Ariola, the record company, announced a major restructuring of its activiities yesterday designed to give more independence to its various operating units. The restructuring, conceived by Elliot Goldman, the president and chief executive of RCA/Ariola, the nation's third-largest record company, would add three individual operating units to the existing two.

title: '87 BUDGET SNAGS ON A SENATE VOTE
description: The Senate, in a move that could hinder chances for a Republican compromise on the budget, voted this evening to restore the Work Incentive Program, one of the few programs the Senate Budget Committee proposed to end.

title: S.E.C. Cites Stock Fraud
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission charged today that the Laser Arms Corporation was a ''bogus company'' that had sold 940,000 worthless shares of stock on the over-the-counter market beginning in December 1985.

title: IMS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The share earnings reflect 2-for-1 stock split paid last month.

title: BLUES ELIMINATE MAPLE LEAFS
description: Kevin LaVallee, who had been benched the last two games, scored in the third period tonight to send the St. Louis Blues to the Stanley Cup semifinals with a 2-1 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs.

title: Man Seized in Slaying Of Woman in Subway
description: A Brooklyn man was charged yesterday evening with the murder of an 82-year-old woman during a purse-snatching April 12 on an elevated train platform in the Bushwick section.

title: Jets' Offensive Line In Line for Overhaul
description: The entire Jet offensive line was called to account today by Mike Hickey, the man who led the club's drafting Tuesday of four offensive linemen among its 11 choices.

title: On Being Hated
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN FAVORS EASING PAY LAW IN CONSTRUCTION
description: President Reagan is endorsing a move to weaken the minimum-wage requirements for construction workers on Government projects, Administration officials said today.

title: The Congressman at the Bridge
description: Who ordained that the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, which spans the entrance to New York Harbor, should be toll-free eastbound? No less authority than the Congress of the United States, that's who.

description: b-Includes a gain of $48,000, or 3 cents a share, from a change in accounting for pensions. c-Net loss

title: Columbia Establishes Japan Business Center
description: A Center on Japanese Economy and Business has been established at the Columbia University Graduate School of Business with a $1 million gift from the trading company Sumitomo Corporation of America.

title: CONCERT: BAVARIAN SYMPHONY
description: COLIN DAVIS brought his Bavarian Radio Symphony -clumsily billed as the ''Bavarian Symphony Orchestra of Munich,'' although hundreds of records have been sold here under its correct name - to Avery Fisher Hall for two concerts Sunday and Monday.

title: Technology; New Approach In Computers
description: MANY computer scientists believe that the next big increase in computer speed will come not by doing individual calculations faster and faster, but by doing many of them at the same time. Now, the Thinking Machines Corporation, a Cambridge, Mass., company, has carried this belief to the furthest extent yet. It introduced a computer yesterday that contains 64,000 processors, each capable of doing calculations simultaneously.

title: Sator Stands the Heat
description: It was a moment that invited gloating. Not a person in the interview room on Sunday night would have blamed Ted Sator if he had leaned back in his chair, scanned the assembled press and said, ''So, you didn't think I could coach, huh?''

title: KOCH IS PUSHING BILL TO TOUGHEN DISCLOSURE LAW
description: Saying that recent allegations of corruption in city government demanded ''prompt'' action, Mayor Koch and the City Council majority leader, Peter F. Vallone, agreed on legislation yesterday to strengthen the financial disclosure laws for city employees.

title: INDONESIA VS. PRESS: TWAIN CAN'T MEET
description: When Joop Ave was the Indonesian Consul in New York 20 years ago, the most common question he got asked was, ''Where in Bali is Indonesia?''

description: The House gave final Congressional approval today to emergency legislation reviving the Federal Housing Administration's authority to insure home mortgages.

description: Wendy's International Inc., the fast-food chain operator, said it had agreed to sell certain assets of Wendy's Capital Corporation, a subsidiary that finances its franchise restaurants, to an undisclosed buyer for more than $60 million.

description: See accompanying notes for special items.(Loss) * Loss in year-earlier period.

title: Europe Air Rules Shift
description: The European Court of Justice ruled today that price regulation of French airlines violates the European Community's founding treaty. The decision could accelerate deregulation of Europe's airline industry.

Market Place; Steinberg's Lilco Move
description: THE nuclear accident in the Soviet Union, which may have clouded the future of commercial nuclear power in the United States and elsewhere, and which has driven utility stocks down sharply, has made Saul P. Steinberg's recent purchase of a 6.3 percent stake in the Long Island Lighting Company even more intriguing.

title: Advertising; W.R. Grace Challenge Of Networks' Policy
description: The three commercial TV networks generally do not accept commercials on controversial subjects, which they consider a proper matter for their news departments. They all turned down an elaborate spot that Lowe Marschalk did for W.R. Grace & Company's campaign against Government deficit spending.

title: ROOKIE BLUNDER ENDS OILER REIGN
description: When he pondered the possibilities inherent in this seventh and decisive game of the Smythe Division championship, the Oilers' goaltender, Grant Fuhr, shook his head and muttered, ''Anything can happen.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, MAY 1, 1986
description: International A Soviet reactor may continue to burn for weeks, but the amount of radioactive material being spewed into the atmosphere is diminishing, the United States reported. The Government said the ''major accident'' probably occurred last Saturday, at least 48 hours before the West learned about it, causing a ''violent explosion'' and ''major damage'' to the reactor. [ Page A1, Columns 3-6. ]

title: The Need to Remember
description: Exactly what Kurt Waldheim did as a German intelligence officer in Greece and Yugoslavia between 1942 and 1945 - whether he had a part in atrocities - may never be known for certain. What is known is that for 40 years he concealed the fact of his military service in the Balkans, misleading the world. That is enough to know.

title: Oh, for the Actor's Life
description: Crowding into the video studio of the City University Graduate Center the other day, 200 drama students, actors, hopefuls and theatergoers got a glimpse into the lives of some of Broadway's brightest performers, as part of the American Theater Wing spring seminar, ''Working in the Theater.''

Occasionally, however, he fronts a group of his own, and through Sunday he is leading a quintet at Fat Tuesday's (190 Third Avenue, at 17th Street) that includes the pianist Sir Roland Hanna.

The remaining schedule, at the Hofstra Physical Fitness Center, is: Tomorrow - Flighted Open Pairs, 2 P.M. and 8 P.M.

description: A suspect in a subway chain-snatching drowned yesterday afternoon when he jumped into the Gowanus Canal to elude a group of men who were chasing him, the police said.

REPLACING SASH CORDS WITH CHAINS
description: IN older houses, double-hung windows with sash cords and weights often develop problems over the years. Newer homes usually have spring balances or tension channels to hold the sashes in position, and these are much less likely to cause problems.

title: 14 SUBSTANCES SHOWERED SCANDINAVIA
description: The Soviet nuclear reactor accident has showered Scandinavia with traces of 14 radioactive substances, some of which are likely to persist for a long time, scientists here said today.

THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Minnesota Twins, at Yankee Stadium, 7:35 P.M. Frank Viola, (3-1) the former St. John's star, is scheduled to pitch the finale of the three-game series for Minnesota against Dennis Rasmussen (2-0).

title: TRADITIONAL DESIGN FLOURISHES IN A ROMANTIC SHOW HOUSE
description: THIS year's Kips Bay Boys' Club decorator show house, a turn-of-the-century mansion at 1 East 94th Street, is less grand and more livable than many of the houses of past years. It is not that the rooms are simple, but rather that they have an aura of elegant comfort. One could easily imagine moving right into some of them, with their appealing use of traditional decorating flourishes: elaborate draperies, in which yard upon yard of chintz and cotton, silk and canvas vie for dramatic effects, and walls that have been given a dizzying variety of marbleized, trompe l'oeil and textured finishes.

title: Talbott Captures Title in Squash
description: Mark Talbott of Marblehead, Mass., took less than 30 minutes to regain the Xerox North American squash-racquets championship Tuesday night with a 15-8, 15-12, 15-10 victory over Steve Bowditch of West Germany at the Commodore Squash Club in St. Paul, Minn.

title: Mezzo Wins Tucker Award
description: A mezzo-soprano, Dolora Zajic, has been named the winner of the 1986 Richard Tucker Award.

title: THE DANCE: SANKAI JUKU OPENS
description: SANKAI JUKU, the Butoh dance group from Japan that created a stir in the fall of 1984 at the City Center, returned there last night with ''Jomon Sho,'' one of the two programs seen previously. ''Kinkan Shonen,'' the other production, returns on May 6.

title: FOUR NEW ADAPTATIONS OF 'MARLOWE' ON HBO
description: HOME BOX OFFICE'S ''Philip Marlowe, Private Eye'' is just good enough to keep you wishing it were better. The series, based on stories by Raymond Chandler, had a brief run on the pay-cable service in 1983 and is now returning with four new hour-long adaptations over the next several weeks. Starring Powers Boothe (''The Emerald Forest,'' television's ''Guyana Tragedy'') as Marlowe, the productions are so obviously taken with Chandler's hard-bitten, tough-guy style that they keep threatening to topple into parody.

title: AMERICAN LOCKER GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $72,596.

title: LIGHT FOR DARK CLOSETS
description: TRYING to find something in the back of a closet can be made considerably easier by one of several types of closet lights. A closet with a source of electricity allows for many options. A Ceiling Lampholder, made of porcelain, is one of the least expensive alternatives. Mounted on the closet ceiling, it holds an ordinary lightbulb and has a pull-chain attached to the switch. Some models also have an extra outlet, which can be used to plug in a vacuum cleaner, for example. Clarity Electric at 1363 Third Avenue, between 77th and 78th Streets, sells one for $5.50.

He said skin tests were more sensitive and more reliable than blood tests in detecting food allergies.

description: Prisoners rioted in five British prisons today, burning one to the ground and starting fires in two others. In the confusion, a total of more than 50 inmates escaped, the police said.

title: MAKING APPLIANCES THAT SUIT THE USER
description: APPLIANCES play a central role in the American dream of the automated home, where life is made easier by machines that carry out household chores. But any machine, no matter how technologically advanced, is still designed for a specific, if imaginary, operator. In January, the Whirlpool Company began marketing washers and dryers especially for the disabled and Spanish-speaking people, addressing a new and fundamental design issue: appliances made for the nontypical user.

title: HOW TO COMBAT TERRORISM
description: One of the most fashionable criticisms of the new American policy of responding to terrorism with force is that it fails to address ''the underlying cause'' of terrorist violence. Underlying causes should certainly be treated whenever possible, but those who urge understanding as an alternative to a military response err in several respects.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday A ROYAL BREED The breed itself has a romantic history: originally created in 16th-century Austria for the Royal House of Hapsburg, the majestic white horses known as Royal Lippizan stallions are the result of centuries of crossbreeding of Spanish and Arabic-Oriental bloodlines. Ghengis Khan is even said to have ridden across Europe on an early ancestor of the Lippizan, but the horses' breeding was later controlled by royalty, and only nobles serving with the Austrian army were given Lippizaners to ride. This weekend the stallions will participate in an equine extravaganza at Radio City Music Hall, where the Royal Lippizan Show will feature Lippizaner balance and precision dressage as well as the famed leaps called ''Airs Above the Ground.'' Performances are tonight at 8, tomorrow at 2:30 and 8 P.M. and Sunday at 1 and 5 P.M. Tickets are $15 and $17.50. Information: 757-3100.

title: Gould Heads ASCAP
description: The composer Morton Gould has been elected president of the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers. Mr. Gould succeeds Hal David, who has been president for the last six years.

title: Random Murder Ruled Out
description: The authorities today ruled out the possibility that a laboratory technician was the random target of fatal Tylenol cyanide poisoning. Chief Ted Weatherly of the Pullman police said suicide was one of the possibilities being considered in the death of Sandie Gregory, 21 years old, who died early Sunday after taking two Extra-Strength Tylenol capsules. Chief Weatherly said tests of empty capsule shells in the woman's apartment turned up traces of the same type of cyanide she had access to in her laboratory.

title: Shrewd Prospect
description: When the United States Football League held its territorial draft last week, one selection, by the Memphis Showboats, went largely unnoticed. It seemed at first a curious oversight, because the prospect was a two-time all-American at the University of Tennessee.

Boorstin, the Librarian of Congress, the First Class of the Order of the Sacred Treasure, the highest decoration that nation gives to foreigners. The actual presentation will be made by the Japanese Ambassador in Washington this month.

title: Two Ballets by Robbins To Be Shown on Channel 13
description: In a choreographic career that extends back to 1944, Jerome Robbins has created more than 50 ballets of all sorts, and the quality level maintained throughout has been extraordinary. In a ''Great Performances'' presentation tonight at 9 o'clock, Channel 13 will show Mr. Robbins's very first work, ''Fancy Free,'' which was choreographed for Ballet Theater, and one done 40 years later for the New York City Ballet, ''Antique Epigraphs.'' They were produced by WNET/New York as the final program in the 10th-anniversary season of ''Dance in America.'' Both works are performed by dancers of City Ballet, of which Mr. Robbins is co-balletmaster. The show was produced by Judy Kinberg and directed by Emile Ardolino.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: WITH its socialites, its big money, its sex and its famous little black bag with its syringe, needles and insulin, the Claus von Bulow case is headed for the screen.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Executive Changes column in Business Day yesterday misstated Thomas W. McIntyre's new position at RCA/Ariola Communications. He is vice president and chief financial officer.

title: ST PAUL COMPANIES(0) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
'DARK,' BLUE JAGUAR WTIH A GHOST
description: TALK about cars that turn out to be lemons! In ''Dark of the Night,'' which opens today at the Quad Cinema, buxom, red-haired Heather Bolton plays Meg, a pleasant young woman who falls for a snazzy blue Jaguar that she soon discovers has a ghostly passenger. The trunk pops up on its own, but the doors sometimes refuse to open at all; the gas gauge is unreliable and the horn starts blaring at odd times.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Company Briefs column of Business Day on Saturday about Ribi Immunochem Research Inc.'s anti-tumor product misstated the company's location and the period when it will begin clinical trials of the product. The company is based in Hamilton, Mont., and will begin trials this year.

title: HEALTHCARE SERVICES GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WORKERS MARCH IN ANTI-DUARTE PROTEST
description: A crowd of workers estimated at 15,000 to 25,000 marched through the capital today in a demonstration of growing trade union activity and broad popular discontent with Government policies.

title: WACHTLER OUTLINES PLAN TO FIGHT COURT SEXISM
description: The state's Chief Judge outlined a program today to combat sexism in the court system that is to include education, continued recruitment and promotion and a panel to monitor the treatment of women in the courtroom.

title: Dining Out Guide: Casual Italian
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. IL CANTINORI, #32 East 10th Street (673-6044) -

title: Allied-Signal Switches To Homer & Durham
description: Allied-Signal Inc. of Morristown, N.J., is switching its $4 million corporate account to Homer & Durham from Doyle Dane Bernbach.

title: MEDSTAT SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $27,500 for the quarter and $60,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss.

title: Japan's Centrality
description: The economic summit conference in Tokyo provides Japan with a timely opportunity to help establish momentum toward liberalization of trade. Unless Japan further opens its markets, the alternative may well be a full-scale international trade war.

title: THE SCREEN: 'LETTER TO BREZHNEV'
description: THE letter to Brezhnev in the movie of that name is written by Elaine, a 22-year-old Liverpool lass who one starry night falls in love with a visiting Soviet sailor. After he goes home, she writes to the Soviet leader for permission to join her sailor. It takes a while to get the hang of the Liverpool lingo, but it's worth some strain. The zesty script by Frank Clarke is at once shamelessly romantic (''You look to the star and think of me'') and unromantically streetwise (''Talk about Russian hands and roamin' fingers''). And the performances of Alexandra Pigg as Elaine and Margi Clarke as her friend Teresa are delectable.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL SAN FRANCISCO (NL) - Recalled Luis Quinones, infielder, from Phoenix of Pacific Coast League.

title: Fruehauf Holders Rebuff Edelman
description: The New York investor Asher B. Edelman today failed to unseat the board of the Fruehauf Corporation but vowed to continue his $935 million campaign to win control of the truck-trailer maker. ''I shall return,'' Mr. Edelman told shareholders.

title: EVANS & SUTHERLAND COMUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Chrysler Incentives
description: The Chrysler Corporation said it was lowering interest rates for some new cars to 5.8 percent and renewing its cash rebate program, which had expired Wednesday.

title: GREYHOUND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes equity in net income of Conagra of $2,212,000 for the latest quarter and $2,156,000 for the year- earlier period. The year-ago quarter results also included gains of $6.9 million from the sale/leaseback of two major terminals, equal to 14 cents a share, as part of an ongoing program to downsize the garage and terminal facilities of Greyhound Lines.

title: FUEL LEAK FORCES NASA TO DELAY LAUNCHING OF A WEATHER SATELLITE
description: The space agency's first attempt to launch a rocket since the destruction of the space shuttle Challenger on Jan. 28 was postponed yesterday when liquid fuel was detected leaking from a Delta rocket hours before it was scheduled to lift off from Cape Canaveral, Fla.

title: BAR OWNER CHARGED IN KILLING
description: A Manhattan bar owner, after fatally stabbing a man Wednesday night during a dispute over a mutual friend, was shot by a policeman while attacking the victim's roommate, the police said.

title: The Thorny Side Of Run for Roses
description: When 16 3-year-olds were entered yesterday for the Kentucky Derby, Mike Battaglia began to perform what he calls ''the most hateful part of my job'' as the linemaker for Churchill Downs: picking the Derby's mutuel field. He ended up choosing Wise Times, Zabaleta, Fobby Forbes, Icy Groom and Southern Appeal. ''As I expected,'' he said later, ''no matter what I did, people are mad at me.''

title: VENTREX LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Another Milestone on Time's Inexorable March to Summer
description: Students from the Rudolf Steiner School on East 79th Street dancing around a Maypole yesterday during a May Day ceremony in Central Park that harkened back to medieval times. They enjoyed sunny skies, at times, with a high temperature of 75 degrees; today is expected to be partly sunny with a high temperature near 70. (NYT/Chester Higgins Fr.)

title: AUXTON COMPUTER ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
West Virginia Man Gets An Artificial Heart
description: A disabled machinist from West Virginia who was awaiting a heart transplant received a Jarvik-7 artificial heart today after doctors determined he had little time left to live.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: MANHUNT. By Peter Maas. 301 pages. Random House. $17.95. MATA HARI: The True Story. By Russell Warren Howe. 292 pages. Illustrated. Dodd, Mead. $17.95. EDWIN P. WILSON is not a nice man. When an associate he was getting drunk with, a pilot called Mike Lucker, made a flippant remark that he interpreted as a pass, he responded by smashing his fist into Mr. Lucker's jaw, breaking it in two places; then he hit him again, crushing his nose.

title: RODINO DELAYS IMMIGRATION BILL TO SEEK COMPROMISE ON FARM ISSUE
description: Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, today postponed action on a bill to curtail illegal immigration. The move appeared to reduce chances for adoption of the measure in this session of Congress.

title: SCRIPPS-HOWARD BROADCASTNG reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: 16 HORSES ENTERED IN RICHEST DERBY
description: Snow Chief drew post 12, and all the speed horses drew outside him, which should make for an interesting run to the first turn Saturday among the 16 3-year-olds who were entered today for the 112th Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs.

title: FRANKLIN RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PEAK ISSUES AT THE ECONOMIC SUMMIT
description: On Sunday, President Reagan begins his sixth summit meeting with leaders of other industrial democracies. While formally limited to economics, it will be dominated by discussion of terrorism - and it must be used to repair damage to the Western alliance.

title: BRAVES WIN, 7-2, TO END MET STREAK AT 11
description: They turned philosophical when the streak was over, pulling out the cliches that usually accompany defeat. But the Mets seemed no different tonight than they were Tuesday or Wednesday, even though they came crashing back to earth.

title: Economic Scene; Chernobyl's World Impact
description: THE disaster at the Chernobyl nuclear generating plant in the Soviet Union and the spread of radioactivity over other countries provide fresh proof of just how vulnerable the American and world economy has become to unpredictable shocks.

title: SCREEN: 'JO JO DANCER'
description: BROWSING through the biography section of any bookstore these days, you might get the impression - especially from the show-biz titles - that life is simply an obligatory, often dreary preliminary to an assault on the best-seller lists.

title: MARCOS LOYALISTS CLASH WITH POLICE
description: Riot police officers firing tear gas and using water hoses tonight dispersed thousands of demonstrators loyal to former President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: ELECTRONIC ASSOCIATES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain equal to 5 cents a share.

BUILDING OUTLAYS OFF
description: Construction spending fell 1.2 percent in March, the biggest decline in more than a year, as housing activity edged down slightly and industrial building took a much steeper plunge, the Government reported today.

title: WALDHEIM RECORDED ORDER TO KILL PARTISANS
description: As a first lieutenant in the German Army in World War II, Kurt Waldheim kept his army group's daybook, which recorded Hitler's order to kill captured partisans in Greece and send suspected resistance fighters to labor camps, according to German war documents.

title: TRANSOHIO FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $2.3 million, or 39 cents a share, from the cancellation of a pension plan.

title: MOOD IS SOMBER AS SPRING PLANTING BEGINS UNDER NEW RULES
description: In a scene that changes little from year to year, clouds of dust like those from Dwight Roth's big green tractor across broad fields of freshly turned soil signal corn-planting time in the Farm Belt.

title: FORTUNE SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $164,000. c-Net loss

title: AUCTIONS
description: JASPER JOHNS'S ''Target,'' a 1961 version in red, yellow and blue of one of the artist's favorite early icons, is the most important of a number of major Pop Art and Abstract Expressionist works going on view today before their sale next week at Christie's and Sotheby's. Mr. Johns's painting of a bull's-eye, from the period when he was also executing images of flags, numbers and alphabets, is expected to sell for $2 million, which would be the highest price ever paid at auction for a work by a living artist.

title: Commodity Trader Opens 'New Book'
description: F. McCoy Coan has been trading wheat, corn and soybeans in the pits of the Chicago Board of Trade since 1968, but what has gone on in the last three days is unlike anything he has experienced before, he said.

title: AT PARTY FOR JUDITH KRANTZ, LIFE IMITATES ART
description: Every couple of years, Judith Krantz slips out of the trusty sweatpants she wears while writing her big-money books and into the new Adolfo outfits she wears while hawking them. This year the book is ''I'll Take Manhattan'' and the Adolfos come in ''those Easter-eggy colors that work well on television,'' Mrs. Krantz was saying the other day in her suite at the Carlyle Hotel.

title: ERIE LACKAWANNA INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
The Unsovereign Seven
description: Good economic news abounds as the heads of seven major democracies convene in Tokyo. Inflation, interest rates and the dollar are all down, encouraging growth and easing the stress on the delicate mechanisms of international finance.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds rose $22.8 million, to $222.86 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, marking the ninth consecutive increase, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: RETAILERS CURB BUYING TRIPS ABROAD
description: Some major American retailers and buying offices are canceling buying trips to Europe and the Middle East in response to recent terrorist incidents, executives said yesterday.

description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $245,000.

description: b-Includes a gain of $155,000 on the sale of properties and investments for the quarter and $8,000 for the year- ago period.

title: Briton Reports Poor Output In Soviet's Nuclear Program
description: A study published today concluded that the Soviet Union's nuclear power program was suffering from low output and service problems before the Chernobyl disaster.

title: Congressional Fitness
description: When the fifth National Fitness Classic gets under way in Houston this afternoon, the first team ever to represent Congress will be in the thick of it. Representatives David E. Bonior of Michigan, Ronald V. Dellums of California and Mickey Leland of Texas will be joined by Jack Russ, the House Sergeant-at-Arms; Patty McGovern, an aide of Representative Stewart B. McKinney of Connecticut, and Bill Lawson and Jeff Darman, who are described as ''fill-ins'' for members of Congress who canceled out.

title: Royal Couple Visits Canada
description: Greeted by thousands of flag-waving fans, the Prince and Princess of Wales began a seven-day visit to mark the opening of the Expo '86 World's Fair.

FINK IS CONSIDERING NOT MAKING A RUN FOR ANOTHER TERM
description: Stanley Fink, who as Speaker of the Assembly is one of the most powerful figures in state government, said today that ''there is a chance that I would not run for re-election.''

title: MOSCOW ACCEPTS FOREIGN DOCTORS' HELP
description: The Soviet Union yesterday accepted an offer of help in treating victims of the nuclear accident at the Chernobyl atomic power plant.

DOLLAR'S FALL HURTS HOECHST
description: Hoechst A.G., the large chemical company, said today that profits and sales fell about 10 percent in the first quarter, in the first acknowledgment that the dollar's decline is having a notable effect on an important German industry.

title: DECISION ON VERTICAL TAKEOFF PLANE FOR MARINE CORPS EXPECTED SOON
description: The Pentagon will soon announce a decision whether to proceed with a program costing more than $20 billion to develop a new type of ''tilt-rotor'' aircraft, Pentagon officials said today.

title: DURR-FILLAUER MEDICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
N. W. Goldstein Rite May 13
description: The date of a memorial service for Nathan W. Goldstein, retired circulation director of The New York Times, has been changed. It will now be held on May 13 at 1 P.M. in St. Malachy's Roman Catholic Church, 239 West 49th Street. Mr. Goldstein, who retired in 1978, died on April 15 at the age of 78.

title: All 'Prisoner' Episodes To Be Televised
description: All 17 episodes of the British television series ''The Prisoner'' will be broadcast consecutively tomorrow and Sunday on WNYC-TV. The 1968-69 series, produced by and starring Patrick McGoohan, tells the story of a former intelligence agent imprisoned in a totalitarian village.

title: MOORE MEDICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
PAKISTAN'S AVENGING DAUGHTER: TIME FOR ANGER?
description: After two weeks of huge and emotional rallies, Benazir Bhutto has made herself the standard-bearer for anti-Government feelings in Pakistan but has failed to stir much support within the Parliament for her demand that elections be held this year.

title: New York as Hardship Post
description: Americans toiling as delegates at the United Nations are entitled to some financial consideration. They need to entertain; they need security protection; they serve limited tours of duty in a costly post where apartments are hard to find even at high rents.

title: ABRAMS AND TOP DEMOCRATS CLASH ON ANTICORRUPTION PLAN
description: State Attorney General Robert Abrams and the state's top Democratic leaders are at odds over an Abrams anticorruption proposal that would bar Democratic Party officials from holding elective office.

title: MOOG INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
4 INDICTED IN INQUIRIES INVOLVING FIRST JERSEY
description: A grand jury indicted three current employees, and one former employee, of First Jersey Securities Inc. yesterday on charges of obstruction of justice and perjury in connection with two government investigations of the Manhattan-based brokerage firm.

description: Revenues represent net shipments.

Guggenheim.

Tickets are $10 to $17.50; information: 247-7800.

description: The American Motors Corporation has notified stockholders that pending lawsuits involving personal injury in Jeep CJ accidents total more than $1.8 billion. The amount sought by plaintiffs consists of $1.2 billion in punitive damages and $640 million in compensatory damages.

Quotation of the Day
description: ''Definitely there has been an accident which has not been liquidated yet and theoretically poses a threat to people outside the Soviet Union.

title: Horticultural Inflation
description: The price of garden-watching, a considerably more sedentary sport than politician-watching, is also going up. Dumbarton Oaks, the Harvard-owned estate overlooking Georgetown, charges admission from April through October, when its gardens make their prized offerings of color and greenery, but that daily fee was raised from $1 to $2 this year. The season pass rose only from $10 to $15, however, so that its holders in effect will visit for free after their eighth visit instead of after their 10th under the former price scale.

description: To the Editor:

title: Afghan Leader Returns From Soviet Union
description: President Babrak Karmal of Afghanistan returned home today after undergoing medical treatment in the Soviet Union, ending speculation that he had been removed from power.

description: b-Includes a gain of $684,000, or 18 cents a share, resulting from the sale of a building.

title: Congress; TV: The Senate Grins and Bravely Tries to Bear It
description: ''I see a little better grooming,'' said Senator Howell Heflin, Democrat of Alabama, aiming a deadpan stare at the tousled gray hair of a Republican colleague, Senator John W. Warner of Virginia. ''Some might even be trying a little powder.''

title: GOING FROM A 'TREE' TO 'DESERT BLOOM'
description: FIFTEEN-YEAR-OLD Annabeth Gish, who received critical praise for her film debut in ''Desert Bloom,'' a story of family turmoil set against the background of the atomic bomb tests near Las Vegas in the 1950's, claims that role was her most challenging to date.

title: 20 Treiman Paintings On Display at Gallery
description: Joyce Treiman, a Los Angeles artist whose canvases combine figuration and Abstract Expressionism, will show 20 recent paintings and 8 drawings at the Schmidt Bingham Gallery, 41 West 57th Street, through May 24.

MICHIGAN GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SCIENCE DYNAMICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
RICH AND POOR: WIDENING GAP SEEN FOR AREA
description: Despite surging business expansion in New York City and its suburbs, the economic gap between the area's rich and poor residents is growing wider and will create enormous new strains on housing, public schools, job training programs and social services during the next 15 years, according to a report released yesterday by the Regional Plan Association.

title: People
description: * Roy Beauchamp has joined Kobs & Brady Advertising as an executive vice president, leaving Grey Direct, the direct marketing agency he helped found six years ago.

title: Pan-Celtic Conference In Manhattan
description: The Celtic League American Branch, a nonprofit cultural organization, is sponsoring its 13th annual ''Pan-Celtic Conference'' tomorrow.

title: AFTER ACCIDENT AT THE SOVIET STATION, NUCLEAR POWER IS QUESTIONED AGAIN
description: Energy experts predicted yesterday that public concern arising from the Soviet nuclear accident would tip the scales against orders for new nuclear power reactors in many countries.

title: Pennzoil Appeals To Supreme Court
description: The Pennzoil Company asked the United States Supreme Court to hear its appeal of a lower court decision that permits Texaco Inc. to pursue its legal battle with Pennzoil without posting a $12 billion bond. Pennzoil said the decision of a Federal District Court, which was later upheld by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in New York, ''sanctions an unprecedented intrusion by a Federal court into an ongoing state court proceeding.''

title: DUEL OF WITS: A RUSSIAN FACES CONGRESS
description: While Soviet officials in Moscow were limiting themselves to terse announcements about the reactor accident in the Ukraine, a Soviet diplomat made an unexpected appearance before the House Energy and Commerce Committee today, where he allowed himself to be relentlessly questioned about the accident and the Soviet failure to inform the world about it.

title: He's Occupied
description: The Sandi Sentell of pro basketball is Senator Bill Bradley, now 42 years old, who hasn't played the game in almost a decade but was drafted in the territorial phase by the New Jersey Jammers of the United States Basketball League the other day. While the U.S.F.L.'s draft was too early for Miss Sentell, the U.S.B.L.'s was too late for the Senator. ''I have already been drafted, by the people of New Jersey,'' he said, ''and I signed a six-year contract.''

title: New York's Contracting System Needs Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Carter Says Death Reports Are Probably Exaggerated
description: Former President Jimmy Carter, who helped dismantle a damaged nuclear reactor in the 1950's, said today that reports of thousands of deaths from the accident in the Soviet Union were probably greatly exaggerated.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Kay Starr, Freddy's Supper Club, 308 East 49th Street (888-1633). After a 15-year absence from the New York stage, the woman who popularized ''Wheel of Fortune,'' ''Side by Side,'' and ''Rock-and-Roll Waltz'' in the 1950's returned to Freddy's last October to wide acclaim, and now she's back for an engagement that extends through Sunday. Miss Starr, who began her career singing with Joe Venuti's big band, was a sophisticated forerunner of earthy pop-country singers like Brenda Lee, and she still swings up a storm, blending old hits and pop standards with recent pop-country tunes. The pianist Frank Ortega leads her backup quartet. Shows tonight and tomorrow are at 9 and 11 o'clock, with a Sunday brunch at 3 P.M. Admission is $20, with a two-drink minimum.

title: HARVARD PROTESTERS OBJECT TO INVESTMENT TIED TO SOUTH AFRICA
description: Twelve demonstrators protesting South Africa's policy of racial separation occupied the office where Harvard University's 350th anniversary is being planned to protest the school's investment in Royal Dutch Shell, which supplies oil to South Africa.

title: Space Teacher Buried In New Hampshire City
description: Christa McAuliffe, the teacher aboard the space shuttle Challenger, was buried here today in a private family service.

title: THE DAY THEY DISCARDED ALL THE LABELS
description: At least on the surface, the Supreme Court seemed to have things backward Wednesday when it overruled a 1965 precedent and handed a major victory to black criminal defendants at the expense of prosecutors and the Reagan Justice Department.

Clocklike Play Backed by Muscle
description: On Easter Sunday last year, Uruguay sweated and strained to a 2-1 victory over Chile - a victory that insured the Uruguayans a place in the 1986 World Cup final round, which will be played in Mexico in June.

title: NEW YORK AIRPORTS ARE SUBTLY GIRDING TO FIGHT TERRORISM
description: Leaning against the Citibank counter in the International Arrivals Building of Kennedy International Airport and wearing a dark three-piece suit and raincoat, he easily passed for a businessman waiting for a visitor.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Dan Driessen, who played with the Cincinnati Reds from 1973 to 1984, has been placed on waivers by the San Francisco Giants for the purpose of giving him his unconditional release. Driessen, 34 years old, who is batting .176, lost his starting job at first base in spring training to Will Clark, a rookie. . . . The Minnesota Vikings announced that Buster Rhymes, a wide receiver, had returned to Hazelden Treatment Center in Center City, Minn., to be ''treated for an illness.''

title: Nebraska Gets Rodgers
description: Terry Rodgers, the son of Johnny Rodgers, the 1972 Heisman Trophy winner and a former member of the San Diego Chargers, has decided to attend Nebraska, his father's alma mater.

title: CANADIENS EDGE RANGERS AS ROY SPARKLES IN GOAL
description: They had become accustomed to nights of tingling drama, to sudden-death goals, and crowds overcome with hysteria. So by Ranger standards, this was a quiet evening of hockey. Quietly, the Rangers lost some of their playoff steam.

title: BELL CANADA ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Return of the Dancing Water
description: What a difference a spray makes: if it hadn't been for the drought, New Yorkers might never have noticed. How good it is, after a year of empty pools, unmirrored monuments and parched fountains, to see water dancing again in parks and plazas and along the avenues.

title: SOH DAIKO, THE FINE ART OF JAPANESE DRUMMING
description: In ancient Japan, folklore has it, a village's boundaries were determined by the farthest point from which the villagers could hear the sound of the taiko - a big drum.

title: A JUDGE DENIES FRIEDMAN'S BID TO FREE ASSETS
description: Stanley M. Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader, lost a bid yesterday to free assets that were frozen after his indictment in the city's Parking Violations Bureau scandal.

title: Gillespie and Hampton
description: The trumpeter Dizzy Gillespie and his quintet will perform tonight at 7:30 and 9:30 at the Fulton Market Jazz Hall of the South Street Seaport, Fulton and Water Streets. Tomorrow at 7:30 and 9:30, the vibraphonist Lionel Hampton will bring his big band. Tickets for each show are $19.50; information, 732-7678.

title: Japan Outline For Economy
description: The Japanese Cabinet approved a general outline today of short- and long-term steps for restructuring the country's economy away from its dependence on exports, an official in the Prime Minister's office said.

title: Stock Slide Eases; Dow Off by 6.20
description: The stock market continued to decline yesterday, but the slide was not nearly as steep as Wednesday's record setter.

title: Day-Care Sex Assaults Bring 30-Year Sentence
description: A former teacher's aide at a Bronx day-care center was sentenced to 40 years in prison yesterday for sexually assaulting two boys at the center.

title: WINDS BLOW FALLOUT TO SOUTHERN EUROPE
description: Winds blowing from the stricken Chernobyl nuclear reactor in the Ukraine carried a scattering of fallout over southern Europe today. But the shift in weather patterns left the skies over Scandinavia free of artificial radioactivity.

title: Leonard May Return
description: Sugar Ray Leonard said yesterday he would end his two-year retirement from boxing if middleweight champion Marvelous Marvin Hagler agreed to a title fight. ''I know exactly what it takes to beat this man,'' Leonard told WDVM-TV in Washington.

title: JOHN NUVEEN & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SUMMIT LEADERS SEEN PRAISING GROWTH, WITH RESERVATIONS
description: The leaders of the major non-Communist industrialized nations plan to present a glowing portrait of the world's economic prospects at their 12th annual economic summit meeting opening in Tokyo on Sunday. They will attribute this brightening future to the success of their own policies helped by the sharp fall in the price of oil, according to officials preparing the summit talks who were interviewed in several capitals.

title: KEARNEY-NATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: b-Includes net of $651,000, or 11 cents a share, from discontinued operations. The year-earlier quarter's results were reclassified for discontinued operations.

title: PLAYS BY GUARE AND FUGARD ARE RULED ELIGIBLE FOR TONYS
description: In a stormy meeting that reversed an earlier decision, the Tony Awards administration committee decided yesterday to consider as eligible for its best play award both John Guare's ''House of Blue Leaves,'' which received its first New York production 15 years ago, and Athol Fugard's ''Blood Knot,'' which was produced here more than 20 years ago.

title: LOW VOTER TURNOUT EXPECTED IN TEXAS PRIMARY TOMORROW
description: This may yet turn out to be the pivotal year in Texas politics that some anlysts expected, but as Texas prepares for statewide primaries Saturday the state's lagging economy and some runaway races appear to be keeping voter interest well below peak levels.

title: Sights and Sounds
description: The painter Romare Bearden and the saxophonist Jackie McLean will perform together Sunday afternoon at 2 in the Wadsworth Atheneum's Avery Theater, 600 Main Street, Hartford, Conn.

title: ADVANCED COMPUTER TECHIQUES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SENATORS SEEK WAYS TO CURTAIL TAX SHELTERS
description: The Senate Finance Committee, tackling one of the most difficult areas of tax-revision legislation, spent today trying to figure out how to define tax shelters and how best to get rid of them.

title: WESTMORELAND COAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Britain May Send Inmates to Army Camps
description: After a night of arson and rioting in at least 20 British prisons, the Government announced today that it was prepared to move prison inmates to military camps rather than back down in a dispute over staffing levels with the union that represents prison warders.

title: MAUI LAND & PINEAPPLE CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
People Express Loss
description: People Express Inc., the holding company for People Express Airlines, Frontier Airlines and Britt Airways, said today it had lost $58 million in the first quarter. The loss follows a $32.2 million loss for the fourth quarter of 1985, and it is three times the $18.8 million that People Express lost during the first quarter of 1985. Revenues were $329.3 million, compared with $195 million in last year's quarter, before the acquisition of Frontier and Britt.

title: British Rock Band
description: The Three Johns, a British rock band, will perform tonight at the World, 254 East Second Street (674-3348). The set begins at 1 A.M.; tickets are $15.

title: SOFTWARE SERVICES(B) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: BUCKS WIN AND EVEN SERIES
description: Sidney Moncrief did not decide he could play tonight until just before the tipoff, when he tested his tender left foot. In the third period, he endured a collision that caused him to limp noticeably. But Moncrief stayed in and provided an emotional spark that lifted the Milwaukee Bucks to victory over the Philadelphia 76ers.

title: ART: FONSECA'S ARCHEOLOGICAL SCULPTURE
description: WHEN the history of 20th-century archeological sculpture is written, Gonzalo Fonseca should have a place in it. His small, excavated, sometimes inhabited slabs of stone are less conceptual than the miniature cities and sites of Anne and Patrick Porier. They do not have the sexual and political edge that Charles Simonds has been trying to build into his erupting mounds.

title: Not Anything Goes
description: Richard Perle, Assistant Secretary of Defense, a brilliant hawk who is by no means a wealthy man, decided to pass up $300,000 the other day. His friends, rich and poor, are glad.

title: Playboy Closings
description: Playboy Enterprises Inc. said it would close the Playboy Club in New York City, which it had reopened just six months ago, as well as clubs in Chciago and Los Angeles. The company cited a $5.3 million third-quarter operating loss from its clubs division. The Chicago-based company said the clubs would close June 30.

title: MENTOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
UP-RIGHT INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: SPY SAYS HE AND CONFEDERATE RISKED DEATH AT SOVIET HANDS
description: John A. Walker Jr., who has confessed he headed a Soviet spy ring, testified today that he told Jerry A. Whitworth that if he continued to alter his career plans without first informing the buyers of the classified Navy data he was passing both men might be killed.

title: FILM: 'BLUE CITY,' FLA.
description: ''BLUE CITY'' is a witless, primitively composed little movie set somewhere south of ''Miami Vice'' country. Though shot in vivid colors, it aspires to be a sort of young people's film noir, and comes out looking like an old people's film gris.

title: ESSELTE BUSINESS SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
KOCH CONCEDES TUROFF ASSISTED '85 RE-ELECTION
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he was aware that the former head of the city's taxi agency, Jay L. Turoff, was helping last year's Koch re-election campaign but not aware of his specific activities.

title: QADDAFI'S TROUBLED ECONOMY
description: The revolution of Libya's Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi at home and abroad is being undermined by economic mismanagement and the collapse in oil prices, according to foreign diplomats and businessmen based in Libya, as well as many Libyans.

title: 30-Month Experiment To Test TV in Courts
description: To the Editor:

title: Ms. Magazine to Begin New Print Campaign
description: Gloria Steinem believes that for the first time there are enough American women who are decision makers, professionals and entrepreneurs to create a critical mass and become a population segment of their own.

title: Bridge: English Has No Equivalent For the 'Coup de l'Agonie'
description: Most foreign languages do not have their own words for technical bridge terms and adopt the English word, perhaps with a minor modification. But there is some reciprocation.

title: 5 Arrested and Cocaine Worth $750,000 Is Seized in a Raid
description: Five men were arrested and about $750,000 worth of cocaine was seized last night in the Washington Heights section of Manhattan, in what the police called the largest seizure to date in a recent crackdown on drug dealers in the area.

title: HUDSON GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Illegal Rodents
description: The City Law Department, at 100 Church Street, near Barclay Street, may have its cafeteria closed down by the City Health Department.

title: 10-1 Shot Wins In 1,000 Guineas
description: Midway Lady, ridden by Ray Cochrane, won the first classic event of the British horse racing season today, capturing the 1,000 Guineas for 3-year-old fillies.

title: PHILADELPHIA SUBURBAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
New Witco President
description: The Witco Corporation, a maker of specialty chemicals and petroleum products, said yesterday that Thomas J. Bickett, 47 years old, its executive vice president had become president and chief operating officer, succeeding William J. Ashe, who retired after 34 years with Witco. Witco announced the move in January but had not said when it would take effect.

title: SOVIET SAYS FALLOUT IS CUT
description: The United States said today that the Soviet Union might have smothered the fire that raged for the last five days at a nuclear reactor in the Ukraine.

title: GCA CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $1,809,000 from discontinued operations.

title: METEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: b-Includes $213,000, or 16 cents a share, resulting from a favorable adjustment to the company's investment portfolio.

title: FIRST FINCORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DSP TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary tax credit of $14,000. c-Net loss d-Includes a gain of $77,000, or 6 cents a share, from a tax loss carryforward. Share earnings reflect deductions of preferred stock dividends of $7,000 and $30,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: White Sox Join Project
description: A proposal to build a $255 million stadium in downtown Chicago that could accommodate baseball and football received a boost Wednesday when the White Sox tentatively agreed to join the project. Al Johnson, an aide to Mayor Harold Washington, said the developers would try to get the Bears to join also because without their participation the stadium would not be built. The Bears are under lease to play through 1999 at Soldier Field.

title: Jewish Music Program
description: The tenor Nico Castel will present a program of Jewish music at the 92d Street Y (at Lexington Avenue) Sunday afternoon at 3 o'clock. The program will include traditional Sephardic chants, Yiddish songs, and works by Kurt Weill and Mario Castelnuovo-Tedesco. Tickets are $10; information: 831-8603.

title: PEOPLE EXPRESS AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a $4.5 million non-cash foreign currency charge to earnings associated with the company's Swiss franc denominated debentures issued in January 1986. The 1985 weighted average common shares outstanding are adjusted for impact of 10 percent stock dividend paid as Class B common stock in September 1985.

title: IN KIEV, TWO FACES OF DISASTER: THE ANXIOUS AND THE OFFICIAL
description: The Kiev shown on Soviet television today was a city without a care.

title: NUCOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 5
ISRAEL URGES PUBLIC ACCESS TO U.N. WAR FILES
description: Israel called on Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar today to ''take immediate steps necessary to insure free access of the general public'' to secret files on 40,000 war criminals, suspects, and witnesses to atrocities during World War II.

title: A 10-DAY CELEBRATION OF DOWNTOWN COMEDY
description: How many comedians does it take to screw in a lightbulb? ''Twenty-seven,'' according to the comedian Nancy Lombardo. ''One to actually perform and 26 to say they could have.''

description: b-After a realized investment gain of $6,800,000. c-After an investment gain of $300,000 and net of $900,000 from discontinued operations.

description: b-Includes a charge of $730,000 for the consolidation of wafer manufacturing facilities.

title: FOSTER CARE AGENCY IS SUED ON BARRING BIRTH-CONTROL USE
description: The former medical-services supervisor of a child-care agency affiliated with the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York has charged in a lawsuit that the agency is illegally preventing teen-agers in its care from using birth control.

title: Olympic Trials Sought by Jersey
description: Governor Kean said today that New Jersey was applying to The Athletics Congress to have the 1988 United States Olympic marathon trials held at the waterfront marathon site in Hudson County.

title: KINARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
INTERMET CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
End in Sight for Crew of Forlorn Ship
description: The sad story of the South American seamen stranded in Brooklyn ended yesterday. And it was a more-or-less happy ending.

title: GRAND JURY SAID TO BE REVIEWING L.I. ROAD-BUILDER'S CITY DEALINGS
description: A state grand jury is investigating whether a Long Island company misrepresented its hiring of minority subcontractors to retain city road-repair jobs, state officials said yesterday.

title: AT CBS-TV, IT'S TESTING 1, 2, 3...
description: NEXT week CBS's top broadcasting executives will meet behind closed doors here to set the schedule for the television season this fall.

title: CROWN RESOURCE reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $76,796 from an accounting adjustment. c-After a $247,643 writedown of abandoned properties.

title: 7 Militiamen Killed In Southern Lebanon
description: Shiite Moslem guerrillas said today that they had killed seven militiamen of the Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army in an attack on an army position. The Israeli said one Shiite was killed and five army members were wounded.

title: APPEALS COURT SUSPENDS JUDGE CHARGED IN FRAUD
description: The state's top court yesterday suspended a Civil Court judge in Brooklyn who has been indicted on charges of paying an arsonist to set fire to his law offices so he could collect insurance money.

title: CINEPLEX ODEON reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $1,532,000. The company's stocks are traded on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: CARRIERS, MS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CORRECTIONS
description: A Washington dispatch last Saturday, about lobbying by Michael K. Deaver, incorrectly described a Justice Department report on Michael K. Deaver Associates' representation of the Korean Broadcasting Advertising Corporation.

title: PROSECUTION OF LAWYER HALTED
description: A Federal district judge in North Carolina dismissed criminal charges Wednesday against a prominent immigrationlawyer who was accused of mail fraud and making false statements to the Government on behalf of a British businessman seeking an American visa.

title: New Music in TriBeCa
description: The percussionist David J. Simons, with guests including the singer Shelley Hirsch, will play new music tonight at Roulette, 228 West Broadway at White Street in TriBeCa (219-8242). Sunday at Roulette, the bassist Anthony Cox will perform with the pianist Peter Madsen and the drummer Jeff Williams. Shows begin at 9 P.M.; tickets are $5.

title: A'S TRUIMPH BY 7-2 AS HAAS GOES TO 5-0
description: Moose Haas limited his former teammates to six hits in eight innings today to become the major league's first five-game winner, and the Oakland A's got two-run homers from Dwayne Murphy and Jose Canseco to defeat the Milwaukee Brewers, 7-2.

title: DEL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 4-for-3 stock split paid March 26.

title: Navajo and Hopi Face A New Trail of Tears
description: To the Editor:

title: PROTECTIVE LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes capital gains of $620,000 for the latest quarter and $336,000 for the year-ago period.

title: Draft Catches Polynice
description: Olden Polynice, the leading scorer and rebounder for Virginia the last two seasons, has given up his final year of college eligibility by declaring himself eligible for the National Basketball Association draft.

title: RIGHTS LEADER GIVES WARNING
description: The director of the New York Urban League said last night that the nation was inching ''closer to social Darwinism'' in which more people are being left behind while a few prosper.

title: Accounts
description: * Vanity Fair to Arnell/Bickford.

title: Dailey to Be Counselor
description: Quintin Dailey, the Chicago Bulls' guard who entered a drug rehabilitation program at Van Nuys Community Hospital in California in February, began training yesterday to become a drug-abuse counselor, according to his agent, Eloise Saperstein, who said that Dailey ''will be released from treatment soon.'' Dailey underwent treatment twice last season.

title: WRONG-WAY GOAL ENDS OILER DREAMS
description: The Calgary Flames, stunned by good fortune, raised their arms in surprise when an Edmonton defenseman mistakenly scored the goal that put Calgary ahead by 3-2.

title: SARATOGA STANDARDBREDS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
ELECTIONS ON FOR JULY
description: Prime Minister Prem Tinsulanonda dissolved Parliament Thursday night after his coalition Government was defeated in a parliamentary vote.

title: Democratic Inflation
description: The cost of political campaigning continues to rise, and so, accordingly, does the cost of being a conspicuous party contributor.

title: NAPCO SECURITY SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HINTS OF CROP DAMAGE ROIL U.S. MARKETS
description: Speculation that the Chernobyl nuclear power plant disaster in one of the Soviet Union's premier farming regions may have damaged production of wheat, sugar and livestock has roiled American agricultural markets as has no other recent development.

title: NOVA FUND INC reports earnings for As of March 31
description: Assets represent total assets. The latest per share earnings is after 32 cents per share dividend and capital gain distributed Feb. 7, 1986 and the year-ago per share earnings is after 18 cents per share dividend paid Feb. 8, 1985. for the year-ago.

title: Indianola, Miss., Names A Black to Lead Schools
description: The school board here appointed a black superintendent of education today in a move expected to end a five-week boycott of white businesses in this predominantly black Delta town.

title: NORTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: b-Includes pre-tax gains of about $11.4 million for the latest quarter and $4.4 million for the year-ago period from the sale of securities. The year-ago period was after a loss from discontinued operations of $1,200,000.

title: MOHASCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
NEW BAND OF OLD STARS IN A DEBUT AS THE GROUP
description: THE GROUP, which is giving its first public performance tomorrow at Greenwich House, is the latest evidence of a growing trend in contemporary jazz. First came Old and New Dreams, the band of former Ornette Coleman sidemen, then more recently Nu (with Don Cherry and Ed Blackwell) and the Ornette Coleman-Pat Metheny ''Song X'' tour. Band leaders are taking vacations from their customary duties to form working associations with other band leaders.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Jon Hendricks and Company, the Village Vanguard, Seventh Avenue South and 11th Street (255-4037). Over in England, teen-agers are dancing to the old Lambert, Hendricks and Ross albums, in clubs that cater to a new jazz-for-dancing trend. Jon Hendricks, who reverses the customary jazz procedure of copying vocal inflections on the saxophone by singing like a sax, is hip again. But while his supple scatting may once have been out of favor, he never abandoned it. His music captures a lifetime of blues and dues while insisting on a certain lightheartedness. It's soulful; it's also fun. Tonight through Sunday, around 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; $10 admission with a one-drink minimum.

title: Housing Officer Seized In Sex Abuse of Boy, 8
description: A housing police officer was arrested yesterday on charges of sexually abusing an 8-year-old boy in six separate incidents at the officer's home on Staten Island, the police said.

title: ANXIETY IN POLAND
description: Here in Poland's second largest city, as well as in other areas of the country, anxieties over the fallout from the Ukrainian nuclear accident tended to overshadow the ritual tug of war between the Government and the opposition over rival May Day celebrations.

title: Kaufman & Broad Lures Investment Executive
description: Ever since he left Chicago at age 17, Philip A. Barach has had wanderlust.

title: BROADWAY
description: IT doesn't seem that long ago, but that, of course, depends on who is doing the talking.

title: INDIA POLICE IN CONTROL OF SIKH TEMPLE
description: A force of nearly 2,000 paramilitary police completed a 12-hour operation this morning to regain control of the Golden Temple at Amritsar from several hundred Sikh radicals. But police officials said almost all the major radical leaders managed to escape.

title: BFI COMMUNICATIONS SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
UKRAINIANS IN NEW YORK TRY TO PIERCE A 'CURTAIN OF SILENCE'
description: Since the news of the nuclear disaster in the Ukraine, Maria Twerdowsky has been listening to the Kiev radio each day at 5 P.M. over the short-wave radio in her home in the Bronx. News of the accident has been scant and contradictory.

description: The latest first quarter includes sales of $14,884,000 by Maloney Enterprises Inc., acquired by Heck's in August 1985 and also the cost of closing one store during the period, which amounted to about $250,000, as well as just over a $1 million pretax loss incurred by Heck's Maloney chain. The year-earlier period's results benefited by an approximate $2.5 million pretax gain from the sale of a note including the interest earned on that note during the period.

title: U.S. CHALLENGING SOVIET WOMAN AT EX-F.B.I. MAN'S SPYING TRIAL
description: Prosecutors in the espionage trial of Richard E. Miller, a former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, today challenged a Russian woman's testimony that he never gave her classified documents or wanted to work for the Soviet Union.

title: Cajun Music
description: Beausoleil, from Louisiana, will play traditional Cajun music tonight at 8 at St. Ann's Church, at the corner of Clinton and Montague Streets in Brooklyn Heights (718-834-8794). Tomorrow at 8 P.M. there will be a country-blues double bill, with the duo of the guitarist-singer John Cephas and the harmonica player Phil Wiggins, and the guitarist-singer Archie Edwards. Tickets are $10, $8 for students.
