A Soggy Rose
description: Pete Rose, whose Cincinnati Reds have been shut out in 3 of their last 4 games and have lost 5 in a row and 9 of their last 10: ''When it rains, it pours. I'm drowning.''

title: 'HARD LOOK' BY U.S. DUE FOR SHOREHAM
description: A key Federal nuclear regulator said today that his agency would be ''taking a hard look'' at license applications of the Shoreham nuclear plant on Long Island and other planned nuclear sites in light of the Soviet accident.

title: BROCK HOTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax loss carryforward of $990,000 and a gain of $4,884,000 from the sale of four Holiday Inn hotels. c-Includes a tax loss carryforward of $6,372,000 and a gain of $21,500,000 from the sale of certain franchise rights and other properties.

title: AS WORRY OVER ACCIDENT RISES, SO DO SALES OF IODIDE PILLS
description: There is often more at work in the marketplace than the laws of supply and demand. Misfortune, too, can move commerce, can make a product a sell.

title: WISCONSIN POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ART: AT ARTISTS SPACE, 3 SURVIVORS OF 1930'S
description: ARTISTS SPACE, now well ensconced at 223 West Broadway, made a name for itself quite some years ago now by its championship of artists - most of them young - who had not yet managed to break into the gallery world. In this way, much good was done. Its present show, ''Moderns in Mind,'' takes three artists who are in a totally different situation. Between them, Gordon Onslow-Ford, Lee Mullican and Gerome Kamrowski must have around 150 years' experience of exhibiting. They rank, in fact, among the survivors of the 1930's who are still hard at work and still finding something to say.

title: Interest Rates Move Higher
description: Short- and long-term interest rates rose in quiet trading yesterday, as many speculators and investors adopted a wait-and-see attitude in advance of next week's Treasury auctions and the April employment statistics to be published today.

title: Market Place; STOCK 'FISHING' IN OIL SERVICES
description: ''BOTTOM fishing,'' or angling for stocks that show prolonged price declines, is a popular sport on Wall Street. It also can be hazardous to the pocketbooks of investors whose timing is off.

title: Diner's Journal
description: THE renascent Off Broadway neighborhood along West 42d Street has a major new attraction. The Village Lobster, a sparkling and animated new seafood house, formerly on lower Third Avenue, has pulled up anchor and docked at 444 West 42d Street, between Ninth and 10th Avenues.

title: Service for Joseph Kaselow
description: A memorial service for Joseph Kaselow, longtime advertising columnist for The New York Herald Tribune, is to be held at 12:15 P.M. next Thursday at St. Peter's Lutheran Church, 619 Lexington Avenue in Manhattan. Mr. Kaselow, who lived in Glen Rock, N.J., died April 9. He was 73 years old.

title: EXPLORING THE GREAT OUTDOORS: WALKING TOURS, STREET CELEBRATIONS AND A BUTTERFLY SAFARI
description: PULL the curtains aside and open the window. It isn't snowing. In fact, the sun is out and a breeze stirs the branches of the tree below, whose spindly shoots seemed so overly optimistic not very long ago. Spring has arrived at last. Now is the time to explore the streets, parks and waterfronts of the city, before the enervating heat of summer comes. And this weekend will be a good time to start that exploration.

title: LOHR TAKES 2-SHOT LEAD IN LAS VEGAS
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 1 -

title: Wells Fargo Deal
description: Wells Fargo Bank said it had agreed to sell seven northern California branch offices to the Hibernia Bank, which is based in San Francisco and is California's 19th-largest bank. The agreement was one of the conditions set by the Federal Reserve Board for Wells Fargo's purchase of the Crocker National Corporation. Terms were not disclosed.

title: DIBRELL BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Advertising; Raytheon's New Push
description: ALTHOUGH it had more than $6 billion in sales last year and has been running corporate ads with varying intensity since the 1950's, the Raytheon Company would like to be better known and better thought of among its several important publics.

description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

description: TULIPS, daffodils, scillas, wisteria and crabapples - spring's finest creations - are bursting upon the city. So are early azaleas and the first dogwood blossoms.

title: PINNACLE PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Grumman Net Falls by 25.4%
description: The Grumman Corporation, citing a decline in profits from its aerospace business, said yesterday that earnings fell 25.4 percent in the first quarter.

title: BANKING MAKES RETURN TO AVE. B
description: The community around East Third Street and Avenue B took it as a challenge two years ago when the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company decided there simply was not enough money in the neighborhood to keep its 55-year-old branch open. The closing left a 100-square block area without a bank.

title: Matwell Leads Memorial
description: A record field of 131 leading amateurs opened competition today for 16 qualifier spots in the William D. Richardson Memorial Tournament, the curtain-raiser for golf competition in the New York metropolitan area for nearly four decades.

title: Deception, Not Policy
description: In the first paragraph of Newsweek's excerpts from David Stockman's account of his years as the Reagan Administration's Budget Director, he writes that his ''real agenda'' was to cause ''drastic, wrenching changes in an established regime'' in order to achieve ''minimalist government.''

title: FIRST SOUTHERN FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $660,000 for the latest quarter and $497,000 for the earlier period.

title: Bill Proposes Standards For Financial Insurance
description: A bill introduced in the New York State Legislature yesterday would set new financial standards for insurance companies that issue policies covering bond issues and other financial transactions.

title: FIVE ARRESTED IN SMUGGLING OF $400 MILLION IN HEROIN
description: The owner of a Madison Avenue beauty parlor and four others were arrested by Federal investigators yesterday on charges of smuggling up to $400 million worth of Turkish-grown heroin into the United States by hiding it in the cosmetic bottles of their couriers.

title: THE SCREEN: 'FEMMES'
description: ''FEMMES DE PERSONNE,'' a French film that is the second offering of the director Christopher Frank, is sad, nostalgic and bleak - a love story without love. It is about the lonely lives of four women and their desperate and doomed search for some kind of feeling, contact or excitement.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, MAY 2, 1986
description: International

title: PANCRETEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Chemical in Deal To Buy Jersey Bank
description: In a major push to become an interstate bank, the Chemical New York Corporation said yesterday that it had entered into a definitive agreement to acquire the Horizon Bancorp once interstate banking between New York and New Jersey becomes legal.

title: SENATORS APPROVE $1 TRILLION BUDGET IN BIPARTISAN VOTE
description: The Senate early today overwhelmingly approved a $1 trillion budget for 1987 that would reduce President Reagan's request for the military by $19 billion and raise revenues by $13.1 billion, $7 billion more than Mr. Reagan had proposed.

description: Italian officials said today that the Government had agreed to a request by the Soviet Union for technical assistance in the wake of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster in the Ukraine.

description: President Reagan met for the first time today with a high-ranking representative of the new Philippine Government, and American officials said afterward that the encounter here had been marked by disagreements.

NCNB Acquisition
description: The NCNB Corporation said it had reached a definitive agreement to acquire Centrabank of Baltimore.

title: Florida's Pharmacists Can Write Prescriptions
description: Florida's 13,000 pharmacists today became the first in the nation to be allowed to write prescriptions, but many of them, fearing lawsuits, said they would ignore the new authority.

title: 2 FESTIVE WASHINGTON NIGHTS HONOR PAINTINGS FROM RUSSIA
description: ''It is human beings who are important -the feelings - they are more important than the rationale,'' declared Prof. Boris Piotrovsky, director of Leningrad's Hermitage Museum, as he gazed at the paintings by Matisse, Cezanne, Monet, Renoir and Gauguin. ''Fine art brings us closer together.''

title: CITIZENS GROWTH PROPERTIES (CO) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31

title: 'HORSE VAN TO HEAVEN'

As the last of 16 horses to arrive only hours before the entry box closed yesterday, Broad Brush is the obvious hunch choice for those who believe that the last shall be first.

title: NETWORKS INTRODUCING NEW SHOWS

ABC will begin unveiling -''and now it begins,'' promise the ads solemnly - its 12-hour production of ''North and South, Book II,'' the sequel to last season's Book I, based on the John Jakes novel ''Love and War.'' The subject is the Civil War. And NBC will broadcast the first half of a four-hour movie entitled ''The Deliberate Stranger.'' The subject is a serial killer, played by Mark Harmon.

title: RESTAURANTS

As for the food, the wide-ranging regional menu can bedazzle at times, making for a truly memorable experience. On some occasions, though, it fails to shine as brightly as the regal surroundings.

title: Books of The Times; Man and Nature
description: SELECTED POEMS. By Robert Bly. 213 pages. Harper & Row. Cloth, $18.95; Paper, $8.95. More than two decades have passed since the limpid, haiku-like poems of Robert Bly's first collection, ''Silence in the Snowy Fields'' (1963), appeared. In the ensuing years, the poet has changed directions several times - eschewing the realm of private emotions for noisy, public pronouncements on the Vietnam War in ''The Light Around the Body'' (1967) and ''The Teeth Mother Naked At Last'' (1970), and returning to a more pastoral mode in works like ''The Morning Glory'' (1975) and ''This Body Is Made of Camphor and Gopherwood'' (1977). What has remained constant in his work, as this new selection demonstrates, is Mr. Bly's interest in man's relationship with nature, and his commitment to an idiom built upon simplified diction and the free associative processes of the unconscious mind.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. 1. This is a novel form of weight control. What is it? 2. ''Bandits captured in battle are to be shot,'' said an entry in a daybook. What daybook is it and why is the entry noteworthy? 3. ''Water, water everywhere, will it ever end?'' a Government bulletin wondered, describing a situation in northern Utah that may transform the area's biggest asset into its biggest potential menace. What is happening? 4. An unexpected message from ''Captain Midnight'' shocked government and communications officials. What happened? 5. According to a mayoral survey of New York City's 59 community boards, (education/park maintenance/sanitation) has replaced police patrols as the primary concern of these local groups. 6. About 1.5 million workers stayed away from work in the biggest strike in their nation's history, pressing demands for an official May Day public holiday. What nation is it? 7. The Supreme Court ruled that prosecutors may not peremptorily exclude blacks from juries out of concern that they will favor a black defendant. True or false? 8. Three firms are combining to create the largest such company in the world. Name the firms. 9. Festivities in Japan celebrated this year as Showa 61, not 1986. Explain. 10. In Los Angeles, firemen battled a blaze in a building listed on the National Register of Historic Places. What building is it? 11. The New York Rangers' survival into the semifinals of the Stanley Cup playoffs has been a major surprise.

description: The Giants opened a two-day rookie minicamp yesterday at Giants Stadium. The participants were the 13 players selected in the National Football League draft Tuesday and 35 people who were passed over.

description: The nationwide movement to help Central Americans enter the United States and harbor them here will grow, not diminish, because of guilty verdicts Thursday against church workers charged with conspiring to smuggle aliens icans into the country, movement workers said here today.

The women in Miss Naylor's second novel, ''Linden Hills,'' are on a somewhat higher rung of the income ladder and live in an upper-middle-class black community.

description: The economic summit conference of the seven great industrial nations in Tokyo is taking place close to the 39th anniversary of Secretary of State George C. Marshall's memorable proposal, in a Harvard commencement speech, that the United States give financial aid to war-torn European countries ''willing to assist in the task of recovery.''

title: Bond Holdings Sells New Unit
description: The Bond Corporation Holdings Ltd. said today that it had sold its newly acquired British film unit, Screen Entertainment Ltd., to the Cannon Group Inc. of Israel for about $266 million in cash and common shares, reaping a profit of about $79 million after owning the unit for less than a week. Alan Bond, chairman of the holding company, said the group included 2,000 films, a major studio and a cinema chain.

description: The rapid spread of mandatory testing programs to identify employees who use illegal drugs is touching off a growing debate over whether private employers have the right to insist on such tests.

title: GINZA, YES, BUT MUCH MORE
description: The Ginza's lights, Shinjuku's skyscrapers, Marunouchi's solemnity, Roppongi's hipness - these are the images that travelers to Tokyo usually take home. They are not false impressions, simply incomplete. Tokyo, for the 11.8 million people who live in it, is not so much a city as a crazy-quilt fresco of self-contained villages, neighborhoods striated with seemingly random narrow roads and cluttered with houses so tightly packed that one could almost hear his neighbor shudder on a winter's night. It is a city of no-name streets, a place to lose oneself.

title: CRUDE OIL FUTURES AT A 9-WEEK HIGH
description: Futures contracts for crude oil closed at $14.73 a barrel yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, their highest level in nine weeks, and oil analysts said that the market was poised to move above the $15-a-barrel level.

title: CITY JOBLESS RATE UP TO 8.7%
description: Unemployment in New York City rose to 8.7 percent in April from 7.9 percent in March, largely because of continued weakness in manufacturing, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: ALVIN W. PEARSON
description: Alvin W. Pearson, former chairman and chief executive officer of the Lehman Corporation, died Monday while on a cruise from Singapore to Athens. He was 84 years old and lived in Upper Montclair, N.J.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Mike Fratello, who guided the Atlanta Hawks to a 50-victory season, the biggest improvement in the league - they won 34 games in 1984-85 - has been named the National Basketball Association Coach of the Year in a vote by 78 members of the news media. The 39-year-old, New Jersey-born Fratello left the Knicks, for whom he had been an assistant coach, to take over the Hawks for the 1983-84 season. Ted Turner, the owner of the Hawks, said Fratello would be offered a multiyear contract after the season. . . . Ivan Lendl, seeded first, was paired against Francesco Cancellotti of Italy in the draw held yesterday for the $500,000 Shearson Lehman Tournament of Champions that opens at the West Side Tennis Club Monday. Lendl, the defending champion and a winner in five of the six tournaments he has played this year, will be returning to competition after sitting out a month with tendinitis in his right knee. Boris Becker of West Germany, who will also be making his debut at Forest Hills, is seeded second. His opening match will be against Juan Aguilera of Spain. The tournament, with a top prize of $80,000, runs through next Sunday. . . . Marvin Webster, the 7-foot-1-inch center who retired from the Knicks in January, has been charged in White Plains with violating a court order that restricts his contact with his estranged wife and family. He was arrested and arraigned, then released without bail until a court appearance May 14. . . . Dr. Bobby Brown, president of the American League, has told the Cleveland Indians that it would be permissible for the team to enter a long-term lease for a proposed domed stadium as long as it contains escape clauses ''that would give them options and a semblance of control over their future.''

title: APRIL UNEMPLOYMENT WAS 7%, LABOR DEPT. SAYS

title: RACE OF 2 FAVORITES SEEN
description: Sixteen horses will run in the 112th Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs Saturday, but not since Affirmed dueled Alydar in 1978 and Spectacular Bid faced Flying Paster in 1979 has a Derby been so widely regarded as a two-horse race. Snow Chief is 6-to-5 on the morning line, Badger Land is 3-to-1, and every other horse is tabbed at 10-to-1 or higher.

title: U.S. IS AUTHORIZING 'TILT-ROTOR' PLANE
description: The Pentagon said today that it had decided to proceed with the development of a ''tilt-rotor'' aircraft at a total cost exceeding $20 billion. But the Pentagon suggested that it might back out of the program if costs were not kept in line.

title: PARLEY TO DISCUSS NUCLEAR ACCIDENT
description: Shortly after President Reagan arrived here for the economic summit meeting of industrialized democracies, the Administration indicated today that it expected the Soviet nuclear accident to become a major focus of three days of meetings.

title: Amending the Homosexual Rights Law
description: After 15 years of turmoil, New York's City Council passed a far-reaching homosexual rights law that Mayor Koch signed last month. Sexual orientation may no longer be the basis for exclusion from most jobs, living quarters or commercial transactions.

title: 4 More Enter Draft
description: With a midnight deadline approaching tonight, three college players - two of them former New York City high school basketball stars - have decided that three years of college ball were enough. Dwayne (Pearl) Washington of Syracuse University surprised almost no one yesterday when he announced he would give up his final year of eligibility to enter the National Basketball Association draft.

description: Of America's 115 large nuclear reactors, nine share characteristics with the runaway plant in the Soviet Union, Federal officials say. Each of the nine has extra safety equipment, but only one meets all safety codes for commercial reactors.

title: MONARCH MACHINE TOOL CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SCREEN: 'CUT AND RUN'
description: You don't often see movies where the shoot-out scenes pit machine guns against poison darts or where an American teen-ager roams the jungle wearing a Mickey Mouse T-shirt. But ''Cut and Run,'' which opened yesterday at the RKO National Twin and other theaters, piles up unlikely event after unlikely event, trying to be a trendy adventure.

title: PREVIOUS ISSUES
description: 1975: Rambouillet, France: Energy policies and the improvement of relations with developing nations. 1976: Dorado, P.R.: Reducing dependence on imported oil. 1977: London: Unemployment, preventing the spread of nuclear weapons, international arms sales, North-South talks and aid to developing nations, human rights and carrying out of Helsinki Accords. 1978: Bonn: Actions against nations that harbor aircraft hijackers. 1979: Tokyo: Energy crisis and reliance on foreign oil, plight of Indochinese refugees and commitment by nations to accept more refugees. 1980: Venice: Soviet sweep into Afghanistan, hijacking and hostage-taking, developing nations and need to improve their energy output, Middle East peace process, refugees in Africa, Caribbean and Asia. 1981: Ottawa: Proposed Soviet gas pipeline to Western Europe, fighting in Lebanon and Israeli raids, international efforts to deal with population growth. 1982: Versailles, France: Falkland conflict between Britain and Argentina, Israeli invasion of Lebanon, the effect of technological development, Soviet-European gas pipeline. 1983: Williamsburg, Va.: United States deployment of Pershing 2 and cruise missiles in Europe, United States-Soviet nuclear arms reduction talks. 1984: London: International terrorism, East-West relations and commitments to ''nonuse of force,'' arms control, Iran-Iraq war, human rights. 1985: Bonn: United States Strategic Defense Initiative, United States-Soviet nuclear arms talks, international drug trafficking.

title: COMPUTER HORIZONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
PVC CONTAINER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Pan Am Quarterly Loss Declines to $118.4 Million
description: The Pan Am Corporation yesterday reported a loss of $118.4 million for the first quarter.

title: BLUES WIN OPENER
description: Mark Reeds and Mark Hunter scored 66 seconds apart late in the third period tonight to rally the St. Louis Blues to a 3-2 victory over the Calgary Flames in the opening game of their Stanley Cup semifinal series.

title: TEA AND BATIK: THE FIRST LADY'S TOUR
description: Nancy Reagan may be feeling jittery, as some in the White House suggest. She is traveling on her own in Malaysia and Thailand at a time when fears about terrorist reprisals against the United States shiver through the Administration and the country.

title: MAN HELD IN DESIGN STUDENT'S MURDER
description: A part-time security guard from Brooklyn was arrested yesterday and charged with murdering a 20-year-old design student in the doorway of her brownstone apartment in the Fort Greene section last week, the police said.

title: FAREWELL, FED, FOR NOW
description: The chair in which he sat for 49 months in the Federal Reserve's elegant board room had already been shipped to his new Georgetown office as a keepsake, and Preston Martin, one of the board's great dissenters, was in an expansive mood when interviewed this week.

title: MALPRACTICE INSURERS STIR WRATH OF WEST VIRGINIA
description: Top officials here are moving rapidly to eject malpractice insurance companies from West Virginia and replace them with a state-owned insurance system. In the process, they are helping to turn this small state into a major battleground in the nation's liability insurance dispute.

title: PRETORIA GIVES SIGNAL ON TALKS ON REBELS
description: The South African Government has signaled its readiness to enter into talks about the possibility of legalizing the banned African National Congress and releasing Nelson Mandela, its most prominent leader, who has been in jail for nearly 24 years.

title: VERTIPILE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 1
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,156,000 from life-insurance proceeds for the company's former chairman and chief executive for latest year, and a charge of $1,155,000 for plant closing costs for previous year. c-Net loss

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, MAY 3, 1986
description: The Economy

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about a court fight between Jordache Enterprises and Guess? omitted the full name of an attorney for the Marciano brothers, founders of Guess? It is Marshall Grossman.

title: Kemp Near Settlement
description: Jan Kemp said yesterday that she had reached a tentative settlement with the University of Georgia under which she would receive $1 million and would return to the faculty. Mrs. Kemp, who had asserted that she was dismissed for protesting special classroom treatment for star athletes at Georgia, won $2.58 million in a Federal lawsuit decided in February. However, a judge last week ordered the amount reduced to $680,000. Mrs. Kemp, former coordinator of the English program in the remedial Developmental Studies Program at Georgia, said that under the terms of her reinstatement to the faculty, she would not report to the two administrators against whom she had brought suit.

title: CORRECTION
description: A front-page picture caption in Business Day on April 25 gave an incorrect date for a visit by Bernard Baruch to the college named for him. It was 1958, not 1953.

description: b-Net income

EDUCATION COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NO 'SILENCE,' SOVIET PRESS AIDES SAY
description: The chief spokesman for the Soviet Foreign Ministry denied yesterday that Moscow had imposed a ''premeditated silence'' on information about the nuclear accident in the Ukraine.

title: Aquino Dismisses A Police Chief
description: President Corazon C. Aquino dismissed a police chief today who she said had dealt too leniently with demonstrators calling for the return of Ferdinand E. Marcos.

BOWMAR INSTRUMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

title: DEAVER WAS IN WHITE HOUSE WHEN HIS FIRM WAS SET UP
description: Documents filed with the State of Delaware show that Michael K. Deaver's public relations concern was incorporated before Mr. Deaver left his position as White House deputy chief of staff.

title:
PATENTS;
NASA Air Sampler Used on Space Shuttle
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration received a patent this week for an air sampler that has been used on three space shuttle missions, including a flight of the space laboratory.

title: A Former Congressman Found Guilty of Bribery
description: A former Congressman was convicted today of paying a $25,000 bribe to an Indian chief for a contract to run bingo games on an Indian reservation in Louisiana.

title: Student at Pace University Raped in Campus Bathroom
description: A Pace University senior was raped and robbed last night in a bathroom in the main building of the downtown campus, the police said.

title: ASTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TOKEN CLERK INDICTED ON GUN CHARGES IN SHOOTING
description: A grand jury yesterday indicted a Brooklyn subway token clerk on weapons charges in the shooting death last January of a man who he said had tried to rob him of Transit Authority money.

title: BROADWAY FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GENTEX CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
What Mr. Statue of Liberty Thought of America
description: What kind of nation is captured in the symbol of a lady holding a torch? The answer, in part, is found in the original scribblings of a young Frenchman, Auguste Bartholdi, who first came to America in the summer and fall of 1871 to drum up support for his Statue of Liberty.

title: MUST SUNY AT BUFFALO BECOME A PIGSKIN FACTORY?
description: If the Board of Trustees gives its permission, we may be about to witness the Midwesternization of the State University of New York at Buffalo. And that would mean a big change in the university's character.

AMETEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
IN A CRISIS, WHO TO TUNE IN? IN THE SOVIET BLOC, PROBABLY WESTERN RADIO
description: Since Monday, with little information available from official sources about the nuclear accident in the Soviet Union, Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty have been a source of breaking news to their Soviet bloc audience.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, MAY 3, 1986
description: International

title: JOB CORPS CENTERS FACE CUTBACKS UNDER BUDGET
description: Six Job Corps centers will close as a result of spending cuts under the new budget-balancing law, Labor Department officials said today.

title: WESTWORLD COMMUNITY HEALTHCARE reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-l stock split distributed on June 10, 1985.

title: Pact to Boeing And Textron
description: The Boeing Company and Textron Inc. have been awarded a $497.3 million joint contract for full-scale development of a tilt-rotor aircraft for the armed services, the Pentagon said.

title: Voters in Warren, R.I., Reject Teacher Pay Plan
description: Residents of this factory town have voted nearly 10 to 1 against proposed pay increases for striking teachers of 18 percent over three years.

title: LTV-Erie Mining
description: The LTV Steel Company, a subsidiary of the LTV Corporation, said it had acquired the Erie Mining Company. Terms were not disclosed, but the company said the acquisition had been a result of equity interest exchanges with the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, Stelco Inc. and Interlake Inc., all former partners in the Minnesota Iron Ore Mining Company. LTV previously had a 35 percent stake in the company, Erie, which employs about 1,150 people, mines and processes low-grade iron ore into pellets, the basic iron feedstock of the steelmaking process.

U.S. TELLS WOMEN AND CHILDREN TO SHUN POLAND OVER HEALTH RISK
description: The United States Government today advised women of child-bearing age and all children not to travel to Poland because of the potential health hazards caused by the nuclear reactor accident in the Ukraine.

title: FUEL-PRICE DROP TO BRING SAVING IN TRANSIT COSTS
description: Plummeting fuel prices are expected to save millions of dollars for the New York area's mass-transit systems this year, but the savings will have only a minor impact on their operating budgets.

title: AROUND THE TABLE
description: The Schedule (All times are local. Tokyo time is 13 hours ahead of New York time.)

title: FIRST FARWEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

title: Double Duty on the Boards
description: It was not until noon yesterday that Christopher d'Amboise got out of bed - slowly.

title: BLUE JAY ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
JAPANESE FAVOR A GLOBAL ROLE, A SURVEY FINDS
description: Most Japanese believe their country has become a global power and that, as such, it should be playing a broader role in international affairs, according to a poll conducted by the New York Times, CBS News and the Tokyo Broadcasting System.

title: The Back Door to Oz
description: Say what you will about David Stockman's loyalty in publishing a book on his experience in the Reagan Administration while it still sits. Question his political sophistication if you must; assail his scathing characterizations of Donald Regan, the White House chief of staff, and others. Still, ''The Triumph of Politics'' yields a rare and valuable look into the illusions within the illusion. It takes the reader into the Emerald City through the back door and shows what Dorothy didn't discover until Toto knocked over the screen: Oz the Great and Terrible was a humbug.

title: TV: TWO NEW SERIES FROM BRITAIN ON 13
description: Two new series are being added to public television's roster of British imports. Both were produced for London Weekend TV, and both try hard to be as endearingly eccentric as only a certain English class and breed can be. ''Agatha Christie's Partners in Crime,'' on Channel 13 this evening at 9 o'clock, generally succeeds only in being silly. ''Mapp & Lucia,'' beginning on the same channel tomorrow at 10 P.M., is positively delicious.

title: 6 REACH NORTH POLE, WITH ONLY DOGS FOR HELP
description: In a grueling test of endurance and self-reliance, six American and Canadian explorers reached the North Pole yesterday evening after nearly two months of walking, jogging or skiing over the rugged Arctic ice pack. They were the first people to reach the Pole assisted only by dogs since Robert E. Peary planted a flag there in 1909.

title: SOUTHERN MINERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
'ANTI SOVIET HYSTERIA,' RUSSIAN TERMS REPORTS
description: A high Soviet official today accused Western journalists of exaggerating the Chernobyl nuclear disaster ''to whip up anti-Soviet hysteria.''

description: b-Net income

The latest year loss also includes a loss of $10,406,000 attributable to discontinued operations.

title: MERCHANT BANK HEAD RESIGNS HANVOVER POST
description: In a move that is expected to lead to a restructuring of the investment-banking division at the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, C. William Schroth has told top management that he will resign as head of the bank's merchant-banking group.

title: ANDREW CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
KOCH SEEKING INCREASE FOR INVESTIGATION UNIT
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that his new spending plan would nearly double the budget of the city's Investigation Department and give its commissioner broad new budgetary powers over the 23 inspectors general, who look for corruption and waste in city agencies.

title: SALVAGED CHINESE ITEMS ARE SOLD IN AMSTERDAM
description: More than 100,000 pieces of Chinese porcelain and gold bullion from a European merchant ship - wrecked two centuries ago in the South China Sea and salvaged last year by a British captain and his crew - were sold this week in Amsterdam for $15,255,102, one of the highest totals ever in an auction of porcelains.

description: b-Includes a loss of $75,000 from discontinued operations.

description: The New York City Art Commission, which reviews and approves works of art put in city buildings, as well as the design of all buildings and parks placed on city land, yesterday announced the 1985 winners of its annual awards for excellence in design.

title: WM. E.  WRIGHT reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
THE OUTLOOK FOR LOBBYING: CRITICAL CAPITAL IS PONDERING THE DEAVER EFFECT
description: Senator David Pryor, an Arkansas Democrat, complains he cannot walk down a Capitol corridor without being besieged by lobbyists. Senator David L. Boren, an Oklahoma Democrat, says farmers back home believe influential lobbyists for foreign interests prevented exports of United States farm products. Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, Ohio Democrat, says, ''The plain truth is that Washington has become a sinkhole of influence peddling.''

title: Mild Quake in Japan
description: A mild earthquake shook southwestern Japan today, but there were no reports of injuries or damage, the police said. The quake measured 4.6 on the Richter scale and had its epicenter in central Tokushima prefecture, about 300 miles southwest of Tokyo.

title: SEMICON INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
MILLICOM INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31

title: POLAND, TAKING A RISK, CHOOSES PATH OF CANDOR
description: In its approach to the fallout problems caused by the Soviet nuclear accident, the Polish Government has taken a clear foreign policy risk by showing far more candor than the Soviet Union.

title: The Waldheim File
description: Democratic members of the House Judiciary Committee are complaining that the Administration is pointedly keeping them in the dark on the Kurt Waldheim matter. They say, for example, that they cannot even confirm a report that a senior Justice Department offficial recommended banning the former United Nations Secretary General from entering the United States because of his actions as a German Army officer in World War II.

title: 'NO PASS, NO PLAY' RULE RAISES FUROR
description: When two high school football players here were benched under new ''no pass, no play'' rules last fall, nobody cried foul.

title: The Housing Crisis Is a National Scandal
description: To the Editor:

title: ROBERT H. SAVAGE
description: Robert H. Savage, a corporate specialist in investor relations, died Wednesday at the Bridgeport (Conn.) Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived in Stamford, Conn.

title: NUCLEAR TEST MAY HAVE FAILED, OFFICIALS SAY
description: An underground nuclear explosion to test the effects radiation has on military equipment experienced serious complications and may have been a failure, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: ASBESTOS SUIT GAIN BY SCHOOLS
description: A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, in Philadelphia, has unanimously ruled that schools can now decide for themselves whether to join in huge class action suits for damages against asbestos producers or sue on their own, raising complaints from asbestos lawyers that numerous schools will choose to sue individually.

title: DEAL ON MOGAMBO
description: A half-interest in the breeding rights to Mogambo, the third favorite for the Kentucky Derby, has been sold to Calumet Farm of Lexington, Ky., for at least $10 million, according to Peter Brant, the colt's owner.

description: ''While the President has serious reservations about individual aspects of the Senate budget resolution he believes it is important that the Senate passes a budget for 1987 and recognizes their effort.'' - Larry Speakes. [ 34:2. ]

Senator Out of Hospital
description: Senator Paula Hawkins, Republican of Florida, today left the hospital where she had undergone two operations to alleviate back pain. Doctors said it would be three weeks before she could resume her re-election campaign against Gov. Bob Graham, a Democrat. Mrs. Hawkins's chronic back pain was aggravated in 1982 when a television studio backdrop fell on her.

title: SOUTHEASTERN SAVINGS & LOAN CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bush Calls for Soviet to Give More Data on Atom Accident
description: Vice President Bush today challenged the Soviet Union to share more information about its nuclear accident, calling the secrecy about the disaster ''unconscionable.''

title: Margaret Diaz to Wed
description: Mrs. Alfred N. Wohlwend of Pelham Manor, N.Y., and Manuel Diaz of Muttontown, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Margaret Gilmour Diaz to William Gerard Flynn, a son of Mrs. John T. Flynn and the late Mr. Flynn of West Roxbury, Mass. A July wedding is planned. Her father is executive director of the Steamship Conferences of the North Atlantic.

title: PILOT OF CHALLENGER IS BURIED WITH FULL RITES AT ARLINGTON
description: In the first public service for any of the seven crew members who perished aboard the space shuttle Challenger, Comdr. Michael J. Smith of the Navy was buried today at Arlington National Ceremony with full military honors.

title: FROM PHAROAH'S TOMB TO FIFTH AVENUE
description: MANNEQUINS exist in a kind of historical limbo.

title:
THE GRIM TOLL OF CHERNOBYL;
COURTING A SIMILAR DISASTER IN THE U.S.
description: THE disaster at Chernobyl has renewed debate about the safety of nuclear reactors in general in the United States, but particularly about the five reactors that the Energy Department uses to produce plutonium and tritium for nuclear weapons.

title: IN BUFFALO, DEBATE OVER EFFECTS OF PESTICIDES
description: The health hazards posed by lawn-care chemicals were debated here Thursday before 300 people who crowded into the chambers of the Erie County Legislature.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: DONNA J. VITIELLO is at it again. Today the 39-year-old Pompton Plains woman is holding an auction at the Lakeland Unitarian Church in Wayne, and up for bids are services that Mrs. Vitiello talked her friends into donating.

title: THE PLAYERS
description: Traditional Users This broad category includes tourists and foreign workers who send their earnings home, as well as importers and exporters, multinational companies, government agencies, overseas investors, and international agencies. What distinguishes these players is their fundamental economic need to exchange one currency for another.

title: GREETING MANNEQUINS ON THE STAIRS
description: MANNEQUINS are an integral part of store design these days. ''The image of the store has a lot to do with the kind of mannequins it buys,'' said Ralph Pucci of Pucci Manikins in lower Manhattan.

title: Philadelphia Recruiting Drive Saves Catholic High School
description: The nation's oldest Catholic high school for boys will remain open because a recruiting effort has enrolled 250 freshmen for September.

title: WORKING HIS WAY THROUGH YALE, NONSTOP
description: Mark Hulak is a great guy, his Yale University roommates say, if you can find him.

title: FILM: AUSTRALIA'S 'BLISS'
description: ''Bliss'' was shown as part of the 1985 New Directors/New Films Series. Following are excerpts from Richard F. Shepard's review, which appeared in The New York Times Oct. 4, 1985. The film opens today at the Plaza Theater, 42 East 58th Street. EVEN in its moments of wildest and darkest comedy - which are sometimes difficult to distinguish from other intervals - ''Bliss,'' an Australian movie, is deadly serious. If it caused controversy Down Under, according to reports, it may cause more in the way of bewilderment here.

title: THE 'VAST WASTELAND,' 25 YEARS LATER
description: Twenty-five years ago, Newton N. Minow, the newly appointed chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, borrowed an image from T. S. Eliot and publicly labeled much of television's programming ''a vast wasteland.'' With some updating for subsequent technological developments, the bulk of that speech's criticisms remain surprisingly valid. Still locked in pursuit of the biggest possible audiences, television has become a citadel of the safe and the conventional. Formulas and stereotypes are the norm. Controversy or even mild discomfort are frowned upon. One glaring paradox: In a nation that traditionally celebrates rugged individualism, television actively discourages personal statements that might be deemed unsettling.

title: RED LIGHTS ARE FADING ON BALTIMORE'S DOWNTOWN STRIP
description: This city's red light district is fading, and a lot of people feel pretty good about it.

title: 'QUIET TRIUMPH' AT HAZARDOUS-WASTE SITE IN JERSEY
description: Residents here have fought for six years to save Burnt Fly Bog, a 40-acre tract of swamp and woodland poisoned by industrial waste.

title: Anne O'Neil Wed To Juan Ocampo
description: Anne Kennard O'Neil, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James M. O'Neil of New York, was married yesterday to Juan Manuel Ocampo, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Jaime Ocampo of Lake Bluff, Ill. The Rev. John E. Halborg performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York.

title: ME, MY THINGS AND I
description: WHEN MY friend Michael called, he was beside himself with excitement. ''Quick,'' he roared over his car phone (1985), ''you've got to meet me at my house! You've got to see it!'' ''It,'' I knew, was yet another milestone in Michael's quest for the ultimate status symbol. I quickly drove to Michael's house in Stamford, Conn., just 15 minutes away. Yet, when I arrived, I was shocked to find him sobbing inconsolably in his driveway, beating his fists on the roof of his black Ford Mustang turbo convertible (purchased last year, replacing a Saab, replacing a BMW, replacing a Volvo, replacing a VW Bug with a McCarthy sticker in the rear window). ''What's wrong?'' I asked. ''Look,'' Michael wailed, pointing at the roof of his post-modernist house (1982), where a massive white dish was perched above his solar heating panels (1983).

title: INVESTIGATION OF OIL SPILL IS ENDED BY COAST GUARD
description: A tanker that spilled 435,000 gallons of crude oil last fall after losing power and drifting aground should have dropped anchor to avoid the accident, a Coast Guard investigator has concluded in a report.

title: Linsey Tully Is Married
description: Nancy Lynne Tully, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Robert Tully of Armonk, N.Y., was married yesterday to Malcolm Alyn Birnbaum, a son of Beatrice Silver Kolton of Forest Hills, Queens, and Irwin Birnbaum. The Very Rev. James Parks Morton, Dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, performed the ceremony at the Tavern on the Green.

title: PEOPLE IN CRISIS DIAL A 'HELPLINE' IN NEW YORK
description: It was late when the phone rang, but not too late. The caller, her voice slurred and barely audible, said she had taken an overdose of sleeping pills and turned on the gas in her apartment. In the background a child was crying. While the woman was falling unconscious, the stranger she had called kept talking with her until he learned her name and address.

title: COOL AND COLLECTED FIRST LADY CONTINUES TOUR OF MALAYSIA
description: The Secret Service agents looked tense. The advance staff looked tense.

title: CAN'T STOP NOW, NO TIME FOR THEORY
description: A MAN OF LETTERS Selected Essays. By V. S. Pritchett. 305 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95.

title: Rosemary Clooney Sings at Michael's Pub
description: As much as any pop-jazz singer, Rosemary Clooney exemplifies the values of simplicity, straightforwardness, and fidelity to a composer's intentions. She spins out lyrics with a low-keyed conversational ease, complemented by a subtle undercurrent of humor and impeccable diction.

title: SIMPLE FARE
description: Whether it is called a club, a hoagie, a grinder, a BLT, a Reuben or a beef-on-weck, the sandwich is one of the most enduring and endearing classics of the American diet. Its name, shape, size and components may change from one region to another, but the appeal of piling high some meat or fish between slices of bread, then letting whimsy determine the garnish, is so fundamental as to be almost instinctual.

title: PSYCHOPATHORAMA
description: FUEL-INJECTED DREAMS By James Robert Baker. 323 pp. New York: Plume/ New American Library. Paper, $5.95. E. P. Dutton. Cloth, $15.95. ''THIS is Scott Cochran, macho superstud, male feminist, and untreatable schizophrenic. You're listening to Radio Noir.'' ''Fuel-Injected Dreams'' takes off with the voice of its manic D.J. narrator, a voice James Robert Baker seems to capture very well. Cochran is a middle-aged casualty of several broken marriages, a loner living in a dumpy Los Angeles motel, who pours all his energy into a late-night radio slot that he fills with most of the mid-60's pop groups that ever existed and a few more that Mr. Baker has invented, his sets cemented together with a fast, self-parodying patter that includes the occasional visionary, apocalyptic gleam. ''I wanna get on a death trip'' is a line Cochran throws away casually on the airwaves, but soon enough he gets his wish.

title: On Shrinking The Subways
description: One way to save New York's subway system, some transit planners have been suggesting, is to do away with part of it. Last week, under prodding from City Councilwoman Carol Greitzer of Manhattan, the Transit Authority acknowledged that it would formally study the possibility of eliminating parts of 11 lines.

title: Sandi Mendelson Becomes a Bride
description: Sandi Beryl Mendelson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Mendelson of Jackson Heights, Queens, was married yesterday to Bryon Cary Preiss, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Preiss of New York. Rabbi David B. Kahane performed the ceremony at the Woodcrest Club in Syosset, L.I.

title: 50,000 Pakistanis Rally For Opposition Leader
description: The opposition leader Benazir Bhutto was greeted by more than 50,000 cheering supporters today as she continued her drive for the ouster of the President, Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq.

title: HAZARDS LURKING ON COMEBACK TRAIL
description: THE hospital was a lonely place for John Montefusco. Reality set in. When the surgery was over, he lay quietly in bed, alternately believing that his career as a baseball pitcher - ''The only thing I know how to do,'' he says without shame - was both resuming and ending. There were elements of confusion, then relief.

title: THE TALE OF ROBINS ISLAND: NATURE VS. DEVELOPER
description: 9420>TWENTY-six years ago Lee E. Koppelman, the Suffolk County planning director, first placed Robins Island, a 434-acre spot in Peconic Bay, on a list of parcels the county should preserve in the natural state.

title: A CAT FROM CAPE COD COMES TO 'VISIT'
description: SHE was a foundling, born in a box in a station where our son, Kevin, pumped gas as one of his summer jobs. He thought she was the pick of the litter, quite irresistible with her patent leather black coat and eyes like beaming yellow headlights. What else could he do but bring her to the little house that he shared with five people while working in Cape Cod. The only trouble was that it was August; summer would soon fade into the beginning of another school term. What to do with the foundling?

title: MOVING ON TAXES AND THE BUDGET
description: AS the White House party made its way to Tokyo last week, concentrating on international matters, Congress pressed ahead with a domestic agenda that is in many respects very different from the President's. By a 70-to-25 vote, the Republican-controlled Senate approved the first bipartisan budget of the Reagan era, a plan for 1987 that cuts the White House's proposed military budget by $19 billion and raises revenues of $13.2 billion.

title: Dodgers Shut Out Cards for 7 in Row
description: Fernando Valenzuela pitched a five-hitter tonight for his first shutout of the season and the center fielder Reggie Williams saved a run with a diving catch as the Los Angeles Dodgers defeated St. Louis, 3-0, for their seventh consecutive victory.

title: TRACKING AN ERA BY ITS CLOTHESHORSES
description: TO the trained sociological eye, mannequins are more than clothes horses; they are barometers of social change.

title: S. R. Gates Wed To Joan Stempel
description: Joan Vicki Stempel, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur Stempel of Teaneck, N.J., was married yesterday to Stephen Raymond Gates, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd Gates of Norway, Me., and Weston, Mass. Judge John P. Ryan of the Virginia Domestic Relations and Juvenile Court performed the ceremony at Oatlands Plantation, a property of the National Trust for Historic Preservation in Leesburg, Va.

title:
ART;
CATCHING CORNERS OF THE HUMAN SPIRIT
description: ALICE NEEL has often been described as a ''collector of souls,'' as though her portraits were magical specimen cases in which the essences of her subjects were pinned like butterflies.

title: NEW AND VARIED FORMS OF FREE SPEECH
description: THE First Amendment's protection of freedom of speech and the press is being put to some unfamiliar uses these days, in part because new technology has spawned new modes of communication and in part because of the Supreme Court's movement into protecting corporate speech.

title: MONDELLO PUTS MARK ON G.O.P.
description: WHEN Joseph N. Mondello was elected chairman of the Nassau County Republican Committee three years ago, he set three goals: putting the party in the black, resolving the 1 percent kickback suit against it and demonstrating, he said, that ''you don't have to be feared to be an effective leader.''

title: PAST RIDES AGAIN AT DERBY MUSEUM
description: IN the sunny chill of the Churchill Downs parking lot, an improver of the breed took off his tan jacket to put on a brown sweater.

title: LETTERS TO A POPULAR AUTHOR FORM A NEW BOOK
description: WHEN Judy Blume moved to Fairfield County last fall, a local elementary school sent her a poster-size card that read: ''Welcome Judy Blume - We hope you like our town as much as we like your books.''

title: SOMETIMES THE ONE-ACT PLAY SAYS IT ALL
description: The one-act play has always had its ups and downs. When I first came to New York, I shared an apartment on MacDougal Street across from the Provincetown Playhouse. The theater was rarely used in those days, but I knew that in earlier time, it had been home to Eugene O'Neill and other serious and talented playwrights and their one-acts. And not long before my arrival in New York, Clifford Odets's ''Waiting for Lefty'' had been produced and had inspired many of the playwrights of his day interested in social change.

title: September Wedding for Laura Roulet To Rafael Hernandez, Future Lawyer
description: Dr. and Mrs. Norman L. Roulet of Shaker Heights, Ohio, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Laura Roulet, to Rafael Hernandez Mayoral, a son of Gov. Rafael Hernandez Colon of Puerto Rico and Mrs. Hernandez, of San Juan and Ponce. A September wedding is planned.

title: COORDINATING THE WORLD'S GROWTH; THE ISSUES
description: The seven industrial powers are not likely to alter the course of the world economy during their three-day meeting starting today, but they will be discussing where they want to move it over time. They are expected to take up these topics: The Pace of Growth Industrial world growth has picked up this year, but in the United States growth has been looking fragile and in Japan it has slowed as the yen has strengthened.

title: ON A SUNNY DAY IN SWEDEN, FEW WORRIES ABOUT RADIATION
description: In the affluent northern suburbs of Stockholm where Sweden's radiation watchdogs study their instruments, hundreds of families laid out picnic lunches on meticulously groomed lawns, basking in the warm spring sunlight today.

title: Candace F. Byers Planning to Wed Executive in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. James N. Byers 3d of Providence, R. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Candace Forman Byers to Robert Clermont Livingston Timpson Jr., a son of Elizabeth Hutton Timpson of Kent, Conn., and Nantucket, Mass., and Mr. Timpson of Southampton, L.I. The wedding is planned for June 21. Miss Byers is the manager of market information and analysis for the International Business Machines Corporation in Armonk, N.Y. Mr. Timpson is a vice president of industry marketing in I.B.M.'s Information Systems Group in Valhalla, N.Y. The future bride graduated from Miss Porter's School and Bennington College.

title: THE SUMMIT THAT FELL FROM THE SKY
description: MAYDAY Eisenhower, Khrushchev and the U-2 Affair. By Michael R. Beschloss. Illustrated. 494 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $19.95.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
FOCUS ON DISABLED
description: At least 94 booths will be set up to provide information for and about the disabled at ''Spectrum '86,'' a daylong exhibition Wednesday at the County Center.

title: CHAMBER: DEL TREDICI
description: THE Chamber Music Society ended its season Friday at Alice Tully Hall with the premiere of a work it had commissioned. David Del Tredici, who has been busy in important places around the city during the past week, was the composer, and the piece, called ''Haddocks' Eyes,'' featured a soprano-narrator and 10 musicians.

title: 'A Lesser Life'
description: To the Editor:

title: REMEMBER, YAAR, IT IS WE WHO FEEL SORRY FOR YOU
description: AMONG the least understood (misunderstood?) of Asian immigrants is the Indian.

title: EVENING IN CENTRAL PARK
description: During the summer in Cincinnati, people flock to a post-modern, Michael Graves-designed outdoor amphitheater next to the Ohio River to listen to classical music concerts. In Los Angeles, the Hollywood Bowl draws untold thousands to exchange cars for starlit evenings of culture. San Franciscans go to Golden Gate Park, Boston hosts the Boston Pops and the Boston Ballet by the banks of the Charles. In New York, there are concerts or opera or Shakespeare in the city's parks all summer long. Many of these avid music lovers, theatergoers, dance aficionados and opera buffs have more than culture in common, however. Call it a vice or call it a virtue - they are gourmets on the go.

title: CAREER COUNSELING IS AIMED AT OUT-OF-WORK LIGHTHOUSES
description: The ravages of nature and vandals are threatening some of the nation's Coast Guard lighthouses, but the once stately buildings can be saved without a lot of Federal help, preservationists say.

title: IN WHITE PLAINS, NEW LIBRARIAN HAS A MIND LIKE A CATALOGUE
description: THE large sign that greets the public entering the White Plains Public Library invites visitors to ''Meet LUIS - Search Him,'' but some of the patrons refrain from immediate interaction. It is not that LUIS is socially unacceptable but rather that LUIS is new and strange to them. Once introduced, however, many patrons are won over and profess enthusiasm and loyalty.

title: KNOCKOUT STRING ENDS
description: Mike Tyson, the undefeated heavyweight, heard boos today while achieving his 20th victory, a unananimous but close decision over James (Quick) Tillis, the first opponent he has failed to knock out.

title: NOTHING PREPARES YOU FOR APARTHEID
description: I SPRAWLED OUT IN THE BACK SEAT OF THE car, put a jazz tape in my cassette player and tuned my mind to another planet as two black South African journalists and I headed toward Johannesburg along a highway in the Orange Free State, a rarely compromising bastion of South African conservatism. We had spent most of the day covering the funeral of a former leader of the African National Congress, working under a pitiless sun in a patch of desolation that is part of the so-called black homeland of Bophuthatswana.

title: SECT CAUSES SPLIT IN JERSEY PARISH
description: Members of the Roman Catholic Church here assert that families who have joined a fundamentalist group are trying to take over the parish and its school. They also charge that the group, the People of Hope, is elitist and secretive.

title: FINDING A REAL HOME AWAY FROM HOME
description: My favorite tourist pastime is breaking and entering. Whenever I travel to a foreign country, the first thing I do is case the joint, looking for ways to get in. I don't want to remain forever the tourist, the perpetual alien, my nose pressed against the pane. I want some stranger to notice me, go to the door, invite me in and make me feel at home. I long for a close encounter of the tourist kind.

title: DISASTERS: RAIN, BUGS, ETC.
description: One July I planned a party at a beach house - giving a party outdoors in summer would be an easy way to entertain, I thought. It was going to be stress-free, I decided. No dressing up. A potluck buffet as effortless as the camaraderie. I had forgotten one thing, though: the power of the unexpected.

title: IN EUROPE, CALLERS DON'T ASK ABOUT WEATHER
description: From late Thursday until early Friday about 1,200 people phoned the West German Meteorological Service in Offenbach, but according to meteorological officials only two callers wanted to know about the weather.

title: Another Triumph for a Bird-Rescue Team
description: To the Editor:

title: ORGANIZATIONS CAN PROFIT FROM CRISIS
description: THE Westchester Opportunities Center and Wildcliff Museum have closed their doors. Alarming reports suggesting a similar fate are being heard about such diverse community agencies as the Alliance for Juvenile and Criminal Justice, the Hudson River Museum and various day-care centers. The drastic reduction in Government aid in recent years and proposed changes in the tax law are bringing many community agencies in Westchester to the crisis point.

title: A RETICENT RESPONSE TO NUCLEAR CALAMITY
description: IT may be months or years before the world learns exactly what happened at the Soviet Union's Chernobyl nuclear power station and why radiation was spewed over much of Europe. But one thing that emerged with striking clarity in the days after the incident was first reported was the profound difference between the surfeit of speculation, questioning and information that flooded the West, and the few bare facts divulged in the East.

title: THE GLORIES OF ANCIENT GLASS AND VASES
description: The offbeat antiquities that collectors pursue today are dictated by the dwindling supplies available and fluctuations in taste. These factors are reflected in two current exhibitions - ''The Legacy of Ancient Glass,'' at Michael Ward, 9 East 93d Street (through June 14), and ''Ancient Vases - Magna Graecia,'' at Andre Emmerich, 44 East 57th Street (through July 3).

title: EAST END TRASH SOLUTION EYED
description: LONG ISLAND'S five eastern towns are seeking a solution to the solid waste problem largely independent of the rest of the Island. But their efforts depend upon state approval, which state officials say is unlikely.

title: Kiev Team Wins
description: Using speed, teamwork and superior technique, Dynamo Kiev of the Soviet Union played a controlled attacking soccer match Friday night in Lyons, France, and defeated Atletico Madrid, 3-0, to capture the European Cup Winners Cup. Dynamo Kiev's hometown is near Chernobyl, where a nuclear accident took place last week. ''As far as the events of Chernobyl go, my players were aware of it but were not disturbed in their prepartion for the match,'' said the Dynamo coach, Valeri Lobanovski.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
A COMMUNITY WAS 'AT ITS FINEST' IN THE FACE OF BIGOTRY
description: MAY 6 - this Tuesday -marks Yom Hashoah (Holocaust Remembrance Day) in the Jewish calendar. For me, it is an opportunity to put down on paper an event that I and my community lived through.

title:
PAPERBACKS;
THE BEAST IN US
description: THE CARNIVAL OF THE ANIMALS By Moacyr Scliar. Translated by Eloah F. Giacomelli. 86 pp. New York: Available Press/ Ballantine Books. Paper, $4.95. THE ONE-MAN ARMY By Moacyr Scliar. Translated by Eloah F. Giacomelli. 153 pp. New York: Available Press/ Ballantine Books. Paper, $5.95. MOACYR SCLIAR is scarcely known in this country, although his reputation is strong and growing in his native Brazil. Since his collection of stories, ''The Carnival of the Animals'' (1968), Mr. Scliar has published 10 novels and many more short stories, and won prizes and a sizable audience.

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption in The Times Magazine on April 6 with the article ''The Guerrilla Network'' misidentified a Soviet installation in Nicaragua. The picture showed a Soviet hospital at Chinandega that was founded in 1982 to help flood victims in the region.

title: JAY TUROFF: A CLASSIC SUCCESS STORY LEADS TO DUAL PORTRAIT OF EX-TAXI CHIEF
description: Law-enforcement officials have drawn from a yearlong investigation a portrait of Jay L. Turoff as a political clubhouse loyalist catapulted into an important city position by two Democratic Party leaders, Meade H. Esposito and Stanley M. Friedman.

title: GIVING THE DRAGON AN EXTRA PUSH
description: Don't let the names fool you - there is not a lot in common between the Dragon Variation and the Accelerated Dragon, although both are Sicilian Defense cousins.

title: Tara Weiner Fiancee Of James M. Rutman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Weiner of Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Tara Elizabeth Weiner to James Morgan Rutman, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Darrett B. Rutman of Gainesville, Fla., and Durham, N.H. An August wedding is planned.

title:
ON LONG ISLAND;
For Empty Factories, New Life as Offices
description: IN the 27 years since he founded his yacht-building business, called Seafarer Fiberglass Yachts, Brian Acworth has built about 3,000 boats in his 40,000-square-foot industrial building in Huntington.

title: A Deadly Dare
description: As a railroad engineer for more than three decades (one who has had the calamity of killing a young teen-ager who found out with his life he could not taunt a high-speed train and move out of its path in time), I found Roger Hoffmann's article ''The Dare'' (About Men, March 23) shocking. It shocked me because there are impressionable young people who read The Times and might think the idea is exciting, just as Mr. Hoffmann did.

title: SHARING A BIT OF BRITISH HERITAGE
description: Whether it be the family farm or a turreted stronghold, Britain's historic homes often reflect the philosophy that an Englishman's home is his castle, with centuries of care evinced in well-groomed gardens or rooms of burnished antiques. Peeking at the facades of historic country houses through a hedgerow or peering at their treasures from behind a velvet rope on Sunday afternoons has always been one of the pleasures of traveling here. Now it is possible to spend the night in many of the historic houses, as more and more of their owners are choosing to take in paying guests - or even opening their homes as hotels.

title: Rape Suspect Indicted In 3 Other Sex Attacks
description: A Roosevelt Island man who has been held since last October in connection with the attempted murder and rape of a Columbia University student has been indicted on charges that he sexually assaulted three other women last August.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: PUEBLO POTTERY WORKS FROM NEW MEXICO A demonstration of techniques used by nationally known potters from Jemez Pueblo in New Mexico and the exhibition and sale of the works of the resident Gachupin family will take place Saturday from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. in the Scarsdale Girl Scout House Gallery. The prices here are $20 and more for necklaces, $50 for some bowls and vessels and up to $2,000 for the largest, and $600 for a large figure or a group of small figures - about half of the usual gallery charges in the Southwest market.

title: LAID OFF IN GOOD TIMES AND BAD
description: OUT OF WORK The First Century of Unemployment in Massachusetts. By Alexander Keyssar. Illustrated. 469 pp. New York: Cambridge University Press. Cloth, $49.50. Paper, $14.95. RECENT headlines tell us that Texas now has an unemployment rate of over 15 percent. A few years ago, workers fled Detroit and the Northeast squirmed under unemployment rates that climbed to 25 percent in some urban areas and single-industry towns. Next year, high unemployment could even threaten Silicon Valley. This is the 1980's, but it could well be any decade of the last 15. For as Alexander Keyssar demonstrates in this fine book, though the policies with which we confront it have changed, the fact of unemployment has remained a feature of American life from the early industrial age.

title: L.I. STUDENTS, ON RETURN, SAY KIEV LOOKED NORMAL
description: A second group of Long Islanders returned yesterday from a Soviet tour that included a stay in Kiev last week while a seriously damaged nuclear power station just to the north of the Ukrainian capital spewed enough radiation to touch off alarms through much of Europe.

title: A GREAT MAN'S DOODLES
description: AROUND THE DAY IN EIGHTY WORLDS By Julio Cortazar. Translated by Thomas Christensen. Illustrated. 288 pp. San Francisco: North Point Press. $22.50.

title: Publishing and Nonpublishing
description: To the Editor:

title: DOHNANYI SHOWS HIS METTLE
description: Americans ignore American conductors; check the number of Americans who lead major American symphony orchestras. But, it turns out, to slight the home-grown in favor of foreign exotics is an international tendency, not just a national one. American conductors have found favor abroad - most recently, Dennis Russell Davies, James Conlon, David Zinman - before they were recognized at home. And the reverse can happen, too - non-American conductors who win American success (perhaps because they have that intangible advantage of being foreign) and only then are prized at home.

title: SEATTLE SALMON BAKE
description: On those incomparable Northwest summer days when the sky is robin's-egg blue, the water a mass of sunny reflections and the air clear, fresh and pure, entertaining has a special air of celebration to it. Not even an occasional drizzle, almost inevitable in this rainy climate, can dampen the mood; Northwesterners enjoy their region and the vagaries of its weather. Whether a traditional salmon bake on a pebbled beach or a barbecue in the backyard, gatherings delight in the gifts of nature.

title: CHINA HAILS FINDS AT ANCIENT TOMB
description: Reports of fresh archeological discoveries come virtually every week in what Chinese archeologists have described as the greatest era of discovery since their science took root here in the 19th century. But the superlatives have rarely rolled out as they have for the huge tomb attributed to a slave-owning duke who lived more than 2,500 years ago.

title: SWAMPSCOTT, CASH SHORT, EYING A LONG SHOT
description: If this community's 324 town committee members reject a proposal to gamble municipal funds on the state lottery, they may decide to throw in a dollar each to play, according to a sponsor of the proposal, which was born as a joke.

title: A CLASSICAL SHOWPIECE
description: ALLAN GREENBERG IS NOT an architect obsessed with reinventing the wheel. He is perhaps America's pre-eminent classical architect today, and his life's work has been a mission to establish the validity of classicism as an architectural language in our time. His designs, which include a new suite of offices for the Secretary of State at the State Department in Washington, are personal variations on classical precedent -buildings and interiors that draw heavily from the architecture of the past, but that invariably contain elements that mark them as his own.

title: THE GAMES CHILDREN PLAY: ALL TOO REAL
description: I WAS Dale Evans in 1957. I had an assortment of six-shooters that rivaled Annie Oakley's. I planned to grow up and marry Buffalo Bill Cody.

title: IN ONE HELL OR ANOTHER
description: HIROSHIMA JOE By Martin Booth. 441 pp. Boston: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $17.95. WHEN we meet the World War II veteran Joe

title: WATER IS CONCERN FOR WESTCHESTER
description: Westchester County, which shares New York City's water and so its water problems as well, is studying ways to increase the county's supplies, particularly for its rapidly growing northeastern corner.

title: SAVORING SPIRITS
description: Summer is the time for white. White clothes, white sand and white distilled spirits. Mention vodka or gin by the swimming pool and visions of tall Bloody Marys or gin and tonics come to mind. Nothing transports thoughts more smoothly to breezy Caribbean beaches than a frothy rum daiquiri. An icy tequila margarita adds a little south-of-the-border spice to any summer cocktail party. The temperature rises, and long, cold, mixed drinks appear; over the last 10 years or so, as a premium on lightness in taste has surfaced, these are more and more often made with white spirits. Moreover, an increasingly sophisticated drinking public is seeking variety, especially during the summer. Again, the call goes out for drinks with a light touch.

title: EASTERN BRAZIL EXPORTS INFLUENTIAL POP TO THE WORLD
description: Belo Horizonte, the capital of the Minas Gerais province in eastern Brazil, began as a mining town. It is now one of Brazil's major cities, but the vicinity is still best known for the mines that gave the province its name. Its other principal export is the music of a unique group of artists who have had an important impact on jazz and popular music, not just in Brazil but in the United States and Europe as well.

title:
GARDENING;
FOR A PRETTY BORDER, TRY BIENNIALS
description: A BIENNIAL is a plant that is started from seed one year, flowers the next, then dies.

title: THE RUSSIANS ARE TALKING PEACE, BUT ALSO DIGGING IN
description: AFTER more than six years of inconclusive warfare in Afghanistan, the Soviet Union appears to have adopted a contradictory strategy: seeming to move toward a diplomatic solution while simultaneously deepening its involvement in the country.

title: FUTURE SHOCK: THE JAPANESE AND THE PRESS
description: When the planners of the Tokyo summit conference got a chance to show off Japan's latest technology to the world's leaders and the world press, the last thing they needed was for something to go wrong.

title: Susan Ginsburg Plans to Marry
description: Mrs. Ina Ginsburg of Washington and David Ginsburg of Alexandria, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Ginsburg, to Peter Nordberg, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Nordberg of Fox Point, Wis. A September wedding is planned.

title: Baseball's Hits And Misses
description: Leonard Koppett captures, like no other author, the real feeling of what baseball is all about. His use of statistics to aid in the analysis and discussion of the game is indeed the key to its enjoyment. I will keep this article for my son, who is a budding 7-year-old fan, to read when he reaches a more mature ''baseball discussion level.'' HOWARD HERZOG Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: SCHOOL DISTRICTS FIGHT TAX CODING
description: A HUNTINGTON school district has won a court victory against a state tax coding system that school officials say has cost districts millions of dollars in state aid in recent years.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: A WIDENING ATLANTIC? DOMESTIC CHANGE & FOREIGN POLICY. By Ralf Dahrendorf and Theodore C. Sorensen. (Council on Foreign Relations, $5.95.) It is a pity this thoughtful book should appear nowadays, amid the noise of explosions in Tripoli.

title: The Gotti Trial Is Postponed Until August
description: Jury selection for the racketeering trial of John Gotti, reputedly the head of the Gambino organized crime family, had been in progress for 10 days last week when Federal District Court Judge Eugene H. Nickerson excused 31 prospective jurors who had passed an initial screening. He announced that selection would begin over again, using different procedures, on Aug. 18.

title: GARAGE PROJECT IS UNDER WAY IN MOUNT VERNON
description: AFTER years of planning and a few false starts, work has begun on a $6 million multi-level parking garage that will cover a section of the Metro- North New Haven Line railroad tracks set in a 26-foot-deep ''cut'' running through the center of Mount Vernon.

title: DISASTER IN UKRAINE IS CALLED WORST EVER BY U.S. TASK FORCE
description: Federal officials said today that the latest information they had received on the Soviet reactor accident confirmed that it was the worst such accident in history but left many critical questions unanswered.

title: CABARET: KITT MORAN, AT PADDY QUINN'S
description: KITT MORAN is a bright-eyed, enthusiastic, outgoing singer who uses these assets very effectively to sell her songs. But she does not depend on them entirely in her programs at Paddy Quinn's, 945 Second Avenue near 50th Street, where she is singing Wednesdays through Saturdays.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: IT WAS only a few years ago that New Jersey gained a reputation as ''Cancer Alley,'' a name that came from its high incidence of some forms of cancer. But the state also has become the home of what is said to be one of the fastest-growing cancer research centers in the nation: the Center for Molecular Medicine and Immunology at the University of Medicine and Dentistry in Newark.

title: Jackson Sought After Dispute
description: The California Angels outfielder Reggie Jackson was sought by the police today after an autograph-seeker was sent to a hospital following a scuffle at a tavern.

title: ITALIAN SAYS SUMMIT CHIEFS PLAN TO CONDEMN TERRORISM
description: The leaders of the seven major industralized democracies are ready to endorse a broad ''statement of will'' for resisting terrorism, Prime Minister Bettino Craxi of Italy said today after a private meeting with President Reagan.

title: Wilber Morris And His Group Perform
description: The bassist Wilber Morris is a self-effacing band leader with Wilberforce, which performed Thursday at Greenwich Music House. He writes eccentrically shaped tunes, states them in unison with the group, then returns to the role of firm, unflashy accompanist.

title: CONSIDER DAHLIAS: A SUMMER SHOW
description: A dahlia tuber looks as slight and unremarkable as a sweet potato. Yet the energy it puts into growth and bloom from late summer to killing frost would make fossil fuels outmoded if they could be harnessed.

title: RESEARCHERS FAULT HOSPITAL-FEE SYSTEM
description: FIVE years into the state's pay-by-the-illness approach to controlling hospital rates - a period ended in December 1984 - hospital care in New Jersey cost less than the averages for the Northeast and the nation, according to the latest statistics from the Princeton-based New Jersey Hospital Association.

title: Virginia Newman Wed To Thomas J. O'Gara
description: The wedding of Virginia Isette Santos Newman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence W. Newman of New York, to Thomas J. O'Gara, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph O'Gara of Saddle River, N.J., took place yesterday. The Rev. Norman Pelletier performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the St. Jean Baptiste Church in New York.

title: Dr. S. A. Karpow Weds Dr. Celeste Schmucker
description: Dr. Celeste Ann Schmucker, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Schmucker of Jamaica, Queens, and Baiting Hollow, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Serge A. Karpow, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Serge A. Karpow of Alameda, Calif. The ceremony was performed at the Holy Family Roman Catholic Church in Flushing, Queens, by Msgr.

title: Spiritually Unbettered
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Soviets owe the world an explanation; a full accounting of what happened at Chernobyl and what is happening now is the least the world community has a right to expect.'' -President Reagan. [ 1:5. ]

title: RUMANIAN DENIAL ON ALERT
description: Rumania today denied reports that it had declared a state of alert after an increase in radioactivity from the Chernobyl nuclear accident.

title: Deaver Asks for An Independent Investigation
description: In 1984, Edwin Meese 3d, bombarded with questions about his financial dealings, asked for the appointment of a special prosecutor; Mr. Meese was ultimately cleared and confirmed as Attorney General. Last week, his old friend, Michael K. Deaver, the former White House aide who has been accused of running afoul of Federal conflict-of-interest statutes with his lobbying activities, took the same route, asking Mr. Meese for a independent counsel to investigate the charges.

title: A June 7 Wedding For Carolyn Field
description: Dr. and Mrs. James B. Field of Houston and Sea Pines Plantation, Hilton Head, S.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter Carolyn Rundle Field to Gerard Anthony Purcell, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Purcell of Farmingdale, L.I. A June 7 wedding is planned. Miss Field graduated from the Winchester-Thurston School and received a B.A. degree in art history from Middlebury College.

title: Pillsbury Gets His Walking Papers
description: After the appearance earlier in the year of news stories about secret Administration plans to provide sophisticated heat-seeking Stinger missiles to anti-Communist insurgents in Afghanistan and Angola, the Government launched a search for loose lips - a hardly uncommon and rarely successful enterprise. But last week officials disclosed that a source of the Stinger story had been Michael E. Pillsbury, a senior Pentagon aide, and said that he had been dismissed.

title: A Mother Goose Chase Leads to Charlemagne
description: To the Editor:

title: The White House Unveils an Insurance Plan
description: The Reagan Administration last week formally responded to what is widely considered a crisis in the liability insurance industry. It sent Congress three proposals that would, among other things, protect Federal contracters and the Government itself, as well as manufacturers, against awards in personal injury higher than $100,000.

title: Man, 76, Is Charged in Death Of Brother at Nursing Home
description: An 84-year-old man died early yesterday after his 76-year-old brother hit him on the head with a bowling trophy in an argument in a Queens nursing home, the police said.

title: STAGE: HOWARD GOLDBERG'S 'BUSKERS'
description: IN one of the funniest scenes in the film ''Tootsie,'' Dustin Hoffman sees a mime posing precariously in Central Park -and pushes him over. At the Stage Arts Theater for Howard Goldberg's ''Buskers,'' a musical about New York City street performers, one feels the urge to tip over the entire show.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: MEMORIES OF THE ASSASSINATION ATTEMPT AND OTHER STORIES. By Gerard Windsor. (Penguin, $5.95.)
