You begin to get a feeling for this collection of stories by the Australian Gerard Windsor by reading some of the titles: ''Can These Bones Live?,'' ''Wedding Presents for Breakfast,'' ''The Archbishop or The Lady.''

title: Jets Sign Ehrhardt
description: Tom Ehrhardt, the record-breaking University of Rhode Island quarterback from Queens who was passed over in the National Football League draft, has signed a free-agent contract with the Jets, the club announced yesterday. Ehrhardt played for Holy Cross High School in Flushing, Queens, and then for C. W. Post before transfering to Rhode Island, a Division I-AA school, for his last two seasons.

title: Tax Reform Alive Again
description: The battered bill to rewrite the Federal tax code suddenly breathes again. The Senate Finance Committee, which only two weeks ago seemed determined to write a worse code, is now considering a dramatic shift that comes close to true reform. The promise of such a breakthrough is exciting. What seems to be needed to move it to the floor is a strong dose of political fortitude.

title: Recent Sales
description: Bernards Township $259,000 1273 Mount Airy Road *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 14-year-old colonial; *2*family room with raised-hearth fireplace, master-bedroom suite; *2*taxes $3,390. Denville $375,000 50 Copeland Road *2*6-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 1-year-old colonial; *2*leaded glass, sunken living room with fireplace, foyer; taxes $3,422. Fords $82,500 13 Ryan Street *2*2-bedroom, 2-bath, older colonial; *2*fenced yard, attached garage, double-pane windows; taxes $1,123. Lake Hopatcong $139,900 11 Espanong Road *2*3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 16-year-old split level; *2*patio, 2-car garage, finished basement; taxes $1,739. Long Valley $146,000 68 West Valley Brook Road *2*4-bedroom, 1-bath, 25-year-old colonial; *2*oak kitchen cabinets, sun room; taxes $2,570. Westfield $205,000 860 Shadowlawn Drive *2*3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 36-year-old colonial; *2*breakfast room with skylight, basement rec room; taxes $3,641. OTHER AREAS East Williston, L.I. $290,000 14 Post Lane *2*3-bedroom, 2-bath, 7-year-old high ranch; *2*eat-in kitchen, den; taxes $3,300. White Plains, N.Y. $77,000 16 Lafayette Drive *2*8-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 62-year-old frame colonial; *2*open front porch, eat-in kitchen; taxes $1,296. Danbury, Conn. $147,000 5 Wood Street *2*3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 5-year-old colonial; *2*brick exterior, custom kitchen; taxes $1,400.

title: Alden Tullis Is the Bride Of Educator
description: All Angels Episcopal Church was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Alden Swift Tullis, a daughter of Robert Wood Tullis of Chicago and Mrs. Rowan Schurz of South Bend, Ind., to Thomas W. O'Brien, a son of Mary O'Brien of Riverdale, the Bronx, and the late William C. O'Brien. The ceremony was performed by the Revs.

title: Politics of the Press
description: To the Editor:

title: 'JEWISH HUMOR' SERIES, CO-SPONSORED BY YIVO
description: JEWISH humor - the humor of song and skits by the likes of Irving Berlin, Smith and Dale, and Eddie Cantor - will be tackled for the purposes of both fun and learning in the first of a two-part series that starts this afternoon at 2 o'clock.

title: CAN CITY HALL SLAM THE DOOR ON FUTURE SCANDALS?
description: WHILE the full extent of corruption in New York government is still far from clear, major elected officials were all but falling over each other last week with plans to keep what happened from happening again.

title: WHEN ONE EATERY IS LIKE TWO
description: CAN you transfer success? That is a question asked when a good restaurant branches out, and was uppermost in our minds when we arrived at Apulia in South Norwalk.

title: Phil Gramm And Federal Spending
description: I find it ironic that the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings bill should claim to drive down the deficit by cutting programs across the board.

title: JAPANESE ENSEMBLE GIVES NEW LIFE TO AN OLD TRADITION
description: Anyone attempting a quick lunch at a sushi bar knows that things Japanese are popular in New York. In terms of music this means that one can take Japanese zither or flute lessons in Queens or attend performances of ancient Japanese dance, traditional Japanese drama or contemporary Japanese music in Manhattan.

title: OFFICIALS CITE 49 FOOD OULETS
description: The New York City Health Department last week released a list of 49 food establishments cited for violating the Health Code.

title: Leslie Wilcott Marries Hunt Henrie in Boston
description: Leslie Hudson Wilcott, a daughter of Mrs. Gardiner Wilcott of Concord, Mass., and Harry W. Wilcott of Boston and Ogunquit, Me., was married yesterday to E. Hunterson Henrie 3d, the son of Barbara Henrie Faricy of Washington and St. Paul and Dr. Edwin J. Henrie of Newport, R.I. The Rev. Enid Watson performed the Congregational ceremony at the Somerset Club in Boston.

title: Verbatim; Bitterness In Europe
description: EUROPEANS were angered last week as radiation from the Soviet nuclear accident in the Ukraine drifted west and north without warning and with only the barest explanation. The frustration was evident in Scandinavia and in the seven-country Western European Union, where foreign ministers discussed the fallout at a meeting in Venice.

title: NEW STAGE, AND NEW HOPES, FOR A QUEENS TROUPE
description: It is a dream for the Black Spectrum Theatre Company: to bring together the white-collar and the blue-collar, the tuxedo crowd and the corner crowd of St. Albans, a predominantly black community in southeast Queens.

title: Frances Mei Soo Woo Married to Gary Hoppe
description: Frances Mei Soo Woo, a daughter of Lai Shou Woo of Seattle and the late On Lung Woo, was married yesterday to Gary Hoppe, a son of Laura B. Hoppe of Rochester and the late Earl O. Hoppe. The Rev. Thomas D. Bowers performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York.

title: HELPING CHILDREN TO COMBAT DEAFNESS
description: A year ago, 2-year-old Adrienne Thal was diagnosed as having profound loss of hearing.

title: CHICAGO'S MAYOR CAN ACT AS A MAJORITY OF ONE
description: THE results of last week's two runoff elections appeared to bring a lull in the fighting around City Hall here in, as a local newspaper called Chicago, Beirut on the Lake. But after Harold Washington, the city's first black Mayor, had defeated the Democratic machine and gained control of the City Council, albeit by a hair, two questions were being raised. First, how well will the Mayor govern now that he has control? Second, with his victory, has the Mayor, who will be up for re-election next year, lost a valuable campaign issue - the opposition bloc he could have continued to blame for City Hall's shortcomings?

title: DOWN ON ITS LUCK, PORTUGAL STILL HASN'T BOTTOMED OUT
description: IN this sunny hamlet of 2,000 people, far off the main highways, David Morgado, a gray-haired, whimsical farmer, looked at his neighbors, sighed and said: ''It's beautiful living here. I like the calm.''

title: Art
description: ''Sots'' art is a breed of art known here since the late 1970's, when the team of Russian artists known as Komar and Melamid clandestinely shipped to this country works that satirized the Russian bureaucracy. (The two coined the word ''Sots,'' short for ''Socialism,'' as an ironic equivalent for the American term ''Pop.'') In Sots art, banal symbols, icons and signs of the Soviet state are used as departure points for art that can be ironic, nostalgic or comic. Komar and Melamid are its most famous practitioners, but they have been joined here by a number of other Russian emigres.

title: Eddie Monteiro And Nancy Marano
description: The unusual duo of Nancy Marano, a singer, and Eddie Monteiro, who sings and plays accordion, is rarely heard in New York clubs or concert halls largely because Mr. Monteiro is in great demand for private parties. But the series of Thursday afternoon concerts in the arcade of the Olympic Tower - which start at 5:30 - enabled them to give one of their infrequent performances together last Thursday.

title: A Judge Again Freezes Realty Tied to Marcos
description: A Federal judge issued a preliminary injunction yesterday that continued a ban on any transfer of five properties in the New York area that the Philippine Government contends were acquired with funds improperly amassed by former President Ferdinand E. Marcos and his wife, Imelda.

title: Halley's Sequel
description: The first recorded sightings of the Eta Aquarids, which is what astronomers call the meteors that trail like camp followers behind Halley's Comet, were in the year 401 A.D. They come back twice a year, regardless of the position of the comet itself, and the next scheduled visit began yesterday and runs through early Tuesday morning. The Naval Observatory, which monitors such things, says it will be quite a show.

title: HAMBURGERS, CALIFORNIA-STYLE
description: A long white limousine pulls into the neon-lit parking lot of a drive-in restaurant. The driver gets out and returns several minutes later with three hamburgers smothered in a medley of vegetables and a trio of sauces. The host of the evening, a movie star too famous to show his face, pours his guests Champagne from a silver cooler. For the next 10 minutes barely a word is spoken, as grease, mayonnaise, scraps of lettuce, tomato seeds and juice drip and fall onto the leather car seats and three pairs of designer jeans. This is dinner on the town in Los Angeles, the hamburger capital of the world.

title: JUDGE IN DENVER BUSING CASE
description: William Edward Doyle, a Federal appellate judge who presided over a landmark desegregation case in Denver that began in 1968 and took six years to bring to an end, died Friday at St. Joseph Hospital in Denver. He was 75 years old.

title: Iran and Iraq Report Fighting Along Border
description: Iran and Iraq today reported heavy overnight fighting on the south-central war front where Baghdad said earlier this week that it had entered Iranian territory for the first time in four years.

title: PROTESTERS BATTLE POLICE IN SOUTH KOREA
description: Thirty riot policemen were reported injured today in clashes after they fired tear gas to disperse crowds estimated at 10,000 people at an anti-Government rally in this port city.

title: IMMIGRATION BILL IS STILL AT SEA
description: FOR the third time in five years, the House Judiciary Committee was set to take up a comprehensive bill to curtail illegal immigration this week. But the session was postponed at the last minute, and the bill drifted into limbo. Similar bills, pronounced dead in the past, have come back to life, but they never finished the legislative marathon before the clock ran out with the adjournment of Congress. Whether this year will be any different is a hotly debated question.

title: ON LIBYA'S CAMPUSES, THE ENEMY IS ENGLISH
description: At Al Fatah University, a bustling campus of concrete high-rises and outdoor cafes here, Mohammed had just come from his physics class.

title: BEST SELLER: MAY 4, 1986
description: Weeks This Last on Week Fiction Week List 1 A PERFECT SPY, by John le Carre. (Knopf, 3 2 $18.95.) The tale of Magnus Pym, a British secret agent, and his father, Rick, a flamboyant con man. 2 THE BOURNE SUPREMACY, by Robert Ludlum. 1 9 (Random House, $19.95.) The hero of ''The Bourne Identity'' foils a plot to seize Hong Kong and bring China into conflict with the West. 3 I'LL TAKE MANHATTAN, by Judith Krantz. 2 2 (Crown, $18.95.) Rich and beautiful Maxi Amberville conquers the world of magazine publishing. 4 BREAK IN, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $17.95.) 4 7 Mystery, melodrama and bitter family rivalry in the world of British steeplechase racing. 5 THE MAMMOTH HUNTERS, by Jean M. Auel. 6 24 (Crown, $19.95.) Ayla continues her adventures in the prehistoric world. 6 LAKE WOBEGON DAYS, by Garrison Keillor. 5 36 (Viking, $17.95.) Yarns about life in a small Minnesota town. 7 LIE DOWN WITH LIONS, by Ken Follett. 7 14 (Morrow, $18.95.) An Englishwoman caught between the C.I.A. and the K.G.B., romance and loyalty, in Afghanistan. 8 HOME FRONT, by Patti Davis with Maureen 8 6 Strange Foster. (Crown, $15.95.) A semi-autobiographical novel by the daughter of President and Mrs. Reagan. 9 SEASONS OF THE HEART, by Cynthia Freeman. 9 6 (Putnam, $17.95.) A businesswoman is torn between devotion to her husband and her mentor. 10 JOANNA'S HUSBAND AND DAVID'S WIFE, by 12 7 Elizabeth Forsythe Hailey. (Delacorte, $17.95.) Two sides of a marriage revealed through diary entries. 11 THE SONGS OF DISTANT EARTH, by Arthur C. 1 Clarke. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $17.95.) After the destruction of the solar system, two groups of survivors from earth meet on a paradisiacal planet. 12 HIGH JINX, by William F. Buckley Jr. 11 4 (Doubleday, $16.95.) Blackford Oakes on the trail of the traitor who spoiled a plan to liberate Albania. 13 THE HANDMAID'S TALE, by Margaret Atwood. 10 10 (Houghton Mifflin, $16.95.) In the America of the future, men and women perform assigned services. 14 NERILKA'S STORY, by Anne McCaffrey. (Del 13 5 Rey/Ballantine, $12.95.) While fighting a plague on the planet Pern, Nerilka finds a true love. 15 THE WHITE HOUSE MESS, by Christopher 2 Buckley. (Knopf, $16.95.) A parody of White House memoirs, set in the post-Reagan years. Nonfiction 1 YOU'RE ONLY OLD ONCE! by Dr. Seuss. (Random 1 8 House, $9.95.) A checkup at the Golden Years Clinic in pictures and rhyme; the first Dr. Seuss book for adults. 2 BUS 9 TO PARADISE, by Leo Buscaglia. (Slack/ 2 12 Morrow, $16.95.) Another trip with the ebullient advocate of the virtues of love. 3 NECESSARY LOSSES, by Judith Viorst. (Simon & 16 2 Schuster, $17.95.) Life is a series of losses, the author argues, and we must confront them in order to grow. 4 WHEN ALL YOU'VE EVER WANTED ISN'T ENOUGH, by 5 3 Harold S. Kushner. (Summit, $16.95) A rabbi discusses ''the search for a life that matters.'' 5 THE GREAT GETTY, by Robert Lenzner. (Crown, 4 9 $18.95.) The life and loves of J. Paul Getty, who was the richest man in the world. 6 THE MAN WHO MISTOOK HIS WIFE FOR A HAT, by 3 5 Oliver Sacks. (Summit, $15.95.) The loss of the faculty of recognition and other strange neurological disabilities. 7 BLESSINGS IN DISGUISE, by Alec Guinness. 6 6 (Knopf, $17.95.) The autobiography of the distinguished English actor. 8 YEAGER: An Autobiography, by Chuck Yeager 10 43 and Leo Janos. (Bantam, $17.95.) From West Virginia hillbilly to World War II fighter pilot to the first man to fly faster than sound. 8 IACOCCA: An Autobiography, by Lee Iacocca 7 79 with William Novak. (Bantam, $19.95.) The rise of an immigrants' son to top jobs at Ford and Chrysler. 10 ADRIFT, by Steven Callahan. (Houghton 8 10 Mifflin, $15.95.) One man's survival for 76 days on an inflatable raft in the Atlantic. 11 BESS W. TRUMAN, by Margaret Truman. 1 (Macmillan, $19.95.) Her daughter shows that the former First Lady was intelligent and caring as well as private and austere. 12 ARCTIC DREAMS, by Barry Lopez. (Scribners, 11 5 $22.95.) A rhapsodic report on human life and wildlife north of the Arctic Circle. 13 A PASSION FOR EXCELLENCE, by Tom Peters and 15 41 Nancy Austin. (Random House, $19.95.) Ways to achieve distinction in management. 14 WISEGUY, by Nicholas Pileggi. (Simon & 9 12 Schuster, $17.95.) The experiences of Henry Hill as a member of a Mafia family. 15 A LIGHT IN THE ATTIC, by Shel Silverstein. 13 165 (Harper & Row, $13.50.) Light verse, with drawings by the author. And Bear in Mind (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

title: DEVIL DID IT! A BRITISH MAN NETS $313,000
description: Derry Knight told an astonishing story about his membership in a secret Satanic cult called the Sons of Lucifer and his heroic efforts to take over the leadership of the cult to free himself and 2,000 members from the coils of the Devil.

title: Florham Center
description: Since 1970, Cali Associates, a development concern in Cranford, N.J., has specialized in building corporate centers throughout New Jersey.

title: SEARING, EPIC, BLOCKBUSTER, MASS-MARKET QUIZ
description: QUESTION: 1. What percentage of mass-market paperbacks distributed through bookstores and newsstands are returned unsold to their publishers?

title: BALLET'S CHANGING FACE: A ROUNDTABLE REPORT
description: Today the audience for dance in America is probably greater than ever before. While this popularity is encouraging, it raises questions about the future of the art form.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;
PLAINVIEW PIANIST, 24, ON THE FAST TRACK
description: WHEN the Mid-Island Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. signed Jeffrey Biegel to appear in concert this Saturday night, it was a kind of ''local boy makes good'' gesture. The young pianist was born and raised in Plainview and still lives just a few blocks from the Y. But then Mr. Biegel had his formal New York solo debut recently at Alice Tully Hall in Lincoln Center and received such glowing reviews that things will never be the same for the 24-year-old.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Swallowing Yes, No Even more than fathers or lovers, mothers are powerful figures in fiction. In her novel ''Collaborators'' (Knopf), Janet Kauffman's narrator describes her Mennonite mother in church.

title: PREPARING FOR THE SUMMER CRUSH
description: An alluring excursion for vacationers this year is the hour-and-35-minute ferryboat ride across the Strait of Juan de Fuca between Port Angeles, Wash., just north of Olympic National Park, and the English-flavored provincial capital of Victoria, British Columbia. The trip provides motorists with a different perspective from the superhighway link between Seattle and Vancouver, the site of Expo 86, which opened Friday and runs through Oct. 13.

title: Miss McCulloch, Photographer, Weds
description: Cynthia Graydon McCulloch, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Carruth McCulloch of Greenwich, Conn., and New York, was married yesterday to Ronald Roger Conarroe, a son of Mrs. John Francis Cleary of Brooklyn and Richard Riley Conarroe 4th of Fairfield, Conn. The Rev. Richard H. Stearns performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church of Greenwich.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: Baseball's Hits And Misses
description: Strangely, Leonard Koppett is mute on the very worst development in baseball in recent years - the designated hitter (as used in the American League, and now widely followed on lower levels of the game).

title: DESPITE DOWNTURN, HOTELIERS REMAIN OPTIMISTIC
description: HOTEL rooms, like other perishable commodities, have a very short shelf life; if they are not sold within 24 hours, lost revenues can never be recouped. And that is precisely why Westchester hotel managers are troubled. Within the industry, an occupancy rate of 70 percent is considered good. Yet the average occupancy rate for hotels in the county has been at about 59 percent during the first quarter of this year.

title: IN BRIEF: RECENT FILMS ON CASSETTE
description: Night Fright Starring Chris Sarandon, Roddy McDowall and William Ragsdale; written and directed by Tom Holland, 1985 (R) RCA/Columbia Pictures Home Video 106 minutes. $79.95 About a teen-age boy who becomes alarmed at the possibility that a dapper vampire may have moved next door. It ''has a lot more personality than the usual horror film, which is a distinctly mixed blessing. . . . Though Mr. Holland's handling of his stars is successful enough to establish him as a newcomer with promise, his material here is uneven and often flat.''

title: RANGERS' DEFENSE UNRAVELING
description: The worst had already begun to happen.

title: Faith Bremen Is Married To Philip Richard Ruppel
description: Faith Janice Bremen, a daughter of Ruth M. Bremen of Pennsauken, N.J., and the late Harry Benjamin Bremen, was married yesterday to Philip Richard Ruppel, a son of Irmgard Ruppel of New York and Oxford, Conn., and the late Richard S. Ruppel. The Rev. John Leser officiated at the Unitarian Society of Germantown in Philadelphia.

title: MIRROR HANDS OFFER SUBTLE POSSIBILITIES
description: When tournaments take place in old-fashioned hotels, the organizers sometimes have to deal with the problem presented by walls composed partly or wholly of mirrors. Like a Victorian lady worried about the indecent exposure of an ankle, the directors hurriedly cover the mirrors with sheets of paper. This destroys the esthetic effect, but rules out the faint possibility that a player might profit by seeing the reflection of an opponent's cards.

title: THE SCIENCE FICTION SERIES: A NEW WORLD OF REPEATABLE PLEASURES
description: YOKNAPATAWPHA COUNTY was closely based on the real world - that northern corner of Mississippi where William Faulkner spent most of his life.

title: JULY FOURTH AND THE BOSTON POPS
description: The Boston Pops Orchestra has been presenting summer concerts on the Esplanade of the Charles River for nearly 60 years, and, since the Bicentennial celebration in 1976, there has been an annual Independence Day program that has attracted as many as 400,000 spectators to the banks of the Charles. Because Boston is a city that prizes tradition, there has been some consternation over the orchestra's decision to perform at the unveiling ceremony and relighting of the torch of the Statue of Liberty this July 4.

title: MEASURES PRESSED TO COMBAT DANGER OF HAZARDOUS SPILLS
description: DESCRIBING the county's hazardous-materials situation as ''a disaster waiting to happen,'' firefighters, a citizens group and several county legislators are exploring ways to prevent or control accidents involving such materials.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: BEASTS. By Harold Jaffe. (Curbstone Press, Paper, $9. Cloth, $17.50.) Too often strange or uneasy bedfellows, political content and experimental technique mix powerfully in Harold Jaffe's fourth book of fiction.

title: SENATORS DISPUTE PARTS OF EMBASSY SECURITY PLAN
description: The chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee says the Senate is unlikely to approve the State Department's entire $4.4 billion plan for improving security at embassies.

title: Hogeboom Happy
description: Gary Hogeboom, the quarterback who spent six frustrating seasons with the Dallas Cowboys before being traded to the Indianapolis Colts last month, says he's already delighted with his new team, and not because he may have a shot at the starting job.

title: Therese Granger To Marry Editor
description: Therese Evangeline Granger, a vice president of marketing for Citicorp in New York, and Charles L. Martin Jr., editor in chief of Personal Computing magazine in Hasbrouck Heights, N.J., will be married June 13.

title: Music
description: Gifted and versatile though they may be, real men and women sometimes seem a bit gauche when - as actors - they attempt to portray characters seen more in the mind's eye than in real life. For example, it's not easy for a human to transform himself into an easily acceptable incarnation of the devil.

title: CONSUMER RATES
TV FILMS ARE FAST FOOD FOR A GIANT APPETITE
description: ''Making a TV movie is just four things,'' said producer Larry Thompson, easing his Rolls-Royce convertible out of Beverly Hills toward the Hollywood Freeway. ''It's story, stars, wardrobe and close-ups.''

title: SHORE JOBS PLENTIFUL FOR YOUNG PEOPLE
description: ''HAVING a summer job here is great for a teen-ager like me,'' said 16-year-old Tracy Hipko, ''because I can still have fun even while I work.''

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE BILL JAMES BASEBALL ABSTRACT 1986. By Bill James. (Ballantine Books, $8.95.) Bill James, the serious baseball fan's high priest, serves up his annual version of the scripture, complete with both subtle and head-hammering commentary and a plea for continuous study of the national pastime. Mr. James takes his usual statistics-don't-lie approach to the analysis of the game.

title: ACTRESS MIXES SOAP AND STAGE
description: ''I'M pregnant.'' With that matter-of-fact declaration, Jacqueline Schultz, as the unwed Catherine Simms, makes her entrance in a long-running Off Broadway comedy, ''The Foreigner,'' eight performances a week at the Astor Place Theater in Manhattan.

title: IN FISHING VILLAGE, CHANGE IS PAINFUL
description: THE state's only commercial fishing fleet still heads to sea from the docks in Stonington, but the fishermen's wives no longer shop in the borough and their children no longer attend school there.

title: As Racer, Pastorini Is Frugal but Fast
description: In 13 years of professional football, Dan Pastorini never played in a Super Bowl. But in his first full season since trading his football jersey for a fireproof driving suit, the 36-year-old former quarterback is in the thick of the battle for the championship of his new sport: drag racing.

title: Phil Gramm And Federal Spending
description: Phil Gramm's tactics may be unconventional and his style irritating to many of his colleagues, but he is truly the first of a new generation of lawmakers directly to confront 40 years of irresponsible Federal spending (''Phil Gramm's Crusade Against the Deficit,'' by Steven V. Roberts, March 30).

title: PIERCING THE MYTHS OF THE BUDGET DEFICIT
description: A GENERATION ago, in a memorable speech at Yale University, John F. Kennedy warned of the popular myths regarding deficits and debt. Today, President Reagan's former budget director, David A. Stockman, in his new book, ''The Triumph of Politics,'' is full of horror stories of the sheer ignorance and incompetence - to the point of inability to observe the laws of arithmetic - that have shaped the White House path of $200 million budget deficits to a $2 trillion Federal debt.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: RHODE ISLAND INDEPENDENCE It is Independence Day today in Rhode Island; 210 years ago the state's Colonial Legislature, meeting in Providence, repealed a law requiring allegiance to the King of England.

title: An Ever Wider Trade Deficit
description: Last week's report of a $2 billion increase in the trade deficit in March, to $14.5 billion for the month, served three functions, at least.

title: ADULT HIGH SCHOOLS FACING AN OVERHAUL OF ADMINISTRATION
description: SWEEPING changes are expected in the financing and administration of high schools offering courses for adults seeking a diploma. The changes, according to the state's Department of Education, stem from a seven-month study that disclosed numerous abuses.

title: Martha Gilman Weds Dr. S. Gregory Smith
description: The wedding of Martha Gilman to Dr. S. Gregory Smith took place yesterday at the Hotel DuPont in Wilmington, Del. Daniel L. Frawley, the Mayor of Wilmington, officiated.

title: FROM THE LITTLE FUR DESK OF MAXI AMBERVILLE
description: I'LL TAKE MANHATTAN By Judith Krantz. 437 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $18.95.

title: Wedding Planned By Melanie Burns
description: Mrs. Maitland Tabb Ijams of Barneveld, N.Y., and James Ferguson Burns of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Melanie McMillan Burns to Thomas Lyons DeWit of Henniker, N.H., the son of Robert L. DeWit of Yorktown Heights, N.Y., and the late Mrs. DeWit. The wedding is planned for June.

title: Co-op Interviews
description: To the Editor:

title: THE HIGH MORTALITY RATE OF MANHATTAN REAL ESTATE
description: NEAR the heart of Rome, the Pantheon, built nearly 19 centuries ago as a tribute to the gods, still serves as a place of worship, a tourist attraction and a backdrop for fishmongers.

title: VANCOUVER STRUGGLES AS IT CELEBRATES
description: WITH the Prince and Princess of Wales and all the glitter that surrounded the opening on Friday of the world's fair called Expo 86, it would be easy to forget the original purpose of the celebration: a party to celebrate the 100th birthday of Vancouver.

title: PRODUCTS OF DODGER SYSTEM ABOUND IN THE MAJORS
description: WHEN the Los Angeles Dodgers not long ago had their players named National League rookies of the year for four consecutive seasons, it was unusual but not surprising. The Dodgers, after all, are noted for the productivity of their minor league system. So fertile is the system that the Dodgers have produced more 1986 major league players than any other organization.

title: SUMMIT IN TOKYO: THE GLOBAL MONEY MARKET AND THE WAY IT WORKS
description: Advances in telecommunications and computer technology have played a pivotal role in the emergence of today's international financial system. The new technology has knit trading centers around the globe into a single international market. It has also encouraged the development of new financial products, accelerated the pace of trading and added to its volatility. In recent years, the following four technologies have been most important:

title: U.S. INDIANS' HEALTH LAGS DESPITE ADVANCES
description: The health of American Indians has improved markedly over the last 30 years, but Indians continue to be sicker and die younger than other Americans, a Congressional study concludes.

title: MILTON BABBITT HAS DONE IT HIS WAY
description: Milton Babbitt, William Shubael Conant Professor of Music, Emeritus at Princeton, will be 70 on Saturday. To commemorate the occasion, Nassau, the university's weekly newspaper, sent its news editor to interview him. In what must be among the most unusual coincidences in academia in modern times, the interviewer was Randy Schoenberg, grandson of Arnold Schoenberg, the composer and theoretician who has set the tone for Mr. Babbitt's last 60 years.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: MARJORIE MERRIWEATHER POST never invited me to her place in Brookville. No matter, I had a better time recently at her old digs in Palm Beach, Fla. In fact, I even explored Dina Merrill's bedroom.

title: TRAFFIC IN MANHATTAN INCREASES 7.6%
description: The volume of traffic moving into and out of Manhattan increased 7.6 percent last year, the largest jump since 1964, according to City Department of Transportation figures.

title: LEGISLATURE TACKLES ITS OWN RED TAPE
description: A LEGISLATIVE committee is scheduled to take up tomorrow a bill designed to unravel the miles of red tape that have become an unwelcome spinoff of the legislative process.

title: ELIZABETH TAYLOR - HER LIFE IS THE STUFF OF MOVIES
description: As Elizabeth Taylor demonstrates in ''The Sandpiper'' (1965), it's not impossible to do a convincing love scene while a bird is walking around on the top of your head. Yet it can't be easy. The bird that threatens to upstage Miss Taylor and Richard Burton, as they lounge in front of a Big Sur fireplace talking about love and freedom of choice, is nothing as spectacular as a condor or as comic as a medium-sized roasting chicken. It's a sandpiper, but even tiny sandpipers are unreliable.

title:
DINING OUT;
BULLY BOY IN CONGERS MARKING 26th
description: THIS year the singular Bully Boy Chop House celebrates its 26th birthday, and the restaurant is still growing. A recent addition has brought the number of cozy and attractive dining areas to eight, a far cry from the original one-room roadhouse with which Thomas H. McQuade, the owner, began his labor of love.

title: REDESIGNING LIZ CLAIBORNE'S EMPIRE
description: A DECADE ago, Elisabeth Claiborne Ortenberg and her husband, Arthur, were bored with their lives. She had spent more than 20 years as a designer for other manufacturers. He had been in the textile industry just as long. They made a list of options and narrowed the decision to two: either spend the rest of their days on the beach or begin a clothing company of their own.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an April 20 article, ''New Hope for Infertile Couples,'' and in a picture caption accompanying it, the chief of human reproduction at North Shore University Hospital was incorrectly named. He is Dr. David L. Rosenfeld.

title: MUSICIAN SUMMONS OLD OPERATIC SOUND
description: KENNETH PIOTROWSKI hopes to drive ''Lucia'' to the madness her creator, Gaetano Donizetti, originally had in mind.

title: BLUE-COLLAR WORKER BECOMES BLUE-CHIP MARATHON RUNNER
description: Rob de Castella won the Boston Marathon last Monday and collected almost a third of a million dollars in prize, appearance and contingency money. Bill Rodgers earns a half-million dollars a year from marathons, other road running and his running-clothes business. Alberto Salazar still enjoys a six-figure income from running although injuries have kept him out of marathons since 1983.

title: A Roundup of Mideast Hostility
description: Libyan officials were accused last week of plotting terrorist violence against Americans in Turkey.

title: ELEGANT SHELTER
description: Even with benevolent heavens - no torrential downpours, no high winds, no plummeting temperatures - tents are still the most practical solution for holding outdoor dinners, dances or casual buffets. They need not be demure canvas structures fit only for blushing brides, either. More sophisticated, not to mention inventive, alternatives exist.

title: A RARE LOOK AT AN OUTSTANDING MANSION
description: ONE of the county's least known and most outstanding period mansions will be on display this Friday when Elizabeth Seton College opens Alder Manor in North Yonkers for a dinner lecture and tour.

title: Dial-an-Expert
description: A Washington editor is hawking a list of experts on subjects ranging from baldness to terrorism, all of them held out as willing to participate in a talk show at the drop of a phone call. The directory being offered by Mitchell P. Davis of Broadcast Interview Source will not, he promises, lead radio interviewers to ''the ones who pass you along to someone who is out to lunch, the ones who don't return calls, the ones who have to check with the home office.''

title: IN FIARFIELD COUNTY, A LOOK AT YEAR 2000
description: IN a project called Fairfield 2000, politicians, business leaders and educators throughout Fairfield County are joining forces to combat the housing, transportation and employment problems they have in common now - and to ask what life in the county will be like in 14 years.

title: CHILDREN GLIMPSE OTHER SIDE OF OPERA
description: SIX-HUNDRED county schoolchildren know that there is more to ''gel'' than toothpaste, that an ''instrument'' isn't necessarily something you play, and that ''building'' sometimes requires needles and thread. They have been ''backstage'' at the New York City Opera in their own classrooms, in an innovative program introducing all aspects of opera to third through fifth graders.

title: ALBUQUERQUE IS SHAKEN BY CRIMES OF VIOLENCE
description: A series of violent crimes have prompted a sharp increase in meetings on crime prevention here and have stimulated concern about attacks against women.

title: MIDLIFE MACHO
description: WHEN MY 15-YEAR-OLD SON PULLED THE faded green beret out of a trunk stashed away in our Vermont summer house, it was hard for him to reconcile this military artifact with the graying, slightly paunchy father who had to grope before breakfast for his spectacles.

title: Melissa C. White To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. James M. White of Mamaroneck, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Melissa Constance White, to Timothy Ignatius Maloney, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis H. Maloney of Basking Ridge, N.J. A June 21 wedding is planned.

title: DANCERS RISE FROM THE ASHES
description: THIS is the Eglevsky Ballet's 25th anniversary year, although no one has done much official celebrating so far.

title:
MUSIC;
'BUTTERFLY' TO OPEN HOLLYBUSH FESTIVAL
description: THE Hollybush Festival will begin its fourth season Thursday with a performance of Puccini's ''Madama Butterfly'' by the Hollybush Opera Theatre.

title: U.S. BEGINS TESTS OF KATONAH WELL FOR CONTAMINATION
description: THE Federal Environmental Protection Agency was scheduled to begin drilling in Katonah last week in a $453,000 study to find out whether the Katonah community well, which was shut down in 1978 for contamination, is still contaminated.

title: SHEDDING LIGHT
description: Lighting can set a party's mood. A few colored spots can turn a town-house garden into a carnival; a small suburban backyard can appear vast with the addition of dim lights nearby and bright lights at the back.

title: PARTY BY THE POOL
description: Each time I have been entertained in a Vietnamese home it has been a typical summer night in Washington - hot and humid. The hostess's choice of food has always seemed especially felicitous. The marvelous variety of unusual dishes and the lightness of the cuisine, with its finely tuned use of gentle seasonings, have been particularly appropriate for hot weather. So it is no wonder that such fare is especially appropriate for, and becoming increasingly popular at, stylish pool parties across the country.

title: INDIANAPOLIS
description: Indianapolis used to be the punchline to the joke that went: What city watches a race one day and naps the rest of the year?

title: Agnew Papers Still on Hold
description: The University of Maryland says it will be three to five years before it opens for inspection the hundreds of boxes of papers and memorabilia donated 12 years ago by former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew.

title: TOPICS
description: IT was Norma White's delightful Opinion Page article, ''Man vs. Crow: You Have to Talk Their

title: EXITING GRACEFULLY FROM A MUTUAL FUND
description: GETTING into mutual funds is easy enough, but getting out is another story. ''Most shareholders just don't understand the tax consequences of mutual funds,'' said Glenn O. Head, chairman of the First Investors Management Company, Inc., which manages mutual funds. ''They don't realize that, when they pick up the telephone to switch money from one fund to another, it's considered a taxable sale.'' However, a little strategic planning can minimize Uncle Sam's share of the take and smooth your exit, say the experts, whether you are selling a few shares to lock in profits or checking out of your fund altogether.

title: A FLEMISH MASTERPIECE BEARS UP UNDER SCRUTINY
description: Among the European Old Master paintings that have come to general notice since the end of World War II, few have won for themselves so large and so well-informed a constituency as the ''Annunciation,'' by the 15th-century Flemish painter Dieric Bouts, that was bought in January of last year for the J. Paul Getty Museum. It was known that both the Metropolitan Museum in New York and the Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth had coveted the picture, which now hangs in the Getty in Malibu, Calif.

title: WORK STARTING ON EMBATTLED SITE
description: AFTER six years of bitter legal battles, a Manhattan developer will begin excavation this month for a luxury apartment house on the site of the old Margaret Hotel in Brooklyn Heights.

title: SECURITY PUTS SQUEEZE ON TOKYO
description: Central Tokyo was virtually a forbidden city today.

title: PROSPECTS
description: G.N.P.: A Gloomier Guess Last Friday, the 50 economists who participate in the Blue Chip financial forecasts published by Eggert Economic Enterprises Inc. in Sedona, Ariz., lowered their predictions for this year's real gross national product. ''They're pulling in their horns,'' said Robert Eggert. Just a month ago, the group said that 1986 real G.N.P. would be 3.1 percent. Now the consensus is that it will be 2.9 percent, sharply lower than the Administration's goal of 4 percent for this year.

title: Q AND A
description: Raffling Off a Condo Question: I have been trying for several months to sell the one-bedroom condominium I own on East 79th Street in Manhattan. I have read about other people across the country who have sold properties by raffling them off. I am considering doing this myself. Is this legal in New York? . . . R. B., Manhattan Answer: According to David Fishlow, a spokesman for the Attorney General's office, it would not be legal for you to sell your apartment through a raffle. State law prohibits raffles of any kind in which participation is contingent on the sale of tickets for a chance to win. Drawing the Shades Question: Why do shops and stores under renovation always cover up or paper over their windows while the work is going on? Is there a city regulation that requires that they do it? . . . C. G ., Manhattan Answer: The practice is a tradition rather than a regulation. The Buildings Department, which sets standards and requirements for extensive renovations, has no requirement that the windows in shops, restaurants or any other retail spaces be covered while interior work is going on.

title: Dance
description: There are reasons for celebration this week. The ninth annual DanceAfrica festival takes place at Brooklyn Academy of Music Saturday night and next Sunday afternoon.

title: PRESS PASSES ARE IN DEMAND FOR LIBERTY WEEKEND EVENTS
description: Three news organizations in China have asked for press accreditation. Sri Lanka wants to send reporters. So do newspapers in South Korea, Indonesia and Argentina.

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption in the March 30 magazine misidentified the location of a meeting attended by Senator Phil Gramm. The session, a meeting of the Armed Services Committee, took place in Room 222 of the Russell Senate Office Building.

title: FROM GRAIN TO GROPIUS
description: A CONCRETE ATLANTIS U.S. Industrial Building and European Modern Architecture. By Reyner Banham. Illustrated. 266 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The MIT Press. $25.

title: STUDENT SCRIPTS WARN OF ALCOHOL ABUSE
description: TEEN-AGERS are using a new way to tell their peers about the hazards of drunken driving: by writing and producing videotaped programs for local television.

title: Bombing on Irish Border
description: A car bomb destroyed an unmanned British Army checkpoint, demolished a tavern and set a gas station afire early today at Clady, near the border with the Irish Republic, but there were no casualties, the police reported.

title: FRESH AIR FUND OPENING ITS 110TH CAMPAIGN TODAY
description: For more than a century, underprivileged children from New York City have counted on the Fresh Air Fund for summer vacations in the country, and this year will be no exception for some 12,000 boys and girls looking forward to swimming in a lake or hiking in the woods.

title: DINING IN
description: During the past year, I have dined out about 450 times, give or take a few sidewalk snacks, which leaves precious little time for enjoying home-cooked meals. I have sampled scores of fantastic restaurant dishes - and hundreds of less stellar efforts - from every corner of the ethnic smorgasbord that is New York. Still, there are certain homespun foods that I long for at times, foods that, for some reason, rarely translate well in institutional settings.

title: Liverpool Takes Title
description: Liverpool clinched the English League soccer title today with a 1-0 victory over Chelsea on a goal in the 23d minute by the player-manager, Kenny Dalglish.

title: Small Worlds
description: To the Editor: The articles entitled ''Discovering Small Worlds'' (Travel, March 23) made me want to describe a vacation we took in the summer of 1973. Our family of six included our four children, aged 1, 2, 7 and 9 years.

title: Social Events; Springtime Benefits
description: Children's Diseases May 4 - The Children's Blood Foundation, which supports research on several childhood diseases and treatment of them, is holding a country-western supper-dance at the Shanghai Reds restaurant in Weehawken, N.J., overlooking the Hudson River and the Manhattan skyline. A round-trip boat ride is included. The boat leaves the West 42d Street pier at 3:30 P.M. and returns at 7:30 P.M. Tickets, $100 at the boat or restaurant. Cocktails and Auction May 5 - Jams and jewels, haircuts and haute cuisine will be among items and events to be auctioned in the Hilton and Empire Rooms of the Waldorf-Astoria. A 6 P.M. cocktail party starts the benefit for Phoenix House, the drug rehabilitation agency. Tickets, $75, from 212-595-5810, extension 104. Concert at Church May 5 - Since its founding in 1925, the Turtle Bay Music School has provided musical education, often at modest cost, and now has 500 students. It depends in large measure on contributions and benefits such as an 8:45 P.M. concert by the Empire Brass Quintet with works from Bach to Bernstein at St. Peter's Lutheran Church on Lexington Avenue at 54th Street. A cocktail party follows. Tickets, $30 for people 25 years old and younger and $60 for those over 25, from 212-753-8811. Aiding Nature May 6 - Nineteen years ago, scientists and naturalists joined to save the osprey and other wildlife from DDT poisoning. Out of this successful effort came the Environmental Defense Fund, which will have a dinner-dance and awards benefit with Joseph Papp as host at the Plaza starting with cocktails at 7 P.M. Tickets for the black-tie event are $250 from 212-686-4191.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: VISITING VANDERBILT If the historic Vanderbilt Museum house in Centerport is on your list of places to go, today's a good day. During the Eagle's Nest opening season celebration, visitors to the 43-acre estate, with its lavish mansion and hall of fishes, overlooking Northport Harbor, can attend a special reception today, ''Behind the Scenes at Eagle's Nest.'' Regular visits, from noon to 5 P.M., cost $2.50, or $2 for children. The reception, from 4 to 5 P.M., is free It includes a sneak preview of ''Sandblasting and Scaffolds - the Restoration of Eagle's Nest,'' an exhibition dealing with the extensive renovation currently under way at the museum. The museum is on Little Neck Road, and hours after today are 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Tuesdays through Saturdays; noon to 5 P.M. Sundays, through October.HOLOCAUST PROGRAMS

title: Lynne Lumsden And Jon Harden, Executives, Wed
description: Lynne Ann Lumsden and Jon Bixby Harden, publishing executives, were married yesterday at St. James's Episcopal Church in West Hartford, Conn. The Rev. Ronald Woodruff officiated, assisted by the Rev. Denis Ferrigno, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: SCHOOL OFFERS HELP IN DETENTION HOURS
description: HIGH-SCHOOL detention hall is usually a dreary place, with students watching the clock or dozing over unfinished homework. But at Stratford High School, the detainees play games - with the blessing of the school administration.

title: CONCERT FINALES: PUCCINI TO ELLINGTON
description: IT'S just the opposite of a lull before the storm in the county's musical sector just now. There is a veritable storm of concert finales before the lull of the season's end.

title: Mary Duncan Is Engaged
description: The engagement of Mary Hammond Duncan to Mark Roy Thompson has been announced by her father and stepmother, Mr. and Mrs. John Bruce Duncan of New Canaan, Conn. Mr. Thompson is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Malcolm C. Thompson of St. Louis. A June wedding is planned. Miss Duncan, a daughter of the late Leila Hammond Duncan, graduated from Denison University. Mr. Thompson, a product specialist at the Perkin-Elmer Corporation in Wilton, Conn., graduated from the College of Wooster and received a doctorate in analytical chemistry from the Virginia Polytechnic Institute.

title: W. SHEFFIELD COWLES
description: W. Sheffield Cowles, a nephew of President Theodore Roosevelt and Speaker of the State House of Representatives in the 1950's, died Friday at his home here. He was 88 years old.

title: REAGAN IS CRITICAL
description: President Reagan charged today that by withholding details of the Chernobyl nuclear accident the Soviet Union ''manifests a disregard for the legitimate concerns of people everywhere.''

title: L.I.R.R. DISPUTE TRAPS RIDERS
description: COMMUTERS on the Long Island Rail Road are caught in the middle of a year-and-a-half-old contract dispute between the railroad's management and its 15 unions.

title: ISSUES FROM THE COMMONWEALTH CELEBRATE A POPULAR THEME
description: Members of the Commonwealth are celebrating the 60th birthday of Queen Elizabeth II with an outpouring of stamp issues. Britain is celebrating with a set of four stamps issued April 21. Six portraits, in se-tenant pairs, show three illustrations of the Queen. Similar designs are used on separate pairs of 17 pence and 34 pence stamps. Additional nations may announce stamps for this omnibus, but it appears that the issue will be one of the smaller groups in recent years.

title: Jennifer Weis, Editor, To Wed John Monsky
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Weis of Sunbury, Pa., and New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Jennifer Ross Weis to John Richard Monsky, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Monsky of Jacksonville, Fla. A June 15 wedding is planned.

title: FERDINAND WINS THE DERBY WITH SHOEMAKER
description: A horse from California was supposed to win the 112th Kentucky Derby today at Churchill Downs, but hardly anyone expected it to be Ferdinand, a 17-1 shot ridden by a 54-year-old jockey and saddled by a 73-year-old trainer. But at the finish of a slow and roughly run Derby, it was Ferdinand, ridden by Bill Shoemaker and trained by Charlie Whittingham, drawing away to a 2 1/4-length victory over Bold Arrangement and Broad Brush, with the favored Californians, Snow Chief and Badger Land, off the board.

title: DINER IN 'DINER' FACES REAL LIFE IN BALTIMORE
description: The 1950's-style eatery used in the filming of the movie ''Diner'' will stay open despite its financial problems, Mayor William Donald Schaefer says.

title: COUNCIL IS LISTENING TO TEEN-AGE PARENTS
description: CELESTE L. COLATRELLA was 16 years old and a junior at Killingly High School in Danielson when she became pregnant last November.

title: South African Blacks Take a Defiant Holiday
description: South Africa's black unions defied employers and the Government last week by taking an unapproved May Day holiday. An estimated 1.5 million blacks in the largest cities, Johannesburg, Cape Town, Durban and Port Elizabeth, showed their muscle by staying away from work.

title: On Language; ON SURGICAL STRIKE
description: MODERN WAR needs modern lingo.

title: The Tips of Failure
description: Every week or so, it seems, some thunderclap in the news reminds us of the accidents of life and the unpredictable consequences of human presumption.

title: NEW CHIEFS AT U.S. NEWS STIR ANXIOUS CURIOSITY
description: At the glossy Washington headquarters of U.S. News & World Report, new reports on readership and circulation prompted rejoicing as the results were passed from office to office.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: TIGRELA AND OTHER STORIES. By Lygia Fagundes Telles. Translated by Margaret A. Neves. (Bard/Avon, $3.95.) The Brazilian writer Lygia Fagundes Telles's eighth short-story collection has an extraordinary variety of characters, plots and narrative strategies yet never seems academic or willfully experimental.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: THE state's Department of Environmental Protection has proposed its second water-supply critical area. It is in Camden County, most of Gloucester and Burlington Counties and parts of seven others.

title: Balloonists Take Off In Annual Contest
description: Balloonists from Japan, Germany, Switzerland and the United States took off in six balloons today in the 80th annual Gordon Bennett Balloon Race.

title: FRESH FROM THE TERRACE
description: During the bountiful summer months, people who own city terraces go about with a certain air of satisfaction. It is not detectable immediately, but it always crops up. ''Yes,'' they say, ''the raspberries were delicious this morning.'' ''Strange,'' you respond, ''I haven't seen any local raspberries in my market yet.'' ''Oh, no'' - and here comes the smug smile - ''I grow them, you know. I've had a handful for my cereal every morning since mid-June.'' Dead stop. Nothing you can report about sunny weekends in the Hamptons or firefly displays in Connecticut will outclass those raspberries.

title: FROM OUR MOTHERS' LIBRARIES - WOMEN WHO CREATED THE NOVEL
description: AT a crucial moment toward the end of Jane Austen's ''Persuasion,'' the novel's heroine, Anne Elliot, laments that ''men have had every advantage of us in telling their story.'' Conventional wisdom about literary history would seem to suggest that she is correct. From Shakespeare to Shelley, from Defoe to Dickens, literature's ''centuries'' have had, in Wallace Stevens's words, ''a way of being male.'' Of course, when we look into the past seeking what Elizabeth Barrett Browning once called esthetic ''grandmothers,'' we have always found a few women. But this only means that, confirming Anne Elliot's pained complaint, female literary history has usually been seen as, to quote the critic Elaine Showalter, ''desert bounded by mountains on four sides: the Austen peaks, the Bronte cliffs, the Eliot range, and the Woolf hills.''

title: 'HELLO, BABY, THIS IS DADDY'
description: I FIRST found out that I would be a father early one summer morning when my wife's monthly ritual of taking a home pregnancy test showed that another life had started. There was one ring at the bottom of the glass container. Cheryl and I tried for a year and a half to conceive; I never imagined it would take so long. Two people, both in their 30's, worried about such things as age and childbirth. For a long while I thought something might be wrong. Now, I was going to be a father for the first time.

title: '20 Under 30'
description: To the Editor:

title: WILL THERE BE BROWNOUTS THIS SUMMER?
description: THE Long Island Lighting Company is warning its customers of possible power shortages this summer. But state and Suffolk County officials maintained last week that Lilco's warnings are exaggerated and are an effort to increase public pressure to bring its Shoreham Nuclear Power Station into operation.

title: IT'S A COPIER, IT'S A LASER PRINTER
description: LASER printers are marvelous machines for turning out hard copy resplendent with intricate graphics and a variety of typefaces that make documents positively scream for attention. But for some time now I've been wondering why, considering that the laser engine that forms the technological foundation of such printers is the same as the one used in office copiers, someone doesn't produce a printer that can also double as a copying machine. It would seem to make so much more economic sense to have one machine handling both jobs than to have two machines, each used part-time.

title: Tunis and His Readers
description: To the Editor:

title: POLAR EXPLORERS FLYING HOME
description: Airplanes lifted six exuberant explorers and their 21 sled dogs from the the North Pole yesterday morning as a grueling two-month test of endurance and willpower ended in triumph. The American and Canadian explorers were the first to reach the Pole assisted only by dogs since Adm.

title: REBEL AMONG REBELS
description: THINKING BACK The Perils of Writing History. By C. Vann Woodward. 158 pp. Baton Rouge: Louisiana State University Press. $12.95. THE acclaimed historian

title: THE SUN NEVER SETS ON BOWLER HAT
description: THERE will always be an English gentleman, or at least those who dress like one. Hawaiian shirts may come and go, pink high-top sneakers may stomp intermittently on the scene, tank tops may occasionally rise to the surface.

title: Wright Brothers Disputed Again
description: YET another challenge emerged last year to the claim of Orville and Wilbur Wright that they achieved powered flight first at Kitty Hawk, N.C., on Dec. 17, 1903. Two men in Fairfield, Conn., took exception.

title: LOOK AT FATHER, HE IS GROSSED OUT.
description: MORE FUN WITH DICK AND JANE Written and illustrated by Marc Gregory Gallant. 70 pp. New York: Penguin. Paper, $5.95. LEARNING to read is a thrilling experience. Once we can re-create in our own minds a story someone else wrote down at another time in another place, we can begin to control the information we take in. And yet our experience is limited at the time most of us learn; it's presumed we're fragile, and ignorant about meaning and nuance, and this is probably why the people who write the texts from which we learn make them so bland.

title: Golf Event To Hadden
description: William Hadden 3d of the New Haven Country Club overcame harsh weather, bad breaks and a sturdy opponent today to win the William D. Richardson Memorial amateur golf tournament at The Seawane Club. Hadden, who also won this event in 1984, defeated Robert Housen of the Manasquan River Country Club, 1 up, in a match that went 19 holes and lasted 4 hours 20 minutes.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: SCHLOTT REALTORS will move its headquarters tomorrow from Fair Lawn to a two-story building on Route 23 in Wayne.

title: THIS IS THE PROPER TIME FOR HARDY VEGETABLES SEEDING
description: There should be no delay in planting two of the most important crops: leeks and edible-pod peas. Both are simple to plant and rewarding to raise.

title: SMALL WORLDS
description: To the Editor: After six years of summer vacations in Europe, my husband and I decided not to change the pattern. Why not bring our 7-month-old son with us?

title: Bridge for Sale
description: A 350-ton historic bridge in Stamford, Conn., made of wrought iron was up for sale last summer. No price was set.

title: Look for the Union Card
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s program to provide union members with a free low-interest credit card is gathering momentum. The American Federation of State County and Municipal Employees has just agreed to bring its one million members into the program, bringing to nine the number of participating unions and to four million the total number of covered workers.

title: AN IRASCIBLE SHOWMAN COMES BACK TO BROADWAY
description: He limps slightly as he walks into the Music Box Theater, an irascible master showman returning to Broadway. Half a dozen assistants, nervously awaiting commands, gather around David Merrick before the Broadway preview of ''Loot.''

title: TURNPIKE WIDENING FACES NEW DELAYS
description: THE controversial plan to widen the New Jersey Turnpike, already reeling under widespread opposition, has fallen months behind schedule.

title: HE COULD NEVER BE LIKE EVERYONE ELSE
description: MY BEAUTIFUL LAUNDRETTE AND THE RAINBOW SIGN By Hanif Kureishi. 111 pp. Boston: Faber & Faber. Paper, $8.95.

title: ALUMNI GROUPS AT HARVARD AND DARTMOUTH FACE VOTE ON SOUTH AFRICA ISSUE
description: The dispute over colleges' investments in companies doing business in South Africa has become an issue in elections for the board of trustees at Dartmouth and the board of overseers at Harvard.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: SCENES AT STUN-GUN TRIAL
description: At about 3 P.M. Friday, the feeling grew in the corridor of State Supreme Court in Queens that the climax was near.

title: 2 in San Francisco Sentenced in LSD Case
description: A San Francisco physician and his wife have been sentenced to prison in a case that investigators said involved about 1.6 million doses of the hallucinogenic drug LSD.

title: AS SPRING RETURNS, SO DO THE SHAD
description: THE annual shad run is under way, drawing thousands of fishermen to the banks of the Connecticut River, and prompting shad festivals and shad bakes from one end of the state to the other.

title: CANADIENS DEFEAT RANGERS, 6-2, FOR 2-0 SERIES LEAD
description: The Rangers had accomplished so much recently that it was easy to expect that at any moment someone would step forward, do something heroic, and their special playoff season would resume its course.

title: TWO WOMEN, TERRIFIED
description: CAMPING OUT By Eleanor Clark. 223 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $16.95. SOME of my friends and I first came to Eleanor Clark's ''Rome and a Villa'' because our mothers pressed it on us with eager hands. Those aging sedentary housewives who had traveled largely in their imagination took vicarious joy in its opulence of experience and learning. For once we listened to them, and read a book they loved. Having begun, who could resist it? We too were enamored of its style and its stylishness, and have cherished Miss Clark ever since for the immaculate writer and intuitive witness that she is.

title: Topics; Cheers and Catcalls; Ignorant Protest
description: New York's Metropolitan Transportation Authority faces the continuing need to raise capital while holding down fares. It therefore has every reason to ask whether sections of its least heavily traveled rail lines, many of them elevated, would be better replaced with bus or other service.

title: PRETORIA OFFICIAL CALLS SEGREGATION KEY TO CHANGE
description: A senior South African Cabinet minister says that changes in racial policies in South Africa will not be possible without continued segregation of schools and housing to assure whites about their future.

title: Unarmed Man Gives Up After Hijacking Attempt
description: An unarmed man who said he was carrying a pistol hijacked a Horizon Air commuter plane carrying 13 people and diverted it to an airport here, where he surrendered early today.

title: LIVING LIKE A LORD IN BRITAIN
description: For the first time, one of the genuinely grand houses of the English countryside - famous for its gardens and its architecture, its owners and their house guests - has been turned into a hotel. It is called Cliveden, and since February it has been welcoming overnight guests prepared to pay at least $250 a night to sleep where princes slept, to eat breakfast where literary lions did, to have their suitcases unpacked by a maid and to drink champagne fetched by a butler. The $250, let it be stipulated, includes the butler but not the bubbly.

title: THE SOVIET ECONOMY WILL PAY
description: By any dimension, the nuclear accident at Chernobyl is very serious. But it is premature - and would be imprudent - to draw far reaching judgments about its impact on Soviet domestic and foreign policy. The disaster can be exploited constructively by the United States and its allies, not to try to roll back or weaken the Soviet regime but rather to enhance opportunities for understanding on both arms control and other issues. The United States has strong cards to play, but we need to play them effectively.

title: NEWTON MINOW TAKES ANOTHER LOOK
description: Newton N. Minow was 35 when he was appointed chairman of the Federal Communications Commission in 1961 by President John F. Kennedy. Mr. Minow reflected recently on the present state of the medium he once assailed as a ''vast wasteland.''

title: In a City of Words, Literature Lives
description: She came to Washington from a small industrial town in Ohio two decades ago. After taking a job as a secretary, she was accepted in a writing program at George Washington University, joined the Capitol Hill Poetry Group and sent off poems to Pudding Magazine, 13th Moon, Minnesota Review and other ''little'' magazines.

title: MOVE THE YANKEES? THIS FAN VOTES 'NO!'
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Margaret Jackson Weds R. C. Paul
description: Margaret Ann Jackson and Robert Carey Paul were married yesterday at the Carlyle Hotel. The Rev. Philip A.C. Clarke, a Methodist minister, and Rabbi Charles Lippman officiated.

title: A DOWN-TO-EARTH LOOK AT TRAVEL STOCKS
description: ENTERTAINMENT and hotel stocks have risen sharply in recent months, as investors look for a boom in domestic vacation travel this summer. But some issues have risen so much that even analysts who like the companies' long-term prospects warn that the enthusiasm may be overdone. Earnings of many domestic companies will be up, they say, but the gains may not be dramatic.

title: DANCE: PARKER TROUPE
description: RANDALL FAXON PARKER presented a pleasant, easygoing hour or so of dance on Friday at the Jose Limon Dance Foundation studio, where her recently formed company, Randance, performed as part of the foundation's New Dance Series. A somewhat grave translucency characterized Miss Parker's performing with a wide variety of modern dance groups in the 1960's and 1970's - a readability that also informed the six dances presented here.

title: TRACKLESS TROLLEY SOUGHT FOR RESORT
description: THE operator of a tour service has petitioned the state's Department of Transportation for permission to bring back trolleys - but a trackless type - to Absecon Island, and the City Council here and Mayor James L. Usry believe this might ''prove to be the way to go.''

title: RESORT TO GET OFFICE COMPLEX
description: THE Federal and state governments, the city and a private developer are involved in the construction of a 17-story office complex here whose lessees will include the state's Casino Control Commission, Division of Gaming Enforcement and Athletic Commission.

title: Why We Shouldn't Return to the 12-Hour Day
description: To the Editor:

title: A REGION EDGES AWAY FROM DEMOCRACY
description: THE White House thought it discerned ''winds of freedom'' blowing in Southeast Asia. Perhaps so, but as President Reagan landed in Bali last week to meet leaders of the region, there were troubling signs of instability and repression. Indonesia was caught up in near paranoia over the Western press. The Government of Thailand, one of Washington's best friends, fell amid charges of large-scale bribery. And in Malaysia, an elected state Government was fending off the imposition of a ''consensus democracy'' that would force it to share power with enemies trying to bring it down.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''The Administration's blind commitment to free trade is threatening the survival of basic U.S. industries.'' Fiber, Fabric and Apparel

title: WHO WANTS TO TEACH?
description: YOU'RE SMART. WHY ARE YOU BOTHERING to teach? '' The question came from a fellow student at Rutgers, the State University of New Jersey. The Cook College senior to whom it was addressed was one of the few students in the difficult biochemistry curriculum who wasn't applying for medical or graduate school or seeking a job in private industry. Mary Jo Knipper wanted to be a teacher, a choice her ambitious classmate could not understand.

title: The Pursuit of Happiness
description: To the Editor:

title: FORMER DISCO SOUNDS A NEW NOTE
description: NICOLE'S in Port Washington once was partly a discotheque, but now has taken a more serious turn with a new chef and a French-Continental menu.

title: A COUNTRY COTTAGE FOR RENT
description: Little wonder we love to read English novels, full of lonely, wind-swept moors and mill cottages on river banks; their landscapes are dreamscapes. We hardly see the likes of them on our shopping sprees to London or bus tours to Oxford, Cambridge and the cathedral towns.

title: BIG LABOR TRIES TO END ITS NIGHTMARE
description: GROPING for escape from the troubles that enshroud America's unions, the high command of organized labor is thinking the unthinkable to a degree unparalleled in union history.

title: Next-to-the-Last for Rector Place
description: A new condominium is opening in the Rector Place residential neighborhood, an array of rentals and condominiums around a half-acre park in Battery Park City.

title: U.S. Offering Gateway Park Properties for Leasing
description: STRAPPED for funds to improve the parks in New York and New Jersey's Gateway National Recreation Area, the National Park Service is planning to lease scores of buildings within the parks to private developers for such suggested uses as restaurants, dinner theaters, concert stages or corporate conference centers.

title:
GARDENING;
FOR A PRETTY BORDER, TRY BIENNIALS
description: A BIENNIAL is a plant that is started from seed one year, flowers the next, then dies.

title: Nancy Herfort Engaged
description: Dr. and Mrs. Alan Herfort of White Plains and Stockbridge, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Nancy Ann Herfort to Charles Ira Clarvit, a son of William Clarvit of Amityville, L.I., and the late Selma Clarvit.

title: More for His Money
description: With a rent budget under $300 a month, most people looking for an apartment on Manhattan's East Side would have trouble getting a foot in the door. Herbert S. Okun, a deputy chief United States delegate to the United Nations, has three bedrooms in a high-rise at 420 East 54th Street.

title: Talking Supers; Making The Right Choice
description: A SKILLED superintendent is the essential employee in the smooth running of a cooperative building. Perhaps that is why the hiring of a new one tends to be approached with such trepidation.

title: CELEBRITIES ON LIFETIME TELL ABOUT LIFE WITH MOTHER
description: From Dr. Ruth Westheimer to Dr. Joyce Brothers to the children's author Judy Blume, diverging voices and differing perspectives will be contributing to an informal celebration of Mother's Day, scheduled this week by Lifetime.

title: CITIZENS GATHERING TO DEFEND RIVERS
description: HIGHLY visible and vulnerable symbols of life, rivers and streams - and the forests and meadows through which they rage or meander - tug at man's heart. And when a scheme to violate any one of them is proposed, a band of its supporters emerges, serving notice that tampering with the integrity of moving water and its environment is no casual endeavor.

title: RADAR TRAPS ROB POLICE OF RESPECT
description: SPRING creeps in bit by bit. As leaves appear on trees, as robins come in increasing numbers to our lawns, as bulbs planted last fall push up from the ground, so too emerge the police radar units in a heady burst of springtime enthusiasm.

title: USING BARGES TO REVIVE A RAIL ROUTE
description: Little more than three miles separates Brooklyn from New Jersey across Upper New York Bay. By freight train, however, the trip between the two can cover 280 miles and take more than 24 hours.

title: Baseball's Hits And Misses
description: Leonard Koppett omits the most significant development in baseball since World War II - integration.

title: Fear of Terrorism Affecting Yacht Race
description: If this were any other year, the selection of three sailboats to compete in the Sardinia Cup race series this September would be a routine matter. But fears of terrorism in Europe have caused yachtsmen to think twice this year about sailing in Mediterranean waters.

title: BLEEDING KANSAS
description: HEART OF THE COUNTRY By Greg Matthews. 532 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $17.95.

title:
CHERNOBYL: COSTS AND A WARNING;
SMUGNESS IN AMERICA IS POINTLESS
description: ''Containment'' is not just a United States cold war policy toward the Soviet Union. It is also an important safety feature at American nuclear plants - one that utility officials say will keep us safe from the kind of accident that occurred at the Soviet nuclear plant at Chernobyl.

title: WORD PROCESSING GIVES STUDENTS A HEAD START
description: As a professor in the writing program at Fairfield University and a former business executive who retired after 39 years of a combined journalism and public-relations career, I would like to endorse whole-heartedly Jack McGarvey's Opinion article [ ''A Call for a New Writing Classroom in Our Schools,'' April 13 ] .

title: IMMIGRANT'S TALE AT GEORGE ST.
description: IT WAS once said that Jewish immigrants might have come to this country in search of streets paved with gold but, instead, there were no streets and, what's more, they were expected to pave them.

title: THE CULTURES OF INDIA THRIVE IN JERSEY CITY
description: WELL-DRESSED Indian men in business suits and women in saris stroll along a block of Newark Avenue here between Kennedy Boulevard and Tonnelle Avenue, shopping or on the way to worship at the Hare Krishna Temple.

title: Elizabeth Powers Is Bride Of Steven Edward Trupp
description: Elizabeth Ann Powers, a daughter Of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Powers of Upper Grandview, N.Y., was married yesterday to Steven Edward Trupp, the son of Dorothy Margaret Trupp of Sayville, L.I., and Edward Paul Trupp of St. Thomas, V.I. The Rev. Victor R. Yanitelli performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in Manhattan.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Auto Racing Nascar Winston 500, at Talladega, Ala. (Television - ESPN, 2 P.M. live.) Baseball Yankees vs. Texas Rangers, at Yankee Stadium, 1:30 P.M. Ron Guidry, off to a 3-0 start, is scheduled to pitch for the Yankees. (Television - Channel 11, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 1:30 P.M.) Mets vs. Reds, at Cincinnati, 2:15 P.M. Ron Darling, who has allowed 5 home runs in his first 20 innings, makes his fifth start of the season. (Television -Channel 9, 2:15 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 2:15 P.M.) Dodgers vs. St. Louis Cardinals, at Los Angeles. (Television - Channel 7, 3 P.M.) Phillies vs. Atlanta Braves, at Philadelphia, 1:35 P.M. (Television - WTBS, 1:30 P.M.) College: Seton Hall vs. Pittsburgh, at South Orange, N.J., 1 P.M. (Radio -WSOU-FM 89.5, 12:50 P.M.) Basketball Hawks vs. Boston Celtics, at Atlanta. A victory by Boston would give the Celtics a four-game sweep of the Eastern Conference semifinal series. (Television -Channel 2, 1 P.M.) Mavericks vs. Los Angeles Lakers, at Dallas, Game 4 of the Western Conference semfinal series. (Television -Channel 2, 3:30 P.M.) Nuggets vs. Houston Rockets, at Denver, Game 4 of the other Western Conference semifinal playoff series, 3:30 P.M. Golf Panasonic Las Vegas Invitational, fifth and final round (Television - Channel 4, 4 P.M.) L.P.G.A. Moss Creek Women's Invitational, at Hilton Head, S.C. Gymnastics U.S.A. vs. Soviet Union Gymnastics Challenge, at Nassau Coliseum, Uniondale, L.I., 2 P.M. The final stop on the tour matching the two countries for the first time since 1983.

title: THE GRANADA OF FEDERICO GARCIA LORCA
description: One spring afternoon, a month before his 31st birthday, the poet stood before a crowd of friends and family who had gathered in his hometown to honor him. It had been a triumphant year for him professionally, a harrowing one personally. ''If by the grace of God I become famous,'' he told the crowd, ''half of that fame will belong to Granada, which formed me and made me what I am: a poet from birth and unable to help it.''

title: Topics; Cheers and Catcalls; Songbird Uncaged
description: Fela Anikulapo Kuti, known throughout Africa simply as ''Fela,'' is a Nigerian singer and songwriter famous for his syncopated Afro-American melodies and brash, populist themes. He fell silent in November 1984, when he was sentenced to five years in prison for allegedly trafficking in foreign currencies.

title: THREE KREMLIN LEADERS VISIT AREA OF THE CHERNOBYL NUCLEAR STATION
description: Three Politburo members inspected the area of the damaged Chernobyl nuclear power plant today, marking the first public demonstration of concern over the accident by the top Soviet leadership.

title: THIRD U.S. ROCKET FAILS, DISRUPTING PROGRAM IN SPACE
description: An unmanned Delta rocket carrying a weather satellite lost power in its main engine and pitched out of control about 70 seconds after launching today from Cape Canaveral, forcing safety officers on the ground to destroy it by remote control.

title: SOME CAVEATS FOR CHILDLESS COUPLES
description: ABOUT one in seven American couples who want children cannot have them. And experts say the national fertility rate will decline further as more women delay child-bearing until their less fertile years.

title: SHIPPING GARBAGE IS NO ANSWER
description: Regarding the two articles on Long Island's garbage problem that appeared April 6: I find it absolutely absurd and irresponsible to spend millions of dollars for shipping garbage - much or most of which is toxic -upstate or out of state.

title: LANDSCAPES AND STILL LIVES
description: THE FLYING CHANGE By Henry Taylor. 55 pp. Baton Rouge: Louisiana State University Press. Cloth, $13.95. Paper, $6.95. SAINTS AND STRANGERS By Andrew Hudgins. 82 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. Cloth, $13.95. Paper, $6.95. PLACES/EVERYONE By Jim Daniels. 80 pp. Madison: The University of Wisconsin Press. Cloth, $12.50. Paper, $7.95. IN ''The Flying Change,'' which has just been given the Pulitzer Prize for poetry, Henry Taylor writes the poems of a country squire. Most of the time this country life is all too settled, predictable and complacent; the squire, after all, enjoys all the pleasures of a farmer's life with none of the risks. Indeed, the gentleman farmer may pursue pleasures for which the real farmer has neither time nor inclination, as in ''Evening at Wolf Trap'': Once, outside the theater's weathering walls, we sat on the grass with wine and cheese, French bread and fruit; and as we ate, our talk was sometimes interrupted by a small crowd farther down the hill, throwing a frisbee.

title: No Sympathy for Dave Parker
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Skiles Enters Jail
description: Scott Skiles, the Michigan State basketball star who violated the terms of his parole on an Indiana marijuana conviction by buying liquor at a store in Michigan, has begun serving a 30-day sentence at the Marshall County Jail in Plymouth, Ind. Although Skiles could have waited until after the current semester before reporting to the jail, he notified the authorites that he was leaving school to begin serving the term early because there were too many distractions on campus. He said he planned to return to Michigan State to complete his degree requirements during the summer session.

title:
DINING OUT;
IBERIA, YOU SAY? NO, IT'S NEWARK
description: NEW JERSEY residents who might be understandably reluctant to embark on a European vacation this summer could do worse than to check out some of the things available in their own backyard. Apart from the glorious countryside and wonderful beaches in the state, there are also restaurants representing many cultures.

title: William Bryce Thompson 4th Weds Frances Bronson Lippincott in Jersey
description: Frances Bronson Lippincott and William Bryce Thompson 4th were married yesterday at St. John the Evangelist Roman Catholic Church in Lambertville, N.J. The Rev. Patrick Connor performed the ceremony.

title: 2 PLANS IN JERSEY ON INSURANCE ILLS
description: Republicans and Democrats in the New Jersey Assembly are to introduce bills Monday that propose far different solutions to the shrinking availability of liability insurance.

title: Laura Corvinelli Wed To Thomas G. Bishop
description: Laura Ann Corvinelli, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arduin Joseph Corvinelli of Yonkers, was married yesterday to Thomas Geoffrey Bishop, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Geoffrey James Bishop of Brighton, Australia. The Rev. Gerald Cohen performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Dwight Memorial Chapel of Yale University in New Haven.

title: Suicide Problem At Twin Bridges
description: AFTER 34 suicides in seven and a half years at two bridges, the District of Columbia said it would install protective fences on the structures. The National Trust for Historic Preservation and some residents objected.

title: Cynthia Granger And J. J. Temple To Marry in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Granger of Chatham Township, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Cynthia Grace Granger to Jeffrey Joseph Temple, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Temple of East Brunswick, N.J. An October wedding is planned. Miss Granger, a senior account officer at Citibank in New York, graduated from Franklin and Marshall College.

title: STATE COURTS SURPASS U.S. BENCH IN CASES ON RIGHTS OF INDIVIDUALS
description: State courts around the country are citing state constitutions to expand the protection of individual rights beyond the minimum requirements set by the United States Supreme Court in its interpretation of the Federal Constitution.

title: SQUEEZING THE MIDDLE CLASS
