description: THE AMERICAN PROFILE POSTER Who Owns What, Who Makes How Much, Who Works Where, and Who Lives With Whom. By Stephen J. Rose. Poster designed by Dennis Livingston and Kathryn Shagas. Illustrated. 37 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. Paper, $8.95.

title: HOME-VIDEO BOOM GENERATES SPINOFFS
description: THE home video boom - the Electronics Industries Association reports that 30 percent of all homes in the country now have video cassette recorders - has brought to New Jersey new business enterprises that are capitalizing on consumer interest in a wider and more-sophisticated selection of videotapes and disks.

title: Radioactive Traces in Israel
description: Unseasonal rainfall Friday night and today dropped traces of radioactive iodine on scattered pockets in Israel, the Health Ministry reported tonight. Prof. Dan Michaeli, Director General of the ministry, said the levels were insignificant and people could consume them for years without affecting their health. Meteorologists forecast that the heavy, sporadic rainfall, which is unusual for this time of year, would continue.

title: 2 BROTHERS, 6 AND 8, SURVIVE 5-FLOOR FALL FROM THEIR WINDOW
description: Two brothers, 6 and 8 years old, survived a five-story fall early yesterday from a window of their apartment in a housing project in Far Rockaway, Queens, where they had been pretending to be the comic strip character Spiderman, according to the police.

title: Article 390486 -- No Title
description: The Defense Department may have to ask Congress for additional funds to build the B-1B strategic bomber because the primary builder expects to exceed the contract's cost target by $500 million.

title: Sham Subpoena Criticized
description: Charges of conspiracy and obstruction of justice have been dismissed and evidence of perjury against two former state legislators thrown out by a judge who said the Federal Bureau of Investigation created a ''perjury trap'' by using a false subpoena. Federal District Judge Thomas N. O'Neill Jr. said Tuesday, in dismissing the charges against the former lawmakers, Charles N. Caputo, 74 years old, and Leonard L. Martino, 58, both of Pittsburgh, that using a false grand jury subpoena ''obviously exceeds the bounds of propriety.''

title: Contemporary Music Series
description: The pianists Boaz Sharon and Hao Huang will present two New York premieres tomorrow night at 8 in the last concert of the ''Washington Square Contemporary Music Series.''

title: MUSIC: PHILHARMONIC, MOZART AND SCHOENBERG
description: AS a piece of program-making, the current New York Philharmonic offering at Avery Fisher Hall - to be repeated Tuesday, with Richard Strauss's ''Till Eulenspiegel'' at the end instead of Tchaikovsky's ''Francesca da Rimini'' - is a mismatched grab bag. But at its center lie two linked piano concertos, and both receive remarkable performances.

title: Closing Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: EAST END LICENSES DEBATED
description: THE Town of East Hampton is considering stiffening or dropping its licensing requirements for construction and home renovation contractors because of the large number of applications and consumer complaints, and because some contractors do not bother to obtain town licenses.

title: TUNIS AND HIS READERS
description: To the Editor:

title: IN BRIEF: RECENT FILMS ON CASSETTE
description: Return of the Jedi Starring Mark Hamill, Harrison Ford, Carrie Fisher and Billy Dee Williams; directed by Richard Marquand, 1983 (PG) CBS/Fox Video 133 minutes.

title: Sonja Gora Affianced To William J. Maroni
description: Dr. and Mrs. Edwin K. Gora of Providence, R.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Sonja A. Gora to William J. Maroni, Deputy Under Secretary for Congressional Affairs in the Department of Labor. A Sept. 27 wedding is planned.

title: HADDONFIELD OPENS HISTORIC HOMES
description: THIS historic Camden County borough where, in defiance of the British Crown, New Jersey in 1777 officially became a state with its own Great Seal, will be a gathering place Friday and Saturday of admirers and students of Victorian-era architecture.

title: Miss Nazareth, Lawyer, Is Wed
description: Annette LaPorte Nazareth, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George R. Nazareth of Cumberland, R.I., was married yesterday to Roger Walton Ferguson Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ferguson of Washington. The Rev. Howard O'Shea performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Manning Chapel at Brown University.

title: One Killed in Shelling Across Beirut Green Line
description: One person was killed and four people were wounded today when mortar shells hit a crowded area of West Beirut, hospital sources said.

title: A Giant Shadow
description: The huge Television City development proposed by Donald J. Trump on the Hudson River between 59th and 72d Streets would keep the southern end of Riverside Park and much of Manhattan's Upper West Side in shadows for hours at a time, according to a study made public last week.

title: Beauty; GRACE FROM THE MARTIAL ARTS
description: THE MARTIAL arts teach self-defense. How to punch, kick, thrust and throw an opponent and win a fight. Or better still, avoid one. Taekwondo, karate, kung fu, aikido and jujitsu, or any of the multitude of combinations of these five basic types, build confidence, discipline - and a degree of physical fitness that yields high health and beauty dividends.

title: Limiting Sprawl In a Boom Town
description: Overland Park, Kan., a sprawling suburb just across the state line, will soon vote on an ambitious $18 million bond issue aimed at keeping the community from being completely blanketed by highways, office parks, shopping malls and housing developments.

title: GOMEZ DOWNS JAITE
description: Andres Gomez of Ecuador defeated Martin Jaite of Argentina, 6-2, 6-3, in semifinal play of the United States Open Clay Courts tournament today to reach the championship match for a fourth consecutive year.

title: STAMFORD REVEALS ART CENTER DESIGN
description: AUDIENCES attending performances at the Stamford Center for the Arts in the next two months will be the last to see the old Stamford Theater in its present form. At the end of June the theater, built in 1914, will be closed and construction of a new $12 million theater complex will get under way.

title: WORK PROGRAM HELPS TROUBLED YOUTHS
description: ON a recent afternoon behind the low brick building that houses the UConn Cooperative Extension Service office in Hamden, three fledgling carpenters were building a greenhouse for the Extension Service. And they were learning much more than basic carpentry.

title: A SAMPLER OF SPRINGTIME FOR THE TABLE
description: SPRING brings new treats to the table: the finest asparagus, young carrots, tender peas and fresh fava beans. These are good enough to eat on their own, as a separate course. A meal might begin with a creamy risotto, made with asparagus and fava beans or young peas, followed by a broiled veal chop or chicken breasts sprinkled with fresh herbs. All kinds of spring vegetables can be steamed and marinated in a garlic vinaigrette and served at room temperature, in the Italian manner. They are best eaten within a few hours of being cooked and not kept in the refrigerator to be served cold and lifeless the next day. Freshness is what spring is all about.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: STANISLAVSKY: A Life, by David Magarshack. (Faber & Faber, $13.95). A biography of Konstantin Stanislavsky (1863-1938), who founded the Moscow Art Theater and developed the Stanislavsky system of acting. Brooks Atkinson said here in 1951 that the author ''has industrially and reverently filled out the life of a master of the theater. . . . Mr. Magarshack's conscientious biography completes one of the great theater stories.'' Da Capo has reissued A METHOD TO THEIR MADNESS: The History of the Actors Studio ($11.95), by Foster Hirsch, an account of the system's importation to the United States and its transformation into ''the Method'' at New York's Actors Studio. Our reviewer, Marshall W. Mason, found the work ''authoritative and academic'' and said it ''accurately sketches the evolution'' of the Stanislavsky system, but he said it sheds little light on ''how Stanislavsky's ideas became distorted into [ Lee ] Strasberg's Method.'' THE GRASS, by Claude Simon. (George Braziller, Paper, $8.95. Cloth, $16.95.) Louise, who narrates this novel by the 1985 winner of the Nobel Prize in Literature, lies beside her lover amid grass and reeds and tells him the story of her aunt, who lies dying, and of the wasted lives of those around her. ''There is no apparent order, no continuous narrative in the book,'' Henri Peyre said in The Book Review in 1960. ''It is steeped in nature, rich in sensations of smell and of touch, orchestrated by a musician of words. . . . 'The Grass' is an obscure and difficult novel, to be enjoyed by the unhappy few.''

title: Nantucket Moves To Aid a Park
description: NANTUCKET, an island of 6,000 year-round residents and $155 million in 1985 real estate sales, is a hot market today, but it wasn't in 1901 when John Hathaway, founder of the Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company, bought 78 acres on the southern shore.

title: RING LARDNER BY ANY OTHER NAME: REAL-LIFE CHARACTERS IN FICTION
description: AHEARN, in ''The Young Lions'' (1948) by Irwin Shaw. Critics welcomed this as an outstanding novel of the Second World War. But Ernest Hemingway -according to his biographer, Carlos Baker - thought it a disgraceful, ignoble book, written by a coward who had never fired a shot in anger. He took the American war correspondent, Ahearn, to be a caricature of himself, and saw his younger brother, the journalist and wartime documentary film maker Leicester Hemingway, in Pvt. Leroy Keane, an obnoxious communications clerk striving to live up to the image of an elder brother who had been a hero of the First World War.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE WRITER AS CELEBRITY: Intimate Interviews. By Maralyn Lois Polak. (M. Evans, $9.95.) Isaac Asimov is an acrophobic. Jean Shepherd feels hostile toward Woody Allen and Neil Simon.

title: Robin F. Edelstein Marries Lee Milich, Fellow Lawyer
description: Robin F. Edelstein and Lee Milich, both lawyers in Miami, were married yesterday at Temple Beth El in Cedarhurst, L.I. Rabbi Gilbert Rosenthal performed the ceremony.

title: ANSWERS
description: 1. An average of 40 percent. 2. ''Fear of Flying'' by Erica Jong (New American Library, 1974), with 5.7 million copies in print. 3. ''The Elements of Style'' by William Strunk Jr. and E. B. White (Macmillan). 4. Twenty-five cents each. 5. Leon Kenyon Engel, whose ''Tennessee!,'' written by the psueudonymous Dana Fuller Ross, is currently on the paperback fiction best-seller list. 6. Louis L'Amour, a favorite author of President Reagan, received it in 1984. Mr. L'Amour now has 90 titles in print in paperback, with total sales exceeding 100 million copies. 7. Ian and Betty Ballantine were the founders of the American branch of Penguin Books in 1939, Bantam Books in 1945 and Ballantine Books in 1959. Mr. Ballantine is the editor of ''Yeager: An Autobiography'' by Chuck Yeager and Leo Janos, Mrs. Ballantine of ''Out on a Limb'' and ''Dancing in the Light'' by Shirley MacLaine. 8. ''Hamlet,'' ''Macbeth,'' ''Othello'' and ''Romeo and Juliet.'' 9. Romance and horror. 10. 2,500. 11. ''The World According to Garp'' by John Irving appeared in six differently colored covers in 1979. ''Winds of War'' by Herman Wouk had six different cover designs in 1980. Both were the inspiration of Milton Charles, Pocket Books' art director. 12. The ''Rand McNally Road Atlas: United States/ Canada/Mexico,'' which last year achieved a sale of 3.8 million copies. Runners-up are ''The Old Farmer's Almanac'' (2.25 million copies) and ''The Guinness Book of World Records'' (one million copies). 13.

title: YANKEES DEFEAT RANGERS BY 9-4
description: The Yankees and the Texas Rangers have played better games in Florida during spring training. In ''B'' games with minor leaguers.

title: UPSTATE HOSPITAL CITED FOR UNETHICAL CONDUCT
description: A small hospital near Buffalo that promised doctors cash bonuses, free meals and free rounds of golf for bringing in patients has been cited for violating the state public health law and for unprofessional conduct.

title: Dancing Brave Takes Rich Newmarket Race
description: Dancing Brave, the unbeaten favorite, pulled away from a strong field and won the 2,000 Guineas English classic by three lengths today. Ridden by Greville Starkey, the 3-year-old colt defeated Green Desert, with Huntingdale third.

title: Barbara Atwell and Peter Hurst Jr., Lawyers, Wed
description: Barbara Lynn Atwell, an associate in the law firm of Arnold & Porter, and Peter Frederick Hurst Jr., a lawyer in the general counsel's office of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, both in Washington, were married yesterday. The Revs.

title: IN BRIEF: RECENT FILMS ON CASSETTE
description: The Goonies Starring Sean Astin, Josh Brolin and Jeff Cohen; directed by Richard Donner, 1985 (PG) Warner Home Video 114 minutes. $79.95 A contemporary adventure-thriller about a group of young friends who set out on an underground search for a missing pirate treasure. The film, from a story by Steven Spielberg, ''has the kind of breakneck pacing that keeps it fast, funny, ingenious, entertaining and - only a small point while the movie is in progress - almost entirely without staying power.''

title: THE SHOE FITS AGAIN
description: ALMOST hidden between three big, blue-uniformed state troopers, Bill Shoemaker was walking quickly through the empty paddock at Churchill Downs when the departing spectators noticed him.

title: DAY CARE TERMED MAJOR COUNTY ISSUE
description: COUNTY EXECUTIVE Andrew P. O'Rourke is calling for stricter state standards regulating day care and for more aggressive enforcement of existing standards.

title: On Growing Up as a Normal Adopted Child
description: To the Editor:

title: MAKING MONEY OUT OF 'MELLOW'
description: MOST of the large white placards rising from the sea of albums in Tower Records stores advertise categories of music like rock, gospel, country and jazz. But in many of the stores, one placard reads simply Windham Hill. ''We had so many people coming in looking for Windham Hill music that we had to create a whole separate section,'' said Brian M. Bacchus, the jazz purchaser for Tower Records's Greenwich Village store.

title: LEAGUES RE-FORMS IN 2d YEAR
description: BECAUSE of its novel summer schedule, not many people thought the U. S. Basketball League would succeed during its inaugural season last year. And, in fact, the league was hardly a rousing success.

title: CHILDREN AS HOSTS
description: One group of hosts and hostesses that is usually left out of newspaper and magazine articles that offer tips for exemplary entertaining is the 10-year-old-and-under set. This is most unfortunate, for who more than children is inclined to entertain frequently? They have lots of free time, few responsibilities to restrict their plans, vivid imaginations and plenty of willing and equally sociable friends.

title: London Museums
description: To the Editor: Not mentioned in the article entitled ''Family Guide to Museums in London'' (Travel, March 23) is the outstanding children's attraction where my children have spent many fun-filled days - the London Toy and Model Museum, at 23 Craven Hill, which is within a short walking distance of Paddington Station and the Lancaster Gate underground stop.

title: Elizabeth Harper Is Wed in Capital
description: Elizabeth Warren Harper and Daniel Francis Danello, both 1981 graduates of Harvard College and lawyers in Washington, were married there yesterday at St. John's Episcopal Church on Lafayette Square. The Rev. James C. Holmes, assistant minister of the church, performed the ceremony assisted by the Rev. James T. Maier, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Robin E. Luca, a Lawyer, Married to Edward D'Elia
description: Robin Elise Luca, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Adolfo Luca of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Edward G. D'Elia, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius D'Elia of Monsey, N.Y. The Rev. Guy Puglisi performed the ceremony at Regina Pacis Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn.

title: Awards Given to Artists
description: The Empire State chapter of the National Society of Arts and Letters presented its gold medal of merit award Friday to Louise Nevelson, the sculptor, at the National Arts Club. Young artists awards were given for painting to Lori Zummo and Andrew John Bacha. Dinner speakers included Kitty Carlisle Hart, chairman of the New York State Council on the Arts, and Hilton Kramer, editor and critic.

title: UCONN CONSULTANT DISCOVERS PROBLEMS
description: MAJOR organizational problems at the University of Connecticut were outlined in a preliminary report last week by a management consultant.

title: Fear of Travel Gives Terrorism a Victory
description: To the Editor:

title: 20 DIE IN SRI LANKA IN BLAST ON A JET
description: An explosion believed caused by a bomb ripped through the tail section of a Sri Lanka jetliner this morning while passengers were still boarding the craft, killing 20 people inside the plane or on the ground.

title: GREATER RANGE IS PLANNED FOR A CLASSIC FILM
description: The Eastman Kodak Company used a gathering of 200 photographers here this week to begin testing the waters with a new ISO-200 Kodachrome 35-millimeter film. By late summer, Kodak is expected to introduce this new, faster version - not currently available - into the Kodachrome family, thus taking the popular high-quality fine-grain emulsion to a new stage of development.

title: MICROCOSM OF SOUTH AFRICA'S WOE
description: IT is a rare week that the turmoil in South Africa has not been a major news story. We're becoming accustomed to television shots of funerals attended by thousands, and to the sight of violent demonstrations.

title: SUMMER ARTS PROGRAM SETS 2 AUDITIONS
description: THE Summer at Montclair program of the New Jersey School of the Arts, begun last year, will hold auditions at Montclair State College on May 18 and June 14.

title: BRAZIL MAY SOON TAKE HEED OF ITS HAVE-NOTS
description: DURING two decades in power, Brazil's military rulers opened the interior to agriculture, invested heavily in energy and communications and encouraged industry to compete abroad. By the time they stepped down last year, Brazil had the eighth largest economy in the West and seemed likely to pass Canada, Italy and Britain in the 1990's.

title: Mets Defeat Reds, 4-1
description: In other years with other teams, John Denny became the greatest Met-beater among active National League pitchers, with a 16-5 career mark.

title: MASSACHUSETTS SETS VOTE ON ABORTION LIMITS
description: After a long and emotional debate, the Massachusetts Legislature has approved a constitutional amendment that would allow the state to place some restrictions on abortion. The amendment is to be on the November ballot for a final decision by the voters.

title: DUKE WOULD SELL ITS HOLDINGS IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: The Duke University board of trustees voted today to sell holdings in companies doing business in South Africa if the structure of racial separation in that country has not been dismantled by January.

title: ROLE-PLAYING, TO UNITE YOUNG AND OLD
description: Third graders and septuagenarians stepped into each others' shoes in the Bronx recently.

title: COMBINING CONDOS HIGH ABOVE THE CITY
description: BRADLEY AND HELEN NITKIN on the West Side are delighted that they did it but glad that it is behind them. Jeffrey and Ina Stern on the East Side are just starting to go through it and are exhilarated by the prospect.

title: Not Football or Soccer
description: Rugby, similar to football and soccer, has eight forwards and seven backs on a side and a big field, 110 yards by 75 yards, with two goal posts. A game is played in two halves of 40 minutes each, and substitution is allowed only for injury.

title: RECITAL: ZAZOFSKY AND SIEGEL PERFORM
description: PETER ZAZOFSKY and Jeffrey Siegel's program at Carnegie Hall Friday night was really three concerts in one - a solo violin recital, a piano recital and a joint collaboration.

title: SWIMMING FOR BABIES: FUN AND SAFE
description: I'd like to comment on the March 16 article ''Infant Swimming Classes Debated.'' Each of us mothers, after class in the locker room, praised the Huntington Y.M.C.A. and its new policy of no forced submerging and attitude of ''just having fun.''

title: AN 'OUTSIDER' ATTENDS HEBREW SCHOOL
description: IT was Millie's idea that I go to Hebrew Sunday school. Millie and I became friends about two weeks after I had moved to the neighborhood in the Bronx from Yonkers. Being acutely shy, I was not about to be aggressively social until my mother decided that the time had come for strong measures. She insisted that I go out to play and not return until I had a friend.

title: Miss McCarthy Becomes Bride
description: Elizabeth Frazer McCarthy, the daughter of Nancy Frazer Luckett of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., and James Harry McCarthy of West Palm Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to David Kurt Carlson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. D. Bret Carlson of Fairfield, Conn. The Rev. Joseph H. Gilmore performed the ceremony in the South Presbyterian Church in Dobbs Ferry.

title: Contra Aid Slides Down the Agenda
description: The Reagan Administration has suffered another setback in its effort to win Congressional approval of $100 million in aid for the rebels fighting the Sandinsta Government in Nicaragua.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, MAY 4, 1986
description: International

title: HANGING TOGETHER
description: THE UNITED STATES AND THE REGIONAL ORGANIZATION OF ASIA AND THE PACIFIC, 1965-1985 By W. W. Rostow. Maps. 265 pp. Austin: University of Texas Press. $30.

title: ANNIVERSARIES SET THE TONE
description: After 1985's European Music Year outpouring, it might be assumed that this year's festival scene would be somewhat subdued, but that is not the case. Like the sudden appearance of greenery and flowers that come with spring, there is an undiminished resurgence of musical activity.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
A RARE SILVER DOLLAR TO BE AUCTIONED
description: The Garrett specimen of the 1804 silver dollar will be the star attraction at a public auction by Bowers and Merena Inc. of Wolfeboro, N.H. This rare and romantic coin will come up for sale next month on June 23-25 at the St. Moritz Hotel in New York.

title: Comings and Goings
description: George Burns, the golfer who lost a three-way playoff at the 1985 Westchester Classic, has entered the 1986 event, which will begin June 5. . . . John Stuper, the winning pitcher for the St. Louis Cardinals in Game 6 of the 1982 World Series, has been named baseball coach at his alma mater, Butler County Community College in Pennsylvania. Stuper, who had a 33-28 record in the majors, was released after a tryout with Montreal last month.

title: ISLIP SIGN BAN IS CHALLENGED
description: AN advertising company is challenging a billboard ban in the Town of Islip, where the company has a dozen signs it refuses to remove.

title: Phil Gramm And Federal Spending
description: To call Phil Gramm's efforts to reduce the Federal deficit by selected cuts in Federal spending a ''crusade'' falls a bit short of the mark.

title: ERVING ADJUSTS TO PROLONG HIS STAY AT THE TOP
description: HE has heard the voices, the taunts, emanating from the crowds in arenas throughout the country. ''Julius, you're not the same.'' ''Julius, don't embarrass yourself.'' ''Julius, you're too old.'' But Julius Erving, basketball's 36-year-old statesman, has also heard other voices, whispering to him as he traveled through airports, walked along crowded streets or paused for a meal during this, his 15th professional season.

title: CONTEST BRINGS LIFE TO STUDY OF HISTORY
description: YOUNG history buffs from around the state will converge on Hartford next Saturday for the annual Connecticut History Day contest, to be held at the Connecticut Historical Society.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: NEW ESSAYS ON THE PSYCHOLOGY OF ART. By Rudolf Arnheim. (University of California, Paper, $10.95. Cloth, $28.50.) Rudolf Arnheim is the Masters and Johnson of art; his methodology is effective but so clinical as to appear unromantic.

title: Gorilla Bites Keeper's Thumb, Which Is Restored in Surgery
description: A zookeeper at the Bronx Zoo had her right thumb severed and the top of her right index finger bitten off yesterday when a gorilla attempted to seize food she was carrying, authorities said.

title: CONCERT: THE MOZARTEAN PLAYERS PERFORM
description: MOST of the pleasures of early-instrument Mozart were to be had at one point or another in the Friday concert of the Mozartean Players Classical Orchestra at the Metropolitan Museum. The little Divertimento in D (K. 136) can rarely have sounded so fresh and transparent.

title: THE PARTICIPANTS
description: President Reagan The American leader sees a chance at his sixth summit meeting to make a mark with fresh ideas on international economic coordination. His hand is strengthened by the success of last fall's efforts to reduce the dollar's value to more competitive levels. The 75-year-old President will also seek support for strong anti-terrorist measures.

title: PROTECTING CRIME VICTIMS
description: FOR FIVE days last month, New Jersey marked, as did the rest of the country, ''Crime Victims Rights Week.''

title: MAKING ROOM AT THE TOP FOR WOMEN
description: LESS than a generation ago, most colleges run by women were small Roman Catholic schools headed by nuns. Even many prestigious women's schools, such as Vassar and Mount Holyoke, had male presidents.

title: SAMPLING OF SPRINGTIME FOR THE TABLE
description: SPRING brings new treats to the table: the finest asparagus, young carrots, tender peas and fresh fava beans. These are good enough to eat on their own, as a separate course. A meal might begin with a creamy risotto, made with asparagus and fava beans or young peas, followed by a broiled veal chop or chicken breasts sprinkled with fresh herbs. All kinds of spring vegetables can be steamed and marinated in a garlic vinaigrette and served at room temperature, in the Italian manner. They are best eaten within a few hours of being cooked and not kept in the refrigerator to be served cold and lifeless the next day. Freshness is what spring is all about.

title: TRANSFORMATION COMES NATURALLY TO MUMMENSCHANZ
description: Mummenschanz - currently at the Joyce Theater - would not be Mummenschanz without the idea of transformation. The ingenious mime trio from Switzerland - Andres Bossard, Floriana Frassetto and Bernie Schurch - used to spend a great deal of time onstage in the 1970's changing before our very eyes. Or rather, since the three performers were always masked, it was their masks that changed. These, of course, were anything but conventional. Putty faces were pulled or pushed into or out of shape during hostile, silent encounters. A dialogue between two sets of note pads would result in grins or frowns being drawn on the paper in seconds. Moods changed with the pull of a toilet-paper roll - that is, when the face of each character was made up of toilet-paper rolls. A giant clam might just open its mouth and yawn.

title: 'Moonlighting' and the Late Pogo
description: Upon reflection, I was struck by two items in Joy Horowitz's article ''The Madcap Behind 'Moonlighting' '' (March 30), which reminded me of the late Walt Kelly's Pogo.

title: THE PURPOSE OF SPECIAL EDUCATION
description: I'm a high school mathematics teacher with 10 years of college, a Ph.D. and 26 years of teaching experience. I'm also the parent of a 13-year-old autistic boy.

title:
GARDENING;
FOR A PRETTY BORDER, TRY BIENNIALS
description: A BIENNIAL is a plant that is started from seed one year, flowers the next, then dies.

title: PANEL OF DEMOCRATS STUDIES POLICY DIRECTIONS
description: Members of the Democratic Policy Commission sat in a hotel meeting room here Friday and today discussing education, the rural economy, international trade, military and foreign policy, family life and economic development.

title: THE WORST EFFECTS WILL EMERGE SLOWLY
description: THE history of the 20th century is a confirmation of the wisdom that the impossible is always possible. Whether in the destruction of Challenger or in the meltdown at Chernobyl, the seeds of disaster were planted long before the event, and the repercussions will be felt long after.

title: MUST SCHOOL BE JUST ACADEMICS?
description: WHEN my children started to school in the late 50's, James B. Conant of Harvard University had just presented his definition of the comprehensive high school: It should serve the needs of all facets of the community, and, to accomplish this end, required an enrollment of at least a thousand students.

title: NO DANGER FOUND IN WARSAW
description: A radiation specialist from the United States Environmental Protection Agency found today that radiation levels in Warsaw were minimal and posed no health risks.

title: Eight Are Guilty In Sanctuary Trial
description: Was it, as a defense lawyer accurately summarized the prosecution's contention, ''just a plain old alien-smuggling conspiracy''? Or had 11 church workers, in providing sanctuary for refugees from violence-torn Central America, been obeying a higher law?

title: IN CONCERTS AND CONTESTS, A FOCUS ON YOUNG TALENT
description: SCHOOL vacations are almost here, but some students have more than final examinations and term papers on their minds. These are the young Connecticut musicians whose performances deserve support and encouragement.

title: Dedeaux to Retire?
description: These are the numbers of Rod Dedeaux: 71 (years old), 45 (years head baseball coach at the University of Southern California), 1,332 (Trojan victories), 28 (conference championships), 11 (national championships), 5 (consecutive national championships), 0 (additional years expected to coach). Dedeaux's speculation on retirement: ''I'll examine the situation after the season ends and make a decision at that time.

title: Sandra L. Miller Weds John Firestone
description: Sandra L. Miller, a daughter of Mrs. Edward M. Miller of Fort Lee, N.J., was married yesterday at the ''21'' Club in New York, to John Richard Firestone, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel Firestone of Houston. Dr. Sheldon Ackley, a senior leader of the New York Society of Ethical Culture, performed the ceremony.

title: 'PAINTING CHURCHES' DONE WITH FLOURISH
description: ''THIS is it!'' exclaims the character Fanny Church, who is in her 60's. She is referring to her life: the foreseeable end of it. ''All I'm trying to do is exit with a little flourish . . .'' she declares.

title: REPLACING A BROKEN LAMP SOCKET
description: WHEN a lamp bulb does not light after the switch has been turned on, there are two things that any sensible person will immediately do: Make sure the bulb is good by trying a new one in the same lamp socket or by trying the bulb in a lamp that you know is working; and make sure the outlet is ''hot'' -that is, be sure the switch that controls that outlet is on, or check to see if the fuse or circuit breaker has blown.

title: Elevators
description: To the Editor:

title:
THE GRIM TOLL OF CHERNOBYL;
A THREAT TO SOVIET ECONOMIC REFORM
description: WHILE there obviously is never a good time for a nuclear meltdown, the Chernobyl disaster comes at a particularly awkward moment for the Soviet economy. It may well abort Mikhail S. Gorbachev's ambitious effort to turn the Soviet economy around.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
SCIENCE AND THE PUBLIC
description: One hundred years ago, a small group of scientists at Cornell University founded an organization to encourage excellence in scientific research.

title: POLL FINDS APPROVAL RATING FOR REAGAN IS HIGH AS EVER
description: President Reagan's approval rating from the American people matches the highest level he has ever recorded, a New York Times poll shows, even though support for the bombing of Libya last month has slipped a bit from what it was immediately after the attack.

title: GUNS TIPPING CRUEL BALANCE IN THE SUDAN
description: They came in the morning and again after dark, the woman recalled. They killed and kidnapped the people of her village, and what property they could not carry away they set afire.

title: Mary Johnson Is the Bride of Michael M. Kessler
description: Mary Elizabeth Johnson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Warren L. Johnson of Alexandria, Minn., was married yesterday to Michael Marcus Kessler, the son of Maj. Paul Kessler, U.S.M.C., retired, and Mrs. Kessler of New York. Chief Judge Robert A. Forsyth of the Hennepin County Court in Minnesota performed the ceremony at the Wayzata (Minn.)

title: HERBARIUMS ARE FOR LEARNING
description: Amateur flower gardeners, dredging through a murky academic background that possibly included Latin as a required junior high school subject, might assume an herbarium is a quiet enclosure in which lavender, thyme and sage vie for places in the sun and bees hum eternally. They would be mistaken.

title: 1,000 MEET TO FIGHT DEMOCRATIC SHIFT TO RIGHT
description: More than a thousand Democratic activists began charting ''new directions'' for their party here this weekend, hoping to check what they perceive as a shift to the right by the party's national leaders.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: INSIDE TRACK: How to Get Into and Succeed in America's Prestige Companies. By Ross and Kathryn Petras. (Vintage Books, $8.95.) The premise here is rather like that of student course critiques from college days, the ones that assured you could sleep through Botany 101 and still fulfill your science requirement. ''Inside Track'' takes the student off campus and into the job market, with a breezy, relatively straightforward and ultimately unsatisfying look at life and job prospects at more than 50 American companies (and a couple of Government agencies) - based primarily on anonymous interviews with current employees. The profiles of these ''prestige companies - the companies where most people really want to work'' - are geared toward young people fresh from college or those who have been jogging through the rat race for a couple of years. Even so, some of the information seems, well, kind of silly. A section introducing profiles of Chrysler, Ford and General Motors, for instance, notes that you'd better like cars; and a section on the auction houses Christie's and Sotheby's declares you've got to love art. Beyond this, the supposed inside dope, con-tained in sections dubbed, ''Heard at the Water Cooler - What It's Really Like to Work Here,'' is thin on the kind of information that counts for women and minorities. No matter what the stated intentions of a company's management might be, a fact of life is that the experiences of blacks are going to be different from those of their white colleagues.

title: FROM THE HEART
description: SEX AND DEATH TO THE AGE 14 By Spalding Gray. 265 pp. New York: Vintage Books/ Random House. Paper, $5.95.

title: IN BRIEF: RECENT FILMS ON CASSETTE
description: Weird Science Starring Anthony Michael Hall, Kelly LeBrock, Ilan Mitchell-Smith and Bill Paxton; directed by John Hughes, 1985 (PG-13) MCA Home Video 94 minutes. $79.95 A comedy about two teen-age boys who attempt to realize their fantasy through wishful thinking and the supernatural. ''John Hughes still has his gift for finding talented young actors: Anthony Michael Hall is well teamed with Ilan Mitchell-Smith. . . . However, most of 'Weird Science,' for all its repetitive vulgarity and its wide array of gimmicks, is essentially much too calculating and cautious.''

title: 'Moonlighting' and the Late Pogo
description: Cybill Shepherd and Bruce Willis are the Dagwood and Blondie of the detective game.

title: CONCERT: GIDON KREMER, VIOLIN
description: THE Lockenhaus Festival, a sort of summer think tank for musicians in Austria, dispatched six representatives to the Metropolitan Museum Wednesday night for a program of Mozart, Mahler, Brahms, Webern and Hindemith.

title:
ANTIQUES;
A CELEBRATION OF CRAFTSMANSHIP
description: TRADITIONAL crafts of the 18th and 19th centuries will be demonstrated and sold by more than 90 juried artisans Saturday and next Sunday at the Mercer Museum here.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: IF you aren't one of them, it's maddening to see them in action or, in this case, inaction. They sit, slouch or lie flat on their backs. Their faces are beautifully relaxed, completely shorn of worry. Their lips curl in a gentle smile. Sometimes, a little music accompanies the peaceful picture - a delicate snore, a whisp of a wheeze, a soft percussion of tiny grunts - nothing overwhelming or too hearty because this is a sonata, not a symphony. These people aren't sleeping - almost anyone can do that. They are catnapping, and not almost everyone can do that.

title: SETTING THE TABLE
description: A great deal of contemporary tableware that works well outside brings nature's qualities to mind. Italian terra cotta or marbleized ceramics evoke an ancient world.

title: SMALL TOWN BALKS AT A PRISON PLAN
description: The way the people of New Braintree tell the story, the state just moved into town one day and began surveying the site of a former Seventh-Day Adventist school for a prison.

title: Perfect Spy, Good Review
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE SARDINE DECEPTION. By Leif Davidsen. Translated by Tiina Nunnally and Steve Murray. (Fjord Press, $6.95.) This first novel by a Danish journalist catapults an emancipated new man into traditional tough-guy territory.

title: IT ALL DEPENDS ON GEOMETRY
description: IN SEARCH OF THE BIG BANG Quantum Physics and Cosmology. By John Gribbin. Illustrated. 413 pp. New York: Bantam Books. Paper, $9.95.

description: THE WAR A Memoir. By Marguerite Duras. Translated by Barbara Bray. 183 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $13.95.

description: An August wedding is planned by Pamela Iris Bernstein and Michael Alexander Lynn, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Herbert M. Bernstein of New York and Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced.

title: LISBON GETS A MALL, AND MORE
description: Since medieval times, the austere crenelated castle of Sao Jorge has dominated Lisbon's hills, but now there are new towers that give the horizon a space age look.

title: PARCELLS IMPRESSED BY 49ERS' TRADING
description: ''Masterful'' was how Bill Parcells, the Giants' coach, described all the maneuvering by the San Francisco 49ers during the draft last Tuesday.

title: Strategic Planning
description: To the Editor:

title: Tax Payment Blocked For Presley Estate
description: A judge has temporarily prohibited Tennessee from collecting millions of dollars in inheritance taxes from Elvis Presley's estate, pending a decision on its value.

title: HIGH COST OF LIVING REQUIRES DAY CARE
description: In response to the April 13 letter by Mrs. [ Deborah ] Lothrop about child-care: I do not know how Mrs. Lothrop was raised, but she seems incapable of the ''respect, compassion, and kindness'' she assumes her ''constantly adored'' child will have. How else explain her arrogant, insensitive attack on young mothers who need to work because their husbands' wages are not enough to pay the high cost of living in today's world, or because they are single parents. I was fortunate enough to be able to stay home with my four children for 15 years, but I had friends who had to work, and their equally beloved children did not become the ''spiritually anguished'' adults Mrs. Lothrop so direly predicts.

title: Required Reading; The Nuclear 'Menace'
description: Excerpt from a House speech by Representative Ted Weiss, Democrat of Manhattan, April 30:

title: INNOCENT ABROAD, INNOCENTS AT HOME
description: Last summer, my 14-year-old son, who had been growing more swiftly than Pinocchio's nose, decided to test his wings and venture out of the United States for the first time to bike through England and France. His journey, he informed us, would take him through the Cotswold Hills and Hardy country, to Henley-on-Thames, Oxford, Stratford-on-Avon, London, and then through the Loire Valley in France with its beautiful villages, great chateaus and lovely farms, ending in Paris.

title: GOALS IN CULTURAL EXCHANGE
description: To the Editor:

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
SKIN
description: IT'S Saturday afternoon at Bloomingdale's in White Plains, and Robert Dolphin, makeup artist and showman extraordinaire, is re-vamping yet another face. The subject, middle-aged, with a nice, strong smile, raises her chin expectantly. She closes her eyes. Mr. Dolphin scrutinizes her features and - sponges and brushes and pencils poised - begins his spiel.

title: SOVIET AIDE'S INTERVIEW WITH WEST GERMAN TV
description: Following are excerpts from an interview on Friday with Boris N. Yeltsin, the Moscow Communist Party leader, by the West German television network ARD, as translated by The Associated Press:

title: PUCKETT HITS 11TH BUT TWINS LOSE, 7-4
description: Home runs by Detroit's Darrell Evans, Pat Sheridan and Darnell Coles more than offset home runs by Minnesota's Gary Gaetti and Kirby Puckett as the Tigers beat the Twins, 7-4, tonight.

title: CATHOLICS FRAME DETERRENCE STUDY
description: A panel of American Roman Catholic Bishops is to re-examine the morality of deterring attack through the threat of nuclear retaliation, a doctrine that the bishops gave conditional acceptance in a 1983 pastoral letter.

title: Round Trip
description: The plot sounded familiar:

title: TALES OF THE '49ERS
description: THE BIG TIME The Harvard Business School's Most Successful Class -and How It Shaped America. By Laurence Shames. 226 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $17.95.

description: EVERYTHING TO LOSE Diaries 1945-1960. By Frances Partridge. Illustrated. 383 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $19.95.

title: R. Christian B. Evensen Marries Loretta Gartner
description: Loretta Lucijia Gartner, a vice president in the interest rate products group of Drexel Burnham Lambert in New York, and R. Christian B. Evensen, a vice president in the investment banking group of Merrill Lynch Capital Markets in New York, were married yesterday. The Rev. Philip L. Anderson performed the ceremony at the Congregational Church of the Lighted Window in La Canada-Flintridge, Calif.

title: DRESSING FOR STYLE AND COMFORT
description: No matter who you are or where you are, white linen, that sporty summer classic, will stand you in good stead. It looks especially witty on urbanites fresh from the land of punk, as do suddenly chic reminders of the country club - madras and pastel colors, bright prints and pants crawling with frogs and whales.

title: A VEGETABLE BAN DISMAYS ITALIANS
description: A ban by the Italian Government on the sale of leafy vegetables as a result of the Soviet nuclear accident, and an advisory that children should not drink fresh milk, unleashed angry protests from farmers today and expressions of bewilderment from consumers.

title: Man With Heart Device Gets a Human Organ
description: A West Virginia man who received a Jarvik-7 artificial heart two days ago was given a human heart today in an operation lasting nearly five hours, a hospital spokesman said.

title: NOW, AN AD AGENCY IN THE JUMBO SIZE
description: The mega-agency created by the merger agreement of Harper Needham, BBDO and Doyle Dane Bernbach is the latest, and biggest, consolidation in the advertising industry. Agencies once were considered big have found themselves needing more arms to pull in business from overseas or to serve the international needs of domestic clients. Many small shops have already been swallowed up, so analysts say it was a matter of time before the bigger agencies started talking merger. The new holding company, as yet unnamed, to be created in this latest deal will have about $5 billion in annual billings, more than anyone else in advertising. Allen G. Rosenshine, BBDO's chairman and chief, will be chairman of the new company; executives of the other two agencies will take top posts in two independent international agencies and a specialty group that the company will operate.

title: Angela S. Chan Is Married To Mark Matthew Meinero
description: Angela Sau Chan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Yan Lap Chan of Briarwood, N.Y., was married yesterday to Mark Matthew Meinero, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack T. Meinero of Glen Cove, L.I. The Rev. Orlanda Bragnola performed the ceremony at the First Unitarian Church of Brooklyn.

title:
WINE;
A LOOK AT OPTIONS FOR THE WEDDING RECEPTION
description: WINE options usually available to wedding hosts at area restaurants and banquet halls include using the brands poured at the bar, upgrading to a higher-priced label on the house list, requesting that the establishment serve particular products not normally stocked or bringing in bottles purchased privately. The simplest solution to all this is to accept whatever is offered as part of a set package - most commonly reds and whites selling in shops for $3 to $5 a bottle. To encourage wedding parties to serve wines of better quality, some restaurants, such as Le Chateau (Route 35, South Salem) and Xaviar's (at the Highland Country Club in Garrison), offer brands on their regular list at a 15 percent discount.

title: Housing Values Soaring in Connecticut
description: THE economic surge in Connecticut over the last few years, together with a fast-diminishing amount of land available for new residential construction, helped last year to raise property values faster than in many other parts of the country, according to the 1985 Annual Housing Market Report issued last month by the Connecticut Department of Housing.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch about Wyoming's economic hardship in The Nation section on April 6 incorrectly described the demise of the Wyoming Production Credit Association. The association, which was in financial distress, merged in December with 36 similar companies in three other states into a new entity called the Production Credit Association of the Midlands.

title: MOST CHILE EXILES STILL KEEPING THEIR DISTANCE
description: More than a dozen years since Chileans began to flee their homeland for political reasons, only a few have returned, and critics of the military Government point to the exile issue as one of the worst stains on the national conscience and image.

title:
GARDENING;
FOR A PRETTY BORDER, TRY BIENNIALS
description: A BIENNIAL is a plant that is started from seed one year, flowers the next, then dies.

title: NEW ROUND IN THE FORMAT RIVALRY

title: Tennessee Readmits County That Seceded in the Civil War
description: A century and a quarter after Scott County seceded from Tennessee and remained loyal to the Union, the rift is over.

title: YALE CREWS WIN TO STAY UNBEATEN
description: Yale University's heavyweight crew remained undefeated today, downing Princeton and Cornell on Lake Carnegie and and raising a valid claim to the No. 1 ranking among Eastern crews.

title: THE MET'S GREAT MOMENTS HAVE BEEN FEW THIS SEASON
description: So, there it goes again, the Metropolitan Opera, and not a moment too soon. The 1985-86 season, which ended last night with a performance of ''L'Italiana in Algeri,'' had a few memorable moments scattered through its 32 weeks, but the indelible impression it leaves is one of persistent, carefully planned mediocrity. Or, at best, the most modest, provincial sort of competence. The singers scheduled in this ultimate ''Italiana,'' for instance, were named Gail Dubinbaum, Betsy Norden, Ernesto Palacio, Vernon Hartman, John Darrenkamp, Paolo Montarsolo and Diane Kesling. It is difficult to understand how a company with the Metropolitan's pretensions could close out its subscription season with such an undistinguished cast, but humdrum was the rule this season, not the exception. The fact that smaller American companies have long been able to offer their audiences fare as good as this must account in part for the painfully slow death of the Metropolitan's national tour, which fades out of existence after this month's four-city run.

title: VATICAN, TAKING SOME BLAME, CITES THREAT OF CULTS
description: The Vatican has issued a highly unusual report on the challenge posed by new religious cults to the Roman Catholic Church, warning that some cults are supported by ''powerful ideological forces as well as economic and political interests.''

title: IN BRIEF: RECENT FILMS ON CASSETTE
description: Silverado Starring Kevin Kline, Scott Glenn, Rosanna Arquette, John Cleese, Kevin Costner and Brian Dennehy; directed by Lawrence Kasdan, 1985 (PG-13) RCA/Columbia Pictures Home Video 132 minutes.

title: SCHEMING AGAINST MAN, THEIR MASTER
description: OTHER FIRES Short Fiction by Latin American Women. Edited by Alberto Manguel. 222 pp. New York: Clarkson N. Potter/Crown. Paper, $9.95.

title: 2,000 Afghan Guerrillas Reported Dead in Attack
description: The official Soviet press agency Tass has said that more than 2,000 Afghan guerrillas were killed and about 4,000 wounded last month when Communist forces overran a rebel base near the Pakistani border.

title: IN LONDON, GREEN LASERS AND RED SMOKE
description: After ''Cats'' there was ''Starlight Express,'' and after ''Starlight Express'' there was ''Les Miserables.'' British musical productions, not long ago known (if known at all) mainly for their homely charm, have been getting more Babylonian in size and visual impact; and the trend seems set to continue. Tim Rice's ''Chess,'' due to open in London May 14, and Andrew Lloyd Webber's ''Phantom of the Opera,'' promised for later in the year, are bound to be lavish affairs - if not quite as grandiose as the musical which has recently opened at the Dominion Theater.

title: Protestant Ethic
description: To the Editor:

title: WOMEN AT RUTGERS EXCELLING IN TENNIS
description: MOST afternoons these days, a number of Rutgers University students start drifting toward the area near the football stadium where the women's tennis team is working out. The workouts, under the darting, probing eyes of Coach Marian Rosenwasser of Somerset, are a little unusual.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:For years I have dreamed of visiting Easter Island, but little information is available. Would it make sense to combine the trip with a stay in Rio de Janeiro? -G. E. K., New York Answer:The simplest way of getting to Easter Island, which is in the South Pacific about 2,350 miles west of Chile (to which it belongs), is to fly to Santiago on LAN-Chile Airlines and connect with the carrier's flight to the island. There are five flights a week (six from June 24) from New York to Santiago, and one flight a week between Santiago and Easter Island, except in high season - during July and from November to March - when there are two. Round-trip flights to Santiago start at $836 in low season, $936 in high; the five-hour Easter Island flight costs another $369, round trip, the year round. A $469 Visit Chile fare permits flights from Santiago to five Chilean cities, including Antofagasta and Arica, as well as the island. The only scheduled air service to the island is on LAN-Chile.

title: IT JUST CAN'T AGREE ON THEM
description: JAPAN, at least in its mind's eye, is finished with the 20th century, and has moved on to the next.

title: 3d Death Sentence Imposed
description: Alton Coleman, who was twice sentenced to death for killings committed in a seven-week spree of crime, received a third death sentence Friday for strangling Tamika Turks, 7 years old. In sentencing Mr. Coleman, 30, Judge Richard W. Maroc of Lake Superior Court also imposed consecutive 50-year prison terms for the attempted murder and molesting of the victim's aunt. The judge delayed setting an execution date pending Mr. Coleman's automatic appeal.

title: LAKE GEORGE CONFRONTS A NOXIOUS WATER WEED
description: A noxious weed has turned up in Lake George, posing a serious threat to the pristine water at this major vacation resort, according to state and local officials.

title: MUSIC: TWO TROUPES COLLABORATE IN 'FURIES'
description: TWO 1960's-style avant-garde theater troupes, the Talking Band from the United States and the Roy Hart Theater from France, have collaborated on an Aeschuylus production they call ''Furies,'' now playing in the crypt of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine through May 18. Both groups have done excellent work here in the past, and ''Furies'' has its moments. But ultimately it fails to find a sufficiently unusual or compelling style to justify yet another production of these archetypal tales of the House of Atreus.

title: CONFLICT IN MANILA: POLITICAL DETAINEES
description: Nearly two months after President Corazon C. Aquino ordered the release of all political prisoners, nearly 500 remain in military and civilian jails, according to some human-rights activists here.

title: SCHOOL BOARD'S READING YARDSTICK: BOREDOM
description: A school board has dropped a summer reading program including the works of Mark Twain, John Steinbeck and Charles Dickens because of fears that their books would bore students.

title: FRENCH SONGS AND FOREIGN VOICES PROVE AN INTRIGUING BLEND
description: New releases of French vocal music offer variety in genre and style, some new discoveries and a considerable amount of audio thrills. What they do not offer are French interpreters. This points up a puzzling phenomenon, further aggravated by the recent retirement of such luminaries as Regine Crespin and Gerard Souzay: Where are the ''world-class'' French singers? There are, and always have been, singers whose art transcended borders, and who could interpret the French repertory to the manner born. Mary Garden, Conohita Supervia, Maggie Teyte and Victoria de los Angeles belonged to that select group whose current prime representative is Elly Ameling. She has now added the Berlioz orchestral song cycle ''Les nuits d'ete'' to her ample recorded repertory (Telarc CD 80084, also available on LP as 10084).

title: Sydna Bernstein To Become Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur L. Bernstein of Ossining, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sydna Bernstein, to Dr. Gary Brandon Wenick, a son of Maria Wenick of Jackson Heights, Queens, and the late Mr. Stephen L. Wenick. A September wedding is planned.

title: Retirement Plans
description: To the Editor:

title: LET UP ON FOSTER
description: WHEN the Mets return to Shea on Tuesday night, it will be as good a time as any for Met fans to exercise a little restraint and get off George Foster's case.

title: A REVIVAL 'WHERE IT ALL BEGAN'
description: For more than a century, a three-mile stretch of the east side of the city was known simply as the Warehouse District. It was a rundown jumble of foundries, small factories and warehouses that blocked the view of the Detroit River from the heart of downtown.

title: U.S. and Vietnam Still Talk at Cross-Purposes
description: To the Editor:

title: PORT CHESTER
description: MARY LUXENBERG, the co-director of Port Chester's sole art gallery, was taking a determined stroll toward the river. ''When you see the waterfront here,'' she said, ''you can see the key.''

title: OPPENHEIMER AND THE INDIAN
description: STALLION GATE By Martin Cruz Smith. 321 pp. New York: Random House. $17.95. STAFF SGT. JOE PENA, the larger-than-life

title: MISTRIAL IS DENIED IN SUIT OVER WILL
description: A judge denied a motion last week for a mistrial in the court battle over the $500 million estate of the late J. Seward Johnson.

title: The Chilling Silence at Chernobyl
description: The radioactivity released from one nuclear accident will soon be detectable all around the world. But Soviet officials continue to suppress almost all significant information about the disaster. Behind a wall of excuses, they persist in denying neighbors and Soviet citizens alike the facts they need to protect their health and assuage anxiety. In the modern world, that's no longer acceptable behavior.

title: Oratorio Society At Carnegie Hall
description: The Oratorio Society of New York's Thursday evening concert at Carnegie Hall began rather shakily, with a meandering performance of Beethoven's ''Choral Fantasy'' (Op. 80). David Ralph was not a strong pianist; he dropped a lot of notes and generally lacked much sense of forward momentum.

title: ENGLISH CINEMA, DUTCH PORCELAIN
description: To London To Savor the World of Film For those whose zest for travel is rivaled only by their ardor for movies, a trip is planned that may seem - to steal a line from Humphrey Bogart in ''The Maltese Falcon'' - like the stuff that dreams are made of.

title: Norman Is Leader In Las Vegas Golf
description: Greg Norman, the big Australian who finished tied for second in his last two outings at the Masters and the Heritage Classic, said today that he learned last week that he has been suffering from walking pneumonia and another bronchial ailment since February 1985.

title: PHOTOJOURNALISM THAT COLORS THE NEWS IN MANY WAYS
description: Because it reaches millions of people every day, and directly affects their thoughts, photojournalism can be considered one of the liveliest visual achievements of the 20th century. Out of this genre, that records the ''real'' world of small and large events, have come many images now firmly imprinted on our consciousness - among them Robert Capa's photograph of a rifleman stopped in midstride by a bullet during the Spanish Civil War, Dorothea Lange's portraits of Depression-numbed migrants, the starved babies of Biafra as witnessed by Donald McCullin, a street scene involving a small boy and two bottles of wine immortalized by the lens of Henri Cartier-Bresson.

title: ROCK AROUND THE SCHLOCK - THE TROUBLE WITH POP STAR BIOGRAPHIES
description: IN the beginning, paperback books were considered disposable culture. So was rock-and-roll.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN MANNEQUINS
description: SOME years ago, at a department store in White Plains, a burglar alarm sounded after closing time. Two security guards, slipping through the darkened store, spotted a crouching figure. They pounced swiftly, wrestling the suspect to the floor - and discovered they had taken a naked mannequin into custody.

title: TOPICS
description: IN 1863, Horace Greeley, editor of The New York Tribune, advised my great-granduncle, John Mahan, ''Go west, young man.'' Though Uncle Johnny had heard of desperadoes with guns blazing, the 21-year-old pressman left Brooklyn to pioneer in the West. Our family legends told of his exploits as a sheriff in the Black Hills, investor in silver mines and founder of a fortune.

title: Somersaulting Mark Set on Revere Route
description: A New York health food store manager has claimed a new world record for somersaulting over the entire 12-mile, 390-yard route of Paul Revere's famous ride.

title: Starring Role For Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIANS could have been forgiven this past week for confusing their city's streets with a Hollywood back lot.

title: IN BRIEF: RECENT FILMS ON CASSETTE
description: National Lampoon's European Vacation Starring Chevy Chase, Beverly D'Angelo, Dana Hill and Jason Lively; directed by Amy Heckerling, 1985 (PG-13) Warner Home Video 94 minutes.

title: Citified Trees
description: What with poor soil, exhaust fumes and high winds that whip down the urban canyons between tall buildings, trees generally do not thrive in city settings.

title: LAURA DERN IS A TEEN-AGER TO TAKE SERIOUSLY
description: ''People now tell me it's a good thing I stayed away from teen films,'' Laura Dern said in some amusement. ''Well, it wasn't my choice. I wasn't hired. You name a movie with a young girl in the last five years, and I'm sure I was up for it.''

title: HOSPITAL BEDS: THE NEW MATH
description: A YEAR ago, several Long Island hospitals were so full that patients admitted through the emergency room often had to be put up in makeshift quarters - a bed in a hallway or treatment room - until a room became available.

title: Affordability
description: To the Editor:

title: DESIGNER DONNA KARAN: HOW A FASHION STAR IS BORN
description: FOR A DESIGNER OF clothes on New York's Seventh Avenue, the capital of this country's women's fashion industry and the center of a $20 billion business, a car and driver is a sure sign of success. Each weekday evening near 39th Street, in the vicinity of 550 Seventh Avenue, the most elite building in the garment district, the chauffeurs and limousines can be seen arriving in clusters. Bill Blass's navy blue Lincoln Town Car arrives with Charlie at the wheel. Carrington leans against Ralph Lauren's black strech limo with its discreet ''R.L.'' monogram on the passenger door. Perry Ellis's Jaguar sedan purrs at the curb, in the care of Oscar. Tomas awaits Oscar de la Renta in a Mercedes sedan. Stefan is at the ready with Geoffrey Beene's Mercedes station wagon, and Kevin is in charge of Calvin Klein's black Mercedes 500 SEL.

title: Baseball's Hits And Misses
description: Leonard Koppett's catalogue of ''Baseball's Hits and Misses'' (March 30) would be right on the money if only he recognized that each of his ''hits'' is, in fact, inseparable from his ''misses.''

title: PORT AUTHORITY STATEMENTS ON OVERTIME CRITICIZED
description: Recent statements by the management of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey about police lieutenants' overtime mislead the public. They shift the blame for poor and ineffective management to the police associations, which have no control over the multibillion-dollar agency.

title: Cable TV
description: There are film music rewards on cable this week in features of varying quality. The best stage adaptation is ''Finian's Rainbow'' (1968), with that gleaming Lane-Harburg score rendered by Fred Astaire, Petula Clarke and Tommy Steele - Sunday at 8 A.M. and 8 P.M., and Friday at 5:30 P.M on Cinemax.

title: THE DANCE: 'PROXIMOLOGY,' BY TIMOTHY BUCKLEY
description: DANCERS love to put on dances about dancers putting on dances. The most recent of the many choreographers who have staged works about the perils and glories of rehearsals and performances was Timothy Buckley, who offered ''Proximology'' on Friday night at the Kitchen.

title: DOWNTOWN DEVELOPER: Willard G. Rouse 3d; RESHAPING PHILADELPHIA'S SKYLINE
description: IN a clank and clatter of building activity that seemed all but forgotten here a decade ago, the steelwork is rising at 17th and Market Streets for One Liberty Place, a 60-story skyscraper that is shattering Philadelphia tradition. The post-modern shaft of blue-and-gray granite, designed by Chicago architect Helmut Jahn, will be the first Philadelphia building to rise higher than the Quaker hat on the statue of William Penn atop City Hall's bell tower.

title: AFTERNOON IN THE COUNTRY
description: Although most people think of the word picnic as being as American as corn on the cob, it is believed by many linguists to be as French as fresh croissants. It derives, specifically, from the French words piquer, meaning to pick, and nique, a trifle. The compound piquenique came into use in the early 1700's, around the same time that the painter Nicolas Lancret started depicting daintily dressed ladies and gentlemen enjoying just that.

title: AIDS GROUPS ASSIST ADDICTS
description: AFTER focusing almost exclusively on homosexual men, Connecticut begins reaching out this month to its fastest-growing population of AIDS victims - users of intravenous drug.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK;
Business Rents Curbed on Coast
description: When Charles Osbourne found out in 1982 that he was losing his lease on the Elmwood Pharmacy because his landlord had sold the building, he had little idea that the campaign he would wage to keep his soda fountain would lead to the nation's only commercial rent-control law.

title: Boeing's Venture
description: To the Editor:

title: Going the Wrong Way
description: To the Editor:

title: SUDAN'S NEW LEADERS ARE IN A CORNER
description: THE stresses of intensifying civil war are palpable in this crumbling southern provincial capital. Many of the women and children have been sent north for safety; 40,000 refugees have crowded into the dust and oppressive heat of the city. Enforcing an after-dark curfew, jittery policemen ''shoot first and ask for identification later,'' a resident warned. Travelers move with great caution on outlying roads, wary of land mines.

title: LIMITING DISCRIMINATION IN JURY SELECTION
description: The White House has applauded as the Supreme Court, in some rulings in recent years, has moderated the legacy of the 1960's, when Earl Warren was Chief Justice. But last week's decision on discrimination in jury selection shows how risky it is to pigeonhole any Court as ''liberal'' or ''conservative.''

title: DARIEN LIFTS SIGHTS WITH 'MUSIC MAN'
description: FOR the six-year-old Darien Players, the current staging of ''The Music Man,'' which began a four-performance run last week and will be shown again Friday and Saturday, marks the beginning of a ''guest artists series'' - and of the players' first shot at a big musical with new and untried talent.

title: NEWARK MONORAIL TOPS LIST
description: TRANSPORTATION planners are giving high priority to a monorail system linking Newark's Penn Station with its International Airport. It was one of seven potential monorail routes identified by the state's Monorail Authority Study Commission in its final report to Governor Kean last week.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; GUITARIST, PIANIST, SOPRANO AND CELLIST IN RECITALS
description: Wim Hoogewerf Wim Hoogewerf, who made his New York debut Saturday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, is a guitarist of uncommon skill, dignity and enterprise. He studied with Dick Visser in Amsterdam, and later at the Universite Musicale Internationale de Paris with Oscar Cacers.

title: JOANNA GLEASON KEEPS A SECRET AS ACTING TOOL
description: WHENEVER she appears on stage, Joanna Gleason says, she keeps a secret.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: NATURAL SELECTION. By Margaret Mulvihill. (Pandora Press, Paper, $8.95. Cloth, $16.95.) There are enduring plots - prodigal sons, errant wives, natural disasters - and some relatively new ones.

title: Trilling's Novel
description: To the Editor:

title: CELEBRATING THE TRADITIONS OF COUNTY'S ITALIAN IMMIGRANTS
description: ALL cannot live on the plaza, but everyone may enjoy the sun - Italian proverb.

title: HOW AN ALMOST-SEVERED LEG WAS SAVED
description: IT WAS Friday the 13th and Barbara Cassara, a 29-year-old secretary, was moving from Elmwood Park to Hackensack. Little things had been going wrong all day, she recalled.

title: SHUTTLE PANEL'S FINAL QUESTION
description: MORE than three months after the shuttle Challenger disintegrated in the sky, the Presidential panel investigating the disaster met behind closed doors Friday to grapple with the still unanswered question: How could the space agency have ignored overwhelming evidence that a rupture of a booster rocket joint was a calamity waiting to happen?

title: DARTMOUTH RUGBY: SERIOUS, SOCIAL
description: THANKS in part to a trust fund, rugby at Dartmouth is a respected sport this spring and one so successful that the team represented the East this weekend in the national championship tournament at Pebble Beach, Calif.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: HISTORY'S MISTRESS: A New Interpretation of a Nineteenth-Century Ethnographic Classic. By Paula Weideger. (Pelican Books, $6.95.) In 1885, a German gynecologist named Hermann Ploss published a daring anthropological account of the legends, myths, rituals and beliefs that governed women's lives.

title: NEW NATIVE WINES
description: Oregon, Washington and Idaho, vineless wastelands a couple of decades ago, today are America's newest major wine region. As recently as 1960, there wasn't a single winery in the Pacific Northwest that produced classic, European-style wine. At last count there were about 100.

title: THE PERFECT HOSTESS
description: This story begins with a friend of mine, an Englishwoman living in Italy who is one of the finest hostesses I know. Other than by the feminine pronoun, she shall remain nameless, for she would be deeply embarrassed at my admiration, more so at my naming her in print. But those who have been on the receiving end of her hospitality, whether in her small, tidy apartment in Rome, at her handsome but unostentatious country home on an Umbrian hillside, or occasionally at a friend's flat when she passes through New York or London and lends her talents to a small dinner party, will know of whom I speak and share my sense of gratitude and awe.

title: GOALS IN CULTURAL EXCHANGE
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK'S HOUSING CHIEF SETTLES IN
description: Paul A. Crotty had been Commissioner of the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development for just a few days, but already seemed ensconced in the job.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: FLORAL STREET. By Simon Burt. (Faber & Faber, Paper, $9.95. Cloth, $22.95.) These stories cut - sharp, incisive little wounds that have the sting of paper cuts yet endure like ritual scarification.

title: Caroline Gavlick Wed To C. B. O'Callaghan
description: Caroline J. Gavlick, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. Gavlick of Fairfield, Conn., was married yesterday to Christopher B. O'Callaghan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. R. Anthony O'Callaghan of Armonk, N.Y. The Revs. Edward J. Scull and Joseph A. Arroyo performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the St. Pius X Church in Fairfield.

title: GOURMET GALAXY
description: MMMMM, mmmmm. Food. Most people love it; everyone needs it. What a fine way to raise money - put together a cookbook.

title: Onyxly Wins on Turf; Ends Well Runs Fifth
description: Jose Santos completed a consecutive triple when he rode Onyxly to a front-running 2 1/4-length victory in the $93,150 Fort Marcy Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. Equalize was the runner-up, 3 1/4 lengths ahead of Lieutenant's Lark.

title: Rising Stakes For New Zealand
description: The United States has upped the ante in its continuing dispute with New Zealand.

title: CONCERN ON PRISON EXPANSION
description: A PROPOSED 200-bed expansion to the Bedford Hills Correctional Facility for women has raised concerns in Bedford about the project's impact on the environment and the community.

title: CONNECTICUT HOUSE APPROVES $78 MILLION TAX CUT
description: The Connecticut General Assembly began its rush toward adjournment this week with a flurry of legislation to cut state taxes, ease the rising cost of liability insurance and make it easier to impose the death penalty.

title: CRAFT CAREERS CONFERENCE SET
description: ''WHAT DO you want from your career?''

title: CHOREOGRAPHERS FIND A SELLER'S MARKET
description: THE spring ballet season in New Jersey is bursting with premieres, and aficionados, because of performance conflicts that attest to the explosion of dance in the state, will have to make some difficult choices.

title: SPRING DROUGHT SPREADS OVER SOUTHEAST
description: The level of Lake Sidney Lanier, the 39,000-acre reservoir that supplies most of Atlanta's drinking water, is six feet below what it should be, and it is still falling.

title: The Ripple Effect Produced by the S.R.O. Moratorium
description: PRESUMABLY as a stopgap measure, the city put into effect in January 1985 what was to be an 18-month moratorium on demolitions of single-room-occupancy buildings, or alterations or conversions that caused a loss of rooms in those buildings.

title: Amanda Acker to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Christopher B. Acker of Ogdensburg, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amanda Mathilde Acker, to James Alfred Rice 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Davison Rice of Flint, Mich.

title: Dr. Feraru Is Betrothed To Dr. Howard Aronow
description: Dr. and Mrs. Felix Feraru of Bayside, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Elaine Rose Feraru, to Dr. Howard Aaron Aronow, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jay Aronow of Fullerton, Calif.

title: CHERNOBYL ROUSES BAD MEMORIES, NEW FEARS
description: THE Soviet nuclear reactor disaster last week spurred fears that the West's atomic power industry has been trying to soothe for the seven years since Three Mile Island. The concern was tempered by Western experts' assertions that Soviet nuclear safety planning is the world's worst and by the fact that the design of the Chernobyl reactor differs significantly from most Western plants. Still, there were enough similarities to give officials, experts and critics pause.

title: 23 STATES HOLD ELECTIONS OVER THE NEXT 2 MONTHS
description: The 1986 primary election season, which got off to a jolting start in Illinois earlier this year, moves into full swing this month and next as voters in 23 states choose candidates for state and Federal offices.

title: Rachel M. Daher Wed To Peter H. Stephaich
description: Rachel Mendes Daher, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Omar Daher of Juiz de Fora, Minas Gerais, Brazil, and Peter Hitchcock Stephaich, a son of Peter Stephaich of Paris and Louise H. Stephaich of Palm Beach, Fla., and New York, were married yesterday in the Church of Nossa Senhora da Gloria do Outeiro in Rio de Janeiro. Msgr. Narbal da Costa Spencel performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: BOEING'S VENTURE
description: To the Editor:

title: West German and Japanese Talk on Exchange-Rate Issue
description: West Germany's Finance Minister, Gerhard Stoltenberg, and his Japanese counterpart, Noboru Takeshita, today discussed the problem of foreign exchange rates, a Japanese official said.

title: Dewey's Ship Gets Reprieve
description: The Cruiser Olympia Association has been given more time to raise money to keep an aging warship afloat on the Delaware River.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: CONCERT OF SPORT The Hartford Whalers hockey team, which had a pretty good year, will get the biggest tribute of the evening when the Hartford Symphony Pops Orchestra performs a sports program at 8 P.M. Saturday in Bushnell Hall. ''We commissioned Richard Hayman,'' the Pops conductor, ''to compose a symphonic arrangement of the Whalers fight song,'' said David Snead, marketing director for the orchestra. While the song is original, Mr. Snead said, ''no one seems to know who wrote it. There was no printed copy; Dick Hayman had to work from a tape of the hockey players singing it.''

title: CASUAL SUMMER STYLE
description: Spontaneity is one of the pleasures of entertaining, or of being entertained. When friends gather, they are more receptive to a relaxed, seemingly impromptu, style, and a host or hostess can use this to great advantage.

title: THE SUMMIT QUANDARY: TO ACT TOGETHER OR NOT
description: ''One of the worst days in my diplomatic life,'' is how President Carter summed it up the last time the seven major non-Communist industrial nations met in Tokyo, seven years ago.

title: HAYMARKET LABOR MARTYRS HONORED
description: A hundred years ago today, several workers were killed and about 30 were injured when the police opened fire at a rally for an eight-hour work day at the McCormick Reaper Works. A protest meeting was hurriedly called for 7:30 o'clock the next night, May 4, 1886, in Haymarket Square.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: MAY 4, 1986
description: Fiction

title: A PAIR OF ACTORS AT THEIR SUMMIT
description: The British call it a two-hander: two actors alone on stage sustaining an evening of theater. The label suggests something sporting, like tennis or a game of cards. A two-hander is often a challenge round, with dialogue volleyed back and forth, a team play that is also, in a sense, a competition. Sometimes, because of the unequal weight of the roles, the players are not evenly matched. When Jessica Tandy and Hume Cronyn take the stage, as they do in ''The Petition,'' and as they did in ''The Fourposter'' and ''The Gin Game,'' ''two-hander'' seems far too inadequate a description. These are two actors at the summit.

title: WESLEYAN HONORS THE MOVIES
description: PROMISING chills, thrills, suspense and romance, American movie posters have served as both commercial advertisements and purveyors of the mythology of film. And now the movie poster's evolution over 30 years is being celebrated at Wesleyan University in Middletown, as part of the opening of the school's new Cinema Archives.

title: The Long Arm of Law Day
description: A Washington lawyer who tried Friday to telephone a client in the Army's disciplinary barracks in Leavenworth, Kan., found himself frustrated by his own calling. ''You're not going to reach any of them today,'' the prison operator told him. ''They're all tied up with Law Day.''

title: SUB'S SAD DUTY: FINDING THE SHUTTLE
description: THE nuclear-powered research submarine NR-1 is back at its home port in Groton after a strenuous mission - the search off Florida for debris from the space shuttle Challenger.

title: Lisa Beth Koteen Wed To Mark L. Gerchick
description: Lisa Beth Koteen, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Koteen of Washington, was married yesterday to Mark Lawrence Gerchick, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Elias H. Gerchick of Scarsdale, N.Y., and New York. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Andrew Baker at the home of the bride's parents.

title: UCONN WANTS ATHLETES WHO ARE SCHOLARS
description: THE University of Connecticut - which in eight years has had only four of its basketball players graduate - plans to produce concrete proposals this month for improving the education its athletes receive.

title: Strategic Planning
description: To the Editor:

title: HORSE MANURE? TRY RECYCLING
description: Your featured story of April 13 about North Salem's horse-manure ''problem'' [ ''With Horses Everywhere, Alas, Manure'' ] gave me a different kind of problem. From the ''Alas'' in the headline almost to the end of your story way back on page 15, I read nothing but head-scratching in North Salem about what to do with this terrible stuff and how to ''manage'' it. Finally, in almost the last breath, comes the little-bitty detail that this stuff, decomposed, becomes ''a weed-free topsoil dressing, which could be sold.''

title: LITTLE NEMO MEETS DICK TRACY
description: MURDER BY REMOTE CONTROL By Janwillem van de Wetering. Illustrated by Paul Kirchner. 96 pp. New York: Available Press/ Ballantine Books. Paper, $4.95.

title: Rail Lines Luring New Office Complexes
description: ALL over New Jersey, train stations along the state's hundreds of miles of rail lines have been abandoned over the last decade because of the lack of riders.

title: THE HEART OF THE MATTER
description: A Tussle for Control Each day, governments watch nervously as a blizzard of round-the-clock trading sets new values for the dollar, the Japanese yen, the German mark and other major currencies. The stability of governments can rest on the outcome of such foreign exchange transactions. So can the prosperity of citizens, because exchange rates - such as the amount of yen a dollar will fetch - help to determine what products people buy, which factories hum, who loses jobs and whose savings are ravaged by inflation.

title: Villanova, Syracuse Lead Big East Track
description: Jennifer Rahn won the javelin throw and her teammate, Vicki Huber, won the 3,000 meters to lead Villanova to first place after one day of competition at the Big East track and field championships today. Competition concludes Sunday with 14 events for men and women.
