title: TROUBLES ABROAD MAY BE BOON LOCALLY
description: THE fear of terrorism abroad, along with a drop in gasoline prices and a weaker dollar, is expected to mean a boom summer for domestic travel, and Connecticut officials hope that will create the best season ever for tourism in the state.

title: WORLD ECONOMY: TIGHTER GRIP SEEN
description: Early arrivals at the seven-nation economic summit meeting said today that the abrupt decline of the dollar and the sharp rise of the Japanese yen demonstrated a need for tighter control over the world economy.

title: CONSUL WHO AIDED JEWS GAINS IN RECOGNITION
description: From 1938 until Spain closed its border to them in late 1940, many Jews fleeing Nazi terror found an escape route through the Bordeaux region of France, south to Bayonne, into Spain at the border town of Hendaye and on to neutral Portugal.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: SMOKELESS WORKPLACES Unlike most secondhand items, secondhand cigarette smoke is not cheap. Smoke from an idling cigarette contains more tar and nicotine than an inhaled one, causing health problems for nonsmokers as well as smokers, and contributing to an estimated $65 billion a year in lost productivity and disease.

title: Headliners; Writers' Block
description: Richard N. Perle, the Assistant Secretary of Defense for International Security Policy, has spent 17 years in Government, so it can be presumed he knows whereof he speaks.

title: GETTING THE SKELETONS OUT - A NEW TURN FOR MYSTERIES
description: NOT so long ago, it seemed as if the only mystery choices on the paperback racks were 17 Agatha Christie classics, a couple of Mickey Spillane head bashers and, if you were determined to push your options, Charles Dickens's ''Our Mutual Friend.''

title: ATHENIANS NOT WILD ABOUT HARRY ANYMORE
description: In a move seen by some Greek political commentators as symbolic of the governing party's attitude toward the United States, the Athens City Council voted this week not to restore to its pedestal a statue of Harry S. Truman that was blown up by a leftist group in March.

title: TEEN-AGE PREGNANCIES CALLED MORAL PROBLEM
description: I read with interest the April 20 article by State Senator Donald T. DiFrancesco on a solution to the problem of unwed teen-age pregnancies. While I greatly admire the Senator, I must disagree with his recommendations.

title: ROMAN CATHOLIC CHURCH DISCUSSES ABUSE OF CHILDREN BY PRIESTS
description: Faced with more than 40 cases in the last two years of Roman Catholic priests accused of sexually abusing children, church officials in this country are beginning to talk openly about the problem.

title: WHO'S PLAYING AT THE FESTIVALS
description: The following directory of music festivals is based on a survey of events in Europe, the Middle East, the Caribbean and Mexico judged to be of more than local interest. It contains dates, locations, performers and program information, and where available, the range of ticket prices, but not all program information was available at press time. In all cases, programs, performers, prices and other details are subject to change.

title: 2 BLANK PAGES HALT THE S.A.T. FOR THOUSANDS
description: As many as 7,500 of 300,000 high school juniors who took Scholastic Aptitude Tests across the country yesterday found two blank pages in their test booklets and were unable to complete the examinations, according to officials in charge of the test.

title: Jane A. Schwitter Becomes a Bride
description: Jane Ann Schwitter, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Joseph Schwitter of New York and Amagansett, L.I., was married yesterday to David Fleming Beard Ruppe, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Francis Ruppe of Wilmington, Del., and Dorset, Vt. The Rev. Francis B. Creamer Jr. performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in East Hampton, L.I., assisted by the Rev. Adam Lewis, rector of Christ Episcopal Church Christiana Hundred in Greenville, Del.

title: Data Bank May 4, 1986
WHERE EUROPE BOUNCES TO THE BEAT
description: Strolling the ancient streets of Perugia, you pass an Etruscan arch and wander down a steep flight of medieval stone steps. Suddenly, you're jolted back into the 20th century by the sound of a saxophone wailing a Charlie Parker riff.

title: Unions Sue Amtrak on Tests
description: Eighteen railroad unions have filed suit against Amtrak, the National Railroad Passenger Corporation, in an effort to bar its testing of employees for drugs and alcohol.

title: HAWKS HOPING TO STAVE OFF ELIMINATION
description: No matter how bleak the situation, the underdog tries to put on a happy face.

title: ANDRE PREVIN BACK IN L.A.
description: ANDRE PREVIN stands on the stage of the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion, listening for the first time to Sir Edward Elgar's ''Enigma'' Variations played by his new orchestra, the Los Angeles Philharmonic. He wants to hear how they do it before telling them how he wants it done.

title: Two Convicted in Stun-Gun Trial
description: Two New York City police officers were found guilty last week of assaulting a Queens teen-ager with an electric stun gun to force a confession to a minor drug charge. The officers were the first of five to go on trial in connection with charges that prisoners were tortured with stun guns in separate incidents at the 106th Precinct in Queens last year. The allegations led to a major shakeup at police headquarters and in the borough's police command.

title: Kathleen Traynor Wed in Berkeley To R. D. Millard
description: Kathleen Suzanne Traynor, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Michael Traynor of Berkeley, Calif., was married yesterday to Richard Dudensing Millard, a son of Mrs. Peter deFlorez Millard of New York and Barneveld, N.Y., and the late Richard Bowen Dudensing of New York. The Rev. James Edward Williams performed the ceremony at St. Clement's Episcopal Church in Berkeley.

title: Littler Takes the Lead
description: Gene Littler shot a six-under-par 66 today to take a five-shot lead after two rounds of the $250,000 Sunwest Bank-Charley Pride Senior Golf Classic at Four Hills Country Club.

title: Attica and the Police
description: To the Editor:

title: Condos Going Up on Mt. Kisco Estate
description: A Westchester County estate of nearly 70 acres, where the large greenhouse and stables stood abandoned for many years, is giving way to a town-house condominium project in Mount Kisco.

title: JERSEY AIDE CHARGED IN ACCIDENTS
description: A high-ranking New Jersey law-enforcement official has been charged with drunken driving and leaving the scene of an accident.

title: CD SWEETNESS AND 'AIR' ARE OBTAINABLE - AT A PRICE
description: My former friends haven't spoken to me since March 16. That's when I wrote about a psychometric investigation which found that some people don't hear much difference between various makes and models of CD players.

title: Willow Soltow Is Wed To Theodore H. Crane
description: Willow Ann Soltow, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William D. Soltow Jr. of Riverside, Conn., and Sanibel Island, Fla., was married yesterday to Theodore H. Crane, the son of Mr. and Mrs. George Crane of Riverdale, the Bronx, at the summer home of the bride's parents in Clinton, Conn. Leonard Plotnick, a justice of the peace from Woodbridge, Conn., officiated.

title: SCURVY RASCAL SEES IT THROUGH
description: FLASHMAN AND THE DRAGON By George MacDonald Fraser. 320 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95.

title: EMPLOYEES WITH DRUG PROBLEMS GET AID ON THE JOB
description: A GROWING number of Long Island employers, from private companies to school districts, are offering programs to help workers with drug or alcohol problems save their jobs and straighten out their lives.

title: BRIDGEPORT'S DAY TO PROMOTE ITSELF
description: BRIDGEPORT will put out the welcome mat for more than 200 business executives this week, to show off the city's development potential.

title: Amy L. Davis Engaged To Wiliam Ambrose
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Davis of Bedford, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Amy Louise Davis to William Whitney Ambrose, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin R. Ambrose of Darien, Conn. An August wedding is planned.

title: BLOOD, SWEAT AND TEARS IN THE YARD
description: IF winter comes, can spring cleanup be far behind? This is the question I asked myself recently when rummaging through the checkbook stubs. I don't mind telling you that it was a shock to see an April 1985 entry marked ''$140 - Spring Cleanup.''

title: REACTOR SAFETY PROBLEMS OF 1985 LISTED
description: Safety suffered at commercial nuclear reactors in the United States last year because of broken emergency equipment, inadequately trained operators, badly designed or maintained machinery, management weaknesses and insufficient attention to detail, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said in a report released today.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK;
Harbor Project Lauded for Scale
description: Historic preservationists, who normally view new developments with a skeptical eye, are pointing to Rowes Wharf, a $193 million mixed-use complex now rising along the waterfront, as a good design for this city's diminutive scale.

title: WALDHEIM FACING THE VOTERS TODAY
description: An embittering presidential election campaign that ended today has polarized Austria and splintered its postwar political consensus, according to several senior figures in the Government and the opposition.

title: ROCKEFELLER UNIT DOUBLES ITS THIRD-WORLD AID
description: The Rockefeller Foundation, adopting an expanded global program, will spend up to $300 million in the next five years to promote economic and social development in third-world countries. The sum is double the money the private philanthropy provided for overseas aid in the last five years.

title: House and Hearth And City Politics
description: Two weeks after he had proposed changes in New York City's zoning and building codes to spur the private development of moderate-income housing, Mayor Koch last week recommended putting the city's own money behind another ambitious housing effort. Indeed, that seemed an understated way to describe the Mayor's 10-year, $4.2 billion plan to build or renovate 252,000 apartments, 219,000 for families with annual incomes below $25,000 and the rest for families earning between $25,000 and $48,000.

title: Smith to Defend Title
description: Lonnie Smith, the World Boxing Council super-lightweight champion, who had been ordered to defend his title by tomorrow or lose it, said he planned to go ahead with a scheduled defense, against Rene Arredondo, in Los Angeles tomorrow night even though he was still hampered by a severely bruised arm. ''I'd rather go on handicapped than just give the title back,'' Smith said.

title: AN ENGINEER-MUSICIAN PURSUES THE SOUND OF PERFECTION
description: ''I ONLY do what I love to do,'' said Norman C. Pickering of Southampton.

title: Allison Corbetta to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Louis J. Corbetta of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Allison Jeanne Corbetta to Mark Samuel Radin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald L. Radin of Buffalo. A September wedding is planned by Miss Corbetta, a clinic assistant at Planned Parenthood of Connecticut in Stamford, and Mr. Radin, a computer cartographer with the New York State Legislative Task Force on Demographic Research and Reapportionment.

title: SHOULD HOLDEN CAULFIELD READ THESE BOOKS?
description: THERE are some strange discrepancies between the way most of us want our children to grow up and the books we give them to read while they are doing it. We want them to grow into a responsible adult frame of mind, to grow in confidence, to look outward at the work to be done and the fights to be fought; not to regard themselves as victims of a biological dirty trick, not to make a new allegiance, a kind of Third World Nation, out of adolescence. But consider the four great adolescent classics of the last generation or two: ''The Catcher in the Rye,'' ''Lord of the Flies,'' ''To Kill a Mockingbird,'' and ''A Separate Peace.''

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
MY PLAYOFFS WITH THE RANGERS, AS PLAYER AND COACH
description: I GUESS you would say I'm pretty familiar with Ranger playoff glory. I joined the Ranger organization in 1943, with the New York Rovers, which was one of their farm clubs, and I played with some players who had won the Stanley Cup in 1940. Then I played on the Ranger team that made it to the Stanley Cup final in 1950, and coached the team that made the final in 1979. I'm quite sure nobody else can say they were involved with both those teams, 1950 and 1979.

title: Logging Plan Splits Allies
description: THE National Forest Service's 10-year management plan for the White Mountain National Forest in New Hampshire has divided national and local conservation groups over the extent of proposed timber harvesting and roadbuilding.

title: AMID YALE'S TULIPS AND DAFFODILS, A TIME OUT FROM STUDIES
description: IN the last six years, Gary M. Lavorgna has encouraged students to supplement their education at Yale with an education about Yale.

title: Percussion Ensemble Of New Jersey Concert
description: Percussion instruments offer such instant access to power and brilliance that the medium tests both the integrity and taste of composers who use them. The New Jersey Percussion Ensemble, appearing under the auspices of the Guild of Composers at the McMillin Theater Thursday night, offered some nice examples of the first quality and a few lapses in the latter.

title: 76ERS TOP BUCKS, 107-103, FOR A 2-1 EDGE
description: One player says he will play just one more year, while the other says he'll call it quits as soon as the Phildelphia 76ers' improbable season ends. But this afternoon, 36-year-old Julius Erving and his 34-year-old teammate Bobby Jones showed that there's still some spark left in both.

title: ANOTHER PIECE OF CHILDHOOD SLIPS AWAY
description: THE BEGINNING of every baseball season still holds me hostage to those unending hot summer days of my youth. Not only is there the memory of Robin Roberts blowing away batters with high hard ones, or Willie Mays chasing down towering drives in center field, or Carl Furillo cutting down runners with a rifle he called an arm, but there is also this muscular memory: going into the hole from my shortstop position, backhanding a wicked one-hopper, planting my feet and unfurling a rope of a throw to first to catch the hitter by a stride. Those kinds of plays were good enough to get me an offer to go down to the minor leagues. I figured I would never hit the deuce good enough to make the majors, so I went to college.

title: The Sovereignty Itch
description: This is now the 12th annual summit of the major industrial nations, the sixth which President Reagan has attended. People involved ask themselves what purpose they serve.

title: Fresh Air and Lightning Bugs
description: ''At first it was hard to go to sleep - it was too quiet outside. But then I got used to it.'' For 8-year-old Aletha from Harlem, the absence of street noise in rural Connecticut was only the first strange experience. ''Next to the road here,'' she wrote home, ''they don't have sidewalks and there's no broken glass in the gutters. There are daisies growing by the side of the road.''

title: THE PLAYS
description: Commercial Transactions The world's financial system was originally driven by three straightforward types of transaction: international trade; tourism and travel, and international investing. In each case someone must convert one currency into another in order for the transaction to be completed. Commercial banks handle most of these exchanges. Investment banks are active in the booming field of swaps, where companies borrow in one currency, then trade into another to take advantage of varying interest rates.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: CHA-CHAING AT ARUTHUR'S A first glance it could be a wedding reception.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: A CIRCUS ON U.S. 1 The Big Apple Circus, known for its one-ring intimacy and versatile performers, will pitch its bright blue tent on U.S. 1 near Princeton Thursday for a six-day run.

title: Tours for Today
description: Robin Lynn of the Municipal Art Society looks at Broadway as a metaphor for New York. ''Look at how it changes and you'll see how the city is changing,'' she said.

title: Caramoor Festival To Begin June 28
description: The 41st annual Caramoor Music Festival in Katonah, N.Y., will run from June 28 through Aug. 24.

title: Test Ban Would Help Contain Nuclear Proliferation
description: To the Editor:

title: Horizon's Chief Pleased With Chemical Accord
description: For William J. Shepherd, president and chief executive of Horizon Bancorp, New Jersey's fifth-largest bank holding company, the decision to sell the company to the Chemical New York Corporation once state banking laws permit was not a terribly difficult one.

title: DENIAL BY WALTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Coffee Group Sets Penalties
description: The International Coffee Organization passed two resolutions Friday that will allow penalties to be imposed on member countries that sell coffee more cheaply to nonmembers.

title: Esther Tufty Is Dead at 75; Began News Service in 1935
description: Esther van Wagoner Tufty, a Washington journalist since the days of the New Deal, died today in Alexandria, Va. She was 89 years old.

title: PURCHASERS INDICATE SLOWDOWN
description: The economy slowed in April as production, inventories and employment declined, the National Association of Purchasing Management said yesterday in its monthly report.

title: PAUL R. RICHARDS, 77, FORMER BASEBALL MANAGER
description: Paul Rapier Richards, a former major league baseball player, manager and executive, died here this afternoon of an apparent heart attack while playing golf. He was 77 years old.

title: WIESEL REAPPOINTED TO PANEL
description: The White House announced today that the Holocaust survivor and author Elie Wiesel would be appointed to a second term as head of the United States Holocaust Memorial Council. The announcement, issued during President Reagan's visit to Tokyo for the economic summit meeting, came almost a year after the President made a visit to a German military cemetery that put him at odds with Mr. Wiesel.

title: ROCKETS FIRED AT PALACE, SITE OF SUMMIT WELCOME
description: Penetrating the extraordinary security surrounding the economic summit meeting, attackers today fired five homemade rockets at the state guest house during welcoming ceremonies there for the leaders of the industrial nations meeting in Tokyo.

title: PACE CAR DETOUR DELAYS ALLISON VICTORY
description: Darren Crowder of Birmingham, Ala., a 20-year-old spectator, jumped into an unoccupied pace car today before the start of the Winston 500 Nascar stock car race and led the police on a chase around the track.

title: JAPAN MICROPROCESSOR EFFORT AT STAKE IN INTEL CASE
description: The trade tensions between American and Japanese semiconductor companies are heading into the courtroom in a case in which the Intel Corporation is charging Japan's NEC Corporation with copyright infringement.

title: Washington Watch; Argentine Soybean Dispute
description: The Government's stepped-up agricultural trade offensive has spread to South America. While still fighting the European Community's efforts to curb imports of American soybeans to Portugal, the Reagan Administration is now aiming salvos at Argentina for maintaining a differential export tax on sales of soybean oil and meal.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Deaver's Trip to India And a Matter of Trade C71>
description: American business leaders traveling overseas often stay at the American ambassador's residence, especially if the ambassador is a friend. Such was the case two weeks ago when Michael K. Deaver, former deputy White House chief of staff, made a visit to India to talk business with Indians interested in the services of his Washington lobbying concern.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: A recent article on Bob Feller projected what his career pitching statistics might have been had he not missed three years because of World War II. Didn't Ted Williams miss more time, and if so, what would his projected career statistics look like?

title: DANCE: NANCY MEEHAN
description: NANCY MEEHAN'S choreography remains fiercely original among various trends in modern dance today. More than any other dance works, hers are easier to sense than to explain.

title: 'THE ROMANY TRAIL,' ON CHANNEL 31
description: ''THE ROMANY TRAIL,'' like the other ''Beats of the Heart'' music documentaries shown Mondays on WNYC/Channel 31, can make your jaw drop regularly with astonishment.

title: OUTLOOK SCRAMBLED BY DERBY SURPRISE
description: Bill Shoemaker, who won his fourth Kentucky Derby at the age of 54 aboard Ferdinand here Saturday, and Charlie Whittingham, the popular trainer who was notching his first Derby victory at the age of 73, were the toast of Louisville Saturday night. They received tearful hugs and standing ovations everywhere they went, even from rivals at the track.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Dresher Inc., Bedford Park, Ill., a maker of brass beds and brass accessories, promoted Joseph E. Geiger, executive vice president, to president and chief operating officer.

title: NO DISCORD, FILIPINO SAYS OF U.S. TALKS
description: Vice President Salvador H. Laurel said today that he had explained to President Reagan his Government's reasons for denying a passport to Ferdinand E. Marcos and that Mr. Reagan ''understood our position.''

title: President Named Head Of Vulcan Materials
description: The Vulcan Materials Company, a major manufacturer of building materials and chemicals that has remained solidly profitable despite various problems in recent years, has announced that Herbert A. Sklenar, its president and chief operating officer since 1983, has been named chief executive.

title: NO OUTCRY ON SCANDAL IS DETECTED BY ALBANY
description: In the Capitol corridors in these days of municipal scandal, elected officials talk often about how they have read the pulse of the public and found deep outrage of the sort that spurs reform.

title: ROMANS PROTEST MCDONALD'S
description: The first McDonald's fast-food restaurant in Italy firmly planted its golden arches above a doorway in the heart of the Piazza di Spagna on March 20. Since that day, life for Valentino, the Italian fashion designer, has not smelled the same.

title: LEADERS IN TOKYO SET TO DENOUNCE ACTS OF TERRORISM
description: Advisers to the heads of the leading industrial democracies produced draft statements on nuclear safety and international terrorism in an all-night session, and President Reagan was described today as ''extremely pleased'' with the efforts to address the two issues here.

title: Thief Fleeing in a Van Kills Man in Brooklyn
description: A van being driven by a fleeing thief yesterday struck and killed a Brooklyn man crossing the street near his home in the Borough Park section, the police said.

title: RUE IN THE CAPITOL ABOUT A FENCE OUTSIDE
description: Just about every member of Congress agrees that the United States Capitol is the pre-eminent emblem of American democracy. But they are deeply divided over the appropriate way to protect the building and the people who work there in an age of terrorism.

title: A BOSTON ADVISER UNDER S.E.C. FIRE
description: For seven years Mark E. Spangler appeared to be a rising young financial consultant and money manager here. His Spangler Group Inc. claimed impressive returns on its investments, as much as 86.4 percent a year, and the company's client list grew to 150, representing $25 million under management.

title: POLAND DEFENDS MOVE TO WITHHOLD RADIATION DATA
description: Polish scientists acknowledged today that they withheld specific readings on radioactivity levels so as not to stir panic.

title: Break Up The Mets!
description: FOR the Mets, the magic number is only 137.

title: Miss Pomice Is Bride Of Javier G. Timerman
description: Eva Pomice, a reporter-researcher at Forbes magazine, and Javier Gustavo Timerman, an assistant foreign-exchange trader, were married yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria by Associate Justice Bentley Kassal of the Appellate Division of New York State Supreme Court.

title: Upsets Mark Owens Meet
description: Two athletes ranked No. 1 in the world in their specialties were upset today at the Jesse Owens Track and Field Classic at Ohio State University.

title: Advertising; A Magazine to Focus On Children and Attire
description: In her office at Hearst's Harper's Bazaar, Mary Anne Sommers, advertising director, would somethings think about the fact that although children's ready-to-wear clothing was doing well there was no consumer publication to support that category, as there is for women's and men's attire.

title: Smashing Barriers
description: The newest star of the Junkyard Dogs defense - indeed, Georgia's No. 1 threat to opposing quarterbacks - is a Frenchman who grew up in the resort town of Biarritz. Maybe few people in Biarritz have ever heard of Herschel Walker, but nobody at all in Athens, Ga., had ever heard of Richard Tardits when the former member of France's national rugby team paid his own way across the Atlantic and went out for Bulldog football last autumn as a freshman walk-on.

title: Morocco a Model For Baker Initiative
description: Ahmed, a ragged youth who pushes a wheelbarrow on a building site here, has never heard of James A. Baker 3d. But in his own way he is involved in a project that symbolizes the Treasury Secretary's proposed strategy for easing the debt burden in developing nations.

title: At Carnegie Hall, Inspiring the Troops
description: Everywhere there were signs of someone moving out.

title: DOMINICAN ELECTIONS: MANY SEE A CLOSE RACE
description: Until a few weeks ago, the leading contender for the presidency here was a frail, 78-year-old blind man, Joaquin Balaguer.

title: Truth in Numbers
description: The way Alan Abramowitz and Jeffrey Segal figured it, such statistics as points scored, rebounds grabbed and balls stolen were unreliable gauges of a player's contribution. And subjective judgments, whether in all-star voting by fans or all-pro selections by writers, were even less reliable. What was needed, they decided, was a fine-grain statistical evaluation taking into account the relative importance of baskets, rebounds, turnovers and the other events tracked by the National Basketball Association.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, MAY 5, 1986
description: International

title: AFGHAN LEADER QUITS TOP POST, MOSCOW REPORTS
description: Babrak Karmal, installed as leader of Afghanistan when Soviet troops moved into the country in 1979, resigned today and was replaced by the former chief of the Afghan secret police, the Soviet press agency Tass announced.

title: Wrapped Body of Man Found At a Parking Lot in Chelsea
description: The body of a New York City man who had been shot in the head was found wrapped in a canvas drop cloth in a parking lot in the Chelsea section of Manhattan last night, the police said.

title: A Little Night Music
description: A yellow cab was the green room for a trio from the Mannes College of Music as they shuttled between two very different engagements.

title: SOVIET ECONOMIC STRAIN EXPECTED AFTER DISASTER
description: The accident at the Chernobyl nuclear power station in the Ukraine may put further strains on a Soviet economy already weakened by the collapse in world oil prices and a sharp deterioration in its trading accounts with the West, according to Government and private analysts.

title: WOODPECKER, BELIEVED EXTINCT, SEEN IN CUBA
description: American and Cuban scientists have discovered at least two ivory-billed woodpeckers in a Cuban forest in the first sighting in years of a handsome North American species that many experts had believed extinct.

title: CONCERT: MERCADANTE FLUTE WORK
description: SAVERIO MERCADANTE is not exactly unknown - he wrote some 60 Italian operas in the successive shadows of Rossini, Bellini, Donizetti and Verdi - but his music is heard infrequently enough that the inclusion of one of his youthful flute concertos lent an interest otherwise lacking to James Galway's concert with the National Arts Center Orchestra of Canada yesterday afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: TOKYO'S POLICE EMBARRASSED AS RADICALS THWART SECURITY
description: Attackers who today fired five homemade rockets aimed at Akasaka Palace minutes before President Reagan was to arrive were able to outwit the largest and most elaborate security arrangements ever assembled in Tokyo and deeply embarrass the police.

title: LATEST PERFORMANCES SPU CRENNA'S CAREER
description: Richard Crenna has been a recognizable television personality since he played the adenoidal high-school jock, Walter Denton, on ''Our Miss Brooks'' - and he hasn't stopped working in the 30 years since that show went off the air. But in the past few years, the career of the 59-year-old actor has taken what he called ''a turn for the better.'' In the past he sometimes was dismissed as a bland, stolid, cardboard hero. But his performances in recent films such as ''Body Heat,'' ''First Blood,'' ''Rambo: First Blood Part II'' and ''The Flamingo Kid'' confirmed his versatility, and last fall he won an Emmy for the ABC movie ''The Rape of Richard Beck.'' Last month, he was highly praised for his performance in a CBS courtroom drama, ''A Case of Deadly Force.''

title: THE LONG SHADOW OF THE HOLOCAUST: HOMAGE TO A HERO
description: How much longer? The question is sometimes asked when the Holocaust is commemorated, as it will be tomorrow, the annual Day of Remembrance. The world, it is often said, is quickly bored by the recital of misfortune and willingly avoids the sight of distress. But the trauma is deep and the memory of nations is long.

title: TECHNOLOGY'S FALSE STEPS: THE ATOMIC DIFFERENCE
description: Technology in 1986 seems to have suffered a devastating one-two punch. The first blow was to rocketry as a space shuttle blew up, followed by reverberating explosions of an Air Force Titan rocket and a Delta carrying a weather satellite; the second blow was to nuclear power, as a reactor failed catastrophically in the Ukraine.

title: Villanova First
description: Gerry O'Reilly won the 5,000-meter run today to lead Villanova to its fourth consecutive Big East Conference outdoor track and field championship.

title: Bette Blumberger Wed To Richard B. Saltzman
description: Bette A. Blumberger, a daughter of Helen E. Blumberger of Pittsburgh and the late Benjamin Blumberger, was married yesterday to Richard B. Saltzman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Saltzman of New York and Tamarac, Fla., at the Burden Mansion in New York by Rabbi Harlan J. Wechsler.

title: Pope Urges Dialogue With Orthodox Church
description: Pope John Paul II, noting the celebration today of Easter by Eastern Orthodox Christians, urged more dialogue between that church and Roman Catholics.

title: U.S. REPORTS 10 PERCENT DROP IN RAILROAD ACCIDENTS IN 1985
description: Railroad accidents of all types fell 10.5 percent last year from 1984, the Federal Railroad Administration has reported. But accidents at highway grade crossings, the most common kind of rail-related accident, declined just one-tenth of a percent, according to the agency.

title: Free Chamber Concert At the Lehman Center
description: The Lehman College Chamber Players, joined by the violist Eugene Becker, will give a free concert at noon today at the Lehman Center for the Performing Arts.

title: Meg Lowenthal Weds Seth Akabas, Lawyer
description: Meg Lowenthal, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mort Lowenthal of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to Seth A. Akabas, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron L. Akabas of New York. Rabbi Edward Feld performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. Sidney V. LeVine, in Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. White Sox, at Chicago, 8:05 P.M. The Yankees open a road trip of eight games in nine days (Television -SportsChannel, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8 P.M.) Reds vs.

title: How 25-Cent Fuel Tax Might Make a Difference
description: To the Editor:

title: CONSERVATIVE POLICY UNIT TAKES AIM AT NEW YORK
description: The audience will not be large, 90 people or so. The speakers will not be particularly unusual. And the topic will be a local chestnut - how to promote economic growth in the state.

title: Stier and Abramovic, Clarinet and Piano
description: It was pleasing to hear both Leonard Bernstein's Clarinet Sonata and the Brahms F minor so nicely played by Charles Stier on Saturday, but it was Charles Abramovic, Mr. Stier's co-artist at the piano in this Carnegie Recital Hall event, who truly stirred the listener's interest.

title: Bank Director Fines Voided
description: Bank regulators overstepped their authority by imposing fines on directors of a bank accused of violating banking regulations, a Federal appeals court has ruled.

title: Martha Graham Season Is Set to Open May 27
description: The Martha Graham Dance Company will begins its 60th anniversary year with a three-week season at City Center, from May 27 to June 15. Highlights of the season will include two world premieres by Miss Graham, set to music by Bela Bartok and Klaus Egge, and revivals of Miss Graham's ''Heretic'' and ''Tanagra,'' last performed in New York in the 1930's, and ''Letter to the World,'' ''Part Real Part Dream,'' ''Every Soul is a Circus,'' and ''Plain of Prayer.''

title: The Fallout's Fallout
description: European neutralists, moral equivalizers and evenhanded disarmament activists were in for a rude shock last week: in the wake of the world's worst nuclear accident, the Russians acted like the Russians.

title: THE LONG SHADOW OF THE HOLOCAUST: THE WILL TO FORGET
description: By reawakening the dark memories of the Nazi movement to destroy European Jews, the annual Day of Remembrance renews all the dilemmas of remembering and forgetting. Each year's rites of commemoration are as painful as they are poignant. It should not be surprising that there is a tendency to put those memories to rest.

title: MORE DRAMA
description: Georgetown University may or may not have hit the jackpot.

title: THE POLITICAL SUMMIT; U.S. SAID TO GET CHANCE TO AFFECT SOVIET POLICIES
description: Senior officials traveling with President Reagan said today that they thought Moscow's handling of the nuclear accident had handed the United States an opportunity to affect the policies of the Soviet Government in other areas.

title: U.N. NUCLEAR EXPERTS HEADING FOR MOSCOW
description: The Soviet Union announced today that it had invited the head of the International Atomic Energy Agency to visit Moscow to discuss the accident at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant.

title: FARMERS' ANGER STIRS UNCERTAINTY IN ELECTIONS
description: Wayne Cryts drove past the fields swelling green with winter wheat, past the church where he married his wife, past the graveyard where some of the six generations of his family in Missouri, farmers all, now rest.

title: ENVOYS ASSESS DAMAGE TO GORBACHEV POLICIES
description: With Western leaders prepared in Tokyo to make a major issue of the accident at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant, diplomats say the incident could become a serious setback for Mikhail S. Gorbachev's foreign and domestic policies.

title: ECONOMIC HOPES RISING AMID NEWARK TROUBLES
description: Two decades after urban riots destroyed entire neighborhooods here, Newark is showing the first signs of an economic revival similar to those that have already occurred in other Northeastern cities.

title: Today the Summit - Tomorrow, Business
description: One of President Reagan's major objectives at the Tokyo summit is to persuade Japan to give American exports an even break in Japanese markets. But whatever the results of the summit, Mr. Reagan's efforts won't make a significant difference unless American business pays considerably greater attention to teaching its employees how to deal with Japan's language and culture.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: /'We are outraged by the guerrilla attacks, but relieved there were no injuries.'' - Masaharu Gotoda, the Chief Cabinet Secretary in Tokyo. [ A7:3. ]

title: Israeli in Disguise Learns the Anguish of an Arab
description: In March a Jerusalem newspaper assigned a Jewish reporter to spend six weeks circulating here and in Tel Aviv disguised as an Arab.

title: Bridge: Two Couples Keep Winning At Knockout Event on L.I.
description: The Long Island Regional Knockout Team Championship ended Saturday night at Hofstra University in Hempstead in a victory for two married couples who have had a string of successes in the past year: David and Lisa Berkowitz of Secaucus, N.J., and Harold and Joyce Lilie of Manhattan. On this occasion they had recruited Larry Cohen of Little Falls, N.J., as a fifth.

title: RANGER LEFT-HANDERS STOP YANKS
description: Don Baylor, where are you when the Yankees need you?

title: U.S., Soviet in Tie
description: The 1984 Olympic gold medalist Greg Louganis won the men's 10-meter platform event today as the United States and Soviet Union tied, 44-44, in a two-day diving meet. The competition was the first such dual meet since 1979.

title: TEXAS PRIMARY SETS STAGE FOR REMATCH FOR GOVERNOR
description: The stage has been set in Texas for a replay of the gubernatorial race of four years ago.

title: A JAZZ REVIVAL ON MAJOR U.S. LABELS
description: For the first time since the late 1960's, every major American record company is actively recording jazz. Such major labels as Atlantic, RCA and MCA Records have revived their jazz programs within the last two months, joining CBS, Polygram and Capitol-EMI in the jazz field.

title: Justice Must Be Race Blind
description: When Government purges juries of black citizens, it commits an offensive constitutional crime. It denies defendants their right to a representative jury and tells blacks they're unfit to judge fellow Americans. It has long been a Federal offense to apply a racial test in summoning potential jurors, but some prosecutors found subtler ways to create all-white juries. One favored technique has been to use the allotment of peremptory challenges -which need not ordinarily be explained - to dismiss black jurors who pass every reasoned test.

title: Thrift Unit Is Closed
description: A savings and loan institution based in Lake Providence with branches in eight other Louisiana cities was closed Friday after the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said it was insolvent.

title: Waldheim Is Assailed At Warsaw Ghetto Rite
description: Jews who gathered yesterday to commemorate the Warsaw Ghetto uprising in World War II called on Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d to bar Kurt Waldheim from entering the United States.

title: 2 FRENCH LEADERS TAKE DELICATE DUET TO TOKYO
description: The odd political arm-wrestling going on between President Francois Mitterrand, France's Socialist head of state, and Prime Minister Jacques Chirac, its new conservative head of government, reached the Tokyo summit meeting this afternoon with the arrival of Mr. Mitterrand aboard a supersonic Concorde. His arrival was timed to put him here a day ahead of Mr. Chirac, who comes Monday afternoon on a scheduled Air France flight from Paris.

title: Texas Eastern Exploring
description: The Texas Eastern Corporation said today that it had suspended its domestic oil and gas explorations, for which capital spending had been averaging about $45 million a year. Capital expenditures that are related to domestic oil and gas properties will be limited to developing reserves and certain ongoing projects.

title: DELTA ROCKET EXPLOSION CLOUDING CELEBRATION OF U.S. MANNED FLIGHT
description: This weekend promised to be a bright one for Cape Canaveral and the 15,000 workers in the space program here.

title: CARDS END DODGER STREAK AT 7
description: Bob Forsch and three relief pitchers combined on a three-hitter, and Mike LaValliere and Ozzie Smith singled in runs in the third inning today to lead the St. Louis Cardinals to a 3-1 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: INSIDE STATE GUEST HOUSE, VERY LITTLE OF FLAVOR OF JAPAN
description: The seven leaders at the economic summit conference are meeting in a state guest house that stands as a monument to Japan's capacity for well-crafted imitation.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: JOHN MAYNARD KEYNES. Volume One: Hopes Betrayed 1883-1920. By Robert Skidelsky. Illustrated. 447 pages. Elisabeth Sifton/Viking. $24.95.

title: THE U.N. TODAY: May 5, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Economic and Financial Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: 20,000 Railroad Workers Picket for Second Day
description: Some 20,000 union members employed by the Santa Fe Railway today picketed a second straight day in a protest strike over the company's decision to use management personnel while testing a new type of train.

title: Aqueduct Suffers Snag in Betting
description: Aqueduct's parimutuel system malfunctioned following the running of the eighth race yesterday and, as a result, the New York Racing Association was forced to declare the ninth race a nonbetting event. It was run for purse money only.

title: EXCERPTS FROM RUSSIAN'S COMMENTS
description: Following are excerpts from comments today by Georgi A. Arbatov, head of the Soviet Union's U.S.A.-Canada Institute. He spoke in English from Moscow in reply to telephone questions from an international audience of the BBC program ''It's Your World.''

title: WALDHEIM IS GIVEN PLURALITY IN VOTE BUT FACES RUNOFF
description: Kurt Waldheim, the former Secretary General of the United Nations, fell just short of a majority in Austria's presidential election today but emerged as the strong favorite to win a runoff vote next month.

title: SCHOOLS URGE GIRLS TO USE COMPUTERS
description: Amid increasing concern that girls in elementary and secondary schools are avoiding computer training, educators in the New York metropolitan area have undertaken studies to find out why and to come up with solutions.

title: Jay Lazerowitz Is Married To Janet Lynn Rosenblum
description: Janet Lynn Rosenblum, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel M. Rosenblum of Brooklyn, was married last night to Jay Lazerowitz, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Lazerowitz of Fair Lawn, N.J., at the Kingsway Jewish Center in Brooklyn by Rabbi Simon Glustrom.

title: DANCE: CODANCECO PRESENTS 4 PIECES
description: THINGS got off to a good start Saturday night when Codanceco performed at the Dance Center of the Emanu-El Y. The well-produced progam opened with Mark Morris's quietly provocative ''Songs That Tell a Story,'' a familiar repertory piece, then moved on to an excerpt from Ralph Lemon's peculiarly titled ''Plan de Liebe'' that whetted the appetite for the dance's full premiere in the fall.

title: TV SPORTS: ON TARGET WITH FERDINAND
description: THE crucial issue in assessing ABC's telecast of the Kentucky Derby Saturday is whether viewers were so inspired that they are determined to be in Louisville next year. That is the goal Dennis Lewin, senior vice president of ABC Sports, had set for his staff - to convey ''the full flavor of Derby Day'' so well that everybody who watched from home would want to be there. Well, I'm not going to Louisville next May.But hold on before galloping off with the notion that ABC failed. Sure, in some ways the telecast was thin and watery, a low-calorie version of the real thing. Think of it as ''light'' television - with one-third less satisfaction. Too many broadcasters, for one thing.

title: 16-Year-Old Confesses To Killing His Mother
description: A 16-year-old boy walked into a Manhattan police station yesterday morning and confessed to having stabbed his mother to death two days earlier, apparently in a fight over his use of cocaine, a police spokesman said.

title: WEBB STANDS TALL, HAWKS STAY ALIVE
description: During the regular season, Spud Webb scored 23 points and had 13 assists for the Atlanta Hawks in a victory over the Los Angeles Lakers. In the first round of the playoffs, the National Basketball Association's smallest player set a franchise record with 18 assists in the second game against the Detroit Pistons and his two free throws in the second overtime of the fifth game put the Hawks into the Eastern Conference semifinal against the mighty Boston Celtics.

title: Donakowski and Borralho Win in Waterfront Race
description: The dominant forces in today's New Jersey Waterfront Marathon were Bill Donakowski among the men, Rita Borralho of Portugal among the women and a chilly, biting wind and 47-degree cold that made it feel more like March than May.

title: SOVIET OFFICIAL FACES WORLD'S QUESTIONS ON THE BBC
description: In a live shortwave broadcast today by the British Broadcasting Corporation, listeners around the world were given a chance to telephone questions to a leading official of the Soviet Government, directly and publicly. The sharper questions, mostly about the recent nuclear accident at Chernobyl in the Ukraine, seemed to stir him to anger.

title: LA JOLLA'S HABITANT
description: IT is safe to say that of all the players in the National Hockey League, Chris Chelios of the Montreal Canadiens is the only one who had his entire career turn for the better on the sandy shores of La Jolla, in the State of California.

title: Jackson Involved in Incident
description: The district attorney's office Monday will review an incident at a tavern involving the California Angels' Reggie Jackson and an autograph seeker who was treated at a hospital for bruises following a scuffle, the police said today.

title: People Express Bid Is Backed
description: The takeover of Provincetown-Boston Airlines by People Express Airlines was approved Saturday by a Federal bankruptcy judge.

title: Cornelia A. Kennedy, A Writer, Is Married
description: Cornelia Anne Kennedy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Kennedy of Fairfield, Conn., was married yesterday to Ronald Steven Suskind, a son of Shirley Berney of Hollywood, Fla., and the late Walter B. Suskind of Wilmington, Del. Rabbi Arnold Miller performed the ceremony at the Fairfield home of Mr. and Mrs. John de la Ronde Baquie, friends of the couple.

title: GOOD BOND DEMAND EXPECTED
description: Interest rates for Treasury notes and bonds have increased modestly since the Treasury announced plans to sell three new issues this week, and analysts expect that yields are now close to the levels that insure good investor demand.

title: 3 Oil Concerns Gain in Court
description: Three major oil companies - Mobil, Phillips Petroleum and Chevron - have won the right to challenge an arbitration panel's division of the proceeds of oil and natural gas from Prudhoe Bay in Alaska.

title: NORMAN POSTS A 65 AND WINS $207,000
description: Greg Norman tied a PGA Tour record by completing a tournament in 27 strokes below par to easily win America's richest golf tournament, the $1.15 million Panasonic Las Vegas Invitational, by seven shots today.

title: MINERS HALT STRIKE IN BELGIUM
description: Belgian coal miners halted a two-week-old strike against mine closures today until details of a restructuring plan for the industry are made public, a spokesman for the miners' unions announced.

title: JAPAN'S RADICALS SKILLED AT HAVOC
description: The Japanese radicals who fired a salvo of rockets toward the site of the economic summit meeting today are skilled at creating havoc with little bloodshed.

title: Washington Watch; Briefcases
description: * James C. Miller 3d, the budget director, has ''an almost impossible job,'' according to David A. Stockman. his predecessor. Mr. Stockman predicts that Congress will ''unplug'' the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings deficit-reduction law and says that even a proposed line-item veto for the President would have little effect on Federal spending.

title: Gomez, Graf Win
description: Second-seeded Andres Gomez of Ecuador defeated top-seeded Thierry Tulasne of France in straight sets today to win the United States Open clay courts men's singles title.

title: U.S. Cites a Deadline To Companies in Libya
description: United States officials stepped up the pressure today for American companies with oil interests in Libya to leave the country, saying that a deadline was approaching.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: COURTROOM GLIMPSES OF A SPY
description: Why did John A. Walker Jr., the confessed leader of a Soviet spy ring, join the Ku Klux Klan?

title: It's Time to Re-evaluate New York City School Decentralization
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Metropolitan Report on April 10 about a city program to crack down on parking violators misstated what a Federal indictment depicting corruption in the City Parking Violations Bureau said about Datacom Systems Corporation, a private collection company. The indictment charged that two former city officials, in separate incidents, paid $50,000 in bribes to help Datacom ''obtain revenues'' from the city. Datacom was not charged with any crime

title: Leader of Buyout Adds Post at Ceco
description: Erwin E. Schulze, the 60-year-old chief executive and president of Ceco Industries and the leader of a management buyout bid for the construction and building products concern, has now been named chairman as well.

title: MANY FAULT PAROLE BUT A SURVEY SHOWS FEW FAVOR ENDING IT
description: Most Americans are critical of the parole system but few believe it should be abolished, according to a study by a private research organization. And most people want criminals to serve longer prison sentences, the study found.

title: Washington Watch; Airline Slot Sales in House
description: The Congressional attack on the Transportation Department's new regulation allowing airlines to buy and sell their arrival and departure slots at four major airports in the New York, Chicago and Washington areas is expected to move to the House this week.

title: Advertising; New Yorker Raising Circulation Rate Base
description: The New Yorker, which came under new ownership a year ago, announced Friday that it is raising its circulation rate base for the first time since 1981 with the Oct. 6 issue.

title: Advertising; Frontier Air Moving Ad Account to Bloom
description: The Dallas office of the Bloom Agency has picked up the Frontier Airlines account, probably billing more than $10 million a year.

title: Rosanne Thomas, Writer, Is Married to Roy B. Cohn
description: Rosanne Daryl Thomas, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Thomas of Clifton Park, N.Y., was married yesterday to Roy B. Cohn, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Cohn of East Brunswick, N.J. Rabbi Linda Henry Goodman performed the ceremony at the Conservatory Garden in Central Park.

title: Arson Suspect Is Held In Massachusetts Fire
description: 4 in a card game was arrested Saturday and held without bail on suspicion of setting a fire that killed two players and seriously injured two others in the game, the police said.

title: 2 Sudanese Parties Agree To Share Power
description: The Umma and Democratic Unionist parties today agreed to share power in a broad-based Government and leave the militant National Islamic Front in opposition, the official Sudan press agency reported.

title: BHUTTO WARNS ZIA ON ELECTIONS
description: The opposition leader Benazir Bhutto today threatened to mobilize her supporters against the Government if the President, Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, did not set a date for elections soon.

title: TWINS' PUCKETT STARTS FAST
description: When Kirby Puckett walked to home plate at the start of Friday night's game in Detroit, the Tigers' catcher, Lance Parrish, gently put his hand on the bat of Minnesota's leadoff hitter.

title: FOR SHOEMAKER, IT'S BUSINESS, AS USUAL
description: The little man in the sunglasses nodded and smiled as a noon crowd of about 50 earlybirds gave him an impromtu ovation. Bill Shoemaker, fresh from Los Angeles International Airport, was going back to work at Hollywood Park less than 24 hours after his victory aboard Ferdinand in Saturday's Kentucky Derby.

title: J. G. McCusker, Director, Marries Gabrielle Schang
description: The Chapel of the Church Center for the United Nations was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Gabrielle Schang, a daughter of Mary Jane Schang of New York, and the late Frederick C. Schang 3d, to Joseph G. McCusker, the son of Theresa W. Moore of New York and the late Elmer H. McCusker. The Rev. Jack Haney of the United Church of Christ officiated.

title: 'I Am the Law'
description: Nick and Sam are in a violent feud. Nick goes to court to settle who is the aggressor, who the victim. After the court says it is ready to decide, Sam denounces the proceedings and walks out. He goes on shooting at Nick's house, saying he has a legal right to do so because Nick is an aggressor.

title: AMID AN ARMADA, FIRST LADY TAKES A BANGKOK BOAT RIDE
description: It looked more like an Asian armada than a riverboat cruise, what with all the frogmen on rafts and sailors on gunboats and policemen in motorboats and sharpshooters in helicopters.

title: PEERS TO PAY TRIBUTE TO ELIZABETH TAYLOR
description: Elizabeth Taylor, whom America has watched evolve on film from a precocious little girl into a sensuous and serious actress, is to be honored tonight by the Film Society of Lincoln Center.

title: THE CASE OF THE CHANGELING SPY
description: WILL anyone ever again be able to write a good old-fashioned spy thriller of a quality associated with Eric Ambler or John Buchan? The question is prompted by ''A Perfect Spy,'' John Le Carre's new novel. Here Mr. Le Carre, that master of international hugger-mugger, has, like a champion who decides there is no challenge in doing again what he has already done superlatively, gives but a passing show of spy stuff and concentrates on character, the shaping of superspy Magnus Pym, largely by his rapscallion of a father.

title: On Not Moving Forward in Southern Africa
description: To the Editor:

title: THE CHANGE OF LEADERS IN AFGHANISTAN: A BACKDROP OF STRIFE
description: Babrak Karmal came to power as Soviet troops rolled into Afghanistan in December 1979, saying they were helping the Afghan Government fight an armed insurgency. As the Soviet troops entered the country, the leader, Hafizullah Amin, was overthrown and killed; he had taken power just eight months earlier from Noor Mohammad Taraki, who was himself killed after he lost power. Mr. Taraki, in turn, had taken over in a bloody coup in 1978.

title: 600 APPLAUD RETURNING ARCTIC EXPLORERS
description: Four members of the six-person team that reached the North Pole Friday after a 56-day, 500-mile trek received a heroes' welcome here today.

title: LOCAL PRESSURE BRINGING MORE LENDING IN INNER CITIES
description: St. Louis has long been troubled by poverty and decaying housing. Yet a few weeks ago, Boatman's National Bank, Missouri's largest, signed an agreement with neighborhood groups in that city to invest $50 million a year in home loans to residents with low incomes.

title: THE ECONOMIC SUMMIT; LIVELY JOUSTS FOR POWER FLAVORED BY PERSONALITY
description: It is called a summit conference because it is a meeting of the mighty. But on economic issues, what is going on here is a jousting for power over the world economy. And because it is a human process, it sometimes turns on the chemistry of powerful personalities in conflict and on such questions as which nations to let in on which discussions.

title: BIG LANDLORD IN BOSTON GUILTY IN CONSTRUCTION BRIBERY CASE
description: Harold Brown, Boston's biggest residential landlord, pleaded guilty Friday to a charge that he paid a $1,000 bribe to a city official for a permit for a $2.5 million apartment complex.

title: South Korea Holds 146 in Inchon Riots
description: The police held and questioned 146 people in Inchon today after violent anti-Government riots.

title: Will Tokyo Bring a Dollar Deal?
description: The dollar's value abroad has fallen by a third since last fall and the Reagan Administration's economists are jubilant. But their enthusiasm for still more decline is not shared by West Europeans and Japanese, who fear their exports will become uncompetitive. The subject is sure to be discussed heatedly by the heads of government meeting in Tokyo this week.

title: Advertising; Handling Ad Clients In Mideast
description: WITH the international travel market in a spin from terrorism these days, it would seem the least-sought-after advertising clients would be those connected with the Middle East.

title: No Headline
description: The Military Lessons of Libya

title: NASA SAYS ROCKET'S FAILURE CRIPPLES LAUNCHING CAPACITY
description: The nation's ability to lift commercial, scientific and military satellites into space is crippled, at least for the near future, space agency officials said today after the third consecutive failure of a major space mission in 14 weeks.

title: BAN ON PLASTIC GUNS PROPOSED BY LAWMAKERS
description: Gun-control advocates and some members of Congress are trying to ban weapons that do not yet exist: all-plastic guns that could pass unnoticed through airport security devices.

title: MAVERICKS CORRAL LAKERS BY 120-118
description: The Dallas Mavericks evened their Western Conference semifinal playoff series against the Los Angeles Lakers today with a 120-118 victory.

title: Article 427886 -- No Title
description: The Treasury's record $27 billion package of note and bond auctions will dominate this week's credit market activity, overshadowing a substantial amount of tax-exempt financing and a flurry of speculative-grade corporate bond issues.

title: METS ROMP TO END TRIP AT 9-1 AS STRAWBERRY SLAMS A PAIR
description: The Mets have gone beyond amazing. Now, they are concerned with looking good while winning.

title: What a Mystery
description: A small political tremor was detected in the House of Representatives last week, and uncertain Hill seismologists are still trying to read its significance.

title: FOR THE CLASS OF '86, RELIEF AND ANXIETY
description: ''The symptoms of senioritis are both physical and intellectual,'' said Jean Kwok, an 18-year-old senior at Hunter College High School in Manhattan. ''Physically - well, you experience a certain sluggishness, often alternating with spontaneous bursts of joy at your own lack of responsibility. Intellectually - oh, how to describe it? It's as if your brain degenerates to an undifferentiated mass of tissue.''

title: Soviet Says U.S. Seeks To Manipulate Session
description: The Soviet Union today called the summit meeting of the world's seven leading industrialized democracies an attempt by the United States to further its ''aggressive'' world policies and said the meeting showed deep differences dividing the nations.

title: Amelia R. Wood Weds D. F. Silver
description: Amelia Russell Wood, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Percy Hoxie Wood Jr. of San Cristobal de Las Casas, Mexico, formerly of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday to David Franklin Silver, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Alan Silver of Upper Montclair, N.J. The ceremony was performed by Algernon D. Black, leader emeritus of the Society for Ethical Culture, at the Manhattan apartment of Richard Scott Essex, a friend of the couple.

title: 2 Held in Hong Kong Fraud
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has arrested two men in a $66.8 million scheme that it said led to the collapse last year of the Overseas Trust Bank Ltd. in Hong Kong.

title: A DOSE OF RADIOACTIVITY TAKEN QUIETLY BY FINNS
description: When the radioactive cloud from the Soviet Union's crippled nuclear reactor swept across Scandinavia last week, the criticism from most governments in the region was sharp and swift. Denmark called Moscow's delay in admitting the accident ''totally unacceptable,'' and Sweden warned that Moscow's failure to disclose details of the accident could set back future relations between the two countries.

title: CONFERENCE CELEBRATES CITY'S UNSUNG FOLK ARTISTS
description: For an academic conference, the presentations were unorthodox: slides of Italian-American lawn shrines, the patter of a New York City tour guide and a performance by a group of rap artists.

title: Washington Watch; Oil-Auto Fight On Gas Vapors
description: IN a lobbying battle of corporate titans, the oil and automobile industries are now toe to toe as they await the Environmental Protection Agency's decision on how to reduce vapor emissions at the gasoline pump. Each seeks to have the other one solve the problem.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

title: ODETS'S 'ROCKET TO THE MOON' ON 13
description: CLIFFORD ODETS (1906-63) is recognized by many critics as the playwright most identified with the 1930's. Certainly, he vividly captured some of the period's social ferment in ''Waiting for Lefty'' and ''Awake and Sing.'' But much of the rest of his work, drifting into a kind of proletarian romanticism, is more problematic. There is, for instance, ''Rocket to the Moon,'' considered a failure even when it opened in 1938. Now, with press releases insisting that the play has been ''misunderstood and neglected for years,'' public television's ''American Playhouse'' is reviving the work, tonight at 9, in an exceptionally skillful production featuring several fine performances. In the end, though, the play itself is less memorable for its insights than for its curious innocence.

title: Christine Diwyk, Piano, At Carnegie Recital Hall
description: The pianist Christine Diwyk's most impressive quality is a lovely, singing legato continuity - a quality utilized all too rarely on Saturday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: Market Place; Putting a Price On Time Cable
description: TIME INC.'s recent announcement that it plans to offer 20 percent of its cable subsidiary, American Television and Communications Inc., to the public has touched off a wave of speculation about the price tag the venture will carry and the impact the offer will have on the stock of Time itself.

title: Assuring More Blossoms
description: Following the close of Washington's cherry blossom season, the National Park Service has begun an appeal for private contributions to replenish the grove of some 3,000 Japanese trees around the Tidal Basin near the Jefferson Memorial. A donation of $150 will provide a tree 5 to 6 feet high, pay for its planting, put the donor's name in an official tree directory and produce a Federal tax deduction.

title: OUTDOORS: SHAD ON THE RUN
description: ANNUAL spring runs of American shad are once again luring anglers to the Northeast's major spawning rivers for the species, the Delaware, Hudson and Connecticut.

title: Anna Rubin in Program Of Avant-Garde Works
description: Anna Rubin's Saturday night concert at Roulette was a study in contrasts - between sound and vision; between the fluid lyricism of an oboe and the stark stabs of percussion instrument; between organized electronic noise and spontaneous improvisation, and even between a single instrument and three pre-recorded ''ghosts.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, MAY 5, 1986
description: International

title: GILBERT NEARS TOP ON TENNIS LADDER
description: EVER since 1968, when professional tennis emerged from the days of whirlwind one-night stands and nickle-and-dime prize money to become a glamorous and lucrative sport, a succession of Americans such as Stan Smith, Arthur Ashe, Jimmy Connors and John McEnroe have been at or near the top of the rankings. That may explain the line of questioning Brad Gilbert has encountered in his travels this year. More than just another good player on the tour, American fans are looking for an heir to the tennis fortune, someone who can capture their imaginations and move up to No. 1 as Boris Becker of West Germany promises to do.

title: GOALIES FEEL PRESSURE; RANGERS ARE QUIETED
description: IN the playoffs, the big scorers may be glorified, and every goal can be a game-winner, but the closer the competitors get to a Stanley Cup, the more those gunners start to blur together, and it is the goaltender who, in his solitary confinement between two metal posts draped in netting, becomes most indispensable to a team's success.

title: As Turkey Sows, So Shall It Reap
description: To the Editor:

title: 28,000 'DOCTORS' ARE FEARED UNFIT
description: Across the United States, as many as 28,000 people may be practicing medicine and treating tens of thousands of patients each year, even though they do not hold physician's licenses and in many cases have little or no medical training, state licensing officials report.

title: FLAMES ROUT BLUES TO TIE SERIES 1-1
description: Doug Risebrough struck for three goals and an assist tonight to power the Calgary Flames to an 8-2 romp over the St. Louis Blues, evening the Stanley Cup semifinal series at one victory apiece.

title: Michael Levitin Is Married To Meredith Wise Mendes
description: Meredith Wise Mendes, a daughter of Peggy D. Mendes of Hartsdale, N.Y., and Alvin P. Mendes of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Michael Levitin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin H. Levitin of Michigan City, Ind. Rabbi Maurice Davis performed the ceremony at the Sunningdale Country Club in Scarsdale.

title: BOMB ON SRI LANKA JET WAS IN CARGO
description: A bomb that blew apart an Air Lanka jet at the international airport here Saturday went off in a cargo hold and may have been planted in a consignment of vegetables, the head of the airline said today.

title: TAX REVISION: AN ISSUE WITH 9 LIVES
description: Tax-revision legislation seems like one of those trick birthday candles that cannot be blown out.

title: SIN ISSUES SOON FACE JUDGMENT
description: Not since 1880 when the Kansas Idea, a harbinger of Prohibition, became enshrined in the state's Constitution have ''sin'' issues cast a longer shadow on this state's ballot than they will this year.

title: Tradition at Risk
description: The College World Series, which has served as the Division I baseball championship since 1950, has always been a, well, collegial experience. In part that's because the eight-team, double-elimination format tends to keep most of the teams in town for much of the 10-day event, and in part it's because the town is Omaha, a folksy heartland city with a 15,000-seat stadium that has opened its heart to the annual influx of baseball folk and helped keep alive sleepy traditions and relaxed fellowship.

title: TEXAN SEES HIS TRUCK STOP BLOSSOM INTO A TOWNSHIP
description: Carl Cornelius decided a decade ago he wanted to build a town.

title: Suffolk Officer Held In Vehicular Assault
description: A Suffolk County police officer was charged yesterday with driving while intoxicated and vehicular assault in a Saturday night accident in which the officer, who was off duty, hit and critically injured a young woman, authorities said.

title: KOCH TO MAKE PUBLIC HIS $21.5 BILLION HOLD-THE-LINE BUDGET PLAN
description: Mayor Koch is to make public today his budget proposal for the coming fiscal year, a $21.5 billion plan that counts on increased taxes and includes few new programs or improvements in services.

title: 2 Military Copters Collide in Taiwan
description: Two military helicopters collided in midair during a drill and crashed into a rice paddy, killing 22 soldiers and injuring two others, a newspaper reported today.

title: The Heliophile in the Barrel Was Diogenes
description: To the Editor:

title: Balloon Race Ends Without Clear Winner
description: The annual Gordon Bennett Balloon Race ended without a clear winner early today, and race officials said they were trying to determine who traveled farthest, a Japanese team or a United States and Swiss entry.

title: I.M.F. Cuts Loan Rates
description: The International Monetary Fund said Friday that the interest rate on some of its loans had been cut from 7.87 percent, to 7 percent, retroactive to Nov. 1.

title: KIDDER'S ROAD TO ACQUISITION
description: On Jan. 23, Ralph D. DeNunzio was presiding over the regular biweekly meeting of the management committee of Kidder, Peabody & Company when his secretary broke in to deliver a note. Mr. DeNunzio, Kidder's rotund, 55-year-old chief executive, had just received word that Morgan Stanley & Company, for five decades the model of an elite private Wall Street investment bank, had decided to sell shares to the public.

title: Eve Tyroler Is Married
description: Eve Tyroler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles M. Tyroler of Lawrence, L.I., was married yesterday to Robert Lewis Wachtel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Wachtel of Jersey City. Rabbi Gilbert Rosenthal officiated at Temple Israel in Lawrence. The bride, a speech pathologist at the Kessler Institute in West Orange, N.J., is a great-granddaughter of the late Israel Miller, founder of the I. Miller & Sons shoe store chain. Mr. Wachtel is manager of the Johnston & Murphy shoe store in Short Hills, N.J.

title: DANCE: NETHERLANDS JUNIOR COMPANY
description: THE Netherlands Dance Theater, with Jiri Kylian as chief choreographer and artistic director, has paid several visits to New York. Now an apprentice troupe, the Netherlands Dance Theater Junior Company, is on tour in the United States for the first time.

title: BOSS TWEED'S COURTHOUSE: AN ELEGANT MONUMENT TO CORRUPTION
description: Boss Tweed's courthouse has revealed its secrets slowly.

title: RECITAL: CLAUDIO ARRAU
description: EDUCATION is less a process of accumulation than a discarding of what we don't need. Thus the happiest moments of Claudio Arrau's piano recital at the 92d Street Y on Saturday were its simplest ones. This all-Beethoven evening, in other words, was most important for what it did not do.

title: INDIANS WIN, 6-4, TO MOVE INTO FIRST
description: Brook Jacoby doubled home a run in the top of the 10th inning to help the Cleveland Indians beat the Chicago White Sox, 6-4, today and move into first place in the American League East.

title: Religion and the 4th Estate
description: It did not surprise his fellow Columbia Journalism School alumni when John P. Foley spoke of the journalist's need for ''sensitivity to the reality of the spiritual and religious dimension of human life'' at Friday's alumni awards ceremony.

title: Applying the Pressure
description: To convey American disapproval of another country's leadership, it is not necessary to sever diplomatic relations or drop bombs on military installations. The State Department has considerably less drastic methods for discouraging countries like Nicaragua, where the United States still has an embassy but also helps finance insurgents trying to overthrow the Government.

title: Amie Karp Is a Bride
description: The wedding of Amie Yael Karp, a daughter of Lieut. Col. Daniel J. Karp, U.S.A, retired, and Mrs. Karp of Livingston, N.J., to Crist Edward Inman, a son of Titika Inman of Greenwich, Conn., and the late E. Ray Inman, took place yesterday at Stronghold Mansion in Bernardsville, N.J. Rabbi Alfred B. Landsberg officiated. Mrs. Inman, a graduate of New York University, is an editorial assistant for Silhouette Books in New York. Her husband, a graduate of Principia College, is a sales representative for Prudential Services in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: A FORESTER'S TOUGH REGIMEN
description: The language of Ray Smith, president and chief executive of Canada's biggest lumber company, is often as tough as the rocky coastal terrain where his company, MacMillan Bloedel Ltd., usually cuts most of its timber.

title: COUMO AND O'ROURKE STAR AS VAUDEVILLIANS
description: Andrew P. O'Rourke's performance began inauspiciously, with a headlong tumble up the steps to the stage at the Convention Center, the scene of last night's Legislative Correspondents Association show.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: HIGH-TECH ENTERTAINMENT The video artist is being celebrated today at Performance Space 122 (477-5288), 150 First Avenue, at Ninth Street, as part of the Veselka Performance Festival, which runs through May 11. Called ''Video Bonanza!,'' today's event is a joint effort of Electronic Arts Intermix - a video-art distribution and postproduction studio - and P.S. 122. Recent works from Electronic Arts Intermix's editing studio will be shown.

title: College Player Belts 4 Homers
description: Doug Blasse, Virginia Tech's left fielder, slammed four home runs, broke five school hitting records and tied three National Collegiate Athletic Association marks today as the Hokies trounced Howard, 30-0.

title: Patti Rose Bride Of Mark Mandel
description: Patti Renee Rose and Mark Steven Mandel were married yesterday at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I., by Rabbi Amos Miller.

title: A FAVOR CAN CARRY A PRICE
description: IT can all start with the fatal question, ''Could you do this one favor for me?'' With that, and whatever response it engenders, begins the interpersonal maneuvering, the power plays, the jockeying over who owes what to whom.

title: ECONOMIC ISSUES SPUR STATES TO ACT ON SCHOOLS
description: In 1980, at the Republican National Convention, Gov. Lamar Alexander of Tennessee recalls going to a cocktail party in suburban Detroit where all the talk was of Michigan's ailing economy.

title: Washington Watch; Halliburton's Libyan Taxes
description: The Internal Revenue Service charges that the Halliburton Company improperly deducted on its 1979 tax return $5.7 million in taxes the oil-service company paid to Libya. The allegation is part of an I.R.S. notice that the company owes more than $32 million in back taxes for 1977 to 1979.

title: THE POLITICS OF LOCAL SCHOOL BOARDS
description: In a room on the first floor of Public School 64 in the South Bronx, four women sat last week stuffing envelopes with campaign fliers for a local school board member.

title: Polynice to Stay At Virginia
description: Two days after announcing he would leave the University of Virginia to play professional basketball, Olden Polynice said Saturday night he had changed his mind and would remain in school.

title: Henry Clay Is Rated Greatest U.S. Senator
description: Henry Clay of Kentucky, known as the ''Great Compromiser'' for his mediation between the North and the South before the Civil War, has been ranked as the nation's greatest Senator in a national poll of college professors.

title: PLAYED STAGE AND FILM ROLES
description: Robert Alda, the actor who created the role of the suave gambler Sky Masterson in the Broadway musical ''Guys and Dolls'' and who portrayed George Gershwin in the film ''Rhapsody in Blue,'' died Saturday night at his home in Los Angeles as a result of a stroke he suffered two years ago. He was 72 years old.

title: Arms and the Woman
description: For years it seemed that just about every women's group interested in military issues was in favor of disarmament. But now a new women's organization is taking a different path.

title: U.S.-BRAZIL COMPUTER DISPUTE BREWS
description: Over the past three years, the Reagan Administration has tried gentle persuasion, public criticism, threats of retaliation and finally private negotiations, but all to no avail.

title: 2D REACTOR WORRIES U.S. AIDES
description: United States officials said today that they were concerned that cooling problems at a second nuclear reactor at the Chernobyl complex in the Ukraine could result in a further release of radioactivity into the atmosphere.

title: Lutheran Activist Barred As Church Reopens
description: A Lutheran church locked up 16 months ago because of dissension over the dismissal of its activist pastor reopened today but a sheriff's deputy barred the pastor, D. Douglas Roth, and 50 supporters from entering.

title: S.E.C. SETS ACTION ON FILING PLAN
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission plans to begin on Tuesday the long-awaited process of selecting a contractor to operate the agency's electronic filing and retrieval system.

title: Dr. Susan Ascher Wed
description: Dr. Susan M. Ascher and Dr. Paul E. Kalb were married yesterday at the Harmonie Club in New York by Rabbi Robert Widom. Dr. Ascher, who will retain her name professionally, is an intern at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. She is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Floyd Ascher of Franklin Square, L.I. Dr. Kalb, a resident in internal medicine at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, is the son of Carol Cohen of Roslyn, L.I., and the late Dr. Seymour Kalb.

title: Jeweler Found Shot to Death In His Diamond District Office
description: A 68-year-old jeweler was found shot to death in his office yesterday in the diamond district here, the police said.

title: Ten Houses Damaged By Blaze on Fire Island
description: A fire of undetermined origin caused major damage to five beach houses and less serious damage to five others in the affluent Fire Island resort community of Fire Island Pines yesterday evening. No injuries were reported.

title: TINSLEY LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 23
Clone War Escalates
description: FOR years the Tandy Corporation of Texas held fast to the Lone Star philosophy of independence, making computers that ran only Tandy software and little else. If a customer bought a Tandy/Radio Shack computer, he or she was locked into buying from Radio Shack stores. Even after International Business Machines entered the market and established the closest thing to a universal standard, Tandy seemed to ignore it.

title: Breeder Offering Stock and Warrant
description: International Thoroughbred Breeders Inc., a horse breeder and operator of racing tracks, has amended its registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission to publicly offer stock and stock purchase warrants, through underwriters led by First Jersey Securities.

title: HEMOTEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
For Want of an Initial
description: The subject matter was serious -Mayor Koch's budget proposal for the coming fiscal year - but in the midst of all the sober talk about financial projections, taxes and Federal aid yesterday was a curious sidelight. What ever happened to the Budget Director's ''L''?

title: WALKER'S CREDIBILITY QUESTIONED AT SPY TRIAL
description: Defense attorneys in the espionage trial of Jerry A. Whitworth focused today on the credibility of his chief accuser, John A. Walker Jr. In the first full day of cross-examining him, the defense lawyers brought out discrepancies between Mr. Walker's testimony last week and what he told investigators for the Federal Bureau of Investigation when they interviewed him in July 1985, after his arrest.

title: QUAKE IN SOUTHEAST TURKEY LEAVES 15 DEAD AND 100 HURT
description: An earthquake caused widespread damage in southeastern Turkey today, and the Government radio said 15 people were killed and 100 were injured.

title: PLANTS 'VACCINATED' AGAINST VIRUS
description: A TEAM of genetic engineers has reported the first success in giving plants hereditary resistance to a viral infection. The achievement, almost the equivalent of vaccinating a plant species permanently against a virus, has long been a goal in agricultural genetic engineering.

title: A New York Budget to Build On
description: Two shorthand terms tell New York City's new budget story: Gramm-Rudman and 250,000 units. The first, referring to harsh cuts in Federal urban spending, means New York must make up hundreds of millions in lost aid.
