Mayor Koch's new operating budget for 1987 manages to do that while calling only for select tax increases. The second bit of shorthand stands for something that could be vastly more important if carried to fruition: a quarter of a million new homes by 1997.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Paris dispatch on May 1 about the political atmosphere in France after the American bombing of Libya incorrectly characterized a remark by Vernon A. Walters, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, on France's refusal to let American planes enter French airspace. The passage, which said Mr. Walters had ''derided France on television for 'ingratitude,' '' was based on an erroneous paraphrase of remarks he made on the ABC News program ''Nightline.'' In the interview, Mr. Walters offered no such criticism of France.

title: THE LUGGAGE OF YESTERDAY
description: When fashionable women like Rita Acosta Lydig traveled in the early days of this century, they might have carried 20 or more trunks for their clothes, hats and shoes. Dozens of such trunks are among the 200 objects currently on view in ''Bon Voyage! Designs for Travel,'' an exhibition at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum that traces the history of travel accessories from the 14th century to the present.

title: Our Biggest Little Russian Bookshop
description: At a huge book-filled warehouse in Rockville, a Maryland suburb of the nation's capital, Dr. Zhivago and Scarlett O'Hara speak the same language: Russian.

title: CITY'S SCHOOL ELECTIONS: HOW THE BOARDS WORK
description: New York City voters and parents of children in the public school system will go to the polls today to choose the members of the city's 32 school boards. At stake are 288 seats. Registered voters and parents who are not registered voters are eligible to vote. Registered voters should go to their regular polling places. Parents who are not registered and who do not know where to vote should call the City Board of Elections at (212) 924-1860. The polling places will be open from 6 A.M. to 9 P.M.

title: UNITED FEDERAL BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $433,000.

title: Judge Mary Kohler Dies at 82
description: Judge Mary Conway Kohler, a lifelong advocate of child welfare, died of cancer Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 82 years old.

title: Market Place; Near-Term Favorites
description: IN light of the recent weakness in stock prices, many investors are wondering how professional money managers regard near-term prospects for the market. Henry M. Greenleaf and Scott M. Black, two New England-based managers with good track records, share some similar views.

title: LIBYA RAID REFUELS DEBATE ON CARRIERS' ROLE
description: The United States raid against Libya has reinvigorated the debate over the role and cost of aircraft carriers.

title: MACHINE VISION INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
INTERPROVINCIAL STEEL & PIPE LINE LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
City Seeks the Cause Of Revenue Shortfall
description: City officials, troubled by the failure of tax revenue to increase as much as expected, speculated yesterday that there might be problems with the state's computer system or the way the state distributes tax collections to localities.

title: KOCH BUDGET: ELECTION YEAR'S 'ROSY GLOW' FADES
description: It was just a year ago that Mayor Koch, readying his re-election campaign, proposed a city budget that was full of optimism and the cheery rhetoric to go with it.

title: Soviets Report Success in Space
description: Two Soviet astronauts, Leonid D. Kizim and Vladimir A. Solovyov, left the orbiting Mir space station today in a Soyuz spacecraft and headed for its sister-station Salyut-7, the official news agency Tass said.

title: HARCOURT BRACE JOVANOVICH INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ARMATRON INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NATIONAL STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Du Pont Fills Top Posts
description: The E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company said yesterday that Richard E. Heckert, deputy chairman, had become chairman and chief executive. Mr. Heckert, 62 years old, was elected deputy chairman last August and designated at that time to succeed Edward G. Jefferson, 64, who is retiring. Mr. Heckert joined Du Pont in 1949 as a research chemist at the experimental station near Wilmington, Del. He spent his early years with the company managing research programs involving cellophane and Mylar polyester film. He was mananger of the Circleville, Ohio, plant and held manager positions with the fabrics and finishes, film and plastics departments. Mr. Heckert has been a director and member of the executive committee since 1973.

title: PUSH IS SEEN FOR DEAVER INQUIRY
description: The General Accounting Office staff members studying the lobbying activities of Michael K. Deaver have recommended that the matter be referred to the Justice Department for investigation of possible illegalities, according to two officials at the agency.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LATINO PLAYWRIGHTS The staged readings in Spanish and English produced by Latino Playwrights Inc. have generated a number of winners - both playwrights and plays. The playwrights include Jose Rivera, who writes for Norman Lear's television company; Miguel Pinero, a Pulitzer Prize winner who now writes for ''Miami Vice''; Ruben Gonzalez, a writer with ''The Bill Cosby Show''; Anita Velez, a writer with educational television, and Rainaldo Povod, whose ''Cuba and His Teddy Bear'' starring Robert De Niro, is at the Public Theater.

title: SONESTA INTERNATIONAL HOTELS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Ford, Chrysler Trucks
description: The Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation, while pledging to hold the line on car prices, have raised prices on most of their small trucks without making a public announcement, the companies have confirmed. Ford's price increases, effective April 21, ranged from 1.7 percent to 2.9 percent, John Sieg, a company spokesman, said. Chrysler's increases, effective April 29, averaged 2.3 percent, according to Douglas Nicoll, a Chrysler spokesman.

title: Utilities Should Pay for Message Inserts in Bills
description: To the Editor:

title: ALPHA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Javelin Beginner Learns Quickly
description: Athletics is merely a pleasurable diversion for most of the 1,300 male students at Rose-Hulman Institute. Academic achievement is the main order of business.

title: SYM-TEK SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FINAL TEST INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Employees Assured In Big 3-Way Merger
description: Keith Reinhard, chief executive of Needham Harper Worldwide, one of the participants in adland's first three-way mega-merger, distributed a three-page memo to his people Friday. It was intended to assure the nervous ones among them that, outside of the people who had to be let go because of the loss of the big Xerox account, every effort would be made to fit the rest into the new troika organization.

title: ROCKAWAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NEW TRANSIT COURT AIMING TO COLLECT
description: Richie Pietrowski, 18 years old, uneasily looked at Louis Fribourg and explained that he had been ''short of money'' and ''figured the only way to get on the train was to sneak on.''

title: DANCE: BALLET THEATER OPENS WITH PREMIERES
description: WHEN you have six entries on a ballet program and four are excerpts or pas de deux, you know it must be gala highlight time.

title: White House Drops Proposal On Control of National Guard
description: The Reagan Administration has dropped its plan to propose a law limiting state governors' control over their National Guard units, a top official said today.

title: U.S. Steel to Refinance $2.9 Billion of Debt
description: The United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest steelmaker, said yesterday that it would begin a ''major financial restructuring'' this year that would include a refinancing of about $2.9 billion of debt that it incurred when it acquired the Marathon Oil Company in 1982.

title: NO BAIL FOR MAN SUSPECTED OF SLAYING A JOURNALIST
description: A man extradited from Brazil last week to face charges of killing a Chinese-American journalist in California was denied bail yesterday.

title: 'Operational Move' To the Suburbs
description: Five years ago, there were verbal fireworks when the State Power Authority proposed moving some of its headquarters staff members out of New York City. The authority said that rents were too high and that it was having trouble attracting people to work in the city.

title: STEIGER TRACTOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Watch Washington Budge
description: Finally, a sensible Federal budget has started moving through Congress, propelled by a strong, bipartisan majority of the Senate. Even now, President Reagan continues to bluster, insisting that the new Senate budget resolution involves too little for defense and too much for non-defense programs and taxes. But he has surely noticed that a majority even of Republican Senators favored this plan over the one he submitted in February.

title: TEXACO IN A NEW LEGAL RIFT
description: The J. Paul Getty Museum has accused Texaco Inc. of breaking an agreement to protect the museum from legal claims arising out of Texaco's disputed acquisition of the Getty Oil Company, museum representatives said yesterday.

title: FPL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Waste Is Disclosed in Travel By Foreign Service Members
description: Many Foreign Service officers and their dependents have taken Government-paid luxury cruises home or to new assignments that cost far more than regular air fare, Congressional investigators said today.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: LAST week's early New York fashion collections for fall, mostly shown by younger and less-well-established designers, confirm trends seen in Europe earlier this spring: Hourglass and circle-shaped long skirts, column dresses, peplum jackets, oversized overcoats, extra-wide pants, softer shoulders, a continuing reliance on all-black outfits, longer hair or falls for women, body-skimming instead of body-hugging shapes and boldly zippered everythings.

title: DANGERS OF A BALDNESS 'CURE'
description: THE latest discovery in the seemingly never-ending search for a cure for baldness, a drug called minoxidil, can have dangerous side effects, according to a physician at Vanderbilt University Medical Center who has tested it. Although otherwise healthy patients may be able to use it safely, the physician, Dr. Mark C. Houston, said five deaths have been associated with applications of the drug to the scalp to treat baldness.

title: POWERFUL SOURCE OF GRAVITY DETECTED DEEP IN THE UNIVERSE
description: FAR beyond the Milky Way, astronomers have detected an invisible but incredibly powerful source of gravity that appears to defy conventional explanation.

title: The Real Sickness in Kabul
description: Though he may fare better than his executed predecessors, Babrak Karmal has quit, for reasons of health, as leader of the Soviet-imposed regime of Afghanistan. In a change that on its face promises only more bloodshed, he has been replaced by Najibullah, the former director of the Afghan secret police.

title: HOUSEHOLD INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $4 million.

title: HALLIBURTON CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FIRST BOSTON IS SETTLING INSIDER CASE FOR $390,000
description: The First Boston Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to settle an insider trading case brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission against the Wall Street firm. As part of the settlement, First Boston will give the S.E.C. around $390,000 in returned profits and penalties.

title: PACIFIC TIN CONSOLIDATED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Peabody Awards Announced
description: ''An Early Frost,'' an NBC television movie about a victim of AIDS, and Johnny Carson, host of the ''Tonight'' show, were among the 27 winners of the 1985 George Foster Peabody Awards announced today.

title: EXCERPTS FROM JUSTICES' OPINIONS ON JURY MAKEUP IN DEATH PENALTY CASES
description: Following are excerpts from opinions by the Supreme Court today in the case of Lockhart v. McCree. Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist wrote the majority opinion. Associate Justice Thurgood Marshall wrote the dissent.

title: INTER-CITY GAS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Preferred dividend requirements for the latest quarter were $3,235,000, compared to $1,678,000 for the year- earlier period.

title: C O M B CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MODULAR COMPUTER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
UNITED NEW MEXICO FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $186,000.

title: Ex-Cell-O Deal
description: The Cadillac Gage subsidiary of the Ex-Cell-O Corporation has received $15.2 million in contracts from the Army's Tank-Automotive Command for armored vehicles to be delivered to Africa, Ex-Cell-O said. The Commando V-150 armored wheeled vehicles will be built at the Cadillac Gage plant in Greenville, Ohio, assembled in Cocoa, Fla., and delivered through 1987, according to Ex-Cell-O. The contract prohibits the compnay from disclosing the names of the African countries that will receive the vehicles, Keith Langham, an Ex-Cell-O spokesman, said.

title: HOUSE PASSES BILL TO RESTRICT SPREAD OF CAPITAL MEMORIALS
description: Heeding warnings that the nation's capital is being overrun by monuments, the House voted today to restrict the spread of memorials in the city.

title: STATEMENT IN TOKYO ON NUCLEAR DISASTER DENOUNCED BY TASS
description: The Soviet press agency Tass denounced the statement on nuclear accidents adopted at the Tokyo summit meeting today, calling it a ''document clearly devised to intensify anti-Soviet speculation, accusations and lies.''

title: TOKYO SUBWAY TRAFFIC DISRUPTED BY A SERIES OF SMALL EXPLOSIONS
description: Small explosions went off in several subway stations across the city this morning at the height of rush hour as Tokyo residents returned to work after a long holiday weekend.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The message is: 'You've had it, pal. You are isolated. You are recognized as a terrorist.'

title: AID CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $6,226 for the latest quarter and $87,939 for the earlier period.

title: ALABAMA FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, MAY 6, 1986
description: International

title: Israel Studies Bank Scandal
description: The Cabinet in Jerusalem announced today that a committee of ministers ''will address itself'' to the report of a commission that inquired into a 1983 bank shares scandal.

title: LEMIEUX'S OVERTIME GOAL PUTS RANGERS IN 3-0 HOLE
description: Willie Huber wound up for a shot. The puck skipped over his stick. James Patrick, skating backward, fell over, of all people, one of the officials.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: 21-BILLION BUDGET PROPOSED BY KOCH REQUIRES TAX RISES
description: Mayor Koch yesterday proposed a $21.5 billion spending plan for the next fiscal year that would require $160 million in added tax revenue to maintain and slightly improve essential services.

title: SOUTHMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an income tax benefit of $7.1 million due to a reduction in projected reportable income tax liability for the full fiscal year. Share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid in September, 1985, and a 15 percent stock dividend to be paid May 7, 1986.

title: ALO-SCHERER HEALTHCARE YEAR reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Includes income from a minority interest in a subsidiary of $157,291 for the latest year, $123,385 for the earlier year.

title: STANHOME INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HAMMOND CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: 'IN THE REVIVAL TENT'
description: ''IN THE REVIVAL TENT,'' the gospel segment of the Arts & Entertainment Network music series ''New Orleans Now,'' will be shown tonight at 11 and again at 3 A.M. Wednesday on the cable channel.

title: Diplomatic Scrutiny
description: To the Editor:

title: Hold That Divorce
description: The Older Women's League, a Washington-based group, is suggesting to its members who are contemplating divorce that they wait until July 1 to untie the knot. The reason is an obscure section of the 1986 Budget Reconciliation Act that guarantees that women who divorce or are widowed or whose husband retires after that date can adopt and continue the husband's group health insurance.

title: 7 SUMMIT LEADERS CONDEMN TERROR, CITING LIBYAN ROLE
description: The leaders of the seven largest industrial democracies adopted a joint statement today that condemns terrorism as an international scourge that ''must be fought relentlessly and without compromise.''

title: GV MEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-The company sold its first Lastec medical system in March 1986, and therefore had no revenue prior to the latest first quarter.

title: STATE SENATE REJECTS MEASURE TO PERMIT CAMERAS IN COURT
description: By one vote, the Senate defeated legislation tonight that would have opened the state's trial courts to cameras for the first time in half a century.

title: OLD REPUBLIC INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes capital gains of $5,576,141 for the latest quarter and $712,316 for the year-ago period.

title: Congress; A Reincarnation of the Trade Issue
description: The legislative spotlight swings back and forth on Capitol Hill, illuminating different issues at different times in the Congressional session. Sometimes the focus is dictated by outside events, such as an outbreak of terrorism; other matters, like the budget, are regulated by the rhythms of the calendar.

title: INTERNATIONAL CONTAINER SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $148,000 for the quarter and $330,000 for the year. c-After tax credits of $103,000 for the quarter and $156,000 for the year.

ADVANCED COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income includes a tax credit of $13,000.

EASED STANDARDS FOR OIL STIR EXPERTS' CONCERN
description: Banking and regulatory experts are voicing growing concern over new policies and proposed actions by Federal agencies to grant energy companies and their banks lenient accounting and regulatory treatment in dealing with large losses from falling energy prices.

title: ZIMMER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BOSTON EDISON CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
VORTEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Chess: Tie-Break Points Establish Prizes at Lugano Tourney
description: The XIth Lugano International Open Tournament in Switzerland was won by Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland on tie-break points after he, Lev Gutman of Israel and James Plaskett and Nigel Short, both of Britain, had each scored 7 1/2-1 1/2.

title: TEKNOWLEDGE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $174,000 for quarter and $474,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss

title: Horford Debut Set
description: Tito Horford, the 7-foot-1-inch center, will be eligible to play for the University of Miami at the end of the first semester next December, the National Collegiate Athletic Association Eligibility Committee ruled yesterday. Horford, who spent time at Houston and Louisiana State last season before finally settling at Miami, will miss from four to six games because of an unintentional rules violation stemming from his assocation with an amateur team in his native Dominican Republic.

title: CANYON STATE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
VIATECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

title: When the Economic Valium Wears Off

title: A Passport to Humanity For Nation's Children
description: A WALK through the streets around Times Square reveals the shame of New York: little children who grow up in welfare hotels, their playground the city's physical and moral filth. They are destined for life in the underclass of welfare, drugs and crime. The society that now averts its eyes will later see them as a permanent burden and threat. These children are victims of a callousness unequaled in any other Western democracy.

title: RANGERS, CROWD QUIETED BY ROY
description: His name was chanted sarcastically several times, especially after each goal he allowed in regulation. But the only thing Patrick Roy allowed the Rangers and their fans in the overtime last night at Madison Square Garden was a grudging admiration.

title: CONCERT: JUILLIARD
description: ONE of the happy puzzles of the chamber music world is how the Juilliard String Quartet - now approaching its 40th year - manages to change and yet remain pretty much the same. The newest transformation is taking place in the Juilliard's second violin chair. Earl Carlyss is leaving after 20 years and is soon to be replaced by Joel Smirnoff.

title: John Russell Honored
description: The French Government has named John Russell, the chief art critic of The New York Times, a Chevalier of the Legion of Honor. He received the decoration from the French Ambassador, Emmanuel de Margerie, in a private ceremony yesterday in New York City. Mr. Russell joined The Times in 1974, was named chief art critic in 1982 and is the author of many books, including ''Paris,'' ''Max Ernst.''

title: AHMANSON KEEPS IT SIMPLE
description: '' case of champagne arrived at H. F. Ahmanson & Company a couple of weeks ago, a token of congratulations from a rival as Ahmanson recovered its title of biggest savings and loan company in the country.

title: Sri Lanka Lowers Toll In Jet Bombing to 15
description: The Government today lowered to 15 the death toll in the bomb of an Air Lanka jet Saturday.

title: More on Scuffle
description: Donald Weimer, a 26-year-old unemployed office worker from Racine, Wis., told the Milwaukee County District Attorney at an informal hearing yesterday that he had been choked until he fainted by Reggie Jackson of the California Angels during a scuffle in a downtown tavern on Saturday. District Attorney Michael McCann, who is reviewing the incident, said Jackson is not obligated to give a personal statement.

title: BACK FROM POLE, EXPLORER DESCRIBES GRUELING TREK
description: After Will Steger enjoyed his first hot shower, change of clothes and proper meal in nearly two months, he thought about what he and five comrades had just accomplished: the first confirmed trek by dogsled without resupply to the North Pole.

title: POACHERS AND PROTECTORS WAGE WAR OVER RHINOS
description: THE black rhinoceros, already an endangered species, is under attack by heavily armed poachers in one of its last sanctuaries. Officials in Zimbabwe say they have shot and killed nine illegal hunters there since June.

description: b-Net loss Figures are in U.S. funds.

title: Hellfire and Politics
description: Two preachers were holding forth at the Washington Convention Center Friday night: the Rev. Billy Graham, in the midst of an eight-day evangelical crusade, and the Rev. Jesse Jackson, addressing 1,000 activists from the left wing of the Democratic Party. They were preaching in separate halls, but one could stand in the lobby and catch echoes of both. Some Democratic activists arriving for the political gathering made a wrong turn and were a bit confused before they realized their mistake. Mr. Graham was President Nixon's favorite preacher.

title: Pumping Politics
description: Congress may be in better shape than you thought. A seven-member team that included three members of Congress and was headed by Jack Russ, the House Sergeant-at-Arms, finished second among 38 teams in the National Fit-ness Classic in Houston last weekend.

description: The Reagan Administration has decided that by June 30 it will end the special exemptions allowing American oil companies to continue operating in Libya, senior State Department officials said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a dispatch from Papua New Guinea on April 26 about American relations with Southeast Asia referred incorrectly to Abdul Kadir Sheik Fadzir, Malaysia's Deputy Foreign Minister. He is known as Mr. Abdul Kadir, not Sheik Abdul.

title: TEST FOR NAKASONE
description: Whatever its long-range economic and diplomatic impact, the Tokyo summit conference has caused immediate political troubles for Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone.

Grace & Company, the chemical and natural resource company based in New York. Terms of the sale, which requires the approval of both companies' boards, were not disclosed.

title: TONY NOMINATIONS ARE ANNOUNCED
description: The top nominations for this year's Tony Awards, which were announced yesterday, went to ''The Mystery of Edwin Drood,'' the leading musical with 11 nominations, and ''The House of Blue Leaves,'' which led among straight plays with eight.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Houston Astros, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. The Mets open their seven-game home stand against Houston with Dwight Gooden (4-0) facing Bob Knepper (5-0).

title: WOODBRIDGE BINGHAM
description: Woodbridge Bingham, a scholar of East Asian history, died Friday at his home in Berkeley, Calif.

title: THEATER: 'JOE TURNER' AT YALE REP
description: In ''Joe Turner's Come and Gone,'' the new play at the Yale Repertory Theater, the writer August Wilson takes us into a bustling Pittsburgh boarding house. The year is 1911, and the characters are antecedents of the black Americans of Mr. Wilson's dramas of the 1920's (''Ma Rainey's Black Bottom'') and 1950's (''Fences''). The boarding house at first seems a warming place, permeated by the fragrance of fresh-baked biscuits and the feisty gab of men and women searching for their place in a new promised land. That mood is abruptly smashed, however, when a man knocks at the door.

title: U.S. SAYS BULGARIA HELPS FIGHT DRUGS
description: The United States Ambassador here says Bulgaria has adopted a more cooperative attitude to American requests for help in the hunt for international narcotics dealers and couriers.

title: Hull Son Signs
description: Brett Hull, son of the hockey great Bobby Hull, was signed yesterday by the Calgary Flames.

title: Frank A. Daniels Sr., 81, Dies; Head of Raleigh Newspapers
description: Frank Arthur Daniels Sr., chairman of the board of the company that publishes Raleigh's two daily newspapers, died of congestive heart failure today. He was 81 years old. Mr. Daniels began working for the concern, The News and Observer Publishing Company, in the pressroom after graduating from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill in 1927.

title: Late-April Car Sales Fell 5.9%
description: Sales of new American-made automobiles slipped 5.9 percent in the last 10 days of April from the comparable period last year, while light-truck sales rose 9.2 percent, the seven major manufacturers reported today.

''Old Wine, New Science,'' on Channel 13 at 8:30 tonight, tells us how.

The United States, Pakistan and the Afghan resistance should test the Russians' sincerity and, if they are serious, help them to leave.

Last Friday, five Czechoslovaks were ordered to leave Sweden for running what the Swedish Foreign Ministry called ''a Czechoslovak intelligence-gathering operation.''

Chrysler's No. 2 executive, Gerald Greenwald, said at a news conference that the auto maker wanted to retire the loan as quickly as possible because the interest rate was higher than rates Chrysler could now obtain commercially.

title: GROUP HONORS CHILDREN'S TV
description: Action for Children's Television, a Boston-based nonprofit group, today will bestow its 14th annual awards on locally and nationally televised programs for young people in the area of public and commercial broadcasting, cable and home video.

title: OGLEBAY NORTON CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

description: Bones found in a wooded area were identified today as the remains of the 35th confirmed victim of a killer who dumped his first victims in the Green River.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Bristol-Myers Co. announced that Robert J. Helbling had been appointed president of Surgitek/Medical Engineering Corp., Racine, Wis., effective May 15.

title: TREASURY BONDS RISE SHARPLY
description: Treasury bond prices rose sharply late yesterday, as traders reacted to news that the economic summit conference in Tokyo has resulted in an agreement that would promote stability in foreign exchange markets. Rumors that participants had made progress on lowering interest rates also spurred the bond market.

title: Kemp Settlement
description: In a negotiated settlement signed by lawyers from both sides and approved by Federal District Judge Horace Ward in Atlanta, Jan Kemp received $1.08 million on her claim that she was dismissed by the University of Georgia for protesting special treatment of athletes in the remedial Developmental Studies program. Under the agreement, Mrs. Kemp will rejoin the Georgia faculty on July 1 as coordinator of the English section of the remedial program. A Federal jury had awarded Mrs. Kemp $2.58 million, but Judge Ward reduced the award to $680,000. Mrs. Kemp could have forced a new trial on punitive damages by refusing the reduced amount, but the negotiated settlement ended that possibility.

description: International

title: ALTOBELLI MANAGES A YANKEE VICTORY
description: Joe Altobelli has, after all, more managing experience than Lou Piniella, so maybe the Yankees' dugout coach could teach the rookie a move or two - such asgiving the home-run sign at critical moments.

ON EAST SIDE, CUOMO TACKLES QUESTIONS ON FOREIGN POLICY
description: Governor Cuomo last night opposed the sale of Stinger antiaircraft missiles to Saudi Arabia, scoffed at the effectiveness of the United Nations and supported the use of force in combating world terrorism.

title: PEOPLE
description: * John J. Fisher has been named executive vice president at BBDO/ HMC.

title: Forcing New Zealand to Choose
description: If New Zealand outlaws visits by nuclear armed or powered ships, there would be three good reasons for dissolving its alliance with the United States. The reasons are Japan, West Germany and Britain, whose leaders also face enormous pressure to ban America's nuclear weapons.

title: Landscape Must Replace Construction as Top Parks Priority
description: To the Editor:

title: BACKMAN SIDELINED FOR A FEW GAMES
description: Wally Backman used only one word - ''awesome'' - to describe what the 16-4 Mets have accomplished as they prepare to face the Houston Astros, the club with the major leagues' second-best record, tonight at Shea Stadium.

title: Commercial Paper Due In Australian Dollars
description: The growing market in the United States for debt securities denominated in foreign currencies passed another milestone yesterday when the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company announced plans to begin selling commercial paper denominated in Australian dollars.

title: CONDOR EXPERTS IN POLICY DISPUTE
description: A dwindling flock of California condors, one of the most spectacular and most endangered birds in America, forage here on the Hudson Ranch.

title: Suggestions for Next Census
description: The Census Bureau could save time and effort by using the telephone to count the American people, instead of mailing out forms or visiting homes, according to a statistical expert.

title: LOS ANGELES LIBRARY FIRE IS TERMED ARSON
description: A fire that destroyed or damaged up to 800,000 books in the historic Central Library was set, the authorities said today as they announced a $5,000 reward for information leading to a conviction in the arson case.

title: SOVIET FALLOUT SPREADS; SCANDINAVIA GETS MORE
description: Fallout from the Soviet reactor plant accident increased sharply over Scandinavia today, and there were signs it was spreading farther through Western Europe.

title: EFFORT STARTS ON RAISING BARGE
description: Workers began efforts today to raise a barge containing 840,000 gallons of fuel oil that sank in New York water off the East End of Long Island last November.

title: Worshiping At Art's Altar
description: THE tulip trees have spilled their pink and white blossoms, and there is little in the shrubbery and the emerald lawns to excite passers-by. But neither the plantings, handsome as they are, nor the imposing neo-classic Fifth Avenue mansion are what the crowds come to see. The Frick Collection is great paintings in magnificent interiors, and it was jammed.

Muammar el-Qaddafi with sophisticated radar equipment, officials in Tripoli, the Libyan capital, were quoted here as saying.

title: Caretaker Slain in Church
description: The 48-year-old caretaker of the Mount Sinai Church of God in Christ at 927 Herkimer Street in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn was found shot to death yesterday in the church, the police said. The caretaker, Ernest Meadows, was discoverd shortly after noon in his ransacked apartment in the church in what the police said was an apparent push-in burglary. He had been shot in the head.

title: Lincoln Kirstein Wins Brandeis Award for '86

Previous winners include Balanchine, John Cage, Buckminster Fuller and William Shawn.

title: Royce Stanley Pitkin, Goddard College Head
description: Royce Stanley Pitkin, who founded Goddard College in Plainfield and then saw his educational innovations and progressive philosophy spread across the nation, died Saturday at the Medical Center Hospital in Burlington. He was 85 years old.

Combined, the thrift units, which are owned privately through the First Texas Financial Corporation, earned $61.8 million last year, on assets of $8.3 billion - $3.2 billion at First Texas and $5.1 billion at Gibraltar.

title: CURREN FEELING MORE AT HOME IN CITY
description: There was only a mild reaction from the small crowd watching at the stadium court, Kevin Curren said, testimony that people tend to forget quickly. But he probably felt a measure of relief anyway. Curren did not want the positive events of 1985 to be overshadowed by a flippant remark made in defeat that put him on bad terms with New York tennis fans at the United States Open last summer. Ironically, the remark might have been dismissed were it not for the new-found status he achieved earlier that year.

description: The Zenith Electronics Corporation said that it had developed a high-resolution flat picture tube that does not distort images or reflect background light.

description: As colleges around the country debate whether to sell their stock in companies doing business in South Africa, college fund-raisers are warning that shunned corporations could take their philanthropy elsewhere.

title: Halliburton Shows Loss
description: The Halliburton Company said that its first-quarter earnings dropped by 80 percent, to $11.2 million, or 11 cents a share, from $56.4 million, or 52 cents a share, in the first quarter of 1985. The oil-field services, engineering and construction company said that abnormally high taxes in its overseas operations and falling prices in the oil and gas industry accounted for the profit decline. Sales in the quarter fell 17 percent, to $1 billion, from $1.2 billion.

The mood was unusually subdued throughout most of the sale at which 11 of the 57 artworks offered did not find buyers.

description: The Soviet party newspaper Pravda today published the first detailed account of the accident at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant in the Ukraine. It said an explosion on the night of April 25 touched off a raging blaze that eventually reached inside the reactor and released radioactivity.

title: S.A.T.'s Being Offered Again After Blank Pages Are Found

description: Often an event captures headlines, then fades from view with important questions unanswered - questions that defy news reporting, at least for a while. This column periodically reviews the status of such questions.

title: GHOST HAUNTS HAITI: SPECTER OF DUVALIER'S RETURN

description: THERE has been some debate over the need for color monitors in personal computing.

description: Last Thusday, thousands of workers, leftists and Communists paraded down the streets of Paris on May Day to commemorate the struggle of the working class to secure a better life.

description: The staff of the Securities and Exchange Commission will meet with representatives of options exchanges Tuesday to discuss the ''triple witching hour,'' the Friday every three months when stock options, stock index options and futures on index options come due, an S.E.C. official said today.

title: Whither Vanity?
description: Members of the Capitol security force are quietly suggesting to members of Congress that they give up those distinctive automobile license plates most states thoughtfully pass out to their Congressional delegations. A Representative from California, for example, can have a plate that says MEMBER OF CONGRESS 10, the numeral being the district number.

title: June Election to Fill Post of Rep. Addabbo
description: A special election will be held June 10 to select a successor to Representative Joseph Addabbo in the Sixth Congressional District in southeastern Queens, Governor Cuomo said yesterday.

title: Advertising; 48th Yearly Premium Show
description: RELEASED from the confines of the New York Coliseum, the annual Premium and Incentive Show exploded into the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center yesterday. And there it will stay until Thursday, by which time some 35,000 buyers from around the nation will have had an opportunity to find just the right product or products to hit the hot button of their particular set of covetous consumers.

title: Splendid For Starters
description: It's one thing for President Reagan to load up the Federal judiciary with conservatives. It's quite another for him to nominate unqualified men (he almost never chooses women) or rigid ideologues. In Daniel A. Manion, of Indiana, who fits both descriptions, the Senate Judiciary Committee has a good chance to stand up for a more responsible approach to these nominations.

title: SHIP DRAGS DEAD 'SEA ANIMAL'
description: The Nordic Prince, a gleaming white cruise ship out of Miami, made her way up the Hudson River yesterday afternoon and slipped into Pier 88 at 48th Street to begin preparations for her maiden voyage of the spring season.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, MAY 7, 1986
description: International Top democracies voiced satisfaction over their economic and political agreements at their 12th annual meeting. The Tokyo conference of leaders of the seven major industrial nations of the non-Communist world ended with a lavish formal banquet where they met Crown Prince Akihito. [ Page A1, Column 6. ]

Claytor, chairman and chief executive of Norfolk Southern, had agreed to consider the request.

title: LIBYA CALLS FOR ARAB 'HOLY WAR'
description: Libya called today for a ''holy war'' against ''the conspiratorial measures of the Tokyo summit conference.''

description: President Reagan said today that the bombing raid last month against Libya was not intended to kill Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, but that ''I don't think any of us would have shed tears if that had happened.''

title: A GLOSSARY: SURVEILLANCE AND CONVERGENCE A LA GROUP OF 7
description: The discussions and communique of the summit leaders have included a number of specialized economic and monetary terms. These are explanations of some of those terms:

title: In Father's Footsteps
description: Barry Bonds, the son of the former major league outfielder Bobby Bonds, drove in seven runs for Hawaii on Monday with a grand slam and two singles in a Pacific Coast League game at Calgary, Alberta, that Hawaii won, 18-8. Bonds, 21 years old, was drafted in the first round last June by the Pittsburgh Pirates and hit .299 with 13 homers in 71 games with Prince William of the Class A Carolina League. In three seasons at Arizona State University, the 6-foot-1-inch, 185-pound outfielder hit .347 with 45 home runs, 175 runs batted in and 57 stolen bases.

title: Phone Number
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

Holzman Enters Hall of Fame
description: Red Holzman, Tom Heinsohn and Billy Cunningham were among a group of six enshrined today in the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame.

title: Jet Offer to Brooks
description: The Winnipeg Jets, who have been without a regular coach since they dismissed Barry Long three months ago, have offered the job to Herb Brooks, who coached the Rangers for three and a half seasons before being dismissed in January 1985. John Ferguson, the Jets' general manager and interim coach after Long's departure, interviewed Brooks on Monday and said: ''I think it's going to work out.

title: Advertising; Doyle Dane Net Up
description: The Doyle Dane Bernbach Group also released its first-quarter financial statement. It showed that revenues were up 7 percent, to $54.8 million, from $51.2 million, while net income rose 42 percent, to $1.6 million, from $1.1 million, or 28 cents a share, compared with 21 cents.

title: CRISIS OF CONFIDENCE
description: The United States and the Soviet Union are now at another critical point in their long struggle to control the nuclear arms race, and it's being complicated by the issue of terror in Libya and the nuclear reactor explosion in the Ukraine.

title: TURNING BLACKTOP TO GREENERY
description: Sitting on a stoop in Chinatown, Yick-Man Tse watched with satsfaction yesterday as large chunks of Park Street were bulldozed into a pile.

title: Timely Help for Women in Court
description: Responding to a study that identified ''pervasive'' sex discrimination in New York's courts, Chief Judge Sol Wachtler, the state's top jurist, outlines a comprehensive effort at reform. His determination to keep pressuring the legal community may be as important as the more substantive reforms.

title: CELTICS FINISH HAWKS
description: Boston Celtics history is punctuated with superlatives, but their third-quarter performance at Boston Garden tonight may have topped them all.

title: Advertising; JWT Group Chairman Has Wonderful News
description: The JWT Group, parent of J. Walter Thompson, did a strange and wonderful thing at its annual meeting yesterday. It made news, most of which was reported by Don Johnston, chairman and chief executive.

title: Haight No. 1 Pick In U.S.F.L. Draft
description: Mike Haight, the Iowa offensive tackle who had been the Jets' first-round choice in last week's National Football League draft, was the first player selected yesterday in the United States Football League's open draft.

title: HUNTING CITY BARGAINS FOR THE FRENCH CONSULATE
description: UNLIKE other residents of the Upper East Side of Manhattan, the wife of the French Consul General will not be found shopping in her neighborhood's food markets. Much as Monique Gadaud would like to patronize the Rosedale Fish Market and Lobel Brothers' meat market, E.A.T. or even the Oriental fruit and vegetable markets that dot each block, she says she cannot afford them. Not when she has to entertain at hundreds of lunches, teas, receptions and black-tie dinners promoting France, French commerce and French culture. In January and February alone, 74 people came to lunch, 40 people to dinner and 459 for cocktails.

title: TERRORISM VS. TOURISM
description: Nicholas Athans, as his name suggests, has an affinity for Greece. Indeed, as owner and president of Tourlite, a New York tour operator, Mr. Athans usually sends as many as 50,000 passengers to Italy and Greece for their summer vacation. This month, however, he is hoping to persuade people to visit Rio. Or Venezuela. Or maybe Jamaica.

title: SWIFT ENERGY CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
THEATER: 'CAVE PAINTINGS'
description: ON various experimental stages, audiences have been transported back to the past and forward in space, but ''Living Cave Paintings'' may set a record for theatrical time travel. As an expedition to the world of Cro-Magnon man, this animated environment at the Ohio Theater tries to depict everyday cave man life on this planet some 30,000 years ago.

title: U.S. and Soviet Aides Have Sharp Exchange
description: In an unusually sharp exchange, the chief American and Soviet negotiators arriving for the Geneva arms talks on defense and space traded criticisms today over the American bombing raid against Libya last month.

title: COLUMBIA GAS SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax charge of $38.8 million. c-Net loss includes an after-tax non- recurring charge of $207 million.

title: CASEY SAID TO CONSIDER PROSECUTING PUBLICATIONS
description: The Director of Central Intelligence, William J. Casey, met last week with a senior Justice Department official to discuss the possibility of prosecuting news organizations for their use of classified information, Federal sources said today.

title: EXECUTIONS: PACE TO RISE
description: Hundreds of death row inmates were moved a step closer to the execution chamber by the Supreme Court's decision Monday upholding the exclusion of committed opponents of the death penalty from juries in capital cases. But the immediate increase will probably not be dramatic.

title: Real Estate; Abrams's New Office Downtown
description: SIX months after a conflict-of-interest issue killed a deal that would have moved the New York State Attorney General's office from the World Trade Center to the former A.T.&T. building on lower Broadway, the agency has signed a lease that will put it in another landmark nearby, at 120 Broadway.

title: Syrian Leader Ends 24-Hour Visit to Jordan
description: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria ended a 24-hour visit to Jordan today after talks with King Hussein aimed at improving relations between the two sometimes hostile neighbors.

title: A NEW FACE FOR SHULTZ: TOUGH AND HARD-HITTING
description: There was an outcry this morning when the White House spokesman, Larry Speakes, said there was no need for Secretary of State George P. Shultz to hold another news conference, since the business of the final full day of the summit meeting was actually economics.

title: OIL WORKERS FIND HARD TIMES CAN HIT THEM, TOO
description: They made jokes here in the early 1980's about the plight of the North as blue-collar workers from the Middle West brought their families on Joad-like journeys to Texas, seeking work and new lives. ''Freeze a Yankee - Drive 75,'' the bumper stickers used to read.

title: EX-OHIO GOVERNOR WINS REPUBLICAN PRIMARY FOR 5TH TERM IN OFFICE
description: Former Gov. James A. Rhodes has won the Republican nomination for an unprecedented fifth term as Governor, despite an unexpectedly strong challenge by a state senator in the three-way race.

title: Market Place; Edelman Vs. Fruehauf
description: DAYS before the shareholders of the Fruehauf Corporation were scheduled to vote last week on whether to oust the company's board of directors, as the New York investor Asher Edelman had suggested, the nation's largest truck maker entertained a suggestion from Merrill Lynch & Company that it consider a leveraged buyout.

title: Tandon Announces Deal With Xerox
description: The Tandon Corporation, furthering its entry into the microcomputer market, today announced a multimillion-dollar contract with the Xerox Corporation to manufacture a line of work station products to be sold under the Xerox name.

title: Cohenour and Mahoney Given Derwent Awards
description: The 42d annual Clarence Derwent Awards to the ''most promising female and male actors on the metropolitan scene'' have gone to Patti Cohenour, who plays Rosa Bud in ''The Mystery of Edwin Drood,'' by Rupert Holmes, now at the Imperial theater; and John Mahoney, who plays Artie Shaughnessy in ''The House of Blue Leaves,'' by John Guare, now at the Vivian Beaumont Theater.

title: TELECALC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: SCOTT'S LIQUID GOLD INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: SHARI HARTFORD of Manhattan is in perfect harmony with the audiences that filled the Great Hall of the Moscow Conservatory to cheer and bravo and weep joyfully when Vladimir Horowitz recently returned to perform in Russia. Miss Hartford hears the pianist play quite frequently - well, miniperformances, perhaps, of a half-dozen or so notes, not on a Steinway and none of them actually audible.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, MAY 7, 1986
description: The Economic Summit

title: FIRST OKLAHOMA BANCORPORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a provision of $37.7 million for loan and lease losses. c-Net income

description: b-Includes a tax loss carryforward of $275,000 and a non-recurring charge of $185,000 representing the incurred and projected carrying costs of two restaurants closed in the quarter for which disposition is being negotiated. c-Includes a tax credit of $221,000.

title: TEMCO HOME HEALTH CARE PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in December 1985.

title: Grove Press's Founder Sues Its New Owners
description: Barney Rosset, the founder of Grove Press, has filed a lawsuit against Ann Getty and George WeidMr. Rosset was ousted last month as president and chief executive officer of Grove.

title: A MISUNDERSTOOD STAPLE
description: QUESTION: What is high in carbohydrates and low in fat, high in vitamins A and C, potassium and other minerals, including some calcium, and low in calories, a good source of fiber, delicious whether baked or boiled, a staple for millions and misunderstood as ''too fattening'' by millions more? Answer: The lowly potato. The potato's reputation as a fattening food comes from the way it is prepared: fried in deep fat, dressed with sour cream, crumbled bacon, mayon-naise or butter. Or worse, some fast-food chains are now promoting the potato as the all-purpose, single-course meal with globs of chili, cheese or other gooey fillings. It need not be that way.

title: ICH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After capital gains of $4,130,000 for the latest first quarter and $3,028,000 for the year-earlier first quarter. The share earnings reflect a 3-for-1 stock split to be paid May 19.

title: New Airport Rocketed North of Beirut
description: A newly built airport in the Christian part of Lebanon came under rocket bombardment today only hours after President Amin Gemayel took off from there in his executive jet for Tunisia.

title: TOYS PLUS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
LABRIOLA WINS 4 VOTES OF CONNECTICUT'S G.O.P.
description: Former State Senator Gerald Labriola tonight won four of six local primary elections in the Hartford area that Republican leaders had hoped would establish a clear front-runner for the party's nomination for Governor.

title: California Issue To Build Prison
description: The California Public Works Board is offering $160.6 million of lease revenue bonds for the Department of Corrections with a maximum yield tentatively set at 7.50 percent for bonds due in 2005 through underwriters led by L.F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin.

title: 7 NATIONS' LEADERS PRAISE GAINS MADE AT ECONOMIC TALKS
description: Leaders of the major industrial democracies, ending their 12th annual gathering Tuesday night, expressed satisfaction that they had confronted terrorism while taking important economic steps toward new trade talks and a revamping of the world monetary system.

title: INDEPENDENT INSURANCE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After investment gains of $4,618,000 for the latest first quarter and $33,000 for the year-ago first period.

title: Bridge; Failure of a Penalty Double Surprises a Famous Player
description: Penalty doubles often appear to be guaranteed, gilt-edged, rock-solid, sound as Fort Knox or the Bank of England. But appearances may deceive.

title: TOP DEMOCRATS TO SHUN FRIEDMAN DINNER TODAY
description: Most of the top Democratic public and party officials in the state and city are boycotting the annual dinner of the Bronx Democratic organization tonight because of the indictments of Stanley M. Friedman, the Bronx party chairman.

title: Tenant Kills Landlord Saying She Thought He Was a Thief
description: A woman who shot and killed her landlord today saying that she had mistaken him for a burglar has been charged with aggravated manslaughter, the police said.

title: HESSTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Los Angeles Unit Sets Water Bonds
description: The Los Angeles Department of Water and Power, known as Dewaps among municipal bond traders, is offering $66.6 million of waterworks revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 7 3/8 percent for issues due in 2022 and 2024 through Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.

title: DOYLE DANE BERNBACH GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PERIL OF DELAY IN EVACUATING SOVIET TOWNS IS SAID TO BE DIFFICULT TO ASSESS
description: The implications of the Soviet Union's disclosure yesterday of a 36-hour delay in evacuating towns downwind of the Chernobyl reactor, presumably exposing the populations to radioactive fallout, are difficult to estimate without more detailed information.

title: Israel Plans to Request 2,000 War Crime Files
description: Israel will probably ask for the files of 2,000 suspected war criminals from the archives of the United Nations War Crimes Commission by the end of the week, a member of the Israeli delegation here said today.

title: NORTH AMERICAN BIOLOGICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $65,000 for the latest quarter and $7,000 for the year-ago period.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: EACH year nearly 40 million Americans - one in six -are hospitalized, but few do anything in advance to prepare themselves. As a result, most trips to the hospital are marked by fear, intimidation and psychological distress, which can intensify the usual physical discomfort.

title: SUAVE SHOE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Dietary Indiscretions
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Loading the Argument for Death
description: What more could be said against the death penalty than the Supreme Court has just said in upholding it? According to a 6 to 3 majority, it is perfectly constitutional in capital cases to decide guilt or innocence with juries that are more likely to convict than acquit. The Court once demanded special safeguards for the accused in cases involving capital punishment. Now it rigs matters against them. A system that must rely on biased juries hardly needs opponents to condemn it.

title: SPERRY STOCK RISES ABOVE BID PRICE
description: Wall Street arbitragers bought the stock of the Sperry Corporation heavily yesterday, pushing its price above the $70-a-share offer of the Burroughs Corporation. Rising $6.125 a share, Sperry's stock closed at $71.25.

title: JAPANESE POLICE TIGHTEN SECURITY
description: The police tightened security still further today after explosives went off early this morning in nearly 20 subway stations around the city on the concluding day of the Tokyo summit meeting.

title: ENTERTAINMENT PUBLICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ENTEX ENERGY DEVELOPMENT LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a writedown of $6.3 million on oil and gas properties. c-Net income

title: Tough Remedy For Ring Injuries
description: Boxing has been taking it on the chin from the medical profession for years now, starting well before the American Medical Association's House of Delegates formally adopted a proposal in December 1984 favoring an outright ban. But nobody had ever heard anything quite like an idea advanced recently in Orlando, Fla., by two influential physicians attending the spring meeting of the American Academy of Pediatrics.

title: CUE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 5
WIESEL, AT CAPITOL CEREMONY, LINKS TERRORISM TO HOLOCAUST
description: Speaking today at a ceremony at the Capitol Rotunda to memorialize those killed in the Nazi Holocaust, the author Elie Wiesel suggested that acts of terrorism at the present time ''may well be a consequence of what happened then.''

title: FOR NURSING HOME RESIDENTS, BIT OF HAUTE CUISINE
description: WHEN Gerard Potel began looking for work in this country early last year, he began by placing an ad in The Jewish Press that read, ''French chef with kosher experience.'' Ceil Weisbauer, director of dietary services at Beth Abraham Hospital, a nursing home in the Bronx, hired him a few weeks later.

title: SCI SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Ice Too Crowded
description: Gaining entrance to the Stanley Cup playoffs has long been roughly on a par with winning a free dance lesson from Arthur Murray, but the N.H.L., which awards postseason slots to 16 of its 21 teams, outdid itself this season. The Toronto Maple Leafs' winning percentage of .356 made them the second-worst team ever to qualify for the playoffs (after the old New York Americans, who got there in 1940 despite a .354 average), and the Vancouver Canucks and the Winnipeg Jets, who both finished at .369, were fifth- and sixth-worst in history. Yes, of the half-dozen most feeble squads since Stanley Cup play began in 1893, fully half made the scene this year.

title: Needham Is Making Return to Wall St.
description: James J. Needham, the former head of the New York Stock Exchange, has come back to Wall Street.

title: Drive Starts for Referendum Over Homeless-Family Care
description: A group formed to help the homeless in New York City announced a drive yesterday for a voter referendum that would require the city to shelter all homeless families and ban group shelters for families.

title: HYDE ATHLETIC INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: AUCTION: DAVID SMITH SCULPTURE SETS RECORD
description: David Smith's 1963 welded-steel work ''Voltri-Bolton XXIII,'' suggesting a person half seated, sold last night for the highest price paid at auction for a contemporary sculpture.

title: Welcome to Voucher Land
description: Nine Soviet military officials spent a costly week here last November. Courtesy of the Federal Government, their expenses at the Watergate Hotel were more than $15,000, including $500 on their last day to buy tobacco and liquor to take back home.

title: CHARGES REVIEWED IN EDWARDS TRIAL
description: Gov. Edwin W. Edwards ''sold out'' the people of Louisiana for $1.9 million he received in a scheme to take over the state's program to certify hospitals, a Federal prosecutor charged here today in final arguments in Federal District Court.

title: U.S. ENDS CRIMINAL INQUIRY INTO FERRARO CAMPAIGN
description: The Justice Department said today that it had ended a criminal investigation of Geraldine A. Ferraro's finances without seeking an indictment, but had forwarded the case to department lawyers for possible civil litigation.

title: A Benefit of Garbage
description: Mierle Laderman Ukeles is an artist in residence for City Sanitation Department who has worked with garbage trucks, sweepers and scows.

title: MOSELEY HOLDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After non-recurring losses of $12,024,000, representing final liquidation of inventories and other costs associated with certain ceased U.S. government securities trading activities. c-Net loss. d-Includes a reconciliation provision of $10,505,000 related to an out-of- balance condition discovered in the accounting records of the company's U.S. government securities operations. The company said that effective May 1, it changed its name from Moseley, Hallgarten, Estabrook & Weeden Holding Corp. to Moseley Holding Corp., and that of its domestic broker-dealer subsidiary to Moseley Securities Corp. from Moseley, Hallgarten, Estabrook & Weeden Inc.

title: Congress; Power: More Than Just a Pretty Face
description: Anarchy reigns in Congress, according to the conventional wisdom, in part because the television networks are all too eager to provide a soapbox for any junior member with a message.

description: b-After capital gains of $103,000 for the latest quarter and $122,000 for the year-earlier period.

PRIMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The share earnings reflects 2-for-1 stock split paid Nov. 15, 1985.

title: Doctor Is Held in Sex Abuse Of a Hospital Surgery Patient
description: A 44-year-old surgical resident at the Cabrini Medical Center was charged yesterday with sexual abuse of a patient who was recovering from gall bladder surgery, the police reported.

title: POTPOURRI FOR MOTHER
Berra Honored by Mets
description: Yogi Berra, now a coach of the Houston Astros, was honored before last night's game as part of the Mets' celebration of their 25th anniversary season.

title: Datapoint Buyout
description: The Datapoint Corporation said that the leveraged buyout proposed by its chairman, Asher B. Edelman, and other members of its board and management had been terminated by mutual agreement. Mr. Edelman said that financing for the transaction had been raised but that ''recent improvements in Datapoint's results and prospects have caused me to conclude the proposal should be terminated.''

title: New Chief Is Picked By Graphic Scanning
description: The Graphic Scanning Corporation said yesterday that Stephen M. Greenberg had been elected chairman and chief executive, replacing Barry Yampol, who resigned as part of an agreement with dissident shareholdrs.

title: KILEY AND GUNN SEEN AS SLOWING TRANSIT DECLINE
description: New York City's transit leadership has slowed declines in subway and bus service, but has brought few improvements since taking over two years ago, according to a study released yesterday by Governor Cuomo.

title: PHONE ORDERS BEGIN AS JULY 4 TICKET SALES LAG
description: Mail order ticket sales for paid events during the July 4 weekend celebrations have been lower than expected, promoters said yesterday. The remaining tickets will now be available by telephone.

title: COPLEY PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Comparable figures are not available as the company began operations last July.

title: RANGERS ON BRINK AFTER TIGHT CALLS
description: There is an unwritten rule in hockey - some people in the sport call it the ''Hudson Bay Rule'' - that officials do not call penalties in tight situations in the last 10 minutes of a playoff game unless an infraction is flagrant.

title: MODERN CONTROLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
JAPANESE RADICAL GROUPS RESURFACE AFTER A LULL IN ATTACKS
description: After a long period of relative quiet, Japan's left-wing extremist groups have shown increased willingness to resort to violent, disruptive tactics in recent years.

title: CLINTON'S SATIRE HAS A BITE
description: THE cover of George Clinton's latest album, ''R&B Skeletons in the Closet'' (Capitol), provides a checklist, ''for record company and concerned parent use only.'' It warns that the album may contain material that depicts ''voodoo cultism,'' ''Bambezi fertility rites,'' ''welfare fraud'' and ''suspicious & unknown social impact.''

title: OPTICAL SPECIALTIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: b-Net income.

title: SOUTHERN INDIANA GENERAL & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Here's Looking at You
description: Man, it should be remembered, had been taking pictures of the earth from far above for at least 100 years before the U-2 spy plane ventured over the Soviet Union in 1960. The new ''Looking at Earth'' Gallery opening in the National Air and Space Museum tonight includes pictures of Paris and Boston taken in the 1860's from the baskets of bal-loons, and it ranges from there into the space age.

title: LASER PRECISION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

description: b-Includes a gain of $45 million on the sale of a portion of a Dutch paper company. Preferred dividend requirements totaled $8 million for the latest quarter, compared to $6.3 million for the year-ago period.

title: A RANGER CAPTAIN
description: Bill Cook, who played for the Rangers for 12 years and led them to Stanley Cup championships in 1928 and 1933, died of cancer Monday in Kingston, Ontario. He was 89 years old.

title: MEDCO CONTAINMENT SERVCES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago results reflect the acquisition March 6, 1986 of New Paid Inc. from Porex Technologies Corp., Medco's parent and certain institutional investors.

description: The company is listed on the Philadelphia Stock Exchange.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Houston Astros, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. Sid Fernandez is scheduled to pitch for the Mets in the second game of the series.

title: ROBB RECOMMENDS 'TOUGH DIPLOMACY'
description: Former Gov. Charles S. Robb of Virginia, who has assumed a major leadership role in Democratic Party's centrist wing, asserted tonight that the United States must couple military assistance to Nicaraguan rebels with ''tough, persistent diplomacy'' to bring about a political solution to the conflict.

title: Japan-Ariane Pact
description: Europe's private space consortium, Arianespace, said today that it had signed a contract with Japan's Space Communications Corporation, a joint venture set up by the Mitsubishi Corporation and the Mitsubishi Electric Company, for the launchings of two Superbird satellites.

DRESHER INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NEW YORK LEADERS SPLIT IN TAX DEBATE
description: The plan approved early this morning by the Senate Finance Committee for revising the Federal tax code has split what had previously been a united effort by New York officials, led by Governor Cuomo, to preserve the right of taxpayers to deduct all state and local taxes from Federal returns.

ARAB'S INTERVIEW STIRS NEWS DEBATE
description: An agreement made by NBC News to keep secret the whereabouts of a terrorist suspect in exchange for an interview has stirred a debate within the press and Government over the propriety of the arrangement.

title: Happy Days Here
description: Notes from the suddenly joyous world of the Cleveland Indians:

title: FOX PLANS A TV PROGRAM SERVICE
description: Fox Inc., the movie conglomerate owned by Rupert Murdoch, announced today the formation of a satellite-delivered national program service for independent television stations. As its initial offering, the service, called the Fox Broadcasting Company, will compete with NBC, ABC, and CBS from 11 P.M. to midnight Eastern time Monday through Friday with a live talk show starring Joan Rivers.

title: MODINE MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $265,000 from a pension accounting change for the quarter and $1.6 million for the year.

title: CONTRAS CLEARED ON GUNRUNNING
description: The Justice Department has found no foundation for charges that large numbers of Nicaraguan rebels and private American supporters were involved in gunrunning and drug trafficking, department officials said today.

title: East Coast Awaiting Barium Cloud Tests
description: Bright purple and green clouds are expected to light up the early morning sky tomorrow from Montreal to Jacksonville, Fla., and as far inland as Ohio.

title: MOSCOW NEWS SESSION: BRIEF AND NOT TO POINT
description: The Soviet Union's recent inclination for holding Western-style news conferences and its traditional desire to control information collided today at a briefing on the Chernobyl nuclear accident.

title: N.C.A.A. Drug Ruling
description: If a team in next year's national collegiate basketball tournament has a player who tests positive for drugs, the team could be disqualified from competition even if the tournament has already begun. That was the word from Jack Davis, president of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, who spoke yesterday in Kansas City, Mo., about the drug-testing program approved at last January's N.C.A.A. convention and adopted by the executive committee at meetings this week.

title: Testing Iacocca
description: Is Lee Iacocca ready for Washington? Lacking a political answer to this frequently posed question, one of the capital's television stations will look for an automotive answer instead.

title: TEXT OF ECONOMIC DECLARATION ISSUED AT END OF TOKYO SUMMIT CONFERENCE
description: Following is the text of the Tokyo Economic Declaration issued today by the leaders of the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada at the conclusion of their three-day summit meeting:

title: BLACK-OWNED CONCERNS REFLECTED '85 ECONOMY
description: The nation's 100 biggest black-owned companies generally reflected the pattern of the economy as a whole in 1985, with construction and media companies showing strong sales results and energy and manufacturing concerns reporting more lackluster performances.

title: MICROSEMI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: The share earnings results for 1985 have been restated for June 20, 1985, 5-for-4 stock split.

title: FARM BANK SYSTEM POSTS LARGE LOSS
description: In another reflection of the crisis in American farming, the Farm Credit System yesterday reported a first-quarter loss of $206 million, compared with a profit of $118 million a year ago.

title: SUSPECT REPORTEDLY ASSERTS SYRIA DIRECTED BOMBING AT A BERLIN CLUB
description: A Jordanian arrested in connection with the explosion in a West Berlin discotheque last month has confessed to an earlier terrorist bombing in the city, saying it was organized by the Syrian Embassy in East Berlin, according to security sources.

title: Judges Restrict Sales Of Marcos Valuables
description: A New York State judge has barred several New York City art galleries, jewelers and auction houses believed to have done business with the former Philippine President, Ferdinand E. Marcos, and his wife, Imelda, from selling any artworks, antiques or jewelry belonging to the Marcoses or their associates.

title: Coast Guard Rescues 6 After Sailboat Founders
description: The Coast Guard rescued six people and a dog on a sailboat as it began to sink Monday. A British submarine that answered the group's distress call sank the foundering vessel with small arms fire because it posed a threat to navigation, officials said.

title: The U.N. Today: May 7, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Economic and Financial Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: DELAY REPORTED ON EVACUATION AT NUCLEAR SITE
description: Radioactivity spewed from a damaged nuclear reactor in the Ukraine for 36 hours before people living near the plant were evacuated, the official heading the investigation of the accident said today.

title: LINCOLN SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-earlier quarter's per share figure is not available since the company went public in March.

title: CASTLE & COOKE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary loss of $1,127,000.

title: MUSIC: SCHUBERT SKETCHES
description: IN the last few years of Schubert's short life, a celestially beautiful figure of melodic speech came to special prominence in his work. Basically it consists of repeating the last bit of a melody - adding a bar or two to the second part of a standard two-part phrase - with some poignant change in the repeat.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: Fort Worth is offering $73 million of bonds with yields ranging from 5.25 percent in 1988 to 6.10 percent in 1991, 7.10 percent in 1997, 7.35 percent in 2001 and 7.50 percent in 2007, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: GENERAL BINDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Liberty Mutual And Stein Roe
description: The Liberty Mutual Insurance Company intends to acquire an 80 percent interest in Stein Roe & Farnham, an investment counseling and mutual fund management firm, for an undisclosed amount based on Stein Roe's 1986 earnings. The partners of Stein Roe will continue to own the remaining 20 percent.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''All we sought to accomplish at the summit was achieved.'' - President Reagan. [ A1:6. ]

title: BROYHILL DEFEATS CAROLINA RIGHTIST
description: Representative James T. Broyhill won a commanding victory today over David B. Funderburk, a conservative college professor, in their race for the Republican nomination to the United States Senate.

title: Ticketron Talks Are Completed
description: The Control Data Corporation said it had completed its previously announced negotiations to sell its Ticketron ticket-service unit to an investor group led by Allen & Company, a New York investment banking firm.

title: Libya Raid Illustrates Policy in a Vacuum
description: To the Editor:

title: CSS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $583,000. c-Includes a tax credit of $666,000 and a pre-tax non-recurring gain of $600,000 related to the sale of investment securities.

title: CETEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $32,000.

title: Iraqi Aircraft Attack 2 Ships in Gulf
description: Iraqi military aircraft attacked and set ablaze two supertankers today in the Persian Gulf near Iran's oil terminal at Kharg Island, marine salvage executives here said.

title: Queens Leader to Seek The Rest of Her Term
description: Queens Borough President Claire Shulman formally declared yesterday that she would seek three more years in her post, and that she would not take campaign contributions from people who had matters pending before the Board of Estimate.

title: DEMOCRATS ON BUDGET PANEL IN HOUSE NEAR AN AGREEMENT
description: Democrats on the House Budget Committee neared agreement this evening on a 1987 spending plan that would slash President Reagan's request for the military, raise revenue as much as the Senate and cut the deficit substantially below the $144 billion ceiling set in the new budget-balancing law.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: ECONOMIC PACT GETS PRAISE, BUT ITS EFFICACY IS DOUBTED
description: The Tokyo agreement for greater international economic coordination was greeted today with a mixture of praise for its far-reaching scope and skepticism that it would be effectively put into practice.

title: FIRST COLUMBIA FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SWEEPING TAX BILL APPROVED, 20 TO 0, BY A SENATE PANEL
description: The Senate Finance Committee, by a 20-to-0 vote, approved legislation early today that would make the biggest changes in the Federal income tax law in more than 40 years.

title: The Sculptor's Reactions
description: ''It is cheerful, elegant, well-cared-for and clean; it is the pet and pride of the city,'' Frederic Auguste Bartholdi wrote home to his mother in France on June 24, 1871, after a visit to Central Park.

title: DUAL-LITE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $299,000. c-Includes gains on the disposal of discontinued business of $68,000 for the latest 9 months, $35,000 for the year-ago quarter and $107,000 for the year-ago 9 months, as well as tax credits of $947,000 for the latest 9 months and $86,000 for the year-ago quarter and 9 months.

title: WORST BOUNCE OF ALL
description: ''I guess I'm the goat, huh?'' Willie Huber said, so matter-of-factly that he might even have been slightly mocking the traditional sports-page need for every losing team to have a goat in baseball or the Stanley Cup playoffs.

title: SOUTH AFRICA REPORTEDLY SENT APPEAL TO ECONOMIC PARLEY
description: President P. W. Botha of South Africa is reported to have appealed to leaders at the Tokyo economic summit meeting to acknowledge his program of cautious racial change and to support his case in negotiations on the release of Nelson Mandela, the jailed nationalist.

title: Advertising; Geer, DuBois
description: Geer, DuBois has become the agency for Fred. S. James & Company, the North American arm of the Sedgwick Group, a British insurance company. The James concern, which did not have a previous agency but is now planning to spend between $2 million and $3 million for advertising, is in the business of providing property and casualty insurance brokerage.

title: IONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Penn Station Redux
description: To the Editor:

title: Now for the Descent: Thatcher Leaves First
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher left for Britain tonight after the seven-nation economic summit conference.

title: TRIAL IS ORDERED IN MURDERS OF 14
description: After nine weeks of testimony, a municipal judge today ordered Richard Ramirez, accused in a string of random, brutal slayings here, to stand trial in connection with 14 deaths and 36 other felonies.

title: That's Enough
description: Coach Mike Sertich of the University of Minnesota-Duluth, who has just lost Bobby Hull's son Brett to the Calgary Flames: ''The knock on him is that all he can do is score goals. All Picasso could do was paint.''

title: 'THE PRECIOUS LEGACY' OF CZECH JEWS
description: ''THE PRECIOUS LEGACY'' is deeply felt and reverently made, a memorial service of sorts to the vanished Jews of Prague. For 1,000 years they lived in that city - ''the Paris of the East, the Jerusalem of the West'' - and then in a few short years they were gone. ''The Precious Legacy,'' on Channel 13 at 8:30 tonight, looks at the hallowed possessions they left behind.

title: A Watergate Warning
description: A history professor who is writing a book about Watergate has been warned that ''it would be unfortunate if you were to in any way deviate'' from the version of events depicted in a Watergate book written eight years ago by Maurice H. Stans, finance chairman of the President Nixon's 1972 re-election campaign.

title: Sculpture in Search Of a Home

Perched on floats in the Duck Pond at the southeastern end of Central Park, the 12-foot-long, two-ton work, ''Two Piece Reclining Figure: Points,'' moved 100 feet north, until it became lodged in mud.

description: Jeff Lahti, the right-handed relief pitcher who in 1985 led St. Louis Cardinals pitchers with 19 saves, underwent arthroscopic surgery on his sore right shoulder, which had been paining him since spring training.
