description: The Senate tonight decisively rebuffed the Reagan Administration's request to sell $354 million worth of advanced arms to Saudi Arabia.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: TO family and friends assembled around my table, the most appealing category of food is probably a seafood soup or stew - be it the most famous of all French soups, bouillabaisse (Americanized with a saffron flavor), an Italian-style clam soup (made with the smallest littleneck clams) or the most American of seafood soups, New England clam chowder.

title: MICHIGANDERS AWE AND ARE AWED IN ITALY
description: It's not every day that the owners of an American restaurant bring 21 of their staff from Michigan to be wined and dined in the best restaurants and cellars of Italy. But then Charles and Ginger Mostov are not everyday people.

description: The United States and other countries might be able to reduce their interest rates further, a senior Administration official said here today.

description: In the last week, Soviet officials and the Soviet press have issued a trickle of facts about what happened at the Chernobyl atomic power station in the Ukraine. The following is a reconstruction of the accident drawn mainly from these accounts.

description: Rear Admiral Arthur Graham Hall, retired, former superintendent of the United States Coast Guard Academy in New London, Conn., died of cancer Friday at his home in Stuart, Fla.

title: YANKS' LATE RALLY TOPS WHITE SOX
description: The Yankees' apparent lack of confidence in Dennis Rasmussen's ability to pitch past the sixth inning nearly cost them a game tonight. ''It would've been a shame to lose that game because I was taken out after six innings,'' a disappointed Rasmussen said.

AT 69, MASTER STORYTELLER WINS NEW RECOGNITION
description: ''My wife's a poet,'' Peter Taylor said in a recent conversation, ''and I tell her novelists have potentially a mass audience, poets have each other, but short-story writers don't have much. We don't even usually read each other.''

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Cablevision Systems Corp., Woodbury, L.I., announced three promotions, naming Robert S. Lemle and Barry J. O'Leary senior vice presidents and Jerry Shaw vice president and controller.

title: EASY BASIC QUENELLES
description: BERORE the chef's life was made immeasurably softer with the invention of the food processor, making quenelles was a slow and arduous task. I recall hours spent mincing, rolling and cutting fish and chicken quenelles, which in the old days were rather dense and heavy little creations thickened with flour, milk and bread, then coated with lard.

title: 'BLUE LIGHTNING,' CBS ACTION DRAMA
description: WASTING no time in getting to the point, ''The Blue Lightning'' opens with a man begging for mercy after being lashed, crucifixion-style, to a tree in the wilds of Opal Ridge, Australia. ''Quentin, my boy,'' sneers the sadistic Irish villain named McInally (pronounced McKinley), ''try to have a little dignity.'' But instead of leaving Quentin to be eaten alive by wild dogs, McInally shoots him dead on the spot. And from there on in this television movie being shown on CBS tonight at 9, it's no more Mr. Nice Guy.

title: DIVER TO EXPLORE EAST RIVER WRECK FOR TREASURE
description: A specially trained diver will soon plunge into the murky East River seeking a way into sunken wreckage that could be the British warship Hussar, which went down, reputedly with a fortune in gold and silver, in 1780.

title: State Formally Bans Selling Or Possessing Striped Bass
description: New York State yesterday formally banned the sale or possession of striped bass, whether caught by commercial or recreational fishermen.

title: SUMMIT CURRENCY PLAN WELCOMED IN GERMANY
description: West German economists today generally welcomed the summit plan to coordinate economies more closely, saying it could contribute to preventing the wild fluctuations that have occurred in recent years.

title: BENJAMIN STRONG
description: Benjamin Strong, former chairman of the United States Trust Company of New York, died last Friday at Medford Leas, a retirement community in Medford, N.J. He was 89 years old.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article on the Style page on Monday about the feelings of high school seniors misidentified a Fieldston student. He is Miyan Levenson, not Ziyan Levenson.

title: 3-Year Notes Yield Only 6.97%
description: Interest rates rose modestly yesterday, as securities dealers noted that the low levels reached in late Monday trading were too low to attract sufficient investor demand at this week's Treasury note and bond auctions.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Chicago Cubs activated Lee Smith, a relief pitcher, and asked waivers on Dick Ruthven, a right-handed starting pitcher, for the purpose of giving him his unconditional release. Smith, a right-hander, had been on the 15-day disabled list because of a pulled groin muscle. . . . Dennis Rappaport, co-manager of Gerry Cooney, said Cooney's fight with Eddie Gregg May 31 will be held in San Francisco.

title: SPRING ROLL: BIG FLAVOR, SMALL SIZES
description: MOST Americans know them as egg rolls: stout, deep-fried cylinders of flour, egg and water stuffed with barbecued pork, occasionally bits of shrimp and a generous portion of cabbage and celery. The classic Chinese rendition, known as a spring roll, is long and thin, wrapped in a lacy, delicate skin, stuffed with a blend of shredded pork, shrimp, Chinese black mushrooms and bean sprouts, then deep-fried. The two dishes are only a small sampling of the broad category of Chinese rolls.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: For Mother's Day For Mother's Day, the Chelsea Baking Company is offering a special strawberry shortcake with gossamer sponge layers, mousseline cream and fresh strawberries at its sleek and attractive new retail selling area, 259 West 19th Street. The shortcake, which can be inscribed, is $25 and will serve 14 people. A light chocolate cherry cake is crafted along similar lines. Order by 2 P.M. Thursday for pickup by 4 P.M. Saturday. Telephone: 212-242-7692.

description: The Senate voted 89 to 9 today to confirm James C. Fletcher to head the National Aeronatics and Space Administration for a second time.

title: Kidder Forms Group To Market 'Junk Bonds'
description: Kidder, Peabody & Company, wasting no time in taking advantage of its liaison with General Electric Financial Services Inc., yesterday announced the creation of a new 30-member group specializing in high-yield corporate bonds.

title: The Lampedusa Mystery
description: Lampedusa is a very small rocky island in the southern Mediterranean, bypassed even when the great battles of World War II raged thereabouts. Before the fall of Mussolini, it surrendered to a British pilot who landed his plane on the island when it had run out of fuel.

title: Pentagon; Redesigning the Military Command Camel
description: Ever since the Defense Department was founded, few have been satisfied with it and many have sought to change it.

title: STAGE: 'BIRDS,' BY PENA
description: ON the evening of your reviewer's visit to the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater, its performance of ''The Birds Fly Out With Death'' was in English. Can that be why Edilio Pena's play, the first by the Venezuelan writer to be produced in the United States, seemed incomprehensible?

title: CITY BALLET: 'UNION JACK'
description: ''U NION JACK,'' one of the most original ballets in existence, has returned to the New York City Ballet's repertory this season, and the wit and imagination George Balanchine poured into the production remain as amazing as ever.

title: OPERA: 'LA GIOCONDA'
description: ''L A GIOCONDA'' does not hold the place in the repertory that it once did, which one would like to believe is because the public now recognizes Ponchielli's opera as an inferior specimen of its blood-and-thunder type. Actually, however, the work is likely to be revived occasionally whenever a soprano voice capable of handling its heavy demands turns up on the international scene. That happenstance undoubtedly explains why Eve Queler and her Opera Orchestra of New York chose to close its season Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall with a concert version of ''La Gioconda.'' Available to fill the title role was the stentorian-toned Bulgarian soprano Ghena Dimitrova, whose New York debut in ''Nabucco'' during Miss Queler's 1983-84 season aroused extraordinary interest.

title: Stocks Mixed; Dow Drops by 5.82
description: Volume improved moderately on Wall Street yesterday, but stock prices were mixed as investors, seeing interest rates inch higher, decided to capture some profits in blue-chip issues.

title: A VERY SPECIAL RELATIONSHIP
description: She put a picture of the President in a ''casual pose'' by her bedside at the hotel and at the palace where she stayed without him this week. She called him whenever she could find matching patches of ''private time'' on their schedules to tell him about her tours of Buddhist temples, her tete-a-tetes with kings and queens, the glistening gifts of gold and silk. ''I felt,'' she said, ''like Anna and the King of Siam.''

title: Martin, White Sox Talk
description: When Billy Martin has a managing job, he is often immersed in speculation about when he will be dismissed. When he isn't managing, he is the focal point of speculation about when he will manage again.

title: F.B.I. Chief Praises Leaders
description: The Director of the F.B.I., William H. Webster, praised the other leaders at the Tokyo summit meeting today for joining President Reagan in denouncing terrorism. ''With their help and their cooperation, I think the President and the rest of us are going to see some effective action in the future,'' he said.

title: BELATED TREAT IN JAPAN: A QUICK PEEK AT PALACE
description: Other than endless street barricades, police spot searches, hit-and-run radical attacks, slow business and patience occasionally frayed at the edges, the people of Tokyo have not had much to show for the summit conference.

title: THE POLITICAL SUMMIT; SUMMING UP: 3 DAYS' WORK IN TOKYO
description: Japan is a country where political indirection is an art form, a country where the simplest question elicits an answer as oblique and convoluted as Kabuki.

title: WOULD-BE CUP CHALLENGERS TRY VARIED TACKS FOR FUNDS
description: The American syndicates trying to bring the America's Cup back from Australia are trying to warm corporate America to their quest.

title: 'What Works'
description: President Reagan appears to be determined to make ''What Works,'' the 65-page Department of Education booklet on teaching and learning, an international best-seller. Over the weekend in Tokyo he decided he wanted to give Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher a copy autographed by Secretary of Education William J. Bennett, but Mr. Bennett was out of town Monday, so a plain copy was hustled into the first diplomatic pouch headed for Tokyo.

title: MOST LEADERS SEEN AS WINNING ON MAJOR GOALS WHILE CONCEDING LITTLE
description: The scorecard for the Tokyo summit conference, unlike those of some earlier meetings, suggests most leaders achieved their main objectives without the need to offer significant offsetting concessions, according to officials involved in the talks.

title: S.E.C. BARS CHANGE ON ACCOUNTING
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission unanimously rejected a proposal today that would have enabled oil and gas companies to avoid large write-offs as a result of the falling value of their oil and gas reserves.

title: Why a New Standard for Past Campaign Contributions Is Unfair

title: Economic Scene; Even Volcker Is Optimistic
description: THE just-ended Tokyo conference marks a cautious but constructive step toward greater economic cooperation among the seven largest industrial democracies. Immediately after the agreement on a plan to help stabilize currencies was announced, there was enthusiasm in the United States stock and bond markets, which apparently concluded that the conference's outcome implied a further decline in interest rates and a spur to investment and economic growth.

title: CHARITY DONATIONS SET A RECORD IN '85
description: CHARITABLE contributions reached a record of $79.8 billion in 1985, and for the first time in 16 years individual Americans gave more than 2 percent of their personal income to philanthropy.

title: LOCAL AT HORMEL SUES PARENT UNION
description: Leaders of a meatpackers' local on strike against Geo. A. Hormel & Company filed suit against their parent union today in a move to block efforts to place the Austin, Minn., local in trusteeship and remove its officers.

title: BECKER PROVIDES THE GLAMOUR
description: Daring to win the Wimbledon singles championship when he was just a 17-year-old upstart had repercussions that Boris Becker probably never envisioned. In Europe he became a folk hero, besieged by adoring fans from hotel lobbies to center court. And across the Atlantic, Becker gave some of the more parochial American fans a tennis complex that has them wishing that John McEnroe makes a speedy and successful return to the game.

title: Enron Combines Its Pension Plans
description: The Enron Corporation, the new name for the company created by the merger of the Houston Natural Gas Corporation and Internorth Inc., said it was combining the two companies' pension plans in a move that will yield $130 million after taxes. Formed last July, Enron, based in Omaha, is primarily engaged in the transmission and sales of natural gas in North America.

New Tremor in Mexico
description: An earth tremor measuring 4.5 on the Richter scale shook areas of Mexico's Pacific coast today, but there were no reports of casualties or damage. Seismic experts in Mexico City said the epicenter of the tremor, which hit at 7:17 A.M., was in the coastal area of the state of Michoacan. It was the third significant quake felt in Mexico in a week.

title: The Worm and the Apple; About Time; Pampered Potholes

description: The number of AIDS cases in the United States is expected to rise for at least two more years, a Federal health official said yesterday.

description: With no fanfare, but with considerable surprise, the Jets cut Marvin Powell, their five-time Pro Bowl right tackle, prompting his lawyer to say today that the team acted because Powell is president of the players' union.

title: MUSIC: 'SALSA MEETS JAZZ'
description: FOR sheer explosiveness, the keyboardist Michel Camilo's septet can match any Latin-jazz band now performing. The group appeared Monday at the Village Gate, with the pianist Hilton Ruiz as guest soloist in the ''Salsa Meets Jazz'' series.

title: Missiles and Messages for the Saudis
description: Money alone cannot buy all the American weapons and goodwill Saudi Arabia wants, and Congress can usefully repeat that message on occasion. But it serves no American interest to cut off the Saudis altogether. On the contrary, to do so would only drive them into other markets and break their relations with our military. Congress is wrong to try to block the proposed sale of $354 million worth of arms, mostly antiaircraft missiles.

title: THE STAGE: 'KINDNESS'
description: SIX friends, seniors facing graduation, are at a school prom. The mirrored ball is spinning, and memories are in the making. Two boys are dressed in tuxedos, three girls are in gowns. The sixth, Buzz, is decidedly out of costume, though he is dressed in basic black. His classmates treat him like one of their number, perhaps as a foreign exchange student, but his difference is as plain as the fur on his face. Buzz is a gorilla. The play is ''Kindness'' (at the La Mama Annex), a case of Ping Chong in an antic New Vaudeville mood, complete with running gags and routines, but with a bittersweet aftertaste. The title, in typical Ping Chong fashion, is intended as a pun. ''Kindness'' means sympathy, friend to friend, and it also refers to species, as the author-director suggests, splitting the word in two, ''kind-ness.'' The world is populated by humankind and gorilla-kind.

title: WINE TALK
description: AT a dinner at the Four Seasons recently, Gerald Asher, one of the most astute of current commentators on wine, made some critical and long-overdue remarks about the status of wine tasting, particularly ''negative'' tastings of Californian wines. His feeling is that too many tastings single out a couple of wines for praise at the expense of all the others in the group. It stands to reason that if 20 wines are judged, only one is first. The winning winery sends out a glowing press release. The rest grind their teeth.

At 92, Temperature Ties Record for Date
description: The thermometer in Central Park tied the record yesterday when it hit 92 degrees at 2 P.M., and most New Yorkers were surprised, but not all.

TELXON CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes foreign tax credits of 06,000 for the quarter and $224,000 for the year. c-Includes foreign tax credits of $39,000 for the quarter and $114,000 for the year.

The Menu At the Banquet
description: Following is the menu for the banquet given tonight at the Imperial Palace by Emperor Hirohito at the end of the economic summit conference: Swallow's Nest Soup, Harvest Fish in White Wine, Leg of Lamb, Salad, Ice Cream, Mount Fuji Melon and Strawberries. The Wines: Bernkasteler Doktor 1982, Chateau Margaux 1979, Moet & Chandon Dom Perignon 1976, Sake.

title: TV Station Vandalized, Delaying Series on Klan
description: A television station preparing to show a series of reports on the Ku Klux Klan and neo-Nazis was forced off the air for nearly three hours after someone took an ax to its equipment, a spokesman said.

title: FEDERAL COURT NOMINEE DENIES RACIAL INSENSITIVITY
description: President Reagan's nominee for a Federal district judgeship in Alabama offered a detailed, impassioned rebuttal today to charges that he was insensitive to racial minorities.

title: Hutton Deal With Mendik
description: E. F. Hutton and the Mendik Company announced yesterday that they had formed a limited partnership to buy and manage existing commercial real estate in the New York metropolitan area.

title: ALCAN SEARCH: NEW PRODUCTS
description: Timothy C. Tuff, the president of the United States unit of Alcan Aluminium Ltd., keeps a red plastic toy boat on his desk as a symbol of his efforts to promote aluminum power.

title: 2 Texas Executions Blocked By U.S. Courts
description: Federal courts today blocked the executions of a rapist-murderer, scheduled to die Wednesday, and a man convicted of murder in a $1 robbery who was scheduled to die Thursday.

title: THERAPEUTIC TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said year-ago quarter and 6-month results include a non- recurring gain of $250,000 from an incentive grant from the state of Ohio.

title: UNIFAST INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
More Than Libya Was Ground Zero
description: President Reagan's bombing raid over Libya endangered far more than the Libyans. It endangered the North Atlantic alliance, cornerstone of American foreign policy in the Western Hemisphere.

title: Statements in Killings in West
description: Richard Ramirez told the police shortly after his arrest last summer that he was the killer wanted for 15 slayings in California, according to transcripts of court proceedings unsealed today.

title: Banc One to Buy American Fletcher
description: The Banc One Corporation of Columbus, Ohio, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the American Fletcher Corporation, the second-largest banking company in Indiana, for $60 a share in Banc One stock, or $597.3 million.

title: SCAT HOVERCRAFT reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company began operations in June of 1985 and did not report figures for the year-ago period.

title: FOREST OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Juice and the Deficit
description: The lawmakers whose names have become something of a synonym for governmental penury by virtue of the budget-balancing law they sponsored in the Senate - the Republicans Phil Gramm of Texas and Warren B. Rudman of New Hampshire and the Democrat Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina - got what appeared to be a nice gift from constituents the other day: several crates of citrus delivered to their Senate offices.

title: SAATCHI & SAATCHI DEAL FOR BATES AGENCY SEEN
description: Saatchi & Saatchi, the British advertising company, agreed on Tuesday night to acquire Ted Bates Worldwide, the third-largest advertising agency in the United States, according to three independent sources.

title: UNION TEXAS PETROLEUM reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Latest-quarter results were affected by higher financial costs related to the company's leveraged buyout, or $24 million after taxes, and certain costs associated with a reduction in the workforce of $12 million, after taxes. The company is privately held.

title: FMR Holdings
description: The FMR Corporation, a Boston-based investment holding company, said it had reduced its stake in the Sheller-Globe Corporation to 3.5 percent of the company's shares outstanding, from 8.1 percent.

title: ADVERTISING
description: * Sudler & Hennessey has been assigned two new products from Stuart Pharmaceuticals, which brings the total to 18 Stuart products.

title: SHULTZ, IN SEOUL, SAYS U.S. BACKS KOREA'S EFFORTS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz, arriving here for a 24-hour visit, said today that the Reagan Administration strongly supported the South Korean Government's efforts to make changes and assailed those in the opposition who ''incite violence.''

title: UNITED INSURANCE COS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $190,000.

title: Bloom Agency Ads
description: The Bloom Agency in New York has won the first consumer advertising assignment from the Mentor Corporation, a Minneapolis manufacturer of hospital supplies.

title: Corestates Making Management Shifts
description: The Corestates Financial Corporation, a multibank holding company based in Philadelpia, said yesterday that it had named Terrence A. Larsen president and chief operating officer in a restructuring to prepare it for possible interstate banking.

title: REAGAN, HOME FROM TOKYO MEETING, IS JUBILANT
description: President Reagan, returning to an enthusiastic welcome here, said today that the leading industrial democracies had moved ''beyond words and rhetoric'' in a unified struggle against terrorism.

title: U.S. HEEDED NAKASONE PLEA IN AIR-CARGO DISPUTE
description: The Department of Transportation, following a personal request to the White House by Japan's Prime Minister, Yasuhiro Nakasone, has rescinded an order requiring Japan Air Lines to provide exhaustive data about its cargo flights to the United States, according to Congressional and Administration officials.

title: CONCERT: MUSICA CAMERIT
description: MUSICA CAMERIT, the resident chamber-music ensemble at Merkin Concert Hall, came up with an imaginatively varied program for its concert on Tuesday night. The most rewarding work, Copland's Quartet for Piano and Strings, was preceded by Schumann's Adagio and Allegro for Horn and Piano and followed by Peter Maxwell Davies's ''Sea Eagle'' for horn, the Mozart-Hoffmeister Quartet in G for Flute and Strings and Mozart's Horn Quintet in E flat.

title: TRANSTECTOR SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income

title: TYSON LOOKS TO GARDEN
description: Four days after extending his string of consecutive heavyweight victories to 20 with a 10-round decision over James (Quick) Tillis, 19-year-old Mike Tyson was concentrating on a potential No. 21 yesterday at a boxing luncheon held to publicize his 10-round bout May 20 at Madison Square Garden against Mitch Green. The fight will be the Garden main arena's first heavyweight feature event in more than five years unless the Rangers somehow reach the Stanley Cup final round and play their first home game there May 20. The Tyson-Green fight would then be moved to the 4,500-seat Felt Forum.

title: BUFFTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 1-for-5 reverse split, effective Oct. 1, 1985.

title: Belfast Council Bows To Court and Convenes
description: In the first significant break in a united Protestant campaign of opposition to the British-Irish pact on Northern Ireland, the Belfast City Council has voted to obey a High Court order to resume normal activities.

title: FIRST CENTRAL FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: CUOMO NAMES POVERTY PANEL
description: Governor Cuomo established a panel to study ways to combat poverty and increase the effectiveness of social programs yesterday.

title: SENATE APPROVES MILITARY CHANGES
description: The Senate today unanimously approved the most sweeping plan to reorganize the nation's military hierarchy in nearly 30 years.

title: FIRST VERMONT FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago share earnings reflects the merger with Banknorth Group Inc. on Dec. 31, 1985, that was accounted for on a pooling of interests basis.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about the acquisition of Kidder, Peabody & Company by the General Electric Company misidentified the law firm that represented G.E. It was Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson. Sullivan & Cromwell represented Kidder, Peabody.

title: TURNER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago results have been restated to reflect a reduction in pension expense pursuant to the company's 1985 adoption of SFAS 87.

title: CONGRESS IS TOLD OF CUTS IN JOB CORPS
description: The Labor Department notified some members of Congress today that it would close six Job Corps centers as a result of spending cuts its must make under the new deficit-reducing law.

title: CAMERAS-IN-COURT MEASURE FALTERING IN THE STATE SENATE
description: Because of last-minute lobbying from law-enforcement groups and impassioned floor debate from a freshman Senator concerned about rape victims, a bill to allow cameras in the state's trial courts has unexpectedly lost support in the Senate.

title: DEMOCRATS ASSAIL REQUEST BY F.B.I.
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has begun its investigation of Michael K. Deaver by seeking to question the five Democratic Senators on the Judiciary Committee who asked the Justice Department to investigate his lobbying activities.

title: What Kind of 'Like-Minded' Judges?
description: President Reagan's nominees for the Federal courts severely test his indisputable right to staff the bench with like-minded judges. More power to the Senate for resisting those whose background marks them as barely fit, or worse.

title: VIOLENCE MARS BANGLADESH ELECTION
description: The first parliamentary election in Bangladesh in seven years brought out millions of voters today but was marred by widespread violence, voter intimidation and fraud that appeared to favor the political party supported by the martial-law Government.

title: Major U.S. Grade of Oil Tops $15-a-Barrel Level
description: Surging demand for gasoline, combined with declining inventories, pushed the price of the major American grade of crude oil above $15 a barrel yesterday. Its last close above that level was on Feb. 24.

title: CUSHMAN ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Laidlaw Seeking Mayflower Group
description: Laidlaw Transportation Ltd., a transportation and waste management concern in Burlington, Ontario, said it had offered $28 a share, or $215.6 million, to acquire the Mayflower Group Inc., one of the nation's largest moving companies.

title: MORTGAGE RATES FELL AGAIN IN APRIL
description: Interest rates on mortgages fell further last month, but not as substantially as in March, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said yesterday. It was the seventh consecutive monthly decline.

title: STUDY FINDS GAMMA GLOBULIN BENEFITS CHILDREN WITH AIDS
description: Gamma globulin injections seem to lower the number of certain infections among children with AIDS but do not cure the lethal ailment, researchers said yesterday.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL HOUSTON (NL) - Activated Jim Deshaies, left-handed pitcher, from the 15-day disabled list; sent John Mizerock, catcher, to the club's Class AAA team in Tucson.

title: BEST BUY CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
SPECTRUM GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $857,000.

title: WESTERN CAPITAL INVESTMENT reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bid Actions Assailed
description: The Pentagon practice of awarding contracts without competitive bidding has produced windfall profits for military contractors at taxpayers' expense, a House committee report said today.

title: BITTERNESS OVER COACHING WEARING DOWN UNITY
description: Argentines are sending their national soccer team off to the World Cup in Mexico with a public debate that, at times, seems to be a particularly dirty political contest. Other times, everybody appears to be following a soap opera script.

title: Garry Maddox Retires
description: Saying the decision was ''harder than laying off the first pitch - and you know how hard that was for me,'' Garry Maddox of the Philadelphia Phillies ended his 14-year career in the majors yesterday because of a recurrent back problem. Maddox, who is 36 years old, was a career .284 hitter and an eight-time Gold Glove winner as a center fielder, making only 73 errors in 4,620 chances for a .983 fielding percentage.

title: TELEQUEST INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PIONEER GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: THE DANCE: SANKAI JUKU
description: THE most spectacular performer in ''Kinkan Shonen (The Kumquat Seed),'' which Japan's Sankai Juku presented Tuesday night at the City Center, was not a dancer but a peacock. Making its entrance in the third scene of Ushio Amagatsu's 90-minute choreographic work, the bird stayed motionless while Mr. Amagatsu held it as if it were a piece of cloth. Then it flapped about and perched on his back. Later, it strutted this way and that. Finally, it rose in a stately flight up to the balcony. No doubt about it, the peacock was just fine.

title: Schlosser Will Head Film-Making Museum
description: Herbert S. Schlosser, a former executive with RCA and NBC, has been elected chairman of the board of the American Museum of the Moving Image, which will open next year in Astoria, Queens.

title: WESTERN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said year-ago share earnings were not comparable because the first quarter was prior to its merger with Lawrence Federal in July 1985.

title: Paine Webber Officer Quits
description: Paine Webber Group Inc., the investment brokers and bankers, said yesterday that Michael J. Johnston had resigned as president of Paine Webber Capital Markets, the investment banking subsidiary.

title: Insiders' Signatures
description: When Stephen Hess was contemplating a jacket design for his new book, ''The Ultimate Insiders,'' a study for the Brookings Institution on how senators deal with the press, he decided a collage of 100 senators' signatures would be appropriate.

title: R.A. LOVETT, EX-CHIEF OF DEFENSE WHO PRESSED BUILDUP IN 50's, DIES
description: Robert A. Lovett, Secretary of Defense from 1951 to 1953 and onetime Under Secretary of State, died yesterday at his home in Locust Valley, L.I. Mr. Lovett, who was 90 years old, had suffered from cancer and kidney ailments.

title: Missing Out On 'A Lot of Fun'
description: The new majority leader of the City Council, Peter F. Vallone of Queens, called it an ''orientation session'' for new members. But the head of the State Committee on Open Government, Robert Freeman, called it a ''meeting relating to city business'' and said that by law it should have been open to the public.

title: BUSINESS MAY BACK TAX PLAN
description: The tax-overhaul bill approved early today by the Senate Finance Committee would raise the total levy on American corporations by about $100 billion over five years even as it cuts their tax rate to 33 percent from 46 percent.

title: DECISION DUE ON BURNING TOXIC WASTES OFF JERSEY
description: Every year, more than 290 million tons of hazardous wastes - more than a ton for each man, woman and child - are produced in the United States, according to Federal officials.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: AFRICAN ESTHETICS Carlo Monzino, who used to own a chain of department stores in Italy, owns one of the world's finest collections of African art. He got most of his collection from the sculptor Jacob Epstein in the 1960's. Afterward, he made his acquisitions more directly.

title: And Now, Rent-a-Roof
description: The roof of a Brooklyn coffee warehouse is working its way into the celebration over the Fourth of July weekend for the Statue of Liberty.

title: Nevada Housing Mortgage Bonds
description: The Nevada Housing Division is offering $53 million of single-family mortgage revenue bonds, a type of tax-exempt bond that has been in scant supply this year, with a maximum yield tentatively set at 7 7/8 percent through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. For shorter maturities, yields range from 6.90 percent in 1994 to 7.20 percent in 1996 and 7.70 percent in 2001.

title: OROSCO AND KNIGHT SAVE METS
description: At the end - after the bloop single to center and the run-saving stop at third base and the harrowing catch in right field - Jesse Orosco turned and shook Ray Knight's hand. The Mets did not win this one easily, but they won. Again.

title: TS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: PIANO: IRVING FIELDS AT THE PLAZA
description: LIVE piano music in restaurants must find a delicate balance between the listenable and the invisible. It must be light enough to allow the steady pursuit of quiet conversation, yet well enough played to justify its existence.

title: I.B.M. Leads Selloff; Dow Falls 12.65
description: A sharp drop in the price of I.B.M. shares was the catalyst for a selloff yesterday on Wall Street, where investors were already concerned about the impact of this week's $27 billion Treasury refunding and tax revision.

title: WHAT TO COLLECT NEXT
description: PREDICTING collecting trends in the decorative arts is not so different from forecasting which stocks will soar on Wall Street - theories abound, and timing is everything.

title: Bucharest Wins European Cup
description: Steaua Bucharest beat Barcelona by 2-0 on penalty kicks to win the European Champions' Cup in soccer today after the two teams were tied, 0-0, after regulation and overtime.

title: WORLD MAIL CENTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
New York's 1,077 Oases
description: All the world knows Central Park, but most New Yorkers are likely to be more familiar with parks that are their neighborhoods' backyards. According to a mayoral survey, local community boards now value better maintenance of those backyards even more than additional police patrols and garbage pickups.

title: TVI ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss The company is listed on the Philadelphia Stock Exchange.

title: Rebel Slain, Colombia Says
description: One of the founders of Colombia's M-19 guerrilla group has been killed in fighting in the northeastern province of Antioquia, according to an army general. Gen. Rafael Padilla, commander of the Medellin-based Fourth Brigade, said Tuesday that the guerrilla leader, Israel Santamaria, 46 years old, and another M-19 leader had been killed in a clash with troops near Abriaqui, 115 miles north of Medellin. He gave no date, but military sources said the clash occurred in mid-March.

title: American Cable Offer
description: The American Cablesystems Corporation is offering $100 million of 10-year notes, and 3.75 million common shares through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company.

title: XTRA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a one-time charge of $34,036,000 from a writedown of certain older units of its revenue equipment fleet and after a loss from discontinued operations of $3,095,000, representing the disposal of the company's Dunhan manufacturing operations. c-Net income

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: HOMEOWNERS are finding that solid vinyl gutters are probably the best replacement for old roof gutters of wood or metal. They do not rot, rust, dent or chip. They will never show scratches or need painting, unless a change of color is desired. And ice won't stick to them.

title: Peugeot Has a Profit
description: Peugeot S.A. said today that it had a profit last year of $23.5 million after a loss of $29 million a year earlier.

title: Market Place; Dow Slippage: How Steep?
description: ''I S this the start of a major break in stock prices?'' Nervous investors kept asking that question after the Dow Jones industrial average plunged 41.91 points, to 1,783.98, on April 30 in the worst single-day point loss ever for the blue-chip index.

title: WOODHEAD INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SAVING, SPENDING, PAYING: HOW THEY WOULD CHANGE
description: The tax revision plan approved by the Senate Finance Committee early today would have a far-reaching impact on the everyday financial affairs of individuals, from the way people save for retirement and their children's college education to the amount they borrow to finance a car.

title: 12 Journalists Named 1986 Nieman Fellows
description: The Nieman Foundation at Harvard University announced today that 12 United States journalists had been appointed to the 49th class of Nieman Fellows.

title: TAX REVISION IN '86 IS ALMOST ASSURED, LAWMAKERS INSIST
description: Leading senators and representatives from both parties said today that the Senate Finance Committee's unanimous approval of a tax bill shortly after midnight meant that comprehensive tax-revision legislation would almost certainly be enacted before the end of this year.

title: Advertising; MCI Gets Physical In TV Ads
description: IF all goes as planned, stockholders of the MCI Communications Corporation meeting in Washington today should be treated to a display of the winning qualities of a threesome of tight-lipped, killer-instinct yuppie males engaged in manly competition in racquetball, fencing and judo. One way or the other, they are identified as MCI.

title: TERMINAL DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Technology; Making Metals Wear Longer
description: A HIGH-TECHNOLOGY process long used to make computer chips is starting to find a new life in more basic industries. The process, known as ion implantation, promises to make metals and other materials harder and more resistant to wear. The process is already being used to make longer-lasting artificial hip and knee joints, jet engine bearings and cutting tools and molds.

title: CRYSTAL OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a writedown of $174,000,000 and a loss from discontinued operations of $10,000,000. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $292,000.

title: VANBIESBROUCK AND RANGERS STOP CANADIENS, 2-0
description: The goaltender's flub came early, and the Rangers had one goal. The breakaway and the slap shot came later; the Rangers had their second goal. And so the Rangers' crazy trip through the playoffs continues.

title: WESTERN INVESTMENT REAL ESTATE TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes gains of $113,000 and $31,000 for latest and year-earlier periods, respectively.

title: SOME JAPANESE ASSERT TOKYO GAVE IN AT TALKS
description: Japanese political and business leaders expressed unhappiness today with the results of the Tokyo summit conference, many of them saying Japan had yielded too much to the other countries on vital diplomatic and economic matters.

title: PERENNIAL SEARCH FOR LIGHT AND VISTAS
description: TO write a pukka epic you have to follow certain rules. Rule No. 1 is that you plunge into the action right in the middle, in medias res, as Virgil rather neatly put it, with plenty of scary stuff going on. Later on, with the public hooked, you go back and explain how it all came to pass. But in Rule 1, at least, Virgil and gardeners are in the same boat. It is already happening out there. Nature (and the previous occupier) have made their dispositions. There are no clean slates in our craft or, more accurately, no blank canvases.

title: LIQUID AIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FAITHFUL FLOCK RETURNS TO ITS TIMELESS TOWN
description: Here in the sparsely settled foothills of the Adirondacks, it takes a remarkable event to attract enough people even to call it a crowd.

title: Two Stakes in Comdata Network
description: CNI Partners, a general partnership made up of the Houston Imperial Corporation, a real estate concern, and the Mason Best Company, a Dallas-based limited partnership, said that it holds 9.5 percent of the 20.5 million shares outstanding of Comdata Network Inc., a Nashville-based funds transfer service.

Books: Another Round
description: TABLE MONEY By Jimmy Breslin. 435 pages. Ticknor & Fields. $17.95. IT is easier to write a book about New York than it is to write a good novel about New Yorkers.

title: BURROUGHS IN SPERRY STOCK TENDER
description: The Burroughs Corporation, waiting barely three days for the Sperry Corporation to respond to its $4.1 billion takeover bid, announced late yesterday that since the computer maker had not replied, it was taking the offer directly to Sperry stockholders.

title: A Romance Theme For Tofutti Product
description: ''Are you in the mood for love?''

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article on April 23 about NASA management and the text of a statement by the space agency printed on April 26 referred incorrectly to a NASA official convicted of fraud. The official, who has since died, was a former director of NASA's Lewis Research Center in Cleveland.

title: Bridge: Dinner in Hawaii to Honor Memories of Von Zedtwitz
description: The giants of bridge history may be gone, but they are by no means forgotten. Among those who were strictly amateurs, the greatest of them all, considering contributions to the game as well as playing prowess, was surely Waldemar Von Zedtwitz.

title: FRENCHMAN KIDNAPPED IN BEIRUT
description: Zn elderly Frenchman was kidnapped in West Beirut today, and a Lebanese professor at American University here was reported missing and feared abducted.

title: A New Season
description: Remember Peter Murphy, the punter who quit the Columbia football team after Coach Jim Garrett's enraged denunciation of the Lions in general and Murphy in particular last fall?

title: SANDSTROM PROVIDES A SPARK
description: There are several members of the Rangers who say the team is effective when Tomas Sandstrom, the tall and lanky Swedish right wing, goes well.

title: STAGE: 'MAGGIE MAGALITA'
description: THE title character in Wendy Kesselman's ''Maggie Magalita'' is an adolescent Hispanic-American with an almost desperate urge to assimilate. With the arrival in New York of her non-English-speaking grandmother, she finds herself awakened to, and embarrassed by, her ethnic roots.

title: Yugoslavs Seek Death For Nazi War Criminal
description: State prosecutors demanded the death sentence today for an 86-year-old accused Nazi war criminal on trial in Zagreb, the official Tanyug news agency reported.

title: Writing as a Condition For School Promotion
description: To the Editor:

title: WESTERN WASTE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FRIEDMAN, AT DINNER, FAULTS U.S. PROSECUTORS
description: Alternately serious and joking, Stanley M. Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader, criticized Federal prosecutors and the Reagan Administration at the annual Bronx Democratic dinner last night.

title: THE ART OF BONSAI: TIME AND PATIENCE
description: THIS week at Akasaka Palace in Tokyo, President Reagan and other leaders at the summit conference admired bonsai - the traditional Japanese dwarf potted plants. Before a luncheon Monday, the group viewed more than 20 miniaturized wisterias, azaleas and evergreens laid out on tables in the garden in front of the low-slung gray-tiled state guest house, The word bonsai (pronounced bon-SIGH) literally means tray planting. As early as the 12th century, Japanese gardeners were fascinated by the form. Dwarf versions of trees and shrubs are created by potting and training young plants.

title: WASHINGTON NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes capital gains of $2,831,000 and $3,588,000 for latest and year-ago quarters, respectively.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Allis-Chalmers Corp., Milwaukee, said it had agreed to terminate 11 pension plans in 1985 by paying $21.2 million to the Federal Pension Benefit Guaranty Corp. in the form of a 10-year promissory note at 9 percent interest.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Mavericks vs. Los Angeles Lakers, at Dallas. Sixth game of Western Conference semifinal. The Lakers won at home Tuesday night and lead the series by 3-2.

title: TRANS-LUX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income Share earnings reflect a 5 percent stock dividend paid in March.

title: MUSEUM CHAIRS AS ART, FUNCTION
description: EVERY museum has public seating, but visitors who pass through the galleries and hallways of the Boston Museum of Fine Arts may rest on some of the finest in contemporary handcrafted furniture.

title: IRANIAN OFFENSIVE AWAITED
description: Iraqi planes bombed Teheran's main oil refinery today, the first air attack on the Iranian capital in 11 months. The national press agency said at least five people were killed.

title: SUBURBAN LIVING: SHARING A HOUSE AND, OFTEN, THE FUN
description: THE outside of the gray clapboard two-family home at the end of a cul-de-sac in Fairfield, Conn., looks much like every other house on the street. The front lawn is neatly kept. The black paint on the shutters and the white trim are starting to bubble and peel a little. And lined up in the parking area in front are a couple of not-so-new cars.

title: DANCE: BALLET THEATHER IN 'JARDIN AUX LILAS'
description: SOME dancers register the feverish, covert passions of Antony Tudor's ''Jardin aux Lilas'' like electric currents passing along the surface of the skin. Leslie Browne and Martine van Hamel approached the ballet differently, in a performance presented by the American Ballet Theater on Tuesday at the Metropolitan Opera House, and the results were stunning.

title: Costa Rican Debt Move
description: A foreign exchange shortage has forced Costa Rica to suspend its debt interest payments pending disbursement of new loans from the World Bank and the Agency for International Development. The central bank president, Eduardo Lizano, in announcing the decision late Tuesday, said the Government had been forced to request the moratorium because of a delay in disbursement of about $80 million in new loans.

title: Late Innings?
description: Eddie Einhorn, president of the Chicago White Sox, on the future of Manager Tony LaRussa: ''Show me a team in last place, and I'll show you a death watch. I'm sure they're considering Schottzie now to manage the Reds.''

title: ACCORD REACHED IN ALBANY ON A COMPUTER-CRIME BILL
description: Agreement on broad legislation that would make it a crime to break into computers was announced today by Governor Cuomo, State Attorney General Robert Abrams and key legislators.

title: 'Any Scoop On Billy?'
description: Just thinking about the cold weather in Montreal last weekend, Yogi Berra shivered.

title: LINEN SHOP DRESSES UP
description: THE luxurious table, bed and bath linens store, D. Porthault & Company, just moved to 18 East 69th Street, which was renovated by the architects below, Paul Segal and Joan Krevlin of Paul Segal Associates. Mr. Segal described the brownstone as ''a happy coincidence.'' He said, ''A building that was once a private home was a plus because Porthault sells things that go in a house.''

title: HANNA, MA CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $1.8 million on the sale of its Nipigon Transport Ltd. subsidiary.

title: School Hostages Released
description: A ninth-grade boy who took an English class, two teachers and a principal hostage at gunpoint was ''just unhappy with life in general,'' a school official said after the standoff ended without injury Tuesday. A state police officer and guidance counselor talked with the boy over the intercom system at Mountain View High School and helped persuade him to release the hostages.

title: Don't Give Britain Trans-Atlantic Air Advantages
description: To the Editor:

title: Gov. Edwards Leaves Opening for Appeal
description: Gov. Edwin W. Edwards today repeated a pledge to resign if convicted of Federal racketeering and fraud charges. But he did not say whether he would resign before or after the appeal process was completed in the event of a conviction.

title: 40-YEAR-OLD WARSHIP BEGINS A NEW LIFE IN WEST
description: The U.S.S. Missouri, after two wars, nearly 30 years of retirement as a floating museum and a $475 million refurbishment, has sailed into San Francisco Bay to start life anew as a warship.

title: Fostina Dixon at Benefit
description: Fostina Dixon and the Winds of Change, who have appeared at the Kansas City and Kool Jazz Festivals, will perform on May 17 in a benefit for New York Women Against Rape, which provides free, bilingual education and counseling services.

title: MIXED END OF SUMMIT
description: It is at least conceivable that the summit conference this week planted seeds that will change the economy of the world. This is a mixed blessing, for the seven summit leaders planted one seed of harmony and another of discord.

title: KEEPING PIGEONS AWAY
description: IF pigeons landing on the windowsill are a nuisance, there are a number of ways to discourage them from doing so. Acme Exterminating Company, 460 Ninth Avenue, at 35th Street, sells a liquid called Roost No More that is spread across the length of a windowsill, making the sill undesirable for roosting pigeons (birds will not, however, get stuck in the paste and be unable to move).

title: PEOPLE
description: * Sean Driscoll has been promoted to group senior vice president at Warwick Advertising.

title: CARPENTERS' UNION OFFICIAL IS SHOT IN MIDTOWN
description: A carpenters' union official was shot in the lobby of his office building in midtown Manhattan yesterday and the police said they were investigating the possibility that the attack was motivated by a union dispute. The gunman escaped.

title: BEKER INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $7,128,000. c-Includes a provision for a loss on disposition of discontinued operations of $18,357,000. The reporting periods are corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Phoenix Issue
description: A $93.5 million issue of Phoenix water system refunding revenue bonds was tentatively offered yesterday through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company with a maximum yield of 7 1/2 percent for bonds due in 2003.

JOHN GOES 7 INNINGS TO BEAT WHITE SOX
description: Tommy John, playing the role of ageless wonder, completed a remarkable odyssey tonight by pitching the Yankees to a 5-1 victory over the hapless Chicago White Sox.

title: 10-Year Notes' Yield Is 7.47%
description: The Treasury completed the second leg of its three-part $27 billion note and bond financing yesterday when it sold 10-year notes at an average yield of 7.47 percent, the lowest rate since the Government began selling 10-year issues in 1976.

title: Tricky Tokens
description: Some of the new ''bull's-eye'' subway tokens look more like doughnuts.

title: MARINA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $2,920,000. c-Net income.

title: CORRECTION
description: The headline of a brief article in Business Day on Tuesday about the first-quarter earnings of hte Hallibur-ton Company described them incorrectly. The company was profitable.

title: Trafalgar to Buy John Brown
description: John Brown, the 150-year-old company famous for building luxury trans-Atlantic liners, said it would accept a takeover bid from Trafalgar House, the property and construction company, which said it would offer $122 million for John Brown, now primarily an engineering and construction concern.

title: Tesoro Loss Increases
description: The Tesoro Petroleum Corporation, a diversified energy company, said today that it lost $54.1 million in its second fiscal quarter, a big increase from the $4.4 million it lost in the comparable quarter last year. Revenues fell 41.8 percent, to $369.2 million, from $634.1 million.

title: CLEAR CHOICE CAPTURES WITHERS
description: Clear Choice, the D. Wayne Lukas stable's second-string 3-year-old, scored a 2 3/4-length upset victory over Tasso in the $96,750 Withers Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday. Both colts will make their next starts in the Preakness Stakes on May 17.

title: Chernobyl and the 'Global Village'
description: In 1957, an accident at a Soviet nuclear waste dump contaminated 25,000 square miles of land near Kasli, in the Ural Mountains, but it took months for word to spread outside the country.

title: MARRIAGE RATE HITS LOW MARK
description: The marriage rate for eligible women ages 15 to 44 has dropped to the lowest level ever recorded, the Federal Government reported today.

title: Revere Copper Gets New Offer
description: Revere Copper and Brass Inc. said that it had received a $20-a-share acquisition proposal, worth $174 million, from a New York investment management firm. Revere, which makes aluminum and brass products, was formed in 1928 by the consolidation of six companies, one of them founded in 1801 by Paul Revere.

title: NATIONAL WESTERN LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes capital gains of $890 for the latest quarter and $59,687 for the year-ago period. c-Includes a tax credit of $23,000. The year-ago figures were restated.

title: 2 Fly to Second Space Station
description: Two Soviet astronauts completed the first transfer between two space stations Tuesday, leaving behind their home of 52 days for an older station where they previously established a space endurance record, the official Soviet press agency Tass reported.

title: DISASTER GOES ON, A RUSSIAN REPORTS
description: One of the Soviet Union's top physicists said today that the battle against the Chernobyl nuclear disaster was still a defensive one and that the large damaged reactor continued to generate heat.

title: At the Summit: More Wind Than Work
description: The leaders of the industrial world earned only some of the congratulations they showered on themselves as they ended their meeting in Tokyo. Their communique overflowed with pledges to mesh economic policies. But it didn't even hint that, right now, the United States, Japan and West Germany disagree over what each should do next. That's hardly a promising start.

title: JUDGE DISMISSES SUITS IN DOWNING OF KOREAN PLANE
description: A Federal judge yesterday dismissed damage suits brought against United States Government agencies by families of the passengers killed when a Korean Air Lines Boeing 747 jet was shot down by a Soviet fighter in 1983. All 269 people on board were killed. The judge, Aubrey E. Robinson Jr., said in Federal District Court in Washington that neither the Federal Aviation Administration nor the Defense Department had failed to perform any required duties in connection with the flight, in which the airliner strayed more than 300 miles off course into Soviet airspace.

title: UNESCO DISMISSALS ANGER WESTERN MEMBERS
description: The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization has dismissed a prominent critic of the agency's Director General and, in a second action, has informed its highest ranking American that he must leave the organization, Unesco employees and Western diplomats said today.

title: DRYDEN SAVES BEST FOR ROOOOOO-WAH
description: ROOOOOO-WAH, ROOOOOO-WAH, ROOOOOO-WAH...

title: CONSUMERS WATER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
JUSTICE AGENCY SAID TO RESIST C.I.A. CALL TO PROSECUTE NEWS GROUPS
description: The Justice Department is resisting the Central Intelligence Agency's call for prosecution of news organizations that have published information classified as secret, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: CONTINENTAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes net realized capital gains of $109.3 million. c-Includes net realized capital gains of $23.3 million and a loss from discontinued operations of $400,000.

title: CANADIAN OCCIDENTAL PETROEUM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

title: OF YESTERYEAR'S PLAYS AND THIS YEAR'S TONYS
description: ONE'S first response upon reading this year's list of Tony Award nominees is a nice long ''Phew!'' There were no glaringly unjust omissions of the Dustin Hoffman sort this year. It's when one starts to look at the inclusions on the nomination list, rather than the omissions, that one finds the whoppers that reveal the Tonys for what they are: a last-ditch attempt to rewrite the history of an arid Broadway season.

title: OFFICIALS DOUBT U.S. REACTOR PERIL
description: Energy Department officials testified today that they considered it ''virtually impossible'' for a graphite fire to occur in the American reactor that is most like the Soviet Union's crippled Chernobyl reactor.

title: THE ECONOMIC CENTERPIECE OF THE SUMMIT
description: The economic centerpiece of the Tokyo summit conference was an agreement on a procedure intended to reduce dramatic swings in the value of the dollar and other major currencies. The procedure, described as a ''managed float,'' is an effort to influence foreign exchange rates mainly by dealing with the underlying economic problems, rather than by directly buying or selling currencies in the world markets. These are some of the highlights of the procedure:

title: SENATOR SAYS NASA CUT 70% OF STAFF CHECKING QUALITY
description: The space agency has reduced the number of people who monitor the quality of work and equipment by 70 percent over the last 15 years, Senator Albert Gore Jr. said today.

title: RESEARCHER ACCUSED IN TEST OF GENE-ALTERED VIRUS
description: The Baylor College of Medicine in Houston accused one of its leading researchers yesterday of violating Federal guidelines and university rules by participating in an unauthorized field test nearly two years ago of an animal vaccine made from a living, genetically engineered virus.

title: Driver Gets 5 Years
description: John Paul Jr., a race car driver from Lawrenceville, Ga., was sentenced to five years in prison in Jacksonville, Fla., after pleading guilty to a charge of racketeering. In exchange, the Federal Government dropped four drug-related charges against him and assured him that he would not have to testify against his father, John Paul Sr., who is charged with being part of a marijuana-smuggling ring.

title: AS 'WHEEL' GOES, SO GO TV PROFITS AND CAREERS
description: It is a force so powerful that it can ruin Dan Rather in Cleveland and make him a hero in New York on the same day. It can make or break careers, dash or confirm the cleverest programming strategy.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Allied Stores Corp. announced that its president, Elliot J. Stone, had been promoted to chairman of Jordan Marsh Co. New England, its 18-store division, and would continue as chief executive and that Richard F. Van Pelt, executive vice president-control and operations, had been promoted to president and chief operating officer.

title: ALEUTIAN EARTHQUAKE SPURS EXTENSIVE SEA WAVE ALERTS
description: A series of earthquakes beneath the sea south of the Aleutian Islands today prompted warnings of tsunamis in Japan, Hawaii, and along the west coast of North America from Alaska to Mexico.

title: VITAL PRIMARY SIGNALS
description: The primaries in Texas, Ohio and North Carolina produced no surprises, but some analysts say the results have set up general election campaigns that will test the ability of both Democrats and Republicans to manage a new set of regional economic issues.

description: An explosion from a bomb rocked a shopping center in a suburb north of Johannesburg today, shattering windows but causing no injuries, the police and witnesses said.

title: Aquino Gives Insurgents 6 Months to Hold Talks
description: President Corazon C. Aquino said today that the leaders of the Communist insurgency had not yet responded to her offer to hold talks and that she would give them about six months to do so.

All the President's Bees
description: The White House has all kinds of contingency plans for sudden developments in a complex world, but the architects of changing events were at a loss when a swarm of bees invaded the South Lawn. How do you handle 20,000 angry bees? The answer, of course, is gingerly, but no one seemed to know just who was supposed to do the handling.

title: STOCKHOLDER SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
OPERA: 'LA GIOCONDA'
description: ''LA GIOCONDA'' does not hold the place in the repertory that it once did, which one would like to believe is because the public now recognizes Ponchielli's opera as an inferior specimen of its blood-and-thunder type. Actually, however, the work is likely to be revived occasionally whenever a soprano voice capable of handling its heavy demands turns up on the international scene. That happenstance undoubtedly explains why Eve Queler and her Opera Orchestra of New York chose to close its season Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall with a concert version of ''La Gioconda.'' Available to fill the title role was the stentorian-toned Bulgarian soprano Ghena Dimitrova, whose New York debut in ''Nabucco'' during Miss Queler's 1983-84 season aroused extraordinary interest.

title: WORKING PARENTS, MODEST DREAMS
description: Morning is the hardest part of the day for Lourdes Garcia. It is then, tired after a night spent punching data into computers at the Manhattan District Attorney's office, that she dresses her 4-year-old son, Joseph, cups his hand inside hers and takes him to the Virginia Day Nursery.

title: How the Proposals Compare with Current Law
description: President Reagan has supported the basic principles of the House bill passed last December but opposes several of the specific elements. He wants a top individual tax rate of no more than 35 percent; a personal exemption of no lower than $2,000 for lower- and middle-income taxpayers, and more favorable business depreciation rules. After passage of the Senate Finance Committee tax bill early Wednesday morning, the President said he believed he could support that bill but has some ''questions'' about unspecified elements. Current lawfor 1986 House bill Senate Finance Committee bill INDIVIDUAL TAX RATES: 14 rate brackets from 11% to 50% Four rate brackets: 15%, 25%, 35%, 38% Two rate brackets: 15%, 27% EXEMPTIONS: Self, spouse, dependents $1,080 $1,500 for those who itemize deductions; $2,000 for non-itemizers For all but wealthiest taxpayers, $1,900 in 1987 and $2,000 in 1988 STANDARD DEDUCTIONS: Single returns $2,480 $2,950 $3,000 Joint returns $3,670 $4,800 $5,000 Heads of households $2,480 $4,200 $4,400 INDEXING FOR INFLATION: Adjusting tax-rate brackets and increasing personal exemptions and standard deductions for inflation Yes Yes Yes PERSONAL DEDUCTIONS:

description: THE singing team of Marion Cowings and Kim Shaw is somewhat of a novelty in a jazz club such as Fat Tuesday's, where they appeared yesterday and Tuesday. The only singers who might be compared with them are Jackie Cain and Roy Kral, but there are distinct differences.

title: A Tax Triumph for All Americans
description: Sometimes, against all odds, the good guys win. In spite of intense lobbying by special interests and in spite of seeming public apathy, the Senate Finance Committee has voted to revolutionize a tax system that Jimmy Carter was right to call ''a disgrace to the human race.'' It's a victory that re-ignites visions. Maybe the tax system can yet, after all, be made simpler, fairer and more efficient for all Americans.

title: In the Soviet Union, Many Shcharanskys
description: Anatoly B. Shcharansky arrives in New York today, his first trip abroad since he left the Soviet Union for Israel in February. Mr. Shcharansky has come home to Israel, and he is free to travel as he likes, but the plight of Soviet Jews persists.

description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $60,641,000 for the latest quarter and $39,362,000 for the year-ago period.

title: Scores of Confessions Of a Killer Called Bogus
description: Numerous killers are free because the authorities have been fooled or have accepted bogus murder confessions from a condemned killer, Henry Lee Lucas, just to clear cases, Attorney General Jim Mattox of Texas said today.

title: AC&R Gets Konica
description: Konica Professional and Consumer Products division, Konica U.S.A. announced the appointment of AC&R Advertising as its agency for the company's photographic film, paper, cameras and mini-lab equipment. Billings are expected to be more than $1.5 million. The previous agency was Warner Bicking & Fenwick.

title: HOUSE DEMOCRATS LINK TAX RISE TO G.O.P. SUPPORT
description: Democrats on the House Budget Committee intend to propose a revenue increase for the 1987 budget more than twice as large as President Reagan proposed, but they say the additional amount will be dropped if Republicans refuse to support it on the floor.

title: Actor Backs Accord In Drilling Off Coast
description: Some oil companies and environmental organizations have reached agreement under the sponsorship of the actor Robert Redford on what areas of the Bering Sea should be offered for oil and gas exploration, the Interior Department said today.

title: Evicting Family Members or Roommates Is No Gain for Housing

title: BUCKS ACHIEVE 3-2 LEAD
description: Paul Pressey scored 13 of his 23 points in the fourth quarter, and Terry Cummings converted three free throws in the last 14 seconds, pacing Milwaukee to a 113-108 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers tonight and giving the Bucks a 3-2 edge in their playoff series.

title: RALPH LAUREN AND OSCAR DE LA RENTA: A GOOD DAY FOR FASHION
description: BETWEEN Ralph Lauren and Oscar de la Renta, yesterday was a good day for fashion.

title: Fred Cole, Historian; Led Library Council
description: Fred Carrington Cole, a scholar of Southern history and former president of the Council on Library Resources and of Washington & Lee University, died of congestive heart failure Tuesday at his home in Chapel Hill, N.C. He was 74 years old.

title: EUROPE ACTS TO BAN FOOD FROM EAST
description: A group of European Community experts agreed today to ban imports of fresh food products from Eastern Europe because of the dangers of radioactive contamination from the Chernobyl nuclear disaster.

title: Internal Bleeding Kills A Transplant Patient
description: Mary D. Gohlke, who lived five years with the transplanted heart and lungs of a teen-ager killed in a traffic accident, died Tuesday of internal bleeding that apparently started when she tripped and fell over a cord at her home, doctors said. She was 50 years old.

title: Japan Joining the World?
description: The Tokyo summit will go down as a milestone, some participants said a ''threshold,'' toward a new level of acceptance that the world's economy is inextricably linked.

description: To the Editor:

title: Regional Magazine Set By Arkansas Publisher
description: Alan Leveritt, a Little Rock, Ark., publisher of Arkansas Times magazine, is moving from statewide to regional with a new publication called Southern magazine, which he intends to be a combination of the literary qualities of The New Yorker and the regional flavor of Texas Monthly. That would make it attractive to both men and women readers - unlike Southern Living and Southern Accents, he said, because both of them are ''skewed to women.''

title: For Gymnastics, A Hard Tumble
description: The University of Oregon, faced with one of those sports-budget squeezes that seem to be afflicting a growing number of schools, has dropped its swimming program and women's gymnastics as well. The announcement came Tuesday - ''a sad day for Oregon athletics,'' said the athletic director, Bill Byrne - and marked the latest of the cutbacks that have brought a longterm decline in member colleges' participation in a variety of ''nonrevenue'' N.C.A.A. sports.

title: WEBB, DEL E INVESTMENT PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: No comparable first quarter 1985 figures were available since the real estate investment trust was formed in the third quarter of 1985.

title: ORESAR SAVORS HIS UPSET OVER GOMEZ
description: Bruno Oresar's brush with greatness was brief but noteworthy. It came in the interview room when Ivan Lendl, the top-ranked tennis player in the world, walked past him on the way out. Oresar, his long blond hair matted with sweat but his mood buoyant, could appreciate the moment nonetheless. These players may be a world apart in the rankings, but victory enabled them to occupy common ground yesterday.

description: John S. Dyson, the former chairman of the State Power Authority, is all but certain to seek the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate, Democratic politicians and Dyson aides said yesterday.

description: MacNamara, Clapp & Klein has become the first agency for the Keystone Camera Corporation of Clifton, N.J. So far, the company has sold on price, running no ads. But now it is introducing a line of fashion watches named Le Clic and is willing to put $2 million into advertising.

description: The Phelps Dodge Corporation said yesterday that its 56-year-old president, G. Robert Durham, had been named to the additional post of chief executive.

description: Ray Compton, vice president of operations for the Indiana Pacers, on Sunday's N.B.A. lottery, in which both Boston and Philadelphia will participate: ''It's like playing poker with the Rockefellers and the Kennedys.''

title: Grenfell Adds Trading Unit
description: Morgan Grenfell Inc. has formed a new capital markets group to initiate and execute domestic and international debt securities transactions. It also announced on Tuesday the appointment of a team of six executives, formerly with Chemical Bank Capital Markets, to manage the new group's activities.

title: MUSIC: VASARY CONDUCTS DAVIES'S 'ORKNEY' WORK
description: PETER MAXWELL DAVIES has composed in a variety of forms, including the symphony, but he seems particularly drawn to music theater of a bizarre sort. Such works as the chamber drama ''Eight Songs for a Mad King'' and the full-fledged opera ''The Lighthouse'' disclose his dramatic leanings most obviously, but virtually all his pieces draw on and exploit a story line, often with dark undertones. ''An Orkney Wedding, With Sunrise,'' which the American Symphony Orchestra played last night at Carnegie Hall under Tamas Vasary's direction, is an example of his work in this narrative vein, though it is uncharacteristically blithe in spirit and surprisingly tuneful. Much of the time, in fact, it sounded startlingly like Copland in his ''Appalachian Spring'' mood.

title: N.A.R.B. Questions Comparison by Sterling
description: The National Advertising Review Board announced yesterday that it had found Sterling Drug Inc./Glenbrook Laboratories division's ingredient claim in print, radio and TV ads marginally acceptable, but its brand-to-brand comparison totally unacceptable.

title: SUIT ON GENE-SPLICING DISMISSED
description: A Federal district judge has ruled that the Agriculture Department need not file a statement on the impact the environment might suffer from gene-splicing and other research it finances to improve the productivity of animals.

title: SOCIALIST AND A TOUGH MAYOR
description: Gaston Defferre, the strong-willed Socialist who was longtime Mayor of Marseilles and a former French Interior Minister, died in a Marseilles hospital yesterday after suffering head injuries in a fall at his home. He was 75 years old.

title: Commuter Train Crash In Boston Hurts 200
description: A train packed with commuters slammed into the rear of an idle freight train in the fog this morning, injuring 200 people, nine seriously.

title: A DOCUMENTARY, 'BEYOND SORROW'
description: SOMETIMES ''Beyond Sorrow, Beyond Pain'' is done in by its own excess; often it is self-conscious, looking like a student exercise in film making, which, in a way, it apparently is. Stay with it, however, because eventually it develops a raw, emotive power. The film, the final presentation in Channel 13's ''Channel Crossings'' series, will be seen at 11 o'clock tonight.

description: A tract near Times Square earmarked for a huge wholesale merchandise mart is one of at least five sites being considered for a new NBC headquarters, according to developers, government officials and people in the company.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, MAY 8, 1986
description: The Senate Tax Plan The outlook for tax revision is very bright, members of Congress of both parties said. They contended that the Senate Finance Committee's unanimous approval of a tax bill in the early hours Wednesday meant that comprehensive tax legislation would almost certainly be enacted. President Reagan has already expressed pleasure at the committee's action. But the bill still faces a rough road before it can reach a House-Senate conference. [ Page A1. ] Individuals would get an average 6.2 percent tax cut. The top rate would fall to 27 percent, from 50 percent, and dozens of tax benefits would be eliminated under the proposal. [ A1. ] Wall Street is concerned because capital gains on investments would be treated like any other income and deductions for investments in Individual Retirement Accounts would end for people covered by a company pension. [ D22. ] The Senate bill would not raise corporate income taxes as much as previous proposals. [ D22. ] Markets The Treasury completed the second part of a $27 billion auction by selling 10-year notes at an average yield of 7.47 percent, the lowest rate since the Government began selling 10-year issues in 1976. Institutional buying was not enthusiastic, but there was buying by securities dealers and speculators who expect lower interest rates and higher prices. [ D1. ] Yields at banks fell in the week. [ D15. ] The dollar fell to another postwar low of 164.10 yen in New York.

title: BOMBING IN SRI LANKA CAPITAL KILLS 11
description: A bomb exploded today in Sri Lanka's Central Telegraph Office, killing at least 11 people and wounding more than 115, 20 of them critically, the police said.

title: Trade Talks With Japan
description: Japan has agreed to a request by the United States to hold talks on trade liberalization in transportation equipment, including auto parts, Representative Sander M. Levin, Democrat of Michigan, said today.

title: Explain, Explain, Explain
description: It is an old complaint among elected representatives: Nobody really understands their districts. But maybe Jaime B. Fuster, Puerto Rico's delegate in Congress, has better grounds than most to plead the case.

title: Hearing on Waste Set By Connecticut Town
description: A businessman's effort to build a large incinerator and ash landfill in the rural eastern Connecticut town of Lisbon cleared a hurdle Tuesday night.

title: POLAND ASSAILS WEST, BUT NOT MOSCOW, ON REACTOR
description: The Government assailed the West this week on the grounds that it sought propaganda gains from the Chernobyl reactor accident in the Ukraine, but there was not a word of complaint against Moscow for its responsibility in the disaster.

title: More Plastic Cars
description: The General Motors Corporation said that it would probably be producing one million plastic-body cars a year by 1990, which would have major implications for the American steel industry. One million cars, at current sales rates, represents more than 20 percent of G.M.'s car production. Robert Costello, G.M.'s executive director of purchasing, said today at a meeting of the Steel Service Center Institute, ''We are looking at the likelihood that GM may produce as many as one million cars with plastic outer panels by 1990, which is up from 150,000 this year.''

title: CONVERT HAILS VISIT BY POPE TO SYNAGOGUE
description: Jean-Marie Cardinal Lustiger, a convert from Judaism who is the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Paris, told a midtown luncheon audience yesterday that Pope John Paul II's recent goodwill visit to a synagogue gave visible expression to many years of ecumenical efforts by Christians and Jews.

title: CANAL COUNTDOWN IS RUNNING: IS PANAMA READY?

It was the realization of a long-delayed dream that went to the heart of Panamanian national sovereignty.

Neither the musicians nor audiences - what there were of them - were ready for the contemporary American or even British music he wanted to play.

description: The managers of the program to seek a defense against long-range missiles say they realize they must not only design devices that work but must also find some way to drive down the cost dramatically.

title: Q&A
description: Q. It takes an inordinately long time for the water to get hot when our bathroom faucet is turned on. This wastes water and is annoying when you are in a hurry. Is there anything we can do? A. This is not uncommon. There is a lot of pipe between the water heater in your basement or utility room and the bathroom. When the hot water hasn't been on for some time, the pipes are full of cold water, and it has to run out first.

title: Jets Go to Camp
description: Dan Radakovich brought his rebuilt, revamped, and restructured offensive line - excluding the two highly acclaimed rookies - to the field for the first time yesterday. It was the first day of the Jet veterans' minicamp in Hempstead, L.I. Radakovich has switched from coaching the linebackers to running the offensive line.
