title: Giant Group's 10% Stake in TRE
description: Giant Group Ltd., the cement manufacturer, disclosed that it holds about 10 percent of the TRE Corporation's 6.6 million shares outstanding. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Giant Group, based in Harleyville, S.C., said it had purchased the TRE shares for investment purposes but added that it might purchase additional shares in the Los Angeles-based aerospace design and engineering company through various means, including a possible tender offer or merger.

title: INDIANS HALT ROYALS FOR 10 IN ROW, 7-1
description: Pat Tabler doubled in two runs and scored on Mel Hall's double in the fifth inning tonight, helping the Cleveland Indians stretch their winning streak to 10 games with a 7-1 victory over the Kansas City Royals.

title: No Way to Judge Refugees
description: Last August, a 20-year-old Czechoslovak named Petr Klima defected to the United States. It was a daring defection, complete with a secret meeting in a West German forest and 10 days of hiding out in hotel rooms in as many different cities. Even before arriving in America, Mr. Klima applied for and received political asylum.

title: Drug Rumors Surface
description: The officer in charge of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police's drug squad says the force has information that certain Edmonton Oilers have used drugs, according to a report in Sports Illustrated. ''We do not have evidence to lay charges, but we have information that there are users on the club,'' Staff Sergeant Hal Johnson told the magazine.

description: In decades past, West Virginians pointed to the gilded dome of their State Capitol as a symbol of the considerable pride they have always taken in their state.

description: Lord Shinwell, a fiery veteran of the trade union movement who became a Labor peer, died at his home in London today at the age of 101, his family said.

title: JAY LENO COMEDY SPECIAL ON CABLE
description: EXCEPT for his pink shirt and silver jacket, Jay Leno could be the friendly fellow down the street, waiting to take over his father's hardware business. It is always a bit of a surprise to learn that he earns his living by telling jokes. Having honed his comedy act in New York clubs and on David Letterman's late-night NBC show, among other places, Mr. Leno now has his own pay-cable special. ''Jay Leno and the American Dream'' can be seen on Showtime tonight at 7. He is just about unique among contemporary comic performers for having material that, uncensored, can be scheduled in the early-evening family entertainment hours.

title: IMPROVING HIS GAME
description: It may be difficult to comprehend continued improvement by Dwight Gooden, but that appears to be what's happening. Based on his statistics for the first six games this season, he is staying in games longer than in his first two seasons and giving up fewer runs, earned runs, hits and walks per appearance. His average strikeouts are down, but that simply means fewer pitches thrown - a shorter day at the office, as it were.

title: Ill-Timed Long-Term Aid for Pakistan
description: Congress soon is to act on an Administration request for a six-year, $4.02 billion assistance program for Pakistan. A close look at Pakistan suggests this aid is ill-timed and may prove contrary to our foreign policy interests and democracy in Pakistan.

title: VILAS DOESN'T FEEL NOSTALGIC
description: An occasional trip into the past can rekindle fond memories. But sometimes, Guillermo Vilas said, it can be painful. It can shatter a romantic notion of the way it was or was perceived to be. By his recollection, Forest Hills was a sprawling tennis palace where thousands cheered and the atmosphere could be intimidating. This week, Vilas has found it to be a quaint club, a nice place to play tennis, but obviously no longer big enough to accommodate a modern-day Grand Slam event, despite its tradition.

title: FOX PLANS 'BEVERLY HILLS' TV SERIES
description: ''Down and Out in Beverly Hills,'' 1986's first box-office hit, will be turned into a half-hour situation comedy to be shown in prime time by the newly announced Fox Broadcasting Company.

title: SCREEN: 'SHORT CIRCUIT'
description: MOVIE robots come in all sizes, shapes and states of mental and emotional fitness. Some are lovably comic, like R2D2 and C3PO, the Laurel and Hardy of the ''Star Wars'' trilogy. Some are vengeful, disembodied intelligences like HAL, the computer in ''2001.'' Some, like those in ''Blade Runner'' and ''The Terminator,'' are humanoids. They resemble ordinary people until they crack open to reveal a tangle of wires and micro chips. Those in ''Sleeper'' look like mournful penguins.

title: BLUES WIN, TIE SERIES
description: Rick Meagher scored two goals, the second while his team was short-handed, to lead the St. Louis Blues to a 5-2 victory over the Calgary Flames tonight and even their best-of-seven Stanley Cup semifinal series at two games each.

title: The Arab World Is Sitting It Out
description: Among the loudest voices heard in the debate over the merits of the air strike on Libya were those forecasting an eruption of anti-Americanism throughout the Arab world. Arab inaction in the aftermath of the raid has given the lie to these forecasts.

title: New Kodak X-Ray
description: The Eastman Kodak Company has introduced a new X-ray system to detect breast cancer that it says cuts radiation exposure by 60 percent. The new process is similar to using faster film and a more sensitive camera to get better photographs with less light.

title: THE SECRET MANDATE
description: Every little scandal has a rhythm of its own.

title: TSUNAMI: SIGN OF SHIFTING SEA FLOOR
description: In 1946 the Aleutian Islands were struck by an earthquake of slightly less magnitude than the most severe one that occurred Wednesday; it was centered farther east along the chain but in a comparable geologic setting. In the islands, it toppled the Scotch Cap Lighthouse and its five occupants into the sea; thousands of miles away, it generated the most destructive Pacific Ocean tsunami, or ''tidal wave,'' in recent times.

title: HOUSE PANEL VOTES '87 BUDGET LEVELS
description: The House Budget Committee tonight approved a 1987 budget plan that cuts the President's military budget below this year's level and raises revenue by $13.2 billion, the amount voted by the Senate.

title: PERSISTENCE OF BILL BRADLEY IS PAYING OFF
description: For five years, Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey has been trying to build support in Congress and across the country for dramatic changes in the tax code, including much lower rates and the elimination of most itemized deductions.

title: HE MUST REPAY $375,000
description: Albert King was declared a free agent yesterday and was ordered to repay the Nets $375,000, a portion of his 1985-86 season earnings. The action came after the National Basketball Association had challenged a $3.3 million, five-year offer made to him by the Knicks.

title: INDUSTRIES SEE BOTH WINNERS AND LOSERS IF BILL BECOMES LAW; A RADICAL SHIFT IS EXPECTED IN REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT
description: While business in general and many consumer groups say they are satisfied with the sweeping tax plan approved this week by the Senate Finance Committee, a number of trade and industry groups are starting to voice alarm over some of the plan's provisions.

description: New York can be a forbidding place for first-time foreign visitors, but apparently not for one West German couple. Every time they turned around, one New Yorker or another seemed to be going out of his way to be helpful.

description: MICHEL FOKINE and George Balanchine, two of 20th-century ballet's greatest innovators, were trained in Russian ballet's stronghold of tradition, the Maryinsky Ballet - now the Kirov.

description: The director of the city's Emergency Medical Service said yesterday that the agency had paid an additional $10,000 apiece for 100 ambulances because the low bidder had not met specifications that were changed to keep up with new technology.

title: Identity Crisis At a Ball Park
description: In 1977, the City of Memphis held a ceremony in which the baseball stadium was renamed for Tim McCarver, a hometown boy who at the time was still engaged in a 21-year major-league career. After his retirement in 1980, though, McCarver's job as a television announcer - first with the Phillies, now with the Mets - took him away from his birthplace and removed him somewhat from local consciousness, or at least from George Lapides's consciousness.

description: Three noted writers - E. L. Doctorow, Joyce Carol Oates and James Dickey - will take part in a free conference on literature tomorrow at the Loeb Student Center at New York University, Washington Square at La Guardia Place. It opens at 2 P.M. with a discussion on ''Theories of Genre,'' featuring faculty members from Harvard, Cornell and the State University of New York. Information: 598-7560.

title: AIDE'S ROLE ON ASBESTOS IS QUESTIONED
description: A White House aide has told Canadian officials that the Office of Management and Budget would try to block rules proposed by environmental officials banning the use of asbestos, according to a Canadian Government document made public today.

title: FAR FROM MANILA, THEY'RE FIGHTING FOR CITY HALL
description: Zamboanga has coconut palms, sandy beaches, clear water, fresh fish and papayas and lots of sunshine.

title: Reuss Laughs Last
description: Fed up with repeated rumors that he would be traded by the Los Angeles Dodgers, Jerry Reuss decided he could get a few laughs out of the situation. The left-handed starting pitcher had heard that the Yankees were interested in acquiring him, so Reuss saw his golden opportunity on Tuesday in Chicago after the Dodgers played the Cubs in the afternoon and the Yankees prepared to oppose the White Sox that night.

title: BRAVES' MURPHY HITS 2 HOMERS
description: Dale Murphy hit two home runs to account for five runs as the Atlanta Braves routed Cincinnati, 10-5, today, handing the Reds their 10th loss in their last 11 games.

title: MATTEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $8,000,000. Preferred stock dividend requirements exceeded net income in the latest quarter.

title: INCREASED SCRUTINY OF FOREIGN INVESTORS BACKED
description: Democrats on a House panel expressed support today for legislation that would provide greater scrutiny of foreign investments in the United States, but Administration officials warned that the bill would discourage needed foreign funds.

title: Toronto Symphony
description: Andrew Davis will lead the Toronto Symphony in music by Mendelssohn, Stravinsky and Rachmaninoff tomorrow at 8 P.M. at Carnegie Hall.

title: INEXCO OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Reflects a charge of $81.3 million for the writedown of oil and gas reserves. c-Net income

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: James Cleveland and Dorothy Norwood, the Apollo Theater, 253 West 125th Street (682-4110). This weekend, the patriarch of modern gospel will rejoin one of his earliest collaborators for concerts that should make the Apollo's rafters shake. James Cleveland and Dorothy Norwood sang together in the Caravans during the 1950's, establishing them both on the gospel circuit. Mr. Cleveland went on to revitalize gospel music, joining his rough-hewn baritone voice to arrangements that keep on building with propulsive piano and organ riffs and inventive call-and-response singing, borrowing from (and later reshaping) soul and rock music. Miss Norwood, meanwhile, built a career on story-songs that she belts out in a raspy, emotive voice. Since Mr. Cleveland recently produced an album for Miss Norwood, they're likely to sing together as well as with their own groups. Tonight at 8 o'clock and tomorrow at 8 and 11 P.M.; tickets are $5 to $25.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: EAST meets West in a collision of colors and cuisine at the rakish new Cafe Japonais on East 58th Street between Park and Madison Avenues. This month-old establishment is already drawing legions of curiosity seekers to its open and airy two-level dining room and sushi bar done in brash aqua with a gold tile ceiling, a hand-painted mural of sumo wrestlers and funky color-splashed chairs.

title: M.D.C. Puts Yield Of Notes at 11.75%
description: M.D.C. Holdings, a home-building company based in Denver, is offering $440 million of 11 1/4 percent senior subordinated notes due in 1996 at a price of 97.10, to yield 11.75 percent, through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert.

title: U.S. JUDGE CITES CATHOLIC GROUPS FOR CONTEMPT
description: The two principal national organizations of the Roman Catholic Church in the United States were held in contempt of court yesterday by a Federal judge in Manhattan.

title: LORD SHINWELL, A FIERY FIGURE IN BRITISH POLITICS, DIES AT 101
description: Lord Shinwell, a fiery veteran of the trade union movement who became a Labor peer, died at his home in London today. He was 101 years old.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: ''F ILM schools realize that the changes in the technology and, at the same time, in the whole film and television business are very dramatic and that the need for technically skilled film makers is actually diminishing,'' said Frantisek Daniel. ''But what is needed is people with ideas.''

title: New York Cabaret Law an Anachronism
description: To the Editor:

title: SENATORS ON PANEL SHARPLY CRITICAL OF SPACE PROGRAM'S MANAGEMENT
description: Management of the nation's space program was sharply criticized and questioned today at a hearing before a Senate committee.

title: New Afghan Leader Orders A Drive Against Corruption
description: Afghanistan's new Communist Party leader, Najibullah, today ordered a drive against mounting corruption in the country, the official Kabul radio said.

title: Eruption Alert Issued For Mount St. Helens
description: Earthquake activity at Mount St. Helens has increased, and a dome-building eruption is likely in the next few days, a scientist said today.

description: b-Includes a tax credit of $175,500.

title: COCA-COLA FILLS ATLANTA WITH A CLELBRATION OF ITS CENTENNIAL
description: One hundred years after an Atlanta pharmacist, John Styth Pemberton, mixed up the first sticky batch in a backyard cooker, the people who run the Coca-Cola Company are throwing a birthday party with almost 24,000 guests to help them celebrate.

THE RANGERS: STAYING ALIVE
description: The new stitches provided the answer, but the question needed to be asked, anyway. Was it a good idea for James Patrick to pull off his helmet before fighting Claude Lemieux Wednesday night?

title: Traces of Radioactivity Are Detected in Albany
description: Minute amounts of iodine 131, radioactive waste from the nuclear accident in the Soviet Union, have been detected in samples of rainwater gathered Wednesday in Albany, state officials reported yesterday.

title: Branca-Davis Concert
description: Glenn Branca and Anthony Davis, who combine jazz and rock with classical forms, will present a concert of new works at Alice Tully Hall Sunday night at 8. Tickets are $12; information: 362-1911.

title: THE WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday THE NEW-MUSIC MAKERS New-music groups are said to come and go, but Speculum Musicae, the New York chamber-music ensemble, has played avant-garde works for 15 years, and to continual acclaim. Tonight, in a commemoration by the Brooklyn Philharmonic of the talent and staying power of the group's 13 members, Speculum Musicae will appear in the final performance of the philharmonic's Meet the Moderns series. The performance is to include works by Roger Sessions, Toru Takemitsu, Alvaro Cordero and Lukas Foss, the conductor and music director of the Brooklyn Philharmonic. The guest soloist is the soprano Judith Bettina. The concert begins at 8 P.M. in the Great Hall at Cooper Union, on Seventh Street at Third Avenue. Tickets are $7.50 ($5 for students and the elderly). Information: (718) 636-4120.

title: BURROUGHS IS SEEKING TO OVERHAUL ITS IMAGE
description: In the six years since W. Michael Blumenthal took command of the Burroughs Corporation, he has rejuvenated the company's computer offerings, slashed its overhead, focused its attention on lucrative new markets - and still failed to garner either significant profits or a larger share of the computer market.

title: NORTHGATE EXPLORATION LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Chinese Oil Exports
description: A senior Chinese official was quoted today as saying Peking would freeze oil exports to support the efforts of the Organization of Oil Exporting Countries to stabilize the world oil market.

title: Pirates Release Kemp
description: Steve Kemp, a left-handed-hitting outfielder who compiled a batting average of .280 and hit 129 home runs in nine seasons with the Detroit Tigers, the Chicago White Sox, the Yankees and the Pittsburgh Pirates, yesterday was placed on waivers by the Pirates for the purpose of giving him his unconditional release. Kemp, 31 years old, was hitting .188 with one home run in 13 games.

title: Ruth Casa-Emellos, 88, Dies; Kitchen Expert at The Times
description: Ruth P. Casa-Emellos, a former home economist for The New York Times, died of pneumonia Saturday at a nursing home in Winston-Salem, N.C. She was 88 years old and lived in Winston-Salem.

title: Rebels Claim Bombing Of Office in Sri Lanka
description: Tamil guerrillas asserted responsibility today for bombing the main telegraph office in Colombo, and they predicted more violence unless the Government ends its campaign against Tamil separatists.

title: FUNDSNET INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Advertising; Bologna International Loses 4 Co-Founders
description: Four of the co-founders of Bologna International, a health care ad agency, in 1980, have left to found Girgenti, Hughes, Butler & McDowell.

title: CRIMINAL INQUIRY CLEARS GROSS
description: The special state prosecutor for criminal justice in New York City, ending a 15-month inquiry, said yesterday that he had found no evidence that the city's Chief Medical Examiner committed any crime in handling the cases of seven people who died in police custody between 1980 and 1984.

title: Brooklyn Heights Stroll
description: A stroll this weekend along the Brooklyn Heights promenade will provide more than a lovely view of lower Manhattan.

title: As Moynihan Sees It
description: Perhaps only Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan could have managed the comparison. In a forthcoming article in The New Republic, the New York Democrat concludes that philosophical extremists are endangering both political parties: Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. on the Democratic side with his ''neo-fascist Jew-baiting conspiratorial ideas'' and David A. Stockman on the Republican side with his ideas, at least until he left Government, of encouraging large Federal deficits to force spending cuts. ''Our ideological immune system is not working very well in either party,'' Mr. Moynihan said.

description: b-Includes a writedown of vessels and other assets of $26,959,000. c-Net income.

title: Tasso to Skip Preakness
description: Tasso, who passed up the Kentucky Derby last Saturday because of minor injuries but looked fully recovered running a strong second in the Withers Stakes at Aqueduct Wednesday, will also skip the Preakness Stakes on May 17, his trainer announced today.

title: PHILADELPHIA GRAND JURY TO STUDY DEATHS IN POLICE SIEGE OF RADICALS
description: The Philadelphia District Attorney announced tonight that he would call a special grand jury to investigate whether top city officials and others should face criminal charges for their actions in last May's confrontation with the radical group Move.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CALIFORNIA (AL) - Gary Pettis, center fielder, has been suspended for two games by the American League for bumping Umpire John Shulock in a game in Milwaukee May 1. The suspension takes effect today.

title: How a Blind Ad Led To Aamco's Presidency
description: Abraham Bernstein, who answered a blind employment advertisement in 1967 at Aamco Transmissions Inc., has been named president and chief operating officer of the company.

title: SHULTZ REBUFFS MANILA'S AID REQUEST
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that it was impossible for the United States to meet President Corazon C. Aquino's public appeal for a huge aid program to rescue her nation's economy.

title: U.S. TOPIC AT GENEVA: VERIFYING LIMITS ON MISSILES
description: The United States intends to discuss in greater detail ways to verify limits on medium-range mobile missiles in the new round of Geneva arms talks that began today, Reagan Administration officials say.

title: IIS INTELLIGENT INFORMAION SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Mariners Dismiss Cottier
description: The Seattle Mariners, losers of 16 of their last 20 games, dismissed Manager Chuck Cottier today, the team announced. Chuck Armstrong, the team's president, said a new manager would be named in ''a few days,'' and reports indicated the choice would be Dick Williams, who has managed five major league teams.

title: Four Women to Read
description: Four writers - Fay Chiang, Cheryl Clarke, Toi Dericote and Rosario Morales - will read from their works on Sunday at 4 P.M. at the Central Presbyterian Church, 593 Park Avenue, at 64th Street.

title: Market Place; Nuclear Power Alternatives
description: THE Chernobyl nuclear plant disaster may have resulted in an indirect benefit for companies that provide other forms of energy.

title: WILFRED AMER EDUCATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Recalling R.F. Kennedy
description: A group of lawyers and others who worked for Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy in the Department of Justice when his brother John was President have decided to have a party later this month to celebrate the 25th anniversary of the start of that era. Invitations for a May 29 reception and dinner at the City Tavern Club have gone out under the names of Joseph T. Dolan, now director of the Colorado Department of Highways; John W. Douglas and William A. Geoghegan, both Washington lawyers, and Louis F. Oberdorfer, a Federal District judge in the District of Columbia.

title: Ex-Illinois State Judge Guilty in Court Inquiry
description: A former state judge was found guilty Wednesday of 36 counts of racketeering and other charges, making him the fifth judge convicted in a Federal investigation of corruption in the Cook County court system.

title: FILM: 'DANGEROUSLY CLOSE,' BY PYUN
description: VISTA Verde High School is your typical southern California suburban public school. It's got rich kids, poor kids, rebels and troublemakers. It's also got a clean-cut squad of activists, called the Sentinels, who want to tidy it up. They begin by scrubbing the graffiti off the walls, but their extracurricular activities don't stop there. Dizzy with their own sense of virtue they try - by somewhat radical means - to persuade some of their classmates to tow the Sentinel line. They carry knives and guns and dress up in black hoods and leather face masks to terrorize and torture their fellow students. This leads to absenteeism and a high dropout rate at Vista Verde High. But since the few adults shown are either hopelessly inept, indifferent or psychotic, it takes a long time for anyone to notice.

title: Speculation on Accident In Soviet Spurs Prices
description: Renewed speculation over the seriousness of the Soviet nuclear accident and the expectation that it will lead to higher Soviet grain imports from the West sparked spirited rallies in commodities markets today.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Vintage Jazz at the Vineyard, 309 East 26th Street (683-0696). On Sunday, Dick Sudhalter's series celebrating the jazz styles of the 1920's and 30's and even the 40's, played by seasoned practitioners of the music, turns to what Mr. Sudhalter calls ''the new pioneers'' - the younger generation of jazz musicians who will, as Mr. Sudhalter says, ''carry this whole heritage of ours forward to a new generation of listeners.'' Sunday's ''new pioneers'' are the trumpeter Peter Ecklund and his trio, who will give a concert at 5:30 P.M., and the saxophonist-clarinetist Ken Peplowski, who leads his quartet at an 8:30 P.M. recital. Each program will consist of two hours of music and a midpoint discussion with the musicians about the vintage jazz they play. The evening will wind up with a jam session involving both groups. Tickets for each concert are $8 for general admission or $12 for a table and complimentary bottle of wine. For both concerts, general admission is $14, or $20 for a table and the wine. For reservations, the numbers to call are the box office (683-0696) or Chargit (944-9300).

title: Accepted at City College
description: It is a favorite story that former Mayor Robert F. Wagner likes to tell.

title: 'MY MOTHER MARRIED WILBUR STUMP'
description: PASSING up the pink carnations, fancy boxes of candy or any other traditional trappings of Mother's Day, Channel 13 is presenting - this Sunday at 11:30 P.M. - a video family album entitled ''My Mother Married Wilbur Stump.'' It was compiled by Skip Sweeney, a founder of San Francisco's Video Free America, an alternative media facility.

title: CRABLE TAKING A CRASH COURSE
description: While everyone on the Jets watches the unfolding soap opera on the offensive line, there is another unit that has worried Coach Joe Walton nearly as much - the linebackers.

title: Peru Says It Detained 38,000 During Curfews
description: The Peruvian War Minister said in an interview published today that the military, fighting an upsurge in urban guerrilla violence, had detained 38,111 people and shot dead 4 people in the last three months for curfew violations in Lima.

title: Dangers of Prescribing Mind-Bending Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: OPEC Output Rise Seen
description: OPEC has sharply increased oil output in the last two weeks to defend what it considers a fair share of the market, a top minister of the 13-nation Organization of Oil Exporting Countries was quoted as saying.

title: EXECUTIVES CHANGES
description: * A. H. Belo Corporation, Dallas, which owns several newspapers, radio and television stations, announced that Dealey D. Herndon had been elected to the board of directors for a three-year term.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE BLOODY CROSSROADS: Where Literature and Politics Meet. By Norman Podhoretz. 221 pages. Simon & Schuster. $16.95. ALTHOUGH he is best known today as a writer on politics, Norman Podhoretz began his professional life as a literary critic, and in the essays gathered together in his latest book he partly resumes his original role. For the most part they are reports from what Lionel Trilling once called, in a phrase that gives the book both its title and subtitle, ''the bloody crossroads where literature and politics meet'' - bloody because writers have so often been the victims of political oppression, no less bloody because so many of them have encouraged or condoned that oppression.

title: AROUND THE NATION
description: Only 3.3 percent of the more than 200,000 public school teachers in Texas failed a statewide competency test, the State Board of Education was told today.

title: Japan and U.S. Must Make Adjustments Together
description: To the Editor:

title: HIJACKING CONVICTIONS UPHELD
description: An appeals court in Genoa today upheld the convictions of three Palestinians accused of hijacking the cruise ship Achille Lauro last fall. The Palestinians, and an accomplice, were convicted on arms charges last November.

title: 'I MARRIED AN ANGEL' BEING REVIVED
description: The New Amsterdam Theater Company, which has just earned a special Drama Desk award ''for bringing back the Golden Age of the American musical in distinguished concert productions,'' will retrieve another nugget next weekend when it presents ''I Married an Angel'' at Town Hall May 17 at 8 P.M., May 18 at 4 and May 19 at 8.

title: Lucile A. Curtis Dead; Foreign Service Pioneer
description: Lucile Atcherson Curtis, the first woman to serve in the United States Foreign Service, died at her home today after a long illness. She was 91 years old.

title: COSMO COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ART: BRITISH INDIA, SOME POIGNANT VIEWS
description: A LATECOMER in the nationwide Festival of India is the exhibition called ''From Merchants to Emperors'' and subtitled ''British Artists and India, 1757-1930,'' which has just opened at the Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street. (It can be seen there through July 31.) Drawn primarily from the holdings of Paul F. Walter, a New York collector with panoramic interests in many fields, it includes watercolors, drawings, prints and early photographs.

title: PROJECTS IN WHITE PLAINS FEATURE CLUSTER HOUSING
description: In 1981, when White Plains adopted what it called conservation zoning, the goal was to encourage better site planning and environmental preservation on remaining large tracts of undeveloped residential land. On tracts of 15 acres or more, the law allows builders to cluster housing, with up to four housing units per structure, if their plans pass muster at the Planning Board as environmentally sound.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: NO, that wasn't a Fellini movie being shot at the Museum of Modern Art on Tuesday night. Yes, there were bright lights and cameras and 500 people babbling in Italian and English, and an assortment of costumes ranging from haute couture to haute SoHo. There were even a few actors (Monica Vitti, Alberto Sordi, Isabella Rossellini), but the directors (Martin Scorsese, James Ivory, Alberto Lattuada) were also part of the scene. So were Blanchette Rockefeller, Donald and Catie Marron, Richard Oldenburg and Lili Auchincloss. It was, of course, a party. A party to celebrate ''Comedy, Italian Style,'' a film retrospective that opens today at the museum.

title: COURT APPROVES EXPULSION ORDER FOR AN L.I. MAN
description: A Federal appeals court in Manhattan yesterday upheld a deportation order against a Long Island man who purportedly commanded a death camp in Nazi-occupied Estonia where 12,000 Eastern Europeans, including 2,000 Jews, were executed.

title: TEACHERS TELL OF DAILY ORDEAL IN CITY SCHOOLS
description: Teachers in New York City often spend their own money for essential classroom supplies, routinely face autocratic principals and frequently are the victims of violence, the president of the United Federation of Teachers said yesterday.

title: TOP STATE COURT UPHOLDS TIMES SQ. RENEWAL
description: The State Court of Appeals unanimously upheld the $2 billion Times Square redevelopment plan yesterday in two strongly worded decisions that dismissed six legal challenges.

title: OXFORD DICTIONARY YIELDS TO WIMMIN, YUPPIES AND YUCK
description: The fourth and final volume of a supplement updating the Oxford English Dictionary was published here today, revealing that the Queen's English these days bristles with Chinese, Yiddish, Indian and other languages.

title: MAN IS CHARGED WITH ARSON
description: A man was charged today with murder and arson in fires at an apartment complex where eight people died trying to escape, including a man found dead in a hall with a flashlight in his hand, the authorities said.

title: 6-DAY-OLD STRIKE ENDS AGAINST SANTA FE RAILROAD
description: A six-day strike against the Atchison, Topeka & Santa Fe Railway ended today after a Federal district judge issued a restraining order barring the railroad from operating trains without union employees.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds rose $1.75 billion, to $224.67 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

description: Debt

Poetry and Music Of India in the Park
description: A free, alfresco presentation of Indian poetry and music will be given tomorrow afternoon at 2 at the Central Park Band Shell, at 72d Street.

title: AS ALL HAITI WATCHES, FIRST DUVALIER AIDE IS TRIED
description: In a cramped and steamy courtroom, the provisional Government has begun the first of what it says will be a series of public criminal trials of officials of the deposed Duvalier Government who are accused of torture, murder and other abuses of power.

title: Dixon Chases 400 Mark Running in 200
description: In 1984, Valerie Brisco-Hooks and Chandra Cheeseborough became the only American women ever to run 400 meters faster than 50 seconds. Diane Dixon of Brooklyn is on target to join them, although she is taking a roundabout way.

title: COOK DATA SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a non-cash, non-tax-deductible charge of $118,000 for the company's share of operating losses attributable to its investment in an emerging company. c-Net income and includes income from discontinued operations of $138,000. The company had no revenue a year ago because it sold its operating subsidiary in July 1985. Therefore, current accounting regulations require historical revenue and expenses of the former subsidiary to be treated as a discontinued operation. The latest quarter's revenue arises from the company's video store operations opened last October.

title: BROADWAY
description: IF a track record means anything, ''The Common Pursuit,'' scheduled to open Off Broadway this fall, should be a winner.

title: F.A.A. SAYS IT WILL SUE
description: Eastern Airlines refused today to pay a proposed $9.5 million civil penalty for alleged violations of aircraft maintenance and safety regulations.

description: b-Net loss.

title: Advertising; President Leaves Post at Carl Byoir-U.S.
description: William Galvin, after a month and a half as president of Carl Byoir-U.S. operations, left the company last Monday.

description: b-Includes charges for the reversal of a tax loss carryforward of $35,000 for the latest quarter and $54,000 in the year-ago quarter. c-Includes a gain of $150,000. d-Net income includes a tax credit of $140,000.

title: RATE STRUCTURE ISSUE RAISED
description: At second glance, the tax-rate structure outlined in the Senate Finance Committee's tax revision plan is neither as low, nor as simple, as advertised.

title: A BIG WEEKEND FOR THE SMALL OPERA TROUPES IN NEW YORK
description: WHEN the Metropolitan Opera closes up shop for the season, opera doesn't; in a way, to an opera watcher in New York, it's like moving aside a big rock to observe the teeming life scurrying about in its shadow. This weekend there are at least 22 operatic performances in the five boroughs, and close calculations reveal that any one operagoer can, through careful planning, hear as many as six different works (though it might mean dashing out of ''Brigadoon'' at the Fashion Institute Theater before the denouement Sunday in order to catch ''Sweethearts'' at the Cherry Lane the same afternoon (see box on page C4 for schedules).

title: TROVES OF TREASURE AT THE AUCTION HOUSES
description: AUCTION-HOUSE browsing, one of the most popular rites of springtime in New York, is expected to hit its peak this weekend when there are more exhibitions and sales of art, prints, photographs, books, Oriental rugs, classic cars and collectibles than at any other time during the year.

title: ZENITH NATIONAL INSURANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a realized gain on investments of $2,543,000. c-Net loss includes a realized gain on investments of $648,000.

title: SYRACUSE SUPPLY CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Guitarists' 'Old Sambas'
description: The guitarist-singer Arto Lindsay and the guitarist Bill Frisell will play a concert called ''Old Sambas in New Settings'' tonight at 8 o'clock at the Center for Inter-American Relations, 680 Park Avenue, at 68th Street (249-8950). Tickets are $12.

title: MOORE PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Trooper Is Sentenced In the Death of Driver
description: A New Jersey state trooper convicted of violating the civil rights of a drunken driver on the New Jersey Turnpike in 1982 by beating him to death was sentenced by a Federal judge today to 10 years in prison.

title: CONCERT: DRUCKMAN PREMIERE
description: THE NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC'S second-to-last program of the season, conducted last evening by Zubin Mehta, ranged from the old to the new to the unusual, with results that were sometimes splendid, sometimes perplexing. Representing the unusual most interestingly was Tchaikovsky's generally neglected and scorned Piano Concerto No. 2, which Jerome Lowenthal played with ardor and evident respect. The appearance of this rarely exhumed piece was remarkable enough, but Mr. Lowenthal went further and played the original, more florid version of the score, which circulated after Tchaikovsky's death, when it circulated at all, in a heavily cut and simplified edition by Alexander Siloti.

title: Charge! They Whose Tax Oxen Have Been Gored
description: First an army of 7,000 real estate agents will assault Capitol Hill from their forward base at the Washington Hilton.

title: INDUSTRIES SEE BOTH WINNERS AND LOSERS IF BILL BECOMES LAW; INTEREST DEDUCTION LIMIT DOESN'T ALARM LENDERS
description: While business in general and many consumer groups say they are satisfied with the sweeping tax plan approved this week by the Senate Finance Committee, a number of trade and industry groups are starting to voice alarm over some of the plan's provisions.

title: THRONG GREETS SHCHARANSKY
description: Anatoly B. Shcharansky arrived in the United States yesterday for a 12-day visit during which he said he would thank the American people and their leaders for their aid in freeing him from imprisonment in the Soviet Union.

title: ORBIT INSTRUMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
COSTA RICAN VOWS TO BE A PEACEMAKER
description: Oscar Arias Sanchez was sworn in today as Costa Rica's 47th President and declared his commitment to a peaceful resolution of the conflicts in Central America.

title: 36 DUTCH SAILING CRAFT TO BE IN LIBERTY FLEET
description: Thirty-six Dutch families with their fleet of flat-bottomed boats, descendants of the vessels built by the original Dutch settlers of New Amsterdam, will cross the Atlantic to take part in the parade of sailing ships during the Statue of Liberty centennial.

title: TRINITY RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Park Bar to Nonresidents To Be Tested in Michigan
description: A circuit judge ruled today that the city of Dearborn could legally pass a law barring nonresidents from its parks, but he held that the question of whether that law promoted racial discrimination required a trial.

title: Guatemala Inoculations
description: Guatemalan health workers will seek to inoculate one million children on the weekend of May 17 and 18, it was announced today.

title: ART: A SARGENT SHOW FOCUSES ON LANDSCAPES
description: A PAINTER of portraits that arouse either admiration or disdain, John Singer Sargent was featured last year as a draftsman, at the National Academy of Design. This year, at Coe Kerr Gallery, 49 East 82d Street, he appears as a landscapist, specifically in England during the years 1883 to 1890. Titled ''Sargent at Broadway, the Impressionist Years,'' the show is a benefit for the Royal Oaks Foundation Inc., an American charity affiliated with the British National Trust - hence the $3 admission.

title: Dr. Albert Forsythe, 88, Dies; Among First Black Aviators
description: Dr. Albert E. Forsythe, a pilot who helped open aviation to blacks in the 1930's, died Tuesday at Beth Israel Hospital in Newark. He was 88 years old and lived in Newark.

title: Economic Scene; New Optimism In Tax Battle
description: SUDDENLY after being down for the nine-count - and indeed after having been counted out by many sophisticates at ringside - a proposal to overhaul and simplify the United States tax system is back on its feet, swinging and with a good chance of winning.

title: CMX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $72,000 for the quarter and $165,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss includes an extraordinary gain of $162,000 from the forgiveness of debt.

title: SPAN-AMERICA MEDICAL SYSEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: DISAPPOINTING CHOICES FOR NEWARK
description: Economic revival, already old news in many Northeastern cities, remains only a fragile, incipient development in Newark. Unfortunately, there is little hope that Tuesday's election will produce a Mayor who can inspire its growth.

title: KENWIN SHOPS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: MORE THAN BAD LUCK AT NASA
description: A remarkable string of catastrophes has now denied America almost all access to space. The shuttle disaster, two Titan rocket failures and the crash of a Delta rocket have effectively crippled the major means of putting payloads in orbit. Is the run of disasters due to bad luck or bad management?

title: Classes in Climbing Offered
description: If you have a desire to sample the thrills and discipline of rock climbing, weekend instruction will be offered this spring, summer and fall by the New York School of Rock Climbing.

title: INDIANS' PATH: WORST TO FIRST
description: Not even the architects of the Cleveland Indians' would-be revival could have predicted the dramatic turnaround the team has achieved.

title: HOUSE UNIT MOVES TO GET RECORDS ON $13 MILLION IN AID TO CONTRAS
description: A House panel, trying to discover what happened to $13 million in nonlethal aid to Nicaraguan rebels, voted unanimously today to subpoena the records of bank accounts in which the money was deposited.

title: LOEWS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes investment gains of $13.7 million and a loss of $1.5 million from a change in pension accounting methods. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $2.9 million and investment gains of $45.4 million.

title: SAN/BAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income after an extraordinary credit of $8,590,000 from the settlement of a lawsuit.

title: XCOR INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $190,000. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $2,000 and a tax credit of $51,000.

title: TEMPO ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-earlier period's results were restated to reflect a pooling of interest acquisition. The company was formerly called Satellite Syndicated Systems Inc.

title: PETER RODINO AND SPECIAL INTERESTS
description: Immigration reform, says Brooklyn's Representative Charles Schumer, is a ''metaphor for governance . . . Can the general interest transcend the specific interest?'' And how! is the answer Senate Finance Chairman Bob Packwood has just given for tax reform. The same could still be true for immigration reform - except that the movement is backward. This was the week the bill was supposed to go to the House. What it produced instead was five suspicious weeks of more delay.

title: Advertising; Addendum
description: * Penthouse International has purchased Four Wheeler, an automotive magazine published in Canoga Park, Calif.

title: BIG SEA WAVE IS A WASHOUT FOR HAWAII AND NORTHWEST
description: Tens of thousands of people hurried to high ground in Hawaii, Alaska, Oregon, Washington and California after the Pacific Tsunami Center issued warnings Wednesday night of giant sea waves caused by a series of earthquakes near the Aleutian Islands.

title: INDUSTRIES SEE BOTH WINNERS AND LOSERS IF BILL BECOMES LAW; PLANNING FOR RETIREMENT COULD CHANGE DRAMATICALLY
description: While business in general and many consumer groups say they are satisfied with the sweeping tax plan approved this week by the Senate Finance Committee, a number of trade and industry groups are starting to voice alarm over some of the plan's provisions.

title: NERCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
2 Offerings Made By Nassau County
description: Long Island's Nassau County is offering $75.7 million of general improvement and sewer district bonds in two separate transactions. All the bonds are insured by the Federal Guaranty Insurance Company.

title: BURROUGHS'S SPERRY BID UNDER WAY
description: The Burroughs Corporation's takeover bid for the Sperry Corporation opened officially yesterday in a public tender offer at $70 a share, but Wall Street professionals bid the price of Sperry stock up in the expectation that Burroughs - or someone else - might pay more. The stock closed at $72.75, up $2.25. How much more someone might pay was difficult to assess, but many leading Wall Street traders said that $75 a share or even a bit more did not seem unreasonable. Many traders gave Burroughs and its current offer of $4.1 billion a strong edge and saw little that could prevent Burroughs from eventually winning Sperry.

title: Dallas Raid Nets 5 People And 23 Pounds of Heroin
description: Federal drug agents and Louisiana troopers raided a hotel here and confiscated 23 1/2 pounds of Mexican heroin, the authorities said today.

title: VIE DE FRANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 5
RESTAURANTS
description: WHEN Cafe Luxembourg opened three years ago it became an overnight hit, a stylish and serious restaurant in the gastronomic tundra surrounding Lincoln Center. Unaccountably, the success of this Art Deco haute cafeteria has failed to spawn worthy imitators. Aside from a few glorified watering holes in the neighborhood, Cafe Luxembourg still has the hip night scene pretty much to itself.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: SCIENTIFIC-ATLANTA INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Physician Is Wed To Jodi Horowitz
description: Jodi Horowitz, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Horowitz of East Hills, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Mitchell Efros, a son of Maxene Efros of Roslyn, L.I., and Charles Efros of New York. Rabbi Joseph Sternstein performed the ceremony at the Glen Head (L.I.) Country Club.

title: Dining Out Guide; With Out-of-Town Guests, Downtown
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. THE COACH HOUSE, #110 Waverly Place, west of Washington Square (777-0303) -

title: GOODYEAR TIRE & RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and after income of $6.4 million, or 6 cents a share, from discontinued operations.

title: CATHERINE CLARK
description: Catherine Clark, who opened a small store 40 years ago to offer her homemade bread, an enterprise that became the multimillion-dollar Brownberry Ovens bakery, died at a convalescent home Friday. She was 79 years old.

title: M. P. CARTWRIGHT
description: Marguerite P. Cartwright, a sociologist and journalist who specialized in African affairs, died Monday at St. Vincent's Hospital after suffering a stroke.

title: Koch Unhurt in Crash Of 3 Cars at Mansion
description: A limousine carrying Mayor Koch and a press aide was involved in a three-car collision last night as the limousine left Gracie Mansion. No injuries were reported, although damage to the left side of the limousine was considerable, according to the aide, Tom Kelly.

title: 16,000 Acres Blackened By North Carolina Fire
description: About 200 firefighters dug trenches yesterday in an effort to stop a raging fire in North Carolina as air tankers poured chemicals on the blaze that has charred more than 16,000 acres in four days.

title: ALC COMMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: The U.N. Today: May 9, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M.

title: INDUSTRIES SEE BOTH WINNERS AND LOSERS IF BILL BECOMES LAW; POLLUTION-CONTROL BONDS AFFECTED BY PLAN
description: While business in general and many consumer groups say they are satisfied with the sweeping tax plan approved this week by the Senate Finance Committee, a number of trade and industry groups are starting to voice alarm over some of the plan's provisions.

title: Mittleman Sets Record
description: Stu Mittleman of New York, who averaged only three hours of sleep each night for almost 12 days, finished first yesterday in the second Sri Chinmoy 1,000-mile race over a one-mile loop in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, Queens. Mittleman, 34 years old, broke the world record for the distance, which has been contested only five times.

title: CUOMO PLEDGES UNITY ON TAXES WITH MOYNIHAN
description: In an effort to close their rift over the Senate's tax revision plan, Governor Cuomo and Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan yesterday vowed ''our united efforts'' to restore the deductibility of state sales taxes to any tax revision bill.

title: The U.S. Evinces Interest In a Company's Breakfast
description: What whetted the appetites of Federal officials was not the prospect of breakfast at Windows on the World. Instead, they were eager to make an arrest.

title: FOOTE, CONE & BELDING COMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GWC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NEW BREED OF CAT'S-EYES LIGHTING UP CITY'S ROADS
description: Cat's-eyes, the road reflectors that have long outlined the lanes of Southern and California highways, are now standing watch on the streets of New York City.

title: HOUSE PASSES A SPENDING BILL
description: The House today passed a $1.7 billion spending bill that had been delayed by jurisdictional battles and contention over President Reagan's request for aid to Nicaraguan rebels.

title: A WEEKEND FESTIVAL OF MIDDLE EASTERN ARTS
description: One day in 1972, when Joseph Eger was working with the Haifa Symphony in Israel as a guest conductor, a musician in the orchestra came up to him after a rehearsal and offered to take him on a visit to the West Bank.

title: A New Attitude?
description: In the first days after the Chernobyl nuclear accident, the Soviet Government once again earned the world's indictment for failing to make warning information promptly available. Is it possible, however, that the Russians finally are learning to respond to international outrage with something other than the usual stonewall and stone face?

title: RESIDENTS OF KIEV WARNED TO GUARD AGAINST RADIATION
description: The Chernobyl nuclear accident continues to pose a health threat in Kiev, the Soviet Union's third largest city, and residents there have been told to keep their windows closed, wash frequently and take other precautions in hopes of fending off radiation contamination.

title: READER'S DIGEST AWARDS $3 MILLION TO ARTS GROUPS
description: Reader's Digest announced yesterday an award of $3 million to 49 dance and theater companies across the country for the creation and production of new works. The grants will be given under the Reader's Digest Dance and Theater Program, a new project sponsored by the Wallace Funds, established by DeWitt and Lila Acheson Wallace, co-founders of Reader's Digest.

title: COURIER DISPATCH GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
VESTRON INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WILL'S PREPARER DEFENDS HERSELF IN JOHNSON TRIAL
description: Nina S. Zagat, the lawyer who prepared the final will of the late J. Seward Johnson, spent the entire day yesterday as a witness in Surrogate's Court in Manhattan defending herself from lawyers who tried to show that Mr. Johnson was too sick to understand the will.

title: ZERO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings for year-ago periods were adjusted to reflect the 5-for-4 stock split paid in March 1986 and the acquisition of Contempo Engineering in August 1985, which was accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: INDEPENDENT BANKSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WALKER, HIRAM RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes special gains of $3 million and $8 million for quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes special gains of $8 million and $16 million for quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: SCREEN: 'FIRE WITH FIRE'
description: CAN a girl from a Roman Catholic boarding school find happiness with a guy from a minimum-security prison down the road? That is the question posed by ''Fire With Fire,'' which opens today at Loews State and other theaters. If you think the question is uninteresting, wait till you see the movie.

title: ULTIMATE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Slain Man in Chelsea Identified as Yugoslav
description: The police last night identified a murder victim found Monday night wrapped in a canvas dropcloth in a parking lot in Chelsea as Jock Slobodan, 43 years old, of 140 East 46th Street.

title: WHITE HOUSE BACKING C.I.A. ON PROSECUTING PUBLICATIONS
description: The White House said today that it favored prosecution of individuals or publications that may have violated laws barring unauthorized disclosure of classified information.

title: CLOONEY AND BENNETT, OLD-SCHOOL PROFESSIONALS
description: PROFESSIONALISM in pop music is a concept that in the age of the instant rock star seems almost quaint. But patience, attention to craft and humility can pay long-term show-business dividends. Both Tony Bennett, who is making his first Manhattan appearance in several years at Radio City Music Hall this weekend, and Rosemary Clooney, who is performing at Michael's Pub through May 17, are consummate pop professionals of the old school. And both have been rewarded with careers that have taken upward artistic trajectories four decades after they began.

title: ON MOSCOW TRAINS, CHILDREN OF KIEV
description: As the overnight trains from Kiev edged the final yards into the Kiev Station, the windows sliding past the platform merged into an unbroken mural of children's faces, their curious eyes large, their noses flattened against the glass.

title: British Broker Intent On Pursuing Zondervan
description: Christopher J. Moran, the first British insurance broker ever expelled from Lloyd's of London, said yesterday that he was determined to press ahead with his bid for the Zondervan Corporation, despite strong opposition from the Michigan-based Bible publisher.

title: GREENWICH SEEKS TO PROD GEESE INTO LEAVING BEACH
description: They continue to eat what they please and generally make themselves at home, despite being insulted, chased and fired upon by cannons.

title: PACIFICORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DATAPRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $2,270,000. c-Net income

title: UNION TAKES OVER LOCAL AT HORMEL
description: Officials of the United Food and Commercial Workers declared today that the international union was in control of a local on strike against Geo. A. Hormel & Company. They said they were removing local leaders who refused to end the 8-month-old strike.

title: Ojeda Gets an Insider's Look
description: Bob Ojeda had read the papers and checked the standings daily, but he knew very little about the Mets. They were good, and they were young. But they were also a second-place team. And they were far too distant for Ojeda, who played in the other league, to even think about.

title: THE SCREEN: 'SHADOW,' KENYA TALE
description: ''I N THE SHADOW OF KILIMANJARO,'' which opens today at the U.A. Twin and other theaters, was inspired by incidents that occur from time to time in Kenya's national parks. During the severe droughts that periodically scourge the African continent, wild animals may attack and devour villagers who live near their prowling grounds.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a London dispatch in some copies yesterday about British inquiries into the attempted bombing of an El Al airliner misstated the reported police confession of a Jordanian suspect in another case. The suspect, Ahmed Nawaf Mansour Hazi, was said to have told West German investigators that the Syrian Embassy in East Berlin supplied him with explosives for an attack in March on the German-American Friendship Society in West Berlin, not on a West Berlin discotheque in April.

title: SUSPECT QUOTED: 'I LOVE TO WATCH PEOPLE DIE
description: In his cell last October, Richard Ramirez told a prison guard that he killed ''about 20 people in California'' and ''I love to watch people die,'' the guard has testified.

title: LEGG MASON INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Cincinnati Reds, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. The Mets are the top team in the major leagues at this moment and the Reds are the bottom team. (Television - SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Texas Rangers, at Arlington, Tex. Opening game of three game- series. (Television - Channel 11, 8:30 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 8:30 P.M.) Braves vs. Philadelphia Phillies, at Atlanta (Television - WTBS, 5:35 P.M.) Basketball 76ers vs. Milwaukee Bucks, at Philadelphia. The Bucks won at home Wednesday night to take a 3-2 lead in the Eastern Conference semifinal series. (Television - WTBS, 8:20 P.M.) Golf L.P.G.A. United Virginia Bank Classic, at Sleepy Hole Golf Club, Portsmouth, Va. Byron Nelson Classic, at Irving, Tex. Second round and completion of the rain-delayed PGA Tour tournament. Benson & Hedges Invitational, at the Dominion Country Club, San Antonio. Second round of PGA Senior Tour event. (Television - ESPN 4:30 P.M. Hockey Rangers vs. Montreal Canadiens, at Montreal. John Vanbiesbrouck's 2-0 shutout Wednesday night kept the Rangers alive and sent the Prince of Wale Conference championship series back to Montreal. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 7:20 P.M.) Tennis Shearson Lehman Brothers Tournament of Champions, quarterfinals and doubles semifinals, at the West Side Tennis club, Forest Hill, noon and 6:30 P.M. (Television - FNN Score, 6:30 P.M.) Other Events HARNESS RACING: Roosevelt, 8 P.M. The Meadowlands, 8 P.M. (Television - MSG, 12:15 A.M. tape.)

description: b-Includes a capital gain of $304,000.
