CHYRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
RANDOLPH UNFAZED BY UPS AND DOWNS
description: Willie Randolph was not always like this.

title: Sikh Party Splits, Losing Punjab Majority
description: The governing moderate Sikh party in Punjab was reduced to a legislative minority today when it split after a weeklong revolt over a Government-backed raid on the Golden Temple in Amritsar.

title: AMERICAN COMMUNITY SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: HELMERICH & PAYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes writedowns of oil and gas reserves of $12 million for the quarter and $14 million for the 6 months. c-Includes gains from the sale of securities of $9,210,000 for the latest 6 months and $4,920,000 for the year- earlier period.

title: Suffolk Is Urged to Sue On Shoreham as Fraud
description: The Suffolk County Legislature was asked yesterday to initiate a $6 billion Federal lawsuit against the Long Island Lighting Company on the grounds that it concealed faulty design and construction at the Shoreham nuclear plant.

title: THE LAG IN THE UKRAINE
description: Tucked into a long Izvestia report today on the Chernobyl reactor accident was a statement that ''unfortunately'' the service responsible for monitoring radiation inside the plant had had no contact with the service that monitored radiation outside the plant.

title: CADE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $2,856,000 from a life insurance policy.

title: 30-YEAR BOND SALE A RECORD
description: The Treasury was able to sell a record $9 billion of new 30-year bonds yesterday at the lowest yield since 1973, but the success of that auction was marred late in the day when interest rates rose modestly, and doubts emerged about the likelihood of continued rate declines.

title: That Kemp Camp
description: As befits an undeclared Presidential candidate, aides to Representative Jack F. Kemp pump out a good deal of mail to reporters in Washington and elsewhere these days, making sure everyone is aware of the upstate New Yorker's political activities. Sometimes, just to see if the recipients are paying attention, they run a check.

title: 60 FILMS COVER 3 DECADES OF 'COMEDY, ITALIAN STYLE'
description: NEW YORK is about to see Italy's comic spirit personified on the screen. ''Comedy, Italian Style,'' a parade of 60 movies subtitled in English, starts today at the Museum of Modern Art and will run all summer long.

title: KEY SENATE PANEL BALKS OVER NOMINEE TO COURT
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee today denied approval to the nomination of a Reagan Administration candidate for a seat on the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit in Chicago.

title: COASTAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and does not include American Natural Resources Co., which was merged into Coastal effective March 31, 1985.

title: MARTIN ANDERSEN
description: Martin Andersen, who stepped off a train in Orlando nearly broke in the Great Depression and made a fortune as the fiery owner and editor of the city's newspapers, died Monday night after a long illness.

title: Advertising; Ogilvy & Mather Plans An Office in Peking
description: Sometime in June Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide expects to open an office in Peking, becoming the first American agency with an outpost in the Chinese capital.

title: FIRST CENTRAL FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss Figures are corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: U.S. ADMITS ERRORS IN LIBYA RAID
description: The Pentagon has officially confirmed for the first time that United States planes inadvertently hit civilian areas in the American raids on Libya on April 15.

title: DR. LOUIS LEITER
description: Dr. Louis Leiter, an authority on kidney disease and a former chief of medicine at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx, died of Alzheimer's disease Monday at his home in Los Gatos, Calif. He was 87 years old.

title: Case IH Closings
description: Plagued by overcapacity, Case IH, a subsidiary of Tenneco Inc., said today that it plans to close three farm and construction equipment plants that employ 1,500 workers. By closing plants in Terre Haute, Ind.; Bettendorf, Iowa, and Rock Island, Ill., Case IH would reduce its manufacturing space in North America by 25 percent. Case said operations from the closed plants would be moved to plants in Burlington, Iowa; East Moline, Ill., Wichita, Kan., and Racine and Wausau, Wis.

title: NANTUCKET INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 1
FILM: 'HORSE,' FROM JAPAN
description: KAJIRO YAMAMOTO'S ''Horse,'' the 1941 Japanese film opening today at the Film Forum 2, is an important footnote to cinema history but, like all footnotes, it needs a context, specifically, that of the Film Forum's current Akira Kurosawa retrospective.

title: FROM TWO YOUNG DESIGNERS, TWO FASHION VIEWS
description: Andre Walker and Karl Davis are two of New York City's most promising young designers. They are both from Brooklyn and in their early 20's. And both were initially financed by supportive, fashionable mothers. But there the similarities end.

title: Congressional Mail: Hang the Cost
description: Thanks to a ruling by the Comptroller General of the United States, members of Congress have been handed something of an open checkbook on mailing costs.

title: Sullivan Seeks More Pressure
description: The Rev. Leon Sullivan, the Philadelphia minister who developed the code of conduct for doing business in South Africa that has been endorsed by scores of American companies, said yesterday that he had asked the companies to step up their opposition to South Africa's racially discriminatory policy of apartheid.

title: FAIRMONT FINANCIAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $392,000 and realized investment gains of $35,000.

title: COMPUTER IDENTICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: ROCKETS AND LAKERS ADVANCE
description: Lewis Lloyd scored 4 of his 25 points in the second overtime, and the Houston Rockets survived most of the two overtime periods without Ralph Sampson and Akeem Olajuwon tonight to eliminate the Denver Nuggets with a 126-122 victory.

title: Bangladesh Opposition Charges Vote Rigging
description: Opponents of the martial law Government of President H. M. Ershad charged today that there was ''massive rigging'' in the parliamentary election Wednesday but said they would accept the seats they had been given credit as winning and sit in the new Parliament.

title: HAZARDS CITED BY STATE
description: The Roberto Clemente shelter for homeless families in the Bronx, long criticized as substandard and even dangerous, was ordered shut yesterday by state officials because of fire and health hazards.

title: THE SENATE TAX PLAN: THE LAWMAKERS AND WHAT THEY FORGEDMAN IN THE NEWS: Robert William Packwood; APPARENT LOSER EMERGES TRIUMPHANT
description: Barely two weeks ago, Senator Bob Packwood looked like a loser.

title: SPORTSWEAR: SOPHISTICATED IS THE WORD
description: Sportswear took center stage yesterday as the fall and winter showings in New York moved into their final days. Gloria Sachs displayed growing authority and a sure hand as she turned cashmere, challis and paisley-printed silk into separates to be worn with ease and comfort.

title: DOW UP IN SLUGGISH TRADING
description: Stock prices rose moderately yesterday on Wall Street, but trading remained sluggish as investors grappled with a host of potentially bothersome factors like tax revision, government refinancings and the economy.

title: ISS INTERNATIONAL SERVICE SYSTEM (DANISH, CO)(A) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: LIFE CARE COMMUNITIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
AMERICAN HEALTHCARE MANAGEMENT reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Lebow Enters Bid
description: The New York Road Runners Club has submitted a bid to The Athletic Congress to be host of the United States men's marathon trials for the 1988 Olympic Games.

title: SCANDAL PAPERS CITE A WARNING TO KEY WITNESS
description: Shortly before his indictment on state charges, the former president of Citisource Inc. was warned that Stanley M. Friedman operated in a ''world of deep, dark shadows,'' and that the official and his family could be in danger if he cooperated with authorities, according to papers filed yesterday in Federal court.

title: SPY INSISTS DEFENDANT KNEW WHO GOT SECRETS
description: John A. Walker Jr. told the jury in the espionage trial of Jerry A. Whitworth today that ''common sense'' told him that Mr. Whitworth knew that the classified Navy data he is accused of stealing was being passed to the Soviet Union.

title: Saga Shares Soar After Marriott Bid
description: Shares of the Saga Corporation jumped $7.125 today on the New York Stock Exchange after Wednesday's unsolicited offer by the Marriott Corporation to acquire the operator of restaurants and contract food services. Marriott offered to pay $34 in cash for all Saga shares, for a total of about $435 million, but the shares of Saga, based in Menlo Park, Calif., closed significantly higher, at $36.625.

title: AMERICAN INTEGRITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AT THE CANNES FESTIVAL, ESCAPISM AND REALITY
description: A lighthearted and tongue-in-cheek comic epic called ''Pirates,'' directed by Roman Polanski, today opened the Cannes Film Festival, which seemed likely in this, its 39th year, to be accented by two contradictory moods: old-fashioned escapist adventure on the screen and worry about possible terrorist attacks in real life outside.

title: The Senate Plan And Tax Liability
description: Average reduction in income tax liability for various income classes in 1988 tax year.

title: COMDIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $4,537,000 from the sale of Comdial Ltd.

title: TAX WRITERS DISCOVER LITTLE FAVORS MEAN A LOT
description: Last Saturday night Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan and his tax counsel, Joseph Gale, met in the Senator's office and reviewed a boxful of requests from New Yorkers for special exceptions in the pending tax legislation.

title: ARMS AS AID: RISING DOUBT
description: The overwhelming Congressional votes this week against President Reagan's proposed arms deal with Saudi Arabia reflect rising doubts among legislators about the Administration's plans to use American-supplied weapons as a primary instrument of foreign policy.

title: Chutist Surrenders
description: One of the two Londoners who parachuted from the 86th floor of the Empire State Building two weeks ago, 27-year-old Alasdair Boyd, gave himself up to the police yesterday, and said he would go straight.

title: Ford Job Cuts
description: The Ford Motor Company said it planned to eliminate up to 25 percent of its salaried automotive employees in North America by 1990, which would affect up to 13,000 jobs, company officials said. Ford's chairman, Donald E. Petersen, told shareholders at the company's annual meeting that ''much of the reduction will come through attrition.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, MAY 9, 1986
description: International Residents of Kiev have been warned to keep windows closed, wash often and take other precautions in hopes of fending off radiation contamination from the nuclear accident at Chernobyl. The Soviet authorities continued to say radiation levels in Kiev, the third largest Soviet city, were safe for air, water and food, but did not provide exact figures. Officials said 84,000 people had been evacuated. [ Page A1, Column 6. ]

title: NORTHWESTERN NATIONAL LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes capital gains of $5,257,000 for the latest quarter and $680,000 for the year-ago period.

title: Intervention Accord Seen
description: Japan and West Germany have agreed to intervene in currency markets to keep the yen from climbing further, according to traders and press reports here.

title: Advertising; Foote, Cone Net Up
description: Foote, Cone & Belding Communications released its first-quarter results yesterday. Revenues were $69.7 million, up 8.9 percent from the $64 million in the comparable period last year, while net income rose 83.3 percent, to $2.2 million, from $1.2 million, or 58 cents a share, compared with 32 cents a share in the previous period.

title: SYRIA PROTESTS CHARGES IT IS LINKED TO TERROR
description: Syria said today that it had protested to West Germany over allegations that a terrorist bombing in West Berlin in March was linked to the Syrian Embassy.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Gerard A. Hyde has been named senior vice president and management supervisor by Muir Cornelius Moore.

title: FPA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: But Is It Art?
description: When the Corcoran Gallery describes a work of art as ''site-specific,'' it means it is designed for a particular setting and, sometimes, immovable as well. In this fairly unusual category, the gallery is offering ''Truisms'' a work by Jenny Holzer, a New York artist, that can only be viewed on an electronic signboard near Dupont Circle, about a mile from the art museum.

title: AGAINST THE WIND IN SEOUL
description: ''There is no denying that the winds of freedom are blowing, east and west,'' President Reagan said two weeks ago. ''They are brisk and bracing winds, sweeping out the old and, I believe, ushering in a new era of freedom, an era in which democracy is once again recognized as the new idea.''

title: BENEQUITY HOLDINGS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: No year-ago period figures were available since the company began operations May 16, 1985.

title: Zimmerman Plans Suit
description: In an effort to permit Gary Zimmerman to play as an offensive lineman for the Minnesota Vikings, his attorney said Wednesday that he would file suit against the United States Football League and two of its teams. Jim Kiles, a lawyer in Washington, said the 75-page complaint would be filed against the league, the Los Angeles Express and the Memphis Showboats to free the 6-foot-5-inch, 280-pound lineman from any obligation to a U.S.F.L. team.

title: STARRETT, LS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ART: ENZO CUCCHI SHOW AT THE GUGGENGEIM
description: THE first American museum exhibition devoted to Enzo Cucchi is unusual and troubling. The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum did not organize a retrospective of the 36-year-old Italian Neo-Expressionist's work. Nor did it select a cross section of paintings in which an argument for the artist's importance and for the necessity of a museum show would be clear. Instead it essentially allowed the artist to decide the exhibition himself.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Executive Changes column in Business Day on Monday misidentified Brian H. Dovey's new position at Rorer Group Inc. He is president.

title: PERINI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $1,479,000. The amounts previously reported for 1985 have been reclassified to reflect decisions made later in 1985 to discontinue certain construction activities and withdraw from these market segments.

title: CMX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $72,000 for the quarter and $165,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss includes an extraordinary gain of $162,000 from the forgiveness of debt. The latest 9 months net income figure is corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Judge Stays Contempt Fines Against Two Catholic Groups
description: A Federal judge yesterday stayed his ruling ordering the two principal national organizations of the Roman Catholic Church to pay contempt-of-court fines of $50,000 a day.

title:
Patents;
USE OF IBOGAINE TO FIGHT ADDICTION
description: Howard S. Lotsof, president of the Dora Weiner Foundation on Staten Island, expects that the use of ibogaine, as disclosed in his patent No. 4,587,243 this week, will be an important tool in the war against heroin and cocaine addiction.

title: SPECIAL UNITS COME UP SHORT
description: The ineffectiveness of the Rangers' special teams was the most obvious weakness in their season-ending loss tonight at the Forum.

title: RAYMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
CHIP ORDERS INCREASE, BUT SHIPMENTS ARE OFF
description: A key indicator of the health of the semiconductor industry continued its improvement in April, the industry's trade association reported today.

title: BOESKY BUYS 10% OF SPERRY
description: Ivan F. Boesky, the biggest trader in the little-understood business of arbitrage, said yesterday that he had bought more than five million shares, or slightly less than 10 percent, of the Sperry Corporation.

title: MUSIC: VIOLONCELLO SOCIETY
description: Cellists apparently believe in the efficacy of networking and have been involved in it for at least three decades now. In 1956, a group in this area established the Violoncello Society Inc., and at Merkin Concert Hall on Wednesday night it celebrated the 30th anniversary of the organization.

title: Bean Takes Lead In Nelson Classic
description: Andy Bean, finishing his round as rain was coming down, posted a two-under-par 68 today to take a one-shot lead over Mark Wiebe and Jim Gallagher after two rounds of the $600,000 Byron Nelson Golf Classic.

title: Upjohn Draws U.S. Scrutiny
description: United States drug safety regulators say they are weighing whether a recent Upjohn Company news release touting its Minoxidil high blood pressure drug as a cure for male baldness violated Federal drug law. Minoxidil, when taken orally, has been approved for use against high blood pressure, but it has not yet been approved as a baldness cure, and Upjohn in 1985 put a warning label on the drug cautioning against its use on the skin.

title: SHCHARANSKY URGES PUBLIC PRESSURE ON SOVIET
description: Anatoly B. Shcharansky, the former Soviet political prisoner, urged yesterday that the United States maintain public pressure on Moscow to relax restrictions on the emigration of Jews from the Soviet Union.

title: SEAGULL ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax writedown of $26.6 million on its oil and gas reserves. c-Net income

title: STAFF BUILDERSN INC (NY) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income

title: Show and Tell: My First Day of Retirement
description: Yesterday was the first day of my retirement. I file this report on it in hopes that others may benefit from my mistakes.

title: ERB LUMBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Politics, Not Muckraking, Breeds Cynicism; A Forgotten Hero
description: To the Editor:

title: CAPITAL SOUTHWEST CORP reports earnings for As of March 31
Celebrating the Virtues Of Independent Publishing
description: At a party at George Plimpton's this week, the host recalled the problems he had had publishing a literary anthology that depended on support from the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: Don't Erode the Job Corps
description: Faced with a Gramm-Rudman-Hollings mandate to cut the Job Corps budget by 4.3 percent, the Department of Labor wants to close six centers with 1,223 training slots. Congressional supporters fear a guerrilla war against the program by a hostile Reagan Administration.

title: TENZING NORKAY, 72, IS DEAD: CLIMBED EVEREST WITH HILLARY
description: Tenzing Norkay, the Sherpa who stood atop the world on Mount Everest with Sir Edmund Hillary in 1953, died here today of a lung infection. He was 72 years old.

title: Pagel in Accord
description: Mike Pagel and the Indianapolis Colts have agreed on a plan that may eventually send the quarterback to another team. Pagel's agent, Jim Steiner, says the idea is for Pagel to test his worth on the free agent market, and he has reportedly scheduled a tryout with the Cleveland Browns.

title: Bangladesh Stops Count In Parliamentary Vote
description: The Election Commission has suspended vote tallies in the disputed parliamentary election, raising the possibility new elections could be required for as many as 116 of the 300 seats being contested.

title: Car Lurches Forward, Injuring 4 on Sidewalk
description: Four pedestrians were injured in midtown Manhattan yesterday when a car pulling out of a parking lot went out of control and lurched across a crowded sidewalk, authorities said.

title: Death Sentence Barred In Reporter's Slaying
description: The death sentence given John Harvey Adamson for killing the reporter Don Bolles in 1976 was overturned today by a Federal appeals court because he was tried for first-degree murder after being sentenced for second-degree murder.

title: Hilton Ruiz, Pianist
description: The pianist Hilton Ruiz will perform tonight and tomorrow at the West End Cafe, 2911 Broadway, at 114th Street (666-8750). Sets begin at 9 P.M., 10:30 P.M. and midnight and at 1:15 A.M.; there is no fourth set tomorrow. There is a $5 cover and a $5 minimum.

title: Charles Cortez Abbott Dies; Founder of Business School
description: Dr. Charles Cortez Abbott, founding dean of the University of Virginia's Darden School of Business, died Thursday at his farm in Pomfret, Conn. He was 78 years old and suffered a stroke a week ago.

title: FRANCE HONORS THE ELUSIVE BECKETT
description: Samuel Beckett was everywhere during the last two weeks here. And nowhere also.

title: With the Kennedys
description: ''This is not a fund-raiser for Kathleen and Joe,'' said Senator Edward M. Kennedy, referring to the two offspring of Robert F. Kennedy who are running for Congress this year.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * AMR Corp., Dallas, the parent company of American Airlines, has formed a new subsidiary, AMR Information Services Inc., to oversee its expansion and acquisitions in the field of information processing.

title: WEDGIES AND PLATFORMS ARE BACK IN THE RACE
description: Ever since the glory days of Carmen Miranda in the 1940's, platform shoes and wedgies have gone in and out of fashion. When platforms are in, women extol the comfort of an inch of padding between the pavement and the soles of their feet. They say that walking on wedgies with flat bottoms gives them a greater feeling of solidity underfoot than walking on heels of the same height. Some women even wear wedgies for the same reason Miss Miranda did: to look taller.

title: WHAT MARRIOTT SEES IN SAGA
description: The Saga Corporation, a big name in campus dining halls, is inching close to a business recovery, analysts say, but it may not wait around for it.

title: OPERA: GLUCK'S 'ORFEO'
description: If Gluck's ''Orfeo ed Euridice'' admonishes the extravagance of ''opera seria'' style, it sways us to its side not with moral or esthetic argument but by its own sheer beauty. In this wonderful music, simplicity of line - a rejection of the purely ornamental -achieves puritan sincerity without the coldness of heart that so often accompanies puritanical ideals.

title: Prince and Princess of Wales Start Six-Day Visit to Japan
description: The Prince and Princess of Wales toured Buddhist temples and ancient castles, attended a tea ceremony and ate their first Japanese meal today, the first day of their six-day tour of Japan.

title: 76ERS ROUT BUCKS BY 126-108
description: The Bucks, who have lost to the 76ers in the playoffs in four of the last five seasons, had an opportunity to eliminate Philadelphia tonight. A victory would have achieved some vindication from last year's playoff when Milwaukee was embarrassed by the 76ers in a four-game sweep.

title: EUROPEANS SQUABBLING OVER FOOD: IS THEIR PRODUCE FREE OF RADIATION?
description: The countries of Western Europe, deeply divided by conflicting political and economic concerns, are squabbling among themselves over their home-grown produce and whether it is sufficiently free of radiation from the Chernobyl nuclear disaster to be sold for export.

title: THE QUEEN, BETSY ROSS AND PAPUA NEW GUINEA
description: Because this is a Commonwealth country, there was an official parade recently in honor of Queen Elizabeth II's 60th birthday. It lasted seven minutes. Almost nobody, not even Prime Minister Paias Wingti, showed up for it. If Papua New

title: Bridge; 1986 World Championships To Offer Wide Mix of Events
description: The world championships scheduled for Miami Beach in September are expected to attract a much bigger entry than the 1984 Olympiad in Seattle.

title: Deals on Meals
description: As the Senate Finance Committee was wrapping up its work on tax-revising legislation this week, the question arose of the deductibility of business meals, often called the three-martini-lunch. Senator Bob Packwood, the Oregon Republican who is committee chairman, wanted to allow only 80 percent of the cost of business meals to be deductible.

title: Swiss Yacht Is First
description: The Swiss maxi entry, UBS Switzerland, finished first today in the fourth Whitbread round-the-world yacht race, completing the 27,000-mile event hundreds of miles and at least two days ahead of Cote d'Or of Belgium and Drum of Britain.

title: NUMAC OIL & GAS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bulgarians Have Known Oppression at Many Hands; Turkish Kurds
description: To the Editor:

title: Fratello Asks New Pact
description: The Atlanta Hawks' Mike Fratello, the National Basketball Association's Coach of the Year, would like the owner, Ted Turner, to extend to him the same show of confidence Turner has displayed to another employee, Chuck Tanner, the manager of the Atlanta Braves. The Braves last year reportedly signed Tanner for five years at an annual base salary of $300,000.

title: WETTERAU INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: The company said the 10 percent increase in its latest quarter net income was achieved despite higher insurance premium costs amounting to about $1.3 million after taxes, or 9 cents a share fully diluted.

title: Players; NEW PLAYER ECHOES HIS FATHER'S ERA
description: The prospect seemed worth a chance. He had been a fairly ordinary hockey player until the 1983-84 season. He had considered giving up the game until a friend suggested he try out for the Penticton Knights, a tier II team in the British Columbia Junior Hockey League, and his career began to bloom.

title: DAISY SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income c-Includes a gain of $603,000 from an accounting change.

title: For World Monuments
description: Ambassador Rinaldo Petrignani of Italy and his wife, Anne, will hold a $150-a-ticket benefit gala May 22 in behalf of the World Monuments Fund.

title: Bond Prices Steady After Fall
description: Bond prices closed little changed yesterday after recovering from an early, sharp drop. Trading was light and nervous.

title: BERKEY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain on the sale of discontinued operations of $601,000. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $779,000.

title: Kate Smith Has Surgery
description: The singer Kate Smith underwent surgery for breast cancer today, and a spokesman at Raleigh Community Hospital said the outlook was satisfactory. Dr. William G. Sullivan performed a mastectomy, and there are no plans for additional therapy, the spokesman said. It was the second time the 79-year-old singer had major surgery this year. Her right leg was amputated above the knee Jan. 12 because of circulatory complications caused by diabetes.

title: Party Time on Wall St.
description: ''Everybody's in a festive mood,'' said James Stannard, an institutional securities clerk for Alex Brown & Sons as he stood on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange last night. ''And that's not normal.'' Mr. Stannard was one of about 2,500 people who paid $250 last night to roam the floor, drink in hand, as the exchange raised money for the restoration of the Statue of Liberty in what officials said was the largest party ever at the exchange.

title: Nicaragua Embargo And U.S. Trade Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Strike Is Threatened By Amtrak Engineers
description: The union representing Amtrak engineers threatened today to stage a nationwide strike against the national rail passenger line as early as Monday over work and safety rules. The railroad said it did not know of the dispute.

title: MEDICAL COLLEGE SAVORS RETURN FROM THE BRINK
description: Lofty old trees and stately colonial buildings dot the campus of New York Medical College in Valhalla, N.Y.

title: LEE DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,139,000 for the quarter and $2,589,000 for the year.

title: FINDING EVERY NOOK AND CRANNY AT THE LIBRARY
description: Under such pressure, a lesser library science professional might just slip a book like the one before him -''The Nevada Controller's Office Annual Report 1867-1878 (Incomplete)'' - off the shelf and just furtively chuck it out.

title: Japan Vote Plan Is Blow to Nakasone
description: Ruling and opposition party leaders today accepted in principle a reapportionment plan that would make it difficult to call a lower house election at the same time as an upper house one scheduled for this summer.

title: U.S. SAYS GOTTI COMMITTED CRIME WHILE ON BAIL
description: Government prosecutors said yesterday there was ''probable cause to believe'' that John Gotti, the reputed head of the Gambino crime family, and two co-defendants had committed serious crimes while free on bail.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Weekend yesterday about the New Amsterdam Theater Company's revival of ''I Married an Angel'' gave incorrect dates in some editions for performances at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street. A concert version of the musical will be presented May 17 at 8 P.M., May 18 at 4 P.M. and May 19 at 8 P.M.

title: Fragile Democracy in the Sudan
description: Praise is now due the Sudan. This huge country linking black Africa and the Arab Middle East has just democratically chosen a new government. That makes it the only proper democracy in the Arab League, and one of the rare democratic regimes on the African continent.

title: GASOLINE PRICE RISE IS FORECAST
description: Despite the continuing surplus of crude oil in the world, oil industry analysts and officials predict that retail gasoline prices in the United States will increase during the peak summer driving season.

title: Harris and Trio
description: The Jazz Cultural Theater, 368 Eighth Avenue, above 28th Street (502-4300), will present the pianist Barry Harris and his trio tonight. Sets are at 10 and 11:30 and 1 A.M.; admission is $8, or $5 for students and over 65's.

title: Wells to Cut Crocker Staff
description: The Crocker National Corporation said yesterday that about 50 of its top 75 officers would be dismissed when the Wells Fargo Corporation takes over Crocker later this month.

title: ON A UKRAINE FARM, GEIGER COUNTERS
description: Drenched in the sun and covered with apple blossoms, the Kopelovo state farm seems a Ukrainian idyll - except for the Soviet Army medical tent under the chestnut tree.

title: Bomb Kills 2 on Teheran Bus
description: A small bomb exploded under the front seat of a Teheran double-decker bus today, killing the driver and the conductor, the national press agency Irna reported. The agency described the explosion as the work of the Mujahedeen Khalq, a Paris-based opposition group.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report yesterday about Dutch ships' planned trip to New York for the Statue of Liberty celebration in July gave an incorrect telephone number for boat reservations and misstated the trip price. The number is (212) 751-7286. Day and evening trips on July 3 will be $200 a person per trip, and an all-day trip on July 4 will be $400.

title: THE DANCE: 'QUIET CITY' BY ROBBINS IN PREMIERE
description: The tendency of ballets toward the static and literary became pronounced in the 1940's. At least, this was Frederick Ashton's view in 1946, when, he said, there was a need for ballets where dance values were primary.

title: Waterfront in Pictures
description: Tucked in a corner of the vast lobby of 2 World Trade Center are 30 color photographs by members of the Sierra Club.

title: TECHNICAL TAPE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CONGRESS ACTIVITY AND REAGAN ABSENCE
description: Bob Dole, the Senate Republican leader, was ticking off the legislative accomplishments of the last two weeks. The Senate passed a budget for 1987, plus legislation easing gun controls and a reorganization of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. Then the Senate Finance Committee reported out a major tax plan by unanimous vote.

title: Agca Is Hospitalized In Italy for Tuberculosis
description: Mehmet Ali Agca, the man convicted of the 1981 shooting of Pope John Paul II, has been admitted to a hospital where he was diagnosed as having tuberculosis, his lawyer said today.

title: WHAT PEOPLE ARE ASKING ABOUT THE TAX PLAN
description: The historic tax revision plan unanimously approved by the Senate Finance Committee would touch virtually every individual and business in America.

title: SAILOR IS CHARGED AS A SPY ON COAST
description: A Navy enlisted man was charged with espionage today for trying to sell weapon secrets, the Navy said.

title: Indians Lose And Fall to 2d
description: Tim Hulett's two-run single with two outs in the ninth inning capped a three-run rally tonight that allowed the Chicago White Sox to end their six-game losing streak with a 4-3 victory over the Cleveland Indians.

title: New Tactics on South Africa
description: For more than a year they paced the sidewalks outside the South African Embassy, denouncing that country's racial laws day and night, in rain, snow and broiling sun, holding high their placards, waiting for the police to come.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, MAY 10, 1986
description: The Economy

title: Boxing Injury Studied
description: The American Medical Association has renewed its campaign for a ban on professional boxing through a study in its journal that contends that severe eye injuries are far more common than boxing spokesmen admit. The study reports that between 1983 and 1985, the Wills Eye Hospital in Philadelphia treated nine cases of detached or torn retinas caused by boxing blows.

title: JAZZ: ABERCROMBIE AND MARZ
description: Bradley's, the restaurant and bar at 90 University Place, is usually thought of as a musical home for jazz pianists (a piano belonging to the late Paul Desmond is the centerpiece of the room). But since its earliest days, Bradley's has occasionally welcomed a guitarist.

title: JAITE BEATS BECKER IN TWO-SET UPSET
description: The tennis lessons did not end on Centre Court at Wimbledon last summer. Boris Becker was not wrapped in a cloak of invincibility when he won the men's singles title, protected from the bumps in the road that can make life on the tour difficult for a young player. Ion Tiriac, Becker's manager, sometimes wonders whether his 18-year-old protege understands that Wimbledon would place more demands on him.

title: AQUINO TELLS SHULTZ SHE ACCEPTS U.S. REFUSAL TO PROVIDE MORE AID
description: President Corazon C. Aquino told Secretary of State George P. Shultz today that although a new American aid package ''fell far short of what was needed'' to help the Philippines, she was reconciled to not getting more at this time, her spokesman said.

title: FIRST CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BRONX DEVELOPMENT OFFICIAL TESTIFIES BEFORE GRAND JURY
description: A politically connected Bronx official has testified under immunity before a grand jury investigating political fund-raising and possible corruption in economic-development agencies in the Bronx, according to prosecutors, lawyers and political figures.

title: Wells's Homer Helps Team Win
description: The former major leaguer Greg Wells hit a two-run homer today, helping the Hankyu Braves beat the Nankai Hawks 7-3 in a Japanese League game.

title: Sarah McDonald Becomes a Bride
description: Sarah Josephine McDonald, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas D. McDonald of Chappaqua, N.Y., and Jean Marie Vandenhende, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Julien Vandenhende of Tourcoing, France, were married yesterday in the Church of St. John and St. Mary in Chappaqua. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Charles Murray Kavanagh, the executive director of Catholic Seminaries in Washington.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Real Estate column yesterday incorrectly described Emil (Bus) Mosbacher, who was protocol chief for President Nixon. He is not ''late''; he is 64 years old and lives in Greenwich, Conn.

description: b-Net income

title: Dow Is Up 3.22 in a Late Rally
description: Recovering from early losses, the stock market gained ground yesterday for the second consecutive day, but the rally was feeble as investors appeared concerned about the outlook for both interest rates and oil prices.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Auto Racing Indianapolis 500 pole-position qualifying trials. Pancho Carter won the pole position in last year's Indy with a qualifying speed of 212.583 miles an hour. The Indy 500 is May 25. (Television - Channel 7, 5 P.M.) Baseball Mets vs. Cincinnati Reds, at Shea Stadium, 1:20 P.M. Ron Darling has the starting assignment for the Mets. (Television - Channel 4, 1:15 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 1:15 P.M.) Yankees vs. Texas Rangers, at Arlington, Tex. Ron Guidry is scheduled to make his seventh start of the season. (Television - Channel 11, 8:35 P.M. Radio -WABC, 8:30 P.M.) Braves vs. Philadelphia Phillies, at Atlanta. (Television - WTBS, 7:35 P.M.) Basketball Houston Rockets vs. Los Angeles Lakers, at Inglewood, Calif., opener of Western Conference four-of-seven-game championship series. (Television -Channel 2, 3:30 P.M.) Hockey Flames vs. St. Louis Blues, at Calgary, Alberta. Game 5 of the Campbell Conference Championship. The winner will take a 3-2 edge. (Television - ESPN, 8 P.M.) Tennis Shearson Lehman Brothers Tournament of Champions, at West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, 12:15 P.M. Only the second of the semifinal matches will be televised. (Television - Channel 7, 3 P.M.) Thoroughbred Racing Belmont, 1 P.M. The $150,000-added Carter Handicap for 3-year-olds and up at seven furlongs is the opening-day feature. This is the first Saturday opening in the track's history. (Television - SportsChannel, 6:30 P.M. and 11 P.M). Garden State, 1 P.M. Track and Field Metropolitan Intercollegiate Championships, at St. John's University, Utopia Parkway and Union Turnpike, 9:45 A.M. Women are competing for the first time.

description: The House of Representatives has approved a measure prohibiting the Labor Department from closing any Job Corps centers.

description: Willie Brown gripped his tennis racquet and stood at net, poised to parry a high lob.

title: U.S. Lifts Warning to Some Against Traveling to Poland
description: The State Department is no longer warning against travel to Poland by children and women of childbearing age, a Federal task force monitoring the Chernobyl nuclear accident said today.

title: A New Job
description: William Perry, a Senate Foreign Relations Committee staff adviser to Richard G. Lugar, the chairman, will assume new duties later this month as director of Latin American affairs on the National Security Council.

description: b-Net income includes a tax credit of $55,000.

title: CRITICS SAY PROTECTION OF WETLANDS IS ENDANGERED
description: Federal protection of the nation's wetlands is in danger of being undermined, members of Congress and environmentalists warned today.

description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $804,000. c-Includes a gain from discontinued operations of $27,000. The year-ago sales were restated to exclude discontinued operations.

title: OJEDA STRIKES OUT 10 TO GO 5-0
description: In the world of superlatives that they seem to be inhabiting these days, the Mets reached for even more last night as they defeated the Cincinnati Reds, 2-1, for their sixth straight victory and their 19th in 23 games this season.

title: DAYS INNS OF AMERICA INC reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $3,466,000 from the early extinguishment of debt. The company went public in December 1985 and year-ago results are pro forma.

title: Bonn Denies Dollar Pact
description: West Germany has made no formal agreement with Japan to intervene jointly on currency markets to support the value of the dollar, a spokesman for the Finance Ministry said today. He denied reports in the German and Japanese press that such an accord had been struck.

title: LEADER IN EDUCATION AND SCIENCE WAS 91
description: Dr. Paul Magnus Gross, a specialist in physical inorganic and fluorine chemistry, university administrator and government consultant in education and science, died Sunday at Duke University in Durham, N.C. He was 91 years old.

title: Bronx-Lebanon Is Still a Highly Used Hospital
description: To the Editor:

title: SOME FEAR CUOMO-MOYNIHAN DISPUTE MAY DAMAGE STRATEGY ON DEDUCTIONS
description: The unusual public dispute this week between Governor Cuomo and Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan stems from the distinctly different roles that each official holds in the battle to retain the right of taxpayers to deduct state and local taxes from their Federal returns.

title: RANGERS SPIRITED BID FOR CUP DASHED BY CANADIENS
description: After all the upsets and all the comebacks and all the great expectations that had arisen really from nowhere, the Rangers' improbable quest for a Stanley Cup ended tonight.

PACT REACHED ON DAIRY HERDS
description: The Agriculture Department agreed today to ask dairy producers to voluntarily delay the slaughter of their herds under a subsidized program to cut production.

title: Koch Might Have Avoided Embarrassment
description: Turn back the clock a quarter century and you would find Edward I. Koch among the leaders of the movement to reform the Democratic Party who advocated policies that, were they in place today, might have helped City Hall avoid much of the embarrassment it now faces.

title: PATH Vice President Caught in Fare Evasion
description: Richard R. Kelly tried to save 75 cents last month and it may cost him $4,600.

title: Toll in Sri Lanka Plane Blast Rises to 16 as Woman Dies
description: A newlywed, pregnant passenger wounded by a terrorist bomb that ripped apart an Air Lanka jetliner at Colombo International Airport last Saturday died today in a hospital, raising the death toll to 16.

title: Canada's Jobless Rate
description: The unemployment rate in Canada remained at 9.6 percent in April, the same rate as in March but still at its lowest level in four years, the Government's Statistics Canada agency said today. There were 416,000 more people working in April than a year ago.

title: Chamber Concert
description: The newly formed St. Bartholomew Chamber Orchestra will present a program of works by Poulenc, Barber and Britten tomorrow afternoon at 4 o'clock at St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue at 51st Street.

title: LaRUSSA STAYS ON; MARTIN TALKS FAIL
description: Tony LaRussa still has his job as manager of the Chicago White Sox. Dick Williams has replaced Chuck Cottier in the manager's post with the Seattle Mariners. And Billy Martin, who talked with the management of both clubs this week, remains a Yankee broadcaster.

title: CLC OF AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SYRIA HINTS AT A REVIVAL OF DISSIDENTS
description: Syria has broadcast a report indicating that the Moslem Brotherhood, an organization of militant fundamentalists suppressed by Syrian troops four years ago, has resumed its efforts to destabilize the Government of President Hafez al-Assad.

title: AIDE DENIES CHARGE HE PUNISHED WORKER FOR TUNNEL WARNING
description: A deputy commissioner in the Department of Environmental Preservation has presented a detailed denial of charges that he retaliated against an employee who warned of possibilities for corruption in the construction of the city's Third Water Tunnel.

title: FISCHBACH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary losses of $664,000 for the quarter and $1,414,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes extraordinary losses of $710,000 for the quarter and $1,910,000 for the 6 months.

title: Penalties at T.C.U.
description: As a penalty for infractions - including cash payments from boosters to players - that occurred in the Texas Christian University football program from 1979 to 1985, the National Collegiate Athletic Association yesterday imposed a series of penalties. The N.C.A.A. banned the football team from bowl competition next season, ordered the school to forfeit television revenues amounting to $342,203 from the 1983 and 1984 seasons and demanded a cutback of 35 football scholarships during the next two years.

title: Your Money; Protective Tax Planning
description: TAXPAYERS, suddenly facing the possibility that a vast change in the tax law might really be in the cards, may have to take protective investment action, tax experts are predicting.

title: West German Atom Protest
description: Several hundred anti-nuclear demonstrators laid siege to a nuclear waste dump near this village on the border with East Germany early today after bitter battles with the police yesterday. A police spokesman said the demonstrators made repeated efforts to tear down fencing encircling the site at Gorleben.

title: ASTROCOM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
KIRBY EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a $4.7 million writedown of oil and gas properties.

title: A STAR FINALE: BEENE AND KARAN
description: Geoffrey Beene presented a collection of couturelike brilliance and Donna Karan continued her exploration of sophisticated wrap-and-tie and bodysuit dressing. In their disparate ways, the two designers provided a splendid finale yesterday to the fall and winter showings in New York.

title: THE DANCE: SHAKTI'S 'SALOME' AT THE TRIPLEX
description: Shakti has a lush presence and way of moving. And her ''Salome,'' preformed on Wednesday at the Triplex Theater as part of the Fools Company's International OFFestival, serves primarily to focus on that lushness.

title: Icahn Said to Increase His Stake in Viacom
description: The New York investor Carl C. Icahn is believed to have purchased another 1.5 million shares of Viacom International Inc. yesterday, and he may now own well over 12 percent and possibly as much as 15 percent of the entertainment company's stock, according to various sources on Wall Street.

title: AMETEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title:
Patents;
MANY INVENTIONS FOR NUCLEAR REACTORS
description: More than a dozen inventions for nuclear reactors were patented this week by American and foreign inventors. Of three patents assigned to the Department of Energy, one covers a nuclear reactor safety device that may be used in liquid metal-cooled reactors.

title: CORRECTION
description: A listing in ''For Children'' in Weekend yesterday gave an incorrect location for ''Stories in the Wind: Tales, Myths and Legends of the Bushmen.'' It will be held at 1 P.M. today in the Lindner Theater, American Museum of Natural History.

title: Man Is Found Slain in Car
description: An unidentified man, shot in the head a number of times, was found dead in a parked Lincoln on the west side of 10th Avenue between 35th and 36th Streets at about 10 last night, the police said. Acting on a tip from an unidentified witness, police officers in the area arrested Stephen Locurto, 24 years old, of 299 Graham Avenue in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn. A .38-caliber revolver with five spent shells was recovered from Mr. Locurto, who was charged with murder, the police said.

title: DYNAMICS AND NORTHROP VYING ON U.S. FIGHTERS
description: Two giant aerospace companies today delivered to the Government their proposals for building billions of dollars worth of combat planes designed to protect American airspace against invading bombers.

title: CONSENSUS OF EXPERTS: THE ACCIDENT ISN'T OVER
description: American technical experts widely believe that the graphite core of the crippled Soviet reactor is still burning but say the chance that molten nuclear fuel will burn through the reactor's foundation and explode violently is remote.

title: Salomon to Aid Leaseway Sale
description: The board of directors of the Leaseway Transportation Corporation said it had retained Salomon Brothers Inc. to help find a buyer for the $1.4 billion trucking and leasing concern. The action by the board represents another phase in the battle over control of the company.

title: TV: 'TRAPPED IN SILENCE' EXPLORES ELECTIVE MUTISM
description: Elective mutism - an emotionally induced condition where a person is capable of speaking but refuses to do so - hardly seems like the ideal theme for the two-hour ''CBS Sunday Night Movie'' (9 P.M., Channel 2) that closes out the weekend before the 11 o'clock news. It isn't exactly the standard entertainment feature that usually inhabits sitcomland; without a laugh track, in fact, it hardly seems like real television. But the program is serious and informative in a documentary sort of way.

title: ENGLISH FARMHOUSE CHEESES COME TO AMERICA
description: Americans seldom have an opportunity to taste the quality cheeses produced in England, the ones labeled farmhouse to distinguish them from the majority of English cheeses produced in factories.

title: ENTEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $2,925,000. c-Net income includes a gain from discontinued operations of $,1000.

title: W.R. GRACE RESTAURANT UNIT BUYOUT
description: W. R. Grace & Company said yesterday that it had agreed in principle to a leveraged buyout of its restaurant group in a deal that should bring the company more than $500 million.

title: CALIFORNIA REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $85,000, or 3 cents a share, from the sale of real estate.

title: TOP EXECUTIVES SAY THEY BACK SENATE TAX BILL
description: The heads of most of the nation's biggest corporations say they are inclined to support a radical overhaul of the tax code passed this week by the Senate Finance Committee despite specific provisions that would be costly to their companies or industries.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: FOR YOUNG EARS Children between 6 and 12 years of age are the target audience of a trio of chamber musicians presenting a program today of early music for young people, ''Animals on Original Instruments,'' which are fables set to music. The trio, Andrew Appel, harpsichordist; Ruth Cunningham, flutist, and Cheryl Bensman, soprano, will accompany a narration by Barbara Zinn Krieger.

title: AM-Harris Link
description: AM International Inc. said it had agreed to buy the Harris Graphics Corporation for $22 a share in cash, or a total of $246 million.

title: Passover Thoughts
description: To the Editor:

title: Army Withholds Funds From LTV
description: The LTV Corporation said today that the Army had withheld several million dollars in scheduled payments for a new land vehicle, known as the Hummer, until repairs on more than 2,700 delivered vehicles and another 9,000 assembled units were completed.

title: GIBSON'S 16-YEAR TENURE DRAWS MIXED REVIEWS
description: In the final days of campaigning before Tuesday's election, Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson, seeking an unprecedented fifth term, has stressed that the city is on the brink of economic recovery.

title: CONCERT: KABUKI MUSIC
description: Ethnomusical demonstrations tend to be rather cut-and-dried affairs: the audience is shown how one instrument works, then another, with a few measures of music thrown in for spice. Therefore, one was grateful that the Nagauta To-on-Kai, which presented a concert called ''Nagauta: The Music of Kabuki'' at the Japan Society Wednesday night, devoted the entire first half of its program to extended demonstration.

title: A PARTY FOR THE TUXEDO AT 100
description: Robert Beaty thinks it is fortunate that Griswold Lorillard invented the tuxedo when he did.

title: UNREPORTED ROCKET FAILURE IS ACKNOWLEDGED BY NASA
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration acknowledged today that a research rocket misfired over the New Mexico desert late last month without any public announcement.

title: PLEA FOR LIVER RAISES QUESTION ABOUT DONOR SYSTEM IN NATION
description: Until two weeks ago, Alex Girard was a normal, healthy 9-month-old. Then he developed a rare, acute form of hepatitis. Today doctors said that he would not live unless he had a liver transplant within five days.

title: Heroic Refusenik
description: SHCHARANSKY. Hero of Our Time. By Martin Gilbert. 467 pages. Illustrated. Viking. $24.95. The story of Anatoly Shcharansky is the story of the ''refusenik'' movement in the Soviet Union, the story of all the Jews there who have fought for the right to emigrate. It is a story of courage and honor and ''perpetual optimism,'' and it is also the story of one man, who spent eight years in Soviet prisons and labor camps, defying a system intent on destroying him, with faith and will and humor.

title: Continue the Manned Space Flight Program
description: With vivid scenes of the Challenger space shuttle tragedy still fresh in our minds, it is hard to look ahead to new launches, explorations and technological discoveries. Yet, we must.

title: The Star Wars Chapter 11 Defense
description: The first question for President Reagan's Star Wars missile defense plan is, Will it work? Behind that lies a more basic question: Even if it works technologically, would it be cost effective? Only if it would cost the Russians more to build one extra missile than it would cost America to shoot it down. Otherwise, the Russians could defeat Star Wars -and the American economy - simply by building more and more missiles. Even good defenses will prevail only if they cannot easily be trumped by more offense.

title: SUMMARY SATURDAY: MAY 10, 1986
description: International Soviet officials are working to encase the damaged Chernobyl reactor in jacket of concrete, according to the head of the International Atomic Energy Agency. The process, technically called entombment, is intended to seal off any release of radioactive material, including the possibility that the molten radioactive fuel might melt through the plant's basement and into the groundwater, causing an explosion. [ Page 1, Column 6. ] Western Europe is squabbling over its home-grown produce and whether it is sufficiently free of radiation from the Chernobyl disaster to be sold for export. The countries have adopted diverse strategies in coping with the fallout and its effect on their agriculture. Italy is furious over the guidlines set by the European Community on what are acceptable levels of radiation. [ 5:1. ] U.S.-Philippine tension over American economic aid for the new Government declined after a meeting in Manila between President Corazon C. Aquino and Secretary of State George P. Shultz. Mrs. Aquino told Mr. Shultz that although a new $500 million aid package ''fell far short of what was needed'' to help the Philippines, she was reconciled to not getting any more at this time, her spokesman said. [ 1:4. ] Spain expelled a Libyan diplomat -the consul general in Madrid - and arrested a Spanish Army colonel who it said had asked Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi for money to finance extreme-right wing activities. Spanish authorities said the consul general, Saad Ismail, arranged a meeting between Colonel Qaddafi and Col. Carlos Meer de Rivera, the Spanish Army officer in custody.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50. 1. This marred a welcome. Explain. 2. The Supreme Court ruled that committed opponents of the death penalty (may/may not) be barred from juries in capital cases. 3. The six people who emulated Adm. Robert E. Peary were the first ever to have their achievement confirmed. What was the achievement and how was it confirmed? 4. After winning won a plurality in the Austrian Presidential election, Kurt Waldheim said that the controversy over his war record had (helped/hindered) him in his campaign. 5. Wimmin, yuppies and yuck have finally made it. Explain. 6. Tens of thousands of people moved to higher ground in the Northwest, fearing a disastrous tsunami that turned out to be not dangerous at all, What is a tsunami? 7. It was a sentimental day at the Kentucky Derby, with 54-year-old Bill Shoemaker riding Ferdinand, a horse trained by 73-year-old Charlie Whittingham, to victory. How many derbies had Shoemaker and Whittingham each won previously? 8. Although the tax bill passed by the Senate calls for only two basic rates, 15 percent and 27 percent, some upper-income taxpayers may find a part of their earnings taxed at (29/ 32/35/40) percent because of special provisions to keep the wealthy from reaping a windfall. 9. There were whooping, yelling and chanting at the ceremony in which the Rev. Donald E. Pelotte was ordained a Bishop of the Roman Catholic Church.

title: KLOSS VIDEO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a loss from a writedown of leasehold improvements of $131,000, and a loss from a reserve of $50,000 for inventory obsolescence.

title: REPUBLICANS VOW A FIGHT ON BUDGET
description: Congressional Republicans and the Reagan Administration today criticized the 1987 budget approved Thursday by the House Budget Committee. But the committee chairman, William H. Gray 3d, predicted it would pass the House.

title: Barbara Walters to Wed In a Private Ceremony
description: Barbara Walters, an ABC News correspondent and co-host of ''20/ 20'' news program, and Merv Adelson, chairman of Lorimar-Telepictures Corporation, plan to be married tonight at a private ceremony in Beverly Hills, Calif., a spokesman for Mr. Adelson said yesterday.

title: VISTA RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company is listed on the Midwest Stock Exchange.

title: NEW ASIAN IMMIGRANTS, NEW GARMENT CENTER
description: The American dream is the immigrant's dream, a vision so strong it can help change the face of an industry or the shape of a neighborhood.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL OAKLAND (AL) - Placed Jay Howell, pitcher, on the 15-day disabled list and called up Curt Young, a left-handed pitcher, from its Tacoma farm team.

title: Raymark Freeze
description: A Superior Court judge has frozen up to $10 million in assets of the Raymark Corporation in granting a temporary restraining order to a law firm that contends it has strong information that the company is about to file for protection under Federal bankruptcy laws. Raymark's vice president and general counsel, Harry D. Day, said the Trumbull-based automotive and machinery products maker was ''definitely not'' planning a bankruptcy filing. He said the company ''will move next week to get the order lifted as quickly as possible.''

title: INFLIGHT SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After writedowns of $5,550,000 on equipment and other assets. c-Net income

title: DANCE: BATTERY COMPANY
description: The Battery Dance Company celebrated its 10th anniversary with a performance Wednesday night at Schimmel Center of Pace University.

title: Massey-Ferguson
description: Massey-Ferguson Ltd., the Canadian agricultural and industrial machinery manufacturer, completed its previously announced financial restructuring plan, reducing its debt by about 50 percent, to some $408 million and spinning off 60 percent of its troubled companies and foundries division.

title: EXPEDITORS INTERNATIONAL OF WASHINGTON reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ZAYRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 26
description: The year-ago figures were restated for the acquisition in January of Home Club Inc. on a pooling of interest basis. Sales exclude leased department sales.

title: Norfolk Raises Bid for Conrail
description: The Norfolk Southern Corporation increased its bid today for the Government-owned Conrail railroad system, meeting the $1.9 billion suggested by Transportation Secretary Elizabeth Hanford Dole. Mrs. Dole said Tuesday that

title: Comings and Goings
description: Mike Boddicker, the right-hander for the Baltimore Orioles who has been on the disabled list since April 19 with a torn ligament in the middle finger of his pitching hand, has received clearance from team doctors to pitch today at home against the Kansas City Royals. . . . Wayne Garland, a former pitcher for Baltimore and Cleveland, resigned as coach of the Aquinas Junior College baseball team because he couldn't come to agreement with the school on a contract after donating his services for two years. . . . Jim Sundberg, the catcher for the Kansas City Royals, has agreed to a two-year extension of the six-year contract he signed with the Texas Rangers five years ago. Sundberg, 34 years old, has caught 1,639 games over 13 major league seasons. . . . Kelly Leadbetter, the leader at the halfway point in the $92,000 Hennessy Cup golf tournament in Chantilly, France, was fined $75 for slow play yesterday. The fine was the first under the new slow-play regulation introduced this year.

title: OVERLAND EXPRESS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income includes a gain from an accounting adjustment of $811,000.

title: U.S. INSPECTING FOOD FROM 11 NATIONS
description: A team of Federal inspectors stationed at the nation's ports and airports was placed on alert today to monitor food imported from 11 countries that may have been affected by radioactive material from the crippled nuclear reactor in the Ukraine.

title: Bulgarians Have Known Oppression at Many Hands
description: To the Editor:

title: PENN ENGINEERNG & MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Slave To Duty
description: I am sitting here in this foul, accursed cell marveling at what a splendid person I am.

title: TEMPEST IN MIAMI OVER A PLAYWRIGHT
description: In Dolores Prida's bilingual one-act play, ''Coser y Cantar,'' the Cuban-born New York playwright puts two actresses on stage to represent one Hispanic woman torn between her cultural roots and her growing Americanization.

title: U.S. Carrier Coming Home
description: The carrier Coral Sea and seven escorts sailed for home today, completing service in the Mediterranean that lasted more than seven months and included combat action against Libya. The Navy said the carrier would sail for its home port of Norfolk, Va. Accompanying it are the cruiser Biddle and the oiler Monongahela; the frigates De Wert, Jesse L. Brown, Jack Williams and Capodanno, and the ammunition ship Mount Baker.

title: CONTEXT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NASA PLANS INDEPENDENT REVIEW OF ROCKET DESIGN
description: The space agency, in an apparent effort to blunt expected criticism from the Presidential panel investigating the loss of the space shuttle Challenger, announced today that it would form an ''independent group of senior experts'' to oversee the redesign of the space shuttle's solid-fuel booster rockets.

title: CARE ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CHICAGO PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $3,277,000 for the latest quarter and $13,189,000 for the year-earlier period. The company did not report sales figures for the year-earlier quarter because they were derived mainly from the liquidation of assets and interest from investments on accumulated funds. The latest quarter's figures reflect the acquisition of Hoover Co., which occurred during the first quarter of 1985.

title: TELECOM PLUS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: F.B.I. Inquiry At Thrift Unit
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is investigating a thrift unit of the Financial Corporation of America and the unit's former chairman, an F.B.I. spokesman said. The investigation is based on Federal bank fraud and embezzlement statutes, he said.

title: SIM-KAR LIGHTING FIXTURE CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HERSCHEL BERNARDI, 62, PLAYED TEVYE IN 'FIDDLER ON THE ROOF'
description: Herschel Bernardi, a character actor best known for his starring role in the long-running musical ''Fiddler on the Roof,'' died yesterday of a heart attack at his home in Los Angeles. He was 62 years old.

title: CAMPBELL RED LAKE MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $18,566,000, reflecting the decline in value of investment in Lac Minerals Ltd. c-Net income

title: Politics, Not Muckraking, Breeds Cynicism
description: To the Editor:

title: THOR ENERGY RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
description: b-Net income The 1986 results include a $659,000 writedown of oil and gas properties.

title: Bulgarians Have Known Oppression at Many Hands; Armenian Insurgencies
description: To the Editor:

title: SUNLIGHT LINKED TO CATARACTS
description: STUDIES of Nepalese villagers and Australian aborigines have convinced many scientists, including some at the Food and Drug Administration, that excessive exposure to sunlight may cause eye cataracts. They suggest preventive measures for people who spend considerable time in the sun.

title: GRANT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: ISRAELIS SAY SYRIA SEEKS ARMS PARITY
description: Syria, strengthened by substantial rearmament from the Soviet Union, is trying to attain ''strategic parity'' with Israel, according to Israeli and some American officials.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: AFP IMAGING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Reflects a gain from the sale of the company's 50 percent interest in AFP-Matrix Imaging, effective Jan. 31. c-Includes an extraordinary gain of $121,955.

title: CHICAGO MAYOR'S BLOC HAS ITS DEBUT
description: At times it seemed to be democracy in action, and at other times it seemed to be the Chicago City Council's best impersonation of the Second City acting troupe lampooning the Chicago City Council.

title: Yankees Rained Out
description: Mike Witt threw five pitches, Rickey Henderson drew a walk, and then sheets of rain began to fall at Arlington Stadium tonight. It poured for 1 hour 24 minutes and there was a blackout in the ball park that lasted for several minutes before the game between the Yankees and the Texas Rangers was postponed.

title: THE COACH OF CAMELOT
description: Sometimes it seems like Camelot, as if it might have happened only in our imagination: The Knicks of the very late 1960's and the first part of the 1970's. The champion Knicks of 1970 and 1973. King Red and the Knights of the Round Ball.

title: Throwing the Book at the Church
description: Like any charitable organization, a church must render unto the Federal tax collector the records that support its eligibility for tax exemption. Whether the Roman Catholic Church must also yield such documents to citizens challenging its tax status is the question to which Federal Judge Robert Carter has just given a dramatic answer. He has ordered the National Conference of Catholic Bishops and the United States Catholic Conference to produce those records or pay $50,000 each, daily, until they do.

title: NO SIGN OF WAR WITH SYRIA, ISRAEL SAYS
description: Israel's Prime Minister and its army Chief of Staff issued separate statements today indicating that Israel has no intention of beginning a war against Syria and that they see no immediate evidence that the Syrians are planning a war with Israel.

title: SOVIET SAID TO TRY ENCASING REACTOR IN CONCRETE COAT
description: The head of the International Atomic Energy Agency said today that Soviet officials had told him they were working to encase the damaged Chernobyl nuclear reactor in a jacket of concrete.

title: ESPEY MANUFACTURING & ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ADAGE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: b-Net income The results for fiscal 1986 include an inventory writedown of $1,890,000 and a charge of $648,000 related to consolidation of operations.

title: CBS NEWS REPLACES ITS EXECUTIVE PRODUCER
description: CBS News, which has seen a steady erosion of the first-place standing of ''The CBS Evening News With Dan Rather'' in the evening news ratings competition, announced yesterday that it had replaced Lane Venardos as executive producer of the program.

title: Bid for Revere
description: Revere Copper and Brass Inc. said that the Smith-Vasiliou Management Company had raised its buyout offer for Revere to $23 a share, from the $20 offered earlier this week. The amended offer was received by an independent committee of the board of Revere, which makes aluminum and brass products. The company's shares were unchanged at $19.25 today in New York Stock Exchange trading.

title: FREEMONT GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After net realized losses of $2,000. c-After net realized losses of $120,000 and income from discontinued operations of $125,735,000, or $11.66 a share.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL DIAGNOSTICS reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
COMPUTER COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a loss from a reversal of a tax loss carryforward of $119,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $115,000 for the 9 months, plus gain of $777,923 from forgiveness of debt for the quarter and 9 months. c-Includes tax credits of $10,000 for the quarter and $253,000 for the 9 months.

title: WISER OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Jury Deliberations Start In Trial of Gov. Edwards
description: A Federal jury began deliberations today in the second trial of Gov. Edwin W. Edwards on charges of racketeering and fraud.

title: If You Can't Have a Nice Day, Stay Loose
description: To the Editor:

title: A TICKET TALE: POLICE ERROR VINDICATES 900
description: It began with two parking tickets and a complaint of police harassment in Queens and led to a weeklong investigation and a search through thousands of summonses.

title:
PATENTS;
Card-Matching Game
description: A card-matching game, to be used in sales promotion by such companies as supermarkets, was patented this week by Simon N. Winters of Toms River, N.J., and Y. Ting Chu of New York.

title: JUST AN HOUR EAST OF THE CITY, FARM COUNTRY
description: It is spring, and the magic of seed, sun and rain has transformed the most productive farm county in New York State into a brilliant blanket of green.

title: Hormel Strikers Lose Two Court Decisions
description: Striking employees of the Geo. A. Hormel & Company lost two legal battles today when one Federal judge refused to bar the international union from placing their local in trusteeship and another ordered them not to harass the trustee or remove records from union offices.

title: OFFICIALS SAY U.S. PLANS INDICTMENT OF TEAMSTER CHIEF
description: Federal prosecutors are expected to seek an indictment as early as next week against Jackie Presser, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, involving charges that he appointed union employees who did no work, according to Justice Department officials.

title: Reagan's Support for the Contras Is a Charade
description: As the debate over aid to the ''contras'' renews itself year after year without any appreciable change in the situation in Nicaragua, more and more observers of all political persuasions are beginning to question the premises of President Reagan's policies. Liberals argue that such aid can only drag us into war, while some conservatives say the defeat of the Sandinistas would require a much larger commitment. While there is truth in both positions, few commentators have really grasped the nature of the game the Administration is playing.

title: BEL FUSE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
World Bank Loans
description: China will get $190 million in loans to expand a major port and develop fisheries near eight cities, the World Bank announced this week. The bank also announced a loan of $34 million to encourage the use of natural gas in Indonesia, one of the world's major oil producers, and it said Tanzania would get an interest-free loan of $90 million to improve its roads and electric power network.

title: Lauri Levitt To Be Bride Of a Banker
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Levitt Jr. of New York and Westport, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lauri Levitt, to Michael Lawrence Friedland, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Friedland of Hewlett, L.I. A September wedding is planned. Miss Levitt, a division manager for Ralph Lauren Women's Wear Inc., in New York, graduated from the Fieldston School and Hamilton College in 1981.

title: Television
description: With Jacques Tati, Charlie Chaplin and the Marx Brothers to the fore, this is a cable film week for laughs and chuckles, vintage style. Sprucing up its programming image, the city-station outlet, WNYC-TV/Channel 31, has a new Sundays-at-9 P.M. festival of four Gallic gems by the bounding Tati, starting with ''Mr. Hulot's Holiday'' (1958) -then ''Mon Oncle'' (same year), ''Playtime'' (1968) and ''Jour de Fete'' (1949). These one-of-a-kind, prize-winning comedies - clean, gentle, subtle and generally hilarious - make wonderful light-hearted family viewing. There are English titles for the sparse French dialogue, though the films are primarily pantomime. (WNYC-TV is carried on cable Channel 3 in Manhattan and broadcast on UHF Channel 31.) At long last - the TV bow of the Chaplin satire, ''The Great Dictator'' (1940), with the great clown as a Jewish barber mistaken for a lookalike character named Adolf Hitler - Monday at 10 A.M., and Thursday at 7 A.M. and 4:30 P.M. on Cinemax. The Marx Brothers will be racing through their glorious anti-war spoof ''Duck Soup'' (1933), with the majestic Margaret Dumont and that rounded tamale, Raquel Torres. ''Soup's'' on at 1:05 P.M. Friday on WTBS. ''Four's a Crowd'' (1938) is a sleek, breezy caper with young Errol Flynn uncorking a surprising comedy flair and gamely matched by Olivia De Havilland, Rosalind Russell and Patric Knowles - Thursday at 10:05 A.M. on WTBS. ''The Whole Town's Talking'' (1935), with Edward G. Robinson and Jean Arthur - Thursday at noon on Cinemax - is a bright, snappy diversion about a meek office clerk mistaken for Public Enemy No. 1.

title:
IN THE NATION;
Chicago: New York Bank Builds a Home On the Wall St. of the Midwest
description: LASALLE STREET is home to Chicago's banking community, where the city's heroes are showered with ticker tape and its lawyers huddle in musty back rooms. Anchored at the south by the venerable Chicago Board of Trade and at the north by a currently volatile City Hall, it is the Wall Street of the Middle West.

title: NEW YORK COURT BACKLOG DWINDLING
description: A new system of scheduling and assigning cases in the state's courts has speeded the pace of justice in New York since its introduction in January, court administrators say.

title: THE RUSH TO WRITE 'SON OF IACOCCA'
description: FOUR years ago on this date, The New York Times hardcover best-seller list did not include a single biography, autobiography or memoir.

title: MUSIC: BERLIOZ REQUIEM
description: BERLIOZ'S Requiem dazzles an audience immediately with its scope and magnitude, but holds the attention with its subtlety. Few works scored for comparable forces - the composer asked for 210 singers and a huge orchestra - utilize them so sparingly.

title: SO MANY BOATS, NOT ENOUGH SPACE
description: OWNERS of pleasure boats who have waited until this month to look for a slip for their cabin cruiser on Long Island Sound will have a difficult search.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a diary excerpt from ''The War: A Memoir'' by Marguerite Duras was incorrectly dated in the May 4 Book Review. The passage was written in 1945.

title: SPY CASE IS SAID TO POINT OUT WEAKNESS IN U.S. OPERATIONS
description: One day before a former official of the National Security Agency walked into the Soviet Embassy to make his first delivery of highly sensitive intelligence information, Federal agents intercepted a telephone call setting up the meeting, according to law-enforcement officials.

title: THE VOICE OF LILITH IN THE TREES OF CHICAGO
description: THE SELECTED POETRY OF HAYDEN CARRUTH Foreword by Galway Kinnell. 165 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $19.95. HAYDEN CARRUTH, author of a score of volumes of poetry, now offers a very welcome selection. Uncompromising and very often dour or bitter, his poems are full of private twists and torques, yet sharply expressive for the rest of us too. Their range is wide. They can be minutely and delicately attentive, as in these lines from ''The Poet'': He hears the woodmouse scream -so small a sound in the great darkness entering his pain. And they can repossess the trauma of unresolved horror and anger, as in the opening poem, ''On a Certain Engagement South of Seoul'': When I was nineteen, once, the surprising tears Stood in my eyes and stung me, for I saw A soldier in a newsreel clutch his ears To hold his face together. Those that paw The public's bones to eat the public's heart Said far too much, of course. . . .

title: About Men; Lousy at Sports
description: I'VE DECIDED TO COME OUT OF THE closet. It is not an easy decision to admit openly that I really don't like sports. There - I've said it.

title: CRUSADING FOR TERM LIFE INSURANCE
description: ARTHUR L. WILLIAMS says he is just as pugnacious and crude as he was 20 years ago, when he coached winning high-school football teams in Columbus, Ga.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN RETAILING
description: MOST of the retail news this past year or so has centered on leveraged buyouts, mergers, battles for market shares, and other big-store news. But at the same time, with little fanfare and few headlines, thousands of tiny specialty stores have been springing up across the country, often stealing much-needed sales dollars from older, established department stores.

title: LACKLUSTER 'AGNES' AT THE CROSSROADS
description: LACKING the luster of bravura performances, ''Agnes of God'' is merely a meretricious little play. While titilating one with the sordid details of a contrived, convoluted plot that never gets resolved, the playwright John Pielmeier presumes to raise issues: mystic, abstract, religious and psychiatric.

title: Pocketbook Power
description: Eighteen percent of the wives in two-income American households earned more than their husbands in 1983, the Census Bureau reported last week. The 4.8 million women whose incomes exceeded their husbands' were more likely than the average wife to work year round and full time, to have no minor children at home, to have completed college and to be employed in professional specialties or executive, administrative or managerial occupations.

title: FOREIGN STUDY ENROLLMENT UP
