description: Despite recent threats of terrorism, enrollment in foreign college-study programs has increased for next year, according to an international student exchange organization.

title: Woman, 78, Is Found Dead, Apparently From a Beating
description: A 78-year-old Bronx woman was found dead yesterday morning in the bedroom of her Co-op City apartment, and the police say she might have been beaten to death by a robber who surprised her when she arrived home.

title: CONTRAS EXPECTING SHOWDOWN ON FEUD
description: A long-brewing power struggle among senior Nicaraguan guerrilla officials is expected to lead to a decisive confrontation in the coming week at a meeting of the top rebel leadership in Miami, according to several rebel officials here.

title: Stevenson Goes On
description: Teofilo Stevenson, the two-time world amateur boxing champion from Cuba, is trying for his third world title at the 1986 tournament in Reno, but, win or lose, at the age of 35 he does not have his eye on retirement.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
NEW TRANSIT GUIDES
description: It has taken some time, but the county has finally put mass transportation on the map - on 150,000 maps to be exact. At the beginning of this month, the county unveiled its new Transit Guide, a fold-out directory that includes large, multi-colored bus route maps, information on the county's transit system, and a discussion of its various transit services. The last such guide was put out in 1980.

title: DESPERATION DESCENDS ON OKLAHOMA
description: DON HUGHES watched glumly as 37 years of toil in the oil business turned to dust. The last few hands at his Hughes Drilling Company were hauling in his field equipment, stacking the huge blue-and-white steel rigs, putting away the water tables, the rat holes, the mouse holes and the dog houses. Mr. Hughes had laid off his wife the day before and this was Gaytha Phillips's last day after only four months as receptionist. Soon the gates will be locked and everything Mr. Hughes bought, including his posh office with its copper-hooded fireplace, and his Mercedes Turbo Diesel 300SD with radio telephone will belong to the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company.

title: Ellen Weintraub Wed To William G. Dauster
description: Ellen L. Weintraub, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Weintraub of Whitestone, Queens, was married yesterday to William G. Dauster, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Dauster of Fredericksburg, Tex. Rabbi Helene Ferris performed the ceremony at La Reserve, a restaurant in New York.

title: MAKING CLASSICAL DISKS IS NOW A FOREIGN AFFAIR
description: Sales of classical LP's, CD's and cassettes are booming these days, boosted by the popular acceptance of the compact disk. But while the United States counts as the leading classical-music market - making up some 40 percent of the worldwide total, by most estimates - the bulk of the profits are flowing to non-American record companies. The old days are long gone, when American recording giants like RCA and Columbia dominated classical sales, signing up the great conductors, singers, instrumentalists and orchestras to exclusive contracts. Today, Europeans control the classical record business, just as the Japanese manufacture the majority of the players on which those records are heard. American lovers of classical music have been reduced to the status of passive consumers, controlled from abroad like victims of cultural imperialism.

title: HEALTH & MEDICINE
description: A NEWLY FORMED task force will begin this month to consider whether New Jersey needs more cardiac services, ranging from sophisticated techniques for detecting heart disease to open-heart surgery programs.

title: NEW CASSETTES: WAJDA, WAGNER AND WALT DISNEY
description: Anyuta Featuring Ekaterina Maximova, Vladimir Vasiliev, Gali Abaidulov and Dzon Markovsky; choreographed by Vladimir Vasiliev to music by Valery Gavrilin, 1982 Kultur 68 minutes.

title: CRIME VICTIMS UNIT TO EXPAND
description: DEFENDANTS have always had people to represent them in court, and now, so will the victims of crimes. Joining the judge, prosecutor, bail bondsman, court reporter and defense attorney will be a victim's advocate.

title: Katherine Jassy To Marry in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Everett L. Jassy of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Katherine Anne Jassy, to James P. Savitt. The future bridegroom is a son of Judge and Mrs. David N. Savitt of Philadelphia.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: CARY GRANT IN RED BANK Cary Grant, in an unusual public appearances, will present ''A Conversation With Cary Grant'' at the Count Basie Theater in Red Bank Thursday evening. The program comprises film clips, comments by Mr. Grant and exchanges with members of the audience.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: STUNNING THE PUNTERS. By Robert Sproat. (Faber & Faber, Paper, $11.95.) Spending a few hours with Robert Sproat's delightful collection of stories is the best substitute this side of the Atlantic for stepping inside an English pub.

title:
FOCUS ATLANTA;
MIDTOWN AREA HITS ITS STRIDE
description: THE copper roof that will weather to a turquoise hue atop the first tower of Atlantic Center will be as distinctive a jewel in midtown Atlanta's skyline as the glistening gold-plated dome of the State Capitol is in downtown's.

title: Power Anyone? Tennis Is 'In'
description: Power equals success in the nation's capital, and as the czar of Washington tennis, Allie Ritzenberg wields his own brand of power. For tennis is the hot game here these days, and he is the man who signals thumbs up or thumbs down on membership in St. Albans Tennis Club, one of the city's most exclusive.

title: Clio, Feminist or Not
description: To the Editor:

title: Topics; Still in Circulation; The News That Was
description: With misplaced pride, NBC News last week presented a three-minute television interview with Mohammed Abbas, a widely sought planner of terror attacks. He used the opportunity to threaten Americans, clear up to President Reagan, with new attacks. Mr. Abbas has already been indicted in the United States for plotting the hijacking of a cruise ship that led to the murder of Leon Klinghoffer last October.

title: ABDUL-JABBAR STARS IN LAKERS' VICTORY
description: In the world of sports, old is in these days. First, there was 46-year-old Jack Nicklaus winning the Masters. Next was 54-year-old Bill Shoemaker riding Ferdinand to the Kentucky Derby victory.

title: Being A Jr.
description: My Dutch name notwithstanding, I was born and raised in Venezuela. I thought you might be interested in how Hispanic cultures handle the problem of differentiating between seniors and juniors.

title: Miss Van Ingen Married on L.I. To J. R. Fell 3d
description: Evelyn McLane Van Ingen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence B. Van Ingen of Glen Head, L.I., was married yesterday to John Ruckman Fell 3d, a son of Mrs. Robert L. Stott of New York and John R. Fell Jr. of Locust Valley, L.I., at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley. The Rev. Charles G. Newbery, rector of the church, officiated, assisted by Msgr.

title: RED IN TOOTH AND CLAW
description: INSIDE THE AQUARIUM The Making of a Top Soviet Spy. By Viktor Suvorov. 249 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $17.95. VIKTOR SUVOROV is the pseudonym of a gifted Russian who served as an officer in Soviet military intelligence, known as the G.R.U. Several years ago he escaped to Great Britain, learned to write in English and became a successful author. In this, his fourth and best book, he illuminates life within the secret order to which he belonged.

title: NATIONAL PARKS TRY TO COPE WITH MORE CRIME
description: On the eve of an expected summertime deluge of visitors to the nation's parks, Government officials say crime and related urban problems are increasingly intruding into many wilderness areas. And, despite some gains, they say the national parks are failing to deal adequately with the worst difficulties.

title: Space Project 'Slump' Cited
description: Recent launching failures have put America's space program ''in a slump and a very deep hole,'' Lew Allen Jr., director of the Jet Propulsion Laboratory, told a news conference today, referring to the shuttle loss in January and failures of unmanned rockets. He was here to speak at a Business Council meeting.

title: A Duvalier Aide Goes on Trial
description: As the court martial of Col. Samuel Jeremie got underway in a back room of the main police headquarters in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, there was a feeling that everyone was trying to find his way.

title: Loan Values Redefined
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, commonly known as Freddie Mac, is changing the definition of market value that it allows appraisers to use in determining a property's worth. The change is likely to lower slightly the amount a home buyer can finance through a mortgage and it could put some houses out of the reach of moderate-income families in areas of high demand like New York.

title: MADISON AVENUE CHIC
description: CLASSIC, traditional, preppy, tweedy - by whatever name, simpler, more elegant styles are setting the fashion pace these days. Nowhere is this more evident than along Madison Avenue's stretch of glittery international boutiques.

title:
ANTIQUES;
HISTORIC HOMES OF WATCHUNG HILLS
description: FIVE memorable homes in the Watchung Hills will be opened to the public next Sunday between 11 A.M. and 4 P.M. for a lengthy tour that will celebrate more than 200 years of American architecture and interiors as a serious - and satisfying - art form.

title: NEW JAZZ ORCHESTRA PLANS SEASON
description: A REPERTORY orchestra meant to do for big-band jazz what a symphony orchestra does for classical works will make its debut tomorrow evening at 8 o'clock in the Great Hall of Cooper Union.

title: WESTCHESTER BOOKCASE
description: ''IN SOUTHERN LIGHT - TREKKING THROUGH ZAIRE AND THE AMAZON'' by Alex Shoumatoff. Simon and Schuster. 239 pages. $17.95.

title: Lora Jean Fassett And J. P. Mason Exchange Vows
description: Lora Jean Fassett and J. Parker Mason were married yesterday at the Duke University Chapel by the Rev. Gerald L. Wilson, assistant dean of the Trinity College of Arts and Science at Duke.

title: OFFERING THE MANY FACES OF MOZART
description: ''MOZART is the perfect festival composer,''

title: PEDIATRICIANS: NOT JUST FOR CHILDREN
description: WHEN his doctor inquired during an annual physical whether he was experimenting with drugs or alcohol or had had any sexual experiences, Michael Brassill of Williston Park was surprised.

title:
ART;
BLACK AND WHITE AND LITTLE IN BETWEEN
description: IF THE idea of a multimedia group exhibition limited to work in black and white seems a little stark and uncompromising, a visit to Gallery North in Setauket should dispel such preconceptions.

title: Elspeth Farmer Weds in Washington
description: Elspeth Lanham Farmer, a law student, and James Joshua Rapperport, a computer software consultant, were married last night at the Sulgrave Club in Washington by Rabbi Harold White and the Rev. Vienna Anderson, an Episcopal priest.

title: Waldheim Leads In Austrian Vote
description: Kurt Waldheim did not set out to run on his war record, but there seemed little doubt last week that it carried the former United Nations Secretary General a step closer to Austria's presidency. Mr. Waldheim captured 49.6 percent of Sunday's vote to 43.7 percent for his Socialist opponent, Kurt Steyrer. The rest was split between Austria's emerging ecology movement and the far right. Mr. Waldheim is regarded as the odds-on favorite in a runoff against Mr. Steyrer on June 8.

title: 31 FOOD OUTLETS CITED BY NEW YORK OFFICIALS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 31 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: BULGARIA HAS MET THE ENEMY: IT'S ONLY ROCK-AND-ROLL
description: In the technical language of the report of the Central Committee to the recent Communist Party congress, it was called ''denationalization of the musical environment.'' What it means is rock music, live and recorded, which is as popular in Bulgaria as it is elsewhere.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
CHEF'S DREAM
description: Two years ago, Christian Bertrand, deputy chef at Lutece, the renowned Manhattan restaurant, began scouting for the perfect location to fill a long-time dream: to open his own restaurant.

title: Jennifer Olshan Becomes a Bride
description: Jennifer Sanford Olshan, a daughter of Marvin L. Olshan of New York and Malchia S. Olshan of Carpinteria, Calif., was married yesterday to Scott Graham Estabrook, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth L. Estabrook of Far Hills and Beach Haven, N.J. Justice Martin B. Stecher of State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the Harmonie Club in New York.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: 'OVERNIGHT' SENSATIONS
description: ''AND SO IT GOES'' Adventures in Television. By Linda Ellerbee. 255 pp. New York. G. P. Putnam's Sons. $16.95.

title: Sarah Gardner Becomes Bride Of Bank Officer
description: Sarah Peyton Gardner and Charles Seth Cunningham were married yesterday at the Congregational Church in South Dartmouth, Mass., by the Rev. Nehemiah Boynton 3d,assisted by the Rev. Arthur W. Hargate, an Episcopal priest.

title:
GARDENING;
EDIBLE ADDITIONS TO THE LANDSCAPE
description: PERHAPS the most convincing argument for growing one's own food and vegetables is their superior quality when compared with that from the typical produce market. If more gardeners could compare home-grown produce with commercial produce, more of them would be landscaping with fruits and vegetables.

title: CIVIC ASSOCIATIONS AND CIVIC CHANGE
description: This is in response to an article on March 23, ''Homes vs. Farming Debated.'' The Oakwood/Pulaski farmland in the Town of Huntington consists of a total of 300 acres owned by two farming estates. It is the last remaining significant open-space farmland in the Town of Huntington. The town is now about 97 percent developed with no category in its zoning ordinance to protect open space, farmland or conservation areas at all.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: PREAKNESS FESTIVAL Baltimoreans are holding a weeklong festival to celebrate the 111th running of the Preakness Stakes, the middle event in horse racing's Triple Crown.

title: NEW CASSETTES: WAJDA, WAGNER AND WALT DISNEY
description: The Sword in the Stone Directed by Wolfgang Reitherman; directing animators: Ollie Johnston, Milt Kahl, John Lounsbery, Frank Thomas, 1963 (G) Walt Disney Home Video 79 minutes. $79.95 ''Whoso pulleth out this sword of this stone and anvil is rightwise King born of England.''

title: IN SOUTH AMERICA, MALPRACTICE HAS A MORAL DIMENSION
description: IN several South American countries ruled or recently ruled by military regimes, doctors have begun to consider the involvement of their colleagues in the torture that has been widely reported over the last dozen years. In the process, physicians have begun to accuse and to pass ethical judgment on some of their own, primarily military or police doctors found to have had a role in torture sessions.

title: Who's Laughing Now?
description: Chances are, a group of California car dealers and an insurance company were snickering when they came up with a clever way to get some quick publicity in connection with the Johnny Mathis Seniors Classic golf tournamment last March: offer a new car and a $100,000 to any golfer who might (ha ha) shoot a hole-in-one during the tournament. The snickering stopped after Charlie Sifford stepped up to the tee on the 15th hole on the first round of the tournament and drove the ball into the cup, and nobody has been laughing since.

title: IN VEZELAY, ROMANESQUE MEETS GOTHIC
description: When you travel in the provinces of France, a large number of the things the guidebooks will lure you to are churches, basilicas and cathedrals. To be sure, there are many other sights - the castles of the Loire Valley, the beaches of Normandy, the Roman ruins of Provence. But the medieval or Renaissance church is the chief attraction of many of those villages and towns that lie along rural routes - which brings me to an admission of sorts. I have been wandering the byways of France for many years, enjoying that mix of old stone and green landscape that is the very signature of France, peering often into the solemn and mystically dim, chiaroscuro interiors of numerous village churches, harboring the secret, philistine belief that, from the artistic and architectural points of view, they are all pretty much alike. This is wrong, of course. In my heart, I knew it. But it took a visit to a special place in Burgundy for me to overcome, finally, this unfortunate habit of mind.

title: David H. Knights And Miss Francis Exchange Vows
description: Linda Sears Francis, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Warren William Francis of Providence and Narragansett, R. I., was married yesterday to David Holmes Knights, the son of Robert Elson Knights and the late Mary Holmes Knights of West Newbury, Mass. The Rev. Daniel Burke performed the ceremony at St. Martin's Episcopal Church in Providence.

title:
GARDENING;
EDIBLE ADDITIONS TO THE LANDSCAPE
description: PERHAPS the most convincing argument for growing one's own food and vegetables is their superior quality when compared with that from the typical produce market. If more gardeners could compare home-grown produce with commercial produce, more of them would be landscaping with fruits and vegetables.

title:
CRUSADING FOR TERM LIFE INSURANCE;
HOW THE INSURANCE NETWORK WORKS
description: ''The key issue at A.L. Williams is, we work for our people, they don't work for us,'' said 41-year-old Bill Orender of Dallas, a national sales director -one of 33 countrywide - for the Williams agency. The phrase sounds like a slogan, but Mr. Orender certainly does work for his people, who include some 250 regional vice presidents and about 6,500 Williams agents recruited either by him or by agents he has recruited in the past.

title: NEW CASSETTES: WAJDA, WAGNER AND WALT DISNEY
description: Cyrano de Bergerac Terry Hands's Royal Shakespeare Company production, starring Derek Jacobi and Sinead Cusack; directed for television by Michael Simpson, 1984 RKO Home Video 176 minutes. $59.95 The extravagant Royal Shakespeare Company version of Edmond Rostand's ''Cyrano de Bergerac,'' seen on Broadway in 1984, has been transferred intact to the small screen - with one decided advantage.

title: The Habits of Runners Are Different Abroad
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: SPAIN SEIZES 10 GUERRILLA SUSPECTS; LONDON REPORTS IT HAS 'PLENTY' ON DIPLOMATS BUT GIVES NO DETAILS
description: The Government announced today that it had ordered the expulsion of three Syrian diplomats involved in an investigation of terrorist activities in Britain.

title: Amtrak Offering Talks to Avert Strike
description: Amtrak offered today to negotiate with its engineers union and a spokesman for the passenger line said it was confident it could avert a strike that union leaders have said would begin at 12:01 A.M. Monday.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on May 4 about Port Chester, N.Y., misstated the status of a waterfront residential project. The village has received proposals from six developers and plans to announce its selection by the end of this summer.

title: TRANSFORMING LIES AT THE VERY HEART OF INSPIRED ACTING
description: Jack Lemmon, who has one of the most familiar faces of the American stage and screen, is virtually unrecognizable when he appears as James Tyrone in ''Long Day's Journey Into Night.''

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
GROWING ALTERNATIVE TO LITIGATION
description: We must move toward bringing people swift settlements and eliminating wasteful court disputes. We desperately need other ways to mediate society's conflicts.GOVERNOR KEAN

title: A SALES PITCH FOR AIRPLANE BUFFS
description: RETAILERS, particularly when they are hyping their wares, tend to let their metaphors soar into the wild blue yonder. But for the Cessna Aircraft Company, a new entrant to the retailing trade, the soaring is more than hyperbole. The Wichita-based company, long the nation's largest builder of private and corporate aircraft, has opened two stores whose whole raison d'etre is to inspire shoppers to learn how to fly.

title: AN EXPERT IN HOLDING AUTHORS' HANDS
description: ''SOMETIMES,'' said Owen Laster, ''the agent is the only constant individual in the author's life.''

title: READING RESTORED, EVEN IF IT'S A BORE
description: After receiving considerable ridicule, a school board has changed its stance and voted to go ahead with a mandatory summer reading program in the classics.

title: Topics; Still in Circulation; Political Tool
description: Stanley Friedman, the much-indicted Democratic boss of the Bronx, has an explanation for his legal troubles. ''Republicans in Washington will do everything in their power to embarrass the Democratic Party in New York State,'' he told reporters at the annual dinner of the Bronx Democratic organization the other night.

title: JAZZ: BARBARA CARROLL
description: WHEN Barbara Carroll moved into the Bemelmans Bar of the Carlyle Hotel, Madison Avenue at 76th Street, eight years ago, her singing had a rather tentative quality. That was understandable because for almost 30 years before that she had been simply an excellent jazz pianist, a prime star at the Embers during the 1950's.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Even a small amount of radioactivity entering the environment can become a source of great calamity.'' - Tass, the Soviet press agency, in its first discussion of the health risks from the Chernobyl nuclear accident. [ 13:1. ]

title: IRVING BERLIN AT 98 IS STILL THE GREATEST
description: It would be impossible to celebrate Christmas or Easter, salute the flag, march in a parade or serve in the armed forces without paying homage to Irving Berlin.

title: STAGE: PLAYWRIGHT MAKES ROAD THE VEHICLE
description: THE 10 characters in ''A Small Matter of Sacrifice'' by the Filipino playwright Tony Perez being presented at TOMI spend all but a few minutes of their two hours on stage riding in a van, two cars and a motorcycle going down a highway from Manila to a southern province and then back again. Mr. Perez, the director, Nonon Padilla, and the members of the cast seem to enjoy the challenge of revealing the dark history of a family and exploring large questions about human destiny in such an unlikely setting.

title: Skin Cancer Tests Offered
description: Free melanoma screenings, sponsored by the American Academy of Dermatology and the Dermatologic Society of Greater New York, will be conducted at six hospitals in Manhattan, two in the Bronx, and one in Brooklyn on May 17 and 18. One in seven Americans is afflicted with skin cancer, including malignant melanoma, dermatologists say. Information is available at (212) 421-8990.

title: Miss Edmunds Bride Of Dennis Louis Zakas
description: Marietta Page Edmunds, an associate in the investment banking division of Morgan Stanley & Company, and Dennis Louis Zakas, an associate in the law firm of Winthrop, Stimson, Putnam & Roberts, both in New York, were married yesterday at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in Richmond. The Rev. Reno S. Harp Jr. performed the ceremony assisted by the Rev. Constantine N. Dombalis, Dean of the Greek Orthodox Cathedral in Richmond.

title: NEW PRESIDENT FOR A GROWING SLEEPY HOLLOW
description: WHEN Richard F. Halverson assumes his duties as president of Sleepy Hollow Restorations next month, he will lead an organization about to broaden its base of operations beyond the county to include the entire Hudson River Valley region. The Tarrytown-based organization, which came into being with the personal and financial support of John D. Rockefeller Jr., plans a series of initiatives designed to preserve the quality of life in the Hudson River Valley as it enters the 21st century - initiatives inspired by concern for the region by current Rockefeller family members.

title: WITNESSES FOR MRS. JOHNSON SAY COUPLE WERE AFFECTIONATE
description: Lawyers for Barbara Piasecka Johnson, who is trying to protect a will that awards her virtually the entire $500 million estate of her late husband, J. Seward Johnson, ended the week by presenting testimony from a nun and a maid who depicted the couple as ''affectionate.''

title: A SUCCESS STORY THAT STARTED IN A CHICKEN COOP
description: GROWING up in New York City, Eugene Garfield spent hours in the public library reading, not books, but titles. By the time he was out of high school, he had scanned them all and organized them in his head.

title: Developers Court Tenants With Broad Concessions
description: IN city after city, the commercial real-estate industry is suffering from role reversal. Tenants who used to cower in fear before the extortionate demands of developers now are themselves making outrageous demands and finding that desperate owners of empty new buildings are eager to satisfy them.

title: LOW-COST POWER: O'ROURKE SAYS HE IS 'MORE REALISTIC'
description: EIGHT months after he filed a lawsuit to force the New York State Power Authority to give Westchester a block of low-cost energy now allocated to upstate users, County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke is backing off from the demand.

title: Closing In On High-Tech Crime
description: While television and movies have romanticized the peculiar charm of ''hackers'' - whizzes who use home computers to invade government and corporate records - New York State officials have decided that hacking is simply a fancy name for trespassing.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
BONDS
description: WHEN she was 21 years old, Linda met the woman who gave birth to her. The meeting took place in an ordinary setting, a luncheonette in White Plains and, to anyone who bothered to look, it must have seemed an unremarkable sight - two people chatting over coffee.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: SWANN'S WAY: The School Busing Case and the Supreme Court. By Bernard Schwartz. (Oxford University Press, $19.95.) This book tells about as much of who said what to whom at the Supreme Court as can be told.

title: WHEN MOSCOW LED THE WORLD IN COLLECTING MODERN GIANTS
description: The opening of ''Impressionist to Early Modern Paintings from the U.S.S.R.'' at the National Gallery of Art here was - as everyone knows -a diplomatic event. Though not one of the more carefree events of the kind that this visitor had attended, it augured well for whatever else in the museum world may come out of the agreement signed in Geneva last November.

title: THE CITY'S SCHOOLS ARE MORE FLUSH THAN USUAL
description: IT is customary around this time each year for pundits to note that municipal budgets are political documents. They are that, to be sure, but they are also financial statements, and as such often good indicators of the state of public agencies.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE HUNTING SEASON. By J. K. Mayo. (Henry Holt, $15.95.) When the playwright Anthony Moore opens the door of a cabin on the Channel ferry and discovers a murder in progress, he stumbles into levels of artifice and manipulation that give this elegantly written, character-rich mystery a satisfying depth.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: BLOOD SOLSTICE. By James Howard Kunstler. (Doubleday, $15.95.) James Howard Kunstler's fifth novel achieves a wonderful, if unlikely, combination of humor and suspense in describing how an ingenuous young reporter for a small-time newspaper becomes enmeshed in a web of evil when he attempts to investigate a sinister religious cult.

title: SOVIET STATEMENT ON CHERNOBYL
description: Following is the text of a Soviet Government statement today on the Chernobyl nuclear accident, as distributed in translation by the official press agency Tass:

title: Despina Papazoglou Married to Robert B. Gimbel
description: Despina Papazoglou, a daughter of Cybele Papazoglou of Athens and the late Demetrios Papazoglou, was married yesterday to Robert B. Gimbel, the son of Doris A. Meyer of Delray Beach, Fla., and Greenwich, Conn., and the late Bruce A. Gimbel, at the Grace Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. Ross M. Wright officiated.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: CHAMBER GROUPS LOOK EASTWARD IN EUROPE FOR REPERTORY
description: Many of the chamber groups now showing up on records are relatively unfamiliar names, and more than a few of them are looking to Vienna and eastward into Central Europe for their repertory. The obscurity of these ensembles - as in all such situations - is often unjust, sometimes deserved.

title: Article 123486 -- No Title
description: The mother of a 5-year-old boy shot to death by a police officer who thought the child's toy pistol was a real weapon has agreed to accept a $395,000 settlement from the city.

title: Copenhagen
description: To the Editor: Joseph Lelyveld's article on Copenhagen in winter (Travel, March 30) was most enjoyable if only to learn that a favorite city is just as endearing in the off season.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: AT A CERTAIN AGE. By Herbert Park. (William Abrahams/Dutton, $16.95.) Uncertainty intensifies ''at a certain age.'' Herbert Park's first novel makes this point through the narration of his self-deprecating protagonist, Donal Van Arsdale.

title: 'Hamlet' to Close at Public
description: ''Hamlet,'' starring Kevin Kline, will close following tonight's performance at 7:30 P.M. at the New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street. The production, directed by Liviu Ciulei, opened March 9 for a limited engagement; this evening's will be its 70th performance.

title: Angola Rebels Report Killing 67 More Soldiers and Cubans
description: The South African-backed rebels of Angola said they killed 59 Government soldiers and 8 Cubans and shot down a Soviet-built warplane in fighting this month.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK;
Fort Worth: Twin Benefits in 'Jaws' Gulps
description: LAYMEN have always been troubled by developers who bulldoze forest into prairie and then return to plant puny saplings where mighty oaks once grew. In the Trinity River bottoms in East Fort Worth, the Fort Worth development firm of Newell & Newell saves trees while saving dollars.

title:
ART;
DIFFERENT SPACES, DIFFERENT FORMS
description: A LOOK at some of Long Island's current gallery highlights also draws attention to the types of exhibition spaces. Within three categories -commercial galleries, artist-run ventures and public library exhibit areas - there are shows of more than passing interest.

title: Edward Joseph Collins Weds Donna Corroon
description: Donna Ann Corroon, a daughter of Mrs. Thomas F. Corroon of Garden City, L.I., and the late Mr. Corroon, was married yesterday to Edward Joseph Collins, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Richard Joseph Collins of Yonkers. The Rev. John Dillon, a cousin of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at St. John the Evangelist Roman Catholic Church in White Plains.

title: Clio, Feminist or Not
description: To the Editor:

title: Westchester: New Rochelle Project Brightens A Forbidding Entry to the City
description: THE sparkling bottle-green Cedar Plaza building being completed in New Rochelle is one of the smallest new office buildings in the county, but to its admirers, it looms large.

title: STATE ORDERS CLEANUP FOR A LANDFILL
description: A KINGS Park company has been fined and ordered to clean up a landfill that the State Department of Environmental Conservation contends has illegally operated on company-owned property for the last three months.

title: BUBBLING BIOTECHNOLOGY
description: After two years on the back Bunsen burner, biotechnology stocks have once again caught the fancy of investors. Prices of some issues have doubled in the past six months, and many have held onto most of their recent gains while the blue chips faltered.

title: College to Admit Men
description: Despite protests by students, Goucher College's board of trustees voted today to admit men as undergraduates in the fall of 1987, the first time in the school's 101-year history. The vote followed a four-month debate by faculty, students and alumni, and a major reason for the change was the declining number of college-age students.

title: HOUSEKEEPING IN THE ALPS
description: The cabin glided noiselessly down its cable from the Aiguille du Midi, a narrow peak 12,000 feet above sea level. Below, we saw chains of climbers, roped in lines of half a dozen and more, moving doggedly across the fresh snow. They looked insignificant and vulnerable against the rugged sweep of the slopes, under an electric-blue sky flecked with white clouds.

title: Put Atomic Reactors Under International Control
description: To the Editor:

title: CONSUMER RATES
THE FLOAT, AND HOW TO MANAGE IT
description: THE leaders of the seven largest industrial democracies agreed at the economic summit here last week to set up a system that would help them manage a sloppy world economy. Following are questions and answers about the plan, which its authors, Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d and Deputy Secretary Richard G. Darman, call ''international economic policy coordination.'' Question. What is ''policy coordination?'' Answer. It means that the seven summit countries - the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Canada and Italy - will try to coordinate their domestic economic policies to attain steady growth with a minimum of inflation. If they succeed, the power of their combined economies is such that they could pull the rest of the world with them.

title: Alida T. Chanler An Upstate Bride
description: Alida Therese Chanler, a daughter of Mrs. Hubert Chanler of Geneseo, N.Y., and the late Rear Adm. Chanler, U.S.N., retired, was married yesterday to Daniel Hugh Dierker, a son of Dorothea Dierker of Flagstaff, Ariz., and Dr. Hugh Dierker of Salem, Ore.

title: PHILOSOPHY IN A NUCLEAR KEY
description: THE WHALE AND THE REACTOR A Search for Limits in an Age of High Technology. By Langdon Winner. 200 pp. Illinois: The University of Chicago Press. $17.50.

title: IN SEATTLE, MICROBREWS ARE BIG IN FLAVOR
description: Brewing in the Northwest is taking a step back - back to fresh beers made by hand in small, cottage-industry breweries. Established by such diverse individuals as business school graduates, foresters and seasoned brewers with a yen to work for themselves, small breweries - or microbreweries, as those that produce less than 10,000 barrels annually are technically called - are multiplying in the Northwest like healthy yeast. And Seattle is the best place in the region to sample their products.

title: Perron Brings Stability to the Canadiens
description: Outside The Forum, on St. Catherine Street to the south and De Maisonneuve to the north, car horns were blowing en masse and fans were celebrating in the street.

title: Greenvale's Old Bull's Head
description: To the Editor:

title: The Incredible Improving Tax Plan
description: ''A second American revolution'' is what President Reagan called his sweeping plan to restructure Federal taxes last year. He had the hyperbole right but the details wrong. His complicated package begged to be rewritten and that's what the House did, producing an improved but still-complex bill. Now, miraculously, the Senate Finance Committee, which recently seemed bent on killing reform, has suddenly produced a truly radical plan that tops them both.

title: FOR TWO SUMMER THEATERS, A CONTRAST IN FORTUNES
description: ALTHOUGH Stratford's American Shakespeare Theater will be dark for the fourth successive summer, the sound of music will be heard on its grounds during four concerts in July and August. Meanwhile, the customary spring series of student performances is going on through May 24.

title: GRADES RISE OR FALL WITH THE STOCK MARKET IN UCONN CLASS
description: HILLEL WEISEL of West Hartford began investing in the stock market with $100,000 in January, and within 15 weeks turned it into $204,000.

title:
DINING OUT;
MISSISIPPI MUD IN SOHOBOKEN
description: IT'S SHADES of SoHo in Hoboken, where a new restaurant called Riverstreet features high ceilings, a high decibel level and trendy regional American fare. From the long bar lined with yuppies stopping off for a drink before returning to the the venerable train station across the way, to the friendly young staff - some of them actors between engagements - Riverstreet reflects Hoboken's lively new look.

title: Shultz Praises an Imperfect Seoul
description: Reagan Administration officials say the best way to nudge South Korea toward democracy is to encourage President Chun Doo Hwan and avoid angering his Government. Accordingly, Secretary of State George P. Shultz praised Mr. Chun during a 24-hour visit last week and steered clear of the country's most prominent civilian politicians, Kim Dae Jung and Kim Young Sam.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: IT'S not that the fashionable are unpatriotic. Not at all. It's just that patriotism doesn't have the immediate POW of, say, diamonds, and unless your name is Reagan, it's never helped one iota in getting a good table at Le Cirque or Mortimer's.

title: Stephen Wheeler, Broker, Married to Carol Alfenito
description: Carol Josephine Alfenito, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ralph F. Alfenito of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., and Sosua, Dominican Republic, was married yesterday to Stephen Craig Wheeler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Wheeler of Linthicum and Ocean City, Md. The Rev. T. Carleton Lee performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I.

title: NEW YORK MURDER, MIAMI VICE
description: CINDERELLA By Ed McBain. 262 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $14.95. ANOTHER PART OF THE CITY By Ed McBain. 230 pp. New York: The Mysterious Press. $15.95. WHEN these two new Ed McBain novels landed on my desk, a quick glance at the jacket copy told me which one I wanted to read first. I expected to be only mildly diverted by ''Cinderella,'' the sixth in the Matthew Hope series of macabre murder mysteries in the guise of transmogrified fairy tales. On the other hand, I expected to be wowed by ''Another Part of the City,'' a police procedural - the genre Mr. McBain virtually owns - set, unlike his venerable 87th Precinct series, in New York City rather than the mythical metropolis of Isola. But as it turned out, ''Cinderella'' is the gem, ''Another Part of the City'' the minor entertainment.

title: Carolyn C. Blackburn Wed to George Arfield
description: Carolyn Cartier Blackburn, a daughter of Capt. Cartier Blackburn, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Blackburn of Palo Alto, Calif., and Pensacola, Fla., was married yesterday to George Arfield, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Arfeld of Buenos Aires, and Punta del Este, Uruguay. The Rev. William Holiman performed the ceremony at the First Reformed Episcopal Church in New York.

title: THE SHAKERS' SIMPLE GRACE
description: WHETHER IT BE AN OBJECT AS SIMPLE as a wooden box or as intricate as a tall-case clock, the work of the Shakers more than a century ago is still considered among the purist forms of American design. Function and simplicity were what mattered most to this utopian society. The graceful lines and perfect proportions of everything they made -from their buildings and furniture to their stoves and textiles - have not simply endured; they now seem downright sophisticated.

title: T. P. Livingston Weds Miss Willis
description: Wendell Willis, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Willis Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and Seal Harbor, Me., was married yesterday to Thomas P. Livingston, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald G. Livingston of Morristown, N.J. The Rev. Richard Van Wely performed the ceremony at St. Barnabas Episcopal Church in Greenwich.

title: BALLET: BARYSHNIKOV IN 'GISELLE' AT THE MET
description: THE first ''Giselle'' of American Ballet Theater's season went off smoothly if not brilliantly Friday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. It was, with apologies to Charles Dickens, not the best of times nor the worst of times.

title: Diana Diaz Is Affianced
description: Diana Inez Diaz and Nicholas Williams Sheedy plan to be married in July, according to the announcement of their engagement, made by the future bride's adoptive parents, Mr. and Mrs. Martin Senzer of Great Neck, L.I. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart R. Sheedy of Syosset, L.I. Miss Diaz, who attended Queens College of the City University of New York, is a computer supervisor for the Rayman/Ridless Products Group in Manhattan. Mr. Sheedy, a graduate of the New York Institute of Technology, is a computer consultant for Datax Inc. in Manhattan.

title: MUSIC: SHOW TUNES
description: A DEBUTANTE'S view of the social history of the 1920's, ingeniously developed by Will Holt out of Broadway songs of the 20's, a couple of brief scenes by F. Scott Fitzgerald and a bit of seasoning wit from Dorothy Parker, provided the basis for a delightful program of songs by Irving Berlin, Richard Rodgers and Lorenz Hart, George and Ira Gershwin, Vincent Youmans and a few others at St. Peter's Church on Thursday evening.

title: LOUISIANA'S GOVERNOR ACQUITTED IN 2D TRIAL ON FRAUD CHARGES
description: A jury today found Gov. Edwin W. Edwards and his four co-defendants not guilty on all counts in their second trial on Federal fraud charges.

title: ON THE TRAIL OF COUGARS, CROCODILES AND GOONEY BIRDS
description: When Wolfgang Bayer was just getting started as a producer of wildlife films, he would close his eyes and toss a dart at a map of the world pinned to the wall to help him decide where to shoot his next project. Where the dart landed, he and his camera went. More recently, however, the man who has made more than 200 nature movies and is regarded as one of the world's top wildlife cinematographers - his latest effort, ''The Gooneys of Midway,'' will be shown on WNET/Channel 13's ''Nature'' series tonight at 8 - confines his dart-hurling to pubs. Nowadays, to help him select his subjects, he augments his own knowledge of the world's wildlife with such gadgets as computers hooked up to a nationwide network of scientific data bases. Yet, even sophisticated equipment can have its pitfalls.

title: ST. JOHN'S WINS TRACK TITLE
description: St. John's University produced only two gold medalists in the Metropolitan Intercollegiate Track and Field Association Championships yesterday at its Redman Stadium in Queens but defended its team title.

title: A DOUGHTY LILLIAN GISH TAKES A FRESH FLING AT COMEDY
description: Lillian Gish's fame is rooted in drama and tragedy, but, for her 104th film, the legendary actress has chosen a comedy.

title: Classical Music
description: The critical reputation of Richard Strauss, which fluctuated wildly both during his lifetime and afterwards, now seems to have stabilized. The myth that Strauss was a ''burn-out'' - a genius who created some magnificent works but then devolved into facile repetition - is no longer credible.

title: RESPONSE TO RADIOACTIVE IODINE 131 IS DEBATED
description: The accident at the nuclear power plant in the Ukraine has revived a debate over what should be done if a nuclear accident were to threaten a large American city.

title: 4 NEWARK SCHOOLS START PUBLIC FORUMS
description: FEARFUL that intelligent debate is dying on college and university campuses and eager to keep it alive, a committee of 15 faculty members from the four institutions here - the New Jersey Institute of Technology, Rutgers University, the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey and Essex County College - has begun a program of seminars on public issues.

title: Social Events; Mostly With Music
description: Safari on Third Avenue May 13 - The Safari Grill, Third Avenue at 65th Street, will be the appropriate setting for a dinner-dance benefit for the African Fund for Endangered Wildlife. Cocktails at 8 P.M. will begin the black-tie evening, followed by an exotic African dinner with such foods as bobotie, a curried minced-meat dish. After preventing the extinction of a rare species of giraffe, the group is now raising money to save the endangered black rhinoceros. Tickets, $150, from 212-737-9010. At the Crystal Palace May 13 - The National Foundation for Facial Reconstruction is the principal sponsor of the Institute of Reconstructive Plastic Surgery at New York University, where children disfigured by birth defects or accidents are treated. For the benefit of the foundation, a Movie Star Ball, fashioned after a Hollywood premiere, will be held at the Crystal Palace of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, starting at 9 P.M. Tickets for the black-tie evening -$55 for those 35 years old and under and $150 for those over 35 - from 212-644-0152 or 212-340-6656. Pan-American Music May 13 - A recital of classical piano and vocal music from Spain and North, Central and South America will be heard at an 8 P.M. benefit concert at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street. The evening benefits Pan American Musical Art Research, which promotes cultural interchanges among the Americas. A reception will follow the concert. Tickets, $50, from 212-362-8719. For the Civic-Minded May 14 - Founded in 1932 as an independent group to monitor the financial management of New York City, the Citizens Budget Commission is now expanding its watchdog role to include New York State finances.

title: Rhonda Hecht Is Married To David Everts, Broker
description: Rhonda Alline Hecht, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund H. Hecht of Corpus Christi, Tex., was married yesterday to David Tower Everts, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Nelson T. Everts of Needham, Mass. The Rev. Melvin A. Hawthorne, a Baptist minister, and Cantor Robert Bloch performed the ceremony at the James Burden Mansion, 5 East 91st Street.

title: AT NASSAU, REACHING OUT TO ALL
description: I AM having a great deal of difficulty finding any logic in Prof.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: May 11, 1986 Fiction

title: Music: Debuts in Review; NORWEGIAN OBOIST PLAYS TRANSCRIPTION OF FALLA
description: Brynjar Hoff -- Billed as Norway's leading oboist, Brynjar Hoff made his New York recital debut Monday evening in Carnegie Recital Hall. If one's criterion for fine oboe playing is an invariably sweet, purling tone, then Mr. Hoff fell short; for sheer polished technique, he is surpassed by any number of oboe principals in leading international orchestras.

title: THE COTSWOLDS, AN INN AT A TIME
description: My legs are strong, my feet are fit, my body is sound, but my back: well, even the best backs can turn on their owners during long hikes with a backpack. This is especially true of middle-aged backs. They turn surly when asked to carry 20 pounds up hill and down dale all day. And when asked to make camp and spend the night in a sleeping bag, the best middle-aged back in the world will revolt. Who's to blame it? Is this its reward, after 50 or more years of maintenance-free service?

title: Miss Weintraub, Architect, Weds
description: Deborah Jane Weintraub, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Weintraub of Austin, Tex., was married yesterday to Martin David Chilewich, a son of Norma Chilewich and Simon Chilewich, both of New York. Rabbi Bruce Goldman performed the ceremony at Easterwood Hall in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: Put Atomic Reactors Under International Control
description: To the Editor:

title: SPLIT BY ADOPTION, SIBLINGS MEET 35 YEARS LATER
description: Seven brothers and sisters, separated since early childhood by adoption, gathered with their mother for an emotional reunion today, the first time in their lives they have all been together.

title: TRAVELS WITH MOTHER
description: Ill blows the wind that profits nobody.

title: ENGINEERS TELL OF PUNISHMENT FOR SHUTTLE TESTIMONY
description: The rocket engineers who told a Presidential panel three months ago that they had argued strenuously against launching the space shuttle Challenger in cold weather on Jan. 28 have now informed the panel they have been severely punished by their employer, Morton Thiokol Inc., for their testimony.

title: THEY SEEK SPIRITUAL MEANING IN AN AGE OF SKEPTICISM
description: During a season in which the commercial and promotional machinery of the art world has been relatively quiet, some unusual artistic voices can be heard. They are not new. Indeed many have been around for some time. But they have been developing, for the most part, in unfamiliar places and at their own rhythm. Together they are spreading what may be a surprising message: ''spiritual'' is no longer a dirty word.

title: 'CARMINA' BALLET AT GLASSBORO
description: AMONG this season's many dance offerings, one tempting bit of exotica, rarely performed, is Carl Orff's electrifying ''Carmina Burana.''

title: SRI LANKA VIOLENCE SAID TO OPEN CRITICAL STAGE
description: Two weeks of violence in Sri Lanka have altered almost every aspect of a decade-long armed struggle between ethnic Tamil guerrillas and the Sinhalese-dominated Government of President J. R. Jayewardene, according to diplomats and Sri Lanka officials.

title: Food; THE MIDEAST, IN MINIATURE
description: ONE OF MY FONDEST CHILDHOOD memories is of summer vacations spent with my grandparents in Alexandria, Egypt, their summer home. My grandmother, a diminutive woman, was a superb cook who always allowed me to follow her around in the kitchen. She could be found there early in the morning arguing with her Sudanese cook. He had been trained by a French chef and was very proud of his knowledge of classic French cuisine.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Cincinnati Reds, at Shea Stadium, 1:35 P.M. The Reds will be batting against Dwight Gooden. (Television - Channel 9, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 1:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Texas Rangers, at Arlington, Tex., 3:05 P.M. This is the Yankees' first doublehader of the season, forced by a rainout of Friday night's game. (Television - SportsChannel, 3 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 3 P.M.) Expos vs. Los Angeles Dodgers, at Montreal. (Television - Channel 7, 3 P.M.) Braves vs. Philadelphia Phillies, at Atlanta. (Television - WTBS, 2:05 P.M.) Basketball Bucks vs. Philadelphia 76ers, at Milwaukee. Game 7 of Eastern Conference semifinals. The winner will meet the Boston Celtics. (Television - Channel 2, 1 P.M.) Biathlon Queens Biathlon, at Alley Pond Park, Cross Island and Grand Central Parkways, Queens. Second race in the Goldome Big Apple Series includes a 3-mile run, a 20-mile bicycle race and another 3-mile run. Boxing Frankie Warren vs. Gene Hatcher, 12 rounds for the vacant United States Boxing Association junior-welterweight championship, at Corpus Christi, Tex. Meldrick Taylor vs. Harold Brazier, 10 rounds, lightweights. (Television - Channel 4, 3 P.M.) Tennis Shearson Lehman Brothers Tournament of Champions, final, at West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, 12:45 P.M. (Television - Channel 7, 1 P.M.) Other Events AUTO RACING: The Winston and Nascar Atlanta Invitational, at Hampton, Ga. (Television - ESPN, 3 P.M. live, and 4 P.M. tape delay, respectively.).

title:
IN THE NATION;
Philadelphia: A Pioneering Developer Adds To Its Early Downtown Success
description: FROM his office at 1 Logan Square, Arnold S. Levy, vice president of the Urban Investment and Development Company, relishes a panorama of downtown Philadelphia. Between his 11th-floor window and the statue of William Penn atop City Hall lies the site of 2 Logan Square, Urban Investment's current $130 million office-tower project.

title: POLLS SUGGEST WOMEN SUPPORT DEMOCRATS IN '86 RACES
description: The women's vote, which disappointed some Democrats and feminists by not proving an effective weapon against President Reagan in 1984, could be critical to Democratic successes in 1986, recent polls suggest.

title: LIFE IN THE COUNTY CAN BE TOUGH FOR A 'PUNK'
description: ''NICE Head.'' ''Yes, it is, thank you.'' I have a good group of friends and would probably fit in well in high school except for one problem - my hair. Having spiked, punk hair in Northern Westchester is not easy. The difficulty stretches beyond school and farther. Even in town many people stare and some comment. Things such as, ''Nice head,'' or ''Haaair!'' or I just sense them staring.

title: Q&A
description: Question:Where can I write for information on challenging white-water rafting in the Northeast? - J. F., Mamaroneck, N.Y. Answer:Though it is getting late to plan a white-water rafting trip in many parts of the Northeast, including the Adirondacks of New York, where generally the season is April and May, the sport continues in northern Maine from May through early October. In most areas, the white water is a natural runoff from the snow melt and in late spring the level subsides, but in Maine the Kennebec and Penobscot Rivers are dam-controlled and water is released into them every day. White water flows all summer.

title: Rediscovering Sin
description: Ye gods! What is William F. Buckley Jr. suggesting? In this enlightened age of the libertine, when other intellectuals are heralding the post-Christian era, is Mr. Buckley suggesting that we replace a comfortable, subjective conscience with an objective moral code and guilt?

title: A Pay Fray
description: Some Government employees are annoyed that a new method of computing hourly salaries for Government Service-rated employees, instituted last month, has reduced their biweekly pay by amounts ranging from about $1 to close to $9. In addition, some employees, including those at the Library of Congress, have been told it may be necessary to ''make collection for overpayment'' for two weeks in March. The Office of Personnel Management says the new system should have been in effect then but the employees were paid under the old system.

title: CRIME
description: Who doesn't enjoy reading a well-done caper novel? Hugh Zachary has supplied one in THE VENUS VENTURE (Vanguard, $13.95). It's about a gang stealing the Venus de Milo and holding it for ransom, and it's as neat and readable an adventure as anything in its line within the last few years.

title: Senate Backs Military Reforms
description: Marching in close-order drill, the Senate last week approved without dissent a sweeping reorganization of the nation's military hierarchy. The 95-to-0 vote was hardly unexpected.

title: DISAGREEMENT ON THE 6:10
description: Sally Wendkos Olds's saga of the 6:10 was a story well told [ ''On the 6:10, a Drama in Two Acts,'' Opinion Page, April 20 ] . I, too, found myself angered by the behavior of the woman on the train who was so childish, and annoyed by the solution - Sir Galahad paying her fare.

title:
DINING OUT;
DELIGHTS FOR THE PALATE IN HARRISON
description: ONE approaches Jillyflower's with heightened expectancy, secure that Mark Filippo, the chef, will have created some new fillip, taking a wonderful idea from the traditional past and recasting it to fit a lighter contemporary mode. The language of the menu reveals that Mr. Filippo, like other star chefs, spends a great deal of time thinking about, and perhaps dreaming about, food and its combinations. Nothing perfunctory saps the efforts of this kitchen; certainly, for example, no ubiquitous vegetables of the day. Here garnishes and accompaniments take the form of melt-in-the-mouth, garlicky, flaky tartines; zucchini crepes; scallion timbales; tartelettes of leek - exquisite little morsels that surprise and delight the palate.

title: A CLEAN CHESAPEAKE'S COST
description: ''It is entirely possible,'' Lee M. Thomas, said last week, ''that somewhere in the country, toxic metals are being removed from the air, transferred to a waste water stream, removed again by water pollution controls, converted to a sludge, shipped to an incinerator and returned to the air.'' Like Mr. Thomas, the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, members of a House-Senate conference committee were wrestling last week with questions about such ''cross media'' pollution as they struggled once again to beat a Memorial Day deadline, when spending authority for the toxic waste clean-up program - the ''superfund'' - runs out. Some legislators worried, for example, that sending toxic wastes to sea on incinerator ships, as other lawmakers proposed, would risk polluting the ocean. As the following case studies show, the record of environmental programs with unintended consequences is a long one.

title: THE MAIL-ORDER BRIDE BUSINESS
description: TESSIE FLORENCE HAS BECOME an international matchmaker. Each month, working from her airy four-bedroom house in Santa Maria, Calif., the 42-year-old woman selects 224 photographs from the thousands she receives from Asian women looking for American husbands. In a home office complete with a photocopier and typesetter, she compiles a catalogue of those women and sends it, for a fee, to thousands of men in the United States and Europe who are seeking Asian brides.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: HAVE YACHT, WILL PARTY UNTIL last month, the only seagoing vessel that John Connell of Douglaston, Queens, and Shoreham owned was an undersized sailboat called a Sunfish. And no one would go out on it with him because he always turned it over, his wife, Rosemary, said.

title: WHEN DISASTERS HIT, AMATEURS LISTEN
description: SINCE word of the Chernobyl nuclear power plant disaster reached the West, one of the dozen radio sets mounted inside a tiny, white-trimmed brick building on Main Street in Newington has been trained on Radio Moscow, though what Radio Moscow does not say may be more interesting than what it does.

title: Sudan Government Accord
description: Prime Minister Sadiq el-Mahdi reached an agreement today with southern Sudanese parties on a broad-based coalition Government, his office said. The accord gives the parties a share of the 18 cabinet portfolios proportionate to the southern population, the statement said.

title: Eleni Pournaras Becomes a Bride
description: Eleni Alexandra Pournaras, a daughter of Irene Pournaras of Hamden, Conn., and the late Ulysses Andreas Pournaras of New York, was married yesterday to Albert Gallatin Blakey 4th, a son of Gretchen Vedder Blakey of Hellam, Pa., and Mr. Blakey 3d of York, Pa. The Rev. William Kehayes performed the ceremony at St. Barbara's Greek Orthodox Church in New Haven.

title: Judge on Trial
description: THE case against Justice Richard Neely of the West Virginia Supreme Court narrowed to one issue. Did he violate judicial ethics by requiring his state-paid personal secretary to baby-sit for his son?

title: CHILDREN EXERCISE IN THE DRAMATIC ARTS
description: ''ONE of the most important words is 'imagination' and that means you can go anywhere you want to -and that's what plays are about; when you do a play you have to use your imagination; it's one of the most precious things in life,'' said Kate Fuglei, a young actress from the Lincoln Center Institute in Manhattan.

title: GUATEMALAN STAYS IN STEP WITH ARMY
description: President Marco Vinicio Cerezo Arevalo, the first civilian to govern Guatemala in 16 years, has maintained good relations with the army in his first months in power, according to diplomats and Government officials.

title: SKEPTIC IN A CASSOCK
description: MAKING BELIEVE By John Leggett. 295 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $16.95. EVOKING both childish pretense and the act of compelling someone into belief, John Leggett's title, ''Making Believe,'' neatly implies the substance of his novel, reminding us how innocent an act of faith really is and how destructive it is to have to go along with something you don't believe in. ''Make'' stands for the creative, poetic aspect of belief and for coercion too.

title: Red-Faced In the Village
description: At a casual glance, the two buildings on Horatio Street in the West Village seem to be fairly plain structures, essentially just good examples of revived row houses. But the eye of a careful observer is drawn almost immediately to an area of somewhat lighter brick near the top of one of the buildings.

title: 4 Hurt in Juice Plant Blast
description: Four men were injured, one critically, when a cylinder of ammonia used in refrigeration exploded at an American Juice beverage factory here Friday, the police said. The explosion forced dozens of workers from the plant for about two hours until ammonia fumes were dispersed.

title: HANGING ON TO YOUR HEALTH INSURANCE
description: A little-noticed provision of the new budget reconciliation act, which President Reagan signed into law last month, will enable thousands of people who would otherwise have sacrificed their health insurance benefits because they lost their jobs, or because they were widowed or divorced, to continue their coverage. It should be particularly useful to people who are considered poor health risks.

title: The New Occidental
description: One of Washington's famous old restaurants, the Occidental, is only a few months from reopening on approximately its old Pennsylvania Avenue site, next to the reborn Willard Hotel. And former patrons should rest assured that the autographed photograph collection that encrusted its walls when the restaurant closed in 1971 has been preserved, largely intact, to recreate a familiar environment when the first order of crabcakes emerges from the kitchen in August.

title: IN SAN ANTONIO, OFFICIALS DON'T LAUGH AT TAX FIGHTER THESE DAYS
description: He seems to be everywhere, stalking the Alamo City something like a caricature of frontier justice in his ever-present Stetson, string tie, thick black glasses and cowboy boots.

title: Valerie Schwarz, a Lawyer, Is Wed to Steven J. George
description: Valerie Ann Schwarz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles K. Schwarz of Astoria, Queens, was married yesterday to Steven J. George, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stefanos George of Astoria. The Rev. Nicholas Anctil performed the ceremony at St. Catherine and St. George Greek Orthodox Church in Astoria.

title: REAGAN AND AQUINO NEED SOME TIME TO GET ACQUAINTED
description: ''SHE'S still an enigma to them,'' said one of Corazon C. Aquino's closest advisers. ''The Americans really had long, friendly relations with Marcos, and now they're faced with something entirely new.''

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: A NEW Federal report shows that air quality in New Jersey is improving more slowly than in the country as a whole, but Federal and state officials attribute this largely to efforts by other regions to catch up with what has already been done here.

title: NEW CASSETTES: WAJDA, WAGNER AND WALT DISNEY
description: Wagner's 'Parsifal' A film version by Hans-Jurgen Syberberg, with acting by Michael Kutter, Karen Krick, Edith Clever and Robert Lloyd, and singing by Reiner Goldberg, Yvonne Minton and Mr. Lloyd; Armin Jordan conducting the Monte Carlo Philharmonic and the Prague Philharmonic Choir, 1982 Corinth Video 255 minutes. $119.95 Some video reductions distort film's scale.

title: NEW FATHER FINDS NEW JOY IN RUNNING
description: RUNNING gives my life order and stability. No matter what the weather, what my workload, how I'm feeling, I usually go for a jog at least three times a week. Seasons change, my life changes, and I continually perform the comforting ritual of going for a run. I don the appropriate garb for the weather, I stretch, I do some leg lifts and sit-ups, I bound out the front door and take off for the winding paths of Rock Creek Park, about a mile from where I live in Washington.

title: CATERING TO THE 20-MINUTE SHOPPER
description: ONE businessman's disaster, to paraphrase a cliche, is another's opportunity.

title: Caroline N. Woodward, Harvard Aide, To Marry Richard Grant in December
description: Mr. and Mrs. John H. Woodward of Pottstown, Pa., and West Chatham, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Caroline Newberry Woodward, to Richard George Grant, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Grant of Sudbury, Mass. A December wedding is planned.

title: Miss Sauerhaft Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard J. Sauerhaft of Oceanside, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Margery Lois Sauerhaft to Robert Remler, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Remler of Forest Hills, Queens, and Westhampton Beach, L.I. A September wedding is planned by Miss Sauerhaft, a vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, and Mr. Remler, a chef at the Odeon resturant in New York. The future bride graduated cum laude from Vassar College and studied at tdhe International Institute in Madrid. Mr. Remler graduated from Boston University and the Culinary Institute of America.

title: TIGHTER RACE SEEN IN CONNECTICUT FOR G.O.P. GOVERNOR CANDIDATES
description: State Republican leaders, who had hoped to have a clear front-runner for the party's gubernatorial nomination by now, said this week that the race had become much closer.

title: 3D CHERNOBYL DEATH IS REPORTED
description: Today, for the first time since the Chernobyl nuclear accident April 26, the Government published detailed technical information for dissemination inside the Soviet Union about the health risks posed by radioactive emissions from the stricken Ukrainian power station.

title: AT LAST, FOR GREECE AND ALBANIA, WORLD WAR II IS COMING TO A CLOSE
description: Greece is preparing to put a formal end to a legal vestige of World War II by proclaiming that it no longer considers itself at war with Albania.

title: TORONTO
description: The first thing you notice about Toronto is the C.N. Tower - at 1,815 feet the world's tallest free-standing structure. An appropriate centerpiece for some bold, gleaming city of the future, it is not the perfect symbol for Toronto, a city of modest scale, red brick, clattering streetcars, comfortable homes, garbage almost obsessively collected and police who say ''Sir'' when they write you a ticket.

title: Verbatim; Time and the Nazis
description: 'Our challenge today is to insist that time will not become the Nazis' friend. . . that time will not fade our sense of the specificity, of the uniqueness of the Holocaust. . . that time will not lead us to make the Holocaust into an abstraction.' - Vice President Bush, speaking at a ceremony in the Capitol Rotunda to memorialize those killed in the Holocaust.

title: THE COSMIS MEETS THE ORDINARY. POW!
description: AMERICAN SPLENDOR The Life and Times of Harvey Pekar. By Harvey Pekar. Illustrated by Kevin Brown, Gregory Budgett, R. Crumb, Gary Dumm and Gerry Shamray. Unpaged. New York: Dolphin/Doubleday & Company. Paper, $6.95. HARVEY PEKAR was born, grew up and still lives in Cleveland. I first ran across his name in the 1960's, when he was reviewing jazz records for Down Beat magazine. Since then, he has broadened his scope as an essayist, treating such diverse topics as the comedy team Bob and Ray, the novelists Daniel Fuchs and Henry Roth and aspects of African history. Most of his energies, however, have gone into ''American Splendor,'' an ''adult comic book'' he produces with R. Crumb and other artists. As Mr. Crumb explains in his introduction to this anthology of stories from 10 years of the magazine's issues, Mr. Pekar ''writes the stories in a crudely laid-out comic page format using stick figures, with the dialogue over their heads,'' then gives them to an illustrator who turns them into full-fledged comic strips.

title: HOW FRANCE'S 'CRADLE' WAS ROCKED
description: ''Could the Americans have an inferiority complex toward us? Could they be jealous of our culture, our sophistication, our taste, our subtlety?'' -From the French newsweekly, Le Point, as quoted in a dispatch to The New York Times.

title: THINKING IN UNISON AT THE SUMMIT
description: THE seven major industrial democracies found much to agree upon last week at their summit in Tokyo, and they managed, as summiteers will, to finesse sharp differences. The statements they produced on world politics and economics were specific, but not without carefully cut loopholes and omissions, allowing each head of state to report home that the meeting had been a victory for, variously, the United States, Canada, Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Japan.

title: Q AND A
description: Retroactive Renting Ban Question: For more than three years I have rented a condominium apartment in Nassau County from a man who bought the unit as an investment. Recently, the board of directors for the apartment building passed a resolution saying that all units must be owner-occupied. My landlord has told me that I must move and that he will have to sell his apartment. I would like to know if the condominium board has the right to ban renters retroactively. . . . F D., Roslyn, L.I. Answer: The board is within its rights to change the bylaws of the condominium to prohibit owners from renting their apartments. But according to David Fishlow, a spokesman for the New York State Attorney General's office, the new ban on renting cannot be enforced retroactively. The board cannot require your landlord to terminate a contract that was accepted by that body when you signed your lease. You must be allowed to stay in the apartment for the full term of your lease. My Place or Yours? Question: Last year I married a man who lives in my building. Our apartments are small, rent-stabilized units. Each is too cramped for two people to inhabit full-time and we can not afford to move right now. We have solved this problem by continuing to live in our own apartments but alternating nightly which place we eat and sleep. My landlord has refused to renew my lease because he contends that my apartment is no longer my primary residence.

title: QUIET JOYS: CANOEING OUR OWN GOLDEN POND
description: IT'S hardly like taking the helm of the QE-2 or guiding the Nautilus under the polar ice cap, but when you are sitting in the rear seat of a canoe paddling on Mecox Bay there's no question you are in command of a vessel, even if no one knows it except your wife and the swans.

title: UP A BUSY RIVER
description: It seemed only fitting that the small gift shop aboard the Delta Queen should stock ''The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn.'' As soon as the shop opened after the riverboat embarked from New Orleans on a five-night cruise of the lower Mississippi, I bought a copy. I looked forward not just to rereading what I had first enjoyed in grade school near New York City nearly five decades ago, but also to doing so on the very river that Mark Twain sailed and loved and wrote about.

title: Social Security
description: To the Editor:

title: PIKE PLANNERS CLEAR A HURDLE
description: A MAJOR bloc of opposition to the proposed widening of the New Jersey Turnpike has been neutralized.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an art review on April 13 of a show entitled ''The Mystical Tale'' at the Thorpe Intermedia Gallery in Sparkill, N.Y., a paragraph concerning the work of Christine Heller was inadvertently omitted.

title: Theological Opinions And Catholic Doctrine
description: To the Editor:

title: GROUP RATES CARS ON COSTS OF CRASH REPAIRS
description: An insurance industry group has found that costs of automobile repairs resulting from crashes at 5 miles an hour varied widely depending on the type of car and the angle of the crash. Over all, the group said the Ford Escort showed the best results and the new Yugoslavian import, the Yugo, the worst.

title: Voters in 4 States Stick With Familiar Faces
description: The 1986 primary election season has moved into full swing, with contests last weekend in Texas and a few days later in Ohio, North Carolina and Indiana. Last week's results contained few surprises. Familiar candidates prevailed over newer ones, local and regional issues dominated and there was no clear clue to the year's major question: Will the Republicans, with 22 seats at stake, hold their Senate majority?

title: USE OF BUSING GRANT OPPOSED
description: A DISPUTE has risen in the Hewlett-Woodmere School District over the proposed use of a $130,000 state grant to bus a handful of district students to private Hebrew and Catholic schools in Queens, Brooklyn and Manhattan.

title: SOUP KITCHENS
description: WHEN the county's 22 food pantries and soup kitchens invited Westchester's corporations to lunch last Thursday, there was more than soup on the agenda. Following a tour of the Yonkers Council of Churches Emergency Ecumenical Food Pantry, representatives of 14 corporations were to join regular patrons of the Hudson Place Soup Kitchen in Yonkers for soup, sandwiches and statistics on what organizers describe as the ''staggering'' numbers of Westchester individuals and families dependent on the pantries. The soup kitchens, most of which have been set up in the last year, stretch from Yonkers to Peekskill and include locations in such rural areas as Somers, Brewster and Croton.

title: AIDE SAID CANADA 'COULD USE' DEAVER
description: While Michael K. Deaver was still a senior White House aide but after he had announced his intention to set up a lobbying business, a Canadian official told him that the Government of Canada could use a man of his talents.

title: FALLOUT FROM KYGER CREEK
description: ''It is entirely possible,'' Lee M. Thomas, said last week, ''that somewhere in the country, toxic metals are being removed from the air, transferred to a waste water stream, removed again by water pollution controls, converted to a sludge, shipped to an incinerator and returned to the air.'' Like Mr. Thomas, the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, members of a House-Senate conference committee were wrestling last week with questions about such ''cross media'' pollution as they struggled once again to beat a Memorial Day deadline, when spending authority for the toxic waste clean-up program - the ''superfund'' - runs out. Some legislators worried, for example, that sending toxic wastes to sea on incinerator ships, as other lawmakers proposed, would risk polluting the ocean. As the following case studies show, the record of environmental programs with unintended consequences is a long one.

title: Broker Engaged To Miss Murnane
description: Mr. and Mrs. George Murnane Jr. of Locust Valley, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Marianna McDonnell Murnane to Herbert Ludlam Smith 4th, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Smith 3d of Mill Neck, L.I. The wedding is planned for Aug. 23. Miss Murnane, who graduated from St. Paul's School in Concord, N.H., and Wheaton College, was presented at the 1981 Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball.

title: EXCERPTS FROM TRANSCRIPT OF COMMISSION SESSION
description: Following are excerpts from the transcript of a May 2 closed session of the Presidential Commission on the Space Shuttle Challenger Accident:

title: Apartment Hotels for Businessmen
description: LAST January, an $8.5 million, seven-story luxury apartment hotel called the Bedford opened in Stamford, Conn. Its 42 stylishly furnished, one-bedroom apartments with fully equipped kitchens and maid, telecommunication, phone and concierge services supply more of the comforts of home than most homes.

title: JAZZ: PAT METHENY AND ORNETTE COLEMAN TOGETHER
description: NOW that they've made an album together, ''Song X,'' the guitarist Pat Metheny and the alto saxophonist Ornette Coleman are on tour - one of the year's most significant jazz events. Their stop at Town Hall Thursday lived up to every expectation, with music that was complex, challenging and, above all, celebratory.

title: PART FIVE: INTO AFRICA
description: ALL GOD'S CHILDREN NEED TRAVELING SHOES By Maya Angelou. 210 pp. New York: Random House. $15.95.

title: TRUDEAU'S CARTOON LEGACY IS LIVING ON AT YALE
description: SINCE the beginning of his freshman year at Yale, Sabin Streeter said, he has put the drawing of a daily comic strip ahead of his course work and social life.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: Weeks This List on Week Fiction Week List 1 A PERFECT SPY, by John le Carre. (Knopf, 1 3 $18.95.) The tale of Magnus Pym, a British secret agent, and his father, Rick, a flamboyant con man. 2 I'LL TAKE MANHATTAN, by Judith Krantz. 3 3 (Crown, $18.95.) Rich and beautiful Maxi Amberville conquers the world of magazine publishing. 3 THE BOURNE SUPREMACY, by Robert Ludlum. 2 10 (Random House, $19.95.) The hero of ''The Bourne Identity'' foils a plot to seize Hong Kong and bring China into conflict with the West. 4 THE MAMMOTH HUNTERS, by Jean M. Auel. 5 25 (Crown, $19.95.) Ayla continues her adventures in the prehistoric world. 5 LAKE WOBEGON DAYS, by Garrison Keillor. 6 37 (Viking, $17.95.) Yarns about life in a small Minnesota town. 6 BREAK IN, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $17.95.) 4 8 Mystery, melodrama and bitter family rivalry in the world of British steeplechase racing. 7 LIE DOWN WITH LIONS, by Ken Follett. 7 15 (Morrow, $18.95.) An Englishwoman caught between the C.I.A. and the K.G.B., romance and loyalty, in Afghanistan. 8 THE HANDMAID'S TALE, by Margaret Atwood. 13 11 (Houghton Mifflin, $16.95.) In the America of the future, men and women perform assigned services. 9 HOME FRONT, by Patti Davis with Maureen 8 7 Strange Foster. (Crown, $15.95.) A semi-autobiographical novel by the daughter of President and Mrs. Reagan. 10 SEASONS OF THE HEART, by Cynthia Freeman. 9 7 (Putnam, $17.95.) A businesswoman is torn between devotion to her husband and her mentor. 11 PARADISE POSTPONED, by John Mortimer. 2 (Viking, $17.95.) The talk-show hostess's long professional climb. 1 Advice and Self-Help 1 FIT FOR LIFE, by Harvey Diamond and Marilyn 1 38 Diamond. (Warner, $17.50.) A diet for weight loss and physical fitness. 2 CALLANETICS, by Callan Pinckney with Sallie 2 24 Batson. (Morrow, $17.95.) Exercises to enable women to look ''10 years younger in 10 hours.'' 3 WOMEN WHO LOVE TOO MUCH, by Robin Norwood. 3 32 (Tarcher/St. Martin's, $14.95.) Ways to avoid or end addictive, unhealthy relationships with men. 4 THE RICE DIET REPORT, by Judy Moscovitz. 4 6 (Putnam, $16.95.) A diet developed more than 40 years ago at a clinic in North Carolina is explained by a successful user. 5* THE BE (HAPPY) ATTITUDES, by Robert 5 27 Schuller. (Word, $12.95.) Inspiration from a California clergyman.

title: Amy Kyle and Alfred Rose, Lawyers, Marry in Boston
description: Amy Lynn Kyle, the daughter of John D. Kyle of New York and Dorothy Kyle Brattstrom of Basking Ridge, N.J., and Alfred Otis Rose, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Winston J. Rose of Boxford, Mass., were married yesterday. The Rev. Herman T. Silvius performed the ceremony at the Trinity Episcopal Church in Boston, assisted by the Rev. Steven Wade.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in the Long Island Weekly on April 27 gave an incorrect age for Norman Pickering, inventor of the Pickering stereo cartridge. He is 67.

title: Wedding Planned By Miss Mangan
description: Margaret Mary Mangan and John Martin Murtagh, students at the Fordham University School of Law, plan to be married in September, it has been announced by the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. John Patrick Mangan of Bronxville, N.Y.

title: LITTON TO LEAD FAREWELL CONCERT
description: ''MAY is a perfumed word,'' Henry Wadsworth Longfellow wrote in his 1861 journal. ''It means youth, love, song.'' One can't promise love, but youth and song there will be in abundance next weekend. They will, in fact, be combined at the Horace Greeley School Friday at 8:30 P.M., when 26-year-old Andrew Litton leads the combined choruses of the Horace Greeley and Fox Lane High Schools, and the Chappaqua Orchestra, in Haydn's ''Te Deum'' and the C major Mass of Beethoven.
