title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Infinitesimal Adventures When Nancy Mairs was crippled by multiple sclerosis, she refused to abandon her sense of adventure, scaling it down instead to what she could manage. Here, in ''Plaintext'' (University of Arizona), she shares a few small adventures with her cat Burton, some tropical fish and a blind snake.

title: No Dogs Eaten in 'Whites'
description: To the Editor:

title: WHY IRISH HEROINES DON'T HAVE TO BE GOOD ANYMORE
description: I left my father's house. And ran away with you. And that was no bad choice You gave me everything. THAT poem was composed by Eileen O'Leary in 1773 after her husband had been killed by a British soldier. Her husband, Art O'Leary, who was an officer in the Austrian Army, refused to sell his favorite mare to the British soldier and was shot because Catholics were not permitted by law to possess a horse of more than $:5 in value. She describes in detail her husband's beauty, his white breast, his valor, the children who do not yet know of the tragedy and how she came to know of it when the horse came back, bridle trailing, bloodied from forehead to polished saddle. She mounted it and was brought to the spot where her husband lay. Your blood in torrents Art O'Leary I did not wipe it off I drank it from my palms.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, MAY 11, 1986
description: International

title: San Francisco: Disclosure In Home Sales
description: A NEW California law should leave the potential real-estate buyer with a little less to beware. Effective Jan. 1, 1987, sellers will have to complete a state-mandated disclosure form detailing potential problems with the house.

title: Officials Investigating Death Of Woman in Nursing Home
description: Officials today were investigating the death of a partly paralyzed 81-year-old woman who plunged down a flight of stairs in her wheelchair at a nursing home here.

title: 3 Condo Projects Thrive Along Busy Strip
description: ''ONCE you're up there, it's very attractive,'' said George Russell, marketing director for Foxwood, one of three new condominium developments built in the past four years along a three-quarter-mile commercial stretch of Route 117 at the northern end of Mount Kisco.

title:
IDEAS & TRENDS;
THE SWISS TRY TO CLEAR THEIR AIR
description: SWITZERLAND has the densest road network in Europe. It also has one of the continent's worst cases of ''Waldsterben,'' the death of forests from pollution.

title: PAYING LESS FOR A LAST-MINUTE TRIP
description: Few travel subjects elicit more inquiries from readers than last-minute discount clubs. They want to know how these clubs operate, how to get in touch with them and whether they offer genuine bargains.

title: Presser May Be Indicted After All
description: In what would be a remarkable about-face, Federal prosecutors are expected to seek indictment ofJackie Presser, the teamster leader, in connection with purported no-show jobs for union workers. Less than a year ago, after a 32-month inquiry into accusations of embezzlement produced indictments of several other teamster officials, the Justice Department had decided not to prosecute him.

title: Why Arab Moderates Don't Disown Qaddafi
description: To the Editor:

title: HANDMADE JAPANESE PAPER
description: Beautiful paper is one of the glories of Japanese craftsmanship. It also makes one of the best presents to take home: it is light in weight and difficult to break, and even a sheet of the finest hand-decorated paper will not even come near the price of, for example, a lacquer box of similar quality. In Kyoto, two shops offer unusual handmade papers and share a common interest in the continuation of the craft of paper making in Japan.

title: Carter Sprint Won By Love That Mac
description: Perfect weather, a packed house and a photo finish in the Carter Handicap marked a dramatic return to racing at Belmont Park yesterday.

title: DANCE: BALLET THEATER AND 'DARK ELEGIES'
description: BY restoring Antony Tudor's ''Dark Elegies'' to its repertory, American Ballet Theater has revived one of our century's finest and most unusual ballets. The work, to Mahler's ''Kindertotenlieder,'' received its first New York performance by the company since 1981 on Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: BRAKING THE SLIDE IN CHEMICAL SAFETY
description: THE World Bank recently made available an excellent manual for hazard assessment that should be of great assistance to fire chiefs and other state and local officials in assessing the disaster potential and risk-control programs in chemical plants. However, the idea that our municipalities should have to rely on the World Bank - an agency that is supposed to help the poorest countries develop into modern, industrial states - for safety advice is a sad commentary on the state of safety practices and regulation here.

title: IN MAYORAL RACE, ATLANTIC CITY FOCUSES ON BLIGHT
description: Despite multimillion-dollar infusions of tax money from casinos, this resort remains a blighted city except for its waterfront strip of glittering gambling palaces.

title: Connecticut: Retail Development Filling In Leftover Commercial Parcels
description: DIXWELL AVENUE in the center of Hamden has long been recognized as an exciting, if somewhat gaudy, boulevard of sound and light - a bustling thoroughfare where neon-lit restaurants and gas stations are intermingled among stores offering everything from bulbs to boots.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: FATHERHOOD. By Bill Cosby. (Dolphin/Doubleday, $14.95.) If you like Bill Cosby you will probably like the first 30 pages of his book.

title: Mary Haskin is Bride Of George W. Penny 3d
description: Union Chapel in Cape May, N.J., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Mary Dana Haskin and George Wilson Penny 3d. The Rev. Horace E. Colpitts, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Aberdeen Takes Cup
description: Aberdeen won the Scottish F.A. Cup today by beating Hearts, 3-0, at Hampden Park. Two goals by John Hewitt and a third by a substitute, Billy Stark, enabled Aberdeen to win the cup for the fourth time in five years. Aberdeen led by 1-0 at halftime.

title: THE DANCE: SOLOS BY JEFF DUNCAN
description: THERE is an increasing interest these days in the developed artistry of modern-dance performers in their 50's and 60's. Well past their technical and physical prime as dancers, such performers can hold the stage with the kind of exceptional if understated power that often marks the difference between dancing steps and performing dances. That was evident in a program of solos presented on Thursday at the Limon Dance Center by Jeff Duncan, a founder of Dance Theater Workshop in 1965 who is now based in Baltimore.

title: THE SPACE AGENCY CAN'T SEEM TO BREAK ITS LOSING STREAK
description: BETWEEN them, the Air Force and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration seemed to have an inexhaustible supply of rockets. But over the last 15 weeks, model by model, almost all the fleet has been grounded.

title: RANGERS ASSESS THE END
description: The bus waited to take them to the plane, which was waiting to bring them back to New York, where they had nothing to do.

title: PATRIOTIC PLENTY
description: This is a patriotic time of year, what with Memorial Day, Flag Day, the Fourth of July (and a refurbished Statue of Liberty) in the offing. Book-of-the-Month Records has taken note of the occasions by issuing an album for the season, a three-record (or three-cassette or two-compact disk) set titled ''Songs of Liberty,'' with the New York Choral Society and the Robert De Cormier Singers and instrumentalists.

title: Ban on Skateboards Draws Ire of Youths
description: About 70 irate teen-agers showed up Tuesday at a meeting of a City Council committee considering a ban on skateboards and won a promise of a compromise from the Mayor.

title: PORTRAITS OF THE PRESIDENTS IN MINIATURE
description: Ameripex, the international stamp show, will open May 22 at the Rosemont Exposition Center near O'Hare Airport on the outskirts of Chicago. One of the finest philatelic events in this country will get off to an exciting start with a set of four miniature sheets issued by the United States Postal Service. The miniature sheets depict the portraits of all deceased United States Presidents.

title: CHINESE FARE UNLIKE ALL THE REST
description: ''SEND in the clones'' might well be the unofficial slogan of many Chinese restaurants in Connecticut. In recent years we have seen one new spot follow another, with virtually the same menu, same dishes and similar ingredients.

title: FLOSS AND GLITTER ON LONG ISLAND
description: THE PRIVATE LIFE OF AXIE REED By John Knowles. 214 pp. New York: A William Abrahams Book/ E. P. Dutton. $15.95. ONE spends a pleasant evening with ''The Private Life of Axie Reed,'' John Knowles's ninth novel. This minor work by the author of ''A Separate Peace'' is easy-reading fiction, reminiscent in attitude of the later works of Tennessee Williams or Paul Horgan. Flossy people. Glittering surroundings. But we see characters boldly, in crisis, rather than in shadowy, ambiguous outlines. We observe their pseudo-adventurous lives, but barely come to know them. Seeking insight, we remain mostly voyeurs.

title: CURB WORK DRAWS CRITICISM
description: A PLAN to install curbs in a 200-acre area of St. James has generated concerns from residents who want to preserve the rural character of the neighborhood.

title: On Comeback Trail
description: It's been a long and painful ordeal for Tony Muser, the Milwaukee third-base coach who suffered severe burns in the gas explosion that rocked the Brewers' spring training complex Feb. 27, and it's not over yet. But the 38-year-old coach, who is still recovering from the burns after a five-week hospital stay, a series of operations and weeks of physical therapy, was able to rejoin the Brewers Friday night, and as far as he was concerned it was about time.

title: SYRIA TIED TO BERLIN BOMBING AND TO ATTEMPT ON EL AL JET
description: British and West German investigators say they have information strongly suggesting that Syria plotted a terrorist bombing in West Berlin and an attempt to place a bomb aboard an Israeli airliner at Heathrow Airport in London.

title: NATURE CENTER GIVES LESSONS IN CARING
description: ALEX PROVINCE of Madison held tightly to a wriggling baby raccoon. ''He's ready to eat,'' the 12-year-old said, bringing a little nursing bottle to the animal's mouth.

title: NIJINSKA, IN HER TIME, WAS A BALLET AVANT-GARDIST
description: Bronislava Nijinska is a choreographer whose achievement has always been more familiar to Europeans than Americans - largely because most of her ballets were originally performed abroad. As a result, the initial impact of her startling innovations as a choreographer, dancer, teacher and theorist was felt most strongly outside the United States and before she settled in this country, in Hollywood, in 1940.

title: 5 Die on Tunis Streetcar
description: A streetcar derailed today in a suburban Tunis neighborhood, killing 5 people and injuring 107, officials said. The accident was caused by human error, they said.

title: Rediscovering Sin
description: William F. Buckley Jr. has failed to consult the facts of history in his contention that a ''rediscovery of sin'' would improve our ''capacity to distinguish between right and wrong'' and lead us to ''better conduct, better lives, nobler visions.'' A vigorous belief in sin has never prevented people from committing acts of barbarism and cruelty.

title: A PLACE FOR WILDLIFE WILL BE KEPT SAFE
description: VARIOUS species of birds descended on Milford Point last week. So did various politicians - and the presence of both groups was no accident.

title: Apartheid Unrest Toll Reported Above 1,500
description: The number of deaths linked to South Africa's political violence in the last 20 months has surpassed 1,500 people, with one third of that total this year, according to a private monitoring group.

title: VANESSA REDGRAVE'S NEW ROLE MAKES A MAN OF HER
description: A tall, crew-cut, broad-shouldered man smashes a tennis ball over a net with enviable power; an attractive brunette weaves in and out of Manhattan traffic, attracting admiring glances, before settling into a coffee shop. Both are the same person: Dr. Richard Bradley who underwent a well-publicized sex-change operation to become Renee Richards. What is equally astonishing is that the two images coalesce in the person of the actress Vanessa Redgrave, who stars in a two-hour CBS-TV presentation, ''Second Serve,'' directed by Anthony Page from a script principally by Gavin Lambert and produced for Lorimar Films by Linda Yellen. It will be shown Tuesday at 9 P.M.

title: Irmgard Sell Married To Michael A. Tappan
description: Irmgard Friederike Sell and Michael A. Tappan were married yesterday at the Village Lutheran Church in Bronxville, N.Y., by the Rev. Paul Boecler.

title: A REGION HAS DIFFICULTY STAYING ON SPEAKING TERMS
description: AT a meeting of leaders of South Asian nations in December, President Junius R. Jayewardene of Sri Lanka declared dramatically that hopes for peace in the region rested on the shoulders of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi. ''He must not fail us,'' Mr. Jayewardene said. ''He cannot. Our duty is to help him to the utmost.''

title: Second Thoughts
description: For the first time, the Senate Judiciary Committee last week declined to approve a nomination by President Reagan for a Federal judgeship. The vote on the nomination of Daniel Manion (top), a conservative Indiana lawyer, for a seat on the United States District Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit in Chicago was 9 to 9, with 7 Democrats and 2 Republicans voting no.

title: HOUSING FOR AGED CANCELLED
description: THE Roman Catholic Diocese of Rockville Centre has canceled plans for a low-income housing project for the elderly in Westbury over what it calls a lack of cooperation from village officials and stiff opposition to the proposal from local residents.

title: Japan's Moral Crossroads
description: Japan is the first underdeveloped country to vault the dividing line and suddenly to confront the problems of wealth. That is provoking a fascinating self-reexamination, particularly within the rising power structure. These are mostly men between 40 and 50 years old, whom some call the ''neo-new leaders.''

title: A LANDFILL HAUNTS THE ISLAND
description: ''It is entirely possible,'' Lee M. Thomas, said last week, ''that somewhere in the country, toxic metals are being removed from the air, transferred to a waste water stream, removed again by water pollution controls, converted to a sludge, shipped to an incinerator and returned to the air.'' Like Mr. Thomas, the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, members of a House-Senate conference committee were wrestling last week with questions about such ''cross media'' pollution as they struggled once again to beat a Memorial Day deadline, when spending authority for the toxic waste clean-up program - the ''superfund'' - runs out. Some legislators worried, for example, that sending toxic wastes to sea on incinerator ships, as other lawmakers proposed, would risk polluting the ocean. As the following case studies show, the record of environmental programs with unintended consequences is a long one.

title: Data Bank: May 11, 1986
Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: SENATE

title: PREPARING A YOUNG DRIVER FOR THE ROAD
description: IN the kitchen on a quiet Sunday morning recently, I began teaching my 15-year-old son about driving a car.

title: Building Up Edgerstoune
description: A 1905 map of Princeton, N.J., shows that a big portion of the town was covered by the estate of A. Douglas Russell, a wealthy businessman. The estate, called Edgerstoune, sat on 371 acres of land described in a sales brochure from the 1920's as ''large fertile fields of rich loam free from stone.''

title: Venice: A City of Love And Death
description: What a surprise to see Erica Jong omit the name of a feminist predecessor in her list of famous novelists who have added to the myth of Venice (''Venice: A City of Love and Death,'' March 23). George Sand, nee Amandine Aurore Lucie Dupin, spent the winter of 1834 at the Hotel Danieli in the company of Alfred de Musset.

title: City's Size and Diversity Keeps the Market Strong
description: MANHATTAN remains the strongest and healthiest office market in the country, but that is not saying a lot in light of a national vacancy rate of more than 20 percent.

title: Mary Susca, Lawyer, Bride of A. M. Sabino
description: Mary Jane Susca, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Louis A. Susca of Jamaica Estates, Queens, was married yesterday to Anthony Michael Sabino, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Vito Sabino of Brooklyn. The Rev. Thomas Brosnan performed the ceremony at the Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Church in Jamaica Estates.

title: COMMERCIALIZING A GENTLE UNGULATE
description: TECUMSEH has seen its share of livestock sales over the years, but this farm belt Nebraska community had never witnessed anything like the extravaganza staged two weeks ago. Some 1,500 people, followed by network television crews, flew in for the largest and most lucrative llama auction ever held. Fred Hartman, a veteran with the gavel, put 247 llamas on the block, grossing a cool $1.5 million. The priciest turned out to be Oscar, a 2-year-old stud with ''banana-shaped ears'' who fetched $54,000, toppling the record of $51,000 set a year earlier.

title: THE TOTALED WOMAN
description: THE THIRD SEX The New Professional Woman. By Patricia A. McBroom. 282 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $16.95.

title: Dental Woes
description: To the Editor:

title: HELI-HIKING IN THE CANADIAN ROCKIES, VENTURING IN EAST AFRICA
description: Roughing It With an Assist From a Copter When summer comes to the Canadian Rockies, a little bit of winter will remain behind this year in the form of touring by helicopter. Taking a cue from the use of helicopters employed to transport skiers to the wilderness, four 10-day tours scheduled this summer under the title ''Darwin's Ranch and the Canadian Rockies'' will ferry visitors into roadless, remote areas for hiking in the company of experienced guides.

title: Elizabeth Dawes to Marry John Knight
description: Mrs. Gordon Townley Williams Jr. of Wyckoff, N.J., and Lyell Clark Dawes Jr. of Francestown, N.H., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Anne Clarke Dawes, to John Harvie Knight, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Eliot Knight of Madison, N.J. An Aug. 23 wedding is planned.

title: Not Talking
description: Johnny Carson, who used to roar at Joan Rivers's sharp-tongued barbs, did not find the comedian quite so funny last week. Miss Rivers - who got her first big break on Mr. Carson's ''Tonight'' show 23 years ago and whose career got a huge boost when she became the show's substitute host in 1983 - announced that she would star next fall in her own talk show, which will appear weeknights from 11 P.M. to midnight Eastern time in competition with the first half hour of the popular ''Tonight'' show on NBC.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Two Professions Feud in Boston --DOCTORS and lawyers are squaring off over a medical malpractice bill before the Massachusetts Legislature.

title: GOSPEL: CLEVELAND SINGERS
description: THE Rev. James Cleveland and Dorothy Norwood, two gospel singers who have been prominent since the 1950's, came to the Apollo Theater for three shows last weekend. Although they sang together in the Caravans and the Gospel Chimes in the 1950's, and have worked together frequently since then, Miss Norwood and Mr. Cleveland didn't sing together Friday night. But they did succeed in making believers shout, clap and dance.

title: PORCELAIN GROWS IN VALUE AFTER TWO CENTURIES UNDER THE SEA
description: David S. Howard, a London dealer, was uneasy two weeks ago on the eve of an Amsterdam auction by Christie's of a sunken treasure from a European merchant ship. The vessel had been wrecked two centuries ago in the South China Sea and was salvaged last year by a British captain and his crew. Up for bidding would be 100,000 pieces of vintage blue-and-white Chinese porcelains, and Mr. Howard was concerned that so many platters, plates, cups and saucers from this Nanking cargo might send prices plummeting for such dinnerwares.

title: Put Atomic Reactors Under International Control
description: To the Editor:

title: Put Atomic Reactors Under International Control
description: To the Editor:

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: FLOWERS AND HERBS When the Hamden Historical Society holds a flower and herb plant sale, as it will from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Saturday at the 1770 Jonathan Dickerman House on Mount Carmel Avenue, it offers a large variety.

title: NEW CASSETTES: WAJDA, WAGNER AND WALT DISNEY
description: This Is Video Clash Featuring the Clash CBS-Fox Video 31 minutes.

title: 10 Years Later, the Legacy of the Moscow Helsinki Group
description: It was 10 years ago tomorrow that several daring Soviet citizens got together and formed a group to monitor human rights in the Soviet Union. They knew they were courting disaster by challenging a state that tolerates no challenges, and in the decade since that day they have paid an enormous personal price for their activities. Nevertheless, even as their suffering continues, they have made a stunning contribution to the cause of freedom and peace within and between nations.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
POLICE TRAINING
description: County and local police officers in Westchester will no longer have to ''steal'' space in order to receive their training.

title: Nuclear Fire's Doubtful Gift
description: Some 84,000 Ukrainians have been evacuated from their homes because of the disaster at the Chernobyl nuclear reactor, and the health toll from radiation may climb fast. Even now, Soviet engineers may not fully understand what is going on in the stricken reactor or even when the accident will be over.

title:
LEISURE;
THE DOGWOOD'S DEMISE IS TAKING ITS TOLL
description: For the past eight years or so, homeowners in the Northeast have been saddened to watch the decline of their native dogwoods (Cornus florida). Questions about the trees have been rampant. The answers are not encouraging, only adding frustration to those who are already bewildered.

title: A TAVERN IS BURNED TO THE GROUND ON AN INDIAN RESERVATION UPSTATE
description: An unlicensed bar on the St. Regis Indian Reservation in upstate New York burned to the ground last night after a group of Mohawk Indians set fire to the building in a protest against a recent wave of alcohol-related traffic fatalities, authorities said. No one was injured in the fire. A crowd of more than 300 tribe members blocked firefighters from reaching the bar, which is on Route 37 west of Hogansburg, N.Y., near the Canadian border, according to the Hogansburg fire chief, Frank A. Lacerenza.

title: FOR VIETNAM VETERANS, FLORIDA WOOD IS 'HOME'
description: It is midmorning under a sweltering sun and a dozen Vietnam veterans living in the bush are working on their second case of beer.

title: Weapons Should Be Subject to Renegotiation
description: To the Editor:

title: CONRAIL DISPOSAL REMAINS UNSETTLED
description: A MICHIGAN Congressman may have pronounced dead the plan of the Federal Department of Transportation to sell Conrail to the Norfolk Southern Railroad, but a New Jersey Congressman believes the deal still has a spark of life.

title: LYME DISEASE IS UP AMONG CHILDREN
description: OF the 1,000 or so new cases of Lyme disease that are expected to be diagnosed in Connecticut this year, a third will be in children, said the director of a new clinic for the disease that was opened last month at Newington Children's Hospital.

title: WHY ARE TREES RIGHT-HANDED?
description: MEDITATIONS AT 10,000 FEET A Scientist in the Mountains. By James Trefil. Illustrated. 236 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $16.95. THE proper method for scientific investigation has been a subject of disagreement for a long time. One view, put forward by Galileo, Francis Bacon and Newton, is that the most effective way to discover scientific laws is through experiment - by setting up controlled situations in which the basic elements of some phenomenon can be isolated and studied independently of complications. Another view, championed by literary figures such as Goethe, suggests that the direct study of almost any phenomenon in nature can lead to insights about fundamental natural laws. In the words of Tennyson: Little flower - but if I could understand What you are, root and all, and all in all I should know what God and man is.

title: Inflation-Rate COLA For Social Security
description: To the Editor:

title: Recent Sales
description: Franklin Lakes $330,000 535 Reservoir Drive *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 16-year-old colonial; *2*pool, patio, Florida room; taxes $3,756. Maplewood $247,000 2 Hemlock Court *2*5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 25-year-old colonial; *2*slate roof, dressing room off master bedroom, porch; taxes $4,811. Mendham $277,000 6 Glengary Drive *2*3 bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 15-year-old colonial; *2*central vacuum, oak floors, slate patio: taxes $3,902. Phillipsburg $59,900 36-38 Washington Street *2*4-bedroom, 2-bath, older, 2-family Victorian; *2*full basement, Delaware River view; taxes $1,190. Short Hills $460,000 70 Harvey Drive *2*5 bedroom, 4 1/2-bath, 15-year-old colonial; *2*walnut paneling; basement rec room with wet bar; taxes $7,921. West Milford $215,000 38 Bordeaux Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 1-year-old contemporary; *2*cathedral ceilings, skylights, wraparound deck; taxes $3,684. OTHER AREAS Richfield, Conn. $557,000 19 Old Branchville Road *2*4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 12-year-old contemporary; *2*enclosed pool, pond, 2.1 acres; taxes $4,987. Ardsley, N.Y. $324,000 58 Eastern Drive *2*4-bedroom, 2-bath, 29-year-old contemporary; *2*wraparound deck, 2.9 acres, taxes $6,340. Mineola, L.I. $196,000 236 Westbury Avenue *2*4-bedroom, 3-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; *2*finished basement, aluminum siding; taxes $2,200.

title: The Practice of Theory
description: Every year at graduation time, hundreds of thousands of young men and women sit through ceremonies in which they are congratulated, exhorted, warned, given prophesies or promises. For many of the graduates, the words spoken by officials or teachers or honored guests are quite familiar - a celebration, often enough, of the intellectual life: its assumptions, purposes, opportunities. For years, those young men and women have been immersed in that life - trying to do the best job possible, and hoping thereby to gain the best possible footing in the so-called real world where grownups live.

title: YOUTH SPENT IN SOUTH AFRICA: BEAUTY, BEASTLINESS
description: IT was a year ago that the first violence in the current wave of unrest occurred in my hometown, Uitenhage, South Africa. The order for the police to shoot into a crowd armed only with sticks and stones, killing more than 20 black Africans, came from the Magistrate's Office, where I had once worked. I felt shock and shame, as if I shared some responsibility for this massacre, although I had left more than 40 years ago.

title: Congress Balks At Sale of Missiles To Saudi Arabia
description: The United States has sold billions of dollars worth of weapons to Saudi Arabia over the years, but last week Congress said no to the latest sale -advanced missiles valued at $354 million. The White House said President Reagan would veto the stop order, contending that it ''undermined U.S. interests and policies throughout the Middle East.''

title: Condos From the Crucible
description: In 1853, the J. H. Gautier Company built a crucible works on the Morris Canal in the Paulus Hook section of Jersey City.

title: EAST BLOC AIDES CITE ENVIRONMENT PROBLEMS
description: The environment of Eastern Europe is deteriorating and efforts to combat pollution lag far behind the West, according to experts from four of the Communist nations.

title: Paula Haynes Is Bride Of Geoffrey John Isles
description: Paula Hayward Haynes, a psychiatric social worker, and Geoffrey John Isles, a glass sculptor, were married yesterday in an Episcopal ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Church by the Rev. Warren Edward Haynes, the bride's father.

title:
ART;
WINNERS ON PARADE AT THE NEUBERGER
description: REGARDING the making of art in the United States, the left coast doesn't always know what the right coast is doing. That is the reason for the elaborate program called Awards in the Visual Arts financed by the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States and by the Rockefeller Foundation.

title: A WORST CASE THAT ISN'T A SCENARIO
description: THE scene at Kiev Station in Moscow each morning last week told more about the Chernobyl nuclear accident than most of the Government's pronouncements since the explosion April 26. Hundreds of women and children streamed out of trains from the Ukranian capital, which is only 70 miles from the damaged reactor.

title: Miss Podlubny Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leon Miecyzslaw Podlubny of Knighton, Leicestershire, England, have announced the engagement of their daughter Sara-Jan Victoria Podlubny to John Berry Millard, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Whittemore Millard of Old Greenwich, Conn. A July wedding is planned. Miss Podlubny's father is a retired textile engineer. Mr. Millard's father is president of Turtle & Hughes Inc., a distributor of electrical equipment in Linden, N.J.

title: Seven in Dayton, Ohio, Killed in Apartment Fire
description: Fire swept through a two-story apartment building here early today and killed seven people One child received minor injuries after jumping from a second-story window, a coroner's investigator said.

title: WORKING TO MAKE LIFE PRETTIER
description: VIENNA GIRL By Ingeborg Lauterstein. 383 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $16.95.

title: Loren Feldman Weds Jill Schoenstein, Editor
description: The wedding of Jill Schoenstein and Loren Feldman took place yesterday at the Philadelphia Art Alliance. Rabbi Susan Schnur officiated. Mrs. Feldman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Schoenstein of Princeton, N.J., graduated in 1982 from the University of Pennsylvania, four years after her husband's graduation.

title: HOMELESSNESS AS A BALLOT BOX ISSUE
description: A COMMITTEE of notable New Yorkers, including Cyrus Vance, Joseph Papp and the Rev. Paul Moore Jr., has launched a drive to get onto the November ballot a proposition that would require the city to provide adequate shelter for any homeless family.

title: Wendy Morgan Hart Wed To Stanford H. Brainerd
description: Wendy Morgan Hart, the daughter of Olcott D. Smith of Farmington, Conn., and the late Lucy Brainerd Smith, was married yesterday to Stanford H. Brainerd, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Howard S. Brainerd of Easton, Pa. The Rev. E. Page Rogers performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Middle Haddam, Conn.

title: Topics; Still in Circulation; Midlife Marvels
description: It's a thrill to watch a young athlete run faster, jump higher, pitch more strike-outs or slice microseconds off a swimming record. But it's also very much to be expected. Today's young champions, after all, are better fed and better trained than past record setters.

title: WHERE LATE-BLOOMERS SUCCEED
description: AS a high school senior in Wheeling, W. Va., Doug Wojcik expected to go straight from being an all-state schoolboy guard into a Division I college basketball program.

title: YANKS HOLD OFF RANGERS, 4-3
description: Someone asked Ron Guidry if the thought had crossed his mind, perhaps just once, that he might make some kind of strikeout history tonight. Guidry smiled.

title: Pele Aching to Play
description: With the Brazil World Cup team plagued by injuries, defections and dissension as it prepares for next month's competition, Pele, the nation's legendary soccer star, thinks he knows just what the team needs to restore some of its former luster: Pele. ''I know I can play at least 45 minutes in each game and this could be very useful for Brazil,'' the 46-year-old Pele told a Rio newspaper after the team arrived in Mexico for the matches.

title: IN THE LAND OF THE MAGIC ASTERISK
description: THE TRIUMPH OF POLITICS How the Reagan Revolution Failed. By David A. Stockman. Illustrated. 422 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $21.95.

title: NEW CASSETTES: WAJDA, WAGNER AND WALT DISNEY
description: Ashes and Diamonds Starring Zbigniew Cybulski, Ewa Krzyzanowska, Adam Pawlikowski; directed by Andrzej Wajda, 1958 Embassy Home Entertainment 97 minutes.

title: Miss White To Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. William G. White of Springfield and Harwichport, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Maureen Catherine White, to Steven Lawrence Rattner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Rattner of New York and Great Neck, L.I. A June 22 wedding is planned.

title: CONSERVING THE GLITTER OF TIMES SQ.
description: At night, sidewalks glitter with glass particles embedded in concrete. Overhead, images from ''supersigns'' leap from building to building and enormous inflatable advertisements - oranges, bananas and cans of beer - hang from office windows.

title: VANCOUVER'S FAIR BRINGS EVICTIONS
description: Ed Goulet, 65 years old, sat in a small hotel room, musing about his situation. Everything he owns was contained in two dirty cardboard boxes.

title: UPDATED CAR STEREO ENHANCES TRAVEL
description: With rrthe price of gasoline once again within the realm of reason, the traditional pastime of motoring for pleasure is back in style. And with many Americans leery of foreign travel in parlous times, it is expected that many people will take vacation trips by car this year. Chances are they can make their journeys more enjoyable by updating their car stereo systems, for it is an axiom of highway geometry that nothing shortens the distance between two points like a bit of music to suit one's mood.

title: MUSIC: AT FISCHER HALL, SEOUL PHILHARMONIC
description: THE Seoul Philharmonic Orchestra began its Avery Fisher Hall concert, as foreign visitors traditionally do, with two national anthems. These were followed by a contrasting pair of cho-yop.

title: PANEL MINIMIZES DANGER FROM WESTCHESTER A-PLANTS
description: The nuclear power center at Indian Point, because it is in the heavily populated New York metropolitan area, would probably be the most hazardous nuclear site in the United States in the event of any major release of radiation, according to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

title: BAYOU BOOGIE GETS A DAY IN THE SUN
description: Every year from the last weekend of April through the first weekend of May, squeezed between the torrential rains of spring and the oppressive heat and humidity of summer, New Orleans becomes the backdrop for a musical extravaganza called the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival. Drawing upon the swamps, bayous and flatlands of Louisiana and the neighorhoods, churches and clubs of the city, the festival showcases the obscure, the homespun and the once well-known along with today's most popular musicians.

title: AFTER THE BLACK DEATH
description: THE TIES THAT BOUND Peasant Families in Medieval England. By Barbara A. Hanawalt. Illustrated. 346 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $24.95. IN the last two decades the history of the family has enjoyed a remarkable popularity, partly, I think, because of the titillation to be derived from seeing others as we see ourselves. By that I mean so much of the writing in this field has been concerned with emotions and sentimentality that one cannot help believing that the writers are themselves concerned about their own feelings. Unfortunately, far too much of this historical work on the organization of family life has been bereft of a foundation in the exigencies of daily life.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: MUSIC and art have walked hand in hand at the Rosen house in Teaneck for many years.

title: The Birds Aren't Singing Again This Year
description: To the Editor:

title: PHILADELPHIA SEEKS HEALING A YEAR PAST POLICE BOMBING
description: Clifford Bond led the struggle a year ago to evict the radical group Move from his neighborhood, only to see his efforts give way to horror, bitterness, some guilt and an acute sense of betrayal. Now that a special grand jury has been called to investigate the events of last May, he says amen.

title: TOWN PROPOSAL TO BAN SURFING IS GREETED BY A WAVE OF PROTEST
description: A FEW years ago, a popular film depicted a beach community whose public officials were loath to tell vacationers that it was not safe to go in the water.

title: BRITISH STATEMENT ON EXPULSIONS
description: Following is the text of the statement by the British Foreign Office today on the expulsion of three Syrian diplomats and on official conversations with the Syrian Ambassador in London, Loutof Allah Haydar:

title: PROSPECTS
description: Tax Revisions If the tax revisions passed by the Senate Finance Committee last week make it through Congress, how will the economy fare next year? According to Irwin Kellner, chief economist at Manufacturers Hanover Trust, savings will drop, and consumer spending, economic growth rates and inflation will all rise.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: GARVEY. By Steve Garvey with Skip Rozin. (Times Books, $16.95.) Steve Garvey began as a sometime bat boy for the Brooklyn Dodgers and later rose through the team's farm system to become the most celebrated Los Angeles Dodger of the 1970's.

title: MUSIC: 'LA GIOCONDA' AND 'VERDI GALA' AT CARNEGIE
description: ON Tuesday, Eve Queler and her Opera Orchestra of New York offered a concert performance of ''La Gioconda'' at Carnegie Hall that included Ghena Dimitrova and Piero Cappuccilli in the cast. On Thursday the two singers, Miss Queler and her orchestra returned to the same hall for a ''Verdi Gala'' to benefit the orchestra and to celebrate its 15th anniversary.

title: 'Game' That Cuts Utility Bills
description: IT was billed as a new board game:

title: BREAKING WITH TRADITION
description: BERNARD DAURE IS GOING AGAINST A THOUSAND years of tradition, which, for a Frenchman, is no small thing. Mr. Daure is the owner of the Chateau de Jau, near Perpignan, in southern France. Like most of his neighbors in the region of Roussillon, Mr. Daure makes wine. Unlike most of his neighbors, he makes a wine that can hold its own in any company. For them, tradition is a prison, a stronghold of outmoded ideas and inherited fallacies from which they can't escape.

title: 'HELLO? IT'S WOLFGANG CALLING, NOW, ABOUT MY CONCERTOS...'
description: ''Great minds who have gone on before may be trying to contact you. They cannot get through because of the walls of misunderstanding that Earth people erect in ignorance of the mysteries of interplanetary spiritual transmission. Subscribe now and learn how to receive messages from departed geniuses whose mental fields of force still surround us.'' - From a brochure offering membership in a California book club.

title: Leslie MacNeil Is Engaged To Robert Helm Dobbins
description: Mr. and Mrs. J. Carleton MacNeil Jr. of Milwaukee have announced the engagement of their daughter, Leslie Ann MacNeil, to Robert Helm Dobbins, a son of Mrs. John Dunlap Dobbins of Louisville, Ky., and the late Mr. Dobbins. A June 21 wedding is planned.

title: Being A Jr.
description: Being ''numbered'' myself (3d) and choosing to number (4th), I believe the practice has produced a stronger bond between my son (the 4th) and his grandfather, Jr., than might normally be the case. There is much I have had to relate to him about my late grandfather - questions my son might not have asked if he had not received the same name. There is something in all of us that wishes for immortality, and the perpetuation of a name does that to a small degree. ANTHONY SMOLENSKI 3d Buffalo

title: From Pastorals to Hurricanes
description: Winslow Homer predicted he would be remembered for his watercolors, though when he began using paint pans in 1873 he was already 37. The first of the nearly 700 he did - bucolic farm scenes, wooden children and enigmatic women buttoned into modish Victorian dresses - show influences of his early work as an illustrator and reflect the longing of America after the Civil War for pastoral odes and new cultural vigor.

title: Clio, Feminist or Not
description: To the Editor:

title: Volvo Offers Peace of Mind
description: THE dealership was a vacant lot in a Navy town south of Providence, R.I., and the stock consisted of two new Volvos, miniature versions of 1946 Ford sedans. The year was 1958 and I was just back from Operation Deep Freeze in the Antarctic, hot for a car and unsuccessfully trying to talk sensible price to the salesman.

title:
ART;
STILL LIFE, OLD BUT STILL VIBRANT GENRE, AT THE STATE MUSEUM
description: EVEN the name of the genre, ''still life,'' tells one that the art is conservative. Still life has stayed essentially the same probably since the frescoes of Pompeii. Yet, at the State Museum here, Zoltan Buki, curator of the exhibition, has mounted a very pleasant contemporary still-life show that, in his words, ''compares and contrasts'' the work of each artist.

title: Gillian Jolis Engaged
description: Gillian Jolis, director of sales for Warner Audio Publishing, a division of Warner Communications, and Andrew E. Goldstein, an associate in the law firm of Tucker Globerman & Feinsand, both in New York, plan to be married June 7. The parents of the future bride and bridegroom are Bernard Jolis of New York and the late Ruth Krashes Jolis and Sarah Goldstein of New York and the late Victor Goldstein.

title: Jazz
description: Tributes to celebrated jazz musicians, which have become a regular part of the ''Highlights in Jazz'' series during its 13-year run, have always been among the most interesting and, often, surprising of the ''highlights'' concerts. They raise sentimental memories and give other musicians a welcome opportunity to pay their respects, musically, to very deserving colleagues.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE HORSE TRADERS. By Steven Crist. (Norton, $16.95.) In this engaging and colorful behind-the-scenes book, Steven Crist introduces us to a most untraditional collection of track millionaires and old-fashioned high rollers who are replacing racing's bluebloods and paying multimillion-dollar prices for untried yearlings.

title: Emily's List
description: Emily's List not only has a name that is distinctive from other political action committees, it also boasts of being able to generate much more money directly for its candidates than the garden-variety PAC's. By law, political action committees are limited to giving an individual candidate $5,000 in a primary campaign.

title: IS TECHNOLOGY CREATING A REALITY OF ITS OWN?
description: We are less than halfway through 1986, but already it is clear that television is having an extraordinary year. We grieved collectively over the Challenger tragedy because of television; we watched, and almost certainly influenced, the Philippine election. Other nations reacted to television, too. It seems unlikely that Moscow would have dispatched a diplomat to testify before Congress about Chernobyl if television coverage of the nuclear accident had not been turning against the Soviet Union. The particular diplomat, a second secretary in the Soviet Embassy in Washington - youngish, blow-dried hair, unaccented, if not quite colloquial, English - looked like an out-of-town anchorman. World events, it sometimes seems, are now in thrall to a technology. How an event looks determines how it is played out. Something unprecedented seems to be happening.

title: Lisa Sandy Is Married To Marc Sobel, Lawyer
description: Lisa Ann Sandy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice O. Sandy of Bowling Green, Ohio, was married yesterday to Marc Alan Sobel, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Arnold M. Sobel of Westwood, N.J. Rabbi Andre Ungar performed the ceremony at the English-Speaking Union in New York.

title: TEAMS REFINE PLANS FOR NUCLEAR ALERT
description: THE Soviet nuclear reactor accident at Chernobyl last month has focused new attention not only on fears of a possible accident in New Jersey, but also on measures designed to save lives if there is one, Maj. Joseph J. Craparotta, deputy director of the State Police Office of Emergency Management, said in an interview last week.

title: Rediscovering Sin
description: I have always found puzzling William F. Buckley Jr.'s worship at the shrines of both St. Thomas Aquinas and Adam Smith (''Thou Shalt Not,'' April 6). Even more puzzling to me is his belief that the sense of sin can serve as a guide to moral behavior. If sin is defined as a violation of a revelation from God, then, obviously, until we can agree whether God exists and what His or Her or Its commands are, we have no moral guidance.

title: Seattle: A 55-Story Tower Inaugurates A New Downtown Zoning Plan
description: ALMOST a hundred years ago, during a rare dry spell, a cabinetmaker spilled boiling glue on the wooden floor of his basement in downtown Seattle. Within hours, the core of the frontier town, which had been built from Douglas fir on steep hills next to a natural port, was in flames; the next day, the city was a smoldering heap under a red cloud.

title: CONCERT: NEWBAND
description: NEWBAND'S concert at Carnegie Recital Hall Friday night reintroduced us to the zoomoozophone -a vast mallet percussion instrument reminiscent of the gamelan orchestra but with huge capacities both for delicate timbral effects and astonishing levels of reverberance.

title: BEYOND CHERNOBYL, FALLOUT FOR LILCO
description: AS PARTIAL accounts of what is being called the world's worst nuclear power reactor accident continued to emerge from the Soviet Union last week, officials of the Long Island Lighting Company served notice that they would continue to press for Federal licensing of the Shoreham nuclear plant.

title: FOOTBALL LEAGUES READY FOR COURT FIGHT
description: AFTER three years of separate seasons but contentious coexistence, the United States Football League and the National Football League will take their differences into Federal District Court in Manhattan tomorrow, for the start of an antitrust case that could radically change the structure of professional football.

title: THE CALLINGS
description: JEFFREY VAMOS WAS 5 YEARS old when a tornado hit Warsaw, Ind., where he lived. In the middle of the night, Jeffrey's father, William, who was the minister at the local Presbyterian church, hurried the family into the cellar to wait until the tornado passed. When they came upstairs again, Jeffrey couldn't sleep. He climbed onto his father's lap and asked, ''Dad, why did God make tornadoes?''

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
FOOTBALL TAKES ITS GAME TO COURT, FOR HIGH STAKES
description: TOMORROW morning, all-star teams representing the National Football League and the United States Football League will face each other in what could become the most important football-related contest since 1967, when the N.F.L. and the A.F.L. played the first Super Bowl. Tomorrow, however, the two teams will be made up of lawyers, not players. And the match will take place in Federal District Court in Manhattan, rather than on a playing field.

title: More Charges And a Guilty Plea In City's Scandal
description: Four months after prosecutors began to suggest that some New York City officials had misbehaved, the municipal scandal has produced charges involving three agencies: the Parking Violations Bureau, the Taxi and Limousine Commission and the Health and Hospitals Corporation. There were developments last week involving two of them.

title: Alison Page Dobyns Wed
description: Alison Page Dobyns, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd Dobyns of New York, was married yesterday to David Farmer Aycock, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Benjamin Franklin Aycock of Greensboro, N.C. The Rev. John T. Broom performed the ceremony at Holy Trinity Episcopal Church in Greensboro.

title: ROOKIE A SPEEDY RIVAL FOR HENDERSON dien
description: THE dueling banjos were in the movie ''Deliverance.'' The dueling base-stealers will be at Yankee Stadium this week. They are Rickey Henderson of the Yankees and John Cangelosi of the Chicago White Sox. Henderson is the six-time American League base-stealing champion; Cangelosi is the young upstart base-stealer. They staged the first phase of their duel last week in Chicago.

title: Miss Loeb Plans To Wed June 22
description: Mr. and Mrs. J. Walter Loeb of Monsey, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Deborah Ann Loeb to Dr. Steven Lawrence Cohn, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Cohn of Bayonne, N.J. A June 22 wedding is planned.

title:
GARDENING;
EDIBLE ADDITIONS TO THE LANDSCAPE
description: PERHAPS the most convincing argument for growing one's own food and vegetables is their superior quality when compared with that from the typical produce market. If more gardeners could compare home-grown produce with commercial produce, more of them would be landscaping with fruits and vegetables.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEGACY. By Susan Kay. (Crown, $17.95.) Historical fiction is an uneasy hybrid, claiming the liberties of fiction while recycling the ready-made fabric of fact.

title: THE AGENDA: TRACKING THE VIOLENCE IN ULSTER
description: An ordinary month in Northern Ireland began with a young man's accusation that a soldier had put a rifle in his mouth, and it ended with a grenade attack on three policemen.

title: LIVERPOOL ACHIEVES A SOCCER 'DOUBLE'
description: Liverpool rallied to score a 3-1 victory today over its crosstown rival Everton to win the Football Association Cup, the Super Bowl of British soccer.

title: Court Orders Hearing For Ex-Representative
description: A Federal appeals court panel has ordered further proceedings in a request for a new trial by former Representative Richard Kelly, Republican of Florida, who was convicted in 1981 on bribery charges and is now in prison.

title: Developers Squeeze New and Old Uses Onto Difficult Sites
description: DAVID EDELSTEIN, a 36-year-old Manhattan developer who is president of the Sutton Land Company, is building a 40-story condominium tower called the Channel Club on York Avenue between 86th and 87th Streets.

title: MEARS SETS RECORD, GETS POLE
description: A nervous Rick Mears today drove the fastest qualifying lap in auto racing history - 217.581 miles per hour -and earned his third pole position for the Indianapolis 500 with a four-lap average of 216.828 m.p.h.

title: Betsy Smith, Lawyer, Marries Daniel Alpert
description: Elizabeth Ann Smith, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Smith of Clarksboro, N.J., was married yesterday to Daniel Alpert, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald G. Alpert of Woodbridge, Conn. Rabbi Roy Rosenberg and the Rev. William McGowen, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Irvine Auditorium of the University of Pennsylvania, from which the couple graduated.

title: Time Runs Out for Oil Units in Libya
description: The companies - Amerada Hess, Conoco, W. R. Grace, Marathon and Occidental Petroleum - had valued their tangible and intangible assets behind the lines in Libya at $2 billion, according to Congressional sources. The Treasury Department put the figure at ''more than $1 billion.''

title: Falling Inflation Prompts A Shift in Investments
description: AFTER several years of emphasis on office construction, major institutional investors across the country appear to be pulling in their horns. In the wake of overbuilding of offices in many cities, industrial projects and housing are expected to get a relatively greater share of attention from builders and their financiers.

title: Facing Facts Factually
description: I WAS AT THE BALLET. I had an aisle seat. The couple next to me, strangers in their early 40's, had that well-bred bearing of British royalty. The woman especially. The lights went down and the ballet began. Half a minute into the program, the couple began to squirm. To fidget. To twitch. Then to moan and actually groan. The woman finally flung herself upon her purse. She almost tore it to shreds looking for something. Medicine, I thought. No. Out came one of those little pen lights. She turned it on and with trembling hands rustled through the pages of her program. Her male companion seemed to be urging her to hurry.

title: LEAKS Vs. PUBLIC SERVICE ANNOUNCEMENTS
description: RONALD REAGAN, Caspar W. Weinberger and William J. Casey share a profound distaste for leaks to the press. But, as demonstrated once again last week, the President, the Secretary of Defense, and the Director of Central Intelligence have been inconsistent in their approach.

title: COMMUTING BY COMPUTER REMAINS LARGELY IN THE FUTURE
description: NOT so long ago, the personal computer was being touted as the harbinger of a new information age. Soon, the futurists said, the nation would be abuzz with tens of millions of workers ''telecommuting'' from their ''electronic cottages.'' Some even spoke darkly of exploited workers toiling in the ''electronic sweatshop.''

title: Iranian President Calls For Demilitarized Gulf
description: Iran's President, Hojatolislam Ali Khamenei, said today that he would like to see the Persian Gulf demilitarized, the Teheran radio reported.

title: DONOR LIVER CAME TOO LATE FOR INFANT IN BOSTON
description: A 9-month-old boy whose desperate need for a new liver caught the attention of Nancy Reagan died while undergoing transplant surgery today.

title: BOARD TO WEIGH UNITS ON PARKING AND PLANNING
description: COUNTY EXECUTIVE Andrew P. O'Rourke asked the Board of Legislators for authority last week to expand parking facilities within the county and to regulate local planning decisions when they have an impact on neighboring communities. Both would require approval by the state Legislature.

title: IN HAITIAN TOWN, A CRY FOR ATTENTION
description: The people of this town near the border with the Dominican Republic marched through the dusty streets here this week carrying flags of the Dominican Republic and red banners that they said were ''Russian flags.''

title: TAX REVISION GETS NEW LEASE ON LIFE
description: Bob Packwood snatched victory from the jaws of defeat in a stunning turnaround that saw his Senate Finance Committee unanimously pass a tax plan that even the Oregon Republican was close to calling a lost cause. The plan would greatly simplify tax filing for individuals by eliminating most deductions and reducing the number of individual tax brackets to two, with a top rate of 27 percent. For businesses, taxes would increase by about $100 billion, but the extra bite would be soothed somewhat by more favorable depreciation rules and other provisions.

title: PROTECTING PICTURES FROM ACTS OF GOD AND MAN
description: A RECENT television news program showed a California woman who had just left her burning home clutching a box. ''Everything else can be replaced,'' she told the television reporter. ''But the family pictures are irreplaceable. That's all that I took.'' Anyone who values photographs as history can understand the woman's feelings.

title: ASTROS RELISH EARLY SUCCESS, BUT CITY OF HOUSTON DOESN'T
description: UNTIL they collided with the Mets last week - it was, in truth, more of a rubout than a mere interdivisional series - the Houston Astros had been one of the early-season darlings of baseball. Like the Cleveland Indians and the San Francisco Giants, the Astros had become a curiosity, rising beyond reasonable expectations and finding themselves in first place in the National League West, of all places.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: ALTHOUGH the lunch menu at the King's Table in Hackensack on any given day ranges from baked ziti to pepper steak, the price never varies. It's all free, part of the Salvation Army's new feeding program for those in need.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a typographical error, an article last Sunday about efforts to establish stricter standards for regulating day-care facilities included an incorrect number. Last year and this year to date, 12 centers in the county have been the subjects of complaint and all have been closed or brought into compliance, according to records of the state's Department of Social Services.

title: Robert S. Bessin Wed To Jane Anne Kornfeld
description: Jane Anne Kornfeld, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Peter Kornfeld of Tenafly, N.J., and East Hampton, L.I., and Robert Steven Bessin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Bessin of Los Angeles, were married last night at Temple Sinai in Tenafly by Rabbi Bruce Block and Cantor Nathaniel Benjamin.

title: THE ROTTEN LUCK OF KATE AND BABA
description: THE COUNTRY GIRLS TRILOGY And Epilogue. By Edna O'Brien. 532 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $18.95. JUST as women used to have hope chests, Edna O'= Brien has a hopelessness chest, where she treasures up material for her novels. In the early books, the hopelessness is bitter and destructive; in her middle and late period, it is flailing and ironical.

title: THE STORY OF A TOWN
description: OUR FAMILY CHRISTMAS CARD THIS YEAR showed the five of us - my husband, Steve Bethel; our children, Audrey, Charlie and Willy, and me - lined up on our couch, beside the tree we had just cut down. Three good-looking and healthy children; two parents, married to each other. Snowdrifts outside, and a big black dog - just out of camera range - licking our feet. There is even an American flag that my sons like to use for parades, propped in the background. Our arms are around each other, and we are (except for Charlie, who sucks his thumb) laughing.

title: THE MAN WHO MADE US ALL KEYNESIANS
description: JOHN MAYNARD KEYNES Volume One: Hopes Betrayed 1883-1920. By Robert Skidelsky. Illustrated. 447 pp. New York: Elisabeth Sifton/Viking. $24.95.

title: ROHATYNS SET OFF DEBATE BY FAULTING GALA EVENTS
description: Ever since Felix G. Rohatyn and his wife, Elizabeth, publicly questioned the opulence of the charity balls of New York's so-called golden institutions, the rumblings have been reverberating within a small but socially prominent circle.

title:
IN THE REGION;
Long Island: Postmodern Project Points Way To Owner-Occupied Offices
description: THE Meadowbrook Forum, a 358,000-square-foot project proposed by the Jobco Organization for a 20-acre site in East Meadow at Mitchel Field, will be breaking with tradition in ways that are sure to catch attention.

title: 2 Catholic Groups Held in Contempt
description: A Federal judge in New York City gave the debate over the separation of church and state a new dimension last week, holding two major organizations of the Roman Catholic Church in contempt of court. The reason, he said, was their refusal to turn over documents subpoenaed in a six-year-old lawsuit over the church's tax-exempt status.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: GRANDMA NEVER LIVED IN AMERICA: The New Journalism of Abraham Cahan. Edited by Moses Rischin. (Indiana University Press, $19.95.) Abraham Cahan (1860-1951) came to New York from Russia in 1882 and is probably best known for his work on The Jewish Daily Forward, of which he became editor in 1902.

title: DANCE: JOAN LOMBARDI AND NOVENSEMBLE
description: JOAN LOMBARDI'S Novensemble presented a program of dance on Friday at the Nikolais Louis Dancespace that was distinguished by its pretty costumes, designed by George Hudacko. The dancers were attractive and personable and they moved well. And the five new dances presented, four of them by Miss Lombardi, touched upon a variety of themes and moods.

title: Miss Bibb Weds M. S. Yamashita
description: Elizabeth King Bibb, a daughter of D. Porter Bibb of New Hope, Pa., and Margaret Clark Bibb of Simi Valley, Calif., was married yesterday to Michael Shaw Yamashita, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Susumu Yamashita of Mendham, N.J. I. Jackson Angell, the Mayor of Mendham, performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's home in Mendham.

title: Endorsement for Democrats
description: Governor Cuomo, Attorney General Robert Abrams and Mark Green, the only Democrat who has announced thus far for this year's Senate race, won overwhelming endorsements at a statewide nominating convention of the New Democratic Coalition in Manhattan yesterday.

title: Small Tenants Finally Have Their Day
description: IN the world of commercial real estate, the large corporate tenant has always been the one wooed by developers. ''The small tenant is generally discriminated against,'' said William T. Yorio, a vice president of Cushman & Wakefield of Garden City, office leasing specialists.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LONG MARCH DIARY: China Epic. By Charlotte Y. Salisbury. (Walker & Company, $16.95.) For a woman who describes herself as a homebody, Charlotte Salisbury has seen more than her share of the obscure portions of the world.

title: PIT STOP IN PARADISE
description: THE SONGS OF DISTANT EARTH By Arthur C. Clarke. 256 pp. New York: A Del Rey Book/Ballantine Books. $17.95. ARTHUR C. CLARKE breaks all the rules. He writes best sellers that have virtually no sex or violence in them, no family tensions, no conventional heroes or villains. Despite these drawbacks, more than two million copies of his last science-fiction novel, ''2010: Odyssey Two,'' are in print. Before that his ''Fountains of Paradise'' sold in the hundreds of thousands, and his best-known books, ''2001: A Space Odyssey'' (co-written with Stanley Kubrick) and ''Childhood's End,'' are still in print after several decades. The secret of his appeal lies in his revival of the oldest form of how-to literature - philosophical fiction, which, borrowing tools from both logic and poetry, intends to tell us how to live and die with dignity.

title: Divers Complete First Step In Effort to Raise Oil Barge
description: Divers completed the first step today in raising a barge loaded with 840,000 gallons of fuel oil that sank in waters off the east end of Long Island last November.

title: BROOKLYN PRIEST SHOT DEAD IN CAR, APPARENTLY BY THIEF
description: A popular Roman Catholic priest who directed child-care services for the Diocese of Brooklyn and was about to receive his first pastorate was shot to death in his car early yesterday in an apparent robbery in downtown Brooklyn, the police reported.

title: Boston: Retirees Down East
description: WHEN older people look for a place in the sun to retire, it isn't always Florida or Arizona. Tens of thousands are choosing coastal New England, especially Cape Cod in Massachusetts and the area around Portland, Me., which meteorologists say are sunnier and warmer than most of the Northeast.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''We looked each other in the eye, discussed the challenges we face and reached understandings that will serve the cause of our mutual security, freedom and prosperity.''

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture with the Headliners column last Sunday was published in error. It showed Arthur M. Okun, a former member of the Council of Economic Advisers, not Herbert S. Okun, the deputy chief delegate to the United Nations.

title: PROCRASTINATION IS A VIRTUE, NOT A VICE
description: I AM a procrastinator. I expect this pronouncement to be greeted with disapproving silence, a barely audible ''tsk-tsk,'' perhaps.

title: Proud Occasion
description: In a ceremony marked by Indian prayers chanted to beating drums, eagle and buffalo dances by Zuni and Apache youths, and the bearing of gifts of pottery and sacred corn, the Rev. Donald E. Pelotte was anointed last week as the first American Indian to become a bishop of the Roman Catholic Church. Bishop Pelotte, the son of an Algonquin laborer, rose from poor beginnings in Maine to become, at 41 years of age, one of the country's youngest bishops.

title: WHERE THE STEAK REIGNS SUPREME
description: NOSTALGIA buffs with fond memories of the 1950's should feel right at home at Peter Luger Steakhouse in Great Neck, a branch of the Brooklyn landmark in the Williamsburg section. The restaurant reopened about two months ago after having been shuttered for a year and a half following a fire.

title: Christine Alexander Bride Of Cary Shalin Languirand
description: Christine Bray Alexander, the daughter of Gretchen W. Alexander of Westport, Conn., and William P. Alexander of White Plains, was married yesterday to Cary Shalin Languirand, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard W. Languirand of Homewood, Ill.

title: DICED ASPARAGUS IN THREE STYLES
description: ASPARAGUS, the quintessential springtime vegetable, is in season now. Bundles of spears are lined at attention in supermarkets and at produce stands and the prices are becoming reasonable.

title: Terror vs. the Third World
description: In the fight against terrorism, there can be no such thing as nonalignment. Terrorism is a cancer that has afflicted developing countries as much as it has hurt the West.

title: REAL POLISH JOKES THRIVE ON REAL POLISH SOCIALISM
description: Coal production may fluctuate and export earnings may falter, but the output of real Polish jokes remains at a high level.

title: THE COST OF HAVING AN OFFICE OVERSEAS
description: IT happens to almost all successful companies.

title: TORCHED BY GOD AND MAN
description: LIVING DOGS AND DEAD LIONS By R. Lanny Hunter and Victor L. Hunter. 260 pp. New York: Viking. $16.95.

title: Carter and the Court
description: To the Editor:

title: JAZZ CELEBRATION IN NEW HAVEN
description: JAZZ talents from around the country will gather in New Haven next weekend to perform and to discuss the history and significance of jazz in America, in a two-day program of music and critique.

title: CARNEY MULLS A FIFTH TERM, WITH G.O.P. FOES IN WINGS
description: HIS political career at stake, Representative William Carney this weekend is weighing whether to seek a fifth term in the face of an almost certain Republican primary fight in September and a strong Democratic challenge in November.

title: Bolivia Replies
description: To the Editor:

title: Mason and a Widow In a Tombstone Pact
description: A stone mason who removed a tombstone to sandblast away the names he had cut into it has agreed to clean up the grave.

title: CURB ON EAST EUROPEAN PRODUCE
description: The European Community, concerned over the possibility of radioactive contamination from the nuclear power plant accident in the Ukraine, tentatively agreed today to ban imports of fresh fruits and vegetables from seven East European countries, But there were indications that the accord could fall apart because of lingering opposition from Italy.

title: Dr. Allan Tiedrich to Wed Deborah Ellen Weisbard
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Weisbard of West Orange, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Deborah Ellen Weisbard to Dr. Allan Tiedrich, the son of Bertha Tiedrich of Delray Beach, Fla., and the late Albert Tiedrich.

title: THE COURT, CAPITAL PUNISHMENT AND 'DEATH QUALIFIED' JURIES
description: THE main thrust of the Supreme Court's constitutional rulings on the death penalty since 1972 has been to require special procedures to prevent the arbitrary, biased or erroneous imposition of the ultimate sanction. ''Death is different,'' the Court said in 1976. Last week, however, the Court upheld another kind of special procedure unique to capital cases - one that, by screening out committed opponents of the death penalty, may produce juries more likely to vote for conviction. The decision was a major defeat for opponents of the penalty. It illustrates the tension between the aspirations of Justices in the Court's moderate center to guard against unfairness and their increasingly dominant desire not to place undue burdens on states that want to execute vicious killers.

title: Can Demand for Space Keep Up With Supply?
description: SOME of the office buildings finished recently are urban and others are in office parks; some are towering and others squat; some are high-tech and others conventional. But there is a single word that describes a growing number of them: Empty.

title: DISABLED MOTHER LENDS SON ABILITY
description: I AM just returning home from my friend Fran's graduation. Everyone is proud of her: she is in her mid-30's and just received a master's degree in special education. She has given up a successful career as a dancer and will soon be starting as a teacher of handicapped children in the East Bronx.

title: ZOOMOBILE OFFERS ANIMALS ON WHEELS
description: ON a recent spring afternoon, dozens of 3- to 5-year-olds, giddy with anticipation, peered through cages to see big snakes, small kangaroos and a wild ferret.

title: F.B.I. Discipline Linked To Shooting of an Agent
description: An agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation was dismissed, another resigned and three were disciplined for an operation here that ended when two agents mistakenly shot to death a fellow agent, who was the first female agent killed in the line of duty, The Arizona Republic reported today.

title: New Jersey: Office Tower on the Hudson Vies For Title of the State's Tallest
description: SINCE it was erected in 1930, the National Newark and Essex Bank Building at 744 Broad Street in Newark has been the tallest building in the state. Now, however, its reign is being challenged.

title: GEMS IN THE JUNK PILE
description: Give me your ill-used, your discarded, your unprepossessing moves and see what wonders I will make of them. This is the proper motto of the dedicated openings researcher.

title: ELLIS I. PROPOSAL IS SEEN AS FAULTY
description: A $150 million proposal for an ''ethnic Williamsburg'' on the southern half of Ellis Island, drafted at the request of Lee A. Iacocca, is not financially viable at this time, a Federal official in charge of the island's rehabilitation has concluded.

title: GREAT SWAMP MASTER PLAN DEBATED
description: THE Great Swamp National Wildlife Refuge, created in the 1960's to forestall unwanted development in southeast Morris County, must now coexist with the growth that came anyway.

title: A Handbook For Emergencies
description: HORDES of backpackers, hikers, campers, anglers and canoeists will soon be venturing into the wilderness, and accidents or illnesses will inevitably befall some of them.

title: GRITTY AND TOUCHING IMAGES BY FAURER AT WESLEYAN
description: LOUIS FAURER was included in the Museum of Modern Art shows ''In and Out of Focus'' (1948) and ''The Family of Man'' (1954), and six years later, he soloed at a small private gallery. The photographer then vanished, not to return until the late 1970's, with a New York show.

title: Floris
description: To the Editor: We loved your article on Floris (''On the Right Scent Since the Powdered Wig,'' Travel, March 16) but you don't have to travel to London any more to buy Elite or the floral fragrances. We now get ours from Caswell-Massey in Upper Montclair.

title: FRESH AIR FUND BUILDS SUMMERTIME FAMILIES
description: This summer, 9,500 children will leave the noise, traffic and heat of New York City's streets for the countryside and suburbs as part of the Fresh Air Fund's Friendly Towns program.

title: Notre Dame's Board Chief
description: Donald R. Keough, president of the Coca-Cola Company, was elected Friday as chairman of the board of trustees of the University of Notre Dame.

title: SIENA IN ITS GLORY DAYS
description: At last, everything ready, out came the mounted carabinieri, all pomp and precision, swagger and strut. In tight, smart-stepping formation they followed their commander into the Piazza del Campo, the horses handsome in their full-dress leather and brass, the military police starched and polished in black, white and regimental red.

title: A Week to Remember
description: In the first week of May l986 there were some glimpses of common sense in the world, even some signs of cooperation between the quarreling nations and politicians. It may not last, but it was a week to remember.

title: NEW CANAAN
description: A SCENIC hillside in New Canaan known as God's Acre has, on more than one occasion, prompted a potential home buyer to wisecrack: ''Who else could afford these prices?''

title: Mary L. Halsey Becomes a Bride
description: Mary Lynn Halsey and Peter W. McAloon were married yesterday at St. Teresa of Avila Roman Catholic Church in North Tarrytown, N.Y., where she represented the fifth generation of her family to be married.The Rev. Christopher H. Daly performed the ceremony.

title: NORTH CAROLINA FOREST FIRE ROUTS HUNDREDS
description: A fire that has charred 40 square miles of forest made a loop across southeastern North Carolina today, and officials told people in hundreds of homes along the coast to evacuate.

title: ORAL HISTORIES: HOW TO AVOID THE PITFALLS
description: IF someone had proposed doing an oral history 25 years ago, ''no one would have known what they meant,'' said John F. Sutherland, professor of history and director of the Institute for Local History at Manchester Community College.

title: LIZA MINNELLI SOUNDS A NOTE OF NOVELTY
description: How does Liza Minnelli pull things together for a show?

title: AT SUFFOLK, FEWER STUDENTS, BETTER SCORES
description: PROF. William F. Powers's article, '' 'Quality Control' at Community Colleges,'' [ April 27 ] indicates an abysmal lack of knowledge concerning the mission of the community college, the role of the teacher in the classroom experience and the academic services offered by his own institution.

title: CORRECTION
description: The author of the Philip Marlowe detective series was incorrectly identified in a brief review April 13 of the novel ''Unbalanced Accounts'' by Kate Gallison. Raymond Chandler wrote the series.

title: AMERICA'S CUP QUEST STARTS
description: Early last week, an America's Cup bumper sticker from New York's challenging team was found glued to a coin basket at the Newport Bridge. A day later, a sticker from Chicago's team appeared beside it.

title: Barbara S. Hammond Is Wed in Connecticut
description: Barbara Stevens Hammond, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Stevens Hammond Jr. of Branford, Conn., was married yesterday to Newton Carlson Schoenly Jr., the son of Mr. Schoenly, a Presbyterian minister, and the late Mrs. Schoenly of Hanover, Mass. The Rev. Everitt L. Fullam performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Branford.

title: Dance
description: Marleen Pennison's choreography has been described as ''danced short stories'' and her newest work, ''Walls Could Talk,'' is said to be a house with stories to tell. Miss Pennison promises to trace the lives and vicissitudes of several families in a house in the South.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Adrienne's: All Stock Up to 50% Off Adrienne's, opened 25 years ago in Eastchester with first-quality women's sportswear and dressy clothes, begins its going-out-of-business sale tomorrow with everything 20 to 50 percent off; the sale's final day is June 30. The store is closed Sunday and Tuesday and checks can be accepted, but not credit cards, during the clearance. Sizes are 6 to 14 and some 16's.

title: RANGER ROOKIE IS COMPOSED
description: It was raining, so Pete Incaviglia retreated to an indoor batting cage beneath the bleachers and took his pre-game swings. And when he was finished, he walked slowly across the outfield grass, ducked through a doorway in the right-field corner and disappeared. The fans who had followed him there stood motionless, still clutching their pencils and pieces of paper.

title: STUDENTS OPERATE OWN BOOKSTORE
description: A NEW bookstore opened recently in Westport that is dedicated to enhancing the importance of reading among the town's high-school students by making it more convenient for them to buy books.

title: REMEMBERING MAMA -- BELLE OF THE BALL
description: WE ALL agree that our mothers are special.

title: FRANCE JAILS 2 IN ODD CASE OF ESPIONAGE
description: A former French diplomat and a Chinese opera singer have been sentenced to six years in jail for spying for China after a two-day trial that traced a story of clandestine love and mistaken sexual identity.

title: MODERN LOVE IN RHYTHM AND RHYME
description: THE GOLDEN GATE By Vikram Seth. 307 pp. New York: Random House. $17.95. 1 A novel written all in sonnets, ''The Golden Gate'' by Vikram Seth Depends for its appeal upon its Charming views of life and death, Love and work of yuppies in That trendy Calif. county, Marin, And nearby San Franciscan venues.

title: The Doctor As Guinea Pig
description: Although Lawrence K. Altman does a nice job of balancing the scientific and personal pros and cons of medical self-experimentation, he neglects broader ethical considerations.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: WALT WHITMAN: A Life, by Justin Kaplan. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $12.95.) This ''excellent'' biography takes a view of Whitman that is ''affectionate but undeluded,'' Helen Vendler said in The Book Review in 1980. ''The smokescreen of simplicity with which Whitman concealed his complexities is presented just as ably here as is the true simplicity of attachment and perception of which Whitman was capable. . . . Mr. Kaplan's attitude is the necessary one: that Whitman is vast and contains multitudes, just as he said.'' KING OF THE JEWS, by Leslie Epstein. (Plume/New American Library, $7.95.) Leslie Epstein's novel of the Holocaust succeeds where many fail, Robert Alter said here in 1979, because the author ''intelligently focuses his narrative not on the obscene mechanisms of mass murder itself, but on the morally ambiguous politics of survival of a Judenrat,'' or Jewish town council, in a fictional Polish ghetto. Calling the work ''quietly controlled, eerily lucid,'' he wrote, ''No work of fiction has opened up so fully the unbearable moral dilemma in which the Judenrat members found themselves.''

title: Something's Out There, And It's Massive
description: Astronomers noted in the late 1970's that their sightings of quasars, the bright cores perhaps billions of light years from Earth, sometimes produced double images; for some reason, the quasars' light was being bent, as though by a lens. The scientists speculated that such an effect could be caused by the gravitational field of a very massive object, such as a cluster of galaxies.

title: FUEL-ROD STORAGE STIRS FEARS
description: THE Mayors of Lower Alloways Creek and Lacey Townships, where some people have been living near nuclear-power generating plants for as long as 17 years, say there is no indication of new fears because of the Soviet reactor accident last month.

title: A SPINNER OF TALES MOVES INTO THE MAINSTREAM
description: He has conducted fact-finding missions to ''golden age'' homes for senior citizens in New England, to brothels in Thailand and to sensory-deprivation tanks in California. He has delighted audiences in German beer halls, in Australian theaters and on public television. But until now, Spalding Gray has never displayed his brand of solo performance in a mainstream theater in New York City, where he has lived for more than 20 years. That will change this week when Mr. Gray temporarily forsakes his headquarters at SoHo's Performing Garage to begin a monthlong run at Lincoln Center's Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater, thereby joining the ranks of artists such as Laurie Anderson, Eric Bogosian and Whoopi Goldberg, who have emerged from avant-garde performing spaces to attract a wider audience.

title: LEARNING TO LOVE MOTHER, AGAIN
