description: MY mother read my horoscope to me: ''Do some serious thinking about a personal relationship. Relinquishing this tie could free you to live a happier life.''

title: Mystery Surrounds N.B.A.'s Lottery
description: IN the National Basketball Association's first draft lottery a year ago, there was a great deal of suspense over who would get the first choice but no suspense at all over what would be done with it.

title: Moncrief's Status Key Item for Bucks
description: No, Sidney Moncrief said, his injured left heel, the one that has forced him to miss three of the first six games of his team's playoff series against the Philadelphia 76ers, does not hurt all the time.

title: TAKEOVER IS URGED FOR PARKWAY LEG
description: ASSEMBLYMAN Fred Parola of Wantagh recently recalled a conversation with the public planner Robert Moses. Mr. Moses told him, Mr. Parola said, that when he planned the Long Island parkway system he had envisioned a bucolic, tree-lined road leading to Jones Beach.

title: HIKING HUT TO HUT IN AUSTRIA
description: On the north side of the Karwendel valley in western Austria, the mountain trail runs several hundred feet above the valley floor, picking its way through low pine woods and crossing streams that tumble steeply down the mountain.

title: Slaughterhouse Blossoming Into Co-ops
description: LOCATION, it is said with numbing regularity, is real estate's most important factor.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: A SWELL STYLE OF MURDER. By Rosemarie Santini. (St. Martin's, $12.95.) A hand is tipped - with a wink -early in this neat little entertainment when the heroine says, ''We're in this together.

title: BINS AND BARRELS OF SPICES AND SWEETS
description: TO a shopper with a sweet tooth, Tidbit Alley Inc. represents a dream come true. It is crammed to the walls with open bins and barrels, containing all together 375 flavors of candies, nuts, spices, teas, coffees, dietetic food items, dried fruits, cereals. All the shopper has to do is fill a plastic bag from the bin or barrel, weigh it, pay - and munch.

title: Yellow-Page Blues
description: To the Editor:

title: SPACE AGENCY HID SHUTTLE PROBLEM, PANEL CHIEF SAYS
description: Problems in the space shuttle's booster rockets were ''almost covered up'' within the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, according to the head of a Presidential investigative commission.

title: Perspectives: Warehousing; Vacancies Vital in the Revival of Housing as Co-ops
description: IN Brooklyn's Park Slope section, a 35-unit building was converted into a cooperative in March with no purchases by long-term tenants, according to the State Attorney General's office. The same thing happened at a 12-unit building in the Prospect Heights section of the borough.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Sunday about the worst nuclear reactor accidents of 1985 misidentified the site of an incident in which two workers were exposed to radiation. It occurred at the Rancho Seco plant near Sacramento, Calif., not the San Onofre complex in San Clemente.

title: Dallas: A New Entry Prepares to Open In the Face of a Sceptical Market
description: THE take-off angles for planes departing from nearby Love Field prevented William T. Criswell from considering the idea of making his two new office towers the tallest in downtown Dallas. He chose, instead, to make a statement through a striking prismatic, glass design with an expansive water garden bubbling across the base of a 5.8-acre parcel of land.

title: TRENTON STATE BASKING IN NEW REPUTATION
description: ''A COLONIAL clock tower tops the red-brick, Federal-style main building on the grassy central quadrangle,'' begins an article in this month's Money magazine. ''More than half the students come from the upper 20 percent of their high school graduating classes . . .

title: EXPLOSIONS, A REPLACEMENT AND AN ELECTION
description: AFGHANISTAN -- His two predecessors were killed, but Babrak Karmal, who was installed as Afghanistan's leader when Soviet troops entered the country in 1979, apparently lost only his position as General Secretary of the People's Democratic Party last week. Tass, the Soviet press agency, said Mr. Karmal was still President but had been replaced by a man known only as Najibullah, the former chief of the secret police.

title: TOWNSHIP SEALED BY SOUTH AFRICA
description: Police and army units moved into the strife-torn black township of Alexandra, near Johannesburg, today, arresting 16 people in a daylong sweep that included house-to-house searches.

title: John H. Kennedy Marries Patricia Louise Donahue
description: The wedding of Patricia Louise Donahue to John Hollingsworth Kennedy took place yesterday at the Rowayton, Conn., home of the bridegroom's sister, Anne Kennedy Ehrbar.

title: STRATEGIES FOR MAKING 'GIFT OF A LIFETIME'
description: RESOLVING to read is an enormous act of self-discipline. To develop the habit of reading is to undergird our entire personality with a behavior that structures our lives.

title: VILAS TO FACE NOAH IN FOREST HILLS FINAL
description: They had been asked to spend a week at Forest Hills living in the past, which sometimes gave the impression that neither had a future in their chosen field. But the tennis world turns slowly as Guillermo Vilas and Yannick Noah have probably discovered, and the stories they wrote on the clay courts around the world have not been easy to forget. Today, perhaps, one will have the opportunity to turn the page.

title: The Doctor As Guinea Pig
description: Congratulations to Lawrence K. Altman on his article ''The Doctor as Guinea Pig'' (April 6), about Dr. Victor Herbert.

title: THE TREES THAT SHARE OUR LAND AND OUR LIVES
description: EVERY now and then, a strange car comes in our driveway and the occupant asks if we want to sell the two tall black walnut trees growing in our front field. Towering over the hemlocks in the hedge, they can be seen from the road if one is looking for black walnuts. ''I'll give you $450 for the bigger one,'' a man said to me a while ago.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: COSTUMES AT LYNDHURST Most of Anna Gould's clothes were made to order at Maison Burano, 680 Fifth Avenue - a business that passed out of existence decades ago. But her clothes did not. A dozen costumes with accessories, and a number of additional hats and other items, are being shown in the first costume exhibition ever mounted by Lyndhurst, the Gould family estate in Tarrytown. The exhibit opens today and remains through Oct. 30.

title: A BLOCK GROUP ON WEST SIDE REVIVES NEIGHBORHOOD SPIRIT
description: A city block can resemble a small town, providing a refuge from the enormousness and constant change that characterize urban life.

title: Galia Levin Plans to Wed Richard Stern in Summer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Isaac Levin of Hadera, Israel, have announced the engagement of their daughter Galia Levin to Richard H. Stern, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Abe Stern of Spring Valley, N.Y.

title: Elizabeth Love Is Wed
description: Elizabeth Alexandra Love and John Francis Goot were married yesterday by the Rev. John Crocker at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Brookfield Center, Conn. The bride is the daughter of Barbara Love Claypool of Swan Lake, N.Y., and Talbot A. Love of Tuxedo Park, N.Y. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Francis Goot of Brookfield Center. Mrs. Goot graduated from New York University's School of Arts and Sciences. Mr. Goot, a talent coordinator at Donovan Data Systems in Manhattan, graduated from Fordham University.

title: Being A Jr.
description: I was rather surprised to read that Rafael Suarez enjoys being a Jr.

title: Sarah Elizabeth Fries Wed to Jon D. Packer
description: Sarah Elizabeth Fries and Jon Durell Packer were married yesterday at the Harvard Club in New York by Justice Geraldine T. Eiber of the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court.

title: Queens Fears Impact of New Multifamily Dwellings
description: A SURGE of building in Queens has prompted the Borough President to establish a zoning task force to examine what she termed ''a spreading and dangerous pattern'' of new multifamily housing that clashes with the one- and two-family homes that characterize many of the borough's residential communities.

title: On Language; Discussing Discussants
description: THE WORD DISCUSSANT . . . does not appear in my dictionary,'' writes Allen R. Kramer, an architect in St. Michaels, Md., attaching a Baltimore film-forum program that lists moderator and discussant after each movie to be shown. ''I fear it is the kind of word which [ sic ] will quickly spread to TV forums and assorted groups devoted to talking about uplifting subjects. Perhaps some comments from you can prevent an epidemic.''

title: NEW STATE OFFICE TO ADDRESS HISPANIC NEEDS
description: Governor Cuomo, citing the need to improve the status of ''all members of the family of New York,'' has set up an Office for Hispanic Affairs to advise state agencies and serve as ombudsman for Hispanic interests.

title: CLASSIC-GUITAR DUO TO PLAY AT PRINCETON
description: A PHOTOGRAPH of Michael Newman and Laura Oltman shows them with their guitars, their 10-gallon hats and their retired race horse, Bunny, and looking much like typical country folk singers.

title: Child in Tow
description: To the Editor: Every once in so often the Sunday Travel section will send me into a frenzy of remembering. It happened on a recent Sunday with the wonderful articles on traveling with children (''Discovering Small Worlds,'' March 23).

title: Why Arab Moderates Don't Disown Qaddafi
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. Marcia Fishman to Wed an Ophthalmologist
description: Dr. Marcia C. Fishman, a radiologist, and Dr. Jonathan C. Javitt, an ophthalmalogist, plan to be married June 29, the future bride's father, Jack Fishman, has announced.

title: THAT CERTAIN THING CALLED THE GIRLFRIEND
description: And Ruth said, Entreat me not to leave thee, or to return from following after thee: for whither thou goest, I will go; and where thou lodgest, I will lodge: thy people shall be my people, and thy God my God: Where thou diest, will I die, and there will I be buried: the Lord do so to me, and more also, if aught but death part thee and me. -- Ruth 1:16-17.

title: Flames Beat Blues
description: Dan Quinn scored twice and Calgary killed eight penalties tonight, lifting the Flames within one victory of the Stanley Cup final with a 4-2 victory over the St. Louis Blues.

title: TROUBLES IN THE TOILET TANK: TIME TO REPAIR AND UPDATE
description: ALTHOUGH the inside of a typical toilet flush tank may look complicated, it is actually a fairly simple mechanism made up of two valve systems.

title:
REALIZING A DECADES-OLD DREAM;
THE IRRESISTIBLE LOGIC OF TAX REFORM
description: THE Senate Finance Committee has been forced by the inexorable logic of comprehensive income taxation to report out a real tax reform bill. Apparently, the trade-off of tax preferences for lower tax rates was irresistible.

title: DOUBLE SNUB FOR BILLY MARTIN
description: AS much to his surprise as to his regret, Billy Martin is not managing the Chicago White Sox or the Seattle Mariners now. The four-time Yankee manager and part-time Yankee broadcaster discovered Friday that the White Sox preferred to retain Tony LaRussa, the Mariners preferred to hire Dick Williams, and neither team preferred him. Not only was Martin snubbed, but he was snubbed by two clubs on the same day. The trend is too sensible to survive.

title: METS WIN 7TH IN ROW, 5-1, FOR 18TH IN LAST 19 GAMES
description: These are the best of times for the Mets and the worst of times for the Cincinnati Reds, and both kinds of times continued yesterday before another large and duly impressed crowd of 45,303 fans in Shea Stadium.

title: THE DISPOAL ALTERNATIVES
description: NO ONE WANTS RADIOACTIVE waste in, over or under his backyard. But even if the United States builds no more commercial nuclear power reactors, the 95 already in operation will have produced some 100,000 metric tons of highly radioactive nuclear fuel waste by the year 2020. Already, the equivalent of 20,000 metric tons of solid and liquid waste produced by power plants and weapons factories is awaiting disposal.

title: Ruling Party Now Leads In Bangladesh Returns
description: The ruling party, backed by President H. M. Ershad, took a commanding lead in national elections today when vote counting resumed after a halt was called as the party fell behind.

title: THE GROUND GLASS GROUP CELEBRATES ITS 10th
description: THE Ground Glass may be sharp, but it is not rough around the edges.

title: Pakistanis Order Curfew for Karachi
description: The authorities ordered an indefinite curfew tonight in parts of Karachi after gunfights erupted between two groups, wounding at least five people.

title: NEW YORK TRIES STREET-TALKING ITS STUDENTS
description: New York City and several school districts in the metropolitan area, in an effort to help some students, are using educational recordings based on rap music, a style of rhythmic talking that originated on the city's streets.

title: UNSPEAKABLE TORTURES
description: REQUIEM FOR A WOMAN'S SOUL By Omar Rivabella. Translated by Paul Riviera and Omar Rivabella. 116 pp. New York: Random House. $14.95. THE excesses of the recent military regimes in South America have become the fountainhead of an angry, unforgiving literature. For a new wave of writers, the grotesque nature of dictatorships cannot be adequately conveyed even by the masterly surrealism of a Gabriel Garcia Marquez. These writers view themselves as scribes, faithful chroniclers of the many acts of torture, execution and psychological terror that are all too fresh to be relegated to the domain of allegory. The subject of Omar Rivabella's ''Requiem for a Woman's Soul'' is torture, described in such harrowing, unrelenting detail that none of it can be dismissed as a product of the imagination. Indeed, the author, an Argentine journalist and human rights advocate, has based his novel on the testimony of victims of repression in his country. More than once, the reader is tempted to put down this slim volume, lock it away, forget its stomach-churning passages. But to no avail. Sooner or later, the compul-sion to press onward, no matter how painful, becomes overwhelming.

title: NEW SAFEGUARDS FOR HOME PESTICIDES ARE DEBATED
description: Environmentalists and their allies, warning about dangers in the wide use of pesticides in cities and suburbs, are seeking greater legal safeguards.

title: Patricia A. Brandy to Wed Francis Connor on Sept. 27
description: Dr. and Mrs. Joseph R. Brandy 3d of Ogdensburg, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Patricia Ann Brandy to Francis Thomas Connor, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Connor of Stamford, Conn. The wedding is planned for Sept. 27.

title: CONVILLE CUP WON BY TEMPLE CREW
description: The Temple University varsity heavyweight crew won the featured Conville Cup for heavyweight eight-oared crews for the fourth consecutive year in the final race today of the 48th annual Dad Vail Regatta.

title: COACH ATTAINS MILESTONE OF 600th VICTORY
description: HE was going for his 600th coaching victory at the University of New Haven - a number never before reached by a college baseball coach in the state, and indeed, only once in New England.

title: LIVERPOOL'S BLEAK ATMOSPHERE NURTURES A VIBRANT MOVIE
description: Teresa - a platinum-haired blonde given to wearing skintight dresses and fire-engine red lipstick - works in a chicken factory where her job consists of removing a chicken's innards, wrapping the parts and stuffing them back up the chicken, a task she herself describes in considerably raunchier terms.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a dispatch on April 20 from Port-au-Prince, Haiti, about a visit by the American economist Arnold C. Harberger misidentified a school where he has taught. It is the University of Chicago.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: IN 1944, when I was a soldier on his last furlough before going overseas, I was living in Manhattan and dating a girl who lived in Garden City. She invited me out to Long Island and after dinner with the family I confessed to her that I didn't have much money.

title: Melissa Moidel Engaged
description: The engagement of Melissa Moidel to Steven B. Schwartz, the son of Florence Nurin of Stratford, Conn., and the late Bernard E. Schwartz of West Hartford, Conn., has been announced by her parents, Verna Moidel and Jacob Moidel, both of Brooklyn. The wedding is planned for June 1.

title: 15 Charged in Welfare Case
description: Fifteen people have been charged in connection with a ring that frauduently received more than $1 million in welfare benefits. Officials said some of those arrested posed as drivers, interpreters and lookouts for people who were illegally applying for and receiving welfare benefits.

title: PLANNERS AND PRESERVATIONISTS CLASH AT OLD STATE HOUSE
description: IN the latest chapter of a continuing battle between Hartford's city planners and preservationists, the Old State House Association appears to have prevailed in protecting the building's grounds from encroachment - for the moment, at least.

title: Bonnie Lee Blafer to Wed Carl J. Schweinler Aug. 17
description: Announcement has been made by Daisy Blafer of Pompano Beach, Fla., of the engagement of her daughter, Bonnie Lee Blafer, to Carl J. Schweinler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl L. Schweinler of New Canaan, Conn.

title: INDIANS LOSE, 4-0, IN THE 11TH INNING
description: A two-run single by Carlton Fisk highlighted a four-run 11th inning, and Neil Allen and two relievers combined on a three-hitter to give the Chicago White Sox a 4-0 victory over the Cleveland Indians today.

title: EXPOS WIN BY 3-2 FOR 7TH IN A ROW
description: As far as Herman Winningham is concerned, he made the right mistake.

title: Justice's Waldheim File
description: Top Justice Department officials reportedly were infuriated and worried by the disclosure of a departmental memorandum recommending that Kurt Waldheim be barred from entering the United States because of his war record. Fearful that the document, written by Neal Sher, director of the department's Nazi-hunting unit, might affect the voting in the Austrian presidential election, the officials were dismayed when the paper ended up in the hands of reporters several days before the election last weekend.

title: Alive, Well And Living in Cuba
description: They were black and white and sought all over, at least in Cuba and the Southern United States. Finally, according to a report last week, two ivory-billed woodpeckers, a handsome species believed for years to be extinct, have been spotted in a Cuban forest.

title: SUDDENLY, THE TAX BILL IS PICKING UP SPEED
description: LESS than two weeks ago, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, proclaimed that tax revision legislation was ''hanging by a thread.'' Now, following one of the most surprising legislative turnabouts in years, Mr. Dole and other leading senators and representatives from both parties believe that the biggest changes in the Federal income tax law since World War II will almost certainly be enacted before the end of the year.

title:
GARDENING;
EDIBLE ADDITIONS TO THE LANDSCAPE
description: PERHAPS the most convincing argument for growing one's own food and vegetables is their superior quality when compared with that from the typical produce market. If more gardeners could compare home-grown produce with commercial produce, more of them would be landscaping with fruits and vegetables.

title: Salt Lake at Record High
description: The Great Salt Lake's surface has approximately matched its historical high of 4,211.6 feet above sea level, according to the latest estimates cited Friday by Bill Alder, chief meteorologist for Utah at the National Weather Service.

title: NICARAGUA TRIES TO PUT IT IN WRITING
description: SINCE taking power after an armed insurrection in 1979, the Sandinistas have adopted various trappings of parliamentary democracy. They have established an ostensibly independent judicial system, created a National Assembly and held a presidential election. Although these steps did not alter the fundamentals of Sandinista rule, they offered a measure of popular participation and won compliments from some West Europeans and Americans.

title: Marcia L. Pinover Is Bride Of Capt. Thomas N. Beatty
description: Marcia Lynn Pinover, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Stanley Pinover Jr. of Darien, Conn., and Capt. Thomas Nathaniel Beatty, U.S.M.C., a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Robert Loring Beatty of Darien, were married yesterday at St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in Darien by the Rev. Edward Howley and the Rev. Francis Virgulak.

title: Theatrical Seminar
description: The comic performer Eric Bogosian; Robert Brustein, the artistic director of the American Repertory Theater, and Ruth Maleczech, a member of Mabou Mines, will take part in a seminar entitled ''The New Theater: What's Next?'' tomorrow at 7 P.M. at the Roundabout Theater, 100 East 17th Street. The seminar is sponsored by the Alliance of Resident Theaters/ New York, Inc. Admission is $10. Information: 989-5257.

title: Robert Sedgwick Weds Miss Torelli
description: Helen Torelli and Robert M. Sedgwick, both lawyers, were married yesterday at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Stockbridge, Mass. The Rev. Harold Sedgwick, the bridegroom's cousin, performed the ceremony.

title: THE MANY VOICES OF ISLAND CHORALES
description: The interesting ''About Long Island'' column on April 27 describes the Armand Sodero Chorale and reflects the enthusiasm and seriousness of purpose of the many choral singers on Long Island.

title: '87 FALLOUT IS SEEN FOR MUNICIPAL ELECTIONS
description: VOTERS will go to the polls Tuesday in dozens of municipal elections, including some that cast shadows on next year's state legislative races and at least one with national implications.

title: AT L.I. NEONATAL UNIT, PROGRESS OUNCE BY OUNCE
description: Every morning at 6:30, while Margaret Wray is still asleep, her husband calls the hospital to check their son's latest weight. ''I'll open my eyes and my husband's looking at me,'' Mrs. Wray said. ''He'll say, 'Marg, he gained 2 ounces!' Then he starts dancing around the room.''

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: HAPPY MOTHER'S DAY Never let it be said that Mother's Day is always perfume, handkerchiefs and dinner on Long Island. For example, how about a Mother's Day bird walk in search of warblers? There are two on tap today: One, courtesy of the Long Island Green Belt Trail Conference, starting at 9 A.M., wanders through three miles of Massapequa woods in search of the colorful migratory birds (call George at 785-6896 for particulars). The other, farther east in the Yaphank Woods, begins at 8:30 A.M. and is sponsored by the Environmental Centers of Setauket-Smithtown (call 979-6344 for information).

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: ABIYOYO By Pete Seeger. Illustrated by Michael Hays. Unpaged. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $15.95. (Ages 5 and up) WHENEVER Pete Seeger, the venerable folk singer, gives a concert, it seems that the younger members of his audience wait for one particular moment. If it hasn't happened by intermission, the braver children make their way to the stage with scraps of paper on which one word is scrawled: ''Abiyoyo,'' meaning Mr. Seeger's song about a mischievous little boy and his equally mischievous father, and of their triumph.

title: PRAYERS AND POLICE IN PENNSYLVANIA
description: When members of a Lutheran congregation gather for services this weekend in the suburb of Clairton, more than worship will be on their minds.

title: Melodic Selling Of Philadelphia
description: SELLING Philadelphia as a vacationland may be no pushover. But last summer, the City Convention and Visitors Bureau took on the challenge by adopting a promotional song and putting it on television.

title: Residents of an Italian Island Seek Protection From Libya
description: Hundreds of residents of this Italian island halfway between Libya and Sicily staged a loud demonstration today demanding protection from a possible Libyan attack, the police said.

title: SGT. PRESTON STRIKES AGAIN
description: IT would be outright arrogance to suggest that the New York Yankees should always be in the World Series or that the Boston Celtics should always be in the National Basketball Association final or that Notre Dame should always play somebody for the college football championship.

title: THE OFFICE COPIER AS LASER PRINTER
description: THE pleasure I expressed last week over the fact that someone had finally brought out a machine combining the functions of a laser copier with those of a personal computer printer remains undiminished. Judging from the response I have received, a lot of readers have been wondering, as I did, why such a seemingly natural combination has been so late in arriving. After all, the underlying technology is the same, and having one unit to serve both purposes would save time, space and money.

title: Chicago: Selling A Wright
description: FOR almost two years, the ''For Sale'' sign was out in front of a famous Gold Coast mansion designed by two of the nation's greatest architects - Louis Sullivan and Frank Lloyd Wright. Many architects were surprised that it was taking so long to sell the 94-year-old, 16-room house because it is the first major residence designed by Wright.

title: BUDGET SETS THE STAGE FOR NOVEMBER
description: IN contrast to last year's session of the General Assembly, which was marked by unusual comity between Governor O'Neill and the Republican-controlled legislature, the 1986 session was more notable more for its disagreements.

title: THEATER: ORWELL'S '1984' RISES FROM PAGE TO STAGE
description: In four years, Jiri and Blanka Zizka, a young husband and wife team of directors, have turned the tiny Wilma Theater into a dauntless Philadelphia equivalent of Off Broadway. Almost every performance, the 93-seat house is filled with theatergoers held by such varied fare as Peter Weiss's ''Marat/Sade,'' the Brecht-Weill ''Happy End,'' Peter Nichols's ''Passion'' and Romulus Linney's ''Childe Byron.''

title: RECITAL: PIANIST PERFORMS
description: RONALD SADOFF brought a nice sense of freedom to his evening of piano music at Carnegie Recital Hall on Thursday. But with it came a randomness of mood and expression that at times seemed almost careless. Mr. Sadoff set the tone for his recital at the beginning in two items from Bach's ''Art of Fugue.''

title: CORRECTION
description: An interview with Vanessa Redgrave on page 1 of the Arts and Leisure section today misidentifies one of the dual roles she plays in the television film ''Second Serve.'' The film dramatizes true-life experiences of Dr. Richard Raskind, who, after a sex-change operation, became Dr. Renee Richards, but for legal reasons Dr. Raskind is referred to in the film by a pseudonym, Dr. Richard Radley.

title: CORRECTION
description: The directory of music festivals abroad in last Sunday's Travel section omitted the site of the Rossini Opera Festival. It will be held in Pesaro, Italy, from July 31 to Sept. 18.

title:
INVESTING;
AT LOEWS, A QUIET BEAR MOVES TO CASH
description: JOSEPH ROSENBERG is an unabashed bear. He owns almost no bonds and virtually no stocks.

title: Cup Playoffs Need Format Change
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: PLAN OUTLINED TO REMOVE TOXINS AT DURACELL SITE
description: THE first phase in cleaning up toxic wastes at the Duracell Company's former battery-manufacturing plant in North Tarrytown is expected to get under way this summer, according to state environmental officials.

title: SCHOOLS PHASE OUT COMPANY TAX HELP
description: NASSAU and Suffolk County school districts are phasing out a state program that gives companies a 10-year property-tax abatement to locate in their areas. Local officials say the incentive is no longer necessary to attract new businesses.

title: CASTING AN ANTHROPOLOGICAL EYE ON AMERICAN CONSUMERS
description: STEVE BARNETT, a cultural anthropologist, spends much of his time doing field work: He watches the natives and learns about their culture as they go about their daily routines.

title: 'LET'S GO FOR IT!' SAYS REAGAN, ASSESSING TAX PLAN
description: President Reagan today praised the tax revision plan before the Senate as ''one of the most exciting economic changes of my lifetime'' and said the measure could increase the average family's income $600 to $900 a year.

title: LANDLORDS ASSERT THE POOR BENEFIT LEAST FROM RENT CONTROLS
description: Rent control in New York City has disproportionately benefited those people who need it least - higher-income residents of Manhattan - according to a study commissioned by the Rent Stabilization Association, a group representing 25,000 landlords.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
A NATION'S HERO
description: The late David Ben-Gurion, a man esteemed in Israel as ''Father of the Nation,'' is featured on a stunning new medal marking the centennial of his birth. The medal is being issued in a limited edition by the Judah L. Magnes Memorial Museum of Berkeley, Calif., an institution that proclaims itself ''The Jewish Museum of the West.''

title: FINE-TUNING
description: At his first lesson the beginner is taught to open the bidding with 13 points and otherwise to pass. This guideline will serve well enough, but there is a good deal more to it than that, as he eventually discovers. How should he count distribution? What are 10's worth? When it comes to fine-tuning the opening bid, experts using standard bidding methods are not entirely in agreement.

title: SOUTH KOREA RALLY ENDS IN CLASH WITH POLICE
description: A peaceful anti-Government rally and march by thousands of South Koreans ended this evening with riot policemen firing tear gas to disperse several hundred students who attacked them with clubs and rocks.

title:
IN THE NATION;
Boston: Massive Waterfront Project May Be the Last of Its Kind
description: INTERNATIONAL PLACE, the 46-story, 1.8 million-square-foot office complex now under construction on Boston's waterfront, may be the city's grandest commercial project ever, but it also may mark an end rather than a beginning.

title: CHERNOBYL'S POLITICAL FALLOUT IN U.S.
description: The Chernobyl accident has pushed the issue of nuclear power to center stage in the gubernatorial campaign in New Hampshire, where the Seabrook nuclear power plant is set to come on line this fall.

title: West Coast Wedding For Dr. van Adelsberg
description: Dr. Janet Scott van Adelsberg, a fellow in nephrology at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Ronald Edmond Drusin, an associate professor of clinical medicine at the the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, of which he is an alumnus. The Rev. Jack Heinsohn performed the ceremony in Los Angeles at the Immanuel Presbyterian Church, of which the bride's mother, Madge van Adelsberg, is an elder.

title: Talking Roof Repairs; Reducing Both Costs And Grief
description: THE roof over one's head, in a homeowner's variant of Murphy's Law, always begins to leak just when the owner can least afford the time or money to repair or replace it.

title: Jill Fairchild to Marry Peter Melhado
description: The engagement of Jill Fairchild to Peter Alan Buhl Melhado, a son of Mrs. William H. Mann of New York and Frederick A. Melhado of New York, has been announced by her parents, Jill Lipsey Fairchild and John Burr Fairchild, both of New York.

title: Nikki Katz Is Married
description: Nikki Karen Katz, the daughter of Sallye Katz of Flushing, Queens, and the late Arthur Katz, was married yesterday to Peter Verdecchia, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Robert Verdecchia of Commack, L.I. The ceremony was performed at the Thatched Cottage in Centerport, L.I., by Rabbi Nathan Schwartz. Mrs. Verdecchia is a unit manager for the ''20-20'' program on ABC-TV. Mr. Verdecchia is a foreman for the Nastasi-White Construction Corporation in College Point, Queens.

title: LATE BLOOMERS AT NOYES MUSEUM
description: HOW late can a ''late bloomer'' bloom? An exhibition at the Noyes Museum here testifies that one is never too old to begin a serious pursuit of art.

title: RESCUE AMERICAN LETTERS: TAKE A POET HOME TODAY
description: WITH the recent death of Mrs. Frederick Bowen of Bartholomew, Ala., the 14-member Bartholomew Friends of Poetry disbanded last month, reducing to 83 the number of poetry readers in this country who neither write the stuff themselves nor teach it for a living. In subsequent weeks, suicide hot lines across the nation have been swamped with calls from the nation's 65,000 published poets. One Pulitzer Prize winner confessed: ''It all seems so pointless. I still go to my office every morning and work on the lines left over from the day before. Sure, sometimes I add a new word here or there, sometimes I'm able to arrange the words in different ways, but I can't help asking myself, 'Is anyone out there?' '' After a poignant pause, the veteran versifier whispered, ''When Mrs. Bowen died, I felt so alone.''

title: NATURE WATCH
description: COMMON DANDELION

title: No-Smoking Law Goes Too Far for Restaurants
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW ISSUES SURGING THROUGH THE MARKETS
description: The bulls that have been running on Wall Street since last September are giving new life to many of the stock market's most venerable names. But some of the headiest performers in the surge have been fledgling stocks that were not even around last fall.

title: EXPOS WIN 8TH IN A ROW, 4-3
description: Tim Raines delivered a run-scoring single and ended the game by throwing out Steve Sax at the plate today as the Montreal Expos extended their winning streak to eight games with a 4-3 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: FOYT QUALIFIES AT INDY
description: A.J. Foyt, a four-time winner whose career has spanned three generations, qualified today for his 29th consecutive Indianapolis 500 with a four-lap average of 213.212 miles an hour.

title: The French, Helas, Have Turned Into Cars
description: To the Editor:

title: Record Japan Surplus
description: Japan's trade surplus widened to a monthly record $6.8 billion in April from a previous high $6.6 billion in March, the Kyodo News Service said today.

title: FERDINAND STEADY BUT NOT FAVORITE
description: The horse that wins the Kentucky Derby presumably has beaten the best 3-year-olds around and deserves to be favored to do it again in the Preakness Stakes two weeks later. This year, for the first time since 1970, that may not happen.

title: Lawyers' Strike Continuing
description: The board of directors of the California State Bar has voted to begin hiring permanent replacements for 33 lawyers who went on strike April 25 in a pay dispute.

title: THE STATEMENT ON CHERNOBYL
description: Following is the text of the Soviet Government's statement today on the Chernobyl nuclear accident, as distributed in translation by the Soviet press agency Tass:

title: And So It Goes: Responses to Kurt Vonnegut
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, MAY 12, 1986
description: The Economy

title: Topics; Forms of Inducement; Early Winner
description: Queens Borough President Claire Shulman pioneers a refreshing approach to city politics. Instead of waiting for legislated campaign finance reforms, she has imposed her own cap of $2,000 on all campaign contributions.

title: 1 Killed and 2 Injured As a Boat Turns Over
description: A man was killed and two others injured today when their 18-foot fishing boat capsized in the Jones Inlet near here, the Nassau County police said.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LITERARY EVENING The Source Foundation is known for its readings of works by playwrights such as Strindberg, Chekhov and Ibsen. Tonight the nonprofit organization will present Ibsen's ''Hedda Gabler.''

title: LeFrak Grows Impatient
description: When Samuel J. LeFrak talks about building homes, he talks about 2,000 units at a time.

title: And So It Goes: Responses to Kurt Vonnegut
description: To the Editor:

title: NBC'S 60TH-YEAR 'ANNIVERSARY CELEBRATION'
description: COMING up on its 60th birthday this year - the official on-air debut was on November 15, 1926 - NBC is throwing itself a three-hour ''Anniversary Celebration'' tonight, beginning at 8 o'clock. The executive producer is Alexander Cohen and the writer and co-producer is Hildy Parks. The same team assembled such famous-faces TV specials as ''Night of 100 Stars.'' Here, unto hypnotic tedium, is more of the same, an extended exercise in visual name-dropping with occasional breathing space to comment portentously on the significance of it all.

title: NOAH OUTPLAYS VILAS IN FINAL
description: It is during the times when he is playing his best that Yannick Noah becomes ambivalent about success. Victory raises questions about his goals in tennis that Noah is not sure he can answer. Victory makes demands on his private life that he is not sure he is willing to meet. Victory may make him wonder whether he will eventually have to pack his bags again and move on.

title: NICARAGUA BALKS AT LATIN PEACE ACCORD
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra has indicated that Nicaragua is not ready to sign a Central American peace agreement that has been drawn up by the Contadora group.

title: Brazil to Curb Coffee Sales
description: Brazil, the world's biggest coffee producer, has pledged to cut back on exports of its Robusta beans so as not to threaten Africa's traditional markets, according to Paulo Graciano, the president of the Brazilian Coffee Institute.

title: Open the Waldheim File
description: Enough Austrian voters apparently were troubled by doubts about Kurt Waldheim's fitness to serve as their president to deny him his predicted majority in a first-round election. That gives the country until the June 8 runoff to ponder war-crimes charges against him, and crucial to any final judgment is hostile testimony contained in long-buried files kept at the United Nations.

title: OIL HEIRESS BRINGS ELEGANCE TO THE WORLD OF BOXING
description: SHE sits front row center in her royal blue Adolfo knit dress, lapis earrings and matching shoes, her silver hair, brilliant blue eyes and patrician features - a picture of demure elegance.

title: U.S. and Mexico Seek End to Tuna War
description: For almost six years now, Mexico and the United States have been locked in a trade war over tuna fish. Mexico is forbidden to market its tuna to the American consumer, and the United States tuna fleet is banned from the tuna-rich Pacific Ocean waters within 200 miles of Mexico.

title: Topics; Forms of Inducement; The Twain Solution
description: Angered that her classmates seemed better prepared for college, a recent graduate of Silver Lakes High School in Kingston, Mass., ran for the local school board. But once in office, her commitment to educational rigor seemed to fade.

title: Chrysler Picks Ex-Aide At Ford for World Unit
description: When the Chrysler Corporation offered Michael N. Hammes, vice president-truck operations for the Ford Motor Company of Europe, a job as general manager of its newly formed international operations unit, he did not take long to respond.

title: Four Writers to Read
description: Four writers - Harold Brodkey, Gordon Lish, Yannick Murphy and Cynthia Ozick - will read from their works at a benefit on May 28 at 7 P.M. at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th Street.

title: Spilling the NID
description: William Casey, Director of Central Intelligence, appears to be getting nervous in the service on the subject of leaks. Having been made the laughingstock of world spookery by his mishandling of the defector Yurchenko, he is now threatening journalists with jail terms for publishing secrets other than those leaked from the top.

title: 300,000 AT RALLY FOR SHCHARANSKY HEAR HIS THANKS
description: Anatoly B. Shcharansky thanked hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers yesterday for raising the ''voice of freedom'' year after year in behalf of Soviet Jews who are imprisoned, persecuted or denied the right to emigrate.

title: FED IS WARY ON NEW BANK PRODUCTS
description: Growing concerns about the risks of innovative financial practices by banks were expressed at a forum held last week by the Federal Reserve. And although no firm conclusions were reached, Fed officials reportedly hinted to the bankers in attendance that major changes in bank regulation could be expected.

title: A Real Showstopper
description: Drama of an unrehearsed kind dominated the first act of ''Benefactors'' Saturday night when an apparently intoxicated man disrupted the play and threw things into the audience before a policewoman persuaded him to leave.

title: Advertising; New Face Is Planned For Avon
description: AVON PRODUCTS is banking on advertising to pull itself out of the hole that a cutback in advertising dropped it into.

title: Lisa Koenigsberg Becomes a Bride
description: Lisa Koenigsberg, a historian, and Kevin David Weir, a banker, were married yesterday by Rabbi Roy A. Rosenberg at the Center for Inter-American Relations in New York.

title: DANCE: EGLEVSKY BALLET IN 'VALSE-FANTAISIE'
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 10 - The Eglevsky Ballet was musically and choreographically ambitious tonight at the John Cranford Adams Playhouse of Hofstra University. The Merrick (L.I.) Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Charles Gouse, was in the pit, and the program included a choreographic rarity.

title: SPY TRIAL CLASH TURNS ON MOTIVES OF EMIGRE
description: The espionage trial of Richard W. Miller reached a peak last week when the prosecutors and defense clashed over the motives of a Russian emigre who testified that Mr. Miller was innocent.

title: Perle Pulls Back
description: Assistant Defense Secretary Richard N. Perle is not known around Washington as a shrinking violet. But the other day, when Representative John Bryant, a Texas Democrat, held a hearing on whether there should be greater disclosure of foreign investment in the United States, Mr. Perle suddenly fell silent and withdrew as a witness, pleading a ''scheduling conflict.''

title: SHCHARANSKY AMONG FRIENDS
description: Before facing a sea of people at yesterday's mass rally, Anatoly B. Shcharansky got ready with a prayerful reunion with friends he had never met at a place he called ''the headquarters of the struggle for my release.''

title: JUDSON S. SAYRE
description: Judson S. Sayre, founder and president of Bendix Home Appliances Inc., manufacturer of the Bendix washing machine, died Tuesday at the Miami Heart Institute in Miami Beach, Fla. He was 87 years old. Mr. Sayre, who started his career as a salesman, introduced the Bendix ''automatic home laundry'' to this country and achieved the ultimate in sales promotion, the identification of the trade name with the product.

title: KNICKS 5TH
description: A year ago, the telephones were ringing at Madison Square Garden and fans were flocking to the box office to celebrate the Knicks' winning the first National Basketball Association lottery, an event that would bring them Patrick Ewing.

title: Baker Lauds Group of 7
description: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d said in an Italian newspaper interview that the agreement to add Italy and Canada to the so-called Group of Five ''should improve coordination of the policies of the economic leaders.'' Mr. Baker told the daily paper La Republica that he had supported the changes in the Group of Five, which comprises the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain and France.

title: The U.N. Today: May 12, 1986
description: ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Meets at 3 P.M.

title: U.S. AIDES ACCUSE MEXICO AS DRUG TRADE SURGES
description: American officials, normally circumspect about problems with Mexico, have begun issuing open denunciations of what they say is a huge increase in drug trafficking and related Government corruption.

title: CARNEGIE HIATUS SHIFTS MUSIC SCENE
description: Next week's closing of Carnegie Hall for eight months of renovations will create more problems for smaller independent presenters, debut recitalists and local groups than it will for the hall's more glamorous visitors, a check with the city's concert givers indicates.

title: Sex Discrimination In Custody Cases
description: To the Editor:

title: REPORTS CHARGE AN F.A.A. OFFICE SYSTEMATICALLY MISHANDLED FUNDS
description: A regional office of the Federal Aviation Administration, under scrutiny for its handling of a major airline safety inspection, has come under separate investigation for financial misdealings and ''allegations of a criminal nature,'' internal reports show.

title: Unusual Rise In Gas Prices
description: Retail gasoline prices, after a five-month decline, are on a unprecedented upswing for this time of year, an industry analyst said today.

title: PBS STATION IN MIAMI ABANDONS TELETHONS
description: Late at night, long after southern Florida's Public Broadcasting Service outlet WPBT has signed off the air, the station's main studio in North Miami is brightly lighted and filled with technicians and actors producing a Toyota commercial.

title: TURN RIGHT TO BAFFLEMENT
description: Coming from Detroit, the Motor City, Senator Carl M. Levin is perhaps more attuned than many legislators to the travails of traveling by car.

title: FREE-MARKET WATER: WEST STUDIES POLICY CHANGE
description: Two words are generating a lot of heat in the West these days: water marketing.

title: Tentative Settlement In Rhode Island Strike
description: Students are to be back in school Monday for the first time since April 21 after teachers ratified new contract, ending a 3-week strike over pay issues.

title: E. J. Greene Wed To Miss Wilhite
description: The wedding of Cheryl Wilhite and Elliott Jay Greene took place yesterday at the home of the bridegroom's father and stepmother, Mr. and Mrs. Henry G. Greene, in Scarsdale, N.Y. Justice Burton B. Roberts of State Supreme Court officiated.

title: DEPUTIES CUT TIES TO A CONTRA CHIEF
description: Capping three years of bitter discord, virtually all the military commanders fighting under Eden Pastora Gomez, the Nicaraguan rebel leader, have cut their ties with him and agreed to wage a joint campaign with American-backed rebels.

title: ROUNDUP OF QUARTERLY PROFITS AND SALES AT 288 COMPANIES
description: (Loss) * not applicable, loss in 1985 period.(1) Quarter ending in Dec.(2) Quarter ending in Jan.(3) Quarter ending in Feb.(4) Quarter ending in April

title: N.B.A. Rich Get Richer
description: EVEN before the National Basketball Association lottery began, Red Auerbach was puffing on his victory cigar. But for a change, the Boston Celtics' president finished second. And the Philadelphia 76ers, with a first-round choice obtained in 1979 from the San Diego Clippers for the forgotten forward Joe (Jelly Bean) Bryant, will have the first choice in the June 17 draft of college talent.

title: Gejdenson's Loss
description: Remember when Representative Alan B. Mollohan of West Virginia defeated Representative Sam Gejdenson of Connecticut for a prized Democratic seat on the House Appropriations Committee, overriding the House leadership?

title: ACADEMY OF SCIENCES PICKS MEMBERS
description: The National Academy of Sciences, the private organization of scientists and engineers who act as official advisers to the Federal Government on matters of science and technology, has elected new members.

title: BATES SAID TO ACCEPT SAATCHI BID
description: Ted Bates Worldwide, the third-largest American advertising agency, has agreed to be acquired by Saatchi & Saatchi of London, Britain's and Europe's largest, for $400 million down and another $50 million in 1988, according to sources close to the negotiations.

title: KEY OFFICIALS CALL SCANDAL UNDETECTABLE
description: They did not know about the corruption scandal that has enveloped the Koch administration. They could not have known, and given the nature of city government, it is conceivable the same thing could happen again.

title: A VERY GENERAL STORE CLOSES IN PRINCETON
description: In many ways, Mary's Store was Princeton's version of a Harpo Marx overcoat: no matter what you were looking for, it was in there somewhere.

title: Mesa Plans Cut In Oil Output
description: Mesa Limited Partnership, the unit formed last year to manage the oil and gas assets of the Mesa Petroleum Company, said Friday that beginning June 1 it would reduce its oil production by up to 20 percent.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, MAY 12, 1986
description: International U.S. antiterror policy is threatened by budget cuts, Secretary of State George P. Shultz said. He said would have ''to drop everything else'' to lobby for restoration of budget cuts in Congress that he asserted threatened to deeply impair the Reagan Administration's foreign and counterterrorism policies. He said the Administration had had to ''squeeze'' money to give the Philippines even an additional $150 million in aid. Mr. Shultz also said the Senate's failure to back the program for enhanced security at American embassies could cause ''another tragedy'' at some mission overseas. [ Page A1, Column 6. ] Syria ordered the expulsion of three British diplomats in retaliation for Britain's ouster of three Syrian envoys from London. A Syrian Foreign Ministry announcement on the Damascus radio said the British Ambassador in Damascus, William Roger Tomkys, was told that the three embassy staff must leave within a week. On Saturday, the British Government ordered the expulsion of three members of the Syrian Embassy whom Londeon wanted to questions as part of an investigation into terrorist activities in Britain. [ A1:5. ]

title: RANGERS SEE FINISH AS A STARTING POINT
description: ''It's not over yet.'' That was all Ted Sator said when the Rangers' playoff season ended. As mystifying as it seemed at the time, it revealed an admirable sentiment: the coach viewed the experience as stage one in his program, not the final stage.

title: Workers on 911 Line Protest
description: Police officials and union leaders representing civilian dispatchers are to meet Monday to discuss a nine-hour walkout Saturday by 40 operators of the 911 emergency switchboard.

title: SHULTZ SAYS CUTS BY CONGRESS HURT ANTITERROR POLICY
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that Congress was threatening to deeply impair the Administration's foreign and counterterrorism policies by its recent budget cuts.

title: Dingell on Japanese Trade...
description: It is likely to take a vote on the floor of the House to resolve a contest between two powerful committee chairmen over the best way to retaliate against countries such as Japan that do not give American exporters a fair shake in telecommunications.

title: New Amfac Head Cites Problems
description: Ronald R. Sloan was a vice president at a frozen potato company called Lamb-Weston when Amfac Inc., a huge diversified services corporation, bought it in 1971. Things worked out well for Mr. Sloan, whose election as president and chief executive of Amfac becomes effective today after the annual meeting.

title: PROST WINS, LEADS TITLE RACE
description: Alain Prost of France sped away from the pole position today to win his third consecutive Monaco Grand Prix and take the lead in the Formula I auto racing world championship standing.

title: NOT THE WHOLE PACKAGE
description: Last week, Congress turned down the Administration's proposal to sell $354 million worth of sophisticated missiles to Saudi Arabia. The question is far from closed, however, for the President is expected to veto the resolution and Congress is then expected to try to override his veto.

title: Ally & Gargano Gains
description: Ally & Gargano, the newest of the publicly held ad agencies, last week released the financial statement for its fiscal third quarter, ended March 31. Revenues were down slightly to $43.1 million from $43.4 million a year earlier, but net income rose to $655,000, or 30 cents a share, from $400,000, or 18 cents a share.

title: IN ATOMIC DEBATE, CHERNOBYL'S CLUES
description: With the accident at the Chernobyl nuclear plant in the Ukraine, the Soviet Union may have unintentionally created a vast field experiment that could shed light on some of the most disputed questions facing the nuclear industry in the United States.

title: YOUNG MOTHERS CITE PROBLEMS
description: Mother's Day celebrations often gloss over the struggles of motherhood. But at a service at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine yesterday morning, this theme was examined by four women who became mothers as teen-agers.

title: Use of Antidote Is Approved For a Dangerous Heart Drug
description: The Food and Drug Administration has announced approval of an antidote to digoxin, a heart drug used by about 4 million people that has been blamed for the deaths of about 175 people a year through overdoses.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;
Scaled-Down Sport
description: If you've never heard of arena football, the reason is that nobody else had either until a couple of weeks ago, when Jim Foster introduced his new venture in an experimental game at Rockford, Ill. Foster, a 35-year-old Chicago-based entrepreneur, had distributed 3,000 free tickets in hopes that perhaps 500 football fans might show up to watch the proceedings and then complete market-research questionnaires. Instead, on a gorgeous Sunday morning, he drew indoors a total of 1,000, who saw two local semipro teams limit themselves to eight men on a side and pound each other for three quarters on a field 50 yards long and 80 feet wide.

title:
Outdoors;
Searching for Marina Space
description: ''F INDING a slip for my boat was harder than finding my apartment.'' The boat owner, new to New York, half-jokingly wonders why there are no boat-slip brokers.

title: It's Unfair to Goliath
description: The public-relations advisers to Pennzoil have been circulating brochures about the fantastic case in which their client was awarded damages against Texaco of more than $10 billion for interfering with a proposed Pennzoil- Getty merger. One of these brochures contains an account of the trial by Jim Shannon, a member of the jury, who stoutly defends the award.

title: Judges' Group Opposes State Red-Light Areas
description: The Federation of New York State Judges called on the State Bar Association yesterday to reject a proposal that the state permit red-light districts where prostitution would be allowed.

title: Caution Seen in Bond Outlook
description: Bond market participants have not abandoned forecasts that a weak economy will lead to renewed declines in interest rates, but there is growing recognition that recent increases in oil prices and rapid money-supply growth will make rate declines more difficult to achieve.

title: Ogilvy and T.W.A.'s Relationship Unclear
description: There was a rumor circulating Friday that struggling Trans World Airlines had split with its advertising agency, Ogilvy & Mather, and that the budget once quoted at $70 million has shrunk to about half that.

title: MEXICO REBUTS CHARGES BY U.S. ON DRUG FLOW
description: Mexican officials have rejected assertions by United States officials that Mexico is doing nothing to combat drug traffic across the border and that Mexico is not cooperating with American efforts to combat the drug flow.

title: Yes - and Israel Gains
description: Congress must adopt a more sophisticated arms policy toward the Middle East.

title: OPERA: MALFITANO IN 'DAPHNE' AT STRAUSS FESTIVAL
description: FOR many years it was generally conceded that Richard Strauss's late operas were fated to be loved by a few and ignored by most. ''Daphne,'' a product of his World War II years, certainly fell into this connoisseur category, even though it overflows with some of the composer's most richly colored and rhapsodic music. Lately, however, listeners in search of something to love about 20th-century opera have been taking a more sympathetic view of the flaws in late Strauss works, which do seem to shrink in significance as time goes by.

title: Rev. Wilbur Hogg Dies at 69; Ex-Albany Episcopal Bishop
description: The Rev. Wilbur Hogg, who served as bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Albany for 10 years before his retirement in 1984, died Saturday in Portland, Me. He was 69 years old.

title: RED SOX IN FIRST PLACE
description: Rich Gedman went 4 for 4 and Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd and two relievers combined on a seven-hitter today as the Boston Red Sox survived four Oakland home runs to beat the A's, 6-5. The victory enabled the Red Sox to move into first place in the American League East.

title: ... And Dingell on Conrail Sale
description: Mr. Dingell's ultimatum to Transportation Secretary Elizabeth Hanford Dole to jettison her proposal to sell the Consolidated Rail Corporation to the Norfolk Southern Corporation has set the stage for a showdown between the Administration and a coalition of House Democrats and Republicans who do not like the deal.

title: BUCKS BEAT 76ERS AND CLINCH SERIES
description: After 13 days, which included six exhausting games and 47 minutes 57 seconds of emotional, physical and brilliantly contested basketball, it was all up to the man who had been in that kind of situation so many times before. With just three seconds remaining in the seventh and deciding game of the playoff series between the Milwaukee Bucks and the Philadelphia 76ers, Julius Erving, ball in hand, could decide whose season would continue and whose would end.

title: BALLET: TCHERKASSKY DANCES ROLE OF GISELLE
description: LOVE, betrayal, remorse and regeneration - all these ingredients make up the quintessential Romantic story in the 1841 French ballet ''Giselle.'' Marianna Tcherkassky and Kevin McKenzie offered a superb lesson in how to bring that story alive for our own time in American Ballet Theater's ''Giselle'' Saturday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Lloyd Beats Rinaldi
description: Chris Evert Lloyd, the top-seeded player, defeated second-seeded Kathy Rinaldi, 6-4, 2-6, 6-4, today to capture the $150,000 Virginia Slims of Houston tournament.

title: Wild Birds in Jeopardy Again
description: New York has just become the first state to forbid the sale of exotic birds caught wild in other countries. Importers and retailers, seeking to eviscerate the new law, have already persuaded the State Senate to limit it to endangered species.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: IMPOSTORS. By George V. Higgins. 362 pages. Henry Holt. $16.95. ''I

title: Report Asserts Parole Is Revoked More Often
description: The number of Federal inmates whose paroles were revoked because they committed new crimes doubled between 1979 and 1985, the Bureau of Justice Statistics said today.

title: Travelers Entering U.S. Facing $5 Customs Fee
description: The Customs Service plans to begin charging $5 per person for inspecting the luggage of travelers entering the United States by plane or ship, the agency announced today.

title: BIG FIELD, COSTLY CAR, AND DRINK
description: Gov. Bill Sheffield has drawn 13 opponents in his campaign for re-election to a second term. And with the deadline less than a month away, a 14th, former Gov. Walter J. Hickel, stands teetering in the wings undecided.

title: TAIWAN IS SEEKING HIGH-TECH GROWTH
description: Five years ago, at an age when many successful American executives turn their thoughts to golf, C. H. Li retired from his $100,000-a-year job as research director for Honeywell Inc. in Minneapolis and started work at a fraction of the salary in Hsinchu, the city that officials here like to call Taiwan's Silicon Valley.

title: Malpractice Insurance Drives Up Medicaid Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: Johns Hopkins Is Top-Seeded
description: Johns Hopkins, the three-time defending champion, will be the top-seeded team in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I men's lacrosse tournament.

title: CHANGING BONE MARROW: NOW A TEST IN THE FIELD
description: Almost as many bone marrow transplantations were probably done last week as a result of the Soviet nuclear accident as would ordinarily be done in a month in a major transplant center in the United States.

title: FLAMES CAN CLINCH
description: Special teams and a special effort by some young players have given the Calgary Flames a lead of three games to two over the St. Louis Blues in their Stanley Cup semifinal playoff series.

title: And So It Goes: Responses to Kurt Vonnegut
description: To the Editor:

title: ROSE STARS IN BOTH HIS ROLES
description: It was not exactly your basic working day for a 45-year-old man, but for Pete Rose it was one more day of decision and performance in a career that began 23 years ago in the uniform of the Cincinnati Reds, and he made the most of it.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

title: CROWDS AND YELLOW RIBBONS GREET LOUISIANA GOVERNOR'S ACQUITTAL
description: Back in Baton Rouge this weekend after his trial, mistrial, retrial and ultimately acquittal, Gov. Edwin W. Edwards, aiming toward the television cameras, had a few carefully chosen words for his constituency.

title: The Background; One-Act Opera by Strauss
description: Strauss composed ''Daphne,'' the 13th of his 15 operas, during the late 1930's, when the Nazis were consolidating their power in Germany and preparing to overrun much of Europe. When his admired Jewish friend and librettist, Stefan Zweig, became unacceptable to the anti-Semitic regime, Strauss reluctantly turned to Joseph Gregor, an Austrian writer and a stage archivist, for a text based on the classical myth of the maiden who falls in love with a god.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''They tried their best to find a place where I was isolated.

title: CURATOR YIELDS HIS JOB AT REAGAN'S REQUEST
description: Clement Conger is something of a legend here.

title: MEMOIRISTS WHO SERVE AND TELL
description: WHATEVER one might be led to believe by the response to his recent ''Triumph of Politics: How the Reagan Revolution Failed,'' David A. Stockman is actually not the first person in American history to resign from a Government post and then write a memoir while the President he served was still incumbent. In fact, Mr. Stockman is not even the first memoirist of the present Administration, what with former Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.'s having published ''Caveat: Realism, Reagan and Foreign Policy'' two years ago.

title: BAYONNE'S RACE FOR MAYOR FINDS G.O.P. IN A ROLE
description: Politics in this peninsula town, once called ''Oil City'' when it was home to some of the nation's first refineries, is a game dominated by Democrats.

title: Bank Leumi Resignation
description: Israel's most prominent banker, Dr. Ernest Japhet, tonight resigned as chairman of Bank Leumi in the wake of a recent bank shares scandal. Eli Hurwitz succeeds him.

title: DAMASCUS EXPELS 3 BRITISH ENVOYS
description: Syria said today that it had ordered the expulsion of three British diplomats in retaliation for the ouster by Britain of three Syrian envoys on Saturday.

title: And So It Goes: Responses to Kurt Vonnegut
description: To the Editor:

title: 46 Are Arrested in Clash At Murdoch Press Plant
description: The police clashed with hundreds of demonstrators early today outside the east London printing plant of Rupert Murdoch, the newspaper publisher. The police said 46 people were arrested and nine injured.

title: LIBERTY EVENT TO BRING BIG FAIR TO CITY STREETS
description: At midnight on July 3, some 5,000 carpenters, stagehands, technicians and engineers are to swarm into lower Manhattan to undertake the daunting task of building 400 booths and seven stages - four large and three small -by 9 A.M. the next day. They will be setting up the biggest street fair that just about anyone can remember.

title: Fire at Nuclear Plant Burns Cooling Tower
description: A fire destroyed a cooling tower at the closed Browns Ferry Nuclear Plant Saturday, but a spokesman said the blaze never threatened the main reactor building, less than half a mile away.

title: CARTER GIVES THE SIGNS OF CONFIDENCE
description: THE ground ball that resulted in a double play to end a game last week also ignited the catcher. Like some over-armored knight, he bounded madly to the pitcher's mound, his shinguards clanking, his chest protector flapping and his square jaw going. He was shouting at the pitcher. The pitcher was Dwight Gooden. The catcher was Gary Carter. What was he shouting? ''You're the best, Doc, you're the best!''

title: 'DIANA FEVER' COMES TO A QUIET EMPEROR'S LAND
description: Japan extended to visiting royalty today what it can seldom extend to its own ancient monarchy - a public embrace.

title: CHURCH AND POLITICAL ISSUES: HOW FAR IS TOO FAR?
description: A Federal judge's decision to hold the country's two foremost Roman Catholic Church groups in contempt of court dramatizes a continuing controversy over the rights of religious groups to get involved in politics.

title: BEHIND FASHION WEEKS'S GLITTER
description: Just before dawn on Friday, in the ballroom of the Pierre Hotel, all eyes were focused on the lights. Geoffrey Beene's fashion show was to begin in less than four hours, and the special effect that would close the production - spotlights that formed stars and stripes - did not have the crisp, dramatic look that the designer had intended.

title: Kodak Jobs for J.W.T. And Young & Rubicam
description: Eastman Kodak, which is in a worldwide consolidation of its advertising assignments while going from three agencies to two, reported Friday that it is assigning all of its business in the Far East to J. Walter Thompson, with Young & Rubicam, one of its two agencies.

title: Top Bracket Below 30% Predicted
description: Representative Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, predicted today that Congress would approve a top tax bracket below 30 percent.

title: Graduation Circuit
description: Now that he bears the seniority of a second Presidential campaign, the Rev. Jesse Jackson has graduated to appearing at some fairly imposing academic institutions. On May 30, he is to deliver the commencement address at the School of Advanced International Studies of Johns Hopkins University in Washington. Among his predecessors in this role have been Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone of Japan; John Kenneth Galbraith, the author and diplomat, and Paul H. Nitze, the arms control negotiator.

title: INDIANS' RAGE AT ILLEGAL BAR FUELS UPSTATE FIRE
description: All that remained of the rage today were the ashes of Josie's Place and the brick chimney that loomed over them.

title: Cashing In
description: It's dollars to doughnuts that a team that wins a division championship, draws record attendance and takes in record revenues is going to earn record profits - or would, if it could get away with paying the players doughnuts instead of dollars.

title: RETAILERS CITE WEAK APRIL SALES
description: Seven of New York City's biggest retailers found that sales in April reverted to the sluggish pace of recent months, a spot-check has shown.

title: Mount St. Helens Shows Change in Readings
description: An easing in the rumbling beneath Mount St. Helens and a change in seismic readings gave geologists new indications today that a dome-building eruption of the volcano was under way.

title: CUOMO TELLS GRADUATES TO BUILD NEW AMERICA
description: Governor Cuomo urged graduates of Syracuse University today to think beyond personal ambition and dream of an America that ''doesn't leave anyone out.''

title: LAST-MINUTE AMTRAK TALKS AVERT ENGINEERS' WALKOUT IN NORTHEAST
description: Emergency negotiations between Amtrak engineers and the national rail line averted, at least temporarily, a strike threatened for midnight tonight that would have crippled passenger service in the Northeast and perhaps elsewhere.

title: In Search of a Sound City Tax
description: New York City needs a new tax. That's the dark side of Mayor Koch's new $21.5 billion budget, half-hidden in the shadow of his enthusiasm for a 10-year housing plan. City taxes are yielding less than expected while Federal aid cuts are deeper; the Mayor can't balance his budget without an additional $160 million. What's the best way to raise it?

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Friday about the opening of the Cannes Film Festival misidentified the actor who plays the Spanish princess in ''Pirates,'' a film entered in the festival. She is Charlotte Lewis, not Damien Thomas.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Comdata Network Inc., Nashville, named R. Lewis Jones chairman, succeeding Curtiss W. Harter Jr., who resigned for health reasons.

title: SUSPECT HELD IN THE MURDER OF PRIEST, 49
description: An 18-year-old Brooklyn man was arrested by the police yesterday and charged with the murder of a Roman Catholic priest who had been shot to death in his car early Saturday in a rundown industrial section of downtown Brooklyn.

title: Afghan Demonstrators Protest Ouster of Karmal
description: At least eight protests, most of them student demonstrations broken up by the secret police, have been held in Kabul in support of the former Afghan Communist Party leader, Babrak Karmal, Western diplomats said today.

title: And So It Goes: Responses to Kurt Vonnegut
description: To the Editor:

title: Bangladesh Ruling Party Wins Half of Seats
description: The Jatiya Party of President H. M. Ershad has won 132 of 264 contests decided by last week's parliamentary elections, officials said today after completing the vote count.

title: RACING DIVIDED OVER MEDICATION
description: Critics of racehorse medication had a field day. Ferdinand and Bold Arrangement, the only runners in the May 3 Kentucky Derby field to go postward without pharmaceutical assistance, finished first and second. The other 14, scattered over the length of the Churchill Downs stretch, got either Butazolidin or Lasix - or both - as allowed by the rules of racing in Kentucky.

title: COURT HELPS ODD COUPLE GET TO PROM
description: Two young women who won a court battle to attend their high school prom together enjoyed the big event after overcoming a last-minute problem: They forgot to bring their ticket.

title: Caucus Room Memories
description: When the American Jewish Committee asked Hyman Bookbinder where he wanted his retirement reception held, he unhesitatingly chose the caucus room of the Russell Senate Office Building. In that historic chamber Senator Estes Kefauver investigated crime, Senator Joseph R. McCarthy charged that Communism had infiltrated the State Department and the Army, and the Senate Watergate Committee investigated the Nixon White House.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Atlanta Braves, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. The Mets lost the only game of their recent road trip in Atlanta.

title: Bridge: Two From Texas Take Lead In Event at Cavendish Club
description: Two Texan experts who are not a regular partnership led the field of 36 pairs in the prestigious Cavendish Club Invitational Pairs event in Manhattan last night.

title: Ruth Batchelor Is Married To Peter Kory, Developer
description: Ruth Batchelor, a songwriter, freelance journalist and television producer, was married yesterday to Peter Kory, a real-estate developer, at the Westbury Hotel by the bride's son, the Rev. Douglas Batchelor, a Seventh-day Adventist minister.

title: REACTIONS TO THOSE WHO BEG
description: THEY meet the trains from Connecticut and Westchester and Long Island in the morning. With hands and cups extended to catch the dropping coins, they form a kind of human toll road over which the suburban commuters must pass to enter the city.

title: CORPORATE NET BELOW FORECASTS
description: Corporate profits in the first quarter were below expectations, despite solid expansion in the ecomony, economists said. Furthermore, they added, the impact of lower oil prices on corporate profits has largely been negative, with improvement not being forecast until the second half of the year.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;
Old College Drive
description: There won't be any cheerleaders, pompon girls, marching band or homecoming queen. But more than 50,000 cheering fans will be witnesses to sports history next Saturday afternoon when the Wesley College Wolverines take the field - er, track -for the Budweiser Grand National 200 at Dover Downs International Speedway in Delaware: According to Nascar, Wesley is the first college that has ever sponsored a team in an auto race.

title: CAMPUS REPORT: COMPUTERS IN, TYPEWRITERS OUT
description: On college campuses throughout the New York metropolitan area, the old clickety-clack of typewriters increasingly is being replaced by the whir of computer terminals.

title: Treasury Financing Takes a Break
description: Treasury financing is confined this week to the bill market, where today's regular auction of three-month and six-month issues will be followed by a one-year bill sale tomorrow.

title: HAITIANS REPORT TRACING TRANSFER OF MILLIONS ABROAD BY DUVALIER
description: Government officials searching for money believed embezzled by President Jean-Claude Duvalier before he fled the country say that they have traced the transfer out of Haiti of more than $300 million and that he may have hidden as much as $900 million in foreign banks.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Which major leaguer was the last member of the New York Giants to retire and which was the last one for the Brooklyn Dodgers?

title: And So It Goes: Responses to Kurt Vonnegut
description: To the Editor:

title: Carter Contends Koch Harmed '80 Campaign
description: Former President Jimmy Carter said yesterday that he believed Mayor Koch had made a deal with Republican leaders to undermine Mr. Carter's 1980 re-election campaign.

title: Staying Close to Home
description: When Rita Zimmer talks about building homes, she talks about 15 units at a time.

title: Allegheny Stake Bought
description: Southeastern Asset Management Inc., an investment adviser based in Memphis, said it had purchased a 9.1 percent stake of the shares outstanding of Allegheny International Inc., a diversified manufacturer of industrial and consumer products.

title: Catching Up
description: * A baseball season has come and gone, but the sculpture of Phil Niekro still sits, draped in brown plastic and protected by wood paneling, in a tunnel beneath Atlanta-Fulton County Stadium. A ceremony in which the the statue was to have joined those of Ty Cobb and Hank Aaron outside the ball park was scheduled for late last season, but Niekro couldn't make it: The Yankees were in a pennant race, and he didn't want to be distracted.

title: NASA Delays 2 Launchings Expected to Color the Skies
description: Cloudy weather today forced the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to postpone for the fourth time the launchings of rockets carrying experiments that are expected to produce colorful skies along the East Coast.

title: Market Place; Airlines Gird For Summer
description: THE two largest international carriers in the United States - Pan American World Airways and Trans World Airways - are looking to the upcoming summer tourist season with trepidation, but not with fears of extinction.

title: Washington Watch; Conversions Of Thrift Units
description: NOW that the regulators and the Administration have produced what appears to be a workable $25 billion, five-year rescue plan for the troubled Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, they are concerned about another problem, thrift institution defections.

title: THE BUDGET KNIFE IS TURNED INWARD
description: There are 75 vacancies on the Capitol Hill police force. The pages for the House of Representatives will work without pay this summer. In the midst of trying to put together a budget proposal, the House Budget Committee has lost two senior analysts.

title: KREMLIN ASSERTS 'DANGER IS OVER'
description: Senior Soviet officials asserted today that a ''turning point'' had been reached in the Chernobyl nuclear reactor accident and that the plant no longer threatened a ''catastrophe.''

title: Fletcher Chief Sees Banc One Network
description: Frank E. McKinney Jr. is an Indianian through and through. He was born and raised in Indianapolis, went to Indiana University and rose to be head of the state's largest bank, where his father had been chairman before him. But now that bank and its holding company, the American Fletcher Corporation, is being taken over by Banc One of Columbus, Ohio.

title: STUDYING THE BEHAVIOR OF BULLY AND VICTIM
description: ''What do we know about bullies?'' the psychologist asked the class before him in the Ardsley Middle School.

title: Warwick Shop Gets New Chief
description: John Warwick, second-generation leader of the 47-year-old Warwick advertising agency, has turned the helm over to someone outside the family, Wilder D. Baker, 54-year-old Yale alumnus, who joined the agency in 1976. Mr. Baker, who is from San

title: Four Honorary Degrees Awarded by Skidmore
description: Skidmore College awarded degrees to 563 graduates at its 75th annual commencement exercises Saturday as the retiring chairman of the school's board of trustees spoke of the college's history.

title: INSURANCE COSTS IMPERIL RECREATION INDUSTRY
description: Soaring costs for liability insurance are buffeting recreation facilities and businesses on the eve of the summer vacation season.

title: 4 More Are Killed In South African Strife
description: A policeman killed three black youths in Soweto and a bus driver was burned to death in overnight violence, the authorities said today.

title: FILM SEES TALENTS AS AGELESS
description: A FINELY drawn documentary film begins with those lovely lines from the Dylan Thomas poem ''Do Not Go Gentle Into That Good Night'' as its theme:

title: BADGERS OUTROW RADCLIFFE
description: Wisconsin captured the Governor's Cup for varsity eights today, providing a rousing finish to the eighth annual Women's Sprint Championships on a windy Lake Waramaug course.

title: SENATE TAX BILL LESS GENEROUS
description: The Senate Finance Committee's tax revision plan provides a more delicate balance between winning and losing for middle-income taxpayers than the tax bill passed by the House of Representatives, according to a detailed analysis of individual examples.

title: Holly Cohen Is Wed to Richard Osman
description: Hollis Martha Cohen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Cohen of New York, was married yesterday to Richard Michael Osman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert I. Osman of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbis Judah Nadich and Harlan Wechsler and Cantor David Lefkowitz performed the ceremony at the Park Avenue Synagogue.

title: HINT OF NOSTALGIA AT CANNES FESTIVAL
description: The sequel to a modern romantic classic, a historical drama involving Jews and Nazis in postwar Argentina, and a journey through the sordid underworld of London were among the non-American films attracting attention during the 1986 Cannes Film Festival, which began Thursday and so far has been marked by no dominant trends or themes. The festival ends May 19.

title: U. OF NEW MEXICO LEADER SAYS HE'S HAD ENOUGH
