description: The president of the University of New Mexico, complaining that its Regents treat him like a butler who might steal the family silver, has announced he will leave by the end of the year.

title: Oslo Devalues Krone
description: The Norwegian Prime Minister, Dr. Gro Harlem Brundtland, announced a 12 percent devaluation today of the Norwegian currency, the krone, effective immediately. Dr. Brundtland, whose Labor Party Government took office three days ago.

title: FOR AIDS VICTIMS, A CHURCH'S PRAYERS - AND FOOD
description: Along about 5 o'clock on Tuesday evenings, 50 or so men and women form a circle around tables neatly set for dinner, clasp hands and say grace. All too frequently Peter Avitabile softly announces the name of one of their friends who has recently died. Then the group sits down for an elaborate meal that many of them say nourishes in more ways than one.

title: REDS SOCK GOODEN FOR EIGHT HITS AS METS LOSE, 3-2
description: The Mets came to the end of their seven-game winning streak yesterday when they lost to the Cincinnati Reds, 3-2, before 44,236 wondering fans at Shea Stadium, and guess who the losing pitcher was? Dwight Gooden, of all people.

title: 'Lady's Time' Receives First-Novel Award
description: Alan V. Hewat's ''Lady's Time'' (Harper & Row) has been chosen the winner of the PEN American Center's $7,500 Ernest Hemingway Foundation award for the best first novel published in 1985.

title: Libyan Cites OPEC Output
description: A top Libyan oil official said in remarks published here that OPEC output had reached 18 million barrels a day, and a major cut was needed to raise prices.

title: U.S.F.L. Case Set to Begin
description: The United States Football League's antitrust case against the National Football League was scheduled to begin today in Federal District Court in Manhattan with the selection of six jurors and six alternates.

title: Turner Names Co-presidents
description: The Turner Corporation, one of the nation's largest builders, has named co-presidents: Alfred T. McNeill, 49 years old, to operate the company's construction subsidiaries, and Robert D. Kupfer, 58, to direct international and nonconstruction units.

title: WILSON AND MULLER AT N.Y.U.
description: Heiner Muller is an East German widely regarded as the most important German playwright since Brecht. Robert Wilson is generally considered the most important American avant-garde theater artist, most recently in the news when the Pulitzer Prize board rejected its advisory panel's unanimous recommendation that he be awarded this year's prize for drama.

title: BEAN HANGS ON TO WIN BY SHOT
description: Andy Bean, three shots ahead with two holes to play, turned back a challenge from Mark Wiebe to salvage a one-stroke victory today in the Byron Nelson Classic.

title: YANKS ARE SWEPT BY RANGERS, 6-3, 9-1
description: The Yankees seemed to agree that it was just one of those days. So they collectively shrugged it off, packed their bags and quietly left town.

title: Art Foundation Names Hopkins as Its Director
description: Henry T. Hopkins, director of the San Francisco Museum of Art, will become director of the Frederick R. Weisman Foundation of Art in Los Angeles in November.

title: THE TASADAY REVISITED: A HOAX OR SOCIAL CHANGE AT WORK?
description: After more than a decade, scientists and reporters have returned to visit a remote Stone Age tribe called the Tasaday, and found that its earlier contacts with the outside world have set it on what appears to be an irreversible road to change.

title: OVERLAND EXPRESS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and includes income from cumulative effect of change in accounting principle of $811,000.

title: NEW WORLD PICTURES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary tax credit of $495,000. Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid March 21.

title: Koch to Attend Dellums Tribute
description: Mayor Koch, whose remarks about Representative Ronald V. Dellums angered many blacks, will attend a tribute to the liberal California Democrat Friday in Queens.

title: NEW PAPER FOUND IN WALDHEIM CASE
description: As a first lieutenant in the German Army in World War II, Kurt Waldheim provided information that helped deport thousands of Italian soldiers into forced labor in Germany after Italy's surrender to the Allies in 1943, according to German war documents.

title: SANMARK-STARDUST INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Top Canadian Official Resigns Post
description: The Industry Minister in the Conservative Cabinet of Prime Minister Brian Mulroney resigned today in the face of accusations of conflict of interest raised by the political opposition and the press.

title: GRAPHICS SOFTWARE: FASTER THAN A COLOR PEN
description: THE visual world of the video generation is fast expanding far beyond entertainment to the printed word. Scientific reports, corporate takeover proposals, school assignments and what was once simply text accompanied by tabular data are now adorned with flashy histograms and pie charts. More and more, too, color is adding vividness to these displays.

title: N.H.L. Playoffs; BLUES, IN OVERTIME, FORCE A 7TH GAME
description: Doug Wickenheiser climaxed a St. Louis comeback with a goal 7 minutes 30 seconds into overtime to give the Blues a 6-5 victory over the Calgary Flames tonight and force a seventh game in their Stanley Cup playoff series.

title: UNITED BRANDS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain on the retirement of debt of $2,071,000.

title: Balloting Is Scheduled Today In 32 Municipalities in Jersey
description: Voters in 32 New Jersey municipalities will go to the polls today to decide contests for mayor and council. The polls will be open from 7 A.M. to 8 P.M.

title: 64 on E.M.S. Staff Skip a Work Shift
description: Sixty-four members, or about 28 percent, of the city's ambulance crews failed to show up for work yesterday in what union officials called an unauthorized ''sickout'' to protest salary levels.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: THEY call it Fashion Week even though it lasts two weeks and then some. In the first week, young talent was in the spotlight.

title: HAMILTON OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
19-2 Victory For Rangers
description: Toby Harrah drove in four runs and Larry Parrish hit a three-run homer tonight to highlight a 22-hit attack for the Texas Rangers in a 19-2 rout of the Cleveland Indians.

title: FALL TRENDS: LONGER IS THE KEY WORD
description: The lengthening of clothes for fall and winter has forced a re-evaluation of shape and proportion that has changed the look of fashion. Designers, determined to avoid a matronly look, worked close to the body to emphasize natural curves. Still, they have escaped the vulgarity of clothes that are too tight and cup the hips. Flaring, circular and pleated skirts have returned.

title: NASA HAD WARNING OF RISK TO SHUTTLE IN COLD WEATHER
description: Nearly six months before the Challenger disaster, the space agency was given results of a test showing that safety seals in the space shuttle's booster rockets could fail at temperatures of 50 degrees or lower, according to a newly disclosed document.

title: EUROPE BARS FOOD FROM SOVIET BLOC
description: After a week of complicated and at times embarrassing negotiations, the European Community announced agreement today on a ban on meat, live animals and produce from Eastern Europe because of the Soviet nuclear accident.

title: Baby Boomers
description: Jose Canseco of Oakland and Wally Joyner of California are hitting homers at a rate that would give each of them 50 for the season and make them the most prodigious rookie sluggers in major league history. Here are the first-year players who have hit 30 or more:

title: N.H.L. Drug Inquiry
description: The National Hockey League will likely open an investigation into the use of cocaine by Borje Salming of the Toronto Maple Leafs.

title: The Government's Phones
description: Choosing a phone company for long-distance service has become commonplace since the break-up of the American Telephone & Telegraph Company. But when the Federal Government selects its phone company, more is involved than just checking off the appropriate box on a form that came in the mail.

title: Nebraskans Holding Gubernatorial Primary
description: Nebraskans Tuesday begin choosing a successor to Gov. Bob Kerrey, who is retiring, from among 15 candidates.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Sinking Fund Issue For Ryder System
description: Ryder System Inc. is offering $100 million of 9 percent sinking fund debentures due in 2016 at 99 to yield 9.10 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: WAL-MART STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect the 100 percent common stock dividend paid on Oct. 4, 1985.

title: SYRIANS IN LEBANON SAID TO CARVE A TRENCH SYSTEM CLOSER TO ISRAEL
description: In the last few months the Syrian Army has been building forward artillery and tank trenches in southern Lebanon that are closer to the Israeli border, Israeli and Western military sources said today.

title: Waste Is the Real Culprit in the Federal Budget
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Is Aiding in Plans To Travel, Marcos Says
description: Former President Ferdinand E. Marcos said in a telephone interview with reporters here today that he was in ''constant contact'' with the State Department, which he said was helping him and his family in their attempt to travel to another country.

title: COMCAST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Advertising; Bristol-Myers Plans Group W Program Role
description: Bristol-Myers, one of the first companies to make a major investment in cable television, is now entering into a multimillion-dollar deal with Group W.

title: Trouble Funk's Way With Go-Go Rhythms
description: New Yorkers are finally getting the hang of go-go, the nonstop dance music of Washington. When Trouble Funk played the Ritz late Saturday night, the audience picked up two new dances (the Drop and the Wiggle), waved hands in the air, chanted and shouted on cue and stayed in motion for the entire set - an hour and 55 minutes of music in three long stretches.

title: Ann Golenpaul Dies; Radio Show Producer
description: Ann Golenpaul, who helped produce the long-running radio show ''Information Please'' with her late husband, Dan, died Friday at St. Luke's Hospital after a short illness. She was 79 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: JOHNSON FEARED A KIDNAPPING AIDE TELLS JURY
description: The late J. Seward Johnson had an intense concern with security, keeping a gun next to his bed and frequently wearing a gun in a holster during the day, a member of his private security force testified yesterday.

title: Packwood War Chest Biggest
description: Senator Bob Packwood, the Oregon Republican whose tax revision efforts have thrust him into the national spotlight, has raised and spent more money than any other candidate in this year's Congressional races.

title: Volcano Hidden
description: Mount St. Helens is in the midst of a quiet dome-building eruption, a spokesman for the United States Geological Survey said, but thick clouds have kept geologists from seeing exactly what is happening.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: DOLLAR'S SLIDE CONTINUES DESPITE MOVES TO HALT IT
description: Finance ministers and central bankers continued their tentative campaign to halt the slide of the dollar yesterday, but with no clear sign of success.

title: Ex-Fed Bank President Helps Warburg Expand
description: Anthony M. Solomon, retired president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, will be spending some of his time helping S. G. Warburg (U.S.A.) Inc. to expand its business in the United States.

title: GISH BIOMEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $6,800 for the quarter and $18,800 for the 9 months. c-Net income

title: BRENNER ENTERING LATE-NIGHT RACE
description: Joan Rivers, whose defection from NBC's ''Tonight'' show caused a stir last week, will not be the only graduate of the program entering the late-night talk-show competition next fall. David Brenner, next to Miss Rivers the most frequent substitute for Johnny Carson, will also start a new nightly program in September.

title: IN SHADOW OF CHERNOBYL, ANSWERS ARE SOUGHT
description: TAKING on one of technology's greatest challenges, engineers around the world are stepping up efforts to design safer nuclear power generators. And after successful tests last month, some American experts believe they may be close to developing an ''inherently safe'' nuclear reactor.

title: Rainier Bancorp
description: Rainier Bancorp said it had agreed to acquire Mount Hood Security Bank, based in Gresham, Ore., in a tax-free stock exchange valued at $3.7 million, or 1.7 times book value. Rainier is the first Washington bank to announce plans to acquire an Oregon bank under that state's new interstate banking law. The merger is expected to close in the third quarter of 1986, subject to approval by regulators and Mount Hood shareholders.

title: The U.N. Today: May 13, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Preparatory Committee for General Assembly Special Session on Critical African Economic Situation - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. >ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: 2 in a Chinatown Gang Convicted in Shootings
description: Two teen-agers have been convicted by a Manhattan jury in the shootings last year of seven people, including a 4-year-old boy, during a dispute among members of a Chinatown gang.

title: SAFEGUARD HEALTH ENTERPRISE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Atlanta Braves, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. Finale of the Mets' home stand. Bruce Berenyi will make his first start since April 23, 1985.

title: INVESTIGATORS SAY IT APPEARS DEAVER VIOLATED THE LAW
description: The General Accounting Office told Congress today that Michael K. Deaver ''appears'' to have violated conflict-of-interest laws. The agency sent its findings to the Justice Department for use in considering whether the lobbyist should be prosecuted.

title: DENSE-PAC MICROSYSTEMS reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
Advertising; People
description: * Gail Lieberman and Barbara Titus have been appointed executive vice presidents of Scali, McCabe, Sloves.

title: JUDGE BARS U.S. SUITS ON BHOPAL
description: A Federal district judge dismissed thousands of claims yesterday arising from the December 1984 gas leak at the Union Carbide Corporation's pesticide plant in Bhopal, India, ruling that the courts of India, not those of the United States, were the appropriate place for the claims to be heard.

title: MARTIN'S POSTS AT FED FILLED
description: The White House today announced its intention to nominate H. Robert Heller, a West Coast bank economist, to fill a vacancy on the Federal Reserve Board and to designate Manuel H. Johnson as vice chairman.

title: UCCEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $1,485,000 and a tax credit of $1,360,000. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $71,000 and a tax credit of $800,000.

title: Pension Fund Upheld On Ulster Resolution
description: American Brands Inc. must include in a proxy mailing a resolution calling for the company to increase affirmative action efforts in Northern Ireland, a Federal judge in Manhattan ruled yesterday.

title: BIRTCHER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $80,000 for the quarter and $390,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes a gain of $136,914 from discontinued operations, a tax credit of $272,000 and a gain on disposal of discontinued operations of $3,254,090.

title: Philadelphia Refunding Set
description: A $255.4 million issue of Philadelphia general obligation refunding bonds was tentatively offered yesterday with a maximum yield of 8.42 percent, at a price of 99 1/2, for 8 3/8 percent bonds due in 2009. Underwriters led by F. L. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin also offered shorter maturities, with yields ranging from 5 1/4 percent for bonds due in 1987 to 6.75 percent in 1991, 7.70 percent in 1996 and 8.20 percent in 2001.

title: MORTALLY WOUNDED, PHYSICIAN JOTS DOWN CLUE TO HIS ATTACKER
description: Stabbed in the chest and mortally wounded by a stranger as he sunbathed in a park Sunday, a New Jersey doctor stumbled to his car, scribbled down the license number of the attacker's car, drove a mile to the hospital where he worked and crashed outside the emergency room.

title: SWEDES SOLVE A RADIOACTIVE PUZZLE
description: ON a ragged patch of lawn in Stockholm, behind an old brick building that once housed a veterinary hospital, a squat instrument perched on a wooden tripod peers straight down at the ground through its cylindrical metal snout.

title: ORION CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $5,103,000 and an extrarodinary tax credit of $613,000. c-Net loss includes realized investment gains of $1,419,000.

title: WESTERN HEALTH PLANS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The year-ago quarter and 9 months nets are on a pro forma basis reflecting the results of a formerly not-for- profit division.

title: To Avoid Petty Election Challenges
description: New York City's primary election last fall was marred by last-minute confusion over candidates' qualifications to appear on the ballot. It's too late for the State Legislature to prevent all such problems next September, but interim relief remains possible and desirable.

title: FILIPINO MOSLEMS: A NEW PIECE TO FIT IN THE PUZZLE
description: A couple of fierce battles on the tropical island of Sulu recently revived the nightmare of a nearly forgotten war.

title: WHITE HOUSE FIGHTS FOR SAUDI ARMS
description: The Reagan Administration opened a campaign today to overturn the Congressional actions last week that blocked the sale of $354 million worth of missiles to Saudi Arabia.

title: STATE TAXPAYERS FACE NEW HAZARD
description: New Yorkers would face increased state and local taxes if the Federal tax system is revised along the lines of the Senate Finance Committee's proposal unless Albany makes changes of its own.

title: EMPI INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $57,500.

title: GUEST SUPPLY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ELISABETH BERGNER, AN ACTRESS IN PLAYS AND FILMS, DIES AT 85
description: Elisabeth Bergner, a Viennese actress who was an international stage and screen star for 40 years, died at her home in London yesterday after a long illness. She was 85 years old.

title: Market Place; Investing Club Stock Choices
description: MORE pension funds and other institutions own stock in the International Business Machines Corporation than in any other company. But individuals who belong to the nation's 6,200 investment clubs rank Big Blue second to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company as their favorite holding.

title: CBS'S 'SECOND SERVE'
description: ALTHOUGH hardly believable for a moment from a purely physical standpoint, Vanessa Redgrave's performance in ''Second Serve'' is astonishingly convincing. The television movie on CBS at 9 this evening is based on a true story. Miss Redgrave portrays Dr. Renee Richards, who before a sex-change operation was Dr. Richard Raskind (for whatever legal reasons, the name in the movie has been changed to Richard Radley). Once again, Miss Redgrave can be found taking chances that few actors could attempt or endure. And once again, she demonstrates why she is one of the most remarkable actresses in the English-speaking world.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Butler International Inc., Montvale, N.J., which provides aviation and trucking services, elected Frederick R. Einsidler chairman, replacing G. Norman Widmark, who will retire on July 31 but will remain a director. Mr. Einsidler will continue as chief executive and will be replaced as president by Reginald F. Woods, now executive vice president.

title: Officer Accused Of Killing Wife
description: A New York City police officer shot his wife to death in their apartment in Brooklyn early yesterday in a dispute over her having left home over the weekend, the police said.

title: Mr. Shcharansky's Message
description: To meet Anatoly Shcharansky is to understand why Soviet prisons could not crack this crystal spirit, even in ''punishment cells'' four meters square. A principled democrat, skilled at chess and blessed with humor, he is a well-endowed survivor. But as President Reagan will learn first-hand today, what most buoyed this renowned prisoner was the clamor without.

title: PETER MARINO STRIKES AGAIN
description: THE designer in custom-tailored gray plaid, immaculate white shirt and burgundy bow tie has arrived, and he is very excited. ''Oh, it's all so wonderful!'' he exclaimed. ''Don't you love it!''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Amfesco Industries, Plainview, L.I., announced the closing of two of its manufacturing plants as a major step in the company's reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

title: Pagel Seeks Team
description: Mike Pagel, the Indianapolis Colts' No. 1 quarterback last season, will not return to the club, Coach Rod Dowhower said yesterday.

title: CENTRAL HOLDING reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: MISMANAGEMENT AT CHERNOBYL NOTED EARLIER
description: A month before the Chernobyl disaster, a Ukrainian journal reported management failures and labor dissatisfaction at the nuclear power plant.

title: MANY RANGERS PONDER FUTURE
description: It was a day with a bright blue sky. The Ferris wheel at Playland Amusement Park was getting its first test spins. The Rangers players arrived wearing shorts, relaxed and feeling summery, some eating popsicles, as if their special month of hockey and all the tensions that went with it were a thousand years past.

title: Working Profile; The Life of a 'Watergate Baby': Philip R. Sharp
description: A few years ago, when a man working on a water tank in a small Indiana town fell into the tank, a passer-by immediately called the district office of Representative Philip R. Sharp and asked for help.

title: U.S. Calls on Mexico To Halt Drug Trade
description: The State Department called on the Government of Mexico today to ''halt the production and trafficking of drugs in its territory.''

title: MARCH CONSUMER DEBT WAS UP ONLY SLIGHTLY
description: Americans took out $3.71 billion more in consumer debt than they paid off in March, the smallest monthly increase in almost three years, the Government said today.

title: KANEB SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $3,546,000. c-Net income after income from discontinued operations of $3,262,000. The latest first quarter loss from continuing operations included a $38,600,000 writedown of oil and gas properties.

title: JACO ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
LORAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
INTERNATIONAL ALUMINUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of 11 cents a share. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of 5 cents a share.

title: ANDERSON, CLAYTON & CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $18,050,000 for the quarter and $25,980,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $3,756,000 for the quarter and $9,790,000 for the 9 months.

title: Dow Falls 2.10 in a Minor Setback
description: With participants fearing that both interest rates and oil prices were rising, the stock market yesterday suffered a setback, but only a minor one, as investors again decided that doing nothing was better than either buying or selling shares.

title: Seaver Talk Stirs Again
description: The proposed deal that would bring Tom Seaver back to New York, this time as a member of the Yankees, is apparently simmering again. But there could be a snag.

title: Downtown Shunpike
description: In rhetorical traffic, conditions at the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge are nearing gridlock.

title: Louisianans in Program On Country Singing
description: The Whitstein Brothers, northern Louisianians who play guitar and mandolin and sing vintage country songs in close harmony, provided the outstanding act in ''The Roots of Country Music,'' a program presented by the World Music Institute at the Washington Square Church on Saturday evening. The show, with the folklorist Glenn Hinson as host, explored the varieties of traditional country vocalizing that had long since been absorbed into the Nashville melting pot.

title: Mortgage Bonds By Central Power
description: The Central Power and Light Company, a utility based in Corpus Christi, Tex., is offering $200 million of 8 3/4 percent first mortgage bonds due in 1996 at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: The Homeless
description: To coincide with the airing next Monday night on CBS of ''The Mitch Snyder Story,'' a chronicle of Mr. Snyder's battles in behalf of Washington's homeless, Representative Edward J. Markey plans to introduce a resolution today to designate the week of May 19 ''National Homeless Awareness and Action Week.'' The problem of the nation's estimated 3 million homeless is developing as a political issue on which Democrats say the Reagan Administration is insensitive.

title: KANEB ENERGY PARTNERS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a $64,467,000 writedown of oil and gas properties. The latest figures cover the period Feb. 7, when the partnership was formed, through March 31.

title: MONOCLONAL ANTIBODIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: ROYAL JEWELERS IN NEW YORK
description: In the market for a pair of $1.5 million earrings? A ship's model centerpiece for $85,000? A gilt epergne crowned with the feather symbol of the Prince of Wales for $90,000? A matched set of emerald and diamond jewelry for $700,000?

title: Death Cases Straining Justices
description: Justice Harry A. Blackmun of the United States Supreme Court said today that the ''excruciating agony'' of last-minute death penalty decisions had ''haunted and debilitated the Court'' during its most recent session.

title: 17 of 30 Foreigners Released by Qatar
description: Qatar has freed 17 of the 30 foreign workers it seized last month in a territorial dispute with Bahrain and has said it intends to release the remaining prisoners soon, the Dutch Foreign Ministry said today.

title: CHERNOBYL EVIDENCE SUGGESTS ENORMOUS FIRE, EXPERTS SAY
description: Fallout readings and other analysis suggest that fire from the Chernobyl reactor probably shot more than a thousand feet into the air for two days, carrying radiation from an exposed nuclear fuel core, three scientists studying the accident said yesterday.

title: Pro Basketball; PLAN TO CERTIFY AGENTS AND LIMIT FEES
description: Agents who handle contract negotiations for the 91 players who will become free agents after the playoffs as well as those for the new rookie crop will be subject to new, stringent regulations.

title: Advertising; Bates Chief Sees 'Clout' In Linkup
description: NO sooner did Robert E. Jacoby, chairman and chief executive of Ted Bates Worldwide, announce yesterday what everyone already knew - that Bates was to be acquired by Britain's Saatchi & Saatchi for $450 million - than the questions showered in from the press.

title: Chicago Aldermen Sue To Block Act by Mayor
description: Members of the City Council's opposition bloc filed suit today seeking to block 25 appointments by Mayor Harold Washington that were approved in the first meeting since he gained control of the council.

title: AMERICAN TECHNICAL CERAMCS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Phenom, at 59
description: Back in his hometown one day last year after the World Series, Vince Coleman of the St. Louis Cardinals walked up to Eugene White of the Jacksonville (Fla.) Majors and gave him $1,000 to buy the Majors new uniforms. White could do little but be grateful and wonder, ''What if?''

title: ASPIRING MOGULS TAKE M.B.A.'S TO HOLLYWOOD
description: The roads to fame, riches, power and applause in Hollywood are varied -avenues as different as the casting couch, nepotism, the mail room at the William Morris talent agency or the University of Southern California film school.

title: AD AGENCY MERGERS CHANGING THE BUSINESS
description: Madison Avenue, the symbolic if not actual home of the advertising world, is going through its most dramatic change since the business began a century ago.

title: Grace Restaurant Chief Heads Buyout Group
description: If things go according to plan, Anwar Soliman, after 22 years with W.R. Grace & Company, will soon find himself operating a company on the outside.

title: SIMON SAYS HE IS WILLING TO TALK BEFORE GRAND JURY
description: Borough President Stanley Simon of the Bronx said yesterday that he had been asked to testify before a grand jury investigating leading Bronx Democrats.

title: DESPITE OIL PRICE FALL, ALASKANS STILL GET FREE RIDE
description: Although falling oil prices have cut this state's income by more than half in two years, Alaskans' free ride with their state government is not yet at an end.

title: Carew's Hopes Fade
description: Rod Carew has given up hope of playing major league baseball again. ''I don't have any hopes of anyone signing me,'' the seven-time American League batting champion said yesterday from his home in Anaheim Hills, Calif.

title: Ad Agency Mergers Changing the Business
description: Madison Avenue, the symbolic if not actual home of the advertising world, is going through its most dramatic change since the business began a century ago.

title: AFTER JOYOUS GREETING AT YESHIVA U., SHCHARANSKY IS REUNITED WITH BONNER
description: For the first time since the March morning nine years ago when he was arrested, Anatoly B. Shcharansky was reunited in Manhattan yesterday with Yelena G. Bonner, his compatriot in the Soviet human-rights movement.

title: Arms and the Vendors
description: Paul H. Nitze, the arms negotiator, told a closed session of business executives in Hot Springs, Va., a few days ago that negotiating with the Russians was a little like dealing with a broken vending machine. You put a quarter in and nothing comes out. You can curse, kick and shake it, but one thing is sure, he said, ''You know ahead of time that just talking to it won't do any good.''

title: A Very Disguised Blessing
description: Someone asked an aide to Adlai E. Stevenson 3d if the results of the Illinois Democratic primary on March 18, when two followers of Lyndon LaRouche upset two of Mr. Stevenson's ticket-mates, was ''a blessing in disguise.''

title: TRAINER ADDS DERBY TO HIS ALREADY IMPRESSIVE RESUME
description: Charlie Whittingham is the John Houseman of horse racing, an overnight superstar at the age of 73.

title: UNIX and MS-DOS: Dueling For Dominance in Computers
description: ALL but the simplest computers need an operating system. The operating system has two main jobs: as a translator, for information passing between human and machine, and as a conductor, making sure all of the different parts of the computer play together in harmony.

title: MASSEY-FERGUSON LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes reorganization charges of $17.6 million, a loss of $20 million from discontinued operations and a loss of $7.9 million on foreign exchange adjustments. c-Net loss includes a loss of $10 million from operations of the company's Combines business, which has now been separated. d-Includes reorganization charges of $8.3 million, a loss of $31 million from operations discontinued in 1985 and a gain of $5.9 million on foreign exchange adjustments. The company did not report share earnings for the latest quarter, and after preferred share dividend requirements, there were no earnings applicable to common shares in either year. Results for the year-ago period have been restated to reflect the former Combines and Foundries divisions as discontinued operations.

title: THAI FORCES ACCUSED OF TORTURING 3 CAMBODIANS
description: At least three Cambodian refugees under the care of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees have been tortured by Thai soldiers responsible for security at the camp where they were housed, according to Amnesty International and international aid organizations.

title: Minstar to Sell Bowling Unit
description: Minstar Inc., controlled by the Minneapolis investor Irwin L. Jacobs, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its AMF bowling operations to Clayton & Dubilier Inc., a private investment concern, for about $225 million. Minstar also said it would keep a stake in C.&B.

title: Italy Planning Inquiry Into Links With Libya
description: The Italian Defense Minister said today that he had asked for an inquiry into statements by a former Italian intelligence official that Italy, to protect its oil interests in Libya, had helped Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi consolidate his power.

title: IRISH DIPLOMACY IN A BOOK ON ISRAEL
description: Alphabetically, Ireland sits between Iraq and Israel in the United Nations General Assembly. Representing Ireland there between 1956 and 1960, Conor Cruise O'Brien found that he was especially welcomed by both his seat mates. ''Because my place relieved them of sitting next to each other,'' he explained. ''They didn't speak - no communication whatsoever. And contrary to legend, they did not use me as a conduit to pass notes.''

title: BOLAR PHARMACEUTICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Chess: Players of Divergent Styles Share the Top Prize in Italy
description: Two players of diverse styles shared first place in the Banco di Roma International Tournament in Italy.

title: GARDENAMERICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After income of $52,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net loss after a loss from discontinued operations of $1,470,000.

title: RUMANIAN U.N. AIDE SOUGHT
description: United Nations officials said today that they had renewed their demands to the Rumanian Government for information on a Rumanian official employed by the world organization who has been forbidden to return here after being called to Bucharest last December for ''urgent consultations.''

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CINCINNATI (NL) - Recalled Tom Runnells, infielder, from Denver of the American Association.

title: YANKEES HOLD OFF TWINS
description: By the time Dennis Rasmussen walked out to the pitcher's mound in the bottom of the ninth inning tonight, it was already a 9-2 game. The Yankee offense had finally come to life, and now Rasmussen was on the verge of clearing an important hurdle. He was about to throw his first complete game this season.

title: PROFESSIONAL INVESTMENT INSURANCE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Former U.S. Representative Is Released From a Prison
description: Former Representative John Jenrette, who served 13 months of a two-year sentence for conspiracy and accepting a $50,000 bribe, was released today from a Federal prison to a halfway house.

title: SUSPECT, 19, PLEADS NOT GUILTY IN PRIEST'S KILLING IN BROOKLYN
description: A 19-year-old Brooklyn man was ordered held without bail yesterday after pleading not guilty to charges of killing a Roman Catholic priest during a robbery in downtown Brooklyn early Saturday.

title: NUMBER OF OIL RIGS JUST KEEPS FALLING
description: The search for oil in this country reached its lowest point since World War II last week, and industry experts said they saw no end in sight.

title: HORN & HARDART CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, MAY 13, 1986
description: Markets

title: CODENOLL TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BUSINESS MEN'S ASSURANCE CO OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes investment gains of $5,694,000 for the latest quarter and $1,098,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: China-Canada Tax Pact
description: China and Canada signed an agreement today on the avoidance of double taxation and the prevention of fiscal evasion, the New China News Agency said. The pact was signed by both Prime Ministers, Zhao Ziyang and Brian Mulroney. The two countries also signed a memorandum of understanding on plant quarantine cooperation and initialed one on scientific and technological cooperation.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Science Watch column last Tuesday about an experimental treatment for baldness included incorrect conclusions about the possibility of health risks in topical application of the hypertension drug minoxidil. Studies have not established a direct link between the use of the drug and deaths among test subjects.

title: BOGERT OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago share earnings reflect a 1-for-10 reverse stock split paid April 2.

title: Cuts at Kodak Unit
description: Kodak Ltd., the British subsidiary of the Eastman Kodak Company, the American photography giant, said that it would cut 900 jobs this year in a cost-cutting move it says was forced by Japanese competition. Kodak, whose products include film, photographic paper and chemicals, said the job cuts would be made at its three factories at Harrow in north London, Kirkby outside Liverpool, and Annesley in central England, and at its Hemel Hempstead headquarters and distribution center north of London. The company said it would attempt to lay off most workers on a voluntary basis.

title: Teen-Ager Held in Shooting
description: A Brooklyn teen-ager was fatally shot in an apartment in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section after a handgun that he and a companion were examining accidentally discharged, the police said. Andre Rivera, 13 years old, of 255 Throop Avenue later died at Woodhull Hospital. The companion, Ivan Colberg, 16, was charged with manslaughter yesterday, the police said.

title: IMEX MEDICAL SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Miss Saiter Weds Sonny Kleinfield
description: Susan M. Saiter, a freelance writer, and Nathan R. Kleinfield, a reporter for The New York Times, were married yesterday at the Municipal Building in New York by Elvira R. Burrows, an official of the City Clerk's office.

title: 7 AMERICANS HONORED WITH MEDAL OF FREEDOM
description: President Reagan, presenting the nation's highest civilian award to the medical pioneer Albert B. Sabin and six other Americans, hailed them today as rebels who defied conventional wisdom and won greatness.

title: RELAXATION: SURPRISING BENEFITS DETECTED
description: THE simple act of becoming relaxed can have surprising health benefits, new research is showing. In addition to the obvious psychological effects of relieving stress and mental tension, the new findings indicate, deep relaxation, if practiced regularly, can strengthen the immune system and produce a host of other medically valuable physiological changes.

title: 'LIE OF THE MIND' NAMED BEST NEW PLAY
description: Sam Shepard's ''Lie of the Mind'' was named the best new play of the 1985-1986 season by the New York Drama Critics Circle at a meeting held yesterday at the Algonquin Hotel. ''Benefactors'' by Michael Frayn was selected as the best new foreign play, and Lily Tomlin and Jane Wagner were voted a special citation for their show, ''The Search for Signs of Intelligent Life in the Universe.''

title: Double Suicide at Campus
description: A doctoral student despondent over the rejection of his thesis at the University of Notre Dame was found dead along with his wife over the weekend in what the authorities said was a double cyanide suicide. The bodies of Solomon Aptekar, 29 years old, and his wife, Irene, were discovered Sunday at their student-housing apartment, a campus spokesman said. The couple, originally from Bombay, India, killed themselves by drinking cyanide, the St. Joseph County Coroner, James McMeel, said.

title: Advertising; Tatham Gets Wonder Bread
description: Almost as if to keep them humble, the members of the management team of Ted Bates Worldwide, preparing for a $450 million cash inflow from the acquisitive Saatchi & Saatchi company, have gotten a little rain on their parade from the Continental Baking Company.

title: SPY'S FORMER WIFE TELLS OF WARNING
description: The former wife of John A. Walker Jr., the man who pleaded guilty last year to leading a spy ring for the Soviet Union, said today that she told Jerry A. Whitworth in 1973 that she knew her husband was recruiting him as a spy.

title: STATE FACING NEW HURDLES ON PLAN TO REBUILD HUTCHINSON PARKWAY
description: In June 1984, state officials began a major reconstruction of seven miles of the 14.5-mile Hutchinson River Parkway, believing they had finally seen the end of a bitter public dispute over the project.

title: FALLOUT FOUND IN U.S. IS SAID TO POSE NO RISK
description: Radioactive fallout from the nuclear accident two weeks ago in the Soviet Union was being measured throughout the United States yesterday. However, officials from the Environmental Protection Agency said that increased radiation levels were hardly perceptible and that they posed no danger to the public.

title: MIXED TAX EFFECT ON FARMING
description: Farm economists across the country predicted today that many of the nation's 600,000 commercial family farmers, particularly those producing milk, hogs and crops grown in orchards, might benefit from the tax-revision bill approved last week by the Senate Finance Committee.

title: DISPLAY COMPONENTS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Lampedusa Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: Wilander Gains At Italian Open
description: Mats Wilander of Sweden swept past Jimmy Brown of Tennessee, 6-2, 6-2, today in the opening round of the Italian Open on the clay court of Foro Italico.

title: INTERNATIONAL THOROUGHRED BREEDERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and after income from discontinued operations of $12,415,308, or 20 cents a share, for the quarter and $12,311,470, or 20 cents a share, for the 9 months.

title: AN INSIDER SCHEME IS PUT IN MILLIONS
description: A Wall Street merger specialist was charged today with using confidential information illegally in a trading scheme that reaped at least $12.6 million in profits while he was employed at three major investment banking firms.

title: FANS' LETTERS SHOW WILSON HE IS NEEDED
description: Dear Mokkie Willson, I really feel sorry for your eye. I was really looking forward to you making those diving catches. . . The letters arrived at Shea Stadium, some almost as if by magic. Just as a hero of another season has inspired mail to ''North Pole,'' some of the letters were addressed to ''New York Mets, Shea Stadium.'' The addressee reached into his locker and pulled out a pile. Many of the letters did not include a zip code. Some had addresses that were provided by more adult-looking handwriting. None was addressed to William Hayward Wilson.

title: EVEREST & JENNINGS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $8,485,000 from the sale of real estate. c-Net loss

title: WITNESS IN SLAVERY TRIAL DESCRIBES THREATS TO LIFE
description: A witness in the trial of four people accused of enslaving drifters on a ranch and torturing one to death testified today that he had been threatened, chained and tortured after he tried to leave.

title: METS WIN IN 9TH ON TEUFEL'S HIT
description: With a .211 batting average, Tim Teufel was the weakest hitter in the Mets' starting lineup last night. Even Sid Fernandez, the pitcher, had a better average (.250).

title: PROCEEDINGS SLOW AS FOOTBALL TRIAL IS UNDER WAY
description: With three years of competition and many months of preparation behind them, the United States Football League and the National Football League began their antitrust trial in a crowded courtroom in lower Manhattan yesterday with the slow process of jury selection.

title: ABS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $303,000.

title: Solo Hiker Arrives At the North Pole
description: A French doctor has completed a solitary 63-day, 500-mile walk to the North Pole.

title: New Biology Center for Yale
description: Yale University and the Howard Hughes Medical Institute plan to build a $28 million center for structural biology on the Yale campus, the school has announced. Hughes, a nonprofit medical research organization based in Bethesda, Md., is to contribute almost $14 million to the center during the next five years. Using Federal grants, Yale is expected to raise the rest, school officials said.

title: ROLE OF SCHOOL BOARDS IS QUESTIONED
description: ERNEST L. BOYER recalled his visit to a sixth-grade class in a New Haven public school. The children were sitting in a tight circle around the teacher, deep in discussion of ''Oliver Twist.''

title: FAIRFIELD COMMUNITIES LAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
OVERSEAS SHIPHOLDING GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Reflects a gain of $2,604,000, or 10 cents a share, from the disposal of vessels, including the value of related unexpired charters.

title: KENCOPE ENERGY COS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest quarter and 9 months losses are after a writedown of $3,450,000 of oil and gas properties due to falling energy prices.

title: Professional Proclaimer
description: Yesterday was a busy day for mayoral proclaiming.

title: 'ORPHAN ANIMALS' ON 2
description: THE difference between Daphne Sheldrick's home movies and those you might have enjoyed or endured at a neighbor's is that her home for 28 years was Tsavo National Park in Kenya, where her husband was game warden. There Mrs. Sheldrick undertook the raising of baby animals who had been separated from their elders - and that is the subject of ''The Orphan Animals of Tsavo,'' which can be seen on Channel 2 tonight at 8 o'clock.

title: OLIVER'S STORES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Apple Founder To Get Degree
description: Steve Wozniak, who built the first Apple computer in his garage and became a multimillionaire as Apple Computer Inc. grew into one of the world's leading high-technology companies, will finally receive a college degree this Saturday.

title: FRANCE REPORTS A CAPTIVE ARAB ADMITS ATTACKS
description: A 25-year-old Tunisian has confessed that he carried out three terrorist acts, including the bombings of Marks & Spencer department stores in Paris and London, the Interior Ministry said today.

title: Careers; Learning To Handle A Crisis
description: BY last week 108 Master of Business Administration students had taken a course in crisis management at Carnegie-Mellon University. Begun about a year and a half ago, it probably was the first formal course in the subject at a leading graduate business school.

title: 'Suspect' and 'Le Carre' Among Edgar Winners
description: ''The Suspect'' by L. R. Wright (Viking Penguin) has been named the best novel of 1985 by the Mystery Writers of America.

title: MERCURY GENERAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $65,000. c-Includes realized investment losses of $64,000.

title: EASTERN OFFERS TO PAY $3.5 MILLION ON F.A.A. FINE
description: Eastern Airlines said today that it had offered to pay the Federal Aviation Administration a record $3.5 million fine for alleged violations of safety rules but that the agency was sticking to its demand for $9.5 million.

title: THEATER: ONE-ACT MARATHON
description: THE Ensemble Studio Theater's annual one-act Marathon is one of the season's happiest theatrical events, but it is for the truly adventurous, not the fainthearted. If exciting new plays and playwrights are common in this festival, there's also the possibility that a lackluster Marathon bill will turn up, making extraordinary demands on an audience's sticktoitiveness. Series A, the first of the three four-play evenings to run in repertory in ''Marathon '86,'' is definitely for the most patient theatrical adventurers. One must slog through two and a half hours of fairly barren writing to unearth the program's single gem.

title: TIDWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company has operated under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code since Aug. 21, 1985.

title: DEATH OF DINOSAURS ASSERTED TO BE GRADUAL
description: IN a new analysis of fossils found in Montana, a group of paleontologists has concluded that the dinosaurs died out gradually, not suddenly, and that the last of these great reptiles apparently became extinct 40,000 years after the postulated meteorite impact 65 million years ago.

title: U.S. Home Shifts Top-Level Officers
description: The U.S. Home Corporation said yesterday that Robert J. Strudler, president and chief operating officer, had been elected chairman and chief executive.

title: Dr. Leland W. F. Stark Dies; A Retired Episcopal Bishop
description: The Rev. Dr. Leland William Frederick Stark, former Episcopal Bishop of Newark, died Thursday at Mountainside Hospital in Montclair, N.J., after suffering a heart attack. He was 78 years old and lived in Verona, N.J.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE CONDUCT OF THE GAME. By John Hough Jr. 340 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $14.95. ROAD GAME: A Summer's Tale. By

title: BANNER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MEMORIAL FOR RABBI GOLDSTEIN
description: Rabbi Israel Goldstein, who headed virtually every major American Jewish organization in a 40-year career, was memorialized last night as one of the great Jewish leaders of the century and praised for his energetic support of the state of Israel. The words of praise came in a service at the Manhattan synagogue he headed for many years.

title: Enron to Shift To Houston
description: The Enron Corporation, the giant natural gas pipeline company formerly called HNG/Internorth Inc., said yesterday that it would move its corporate headquarters to Houston from Omaha, effective July 1. The move dramatizes the shift in control of the company, which was formed when the larger Internorth Inc., long based in Omaha, acquired the Houston Natural Gas Company a year ago for $2.3 billion.

title: Up and Cheering
description: He may have had his tailfeathers ruffled, but Dan Senft, the Baltimore Orioles' Bird, says he will be back at his cheerleading post tonight. Senft was injured when he fell off the roof of the Orioles' dugout in the ninth inning of Saturday's game against the Kansas City Royals.

title: MADISON GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AT LONG LAST, CABLE COMES TO BROOKLYN
description: Peter Orlando of Brooklyn likes to watch television by himself. But these days he has lots of company.

title: Europeans Discuss Private Funding of Arts
description: Panelists at an international conference on state and private support for cultural activities indicated today that Europe may be moving closer to the American tradition of private funding of the arts.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, MAY 13, 1986
description: International Six people have died from ''radiation and burns'' suffered after the explosion and fire at the Chernobyl nuclear reactor, the Soviet Government announced. It is the first time anyone is known to have died from radiation emitted from a civilian nuclear power plant. [ Page A1, Columns 1-2. ]

title: FLETCHER IS SWORN IN AS HEAD OF SPACE AGENCY
description: James C. Fletcher was sworn in as Administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration today at a time that President Reagan described as ''stormy'' for the nation's space program.

title: G.M. Examining Mortgage Plan
description: The General Motors Corporation intends to examine its eight million auto-loan customers, looking for likely home-loan candidates in Michigan.

title: Raising the Tax on Alcohol Doesn't Solve the Drinking Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: Put a Supreme Lesson in the Law on TV
description: To the Editor:

title: 'JOE PISCOPO SPECIAL'
description: THE state of New Jersey may be synonymous in some minds with acrid industrial fragrances, but as the amiable comedian-impressionist Joe Piscopo reminds us, it has also produced Bruce Springsteen and Frank Sinatra - as well as Mr. Piscopo. In the cleverest bit on ''The Joe Piscopo New Jersey Special,'' which airs tonight on ABC at 10, television technology enables Mr. Piscopo, who hails from Passaic, to do impressions of both singers simultaneously, exchanging verses in a medley of ''Born to Run'' and ''Born in the U.S.A.'' The juxtaposition, in which the Chairman of the Board gruffly mispronounces the Boss's last name, turning ''steen'' into ''stine,'' is eerie and touching in the way it recalls the actual television confrontation nearly three decades ago between an edgy Frank Sinatra and an excessively humble Elvis Presley.

title: Spanish Network Settles Dispute
description: The Spanish International Communications Corporation said it had agreed to sell its 10 Spanish-language television stations to settle a bitter legal dispute between its management and a group of shareholders. The agreement, reached Friday under the supervision of Federal District Court in Los Angeles, ends a lawsuit in which shareholders charged that corporation officials had engaged in business transactions with the SIN Television Network that were detrimental to the corporation.

title: AMERICAN CONTROLLED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SOUTHWEST GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HENRY P. McILHENNY, HEAD OF PHILADELPHIA ART MUSEUM
description: Henry P. McIlhenny, collector, connoisseur and successively curator, trustee and chairman of the board at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, died Sunday at Hahnemann University Hospital in Philadelphia after undergoing heart surgery. He was 75 years old and lived in Philadelphia.

title: Oil Ends Slightly Down After Rising Above $16
description: The futures price of the major American crude oil broke through the $16-a-barrel barrier for the first time in nearly three months yesterday, but later fell back to the $15-a-barrel range, posting a slight loss for the day.

title: COMFED SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $597,000 for the quarter and year. c-Includes an extraordinary credit of $467,000.

title: DAHLBERG INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 5
Dainippon Raises Sun Chemical Bid
description: In an unusually aggressive move by a Japanese company, Dainippon Ink and Chemicals Inc. said yesterday that it would raise its buyout bid for the Sun Chemical Company to $85 a share, or a total of $663 million, if the American concern dropped its opposition and entered into serious negotiations.

title: BONDS FALL IN VOLATILE TRADING
description: In a day of volatile and treacherous trading, prices of Treasury notes and bonds fell by a point or more yesterday as securities dealers continued to distribute the new issues auctioned last week.

title: LIBYA EXPELS 36 AT EMBASSIES OF 7 WEST EUROPEAN NATIONS
description: Libya today ordered 36 staff members of seven Western European embassies expelled in what it called a retaliation for ''oppressive'' Western measures.

title: Eye Doctor Backs Leonard Return
description: Whatever the physical hazards that Sugar Ray Leonard would face in a comeback championship fight after four years of almost total absence from the ring, they have nothing at all to do with the severe eye injury he suffered in 1982. That's the judgment of Dr. Ronald Michels, his personal ophthalmologist, whose surgery repaired the partly detached retina that forced Leonard to give up his crown and who has now given him a clean bill in his quest for a match against Marvelous Marvin Hagler.

title: South Korean Coal Plan
description: South Korea plans to import anthracite coal from Canada and Peru this year on a trial basis, officials at the Energy and Resources Ministry said today. The plans were intended to secure a stable supply by diversifying import sources, they added.

title: GIANT GROUP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NEVADA POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Hong Kong Bank Fraud
description: A Hong Kong financier accused of conspiracy to defraud a bank of more than $66 million was remanded in custody after a brief court appearance today. Simon Yip, who returned last week from San Francisco in the custody of Hong Kong officials, was expected to enter a plea next week to 46 criminal charges linked to the near collapse of the Overseas Trust Bank last year, his lawyer said. Mr. Yip headed the now defunct Dominican Finance Ltd. and was honorary consul of the Dominican Republic. The bank was declared insolvent last June and taken over by the Hong Kong Government at a cost of $255 million.

title: 18 Journalists Receive Fellowships at Stanford
description: The John S. Knight Fellowships for the 1986-87 academic year at Stanford University have been awarded to 12 American journalists. An additional six journalists from other countries are to join them as international fellows.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TEN WILLIAMS PLAYS The 14-year-old Acting Company is a touring group whose base is the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington. The Acting Company's travels have taken it to 43 states and it has presented 57 plays to 1.6 million people. The company is in New York these days with its current presentation, a collection of 10 one-act plays by Tennessee Williams - ''Ten by Tennessee.'' In these short dramas some of the themes, characters and language of Williams's later works may be detected.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The world has been opened a little wider for me. The amount of channels is immense.

title: North Carolina Makes Progress Against Fires
description: Firefighters today inched closer to containing a 14-mile-long blaze that has consumed 75,000 acres in its weeklong path through southeastern North Carolina.

title: COLLEGES ASK, WHAT MAKES SCIENCE HARD?
description: What makes science hard? In turn, why do so many highly intelligent college students avoid science and mathematics courses? Are the sciences inherently more difficult than the humanities?

title: Millions Vote, 7 Hurt In Nepalese Elections
description: Millions of Nepalese, ignoring bomb threats by terrorists opposed to the monarchy, cast ballots today for a new Parliament.

title: Spendthrift Farms
description: One of the two major shareholders in Spendthrift Farms Inc. said that he was selling his interest in the troubled thoroughbred farm, while the other major owner said he was not.

title: ENTWISTLE CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Leadership Is Stressed At Pace's Graduation
description: Cornell University's president, Dr. Frank H. T. Rhodes, cautioned Pace University graduates yesterday that ''your professional training, your scholarly skills, will wither from disuse unless you harness them to the task of leadership.''

title: RISING COTTAGE INDUSTRY STIRRING CONCERN IN U.S.
description: As the number of Americans who work at home rises, local governments across the nation are struggling to preserve residential neighborhoods without impeding what some experts call the revival of cottage industry.

title: WILLIAM McM. ADAMS
description: William McMillan Adams, a retired executive of an electric company and a descendant of the American revolutionary Samuel Adams, died Saturday at Princeton (N.J.) Hospital. He was 90 years old and lived in Princeton and Canaan, N.Y.

title: A Good Fence Makes a Bad Capitol
description: Congress often deserves criticism for the way it conducts business. Its members are militantly individualistic, too much power resides in too many hands and its approach to legislation often is either to drag its feet or act precipitously. But for all of these shortcomings, Congress is remarkably accessible to the people it represents. You can still go to Washington, visit your member of Congress and Senator and watch them at work in committee and on the floor. That matchless access is now threatened by a proposal by some leaders of Congress to surround the Capitol with a wrought-iron fence.

title: Lumber Suit Is Delayed
description: Officials of the American lumber industry said today that they had agreed to postpone for a week filing an unfair-trade complaint against imports of Canadian lumber.

title: PAR PHARMACEUTICAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes losses of $223,000 and $439,000 for quarter and 6 months, respectively, which represent losses of the company's injectable drug manufacturing subsidiary acquired in February 1985.

title: What Fish Listen To
description: It has long been known that fish have ears that in some respects are more complex than those of mammals. The mystery has been what fish listen to.

title: David W. Hearst, 70, Publishing Executive
description: David Whitmire Hearst, a son of William Randolph Hearst and a vice president of the Hearst Corporation, died today. He was 70 years old.

title: RALLYING TO HELP PAY FOR A TRANSPLANT
description: Chatham looks like a town where nothing could ever go wrong, especially this time of year, with the lawns such a crisp green and the azaleas in bloom. It has a main street called Main Street, and the community is small enough that all the children can walk to school.

title: 31 Salvadorans Die in Crash
description: An open truck carrying passengers en route here crashed into a bus about 30 miles west of here Sunday night, killing 31 people and injuring 9, the national police said today.

title: THE U.S.F.L.: BORN TO LITIGATE
description: With the life force of a salmon swimming upstream to spawn, with the unerring instinct of a thoroughbred the first time its hooves feel the track, the United States Football League achieved its ultimate destiny yesterday. It went to court. There were no pompon girls, no camera crews, no crunch of pads against pads, no grunting of linemen kicking and gouging in the trenches. But the U.S.F.L. reached its personal Super Bowl by having, as the saying goes, its day in court.

title: BINGHAMS TO OPEN BIDS FOR LOUISVILLE PAPERS
description: The Bingham family of Louisville, Ky., plans to review final offers this week for its newspapers, The Courier-Journal and The Louisville Times, which were put up for sale in January. The deadline for bids was yesterday.

title: SOCIALIST OPENS VERMONT DRIVE TO BE GOVERNOR
description: Bernard Sanders, the Socialist Mayor of Burlington, formally announced his candidacy for governor today in a move that will complicate the re-election campaign of Madeleine Kunin, a liberal Democrat.

title: Turbulent Days for Donald D. Engen
description: Two years after taking command of the Federal Aviation Administration, Donald D. Engen is being increasingly perceived in Congress and the aviation industry as an administrator with little control over his agency.

Evans and Novak Deny Pillsbury Was Source
description: To the Editor:

title: REDS HALT EXPOS
description: Eddie Milner hit a home run with two outs in the ninth inning tonight to give the Cincinnati Reds a 4-3 victory over Montreal and snap the Expos' eight-game winning streak.

Park Chemical
description: The Whittaker Corporation, a diversified health care and technical products company in Los Angeles, moved to expand its specialty chemicals division by agreeing to acquire the Park Chemical Company for $34 a share, or a total of $23.7 million.

description: Coast-to-Coast Stores Central Organization Inc., a chain of more than 1,000 franchised hardware stores, said it had been purchased by a group of institutional and individual investors.

AIR FORCE SPEEDS PLAN FOR ROCKETS
description: The Air Force intends to buy dozens of additional rockets to help clear its satellite-launching backlog, a top military official said today.

title: PROSECUTOR IN BONANNO TRIAL DESCRIBES UNION SLUSH FUND
description: A Federal prosecutor yesterday sketched a pattern of racketeering in the local moving and storage industry that she said had forced many companies to give payoffs to a teamsters' local to assure labor peace and had made it possible for some companies to rig bids on contracts.

title: Burying the Truth at Morton Thiokol
description: The maker of the space shuttle's flawed booster rockets, Morton Thiokol, has a crippling management problem: its management.

title: UPSTATE RESIDENTS' WATER WORRIES HELP MOVE G.E. TO ACCORD
description: Four years ago, when Donna Connelly founded a group called Citizens for Safe Water, many townspeople greeted the move with threats and hostility.

title: MILTON A. SCHIFF
description: Milton A. Schiff, founder and president of the Universal Holding Corporation and former chairman of its principal subsidiary, the John Adams Life Insurance Company of New York, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Lake Success, L.I. He was 74 years old.

title: Picture Week
description: Time Inc. said that it would resume market testing of Picture Week magazine in mid-July in 12 markets.

title: A LINKING OF TAX BILL TO BUDGET
description: Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican majority leader, said today that the tax-revision legislation approved by the Finance Committee last week would raise revenue that could be used in the next fiscal year to meet the requirements of the new balanced-budget law.

description: Japan is still Saudi Arabia's top trading partner, with the United States closing the gap, according to 1985 import statistics issued today by the Saudi Ministry of Finance.

title: 76ers' Picture
description: General Manager Pat Williams of the Philadelphia 76ers, who already have four players under age 24 and now hold two first-round draft picks, on the dominance of youth in next season's squad: ''They'll sign their autographs with crayons.''

description: b-Includes a gain of $131,800 from non-operating income. The share earnings reflect 10 percent stock dividend paid in March.

description: The Soviet Government said today that six people had died from ''radiation and burns'' suffered in the wake of the explosion and fire at the Chernobyl nuclear reactor.

title: LAWMAKERS PRESS STATE DEPT. FUND CUTS
description: Congressional leaders from both parties brushed aside criticism from the Reagan Administration today and said they would push ahead with deep cuts in budget requests for both foreign aid and embassy security programs.

title: Jersey Site Chosen
description: The long-distance running committee of the United States Olympic Committee recommended yesterday that the 1988 Olympic men's marathon trials be held at the New Jersey Waterfront Marathon site at Jersey City. Phil Stewart, a member of the committee, said that the marathon site was also awarded the 1988 and 1989 United States men's marathon championships. Negotiations on details must now be held among the New Jersey Waterfront Marathon officials, the state of New Jersey and the Athletic Congress USA, governing body of long-distance running in the United States, Stewart said.

title: Tourism
description: John F. Kennedy once joked that Washington combined all the charm of the North with the efficiency of the South. The quip doesn't apply that well anymore, what with all the vaunted Sun Belt industrial efficiency, but it is perhaps no surprise that the region giving the biggest Washington party as a prelude to National Tourism Week, May 18-24, is the Southeast.

title: Bad News from Afghanistan
description: There are two ways to read the news from Afghanistan. One way is to understand the ''resignation'' of the Soviet puppet, Babrak Karmal, as an indication that the Russians are preparing to distance themselves from the internal affairs of Afghanistan in preparation for a political settlement and a withdrawal of troops. The second interpretation, which is far less promising for Western interests, suggests that the Russians are poised on the brink of a major effort to eliminate, once and for all, the resistance of the Islamic guerrillas. Afghanistan could then be integrated into the Soviet empire and Moscow could turn its attention to new targets of opportunity. At the moment, at least, this more dire interpretation seems by far the more likely.

title: FITCHBURG GAS & ELECTRIC LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

description: Most pair championships end with at least one partnership hopeful of victory. But at the prestigious Cavendish Club Invitational event Sunday night in Manhattan, all the leaders were gloomily predicting defeat.

description: b-Includes $1,290,000 loan loss provisions, compared to $365,000 in the year-ago quarter.

title: Progress for 4-Year-Olds, and the Nation
description: Mayor Koch has taken a small leap in a wholly admirable direction, which if pursued can brighten New York City's economic and social prospects -and set an example for every city. His austere 1987 budget wisely includes $8 million to start educating 4-year-olds, 3,000 of them. This is one of the most important new initiatives to emerge from City Hall; it would deserve even more enthusiastic support if there were a larger program to support.

title: THE BIG DEBATE OVER LITIGATION
description: IS this country in the midst of a litigation explosion or isn't it? The answer depends on whose statistics you look at.

title: Gandhi Names Sikh To Top Security Post
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, in an unexpected step during a Cabinet shuffle, today promoted a Sikh ostracized by much of the Sikh population to India's top security post.

title: BASIX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $800,000.

title: THE 'UPPITY PUPS' AT SAATCHI'S HELM
description: For the Saatchi & Saatchi Company, the formula was evident from the beginning. Shortly after the advertising agency was founded 16 years ago, by two brothers in their 20's with a grubstake of less than $40,000, Charles Saatchi sent takeover proposals to some large, established London agencies.

title: EMERSON RADIO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,213,000, or 7 cents a share, for the quarter and year from the sale of Imatron Inc. stock.

title: Apartment-Peddling
description: Stroll along Broadway on a weekend afternoon. Peddlers are everywhere. Look at the variety of items they sell from their curbside stands - books and cassettes and sunglasses and socks and counterfeit Rolex watches and, now, condominium and cooperative apartments.

title: CARE ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WELBILT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: Share earnings for 1985 were adjusted to reflect the 2-for-1 split, effective Aug. 5, 1985.

title: An Agenda for More Military Reform
description: Five years ago, military reform was the province of a small band of iconoclasts in the Senate. Now the need for broad changes in the way we train, equip and deploy our conventional forces has become conventional wisdom. Congress and the American people must not, however, let satisfaction with early gains take the steam out of the reform movement before it achieves its fundamental goal - military forces that can win in combat.

title: Friedman Seeks Delay in Court
description: Lawyers for Stanley M. Friedman asked a state appeals judge yesterday to stay all state court proceedings against Mr. Friedman and his co-defendants pending a formal challenge to the appointment of a special term judge to hear the case.

title: Louisiana Land Buying Inexco Oil
description: The Louisiana Land and Exploration Company said it had agreed to acquire the Inexco Oil Company in a stock transaction valued at about $120 million. The agreement calls for the issuance of 0.18 of a share of Louisiana Land stock for each share of Inexco, with an option for partial cash payments for up to 5 percent of the cost of the transaction.

title: Meat and Cancer
description: The relationships between overcooked meat and cancer have been a subject of medical debate for years. The issue is still unresolved, but California scientists have found more causes for worry.

title: Operatic Reworking Of Poe's 'Usher' Tale
description: Edgar Allan Poe's famous tale ''The Fall of the House of Usher'' is a juicy operatic property. Debussy toyed futilely with it for years, and we deeply mourn the loss.

title: LANCER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

description: A $650 million issue of New York State Power Authority revenue bonds was tentatively offered yesterday with a maximum yield of 7.54 percent for bonds due in 2018 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

description: Arndt von Bohlen und Halbach, the last heir to the Krupp industrial fortune, has died of heart failure, company officials said today. He was 48 years old.

title: SECRETS OF MAYA DECODED AT LAST, REVEALING DARKER HUMAN HISTORY
description: CASCADING advances in the interpretation of ancient Maya hieroglyphs have extended the written history of the New World back more than 2,000 years, creating the Americas' first written record from the age before the European invasions.

title: MINSTAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $2,046,000. c-Net income includes income from discontinued operations of $178,000.

title: Fast Food
description: Senator John H. Chafee reports that more than 40 million Americans eat in fast-food restuarants every day and that most of them don't know what they're eating.

title: 2 NEW CORRIDORS IN MIDTOWN SAID TO SPEED TRAVEL
description: The disputed new transit corridors on 49th and 50th Streets are speeding traffic crosstown and cutting midtown air pollution, according to preliminary city figures released yesterday.

title: Animals
description: The Hai-Bar Society of Israel, a wildlife organization devoted to the preservation of animals mentioned in the Bible, is donating three fennec foxes and four dorcas gazelles to the National Zoo as a gift from the people of Israel to the people of the United States. The dorcas, standing no higher than a cocker spaniel and of considerable delicacy, is endangered in the wild.

description: b-After a tax credit of $19,216,000 for latest quarter and includes an extraordinary charge of $5,544,000 and after a tax credit of $19,014,000 for year-ago period.

description: The year-ago quarter results included the cumulative effect of an accounting change of $504,571.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: For Salt Watchers Salt Sense is a new seasoning introduced by the Diamond Crystal Salt Company. It is not a salt substitute since it is 99.95 percent sodium chloride. But, because of the way the crystals are shaped, a teaspoon contains 33 percent less sodium than a teaspoon of conventional table salt, making it useful for people who are interested in reducing sodium intake.

title: SENATE SEEN PASSING DRUG EXPORT BILL TODAY
description: A bill that would permit companies to export drugs awaiting approval for sale in the United States appears likely to pass the Senate by a wide margin Wednesday.

title: HOUSE G.O.P. LEADERS WEIGH BIGGER MILITARY CUT
description: In a move that rebuffs President Reagan and could undermine the stand of the Republican-controlled Senate, House Republican leaders drafted a 1987 budget alternative today that cuts the President's military request by $27 billion -$8 billion more than the Senate cut.

title: NAZI FILE FOUND IN AN OPEN ARCHIVE
description: The master lists of more than 36,000 files of war criminals, suspects and witnesses kept secret in the United Nations archives for nearly 40 years have been discovered on an open shelf in a military archive in Maryland.

title: RESOURCE EXPLORATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
The Name of the Game
description: In pro basketball, it has long been tough keeping up with the Johnsons, 13 of whom played in the N.B.A. this season. Among big-league baseball players, though, there are only three Johnsons - Cliff, Howard and Joe - and their standing on the list of most common surnames is no better than a 12-way tie for fourth place, shared by Brown, Diaz, Henderson, Jones, Moore, Robinson, Thomas, Thompson, Williams, Wilson and Young.

title: Revere Agrees To Buyout Bid
description: Revere Copper and Brass Inc. agreed yesterday to be acquired in a leveraged buyout by Revere's top executive and a New York management firm for $23 a share, or a total of about $200 million.

title: CITY HOMESTEADERS BID ON DREAMS
description: The two-story vacant house on Creston Avenue in the Bronx is the last in a row of occupied brick houses, and the wide wooden steps leading up to its front door are collapsing.

title: T.W.A. Names Y.& R. Agency
description: The off-again, on-again Trans World Air Lines-Ogilvy & Mather relationship is off again. So far off, in fact, that a new agency, Young & Rubicam, has been named.

title: ESCAPING THE WORLD IN A LOFT ON WHEELS
description: I AM part of the first generation of human beings whose parents were foolish enough to buy them actual automobiles while they were still in high school. Perhaps because of a whine I once perfected, which in pitch and tone was audible only to adult members of my own household, my father bought such a vehicle for me not long after I received a driver's license.

title: GIBSON LOSES BID FOR A FIFTH TERM
description: Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson of Newark, who became the first black to head a Northeastern city when he was elected 16 years ago, was defeated yesterday as he sought a fifth term.

title: ACCUSED EXECUTIVE STUDY IN CONTRASTS
description: Dennis B. Levine, the 33-year-old Wall Street executive who was charged Monday in the largest insider-trading case ever, has led a life filled with contradictions and the unexpected.
