description: b-Includes a gain of $1,439,000 from investments. c-Net loss and includes a gain of $23,000.

title: ROANOKE ELECTRIC STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 20
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in March.

title: Occidental Unit Set to Retrench
description: Occidental Oil Shale Inc., after spending more than $300 million to develop its oil shale tract in western Colorado's Piceance Basin, plans to close its operations June 1, a company spokesman, Marney Talbert, said. The company, a subsidiary of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, pioneered a technology to extract shale oil by burning rock inside a mine, rather than withdrawing it for surface burning. Dr. Armand Hammer, Occidental chairman and chief executive, had pushed the company toward oil shale development for more than 30 years.

title: LIMITED INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: The year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding were adjusted for the 2-for-1 stock split of June 7, 1985.

title: SOME MARCH, SOME MEANDER
description: Women walk faster than men, cover more ground, choose more complex routes and give strangers better walking directions, a researcher who has spent years stalking pedestrian behavior said today.

title: E.P.A. APPROVES FIELD TEST OF GENE-ALTERED AGENT
description: After six months of scientific review, the Environmental Protection Agency today approved a permit allowing researchers from the University of California to spray a living, genetically engineered bacterial agent in small-scale field tests in northern California.

title: Times Dance Critic Receives Prize for Book
description: Dance Perspectives Foundation announced this week that the 1986 de la Torre Bueno Prize, given annually for the best book on dance published during the year, has been awarded to Jennifer Dunning for ''But First a School,'' a history of the School of American Ballet (Viking).

title: Burgeoning Brewery
description: Mayor Koch pulled down a handle and lifted a mug of New Amsterdam Amber Beer yesterday at 26th Street and 11th Avenue, marking the opening of what was described as the first full-scale brewery in the city since Rheingold and Schaeffer closed their doors in 1976.

title: Heritage Acquires Option for Rollins
description: Heritage Communications Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired an option to buy 43.5 percent, or 6.35 million shares, of Rollins Communications Inc. from the Rollins family. The acquisition would be the first step toward a contemplated combination of the two companies.

title: JOYNER SMACKS 13TH AS ANGELS WIN, 5-4
description: Wally Joyner, the Angels' outstanding rookie, hit his 13th home run of the season tonight to help California beat the Red Sox, 5-4. Boston fell a game behind the Yankees in the American League East.

title: Reflections on Terror
description: Something useful may come out of the recent acts of terror in the world after all. For they are forcing officials to recognize that many of the rules and customs, privileges and immunities of old-time diplomacy are now seriously out of date.

title: Grey and Romann Shun Rush Toward Mergers
description: The sudden mega-merger craze has suddenly made not being acquired by Saatchi & Saatchi or anyone else a sellable quality.

title: Bozell, Jacobs Aide
description: Michael D. Drexler, 47, one of the more quoted media executives in agency land, has switched his base of commentary to Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt from Doyle Dane Bernbach. In his new post he will be executive vice president, national media director. He was at D.D.B. for almost 12 years after an even longer tour of 14 years at Ogilvy & Mather.

title: U.S. on Greek Austerity
description: A United States Government official praised an austerity program adopted by Greece's Socialist Government but said today that American investment would be difficult to attract unless the economy was liberalized further. The official, H.P. Goldfield, an Assistant Secretary at the Commerce Department, said that last October's austerity measures were a step in the right direction but that additional action was needed.

title: MARK IV INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The company said its latest quarter and year earnings were increased by the June 1985 acquisition of LFE Corp. LFE's results are included as of June 1, 1985.

title: I.R.A.'s: One Federal Tax Break Too Many
description: To the Editor:

title: Getting Tough
description: If the idea behind a college mascot is to instill fear and loathing in a school's rivals, then California-Santa Cruz should be a more fearsome -and certainly a more loathsome -athletic presence next year.

title: TENNEY ENGINEERING INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A RETURN TO FASHION STAGED WITH FLAIR BY DONALD BROOKS
description: DONALD BROOKS provided a charming coda to the two frenetic weeks of fashion openings in New York, which ended Friday. On Monday afternoon, he invited store buyers to his town house at 158 East 70th Street for the introduction of his newest ready-to-wear collection. The first for his own company in almost eight years, the collection consists exclusively of dinner and evening clothes. It brought bravos from members of the audience, who could visualize how well the clothes would work in settings similar to those in which they will be worn.

title: ASTROTECH INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U.S. May Cut Oil Royalties
description: The Reagan Administration is willing to trim royalties on offshore oil tracts that become uneconomical because of low prices, an Interior Department official told Congress today.

title: BROADVIEW FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PUBLIC SERVICE CO OF NEW MEXICO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Trust a 'Star Wars' Shield?
description: Chernobyl and Challenger. Two distinct tragedies with a common implication: complex technological systems, run by vast organizations, are prone to catastrophic failures that only trial and error can reveal. It is folly to presume that systems of such intricacy will always perform in accordance with design -especially those that cannot undergo real-life tests.

title: FOR BETTER LIVING INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $9,000 on discontinued operations.

title: NETWORK OF WOMEN HOPES TO CHANGE AMERICAN PHILANTHROPY
description: SOME are women of wealth whose backgrounds include private schools and debutante balls. Others struggled with poverty and experienced family violence.

title: PATIENT TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $43,000. c-Net loss

title: LAWRENCE, MARTIN LTD EDIIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Let All Young Americans Study Physics
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a film distributor's change of plans, a picture caption in the Arts and Leisure section on Sunday and a film listing in The Guide carried an outdated list of theaters for the opening of ''Sweet Liberty'' today. It will be shown only at the Loews Tower East, Loews State and Loews 84th Street Six.

title: Former Lawmaker Is at Rally After Release From a Prison
description: Former Representative John Jenrette, convicted of taking a bribe, was shaking hands and slapping backs at a political rally in his old South Carolina district hours after his release from prison Monday.

title: WHAT THEY DO WELL AND WHERE THEY FAIL
description: I HAVE always considered the microwave oven to be the Alfa Romeo of the kitchen - fast, compact and technically impressive but, for a family man or woman, not a good choice for the long haul. At the same time, Americans, smitten with time-saving devices, have been buying microwave ovens by the millions.

title: NOVO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes net income from discontinued operations of $64,000 and extraordinary losses of $78,000. c-Includes net income from discontinued operations of $167,000 and extraordinary losses of $90,000.

title: AQUINO SEES PROGRESS IN CEASE-FIRE ATTEMPTS
description: President Corazon C. Aquino said today that she had already sent emissaries to talk with Communist insurgents and that progress was being made in some areas in trying to reach a cease-fire.

title: THE IMPERILED TAX SHELTERS
description: Tax shelters, long an American institution, would largely pass into extinction, at least in their traditional form, if the Senate Finance Committee's tax revision plan were enacted as written.

title: 2 REPORTS ON PRICES DURING PASSOVER
description: CONTRARY to expectations, the prices of many kosher foods in New York City remained fairly stable in the weeks leading up to and through Passover, according to two surveys conducted in all five boroughs.

title: KURZWEIL MUSIC SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Key Rates
description: Previous Year In percent Yesterday Day Ago PRIME RATE 8.50 8.50 10.50 DISCOUNT RATE * 6.50 6.50 8.00 FEDERAL FUNDS * 6.75 6.92 8.02 3-MO. TREAS. BILLS * 6.07 6.15 7.60 6-MO. TREAS. BILLS * 6.08 6.18 7.75 7-YR. TREAS. NOTES 7.57 7.60 10.74 30-YR. TREAS. BONDS 7.39 7.44 11.04 TELEPHONE BONDS 9.02 9.04 11.88 MUNICIPAL BONDS * 7.99 7.93 9.48 * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Taiwan Willing to Talk To China to Get Jet Back
description: Taiwan's national airline said today that it was willing to meet aviation officials from China to negotiate the return of a Boeing 747 cargo jet flown to China by a defector. The talks would be the first such face-to-face negotiations sanctioned by Taiwan.

title: ENERGYNORTH INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Havlicek Bars Coaching
description: John Havlicek, who was the epitome of dedication, hustle and hard work while starring for the Boston Celtics during the 1960's and 1970's, said emphatically yesterday that he had no desire to leave his business ventures to coach basketball. In New York for a promotion, Havlicek said he had no plans to follow former teammates such as K. C. Jones, Don Nelson, Bill Russell, Tom Sanders, Don Chaney, Dave Cowens and Tom Heinsohn into coaching. ''Today's athlete is somewhat different than the athlete that grew up in my era,'' said the 13-time National Basketball Association all-star selection.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: FOR city dwellers, it is sounds, as much as the constantly stronger sun or the fragrant explosions of flowers, that signal the real arrival of spring. We may not often get to hear the sputter and purr of lawn mower on a Saturday morning, or the soft hiss of a garden hose at dusk, but spring in the city does include the sounds of a youngster's giggles at a late but still-light hour. The sounds of roller skates scooting over the sidewalk. Clinking cups and saucers at outdoor cafes, tinkly bells on ice cream carts. The thump of rubber balls smacking the top step of a stoop.

title: Article 782786 -- No Title
description: Dennis B. Levine was arraigned in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday, less than 24 hours after the United States Attorney's Office had arrested him on criminal charges stemming from the largest insider trading case in the history of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Details Sought in Ottawa
description: Opposition Liberals pressed the Progressive Conservative Government today for details about its hiring of Mr. Deaver as a lobbyist for Canada six days after he left the White House.

title: Alas, the Ping Is King
description: To Larry Smith's ears, there is simply no sound on earth that can compare to the satisfying crack of a hard-thrown baseball coming in contact with a well-swung wooden bat. It is also a largely forgotten sound among the colleges, one that has not been heard on their diamonds for more than a decade, ever since aluminum bats became standard equipment. Smith, the baseball coach at Duke, and his colleagues in the Atlantic Coast Conference would like to hear it again, and they've voted unanimously to urge the A.C.C.'s athletic directors to resume use of wooden bats next season.

title: Bryant Charges Bias
description: Emmette Bryant, a guard for the Knicks from 1964 to 1968, said yesterday in Seattle that he had filed a discrimination complaint against the city's police department and a claim for unspecified damages from the city for being singled out for interrogation last month. Bryant, a member of the Tacoma Human Rights Commission and a former assistant coach of the Seattle SuperSonics, said a police officer singled him out while responding to a call about a firecracker explosion.

title: SERVICO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: BEING A BLACK BOBBY MEANS HEARING 'I'M SORRY'
description: Sgt. Andrew Simons, a London police officer with nearly 10 years' experience, never wears his uniform when he is traveling to or from work. About 95 percent of black policemen here, he estimates, feel the same inhibition.

title: DURHAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes capital gains of $1,057,000 and $1,573,000 for latest and year-ago quarters, respectively.

title: India Wary on Carbide Ruling
description: Indian officials reacted cautiously today to the ruling by a United States judge on Monday that India and not the United States was the appropriate place to hear claims arising from the gas disaster at the Union Carbide Corporation's plant in Bhopal, India.

title: HELM RESOURCES CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $86,000. c-Net loss after an extraodinary gain of $271,000 reflecting a public offering by a subsidiary, and a loss from discontinued operations of $166,000.

title: EXECUTE DRUG DEALERS, KOCH SAYS
description: Mayor Koch called yesterday for a Federal law imposing the death penalty on those convicted of ''wholesale distribution of heroin and cocaine.''

title: NORDSTROM INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
IPL SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: b-Net loss

title: Market Place; Control Data Bid to Pay Debt
description: WHEN the Control Data Corporation agreed earlier this month to sell its Ticketron operation, Wall Street cheered. The computer and finance company, market analysts agreed, was starting its journey back to financial good health, and the estimated $200 million that the private investment firm of Allen & Company Inc. paid for the ticket-booking service would pay for part of the trip.

title: QUEENS 9-YEAR-OLD RAPED AND STABBED WHILE IN HER HOME
description: A 9-year-old Queens girl was raped and stabbed in her apartment after she returned home from school yesterday afternoon, the police reported.

title: BAKER SAYS THAT U.S. HAS NO DOLLAR TARGET
description: The Reagan Administration has no target for the dollar's international value but did discuss the importance of ''stability'' in the yen-dollar rate at recent meetings in Tokyo, Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d said today.

title: NORTHEAST SAVINGS FEDERAL ASSOCIATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a $1.1 million charge to non- interest expenses related to the proposed Westchester Financial Services Corp. acquisition, partially offset by a $500,000 gain on the sale of shares of Westchester Financial. c-Net loss and after an extraordinary gain of $1,978,000 for the year.

title: Errors Cited in Train Crash
description: Human error has been cited as causing the head-on collision of two Burlington Northern trains near Westminster, Colo., that killed five crew members last Aug. 2. The National Transportation Safety Board said in a report today that a crew member of the westbound train failed to read the train register correctly and the conductor also failed to correlate the information.

title: THEATER: IBSEN'S 'LADY FROM THE SEA'
description: IT is understandable that ''The Lady From the Sea'' is not performed more frequently. Ibsen's basic themes are in it -the virtual imprisonment of women in 19th-century society and the failure of even the best-willed men to understand the women's predicament, or their own - but his story is a contrivance stalked by ghosts of Victorian Gothic novels and German romances.

title: Blast at Jersey Plant Injures 5 Workers and 2 Firefighters
description: An explosion and fire injured five workers and two firefighters and caused an evacuation today at the B. F. Goodrich Chemical Group plant in this Salem County community, authorities said.

title: ALBUM FOUND IN ILLINOIS SAID TO BE HITLER'S
description: A photograph album that has turned up in Union, Ill., a small town about 50 miles northwest of here, might have belonged to Adolf Hitler, according to United Press International.

title: ORANGE JULIUS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $1,292,000 from condemnation award. c-Net income and after a extraordinary net tax credit of $712,000.

title: VACANT 7 YEARS, A PRIME FIFTH AVE. CORNER IS LEASED
description: The three-level retail space at the southwest corner of Fifth Avenue and 52d Street that has stood empty for seven years was leased last week to a New York-based development company that plans to fill it by Christmas.

title: JUSTICE DEPT. PORNOGRAPHY STUDY FINDS MATERIAL IS TIED TO VIOLENCE
description: A Justice Department commission on pornography has concluded that most pornography sold in the United States is potentially harmful and can lead to violence.

title: The Kremlin's Aims Beyond Afghanistan
description: To the Editor:

title: WINE TALK
description: THE Italian wine scandal, front-page news just weeks ago, has faded in the face of more recent world events. But Italians, whether they are in the wine business or not, will live with its consequences for many years.

title: TRYING TO QUELL A FUROR, FRANCE FORMS A PANEL ON CHERNOBYL
description: France announced the formation of an interministerial committee today to review information about the Soviet nuclear disaster. The Government acted to help allay public concern over its belated disclosure that France suffered much higher doses of radioactivity than normal after the accident.

title: The Greening of Washington
description: These are hard times for lobbyists, not only the conspicuous ones like Michael K. Deaver, the former White House aide, who serve prominent foreign clients but also the vastly greater number who represent domestic interests.

title: MUSIC: GLENN BRANCA AT TULLY HALL
description: ''I JUST want to make some eardrums bleed!'' screams one of the protagonists in ''This Is Spinal Tap,'' the hilarious motion picture about the life and times of a heavy-metal rock band. Those words came back to haunt Sunday night at Alice Tully Hall, for the composer Glenn Branca has apparantly adopted them as a credo.

title: New Notes Sold By First Chicago
description: The First Chicago Corporation is offering $100 million of 8 1/2 percent notes, due in 1998, at 99 1/2 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: RESEACHERS VOW TO BOYCOTT GRANTS TIED TO MISSILE SHIELD
description: More than 3,700 science and engineering professors and researchers have signed a pledge not to accept Pentagon money to work on a defense against long-range missiles, organizers of the boycott asserted today.

title: DOCTORS VS. LAWYERS: RETALIATION IN GEORGIA
description: National pressures have to surface somewhere, and here in this small, slow-paced city on the Atlantic coast, the medical liability insurance crisis has produced a kind of standoff. The doctors have struck back.

title: Penney's Net Increases 26%
description: The J. C. Penney Company, rebounding from a depressed period last year, reported yesterday that its net income in its first fiscal quarter of 1987 rose 26 percent.

title: THEATER: OVERMYER'S 'ON THE VERGE'
description: The fact that a play can have a long, profitable life outside New York is amply demonstrated by Eric Overmyer's ''On the Verge or the Geography of Yearning.'' Last season Mr. Overmyer's speculative comedy had its premiere at Baltimore's Center Stage. Since then, it has been presented at nine other regional theaters, including, currently, the Hartford Stage Company.

title: JAZZ: NEW ORCHESTRA IN DEBUT
description: THE debut of the newly organized American Jazz Orchestra in the Great Hall at Cooper Union on Monday evening provided some very positive answers to its potential for developing a repertory of old and new arrangements for a standard 18-piece instrumentation. For this first concert, John Lewis, the orchestra's musical director and conductor, focused on five leading figures in big-band jazz - Fletcher Henderson, Duke Ellington, Jimmie Lunceford, Count Basie and Dizzy Gillespie. Surprisingly, the complex music of Duke Ellington's orchestra - collectively and individually reflecting the sounds and styles of an array of individualistic musicians - proved to be the most evocative segment of the program.

title: SYMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ALLIANCE WELL SERVICE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE NEWS FROM IRELAND & OTHER STORIES. By William Trevor. 285 pages. Viking. $16.95.

title: Amy Carter's Big Day
description: Amy Carter is scheduled for a busy morning on Capitol Hill today.

title: Dept. of Texas Lawyers
description: As if the tax scene weren't perplexing enough these days with all the action in Congress on revising the tax code, O. Don Chapoton, an Texas lawyer, has just signed on with the Treasury Department as Deputy Assistant Secretary for Tax Policy. What threatens confusion for Treasury employees and clients alike is that the new deputy assistant is the twin brother of John E. Chapoton, who served as Assistant Secretary for Tax Policy from 1981 through mid-1984.

title: Stevenson Gains
description: Teofilo Stevenson, using right-handed power, knocked out Petar Stoimenov of Bulgaria and advanced to the superheavyweight semifinals at the world amateur boxing championships. The 35-year-Cuban, a three-time Olympic champion who is seeking his third world title, will next fight Vyacheslav Yakolev of the Soviet Union, who scored a 5-0 decision over John Zarenkieva of Poland.

title: Auto Jump Spurs 0.5% April Rise in Retail Sales
description: Retail sales rose five-tenths of 1 percent in April, the best showing in four months, the Government said today, but economists said a jump in auto sales hid weakness in other areas of consumer spending.

title: Bridge: Winners at Cavendish Club Escaped the Crocodile Coup
description: The two young experts who, to their considerable surprise, found themselves the winners of the Cavendish Club's Invitational Pairs last weekend narrowly escaped some closing jaws on the diagramed deal.

title: How to Fight Terror From the Air
description: Britain has expelled three Syrian diplomats after they scorned to answer questions about their suspected role in the recent plot to blow up an El Al airliner . . . Israel says it has also detected Syria's hand in the plot . . . in a related episode, West German police suspect Syrian involvement in the March 29 bombing of an Arab-German friendship society in West Berlin.

title: Putnam Won't Give A Tract to Wesleyan
description: Wesleyan University will not be allowed to redeem 600 acres of land seized by Putnam County, N.Y., for nonpayment of taxes, the County Legislature has voted. The college in Middletown, Conn., stopped paying taxes on the land, bequeathed to the college by Walter Merritt, in 1978.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, MAY 14, 1986
description: International

title: 24-Man Roster Is Challenged
description: The Major League Baseball Players Association is challenging the clubs' new practice of having 24 players on their rosters instead of 25.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SAXOPHONIST Paquito D'Rivera did not come to the United States, abandoning his native Cuba, because he lacked appreciation and status. In Cuba, until he left in 1980, he worked with that nation's pre-eminent jazz group, the world-famous Irakere. Here, he is also considered one of this country's major jazz saxophonists and has made five popular solo albums.

title: Bonds to Benefit Schools in Florida
description: The Seminole County School District in Florida is offering $90 million of general obligation bonds with a top yield of 7.60 percent for bonds due in 2005. Merrill Lynch Capital Markets heads the underwriters.

title: Whose Justice for Bhopal?
description: To the vexing question of where to litigate the claims against Union Carbide for the disaster in Bhopal, India in late 1984, Federal District Judge John Keenan has now given an ingenious answer. India sued in New York's Federal Court on behalf of the thousands of dead and injured, hoping for the larger damage awards available in the United States and disingenuously pleading that its own legal system was unfit for the task. Very well, Judge Keenan decided: try the case in India but under conditions borrowed from American justice.

title: A Bureaucrat's War on 'Star Wars'
description: Sometimes in Washington, it is what you don't say that counts.

title: TELESIS SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: SYNTECH INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: After preferred dividends, there were no share earnings in the latest and year-ago quarters.

title: RECIPES CAN EVOKE IMAGINARY JOURNEYS
description: A TASTE OF INDIA. By Madhur Jaffrey. 255 pages. Atheneum. $29.95. CLASSIC INDIAN VEGETARIAN

title: Democrats in Indiana
description: Results of last week's primary elections in two Congressional districts in Indiana have raised hopes of House Democratic leaders that they can significantly improve the Democratic showing there in November.

title: NASA INVESTIGATING REASSIGNMENT OF 2 ENGINEERS
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration is investigating whether its officials had a role in the reassignment of two industry engineers who opposed the decision to launch the space shuttle Challenger Jan. 28, a NASA official said today.

title: Firefighters Gaining On North Carolina Blaze
description: Firefighters said today that they were gaining the upper hand against a week-old brush fire that has scorched 73,000 acres, although gusting ocean winds rekindled fears that the blaze might jump fire lines.

title: Xerox Weighs Pretoria Move
description: The Xerox Corporation is considering pulling its operations out of South Africa if tensions there do not ease and pressures in the United States continue to mount, the company's top executive said. ''I am not optimistic about

title: AGUILERA FALTERS AS METS LOSE
description: The pitch that Rick Aguilera didn't throw cost him one base. The three pitches he threw immediately afterward cost him three runs. The Mets paid the ultimate price, losing to the Atlanta Braves, 6-3, primarily as a result of Aguilera's costly sequence.

title: SCHERER, R P CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $351,000 and $805,000 for quarter and year, respectively. The company said the closing of a hard-shell capsule manufacturing facility at Somerset, N.J., because its major customer, Johnson & Johnson, had discontinued marketing Tylenol in hard-shell capsules resulted in a provision of $4.3 million against income in the latest quarter with no current tax benefit.

title: UNIVERSAL VOLTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $119,137 and $326,103 for quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes extraordinary gains of $7,444 and $79,475 for quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Phoenix Arranges Bond Refunding
description: Phoenix is offering $151.5 million of street and highway refunding bonds with a maximum yield tentatively set at 7.60 percent for bonds due in 2005.

title: Judge Bars Bail for 3 In Detective's Slaying
description: A Queens judge ruled yesterday that three men charged with killing a police detective and wounding another should not be freed on $1 million bail each while they await their trial.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: FOES SEE LENDL AS VULNERABLE
description: Although Ivan Lendl is firmly established as No. 1 in the world, the impression given by his fellow players at Forest Hills last week was that they are not as intimidated by him as they were by John McEnroe when he was on top. A contributing factor is that Lendl is suffering from tendinitis of the right knee. Yannick Noah's victory last Sunday in the Shearson Lehman Brothers Tournament of Champions was offered as further evidence that this is the time for some of the better players on the tour to make their move.

title: Alicia Moreau de Justo Dies; Leading Argentine Socialist
description: Alicia Moreau de Justo, one of the leading Socialists and feminists of Latin America, died Monday. She was 100 years old.

title: SECRETS IN WHITWORTH'S REACH ARE DESCRIBED
description: A Navy intelligence expert testified today at the espionage trial of Jerry A. Whitworth that the defendant had access to message traffic describing antisubmarine and antiaircraft warfare procedures that would have been of ''tremendous value'' to the Soviet Union.

title: F.H.A. Increase Urged
description: President Reagan asked Congress today for a $23.5 billion increase in mortgage insurance available from the Federal Housing Administration. The administration said the current limit of $57.4 billion would be exceeded by increased demand resulting from falling interest rates.

title: CMO Trust Two Offers $500 Million Package
description: CMO Trust Two, a special purpose financing company created by Salomon Brothers Inc. to package and sell collateralized mortgage obligations, is offering $500 million of the mortgage-backed securities.

title: Lighthouse Turns 65
description: Beneath the smell of exhaust and blaring horns from the George Washington Bridge, the Little Red Lighthouse had a birthday party yesterday.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Satellite Co., Rockville, Md., a division of Telecom Inc., named Michael D. Campbell president of its Government Systems division.

title: FIRST EXECUTIVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $6,110,000 and $5,138,000 for latest and year-ago quarters, respectively.

title: 'PIZZA CONNECTION' TRIAL: AN ENDURANCE TEST OF JURISPRUDENCE
description: In the ''pizza connection'' trial, a narcotics case that sounds more like a takeout restaurant, the issues have expanded from guilt and innocence to endurance and ennui.

title: Swift Pace
description: Wally Joyner, the California rookie who finds himself atop the majors in homers and runs batted in: ''I'm riding the wave, and I'm going to enjoy it until I hit the sand.''

title: Pennsylvania Official Indicted in Bribe Case
description: A Federal grand jury today indicted the Pennsylvania Treasurer and a former state Republican chairman in a bribery scheme involving state contracts in which five others have been convicted.

title: Bergelt Advertising Adds Litchfield Group
description: But wait, there has been another acquisition. This, however, is of more reasonable size, out of the billions bracket and back to reality.

title: 2 Charges Dismissed In Scientology Suit
description: A judge has dismissed two key charges in a $25 million fraud suit brought by Larry Wollersheim, a former Scientologist who asserted the church wrecked him emotionally and financially with lies and harassment.

title: Preserving the Gilded Age
description: The time for the Ladies' Mile - that exuberant shopping district of the Gilded Age - has come again.

title: EXPERIMENT SETS SKY AGLOW
description: Bright blue and green clouds glowed briefly along the East Coast early today when scientists conducting an experiment exploded canisters of chemicals in space.

title: TASTY AND HEALTHY BLEND IN MACKEREL
description: IN the spring, as the weather improves and fishermen spend more time at sea, the price of fresh fish starts to fall. Atlantic or Boston mackerel is one of the best and cheapest of these seasonal offerings.

title: PSYCHOTHERAPY IS AS GOOD AS DRUG IN CURING DEPRESSION, STUDY FINDS
description: A long-awaited major study has concluded that two important forms of psychotherapy are as effective as a standard drug treatment in curing depression, a mental disorder that afflicts millions of Americans.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL NEW YORK (AL) - Recalled Al Holland, pitcher, from Columbus of the International League. Placed Rod Scurry, pitcher, on 15-day disabled list.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, MAY 14, 1986
description: Companies

title: ALBANY LOBBYING INTENSIFIES ON BILLS FOR RENT REGULATION
description: Busloads of landlords and tenants descended on the Capitol today, lobbying for opposing bills that would affect the regulation of New York City's nearly one million rent-stabilized apartments.

title: SCIENTIFIC SYSTEMS SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Advertising; TV Spot For Deaf Viewers
description: APPARENTLY aware of the notion that good deeds are best measured by the amount of publicity they amass, the McDonald's Corporation is promoting a TV commercial for the deaf and starring the deaf. It will begin to air on network television tomorrow.

title: CHRISTIE'S TRIAL IS ORDERED
description: A New York state appeals court yesterday reinstated a case brought against Christie's, the auction house, by a seller who said that eight Impressionist paintings consigned to the house for sale in 1981 were overvalued in their preliminary appraisals.

title: E.P.A. VETOES A MALL OVER MASSACHUSETTS SWAMP
description: The Environmental Protection Agency ruled today against construction of a shopping mall on a swamp in Massachusetts.

title: For New Zealanders, An Impossible Dream
description: To the Editor:

title: A PROFESSOR GOING TO CITY HALL
description: Sharpe James, the 49-year-old Mayor-elect of Newark, first won election to the City Council in the South Ward in 1970, the same year that Kenneth A. Gibson, the man he defeated yesterday, began his tenure as mayor.

title: ON THE FRONT LINE OF CITY GOVERNMENT
description: Some people coming into the office are so mad they can barely speak; others just casually drop by to mention what a dirty, crowded, dangerous and dehumanizing city New York is. ''Thanks for listening,'' one complainant chirped yesterday on his way out.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: THE dishes that come together on my stove have many inspirations: the season for a particular game, perhaps; an occasion calling for special foods for special friends; a sudden craving for something different, such as an Asian dish; a desire to create a new dish, an experimental, untried blend of flavors or textures, or - as with the recipe printed here - a yearning to re-create a well-remembered food from my childhood.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Press Notes column yesterday about a joint operating arrangement proposed for The Detroit News and The Detroit Free Press gave an incorrect figure, distributed by the two papers in a news release, for operating losses incurred by The Detroit News in the last five years. It was $24 million, not $12 million.

title: '87 REVENUE GAIN PUT AT $22 BILLION
description: The Senate Finance Committee's proposal to overhaul the tax system could produce $22 billion in added Federal revenues next year, a senior Administration official said today.

title: ELEGANT BUT EASY
description: EVEN when making the simplest meal at home, I resort to easy, carving techniques to make vegetables more decorative and appealing. I am not referring to elaborate, flower-shaped garnishes or vegetables arranged on the plate to resemble a peacock, but simple, artful presentation.

title: ITALY EXPELS A LIBYAN DIPLOMAT
description: Italy announced the expulsion of another Libyan diplomat today, a day after Libya ordered the expulsion of 25 Italians.

title: OLD CARNEGIE HALL TAKES A CURTAIN CALL
description: With its 28-week closing only a few days away, Carnegie Hall decided to put some of its generous friends on stage last night.

title: China's Family Plans
description: To the Editor:

title: FERDINAND IS RATED EARLY PIMLICO PICK
description: Given that no one seemed particularly impressed by Ferdinand's victory in the Kentucky Derby 10 days ago, why are only six 3-year-olds likely to run against him Saturday in the Preakness Stakes at Pimlico Race Course?

title: JUDGE APPROVES U.P.I. STEP IN REORGANIZATION
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge has removed the next-to-the-last legal hurdle in United Press International's prolonged battle to escape bankruptcy, leading to hopes that the news agency could be operating independently June 10.

title: Economic Scene; Kaufman View Of New World
description: WHERE are interest rates going from here?

title: MARSH SUPERMARKETS reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: The company said sales for the year-ago quarter and year were restated to reflect the acquisition of a 30 percent minority interest in Convenience Store Distributing Co., acquired in December.

title: U.S. Ambassadors in Appropriate Quarters
description: To the Editor:

title: What the Tamil Separatist-Terrorists Are Doing to Sri Lanka
description: To the Editor:

title: HOME GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary tax credit of $23 million, or 59 cents a share. c-Net loss and includes net from discontinued operations of $3 million, or 9 cents a share.

title: GENSTAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The company reported no share earnings for the year-ago first quarter after paying preferred share dividends. Results are expressed in Canadian dollars.

title: Holmes a Court Raises B.H.P. Bid
description: The entrepreneur Robert Holmes a Court sharply increased his bid to gain control of Australia's largest company, Broken Hill Proprietary. Analysts said the new offer improved the odds of success for the bid, but the entry of a friendly suitor to rescue the company, or a negotiated Broken Hill buyout of Mr. Holmes a Court, remained possible. B.H.P. is a steel and natural resources conglomerate.

title: SOVIET TO ENCASE DAMAGED REACTOR IN CONCRETE TOMB
description: A senior designer of the damaged Chernobyl nuclear reactor said today that it would have to be sealed in concrete for centuries until radiation emissions were no longer a threat.

title: It Could Happen Here
description: If the tax reform bill were to pass in its present form, I could no longer avoid having my guest bedroom infested with guests.

title: CENTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DAYAN LEGACY PROMPTS DISPUTE ON ANTIQUITIES
description: One of the most controversial archeological exhibitions ever to be displayed at the Israel Museum - the private antiquities collection of Moshe Dayan - has opened to a cacophony of protests and praise. It has raised some very basic questions about how museums should deal with antiquities that have been obtained through questionable means.

title: HOSPOSABLE PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $46,000 related to the settlement of a civil suit.

title: EQUITABLE RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Is Senator Helms Losing His Touch?
description: Senator Jesse Helms has never operated within the boundaries of conventional politics. That is why it is difficult to measure his successes and failures by the standards that are normally applied to political figures in this city.

title: Righetti Preserves A Victory by John
description: When the Yankees pulled Tommy John out of mothballs 11 days ago, they were hoping - perhaps hoping against hope - that he could provide some kind of help for a pitching staff that has endured its fair share of hard times.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: BIT BY BIT, SOVIET GETS NEWS
description: ''This is the agony of our fatherland. And it will take time for this wound to heal. ''Chernobyl . . .'' These dramatic opening words from Pravda's account today, under the headline ''The Battle Continues,'' were a far cry from the brief paragraph in Izvestia on April 29 reporting an ''accident'' at Unit 4 of the Chernobyl nuclear power station.

title: ALSATIAN CHEFS PLAN A CULINARY INVASION
description: THIS city in Alsace, birthplace of Auguste Bartholdi, who sculpted the Statue of Liberty, is spearheading a culinary assault on New York in honor of the statue's Fourth of July centennial. Starting May 19, 22 young local chefs whose restaurants have more Guide Michelin stars than those of any other province in France will be arriving in New York to share kitchen space with 22 other chefs.

title: Texaco Battle
description: Texaco Inc. executives said they were pleased with a legal brief from the New York State Attorney General supporting their contention that New York law was improperly applied by the Texas court that ruled against Texaco in its battle with the Pennzoil Company. The executives, speaking at Texaco's annual meeting in Tulsa, Okla., said the company would continue to fight the $11.1 billion judgment against it, but that it also continued to be interested in negotiating a reasonable out-of-court settlement. Separately, a lawyer for Pennzoil, Joseph D. Jamail, said that a Texas appeals court would hear arguments in the case on July 31.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Chicago White Sox, at Yankee Stadium, opening of a 12-game home stand for the Yankees and the first of two against Chicago.

title: UNIVERSAL MATCHBOX GROUP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DIXON TICONDEROGA CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $205,427 from the termination of a pension plan. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $14,039 and $42,057 for quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: A PANEL CLEARS HOLDING OF STOCK BY CITY OFFICIAL
description: A senior city hospital administrator used poor judgment by holding stock in a company whose operations he in part oversaw, but did not violate conflict-of-interest rules, the Health and Hospitals Corporation said yesterday.

title: Lendl and Noah Advance in Rome
description: Top-seeded Ivan Lendl defeated Francesco Cancellotti of Italy, 6-4, 6-2, today to advance to the second round of the Italian Open tennis championships.

title: CULLING OF U.S. DISABILITY ROLLS IS UNDER WAY
description: The Social Security Administration is informing some people who receive disability benefits that they are ineligible for assistance and will be removed from the rolls, Federal officials said today.

title: NATIONAL GUARDIAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AUSTRON INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Amtrak and Union Agree On Binding Arbitration
description: Amtrak and a union representing more than 300 locomotive engineers today agreed to binding arbitration to settle a dispute that had threatened earlier to paralyze passenger and freight traffic in the Northeast.

title: Let the Courtroom Cameras Roll
description: Just when it seemed that New York had run out of excuses to keep cameras out of courtrooms, some police unions have come up with a few more. Their last-minute lobbying kept the State Senate from passing a 30-month test of photography in trials, a measure already approved by the Assembly.

title: BUFFETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 23
CALIFORNIA BIOTECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company changed its fiscal year-end to Dec. 31 from Nov. 30, effective March 31. These results cover the latest quarter ended March 31.

title: COMPUTER MONITORING OF TRADES AIDED INQUIRY
description: The insider trading case involving a Wall Street merger specialist came to light, in large measure, as a result of computer monitoring of trading at the New York Stock Exchange and the National Association of Securities Dealers, officials said today.

title: Soviet Coach Dismissed
description: After the Soviet Union's four losses in five pre-World Cup exhibition games, Eduard Malofeyev was dismissed as coach of the national soccer team and replaced by Valery Lobanovsky, the coach of Dynamo Kiev and a former national team coach. The change was made in Moscow one week before the Soviet squad, which includes 11 players from the Kiev team, is scheduled to leave for the World Cup finals in Mexico City. Tass, the official Saviet press agency, said Malofeyev was replaced ''in view of his personal request'' and because the national team included so many of Lobanovsky's players.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''We conclude that substantial exposure to materials of this type bears some causal relationship to the level of sexual violence, sexual coercion or unwanted sexual aggression in the population so exposed.''

title: PANEL URGES BLACK COLLEGES TO ADMIT MORE WHITES
description: A Presidential advisory board suggested today that Fisk University and other private, predominantly black colleges with budget problems should recruit more white students, toughen admission standards and seek funds from private rather than Government sources.

title: DEAVER RELINQUISHES PERQUISITES TO TAKE PRESSURE OFF REAGAN
description: Michael K. Deaver relinquished his White House perquisites today in what an aide to the lobbyist called an effort to remove a possible embarrassment to President Reagan.

title: Edelman Stake
description: Asher B. Edelman, chairman of the Datapoint Corporation, said he had raised his stake in the company from 11.1 percent, to 15 percent. On May 6, Mr. Edelman withdrew his $6-a-share, or $100 million, leveraged buyout proposal for the San Antonio-based data processing concern.

title: DRESSY AND ACTIVE
LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: Life in the 30's, a new column by Anna Quindlen, will appear every week in The Living Section.

title: Dallas Markets School Bonds
description: The Dallas Independent School District offered $93.2 million of general obligation bonds yesterday through underwriters led by the Northern Trust Company of Chicago with yields ranging from 4.75 percent for bonds due in 1987 to 6.10 percent in 1991, 6.90 percent in 1995 and 7.55 percent in 2001. The bonds, rated Aaa by

title: EXPORT-CONTROL LIST DEBATED
description: The House of Representatives, prodded by frustrated exporters, is about to take a knife to the ever-growing list of sensitive products that need a special Government license before they can be shipped abroad.

title: Canada Lumber Plan
description: Clayton K. Yeutter, the United States trade representative, said today that the Canadian Government was preparing to make a new proposal in its trade negotiations on lumber with this country. Mr. Yeutter said the Canadians had indicated the new recommendations ''for handling the dispute'' will be made to the United States Government this week, perhaps as early as Wednesday.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: ONE of the most important, yet often neglected, factors in a successful hospital stay is the patient's visitors. They can do much to help the patient cope with illness and hospitalization, and they can be vital to the medical team, providing information and services that will help improve care.

title: SHULTZ DECLARES MARCOS USES EXILE TO HARASS AQUINO
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz publicly rebuked former President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines today for using his safe haven in Hawaii to foment trouble for the new Government of President Corazon C. Aquino.

title: HOUSE DEMOCRATS OFFER A BILL TO SPUR EXPORTS
description: House Democrats presented a new package of trade legislation today that they say is aimed at prying open foreign markets for American goods.

title: APPLIED DATA COMMUNICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Treasury Issues Strengthen
description: Treasury note and bond prices rebounded yesterday as investor and speculative demand improved after prices fell well below the levels set at last week's Treasury auctions.

title: QUESTAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Reflects a one-time after-tax charge of $9,762,000 from a writedown of an oil and gas unit.

title: The U.N. Today: May 14, 1986
description: TRUSTEESHIP COUNCIL Meets at 10:30 A.M. >ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: SHCHARANSKY SEES REAGAN ON RIGHTS
description: Anatoly B. Shcharansky, the Soviet dissident whose imprisonment marred Soviet-American relations for nine years, met for 30 minutes with President Reagan today to discuss ways of pressing Moscow on human rights issues.

title: Communist Won't Run For President of France
description: Georges Marchais, Secretary General of the French Communist Party, has announced that he will not run for President in 1988.

title: NATIONAL CONTROLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $125,000 for the latest quarter and $121,000 for the year-ago period.

title: Jury Chosen in Pro Football Trial
description: A jury of four women and two men will hear opening arguments today in the antitrust case involving the United States Football League and the National Football League.

title: SCREEN: DAILY LIFE IN INDIA
description: ROBERT GARDNER is a talented maker of tantalizing documentaries. His beautifully photographed ''Forest of Bliss,'' which opens today at Film Forum I, is filled with clues and hints, signs and metaphors. Boats emerge from the morning mist and disappear into it; dogs prowl, fight, scavenge; birds, also scavengers, wheel overhead like lords of the place. The place, we are informed by a line on screen, is Benares, in India. You will not learn from Mr. Gardner, who abjures narration here, that one million pilgrims journey each year to this city on the Ganges. But it does become plain that many go there to cremate their dead, or, apparently, just to dump the corpses into the holy waters.

title: Merrill Lynch Picks Technology Chief
description: Merrill Lynch & Company said yesterday that it had named DuWayne J. Peterson executive vice president for operations systems and telecommunications, a new position at the financial services concern that amounts to its communications czar.

title: John Blair Unit
description: John Blair & Company, the nation's largest independent advertising sales representative for radio and television stations, has agreed to sell its Alden Press web printing subsidiary to Alden Holding Inc., a new company formed by the printing concerns's management and a California investment firm.

title: Agreement Is Reached On Cicero Race Policy
description: The nearly all-white Chicago suburb of Cicero has agreed to adopt an open housing policy and hire blacks to settle a three-year-old discrimination suit, the Justice Department said today.

title: TACOMA BOATBUILDING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and after writeoff of an account receivable of $1,950,000.

title: HANDY & HARMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $2.7 million for the writedown of a bad debt associated with the manufacturing jewelry industry. c-Net income.

title: Scurry Out; Holland In
description: The Yankees made the move that was expected today. They placed Rod Scurry, the left-handed reliever, on the 15-day disabled list and activated Al Holland, who joined the club Monday from the Yankees' Class AAA affiliate in Columbus, Ohio.

title: QUEENS DEMOCRATS PICK BLACK LEGISLATOR FOR ADDABBO SEAT
description: Assemblyman Alton R. Waldon Jr. was nominated last night as the Democratic candidate to succeed the late Representative Joseph P. Addabbo of Queens in a special election June 10.

title: Sperry Still Silent
description: The Sperry Corporation's board reportedly met in a long session yesterday to discuss the Burroughs Corporation's hostile takeover bid, but Sperry made no comment about what actions it would take. Since the takeover effort began a week ago, analysts have expected Sperry to take some kind of defensive action, or seek another merger partner. So far, however, Sperry has said nothing publicly about the $70-a-share bid, the second Burroughs has made for the company in a year.

title: BOB SEGER'S VIEW OF LIFE AND LOVING
description: ''IT'S like a full-force gale atop a mountain of cold,'' howls Bob Seger in ''American Storm,'' the passionate antidrug song that leads off his latest album, ''Like a Rock.'' The record, currently lodged at No. 4 on Billboard's pop-album chart, has all the qualities that have made Mr. Seger one of rock music's working-class heroes for the last decade: catchy folkish melodies, an unstoppable drive, lyrics that address people's everyday lives and, most of all, a voice that inspires trust. Like Bruce Springsteen and John Cougar Mellencamp, Mr. Seger exudes the brawny vocal friendliness of an American Everyman, but with a deep and special connection to soul music.

title: U.S. AIDES HARSHLY ASSAIL MEXICO ON DRUGS, IMMIGRATION AND GRAFT
description: Federal officials testifying today before a Senate subcommittee offered what they characterized as the sharpest public criticism of Mexico that has come out of the United States Government in many years.

title: BARNWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss Year-ago quarter and six-month results include a $230,000 charge to reflect a change in the method of accounting for the company's contract drilling operations.

title: CELTICS CRUSH BUCKS IN OPENER, 128-96
description: The capacity crowd of 14,890 Celtic fans began leaving Boston Garden in the third period tonight. By that time Larry Bird, Kevin McHale, Robert Parish, Dennis Johnson, Danny Ainge and Bill Walton, their heroes, were on the bench watching their substitutes put the finishing touches on a 128-96 victory over the Milwaukee Bucks.

title: Laxalt at the Net
description: The 14th annual CBS Tennis Tournament, which combines stars of television and politics with corporate executives, was won Monday night by the team of Senator Paul Laxalt, Republican of Nevada, and William R. Moses, an actor who appears on the network drama ''Falcon Crest.''

title: SAUDI HELP IS CITED BY REAGAN
description: President Reagan said today that Saudi Arabia had helped repel efforts by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, to isolate the United States in the Arab world.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization May 9 May 2 May 10 1986 1986 1985 Gasoline production, daily 6.7 6.5 6.7 Distillate production, daily 2.7 2.8 2.6 Gasoline stocks 208.9 206.3 215.9 Distillate stocks 95.3 96.1 96.5 Crude imports, daily 3.7 3.9 3.7 Product imports, daily 1.8 1.9 1.8 Crude stocks 331.5 337.6 347.1 Crude production, daily 8.8 8.8 9.0 Refinery utilization (%) 85.1 82.1 79.1 Source: * American Petroleum Institute

title: WHY METS SPURNED SEAVER
description: When the Chicago White Sox arrive at Yankee Stadium tonight, Tom Seaver will be with them. Still. During the last weeks of spring training, George Steinbrenner talked almost daily about his negotiations to acquire the 41-year-old right-hander who now has 306 victories. But a Yankee deal with Ken (Hawk) Harrelson, the White Sox executive vice president, has yet to happen.

title: CITY BALLET: 'LA SOURCE'
description: ''LA SOURCE'' is not one of the great ballets in the vast repertory of work by George Balanchine. But the ballet, presented by the New York City Ballet on Sunday afternoon at the New York State Theater, has a distinctively sweet effervescence that matches the Gallic charm of the music by Leo Delibes to which the dance is set. Sean Lavery and Heather Watts, both making role debuts in the ballet, danced the choreography so that the smallest and most delicate gestures and impulses stood out with lovely clarity and style. But that effervescent quality was largely missing.

title: LIVINGWELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $11,000. c-After income from discontinued operations of $70,000 and a tax credit of $690,000.

title: Sourly, the Poles Offer Blankets to New York
description: Poland, irked that an American donation of powdered milk carries the condition that it must be distributed by non-Government agencies, said today that it would give 5,000 blankets and sleeping bags to the homeless of New York City - and insist on the same condition.

title: French Arrest 2 More In Marks & Spencer Case
description: The French police have arrested and charged two more suspects in the terrorist bombings of Marks & Spencer department stores in Paris and London, the prosecutor's office in Nancy said today.

title: THE UNWELCOME GEESE
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: BRITON PRESSES U.S. ON IRISH EXTRADITION
description: The British Secretary of State for Northern Ireland told key United States senators today that it would be ''incomprehensible'' if they were to reject tighter extradition measures against suspected Irish terrorists in the face of President Reagan's repeated vows to fight world terrorism.

title: RECORD SALE FOR LAUTREC'S 'OPERA BALL'
description: Toulouse-Lautrec's ''Opera Ball,'' a festive scene in glowing yellows, blacks and whites painted in 1893, brought the highest price in Sotheby's auction of Impressionist and modern works last night.

title: SIX DEFENDANTS ARE ACQUITTED IN A MOB TRIAL
description: Matthew (Matty the Horse) Ianniello and five co-defendants were acquitted yesterday of Federal racketeering charges involving mob influence in the private garbage-collection industry in the New York metropolitan area.

title: FEATURES FINE-TUNED TO DRAW NEW BUYERS
description: THE microwave oven, marveled at as a Buck Rogers contraption as late as the 1960's, has become a common kitchen convenience. By the end of 1986, industry analysts say, 3 out of every 5 households will own one.

title: NEBRASKANS CHOOSE WOMEN FOR GOVERNOR'S RACE
description: Helen Boosalis, a Democrat, will face state Treasurer Kay Orr, a Republican, in the nation's first woman-against-woman campaign for Governor. They each won their parties' primaries today.

title: OFFSHORE LOGISTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a writedown of $25.9 million on its vessels and aircraft.

title: CUTCO INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
'STARK: MIRROR IMAGE,' A DETECTIVE TALE ON CBS
description: TELEVISION detectives almost always catch their prey; what really matters is how well they project their eccentric, usually wisecracking personalities. Evan Stark (Nicolas Surovy), the hero of ''Stark: Mirror Image,'' is part old-fashioned tough guy, part new sensitive man. And though that sounds like a snappy combination, poor Stark winds up with the worst of both parts - the outer terseness of a Jack Webb parody and the easy sentimentality of Alan Alda. The two halves seem to cancel each other, and all he has left are blond good looks and a plot so incredibly obvious we begin hoping that a last-minute trick will prove it's all been a giant red herring.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Telephone and Telegraph Co. said it had named Zilog, a subsidiary of Exxon Corp., as an alternative source of supply for its 32-bit Unix microsystem chip set.

title: INMATES' CHOICE: FOOD PACKETS OR TV
description: The myth of absolute rule aside, prison administrators have always practiced a form of quid pro quo to keep order. The keepers rarely take something away from the kept without giving something in return.

title: FOR MT. SINAI HOSPITAL, SOLD-OUT BENEFIT
description: YOU didn't need a crystal ball to know that Mount Sinai Medical Center's Crystal Ball would be a success. You only had to look at the engraved invitation with its mile-long committee list of power brokers, to say nothing of the lure of entertainment by Peter Allen and Marvin Hamlisch.

title: PAUL E. NEWMAN
description: Paul E. Newman, former New York advertising executive who became successful Wyoming restaurateur, died of a brain tumor Saturday at the Lander Valley Regional Medical Center in Wyoming.

title: ITEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $100,000 and an extraordinary charge of $2.1 million. Itel said that Great Lakes International, which it acquired in late 1985, incurred a $1.8 million pre-tax loss in the first quarter on revenue of $19.7 million.

title: PENNEY, J C CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 26
description: b-After an extraordinary charge on debt restructure of $24 million.

title: DR. ARTHUR E. ALBRECHT
description: Dr. Arthur E. Albrecht, professor emeritus of marketing at Baruch College, died Monday at his home in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 91 years old.

title: Court Clears the Way To Imprison U.S. Judge
description: A federal appeals court refused today to block Friday's scheduled imprisonment of a judge who would become the first sitting member of the Federal judiciary to be jailed.

title: 'BLACK CHAMPIONS' ON 13 LOOKS AT SPORTS WORLD
description: THE three-part documentary series ''Black Champions,'' which begins tonight at 9 o'clock on WNET/Channel 13, has the distinction of being produced by William Miles. Among Mr. Miles's previous credits on public television are the widely acclaimed ''I Remember Harlem'' and ''Men of Bronze.'' Both went back into invaluable film and photograph archives to catalogue neglected areas in the history of black Americans. Mr. Miles and his partners, including the executive producer, David Loxton, are clearly caught up in a good and rewarding cause.

title: CITY ENDS CONTRACT FOR QUEENS TOWER
description: New York City has abandoned a development contract for a Queens office tower that became a target of investigations into political favors by Donald R. Manes, the late Borough President.

title: UPHILL BATTLE LOOMS FOR BECKENBAUER SQUAD
description: Twelve years ago, the bedazzling Franz Beckenbauer trained with his comrades in this lake-ringed resort not far from the Danish frontier and then captained West Germany to its second World Cup title. Running an hour a day has kept the 40-year-old Beckenbauer looking like a college sophomore, but today he is the national team's coach.

title: RULING WIDENS SHELTER RIGHTS FOR HOMELESS
description: A New York State appeals court ruled unanimously yesterday that all homeless families have the legal right to emergency shelter.

title: FAMILY STEAK HOUSES OF FLORIDA reports earnings for Qtr to April 2
Court to Hear Appeal By Friedman on Judge
description: A state appeals judge yesterday refused a request by attorneys for Stanley M. Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader, to put the state criminal case against him on hold pending a lawsuit challenging the appointment of an upstate judge for the trial.

title: MEYERS PARKING SYSTEM reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $136,000 and a gain of $491,000 on the sale of discontinued operations. c-Net loss and includes a $73,000 loss from discontinued operations.

title: LA GUARDIA SHUTTLE SET BY PAN AM
description: The Pan Am Corporation said yesterday that it would begin shuttle flights from La Guardia Airport to Washington and Boston on Oct. 1. It is entering the routes by buying slots and gates from the Texas Air Corporation for $65 million.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in some copies of Metropolitan Report yesterday about Mayor Koch's plans to attend a dinner honoring Representative Ronald V. Dellums of California misstated the source for remarks by Mr. Koch. It was in the book ''I, Koch'' - not in his own book ''Mayor'' - that he was quoted as calling Mr. Dellums a ''Watusi prince'' and a ''Zulu warrior.'' Mr. Koch later said he meant the terms as compliments.

title: STATER BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
U.S. JUDGE, TERMING GOTTI 'DANGEROUS,' REVOKES BAIL
description: A Federal judge yesterday revoked the bail of John Gotti, the reputed head of the Gambino crime family, saying there was ''substantial evidence'' that Mr. Gotti ''would improperly influence or intimidate witnesses'' if he remained free.

title: COLONIAL COMMERCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $20,616 from the discontinued operations of Big Smith Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary.

title: Gifford Stays in Lineup
description: Frank Gifford, who was reportedly discussing a change from ABC-TV to another network, will stay with ABC and continue on ''Monday Night Football'' as a color commentator, the network said yesterday. Dennis Swanson, president of ABC Sports, said Gifford would team with Al Michaels, who will do the play-by-play.

title: CABLE PAYMENT DELAYED WITHOUT STATE APPROVAL
description: Without state or city approval, the head of a publicly appointed community group in the Bronx authorized a cable television company to delay about $600,000 in payments for community programming in the borough, according to state records.

title: U.S. NUCLEAR FOES DEBATE STRATEGY
description: The accident at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant has provoked questions about strategy in the antinuclear movement in the United States, its leaders say, spurring both renewed public concern over the dangers of nuclear weapons and heightened suspicion of the Soviet Union.

title: PHILADELPHIA BOMBING: CLASH IS RECALLED
description: For a year, this city has been trying to put the disaster behind it. But today was a day of remembrance for all the victims of the deadly confrontation between the police and the radical group Move.

title: SCREEN: ALAN ALDA'S 'SWEET LIBERTY'
description: ALAN ALDA'S talent as a writer-director-star is also his Achilles heel: he's nice.

title: WESTERN EUROPE LEADS IN ARMS SALES, REPORT SAYS
description: Western European nations have significantly increased their share of arms sales to developing countries and sold more arms to these countries in 1985 than the United States or the Soviet Union, according to a Congressional report.

title: GIBSON 'VICTORY' PARTY IS STUNNED INTO SILENCE
description: What was to have been a victory celebration ended in stunned silence here tonight as Kenneth A. Gibson's supporters reflected on the Mayor's surprise defeat after 16 years in office.

title: ARBITRAGERS MAY FACE SCRUTINY
description: Wall Street arbitragers may soon be drawn into an investigation of the trading activities of Dennis B. Levine, a former senior merger executive with the investment house of Drexel Burnham Lambert who has been accused of insider trading, Wall Street sources speculated yesterday.

title: Anitec Image Plan
description: The Anitec Image Technology Corporation said it had tentatively agreed to acquire substantially all the assets of Allied-Signal Inc.'s Sinclair and Valentine division for undisclosed terms. Anitec, which has annual sales of about $120 million, said Sinclair and Valentine, maker of printing ink, has annual sales of about $170 million.

title: INVACARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Letter: On Arms Control; Let's Not Undercut SALT II
description: To the Editor:

title: Dow Slips 1.99 Amid Light Trading
description: Still wrestling with the outlook for interest rates and oil prices, the stock market continued its downturn yesterday as prices sagged a bit for the second consecutive day of light trading.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Workers recently removed the floor covering in my kitchen. They used power sanders, and dust was scattered through the house. I was alarmed to find that the flooring contained asbestos, and apparently the workers failed to follow safe removal and disposal techniques. What can I do about this mess? A. The asbestos dust might or might not be a hazard, depending on whether it has all been cleaned up. It is hard to know for sure without testing the air (asbestos fibers are hazardous only if inhaled). Special contractors handle this work, and in many communities laboratories will test the air. Local health authorities may be able to help you find a lab, or consult the Yellow Pages. More information is available through the Consumer Product Safety Commission at 800-638-2772 or the Environmental Protection Agency at 800-424-9065. Q. In 1979 I installed a cypress fence around my pool, and now a fungus-type growth is appearing on some of the one-by-six boards. In addition, tunnels apparently caused by termites are on the outside of some of the four-by-four posts. I have been told to treat and seal the wood. What do you recommend? A. Wash the fungus off with a mildewcide or a solution of one part liquid laundry bleach to five parts water. Scrub on, let dry on the surface and remove with detergent solution. Treat with clear wood preservative, covering all sides and edges.

title: WASHINGTON REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Need Services? Try Common Law
description: The provision of services in our cities is a highly visible measure of the nation's commitment to equality. A poor neighborhood lacks adequate police protection. The telephone repair person won't venture into the ghetto. The garbage isn't picked up in the barrio. Not only do these indignities make life less safe or less comfortable for the inhabitants, but also they convey the notion that no one cares about them. The failure of many municipalities to provide adequate facilities to their poorest residents is a social condition with a long, inglorious history, emblazoned on our collective consciousness by the metaphor ''the wrong side of the tracks.''

CONCERT: THE CLEVELAND ORCHESTRA
description: MOST of Mahler's music was an insoluble riddle to his contemporaries and it is clear now why it continued to baffle and irritate audiences well into our own time. His ''Knaben Wunderhorn'' songs, for instance, speak the language of 19th-century Romanticism, but they are a sardonic and often bitter commentary on the assumptions underlying the Middle European culture that produced that rich musical idiom. He was a composer torn between a love for the Romanticism in which he grew up and a need to expose what he discerned as its lies and deceptions.

title: BAY PACIFIC HEALTH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

WORKING AT HOME;
TODAY'S CHALLENGE: PUTTING WORK OFF
description: IN the 40 years that my apartment had been occupied by previous tenants, nobody had found it necessary to remove the paint drippings from the brass doorknobs. This told me something: none of them worked at home. Those were the kinds of things that made it impossible for me to meet a deadline. Who could work in such a disaster area? Not until I stank up the apartment with paint remover and scraped off every last dribble of dusty rose semigloss from the 20 knobs could I even think about working. Not until I'd replaced the plants killed by the fumes could I approach my desk.

title: HERS
description: A FEW weeks ago, the television show ''20/ 20'' ran a report on violence against homosexuals. It's on the rise now that AIDS can be used as an excuse. title: CAGNEY-ERA BAD GUYS: MEMORIES OF INNOCENCE
description: IT is the common fate of celebrities to receive excessive attention during their careers and to be instantly forgotten upon their retirements, as press and television turn to other faces. But there are a few who have found their way so deeply into our lives that we can no more discard them than we can rid ourselves of our own pasts. Weeks after James Cagney's death and all the deserved appreciations, he remains in my thoughts and, I suspect, those of others of a generation that grew up with movies in the 1930's. He was one of a handful of stars who gave form to our imaginations, helped us think about our country in a certain way and became part of enduring childhood experiences.

title: DEAD ENDS FAIL TO DISCOURAGE SWEDE SEEKING PALME'S KILLER
description: By today, the 74th day of the investigation into the murder of Prime Minister Olof Palme, who was gunned down here on his way home from the movies with his wife, police investigators had fed 23,272 separate documents into the computer they are using to collate a constantly expanding mass of information.

title: Petrie-Lerner

title: New Mount St. Helens Lava
description: Scientists who entered the crater of Mount St. Helens for the first time in nearly a week confirmed today that new lava had reached the top of the 800-foot-high dome of the volcano. After 10 months of quiet, seismic activity began there April 16.

title: AFTER 16 YEARS, A BITTER CHANGING OF THE GUARD IN NEWARK
description: Sixteen years ago, Janice Thomas was one of the ''Gibson Girls,'' the young women who rang doorbells, stuffed envelopes and carried banners in the mayoral campaign of an engineer named Kenneth A. Gibson. Today, Miss Thomas sat in the glass-strewn parking lot of her housing project here and talked in terms of betrayal about the man she had once helped elect.

title: U.S. LENDS TO EQUADOR IN FIRST OIL-SLUMP AID

title: A SUBSTITUTE FOR BONE MARROW
description: Six of the desperately ill victims of radiation poisoning from the Chernobyl nuclear accident in the Soviet Union were given fetal liver tissue rather than bone-marrow transplants, American doctors in Moscow disclosed yesterday.

title: Hockey TV War Is Brewing Again
description: A year and a half after the National Hockey League worked out a lucrative truce between rival breweries over Canadian network television rights, hockey's great beer war appears to be foaming up once again, this time over local rights. And unless league, brewery and television executives can resolve the new dispute at a meeting in Toronto today, Canadian viewers may be deprived next season of one of the nation's two weekly hockey telecasts.

title: GORBACHEV, ON TV, DEFENDS HANDLING OF ATOM DISASTER
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev publicly discussed the Chernobyl disaster for the first time today, telling the Soviet people that the accident had shown the ''sinister force'' of nuclear energy gone out of control.

title: Canada Says It Hired Lobbyist in Innocence
description: Canada did not knowingly break United States laws by hiring Michael K. Deaver as a lobbyist after he left as White House deputy chief of staff, Joe Clark, the External Affairs Minister, said today.

title: A COTTAGE INDUSTRY IN A NEW YORK CITY LOFT
description: FOR city dwellers, a home office usually comes as an afterthought. A desk, a phone, a computer and some files are squeezed into a small space - a former maid's or child's room, perhaps, or a bedroom corner. Rare is a work space designed at the same time as other rooms and rarer still is much thought given to integrating the privacy, comfort and efficiency needed to have work and home under the same roof.

title: JUSTICE DEPARTMENT PANEL SEEKS WIDE LEGAL ATTACK ON OBSCENITY
description: The Attorney General's Commission on Pornography, calling for a reversal in the nation's law-enforcement priorities, has recommended widespread prosecution of the distributors of obscenity.

title:
IF THE AUSTRIANS ELECT WALDHEIM;
(1) Bar Him From U.S.
description: How should the Reagan Administration respond to the fact that 2.343 million Austrians -49.6 percent of the voters - have virtually assured Kurt Waldheim's election as president in a runoff vote?

title: IRVINE SENSORS CORP reports earnings for 13wks to March 30
description: b-Net income

title: SALMON SALES TAX: IS TRIBE EXEMPT?
description: A test of strength is building between the 3,200-member Lummi Indian Tribe and the Internal Revenue Service over whether the Indian fishermen must pay income taxes on sales of salmon they catch from Puget Sound.

title: KEAN TELLS BARNARD ALUMNAE TO CONSIDER ENTERING POLITICS
description: Governor Kean urged the 94th graduating class of Barnard College yesterday to complete the ''unfinished agenda'' of the feminist movement by pursuing careers in elective politics, which he called ''the last male bastion.''

title: Pulitzer to Buy Back Stock
description: In an apparent resolution of a family battle, the Pulitzer Publishing Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy out the holdings of four dissident shareholders.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BALTIMORE (AL) - Placed Jackie Gutierrez, shortstop, on the the 15-day disabled retro-active to May 12. Recalled Rex Hudler, infielder, from Rochester of the International League.

title: VERSATILITY OF CASTERS
description: CASTERS have many uses around the home. Made for tea carts, planters, tables, couches, dollies, television carts and a host of other purposes, they attach to furniture legs, making them easier to move.

title: Found: Common Ground On Women Who Smoke
description: It is not often that Senators Edward M. Kennedy, the liberal Democrat of Massachusetts, and Orrin G. Hatch, the conservative Republican of Utah, find themselves on the same side of an issue.
