description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of 2 cents a share and 4 cents a share for latest quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss

title: Advertising; People
description: * Frank Savarese has been named a senior vice president of Dentsu Young & Rubicam, USA and Steven Nafelberg has been appointed vice president and media director of DYR, New York.

title: Plea on Farm Foreclosures
description: The House urged the Farm Credit System today to restructure problem loans wherever possible rather than foreclose.

title: LOCALS AT SECOND BASE
description: What do the two New York baseball teams have in common, aside from hopes of being occupied well into October? Both of them have that rare breed, a home-grown player operating at second base.

title: STATE PANEL CLEARS WAY FOR LILCO RATE INCREASE
description: The amount Long Islanders pay for their electricity is likely to double within 15 years if the Shoreham nuclear power plant goes into commercial operation, under a policy adopted yesterday by the State Public Service Commission.

title: Aviary in Utah Is Vandalized
description: Vandals broke into the Tracy Aviary and set fire to three birds, impaled two on a wooden stake and stole one, the authorities said today. The vandals also uprooted two saplings, bent three more, ripped up flower beds and threw a brick through a greenhouse window at Liberty Park on Monday night, officials said.

title: FINK TO GIVE UP POST AS SPEAKER OF ASSEMBLY TO WORK AS LAWYER
description: Stanley Fink, who as Assembly Speaker makes decisions directly and indirectly affecting millions of New Yorkers, announced today that he would not seek re-election to the Assembly.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, MAY 15, 1986
description: Companies

title: A Ban on Smoking
description: Starting today the Federal Merit Systems Protection Board is banning smoking throughout the agency.

title: A MESSAGE OF HOPE FOR THE FAITHFUL
description: He may never have to sell another ticket as long as he lives. Those 59,075 who fill Notre Dame Stadium on autumn Saturdays make up congregations, not crowds, and the ticket-holders are parishioners.

title: GIBSON SURPRISED BY BIG LOSS AT POLLS, BUT OTHERS SAY THEY SAW IT COMING
description: While Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson said today he did not want to speculate about the reasons for his loss to Sharpe James, other politicians said the signs were there.

title: Popes and the Jews: After the Blessing
description: To the Editor:

title: BUDGET WILL PASS, HOUSE LEADERS SAY
description: As the House of Representatives began debate today on its Budget Committee's proposal for 1987 spending, the leadership predicted passage Thursday, but by a narrow margin.

title: TEXAS INTERNATIONAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income Year-ago results were restated to reflect a $6.7 million refund to the company on the windfall profits tax on oil.

title: Pacific Stereo
description: Pacific Stereo, once the nation's largest chain of stereo discount stores, said it had filed a Chapter 11 petition in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Oakland, Calif.

title: 3 OTHERS DIE
description: Three teen-age climbers, found nearly frozen, died today and eight others in their party were missing after they were trapped by a snowstorm Tuesday near the summit of Mount Hood.

title: 2 KOREAN FILM FIGURES TELL OF ABDUCTION TO NORTH
description: A couple who are leading figures in the South Koean movie world and who disappeared into North Korea under mysterious circumstances eight years ago emerged here today and said they had been kidnapped on the direct orders of the son of President Kim Il Sung of North Korea.

title: PROPERTY TRUST OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
UNIROYAL WILL SELL CHEMICAL BUSINESS
description: Uniroyal Inc., a major force in the tire and rubber industry, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its profitable Uniroyal Chemical Company subsidiary to Avery Inc., a holding company with interests in coal, for $760 million.

title: Waterborne Firefighters
description: Seventeen New York City firefighters, squeezed into a slim craft with a dragon head at its bow, paddled furiously out into the harbor yesterday trying to get to Hong Kong.

title: Advertising; Agency's Focus Is On Cable
description: LAWRENCE AND ELEANOR BUTNER, partners in marriage and in advertising, think they are the biggest advertising users of cable television. Their agency, Lawrence Butner Advertising, billing $20 million, is in direct marketing, mostly in subscription solicitation for publications, and has been using cable since 1979, when the agency first used Ted Turner's WTBS superstation.

title: PREFERRED FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FEARING CONFLICT, HOSPITALS CHIEF MAY STEP ASIDE ON CONTRACT
description: The city's top hospital official said yesterday that he was considering excusing himself from any role in a major city contract with the New York University Medical Center, where his wife works as an administrator.

description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: C.D., Fund Yields Off
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were down slightly for the week ended yesterday. However, there are signs that the 10-week decline is stalling.

title: Proxmire and the Siberians
description: Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, is expected to take to the Senate floor today with a demand that Donald A. Hicks, the Under Secretary of Defense for Research and Engineering, ''be fired forthwith'' for remarks suggesting that he might withhold Government research grants from scientists who oppose the Administration's plan for a shield against long-range missiles.

title: Back Pay Is Awarded To Female Firefighters
description: A Federal judge ordered the city yesterday to give back pay and seniority credit to up to 46 female firefighters who were victims of discrimination.

title: UNION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $1,039,000, or 13 cents a share, and $2,237,000, or 31 cents a share, for latest quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Reflects a loss of $709,000 attributable to operations discontinued or disposed of under the company's asset redeployment plan. d-Net loss reflecting a loss of $14.1 million attributable to operations discontinued or disposed of under the company's asset redeployment plan. Latest quarter and 9 months figures include results for Transworld Systems Inc., acquired in July.

title: Tax Reform Is Worth Your I.R.A.
description: Individual Retirement Accounts have become Everyman's tax shelter and Everyman seems pretty upset that the Senate Finance Committee wants to take most of them away. Though I.R.A.'s in their current generous form have been available for only five years, you'd think from all the immediate protests that they were inscribed in the Bill of Rights. They are, and should be, fair targets of serious tax reform.

title: Surgery for Ridley
description: Mike Ridley, the Rangers' rookie center who led the team in scoring with 22 goals and 43 assists for 65 points, is scheduled to undergo arthroscopic surgery tomorrow at Lenox Hill Hospital to repair torn cartilage in his left knee. He is the first rookie free agent out of college to lead an N.H.L. team in scoring. . . . Herb Brooks, former coach of the Rangers, has withdrawn as a candidate for the coaching job with the Winnipeg Jets.

title: Bridge: Granovetter and Rosenberg Win Second Event in Week
description: Some contestants win by an inch and some by a mile but very few do both within the space of three days.

title: Dow, Up 22.94, Outpaces the Market
description: An abnormally sharp rise in a handful of blue-chip stocks gave Wall Street what appeared to be a substantial rally yesterday, but over all the market was only slightly higher and trading activity remained depressed.

title: MacArthur Foundation Names New Chairman
description: Thornton F. Bradshaw, chairman of the RCA Corporation, has been named board chairman of the MacArthur Foundation of Chicago, one of the country's wealthiest private philanthropies.

title: WHAT TO BUY: CLONE OR SECONDHAND?
description: MOST consumer products have a resale market, and personal computers for home offices have been around long enough now for there to be a market for them, too. More and more people are asking, ''Does it pay to buy a previously owned machine?''

title: Simpson Not in Lineup
description: ABC Sports has announced its broadcasting lineup for this fall's college football games and O. J. Simpson was not in it.

title: Brooklyn Union Names New Chief
description: Elwin S. Larson, the president of Brooklyn Union Gas and an employee of the natural gas utility for 39 years, is adding the title of chief executive, the company said yesterday.

title: Thrown for a Loss
description: The offensive tackle Gary Zimmerman, trying to free himself from United States Football League obligations, has lost his bid to attend the Minnesota Vikings' minicamp this week.

title: Comdisco Delay
description: Comdisco Inc., a computer manufacturer based in Rosemont, Ill., said it has temporarily postponed a $250 million offering of convertible subordinated debentures because its common stock price has declined.

title: RESOURCE EXPLORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
LEBANESE REPORT ISRAELI TANK BUILDUP
description: Israel has sent a large number of tanks into a zone under its control in southern Lebanon, apparently to counter what was described as redeployment of Syrian forces in Lebanon's eastern Bekaa region, Lebanese radio and television reports said today. [ There was no confirmation of the reported tank deployments from Israeli officials. ] The Lebanese radio and television reports said as many as 50 Israeli tanks escorted by helicopter gunships had taken up positions in the Arkub region on the slopes of Mount Hermon.

description: The Kurt Waldheim case has raised a series of unanswered questions, including why the documents detailing his military record in the Balkans have been made public only piecemeal since the beginning of March, when the first disclosures were made.

title: Money Milestone
description: JoAnne Carner is taking the weekend off, but Pat Bradley, who's even closer to becoming the first female golfer to a mass $2 million in career earnings, can reach that plateau by Sunday. All she needs is to finish no worse than a lone 14th in the Chrysler-Plymouth Classic, which begins tomorrow in Chatham, N.J. The players (and their number of years on tour) with the fattest career bankrolls in L.P.G.A. history:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: 'FEMMES' EXHIBIT Herbert Gentry saw Europe during World War II when he served in a United States Army artillery and antiaircraft regiment. Afterward, he came home to New York, got out of the Army, enrolled in New York University and decided to head back to France. He continued his art studies there, and was part of the fabric of post-World War II Parisian intellectual and artistic life. He later moved to Sweden, now his primary residence.

title: BISHOP GRAPHICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TAX BILL'S MAIN THRUST SEEMS INTACT
description: Key senators and many lobbyists said today that they expect the Senate to make changes in the Finance Committee's tax-revision bill but to approve intact its fundamental approach.

title: SENATE VOTES CURB ON MAILING COSTS
description: The Senate voted unanimously today to limit the amount of free mailing available to its members, the first restriction on the frank in this century.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Patents column of Business Day on Saturday about the use of ibogaine to fight drug addiction misstated the preferred means of administering it. The chemical should be taken orally - but not by injection, which greatly increases its toxicity, or through the nose, which would be ineffective.

title: KAPOK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss c-Net income and after income from the sale of land of $4,593,000.

title: BELUGA WHALE CALLED B.W. SHOT TO DEATH
description: A young 10-foot female beluga whale, whose friendliness had fascinated people as she swam off the coast of Connecticut over the last 14 months, has been found shot to death in New Haven Harbor.

title: YONKERS AGREES ON PLAN FOR INTEGRATING SCHOOLS
description: The Yonkers Board of Education agreed today to a compromise school desegregation plan that defers some mandatory measures while voluntary efforts are given a chance to work.

title: Kodak Staff Cuts
description: The Eastman Kodak Company told shareholders at its annual meeting that its United States work force had been cut by 6,000 workers as of the beginning of May. It said the move was part of a program to cut the number of employees by 10 percent. The move will reduce Kodak's 1986 earnings by 60 cents a share, but the company said it would save $400 million a year as a result of the staff reduction.

title: Magazine Buyer Sought
description: The Network Publishing Corporation, publisher of Soap Opera Digest, has been put up for sale by The Providence Journal.

title: GARAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FOOTBALL TRIAL TO HEAR ROZELLE
description: Opposing attorneys painted vastly different pictures of professional football yesterday in opening statements to the jury in the United States Football League's antitrust case against the National Football League.

title: Prudential-Macy's Mortgage Deal
description: The Prudential Insurance Company of America said it had agreed to provide $800 million of mortgage financing to R. H. Macy & Company for the buyout by Macy's management and other investors of the retail company. Prudential said its mortgages covering Macy's 71 stores represented most of the real estate financing needed for the transaction.

WOOLWORTH, F W CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Share earnings were adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split to be distributed on May 30.

title: POWER CONVERSION INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Fewer Sears Jobs
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's largest retailer, will need 800 fewer employees this year because it is closing four regional offices, the company's chairman, Edward A. Brennan, said at the annual meeting. Mr. Brennan said the offices to be closed on June 30 are in Philadelphia, Atlanta, Los Angeles and Skokie, Ill.

title: Tax Amnesty In Senate Bill
description: Despite opposition in the Internal Revenue Service, the Senate Finance Committee has slipped into its big tax-overhaul bill a provision authorizing criminal amnesty for tax evaders who confess before they are caught.

title: U.S. Fast Food in China
description: The Kentucky Fried Chicken Corporation says it will become the first American fast-food company in China. It plans to set up a joint venture with a Chinese enterprise to open outlets in Peking.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Chicago White Sox, at Yankee Stadium, 7:35 P.M. Ron Guidry is scheduled to face Neil Allen. (Television - Channel 11, 7:30 P.M. Radio -WABC, 770; 7:30 P.M.) Mets vs.

title: Moynihan Is Seeking to End U.N. Pension for Waldheim
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, New York Democrat, today introduced a resolution in the Senate that urges the United Nations to strip former Secretary General Kurt Waldheim of his $81,650 annual pension.

title: Helms and the Chinese
description: On his recent visit to China, Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d negotiated an agreement that apparently resolves Senator Jesse Helms's objections to a tax treaty between the United States and China.

title: ACME PRECISION PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,842,540 on the sale of property plant and equipment. c-Net loss

title: BATTLE OF ELLIS I.: A PEACE PLAN FROM IACOCCA
description: Lee A. Iacocca said yesterday that a proposed redevelopment plan for Ellis Island, which he vehemently denounced four months ago, could work if it is stripped of what he considered its overly commercial elements.

title: U.S. MILITARY STRATEGY VIEWED AS COSTLY IN STUDY
description: The Brookings Institution published a set of proposals today under which adjustments in Pentagon strategy would halt the growth in military spending over the next four years.

description: Following are excerpts from Mikhail S. Gorbachev's television address tonight on the Chernobyl nuclear accident, as distributed in translation by the Soviet press agency Tass:

title: Tug of War, With a Twist, On Secrets
description: Battles between Congress and the executive branch over access to national security information are nothing new. But there is something distinctly different about the current confrontation between the House Committee on Government Operations and Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger.

title: MSI ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

IF THE AUSTRIANS ELECT WALDHEIM;
(2) Old Bigotry Will Win
description: Kurt Waldheim just missed winning the Austrian Presidency earlier this month, but he got 49.6 percent of the vote even as he wrestled publicly with the specter of his Nazi past. Kurt Streyer, the Socialist candidate whom he will face in a runoff election in June, said that Mr. Waldheim was benefiting from a backlash effect. Backlash may be too polite a word for the Austrian reaction - the groundswell of support and sympathy and highly visible anti-Semitism - to the charges that Mr. Waldheim may have been involved in war crimes in Yugoslavia and Greece.

title: PROFESSIONAL CARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company recently changed its name from Health Extension Services Inc.

title: 4 SUBURBAN ENTREPRENEURS TOTE UP PLUSES AND MINUSES
description: UNTIL a few years ago, it was common for tree-shaded suburban streets to slip into a siestalike silence in the middle of the day. Children were at school, mothers were shopping, fathers were at work and dogs were indoors. People making deliveries and service calls knew to call ahead to see if someone would be home.

title: TRACKING DOWN HARDY PERENNIALS
description: THE interest in gardening in America is clearly on the upswing, and at the moment the hot item seems to be perennials. People whose horticultural imaginations a few seasons ago barely strayed beyond planting a few annuals such as impatiens or marigolds are now turning to hostas lysimachias, sedums and other herbaceous plants that can be counted on to return year after year.

title: ALLIED PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $1,991,000.

title: SAXON OIL DEVELOPMENT PARTNERS LP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Walkathon
description: The girls' softball team at Carrollton (Ohio) High School has just completed its seventh straight winning season since Coach Tom Spiker started the program in 1980. This time the Warriors did it in a walk, if not with ease.

title: TAX MOVE BY CUOMO
description: Governor Cuomo has asked his economic advisers to propose changes in New York's tax code to keep state income taxes from rising automatically if Federal tax revision becomes law.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Food & Fitness column in The Living Section yesterday warned incorrectly about the consumption of fatty fish. Fish, both fatty and lean, from waters that may be chemically contaminated - mackerel, for example, or eel caught in northeastern New Jersey or eel and trout caught in New York State - should be eaten no more than once a month. Salmon and most other fatty fish pose no problem.

title: Senate Panel Votes Cut For Embassy Security
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted deep cuts today in the Reagan Administration's budget request for enhanced security at American embassies.

title: Harcourt's Theme Park
description: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. has closed Circus World, which it bought for $18 million, and plans to reopen it in December with a baseball theme. The 847-acre park near Haines City, Fla., will get a $7 million face lift, the publishing company said. Attendance at Circus World had dwindled.

title: Advertising; Westgate Labs
description: Penchina, Selkowitz has been named the agency for Westgate Laboratories of Edison, N.J., a new company started by former Estee Lauder employees, and headed by Jerold Dreskin.

title: OSHAP TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: All figures were converted from Belgian francs at the rate of 48.07 francs equals $1.

title: A Poised Command
description: President Corazon Aquino argues for time and patience from critics who complain that she hasn't yet started to move her country toward economic recovery. She has a point; she is entering her 12th week in office. But there is a more important, unspoken argument. It is also a good idea not to plunge too fast because that is the way to sort out bad ideas and to avoid mistakes.

title: Legislators Back Plan To Pump Great Salt Lake
description: Utah's Legislature today approved a $55 million plan to pump floodwaters from the Great Salt Lake into the western desert.

title: THEATER: SPALDING GRAY
description: HAVING defined the performance art form of the autobiographical monologue, Spalding Gray has moved deeper into theatrical creativity. ''Swimming to Cambodia,'' his two-part rumination on his role in the film ''The Killing Fields,'' was an insider's report on the battle between illusion and reality. His new monologue, ''Terrors of Pleasure,'' is a hilarious tale of his harrowing quest for home ownership, a milestone on the perilous road to becoming a grown-up.

title: Kangaroo Havoc
description: To the Editor:

title: FLAMES ADVANCE TO STANLEY CUP FINAL
description: Al MacInnis and Colin Patterson scored goals, and Mike Vernon, the rookie goaltender, made 17 saves tonight to send the Calgary Flames into the Stanley Cup final with a 2-1 victory over the St. Louis Blues.

description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $273,000. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $410,000. Year-ago figures reflect an accounting change.

title: REUTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MAYOR-ELECT WITH WINNING MANNER
description: To his family, friends and colleagues, Sharpe James, the veteran City Councilman who confounded some political experts Tuesday by winning the mayoral election here, is a man who knows what he wants and goes after it.

title: PANEL SAID TO ASK TIGHTER CONTROLS ON NASA DECISIONS
description: The commission investigating the Challenger disaster will urge President Reagan to make changes in launching procedures to insure that warnings about severe dangers are brought to the attention of top space agency officials, Administration officials said today.

title: BENNY GOODMAN HAILED BY COLUMBIA GRADUATES
description: With an outpouring of affection for Benny Goodman and an array of balloons floating in a blue sky, 7,161 students graduated yesterday at the Columbia University commencement.

title: TODAY'S HEADLINE, TOMORROW'S BOOK
description: Even as American bombs were falling on Tripoli, Libya in retaliation for terrorist incidents, Farrar Straus & Giroux was shipping to bookstores copies of ''Terrorism: How the West Can Win'' by Benjamin Netanyahu. Within hours of the raid the author, the representative of Israel to the United Nations, was in great demand on network television and radio interview shows, and the book is now in its second printing.

title: Imported Oil Demand Up
description: Demand for imported oil rose again last month while domestic production fell, as low world oil prices continued to make their impact felt on the American market, the Amerian Petroleum Institute said today.

title: GENERAL METAL & ABRASIVES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
New Challenge for Newark
description: Newark voters' surprising rejection of Kenneth Gibson and election of Sharpe James as Mayor ends a 16-year chapter in their troubled city's political history and creates a climate of possibility and hope. Delivering on those hopes is Mr. James's challenge, and it will require a burst of imaginative leadership to reverse the prolonged decline that Mr. Gibson proved unable to reverse.

title: AMES DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 26
Thrift Inquiry On Property
description: The Financial Corporation of America, the nation's second-largest thrift holding company, says some of its officers bought foreclosed real estate from the company at discount prices.

title: Andretti Is Injured
description: Mario Andretti, the 46-year-old race driver who won the Indianapolis 500 in 1969, yesterday suffered bruised knees and a cut to the inside of his left heel in a crash during a practice run for the May 25 race at the Indianapolis Speedway. He was taken to Methodist Hospital for X-rays, which proved negative, and then released.

title: RB INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a charge of $342,000 from the reversal of a tax credit. c-Includes a tax credit of $25,000. d-Net loss and includes a gain of $251,000 from the early extinguishment of debt and a charge of $2,262,000 from the cumulative effect of change in accounting method.

title: ATHENS REPORTER FILES LIBEL SUIT IN '83 DISPUTE
description: A reporter here filed a libel suit today against the publisher of Greece's largest newspaper, a week after the Athens prosecutor charged the journalist with threatening terrorist acts against the paper.

title: YANKEES LOSE IN NINTH
description: Bob Shirley started for the Yankees April 26 because Ed Whitson had a stomach ache and a sore rib. He started May 2 because John Montefusco had sore ribs. When Shirley started for the third time last night, no one had a sore thumb or a stomach ache. When the game was over, however, the Yankees had a collective headache, although it had little to do with Shirley.

title: OFFICELAND INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Air Raid Alerts in Nicaragua
description: Nicaragua will carry out air raid alerts in Managua on Thursday, Friday and Monday as a precaution against an air attack, an official statement said today. The statement by the civil defense authorities said the exercise would be aimed at teaching citizens the difference between various warning signals if foreign aircraft attacked the capital. The Sandinista Government has long said that the United States would attack Nicaragua once it realized the rebels could not overthrow the Sandinistas.

title: Pianist in Benefit Recital
description: The pianist Richard Goode will give a benefit recital tonight at 6 P.M. at Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street.

description: b-Includes tax credits of $122,000 and $115,000 for latest and year-ago quarters, respectively.

title: INVENTORIES MOUNT AS SALES DROP
description: Sales by businesses fell 1.6 percent in March, the third monthly decline in a row, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: VOODOO UNDER ATTACK IN POST-DUVALIER HAITI
description: Thirteen voodoo priests appeared at mass here on a recent Sunday morning and, before the altar of St. Helen's Church, recanted their belief in African spirits and proclaimed their faith in Christianity.

title: Reduce the Pork in Davis-Bacon
description: Do workers on federally funded construction projects need special protection against exploitation? Congress thought they did in 1931, when blacks were flooding North in desperate search of jobs. That was half a century ago. Today, the Davis-Bacon Act, requiring Federal contractors to pay ''prevailing wages,'' has turned into an expensive joke on the taxpayer. The Reagan Administration won't support repeal; it owes too much to the building trades. But finally, it has at least expressed support for limiting the reach of the act.
