title: EDUCATION CHIEF DEPLORES CAMPUS RADICALISM
description: Education Secretary William J. Bennett says he believes that a ''significant body of opinion'' has developed on college campuses in recent years that openly ''rejects the democratic ethic.''

title: UNITED MERCHANTS & MANUACTURING INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $3,525,000 and an extraordinary gain of $285,000 for latest quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net income and includes an extraordinary charge of $742,000 and an extraordinary gain of $1,823,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The latest 9-month results include the operations of the Jonathan Logan division acquired in fiscal 1985 for the entire period as compared to last year's first 9 months which included Logan's operations from Sept. 1 only. The company said that effective Jan. 31, it sold its investment in its Venezuelan operations to affiliates of the local management for a total consideration of $43 million. The loss for the latest quarter and 9 months includes a non-recurring, non- cash charge of $7,439,000 as a result of the sale, and does not reflect the total benefit expected to be realized as a result of the planned debt reduction with the cash proceeds from the sale.

title: NICARAGUA SEEKS PEACE PLAN CHANGE
description: Defense Minister Humberto Ortega Saavedra accused the Reagan Administration today of using the regional Contadora peace talks as a vehicle to isolate Nicaragua.

title: Solomon Blatt, 91, Legislator In South Carolina Since 1933
description: State Representative Solomon Blatt, honored as the country's longest-serving state legislator, died today at the age of 91. Mr. Blatt, who was Speaker Emeritus, had served in the House for more than half a century.

title: Former Colleagues Split In Battle for Leaseway
description: Six years ago William J. O'Neill Jr. and Gerald C. McDonough began working together as managers of the Leaseway Transportation Company in a relationship they describe as ''cordial.''

title: ADVERTISERS ENCOURAGED BY ABC'S FALL LINEUP
description: Madison Avenue advertisers and executives who buy advertising time for major corporations reacted favorably yesterday to ABC's new fall lineup, and predicted the first programming created since Capital Cities Communications Inc. took over the network would lift its sagging advertising base.

title: Bronx Girl, 7, Attacked While Walking Home
description: A 7-year-old Bronx girl was abducted as she walked alone on the street near her elementary school Monday afternoon by a man who drove her to a quiet street nearby and apparently raped her, the police said yesterday.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York and American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE AMERICAN CAPITAL MANAGEMENT & RESEARCH INC.

title: ARK RESTAURANTS reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
U.S. VOICES CAUTION ON LINKING SYRIANS TO TERRORIST ACTS
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it was ''premature'' to draw any conclusions about Syrian complicity in recent terrorist activities.

title: PIZZA INN INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Puffing at City Hall
description: Paul R. Screvane, a former City Council President and Sanitation Commissioner, puffed away on a cigarette yesterday at City Hall.

title: Note and Bond Prices Slump
description: Treasury note and bond prices slumped yesterday, reversing most of the previous day's gains.

title: GOTTSCHALKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: b-Net loss

title: GETTING THE MESSAGE
description: For someone who works at home, without the support of a secretary or receptionist, a phone-answering machine is essential. In the few years that the machines have been on the market, they have evolved from simple message-takers to units with a dazzling variety of features.

title: OWNER OF SPORTS FRANCHISES
description: John F. Bassett, whose efforts to build successful franchises in the United States Football League, the World Football League and the World Hockey Association never materialized, died today at Toronto General Hospital after a long struggle with cancer. He was 47 years old and had been undergoing treatment for brain tumors for two years.

title: CONTROL RESOURCE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
RADICAL SURGE ON CAMPUSES SHAKES SEOUL
description: A surge of campus radicalism, much of it anti-American in tone, has caused deep concern among both Government officials and opposition politicians who worry that the students may be beyond their control.

title: Amoco Oil Sets Cuts in 5 States
description: The Amoco Oil Company, one of the nation's largest gasoline marketers, said today that it was discontinuing its dealer and wholesale marketing operations in Massachusetts, Rhode Island, Texas, Louisiana and parts of Connecticut.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary on April 23 of John J. McCloskey, who in 1942 became New York's first citywide sheriff, misstated his ranking on a Civil Service examination. It was Arthur J. Benline, the Manhattan Superintendent of Housing and Buildings, not Mr. McCloskey, who scored highest on the exam. Mr. McCloskey was second.

title: A MASTER OF CERAMICS, PAST AND PRESENT
description: OTTO NATZLER, one of the best-known American ceramists of the 20th century, is having his first one-man show in New York in more than 15 years.

title: AW COMPUTER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
38 STUDIES JOINED TO MAKE HALLEY'S LESS OF A PUZZLE
description: In the first detailed accounts of what was observed when a succession of five spacecraft flew past Halley's comet in March, participating scientists report findings that confirm earlier speculative observations and add new details to scientific understanding of a celestial body that was almost entirely mysterious three months ago.

title: U.S.-CANADA PACT ON NIAGARA IS SET
description: The United States and Canada agreed today to work for ''significant reductions'' in the contamination of the Niagara River by toxic chemicals.

title: NASA UNVEILS PLAN FOR SPACE STATION
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration unveiled a blueprint today for the $8 billion manned space station it plans to assemble in orbit in the 1990's with help from Japan, Europe and Canada.

title: FOR JULY 4, A QE2-SIZE BASH
description: The Fourth of July flotilla in New York Harbor will include every manner of boat imaginable. There will be canoes, yachts, ferryboats, motorboats, naval gunboats, even an aircraft carrier - 40,000 vessels in all.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, MAY 15, 1986
description: International Mikhail S. Gorbachev said Chernobyl had shown the ''sinister force'' of nuclear energy going out of control. Publicly discussing the disaster for the first time, the Soviet leader offered in a television speech a four-point plan for prompt international exchanges of information on nuclear power accidents, and he announced that he was extending the Soviet Union's halt of nuclear weapon testing until Aug. 6. [ Page A1, Column 6. ]

title: U.S. DOCTORS IN SOVIET FACE A 'BATTLEFIELD'
description: For the last two weeks, Moscow Hospital No. 6, a nine-story brown-brick building on the outskirts of the city, has been the center of a desperate effort to treat the most seriously afflicted victims of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster.

title: SOUTHERN UNION CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CORRECTION
description: An article on Tuesday about Americans who work at home referred incorrectly to Kathleen E. Christensen, director of the National Project on Home-Based Work. As the holder of a doctorate in psychology, she should have been referred to as Dr. Christensen.

title: Four People Indicted In Arms Smuggling Case
description: A Federal grand jury has indicted four people for conspiring to smuggle 3,800 anti-tank missiles from the United States to Iran and Iraq, officials said. The indictment, the result of an undercover operation, was unsealed after the arrest of the two principal defendants, Gil Silva and Zevy Reiss.

title: LEVITT CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MUSIC: 'SOLDIER'S TALE'
description: IT was in 1967 that the puppeteer Bil Baird first presented his version of ''The Soldier's Tale'' by Igor Stravinsky. In 1982 and 1983, it cropped up at the 92d Street Y, and from Saturday through last night, the Y repeated this popular production, coupling it with a puppetless performance of Camille Saint-Saens's ''Carnival of the Animals.''

title: SELECTING THE PROPER DEVICE TO LET COMPUTERS CONFER
description: THE computer in the home cannot be isolated from its electronic kin if it is to be an extension of the business computer in the office.

title: Empire Savings
description: Empire of America Federal Savings Bank, the 13th-largest thrift institution in the country, with assets of $8.5 billion, announced plans to convert from mutual ownership to a shareholder-owned savings bank. The bank, based in Buffalo, expects to raise about $150 million through the sale of 15 million shares at $10 a share, but does not expect to use major Wall Street firms to underwrite the sale of stock.

title: SBARRO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SOVIET SPY JURY IS TOLD OF RECRUITING EFFORTS
description: The daughter and older brother of John A. Walker Jr., who has admitting heading a Soviet spy ring, told a jury today of Mr. Walker's efforts to recruit them as spies.

title: Advertising; Fisher-Price Canada To Backer & Spielvogel
description: Backer & Spielvogel can now expect additional seven-figure billings from Fisher-Price Canada.

title: MODULAIRE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflect a l0 percent stock dividend paid in March 1986.

title: Boy, 1, Falls 4 Floors But Is Only Bruised
description: A 1-year-old boy fell four stories from a window in his mother's apartment in Harlem yesterday and suffered only minor injuries.

title: IRT PROPERTY CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $908,717 from the sale of property.

title: NOMINEE FOR SOCIAL SECURITY DEFENDS DECISIONS ON GRANTS
description: Dorcas R. Hardy, President Reagan's nominee for Commissioner of Social Security, said today that for five years she had tried to advance the goals of a ''conservative opportunity society'' but had met resistance from proponents of a ''liberal welfare state'' in the Department of Health and Human Services.

title: MAJOR REALTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NORRIS OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a $5 million provision for impairment in the value of oil and gas properties.

title: U.S. ATTACHE QUITS SOVIET AFTER CHARGE OF SPYING ACTIVITY
description: The Soviet Union announced today that it had expelled an American diplomat for espionage, saying that he had plotted with a Soviet citizen recruited by the Central Intelligence Agency. It was the second expulsion of an American diplomat in two months.

title: TNP ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $67,000 and $510,000 for latest quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes an extraordinary credit of $269,000 and an extraordinary gain of $1,203,000 for year-ago quarter and year, respectively.

title: ROUSE CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $62,000.

title: INSPIRATION RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $1.6 million from discontinued operations.

title: BRUCE, ROBERT INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Albany Loses a Good Man
description: Speaker Stanley Fink's decision to leave the Legislature is a stunning blow to New York State's government. An energetic, voluble, determined man who played to win every point, Mr. Fink has since 1979 managed to forge the individualistic members of the Democratic Assembly majority into a unified political force.

title: Choice Seat
description: Sam Vincent, the Boston Celtics' little-used first-round draft choice: ''You can't complain. Look at the whole picture. You could be at Cleveland.''

title: The U.N. Today: May 15, 1986
description: ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Social Committee - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. >TRUSTEESHIP COUNCIL Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: SENATE APPROVES DRUG EXPORT BILL
description: The Senate voted overwhelmingly today to allow the export of American-made drugs awaiting approval as safe and effective for domestic sale.

title: Massey-Ferguson
description: Massey-Ferguson Ltd. is changing its name to the Varity Corporation and expects to announce an acquisition soon, its chairman, Victor Rice, said. The name was changed to give Massey-Ferguson a new corporate identitiy, Mr. Rice said.

title: Nova Overtakes Corolla
description: Chevrolet's Nova has passed the Toyota Motor Corporation's look-alike Corolla in sales. In this year's first four months 45,979 Novas were sold, against 37,423 Corollas, Ed Lechtzin, a spokesman for the General Motors Corporation division, said today. The Nova is jointly produced by G.M. and Toyota at Fremont, Calif.

title: DEWEY ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: U.S. NAVY WARNS OFF IRANIAN VESSEL
description: A United States Navy ship came to the aid of an American merchant vessel in the Gulf of Oman Tuesday during an encounter between the freighter and an Iranian patrol boat, Pentagon officials said today.

title: SOUTH ATLANTIC FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes realized gains of $80,689 on life insurance investments and a tax credit of $361,288. c-Includes a tax credit of $19,000.

title: Fannie Mae Selling $10 Billion of Mortgages
description: The Federal National Mortgage Associaton, known as Fannie Mae, yesterday announced the first step toward selling about $10 billion of mortgages currently held in its portfolio.

title: Foes of Stroessner Rally in Paraguay
description: Leaders of Paraguay's banned opposition political front, addressing an independence day rally, called today for a nonviolent campaign to end 32 years of government by President Alfredo Stroessner.

title: QUAREX INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
Carbide Trims Metals Division
description: As part of a year-old plan to divest itself of most of its metals operations, the Union Carbide Corporation said it had agreed to sell its domestic tungsten and worldwide vanadium businesses to an employee group led by William G. Beattie, a former vice president of Umetco Minerals Corporation, a wholly owned Carbide subsidiary. The new company is called the Strategic Metals Corporation.

title: HOMETOWN RELIVES HEMINGWAY STORY
description: IN the spring of 1906 the Hemingway family stood before the cold hearth in the living room of their new home in Oak Park for a dedication ceremony. While 7-year-old Ernest looked on, his father placed a tin box containing family mementos into a cornerstone and a mason slapped concrete over it. Then Mrs. Hemingway sang ''Blessed Be the Tie That Binds'' as the boy placed wood in the fireplace for the first fire.

title: 'Singin' in Rain' to Close
description: ''Singin' in the Rain,'' the musical adapted by Betty Comden and Adolph Green from their 1952 film, will close after the matinee on Sunday at the Gershwin Theater. Directed and choreographed by Twyla Tharp, the play will have run for 367 regular performances and 38 previews.

title: SPEED-O-PRINT BUSINESS MACHINES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Roll Call
description: Robert W. Merry is resigning as a reporter in the Washington bureau of The Wall Street Journal to become executive editor of Roll Call, a tabloid weekly that concentrates on news and gossip of Congress.

title: QUEENS RESIDENTS FIND KOCH'S BUDGET STINGY
description: They came to tell of children being taught in shower rooms and storage closets because their school was too small. One woman asked for light posts for a stretch of boardwalk and another for curbs to go with the new roads in her neighborhood.

title: SYRACUSE LACROSSE REVIVAL SPANS THREE GENERATIONS
description: The story begins in 1922, when Roy Simmons, an accomplished football player, boxer and outdoorsman fresh from Chicago, saw two fellows on the Syracuse University campus carrying funny-looking sticks that had baskets at one end.

title: Checking Other Bartholdis
description: When he walks through Union Square on his way to work at Consolidated Edison headquarters at 14 Irving Place, Kenneth Kowald often takes a look at the statue of Lafayette, especially these days, with all the attention focused on the Statue of Liberty.

title: LINCOLN CENTER SETS THEATER SEASON
description: In its first full season in six years, Lincoln Center Theater will next fall present revivals of two Broadway hits of half a century ago, a festival of South African plays and two new one-act plays by Arthur Miller, among other fare.

title: PRODUCTION OPERATORS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ICO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Mesa Stake In Unocal
description: The Mesa Petroleum Company said today that it intends to sell the 10.3 percent of the Unocal Corporation that it owns. It got the shares a year ago in the unsuccessful attempt by T. Boone Pickens, Mesa's chairman, to acquire Unocal.

title: 2 Are Reported to Have Died In Fire They Set for Insurance
description: A shop owner and his assistant set a fire to collect $175,000 in insurance benefits, then died before they could get out of the building, the authorities said Wednesday.

title: SCREEN: CRUISE IN 'TOP GUN'
description: TO take it from the top, ''Top Gun'' fires off as spectacular a show of state-of-the-art jet battle as the movies have given us. The F-14 Tomcats soar, swoop and somersault at fantastic speed. They catch the enemy from behind in what seems touching distance, and then, in an instant's reversal, are caught in the enemy's sights. As directed by Tony Scott, with the technical assistance of a couple of former Navy pilots, the snappily edited sequences of battle and mock battle sweep us in and out of the cockpit. You can't always be sure exactly what's going on, but it's exciting anyhow.

title: MOSCOW PRESENTS PACT TO ELIMINATE MISSILES IN EUROPE
description: Soviet arms negotiators in Geneva today presented a draft treaty on eliminating medium-range nuclear weapons in Europe, the White House said.

title: RIVER OAKS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: CELTICS STARTERS SHARP IN 122-111 VICTORY
description: The Boston Celtics accomplished a rarity in basketball tonight when all five starters scored 20 or more points.

title: S.E.C. Settles Insider Suit
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged a former director of Intercole Inc., a California rubber and plastics concern, with disclosing confidential information concerning 1984 merger negotiations.

title: U.N. HONORS FARM WOMEN OF AFRICA
description: A woman's day begins at 3 A.M. in Eremina Mvura's village at Skiaobvu in Zimbabwe. That is the hour she awakens to pound grain into flour in a mortar.

title: CONCERT: LOS ANGELES PHILHARMONIC
description: ANDRE PREVIN, who took command of the Los Angeles Philharmonic this season, brought his new orchestra to Carnegie Hall last night with a program that was characteristically Previn. Since from the first years of his career he has been a serious proponent of Mozart, it made sense that the Berlin-born, Hollywood-reared musician should begin this concert with the Piano Concerto No. 17 in G (K. 453), doing double duty as soloist and conductor. And, continuing a long involvement with English music that ripened during his tenure with London's Royal Philharmonic, he conducted one of his specialties, the ''Spring Symphony'' of Benjamin Britten.

title: MEMBERS OF THE TASK FORCE
description: Following are the members of the task force on teaching as a profession: Lewis M. Branscomb, task force chairman; chief scientist and vice president, International Business Machines Corporation, Armonk, N.Y. Alan K. Campbell, vice chairman of the board and executive vice president, ARA Services, Philadelphia. Mary Hatwood Futrell, president, National Education Association, Washington.

title: Reactor Organisms Killed
description: Workers at the nuclear power plant at Three Mile Island have killed millions of one-celled organisms in Unit 2's reactor water, removing an unexpected barrier to the crippled reactor's cleanup, the plant's operator said today. A pump and hydrogen peroxide were used to destroy the algae-like organisms in the warm water around the damaged reactor.

title: VALSPAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 25
ART: ROBERT LONGO AND HIS 'STEEL ANGELS'
description: ROBERT LONGO is a poet of urban life. If Edgar Allan Poe's man of the crowd craved masses of people, Longo seems to hunger for every aspect of New York City - its people, streets and nights, and its relentless bombardment of images and sounds from every conceivable communications medium. Longo's New York has an energy that can charge and waste everything. His mixed-media works are attempts both to live and to understand New York's creative and destructive power.

title: MET PLANS JOHN POPE-HENNESSY ART CURATORSHIP
description: The retirement this October of Sir John Pope-Hennessy as consultative chairman of the Met's Department of European Paintings will be marked by the creation of a curatorship, to be named after him, and by the publication of a bibliography, the museum announced yesterday.

title: CRAFTMATIC-CONTOUR INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
VERNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and includes an extraordinary gain from debt restructuring of $15,500,000 for the quarter and 9 months.

title: ENERSERV PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Teaching Requires More Than Wages
description: New York State insists that teacher salaries be increased by $95 million, but New York City rightly objects. Having already negotiated good salary increases, the city thinks teaching will be better served by spending to reduce class size and to improve other conditions. Governor Cuomo, with the strong support of teachers' unions, did not want to allow such local flexibility.

title: THEATER: RIVERSIDE SHAKESPEARE COMPANY'S 'AS YOU LIKE IT'
description: IF the Riverside Shakespeare Company's ''As You Like It'' became much more exuberant, it would burst through the walls into West 86th Street. A certain amount of energy becomes this play, but Robert Mooney, the director, has also chosen to emphasize very broad humor throughout and that is not always pleasing; in the bustle of such an approach, subtlety of character and even some jokes can be lost.

title: AMERICARE HEALTH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SERIOUS SNACKING ON MULTI-ETHNIC NINTH AVENUE
description: IF you think grilling is a California phenomenon or that grazing - snacking on a sampling of foods instead of eating a formal meal - is something new, take a stroll along Ninth Avenue from 37th to 57th Streets tomorrow or Sunday. The grazers will be out in full force, as they have been since 1974 when grazing was called noshing and the Ninth Avenue International Festival of Food started. This year, 250,000 appetites are expected tomorrow, half a million on Sunday.

title: AMERICAN HOME SHIELD CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $203,000. c-Net loss Preferred dividend requirements exceeded income in the latest quarter.

title: TELECOM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $43,000 on early retirement of debt.

title: 8 DISCOVERED AFTER 3 DAYS ON MT. HOOD
description: Six teen-agers and two of their teachers, who had been buried more than three days under deep snow, were found today after a survivor, on a hunch, led search teams to an ice cave where they had taken refuge.

title: Morgan Grenfell Plans Public Offer
description: Morgan Grenfell Holdings Ltd. said that it plans go public, listing its shares on the London Stock Exchange. The merchant bank said a letter would be sent to its existing shareholders soon and a further announcement would be made then.

title: VARLEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $139,000.

title: Muller Jordan Chosen By Sherwood Brands
description: Sherwood Brands, a candy importer based in Winston-Salem, N.C., is going to dip its bonbons into advertising for the first time, and for that purpose it has retained Muller Jordan Weiss of New York.

title: John Shaw Big Band
description: John Shaw and Assemblage, a big band, will perform tonight at 9 and 10:30. at the Jazz Center of New York, 380 Lafayette Street (505-5660). Tickets are $10.

title: Captain of the Sheffield Jammed Ship Defenses
description: Electronic antimissile defenses on the British frigate Sheffield, sunk in the 1982 Falkland War, were jammed during an Argentine attack by a telephone call from the captain to naval headquarters, the Defense Ministry said today.

title: NEWPARK RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from joint venture operations of $1,656,000. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $80,000.

title: Topics; Facts, in Pictures; Faces of Apartheid
description: The exploitation of South African blacks and the predicament of their white rulers can be measured by counting the instances of township violence or cholera cases or forced removals or pass-law arrests. But numbers can't convey just how debasing apartheid can be, or with what dignity blacks carry its burden.

title: BRAVES BEAT EXPOS, 7-4, IN 10
description: Ken Oberkfell hit a three-run homer in the 10th inning today to give the Atlanta Braves a 7-4 victory over the Montreal Expos.

title: Getting a Taste
description: So how's it feel, Skip?

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on May 12 about the PEN American Center awards carried an incorrect title provided by PEN for the winner of the poetry translation prize. It is ''Popol Vuh: The Mayan Book of the Dawn of Life,'' by Dennis Tedlock.

title: 500 STUDY DANGERS TO NATURE
description: Participants in New York State's recently completed environmental conference were reminded that those who would guard the natural world against further degradation must be able to marry science, politics, social awareness, economics and the collective cunning, intuition and yearnings of mankind.

title: ADAMS RESOURCES & ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $85,000 for the latest quarter and $475,000 for the earlier period.

title: Dr. Abraham Rosenthal, 74, A Surgeon and Pathologist
description: Dr. Abraham Rosenthal, a surgeon and pathologist who was a former assistant chief medical examiner, died yesterday at his home in Queens after a long illness. He was 74 years old.

title: Let the Protesters Themselves Divest
description: The shanty towns at Dartmouth, Harvard, Berkeley, Stanford; the protests on campuses throughout the country urging disinvestment of the securities of companies doing business in South Africa -these staples of this spring's student protests against apartheid in South Africa raise three very different questions. Would disinvestment by university and other trust funds promote the interests of South African blacks? Even if the people administering the trust funds answer ''yes'' to that question, are they morally justified in disinvesting? Even if the answers to both questions were ''yes,'' are students demonstrating disinterested idealism in their campaigns for disinvestment?

title: CYBERTEK COMPUTER PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
State Dept. Conducting Inquiry on Waldheim
description: The State Department is conducting its own investigation into the wartime activities of former Secretary General Kurt Waldheim to determine whether he should be barred from the United States, according to a letter from Deputy Secretary of State John C. Whitehead to the president of the World Jewish Congress, Edgar M. Bronfman.

title: Gooden vs. A List of Legends
description: Dwight Gooden, who pitches for the Mets at Los Angeles tonight, had an earned-run average of 1.04 before Cincinnati nicked him for three runs in five innings last Sunday. Then it zipped to 1.42, suggesting just how tough it will be for Dr. K to cut into the list of modern history's single-season e.r.a. leaders, a roll that is dominated by legends from the dead-ball epoch and that has been cracked only once in the last 68 years. Here's the listing (minimum of one inning pitched for every game on the team's schedule):

title: SYSTEMS & COMPUTER TECHOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The company said the latest quarter loss was primarily related to a $14.9 million provision for litigation and associated costs.

title: STERLING SOFTWARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Figures for 1985 have been restated to reflect the operations of Decision Systems Inc., which was acquired in October 1985 in a transaction accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: Following Up Chernobyl
description: Aside from the death and misery suffered by so many Soviet citizens and perhaps other Europeans, President Reagan and the Western allies have plenty of reason to take quiet satisfaction in the plight of the Soviet Government following the Chernobyl nuclear disaster.

title: 6-YEAR INVESTIGATION ENDS IN MURDER ARRESTS
description: Nearly six years of dogged detective work into the unsolved murders of two motorists who were slain 15 minutes and a mile apart in Queens in 1980 ended yesterday with the arrest of three men who were already in custody in murder cases.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on May 8 about lawsuits against the Financial Corporation of America incompletely described the status of Charles W. Knapp, the company's former chairman, in a suit now on trial. He was an original defendant but won a summary judgment and is no longer a party in the proceedings.

title: NOVO INDUSTRI A/S reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said it converted its figures from Danish kroner to U.S. currency at the March 31, 1986 rate of 8.67 kroner to $1.00.

title: 1987 BUDGET PLAN WITH MILITARY CUT APPROVED IN HOUSE
description: The House of Representatives today approved a 1987 budget plan that sets up a confrontation with President Reagan and the Senate over military spending.

title: BOARD PREPARING TO REVOKE FRIEDMAN'S PENSION RIGHTS
description: Members of the New York Teachers' Retirement Board have decided to revoke the pension rights that were granted to Stanley M. Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader, after he taught a three-hour course at Lehman College, officials representing board members said yesterday.

title: FILM: 'NOME DEL PAPA RE'
description: IT is 1867, and Rome is ruled by the Pope. Garibaldi's rebels are not far away, and a revolution is brewing to overthrow the Pope's temporal authority. Don Colombo (Nino Manfredi), a papal judge forced to order executions, decides to resign - he knows that the people are stirring and that papal rule is ending, and he feels guilty for his part in the repression.

title: NATIONAL FSI INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Advertising; Four-A's Tackles Drug Use
description: Against steady background chatter about mega-mergers, the American Association of Advertising Agencies swung into its 68th annual meeting today with youthful vigor and the best turnout of agency executives in the group's history.

title: MCM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After realized investment gains of $3,657,000. c-Net loss after realized investment losses of $8,000.

title: Harsco Gets Deal Worth $1 Billion
description: The Harsco Corporation, a contractor for combat and tactical vehicles for the Army, said that it had been awarded a five-year contract worth about $1 billion to make 15,218 tactical trucks for the Army.

title: OFFICER IS GUILTY IN HIT-AND-RUN AND COVER-UP
description: A veteran police officer was convicted yesterday of driving an unmarked police car that struck and injured a child riding a bicycle on a Queens street, then fleeing the scene and trying to cover up his crime by falsifying records.

title: GENERAL MICROWAVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TRACING SUSPECT STOCK TRADES
description: An analysis of trading patterns in the stocks that the merger specialist Dennis B. Levine is accused of purchasing on inside information shows that a widening circle of investors caused the stocks' volume and price to surge before the actual announcement of any bids.

title: DESPONDENT MAN IN CONNECTICUT KILLS HIS 3 CHILDREN AND HIMSELF
description: A 28-year-old man, described as despondent after a long period of unemployment, shot and killed his three young children today, then committed suicide with the same pistol, the police said.

title: Travels With Hart
description: In the 1984 campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination, Senator Gary Hart tried to distinguish himself from old-line liberals, specifically Walter F. Mondale, by stressing ''new ideas'' and proposing programs designed to make him appear more of a centrist candidate within the party spectrum.

title: LEUCADIA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $278,000.

title: Britain and Iran In Rift Over Envoys
description: Iran has barred a British diplomat from taking up his post in Teheran in retaliation for Britain's action in blocking the appointment of a leader of the American hostage siege of 1979-81 as Iran's top diplomat in London, the Foreign Office said today.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Frenchman Arrested in Italy In a Chernobyl TV Film Hoax
description: The Italian police announced the arrest today of a 24-year-old Frenchman on charges of duping two American television news organizations by selling them videotape that supposedly showed the burning Chernobyl nuclear plant.

title: NATIONAL INTERGROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $7.5 million. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $8,112,000.

title: ELDEST JOHNSON SON TELLS OF TALK WITH HIS FATHER
description: J. Seward Johnson, 87 years old, lay in a hospital in the spring of 1983 suffering from bone cancer and was undergoing a blood transfusion when his son, J. Seward Johnson Jr., asked him to yield control of the family foundation.

title: Hospitals Unit Sets Up Botnick Inquiry Panel
description: The Health and Hospitals Corporation set up a special ethics panel last night to review a potential conflict of interest by the corporation's chairman, Victor E. Botnick.

title: Diner's Journal
description: LA RECOLTE restaurant in the Hotel Inter-Continental, 49th Street and Lexington Avenue, will close permanently at the end of the month as part of a major renovation at the hotel, according to Fred Peelen, regional vice president of Inter-Continental. Christian Leveque, the restaurant's chef, will be transferred to the Ritz Carlton Inter-Continental in Montreal. Mr. Peelen said La Recolte would be converted to a reception room for the hotel's main ballroom.

title: LANCASTER COLONY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax charge of $11,791,000 related to certain plant closings. c-Net income

title: PETRO-LEWIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a $332 million writedown of oil and gas properties. c-After an extraordinary gain of $8,837,000 from the retirement of subordinated debentures and notes.

title: A 'Sick-Out' in Philadelphia
description: More than 500 lay teachers at Philadelphia's Roman Catholic high schools staged a union-sponsored ''sick-out'' today, forcing principals at nine high schools to dismiss more than 15,500 students for the day. Rita Schwartz, president of the Association of Catholic Teachers, said the teachers decided at a meeting this week to conduct the job action in an attempt to force diocesan officials to establish talks on teacher grievances. She said teachers would be back at work Friday.

title: GORBACHEV MEETS DR. GALE
description: Dr. Robert P. Gale, the American doctor treating victims of the Chernobyl disaster, said at a news conference here today that additional deaths were unavoidable and that there could be long-term health problems for thousands of people who lived near the power plant.

title: Howe Ignores Ban
description: The comeback attempt by Steve Howe, the National League Rookie of the Year with the Dodgers in 1980, hit another snag yesterday when the left-handed pitcher, burdened by substance-abuse problems in the major leagues, was expelled from the minor leagues one day after defying an order by Peter Ueberroth, the baseball commissioner. The commissioner ordered Howe not to pitch Wednesday night for the Class A San Jose Bees because of a ''discrepancy'' in a drug test Howe took May 1.

title: Back to the Old School
description: When he attended Stuyvesant High School in 1947, Vladimir Posner was called to the principal's office after setting off an explosion in chemistry lab.

title: Duke Power Issue
description: The Duke Power Company is offering $175 million of 9 percent first mortgage and refunding bonds due in 2016 at a price of 98.60 to yield 9.136 percent, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. Rated Aa-2 by Moody's and AA- by S.& P., the issue is not refundable for five years.

title: Judge Loses Last Bid To Avoid Jail Term
description: Federal District Judge Harry Claiborne, the first sitting Federal judge convicted of a felony, today lost his last bid to avoid starting a two-year prison term for income tax evasion.

title: CALLON PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a writedown of $23,128,000 on Callon's oil and gas properties. c-Net income

title: Sale of Bingham Papers Nears
description: In a rare break with tradition, the elegant breakfast usually given by the Bingham family on the morning of the Kentucky Derby did not take place this year.

title: Levine Case Investigation
description: The United States Attorney's Office in New York is expected to ask a grand jury shortly to investigate criminal insider-trading charges against Dennis B. Levine, a former senior merger executive at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., lawyers familiar with past proceedings said yesterday.

title: PENNZOIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income Pennzoil revised its latest first quarter earnings due to the writedown of about $120 million of oil and gas properties by its 48.7 percent owned affiliate, Proven Properties Inc. Pennzoil's portion of this writedown is about $58 million.

title: RIVALRY THREATENING TO SPLIT CONTRAS
description: After three days of talks, Nicaraguan rebel leaders remain so deeply divided on how to restructure their guerrilla movement that one key leader is ready to resign, according to several rebel officials here.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: NANNI IL VALLETTO, the glamorous younger sibling of the homespun Nanni on East 46th Street, is one of the more splendiferous Italian restaurants in town - and expensive, too. Every evening a soigne parade of perennially tanned gentlemen in dark European-cut suits escorted by polished and bejeweled ladies glides past the little horseshoe-shaped bar in front where they are greeted warmly by the staff. Luigi Nanni himself, a gruff yet endearing host, may come to the table, dismiss the menu with a wave of the hand, and suggest an assortment of the daily specials.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Huxtable, Christensen and Hood, the Greenwich House Music School, 46 Barrow Street (594-8833). Presented by the New York Pinewoods Folk Music Club, this harmony trio sings popular music from four centuries, including Renaissance and Elizabethan songs, English and Scottish broadsides and ballads, catches, chanteys, hymns, country, Tin Pan Alley and doo-wop. Much of the singing is a cappella. When it's not, their spare, novel accompaniments include accordion, spoons, recorder and missionary-style pump organ. Showtime is tonight at 8. Admission is $7.

title: Liability Law Beyond Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: AIDE TO CUOMO ASSAILS O'ROURKE FOR REMARK
description: Governor Cuomo's chief economic development aide, responding yesterday to remarks by the Republican gubernatorial candidate about a proposed domed stadium in Queens, called candidate, Andrew P. O'Rourke, ''a sewer politician'' who ''should find himself a manhole, climb inside and go cover it.''

title: Mozart Melange
description: The Mannes College of Music will present a Mozartean potpourri called ''The Magic Abduction and Cosi Marriage of Tutte Giovanni'' in the college's concert hall, 150 West 85th Street, tomorrow and Sunday nights at 8. Tickets are $5. Information: 580-0210.

title: Jazz in Newark
description: The violinist John Blake and his quartet and the pop-jazz band Crossing Point will perform tonight at 9:30 and 11 at the Terrace Room of Newark Symphony Hall, 1020 Broad Street in Newark, N.J. (201-643-4550). Admission for the evening of jazz, which begins with sets at 6 and 7:30 P.M. by the jazz group Evidence, is $10, including a free drink.

title: Not-So-Common Security Challenges to Europe and the U.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: AIR MIDWEST INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Mozart on Long Island
description: The Sea Cliff Chamber Players will inaugurate the Long Island Mozart Festival tomorrow night at 8 in the Tilles Center, C. W. Post Campus, Greenvale, L.I. The program will include concertos and other works by Haydn and Mozart, and feature a group of 28 musicians playing together without conductor, with solo performances by the violinist Hamao Fujiwara, the oboist Marsha Heller, the cellist Ko Iwasaki, the pianist Barbara Speer, the harpist Nancy Allen and the flutist Carol Wincenc. Tickets are $9.50 to $17.50. Information: (516) 671-6263.

title: GOULD EARNINGS CHARGE
description: Gould Inc., the electronics, information and military contractor, said today that it would take a pretax charge of $130 million against its first-quarter earnings because of higher than estimated costs for fixed-price military contracts awarded in 1982 and 1983. As a result, Gould said it lost $115.1 million in the first quarter. The company had said previously that it had earned $14.8 million in the quarter.

title: Green Discloses Data On His Income Taxes
description: Mark Green, who is seeking the Democratic nomination to oppose Republican Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, yesterday released summaries of his income tax returns for the last seven years and challenged Mr. D'Amato to do the same.

title: THEODORE WHITE, CHRONICLER OF U.S. POLITICS, IS DEAD AT 71
description: Theodore H. White, the ex-newsboy who became a Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist skilled at humanizing events in his ''Making of the President'' books and myriad other writings, died late last night at Lenox Hill Hospital.

title: Rookie Award for Ewing
description: The Knicks have scheduled a news conference at noon Monday at which Patrick Ewing is expected to be named the National Basketball Association's rookie of the year.

title: PENTRON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $105,200. c-Net income d-After a tax credit of $371,900. e-Net loss

title: UNITED STATES SUGAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: A FOOD FESTIVAL NEEDS MORE THAN FOOD
description: It is not merely the estimated 200,000 pieces of ravioli dished out in two days by Bruno Ravioli Company, or the 2,000 or so quails that Sotiris Karamouzis, owner of Ninth Avenue International Foods, bakes in wine, or the 40 gallons of cider that the Little Apple Baking Company will sell to wash down some 2,000 pastries that keep the Ninth Avenue International Festival of Food going.

title: A FUND-RAISING DINNER BRINGS $700,000 FOR KOCH
description: Mayor Koch closed the fiscal books on his third-term re-election campaign last night with a fund-raising dinner that, in tune with the times, was considerably more subdued and less lucrative than past Koch events.

title: CAMPBELL SOUP COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
PAPERS WON'T FACE CHARGES ON PAST ARTICLES, CASEY SAYS
description: The Director of Central Intelligence, William J. Casey, who said last week that several news organizations had broken the law by publishing classified information, said today that he did not favor prosecution for past violations.

title: AOI COAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: FALKLAND IMPASSE CONTINUES AT U.N.
description: Javier Perez de Cuellar, the United Nations Secretary General, ended a visit here today without having received any sign that Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's approach to talks with Argentina about the Falkland Islands had become more flexible.

title: POPE, EVANS & ROBBINS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,796,000 for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income and after income from discontinued operations of $517,000 for the quarter and $1,621,000 for the 9 months.

title: The U.N. Today: May 16, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Special Committee Against Apartheid, meeting on convention against apartheid in sports - 10:30 A.M.

title: SAUL, B F REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes net of $83,000 from discontinued operations and includes a pretax gain of $121,000 from the sale of properties for the quarter and includes a pretax gain of $174,000 from the sale of properties for the 6 months. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $13,000 for the quarter and $121,000 for the 6 months, and includes pretax gains of $802,000 for the quarter and $1,844,000 for the 6 months from the sale of properties.

title: STAMPFEL'S BOTTLE CAPS: A MERRY MIX OF MUSIC
description: WHAT do you call a band that mixes bluegrass, funk and a rap version of a Robert Service poem, all in the same song? Peter Stampfel, a singer and fiddler with a cracked Appalachian-style voice and a well-developed sense of the ridiculous, calls his band the Bottle Caps, and on its new album the group also combines hillbilly with reggae, sets a fragment of ''America the Beautiful'' atop a rock-and-roll riff from ''Wooly Bully,'' and interrupts an old-timey hoedown for a screaming jazz-saxophone break.

title: 458 Military Recruits Test Positive on AIDS
description: The rate at which military recruits are testing positive for exposure to a virus associated with AIDS remained almost constant in the first three months of the year, a new Defense Department report shows.

title: PAT CONSISTENCY
description: In the twilight, virtually all the other touring pros had departed for their motels, but Pat Bradley had stayed to practice. Mechanically but rhythmically, she was floating 6-iron shots toward the far right corner of the range.

title: LAC MINERALS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Sara Lee Debentures Have a Sinking Fund
description: The Sara Lee Corporation, in its first public domestic offering of debentures in 15 years, is selling $175 million of 8 3/4 percent sinking fund debentures due 2016 at a price of 100, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Brackeen on Piano
description: Joanne Brackeen is playing piano solos tonight through Sunday at Burgundy, 467 Amsterdam Avenue, above 82d Street (787-8300). Music begins at 9 P.M.; there is a $10 minimum at tables, a two-drink minimum at the bar.

title: Sauers Up by One In Texas Golf
description: Gene Sauers chipped in three times and shot a four-under-par 66 for a one-stroke lead over Bill Rogers today in the first round of the $600,000 Colonial National Invitation Tournament.

title: METS TOP RYAN; METS 6, ASTROS 2
description: The Mets beat Nolan Ryan for the second time in a week tonight when they snapped out of a mild slump and overpowered the Houston Astros, 6-2.

title: AT PHOTO SHOWS, A KALEIDOSCOPE OF VISUAL DELIGHTS
description: SPRING is the season when camera toters everywhere wipe the dust from their lenses and head outdoors. The same sense of warm-weather vitality pervades photography exhibitions this month. After a somewhat dormant winter, shows devoted to camera images now seem to be blooming everywhere. It is more than a weekend's occupation to take them all in, but luckily some of the season's offerings will endure into summer.

title: POP AND JAZZ
description: Pharoah Sanders, Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, near West Fourth Street, (242-1785). When John Coltrane added a second saxophonist to his band in the mid-60's, he chose Pharoah Sanders for his radical approach to sound. The thick, reedy harmonics and dinosaurlike chomping Mr. Sanders created have become accepted components of contemporary music, and Mr. Sanders is devoting himself to a more inclusive musicianship. The sonic explorations are still part of his style, but so are a warmly robust way with a ballad, a fondness for African rhythms, and a deep feeling for the blues. Tonight and tomorrow, performances are at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M.; on Sunday, shows are at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M. There is a $10 cover charge and a $6 minimum.

title: Beirut Caller Warns of Peril In Pressure to Free Captives
description: A caller who said he represented a fundamentalist Moslem extremist group warned today that ''increasing reports about Syrian efforts to free the American and French hostages'' could endanger the prisoners.

title: Travels With Bush
description: Vice President Bush has tentatively scheduled a trip to the Middle East in mid-July, a diplomatic mission in behalf of President Reagan that would include visits to Israel, Egypt and Jordan. Syria was a possible stop on the itinerary until suspicions arose recently of that nation's involvement in terrorist activities.

title: ROYAL DUTCH-SHELL GROUP OF COS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Royal Dutch Petroleum Co.'s share of Group net income amounted to $2.44 a share for latest quarter, compared to $2.86 a share for the year-ago period. Shell Transport & Trading Co.'s share of Group net income totaled $1.38 a share for latest quarter, against $1.62 a share for the year- earlier period.

title: ANDROS ANALYZERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
Bike-and-Boat Tour
description: Sandy Ground, a community on the southern shore of Staten Island, has a special place in the history of black Americans. Once the center of a thriving oyster industry, it is also one of the oldest surviving settlements by free blacks.

title: CHESAPEAKE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $370,000, or 13 cents a share, on the sale of real estate.

title: When Government Was a Friend in Need
description: On the eve of the 1948 Presidential election, the pollsters of the United States were convinced they had picked a winner. The Gallup Poll gave Gov. Thomas E. Dewey a five-point margin. Another major poll gave Governor Dewey a margin of 9 percent - a landslide! Life magazine carried a photograph of Governor Dewey in California. The caption read, ''The next President travels by ferryboat over the broad waters of San Francisco Bay.'' Another magazine, Changing Times, wrote a cover story titled ''What Dewey Will Do.'' The columnist Drew Pearson was already analyzing how the Dewey team would run the Government.

title: Pin-Striped Bird Watcher
description: Mayor Koch, wearing a pin-striped suit and binoculars, ventured into a damp Central Park at 7:30 yesterday morning for a bit of bird watching under the guidance of an ornithologist, Susan Drennan. It was a first for the Mayor, and after the 40-minute jaunt, he said it had been fun.

title: GRUMMAN OFFICIAL TO GET PRESIDENCY
description: The Grumman Corporation announced yesterday that it had named John O'Brien an executive vice president, and said he would be named president on Aug. 1, when George M. Skurla, the current president, is scheduled to retire.

title: GEORGE WASHINGTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $5,093 from the sale of securities. c-Net income and after a gain from the sale of securities of $84 and net of $206,453 from the company's American Southern Insurance Co. unit, which was sold in December 1985.

title: Norma Millay Ellis, 92; Arts Colony Founder
description: Norma Millay Ellis, a sister of the poet Edna St. Vincent Millay and the founder of the Millay Colony for the Arts, died Wednesday at Steepletop, the Millay farm in Austerlitz, N.Y. She was 92 years old.

title: At 107 Lbs., a Darling Baby
description: She is frolicsome and lovable and destined to weigh 4,500 pounds.

title: Knock on Wood
description: Ken Adderly, a swift outfielder from the Bahamas and Florida International University, once heard Rod Carew say that a hitter should be good to his bat if he expects his bat to be good to him.

title: MASSMUTUAL INCOME INVESORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
TEEN-AGERS MAKE PARTIES A BUSINESS
description: ''The cost of children's parties is absurd,'' declared John L. Hamburg, a partner in Teen Party Planners. He ought to know - he is 15 years old and says he has been to plenty of ''outrageous'' parties.

title: PERKIN-ELMER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
BARNES ENGINEERING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $41,000 for the quarter and $102,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes tax credits of $22,000 for the quarter and $75,000 for the 9 months.

title: MOZART FESTIVAL SETS SCHEDULE
description: The Mostly Mozart Festival announced yesterday that its season this summer at Lincoln Center would consist of 28 different programs, including at least six concerts a week at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: 66-SECOND NIGHT FOR BRELAND
description: Mark Breland made a fast five grand last night.

title: U.S. Warns Countries About Votes at U.N.
description: Vernon A. Walters, the American delegate to the United Nations, said today that he was warning countries getting American aid that they could expect less money if they voted against the United States in the General Assembly.

title: Icahn, With 16.9%, In Viacom Overture
description: Carl C. Icahn, the New York investor, disclosed yesterday that he held a 16.9 percent stake in Viacom International, the diversified media company. Mr. Icahn also said that he had approached Viacom with a $75-a-share cash offer but that ''he had not received any encouragement from the company.''

title: Bank of Canada Rate
description: The bellwether Bank of Canada interest rate for commercial bank borrowing dipped today for the third consecutive week, falling to 8.59 percent, from 8.72 percent last week.

title: SAGE ENERGY CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: F.C.C. Lifts Bell Unit Curb
description: The Federal Communications Commission took a major step toward complete deregulation of the telephone industry today, voting, 4 to O, to abolish a rule requiring the Bell telephone companies to use separate companies for marketing call answering and message storage services.

title: Oklahoma Gas
description: The Oklahoma Gas and Electric Company said it had signed an agreement to acquire the Mustang Fuel Corporation's natural gas pipeline and gas processing operations in a stock swap valued at $120.6 million. Before the acquisition, Mustang will spin off to its stockholders the Mustang Energy Corporation, which owns and operates various subsidiaries in the pipeline and gas processing businesses, Oklahoma Gas said.

title: Bonner Plans to Leave For Soviet on May 24
description: Yelena G. Bonner said today that she would leave the United States on May 24 to return to the Soviet Union to rejoin her husband, Andrei D. Sakharov, in their place of exile in the city of Gorky.

title: SALE OF CANADA DRY, SUNKIST SEEN
description: RJR Nabisco Inc. plans to announce soon that it will sell its Canada Dry and Sunkist beverage operations to Cadbury Schweppes Inc., industry sources said yesterday.

title: DRUG TREATMENT IN CITY IS STRAINED BY CRACK, A POTENT NEW COCAINE
description: Drug treatment programs in New York City and its suburbs are filled to capacity and are struggling to avoid turning people away as more and more people become addicted to crack, a new and highly potent form of cocaine.

title: PROPOSALS FOR TRANSFORMING TEACHING 'FROM OCCUPATION INTO A PROFESSION'
description: The principal theme running through the Carnegie report, ''A Nation Prepared,'' is the need to transform teaching ''from an occupation into a profession.''

title: COMPLEX, PROBING PORTRAITS IN MABOU MINES REVIVALS
description: THE main character of ''A Prelude to Death in Venice,'' an experimental theater piece that mixes ventriloquism, puppetry and poetry, is a three-foot-high wooden dummy named John. Manipulated by the actor Bill Raymond, John is a personality coming apart at the seams. Talking on two pay phones at once, this would-be film maker adopts different voices for different people. He addresses his mother in an affected Ronald Colman accent and cajoles his girlfriends in the tone of a deep-voiced smoothie. Frantically scrounging for a movie deal, he becomes a wheedling street hustler.

title: INTERNATIONAL BANKNOTE CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $8,691,000. c-Net loss The latest quarter results include a $14.8 million pre-tax gain on the sale of a foreign subsidiary.

title: WEINBERGER ACTS TO TRIM SECTIONS OF TRADE BILL
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger asked the Democratic leadership of the House of Representatives to remove, on national security grounds, several sections of the omnibus trade bill that comes up for debate Monday. The House Rules Committee responded today by agreeing to permit amendments that would weaken the legislation.

title: Indictment of Teamster Chief Expected Today in Cleveland
description: The indictment of Jackie Presser, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, is expected Friday, along with that of an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who used the union chief as an informer, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: HOUSE ROLL-CALL VOTE APPROVING $994 BILLION BUDGET FOR '87
description: Following is the roll-call vote of 245 to 179 by which the House of Representatives today approved a budget of $994 billion for the fiscal year 1987, which begins Oct. 1. A ''yes'' vote was a vote in favor of the budget. A ''no'' vote was a vote against it. Voting ''yes'' were 228 Democrats and 17 Republicans. Voting ''no'' were 19 Democrats and 160 Republicans. An ''xxx'' denotes members not voting. There is one vacancy in the 435-member House. ALABAMA

title: Economic Scene; Stimulating Global Growth
description: DESPITE the disintegrative political forces, ranging from terrorism to the dangers of conventional or nuclear war, the more closely integrated world economy is forcing a re-examination of the bases of national economic policies.

title: COLLINS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss includes losses from discontinued operations of $11,435 for the quarter and $56,074 for the 6 months.

title: REGAN IN ALBANY PLEA ON TAX PLAN
description: State Comptroller Edward V. Regan objected today to the impact on New Yorkers of losing the deductions for sales taxes and Individual Retirement Accounts as proposed in the Senate Finance Committee's income tax bill, but nonetheless he characterized it as ''real tax reform.''

title: HOUSTON INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are restated for an accounting change.

title: AUCTIONS
description: POLITICAL and economic problems throughout Latin America are creating a mixed market for its 20th-century art, at least 50 percent of which is traditionally collected by native Latin Americans. The auctions next week at Sotheby's and Christie's are not expected to reverse this trend, but they may indicate whether major Latin American works continue to command top prices and who is buying the moderate-priced paintings, drawings and sculpture.

title: CONNER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: BURROUGHS MAY RAISE SPERRY BID
description: The Burroughs Corporation said yesterday that it was willing to negotiate ''a meaningful increase'' in its $70-a-share takeover offer for the Sperry Corporation. Its announcement came hours after Sperry disclosed, in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, that it had considered selling itself to another company, divesting itself of its principal assets and forming a joint venture with another concern to thwart Burroughs.

title: SCREEN: 'HARD CHOICES,' ON THE LAM
description: IN the early 1980's, Mary Evans, 26 years old, a lawyer in Tennessee, fell in love with - and engineered the escape of - her client, William Timothy Kirk, 36, a convict charged with the murder of two fellow prisoners. After 139 days on the lam together in Florida, where they seem to have spent most of their time at the dog track, the pair were caught. Mr. Kirk was returned to prison. For her part in the adventure, Miss Evans was disbarred and received a prison sentence of three years.

title: ART: GWEN JOHN WORKS AT DAVIS & LANGDALE
description: IT is mysterious to many that Gwen John (1876-1939) does not stand higher in the feminist Pantheon - or, for that matter, in its gender-free equivalent. Her brother, Augustus John, for many years the most celebrated English artist of his day, may have flown high when he wrote in 1942 that she was the greatest woman painter who ever lived. But her work, like herself, had a reclusive distinction that will outlive many a more spectacular outpouring.

title: HYGEIA SCIENCES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Jazz Benefit for Women
description: There will be a jazz benefit concert tomorrow at 8 P.M. for New York Women Against Rape (212-477-0819), featuring the singer Jeanne Lee and her vocal ensemble and the saxophonist-singer Fostina Dixon and her group, Winds of Change. The concert will take place at Joan of Arc High School, 154 West 93d Street; tickets are $15 and $25.

title: CURB ON I.R.A. IN TAX PROPOSAL RAISING DEBATE
description: The proposal to curtail the tax deduction for Individual Retirement Accounts is emerging as the most disputed part of the Senate Finance Committee's tax-revision plan.

title: Teresat Has Big Plans For Recycled Satellites
description: Henry A. Schwartz wants to buy two retrieved communications satellites from their current owner, Lloyd's of London, and reorbit them using Chinese rockets.

title: End of a Landmark
description: To the Editor:

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: UNDER plans being formulated by the Academy Award-winning producer and director Robert Wise, directors from around the world will gather in New York as the climax of the 50th anniversary observance of the Directors Guild of America.

title: L.I.R.R. Action Delays A Strike Until January
description: The Long Island Rail Road acted yesterday to insure that the railroad's 15 unions would not be able to legally strike until next January. The unions had set a strike deadline for 12:01 A.M. Saturday.

title: AT AMERICAN LEGION POSTS, VETERANS OF VIETNAM FAN THE WINDS OF CHANGE
description: Herman Harrington was an infantryman in Europe, about to be shipped to the Far East when the United States dropped the atomic bomb on Hiroshima near the end of World War II. As a result, he argues with fervor that nuclear weapons can be ''life saving.''

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE CHARACTER FACTORY: Baden-Powell and the Origins of the Boy Scout Movement. By Michael Rosenthal. 335 pages. Illustrated. Pantheon Books. $22.95. THE motto of the Boy Scouts, ''Be Prepared,'' is not only a brisk exhortation; it also enshrines the initials of the movement's founder, Robert Baden-Powell - a fact that ''B-P'' himself more than once called attention to in the early days of Scouting, just in case anyone missed the point. The Scouts are a monument to Baden-Powell's ambitions no less than to his ideals, and to study the origins of the movement, as Michael Rosenthal has done in ''The Character Factory,'' is inevitably to study the life of the man who created it as well.

title: A SOFTER APARTHEID RESERVED FOR AMERICAN BLACKS
description: The woman who owned the boutique seemed to scowl, Audrey Burroughs said, perhaps at the prospect of a small encounter between a black customer and a white vendor that did not seem altogether welcome.

title: Unpublished Cantata By Handel to Be Heard
description: An unpublished Handel cantata for soprano, tenor, strings and continuo will be the featured work at a concert Sunday afternoon by the chamber ensemble Musica da Camera of Fort Lee, N.J. According to Melanie Braun, a musicologist and one of the group's founders, this marks the first performance of the work in the United States.

title: British Caledonian Plans to Cut 1,000
description: British Caledonian Airways said it was laying off 1,000 of its 7,750 employees because Americans afraid of terrorist attacks are staying away from Europe.

title: ARSON CALLED BIGGEST CAUSE
description: Arson has become the single biggest cause of increasingly destructive forest fires in the United States, the Forest Service reported today.

title: CONCEPT DEVELOPMENT reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $12,666,000.

title: Gotti's Bid to Reinstate Bail Is Denied by Judge
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn yesterday denied an application by the reputed head of the Gambino crime family, John Gotti, to reopen a hearing during which Mr. Gotti's bail was revoked or to delay the time for his reporting to be jailed.

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart in Business Day on May 8 showing major tax revision proposals misstated the effect of the Senate Finance's Committee's bill on corporate pension plans known as 401(k)'s. The annual tax-deferred contribution would be limited to $7,000.

title: SUBWAY DEATH CALLED A RESULT OF HUMAN ERROR
description: A chain of errors by two subway clerks and a motorman and a misunderstanding by a transit police officer led to the death last January of an elderly man who was hit by a train after lying on the subway tracks for nearly 15 minutes, the Transit Authority said yesterday.

title: POLY-TECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $426,000.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday FESTIVALS ON FILM When the freelance photographer Roberta Grobel Intrater realized that most of New York City's ethnic festivals had not been thoroughly documented, she set out on an eight-year project. The results can be seen at the New-York Historical Society, which is staging an exhibition of her work in honor of the Statue of Liberty's centennial year. Nine festivals are documented in 65 color photographs, from the St. Patrick's Day Parade to Brooklyn's Cherry Blossom Festival, the West Indian American Day Parade and the East Indian Festival. ''Liberty's Legacy: Photographs of New York's Ethnic Festivals'' is at the New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, at 77th Street, through Sept. 28. The museum is open Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M., Sundays from 1 to 5 P.M. Admission is $2 ($1.50 for the elderly and $1 for children under 12). Information: 873-3400.

title: A 9.81% Top Yield In Lomas C.M.O.'s
description: The Lomas Mortgage Funding Corporation is offering $250 million of collateralzied mortgage obligations through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Mr. Gorbachev Tries Some Candor
description: Misfortune is a good guide to character, no less in Russia than elsewhere. In his televised speech Wednesday, Mikhail Gorbachev candidly described the disaster in terms that evoke sympathy for the Chernobyl nightmare. Had he only done so two weeks ago, the world's concern and compassion might have been unreserved.

title: Linking Adoption And Abortion In One Crusade
description: Most of what Congress does centers on large ideas like Federal budgets or on the specific concerns of constituents, but personal experiences have a way of affecting the legislative process, too.

title: Afghan Announces Collective Leadership
description: The Afghan Communist Party leader, Najibullah, announced a collective leadership today that includes him, President Babrak Karmal and Prime Minister Sultan Ali Kishtmand.

title: A Proper Burden For the Defamed
description: To the Editor:

title: Libya Sues U.S. Bank
description: The Libyan Arab Foreign Bank, a state-owned bank, has sued the Bankers Trust Company to recover deposits frozen in Bankers Trust offices as a result of President Reagan's order to freeze Libyan assets. ''What they are saying is that the Presidential order does not apply to assets overseas,'' said a spokesman for Bankers Trust.

title: AMERICAN PIONEER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax loss carryforward of $925,000. c-Net loss and includes extraordinary litigation losses of $2,400,000.

title: Legitimate Federal Scrutiny of Textbooks
description: To the Editor:

title: FILM: 'THE BOY IN BLUE'
description: ''T HE BOY IN BLUE'' is yet another movie about athletes and it doesn't go beyond the cliche. It follows the by now obligatory formula: start with a good-looking man, preferably young, inarticulate and lower-class, with bulging biceps, shown as frequently as possible glistening with sweat. Then add a crusty coach with a heart of gold. It helps to throw in a few scenes of the grueling training, maybe a true love to spur the hero on, and end in victory accompanied by a swelling musical score. When the formula doesn't work, the film looks just plain silly. In ''The Boy in Blue,'' which opens today at the Festival and other theaters, it doesn't work.

title: VICE SQUAD: KOCH AND CUOMO, THE POSTER STARS
description: Mayor Koch and Governor Cuomo as poster pinups?

title: IVERSON TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
12.4 Million Shares Of Unocal Sold
description: The Mesa Petroleum Company said that it had sold 12.4 million shares of the Unocal Corporation's stock, almost liquidating its stake in Unocal that was accumulated during an unsuccessful attempt to acquire it a year ago. The sale, amounting to 10 percent of Unocal's common shares, was the second-largest block trade ever on the New York Stock Exchange, after a 48.8-million-share trade of Navistar stock a month ago.

title: Charge Against Denny
description: Bruce Schoenfeld, a sports reporter for The Cincinnati Post who charged that his neck was grabbed and his head was banged against a wall by John Denny in a hallway under Veterans Stadium Wednesday night before a game in Philadelphia, has filed a criminal complaint against the Reds pitcher for simple assault, making terroristic threats and harassment. A hearing will be held before a trial commissioner, and if the two sides cannot settle the dispute, Denny will face criminal charges.

title: ART PEOPLE
description: ENZO CUCCHI, the Italian artist who waves his paintbrush like a magician's wand, has conjured up a carnival of images at the Guggenheim Museum, where his first major one-man museum show in the United States is now on view, through July 6.

title: Youths' Favorite
description: To the Editor:

title: EXPERTS VOICE CONCERN ON EAST EUROPE CANCERS
description: Radiation from the Chernobyl nuclear disaster could cause tens of thousands of cancer cases and thousands of deaths in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe in the next several decades, according to the best estimates available now, two physicists said yesterday.

title: GREEN MOUNTAIN POWER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Legless Veteran Ends Cross-Country Trek
description: Bob Wieland, a legless Vietnam veteran, ended his 2,784-mile ''Walk for Hunger'' across the United States Wednesday as he began it, on his hands.

JOYFUL JOURNALIST
description: Teddy White - almost nobody ever called him Theodore - taught the American people more about politics than any writer of his generation.

title: PREAKNESS DRAW HELPFUL FOR FAVORITES
description: In the Kentucky Derby, all of the front-runners in the field of 16 drew outside posts, which led to severe traffic problems when they cut across the field to get to the rail, compromising the outcome.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: JACQUELINE STALLONE wore black, Ann Hamilton, off-white.

title: Bridge: Expert's Luck Was Mixed At Event in Netherlands
description: We all have our ups and downs at the bridge table, but ups and downs away from the table during a championship are rarer. A case in point occurred in the Netherlands in 1980, for Emma Jean Hawes of Fort Worth, a world grandmaster now retired from the game and fighting ill health.

title: G. Schirmer Is Sold
description: G. Schirmer Inc., the American classical-music publisher, has been sold by Macmillan Inc., which has owned the 125-year-old company since 1969, to the Music Sales Corporation, a heretofore largely educational music publisher based in London, Macmillan and Music Sales have announced.

title: CONTINENTAL HEALTH AFFILITES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MEDICAL GRADUATES OF STATE UNIVERSITY URGED TO HELP POOR
description: The graduating class of the State University's College of Medicine in Brooklyn was told yesterday that it faces a major challenge in helping the poor and uninsured gain access to health care.

title: Market Place; Beneficiaries Of Tax Plan
description: RETAILING and service industries promise to be the prime beneficiaries of the Senate tax plan if it is approved, while capital-intensive industries might be hurt, according to a number of analysts and money managers.

title: Papal Priorities
description: Pope John Paul II, when Yannick Noah and other Italian Open participants visiting the Vatican urged that he take up tennis: ''I'm sorry, but I don't have time.''

title: EXCERPTS FROM THE CARNEGIE REPORT ON TEACHING
description: Following are excerpts from ''A Nation Prepared: Teachers for the 21st Century,'' a report by a task force assembled by the Carnegie Corporation of New York:

description: b-Includes a capital gain of $507,000. c-Includes a capital loss of $2,000 and a tax credit of $20,000.

title: PINOCHET IS IN NO HURRY TO RELAX AN IRON GRIP
description: In a country where most people are too law-abiding to display their graffiti skills, one scrawled phrase has stood out recently on a number of buildings: ''Halley, carry Pinochet away with you.''

MONARCH CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After capital gains of $11,228,000 for the latest first quarter and $5,946,000 for the year-ago period.

title: Bonn to Control Arbed Steel Unit
description: The Luxembourg-based steelmaking group, Arbed S.A., agreed to accept the equivalent of 45 cents as the Bonn Government exercised an option to acquire effective control of Arbed Saarstahl G.m.b.H., the German steelmaking unit.

title: Settle G.A.O.'s Account
description: Michael K. Deaver, flattered for five years by media biggies eager for scraps of news from the White House table, has never been treated kindly in this space. In 1982 he was charged with ''advertising for clients,'' and in 1983 castigated for breaching ethics by using his position to sell a diet book. A year later, he was pilloried here for ''making connections'' of future benefit by sprinkling White House dinner invitations on billionaire Hong Kong shipping magnate Y. K. Pao.

title: SENATE CUTS PENSIONS FOR FUTURE SERVICE PERSONNEL
description: The Senate voted 93 to 1 today to cut pensions for future military personnel as part of the Congressional effort to reduce budget deficits.

title: SCREEN: BROOKLYN BARBRA
description: IN taking her camera to Metropolitan Avenue in the Williamsburg and Greenpoint sections of Brooklyn, Christine Noschese was onto something. It's a neighborhood, we learn, in which Italians settled nearly a century ago, Poles about 60 years ago, blacks after World War II. It has been sliced up by the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway and beaten up by all the common depredations of urban life, yet it remains home to a lot of people. Miss Noschese, who grew up in Brooklyn, set out to celebrate the efforts of some of the people to hold onto and improve their communities.

title: SPY TRIAL HEARS DEFENDANT TRADED IN COINS AND COMMODITIES
description: Prosecutors in the espionage trial of Jerry A. Whitworth presented evidence today of Mr. Whitworth's personal financial transactions prior to his retirement from the Navy in October 1983.

title: METS TOP RYAN; WHITE SOX 8, YANKEES 1
description: The Yankees' 8-1 loss to the Chicago White Sox last night was the kind of game that in the past has prompted George Steinbrenner to offer fans free tickets to a future game.

title: COMPUTER ASSOCIATES INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings, which are fully diluted, reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective May 8.

title: Travels With Rehnquist
description: Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist of the Supreme Court accepted a bribe last week in the full view of several hundred witnesses, but no prosecution seems likely to result. Mr. Rehnquist was making a cameo appearance as the Solicitor in Gilbert and Sullivan's ''Patience,'' the current offering of the Washington Savoyards Ltd. Last Friday, resplendent in white wig and black robes, he was induced by the heroine to adjust a raffle over which he was presiding so that she won first prize, the hero.

title: NAVISTAR INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After tax credits of $9 million for the quarter and $22 million for the 6 months. c-After a tax credit of $28 million. d-Net loss after a loss from discontinued operations of $576 million and a tax credit of $48 million.

description: To the Editor:

description: Figures were converted from new Israeli shekels at the rate of $1 equals 1.5 shekels.

title: SCHOOL BOARD CHIEF REBUKES QUINONES ON TEACHER SALARY ISSUE
description: An unusually bitter dispute has broken out between the Schools Chancellor and the president of the Board of Education over how to spend $31 million in state aid earmarked for increases in city teacher salaries.
