title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: Assets of the nation's 361 money market mutual funds fell $169.9 million, to $224.50 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: ADMIT WOMEN? A GENTLEMEN'S CLUB RESISTS
description: The Union League, a shrine to Abraham Lincoln, has stood for more than a century as an outspoken and unbowing champion of the fight against discrimination.

title: Terrorism And Tips On Travel
description: In response to terrorist attacks against Americans overseas, more and more citizens are calling Federal agencies for advice on where and how to travel safety. But the Government seems reluctant to provide more than a minimum of information, saying solid facts are hard to come by.

title: LEHIGH VALLEY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $130,000. c-Net loss after a loss from discontinued operations of $264,000.

title: Lendl Advances In Italian Open
description: Ivan Lendl, the world's top-ranked player, beat Paolo Cane of Italy, 6-2, 6-4, today to advance to the quarterfinals of the Italian Open tennis tournament.

title: U.S. Drops Charges
description: Federal prosecutors have dropped criminal charges against Linda Sue Evans, the former Weather Underground radical who was accused of harboring a fugitive of a 1981 attempted Brink's robbery. Authorities said they took the action to let Miss Evans stand trial in Louisiana, where she is charged with using false identification to buy guns.

title: SCREEN: AGNES VARDA'S 'VAGABOND'
description: FROM the start of Agnes Varda's ''Vagabond'' - when her painterly director's eye moves slowly through frozen vineyards to discover the body of a young woman - to the end, when she has circled back over the final weeks in this teen-age drifter's life, her camera comes to rest again and again on the heroine's extraordinary, mysterious face. It is a broad-featured, clear-eyed face that needs to be scrubbed clean, belonging to a woman who seems both scowling and innocent, whose sultriness owes something to the dark circles under her eyes.

title: CLOTHESTIME INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Rozelle Questioned On TV Contracts
description: An attorney for the United States Football League questioned Commissioner Pete Rozelle of the National Football League for nearly five hours yesterday in an attempt to show that the N.F.L. had acted to hurt the U.S.F.L. On each point, however, Rozelle denied any wrongdoing or improper intent.

title: SEOUL STUDENTS AND POLICE CLASH
description: Students and policemen clashed with gasoline bombs, stones and tear gas on at least four Seoul campuses today in an intensification of violence three days before the anniversary of a 1980 protest against martial law.

title: Travels With Bauman
description: Robert E. Bauman, a former Congressman who is now a homosexual rights activist, has written a book about his political career. ''The Gentleman from Maryland: The Conscience of a Gay Conservative'' is to be published by Arbor House in mid-summer, and excerpts will appear in The Washingtonian magazine in July, along with a profile of the author by Rudy Maxa.

title: RIFT OVER TOWER LEAVES EVEN WINNERS UNHAPPY
description: To some of those involved in the battle, the proposal seemed like a fair trade-off: one huge, well-designed building with beveled edges on the east blockfront of Third Avenue in return for a park behind it between East 64th and 65th Streets.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, MAY 16, 1986
description: International

title: 2 POLICEMEN CONVICTED OF TAKING A BRIBE, SEX INVOLVING A GIRL, 16
description: Two city police officers were convicted last night of receiving a bribe, having a 16-year-old Queens girl perform oral sex on them, in return for not arresting her on minor drug and vehicular traffic charges.

title: Tunnels Contaminated In Nevada Nuclear Test
description: Tunnels at the site of a nuclear test that malfunctioned last month are contaminated with dangerous levels of radiation, and it may be weeks or months before tests can resume there, officials say.

title: Dining Out Guide; Uptown With Out-of-Town Guests
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. CAFE DES ARTISTES, #1 West 67th Street (877-3500) -

title: CARNEGIE PANEL PLANS TO ESTABLISH NATIONWIDE TEACHER CERTIFICATION
description: The Carnegie Corporation of New York plans to establish the country's first nationwide system of certifying elementary and high school teachers.

title: OFFICIALS DISAGREE ON REVIVING SPACE PROGRAM
description: The Reagan Administration was unable to agree today on a plan to revive the nation's troubled space program, amid disagreements over cost and the best method of fostering a commercial space capability.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Seattle Mariners, at Yankee Stadium, 7:30 P.M. Opener of a three-game weekend series. (Television - Channel 11, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 7:30 P.M.) Mets vs.

title: A LURE TO GO PUBLIC IN BRITAIN
description: Across London's financial district today, pinstriped professional investors have been poring over some unusual, if mouth-watering, reading. The documents under examination are chock full of references to chocolate chips, nuts and raisins.

title: AMERICAN CENTURY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income includes tax credits $36,000 for the quarter and $783,000 for the 9 months.

title: PENNSYLVANIA ENGINEERING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $274,000 for the latest first quarter and $268,000 for the year- earlier period.

title: REBUILT FLAMES NEAR THEIR UNLIKELY GOAL
description: The Montreal Canadiens have already won 22 Stanley Cups, and the Calgary Flames have none. It will be the renowned against the unknown when the Flames play hosts to the Canadiens in the opening game of the Stanley Cup final tonight at the Saddledome. That this first all-Canadian series since 1967 is also expected to be all Canadiens doesn't rile Calgary. After all, anonymity is nothing new to the Flames.

title: SHULTZ SAYS U.S. RAID JOLTED BOTH LIBYA AND SYRIA
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the American military raid on Libya had not only put that country ''in retreat'' but had also made Syria ''uneasy'' and led it to ''think hard'' about involvement in support of terrorist activities.

title: Dow Falls 33.60 Points As Interest Rates Rise
description: A big jump in interest rates proved the undoing of Wall Street yesterday, where stock prices fell sharply on moderately heavy volume.

title: U.S. Attorney Reports Indictment of Ianniello
description: A secret two-month old racketeering indictment of Matthew Ianniello was disclosed yesterday by Federal prosecutors in Manhattan.

title: D'Arcy Masius
description: D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, St. Louis, has been named the agency for the Winchester Group of the Olin Corporation. For starters, the agency will focus on the 150-year-old Winchester heritage in a $3 million multimedia campaign. The Illinois-based sporting and military ammunition products company leaves behind MacNamara, Clapp & Klein of New York.

title: Pickets Disrupt Rail Freight
description: Freight service across Conrail's 15-state rail system was substantially disrupted today by union railroad maintenance workers picketing the Government-owned freight carrier in sympathy with striking workers in Maine.

title: DEFENDANT FAINTS AGAIN AT RACKETEERING TRIAL
description: Philip Rastelli, the reputed head of the Bonanno crime family who is on trial on racketeering conspiracy charges, collapsed in court again yesterday, striking his head on a table.

title: Topics; Facts, in Pictures; A Woman's Age
description: Christine Cagney, of ''Cagney and Lacey,'' the popular police drama, hit the big Four-0 Monday night and that's news.

title: Record to Thompson
description: The International Amateur Athletic Federation, the world governing body of track and field, announced yesterday in London that it was awarding the world record for the decathlon to Daley Thompson of Britain for his performance in the 1984 Olympic Games in Los Angeles. The federation said that a close study of the electric phototimer at the Games revealed that Thompson had run one-thousandth of a second faster in the 110-meter high hurdles than had been recorded, adding 1 point to his winning score of 8,797 and tying the world record held by Jurgen Hingsen of West Germany.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on May 1 about press coverage of the Chernobyl disaster incompletely described the Reuters news agency's handling of speculation on a death toll as high as 2,000. On April 29 and April 30 Reuters variously quoted an anti-nuclear campaigner and a Senate source familiar with intelligence estimates involving combined figures for deaths and injuries. Reuters did not base its report on one from United Press International, either with or without credit.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We do not believe the educational system needs repairing; we believe it must be rebuilt to match the drastic change needed in our economy if we are to prepare our children for productive lives in the 21st century.'' -The Carnegie Corporation of New York. [ A17:3. ]

title: INTELLIGENT SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and includes a $8.7 million net charge related to the writedown of inventory.

title: DOMINICANS VOTE FOR A PRESIDENT TODAY
description: All three main presidential contenders in this Caribbean nation are predicting victory in voting Friday.

title: Hamilton, Ohio, Acts To Become Hamilton!
description: If the City Council has its way, Hamilton, Ohio, will become Hamilton! Ohio.

title: EROSION IS REPORTED NOT TO BE A THREAT TO FARMERS' YIELDS
description: Damage caused by soil washing off the nation's cropland should no longer be considered one of the gravest problems threatening the ability of American farmers to produce food, a study released today concluded.

title: Small as All Outdoors
description: Already it's clear to see that Terror Spring is going to be followed by See America Summer. So how, we wonder, can the Administration expect the National Park Service to deal with a lot more people while getting a lot less money?

title: FILM: BROWN AND COBURN IN 'DEATH OF A SOLDIER'
description: ''D EATH OF A SOLDIER,'' which opens today at the Cinema 1, is a pallid Australian film based on the true story of an American G.I. who, in 1942, admitted to the brutal murders of three young Melbourne women. Though Pvt. Edward J. Leonski was clearly as mad as a hatter - his excuse for the crimes was that he wanted to possess the voices of his victims - he was tried by an American military court, convicted and hanged by the neck until dead.

title: ART: POUSETTE-DART'S RECENT PAINTINGS ON DISPLAY
description: NEW YORK gets the recent paintings of Richard Pousette-Dart, at the Marisa del Re Gallery, 41 East 57th Street; the full retrospective it should see is confined to Florida, at Fort Lauderdale's Museum of Art. Regrettable though this is, it is somehow in character for an artist who is, so to speak, ''always a bridesmaid, never the bride.''

title: 2 Die in Soviet Georgia In Quake Near Turkey
description: A strong earthquake in Soviet Georgia two days ago killed at least two people and caused extensive damage, the Tass press agency said today.

title: INTEREST RATES RISE SHARPLY
description: Short- and long-term interest rates rose sharply yesterday, before and after the Federal Reserve announced a larger than expected increase in the nation's basic money supply.

title: BROADWAY
description: TWO bits of happy news. The first is that negotiations are going on to bring Martha Clarke's ''Vienna: Lusthaus'' back to a New York stage. The 60-minute, critically acclaimed work completed a sold-out run at St. Clement's earlier this month and if it does return, it will likely be at the Public Theater. The hope is that it will play at the Public's 299-seat Newman Theater, beginning June 4, under the auspices of -get ready for this one - the New York Shakespeare Festival and Music Theater Group-Lenox Arts Center with Robert de Rothschild. The cast, too, is still under negotiation.

title: APPLIED MATERIALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid April 25, 1986.

title: Athletes 2, Discrimination 0
description: Notes from this barrier-breaking era:

title: OUTPUT UP 0.2% IN APRIL AFTER 2-MONTH DECLINE
description: Industrial production edged up two-tenths of 1 percent in April following two months of decline, the Commerce Department reported today, but analysts said the weak advance offered little hope that the nation's battered manufacturing sector is poised for a rebound.

title: Isaac Stern at Carnegie
description: Carnegie Hall, which will close its doors this weekend for a seven- month period of renovation, concludes the 1985-86 season with a performance by Isaac Stern and the Cleveland Orchestra under the direction of Christoph von Dohnanyi tomorrow night at 8. Mr. Stern will play Beethoven's Violin Concerto; the program will also include the New York premiere of Frank Wiley's ''Abstracts'' and Bartok's ''Music for Strings, Percussion and Celesta.'' Tickets are $11 to $26. Information: 247-7800.

title: ELSINORE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Petro-Lewis, Pennzoil Loss
description: The Petro-Lewis Corporation, one of the nation's largest independent oil and gas drillers, said yesterday that it had lost $346.9 million in the third quarter, compared with a loss of $5.1 million a year ago.

title: DATA CARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: Year-ago results are restated to reflect the acquisition of Credit Card Sentinal Inc. in February, which was accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: STAGE: 'CHOPIN PLAYOFFS,' THIRD OF HOROVITZ TALES
description: HERE comes Ardenshensky, that lovable ''master of disguises,'' an old friend to anyone who has seen the first two chapters in Israel Horovitz's trilogy of plays about Jewish family life in Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario. In the third chapter, ''The Chopin Playoffs,'' Ardenshensky (Sol Frieder), now the oldest man in the Sault, once again assumes the role of a Canadian Jewish equivalent of Alistair Cooke on Masterpiece Theater. For those who missed the earlier plays, he cheerfully brings the story up to date.

title: SPECULUM MUSICAE'S BIRTHDAY GALA
description: ''We're not the Young Turks anymore,'' John Graham, who has played viola for the new-music group Speculum Musicae since its inception, said recently. ''In fact, by some standards, we might be considered rather conservative - we don't play the really far-out, conceptual, San Diego-type stuff. We're established now, but the excitement is still there.''

title: BLACK INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WEATHERFORD INTERNAIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

description: b-Includes a writedown on oil and gas properties of $2,220,000. c-Net income

title: BRITISH LAND OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The latest quarter and 9 months figures reflect a $3.5 million writedown to reflect changes in economic factors affecting one of the company's mortgages and properties.

title: 'Angel' Revival to Begin
description: The first major revival in almost 50 years of the Rodgers and Hart musical ''I Married an Angel'' will begin tomorrow night at 8 at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street.

title: White House; What They're Saying About Michael Deaver
description: Within the White House it is called, simply, ''the Deaver thing.''

title: ARGO PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a $5,473,000 writedown of oil and gas assets. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $92,000.

title: SCREEN: 'ON THE EDGE' DEPICTS RUNNER'S EFFORT
description: ''O N THE EDGE,'' which opens today at the New Carnegie, strikes some familiar chords. An athlete struggles to win with all the odds against him. He whips his body into shape by pushing it almost beyond endurance. The camera lovingly dwells on his training, his developing strength and his pained exhaustion at the end of each day. He is helped by his former coach, a grizzly old-timer who knows all there is to know about the sport but, no longer in demand, has been spending his time telling stories in the neighborhood bar. There is even the obligatory long shot of the athlete, near the end of his training, shown in silhouette at dusk, his arms flung out in triumph.

title: Almay Is Dropped
description: Saatchi & Saatchi Compton has resigned its $5 million Almay Cosmetics and Toiletries account, which it acquired a year and a half ago, to leave itself ''open to accept a major cosmetics and toiletries assignment,'' according to Edward L. Wax, president and chief executive officer of the agency. A spokesman at Almay, a subsidiary of International Playtex, said that no new assignment had been made and refused further comment.

title: ABC PLANS MOVE TO 'CAMPUS' ON WEST SIDE
description: ABC plans to move out of its mid-Manhattan headquarters and to gather on a large Upper West Side ''campus'' most of the offices and studios that are now scattered throughout the city, executives of Capital Cities/ABC said yesterday.

title: HEALTHCARE SERVICES OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GATX Will Buy Up to 30% of Stock
description: The GATX Corporation, one of the nation's largest rail car and aircraft leasing companies, said that to maximize shareholder value it would repurchase up to 30 percent of its common stock outstanding, increase its dividend and adopt a shareholder rights plan designed to thwart takeover attempts.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Jim Calhoun, whose teams at Northeastern won at least 20 games in five of the last six seasons and received National Collegiate Athletic Association invitations the last three years, has been hired as basketball coach at the University of Connecticut. He succeeds Dom Perno, who resigned a month ago after nine years and a 12-16 record last season. . . . The Giants signed 20 free agents yesterday and three of them had some local appeal: Doug Butler, quarterback at Princeton, Henry Santos, quarterback at Columbia, and Al Smith, running back at Rutgers.

title: 'PAUL CADMUS,' ON 13, A STUDY OF THE ARTIST AT 80
description: TELEVISION has never been completely at ease in dealing with art and artists. At its best, the medium can serve as a kind of college extension course, covering vast expanses or focusing on intricate details. At its worst, it can hire a celebrity to oversee a second-rate essay. Then, every once in a great while, a film comes along to demonstrate other possibilities, other approaches. One such production is ''Paul Cadmus: Enfant Terrible at 80,'' which can be seen tonight at 10 o'clock on Channel 13.

title: WHITE HOUSE STRUCTURE A PART OF DEAVER INQUIRY
description: A House committee today initiated an investigation on whether the Office of Management and Budget, National Security Council and other components of the Executive Office of the President were legally part of the White House for the purpose of conflict-of-interest laws.

title: Your Money; New Insurance For Employees
description: WHEN Carole Hatton, an administrative assistant at the Mead Corporation in Dayton, Ohio, was given the opportunity to purchase a group universal life insurance policy at her company at the beginning of this year, she jumped at the opportunity.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY MAY 17, 1986
description: International Eden Pastora Gomez is quitting as the leader of an anti-Sandinista guerrilla force. He announced in Costa Rica that he was laying down his weapons and permanently abandoning his war against the Nicaraguan Government. He described himself as ''shot down by the C.I.A., but not defeated.'' [ Page 3, Column 4. ] A State Department dismissal of an official was ordered by Secretary of State George P. Shultz because the official had made ''an unauthorized disclosure of classified information to the news media,'' the department announced. This was the first time in memory that the department had publicly announced the dismissal of an official for ''leaks'' to the press. It followed by two days Mr. Shultz's complaint at a news conference that the Government had become ''a gusher'' for such leaks. The department declined to name the dismissed official, but two high-ranking officials said he was Spencer C. Warren, a member of the department's policy planning board. [ 3:1. ] American doctors in Moscow said that four more victims of the Chernobyl reactor accident had died in the last 24 hours, bring the total to 13. The physicians, Robert P. Gale and Richard Champlin, who have been helping treat the most seriously afflicted victims at a Moscow hospital, said the additional deaths were caused by radiation exposure. [ 4:3. ] National The Producer Price Index dropped six-tenths of 1 percent in April, its lowest level in nearly two and a half years, the Labor Department announced.

title: Accord Reached on Pensions For New Federal Employees
description: The Reagan Administration and Congressional leaders have agreed on a new pension system for Federal workers hired since 1984 that is designed to save $2 billion a year, officials said Thursday.

title: Cuomo Will Announce For New Term Monday
description: Governor Cuomo plans to announce his candidacy for re-election on Monday, members of his administration said today.

title: BALTEK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $7,494 in the latest quarter and $42,000 in the year-earlier period.

title: D'AMATO ANNOUNCES FOR 2D TERM
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, who had to bus Long Island supporters into Manhattan when he announced six years ago that he would run for the Senate, declared his candidacy for a second term yesterday surrounded by Republican and Conservative party leaders and Robert Dole, the Senate majority leader.

title: 2 Marines Killed by Mortar
description: Two marines were killed and five injured Thursday when a mortar exploded in a training exercise, according to a base spokesman, Lieut.

title: PRATT-READ CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $963,738 for the quarter and $1,407,985 for the 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $304,652 for the quarter and $794,602 for the 9 months.

title: G.M. and Suzuki
description: The General Motors Corporation and the Japanese auto maker Suzuki are close to agreement on a joint car-making venture in Canada and will announce a site soon, a G.M. spokesman said.

description: b-Includes a one-time pre-tax charge of about $700,000 to cover severance costs associated with a 7 percent worldwide work force reduction. c-Net income

description: The Economy

title: Bridge; Queens Player in L.I. Event Works Hard for Extra Trick
description: It is seldom true for bridge players, as it is for the Marines, that ''the impossible takes a little longer.'' A declarer who makes an impossibly large number of tricks has usually brought off a quick swindle or has had the benefit of an opening lead that has permitted discards.

title: Teddy White, the Maker of Epics
description: Theodore H. White became almost as famous as the potentates he wrote about. Armed with a notebook, ingratiating grin and fine intelligence, he grew to be a most discerning witness of America's most distinctive rite, not just the election but the making of our Presidents. Starting memorably in 1960 with the Kennedy-Nixon campaign, he gave shape and drama to the sloppy disorder of four consecutive contests. He had an acute eye for important bit-players, and if his heroes tended to be a bit larger than life, they inhabited epics.

title: JOE SPARMA
description: Joe Sparma, a former Detroit Tigers pitcher and Ohio State University quarterback, died at Riverside Hospital Wednesday, 10 days after suffering a heart attack and undergoing triple-bypass surgery.

ALAMO SAVINGS ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

title: A RETREAT MARKS 100 DISCREETLY
description: One hundred years ago this fall Griswold Lorillard created a sartorial sensation by appearing at the first autumn ball here with the tails of his dinner jacket lopped off. But to Tuxedo Park, the exclusive, gated town that gave men's formal wear its name, the tuxedo's centennial is nothing to celebrate.

title: Labor's Duty to New York's Health
description: All New Yorkers should hope for prompt resolution of the leadership struggle in the city's largest hospital workers' union, which begins contract negotiations this month. Two years ago, the union's internal troubles complicated the negotiations and contributed to a 47-day strike. Whether such difficulties can be avoided this year depends in part on how quickly the Department of Labor resolves a challenge to a union election.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 13. 1. This couple went to their senior prom at Salinas High School in Salinas, Calif. Why was that noteworthy? 2. ''All the resources of a superpower cannot isolate a man who hears the voice of freedom, a voice I heard from the very chamber of my soul.'' Who made this comment and what were the circumstances? 3. Of the 40,000 vessels expected to participate in the Fourth of July flotilla in New York Harbor, perhaps none will have a more dramatic nautical entrance than the Queen Elizabeth 2. Who chartered the ship to carry 1,600 passengers from London to the festivities? 4. Nearly 100 priests and priestesses in a foreign country have been hacked, burned or otherwise put to death since February, as religious vigilantes attempt to eradicate the nation's ancestral religion. Identify the nation and the religion. 5. ''The closest thing we've got to a smoking gun,'' said a source close to the Presidential panel investigating the explosion of the Challenger space shuttle, referring to a letter. What were its contents? 6. Copies of 80 mimeographed lists that have supposedly been top secret for nearly 40 years have been readily available on an open shelf at an archive in Maryland. What lists are they? 7. When Nebraskans vote for a Governor in November, they will be making history. Explain. 8. If tax revision becomes law along the lines of the Senate Finance Committee's proposal, would New York State residents face increased or decreased state and local taxes? 9.

description: b-Net loss

title: Wilma H. Jordan Becomes Bride Of George Green
description: Wilma Hacker Jordan, the daughter of Reo Hacker of Knoxville, Tenn., and the late Mrs. Hacker, was married yesterday to George J. Green, the son of Monroe Green of Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Mrs. Green. Milton Mollen, the Presiding Justice of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, officiated at a private ceremony in Manhattan.

title: ARTRA GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $1,688,000. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $728,000.

title: U.S. Has No Response To Protests by Mexico
description: The State Department has declined to comment on an official note of protest that the Mexican Government presented to Secretary of State George P. Shultz on Wednedsay.

title: Bell Atlantic Paging Service
description: Bell Atlantic has been told to get rid of a substantial portion of its paging marketing business. Federal District Judge Harold H. Greene granted a waiver of the decree that broke up the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and authorized Bell Atlantic to provide paging services outside the area where it provides local telephone service.

title: HOMAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $8,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: KID STUFF For some time children's museums have stood in Brooklyn - one of the nation's oldest is there - and Staten Island. But in Manhattan, the nation's museum capital, folks had been so busy with the big picture that a museum designed solely for children seemed to have had little priority. In 1973, such an institution was founded, the Manhattan Laboratory Museum. It started out on West 86th Street, later moved to 314 West 54th Street, and eventually changed its name. It is now the Children's Museum of Manhattan (765-5904).

title: Cadbury and RJR
description: Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C. said it was negotiating to buy the Canada Dry and Sunkist soft drink units from RJR Nabisco Inc. Cadbury Schweppes, confirming earlier reports of the negotiations, said ''a further announcement will be made in due course.'' It gave no details about when the deal might be completed or what the price would be. If completed, the deal would take RJR out of the soft drink business and make London-based Cadbury Schweppes, which already sells a line of mixers and ginger ale in this country, the third-largest company in the United States soft drink market, with a share of about 5.4 percent.

title: INTEGRATED RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from the energy division of $7,133,000 and an extraordinary loss of $10,510,000 from early extinguishment of subordinated debentures. c-Net income after losses from the energy division of $437,000. Preferred stock dividends were $8,531,000 for the latest quarter and $9,835,000 for the year-ago period.

title: BIOTECH CAPITAL CORPORATION reports earnings for As of March 31
description: Assets reflect net assets.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about the effect of soaring insurance costs on the recreation industry misstated the ownership of the Astroland amusement park at Coney Island. It is privately owned.

title: Writing
description: Patrick J. Buchanan, the White House communications director, faces a ticklish task in choosing a successor to Bently T. Elliott, the director of Presidential speechwriting. Mr. Elliott plans to resign next month to join the staff of Representative Jack F. Kemp of upstate New York, where one of his duties is likely to be helping the potential Presidential aspirant speak fluent Chief Executive.

title: Del-Lords Share Bill
description: The Del-Lords and Rank and File will play a double bill tonight at the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street (254-2800). Tickets are $13.50 ; Rank and File begins about 11:30 P.M.; the Del-Lords at 1 A.M.

title: Cruise Ship Illnesses Up Since Inspections Halted
description: More than 1,100 passengers have become ill aboard two cruise ships based in South Florida in the month since budget cuts forced Federal health teams to drop surprise inspections.

title: Rents That Are Both Too High and Too Low
description: To the Editor:

title: Good Cop, Bad Cop to Mexico
description: Mexico is a proud country beset by humbling problems. How best to confront its lapses in drug enforcement? For more than a year the Reagan Administration has played bad cop, good cop, sending some officials to condemn Mexican corruption and others to engage in soothing negotiations. That's the context in which to assess Washington's most recent, most stinging public assault.

title: CLASSIC CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Roy Haynes Quintet
description: The drummer Roy Haynes will lead his quintet tonight at Mikell's, 760 Columbus Avenue, at 97th Street (864-8832). Sets are at 10 P.M., midnight and 1:30 A.M.; there is a $12 cover and a three-drink minimum.

title: Protest on Liberty Medals
description: The Statue of Liberty-Ellis Island Foundation will give medals to a dozen prominent naturalized citizens during the Fourth of July weekend.

title: Du PONT HEIR'S GIFTS TO LaROUCHE GROUP SPARK A COURT BATTLE WITH FAMILY
description: Since Lewis duPont Smith became attracted to the politics of Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr., Mr. Smith has given the LaRouche organization loans and donations totaling $212,000, he has moved to rural Virginia to be closer to the group's headquarters and he has cut off almost all contact with his family.

title: NEW BRUNSWICK SCIENTIFIC CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
The U.S. Stake in South Korean Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: FLAMES WIN OPENER WITH SURGE IN 3D
description: If the Calgary Flames were tired from their exploits in the pair of seven-game series against the Edmonton Oilers and St. Louis Blues that got them to the Stanley Cup final, they did not betray it tonight. Instead, they used a strong third period to beat the well-rested Montreal Canadiens, 5-2, at the Saddledome and take a 1-0 lead in the series.

title: HOW TO GET TO FIRST BASE IN CENTRAL PARK
description: The past few summers, I've played softball in Central Park. I've learned a number of things: things about myself (I hit up the middle when I'm going good), about other people (left-handed power is at a premium) and about dealing with pressure (a guy on a bike sells a short beer for a buck).

title: 'Leaky' Satellites Need Corks
description: How often, not so long ago, did we hear television anchormen tell us, in hushed tones, ''This report comes to us live via satellite?'' And how often would we slide forward on our chairs and watch with amazement as an image of an event occurring in some far-off place appeared on our screens?

title:
Patents;
A Helicopter Device To Aid in Rescues
description: A helicopter rescue device, in the shape of a platform to be attached to the front of the craft, is designed for quick removal of personnel from a burning building.

title: Pretoria Is Said to Hold Cleric on Arms Charges
description: A leading black South African cleric was reported to have been detained today on charges of illegal arms possession.

title: The Last Great Rain Forest
description: The Tongass National Forest, the last great rain forest in the United States, is being destroyed, pointlessly, by the Government that professes to care about preserving the nation's environment. Why? The forest, which covers most of the southern panhandle of Alaska, is bigger than the state of West Virginia. The value of this land of centuries-old spruce is aesthetic and ecological rather than economic. Access is hampered by harsh weather, difficult terrain and distance to market.

title: LARGE COCAINE SHIPMENT SEIZED
description: Federal officials said yesterday that they had seized 500 pounds of cocaine that had entered New York early this month in large bales of paper on a Colombian freighter.

title: GUIDE TO HOW TAXPAYERS WOULD FARE UNDER SENATE PROPOSAL
description: For those taxpayers who want to see how they would fare under the Senate Finance Committee's tax-revision plan - should it be enacted intact - the following line-by-line instructions, worksheet and tax tables may be helpful. (Note: Taxpayers should break out their 1985 tax return to make their calculations; with it, they will be able to compare what they would pay under the Senate plan, as well as what they would pay if the tax code remains unchanged.) All calculations are for the 1988 tax year - the first year that most provisions in the Senate committee plan are to become fully effective.

title: DANCE: MARLEEN PENNISON OFFERS 'IF WALLS COULD TALK'
description: Marleen Pennison takes on an impressively big and unusual subject for dance in ''If Walls Could Talk,'' a new piece performed on Wednesday at the Marymount Manhattan Theater, where the Marleen Pennison Company will be through tonight. Miss Pennison has a gift for Southern storytelling and often incorporates complex emotional and historical elements into her dance. And ''If Walls Could Talk'' is so blessedly without the kind of protective irony that undermines so much new theater-dance work these days that one wants to enjoy it on those grounds alone. But Miss Pennison's usually shrewd overview of her material has deserted her here.

title: PETROMINERALS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a $4,752,000 writedown of oil and gas assets. c-Net income

title: SLUMPING YANKEES DROP THIRD IN ROW
description: For five weeks, they enjoyed good times. Now, the Yankees are in the depths of a slump - if a three-game losing streak can be considered a slump - and there seems no immediate way out.

title: 3 CANDIDATES ARE CONFIDENT AS DOMINICANS VOTE
description: Under a blazing tropical sun, Dominican voters turned out in large numbers today in one of the most closely contested presidential elections in the history of this Caribbean nation.

title: LTV Beginning Cost-Saving Plan
description: The LTV Corporation, the giant steelmaker and military contractor, said at its shareholder meeting that it was initiating a three-point program aimed at saving its steel segment an additional $200 million this year. The plan, which comes two weeks after the company announced a $550 debt exchange offer, calls for reduced energy use at its steel plants, a lowering of capital spending, and the production of higher-grade steel to improve revenue.

title: CENTURI INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $103,000 for the latest quarter and $448,000 for the year-ago period.

title: INTERPOL OFFICE IN PARIS ATTACKED
description: Terrorists attacked the headquarters of Interpol, the international police agency, with guns and explosives Friday night, wounding a policeman in the arm and shattering windows, the authorities said.

title: Coastal Dry Dock
description: The Coastal Dry Dock and Repair Corporation filed for bankruptcy protection under Chapter 11 of Federal bankruptcy laws in Eastern District Court in Brooklyn. The company, the primary tenant of the Brooklyn Navy Yard, employs from 600 to 1,000 workers, depending upon how many Navy ships it is working on at any one time. ''Their costs of operation have been a major problem,'' said John C. Biggins, interim commissioner of the Office of Business Development for New York. Mr. Biggins said he was ''optimistic'' about the prospects for the company's reorganization.

title: SOON YOU'LL KNOW WHAT'S IN A BURGER
description: After July 1 patrons of McDonald's restaurants in New York State will be able to find out exactly what goes into Big Macs, french fries, Chicken McNuggets and just about everything else sold in the chain. The Attorney General's office describes the decision as an ''unprecedented action,'' but Burger King has beaten McDonald's and the Attorney General to the punch.

title: U.S. Boxer in Final
description: An American, Alex Garcia, an ex-convict-turned-boxer, yesterday advanced to the superheavyweight championship of amateur boxing's world championships by stopping Biagio Chianese of Italy in the third and final round with a fourth standing-eight count.

title: HURST STRIKES OUT 14 IN LOSS
description: Oddibe McDowell, Pete Incaviglia and Steve Buechele backed Jose Guzman's seven-hit pitching with home runs tonight to lead the Texas Rangers to a 4-1 victory over Boston, despite a career-high 14 strikeouts by Bruce Hurst of the Red Sox.

title: MENDIK'S FORMULA FOR SUCCESS
description: Bernard H. Mendik describes himself as New York's most successful janitor, and in a way he is right. The family of businesses he controls does maintain 10 million square feet of office space in Manhattan, the equivalent of the two towers in the World Trade Center.

title: 4 Family Members Die In Kingston House Fire
description: A fire apparently started by a kerosene heater took the lives of a grandfather, his son, and two of the son's children when it flared up in their house here Thursday night, the police said today.

title: DOME MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

title: '84 MEMO ON U.S.F.L. AT ISSUE
description: Commissioner Pete Rozelle of the National Football League testified yesterday that he had no knowledge of a 1984 internal memo in which the league's chief labor negotiator told his staff he intended ''to scare'' the owners about the United States Football League in a ''closet meeting.''

description: Michael K. Deaver, former deputy White House chief of staff, told Congress today that charges that he had exploited his friendship with President Reagan on behalf of his lobbying clients were ''an implicit attack on the integrity of the President.''

title: DANCE: 'GISELLE' PRESENTED BY BALLET THEATER
description: As portrayed by Cynthia Harvey and Patrick Bissell on Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, Giselle and Albrecht were two contented young lovers in the first act of American Ballet Theater's production of ''Giselle.''

description: Avis and National Car Rental charge customers for any damage to a car if they drive ''off paved roads,'' whether or not they pay for collision coverage. Their rental contracts say so.

title: Allure of the Other
description: OUT OF INDIA. By Ruth Prawer Jhabvala. 288 pages. William Morrow & Company. $16.95. Ruth Prawer Jhabvala's India is a place of astonishing beauty and quick, surprising passions, a place where heat and time take their toll, where tradition and modernity, Eastern and Western values collide and confound the observer. It is a place of terrible poverty and jarring horrors - ''people dying of starvation in the streets, children kidnapped and maimed to be sent out as beggars'' -but it is also a place whose loveliness promises revelation and redemption.

BRONX MAN IS KILLED ATTEMPTING TO RESIST A CHAIN-SNATCHING
description: A 37-year-old Bronx man was dragged to his death yesterday when he lost his gold necklace to a chain-snatcher and clung to a door handle as the robber sped away in a stolen car with an accomplice at the wheel, the police reported. A 17-year-old bystander also was injured in the incident.

METS FALL IN 11TH ON SQUEEZE PLAY
description: It was either a duel of renowed pitchers or a comedy of infield errors, and neither Dwight Gooden nor Orel Hershiser was around when it ended. And it ended in a strangely dramatic way, too, when Bill Russell's suicide-squeeze bunt in the 11th inning gave the Los Angeles Dodgers a 4-3 victory over the Mets.

description: The board of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting today approved a $219.7 million spending plan for 1987 in which $3 million is set aside to induce public broadcasting stations to produce new programs that can be shown nationwide.

title: Thomas McLernon, Manager Of Transit Authority in 1950's
description: Thomas J. McLernon, general manager of the New York City Transit Authority in the 1950's, died Wednesday at his home in Spring Lake Heights, N.J.He was 80 years old.

title: LETTER TO COMMISSION ASSERTS NASA DATA WERE DESTROYED
description: Federal officials said today that they are investigating an anonymous allegation that engineering documents at the Marshall Space Flight Center in Alabama were destroyed after the shuttle Challenger's disaster, even though all such data were supposed to be preserved for the accident investigations.

title: WIDE COALITION FORMED BEHIND SENATE TAX BILL
description: More than 100 companies, trade associations, consumer groups and civic organizations announced today that they had joined forces to support the tax-revision legislation approved by the Senate Finance Committee last week and to fight efforts to make fundamental changes in the bill.

That means that any furs still in your closet at home should be sent as soon as possible to a cold-storage vault.

description: Such mainstays of executive pay as deferred compensation and stock options may become a thing of the past if the Senate Finance Committee's tax-revision bill is enacted. As top tax rates fall drastically, executives will end up with more cash and, many tax experts say, there will be fewer tax-reducing programs that are now commonly part of an executive's pay package.

The story is too silly, the murders too predictable and unimaginative, the blood too phony and the acting too much on the level of a bad high school play to send so much as a shiver down anyone's spine.

title: TV: NEW 'STAGECOACH,' STARRING KRISTOFFERSON
description: Once upon a time, Ernest Lee Haycox wrote a short story titled ''Stage to Lordsburg.'' It was published in The Saturday Evening Post. In the 1930's, the story was adapted by Dudley Nichols for the movies and, directed by John Ford, a film classic called ''Stagecoach'' was born, making a star out of John Wayne in the process. In 1966, a remake of ''Stagecoach,'' starring Bing Crosby in the Doc Holliday role that had won an Academy Award for Thomas Mitchell, turned out to be disastrous. Now, the western chestnut has been reheated for television. This version, on CBS tomorrow at 9 P.M., is merely laughable.

title: Back to Science Advisers
description: Science increasingly transforms the military, political and economic landscape in which governments must operate. Nevertheless, since 1972, scientific advice to the United States Government has been remarkably haphazard. For that and other reasons, the nation is embarked on vast programs based on the misconceptions that we have an unlimited supply of scientific talent and that there need be no relationship between cost and benefit.

title: Farm Agency Squeeze

Vance L. Clark, the agency's administrator, said Thursday that some states had exhausted their allocations. In all, he said, the agency has about $159 million that has not been formally obligated as loans to farmers.

description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $2,660,000. c-Net loss includes a loss from discontinued operations of $3,537,000.

title: Medieval Festival
description: Medieval fare will blend with the modern at a festival today at the Church of the Holy Trinity, 316 East 88th Street.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''After five months of leaks, rumors and innuendo, today is my turn.'' -Michael K. Deaver. [ 35:4. ]

title: Reagans, Bushes And the Tax Plan
description: The tax revision plan approved by the Senate Finance Committee has both winners and losers in almost every income class.

title: HMO AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: ROCKETS WIN, TAKE 2-1 LEAD
description: The crown that the Los Angeles Lakers have worn so confidently for nearly a year is suddenly slipping, for the upstart Houston Rockets, a team Coach Pat Riley of the Lakers recently called a ''team of the future,'' have quickly become a team of the present.

title: PEC ISRAEL ECONOMIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $213,086.

title: Conditions for Leonard
description: Jose Sulaiman, the president of the World Boxing Council, says that a proposed middleweight title bout between Marvelous Marvin Hagler, the champion, and Sugar Ray Leonard, the retired former welterweight champion, would be sanctioned only if three conditions were met: The bout must receive support from the public, Leonard must pass a strict physical examination by the W.B.C. medical advisory board and the majority of the W.B.C. executive committee must approve the match. The bout, proposed by Leonard, who has been retired for two years, might be expected to gross about $40 million.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch on Monday from Albuquerque, N.M., about the University of New Mexico, incorrectly described the French film ''Hail Mary,'' which aroused controversy there. The film portrays the Virgin Mary as a Parisian high school student, not a prostitute.

title: SEA CONTAINERS GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PACE MEMBERSHIP WAREOUSE reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
description: b-Includes an extraordinary tax credit of $78,000. c-Net loss

title:
Patents;
A Carrier for Skiers
description: A ski and ski-pole carrier and snow scraper, patented this week, is offered by the Inventors Licensing and Marketing Agency, Tarzana, Calif. Mark H. Uyeda of Fullerton, Calif., received patent No. 4,588,115 for the device, named the Skibble. It is described as compact enough to fit in the pocket of a skier's jacket.

title: SOME IN MOSCOW CALL HIS TV ADDRESS ON CHERNOBYL TOO LATE TO ALLAY FEARS
description: Talking about Mikhail S. Gorbachev's speech about Chernobyl the other night, one Muscovite said the Soviet leader seemed to have forgotten an old Russian proverb: ''The Russian doesn't cross himself until he hears the thunder.''

title: KATY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $153,000 and an extraordinary gain of $892,000 from the termination of a pension plan. The year-ago results are restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: Federal Judge Begins Serving Prison Term
description: Federal District Judge Harry E. Claiborne today became the first sitting Federal judge to go to prison, reporting to a minimum-security camp to serve a two-year sentence for tax evasion while still drawing his $78,200 salary.

title: WIESENTHAL FAULTS JEWISH CONGRESS ON WALDHEIM
description: Simon Wiesenthal, the Austrian hunter of Nazi war criminals, accused the World Jewish Congress today of stirring anti-Semitic sentiment in his country through its campaign against Kurt Waldheim, the former United Nations Secretary General and candidate for the Austrian presidency.

title: Officer Seized in Drug Case
description: A North Bergen, N.J., police officer has been arrested in connection with an operation that manufactured crack, a highly addictive form of cocaine, authorities said last night. The officer, whose identity was not disclosed, was arrested Friday night when he delivered one kilo of raw cocaine to a crack-processing laboratory, according to spokesmen for the Hudson County, N.J., prosecutor and the North Bergen police. Two others were also arrested, and about four pounds of cocaine was seized, said a spokesman for the prosecutor.

title: DAUGHTERS, FIGHTING FOR FREUD'S MANTLE
description: MELANIE KLEIN Her World and Her Work. By Phyllis Grosskurth. Illustrated. 515 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $25.

title: Maryland Has Seat-Belt Law
description: Maryland became the 25th state to adopt a law requiring use of seat belts when Gov. Harry Hughes signed a bill Tuesday. Motorists must buckle up beginning July 1. The police will be able to give a ticket only if they stop a vehicle for another violation.

title: SYRIAN PRESIDENT REPORTED TO FACE HARSH CHALLENGES
description: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria, whose Government has been linked by Western countries to terrorism and a desire to expand Syrian influence in the Middle East, finds himself facing threats from inside and outside his country.

title: BRIGHT YOUNG TALENTS: SIX ARTISTS WITH A FUTURE
description: Now that the art season is winding down, the professional critic is plagued by a two-word question. It comes his way from all over. The young and the old, the rich and the poor, the innocent and the experienced, the stranger and the lifelong friend, the amateur and the professional, the honeymooner and the married-since-ever, all send it by Federal Express. ''Who's new?'' they ask. And very grumpy they get, if an answer is not forthcoming.

title: FEDERAL PAYMENT FOR TRANSPLANTS FOR POOR STUDIED
description: A Federal study commission will soon recommend a comprehensive new policy to encourage the donating and transplanting of human kidneys, livers and hearts.

title: WAR-CRIME VERDICT
description: The criminals of World War II are growing older, but age has not proved a refuge. Andrija Artukovic, an 86-year-old Croatian nationalist extradited from California for trial in Zagreb, Yugoslavia, was convicted last week and sentenced to death by firing squad for ordering mass killings while he was an official of the Nazi-supported Croatian Government in the 1940's.

title: WALL STREET'S ARMY OF INSIDERS
description: THE fine wine flowed and the 190 guests dined on ginger shrimp and roast veal at the festive dinner that Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company threw last month to celebrate the investment firm's just-completed buyout of the Beatrice Companies, the consumer products giant.

title: Putting Kids First
description: I want to commend Gail Gregg for her article ''Putting Kids First'' (April 13), on the dilemma fathers face in choosing between family and work.

title: Four Loophole Senators
description: Four grandstanding Senators up for re-election this fall have rushed to challenge the Senate Finance Committee proposal to cut back the generous tax benefits for Investment Retirement Accounts. To placate the minority of taxpayers who invest in I.R.A.'s and the financial institutions that manage the money, Senators D'Amato, Dodd, Cranston and Murkowski would sabotage the Federal tax indexation formula that benefits all taxpayers.

title: DRESS FOR SUCCESS: THE DUST JACKET AS ART, ADVERTISEMENT AND NUISANCE
description: IT appears to be a matter of fashion, if not one of etiquette, that today's trade book does not make its debut without wearing a dust jacket.

title: MORRIS DANCERS BRING A BIT OF OLD ENGLAND TO LIFE
description: IN moments, the lawn in front of Yale University's Sterling Library changed from an abandoned spot of green to a place of celebration.

title: ONE MAN'S BLUEPRINT
description: PRIDE OF PLACE Building the American Dream. By Robert A. M. Stern with Thomas Mellins and Raymond Gastil. Illustrated. 344 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. New York: American Heritage. $34.95. BOOKS deriving from television shows have rarely been noteworthy for their quality, and the volume accompanying the Public Broadcasting Service series ''Pride of Place,'' aired across the country this spring, adds no luster to that literary genre. Its author, Robert A. M. Stern, is an architect, the director of Columbia University's Temple Hoyne Buell Center for the Study of American Architecture and the author of several books on American architecture. Though the opening credits of the television presentation bear the helpful subtitle ''A Personal View,'' the book regrettably carries no such disclaimer. Thus, the average reader runs the risk of mistaking this polemic in praise of postmodernism, the classical tradition and upper-class architectural tastes as an objective history.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article about state taxes on March 2 in Your Taxes, a special section, incorrectly described Connecticut's assessment on capital gains. It is a flat 7 percent tax.

title: THE UMP AS HERO
description: THE CONDUCT OF THE GAME By John Hough Jr. 340 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $14.95.

title: WHITES WHO LEFT ZIMBABWE, FEARFUL OF FUTURE, DRIFT BACK
description: They left for many reasons. For some, it was a lack of job opportunity. For others, the schools did not seem good enough. And for still others it was just a vague apprehension about what a black majority government would mean for a white minority.

title: A CORRECTION
description: In the New Jersey Journal last week, a statement about the shelter for the homeless in Hackensack was incorrect. It is operated by Bergen County.

title: PLAYING FOR EARLY GAINS
description: It's all right if you cap a long positional battle by winning a decisive pawn, and it's all right to win a decisive pawn if it's a byproduct of your mating attack. These are noble endeavors.

title: BRUSHING UP ON BASIC ARITHMETIC
description: A chart accompanying Robert Hunter's April 13 Forum article (''Taming the Latest Insurance Crisis'') elicited an unusually large number of responses. Following is one of those letters - and a reply from Mr. Hunter:

title: THE LANDSCAPE: LOVE IT OR MOVE IT
description: I HAVE a good friend in Amagansett whose house overlooks an exquisite landscape of rolling lawns, a pond and a distant wood. He does not spend too much time outdoors, however - his idea of a close relationship with nature is to look at this lush creation through the huge windows that precisely frame his view.

title: EVERYTHING HAD ITS PRICE
description: SOLD The Rise and Fall of the House of Sotheby. By Nicholas Faith. Illustrated. 269 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $17.95. ''WHOLLY UNACCEPTABLE'' The Bitter Battle for Sotheby's. By Jeffrey Hogrefe. Illustrated. 238 pp. New York: Wiliam Morrow & Company. $17.95.

title: PREVENTIVE MEDICINE FOR MUNICIPAL SCANDALS
description: IN the four months since Queens Borough President Donald R. Manes was found dazed and bleeding in his car early one morning in Queens, prosecutors' initial suspicions have grown into a full-scale municipal scandal. Officials at three agencies - the Parking Violations Bureau, the Taxi and Limousine Commission and the Health and Hospitals Corporation - have been accused of extorting bribes from businessmen. In all, nearly a dozen people have been charged with offering or receiving bribes in return for city contracts; five have pleaded guilty. (Mr. Manes committed suicide in March, after prosecutors indicated that they were seeking to indict him as well.) The breadth and seriousness of the allegations have caused many to question whether the city government should alter the way it does business. Should municipal work be contracted out to private companies? Should the structure of city government be changed? These were among the questions Alan Finder, an editor of The Week in Review, asked three municipal experts: Charles Brecher, an associate professor at the Graduate School of Public Administration at New York University; Robert F. Wagner Jr., a former Deputy Mayor who is a member of the New York City Board of Education, and John S. Martin Jr., a former United States Attorney in Manhattan. Excerpts of their remarks follow. CHARLES BRECHER: Curbing the Role of Party Regulars

title: A GUITARIST, A FLUTIST AND PIANIST IN RECITALS
description: Svjetlana Kabalin -- The flutist Svjetlana Kabalin, who made her New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall last Sunday afternoon, is a founding member of the Sylvan Wind Quintet, and has performed with the Orpheus Chamber Ensemble, the Waterloo Festival Orchestra and the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra.

title:
INVESTING;
AN UNCERTAIN TIME FOR TAX-EXEMPTS
description: IN recent weeks, tax-exempt bonds have been held hostage by two forces: the likelihood of tax revision and the threat of higher interest rates.

title: Sharon L. Miller Wed in Scarsdale
description: Sharon Lynn Miller, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold L. Miller of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to David Andrew Parker, a son of Dr. and Mrs. William S. Parker of Baltimore. Rabbi Jack Stern Jr. performed the ceremony at the Fenway Golf Club in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: GROWING UP POST-JEWISH
description: THE GREAT PRETENDER By James Atlas. 277 pp. New York: Atheneum. $15.95.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
PATRICIANS WITH A VIEW
description: Located predominantly along the eastern shore of the Hudson River is a fine collection of country villas that represents a broad range of architectural styles. All share a scenic view of the river, as well as past or present ownership by some of the most famous families in America, including the Rensselaers, Roosevelts, Goulds and Rockefellers.

title: Boston Suburb Backed On New Racial Policy
description: A state panel has approved a plan by the Town of Dedham, a nearly all-white suburb of Boston, aimed at hiring more women and members of minority groups.

title: A PLAYWRIGHT'S EARLY WORKS OFFER GLIMPSES OF HIS LATER GENIUS
description: In ''The Lady of Larkspur Lotion'' - the first of 10 one-act plays by Tennessee Williams now being staged by The Acting Company at the Lucille Lortel Theater -a New Orleans landlady comes to demand the rent from a dotty old tenant. The woman says she cannot afford it until she receives the next quarterly payment from the caretaker of her Brazilian rubber plantation. When the landlady lights into her, ridiculing the fiction, a character identified only as the Writer arrives. ''Stop badgering this poor woman!'' he declares. ''Is there no mercy in the world anymore? What has become of compassion and understanding? Where have they all gone to? Where's God? Where's Christ?'' He pauses, shaking with rage. ''What if there is no Brazilian rubber plantation?''

title: DEATH ON STATE HIGHWAYS DECLINE TO LOWEST LEVEL SINCE '49
description: Fatalities and serious injuries on New York State's highways dropped last year to their lowest levels in decades, despite a rising number of drivers and cars on the roads, Governor Cuomo said yesterday.

title: A GUITARIST, A FLUTIST AND PIANIST IN RECITALS
description: Richard Savino -- Richard Savino neatly bisected his May 10th program at Carnegie Recital Hall into a selection of music for lute - by Anthony Holborne, Francesco da Milano and John Dowland - and works for guitar by Mauro Giuliani, Reginald Smith Brindle and Frederico Moreno Torroba. There was even one ''crossover'' piece: a lute suite by Bach played on guitar.

title: A MASTERWORK MADE PUBLIC
description: Gustav Mahler died 75 years ago today, and only now will musicians, scholars and the general public be able to own a facsimile manuscript of one of the composer's symphonies.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: EARLY ELKIN. By Stanley Elkin. (Bamberger Books, P.O. Box 1126, Flint, Mich. 48501, Cloth, $15. Paper, $7.50.) ''I was no prodigy,'' Stanley Elkin warns in his introduction to the odd assortment - three stories, one critique-cum-story, one memoir - that make up the 1950's wing of ''my little awful Elkin museum.'' But he would have us take this book to heart, regardless, as a sort of pep talk on the virtues of resolve, patience and desire in the making of a writer. Indeed, in the long story, ''The Party,'' it is difficult to see the wit or edgy tough-mindedness that would later distinguish such bravura performances as ''The Dick Gibson Show'' and ''The Franchiser.'' Instead we find ethnic sentimentality, clumsy flashbacks, portentous phrasings. Yet, even amid failures of technique and imagination, the Elkin sensibility struggles to its feet. ''That he was unhappy was his tragedy,'' he writes of the protagonist. ''Or rather that he was not happy made him unhappy and that was his tragedy.'' Similarly, ''A Sound of Distant Thunder,'' which gives us a Jewish shopkeeper in a failing urban neighborhood (the prototype, perhaps, for the extraordinary ''Criers and Kibitzers, Kibitzers and Criers''), has, despite its simplistic view of character and fate, a firm grip on the details of work and environment. The story reaches its climax with a sales spiel that anticipates the arias Elkin characters will deliver, to great effect, in the three decades following. In my opinion, the only wholly successful piece - aside from the wise, funny memoir, ''Where I Read What I Read'' - is ''Fifty Dollars,'' and it strikes me as an untypical effort, more somber and mannered than the mature work. Mr. Elkin, it appears, really wasn't a prodigy.

title: Kimberly Warendorf To Wed D. J. Prey 3d
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold M. Warendorf of Bay Head, N.J., and New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kimberly Jane Warendorf, to Duval James Prey 3d, the son of Diane Prey of Somerville, N.J., and Mr. Prey Jr. of Denver. An October wedding is planned.

title: A SOUPCON OF FRANCE IN THE CATSKILLS
description: In the decade following World War II, some expatriate Frenchmen looked at a region of the Catskills and saw the Jura mountain range; others saw the valleys and trout-filled streams by the Pyrenees, or touches of Besancon, or the greenery of Alsace. Now, 30 years after these homesick visions of a world left behind, the Catskill landscape they viewed has become a bit of France.

title: A PAIR OF CANADIAN DON QUIXOTES
description: When the Cavendish Club Invitational Pairs began a week ago, there were a large number of red faces, with shades ranging from slight pink to deep purple. There were also two innocent travelers and two Don Quixotes riding to their rescue.

title: ITALY'S ANNUAL REPORT IS UPBEAT READING
description: DESPITE recent economic concerns such as the discovery that poison had been added to some cheaper varieties of Italian wine, and financial damage to vegetable growers arising from consumer fears of fallout from nuclear clouds coming from the Soviet Union, Italy's overall economy is stronger than it has been in a long time.

title: Putting Kids First
description: The superdad and supermom phenomena are the result of the transition from a one- to a two-gender workplace. The transition can be painful, but the gains - when we work it out - will be great.

title: A SECOND OPINION ON PORNOGRAPHY'S IMPACT
description: IF legislators and law enforcement officials eventually embrace the findings of the Attorney General's Commission on Pornography, the pornography industry will have something to worry about.

title: FREEDOM OF EXPRESSION
description: EXPRESSING one's own sense of style is a guaranteed freedom -or so it says here in the fashion bill of rights. And lately, a lot of folks have been exercising that freedom with gusto.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
SOCCER RIOTS AND BRITISH CHARACTER
description: BRAWLING is as British as shepherd's pie. Murder isn't.

title: Man Who Shot the Pope Is Moved to Lung Clinic
description: Mehmet Ali Agca, the gunman who is serving a life sentence for trying to assassinate Pope John Paul II in 1981, has been transferred from Rome to a Pisa prison clinic that specializes in lung diseases, prison sources said Friday.

title: CONCERT: NEW MUSIC
description: THE New York New Music Ensemble combined three works by established masters with a new song cycle by the young American composer Nicholas Thorne at Carnegie Recital Hall Thursday night.

title: LAKERS' INNER FIRE QUELLED BY ROCKETS
description: Something quite intriguing has happened to the Los Angeles Lakers, pro basketball's defending champions. The swagger of confidence that they had for nearly a year is gone.

title: SAMPSON CLEARS NEW HEIGHT AFTER FALL
description: THAT awful moment, the one Ralph Sampson says changed his life, came without warning, premonition or provocation. In fact, everything was going extremely well at the time for him and his team. Here he was, the taller half of professional basketball's most celebrated front-line duet, waltzing in tandem with Akeem Olajuwon to make the Houston Rockets one of pro basketball's few bona fide contenders. And on this night in late March, the 7-foot-4-inch Sampson was high above everyone around him in Boston Garden, soaring for an offensive rebound.

title: CHAPPAQUA STUDENT PURSUES A CARTOON LEGACY
description: SINCE the beginning of his freshman year at Yale, Sabin Streeter said, he has put the drawing of a daily comic strip ahead of his course work and social life. It is all part of what the 19-year-old sophomore describes as a determined effort to follow in the footsteps of his idol, Garry Trudeau, who draws ''Doonesbury '' and is a Yale alumnus.

title: 800 MARK FOR SCHOOLGIRL
description: Kim Certain, a senior at Long Island's Half Hollow Hills East High School, won the girls' 800-meter run today in the Eddy Games at Union College Field and set a meet record of 2 minutes 8.96 seconds. Her time was only 17 one-hundredths of a second off the New York State record.

title: COMPUTERS TO AID TOURISTS
description: CONNECTICUT'S summer tourism campaign will take on a high-technology twist this week, with the opening of 10 computerized information centers along the Connecticut Turnpike.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: GOLDEN FIRE: A Novel of Ancient India. By Jonathan Fast. (Arbor House, $18.95.) Imagine a mini-series set in the fourth century Gupta period in north India. We have a great king who has turned from the battles of his hotheaded youth to statecraft and poetry. His harem is chock-full of beauties but his heart belongs to one, a blond Goth who, as Jonathan Fast's novel opens, is engaged in one of those life-threatening accouchements that signal the birth of a hero. When we learn there is an evil elder brother, with a hissing lisp, a harelip and a dubious relationship with his own mother, we can see where the novel's going. Mr. Fast even has one character tell us ''every second-rate Sanskrit author has tried his hand at a work about brothers who battle for the throne.'' Nevertheless, ''Golden Fire'' has many treats for the reader. Set pieces like the birth and attempted murder of the infant prince, scenes at a burning ghat and a monastic retreat are lusciously detailed. Mr. Fast's research is terrific, from postoperative sutures contrived from the mandibles of black ants to the use of resin for decorating the sole of the female foot. The trouble is that motivation, psychology and dialogue are all too often flat-footedly 20th-century American. Father and bad elder son discuss sibling rivalry, neglected women take drugs and get fat, prospective fathers wile away the waiting as though they were hanging out with friends in a bar.

title: NEW YORK INSPECTORS CITE 33 FOOD OUTLETS FOR HEALTH OFFENSES
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 33 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: OLD HUNTERDON FARMOHOUSE NOW A DESIGNER SHOWCASE
description: BEFORE moving into the spacious, high-ceilinged ''bank barn'' on their property here in rural Hunterdon County - the barn's foundation is banked into a slope, thereby creating an extra level - Ralph and Margery Crane lived for eight years in a nearby farmhouse.

title: FOR THE RELIEF PITCHER, THE MOMENT OF TRUTH ARRIVES AT AGE 10
description: ... lo, the winter is past, The rain is over and gone, The flowers appear on earth and the crack of the baseball bat is heard in the land.

title: EXONERATION ASKED FOR IRANIAN FUND
description: THE New Jersey chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union last week asked the state's Attorney General, W. Cary Edwards, to clear the name of the Iranian Relief Fund, a fund-raising group that Mr. Edwards's predecessor, Irwin I. Kimmelman, had labeled a ''terrorist organization.''

title: THE MADISON AVE. SPRAWL
description: MADISON AVENUE, the symbolic home of the advertising world, is not exactly what it used to be - an address reserved for well-known big-city agencies:

title: For NASA, Another Week Of Questions
description: With the Presidential Commission wrapping up its review on the Challenger disaster, the future of the shuttle program itself began to get an increasing amount of Washington's attention last week.

title: Heather Hope Weir Weds Peter Boneparth, Lawyer
description: Heather Hope Weir, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Donald Weir of Bethesda, Md., and Peter Boneparth, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Boneparth of Cedarhurst, L.I., were married last night at the Middle Bay Country Club in Oceanside, L.I., by Cantor David Benedict.

title:
INVESTING;
HEDGING WITH NATURAL RESOURCES
description: The Newmont Mining Corporation rose to about $45 a share last week, from $41 a couple of weeks ago, as investors looking for a possible resurgence of inflation fastened on the resource-rich company as a hedge. Pointing to Newmont's five distinct segments - gold, copper, coal, oil and gas, and securities holdings - Oppenheimer & Company's metals analyst, John C. Tumazos, said, ''The stock is one of the most attractive natural resource plays.''

title: AN INTERNATIONAL SALUTE TO THE COLLECTORS
description: The United Nations Postal Administration will issue a set of six stamps at Ameripex Thursday on the theme ''Philately - The International Hobby.'' Thursday is the opening day of this international event.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: HOME TIME. By Beverley Farmer. (McPhee Gribble/ Penguin, Paper, $4.95.) ''Home Time'' is an ironic title for the 14 stories in this impressive collection, the first United States publication by its Australian author.

title: Venting Some Mideast Pressure
description: The Reagan Administration sought last week to avoid strained relations with two of the most powerful Arab nations, Saudi Arabia and Syria, in quite separate situations.

title: IN PURSUIT OF AFFORDABLE HOUSING
description: IN just five years the price of the average house on Long Island has more than doubled - from $63,000 to $137,000. For the first-time homeowner, an almost impossible situation has developed.

title: IN PENNSYLVANIA, DIVISIVE PRIMARIES
description: As Democrats prepare to nominate candidates for Governor and United States Senator in Tuesday's Pennsylvania primary, some Democratic leaders say that their party's future as a statewide force is at stake.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''It's important to dispel the notion that people who are using I.R.A.'s are rich people hiding money for awhile.'' -- David Wise, Harvard political science professor.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
OUT OF AFRICA: TWO POINTS OF VIEW
description: As a documentary medium, the great advantage of photography over any type of drawing or painting lies in its peculiar relationship to visible nature. The viewer knows that at the moment of exposure, something actually existed in front of the camera's lens that looked like the thing that appears in the photograph. Thus a photograph of an astronaut on the moon helps convince the Earth-bound viewer that the moon is an actual place where men may walk, and that it looks more like Death Valley than Scarsdale.

title: Track Nominees
description: Bob Seagren, the pole vaulter who set world records 14 times, and Barney Ewell, a 1948 Olympic gold medalist who set United States and collegiate sprint and long jump records 15 times, are among 11 candidates nominated for places in the National Track and Field Hall of Fame in Indianapolis. The three candidates who receive the most votes from a 600-member selection panel will be inducted along with the coach or official who receives the most votes in the contributor's category.

title: Sanchez Surprises Wilander in 2 Sets
description: Unseeded Emilio Sanchez of Spain produced another upset today by beating second-seeded Mats Wilander of Sweden, 6-3, 7-5, to advance to the final of the $435,000 Italian Open tennis championship against Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia.

title: A $3 Billion City Housing Proposal
description: THIRTY housing specialists say New York City should spend $3 billion in the next five years to rehabilitate 85,000 city-owned housing units for low- and moderate-income tenants.

title: Cyclone Kills 11 in India
description: A cylcone struck overnight in the northwestern state of Rajasthan, and at least 11 people were killed and more than 100 others injured, the United News of India reported today.

title: Iberia Pilots Stage A 24-Hour Strike
description: Pilots for Spain's national airline Iberia began a 24-hour strike today, forcing the airline to cancel 143 domestic and international flights, union and company spokesmen said.

title: FURNITURE FROM THE MASTER CARVERS OF FRENCH ROCOCO
description: An exuberantly carved and gilded Louis XV console -its frame depicting bent branches, wind-swept leaves, broken shells, scrolls and a fragment of a bird's wing - is the most impressive work in ''Menuiserie: The Carved Wood Furniture of 18th-Century France,'' on view through June 14 at Rosenberg & Stiebel, 32 East 57th Street.

title: COLOMBIAN REBELS JOIN IN ELECTIONS
description: Despite widespread disenchantment with what is known here as ''the peace process,'' Colombia's largest guerrilla movement is taking an important step toward ending 30 years of insurgency by joining in presidential elections.

title: CLOSE 2-MAN RACE IN DOMINICAN VOTE
description: With more than 1.5 million votes counted in the presidential election here, Joaquin Balaguer, a 78-year-old former President, began edging away from his nearest rival early this morning with a lead of about 9,000 votes.

title: 'HYPNOTIZED BY TOTALITARIAN POESY'
description: THE BLOODY CROSSROADS Where Literature and Politics Meet. By Norman Podhoretz. 221 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $16.95.

title: DANCE: TUDOR'S 'LEAVES ARE FADING'
description: AMERICAN BALLET THEATER presented the kind of first-rate program on Friday that made one want to dance out of the theater - except that the evening's superlative performing would have put such rank exuberance to shame. There was poetry, chic, sparkle and wit in the four ballets the company presented at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: HOUSE REPUBLICANS ARE A SILENT MINORITY
description: ''WE knew we were going to get rolled,'' lamented Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the House Republican leader.

title: Putting Kids First
description: Though the high-level careers outlined in Gail Gregg's article assure a six-figure salary (if not initially, at least eventually), most blue-collar workers must work endless double shifts, or, like my own father, work two jobs throughout their lives in order to bring home a salary that provides for basic family necessities.

title: Roth's 'Pictures of Malamud'
description: To the Editor:

title: Deirdre Collins, R. J. O'Donnell Exchange Vows
description: Deirdre Janeway Collins, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James F. Collins of Bethesda, Md., and Shelter Island, N.Y., was married yesterday to Robert John O'Donnell, a son of Charles P. O'Donnell of Providence, R.I., and the late Mrs. O'Donnell. The Roman Catholic ceremony was performed at the Union Chapel on Shelter Island by the Rev. Dom Andrew Jenks,and the Rev. Michael Greene.

title: Catherine M. Treboux Weds Video Producer
description: Catherine Marie Treboux, a restaurant manager, and John Vandergrift Summerlin Jr., a video producer, were married yesterday by the Rev. Harold Tiercelin, a Roman Catholic priest, at St. Vincent de Paul Church in New York.

title: CHERNOBYL FUELS NUCLEAR ANXIETIES IN EUROPE
description: ''OUR common abode Europe,'' a phrase favored by Mikhail S. Gorbachev when he woos Western Europe, has taken on a frightening actuality in the three weeks since the burning of the Chernobyl nuclear reactor. The winds, showing no regard for the ideological frontier that sunders Europe, have carried radioactivity and fear to the peoples of the continent, whether allied with or against the Soviet Union.

title: Sarah Graydon Bride Of David W. Peck Jr.
description: Sarah Greene Graydon, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Charles Greene of Gloversville, N.Y., and Delray Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to David Warner Peck Jr., a son of Mr. Peck of New York and the late Mrs. Peck. The Rev. Charles Cary performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Chapel in Quogue, L.I.

title: GOODWILL AFTER CHERNOBYL
description: EDWIN MOSES heard the news about Chernobyl a few hours ahead of most Americans. His wife, Myrella, was visiting West Berlin and called him in California in the middle of the night to tell of the fear that was spreading from the nuclear power plant accident in the Soviet Union.

title: San Francisco: Living With Growth Limits
description: EIGHT months after this city enacted the country's most sweeping growth limits ever, it is experiencing effects no one expected - including, as one critic complained, the loss of ''every developer's God-given right to go broke.''
