title: AMID THE PANHANDLERS, HOLLYWOOD TRIES TO RESTORE ITS FORMER GLAMOUR
description: Like a faded star arrayed in the gown of a long-ago first premiere, the district of Hollywood for 20 years has had little but image as a reminder of its past glories and glamour.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
CHINA MINT ISSUES ANOTHER PANDA COIN
description: China has introduced the 1986 edition of its Panda gold coins. As in the past, the coins are being offered in the standard one-ounce version and in four subsidiary sizes. In addition, the China Mint Company has disclosed that it will issue a 12-ounce ''Giant Panda'' later this year.

title: The Scramble for Elusive 'Affordables'
description: WHEN commercials for $100,000 condominiums in New Jersey were shown on a TV program two weeks ago, so many buyers called in to reserve one that they overloaded New Jersey Bell's circuits and disrupted telephone service for 50,000 people.

title:
ART;
76 ART WORKS CHOSEN FROM 770 FOR JURIED SHOW
description: WITH 770 entries, the Huntington Township Art League's 31st annual Long Island Artists Exhibition, now on view at the Heckscher Museum in Huntington, must rank as the top draw among the region's juried shows. It was selected this year by Carter Ratcliff, a critic and contributing editor of Art in America and Art Forum.

title:
GARDENING;
WORK WITH NATURE, NOT AGAINST IT
description: A DOCTOR once said that the most important thing he had learned in years of practice was that he should not work against nature's own healing processes. Much the same holds true for the gardener and his plants. Working with nature will yield healthier plants than working against it.

title: FOREIGN AID IS NOW AN EVEN TOUGHER SELL
description: EVER since the United States began giving military and economic assistance to other countries at the end of World War II, there have been those who vigorously opposed it. This year, as the budget-cutting atmosphere in Washington makes it harder to justify giving away billions in foreign aid while funds are being slashed from programs to aid Americans at home, there seem to be more doubters than ever.

title: Sylvia L. Dickey Weds Executive
description: Sylvia Lynch Dickey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles D. Dickey Jr. of Devon, Pa., and Gordon R. Whitman Jr., a son of Gordon R. Whitman of Berwick, Me., and the late Anne C. Whitman, were married yesterday at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Weston, Mass., by the Rev. David B. Van Dusen, an Episcopal priest, and the Venerable Robert A. Bryan, the archdeacon of the Quebec North Shore of the Anglican Church of Canada.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: TALES OUT OF SCHOOL: A Teacher's Candid Account From the Front Lines of the American High School Today. By Patrick Welsh.

title: Solid Rock
description: BACK ON THE FIRST DAY OF the year I took a shovel and outlined a circle a foot-and-a-half or so wide in the crust of the front yard. It was early afternoon, sunny off and on, the perfect time of the perfect day to plant a tree, a hope.

title: TIGERS ROUT ANGELS BEHIND LaPOINT
description: Lou Whitaker, Larry Herndon and Darrell Evans each hit home runs, and Dave LaPoint won his first game for the Detroit Tigers today, beating the California Angels, 10-4.

title: TURNING THE FACTORIES INSIDE OUT AT CHRYSLER
description: ''ISN'T that a beautiful sight,'' exclaims Richard E. Dauch as the body of a pickup truck is smoothly lowered onto a chassis at the Chrysler Corporation's newly refurbished assembly plant here. ''Every 54 seconds a chassis frame, cab and cargo box come together to make a truck. It's the most exciting part of an assembly plant.''

title: Anne Elizabeth Behrens Is the Bride Of Matthew Eliot Cafritz in Virginia
description: Anne Elizabeth Behrens, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas R. Behrens of Arlington, Va., and Matthew Eliot Cafritz, a son of Mrs. Laughlin Phillips of Washington and Vineyard Haven, Mass., and Conrad Cafritz of Washington, were married yesterday. The ceremony was performed at the Church of Our Saviour in Leesburg, Va., by the Rev. Elijah White, an Episcopal priest.

title: Ellyn Trautmann Wed
description: Ellyn Garland Trautmann and John Rueger Pflug Jr. were married yesterday at the Episcopal Cathedral of the Incarnation in Garden City, L.I. The Rev. Richard McCall performed the ceremony assisted by the Revs.

title: WARSAW PLAY DRAMATIZING GHETTO DIARY
description: The diary of Mary Berg, a young Jewish woman who survived in the Warsaw ghetto as a United States citizen, with an American flag instead of a Star of David pinned to her coat, opened here as a play last month to mark the 43d anniversary of the ghetto uprising.

title: Jan Hadwen Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. George E. Hadwen of Old Bennington, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jan Carolyn Hadwen to Robert Carlton Hubbell, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Hubbell of Johnson City, N.Y. A September wedding is planned. Miss Hadwen is an associate and director of marketing at Security Pacific Financial Strategies Inc. in New York City. Mr. Hubbell is a vice president of investor relations at Hasbro Inc., a toy company in New York.

title: Karin Martin a Bride
description: Karin Susan Martin, a real-estate broker in Millbrook, N.Y., was married yesterday to Eric Norman Shrubsole, the president of the S. J. Shrubsole Corporation of New York and London, a dealer in antique English and American silver and jewels of which his father, the late Sidney James Shrubsole of London, was the founder. The Rev. David Crossley performed the ceremony at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Lithgow, N.Y., assisted by the Rev. Warren Skipp.

title: THE MORAL STRUGGLE OF A CAD
description: WAKING THE DEAD By Scott Spencer. 396 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

title: AMBULANCE UNITS SEEK TAX MONEY
description: SOARING insurance costs for ambulance companies, combined with increases in cost for supplies and equipment, are prompting many Suffolk County volunteer ambulance companies to seek ambulance districts in which most expenses are paid through taxes.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
REMEMBERING A WONDROUS WHALE
description: ONE day last July, shortly before noon, I decided to go windsurfing on Long Island Sound. I was at my family's cottage on High Island, one of the Thimble Islands off Stony Creek, eight miles east of New Haven Harbor. There was a mild wind from the south, and the sky was hazy. No waves. Good conditions for attempting my third sail on the cottage's new windsurfer.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Plant Offered to Aid Sisterhood Projects Outdoor plants from a wholesale nursery - hanging varieties, annuals and vegetables - will be sold at Temple Israel of New Rochelle today and tomorrow, with indoor displays planned in case of rain. The hours are 9 A.M. to 4 P.M. today and 10 A.M. to 2 P.M. Monday. Proceeds from the sale help support the nursery school and other projects of the Temple Sisterhood.

title: SURVIVORS REPORTED STABLE
description: Friends and relatives gathered today for the funerals of two of the nine climbers who died on a school outing on Mount Hood.

title: Harsh Words For Marcos
description: Mindful perhaps of President Reagan's long friendship for Ferdinand E. Marcos, American officials have not treated the former Philippine President with the disdain usually accorded a deposed dictator. The verbal restraint has contributed to ''cobwebs of doubt,'' as they have been called in the Phiippines.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: THE one thing Joe Armstrong knows about the stationery he received as a gift from President Reagan three years go is that he will probably never use it. The notepaper has three magic words - ''The White House'' - printed at the top of each page and although it's meant to be written on, the sheets will likely remain forever unsullied.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: EARLY COMPOSER'S WORK John Knowles Paine may not be a household name, even in musical households, but he made significant contributions to the world of music, particularly in New England. His Mass in D, which he began composing in 1859, at the age of 20, is to be performed at 8 P.M. Thursday in the South Congregational Church, 277 Main Street in Hartford.

title: AFTER BASS BAN, FISHERMEN CAST ABOUT FOR LIVELIHOOD
description: DANNY KING'S steel ocean haul-seining dory sits on its trailer these days, in a parking lot by an Amagansett seafood market, gathering rust. Its red, white and blue paint job has faded in the half-dozen years since the boat appeared in a National Geographic magazine story on the Hamptons.

title: DEMOCRATS LINE UP TO OPPOSE DIOGUARDI
description: REPRESENTATIVE Joseph J. DioGuardi, a freshman Republican, announced last week, to no one's surprise, that he was running for a second term. He said with a smile that he had been told ''you can't claim victory in the 20th Congressional District until you've won it twice.''

title: THAILAND CLOSES LONG-USED REFUGEE CAMPS
description: The Thai Government has closed three refugee camps housing Vietnamese and Laotian exiles, among them the Songkhla reception center on the Gulf of Siam, where arriving Vietnamese ''boat people'' have been sheltered for more than a decade.

title: New Hires At the Fed
description: In filling two positions on the Federal Reserve Board last week, the White House served several needs.

title: WNYC OFFERS A SALUTE TO THE ART OF GEORGE GERSHWIN
description: As anyone in the business of putting together tributes will tell you, there is a vast variety of ways to tip one's cap. In the case of ''Purely Gershwin,'' a 90-minute homage to George Gershwin that will come to WNYC tomorrow night at 8, the cap was tipped reverently, and with minimal flourish.

title: LYUDMILA PAKHOMOVA
description: Lyudmila Pakhomova, a Soviet figure skater who with her husband, Aleksandr Gorshkov, won six world ice-dancing titles in the 1970's, died today after a serious illness, the Tass press agency reported.

title: CABARET: OSCAR BROWN JR.
description: OSCAR BROWN JR., the poet, singer and songwriter who is also sometimes a playwright, spaces out his visits to New York nightlclubs to such an extent that even his long-term listeners may find such early works as ''The Snake'' and ''Signifyin' Monkey'' reaching them through a hazy mist of memories.

title: CONSUMER RATES
IN BANGLADESH, 'FORGOTTEN REFUGEES'
description: The people in the squalid shantytown of Geneva Camp count themselves among the world's most unwanted refugees. In a generation, they fled two homelands and then found that Pakistan, the country of their choice, would not take them in.

title: ADDING MOUSE POWER TO THE APPLE II
description: THE mouse has become a popular, if controversial, adjunct to personal computing, largely due to its heavy promotion by Apple. That company, creator of the rodent-driven Macintosh, was not the first to extol this device developed in the Xerox Corporation's research laboratories, nor is it the only one to do so today. But it remains the driving support behind the busy little gadget's desktop scurrying.

title: Heidi Gage Is Married
description: Heidi Lynn Gage, a daughter of Alan Kenneth Gage and the late Elaine Tepper Gage, was married yesterday to Robert Nesbit Jenkins at the Brick Presbyterian Church in Manhattan. The Revs.

title: RURAL MEXICO SEES THE U.S. AS A MAGNET
description: At one point or another, it seems, virtually every able-bodied man and some of the women in this small village deep in the mountains of southern Mexico has journeyed north and slipped across the border to spend a season or longer as an illegal worker in California.

title: Old-Timer All-Stars Win
description: Tom Grieve, the Texas Rangers' general manager, and Joe Ferguson, the former Dodger catcher, belted home runs today to lead the Major League All-Stars to a 5-4 victory over a team of former Boston Red Sox in the Equitable Old-Timers' Game. With four Hall of Fame members in the two lineups, Grieve put the All-Stars ahead for good in the second inning of the three-inning game with a two-run home run.

title: Barbara Berzin Marries
description: Barbara Jane Berzin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ben Berzin of Bridgewater, N.J., was married yesterday to Peter Frischman a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Frischman of Livingston, N.J. The Rev. G. Thomas Burns performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Raphael's Church in Livingston. Mrs. Frischman, a certified public accountant, is an assistant manager in the investment bank division of Citibank. Mr. Frischman, also a C.P.A., is an audit officer with Morgan Guaranty Trust Company in New York.

title: METS' SLUMP DEEPENS
description: The Mets lost their second straight game to the Los Angeles Dodgers and their fifth in their last seven today, and fell deeper into a slump that has interrupted the best start in the team's 25 years.

title: SETON HALL UNIVERSITY: BRADLEY SEES CHALLENGE ON GLOBAL SCALE
description: With the applause and cheers of friends and relatives filling the Brendan T. Byrne Arena, 1,100 Seton Hall University students graduated today.

title: Pamela Draper Becomes Bride
description: Pamela Draper, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Draper of Woodstock, N.Y., was married yesterday to Christopher Morris, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Morris of Armonk, N.Y. The Rev. H. Scott Matheney, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Amster Yard in New York.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: GARRISON WALK Manitoga, Algonquian for ''place of the Great Spirit,'' was the Garrison home of Russel Wright, the industrial designer. After his death in 1976 it was transformed into a nonprofit, public environmental center, where workshops, nature walks, research and educational programs are conducted year round.

title: 3D TITLE FOR STEVENSON
description: Teofilo Stevenson of Cuba won his third world title when he stopped Alex Garcia of the United States today, but it was a big day for American fighters at the the World Amateur Boxing Championships.

title: ON FIRE ISLAND, SMALL FIRES CAN BE BIG PROBLEMS
description: WHEN firefighters were called to battle a serious blaze in Fire Island Pines earlier this month, many raced not for a fire truck, but for a ferry.

title: WHAT, WHEN AND WHERE
description: A visitor recently alighted from his car, bearing New York license plates, in front of the laundromat to ask a passer-by where Truro center was. ''You're in it,'' was the reply. The visitor shook his head, got back in his car and drove off without comment.

title: LIFE ON THE CAPE, SUMMER TO SUMMER
description: It's in the nature of our house that the weather seems to be inside as well as out. At North Truro, Cape Cod is no more than two miles wide, from Bay to Backside, and wind and rain can blow furiously and horizontal, sun that made Hopper's light burn brighter than that fine shine. We live on a high exposed hill, overlooking moors that run down to the water, and I've walked in fog in my living room, watched rain bleed and puddle on my sills.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: INCOGNITO MOSQUITO TAKES TO THE AIR By E. A. Hass. Illustrated by Don Madden. 104 pp. New York: Random House. Paper, $2.95.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: IF AT FIRST: A Season With the Mets. By Keith Hernandez and Mike Bryan. (McGraw-Hill, $15.95.) The baseball season is almost two months old.

title: Cynthia J. Hoffman Weds L. E. Mosscrop, a Surveyor
description: Cynthia Jean Hoffman, an interior designer, and Lewis Edward Mosscrop, a land surveyor, were married yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in New Canaan, Conn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Timothy Hood, a Presbyterian minister, assisted by the Rev. Francis Virgulak, a Roman Catholic priest.

title:
THE CHEMICAL INDUSTRY REPLIES;
MAKING AMERICA'S SAFEST INDUSTRY SAFER
description: Last week, Fred Millar of the Environmental Policy Institute explained why, in his view, the chemical industry's declining safety record will be reversed only through greater government involvement and regulation. This is the industry's reply. ALTHOUGH THE CHEMICAL INDUSTRY ranks as the nation's safest, some people persist in arguing that only Federal and state regulation can assure safety from chemical hazards. I can see two reasons for this.

title: SCOTT AND CRUZ LEAD ASTROS PAST CUBS
description: Jose Cruz drove in three runs with three singles and Mike Scott scattered eight hits over eight innings tonight, leading the Houston Astros past the Chicago Cubs, 5-1.

title: Roger D. Stark Is Wed To Anne Elise Hartog
description: Anne Elise Hartog, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack B. Hartog of New York, was married yesterday to Roger Douglas Stark, a son of Ethel Stark of Hemet, Calif., and the late Frank Stark of Cerritos, Calif. Justice Budd G. Goodman of State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the St. Regis-Sheraton Hotel.

title: I.R.S. Revisited
description: To the Editor:

title: Braver Than We Thought
description: Early in his career Ernest Hemingway devised the writing strategies he would follow for life: when composing a story he would withhold mention of its central problem; when writing a novel he would implant it in geography and, insofar as possible, he would know what time it was on every page; when writing anything he would construct the sentences so as to produce an emotion not by claiming it but by rendering precisely the experience to cause it. What he made of all this was a rigorous art of compressive power, if more suited to certain emotions than others. He was unquestionably a genius, but of the kind that advertises its limits. Critics were on to these from the very beginning, but in the forward-looking 1920's, they joined his readers to make him the writer for their time. His stuff was new. It moved. There was on every page of clear prose an implicit judgment of all other writing. The Hemingway voice hated pretense and cant and the rhetoric they rode in on.

title: MUSIC AND DANCE ENRICH LIVES OF THE HANDICAPPED
description: Rolling on the wide Oriental rug, 7-year-old Maureen McElroy forgets for half an hour each week the things she cannot do, such as walk unaided and keep her balance.

title: Hard Times For the F.A.A.
description: The Federal Aviation Administration, which has been running considerable turbulence lately, was further buffeted last week by a report from Congress's investigative arm and a new set of National Transportation Safety Board recommendations.

title: Not Much Fun in Jail
description: Scott Skiles, a basketball standout at Michigan State this season, said he hadn't had much fun either after he stepped out of the Marshall County jail in Indiana yesterday. Skiles, a top prospect in the National Basketball Association draft next month, said there was a lot he hadn't enjoyed about his confinement.

title: CRUISING HOME WATERS
description: Touring the Northeast by water is not a new idea, but the opportunities to do so have grown rapidly this year as Americans seek vacation adventures relatively close to home. In late spring, summer and fall, possibilities abound to sail the Atlantic Coast and many inland rivers and canals. Most of the boats available are large enough to provide conviviality and resort-style comfort, yet are small or compact enough to go places that cannot accommodate ocean liners. Such cruises provide a new perspective to tourism: While afloat, you may feel like an outsider looking in, but on land for shore excursions, you have the familiarity of being in the United States or Canada as you absorb new sights and experiences.

title: Gregory C. Carey And Diana Reed Exchange Vows
description: Diana Frances Reed, a daughter of Adrian P. Reed of Centreville, Md., and Hobe Sound, Fla., and Ariane Wellin of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Gregory Collins Carey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dennis J. Carey Jr. of Sands Point, L.I., and New York. Bishop Theodore E. McCarrick of Metuchen, N.J., performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Church in Greenwich, assisted by Msgr.

title: New Soviet Envoy to Japan
description: Nikolai N. Solovyev, an Asian specialist with the Soviet Foreign Ministry for nearly three decades, has been named Ambassador to Japan, the Tass press agency reported today. Mr. Solovyev, 54 years old, replaces Pyotr A. Abrasimov, who has served in Japan since February 1985 and is now retiring.

title: STEPPING OUT ON SHORE
description: There's a theme for the weekend,'' David L. Wolper was saying. ''The theme is remember, rejoice, renew. We're going to be reflecting about how everyone came to this country. We're going to rejoice by having a great party. And we're going to renew everything the Statue of Liberty stands for.''

title: THE CURTAIN DROPS, AND SO DO THE METS
description: It was either a classic of distinguished pitchers or a comedy of disastrous defenses. But most of all it was a night of bizarre events, a night to remember - or maybe to forget.

title: The Contras Seem Out of Step
description: After stormy discussions most of last week in Miami on how to restructure their movement, leaders of the guerrillas fighting the Nicaraguan Government remained divided, and one was said to be ready to resign. Dismayed at the discord, the State Department threatened to cut off aid unless hard-liners in the movement made concessions.

title: Anne Trible Is Wed in Williamsburg
description: Anne Brooke Trible, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Waring Trible of Dunnsville, Va., was married yesterday to Winston Eason Weinmann, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Giffen Weinmann of New Orleans. The Rev. Thom Blair performed the Episcopal ceremony at Bruton Parish Church in Williamsburg, Va.

title: Distant Morris Complex Draws Tenants
description: BEFORE the Prudential Insurance Company of North America relocated some of its employee health claims processing from Parsippany-Troy Hills to Mount Arlington in January, it ran a quarter-page ad in the local Morris County newspaper.

title: LOSS OF L.I. INDIAN RELICS FEARED
description: ARCHEOLOGISTS are worried that the development of Long Island and amateur souvenir hunters are increasingly and permanently destroying historic Indian relics.

title: STANDOFF AT ANTI-APARTHEID RITES
description: With scores of armed riot policemen watching, thousands of mourners today buried eight blacks who activists said were killed by the police or police-supported vigilantes in recent unrest in this black township.

title:
ART;
FIVE GALLERIES SHOW THEIR BEST IN HARTFORD
description: THE gallery of the Aetna Institute on Farmington Avenue in Hartford is currently performing a great public service, considering that there is more art of quality in Connecticut than there is space to report on it, and that good galleries are pretty widely spaced geographically.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Auto Racing Bumping Day at Indianapolis. The Indianapolis 500 qualifying trials continue, with drivers trying to better the times of cars already qualified and bump the low qualifiers. (Television - Channel 7, 6 P.M.) Baseball Yankees vs. Seattle Mariners, at Yankee Stadium, 1:35 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 1:30 P.M.) Mets vs. Dodgers, at Los Angeles, 3:05 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 3 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 3 P.M.) Blue Jays vs. Cleveland Indians, at Toronto. (Television - Channel 7, 3 P.M.) Braves vs. St. Louis Cardinals, at Atlanta. (Television - WTBS, 4:05 P.M.) Basketball Rockets vs. Los Angeles Lakers, at Houston, Game 4 of the Western Conference championship series, with the Lakers down, 2-1. (Television - Channel 2, 3:30 P.M.) Bucks vs. Boston Celtics, at Milwaukee, Game 4 of the Eastern Conference final. Boxing Marlon Starling, champion vs. Johnny Bumphus, 12 rounds, for the United States Boxing Association welterweight championship, and Vinnie Pazienza vs. Harry Arroyo, 10 rounds, lightweights, at the Civic Center, Providence, R.I. (Television - Channel 4, 3 P.M.) Hockey Flames vs. Montreal Canadiens, at Calgary, Alberta. Game 2 of the Stanley Cup championship series. Calgary won the opener. (Television - ESPN, 8 P.M.) Lacrosse Syracuse vs. Rutgers, at the Carrier Dome, National Collegiate Athletic Association quarterfinal match. Other quarterfinal games match Massachusetts at Johns Hopkins, North Carolina at Maryland and Navy at Virginia. The semifinals will be held next Saturday at the University of Delaware.

title:
GARDENING;
WORK WITH NATURE, NOT AGAINST IT
description: A DOCTOR once said that the most important thing he had learned in years of practice was that he should not work against nature's own healing processes. Much the same holds true for the gardener and his plants. Working with nature will yield healthier plants than working against it.

title: A DECOR TO WOO THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: LAST spring, Chase Manhattan Bank's SoHo branch ranked 48th in growth among the huge bank's 50 Manhattan branches. The situation was critical, recalls Terry Baker, the branch's assistant treasurer. The choice, he says, was ''close the branch or participate in the neighborhood.''

title: WITH THE ENFORCEMENT CHIEF
description: Has insider trading become so widespread that the Securities and Exchange Commission cannot control it?

title: CABARET: 'DECODANCE' SATIRIZES HOLLYWOOD
description: A SUPERCILIOUS temptress in a black-and-white leopard-print ensemble stands in a green canvas field surrounded by three dozen toy Dalmatians while a tenor sings the theme from the movie ''A Summer Place.'' A puppyish young man jumps into the field and ducks under the long strand of pearls that loosely hangs from the woman's neck. Absently pulling on the strand, she turns the necklace into a noose that strangles her doting admirer.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE AMBASSADOR'S WOMEN. By Catherine Gaskin. (Scribners, $18.95.) In this two-family saga set in the years surrounding World War II, Ginny Clayton and Dena Penrose, both in the last lonely weeks of pregnancy, meet on a London bridge in 1930.

title: PLAN TO START ON G.O.P. DELEGATES EARLY IS A MICHIGAN MUDDLE
description: The plan of Michigan Republicans to make this year's party precinct meetings the first battleground of the 1988 Presidential campaign could become a model for how not to play the game.

title: ENGINEERS OFFER AID ON TOXIC WASTES
description: WHEN the telephone rings in the middle of the night at the Toledo, Ohio, home of Dr. Gary Bennett, it is usually the fire department calling him out on an emergency. But Dr. Bennett is not a firefighter. He is a professor of chemical engineering at the University of Toledo and a member of the American Institute of Chemical Engineers.

title: Walker Hangs Up Hat
description: Harry (the Hat) Walker, the former major league outfielder and manager who started the Alabama-Birmingham baseball program in 1978 and coached the Blazers to a 211-171 record in eight seasons, is stepping down because he says the job isn't fun anymore. The 68-year-old Walker, the National League batting champion in 1947 while with the St. Louis Cardinals, spent 42 years in professional baseball, but said of his recent loss of enthusiasm, ''It got to the point it wasn't much fun for me anymore.''

title: Baseball; Fernandez No. 1 on the List Of Dodgers Who Got Away
description: THE Los Angeles Dodgers may have thought they were seeing only half of Sid Fernandez when he pitched against them yesterday, but that was in slimmed-down body only. The pitcher they were seeing must be at least twice the artist he was when Fernandez was in the Dodgers' minor league system. When the Dodgers traded Fernandez to the Mets in December 1983, they whispered to New York baseball writers that they had put one over on the Mets, that this fat kid pitcher would never be much of a major league pitcher because he lacked the desire and self-discipline needed to make it.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, MAY 18, 1986
description: International Syria's President finds himself facing a series of threats. The most immediate one facing President Hafez al-Assad, according to Western diplomats, is a growing fear in Damascus that long-festering tensions with Israel, particularly along the Golan Heights, could flare into a new war, possibly set off by accusations of Syrian involvement in recent terrorist activities. [ Page 1, Column 6. ] Zimbabwe's former white residents are returning, but slowly and in uncertain numbers. In the six years since independence and the installation of a government by blacks, perhaps 100,000 whites have left Zimbabwe, some going to Europe, others to the United States or Australia, but most to South Africa. Some whites returned because of homesickeness, or because of growing tensions in South Africa, but nearly all admit that their worst fears about Zimbabwe were not realized. [ 1:1. ] Stalin's daughter could not readjust to life in the Soviet Union when she returned in 1984 after 17 years in the West, she indicated in an interiew with an American journalist in Wisconsin, where she has been living since her return this year to the United States. Svetlana Alliluyeva said she had difficulty speaking Russian when she went back to the Soviet Union. [ 1:2. ] Some Chernobyl workers panicked and left their posts after the nuclear accident last month, according to Soviet publications. They said these people were being disciplined. Meanwhile, a Deputy Prime Mnister, Ivan S. Silayev, who sits on the inquiry board, said on television that the crippled reactor's temperature had fallen many degrees.

title: JEWISH THEOLOGICAL SEMINARY: DUTY TO TEACH JUDAISM CITED
description: Gerson D. Cohen, presiding over his final commencement as chancellor of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, told graduates last week that it was their duty ''to teach the special vocabulary of Judaism and its meaning, a vocabulary of action, of ritual, of calendar and of faith.''

title: Milan Station
description: To the Editor: Readers of the Travel section may be interested in the details of how our money was stolen, on a train in the Milan station recently.

title: Mannequins
description: To the Editor:

title: SHEDDING THE METS FAD TO RETURN TO BRONX SHRINE
description: I REALIZE this confession chronicling over 20 years of personal and public deceit is unlikely to prompt the wearing of black armbands along Queens Boulevard, or celebratory parades up and down the Grand Concourse. Still I feel it incumbent to explain why one lifelong baseball fan would shed a generation of Yankee hating-Met rooting, and return to his boyhood sanctuary at 161st Street.

title:
DINING OUT;
THE R.A.F. LANDS IN FAIRFIELD
description: HOSE who like restaurants with a theme should love the latest one in Fairfield. Built next to a runway at Essex County Airport, the 94th Bomb Group Headquarters also should appeal to those who might have fond memories of the time they spent during World War II, particularly if they were stationed in England.

title: Reagan Assails House Budget
description: President Reagan today criticized the House for approving a military budget he called ''wholely inadequate''

title: Linda Marie Hall Wed To William Phillips 3d
description: Linda Marie Hall, an economist for the Department of State in Washington, and William M. Phillips 3d, a Foreign Service officer with the department, were married yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Alexandria, Va., by the Rev. Dr. Mark S. Anschutz.

title: HOW SOME PLAYERS FIND A STATE OF DIAMOND CLARITY
description: NOLAN RYAN is standing on the mound. It is dusk. July 9, 1972.

title: WITHOUT SHAKESPEARE, WHAT WOULD CHOREOGRAPHERS DO?
description: A virtual nonperson of late in New York's playhouses, the world's greatest dramatist has set up as scenarist-in-residence at the ballet. In a season that has seen a single notable production of one of Shakespeare's dramas - the Public Theater's ''Hamlet,'' starring Kevin Kline - titles from Shakespeare are turning up on the dance calendar all the time.

title: Caroline F. Smith Becomes a Bride
description: The wedding of Caroline Freeland Smith, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip F. Smith of Williamstown, Mass., to Mark D. Stevens, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Victor W. Stevens of Quakertown, Pa., took place yesterday at the First Congregational Church in Williamstown. The Rev. Robert Buckwalter performed the ceremony.

title: MISS LIBERTY'S SCRAPBOOK
description: Never mind, for a moment, that she is here, in New York Harbor. Try to think, instead, how this city would look without her: how disembodied and abstract our immigrant heritage would seem, how empty the upper bay, how lifeless those postcard ''Greetings From New York.'' It is, of course, impossible to imagine. The Statue of Liberty and the City of New York are indivisible.

title: MILESTONE FOR VERMONT RESORT
description: Since 1886 four generations of the Beach family have owned and managed the Basin Harbor Club in Vermont. This summer the family-owned resort will celebrate its 100th anniversary with a variety of special events: tennis and golf tournaments, talks and exhibits on Vermont history, a dinner dance, a Mozart concert and a reunion of former employees.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: BOYCHOIR IN NEWARK The American Boychoir of Princeton, which has performed at Lincoln Center, Carnegie Hall, Radio City Music Hall, the White House and the Vatican, will make its Newark debut Tuesday at the Cathedral of the Sacred Heart. It will be accompanied by the Cathedral Symphony Orchestra.

title:
NATURE WATCH;
COMMON YELLOWTHROAT
description: Geothlypis trichas Size: Four and a half to five and a half inches.

title: Fan Disappointed With George Foster
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Stanley Fink Says Farewell
description: For seven years, Assembly Speaker Stanley Fink has been one of Albany's ''Big Three,'' part of the triumvirate - with the Governor and the Senate majority leader -that makes the state Capitol run. But in part because he saw no opportunity to move up, Mr. Fink said last week that he would be moving out, leaving the Legislature at the end of the year.

title: THE STATUE AS SOUVENIR
description: THE COMPANY she keeps is not always the best. In the window of the Funny Store, a Times Square bazaar, Miss Liberty struggles to stand proudly, surrounded by dead rubber chickens, executioner's masks, busts of Hulk Hogan, hand-grenade cigarette lighters and skull-shaped marijuana bongs.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: HOME BUILDING in New Jersey last year increased by 25 percent, compared to 3 percent in the nation as a whole, according to the state's Department of Labor.

title: Boasts and Insults; !!!
description: Life must be desperately humdrum in Hamilton, Ohio. This town of 64,000 on the Great Miami River 20 miles from Cincinnati is known for missile parts, food mixes, coated papers and safes.

title: THE CASTLES OF CZECHOSLOVAKIA
description: The raucous screams of two peregrine falcons pierce the thin air, as they tumble, plunge and soar up again in graceful dogfights above the plains of northern Bohemia. The birds are at eye level and extremely close to anyone standing atop the enormous hill that holds the mighty towers and 30-foot-high wall fragments of Hazmburk, one of Czechoslovakia's most renowned castle ruins.

title: WHAT'S GRANDPA WITHOUT THE QUIRKS?
description: NOW that my kids are old enough to make me a grandfather, I realize I'm not qualified for the job. Except for straining to see through bifocals and streaking toward 50, I just don't measure up to the classic standards of grandfatherhood.

title: FUND SEEKING KIN OF 39 VIETNAM CASUALTIES
description: A search is under way for family members of 39 casualties of the Vietnam War whose names are being added to the Vietnam Veterans Memorial.

title: TIME TO STOP SOWING THE SEEDS OF FAILURE
description: THE seed catalogues have been arriving daily. I toss them into the trash, unread. Magazine and newspaper articles are extolling the virtues of the early sowing of seeds and the wonders of little indoor peat pots of tiny tomato and pea plants.

title: TRAVEL BOOKSHELF
description: Island Hopping in New England By Mary Maynard. 170 pages. Yankee Books. $8.95.

title: Putting Kids First
description: No country in the world provides more generous incentives to men to assume parenting responsibilties than Sweden.

title: A DRAMA AT TUNNEL: HOW MUCH IS THAT IN ZLOTYS?
description: DRIVERS have learned, by long experience, that if they hope ever to get home from New York City during the evening rush hour, they must assert themselves.

title: GETTING A CLEAR FOCUS ON THE WORLD OF GLASS
description: In both a literal as well as a figurative sense, the Corning Museum of Glass in Corning, N.Y., calls to mind the fabled phoenix risen from the ashes. It is a repository and an emblem of cultural endurance destined to survive yet another cycle of the ages.

title: LAWS GIVE OLD BUILDINGS A CHANCE TO BE SAVED
description: SOME old buildings are getting a new lease on life, as towns and cities adopt ordinances that give anyone a chance to save the structures from a wrecker's ball.

title: Mary Boney Wed in South
description: Mary Grist Bellamy Boney and James Wholley Denison 3d were married yesterday at St. James Church in Wilmington, N.C. The Rev. Robert Cook and Bishop Thomas Henry Wright 2d officiated at the Episcopal ceremony.

title: Fish and Chips
description: To the Editor: As a native Londoner I was naturally interested in your survey (Travel, March 16) of fish-and-chip shops.

title: CUSTOMIZING ART TO FIT ARCHITECTURE
description: SPREAD out on the kitchen table of painter David Webster's rented SoHo studio are the blueprints for the Centrum, a $75 million office complex that is being developed in Dallas. Two paintings that he did at the request of the project's developers hang on the studio wall, and are indicated by yellow markings on the plans.

title: Q AND A
description: Inheriting a Co-op Question: My husband and I are an older couple who own a cooperative apartment in Queens. Our 38-year-old daughter lives with us, but the co-op is in our names. Our daughter is the beneficiary in our will. My question is, when we die will she be allowed to continue to live in our apartment? . . M. J., Queens Answer: According to David Smith, a real-estate attorney with the firm of Weitzner, Levine, Hamburg & Walzer, the law says that ownership of shares in a co-op are passed to the estate if the owner dies. If ownership is shared by a married couple and one spouse dies before the other, then the surviving partner inherits the shares.

title:
GARDENING;
WORK WITH NATURE, NOT AGAINST IT
description: A DOCTOR once said that the most important thing he had learned in years of practice was that he should not work against nature's own healing processes. Much the same holds true for the gardener and his plants. Working with nature will yield healthier plants than working against it.

title: Headliners; Tainted Trading?
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission called it the largest insider trading action in its history, and the target seemed appropriately prosperous. Dennis B. Levine, a 33-year-old Wall Street merger specialist, was accused last week of using confidential information illegally to net profits estimated at $12.6 million or more over five years while he was employed at three well-known investment houses, most recently - until the charges surfaced, anyway - as a managing director at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. Mr. Levine also was charged in Federal court in Manhattan with illegally obstructing the S.E.C. investigation, which is expected to continue. Mr. Levine's lawyers said he denied any wrongdoing.

title: 141 ARE NAMED PRESIDENTIAL SCHOLARS FOR 1986
description: Education Secretary William J. Bennett has named 141 graduating seniors as 1986 Presidential Scholars, the nation's highest honor for high school students.

title: ROLLING BACK THE BARBARIANS
description: TERRORISM How the West Can Win. Edited by Benjamin Netanyahu. 254 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $18.95.

title: OUR NEIGHBORHOOD LIBERTY
description: Two summers ago, we toured New York Harbor on the evening of the Fourth of July. Eating very well and cackling away in the best of company, we felt ourselves the sons and daughters of Neptune as we rampaged this way and that across the narrow decks of a rented tugboat. Hours passed. The sky turned purple. A chesty little fellow with a tremendous turn of speed, our boat made coded and peremptory noises, standing no nonsense from other craft, whether small or large. All sense of direction long lost, we felt cheerful, secure and rather important as we sped through the night. Ahead lay fireworks. Suddenly, we became aware of an upright and colossal shape, almost within touching distance. Somehow familiar, though clearly a casualty of circumstance, it caused us to fall silent in wonder and awe. Then we said, with a loud and single voice,''But that's it! That's the Statue of Liberty! In bandages!'' We were startled, alarmed, outraged and diminished.

title: Kelly A. McBride Will Be the Bride Of R. W. Hudson
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Dana McBride of Sewickley Heights, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Kelly Ann McBride to R. Webber Hudson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph L. Hudson Jr. of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich. A fall wedding is planned.

title: NEW YORKERS TAKE CHAMBER MUSIC TO NORTH COUNTRY
description: In the handful of one-street towns scattered through the White Mountains of New Hampshire, the only hometown chamber-music ensemble consists almost entirely of New Yorkers.

title: 'SPEAKING PERSONALLY' WRITER SAYS CRITICS MISSED POINT
description: Perhaps this woman considers the U.S. a hardship post and is eagerly awaiting the day when, American money in hand, she can return to India. However, there are many more Indians who came to this country in search of a better life, have found it and would return to India only if bound and gagged.

title: DRAMA BEHIND A WINE CRISIS
description: LAST fall, the Mariani brothers were most concerned about how the rise of the wine cooler and the fall of the dollar would affect Riunite, their spectacularly successful Italian wine.

title: A More Valuable Lira Is Planned for Italy
description: The Bank of Italy has announced plans for a new lira to be worth a thousand times more than the currency is now.

title: GIBSON'S LONG STRUGGLE ENDS, NEWARK'S CONTINUES
description: AFTER working all day Tuesday taking people to the polls, Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson of Newark went home to change his clothes before delivering his victory speech to supporters at the Quality Inn. ''Somewhere in the process between changing my clothes and going back for the speech it became obvious I was going to lose,'' he said. ''I had to give a different speech.'' After 16 years the voters of New Jersey's largest city had decided to make a change, and the 53-year-old Mayor said he never saw it coming.

title: LEARNING TO LIVE WITH RUNAWAY FAME
description: What happens when dreams come true?

title: Miss Kalow Plans A July 5 Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Jay Kalow of Wyckoff, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Kalow, to Daniel Clifford Dektar, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Dektar of Los Angeles. The wedding is planned for July 5.

title: CHILDREN'S READING EXPLORED
description: IS there a best way to teach children to read? What can parents do to spark a child's interest in words, stories and literature? How can summer reading be made enjoyable?

title:
MUSIC;
CELLIST IS SOLOIST FOR MONMOUTH FINALE
description: THE Monmouth Symphony Orchestra's final concert of its 1985-86 series, this afternoon at 3 o'clock, will feature the cellist Paul Tobias as soloist in Schumann's A minor Concerto.

title: DOCTOR ASSISTANTS: TEAMWORK WITH SURGEONS
description: VIRGINIA HILTON sits at a patient's bedside the day before surgery and talks about the operation, often drawing a sketch of the surgical procedure on a piece of paper, and answering the patient's questions. She assists the surgeon during the operation and then provides support for the patient during recovery.

title: SPRAY LUBRICANTS CAN HELP IN MANY JOBS AROUND THE HOME,
description: ALTHOUGH they have been on the market for quite a few years, and although almost every repair technician and mechanic carries one in his toolbox, a surprisingly large number of homeowners and do-it-yourselfers do not realize how useful a spray can of moisture-displacing penetrating lubricant can be.

title: RECENT RELEASES OF VIDEO CASSETTES
description: Hobson's Choice Starring Charles Laughton, Brenda de Banzie, John Mills, Prunella Scales, Daphne Anderson; directed by David Lean, 1954 Embassy Home Entertainment 107 minutes. $39.95 This is a most satisfying plum-pudding English comedy with the professional seasoning of a good cast, the personal stamp of a wise, brisk director and a handsome, atmospheric production set in 1890's Lancashire, where a domineering shopkeeper is trying to marry off his three daughters his own way.

title: Bush Has Malignancy Removed From Cheek
description: Doctors removed a malignant growth from Vice President Bush's left cheek Thursday, his office announced today.

title: Age Discrimination?
description: To the Editor:

title: A SCHOOLBOY'S SUMMER OF WAR
description: CAT'S GRIN By Francois Maspero. Translated by Nancy Amphoux. 295 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95.

title: 5 Found Shot to Death In 2 Colorado Robberies
description: Five people were shot to death and another was shot in the head in robberies of a convenience store and a neighboring bar early today, the police said.

title: THOSE LOW-PRICED PRICE CLUBS
description: PRICE CLUBS have no carpeting, no Muzak, no ad agencies, no prime locations and no shopping bags. No Christmas trees or Hanukkah lights or Easter bunnies herald their shopping seasons. They do not accept credit cards. And some days their warehouses do not open until 11 A.M.

title: SOMERVILLE AWAITS ITS ANNUAL MEMORIAL DAY BIKE RACE
description: MEMORIAL DAY in this Somerset County community is inextricably tied to bicycle racing. The town's principal war heroes are two young men who won the Tour of Somerville in its first three years and then died in World War II.

title: POLICE RATED ON DRIVING SKILLS
description: BYSTANDERS at the Glen Island Casino parking lot in recent months might have thought they were witnessing the filming of a police adventure movie or television show, as three blue-and-white county police cars raced through an obstacle course.

title: Kate Gridley Wed To John Barstow
description: Katharine Mead Gridley, an artist, and John Bentley Barstow, an editor of Horticulture Magazine in Boston, were married yesterday at Christ Congregational Church in Norfolk, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Hugh McCandless, an Episcopal priest, and the Rev. Bruce Anderson, a Congregationalist minister, officiated.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: A TRAVELLER IN CHINA. By Christina Dodwell. (Beaufort, $15.95.) As a fearless and innovative solo traveler, Christina Dodwell is well on her way to becoming a legend.

title: Dr. David Feldman to Wed Debra A. Green in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. David M. Green of Linden, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Debra Ann Green, to Dr. David L. Feldman, a son of Dr. and Mrs. George Feldman of Lawrence, N.Y. An August wedding is planned.

title: DOCUMENTARIES AND BALANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: FORUM OFFERS BRITISH MUSICAL
description: THANKS - and thanks again - to the Forum Theatre Group for importing a long-awaited English musical, ''Mr. Cinders,'' but no thanks to a production that delivers perhaps 20, or maybe 25, percent of the show's potential.

title: 130,000 NEW YORKERS SIGN UP TO JOIN HANDS
description: At least 130,000 New Yorkers have signed up to join hands and form a human chain along a 12-mile route through the city next Sunday as part of Hands Across America, the national fund-raising appeal to fight hunger and homelessness in the United States.

title: Rachel Anne Elliott Wed To Joseph M. Rigolino Jr.
description: Rachel Anne Elliott, the daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Joseph M. Elliott of the Bronx, was married yesterday to Joseph Michael Rigolino Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Rigolino of Poughkeepsie, N.Y. The Revs. William K. Martini and Samuel L. Snodgrass performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

title: CONCERT: TOTH ENDS ORGAN SERIES
description: SINCE February the organist and harpsichordist Gwendolyn Toth has been serving up a four-evening series entitled ''The Art of the Early Keyboard'' at St. John the Evangelist Church at 55th Street and First Avenue. Thursday she concluded the series with a program called ''Sweelinck and the Northern European Organ Tradition.''

title: Mary Hall to Wed Abbett Howland
description: Mr. and Mrs. Mortimer W. Hall of Millbrook, N.Y., have announced the engagement of Mr. Hall's daughter Mary Amanda Hall to Abbett Post Howland, a son of Mrs. Cornelius De Forest Howland and the late Mr. Howland of New York and Milbrook, N.Y. A July wedding is planned.

description: Weeks This Last on Week Fiction Week List 1 A PERFECT SPY, by John le Carre. (Knopf, 1 4 $18.95.) The tale of Magnus Pym, a British secret agent, and his father, Rick, a flamboyant con man. 2 I'LL TAKE MANHATTAN, by Judith Krantz. 2 4 (Crown, $18.95.) A diet developed more than 40 years ago at a clinic in North Carolina is explained by a successful user.

title: NATO Backing Plans On Chemical Weapons
description: The North Atlantic Treaty Organization has tentatively approved the Reagan Administration's plans for production of chemical weapons, but opposition was voiced by several NATO countries concerned that the project could damage East-West relations and set back talks on a global ban on chemical arms.

title: A DAY OF DECISION ON TRASH
description: AFTER years of planning and discussion, North Hempstead Town officials are ready to say where and what type of garbage-disposal plant they will build to meet a pressing state deadline for dealing with solid waste.

title: JERSEY PRISONS LATEST TO BAN X-RATED MOVIES
description: New Jersey corrections officials have stopped the showing of X-rated movies in state prisons after discovering that the films had been rented with state money, not contributions from inmates, as some prison officials had believed.

title: DOLORES WON'T TAKE IT ANYMORE
description: TABLE MONEY By Jimmy Breslin. 435 pp. New York: Ticknor & Fields. $17.95.

title: THE NOT-SO-CLEAR BUT PRESENT DANGER
description: WILHELM CONRAD RONTGEN discovered X-rays in 1895, and it was barely a year later that man-made radiation doomed its first victim -an assistant of Thomas A. Edison - to mutilation and painful death. Scientific understanding of radiation has come a long way in the intervening 90 years, but radiation accidents continue to kill, as Chernobyl has tragically demonstrated.

title: WHAT CAR OF THE TRAIN IS THIS?
description: THEY seem to do things a little bit better on Amtrak. As I hurry through the concourse at Pennsylvania Station each day, I hear the train announcer advise passengers to board the first four cars of such and such a train for a particular station in New Jersey, or the last two for another station.

title: LITTLE LIBRARY CARD THAT DOESN'T
description: WE really do like living in our village. Oh, of course, we have some complaints - a stop sign here, a barking dog there - but it's proven to be a nice place to live. We've done it now for almost 18 years.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
MOUNTAIN MUSIC
description: FROM a house in a hollow comes music of the hills. Follow the winding road, to the stand of big trees, to the wooden bungalow with its long front porch. A dull orange glow shines from one window onto the yard and is swallowed by the dark pines, the India ink, star-studded sky. Through this window also comes something stronger than lamplight: the whine of a fiddle, the beat of a banjo, the sound of a human voice.

title: Dept. of Aspirations
description: Dark Days on the Civil Service Front: A survey of 1,200 present or former officials, conducted by the Federal Executive Institute Alumni Association, found that 55 percent would not encourage young people today to pursue a career in the Federal civil service. Of those polled, 87 percent had 16 years or more of Government service.

title: MASSACHUSETTS MILLS, FRENCH AIR FARE DISCOUNTS
description: A Mill Town Preserves A Heritage With some things new and many things old, the Lowell National Historical Park and Lowell Heritage State Park - a complex of mills, canals and worker housing throughout the Massachusetts city - will open its 1986 summer season this Saturday.

title: THE CHUBBY TRANSVESTITE AND OTHERS
description: BURNING HOUSES By Andrew Harvey. 214 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $16.95. IN Andrew Harvey's book of verse ''No Diamonds, No Hat, No Honey,'' a self-conscious young man, Fernando, and a worldly-wise woman named Lydia carried on a poetic and philosophic dialogue. In Mr. Harvey's new novel, ''Burning Houses,'' dialogue is once again his chosen vehicle, in this case between Charles, a 31-year-old English novelist and travel writer raised in India (Mr. Harvey was born in India and educated in England), and Adolphe, a 67-year-old extraordinarily flamboyant transvestite and internationally known film director whom Charles describes as ''pug-faced, chubby-cheeked, Empress of the Demi-Monde, spiritual adviser to cardinals and princesses, pimps and taxidrivers.'' Their conversations, which take place in Adolphe's lavishly eccentric 18th-century Parisian palazzo on the Place St.-Sulpice, center on Charles's reading of his new novel, ''A Burning House.'' Yet long before we get to that title within a title in a novel within a novel, we become aware that we are being drawn into a narrative in which the distinction between life and art is deliberately being blurred.

title: Article 748886 -- No Title
description: The state has reached out-of-court settlements of more than $6.3 million with four of the six victims of the collapse of the Mianus River bridge on the Connecticut Turnpike in 1983.

title: DECOYS BRING HIGH PRICES
description: BEFORE its auction of the waterfowl decoy collection of Dr. George Ross Starr Jr. earlier this month, the Richard A. Bourne Company of Hyannis, Mass., had predicted that for the first time in history, a single bird would sell for more than $100,000. That prediction was realized in startling fashion when a wood duck drake by the Massachusetts carver Joe Lincoln went for $205,000 in an auction that grossed $1,435,935.

title: ON THE LI RIVER, A LANDSCAPE IN LIMESTONE
description: The route from Guilin to the Li River is a half-paved road through stands of laurel and camphor, past long stretches of waterlogged rice and water-chestnut plots, and fields of sorghum, sugar cane, taro, bamboo, pumpkins and the white blossoms of sesame plants. Amid the fields of yams and peanuts and the hand-flooded breeding grounds for fish sit small tombs, from which the spirits of dead farmers can watch their crops, our guide tells us. In the background are the layered limestone hills of Guilin, those oddly formed, extraordinarily fetching cliffs and peaks that once were part of a prehistoric sea bed centered in what now is Guilin, the scenic focal point of China's Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region, about 250 miles northwest of Canton.

title: LAWSUIT LEADS TO A MUSICAL
description: WIN or lose, ''Professionally Speaking,'' which opens at the Theater at St. Peter's Church in Manhattan on Thursday, may be the first musical revue that evolved from a lawsuit.

title: THE POWER OF HER SEX, THE POWER OF HER RACE
description: MATING BIRDS By Lewis Nkosi. 184 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $13.95. LEWIS NKOSI will always be remembered at Harvard University as the Nieman Fellow who could not go home. Mr. Nkosi, who began his career as a journalist in South Africa in the mid-1950's, left Johannesburg for Cambridge, Mass., in 1961 on a one-way permit. He has been barred from returning ever since. A professor of literature at the University of Zambia, Mr. Nkosi is a highly regarded literary critic whose works ''Home and Exile'' (1965) and ''Tasks and Masks'' (1981) are standards. As a playwright and short-story writer, he is also the most subtly experimental of the black South African writers, many of whom are caught in the immediacy of the struggle against apartheid.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Sunday on the 10th anniversary show of the Ground Glass photography group gave an incorrect credit for one of the photographs. The work entitled ''Finale'' was by Alfred Revzin.

title: FRENCH SAY SUSPECT GIVES CLUES ON TERROR NETWORK
description: Details emerging from an investigation of the man who has confessed to bombing department stores in Paris and London have given the French police important insights into the structure and operations of the terrorist network that employed him, according to terrorism experts and French officials.

title: Eisen Sisters Are Brides in Three Mile Harbor, L.I.
description: Valentina Rachel Eisen and Victoria Jane Eisen, daughters of Mrs. Terry Eisen-Berger of New York and the late Norman Robert Eisen of New York, were married yesterday to Petty Officer 1st Class Duane Allen Heishman, U.S.N., and Matthew Dine, respectively. Mr. Heishman is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jim Heishman of Pinellas Park, Fla. Mr. Dine is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jim Dine of New York. Judge Shepard Frood of the East Hampton, L.I., Town Court performed the ceremony at the Wings Point Restaurant in Three Mile Harbor, L.I.

title: Sharon Andors Is Bride
description: Sharon Greer Andors, the daughter of Dr. Leonard Andors and Leah Andors of Brookhaven, L.I., was married yesterday to Steven Jerrold Steckler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mortimer Steckler of Roslyn, L.I. Rabbi Helene Ferris performed the ceremony at the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue. The bride, who will retain her name professionally, is the subscription manager of American Health magazine and Mother Earth News magazine, both in New York. Her previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: Miss Clark Plans To Marry In Fall
description: An October wedding is planned by Sarah Elizabeth Clark and Mark Paul Kritzman, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Nesbitt Clark Jr. of Riverside, Conn., have announced. Mr. Kritzman is a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Henry Kritzman of Prospect, Conn.

title: NBC's Contribution To Terrorism's Cause
description: To the Editor:

title: YOUTHS TAKE STAGE IN ANNUAL CONCERTS
description: SPRING is still with us, and the state's orchestras are continuing their celebrations of the season.

title: THIS SIDE UP, PLEASE
description: Even in the narrow airplane seat, I had apparently managed to fall deeply asleep, because when I woke, I didn't know how long I'd slept, had no sense of the time, and no idea of the plane's whereabouts. I looked out the porthole - there was no moon; the black sky gave no clues. I looked down at my New York watch, which was set to Los Angeles time, but knew it was wrong because the plane had already left Hawaii on the leg south to New Zealand. It was an indeterminate number of hours after Honolulu time, perhaps another time zone and even a different day, a different hemisphere. The plane was crossing the date line and the Equator during the same night flight, and crossing even the year into a different season.

title: Jeanne C. Winant Becomes a Bride
description: Jeanne Catherine Winant, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert T. Winant of New York, was married yesterday to Raymond Louis La France, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred E. La France of Racine, Wis. Msgr. Michael Wrenn performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Mercy in Port Chester, N.Y.

title: 'SPEAKING PERSONALLY' WRITER SAYS CRITICS MISSED POINT
description: Vinaya Saijwani's May 4 Speaking Personally piece was a slap in the face.

title: Fish Auction Taking New Twist in Maine
description: A new type of fish auction is scheduled to start Sunday on the waterfront here.

title: CHINA AND TAIWAN MEET ABOUT CARGO PLANE
description: Representatives of Communist China and Taiwan's Chinese Nationalist Government met for the first time today in 37 years to discuss the return of a Taiwan cargo jet whose pilot defected to China. The two sides were said to disagree on where the transfer should occur.

title: CHANGES MADE AT THEATER LEAGUE
description: SOME changes are in the works at the Theater League of Westchester as the organization nears the end of its fourth season of producing popularly oriented musical entertainment in the county.

title: Perry's Ring Size: 23
description: Jostens Inc., has made more commemorative rings than anybody else, but according to officials of the Minneapolis company, it has never made so much ring at one time as it has just done for one client. To hear the officials talk, it's a wonder the order didn't get routed to the bracelet department.

title: REDISTRICTING PLAN FOR COUNCIL NEARS FINISH IN YONKERS
description: A COMMITTEE formed as a result of a lawsuit in Federal Court over the representation of minorities on the Yonkers City Council has nearly completed a redistricting proposal.

title: Karin Wittlinger Plans To Be Married June 20
description: Mr. and Mrs. Fritz A. Wittlinger of Katonah, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Karin Lynn Wittlinger, to Bruce Scott Butterfield, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Butterfield of Haworth, N.J. A June 20 wedding is planned.

title: 'New Wave' Kosher Wines
description: In his article '' 'New Wave' Kosher'' (Wine, April 13), Howard G. Goldberg writes that the ''fixation on heavy sweet red wine is an American quirk that . . . dates from shortly after Prohibition.''

title: NEWARK RESULT CASTS SHADOW ON PRIMARY
description: COUNCILMAN Sharpe James's surprising victory over Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson in Tuesday's election is casting its shadow on the June 6 Democratic primary for Congress and Essex County Executive.

title: CABLE TELEVISION IS COMING, AT LAST, TO 2 NORTHERN TOWNS
description: IT has been almost 20 years since residents in North Salem first considered cable television for their town. Because North Salem is hilly, reception in most homes is poor; cable television, residents thought, would improve their reception and offer a greater choice of programming. The neighboring town of Lewisboro began a similar process three-and-a-half years ago.

title: COLLEGE OF MOUNT ST. VINCENT: SCHOOL CELEBRATES WITH PRAYERS FOR MOST FAMOUS GRADUATE
description: The College of Mount St. Vincent concluded year-long celebrations of its 75th anniversary yesterday, with prayers for ''the safety and success'' of the school's best known alumna, Corazon C. Aquino, President of the Philippines.

title: Walecia Konrad a Bride
description: Walecia Konrad, associate editor of Working Woman magazine, and Terence F. Murphy, editor of Entree, a housewares magazine, were married yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: OFF THE BOOKS. By Robert A. Hutchison. (Morrow, $18.95.) David Edwards, a Texan, was a rising junior officer among the foreign currency traders in Citibank's Paris branch when he began to suspect that the chief trader was receiving kickbacks from a broker.

title:
WHAT'S DOING IN;
CAMDEN
description: At an indentation of Penobscot Bay where pine-clad mountains come down almost to the edge of the sparkling sea is Camden, Me., a summer resort whose growth until recently has been slow and decorous. The last big building boom was at the turn of the century, when wealthy industrialists built many of the imposing ''cottages'' that have become its landmarks.

title: Marion Freeman Weds George Corson Ellis 3d
description: Marion Forgan Freeman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David F. Freeman of Rumson, N.J., was married yesterday to George Corson Ellis 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ellis Jr. of Atlantic Highlands, N.J. The ceremony was performed at St. George's-by-the-River Episcopal Church in Rumson by the Rev. George Willis.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL BOND ACT: WHERE THE MONEY WENT
description: With a proposal for a new $1.45 billion Environmental Quality Bond Act before the State Legislature, questions have been raised about the money from the the $1.15 billion 1972 Environmental Quality Bond Act, the last such act.

title: EXTRADITION IS PROVING A TOUCHY SUBJECT FOR THE SENATE
description: EIGHTEEN months ago, in a ruling that still reverberates between Washington and London, a Federal judge refused to extradite Joseph Patrick Thomas Doherty, an Irish Republican Army fugitive convicted of killing a British soldier in Belfast, Northern Ireland. The judge accepted Mr. Doherty's argument that the slaying was a political act, exempt from extradition under a 1972 treaty between the United States and Britain.

title: BILL SEEKS STATE LICENSING FOR FINANCIAL PLANNERS
description: Financial planners in New York State would be required to obtain a license to practice their profession, just like physicians and accountants, under a bill introduced in the Assembly.

title: Merribel L. Symington and Richard E. Ayres Wed
description: Merribel L. Symington, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. M. Brown Levis of Manchester, Conn., was married yesterday to Richard E. Ayres, a son of Mrs. Harold Johnson of Beaverton, Ore., and the late John Lecroy Ayres of Portland, Ore. The Rev. Dr. John Harper performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church at Lafayette Square in Washington.

title: ROY'S COMPOSURE IS PIERCED
description: In the best of times, Patrick Roy, the 20-year-old rookie goaltending sensation of the Montreal Canadiens, talks to his goalposts as if they were linemates. He congratulates them for stopping expertly angled pucks, and for propping him up when the play before his net gets frenetic.

title: Marti Prashker Is the Bride Of Fellow Bank Executive
description: Marti Prashker and William B. Murray, assistant vice presidents of the Bank of America, were married yesterday at the Prashker family home in Alford, Mass. The Rev. D. Bradley Murray, a Roman Catholic priest and uncle of the bridegroom, officiated.

title: Nancy Korn, a Banker, Weds Thomas Rogers
description: Nancy R. Korn, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Sam J. Korn of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Thomas Rogers, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph F. Rogers of Round Rock, Tex. M. Michael Grupp, a leader of the Brooklyn Society for Ethical Culture, performed the ceremony in the penthouse at 236 West 26th Street, a catering hall.

title: CENTERS FOR AGED FACING CHALLENGE OF THE 'OLDEST OLD'
description: MEETING the diverse needs of the very old is a major challenge facing centers for the elderly, says Joan Mintz, deputy director of the state's Division on Aging. ''It is not only that the older population is continuing to grow at a rapid rate,'' Mrs. Mintz said, ''but there are many changes within that population. For instance, the number of people 75 and older is increasing, and centers must address their needs.

title: Selling Out
description: My late father, Ray E. Russell, had a few things in common with Edwin P. Wilson (''Selling Out,'' by Peter Maas, April 13). Both men grew up poor, were members of Future Farmers of America, sailed the Pacific in their youth, worked for a United States Government agency and had extensive dealings with Libya. My father was a little older than Edwin Wilson, though, and became involved with Libya long before Qaddafi was anybody. This was back when the Agency for International Development, my father's employer, was a fledgling called the United States Overseas Mission, created out of Harry S. Truman's Point Four program.

title: FALLING DOWN IN RIO
description: THE HOUR OF THE STAR By Clarice Lispector. Translated, and with an afterword by Giovanni Pontiero. 96 pp. New York: Carcanet. $15.95.

title: WINNING BY DEFAULT
description: DEBT AND DANGER The World Financial Crisis. By Harold Lever and Christopher Huhne. 160 pp. Boston: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $16.95.

title: MUNICIPALITIES RESIST ON TAX-MAP ISSUE
description: A LAW requiring cities and towns to provide the state with tax maps is being strongly resisted in Westchester, with critics calling it a step toward a government of ''Big Brother'' and ''a blow to home rule.''

title: INSURANCE SOLUTION DEBATED IN ALBANY
description: LAST year, the Town of North Hempstead bought $15 million worth of general liability insurance at a total price of $52,950. This year, the town will pay a total of $183,810 - for only $11 million in coverage.

title: LATIN: TOWARD A JOYFUL AWARENESS OF LANGUAGE
description: As the author of the elementary school Latin curriculum being used in the program at Blind Brook-Rye, I was delighted to read the article, ''Fifth Graders Chatting in Latin'' [ April 27 ] . In a formal and extensive study sponsored by the National Endowment for the Humanities, fifth and sixth graders in New York City who were taught this curriculum, ''First Latin: The Discovery of Language, for six months showed significant gains in standardized reading scores over the control groups that did not study Latin.

title: Putting Kids First
description: I graduated from Cornell University and the University of Chicago Graduate School of Business, spent five years trading in the futures markets in Chicago and decided to ''drop out'' when my daughter was born in 1984. My wife and I moved to Florida and, for one year, I attempted to work in my home while my wife studied to pass the bar exam.

title: DANCE: BARYSHNIKOV IN 'THE MOLLINO ROOM'
description: ALTHOUGH ''The Mollino Room,'' which received its New York premiere on Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, has choreography by Karole Armitage, an often controversial young choreographer, what gives American Ballet Theater's production its distinctive look are the designs of David Salle, an often controversial young painter.

title: Running Races That Last Days
description: MARATHON races are mere warm-ups for Marvin Skagerberg. Last year, the 48-year-old New Yorker ran 3,600 miles from Los Angeles to New York in 92 days, to beat Malcolm Campbell of England in a contest that benefited research into amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.

title: GUATEMALA GETS HELP REBUILDING ITS POLICE
description: Guatemala will receive $16 million in foreign aid to equip and modernize its national police force, Interior Minister Juan Jose Rodil Peralta has announced.

title: 2 INQUIRIES REVIEW ROLE OF S.I. PLANNING OFFICIAL
description: A City Planning Commissioner is under investigation by Federal and city prosecutors for his role in helping two real-estate developers acquire multimillion-dollar projects on Staten Island that require approvals by municipal agencies, according to law-enforcement officials.

title: SNOW CHIEF, 5-2, WINS PREAKNESS BY 4 LENGTHS
description: Snow Chief, who finished a distant 11th as the favorite in the Kentucky Derby two weeks ago, rebounded to score a powerful four-length victory over Ferdinand, the Derby winner, in the 111th Preakness Stakes today at Pimlico Race Course.

title: Skagit Valley
description: To the Editor: As frequent visitors to La Conner, Wash., we enjoyed the article on the flowers of Skagit Valley (''Valley of Blossoms in the West,'' Travel, March 23). La Conner is the oldest town in Skagit Valley.

title: THE ROWER'S EDGE: HIGH TECHNOLOGY
description: IT was one of those crew races in which nobody knew who won when the two boats zipped across the finish line side by side and the official on shore made the down-up-down signal with his finishing flag as fast as his wrists could move.

title: Miss Walrath Weds Richard Edelman
description: Rosalind Anne Walrath, an investment banker, and Richard Winston Edelman, a public relations executive, were married last night at the Harvard Club of New York by Rabbi Nathan Landman.

title: PATRIOTISM AND WHITE PEACOCKS
description: THE LION OF PESCARA By George MacBeth. 256 pp. Topsfield, Mass.: Jonathan Cape/Merrimack Publishers' Circle. $14.95.

title: Recuse My Dust
description: RED LEX ALERT!

title: MENOTTI AT 75 KEEPS HIS FESTIVALS SPINNING
description: The Spoleto Festival U.S.A. is a sort of annual cyclone in Charleston, S.C., where three or four concerts take place each day while elsewhere in town people are dancing or rehearsing a play and antiques or watercolors are being hawked on the street next to the T-shirt vendor. This has been going on for 10 years now. Nobody knows quite how, but the why is Gian Carlo Menotti and his ability to inspire affection and chaos. He has been going on for 75 years now.

title: CITY'S SCHOOL-SUPPLY PURCHASING SYSTEM ASSAILED
description: The Board of Education's purchasing operations are in such disarray that many principals find they can get items faster and cheaper from local retail stores, according to a report released yesterday by a civic group.

title: CHERNOBYL PUTS US ALL ON THE SPOT
description: SHORTLY after the Three Mile Island accident in 1979, I cross-examined nuclear experts from Northeast Utilities about the implications of that accident - or was it an ''incident?'' They displayed a faith in nuclear power that bordered on the religious. They asserted that there was not, and could not have been, a fuel meltdown at Three Mile Island. They truly believed that the damaged plant would soon be operating again.

title: SMOKING AT WORK: POLICIES ARE SOUGHT
description: WHAT smoking policies do Nestle's 950 staff members want for their new corporate headquarters in Harrison? About 300 hundred of the employees took less than 24 hours recently to respond to a corporate survey and demand that smoking be restricted. A total of 600 responded in a week.

title: ETERNALLY FEMALE
description: Over one 34th Street entrance to Macy's in Herald Square, some sturdy Greek nymphs are standing in pairs, apparently deep in conversation. Though they appear to support the pediment, their function is not structural: they're there to give the store class, to proclaim its sense of tradition, to promise ''classic'' quality. Through their ornamental grace, these caryatids are selling us the goods inside and, like young women around the turn of the century, when this Macy's opened, they are holding hands in the street.

title: RECENT RELEASES OF VIDEO CASSETTES
description: Homage to Verdi Featuring Sherrill Milnes Kultur 56 minutes. $39.95 This little salute to Giuseppe Verdi tries to be many things -perhaps too many.

title: FROM BIDEN TO BABBITT TO NUNN
description: AGAINST A BACKDROP OF A UNITED States flag that overwhelmed their hotel meeting room in Atlanta, members of the Democratic Policy Commission two weeks ago began drafting recommendations on such issues as the rural economy, international trade, family life and military policy. ''The larger interests and broader agenda of the Democratic Party and the nation have superseded the singular agenda of elite groups,'' declared Paul G. Kirk Jr., the Democratic national chairman who had limited the panel's membership to elected officials.

title: Diane McCarthy Is Wed To John W. Rutledge Jr.
description: Diane Wilmot McCarthy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent T. McCarthy of Valley Cottage, N.Y., and John William Rutledge Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Rutledge of New Canaan, Conn., were married yesterday. The Rev. Pierre A. Botton performed the ceremony at St. John's Roman Catholic Church in Darien, Conn.

title: RECENT RELEASES OF VIDEO CASSETTES
description: Grace Jones: One Man Show MusicVision 49 minutes. $29.95 As conceived by the director-photographer Jean-Paul Goude, pop star Grace Jones is a combination mannequin and living sculpture with a streak of stylized savagery in her personality.

title: Loft Conversion
description: In 1905, Stuyvesant Fish, son of the former New York Governor Hamilton Fish and a descendant of Peter Stuyvesant, the Dutch colonial governor of what was then called New Amsterdam, hired the architectural firm of Robertson & Potter to design a loft building on the family's land.

title: THE NEW SCHOOL PUSHES TO REVIVE Ph.D PROGRAM
description: The New School for Social Research, which many New Yorkers think of mainly for its noncredit evening courses in subjects from film to wine-tasting, is rebuilding the graduate faculty it founded more than 50 years ago as the University in Exile.

title: Unfair Rate Leap In a Tax Proposal
description: To the Editor:

title: 2d Tower at 2d and 40th
description: A land assemblage of ''part parking lot, part restaurant'' is becoming a 48-story condominium, the Commodore, at 40th Street and 2d Avenue.

title: Foreign Policy Review?
description: One of the interesting things about the Reagan Administration's foreign policy is that a majority of the American people, as measured by the popularity polls, support it, while some of the most experienced Republican students of foreign policy, looking to the future, want to amend it.

title: JAZZ: TRIBUTE TO BUDDY TATE
description: ''HIGHLIGHTS IN JAZZ'' ended its 13th season on Thursday at the New York University Loeb Auditorium with a tribute to the saxophonist Buddy Tate that gave the guest of honor relatively little chance to shine.

title: A JETS STAR ARRIVES AT THE CROSSROADS
description: ''I THINK it's important to have goals in life,'' said Robert C. Jackson Jr. of Westbury.

title:
ON LONG ISLAND;
Buying for Retirement Down the Road
description: WHEN the first section of a 300-unit condominium complex opened for sales three years ago on Riverhead's North Shore, the developers were gambling that they could attract buyers to an area that is not known for its resorts or employment opportunities.

title: Johnny Paycheck, the Singer, Given 9 1/2 Years for Shooting
description: The country singer Johnny Paycheck was found guilty Friday of shooting a man in a bar after an argument, and he was sentenced to up to nine and a half years in prison.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: A DEFAMATION suit filed by Representative Robert G. Torricelli against The Palisadian, a Cliffside Park weekly newspaper, and its publisher, Robert Nesoff, has been withdrawn.

title: PROSPECTS
description: A Savings Spree It's a case of bad timing. Consumers finally seem to be saving more - which in the long term could spell more investment and faster growth. But, in the short-term, weak spending translates into more economic sluggishness, says David A. Levy of Levy Economic Forecasts in Chappaqua, N.Y.

title: PAKISTANIS SHOOT DOWN AN AFGHAN MIG
description: Two American-made F-16 fighter jets of the Pakistani Air Force shot down an attacking Afghan Air Force MIG-21 in Pakistani airspace today, damaged a second and chased off two others, Government officials here said.

title: E. B. Foley Is Married To Miss Cox
description: Miranda Cox, a Soviet analyst, and Edward Boardman Foley, a recent law school graduate, were married yesterday at the Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York. The Revs.

title: A Constitution Short on Intent
description: To the Editor:

title:
ART;
A LATIN AMERICAN 'SALAD BOWL' AT THE JERSEY CITY MUSEUM
description: IT HAS been several years since ''salad bowl'' replaced ''melting pot'' to describe this country's ethnic diversity; in the salad, each ingredient retains its own flavor.

title: MOSCOW SAYS SOME AT CHERNOBYL PANICKED AND ABANDONED POSTS
