description: Soviet publications said today that some workers at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant had panicked and left their posts after the accident last month and were being disciplined.

title: MODERN JAZZMEN REVIVE THE PAST
description: At a time when recorded jazz of any kind is not generally viewed as a big-selling item and traditional jazz is considered a minor element within this limited field, it is surprising to find a record company that, since the beginning of the 1980's, has recorded and released more than 100 new, state-of-the-art LP's devoted to jazz in the styles of the 1920's or earlier, as played by contemporary musicians.

title: Hurdle to Compensation Without Lawyers
description: To the Editor:

title: FRESH AIR FUND CREATES TIES TO THE COUNTRY
description: To most New Yorkers, the other side of the world is, say, Singapore. But when Luis Rosario, a 13-year-old from East Harlem, talks of ''getting to go to the other side of the world,'' he is not speaking of the Orient, but of New Enterprise, Pa.

title: Verbatim; Services Denied
description: 'At this point, every baby has turned into a ticking time bomb that can go off in your hand.

title: Searching Pupils For Contraband
description: UNDER a new policy, public school pupils in Milford, Conn., were told that they might be searched if they were suspected of having illegal drugs, weapons or other contraband.

title: UNFAIR RATE LEAP IN A TAX PROPOSAL
description: To the Editor:

title: Julia Lang Is Married
description: Julia L. Lang, an assistant manager at Citicorp Investment Bank, and Edward P. Mally, who expects to receive an M.B.A. degree from the Columbia University Graduate School of Business next year, were married yesterday in Westport, Conn. The Rev. Frank A. Hall, a Unitarian minister, and the Rev. Edward J. Mally, a Roman Catholic priest and the bridegroom's uncle, performed the ceremony at the Westport Unitarian Church. The couple's parents are Mary G. Lang of Westport and the late Frank Lang, and Mr. and Mrs. Albert F. Mally of Somers, N.Y.

title: COUPLE IN SCHOOL BLAST LINKED TO EXTREMIST GROUP
description: The man and woman who took an elementary school here hostage Friday, injuring 70 children when their homemade gasoline bomb exploded, had ties to the Posse Comitatus and other white supremacist groups, according to law-enforcement officials.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
IS THE ENERGY DEPARTMENT PASSE?
description: IN HIS budget message to the Legislature on Feb. 10, Governor Kean proposed abolishing the state's Department of Energy and transferring its functions to other principal departments. Saying that its mission no longer justified department status, he suggested that its functions could be carried on uninterrupted in the Department of Commerce and Economic Development.

title: Alexandra Truitt Weds Executive
description: Alexandra Truitt, a daughter of Anne Dean Truitt of Washington, and the late James McConnell Truitt of San Miguel de Allende, Mexico, was married yesterday to Adam F. Remez, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley M. Remez of Mount Vernon, N.Y. The ceremony was performed at the Cosmopolitan Club in New York by Judge Mary Bednar of the Criminal Court of the City of New York.

title: WORST DROUGHT IN A CENTURY RAVAGES SOUTHEAST FARMS
description: A plume of dust is billowing like wood smoke behind Jackie Busby's tractor as it moves across a field so dry even the weeds look withered. There are clouds overhead, but no rain will fall today on Dooly County.

title: AT THE PHILHARMONIC - GOLD, DROSS AND SOME PERPLEXITY
description: It can be a revealing exercise at the end of any music season to think back - no referring to notes, please -and let bubble to the surface any memorable events that will. With the close of the New York Philharmonic's 1985-86 schedule last night, the time has come to unleash memory once again. Considering that the season spanned seven months and consisted of 37 different programs, including benefit concerts, it would be remarkable if at least a few nights did not stand out. And a few still do, though the ratio of gold to dross does not assay out as high as the orchestra's regular listeners have a right to expect.

title: TO MEMBERS, LOCAL 507 IS A FAMILY BUSINESS
description: To some of its 5,000 members, and to Federal investigators as well, Local 507 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters is like a family business.

title: The New Russian Arms Control Plan Looks Familiar
description: The Soviet arms control negotiators in Geneva last week presented to the American delegation a draft treaty for the elimination of medium-range nuclear weapons in Europe. The United States reaction, in Geneva and Washington, was a mix of skepticism and caution.

title: ROCK 'N ROLLL: A KEY TO ETERNAL YOUTH
description: CHRONOLOGICALLY, I'm old. Not as old as Mick Jagger, of course, but all the same, I'm very, very old.

title: Threat to Dun Liberty Island
description: JERSEY CITY said the National Park Service owed it nearly $1 million for water supplied to Liberty Island, home of the Statue of Liberty. The park service said the city's water meter was faulty and refused to pay.

title: FOR MANY COLLEGE SENIORS, THIS IS THE BIG DAY
description: TRUMPETS, bagpipes, bells - even an airplane trailing a banner - will help provide the pomp for some of the state's nearly 21,000 graduates as they receive their diplomas this spring.

title: Roth's 'Pictures of Malamud'
description: To the Editor:

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: JAMBALAYA IN PHILADELPHIA Philadelphia and New Orleans have joined forces to create an exchange of the best each city has to offer over the Memorial Day weekend. Bourbon Street will meet Broad Street with a mix of Mummers and Mardi Gras, pretzels and pralines.

title: Rugby at Colby Is 'Flourishing'
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: New & Noteworthy
description: PRICK UP YOUR EARS: The Biography of Joe Orton, by John Lahr. (Limelight, $10.95.) The English playwright Joe Orton had written only three full-length stage plays - ''Entertaining Mr. Sloane,'' ''Loot'' and ''What the Butler Saw'' - when he was killed by his homosexual lover at the age of 34 in 1967. While his outrageous farces failed to find an audience in this country in the 1960's, his reputation has risen steadily in the last few years, and the current New York production of ''Loot'' has been critically acclaimed. This biography ''is most helpful in providing special insight into the plays,'' Harold Clurman wrote here in 1978. ''John Lahr has been, and in this book remains Orton's most persistent champion largely because he rightly feels that our day requires the cure of disruptive laughter.'' THE GERMAN LESSON, by Siegfried Lenz. (New Directions, $10.95.) When Siggi Jepsen, a teen-age inmate of a reform school, is ordered to write an essay on the subject of duty, he recalls his childhood in a German village during World War II and the bitter conflict between his policeman father and a famous Expressionist painter whose works had been outlawed by the Nazis. Ernst Pawel said in The Book Review in 1972 that Siegfried Lenz's novel is ''a book of rare depth and brilliance'' that ''signals the emergence of an authentic new voice, shattering in its quiet authority.'' The author's ''wry low-keyed sense of humor is a constant delight,'' he said, and the translation by Ernst Kaiser and Eithne Wilkins conveys ''the full power of the original.''

title: THE TEEN-AGE 'MENACE'
description: A CYCLE OF OUTRAGE America's Reaction to the Juvenile Delinquent in the 1950s. By James Gilbert. 258 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $19.95.

title: D'Amato Makes It Official
description: Since he had assembled a campaign war chest of more than $5 million in recent years, it came as little surprise last week that Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato has decided to use it. The Republican from Long Island formally announced that he would run for a second term in November.

title: The Song Goes On
description: To the Editor:

title: Roth's 'Pictures of Malamud'
description: To the Editor:

title: ONE MAN'S RECIPE FOR A MEADOW GARDEN
description: Meadows are the new thing in landscaping. As is true of so many new things, a lot of misinformation is being passed out. Much hype exists with no relationship to reality, far too much profit oriented bandwagonism. As a result many property owners are led down the path to disappointment and failure.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: WHEN Warren E. Fox of Linwood retired in 1970, he figured to do plenty of fishing. But many of the fish he caught in the Great Egg Harbor River and other waterways in Atlantic County were damaged or diseased.

title: HE SEES TO IT THAT BRITAIN'S CHANNEL 4 STAYS INNOVATIVE
description: It was never meant to be a David-and-Goliath situation. Channel 4, Great Britain's fourth national television channel, was created not to steal audiences from that British flagship, the BBC, but to offer what the BBC does not and to outshine it from time to time.

title: Janine Tobin, an Engineer, Marries Charles R. Pepe Jr.
description: Janine Ann Tobin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William James Tobin of Todt Hill, S.I., was married yesterday to Charles Richard Pepe Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Pepe of Alpine, N.J. The Rev. Patrick Quigley performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Teresa's Church in Todt Hill.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: TIME LOVES A HERO. By Ben Greer. (Doubleday, $17.95.) The Southern writer as virgin, last seen as Stingo in ''Sophie's Choice,'' resurfaces in a coming-of-age novel that never quite comes of age.

title: DEXTERITY AND DIVERSITY ABOUND AMONG BUDDING VIRTUOSOS
description: So many virtuosos come streaming out of our conservatories and universities these days that they sometimes seem like products off an assembly line. Debut recordings by four young soloists -all of them Young Concert Artists competition winners - suggest that, to the contrary, the breed is as diverse as its elders. The styles range from the thoughtful musicianship of the trumpeter Stephen Burns to the alternating dreaminess and impetuosity of the pianist Sergei Edelmann, with the violinist Daniel Phillips and the cellist Colin Carr falling somewhere in between.

title: SLAM BY WINFIELD HELPS YANKS WIN AND END SLIDE, 11-6
description: As managerial moves go, these were almost predictable. Lou Piniella spent the night considering changes, and yesterday he dutifully made them: a new lineup, then a closed-door clubhouse meeting.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: OFFSHORE: A North Sea Journey. By A. Alvarez. (Houghton Mifflin, $15.95.) What, his friends wondered, was a literary guy like A. Alvarez doing in the North Sea oil fields? The British novelist, poet and critic and New Yorker writer says he heard a siren call.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK;
Philadelphia: A New Life for Old Factories
description: THERE is buried treasure in this city's abandoned industrial buildings, and it is being uncovered with substantial profit by real-estate developers like the Breslin Realty Development Corporation of Garden City, L.I.

title: Perspectives: Housing Policy; Manhattanites Seen as Big Gainers From Regulation
description: THE principal beneficiaries of the city's rent-regulatory system are Manhattanites living south of 110th Street, says a new report. And within that core area, most of the benefits go to working adults with no children. At the same time, lower-income households receive the fewest benefits.

title: COURT TO HEAR COMPETITOR'S CASE AGAINST NJ TRANSIT
description: CAN NJ Transit's statutory mandate to provide an ''efficient, effective, coordinated and coherent'' statewide transportation network collide at times with its self-interest?

title: EVEN THE HANDICAPPED CAN LEARN
description: Jane Goldblatt would take us back to a period in America's history that is better forgotten. In her letter to the Long Island editor on April 20, she claims that ''profoundly handicapped children can only benefit from a law that would provide them with a lifetime of care.''

title:
FOOD;
DARK DELICACIES OF THE SEA
description: SOME OF THE most stunning rev-elations of a trip to Southern Europe are the famous ''black ink'' dishes of the Mediterranean: risotto di seppiolina, the velvety, dark risotto with squid from Venice; arros negre, rice, deeply blackened with squid ink, enriched with bits of squid, mussels and shrimp from the Costa Brava; tender cuttlefish cooked in their own ink with wild bitter greens from the Ionian islands; daube des muscardins, a stew of tiny cuttlefish and ink from Martigues, cooked in wine and pungent with the wild herbs of Provence. There is something ineffably sensual about these dishes, something sweet and rich and full of the essence of the sea.

title: Lady's Secret Romps In Shuvee Handicap
description: What was supposed to be a race between two of the best older fillies in the country became a showcase for Lady's Secret yesterday when she led every step of the way to score an impressive 3 1/2-length victory in the $113,800 Shuvee Handicap at Belmont Park.

title: RENEWED INTEREST IN THE BAROQUE YIELDS VARIED TREASURES
description: If Claudio Monteverdi was the first great composer of operas, it was his pupil Francesco Cavalli (1602-1676) who may be counted as the first truly ''popular'' opera composer. He came to maturity just in time to benefit from Venice's unprecedented cultural explosion - 17 theaters literally devouring new operas season after season. Eventually, Cavalli wrote more than 40 of them, and they brought him wide recognition. After centuries of oblivion, several of these operas have reappeared in our era of Baroque reawakening (''Ormindo, ''La Calisto''); now we have ''Xerse,'' in a scholarly and meticulously prepared edition based on various manuscript sources (Harmonia Mundi HMC 1175.78, four discs, also HMC 901175.78 on CD and HMC 401175.78 on cassettes).

title: THE OTHER BATTLE IN CAMBODIA: THE CHILDREN
description: In refugees' bamboo huts at the edge of Thailand, in spartan classrooms in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, and in exile communities in France and the United States, a quiet struggle is being waged over Cambodia's children.

title: A GUITARIST, A FLUTIST AND PIANIST IN RECITALS
description: Christopher Oldfather -- One suspects that the pianist Christopher Oldfather could make a strong impression in any music he chose. Therefore it is our good fortune that Mr. Oldfather selected some unusually challenging 20th-century music to play at his debut concert at Carnegie Recital Hall Tuesday night.

title: SUIT OVER OIL SPILL IN FRANCE ENTERS 2d PHASE
description: Eight years ago the Amoco Cadiz, a 233,000-ton supertanker, went aground off France, causing the worst oil spill in history.

title: SPERRY FIGHTS BACK AGAINST BURROUGHS
description: Sperry tried to rebuff Burroughs's second takeover attempt, but analysts and traders say the two computer companies are not through sparring. Sperry scoffed at the $70-a-share tender offer, and said that if Burroughs gets 50 percent of its stock, it might offer to buy the rest at $80 a share. If Burroughs then tried to buy the stock back from Sperry at $80 a share, it would wind up having to pay more than $4.6 billion total for the company. Burroughs said it would be willing to negotiate, but analysts said it might not be willing to meet Sperry's price - although another company might well be. Sperry stock closed at $73.50 on Friday.

title: UNIVERSITIES DEBATE THE COSTS OF SELLING INVESTMENTS LINKED TO SOUTH AFRICA
description: Leaders of American colleges and universities that have decided to divest their endowment portfolios of stocks in companies doing business in South Africa are sharply divided and anxious over the economic consequences of such decisions.

title: Gandhi Urges Pressure For End to Apartheid
description: In a four-nation African tour, Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India has begun a campaign to urge the Commonwealth countries and the movement of nations espousing nonalignment to press South Africa to end apartheid.

title: MEREDITH MONK SALUTES THE FAMILIAR
description: Meredith Monk has become known for elaborate multimedia spectacles involving large casts.

title: Jetliners Nearly Crash On Chicago Runways
description: Two airliners accelerating for takeoff on intersecting runways at O'Hare International Airport nearly collided today, but one of the jets took evasive action and took off over the other, Federal officials said.

title: Chernobyl, Three Mile Island, Hiroshima
description: The radioactive particles from Chernobyl are nothing less than a message of shared fate. To begin to understand that message, we must look at precisely what has been neglected by commentators on the Soviet accident, as well as by designers of nuclear plants and weaponry everywhere: the psychological factor.

title: POLAROID HAS PUT NEW MAGIC INTO ITS BLACK BOX
description: NOW that Polaroid's Spectra system - which includes a newly designed instant camera, new accessories, new filma dn new laser system for copying and enlarging prints sent to Polaroid - is out of the headlines and on the market, it may be the right time to evaluate what the venture means to photographers.

title: MUSCOOT FARM IN SOMERS OPENS 2 NEW ADDITIONS
description: AS Muscoot Farm begins its 12th season, the transformations it has undergone over those years are increasingly evident. This year's opening ceremonies, held earlier this month, were marked by cutting a green ribbon to the new reception center. A small museum of farm implements was also opened. These two additions are part of the ongoing development of the county park in Somers.

title: MAREE A STRONG 2D IN THE 1,500
description: Sydney Maree had been training hard, but he did not know if he was in racing shape. So today, he drove here from his home in Rosemont, Pa., and finished a happy second in the 1,500 meters in the seventh annual Adidas-Princeton Invitational track and field meet.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BOSTON (AL) - Placed Glenn Hoffman, shortstop, on the 15-day disabled list and called up Rey Quinones, shortstop, from Pawtucket of the International League.

title: AMERICAN BALLET THEATER HAS A BIG WEEK AHEAD
description: Four new ballets and two gala evenings is no small number of events for a ballet company's New York season. And American Ballet Theater, which is presenting those attractions during its current, nine-week season at the Metropolitan Opera House, enters its most hectic period in the next three days, when it presents three of those special events in three days. Tomorrow, at the start of its third week at the Metropolitan, Ballet Theater will present the New York premiere of Sir Kenneth MacMillan's ''Requiem'' to Andrew Lloyd Webber's music. On Tuesday, the company will celebrate Antony Tudor, its choreographer emeritus, with an all-Tudor program. And the New York premiere of David Gordon's ''Murder'' will be performed on Wednesday.

title: Harness Driver Injured in Pileup
description: The harness driver David Dunckley was listed in critical condition today at Winthrop University Hospital in Mineola, L.I., after he was thrown from his sulky in a four-horse pileup at Roosevelt Raceway Friday night.

title: PASTA AND 'PERSONAL PIZZAS'
description: MENUS that feature individual pizzas and unusual pastas like that of Galleria in Garden City South capitalize on the kind of trendy, informal cafe dining that is becoming increasing popular.

title: WAR ON OIL TANKERS HEATS UP IN THE PERSIAN GULF
description: Iran and Iraq are stepping up their two-year-old ''tanker war'' in the Persian Gulf, having sharply increased attacks against neutral shipping there in the last few months, according to diplomats and military experts in the region.

title: Yanks May Go? Why Fight It?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Met Opera Board Names New Chairman
description: James S. Marcus was elected chairman of the board of the Metropolitan Opera Association at the board's annual meeting on Thursday, the company has announced. Mr. Marcus succeeds William Rockefeller, who was elected honorary chairman.

title: BOXING PROMOTER PLANS IRISH ATHLETIC GAMES FOR SUMMER
description: IS Sugar Ray Leonard really coming out of retirement to fight Marvelous Marvin Hagler, the undisputed middleweight champion?

title: Data Bank: May 18, 1986
TO KEEP LOCAL DESTINIES IN LOCAL HANDS
description: SPRING has come to Connecticut and with it building development more extensive than ever before. But as never before, a growing cry for a building moratorium is heard in the land.

title: WHY MUST WE LOSE THE STUDIO?
description: It was disheartening to learn - in connection with the April 20 review of its latest production, ''Split Second'' - that Lindenhurst's Studio Theater is likely to close at the end of the season. During a time when we bask in the glow of lowered inflation, this artistic endeavor seems threatened by higher insurance premiums and a doubled rental charge.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:I would love to see Alaska but not with the emphasis on a luxury cruise. Can you suggest other ways of seeing the state? - P. A. H., Chappaqua, N.Y. Answer:Air services to and within Alaska, bus tours along its highways and travel on ferryboats and, though limited, on railroads, offer a variety of ways for getting around. One possibility for the independent traveler is to use the ferry systems of British Columbia and Alaska that link Courtenay on Vancouver Island and Skagway at the head of the Inside Passage and such ports as Sitka and Haines in between. Passengers can break the journey past snowy peaks, fjords and glaciers in Alaskan ports and make excursions inland.

title: Hobart Captures Title In Lacrosse 7th Time
description: Mike Guy, a junior midfielder, scored two goals midway through the final quarter to rally Hobart to a 13-10 victory over Washington today and give Hobart its seventh straight Division III national lacrosse championship.

title: Jazz
description: A tango revolutionary, an iconoclastic pianist and a wind-instrument player fascinated by non-western music will make rare visits to New York this week.

title: MUSIC: CARTER'S 'SYRINGA,' BY SPECULUM MUSICAE
description: ''WHY pick at a dull pavan few care to follow, except a few birds of dusty feather,'' runs a portion of John Ashbery's poem ''Syringa.'' The composer Elliott Carter set that poem and added various Greek texts as commentary in one of his best-known works, also entitled ''Syringa'' (1978). And it was that piece that formed the climax of the climactic gala concert of the new-music group Speculum Musicae's 15th-anniversary season, Friday night at Alice Tully Hall.

title:
Focus: Durham, N.C.;
'Hot Spot' Getting New Center
description: NORTH of this Research Triangle city, three small tributaries, the Eno, Flat and Little Rivers, stitch together the rolling Piedmont countryside and weave their way through the 5,300-acre Treyburn Project, one of North Carolina's largest and most ambitious commercial-residential real-estate developments.

title: Hiroko Imamura Becomes Bride of Kamla K. Prasad
description: Hiroko Imamura, a Columbia University Law School graduate, and Kamla Kant Prasad, a fourth-year medical student at the University of Connecticut, were married yesterday at St. Paul's Chapel of Columbia University by Jean Kotkin, a leader of the American Ethical Union.

title: Hoboken Block
description: To the Editor:

title: AT GREENWOOD LAKE, POWERBOAT RACES
description: During most of the year, Greenwood Lake is a quiet place, a nine-mile stretch of placid water tucked between mountainous ridges separating New York and New Jersey. But this weekend is different. As many as 70 inboard boats - hydroplanes, runabouts, and skiffs - were expected to gather there for two days of high-speed racing.

title: Hilary Ball Wed To Glenn Carlin
description: Hilary Macdougall Ball, the daughter of Ian M. Ball of New York and the late Lee Lewis Ball, was married yesterday to Glenn Michael Carlin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Carlin of Chatham Township, N.J. The Rev. Henry Ferhen performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at a residence in Westhampton Beach, L.I.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: A CUP OF TEA IN PAMPLONA. By Robert Laxalt. (University of Nevada, $12.75.) The first novel by Robert Laxalt, author of numerous books on Basque and southwestern American culture, involves Gregorio, an aging Basque smuggler, and Nikolas, his chosen successor.

title: Getting the Jump On Rent Bills
description: Bills that could affect New York City's nearly one million rent-stabilized apartments brought tenants and landlords out in force in Albany last week, lobbying against each other.

title: MANY CAUSES MOVE A TEXAS CAMPUS
description: DR. Les Kurtz, a sociology professor at the University of Texas here, is an outspoken liberal who admits his views would have found more supporters in the 1960's than they do now. But when asked when he would rather be teaching, he paused and said the broad range of political viewpoints and activities on campus make the present a more stimulating time to be in academia.

title: BRAVER THAN WE THOUGHT
description: THE GARDEN OF EDEN By Ernest Hemingway. 247 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $18.95.

title: Another Look At Disability Rolls
description: Few of the Reagan Administration's initiatives to tailor more tightly the role of Government provoked a sharper reaction than its reviews of the Federal disability rolls. They were halted in 1984, largely because of the outcry.

title: END THE CHARADE ON THIRD WORLD DEBT
description: FIDEL Castro is right. The third world debt should be renounced.

title: Marianne Cabot Wed To James S. Welch Jr.
description: Marianne Cabot, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis H. Cabot of Cold Spring, N.Y., was married yesterday to James Stirling Welch Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Welch of Louisville, Ky. The Rev. Frederick Buechner performed the Presbyterian ceremony at St. Philip's Church in the Highlands in Garrison, N.Y., assisted by the Rev. William S. Reisman, an Episcopal priest.

title: ONE-MAN SHOWS BUCK HIGH ODDS
description: In ''Sweet Liberty,'' the new film written and directed by Alan Alda, who also co-stars in it, there's a scary, potentially hilarious scene on a roller coaster: Michael Caine, as an arrogantly self-assured, womanizing movie actor named Elliott James, decides to change cars as the roller coaster is making its slow, steady, creaky approach to the ride's first and highest precipice. Elliott, at the last minute, has taken it into his head to move to the front to sit with his pretty, pigeon-brained mistress.

title: 3 KILLED BY GUNMAN AT COCAINE SESSION, ACCORDING TO POLICE
description: A 33-year-old man freebasing cocaine with four friends in his Harlem apartment early yesterday morning shot three of them to death and fired at another, who escaped through a second-story window, the police said.

title: WAR AID FOR MOZAMBIQUE: BRITISH SPIT AND POLISH
description: Capt. Steve Norris of the British Army made a close inspection of the 48 Mozambican Army officers standing at attention before him, briskly trimming stray threads from their camouflage uniforms with a razor blade.

title: Assad Says U.S. Moves Blocked Hostage Effort
description: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria, denouncing what he called President Reagan's ''verbal bombs'' against the Mideast nation, said Syria's efforts to free Americans held hostage in Lebanon were blocked by the American bombing of Libya.

title: TEACHER DRESS CODE IS RESISTED
description: IT STARTED with a principal's telling a seventh-grade teacher to wear a tie. It ended, seven months later, with the Paterson Board of Education's telling 1,800 teachers how to dress for school.

title: THE IACOCCA TOUCH
description: Lee Iacocca firmly states in his tough-talking autobiography that ''there are no free lunches.'' But Lee: a million bucks?

title: Reagan's Rest
description: Well into his sixth year in what is often called the most grueling job in the country, 75-year-old Ronald Reagan will take the longest vacation of his Presidency this summer - or he will if his closest advisers have anything to say about it. Looking forward from May, Presidential schedulers calculate that he and Mrs. Reagan should be able to fly to their ranch in Santa Barbara early in August and remain there for a full month, until after Labor Day.

title: Ursinus Wins
description: Devin Murphy and Beth Bingaman each scored four goals today as Ursinus College rallied from a three-goal deficit to beat defending champion Trenton State, 12-10, for the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III women's lacrosse championship.

title: Selling Out
description: If it required the personal reaction and resolve of E. Lawrence Barcella Jr., an assistant United States attorney in Washington, to bring Edwin Wilson to justice, and if a recent spectacular case of espionage came to light only because an estranged spouse elected for personal reasons to blow the whistle, can we really afford to depend on such subjective defenses for something so essential as the national security of the United States? FRANK J. DEVINE Hackensack, N.J.

title: Who Pays Those Who Certify Rent-Control Increases?
description: A DISPUTE between state and city agencies over which should pay for inspections of rent-controlled apartments has led to a five-month delay in the payment of more than $1 million a month in rent increases for 100,000 apartments and precipitated an uproar among landlords.

title: BETTER THAN NEW
description: The construction site looks like any other. There are cranes and bulldozers and trailers with Playboy centerfolds on the wall and one of those quilted aluminum trucks that sell corn muffins sealed, as if for eternity, in slightly inflated cellophane bags. The men on the job, and the few women too, wear bandannas and down vests and work boots, and they stick their thick gloves in the back pockets of their jeans. Today is Thursday, and so Angelo Bommarito, the foreman for the laborers, zigzags across the site, finding his men and passing out checks. ''Yo, Giacomo,'' he hollers at a man driving a forklift. The man cannot hear above the engine's noise. ''Yo! Payday!'' The man hits the brakes. Giacomo gets his check, but he cannot cash it until he takes the boat back to Manhattan. For this job, even though it is surrounded by all the trappings of any other, is singular. Out here in New York Harbor, some 300 workers are repairing and restoring the Statue of Liberty for her July 4 centennial celebration. Banking by boat is the least of the challenges and a paycheck is far from the greatest of the rewards. ''We got the job of the century,'' says A. J. Anello, the safety superintendent on the project. ''Restoring America's symbol of freedom for America.''

title: MITTERRAND IS MAKING WAVES, BUT SMALL ONES
description: PRESIDENT Francois Mitterrand of France sent up a small warning signal last week. ''I am here,'' it seemed to say. ''Do not ignore me.'' It came during a Cabinet debate on the Pacific island territory of New Caledonia, long a disputed subject between the left and right and a place where violence erupted last year between forces favoring and opposing independence.

title: AS CUOMO SEEKS RE-ELECTION, POPULARITY OUTSHINES RECORD
description: Governor Cuomo addressed a group of elderly people here at the Capitol the other day and told them what they did not want to hear - that the state could not afford a prescription drug plan as broad as they would like.

title: WHAT HE BELIEVED AND WHEN HE BELIEVED IT
description: STOCKMAN The Man, the Myth, the Future. By Owen Ullmann. Illustrated. 343 pp. New York: Donald I. Fine. $18.95. THE REAL DAVID STOCKMAN By John Greenya and Anne Urban. Introduction by Ralph Nader. 302 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $15.95.

title: DIVESTED CONCERNS PROVE PROFITABLE FOR TARRYTOWN GROUP
description: TEN managers, nine of whom are former International Telephone and Telegraph executives, have been quietly buying companies divested by large corporations and bringing them to new profitable levels. They are the principals in Andlinger & Company, an investment-banking and management concern based in Tarrytown. The company was formed in 1976 by Gerhard R. Andlinger, an ex-president of I.T.T. Europe, who reasoned that with the acceleration of acquisitions and mergers, many large corporations would find themselves with stepchildren they couldn't or didn't want to manage.

title: Jean Valentine Kristiansson Is Wed
description: Jean Valentine Kristiansson, the administrator of the New England Society in New York, was married yesterday to William Alfred Winant 3d, a director of Investor Psychology, an investment advisory concern in New York, and the producer and writer of its radio program on financial affairs. The Rev. Herbert G. Draesel Jr. performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity in New York.

title: Tapping the Boom for Low-Cost Housing
description: THE prosperity that most Connecticut residents are now enjoying may be worsening housing prospects for the state's needier citizens.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: DOWN PERISCOPE Sometimes even the oddest things become fairly routine. So maybe it's understandable that Wesley Carman Jr., one of the owners of W. D. Marine in Freeport, was rather blase recently when asked about the submarine in his boatyard.

title: FOR TEEN-AGERS, MEDIOCRITY?
description: FOR the last 20 years, a devoted band of editors, teachers and librarians has been clearing a pathway through the steamy thicket of adolescence and paving it with an amazing variety of books, from urban slice-of-life to dragon tales, historical family dramas to scenarios of terrorism.

title: THE HORSE HAD A MISSION
description: REVENGE is not the word he wanted to use, Carl Grinstead, co-owner of Snow Chief, had said. Redemption was. Yes, he added, he'd love to have a little redemption.

title: ROCK: SIOUXSIE AND BANSHEES
description: SIOUXSIE and the Banshees, who played Radio City Music Hall Thursday, know the power of drone-rock - songs that build simply but inexorably. From their early days as one of Britain's first punk-rock bands, Siouxsie and the Banshees have evolved music that is determinedly static.

title: Engineer Is Wed To Susan Spaller
description: Susan Lynn Spaller, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Martin Spaller of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to John Peter Verschoor, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Curtis C. Verschoor of Barrington, Ill. The Rev. Charles C. Smith officiated at the Congregational Church of New Canaan.

title: Boasts and Insults; Strange Loyalty
description: Michael Deaver, the former deputy White House chief of staff, calls criticism of his lobbying activities ''groundless and impertinent,'' especially the suggestion that he would use his friendship with President Reagan for personal gain. It is, he told a House investigating subcommittee, ''not only mean-spirited, but is also an implicit attack on the integrity of the President.''

title: The Other Ellis Island
description: Even as you climb ashore, 10 minutes from lower New York, it's clear that the great Ellis Island controversy arises from a great misunderstanding. Contrary to wide public impression, no one wants to desecrate or commercialize the vast brick temple through which 12 million people entered America. Far from it. The ornate red building is veiled in scaffolding, evidence of a loving restoration that will cost more than $100 million. By 1992, it will constitute a vast, evocative monument to the Golden Door.

title: ROCK: THE FEELIES HEADLINES TRIPLE BILL
description: NEW YORK CITY and nearby New Jersey have long supported a robust rock subculture, made up of bands that value well-crafted songs and guitiar expertise above synthesizers and silly haircuts. What's been lacking, up to now, is a viable independent record label to showcase some of the area's most talented and original bands.

title: Teamster Leader Follows Tradition
description: Jackie Presser, known in labor circles as someone who keeps his word, had it broken for him last week by a Federal grand jury in Cleveland. The teamster president, who had vowed he would avoid being indicted, was charged with racketeering and embezzling $700,000 from the union to pay employees who did no work.

title: IN GARDEN STATE, A HOT LINE ON BUGS AND SHRUBS
description: The volunteers who run the county hot line know something about the other side of life in this bedroom suburb. They hear it in people's voices, over the phones.

title: Women Win Both Primaries In Nebraska
description: Outsiders seemed more struck with the result than Nebraskans last week, when the conservative but populist farm state became the first to nominate women as the candidates of both major political parties. Local newspaper and party public opinion polls had been predicting that Helen Boosalis, the former Mayor of Lincoln, the state capital, would far outdistance the seven other Democrats running, and that either Nancy Hoch, the Republican Senatorial candidate in 1984, or Kay Orr, the State Treasurer, would lead in the seven-person Republican race. Mrs. Orr displaced Mrs. Hoch, the early favorite; Mrs. Hoch, who is a member of the state university Board of Regents, came in third.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK;
Cincinnati: Winning Ideas For Hillsides
description: AVACANT inner-city hillside lot filled with trash, trees and ripped-up furniture would not seem naturally appealing to architects from 41 states and several Canadian provinces.

title: NORMAL AMERICAN CHILDREN? 'WHERE'S YOUR RESPECT?'
description: AS part of my daily routine, each day I pass a girls school in a beautiful section of a wealthy community in Westchester. The girls who attend it are not deprived, or unloved, or abused or uncared for. They are a group of today's normal American children - children of the 80's.

title: Princeton Selling Stock
description: Princeton University, for the first time, will sell its stock in a company doing business in South Africa, a school spokesman says.

title: WINE MAKERS SEEK SUPPORT FOR GROWTH
description: THE state's wine industry is growing fast and bringing jobs and revenue here, but it needs support from the state if it is to continue to thrive.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;
WIDE HORIZONS FOR DRAMA FESTIVAL
description: THE State University of New York at Stony Brook is thinking big, but starting small.

title: NEW ALLURE OF THE MORTGAGE PARTNERSHIP
description: THE rush to invest in real estate is taking a new twist. Investors are pulling back from equity partnerships, which own properties, in favor of mortgage loan partnerships. According to Robert A. Stanger & Company, first-quarter sales of equity partnerships dropped 18.1 percent, to $1.1 billion, from the first quarter of 1985. By contrast, sales of public mortgage loan partnerships rose 123 percent, to $450 million - even though mortgage rates fell throughout the period.

title:
BRIEFING;
A Chernobyl Symposium
description: The Ethics and Public Policy Center has scheduled a symposium on the Chernobyl reactor accident that will feature Soviet and Eastern European defectors who claim expertise on nuclear issues. For security reasons, the center declines to identify one of the participants in advance; he is described only as ''a very high-ranking former K.G.B. official'' who will be named when he appears at the session at the International Club on Thursday.

title: NASSAU G.O.P. DENIES ENDORSEMENT FOR 3 JUDGES
description: Despite appeals by the state's top judges, Nassau Republicans have again broken tradition and refused bipartisan endorsement to three sitting Democratic judges who had intended to seek re-election this fall.

title: NEW ENGLAND CLAMS: A FRUITFUL HARVEST
description: From the Down East coast of Maine to back bay Boston to Rhode Island's Point Judith and on along the Connecticut Shore, New England's 5,751-mile shoreline yields a fruitful harvest. Several varieties of clams burrow into the sand, silt and mud of the bays and estuaries. All it takes to satisfy the clam lover is a plate of freshly opened Little Necks. ''That's the way we like them, on the half shell,'' says Ralph Boragine, executive director of the Seafood Council in Rhode Island, the tiny state that produces most of the hard clams in the region.

title: STATES HELPING THEIR OWN FARMERS
description: Hubert Schilb was thinking back. His eyes seemed to focus on a distant cloud, far beyond his fields of sprouting corn and the lush green carpets of maturing barley that he will use to feed the litters of pigs squealing in a nearby shed.

title:
DINING OUT;
EUROPEAN CHARM IN RYE
description: THIS tiny restaurant with a great deal of European charm celebrates its 10th year of beguiling diners with a personal cuisine influenced by that of Italy's north, in general, and Milan, in particular, the birthplace of Umberto Proserpio, the chef and owner. Crisp linen, pretty little pots and vases filled with fresh flowers and cheery scenes glazed onto Villeroy and Boch china grace the closely spaced tables. At dinner red-shaded candles glow warmly and invitingly.

title: A CALENDAR OF LIBERTY EVENTS
description: There's more to the centennial of the Statue of Liberty than the celebrations over the July Fourth weekend. Miss Liberty also is being saluted in New York's museums, libraries, art galleries and public places with exhibitions that range from the academic to the artistic, from the poignant to the whimsical. The Statue as

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
MEDALLION AWARDS
description: It is Medallion Awards time again. Tuesday night at Westchester Community College, five individuals will be honored for excellence in their fields and contributions to the community. The 14th annual Medallion Awards dinner, held by the Westchester Community College Foundation, begins with cocktails at 6 P.M.: tickets are $100, call 285-6706.

title: NEWSPAPER CITES OFFICIAL PRESSURE
description: The Administration's current discussions with The Washington Post about publication of an article based on classified information mark the sixth time in the last 12 months that Government officials have pressed the newspaper to withhold or alter an impending article, Leonard Downie Jr., the managing editor of The Post, said Friday.

title: A Short Flight for an Old Bird
description: Sixty-five million years after nature removed the original from the face of the Earth, humans today helplessly watched a $700,000 plastic replica of a flying reptile plunge to the dust of a modern airfield.

title: TIROZZI SEES HOPE ON BILL FOR EDUCATION THIS WEEK
description: WHEN Gerald N. Tirozzi was appointed Education Commissioner in July 1983, he vowed to raise the quality of education and teachers' salaries.

title: Talking Comparisons; Deciding On a Condo Or a Co-op
description: BUYERS seeking cooperative apartments or condominiums often are surprised to find significant price differentials between them, even though the space and amenities may be roughly the same.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There were cases of people deserting, panicking and trying to pin the blame on others.

title: A Chief's View
description: To the Editor:

title: KING STAYS IN FRONT BY A SHOT ON 72-139
description: Betsy King, a five-time winner on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour, maintained a one-stroke lead today in the second round of the Chrysler-Plymouth Classic.

title: STUDY FINDS NEW YORK CITY LAGGING IN HIGH-TECHNOLOGY JOBS
description: In the late 1970's, as high technology became a national preoccupation, scores of American cities initiated economic development programs to secure a piece of that industrial future.

title: THAT'S FLARE
description: Some months ago, in a suite at the Plaza Hotel, an extraordinary meeting took place among a small group of men. It was remarkable that they had never gathered together before, since they were all in the same narrow line of work, all aficionados of color and light, explosives and extravaganzas. Most of them were also Italian-Americans, men born and raised in the family business.

title: A KEY TO THE LIBRARY OF TOMORROW
description: In his scholarly yet entertaining novel ''The Name of the Rose,'' Umberto Eco celebrates the mission of librarians: ''A book is a fragile creature, it suffers the wear of time, it fears rodents, the elements and clumsy hands. . . . So, the librarian protects the books not only against mankind but also against nature, and devotes his life to this war with the forces of oblivion.''

title: THE FASHION FOR FRAGRANCE
description: FRAGRANCES CAN HAVE FAR-REACH-ing effects - a woman's scent arrives in a room before she enters, and it stays behind after she's gone. Their consequences are also wide-ranging in other ways.

title: HEARTY ITALIAN AT THE RIGHT PRICE
description: DINING out does not always mean looking for the ultimate gustatory experience.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Surprised by Peace The sense of restraint and privation that war imposes is hard to shake off, according to Frances Partridge. In ''Everything to Lose'' (Little, Brown), she describes the slow return to simple pleasures in 1945.

title: OFFICE COMPLEX WITH AN EYE TO EXHIBITS
description: CORPORATIONS everywhere are turning their houses into homes with art collections, as well as sponsoring exhibitions. Landlords, however, have yet to join the cultural race in significant numbers, which makes Blue Hill Plaza, an office complex near Pearl River in Rockland County, an unusual, although not unique, enterprise.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN CORPORATE ART
description: AN 18-panel mural, Jim Dine's largest, hangs in the lobby of Nuveen Inc.'s new headquarters building in Chicago. Milton Avery, Marsden Hartley and 12 other American painters have small dining rooms in New York's new Equitable Center named after them and decorated with their works. The building's lobby contains Roy Lichtenstein's largest mural and a museum housing part of the Whitney Collection.

title: GLITTERING HUNGARIAN TREASURES AT COOPER-HEWITT
description: TENTH-CENTURY Hungarians believed in dressing well. Boys were given elaborate silver belts on the day they were initiated into manhood, and one's position in society might be indicated by one's ''sabretache'' - or purse-plate - a decorative covering attached to the outside of the small bag that was used to carry utilitarian objects.

title: POLLS APART
description: IN an ''instant replay'' of a tumultuous meeting in March, the Republican majority on the Harrison Town Board has again squared off against students at the State University of New York at Purchase who object to the removal of two polling places from the campus.

title: ENCOUNTERS WITH LIBERTY: AT FIRST SIGHT
description: DEREK WALCOTT; Saint Lucia, West Indies. Poet and playwright. What I remember is seeing her while going over to Staten Island to visit a friend when I first came to New York, probably about 10 or 12 years ago. The scale of her was staggering, the whole sweep, passing by her on the ferry. What was moving, I think, was the fact that the statue is a woman and not a heroic, manly figure. So for all her scale and immensity, there's something soft about the Statue of Liberty, something tender about her. I think at the heart of the idea of American democracy there is something tender.

title: DARK SECRETS IN 'FOOL FOR LOVE'
description: AS it did with ''True West'' earlier this season, the Arena Players Repertory Theater again shows a sensitivity to the work of Sam Shepard with its current production of ''Fool for Love,'' ably directed by Frederic De Feis.

title: Libyans in North Jersey
description: A former Foreign Service officer who later became City Manager of Englewood, N.J., blames the State Department for allowing the Libyans to establish a tax-exempt ''country residence'' for its diplomats and visitors next to a Jewish day school in that Bergen County community.

title: MANAGING BY TUMULT AT WINNEBAGO
description: TO the outside world, Winnebago Industries, the nation's leading producer of motor homes, is associated with vacations and good times. But inside Winnebago, senior executives often find a dearth of relaxation and fun. They feel tremendous pressure to please the company's crusty, tough-minded founder, John K. Hanson, and few of them can. Every few years, it seems, a chairman or chief executive is ousted or demoted at Mr. Hanson's behest.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
AGELESS CREATIVITY
description: ''I would like the children to have a living example of creativity as something ageless,'' said William Wertheim, the force behind the Intergenerational Arts and Crafts Day that will take place tomorrow at the William B. Ward School in New Rochelle.

title: 45 Condos On 15 Floors
description: Chelsea, the neighborhood sandwiched between Greenwich Village and the Garment District on the West Side of Manhattan, is an enclave with a checkered history. Originally an estate and farm, the area climbed from periods marked by slaughterhouses, shanties and slums to ones of theaters and town houses.

title: 14 Killed in Sri Lanka In Fighting in North
description: Fourteen people were killed today in battles between Government troops and Tamil separatist guerrillas in the Jaffna district in northern Sri Lanka, security sources said.

title: Eastern Grounds 4 Jets For Lack of Documents
description: Eastern Airlines has voluntarily grounded four jets whose leased engines were rebuilt with foreign parts and lacked proper documentation, Federal officials said today. Two flights were cancelled today as a result but no further cancellations were expected, airline officials said.

title: Philippines Facing the Future
description: A great deal is made here of the differences in the motley crew that assembled into President Corazon Aquino's Government after deposing Ferdinand Marcos. Indeed, personal rivalries and jockeying for patronage power are probably more important than contrasts of outlook.

title: SICILY AND THE MAFIA
description: ''My crime was to have been born and bred in a family of Mafia traditions, and to have lived in a society where all are Mafiosi. For this they are respected, while those who are not are scorned.''

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: BACK OF THE YARDS: The Making of a Local Democracy. By Robert A. Slayton. (University of Chicago, $22.) If Studs Lonigan were around to read this book, he wouldn't recognize his old neighborhood.

title: Cynthia A. Roney, Banker, Is Wed to R. A. Goldstein
description: Cynthia Ann Roney, the daughter of Mrs. George D. Yetman and the late Frank F. Roney, was married yesterday to Robert A. Goldstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph H. Goldstein of Flushing, Queens. The ceremony was performed by Richard J. George, a Cambridge, Mass., justice of the peace, at the home of the bride's mother in Brookline, Mass.

title: Yehuda Hellman Dies; Headed Jewish Groups
description: Yehuda Hellman, a leader of several Jewish organizations, died of a heart attack Friday at St. John's Hospital in Chesterfield, Mo. He was 65 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Correction
description: The directory of music festivals abroad, which appeared on May 4, gave an incorrect date for the Reggae Sunsplash in Montego Bay, Jamaica. It will be held from Aug. 27 to 30.

title: A PARIS HOUSE OF RODIN AND ROYALTY
description: Few of Paris's many small museums are more popular than the Musee Rodin, on the Rue de Varenne one block from Les Invalides. This two-story mansion has 20 rooms, not counting the cellar and attic, and all but a few are filled with sculptures, plaster casts -even occasional drawings and paintings -that reveal the sweep of Rodin's artistic vision and growth. In the extensive formal gardens stand more than a dozen of Rodin's large bronze and marble works, including castings of ''The Thinker,'' ''Balzac,'' ''The Burghers of Calais'' and ''The Gates of Hell.''

title: INNOVATION BLOSSOMS ON THE FRINGES OF PARIS
description: Just as Off Broadway is the locus of experimental theater in New York, so too in France one must generally venture out of Paris to view innovative stagings or discover new plays. It is outside the city limits that one finds the artistically venturesome ''theatres peripheriques,'' the suburban theaters strategically located in the working-class districts that encircle the city: Bobigny, St. Denis, Nanterre, Aubervilliers.

title: SUMMERFARE '86; A TIME FOR APPRAISAL
description: EVEN with appearances by internationally acclaimed acting companies, there may be almost as much drama behind the scenes as on the stage this year when Pepsico's Summerfare opens its seventh season July 11 at the State University of New York at Purchase. While audiences assess the theatrical, musical and dance performances, those responsible for the performing arts festival will assess the audiences to determine Summerfare's future course.

title: YES, THE U.S. CAN AFFORD TO HELP MANILA
description: The honeymoon is over between the United States and the fledgling Filipino Government of Corazon C. Aquino -a fact for which both countries should be grateful. The first sharp words on both sides concerned American aid. Although we should be encouraged by the financial assistance already provided by the Reagan Administration and Congress on an emergency basis, there is much more to be done. Additional support is needed, though not necessarily big infusions of Government funding.

title: More and More Children Need Foster Homes
description: To the Editor:

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: WHY IT'S HARD TO MOVE MOSCOW ON HUMAN RIGHTS
description: THERE are few obstacles to decent Soviet-American relations as fundamental as the Soviet Union's denial of individual liberties to its citizens. No matter how vital the process of arms control, how seductive the prospect of trade or how sharp the competition for global influence, the foundation of American suspicion and contempt toward the Soviet leadership remains firmly rooted in its violations of human rights. That is where the Soviet system gives strongest offense to American values.

title: I.R.S. EMPLOYEES ON L.I. PERUSE 8.7 MILLION FORMS
description: In rooms the size of football fields, more than 4,000 Federal employees are at work here trying to make sure that taxes are as certain as death.

title: UNION'S CASH GIFTS SPUR INQUIRIES IN PHILADELPHIA
description: A former Municipal Court officer walked into Judge Thomas A. White's chambers without notice last December, wished him a merry Christmas and left a plain white envelope on his desk.

title: CRIME
description: Certain strengths and certain flaws mark NO ONE RIDES FOR FREE (Morrow, $16.95), an arresting first novel by Larry Beinhart. The strengths are in a kind of passion in the writing. The weaknesses are, paradoxically, in some pretentious and self-indulgent overwriting. When and if Mr. Beinhart puts it all together, he could develop into one of the better exponents of the tough-guy private-eye school.

title: HOW TO FOLLOW THE FLEET
description: Forget Helen of Troy. The face that launches a thousand ships this July Fourth weekend will be that of the Statue of Liberty. What is being called the largest flotilla of sailing ships to assemble in modern history is gathering from all over the world to salute her centennial year. Some 350,000 people are expected to be afloat in the harbor on the great day, while millions more will be watching from the shore.

title: Nancy Drexler to Wed Steven Robert Mendell
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Drexler of Melville, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Gail Drexler, to Steven Robert Mendell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Oliver Mendell of New York and Pound Ridge, N.Y. A June 15 wedding is planned.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: WHY HAS this year been different from other years for Meir M. Berger? One reason is that it is the first time in five years that Cantor Berger did not spend Passover at an Atlantic City hotel-casino.

title: MISLAID ROMANOVS
description: ELIZABETH AND ALEXANDRA By Antony Lambton. 415 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $18.95. THE Grand Duchess

title: Social Events; Temptations of the Evening
description: Cabaret May 19 - Harry Belafonte will be among the performers at Cabaret '86, the fourth annual benefit for the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. The black-tie dinner-dance will begin at 7 P.M. in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Tickets $500, $1,000 and $1,500, from 212-874-4098. On Many Fronts May 19 - The Nieuw Amsterdam ballroom of the Vista International Hotel at the World Trade Center will be converted into a 1920's-style cabaret for a benefit that begins at 7 P.M. for the International Anti-Drug Abuse Foundation, which is based in Tel Aviv. The organization, composed of individuals from Great Britain, Canada, Belgium, France, Switzerland, Italy, Sweden, Israel, Japan, Hong Kong and the United States, has established a dozen walk-in clinics in Israel and is preparing a school program on drug-abuse for Israel. Richard Harris, the actor, will be the master of ceremonies and Sammy Davis Jr. will perform. Tickets $175 for juniors, and $350, from 212-938-9100, ext. 7222. Child's Play May 19 - A buffet benefit for TADA!, a theater and dance ensemble of children performing for children, will begin at 7:30 P.M. at the Theater of the Open Eye at 270 West 89th Street. The organization also conducts workshops at schools and commissions new works for children's theater companies. Tickets $15 for children and $35 and $50, from 212-627-1732. A Dash of Brahms May 19 - Concerts Plus, the sponsor of concerts at Merkin Hall at 129 West 67th Street for the past four seasons, will hold an 11-course banquet at 7:30 P.M. with musical ''surprises,'' at the recently refurbished Shun Lee West restaurant at 43 West 65th Street.

title: 'THE FIRST SPECIMEN YANKEE'
description: FRANKLIN OF PHILADELPHIA By Esmond Wright. Illustrated. 404 pp. Cambridge: The Belknap Press/ Harvard University Press. $25.

title: THE RIDDLES OF EMILY DICKINSON
description: EMILY DICKINSON has received considerable attention during the 100 years since her death on May 15, 1886, and yet she remains almost as mysterious as Shakespeare. Some of her lines are so familiar that we quote them without knowing we are doing so: ''The Soul selects her own Society''; ''I'm Nobody! Who are you? / Are you - Nobody - Too?''; ''Success is counted sweetest / By those who ne'er succeed''; ''Parting is all we know of heaven, / And all we need of hell.'' They have entered our language with some of the anonymous authority of proverbs.

title: ON TRAFFIC CONDITIONS AT LICENSE BUREAU
description: Having just read the three columns of Barbara Harvey's opinion on driver-license renewal [ ''Life, Death on a Renewal Line,'' Opinion Page, April 27 ] , one approaching this ''ordeal'' would tremble with trepidation.

title: LETTING COMPUTERS TRACK AESTHETICS
description: UNTIL two years ago, Lawrence Levine, the administrator of Chemical Bank's 1,600-piece art collection, tried to keep track of the inventory on hundreds of handwritten, and often illegible, lists. Now the location of any piece of art, and its value, purchase date, media, artist, dealer, framer and dimensions, are available at the touch of a button. ''The computer will give me all the art in the London office - or all the art on the seventh floor of the Lexington Avenue office,'' he marvels.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: MAY 18, 1986
description: Fiction

title: LOAN APPROVED FOR HARLEM THEATHER
description: The National Black Theater received final approval last week of a $2 million state loan to renovate its building on 125th Street.

title: SOUTH AFRICA'S PROMISES COME WITH FINE PRINT
description: Two and a half years after it was launched, South Africa's program of limited and cautious racial change seems to be foundering, sending conflicting signals to outsiders and offering the country's 31 million people no clear vision. White rulers are balking at drastic measures to ease the violence in the face of black radicalism that demands their surrender and right-wing white radicalism insistent on a return to the apparent security of what was known as Grand Apartheid.

title: CLARA SCHUMANN AND HER HUSBAND
description: We women composers greatly appreciated the article on April 27 (''Five Female Composers Breaking Barriers'').

title: 'Disorderly' Collection
description: To the Editor:

title: Facade Unites the Old and New
description: Two buildings dating back to at least 1833 and two much newer structures are being brought together with a facade renovation on Post Road West in Westport, Conn.

title: AFRICAN CHOIR: LADYSMITH
description: LADYSMITH BLACK MAMBAZO, a 10-man choir from South Africa, came to Sounds of Brazil Thursday with extraordinary a cappella singing. Bare-chested and wearing crownlike headdresses, fur aprons over loincloths and straw ornaments on their arms and legs, the group harmonized with utter precision.

title: THE 'OUT-OF-CONTROL' SYNDROME
description: MEDICAL research during World War II turned up a surprising phenomenon. Stress-related illnesses such as ulcers, cardiovascular problems and hypertension were much more pronounced in the co-pilots of the bombers than they were in the pilots. Peacetime studies of commercial airline pilots revealed the same results. Co-pilots demonstrated greater levels of anxiety and physical wear and tear. Why had this happened? The researchers found that the co-pilots felt helpless and out of control.

title: WHEN THE DAY IS HAPPIEST
description: IS there anything as tender as an early summer's morning? Though technically not summer, most of the mornings of May and June are a delight.

title: DANCE: JUDITH FUGATE IN DARVASH'S 'GISELLE'
description: THE Martin Luther King High School Auditorium isn't Lincoln Center, although it's just a block west. But ballet-lovers could do a great deal worse than pay a visit to that school theater, where Gabriela Darvash is presenting ''Giselle'' this afternoon. Performed by advanced and professional students of the Darvash Studio, a New York-based ballet school, this version of ''Giselle'' is based on the noted Bolshoi production by Leonid Lavrovsky. It is a simply staged and designed ''Giselle,'' with very good lighting by Greg Bain. But the production vibrates with life -with small, inventive dramatic touches and committed and beautifully schooled classical dancing that would do a professional company proud.

title: William R. Reid, A Financier, Wed To Amy E. Weber
description: The Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Amy Elizabeth Weber to William Rogers Reid. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Ambrose Eckinger assisted by the Rev. Joseph Bishop.

title: CONTROLLING GOVERNMENT INSIDERS ONCE THEY MOVE OUTSIDE
description: ''I HAVE always believed it was improper for people to hold high positions in the government, and then turn around and use that position for profit,'' Senator Strom Thurmond, Republican of South Carolina and chairman of the Judiciary Committee, said recently.

title: Headliners; Gotti's Next Move
description: Today could be John Gotti's last full day of freedom for a while, at least until the conclusion of the racketeering trial now scheduled to resume Aug. 18. Federal Judge Eugene H. Nickerson last week revoked his bail as of noon tomorrow, saying there was ''substantial evidence'' that the reputed head of the Gambino crime family ''would improperly influence or intimidate witnesses'' -as well as continue to participate in Gambino family operations - if he remained at large.

title: 'ON WINGS OF EAGLES' PLODS TO SUPERFICIAL HEIGHTS
description: The timing, it seems, couldn't be better. The five-hour production of ''On Wings of Eagles'' is just the sort of ''we're not going to be pushed around anymore'' adventure story that, in light of the enthusiastic polls following the recent raid on Libya, many Americans should relish. Beginning tonight at 8 on NBC and continuing tomorrow evening at 9, the two-part mini-series recounts the true story of how H. Ross Perot, the Texas industrialist, went about rescuing two of his top executives from imprisonment in Iran in 1979. Bucking the newly victorious Ayatollah Khomeini and assorted namby-pamby officials in the Carter Administration, Mr. Perot simply recruited a tough former Army colonel who, with a special team of Perot employees, led a secret mission to get the job done quickly and efficiently. The result is a kind of Rambo in a three-piece business suit.

title: 2 More Rentals At Rector Place
description: To the Editor:

title: Carita D. Corse, a Psychologist, Wed To Edward Joseph Kelly 3d in Atlanta
description: Carita Doggett Corse, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Doggett Corse of Atlanta, was married yesterday to Edward Joseph Kelly 3d, a son of Mrs. Clifton N. Jacobs Jr., of Norristown, Pa., and Mr. Kelly Jr., of Philadelphia and Jacksonville, Fla. The Rev. Harold H. Pritchett and Judge Clement Ferman Haynesworth Jr., senior circuit judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit in Richmond, performed the ceremony at the All Saints Episcopal Church in Atlanta.

title: TALK WITH STALIN'S DAUGHTER: WHY SHE LEFT SOVIET AGAIN
description: On April 16 Stalin's daughter, Svetlana Alliluyeva, returned to the United States after a year and a half back in her Soviet homeland, from which she defected in 1967. Her American-born daughter, Olga Peters, also left the Soviet Union, to return to a private school in Britain.

title: Capt. J. A. Scott Wed To Manrica Farronato
description: Manrica Farronato, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Adone Farronato of Bassano del Grappa, Italy, was married yesterday to Capt. Jeffrey Arnold Scott, U.S.A., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Scott of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., and Duxbury, Mass. The ceremony was performed by Mayor Antonio Basso at the Bassano del Grappa City Hall.

title: DOCUMENTARIES AND BALANCE
description: John Corry's comments on the brouhaha over ''Flashpoint'' are really beside the point [ ''Balanced Journalism Needn't Preclude a Point of View,'' April 20 ] . Television never has had the right idea about documentaries, and Mr. Corry's insistence upon ''balance'' within a journalistic framework makes that clear.

title: Physician Is Wed To Dr. McGrath
description: Dr. Sarah M. McGrath and Dr. William Tobin McGee, who both received medical degrees from New York Medical College and are completing residencies in internal medicine at the Baystate Medical Center in Springfield, Mass., were married yesterday. The Rev. Charles M. Kavanagh performed the ceremony at St. John and St. Mary Roman Catholic Church in Chappaqua, N.Y.

title: The Senate and The Drug Makers
description: American drug manufacturers have long complained about the fiscal headaches caused by Federal rules that keep them from exporting drugs not yet approved for sale in this country; last week, the Senate voted 91 to 7 to give the industry a little legislative relief.

title:
GARDENING;
WORK WITH NATURE, NOT AGAINST IT
description: A DOCTOR once said that the most important thing he had learned in years of practice was that he should not work against nature's own healing processes. Much the same holds true for the gardener and his plants. Working with nature will yield healthier plants than working against it.

title: Paying the Bill For Shoreham
description: The question was not whether electricity rates would go up on Long Island if the Shoreham nuclear power plant went into full operation, but by how much. The answer came last week from the State Public Service Commission: 5 percent a year for 15 years.

title: COMEDY BY DURANG AT BOSTON POST RD.
description: IF last weekend's sold-out performances of ''Beyond Therapy'' at the Boston Post Road Stage Company are a barometer of audience appeal, Christopher Durang's wicked and wacky comedy is Fairfield County's deserved new hit - and a discovery at that.

title: SOME EXOTICS MAKE ANNUAL APPEARANCE
description: EXCEPT when I'm entertaining friends, most of the meals I cook are for two.

title: Cable TV
description: Catch ''The Mission,'' a perfect example of the rewarding ''sleeper'' - Tuesday at 11 P.M. and 4 A.M. on Bravo. This modest 1984 film is a trim, pointed melodrama made by Iranians, with an Iranian cast in Manhattan, which it mirrors nicely with no tourist-guide lapses.

title: Tilson Thomas Cancels
description: A pinched nerve will keep the conductor and pianist Michael Tilson Thomas from appearing with the American Symphony Orchestra today at 3 P.M. in Carnegie Hall. Gerhardt Zimmerman, music director of the Canton, Ohio, Symphony, will conduct; the pianist will be Jeffrey

title: Dance
description: Ralph Lemon is one of the most successful of those younger modern dance choreographers who have chosen to deal with extra-dance material as well as movement. Dance, music and such things as folktales co-exist with a magical vitality and richness of spirit in his dances. An alumnus of the Merdith Monk, Blondell Cummings and Dana Reitz companies, Mr. Lemon is also a gifted performer. On Thursday he opens an ambitious two-week season at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater.

title: THINK 'MUMS FOR FALL
description: It's not easy to think about autumn when spring is so much with us.

title: MIDLIFE CAREER CHANGES ON THE RISE
description: THE catalyst can be anything from a corporate takeover to a company cutback or simply a desire for a different career, but increasing numbers of men and women in their 40's and 50's, such as William E. Dyer, Todd Kolb and Peter D. Cokin, are making midlife career changes.

title: New Yank Pitching Coach
description: George Steinbrenner's revolving door of pitching coaches took still another turn late Friday night when the Yankee owner dismissed Sammy Ellis and replaced him with Mark Connor, whose hiring came without the blessing or knowledge of Manager Lou Piniella.

title: Sunday Observer; High-Tech Insolence
description: I SUSPECT MY NEW talking car is a psychopathic killer. At first I thought it was merely having a nervous breakdown. That was when it first started saying, ''Thank you. Thank you'' every morning as soon as I opened the door to get behind the wheel.

title: Classical Music
description: After a year's hiatus, the New York Philharmonic's summer festival of new music is back. Horizons '86, which begins Wednesday night at 8 with a program of works by the Hungarian composer Gyorgy Ligeti, is devoted to a two-week examination of music as theater.

title: Recent Sales
description: Manville $97,000 303 West Frech Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old Cape Cod; *2*central air-conditioning, aluminum siding, corner lot; taxes $1,696. Millburn $95,000 406 Millburn Avenue *2*4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; *2*pull-down attic stairs, enclosed porch; taxes $1,378. Pattenburg $114,500 628 Main Street *2*3-bedroom, 1-bath, older colonial; new plumbing and wiring, *2*unheated family room, barn; taxes $1,080. Scotch Plains $213,000 1281 Raritan Road *2*3-bedroom, 2-bath, 34-year-old ranch; *2*skylight in foyer, fireplace, pool; taxes $4,025. South Orange $250,000 162 Irving Avenue *2*7-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 60-year-old Tudor; *2*stained glass, french doors, flagstone patio; taxes $5,644. Springfield $280,000 21 Highlands Avenue *2*4-bedroom, 2-bath, 20-year-old contemporary; *2*marble fireplace, cathedral ceiling, skylights; taxes $3,273. OTHER AREAS Chappaqua, N.Y. $138,000 29 Mill River Road *2*3-bedroom, 1-bath, 86-year-old colonial; walk to train, .08 acre; taxes $2,339. Darien, Conn. $475,000 190 Long Neck Point Road *2*2-bedroom, 3-bath, 16-year-old colonial; *2*wide floor boards, waterfront views, 1 acre; taxes $3,262. Syosset, L.I. $310,000 75 Northgate Road *2*4-bedroom, 2-bath, 20-year-old ranch; *2*den with fireplace, basement, pool, 1 acre; taxes $6,200.

title: ZAIRE TRIES TO BE TRUE TO ITS TRADITIONS
description: Fifteen years ago, President Mobutu Sese Seko decided to catapult Zaire into a distinctively African future, sharply breaking with the colonial past. He attempted to impose a way of thinking - a way of life, really -called ''authenticite'' by the French-speaking elite, through which he hoped to develop the country by relying heavily on indigenous culture.

title: Pro Football; U.S.F.L. LAWYER USES PERSISTENT TACTICS IN TRIAL
description: When he introduced himself to the jury before his opening statement in Federal District Court last week, Harvey Myerson described himself as a ''street guy.'' After the way he questioned Pete Rozelle on the witness stand for two days, it's not hard to see why.

title: MANHATTANVILLE COLLEGE: O'ROURKE ENCOURAGES COMMUNITY ACTIVISM
description: Westchester County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke today urged Manhattanville College graduates to solve problems in their communities ''no matter how tiny a section of the world that might be.''

title: Of Wine and Taxes and Thomas Jefferson
description: To the Editor:

title: A GUIDE TO THE TALL SHIPS
description: At about 11 A.M. on July 4, the Coast Guard bark Eagle will lead a stately procession of Tall Ships past the Statue of Liberty and up the Hudson to the George Washington Bridge. Most are training ships manned by cadets, some female, some as young as 16. In these thumbnail sketches of selected ships, an asterisk indicates a vessel that participated in OpSail '76; mast height is the height of the tallest mast above water level, and length includes bowsprit. 1. GAZELA OF PHILADELPHIA* (United States). Only 20 years ago, this three-masted barkentine was fishing on the Grand Banks under the Portuguese flag as the last commercial square-rigger operating out of Europe. Built in 1883, she is the oldest and largest wooden sailing ship still putting out to sea. Nearly every plank is original. In 1971 she was acquired by the Philadelphia Maritime Museum. Crew, 59; length, 175 feet; mast height, 188 feet. 2. SIMON BOLIVAR (Venezuela). This modern three-masted bark, built in Spain in 1980, can be easily recognized by the gunports painted onto her black-and-white hull and the single-story chart house behind her mizzenmast. Crew, 110; length, 270 feet; mast height, 140 feet. 3. DEWA RUTJI (Indonesia). This three-decked steel barkentine from Jakarta, built in Germany in 1953, has the carved wooden image of an Indonesian god as her figurehead. She is air-conditioned for the tropics, but her cadets sleep in sling hammocks. She will be at sea for 70 days in order to participate in the centennial ceremonies.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: The Homeless Have Another Day in Court
description: Six homeless men sued New York City in 1979 and obtained a consent decree that required the city to provide safe, clean shelter to every homeless man who asked for it. Subsequent litigation extended the right to homeless women.

title: Comings and Goings
description: E. J. (Doc) Kreis, the former Vanderbilt strength coach who pleaded guilty to distributing steroids without a prescription last year, said he had accepted an invitation to accompany a delegation of American strength coaches, athletes and conditioning experts who will go to the Soviet Union next month to conduct a series of demonstrations and lectures. . . . Billie Jean King, whose 20 Wimbledon titles secured her a place in the Guinness Book of World Records, won't have to worry about losing her listing. She was inducted into the reference book's Hall of Fame, making her the first athlete so honored.

title: INSURANCE PLAN FOR TOWNS
description: BY July 1, when most towns in the state are to renew their liability insurance policies, a new insurance company, formed by an association of towns, should be in operation, its organizers say.

title: Sacrilege Seen In Delaware
description: TO scholars as well as the thousands of schoolchildren who visit each year, the Island Field Archeological Museum at South Bowers Beach in Delaware provides a rare glimpse of an American Indian settlement more than 1,000 years old.

title: SPRAY LUBRICANTS CAN HELP IN MANY JOBS AROUND THE HOUSE
description: ALTHOUGH they have been on the market for quite a few years, and although almost every repair technician and mechanic carries one in his toolbox, a surprisingly large number of homeowners and do-it-yourselfers do not realize how useful a spray can of moisture-displacing penetrating lubricant can be.

title: W. H. Dobbs 2d Weds Miss Boisi
description: Eileen A. Boisi, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James O. Boisi of Old Brookville, L.I., and William H. Dobbs 2d, a son of William D. Dobbs of Darien, Conn., and the late Marie Shea Dobbs, were married yesterday at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Roslyn, L.I., by the Rev. William Wood.

title: Mlle. Liberte
description: The special bond between France and America goes back at least to our Revolution and Benjamin Franklin's diplomatic mission to Paris.

title: S. P. Harder Wed To York Chi Lau
description: York Chi Lau, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bill K. Lau of Lynbrook, L.I., was married yesterday to Stephen Piper Harder, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John G. Harder of Warren, Me. The Rev. Russell Davis, a Baptist minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Riverside Church.

title: COLLEGES WORRY ABOUT HOW BLACKS VIEW THEM
description: As the Ivy League schools and other highly selective colleges around the nation continue to compete with one another for qualified black applicants, some are worrying about how those prospective students view them.

title: CELTICS GET 3-0 LEAD ON BUCKS
description: After their outside shooting had failed them, the Boston Celtics unleashed their big, talented front line in the final quarter today, and it was too much for the Milwaukee Bucks.

title: LIMITS OF STRENGTH
description: PSYCHOLOGY AND DETERRENCE By Robert Jervis, Richard Ned Lebow and Janice Gross Stein with Patrick M. Morgan and Jack L. Snyder. 270 pp. Baltimore: The Johns Hopkins University Press. $27.50.

title: Boasts and Insults; Whale Mysteries
description: For 14 months, a young female beluga whale disported herself along the coast of Connecticut, making friends with fascinated humans. ''It would follow boats, it would swim with swimmers, it would allow itself to be patted by people from boats,'' recalled Laura Kezer of the Mystic Marinelife Aquarium.

title: GLASS: GALLERIES SHOW ITS MANY GLORIES
description: THE qualities of glass, as they are being investigated by contemporary artists, seem limitless. Artworks in glass can be translucent or opaque, jagged or smoothly finished, brilliantly colored or murky and blown, cast or shaped as commercial plate glass.

title: SANDS POINT
description: A STIFF, salty breeze blows off Long Island Sound, deep blue and glittering on a Sunday afternoon, forcing the waves against the Sands Point shore. From Middleneck Road, a parade of white sails can be seen marching off to the northeast.

title: RIDING BEHIND STEAM ON OLD NO. 47
description: A train departing from a station is a ritual, a quite formal one. The men presiding this day at North Conway, N.H., were Edward Sauer, resplendent in a dark blue conductor's uniform; Courtney H.
