Gregg, the 34-year-old locomotive engineer, and Jonathan Howard, a college student who would shovel three quarters of a ton of soft coal into the firebox of locomotive No. 47 on the 11-mile round trip over the Conway Scenic Railroad.

title: Dr. Wendy E. Mahler Weds Douglas Linker
description: Dr. Wendy Ellen Mahler and Douglas Richard Linker were married yesterday at the Edgewood Country Club in Rivervale, N.J., by Rabbi Herbert Weiner.

title: EQUALIZERS END PASSIVE LISTENING
description: Active intervention of almost any sort - and whatever the outcome - often seems very satisfying. At least we are doing something. This may account for, among other things, the rising popularity of equalizers among audio fans.

title: GENERATIONS MEET TO BRIDGE THE GAP
description: WHEN 77-year-old Jacqueline Rogers leaves her home for the Princeton Senior Citizen Resource Center these days, she is probably going to an intergenerational meeting.

title: PHILHARMONIC: ORFF AND COPLAND
description: SYMPHONY orchestra seasons don't really end any more, but this week marks at least the close of the New York Philharmonic's subscription year. There will be little rest for the players. The Horizons '86 contemporary music series begins on Wednesday and runs into June.

title: COUNSEL UPHOLDS LEASE IN DISPUTE ON EAST SIDE
description: The leasing of a landmark building at Bellevue Hospital to a biotechnology company in which a city official held stock was upheld last week by the City Corporation Counsel. The ruling came despite renewed opposition by community groups and the City Comptroller's office.

title: Cindy Joy Weston Becomes the Bride Of Jacob J. Winebaum, an Executive
description: The wedding of Cindy Joy Weston, the daughter of Stanley Weston of New York and Mrs. Sol Liebster of Great Neck, L.I., to Jacob J. Winebaum, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sumner Winebaum of Exeter, N.H., took place yesterday at the Pierre. Rabbi Chaim Etrog officiated.

title: Change of Venue For Bhopal Cases
description: It would be legally inconvenient and arrogant to adjudge the more than 487,000 claims by victims and their families arising from the December 1984 gas leak at Bhopal, India, in the United States, a Federal judge ruled last week.

title: Manila Palace Closed After Burglars Break In
description: Officials closed the presidential palace to the public today because of a break-in by burglars who apparently searched the rooms of former President Ferdinand E. Marcos and his wife, Imelda.

title: Robb R. Allen Is Married To Wendy Dorthea Hylfelt
description: Wendy Dorthea Hylfelt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kai W. Hylfelt of Bardonia, N.Y., was married yesterday to Robb Richard Allen, a son of Lieut. Col. James J. Allen, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Allen of Knoxville, Tenn. The Rev. Charles S. Temple performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration in New York.

title: AGENCIES CLASH ON MIGRANT WORKERS
description: THE state's Public Advocate, Alfred P. Slocum, and the Secretary of Agriculture, Arthur R. Brown Jr., appear to be headed for a confrontation over the role of the Department of the Public Advocate in representing a migrant labor union in court against farmers who refuse to accept union certifications.

title: THE DE MENIL FAMILY: THE MEDICI OF MODERN ART
description: GROWING UP IN HOUSTON, ADELAIDE DE MENIL was embarrassed to bring her friends to the art-filled home of her parents, Dominique and John de Menil. Adelaide wished that the starkly modern house, designed by the then-Mies-disciple Philip Johnson, could be like everyone else's. ''But there were all these weird paintings hanging on the walls,'' she says. ''For instance, there was a big purple and yellow canvas by Leger, and I hated to take my friends through the hall where they could see it. And I loathed the black-tiled floor. I wanted a wooden one.''

title: CHERNOBYL: LESSONS FOR EMERGENCY PLAN
description: WHAT relevance does the Soviet nuclear reactor accident have for Long Island's $4.5 billion Shoreham Nuclear Power Station?

title: THE AVERAGE DOESN'T ADD UP
description: A chart accompanying Robert Hunter's April 13 Forum article (''Taming the Latest Insurance Crisis'') elicited an unusually large number of responses. Following is one of those letters - and a reply from Mr. Hunter:

title: Photo of Mr. Hitchcock with one of his sculptures (NYT/Steve Miller) AT UCONN FOUNDRY, THE ART OF BRONZING
description: DRESSED in silvery protective gear, their hands sheathed in thick mittens, Peter Haas and Anders Bachmann used a large set of tongs to maneuver a heavy vat. Poising it above a container set in a pail of sand, they tipped it gently, pouring a Day-Glo orange liquid into a mold with an oddly familiar shape.

title: Alain de Serigny Dies; Was Algeria Publisher
description: Alain de Serigny, a publisher who was one of the most influential supporters of French rule in Algeria during the turbulent years leading to independence in 1962, died Friday. He was 74 years old.

title: PRO'S HOLIDAY TURNS OUT TO BE A NET GAIN
description: BOB TANIS had his April vacation all figured out: He would drop off his black Labrador retriever, Vollie, with a friend in Wayne; leave his 6-month-old daughter, Rebecca, with his in-laws in Oceanside, L.I., and then fly with his wife, Gail, to Tucson, Ariz.

title: LIBERTY CELEBRATION: SCALED-BACK PLANS
description: IT looked like 11th-hour action by the legislature was needed to rescue the state commission honoring the 100th anniversaries of the Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island, and that is just what the commission got.

title: More on 401(k)'s
description: To the Editor:

title: O'NEILL AND MOFFETT FACE TEST IN VOTE ON TUESDAY
description: THE fight between Governor O'Neill and former United States Representative Toby Moffett for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination will reach a pivotal point Tuesday, with local primary elections in 26 cities and towns.

title: TEAMSTERS' LEADER IS FREED AFTER FACING CHARGES
description: Jackie Presser, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, surrendered to Federal officials today on charges of embezzlement and racketeering involving the local that has been his power base for 19 years.

title: Stefanie Schneider Weds
description: Stefanie Ann Schneider, a marketing manager for the American Express Company in New York, and Douglas James Kahn, a vice president of Donaldson, Lufkin and Jenrette, were married last night in Temple Sinai in Pittsburgh by Rabbi Edward Cohn. Mrs. Kahn, a graduate of Washington University and Columbia University, where she received an M.B.A. degree, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Schneider of Pittsburgh. Mr. Kahn, a graduate of Cornell University and the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania, where he received a master's degree, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mike Kahn of New York and East Hampton, L.I.

title: 35-YEAR 'MISSION' IS COMPLETE
description: In the church his parents brought him to as a child, Dr. Ronald E. McNair was eulogized today as an example to children. And afterward, in a newly cleared plot surrounded by the fields where he picked cotton as a boy, the remains of the Challenger astronaut were finally laid to rest.

title: TRENTON STUDYING ALCOHOL LIABILITY
description: IN AN effort to reduce soaring liability insurance rates for bars and restaurants, some state lawmakers want to make it harder for victims of drunken driving to sue businesses that serve alcohol.

title: Elizabeth G. Griffin Is Wed To Kristoph Rollenhagen
description: Elizabeth Graham Griffin and Kristoph Justus Rollenhagen were married yesterday at St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church in Short Hills, N.J. The Rev. Robert Gibney performed the ceremony.

title: ACCORD SET IN LAWSUIT OVER MISSOURI'S DEATH ROW
description: ''Dungeon-like'' conditions on Missouri's death row, where 42 men await the gas chamber, would be alleviated under a proposed settlement to be filed Monday in Federal District Court here.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: HALLEY FAREWELL If you've got to have a theme around which to build a concert -and it doesn't hurt - ''Farewell to Halley's Comet'' sounds promising enough. After all, the phenomenon is on its way out (catch the final sighting session at Jones Beach State Park West End Field No. 2 on Saturday at 8:30 P.M.), and music is supposed to be ethereal. So taking such works as ''The Heavens Are Telling'' from Hadyn's ''Creation,'' Joseph Gianono's ''Spacial Quantum'' and Randall Thompson's ''Oh Star,'' based on a poem by Robert Frost, the Long Island Choral Society dedicates its spring concert to the fading comet today at 4 P.M. at Cathedral House, 50 Cathedral Avenue in Garden City. A tribute to Irving Berlin is also on the program, and performing will be winners of the 1986 Young Artist Competition. Tickets are $5.SINGING FOR PEACE

title: OPIUM DENS FOR THE CRACK ERA
description: People climbed down stairs into a blackened basement, sloshed through stagnant puddles and knocked on a steel door. If they said the right words, they were in.

title: AN ABSTRACT SCULPTOR RETURNS TO THE FIGURE
description: Who would have expected an exhibition of new sculpture by Anthony Caro modeled from the human figure? When Caro began making abstract, welded steel sculpture in 1960, it seemed that he had discarded forever traditional ways of thinking about sculpture. His abstract works, originally inspired by David Smith and his friendships with the art critic Clement Greenberg and the painter Kenneth Noland, are among the landmarks of 1960's art and Formalist esthetics.

title: The New Security: Fences to Flowerpots
description: A week ago, the shopping concourse inside the Pentagon became officially off-limits to the public.

title: No Headline
description: Selling Out Edwin Wilson did what the Central Intelligence Agency trained him to do - deceive. Can we expect loyalty from those who have accepted deceit as a way of life? JOHN J. CANNON Mumford, N.Y.

title: Georgina Welford Marries Martin Beirne, Executive
description: St. Catherine's Roman Catholic Church in Spring Lake, N.J., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Georgina Welford and Martin Beirne.

title: THE DANCE: SCHOOL OF AMERICAN BALLET WORKSHOP
description: AMONG the dance world's pleasant rites of spring are the annual School of American Ballet workshops. Designed as showcases for advanced students, these presentations feature ballets both from the international repertory and from that of the New York City Ballet, the school's parent company. In addition, choreographers are often invited to create new works.

title: Spotting Talent Early
description: To Larry Embley, the only problem with his new National Collegiate Scouting Bureau is that nobody thought of it earlier - before he'd spent countless hours scouring the country last year, trying to find a college that would give an athletic scholarship to his son. Larry Jr. was an all-state high school second baseman in Gladstone, N.J., but he lacked the kind of can't-miss talent that is sure to attract nationwide recruiting interest.

title: FEELIN' NOT SO GROOVY
description: GROOVY has been called a speedball, and he is, though a quirky speedball. In his last two races, the Kentucky Derby two weeks ago and the Preakness Saturday, the 3-year-old chestnut colt has proved that he can not only run swiftly forward, but can go backward at an equally alarming rate.

title: THEATER: 'CUBA AND HIS TEDDY BEAR'
description: BEARDED, swathed in a beach towel, Robert De Niro is Joseph Cuba, drug dealer and indulgent father. His son, Teddy (Ralph Macchio), is, at 16, a would-be poet of the streets. Together they are ''Cuba and His Teddy Bear,'' the central characters in Reinaldo Povod's play, which opened last night at the Public Theater.

title: U.S. HELPS TOWN COPE WITH GROWTH OF NAVY BASE
description: Through most of the 1970's, the only new business that came to Camden County was the traffic off Interstate 95. There was shrimping and a paper mill, but like the local school enrollment, the economy was mostly on the decline.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Home Section on Thursday about working at home misidentified Marion Behr. She is president of Women Working Home Inc., publisher of ''Women Working Home - The Homebased Business Guide and Directory,'' and was the founding president of the National Alliance of Homebased Businesswomen. The current president of the alliance is Louise Seeger.

title: Accounts
description: * Multigroup Health Plan, Wellesley, Mass., to Mintz & Hoke Inc., Avon, Conn.

title: Regular Financings Are Scheduled
description: Treasury financing this week consists of the regular auction of new three-month and six-month Treasury bills today, followed on Wednesday by the regular monthly sale of two-year notes.

title: New Start By Chicago Air's Chief
description: Neal F. Meehan, one of the entrepreneurial executives who has headed competitive new airlines spawned by the industry's deregulation, is about to try his luck with a regional carrier. ''In looking for a segment of the industry that really could use some change and a little bit of the spirit of deregulation,'' he said, ''we thought that the regional segment was ready.''

title: A STORYTELLING RENAISSANCE
description: While pillaging the countryside, a gang of hungry bandits banged on a farmhouse door and ordered an old woman inside to fix breakfast. ''Never,'' she scoffed, ''would I cook for the likes of you.''

title: ROCKETS OVERPOWER LAKERS FOR 3-1 LEAD
description: What has been a reign of dominance in the Western Conference in this decade is suddenly and surprisingly in danger of coming to an end.

title: The Resistant Shcharansky
description: Anatoly Shcharansky left his mark on Washington journalism last week in ways more related to his personality than his message. When he spoke at a National Press Club luncheon, the audience was conventionally dressed, but the officers and other news celebrities on the rostrum removed their jackets and neckties in deference to their guest's familiar open-collared sport shirt.

title: Bridge: Kantar's New Book Offers Problems in Matched Pairs
description: Many bridge deals present problems for both the declarer and the defenders. These can be offered to the enthusiast in matched pairs, and have been in a new book: ''A New Approach to Play and Defense'' by Edwin Kantar. It is available for $9.95 from the author, P.O. Box 427, Venice, Calif. 90291-0427.

title: REPORT PREDICTS SMOOTH TRANSIT IN CITY BY 2000
description: By JOSH BARBANEL

title: Soprano-Harpsichord Duo
description: The soprano Francesca Pannell, accompanied by the harpsichordist Elaine Comparone, will offer a recital of classical and contemporary songs tonight at 8 at St. Michael's Church, 225 West 99th Street.

title: BOSTON UNIVERSITY: DARE TO BE HEROIC, SCHOOL'S PRESIDENT URGES
description: John R. Silber, president of Boston University, told the audience at the university's 113th commencement yesterday that he saw a paradox in how ''democracy places the highest value upon the development of the individual, yet is frequently indifferent to heroes and hostile to greatness.''

title: KIROV DANCERS TO PERFORM IN TRENTON
description: Dancers of the Kirov Ballet will appear in Trenton at the War Memorial Theater on June 1 in a special matinee performance that has been added to the Soviet company's current North American tour.

title: Ally & Gargano Gains
description: Ally & Gargano, the newest of the publicly held ad agencies, last week released the financial statement for its fiscal third quarter, ended March 31. Revenues were down slightly to $43.1 million, from $43.4 million a year earlier, but net income rose to $655,000, or 30 cents a share, from $400,000, or 18 cents a share.

title: HOPE OF RESEARCH, REALITY OF DEATH
description: It is a grim but necessary business.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Florida State vs. Louisiana State, at Tallahassee, Fla. On a day when the Mets and Yankees are both idle, the top two college teams in the country are playing on national television.

title: DOMINICAN, TRAILING IN VOTE, ASSERTS VICTORY
description: Former President Joaquin Balaguer widened his lead to 35,000 votes in the official count in the Dominican presidential election today, but his closest rival, Jacobo Majluta Azar, declared himself the winner and called for a recount.

title: TAX PLAN COULD ALTER THE PENSION LANDSCAPE
description: Changes in the Federal tax system that have been proposed by the Senate Finance Committee would provide pension benefits to millions more American workers, according to some tax experts.

title: GRANTS INCREASE FOR WORK IN POPULATION AREA
description: Wealthy foundations regarded as trend-setters are beginning to spend more money in a controversial area: birth control, contraceptive research and teen-age sexuality.

title: A CORNER OF THE SOUTH SEAS IS DRIFTING TO THE LEFT
description: A new nationalism is rising in the islands of the South Pacific.

title: Associates of Helms Settle Suit Over Election Financing
description: Officials of a multimillion-dollar campaign committee allied with Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, have admitted they violated Federal election law in backing other candidates.

title: FOR STEEL INDUSTRY, CAUTIOUS OPTIMISM
description: When steel industry executives gather in New York tomorrow for the 94th annual meeting of the American Iron and Steel Institute, the mood is expected to be somewhat upbeat, for a change.

title: Margot E. Greenbaum Becomes Bride
description: Margot Elizabeth Greenbaum and James Mustich Jr. were married yesterday at the Lotus Club. Rabbi Charles D. Lippman and the Rev. Salvatore Mattarazzo, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the interdenominational ceremony.

title: Leak at Plant Forces Evacuation in Jersey
description: About 10 people were evacuated from their homes this morning in this Morris County town after a leak at a chemical plant, authorities said.

title: 'PAINTING CHURCHES' ON WNET
description: TINA HOWE'S ''Painting Churches'' is one of those perfectly contained, one-set, three-character plays that seem tailor-made for a television screen. The play had its premiere in 1983 at New York's Second Stage, earning a respectable run Off Broadway and several awards for the playwright. For public television's ''American Playhouse,'' tonight at 9 o'clock on WNET/Channel 13, it was taped at KCET's Hollywood studios under the direction of Jack O'Brien, the artistic director of San Diego's Old Globe Theater. It is a lovely, wonderfully affecting production.

title: China and Taiwan Have 2d Round of Talks
description: Officials of Taiwan and China held a second round of talks today to discuss the return of a cargo jet flown to China by a defecting pilot, but the chief Chinese delegate said they again failed to resolve their differences. Another negotiating session was scheduled for Monday.

title: Suit Against Conna Seen
description: Convenient Food Mart Inc. said last week that it would file a lawsuit in Federal Court in Louisville, Ky., against the Conna Corporation to prevent its merger with Dairy Mart Convenience Stores Inc.

title: Applying the Brakes
description: The fatal 160-mile-per-hour crash of Elio De Angelis at the Le Castellet track in France last week was a grim reminder that speeds are up in every form of motor sport, from drag racing to Indianapolis and Formula One.

title: Outdoors: The Lure of Fly Fishing
description: FLY fishermen represent only a small fraction of those who angle in saltwater, but often those who do take up the sport will gain such pleasure from it that they eventually use no other method.

title: Julie Kurtz Is Married To Thomas J. Chapin
description: Julie Ann Kurtz, an associate general counsel of the Celanese Corporation, and Thomas Jonathan Chapin, an assistant professor of physics at Rockefeller University, were married yesterday. Judge Lynne M. Abraham of the Court of Common Pleas of Philadelphia officiated in the home of the bride's mother and stepfather, Mr. and Mrs. Bruce H. Greenfield of Wyncote, Pa.

title: Miss Hausman Becomes Bride
description: Catherine Hausman, a television researcher, and Kelly Edmund Kaminski, a banker, were married yesterday in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University by Rev. Paul Dinter, a Catholic priest, and Cantor Bernard Fitch.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, MAY 19, 1986
description: International

title: REPORT OF BOMB PLOT ALERTS ENGLISH CHANNEL PORTS
description: The police at English Channel ports mounted a huge security and surveillance operation today after getting reports of a terrorist plot to blow up a passenger ferry as it made the trip between Britain and the Continent.

title: TYSON'S BIGGEST FIGHT IS OVER
description: MIKE TYSON sat in the back seat of a limousine that wended its way through mid-Manhattan traffic and he tried to put the next appointment on his busy calendar in perspective.

title: Amy Schiffman Bride Of John Jeffrey Ruskin
description: Amy Miriam Schiffman and John Jeffrey Ruskin were married yesterday at the bride's parents' home in Manhattan by Rabbi Balfour Brickner. The bride, who will keep her name, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Schiffman.

title: Take That, Foreigners!
description: It's time to fight back, by jingo! America won't put up with unfair foreign trade competition anymore! So say many members of the House, including the Democratic leadership. They contend they know the dangers of protectionism, yet what they propose instead would not help. On the contrary, it would shoot American consumers in the foot.

title: PUBLIC LIBRARY: CLASSIC REVIVED
description: In an age in which most great architectural monuments in New York get torn down, ''improved'' with towers plopped on their roofs, or in some other way altered beyond recognition, the New York Public Library looks exactly as it always has. Actually, that is not quite so: it now looks better than it has for almost all of the three-quarters of a century that it has been on Fifth Avenue.

title: EVACUATED TO NEW A-SITE
description: Some of the people evacuated from the danger zone around the Chernobyl nuclear power plant have been temporarily resettled next to another Ukrainian nuclear station still under construction, a Moscow paper has disclosed.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Ampal-American Israel Corp., a subsidiary of Bank Hapoalim B.M., announced that Ephraim Reiner, its chairman and president, had submitted his resignation.

title: CHERNOBYL DESIGN FOUND TO INCLUDE NEW SAFETY PLANS
description: The nuclear power plant that exploded in the Soviet Union last month had more safety features and was closer to American reactor designs than Western experts had assumed in the days soon after the accident, nuclear experts say.

title: Washington Watch; World Bank's Farm Loans
description: THE World Bank is coming under fire from farm-state members of Congress who fret that the bank's loans to Argentina and Brazil will help those countries raise their agricultural production and hurt American farmers in the competition for world markets.

title: Forms of Duress; Police Story
description: One or more tire slashers still stalk the quiet town of Guttenberg, N.J., and Police Chief Joseph Malik is frustrated.

title: ISRAEL AND SYRIA BELIEVED TO FACE RISK OF CONFLICT
description: Complex, long-term changes in the Syrian-Israeli military balance of power have created a situation in which a miscalculation by either side could ignite an armed conflict, according to Israeli, Arab and Western military experts.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: PAINTED GRASS AND LEAR AT THE JOHNSON WILL TRIAL
description: When the court battle over the $500 million estate of J. Seward Johnson Sr. began almost two months ago, witnesses for his six children testified about incidents in which Mr. Johnson's third wife, Barbara, shouted and cursed at him and at servants at their home in Princeton, N.J.

title: STATE UNIVERSITY AT ALBANY: CUOMO EXHORTS 3,500 IN CLASS AT HIS DAUGHTER'S GRADUATION
description: With his daughter Madeline among the 3,500 graduates, Governor Cuomo today delivered the commencement address at the State University at Albany, evoking the tar-paper roofs of his South Jamaica childhood and the dreams of his immigrant parents to spur the students toward a future of generosity.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, MAY 19, 1986
description: The Economy

title: SCORES ARE HURT AS TRAIN DERAILS
description: A nostalgic excursion for 1,000 employees, families and guests of the Norfolk Southern Corporation and its subsidiary, Norfolk & Western Railway, ended in chaos this afternoon when 13 cars of a 23-car train derailed. More than 160 people were hurt, four critically.

title: Cable TV Role Built By Head of Heritage
description: Fifteen years ago, James Hoak, the chairman and chief executive of Heritage Communications Inc., gave up practicing law to start his own cable television company.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary last Tuesday of Henry P. McIlhenny, chairman of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, misstated the affiliation of the Morris Arboretum. It is part of the University of Pennsylvania, in Philadelphia.

title: PEARSON WINS FIRST ON L.P.G.A. TOUR
description: Becky Pearson won her first professional golf tournament today, and to do it she had to sink a 3-foot birdie putt on the final green without showing the flutters she felt inside.

title: Texas Lake Searched For 18 Missing in Storm
description: Rescue teams using a helicopter and boats searched Livingston Lake about 80 miles north of here today for more than 18 people reported missing after a storm and high winds struck fishing tournaments Saturday. At least one person drowned, the authorities said.

title: MUSIC: TEATRO DELL'OPERA'S 'VILLI'
description: ''LE VILLI,'' Giacomo Puccini's first opera, was an auspicious debut. A one-acter created when the composer was 25 years old, ''Le Villi'' is charming and lyrical, rather than intensely dramatic, and deserves a wider audience than it has known. Friday night, Il Piccolo Teatro Dell'Opera (which is, despite the name, a New York organization) did much to win friends for ''Le Villi'' with a semistaged, lyrically sung production at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Suspect in 5 Killings Kills Himself in Colorado
description: A suspect sought in the slayings Saturday of five people at a bar and a neighboring convenience store committed suicide today after the police called his home and told him to surrender, officials said.

title: Playwright in Reading
description: A reading tomorrow of the play ''Victrix'' by its author, Elizabeth Diggs, will open a three-part series of readings at the Parsons School of Design, 66 Fifth Avenue, at 12th Street.

title: SNOW CHIEF AFTER BIG MONEY
description: Snow Chief, who made the most dramatic comeback in Triple Crown history in winning the Preakness Stakes here Saturday, will now embark on a campaign to pile up record earnings.

title: CRIME AND CONTROL ARE ISSUES FOR TEAMSTERS AT CONVENTION
description: The International Brotherhood of Teamsters opens its convention Monday, a twice-a-decade event that meets the requirements of Federal labor law, gives conventioneers a break from routine and ultimately reveals very little about one of the nation's most powerful institutions.

title: Say It With Balloons
description: To what lengths will political candidates go to attract television coverage in May of an election year? Well, Mayor William Donald Schaefer of Baltimore has arranged to tour five downtown parking lots on Monday, in or above each of which will be a giant balloon shaped like an animal.

title: THE 'MAGIC' OF WORTH AVENUE
description: ''The season'' has ended here.

title: Though Duvalier Is Gone, Haiti Still Needs Help
description: In Haiti, as in many deeply troubled places, it was comforting to identify the national demons with one man, and to assume that his destruction would bring theirs. But three months have passed since the former President, Jean-Claude Duvalier, boarded a waiting United States Air Force jet and flew off to an opulent exile in France, and it has become sadly clear that building the ''new Haiti'' will be a slow and painful process - and one that the United States can do little to influence.

title: Budget Law's Effect on Tax Bill
description: A while back Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican majority leader, was hoping that the new balanced-budget law would help him get tax-revision legislation through the Senate. Under that law, once a budget is in place, any amendment that would reduce expected revenue would require a three-fifths majority to pass.

title: 5 STATES: NICE PLACE NOT TO VISIT
description: The Great Lakes states lost residents and jobs by the thousands in the early 1980's while the Southeast gained both. Families are no longer fleeing the aging industrial centers along the lakes in large numbers, but when it comes to vacations, the one-way migration continues.

title: MARINERS BEATEN, 11-3
description: When the day was over, Lou Piniella returned to the manager's office, leaned back slowly against a chair and shook his head. Impatient? He had never been impatient.

title: Climber Killed in Swiss Alps
description: A Belgian was killed and two Frenchmen were seriously injured when seven climbers fell 650 feet on the Grand Combin mountain in southwest Switzerland today, the police said. The climbers were roped together in two separate groups and were just beneath the peak of the 13,000-foot-high Grand Combin when one slipped. He pulled his group with him and they crashed into the climbers below them.

title: GAINS FOR WOMEN PREDICTED IN RACES FOR STATEWIDE OFFICE
description: After more than a decade of progress in the grass roots of state and local government, women are poised to make significant gains this year in races for governor, the United States Senate and other statewide offices, according to political analysts and activists.

title: EMPLOYEE OWNERSHIP CALLED AVONDALE SPUR
description: ''If you listen to all the talk, the smokestack industries are dead,'' said William F. Connell. But he does not believe the talk. Mr. Connell is chairman and chief executive of a new industrial venture called Avondale Industries, a smokestack organization owned by its employees.

title: LIABILITY CRISIS COMPLICATES CONTRACEPTION
description: Dr. Louise Tryer sighed and hung up the telephone in her Seventh Avenue office at the Planned Parenthood Federation of America the other day. The caller was a 38-year-old woman who had been wearing a copper-covered intrauterine contraceptive device for the last three years. Now it was due to be replaced, but neither her gynecologist nor the family planning agencies she had visited would insert a new device. What did Dr. Tryer recommend?

title: SENATE PANEL BILL MIGHT SLOW ECONOMY
description: Economic forecasters say the Senate Finance Committee's tax plan would mean slightly weaker growth for the economy over the long haul, and some say the timing of key provisions could increase the risks of a mild downturn in the short run.

title: Predictable Losers In 'Cheap' Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: DODGERS STOPPED, 8-4
description: The Mets salvaged the final game of their series against the Los Angeles Dodgers today, 8-4, with star-quality help from a couple of unlikely sources: George Foster, who knocked in four runs with two home runs, and Randy Niemann, who pitched nearly four innings of scoreless relief to protect the lead Foster had supplied.

title: SNUFF MAKER'S RISE THREATENED BY SUIT
description: Sean Marsee was 13 years old and a budding track star in Ada, Okla., when he began using snuff, starting with free samples he picked up at a rodeo and working his way up to more than a can a day. In 1983, five years after he began using snuff, the teen-ager developed mouth cancer, and had part of his tongue removed. A year later, at the age of 19, Sean died.

title: LENDL TRIUMPHS IN ITALY
description: Ivan Lendl ended Emilio Sanchez's run of upsets today when he beat the Spaniard, 7-5, 4-6, 6-1, 6-1, in the final of the Italian Open.

title: ARTS ENDOWMENT BEGINS BROAD SCHOOL PROGRAM
description: In a significant step toward making the arts a basic part of education, as are reading, writing and arithmetic, the National Endowment for the Arts has begun a program to promote arts instruction from kindergarten to 12th grade in classrooms across the country. The aim, according to Frank Hodsoll, chairman of the endowment, would be to move schools toward giving all students a chance to graduate ''with a general understanding of, and elementary literacy in, the major art forms.''

title: WHODUNITS FIND CRIME STILL PAYS
description: Whodunits, which in recent years had been supplanted by more spectacular action-adventure series, are making a comeback on television. CBS has just announced that ''Mickey Spillane's Mike Hammer'' will be on the network schedule next fall. HBO is currently broadcasting six new episodes of a detective series, ''Philip Marlowe, Private Eye.'' ''Perry Mason Returns,'' the second most successful television movie of the past year, will pave the way for several more Perry Mason mystery movies on NBC. And the two executive producers of the Perry Mason films, Fred Silverman and Dean Hargrove, have three more mystery series in development at NBC.

title: CANADIENS EVEN SERIES 9 SECONDS INTO OVERTIME
description: The two teams, both with the same silver trophy in mind, could not produce a victory after three periods tonight at the Saddledome. But quicker than ever before in playoff history, a decision was reached after just nine seconds into overtime as the Montreal Canadiens won by 3-2 to even their Stanley Cup final series with the Calgary Flames at one game each.

title: CORRECTION
description: A headline on May 5 on the obituary of Esther Tufty, who operated a news service in Washington, misstated her age. She was 89 years old.

title: RED SOX WIN, 5-4, ON ERRORS
description: A throwing error by George Wright allowed Steve Lyons and Marty Barrett to score in the bottom of the 10th inning today, giving the Boston Red Sox a 5-4 victory over the Texas Rangers.

title: CALIFORNIAN BUSY PATCHING HIS HAND-LINKING PROJECT
description: Some would say it would take a Californian to think up the idea of 11 million hands linked like a paper-doll chain from the Battery in New York to Long Beach Pier in California.

title: INDY FIELD IS COMPLETED
description: The 33-car field for the Indianapolis 500 was completed today with Gary Bettenhausen bumping Dick Simon from the starting grid and George Snider grabbing the last slot during a rain-shortened final qualifying session.

title: Report Links Waldheim To Nazi Hostage Deaths
description: A 1948 United Nations War Crimes Commission report says Kurt Waldheim was responsible for the deaths of hostages held by the Nazis in World War II, according to an article in the current issue of Newsweek magazine.

title: Investing in Futures Isn't Just Gambling
description: To the Editor:

title: Too Much Grease in Albany
description: By sacrificing an unexpected subsidy of $10,000 to aid the homeless, Dr. F. Forrester Church, the pastor of Manhattan's All Souls Unitarian Church, has blown a whistle even New York's Legislature cannot ignore. Is he betraying the poor?In a way; he learned that this gift was part of an excessive $80 million appropriation dispensed by logrolling members without any of the serious examination such appropriations should get.

title: THE 'PEOPLE'S LIBRARY' TO CELEBRATE AS A CATHEDRAL OF KNOWLEDGE FOR ALL
description: When the New York Public Library celebrates its 75th anniversary Thursday, with a day of tributes by dignitaries and famous literary figures and an evening of dining and dancing for some 1,200 invited guests, Bernard Noskin will be absent.

title: Topics; Forms of Duress; Airborne Torture
description: In the Middle Ages, the evil geniuses of torture contrived a device called the little-ease. A person confined in it could assume only one pain-free posture; the slightest shift caused excruciating pain.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;
Runs in the Family
description: Whoever it was that first said nobody can get between twins wasn't talking about Laura and Ann Schweitzer, but he should have been. The Schweitzer sisters, seniors at Rising Sun High School, are the best female track competitors in rural southeastern Indiana, and they've placed 1-2 in nearly every one of the dozens of 800- and 1,600-meter races they've run together since sixth grade.

title: Vidal, Waldheim, Grant
description: Norman Podhoretz, editor of Commentary magazine, that incubator of neoconservatism, and his wife, Midge Decter, driving spirit behind the hawkish, bipartisan Committee for the Free World, have on occasion taken the novelist Gore Vidal to task for the way he condemns the ''predatory'' American past, excoriates the defense budget of the Reagan present, and predicts the doom of our society.

title: A BUSY, GRUELING DAY
description: It was a grueling day for long-distance runners in three American cities yesterday.

title: ST. JOHN'S UNIVERSITY: GRADUATES TOLD TO TAKE RISKS
description: Graduates at St. John's University were urged by the university president yesterday to strive to use all their talents in life and avoid the safe and easy.

title: Of Terrorism, U.S. Arms and the Saudis
description: To the Editor:

title: Willie Nelson Has Surgery
description: The singer Willie Nelson underwent surgery Friday for a severe fracture of his left thumb and will probably remain in a cast until his Farm Aid concert July 4, hospital officials said. Mr. Nelson, who is right-handed, was injured when when he fell off a bicycle, they said.

title: NICARAGUAN REBELS AMBUSH GERMANS AND CAPTURE EIGHT
description: Anti-Government rebels ambushed a vehicle carrying 12 West German construction workers Saturday, wounding one and capturing eight, a Defense Ministry representative said today.

title: At This OTB Parlor, Bettors Think Bigger
description: There are a number of unusual things about the new OTB parlor at 1015 Second Avenue. The rather astonishing thing about it is that patrons have been betting an average of $458 during their visits.

title: SUBURBAN FIRE AND RESCUE SERVICES HAVE WORRISOME VOLUNTEER SHORTAGE
description: A critical manpower shortage on volunteer fire and rescue squads in much of the New York region has raised concerns about slow or inadequate emergency responses.

title: MUSIC: ART INSPIRED BY INDONESIA
description: WHILE the twain may never meet, some Western artists apparently find the East awfully cute.

title: 3-POINTERS BY BIRD LEAD CELTIC SWEEP
description: Larry Bird remembers the day well. It was three years ago in this same visitors' dressing room in the Milwaukee Arena.

title: Sperry Board Quiet on Plans
description: Directors of the Sperry Corporation met for several hours last night, but declined to say whether they had agreed on a possible merger with the Burroughs Corporation.

title: Catching Up
description: * When Roger Clemens set a major league record by striking out 20 batters in a nine-inning game April 29, did Tom Cheney happen to see it? Did he read about it? Did he talk about it? Did he care about it? Surely you jest. Cheney, a right-handed fastballer who won only 19 games over eight seasons before arm problems forced him to retire in 1966, is the only pitcher who's ever fanned more than Clemens in a game of any duration.

title: U.S. UNABLE TO GET ACCORD WITH TURKEY OVER MILITARY BASES
description: The United States and Turkey are locked in what a senior Turkish official called a ''dialogue of the deaf'' that is blocking renewal of an expired five-year agreement under which the United States maintains a significant military and intelligence presence in this country.

title: HIGH ATTENDANCE SEEN FOR STATE PARKS
description: New York State is bracing for record attendance at its state-operated camps this summer, with larger crowds expected mainly because of low gasoline prices.

title: Officeholders' Profits: We Already Have Rules
description: To the Editor:

title: 'JOE TURNER,' THE SPIRIT OF SYNERGY
description: Upon first seeing ''Joe Turner's Come and Gone,'' Lloyd Richards, the director, said he knew what a powerful and important addition to the theater it was. Still, he decided there was something missing.

title: G.M.A.C. Euro Paper
description: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation, the financing arm of the General Motors Corporation, said it would start, on June 24, a Euro-commercial paper program for an unspecified amount to complement its existing program in the United States. Robert Almon, G.M.A.C.'s vice president of borrowings, said that the company was seeking to broaden its investor base in the international capital markets. He noted that G.M.A.C. is the largest issuer of commercial paper in the United States.

title: SOVIET MOBILIZES A VAST OPERATION TO OVERCOME THE DISASTER
description: In the three weeks since an explosion destroyed reactor No. 4 at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant, the Soviet Union has mobilized vast resources of men and machinery in a huge operation to contain and overcome the disaster.

title: 3 Jersey Residents Held As Drug Ring Members
description: Three Hudson county residents, including a North Bergen patrolman, have been arrested in a purported drug ring that made an average of $10,000 a day, a prosecutor asserted today.

title: LaROUCHE GROUPS' DEBT TO U.S. MOUNTS DAILY
description: Every day for 14 months, a ledger at the Federal courthouse here, showing what four groups affiliated with Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. owe the United States, has been getting a new, $45,000 entry.

title: SHEEN'S 'SAMARITAN' AND ROBARDS IN 'JOHNNY BULL'
description: COMMERCIAL television and its advertisers are not in the habit of challenging or unsettling audiences. The best consumer, goes the theory, is a gently stroked consumer. Harsher or grittier realities are not likely to sell much soap. It comes as a bit of a surprise, then, to find not one but two less than cheerily upbeat views of the human condition on tonight's schedule: ''Samaritan'' on CBS at 8:30, and ''Johnny Bull'' on ABC at 9.

title: Four-A's Focuses on Takeovers
description: Never in memory has a conversational topic so dominated an American Association of Advertising Agencies annual meeting as has the recent acquisition by Saatchi & Saatchi.

title: MUSIC: DEBUT BY TORIKAI, AVANT-GARDE
description: WHERE do music and noise intersect? For her first United States performance, a solo concert Friday night at the Experimental Intermedia Center, the Japanese composer Ushio Torikai joined innumerable other musicians who have addressed that question. She sang and she played modern instruments and ancient ones; she also smashed two dozen dishes and upended boxes of beer cans.

title: DANISH REVELERS ARRESTED
description: Carnival revelers plundered shops in the center of Copengagen Saturday night and 45 people were arrested in disorderly incidents, the police said.

title: ABM PACT TIED TO BUDGET CUTS FOR 'STAR WARS'
description: The Reagan Administration may reconsider its commitment to abide strictly by the terms of the 1972 antiballistic missile treaty if Congress does not support President Reagan's Strategic Defense Initiative, according to a report by the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency.

title: SLAM BY BROOKS LIFTS EXPOS, 8-3
description: Hubie Brooks, the National League home run leader, highlighted a seven-run first inning with a grand slam today, leading the Montreal Expos to an 8-3 victory over the San Diego Padres.

title: Dale Partoll, a Dean, Weds Robert Lenzner, Journalist
description: Dale Partoll, associate dean of the Graduate School of Business at Columbia University, and Robert Lenzner, New York bureau chief of The Boston Globe, were married yesterday at the bridegroom's home in New York. Rabbi Thomas Weiner officiated.

title: EVENTS FILL CITY STREETS, BUT TRAFFIC STAYS LIGHT
description: A two-foot tall plaster bust of Elvis, in color? No problem, it was on the corner of Ninth Avenue and 40th Street, for $35 firm. All right, $30 for you.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We would desperately like to please the veterans, and at the same time we find it very necessary to make a scientifically meaningful study or else we've wasted all our time and money, and that does a disservice to everyone.'' - Dr. Carl Keller of National Institute of Evnironmental Health on Agent Orange study. [ A1:3. ]

title: YANKEE 'TWINS' COME AND GO
description: IN his frustration at being unable to change pitchers during an inning, George Steinbrenner changes pitching coaches during a season. For the 23d time in the 14 seasons of the principal owner's reign, the Yankees have waved in another pitching coach.

title: 2 DIE IN FIERY PLANE CRASH ON ATLANTIC CITY ROAD
description: Two men were killed and a woman was critically injured late Saturday when a small plane attempting to take off from an Atlantic City airfield crashed through a chain-link fence, skidded onto a highway and struck several cars as it broke apart and burst into flames.

title: SOUTH AFRICA UNCOVERS BIG ARMS CACHE
description: The South African police said today that they had uncovered the biggest cache of arms ever found in the country's 25-year-old war between the white Government and black nationalist guerrillas.

title: Market Place; Oil Industry's Brighter Side
description: AT a time when depressed industry conditions have forced some energy-related companies to cut or even reduce dividend payments, the refining and marketing part of the oil business has emerged as a shining star. In past years, these so-called downstream operations typically were far less important than the ''upstream,'' or production side, as profit centers.

title: BLENDING A CHORUS OF NO'S TO SAUDIS ON ARMS
description: Senator Slade Gorton, a Washington Republican, generally supports President Reagan on foreign policy matters. But earlier this month he backed a resolution blocking the President's request to sell arms to Saudi Arabia. And if Mr. Reagan keeps his promise to veto that resolution this week, Mr. Gorton says he will vote to override the veto.

title: Kindergartners Learn About Courts and Judges
description: Defamation of character. Allegations of libel and slander.

title: 7 GOLD MEDALS FOR CUBA
description: Cuba won four more gold medals today to gain a total of seven as the world amateur boxing championships concluded.

title: Doctors Remove Legs Of Mt. Hood Climber
description: Doctors today amputated the lower legs of one of two teen-agers who survived a blizzard on Mount Hood that killed nine other people, hospital officials said.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a dispatch from Detroit yesterday on Michigan's selection of Republican Presidential nominating delegates for 1988 incorrectly described the first step of the process. The election of delegates to represent precincts at the county party conventions takes place at the voting booth, along with other primary elections this Aug. 5, not at precinct meetings.

title: A Rooftop Warning For Liberty Weekend
description: Worried that harborside roofs will become dangerously overcrowded viewing areas for the Statue of Liberty centennial celebration on the Fourth of July weekend, the city's Buildings Commissioner sent a warning yesterday to owners of large structures who plan to sell tickets or rent their roofs to spectators.

title: Senate Votes To Scrap T-46
description: The Senate has voted to scrap production of the T-46 pilot trainer that is made by the Fairchild Republic Company on Long Island, but officials said Friday that the move was just one battle in a continuing war.

title: 2 ON U.S. COMMISSION DISSENT ON A PORNOGRAPHY LINK TO VIOLENCE
description: Two members of the Attorney General's Commission on Pornography have issued a sharp dissent to the panel's conclusion that most pornography can lead to violence.

title: STIFF CHALLENGES AT ROYAL BANK
description: When Allan R. Taylor could not decide on a college major at 16 years of age, he decided to work for a year at the local branch of the Royal Bank of Canada in his hometown of Prince Albert, Saskatchewan. Now, 22 promotions later and still without a university diploma, Mr. Taylor, at age 53, is preparing to move from president to chairman and chief executive of Canada's largest financial institution on June 1.

title: Andrew Mark Lippa Wed To Joan Carolyn Markoff
description: Joan Carolyn Markoff, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur M. Markoff of Westport, Conn., and Andrew Mark Lippa, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Simon Lippa of New York and Lake Worth, Fla., were married yesterday in the Mansion at Stouffer Westchester in White Plains. Rabbi Robert Orkand officiated.

title: STUDY OF EFFECTS OF AGENT ORANGE ON VETERANS IS STALLED IN DISPUTE
description: What was to have been the country's most comprehensive study of any toxic effects of the herbicide Agent Orange on Vietnam veterans has stalled six years after it was authorized, and may be abandoned, because of disputes over how to conduct the work.

title: Fed's Citicorp-Quotron Vote
description: The Federal Reserve Board is scheduled to vote today on whether Citicorp, the nation's largest bank holding company, should be allowed to buy Quotron Systems Inc., the worldwide provider of stock quotations and other financial data. In a takeover bid, Citicorp has offered $19 a share in cash, or a total of $680 million, for the data processing company's approximately 35 million outstanding shares.

title: PUBLISHING: WALDHEIM'S MEMOIRS
description: ADLER & ADLER published its first two titles four months ago, but unfortunately for the fledgling Washington-based publishing company, one of them was ''In the Eye of the Storm'' by Kurt Waldheim.

title: The Valley-Rudman Battle
description: A group of conservative New Hampshire Republicans is organizing to block renomination of Senator Warren B. Rudman, co-author of the legislation mandating cuts in Federal spending. They are backing Bruce Valley, a Navy commander now working in the Pentagon who plans to retire July 1 to campaign for the G.O.P. Senate nomination, to be decided in a September primary.

title: BALLET: 'LES SYLPHIDES'
description: IT wasn't the liveliest night of dance American Ballet Theater has presented this season. But Christine Dunham, Cynthia Harvey and Cheryl Yeager rose above that on Saturday at the Metropolitan Opera House. As the waltz soloist in Michel Fokine's ''Sylphides,'' Miss Dunham brought a little brio to this somnolent bit of ballet history with dancing that was clear, precise and expansive, though always delicate enough to seem sylphlike. Miss Harvey brought to her mazurka and the pas de deux a spirituality of the sort associated with Marie Taglioni, in full-bodied, beautifully phrased dancing that was a highlight of the evening. The lead cast also included Ross Stretton and Lisa Rinehart, whose performances were adequate but uninspired.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Lexicon
description: The prevailing wisdom in Washington is that sweeping changes in the Federal income tax system will be enacted before the end of the summer. In the meantime, however, there will be plenty of talk about tax rates and tax breaks as the legislation wends its way through the Senate and and a House-Senate conference.

title: Good Writing Begins at the Dinner Table
description: To the Editor:

title: Toddler Philanthropy
description: Consider all the shock and debris of the New York corruption scandals, of the commissions formed by Governor and Mayor to make everything right, of the urgings of prosecutors and editorialists. Surely all of this will soon produce nationally significant reforms in local campaign financing.

title: CHINA'S PROUD SPACE PROGRAM
description: Most Americans think of China as the land of the bicycle.

title: Dove Bar Begins Its First Big Campaign
description: Dove Bar, the high-priced Chicago-born ice cream pop, is spending $3.5 million on its first major advertising campaign.

title: Daniel Raff Weds Dr. Susan Adelman
description: Dr. Susan Claire Adelman, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Nathan Adelman of New York, was married yesterday to Daniel Martin Gorodyetsky Raff, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton S. Raff of Chevy Chase, Md. Rabbi Ben-Zion Gold, director of the Hillel Foundation at Harvard University, from which the bride received a doctorate degree in clinical psychology, performed the ceremony at the Cronkhite Graduate Center at Harvard in Cambridge, Mass.

title: PG Communications Is Gussow's New Firm
description: Having sold his Magazines for Industry for the second time, and this time for good, Don Gussow, business entrepreneur, is going to start all over again with PG Communications.

title: BRANDEIS UNIVERSITY: BRENNAN URGES VIGILANCE IN GUARDING RIGHTS
description: Associate Justice William J. Brennan Jr. of the Supreme Court warned graduating seniors at Brandeis University in Waltham, Mass., yesterday that the modern age posed special dangers of Government encroachments on freedom.

title: The U.N. Today: May 19, 1986
description: ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Anniversary Rally Broken Up in Korea
description: Policemen fired tear gas at anti-Government demonstrators trying to gather today for a rally on the sixth anniversary of the Kwangju uprising, and a local news agency said 120 people were arrested.

title: Seeking Youth
description: President Reagan will make an effort this summer and fall to communicate with the nation's young people in a series of personal and television appearances stressing education and other issues of interest to youth. He began this campaign last week with a speech in the White House Rose Garden to some North Carolina high school students that was transmitted by satellite to other schools around the country.

title: PENN CREW TAKES WORCESTER BOWL
description: Pennsylvania's crew captured the Worcester Bowl today by winning the featured heavyweight race at the 41st annual Eastern Sprint Rowing Championships. It was Penn's first victory in the race since 1962, when the Quakers shared the title with Yale.

title: FUND FINISHES HALF A CENTURY OF PHILANTHROPY WITH A PARTY
description: After a half-century of philanthropy, the Stern Fund of New York has spent itself out of existence and has thrown a party to celebrate.

title: ADELPHI UNIVERSITY: PRESIDENT SAYS HIGHER EDUCATION HELPS IN SETTING PRIORITIES
description: Dr. Peter Diamondopoulos, the president of Adelphi University, delivering his first commencement address to the university, said yesterday that higher education equipped its recipients to establish priorities for private and public life.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THEIR GREATEST HITS Having survived their first 10 years, two dance companies are celebrating this week.

title: Almay Hires Korey, Kay
description: Almay Cosmetics and Toiletries, a subsidiary of International Playtex, which was resigned by Saatchi & Saatchi Compton last Thursday, announced on Friday that Korey, Kay & Partners would be its new agency.

title: U.S. BOARD STUDIES CHICAGO AIRLINER INCIDENT
description: The National Transportation Safety Board said yesterday that it was investigating the report of a near-collision of two airliners taking off on intersecting runways in Chicago Saturday.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: JOHNS HOPKINS GAINS
description: Brian Wood, a junior attackman, scored two of his four goals during a third-quarter rally today and the senior midfielder Del Dressel added four goals and two assists to lead top-seeded Johns Hopkins past Massachusetts by 13-6 in the National Collegiate Athletic Assocation Division I lacrosse tournament.

title: Dr. Steven Scalia Weds Dr. Elizabeth McCormick
description: Dr. Elizabeth McCormick and Dr. Steven V. Scalia, who received medical degrees on Saturday from Louisiana State University, were married in New Orleans yesterday. Judge Dom Grieshaber of the New Orleans City Court officiated at the Victoria.

title: GRADUATION TICKETS A HOT ITEM ON CAMPUSES
description: The hottest tickets on campuses these days are not for a Mets game or even a Bruce Springsteen concert but for university graduation ceremonies.

title: Viacom, Icahn Talks Reported
description: Viacom International, the diversified media company, and Carl C. Icahn, the New York investor, are discussing the buyout of Mr. Icahn's 16.9 percent stake in Viacom, according to Wall Street sources.

title: A Health-Care Union Returns to Good Health
description: The union that the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther

title: Gannett Bid Said to Win
description: The Gannett Company, one of the nation's largest communications conglomerates, is the winning bidder for the Bingham family's newspapers, according to a report in one of those papers, The Courier-Journal. The report was based on information from an unnamed source, and neither company would confirm it.

title: China Gulf Investors
description: China is stepping up efforts to persuade Gulf oil states to invest in its modernization drive.

title: Trade Deficit Overstated
description: The nation's gaping trade deficit, the subject of so much protectionist attention on Capitol Hill, appears to have been significantly exaggerated in the first few months of 1986 by the inability of Commerce Department statisticians to keep up with the collapse in oil prices. The department's monthly reports have probably been overstating the merchandise trade deficit by as much as 5 percent, or $725 million in March alone.

title: HOFSTRA UNIVERSITY: 'TRUST YOUR GUT,' BARBARA WALTERS SAYS
description: Barbara Walters, the television journalist, urged the 48th graduating class of Hofstra University today to ''work hard and long'' and ''trust your gut'' in making career choices.

title: Survey Sees Outlay Dip
description: Caught in a sluggish economy, American companies say their projected spending for new facilities and equipment in 1986 will be slightly less than what they spent in 1985, according to a survey by McGraw-Hill Economics, a unit of Data Resources Inc.

title: SWISS BANKS EASING SECRECY
description: The decision of a prestigious Swiss bank to provide insider trading documents to the Securities and Exchange Commission is the latest in a series of moves underscoring the increasingly cooperative Swiss stance on international requests for legal assistance.

title: U.S. EASING CURBS ON TRAVEL
description: The Federal Government is now suggesting only a few restrictions on European travel in the aftermath of the Chernobyl nuclear accident.

title: John Ballen Wed To Karen Kuhn
description: Karen Marie Berk Kuhn, who is due to graduate from the Dartmouth Medical School next month, and John William Ballen, an investment officer at Massachusetts Financial Services in Boston, both of whom are magna cum laude 1981 graduates of Harvard College, were married yesterday. Cantor Donald Slonim officiated at the Mohonk Mountain House in New Paltz, N.Y.

title: Jennifer Press Marries John Goodkind
description: Jennifer Mollie Press, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. Press of New York, was married yesterday to John Daniel Goodkind, a son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Robert Goodkind of Rye, N.Y. Rabbi Robert E. Goldberg performed the ceremony at the Beach Point Club in Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: CARING FOR BOTH OLD AND YOUNG
description: ''WE in this middle generation will continue to take care of children and take responsibility for aging parents,'' said Betty Friedan, ''but it must be our choice. We have learned to define our problems and will continue to do so.''

title: KILDUFF TAKES TRAVIS
description: Using a driver off the fairway is not common in competitive golf, but Jim Kilduff used his that way this afternoon and it paid dividends for him.

title: Ellen Resnick Is Wed To Paul Daniel Lewis
description: The Westbury Hotel in Manhattan was the setting yesterday for the wedding ceremony of Ellen Barbara Resnick, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanly I. Resnick of Roslyn, L.I., to Paul Daniel Lewis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter A. Lewis of New York, Quogue, L.I., and Bakersfield, Calif. Rabbi Lawrence Colton performed the ceremony.

title: FRED DICKENSON
description: Fred Dickenson, a longtime newspaper reporter and the writer of the ''Rip Kirby'' detective comic strip, died May 6 in Doctors Hospital in Sarasota, Fla., after a series of strokes. He was 77 years old and lived in Sarasota.

title: OPEC Reviews Nonmembers
description: Oil ministers from five members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries are expected to meet in the Saudi Arabian resort town of Taif on Friday to review the development of ties with non-OPEC oil producers, oil industry sources said today.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: How many times have A. J. Foyt and Mario Andretti won the Indianapolis 500 auto race and how many times have they finished second? What driver has been runner-up the most times?

title: Albany Should Not Overreact to a New York City Scandal
description: To the Editor:

title: A Threat to Both U.S. Radios in Europe
description: Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty are in jeopardy.

title: S.E.C. SEEN EXAMINING STOCK LINK
description: In a move apparently intended to strengthen its case against Dennis B. Levine, the former Wall Street merger executive accused of insider trading, the Securities and Exchange Commission is circulating a list of about 100 takeover stocks at the three investment houses where Mr. Levine used to work, Wall Street sources said late last week.

title: GREEN OUT TO REGAIN GLITTER
description: Mitch Green, the 29-year-old fighter who meets Mike Tyson tomorrow, once was a highly regarded heavyweight prospect.

title: Andrea Warshaw Weds
description: The wedding of Andrea Ruth Warshaw, the daughter of Dena Rosenthal Warshaw and Jerome Warshaw, both of New York, to Lawrence Scot Deitch, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Deitch of New York, took place yesterday at the Hampshire House. Rabbi Judah Nadish officiated. Mrs. Deitch, a graduate of Vassar College, is the editor of the College Digest magazine in Mamaroneck, N.Y. Mr. Deitch, a graduate of Duke University with an M.B.A. degree from Tulane University, is a vice president and account supervisor at Geers Gross Advertising in New York.

title: CONFLICTING VIEWS OF CITY SMOKING BILL
description: The day Mayor Koch announced his proposed smoking-restriction bill, he described it as among about 10 controversial measures - or ''heavy lifts'' - he planned to introduce in his third term. And so it has become.

title: A STEADY FED POLICY EXPECTED
description: Fearing a negative effect on the value of the dollar, Federal Reserve officials are not expected to make any noticeable change in monetary policy at tomorrow's meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee. But the prospect that no substantial change will be made has not been enough to pacify the credit markets, where interest rates on some short- and long-term issues rose about a quarter of a percentage point or more last week.

title: Linda A. Benvin Wed To William Snedeker
description: Linda Anne Benvin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Benvin of Douglaston, Queens, was married yesterday to William Audley Snedeker, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Snedeker of Andover, Mass. The Rev. James Smith performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church in Long Island City, Queens.

title: IF A PENSKE CAR SQUEAKS, THAT'S ONLY BECAUSE IT'S SO CLEAN
description: THE sleek, white Lear Jet whooshed down the runway on its takeoff. Roger Penske cut off his conversation and hunched forward from his seat in the rear.

title: MULRONEY SOARS ABROAD, STRUGGLES AT HOME
description: When Prime Minister Brian Mulroney returned late last week from a two-week tour of Asia, he found a lot more to worry his Conservative Government than its links to the investigations of the Washington lobbyist Michael K. Deaver.

title: Good Food Acquires Great Foods Magazine
description: Good Food, a monthly food magazine published by Triangle Communications, has acquired the subscribers of Great Foods, a bimonthly food magazine which will cease publication. The 600,000 subscribers of Great Foods will begin receiving Good Food in July, bringing subscription orders to approximately one million.

title: GAMBLERS BUS CRASH KILLS ONE
description: A double-decker bus bound for Atlantic City struck a railroad overpass in Bloomfield, N.J., shortly after noon yesterday, killing a passenger and injuring a dozen others, at least one critically.

title: IN KENYA, INCREASING SIGNS OF UNREST
description: The recent arrests and convictions here of several people on sedition charges -the first major political crackdown since a failed coup in 1982 -has cast new light on the political intrigues and insecurities bubbling beneath this East African country.

description: In his seven seasons as a head coach for four teams, Stan Albeck has walked away from three of them. Yesterday, the Chicago Bulls left him behind.

McIlhenny, who died on May 11, has been bequeathed in its entirety - paintings, drawings, sculpture, furniture and the decorative arts - to the Philadelphia Museum of Art, with which Mr. McIlhenny had been associated for 50 years as curator, trustee and latterly chairman of the board.

title: New Quisenberry Role
description: In the last four baseball seasons, Dan Quisenberry of the Kansas City Royals has made 161 saves. In each of those seasons, he has led American League pitchers.

title: Julius Horwitz Is Dead; Wrote on Social Issues
description: Julius Horwitz, the author of nine books, many of them dealing with the welfare system and other social issues, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in Larchmont, N.Y. He was 65 years old.

description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1.4 million.

description: Allen H. Neuharth, chairman of the Gannett Company, said today that acquiring the daily newspapers in this city of the Kentucky Derby was the last step in ''winning the Triple Crown.''

FUJI-ISUZU AUTO PLANT IN U.S.
description: Fuji Heavy Industries and Isuzu Motors have agreed in principle to manufacture vehicles jointly in the United States beginning in 1989, the companies announced today.

title: Tritus Gets Patent On Beta Interferon
description: The Cetus Corporation said that Tritus, its joint venture with Triton Biosciences Inc., had been issued the first patent for genetically engineered beta interferon, betaseron protein. Betaseron is in clinical trials as a potential anti-cancer and anti-viral agent.

title: To Get Teachers Who Can Teach
description: The daunting question of how to improve teaching in America has evoked a provocative answer from a distinguished panel convened by the Carnegie Forum on Education and the Economy. It thinks teachers, like doctors, should be certified by a national standard, and then given a great deal more responsibility for running the public schools. The forum proposes not just to exhort but to carry its ideas into the political ring. The effort deserves enthusiastic encouragement and attentive review.

title: Market Place; Hawaii, Banks And Tourism
description: HAWAII's two major bank holding companies do not receive the intensive coverage that brokerage firms often accord regional banks on the mainland. But a handful of analysts are impressed, continuing to regard these Hawaiian shares as attractive, even after their stellar market performance so far this year.

title: Honda Increases '86 Prices Again
description: The Honda Motor Company, citing the continued strengthening of the yen against the dollar, issued its fourth price increase on cars since the 1986 model year began. Honda said it would raise suggested base retail prices by an average 2.3 percent, or $238, on a typical Honda car, effective immediately.

title: BATTLING FOR DOMINANCE IN THE POST-VETO PERIOD
description: The legislative veto was 50 years old and flourishing when the Supreme Court declared it unconstitutional about three years ago. The fallout from that decision is still settling on Capitol Hill today, with reverberations felt in areas ranging from the Congressional budget process to the sale of missiles to Saudi Arabia.

title: U.S. Bank in Spain Bombed
description: A small bomb exploded early today at a Citibank branch in this central Spanish city, causing damage but no casualties, the police said.

title: FIRST CHINA-TAIWAN TALKS YIELD ACCORD
description: China and Taiwan today concluded their first face-to-face negotiations in 37 years, with Peking agreeing to allow the Nationalist Government to reclaim a cargo plane flown to the mainland by its pilot, who defected.

title: Talking Business with Prestowitz of Commerce Dept.; Trade Friction With Japanese
description: For nearly five years Clyde V. Prestowitz, counselor to the Secretary of Commerce, has been the chief coordinator on issues related to Japan and has built a reputation as one of the sternest critics of Japanese trading policy.

AERIAL SEARCHES OF FENCED AREAS UPHELD BY COURT
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that government investigators do not need warrants to conduct aerial surveillance of areas that any pilot could legally fly over, including the fenced yards of private homes.

title: Holiday on Ice
description: As spring vacations in Florida go, the one that Gerry (Tubby) Aherne puts together strays a bit from run-of-the-mill relaxation. Indeed, if the annual weeklong Florida Palms Old-Timer's Tournament in St. Petersburg is a kind of ''where the boys are,'' then it must be added that the boys' average age is 44 and that the main activity entails mixing yesterday's professionals with today's never-weres in an orgy not of sun and surf but of hockey, which lasts every day from just after breakfast to almost midnight.

title: FED PROPOSES LIFTING SOME BANKING BARRIERS
description: The Federal Reserve Board today proposed eliminating certain important barriers between bank holding companies and their thrift subsidiaries.

description: Q.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: DOUBLY GIFTED. The Author as Visual Artist. By Kathleen G. Hjerter. Illustrated. 160 pages. Harry N. Abrams Inc. $29.95. AMONG their other attractions, the pictures in Kathleen G. Hjerter's ''Doubly Gifted'' hold out the possibility of an engaging new guessing game. The watercolor view of a harbor, for instance, with its dinky houses and ships, and with the sea and sky painted a startling blue -even if you were told that the artist was better known as a playwright, would your first or your second or your 10th guess be that it was by Ibsen? Or what about the three panels in acrylic entitled ''Infuriating Simplicity,'' a triptych of colored squares arranged in interlocking shapes? It may suggest some new school of geometrical abstraction, or perhaps a belated follower of Mondrian and de Stijl, but it is actually an original James Michener.

title: A Radioactive Leak At Indian Point Plant
description: Five gallons of mildly radioactive water spilled outside the containment building at the Indian Point No. 2 nuclear power plant at Buchanan, N.Y., early yesterday, but the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said the incident was not serious.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: NEW VIEWS In its Italian Renaissance-style town house just off Fifth Avenue, at 3 East 63d Street, the 169-year-old New York Academy of Sciences has created a gallery for art exhibitions incorporating scientific themes. The gallery's first show is ''Science in Surrealism: The Art of Remedios Varo.'' Remedios Varo, who died in 1963 at age 55, was one of a small circle of female Surrealists. She was associated with Salvador Dali, Andre Breton and others in the movement in the late 1930's. However, she was unique in her use of scientific themes and images.

title: Powerfood Goes South
description: Donna Tuttle, Under Secretary of Commerce for Travel and Tourism, several weeks ago wrote a letter to the New York hotelier Preston Robert Tisch suggesting they get together for breakfast the next time he was in Washington. Monday morning, the breakfast took place, but it turned out that 50 other guests were also invited to celebrate the opening of National Tourism Week. Mr. Tisch, who is president of the Loews Corporation and chairman of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, is known as the man who coined the term power breakfast, in which the heavyweights of politics, business and the media get together for early morning coffee and rashers. Despite claims to the contrary by several power-grazing Senators at Monday's breakfast that such events have been going on for many years in the capital, Mr. Tisch insisted this was the First Official New York Power Breakfast in Washington.

title: CHIRAC UNDER FIRE FROM SOME ALLIES
description: In the two months since he took office, Prime Minister Jacques Chirac has moved slowly -too slowly, according to a mounting chorus of criticism among his conservative allies - to begin a a program stressing the free market and law and order.

Baseball's television contract mandates night telecasts for postseason play, but city and state laws prohibit baseball from being played at night at Wrigley Field.

DOW IS OFF 1.62 AS VOLUME DECLINES

Market analysts said there were other reasons for the falloff in trading activity, including a holiday in Europe and investor concerns over interest rates and oil prices - both of which have been rising lately.

title: Agustin Gonzalez, 66, Leader in Social Work
description: Agustin Gonzalez, founder and executive director of the Puerto Rican Family Institute, died last Friday at Red Cross Hospital in Mexico City. He had been struck by a car while he was vacationing in Mexico.

title: Yale's Uncivil Disobedience
