I myself am not at all sure that this is a wise course, but that is not the reason I am so troubled by the anti-apartheid demonstrations at my university.

title: Chess: London Council Prize Won By a Last-Minute Substitute
description: The London International Tournament ended in a surprising triumph for Glenn Flear, a 27-year-old British international master, whose 8 1/2-4 1/2 score enabled him to surpass the 13 grandmasters entered. Flear was awarded the $:5,000 first prize by the Greater London Council, sponsor of the event.

title: Ethiopian Overture to U.S.
description: The Ethiopian leader, Mengistu Haile Mariam, said today that he would welcome a rapprochement between his Marxist Government and the United States. He said the biggest obstacle was Washington's ''anti-Ethiopian stance.'' James R. Cheek, the United States charge d'affaires in Addis Ababa, said Washington also welcomes a dialogue, but noted American concerns over Ethiopia's ties to the Soviet Union.

title: SUNSHINE-JR STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
''PORTRAIT OF A TERRORIST'
description: HOW do you like your terrorists? Try sensitive, earnest and principled. On ''Portrait of a Terrorist,'' we get Fernando Gabeira of Brazil, who once helped kidnap a United States Ambassador but now renounces tactics like that. The kidnapping was messy, and Mr. Gabeira now has better things to do. The program will be seen on WNET/Channel 13 at 11 o'clock tonight.

title: KICKING UP THEIR HEELS FOR CHASE
description: IN leotards and legwarmers, they line two flights of stairs leading to the rehearsal studio off Times Square, and trade shop talk of other auditions, other jobs. Someone knows someone who got picked for the chorus of Bob Fosse's ''Big Deal.'' In the studio, meanwhile, the first dozen dancers are told to fling open their arms. ''Big, broad, O.K.?'' says the choreographer. ''You're representing a big bank.'' The 40 young dancers are auditioning for parts in a dance number that will wrap for parts in a dance number that will wrap up a four-day conference for information-processing managers worldwide at the Chase Manhattan Bank at the end of this phrase is almost redundant - these industrial shows, as they are called, offer wages and a chance to dance. For the corporations, they add glitter to meetings that are otherwise conspicuously glitter-free. ''Clients want you to understand their business, but boy, do they love the bells and whistles,'' said Pennie Wilfong, head of Briar Productions, which is producing the Chase show.

title: CUBA TO ABOLISH FARMER MARKETS
description: Fidel Castro says Cuba has halted a six-year-old experiment with free peasant markets, calling it ''a source of enrichment for neo-capitalists and neo-bourgeois.''

title: FUSES OUT, JAVITS HALL OVERHEATS
description: On the first weekend that the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center was fully booked, the air-conditioning didn't work.

title: THE STAGE: THREE LONDON MUSICALS
description: The unthinkable has finally happened -London, an erstwhile also-ran in the contemporary musical theater, threatens to surpass New York as a production center for musical extravaganzas. There are now nine home-grown musicals running in the West End, along with such typical Broadway imports as ''42d Street'' and ''La Cage aux Folles.'' While some of London's newest blockbusters may rely in part on imported talent or money (from the United States, Sweden and France), they all adhere to the form of pop-rock opera that, as perfected by the now severed team of Andrew Lloyd Webber and Tim Rice, is England's latter-day claim to the Gilbert and Sullivan tradition.

title: DR. TIBOR NYILAS
description: Dr. Tibor Nyilas, seven-time United States individual saber champion in the 1940's and 1950's, died yesterday of cancer.

title: Conrail Has Earned Independence
description: The Administration's proposal to sell Conrail to Norfolk Southern has aroused the determined opposition of Representative John Dingell, chairman of the House Commerce Committee. Since the proposal has few friends in Congress, his resistance is almost certainly fatal. It is also for the best.

title: 3 Drowning Victims Found
description: The bodies of three people who drowned in a weekend storm that lashed Lake Livingston with sudden 90-mile-an-hour winds were found today in the wreckage of their sunken boat, raising to five the number of people killed. The three latest victims, believed to be from the Houston area, were found when rescuers towed the 20-foot boat to shore, Capt. Chuck Staton of the Polk County Sheriff's Department said.

title: FORUM GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a non-recurring gain of $24.4 million, or 90 cents a share, from the sale of the company's Acute Care division for the quarter and year.

title: BEYOND SOUTH AFRICA'S BORDERS: THE 3 NEIGHBORS
description: The three black-ruled African countries attacked by South Africa today oppose South Africa's race laws, and all offer political support for Pretoria's black nationalist adversaries. Yet they are vulnerable, economically and militarily, to South Africa's regional might. The three are members of the Organization of African Unity and the six-member group known as the Frontline States, which is committed to supporting apartheid's foes. The three are landlocked and are thus dependent on intermediaries for access to ports. They maintain scheduled, airline flights to and from Johannesburg.

title: ROYAL RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a writedown of $8.7 million on oil and gas property for the quarter and the 9 months. c-Net income.

title: A RELAXED, DORMITORY-STYLE LOCKUP
description: John Gotti, who counts privacy, comfort and freedom among his intangible assets, faces a spartan, crowded life over the next three months at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in lower Manhattan.

title: STAGE: 'TEN BY TENNESSEE,' SHORT WILLIAMS PLAYS
description: THE lonely people in ''Ten by Tennessee,'' an anthology of 10 short plays by Tennessee Williams, reach out for dependency - and find it insufficient life support. In play after play at the Lucille Lortel Theater, we feel the need, loss, regret and despair. At the same time, most of the plays are love stories and almost all are heightened by the author's ebullient humor.

title: EASTOVER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes gains of $107,000 for the latest quarter and $1,169,000 for the year-earlier period from the sale of real estate.

title: M/A/R/C INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: The 1985 share earnings and shares outstanding results have been restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in the form of a 50 percent stock dividend in December 1985.

title: Occidental Reports Further Cutbacks
description: In a move reflecting the continuing effect of depressed prices on the oil industry, the Occidental Petroleum Corporation today announced a second cut in its capital spending budget for the year and the elimination of 2,000 more jobs worldwide.

title: ENERGY DEVELOPMENT PARTERS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a pre-tax writedown of $41,505,000 of oil and gas properties. Year-ago first quarter figures are not available because the company began operations in September.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: Adac Laboratories, San Jose, Calif., which produces image-processing systems for nuclear medicine, named Michael O. Preletz president and chief executive.

title: Advertising; Warning Given on Ad Quality
description: AS the American Association of Advertising Agencies prepared to turn over the grandeur of the Greenbrier to the Association of Life Insurance last Saturday, it gave its membership a final warning that good advertising is being threatened by in-house agencies and a la carte advertising services.

title: GAP INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: b-Net loss and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $893,000.

title: THEATER UNIT IN AGREEMENT ON NEW SITE
description: The Theater for the New City, one of New York's oldest avant-garde companies, appears to have found a new home after three years of complex and often bitter negotiations with municipal authorities.

title: BRITISH FILM WINS TOP CANNES PRIZE
description: The 39th annual Cannes Film Festival tonight awarded its top prize, the prestigious Golden Palm, to ''The Mission,'' a powerful British drama that outlines the conflict between spiritual and temporal forces in 18th-century South America.

title: A VEXING ISSUE IN AD MERGERS
description: On Madison Avenue, the gospel has always been that if you help Procter & Gamble sell Ivory soap, you cannot tout Colgate toothpaste - much less Palmolive soap - for Procter's archrival, the Colgate-Palmolive Company.

title: ENSOURCE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a $14.5 million writedown of oil and gas properties. c-Net income. The company said its shareholders approved a previously proposed 1-for- 10 reverse stock split.

title: LANGLEY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
ROPER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Fotomat Gets Buyout Offer
description: The Konishiroku Photo Industry Company, which makes Konica cameras and film, offered yesterday to pay $1.625 a share in cash, or a total of $16.4 million, for the 40 percent of the ailing Fotomat Corporation that it does not already own.

title: Ted Bates Head Bares Facts on Saatchi Job
description: Robert E. Jacoby, chairman and chief executive of Ted Bates Worldwide, has a contract with Saatchi & Saatchi, his acquirer, to continue at that job and that job only.

title: INSIDER INQUIRY
description: The names of 13 oil companies - all former takeover targets - are part of a list of 102 stocks the Securities and Exchange Commission is circulating on Wall Street to find anyone who has evidence to link Dennis B. Levine, a former Wall Street merger executive, or anyone else, to insider trading, sources close to the investigation said yesterday.

title: JOHNNY CARSON'S TWO NEW RIVALS
description: ONCE again, Johnny Carson is facing challenges to his pre-eminence as the nation's favorite talk-show host. In the past, his competitors have included, just to mention a few, Dick Cavett, David Frost, Geraldo Rivera, Alan Thicke and Jerry Lewis. This time, however, there is an unusual twist. Come autumn, Mr. Carson will be squaring off against Joan Rivers and David Brenner, both of whom got major career boosts on Mr. Carson's ''Tonight'' show. For Carson fans, the scenario could be entitled ''Ingratitude.'' Miss Rivers and Mr. Brenner undoubtedly see themselves as participating in the all-American game of ''Go for It.''

title: CHAPMAN ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a writedown of $20,485,182 for oil and gas gathering and transmission systems. c-Net income

title: SIGMA RESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Sell the Saudis Defense Equipment
description: Congress's rejection of the proposed arms sale to Saudi Arabia helps neither the cause of regional peace nor Israel's security. The Administration's case for what should be a routine sale is strong. The sale would reinforce our strategic interests in the Persian Gulf, maintain a 40-year relationship of supporting the defense of Saudi Arabia, and reduce the possibility that we might have to commit American troops to protect our interests. It would also send a clear signal to Iran not to expand its war with Iraq to other parts of the region.

title: SWEET VICTORY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bones Give Clues
description: Stunted growth in the first years of life can damage health throughout adulthood, a new study says. Researchers working with skeletons found in Illinois have concluded that American Indians who had smaller than normal spinal cord openings in their backbones, a mark of stunted growth, died younger than other Indians found. The results are to be published in the June issue of The American Journal of Physical Anthropology.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: The Lions' House
description: The New York Public Library is a grand place, what with its guardian lions and long facade and awesome stacks. Lunch is eaten on its front steps.

title: Washington State Sets $625 Million of Bonds
description: The State of Washington is offering about $625 million of new general obligation bonds to refund outstanding bonds sold in 1983 and 1984, when interest rates were higher. In recent weeks, more than half of all new tax-exempt bond issues have been sold to refund outstanding high-interest debt.

title: Oil Futures End Above $17 a Barrel
description: Strong demand for gasoline pushed crude oil prices up by about $1 a barrel yesterday, to close above $17 for the first time in more than three months.

title: BALTIMORE GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Year to April 30
H & H OIL TOOL CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Steger Expedition's Edge Over Peary's and Cook's
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, MAY 20, 1986
description: International

title: FONAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $690,000 for the quarter and $810,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss

title: G & K SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
HAVERFORD HONOR IS REJECTED
description: Drew Lewis, the former Secretary of Transportation, stunned an audience by declining an honorary degree from Haverford College because of faculty objections to his actions in the 1981 strike by air traffic controllers.

title: John Blair To Fight Suit
description: John Blair & Company, a mail marketing and broadcasting company, said yesterday that it would move to dismiss a lawsuit in Delaware state court that seeks to block Blair from getting rid of Advo Systems Inc., a coupon distribution subsidiary.

title: TEAM MAY HAVE CLUES TO ELUSIVE NEUTRINOS
description: THE mystery of the missing solar neutrinos, one of the most vexing problems in physics, may have been solved at last by two Soviet scientists.

title: FAIRFIELD-NOBLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Michelob Goes To Needham
description: After about five months of playing its three agencies against one another, Anheuser-Busch has decided to switch its Michelob brand to Needham Harper Worldwide, Chicago, from Ted Bates Advertising/ New York.

title: FLOATING POINT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Filming at the Apthorp
description: Bullhorns blasted the calm of the protected courtyard of the Apthorp yesterday at 6:30 A.M. Residents looked out to see a spaghetti-like tangle of cables, a blaze of lights and nine fancy cars, including two Ferraris, with Rome license plates.

title: STARRETT HOUSING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ASPIN CRITICIZES PENTAGON ON CUTS
description: The chairman of the House Armed Services Committee today criticized as simplistic a list of weapons the Pentagon says might have to be cut to meet military budget goals set by the House of Representatives.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: THE heat is on and the fashion crowd is going out more wearing less. Thierry Mugler, the Paris fashion designer, was in New York Wednesday to be host at the Palladium's first anniversary party. Larissa, a fur designer, fed him and his friends beforehand at Cafe Sphinx.

title: AERO SERVICES INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: SHIFT OF ITS OFFICES LINKS NEW YORK TO BITTER RIVAL
description: To reach New York City's representatives in Washington from now on, you will have to go to New Jersey. New Jersey Avenue, that is.

title: ZIMBABWE AND ZAMBIA ARE DEFIANT AFTER THE BULLETS AND BOMBS SUBSIDE
description: This morning, hours after South African commandos descended on this capital, glass and rubble littered Angwa Street in the downtown business district. All of it was from the shattered white cement building that had housed an office of the African National Congress.

title: RADIATION TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the results were affected by a 13-day shutdown in March at its Rockaway, N.J. facility.

title:
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
Seats Aplenty
description: Yesterday was the first day of the seven-month, $50 million renovation of Carnegie Hall. Workers took down the curtain, dismantled the stage and ripped up the floor.

title: STORES SAY NEW YORK LEADS FASHION RACE
description: The New York fashion collections have received raves from local retailers who find the fall and winter clothes introduced earlier this month dramatic, luxurious and wearable.

title: Amway Payment To Settle Charges
description: The Amway Corporation will pay a $100,000 civil penalty to settle a Government lawsuit accusing it of misrepresenting the earnings potential of its distributors, the Justice Department said.

title: Integrated Shifts Focus From Tax-Shelter Deals
description: The $300 million purchase of a Manhattan office building at 666 Fifth Avenue by Integrated Resources Inc. is one of the biggest deals so far for the financial services concern. ''It's one of the world-class buildings,'' said Selig A. Zises, Integrated's chairman and chief executive. ''We thought we bought it at a very good price.''

title: C.I.A. DIRECTOR REQUESTS INQUIRY ON NBC REPORT
description: The Director of Central Intelligence said today that he had asked the Justice Department to consider prosecuting the National Broadcasting Company on a charge of broadcasting a report containing classified information.

title: Why France Said No
description: The wave of resentment toward France for its refusal to allow American jets to fly over that country to strike at Libya has begun to recede, but we should take time to assess the implications of this reaction in the cold light of reason.

title: GIANTS SHOW STATURE AGAIN
description: The Mets got their first look of the year at San Francisco today, and found all the old charm still there: Little cable cars climbing halfway to the stars, the Golden Gate Bridge piercing the morning fog, the rows of Victorian houses gracing Russian Hill.

title: WHAT TO DO WHEN YOUR PRINTER WON'T PRINT
description: HAVING just finished composing a letter, report or other document on your computer, you sigh with relief, instruct the machine to send the text to the printer and sit back expectantly, waiting for the final product to be delivered. Nothing happens. Or the printer turns out a pageful of lines on which appear the impressions of only the top half of each character. Or there's nothing but a string of 's where your breathless prose should have been.

title: ANDOVER SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings are not available since Andover Savings converted from mutual to stock form on May 8.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: INTEREST RATES RISE SLIGHTLY
description: Interest rates rose modestly yesterday. Some market participants, worrying about fading prospects for additional rate declines, were reducing their holdings of long-term issues that would be most vulnerable to price declines if rates go up.

title: 'BE THE BEST YOU CAN BE'
description: Shortly after 9 o'clock yesterday morning, about 400 student-athletes in 16 sports who will be entering more than 100 different colleges this fall were listening to Senator Bill Bradley.

title: DONALDSON CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $2.1 million.

title: BURROUGHS IS REJECTED IN NEW BID
description: The Burroughs Corporation yesterday raised its offer for Sperry Corporation to $75 a share, or about $4.6 billion, but Sperry angrily rejected the new offer.

title: GANNETT GETS LOUISVILLE PAPERS FOR 300 MILLION
description: The Gannett Company, the nation's largest newspaper group, has agreed to pay about $300 million for the Courier-Journal and Louisville Times Company, both companies announced yesterday.

title: Conviction in Treason Case
description: A 44-year-old linguist was sentenced to 10 years in prison today on a treason conviction. Helene Passtoors, a Belgian and Dutch citizen, was convicted of helping to set up arms caches for the African National Congress and of trying to arrange an escape from South Africa for a congress member. Klaas De Jonge, who was arrested with her last June, escaped from police custody and has been holed up since then in the Dutch Embassy in Pretoria.

title: Futuristic
description: Never one to miss an opportunity to plug an Oregon industry, Representative Les AuCoin of Portland, a Democrat, is inviting his House colleagues to drop by his office today to peer into a machine developed by a company called Eyedentify Inc. of Beaverton, Ore.

title: INDIAN BONES: BALANCING RESEARCH GOALS AND TRIBES' RIGHTS
description: THOUSANDS of Indian skeletons have been uncovered over the years by grave robbers, construction workers, archeologists and natural erosion. Until a decade ago, the remains were commonly taken to museums to be put on public display or into storage, where they were made available for study by physical anthropologists and forensic scientists.

title: To Serve Us at the U.N.
description: To the Editor:

title: LUXURIOUS AT-HOME CLOTHES
description: Fernando Sanchez, who makes a low-cost lingerie collection for Vanity Fair as well as his own lingerie-based signature collection for both sexes, sniffs politely at the word lingerie.

title: DYNAMIC HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PACKWOOD FACES OREGON PRIMARY CHALLENGE
description: Senator Bob Packwood, a Republican, has a strong lead in the polls in his race for renomination in the Oregon primary Tuesday.

title: NEW 'EARS' WILL LISTEN FOR VOYAGER'S SIGNALS
description: BY the time Voyager 2 reaches Neptune on Aug. 24, 1989, the sturdy spacecraft will be some 2.7 billion miles from Earth, and its historic transmissions will be exceedingly difficult to hear. Even travelling at the speed of light, a signal from Voyager will take 4 hours 10 minutes to reach Earth.

title: GAMBLING ON IMPROVING THE SCHOOLS
description: When the Carnegie Forum on Education and the Economy last week issued its first report, ''A Nation Prepared: Teachers for the 21st Century'' it took a giant gamble: That all those who are unhappy about the state of the schools are willing to support a major revolution instead of being satisfied with minor tinkering.

title: PRESIDENTIAL LIFE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes capital gains of $2,200,000. c-Includes capital gains of $252,000 and an extraodinary credit of $811,000. The share earnings reflect 2-for-1 stock split paid Jan. 10.

title: PHOTOGRAPHIC SCIENCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $14,500. c-Includes a tax credit of $105,800 and a gain of $168,225 on the early extinguishment of debt.

title: HEALTHWAYS SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SUNSTATES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $73,000. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $194,000 and a tax credit of $135,000. The year-ago results were restated due to the company's discontinuance of its residential division in December 1985.

title: BUCCANEERS GET POWELL IN TRADE
description: The Tampa Bay Buccaneers attempted to get some running room for Bo Jackson yesterday by trading for the Jets' former all-pro tackle, Marvin Powell.

title: CO-OPERATIVE BANK OF CONORD reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Latest quarter share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in April 1986. The company converted to public ownership in December 1985, so per share earnings are available only for the latest quarter.

title: Puerto Rican Offering Priced
description: A $160 million issue of Commonwealth of Puerto Rico general obligation bonds was tentatively priced yesterday through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company with a maximum yield of about 8 percent for 7 7/8 percent bonds due in 2011 at a price of 98.50.

title: LUCKY STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
U.N. GIVES ISRAELIS WAR CRIME FILES
description: The United Nations today gave Israel the War Crimes Commission files on 347 Nazi war criminals and suspects.

title: CELCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss The company was formerly known as Cellufone Corp.

title: PETROLEUM INVESTMENTS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income. The latest quarter results reflect a $6.8 million writedown of oil and gas reserves.

title: 3 States Bar Activities By LaRouche Concern
description: A fund-raising company affiliated with the political extremist Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. has been barred by three states from activities in which it had been persuading people to lend thousands of dollars on the strength of promissory notes. The practice is under investigation in at least three more states.

title: U.S. Trade: A Case of Needless Protection
description: To the Editor:

title: PRETORIA'S FORCES RAID 3 NEIGHBORS IN MOVE ON REBELS
description: South African forces attacked the capitals of Botswana, Zambia and Zimbabwe today in what military officials said was part of a continuing drive against guerrillas of the African National Congress.

title: Condemned Killer Wins 5-Hour Stay of Execution
description: Lawyers for Ronald J. Straight, scheduled to be executed at 7 A.M. Tuesday for murdering a Jacksonville storekeeper, prepared a last-minute appeal to the United States Supreme Court today after an appeals court refused to block the execution.

title: INTERAND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AS COMPUTERS GET SMARTER, SO DO THE USERS
description: PERSONAL COMPUTING magazine, the country's largest-circulation computer magazine, recently conducted a telephone survey with a sampling of its readers to find out how they use computers. It turns out that the readers think they are quite a bit smarter about computers than they were a year ago.

title: SPEX GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Where to See The Shorebirds
description: Migrating shorebirds feed on many beaches of the Delaware Bay in both New Jersey and Delaware. Especially good spots for viewing high concentrations of crabs and birds are Reeds Beach, Villas and Norburys Landing in Cape May County, N.J., and Moores Beach in neighboring Cumberland County.

title: ADVERTISING IN THE POST-MARTINI AGE
description: Edward N. Ney's enduring image of his early days on Madison Avenue is a glass of milk sitting on an account executive's desk.

title: BROCK CALLS ON TEAMSTERS TO RID UNION OF CORRUPTION
description: Saying that the International Brotherhood of Teamsters had ''lost a great deal of public trust,'' Labor Secretary Bill Brock called on the union and its leaders today to rid itself of corruption.

title: JOHN BUBBLES, THE DANCER, IS DEAD AT 84
description: John Bubbles, who invented rhythm tap dancing and portrayed the original Sportin' Life in George Gershwin's opera ''Porgy and Bess,'' died Sunday night at his home in Baldwin Hills. He was 84 years old.

title: Fed Bank Loan Rates
description: The Federal Reserve Board said today that it would require commercial banks to pay higher interest charges for certain emergency loans from the central bank.

title: Coca-Cola Iced Tea
description: Coca-Cola U.S.A. said that it would introduce a fountain-dispensed iced tea for use by the food-service industry.

title: GOULD INVESTORS TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After gains on disposition of properties, mortgages and investments of $241,000 for the quarter and $311,000 for the 6 months and net of $49,000 and a loss of $306,000 from minority interest in subsidiaries for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-After gains on disposition of properties, mortgages and investments of $959,000 for the quarter and $1,145,000 for the 6 months and losses from minority interest of $333,000 and $474,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Revenue represents gross revenue.

title: HUBCO EXPLORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and includes an extraordinary tax credit of $41,435.

title: The Big Spenders In Our Jury Boxes
description: To the Editor:

CIRCLE FINE ART CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Finance Company Preferred Stock
description: The Household Finance Corporation is offering $75 million of exchangeable money market preferred stock with an initial dividend of 4.85 percent through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers.

title: FINANCIAL DATA LISTED BY 6 SENATORS
description: The assets of the six United States Senators from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut ranged from none to more than $4 million, according to financial disclosure reports filed yesterday in Washington.

title: PRATT HOTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and includes a tax credit of $41,000.

title: Whitworth Spy Trial Finishes Major Phase
description: Prosecutors finished presenting evidence today intended to link Jerry A. Whitworth to espionage activities. They called Michael L. Walker, a member of the Walker family spy ring, to the witness stand.

title: GRAND CENTRAL PUT IN DARKNESS BY POWER LOSS
description: The lights went out in Grand Central Terminal last night. The gold hands of the big clock over the main entrance froze at 7:03, as did the large train-information board. But homebound commuters hardly skipped a beat as they proceeded through the unaccustomed twilight to trains that kept running.

title: U.S. VOICES 'OUTRAGE'
description: The Reagan Administration expressed ''outrage'' today over the South African military attacks.

title: FROM MEDICAL CARE TO SPIRITUAL CARE
description: When a new Roman Catholic priest gives his first mass, there is great excitement in a church, and, afterward, for good luck, people line up to get a special blessing from him.

title: PACKAGING SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $435,000, or 39 cents a share, from the sale of business. c-Includes a gain of $482,000, or 43 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of change in method of accounting for investment tax credit.

title: Leader of Strike at Base Is Slain in Philippines
description: Gunmen today shot to death the Filipino leader of a recent strike at a United States air base.

title: HEARINGS ON HOLD FOR A DEAVER TRIP
description: Michael K. Deaver left today for a one-week business trip to South Korea, delaying his return appearance before a Congressional committee that is examining conflict-of-interest charges against him.

title: AFTER 56 YEARS, YACHT OF 'CHEERFUL LOSER' IS BACK
description: Her 16-story-high mast barely edging under the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, Shamrock V, the fifth and last of Sir Thomas J. Lipton's America's Cup challenge yachts, sailed majestically into New York Harbor early yesterday morning.

title: COATED SALES INC reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
ASSOCIATED COMMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
New Stars On the Circuit
description: THERE is just no keeping up with Henry and Carolyne Roehm Kravis. He makes big money. She makes important clothes. And after yet another hectic day, they withdraw to a handsomely baronial duplex to take stock.

title: DOLE EYES A NOVEL WAY OUT OF TAX SQUEEZE
description: Bob Dole, the Senate Republican leader, said today that he would support using a first-year increase in revenue from tax overhaul legislation to provide the revenue increase proposed by the House and the Senate 1987 budgets.

title: Andretti Pushed Back
description: Mario Andretti lost 28 places on the starting grid yesterday for Sunday's Indianapolis 500, and he was not even in Indianapolis. Instead of starting in the middle of the second row, he will be in the back of the pack.

title: Hand-to-Hand Zapping
description: For many years electric utilities have sought, through circuit breakers and other measures, to avoid overloads that magnetic storms can induce in very long power lines. A major storm can induce relatively high voltages in any long conductor.

title: BIG LOBBYING GUNS LINING UP TO OPPOSE ANTISMOKING BILL
description: An array of lawyers, lobbyists and public-relations people, among the best known and most powerful in New York City, have mobilized to fight Mayor Koch's proposed legislation to restrict smoking in public.

title: SHAREDATA INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes charges of $318,000 relating to the purchase of Electric Book Co. for both quarter and 9 months, and charges of $15,600 and $31,200 for its acquisition of Computer Technology for the same periods, respectively. c-Net loss Year-ago quarter and 9-month revenue figures are not comparable because the company was still in its development stage.

title: NICARAGUA SPURNS ARMS LIMIT PLAN
description: Nicaragua has rejected a proposal to include arms controls in a regional peace treaty, saying the provision would hinder its war against United States-backed insurgents, officials here said.

title: NVF CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $708,000 from the termination of a pension plan.

title: LONG ISLAND LIGHTING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AMERICAN HOME PATIENT CENTERS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

All figures are restated to include results of Hearing Centers of America, Inc., acquired in 1985.

Vollenweider, a scientist with the Canadian Government whose 1968 report on the pollution of the Great Lakes inspired successful cleanup efforts by Canada and the United States.

SAGE DRILLING CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
The Pastime According to Charlie O.
description: Seven things that Charles O. Finley, the last of baseball's great innovators, would do to improve the game: 1. Give the batter a walk on three balls instead of four. ''There've been four balls and three strikes since 1889 - 97 years in which pitchers have been getting bigger and stronger, and the fielders helped by better gloves and improved playing surfaces. It's time to give the offense a boost.'' 2. Schedule interleague play. ''It would be baseball's greatest attendance shot in the arm since Babe Ruth.'' 3. Require the National League to institute the designated hitter. ''The average pitcher couldn't get a hit off my grandma. The d.h. puts more action into the game, and National League fans deserve it too.'' 4. Switch from white baseballs to orange, an old Finley idea. ''It would help batters see the ball and put a vivid color into the game. And fans, especially people watching on TV, could follow the ball more easily.'' 5. Introduce a 20-second clock, requiring pitchers to deliver to the plate before time expired unless there were runners on base. ''The 20-second limit is already in the rule book but never enforced. The clock would speed up the game and finally put a time element into baseball. It would be exciting to see time running out, as in basketball, football and hockey.'' 6. Allow a designated runner. ''He could run the bases for someone else a maximum of three times, and the base runner he replaced could stay in the game.

title: 13 Die in Thai Bus Fire
description: Thirteen people were burned to death and 12 were injured today in a bus fire 67 miles north of Bangkok that began when the driver tried to restart the engine as the conductor tried to fill the gasoline tank, the provincial police said.

description: A bicyclist was crushed to death yesterday morning under the rear wheels of a city bus that struck him on Third Avenue at 55th Street in Manhattan, the police said.

description: The Reagan Administration is divided over whether a Central American peace treaty being put together by a number of Latin American nations can be salvaged as an instrument acceptable to the United States, according to Administration officials.

title: SPRING RITE OF GLUTTONY FATTENS BIRDS FOR JOURNEY
description: Every May the normally tranquil shores of the Delaware Bay are transformed into a frenzy of life as a million migrating shorebirds stop by to partake of the nearest thing to a free lunch that nature has to offer.

title: OFFICIAL DENIES KNOWING OF A CLIENT'S CRIME TIES
description: A member of the city's Planning Commission said yesterday that he was unaware that a private law client was a reputed organized-crime figure, and that he had stopped representing him after his indictment on gambling and murder charges.

description: The Supreme Court today effectively barred natural gas pipeline companies from requiring customers to pay for unused gas each month.

JULY 4 IN CITY: CLOSED ROADS, OPEN CAMPSITES
description: New York City, preparing for the flood of visitors expected for the Statue of Liberty centennial celebration, announced yesterday that it would close major arteries, open space for thousands of campers, put every possible bus and subway train into service and deploy an army of police officers during parts of the four-day July 4 weekend.

title: HUGHES SUPPLY INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Year-ago figures are restated to include Carolina Pump & Supply Co., acquired in July, as a pooling of interest.

title: New York Transit Needs More Capital
description: Gleaming steel and classic burgundy denote the acquisition and renovation of fresh subway cars for New Yorkers. They also make good on promises of long-deferred capital improvement. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority therefore deserves the financial support it needs to carry the program through 1989, but its sources must still be nailed down. Increasing the capital subsidy makes far more sense than holding investment hostage to fare increases.

title: UNANIMOUS DECISION TO TYSON
description: The unbeaten heavyweight Mike Tyson pounded out a lopsided and unanimous decision over Mitch (Blood) Green last night in a 10-round bout at Madison Square Garden to gain the 21st victory of his career.

title: THE ARTIST BEHIND TIMES SQUARE'S GAUDY GLOW
description: The Municipal Art Society, no less, endorses the artwork of Tobias Buchman; is eager for more; wishes it were even more, yes, gaudy. ''The gaudier the better,'' said Virginia Dajani, associate director of the august group.

title: STAGE: 'FUNNY GIRL' AT EQUITY LIBRARY THEATER
description: ''F UNNY GIRL,'' the musical that catapulted the young Barbra Streisand into the stratosphere in 1964, is a star vehicle if ever there was one. Its portrait of Fanny Brice, an ambitious, insecure kook, bursting at the seams with a talent that is matched only by an unbridled chutzpah, is a plum that requires a larger-than-life performer - and not necessarily Miss Streisand - to make it breathe with excitement. At the very least it demands someone with the compulsive clown's instincts to show off and turn everything into a shtick - someone so self-dramatizing that even off the stage she is giving a performance.

title: SPYING SUSPECT: A STUDY IN CONTRASTS
description: For a few years in the early 1980's, Ronald W. Pelton would go to a kitchen for homeless men in inner-city Washington two or three times a week to help serve breakfast. Friends said he was successful as a salesman, a witty person who was pleasant to be with, always ready to give help when needed.

IS THAT ALL THERE IS?
description: Something's missing. Chris Evert Lloyd, in an article on her in the June issue of Life magazine, says, regarding her life as a tennis champion and the wife of the British tennis player John Lloyd: ''We get into a rut. We play tennis, we go to a movie, we watch TV, but I keep saying, 'John, there has to be more.' ''

title: DORSEY ADDS BULK TO GIANTS
description: The first thing you notice about Eric Dorsey is his size. It's not so much his height and weight, it's the muscles on his 283 pounds and 6 feet 5 inches.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SHORT WALK ''Ly Still dear Bads (babies) and Take yor rest/God cald you hom becas he thoug it best.'' These are words from the gravestone of one buried in the graveyard of Trinity Church, the first Protestant Episcopal church established in the United States. Not quite so old is the 140-year-old current Trinity Church building, which stands dark and stern on Broadway at the head of Wall Street. Around the church is a postage stamp-size graveyard where many celebrated and uncelebrated have, as a poet put it, lain down to pleasant dreams.

title: SCHOONER SURVIVORS DESCRIBE ORDEAL
description: In a moment frozen in their minds, surviving crew members from the Pride of Baltimore were quoted today describing how the schooner was hit by a wall of wind that forced her port rail deep into a squall-driven sea, shuddering as the ship failed to recover as more water poured into her sleek hull.

title: Advertising; Interpublic Group Adds Mega-Mergers to Goals
description: As the Interpublic Group of Companies, the granddaddy operator of global agency networks, had its annual meeting yesterday, Philip H. Geier Jr., chairman and chief executive, talked about mega-mergers and promised some of the same.

Hurley, of 71 Pineapple Street in Brooklyn Heights, originally identified as a messenger, had worked at the restaurant for about a year, and had just been promoted from first cook to head chef, Jan Fried, the restaurant's owner, said.

title: BURNS STILL CLINGS TO COMEBACK HOPE
description: He has hopes. To walk and to run again without fear of prolonged pain. To throw a baseball easily. To stand on a pitcher's mound. To pitch at Yankee Stadium. To win once more in the big leagues.

description: International A terrorist implicated Syria in the Rome airport attack last December, according to American officials. title: Donahue Dispute Unsettled
description: Phil Donahue, the television talk-show host, and a pro-nuclear demonstrator with whom he had a fist fight May 11 at La Guardia Airport failed to mediate their differences yesterday. The second man, William Ferguson Jr., 24 years old, said he would file an assault complaint against Mr. Donahue, 50, in Queens Criminal Court. Mr. Donahue said he would not file a complaint against Mr. Ferguson.

description: The defensive specialists, the patient ones, were robust tonight for a change.

title: Broncos to Sign Dudek
description: Joe Dudek, the 6-foot-1-inch, 194-pound running back from Plymouth (N.H.) State College who last fall set National Collegiate Athletic Association all-division career records for touchdowns (79) and points scored (474), has reached an agreement to sign a free-agent contract with the Denver Broncos. Dudek, who was not selected in the National Football League college draft on April 29 even though he finished ninth in balloting for the Heisman Trophy, is expected to sign with the Broncos today or tomorrow in Denver.

title: AMERICAN FIBER OPTICS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Advertising; Army Account Up for Grabs
description: Less than a month after an N.W. Ayer executive who worked on the Army recruiting account pleaded guilty in Federal court to taking kickbacks from suppliers, the Army announced yesterday that it was putting the account up for competition several years before it has to.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''When the best city in the world throws the best party in the world, the entire world is invited.'' - Mayor Koch, on plans for the Statue of Liberty centennial. [ A1:4. ]

title: HOLLYWOOD'S SUMMER SWEEPSTAKES
description: Summer began for Hollywood last weekend.

title: BEST MEMPHIS RIBS WORE MUSTARD COAT
description: ANY good cook knows that great barbecue sauce has to have a special ingredient.
