description: b-Includes a charge of $3,500,000 to settle litigation.

title: Eurobond Data
description: The Association of International Bond Dealers said today that it would establish a new system for reporting Eurobond prices. Starting Sept. 1, participating firms will be required to electronically report each trade and to disclose daily its last bid and offered price for a bond issue.

title: Mercenary Camp Head Accused of Conspiracy
description: Frank Camper, the operator of the Mercenary School in Dolomite, a village just southwest of here, has been charged with conspiring with two California women to blow up the cars of disgruntled employees of the school. No one was hurt in the incident Aug. 13.

title: S.E.C. CUTS STOCK LIST IN INQUIRY
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday delivered to Judge Richard Owen of Federal District Court in Manhattan the names of nine stocks on which it plans to build its insider trading case against Dennis B. Levine, a former Wall Street merger executive.

title: French Election Plan Provokes a Walkout
description: Socialist and Communist members of Parliament walked out of the National Assembly in protest today as the conservative Government presented a plan to change the way legislative elections are held.

title: Fake Pictures at an Exhibition
description: A distinguished-looking browser at McIntosh-Drysdale Gallery last weekend asked the price of a colorful print by the Spanish surrealist Joan Miro.

title: BIRTHDAY GALA FOR SAKHAROV AT TOWN HALL
description: It was a birthday party to remember. There were offerings of roses and lilacs, music and poetry by Russian emigre artists, a gift from Afghan insurgents and a cake with 65 candles.

title: Cyclone in South Pacific Leaves 35,000 Homeless
description: A cyclone struck this South Pacific island chain on Monday, flattening villages, sweeping victims out to sea and leaving homeless an estimated 35,000 people.

title: Advertising; Avrett, Free & Ginsberg Has Day of Good News
description: Frank Ginsberg, the 41-year-old senior executive vice president of Avrett, Free & Ginsberg, has been promoted to president, and at the same time the agency has got a new $8 million account.

title: AIR FORCE STUDIES DELAYING SHUTTLE
description: The Air Force is seriously considering delaying the first space shuttle launching from a new West Coast facility until 1991, when a replacement for the shuttle Challenger might become available, Pentagon officials said today.

title: THEODORE WHITE IS EULOGIZED FOR VITALITY AND INTELLIGENCE
description: Theodore H. White, who chronicled America's Presidential elections in the 60's and 70's, was remembered yesterday as a man of boundless vitality who ''transformed and energized American political reporting'' and ''taught a generation of Americans how their politics worked.''

title: DOC OPTICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Gannett's Neuharth Gives Up Chief's Job
description: John J. Curley, president of the Gannett Company, the nation's largest newspaper group, was named chief executive officer of the company yesterday in a surprise announcement by Allen H. Neuharth, who said he would give up his title as chief executive but remain as Gannett's chairman.

title: COAST GUARD BOARD TO BEGIN FORMAL INQUIRY INTO SINKING
description: Coast Guard officials said yesterday that they would convene a formal board of inquiry tomorrow to investigate the loss of the Pride of Baltimore, the sleek clipper ship that went down north of Puerto Rico last week, leaving 4 members of her 12-person crew missing at sea.

title: Pretoria Strikes Out
description: No one doubts the armed might of South Africa or its ability to pummel defenseless neighbors like Zambia, Botswana and Zimbabwe. Monday's commando raids against ''terrorists'' housed in those countries said nothing new about Pretoria's military prowess. What the assaults betray again is the political weakness of a beleaguered white minority regime. Instead of moving toward open negotiation with the various leaders of South Africa's blacks, it strikes at already disenfranchised and exiled rebels to placate white diehards. The world will unite to condemn this policy, portending disaster for all South Africans.

title: BOONTON ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A President For Honeywell
description: James J. Renier, vice chairman of Honeywell Inc., the information processing and control systems company, has been named to the new positions of president and chief operating officer. Mr. Renier, who is 56 years old, will report to Edson W. Spencer, the Minneapolis-based company's chairman and chief executive.

title: HEATED RUNNERS, HEATED PROTESTS
description: It was sweltering in hilly Pittsburgh on Sunday, and for nearly 3,000 runners it took a special act of will just to stay in the Pittsburgh Marathon. At least two of them, however, had some special help.

title: BLACKOUT AT GRAND CENTRAL ENDS, WITH BUSINESSES TALLYING LOSSES
description: The lights were back on throughout most of Grand Central Terminal early yesterday afternoon, nearly 18 hours after a power failure darkened the terminal and seven surrounding buildings.

title: AMERICAN SURGERY CENTERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MID PACIFIC AIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and includes income from discontinued operations of $85,757. The 1986 first quarter includes the combined results of Mid Pacific Airlines Inc. and Kampgrounds of America Inc.

title: Coping With Mussels
description: ONE of my favorite summertime meals is mussels steamed in white wine with shallots and garlic. They make a superb first course to any meal or a wonderful light entree. At this time of year, all sizes and varieties of mussels are available, and they are practically foolproof to prepare - when the shells open, the mussels are cooked. The only time-consuming aspect is cleaning the shells thoroughly so no sand or grit gets into the broth.

title: MAY DEPARTMENT STORES CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $4.6 million from an installment on the sale of a store and a pre-tax charge of $5.2 million related to the closing of its downtown Strouss/Kaufmann's department stores in Youngstown, Ohio and New Castle, Pa.

title: NO. 2 POLICE OFFICIAL RETIRING
description: Patrick J. Murphy, the No. 2 official in the city's Police Department, said yesterday that he would retire next month to become vice president for worldwide security at Merrill Lynch & Company.

title: Oil Rigs at a Low
description: The number of operating oil drilling rigs in the United States fell again this week to a postwar low of 757, according to the Hughes Tool Company, which conducts a weekly count. Last week the number of operating rigs totaled 809, five fewer than the previous postwar low of 814, reported on March 15, 1971.

title: SIZING UP STEEL BOOTS FOR SCOFFLAWS' AUTOS
description: With an eye for romance, Ross Sandler, New York City's Transportation Commissioner, calls it ''a Cinderella story - trying to find the right boot'' for the city's scofflaws.

title: BISTRO'S CLIENTELE SPECULATES OVER LUNCH
description: The two hungry diners sat down, turned expectantly to a flickering computer screen on a nearby stand and began studying the latest quotations. The news seemed ominous. Making money would not be easy in today's luncheon market.

title: The Crash of the QN
description: What was to have been a triumphal explanation by the inventor of how his pterodactyl model soared 500 feet above Washington appears likely to be more of a post-mortem on its demise. Tomorrow night at the National Museum of Natural History, Paul MacCready faces the unenviable task of giving a detailed explanation of why the Quetzalcoatlus northropi, a halfsize model of a prehistoric flying reptile, crashed last Saturday before several thousand dinosaur-lovers at Andrews Air Force Base.

title: KINCAID FURNITURE CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Tax-Exempt Offerings Go Fast at Higher Rates
description: The tax-exempt bond market readily accommodated a heavy supply of new high-grade general obligation issues yesterday. Securities dealers estimated that the new issues were offered with yields as much as 3/8 percentage point higher than last week's levels, and they added that investor demand was very strong at the higher interest rates.

title: YANKEES BEATEN IN NINTH; A'S 2, YANKEES 1
description: The 22 runs and 29 hits the Yankees amassed in a pair of weekend victories over Seattle should be characteristic of the Yankees' offense, but in reality they were uncharacteristic. The 2-1 loss they suffered to the Oakland A's last night was more representative of the team's perplexing state of hitting this season.

title: NESTOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The share earnings and shares outstanding figures reflect a 100 percent stock dividend paid on Jan. 2, 1986. The company said that work on development programs which has generated revenues for the company to date has been completed and Nestor Inc. is negotiating new development contracts.

title: VOTING CLOSE ON FORCING A MOFFETT-O'NEILL PRIMARY
description: Former United States Representative Toby Moffett said tonight that he won enough local primary elections across the state today to force Gov. William A. O'Neill into a statewide Democratic primary election in September. However, Mr. O'Neill's supporters said that Mr. Moffett had fallen short of the 270 convention delegates he would need to qualify for a statewide primary.

title: MUSIC: 'I MARRIED AN ANGEL'
description: THE original Broadway production of Rodgers and Hart's 1938 hit show ''I Married an Angel'' is fondly remembered for elements that the most meticulous concert revival couldn't begin to reproduce. One is the globe-trotting ''Honeymoon Ballet,'' created by George Balanchine and performed by Vera Zorina, that culminated in a glorious theatrical blizzard. Another is Balanchine's equally lavish show-stopping second-act ballet, ''At the Roxy Music Hall,'' which scathingly satirized the Radio City Music Hall and the Rockettes.

title: MOST OF NEW TAX RULES PREDICTED FOR NEXT JAN. 1
description: An Assistant Secretary of the Treasury told a group of tax accountants today that most provisions of any tax-revision legislation enacted by Congress would take effect no earlier than Jan. 1, 1987.

title: Dent and Bears at Odds
description: Richard Dent, the Chicago Bears' defensive end who was voted the most valuable player in Chicago's victory over New England in Super Bowl XX in January, seems likely to be playing for another National Football League team this fall. ''We've gone as far as we're going to go,'' Jerry Vainisi, the Bears' general manager, said yesterday.

title: MANY NURSING HOMES ARE FOUND TO FAIL MINIMUM U.S. STANDARDS
description: At least one-third of the nursing homes that serve the nation's most severely ill patients fail to meet minimum Government standards, a Senate committee charged today. Some of the homes resemble ''19th century asylums,'' the committee chairman said.

title: MUSIC: NEW WORK BY STEPHEN ALBERT
description: ITS mysteries notwithstanding, composing music is also a business. An individual makes an artifact to be used or sold, hoping from it to feed himself, clothe his children and somehow create the protective space to make life bearable. So it will always be. Stephen Albert's ''Flower of the Mountain,'' played by the Y Chamber Symphony at the 92d Street Y Saturday night, is no different. This setting of Molly Bloom's famous monologue (the words with which James Joyce's ''Ulysses'' so rapturously and affirmatively ends) is as gracious and accommodating to the ears as any recent music could be. The orchestra is ripe and Romantic, the soprano solos scarcely less so. ''Flower of the Mountain'' works hard to please and does so with considerable skill.

title: AMERICAN MEDICAL BUILDINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: On Patrol on 42d St.
description: The Guardian Angels, the volunteer patrollers who started in the subways, are moving above ground, on 42d Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues.

title: DISABLED VIEW THEIR GAINS
description: THE majority of Americans with disabilities feel the quality of their life has improved in the last decade, according to a recent survey conducted by Louis Harris & Associates for the International Center for the Disabled in New York. Two-thirds of those polled say the change comes from opportunities created 10 years ago by a Federal law barring discrimination in programs receiving Federal funds.

title: U.S. AIDES SAID TO HAVE DISCUSSED PROSECUTING NEWS ORGANIZATIONS
description: In the past 25 years, Government officials have discussed numerous times whether to prosecute news organizations for disclosing highly sensitive material, according to former officials.

title: Driver Says He Forgot Bus's Size Before Crash
description: The driver of the double-decker bus that smashed into a railroad trestle on Sunday, killing one passenger and injuring several others, told authorities today that he had forgotten he was driving the larger vehicle.

title: Bucks to the Rescue
description: A financially troubled Shawano County farmer will get Coach Don Nelson's share of his Milwaukee Bucks' playoff money, Nelson said Monday.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: AMERICAN OIL & GAS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income Figures are corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: ACS ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MYLEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $12,000 for the latest quarter and $57,000 for the year-ago period.

title: GREEN PARTY ASKS BREAK WITH NATO
description: The antinuclear and environmentalist Green Party has ended a four-day congress with agreement on a national election program that demands West Germany's immediate withdrawal from NATO and the abolition of nuclear energy.

title: DEERE & COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax provision of $32.2 million for costs relating to a 6 percent work force reduction and restructuring. c-Net income d-Includes an $11.1 million provision for employment reductions.

title: DISSIDENTS LOSE IN TEAMSTER VOTES
description: Delegates to the convention of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters today overwhelmingly rejected dissidents' resolutions to provide for direct election by union members of national union officers and convention delegates.

title: THEATER: KEVIN KLING IN '21A' OFF BROADWAY
description: IF we are to believe Kevin Kling, the 21A bus that runs between Minneapolis and St. Paul carries an extremely odd assortment of down-and-outers. It's sort of an urban Lake Wobegon, only a lot crazier. Since Mr. Kling not only wrote ''21A,'' now at the Westside Arts Theater, but also plays all the parts, we have to take his word for it.

title: ASSOCIATED DRY GOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
CONCERN IN ISRAEL OVER IMMIGRATION
description: Immigration to Israel this year is expected to be at the lowest level in the nation's 38-year history, while emigration is rising sharply, according to reports here.

title: DATAPOINT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 26
description: b-After tax credits of $1,066,000 for the quarter and $2,026,000 for the 9 months. The latest 9 months' loss was also after an extraordinary gain of $3,501,000 from the early extinguishment of debt. c-Net loss d-After an extraordinary gain of $1,914,000 from the early extinguishment of debt for the quarter and 9 months.

title: MAVERICK RESTAURANT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Solutions That Help the Poor to Help Themselves
description: To the Editor:

title: HENLEY'S HISTORIC OFFERING
description: It started as a collection of companies that another company wanted to cast off. Yesterday, it took its place in corporate history as making the biggest initial public stock offering in the American securities market, a deal that grew and grew to more than $1 billion.

title: MISCHER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CONTRAS PLEDGE TO FREE GERMANS
description: Eight West German construction workers captured Saturday in Nicaragua by anti-Government rebels are safe and will be freed, Adolfo Calero, a top leader of the guerrillas who abducted the workers, said here today.

title: PANEL REQUESTS IDEAS OF PUBLIC ON ELLIS I. PLAN
description: The head of a Federal advisory commission considering the future of Ellis Island yesterday appealed to the public for suggestions on what to do with the severely deteriorated southern half of the island.

title: Political Group's Aid Illegal, Judge Decides
description: A Federal court has ruled that the National Conservative Political Action Committee illegally aided the brief 1982 campaign of Bruce Caputo against Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan.

title: ELECTROMEDICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Ready to Hold Hands
description: A few details remain to be worked out, including who will be the first in line, but the organizers of the New York City section of Hands Across America, the drive to help the hungry and the homeless, said they were ready for the event Sunday.

title: FROM A WHEELCHAIR, MOST DOORS ARE CLOSED
description: AT an Italian restaurant on the Upper West Side, a table of customers sipped wine, ate linguini and idly looked out a window at passers-by. Outside, Paul Campos could only stare back. His wheelchair could not cross the restaurant's seven-inch concrete step.

title: WHERE THE FORTUNE READS 'GOOD HEALTH'
description: Someday, if everything goes according to Anthony Q. Chan's plan, Americans will be driving down their highways and turning in at hundreds of signs that say: ''Xian, Over 10 Billion Sold.'' The numbers will refer not to hamburgers, but to egg rolls.

title: SYRIA IS SAID TO PRESS TRENCH WORK
description: The Israeli Army's Chief of Staff said today that Syria was continuing to dig trenches for armor and artillery in southern Lebanon.

title: Next Stop, Wall Street
description: Thomas O. Enders, the United States Ambassador to Spain, is resigning from the Foreign Service this summer after 28 years to become a managing director of Salomon Brothers, the New York investment banking firm. There he will join another former Washington official, David A. Stockman, who resigned as director of the Office of Management and Budget last summer to make the move to Wall Street.

title: U.S. AIDE WHO MET WITH LIBYANS QUITS AS AMBASSADOR TO VATICAN
description: The United States Ambassador to the Vatican, whose unauthorized dealings with Libya had caused concern within the Administration, has resigned, the State Department announced today.

title: REAGAN ACTS TO RESTRICT MACHINE TOOL IMPORTS
description: President Reagan acted today to protect the machine tool industry from foreign competition. He said he had taken this step because present high levels of imports might threaten the nation's security.

title: RED SOX WIN 17-7; BOGGS GETS 5 HITS
description: Wade Boggs had the first five-hit game of his career, sparking a 20-hit Boston attack as the Boston Red Sox routed the Minnesota Twins, 17-7 tonight.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE GARDEN OF EDEN. By Ernest Hemingway. 247 pages. Scribners. $18.95. ''I

title: REAGAN, GIRDING FOR A VETO FIGHT, CUTS PART OF SAUDI ARMS PACKAGE
description: The Reagan Administration, seeking to avert a major legislative defeat over a proposed $354 million arms sale to Saudi Arabia, said today that it would no longer ask for the sale of 800 advanced portable antiaircraft missiles.

title: ETHIOPIAN POLICIES BLAMED IN FAMINE
description: A defector who formerly headed Ethiopia's food relief effort says that his Government's policies, as much as drought, were responsible for the catastrophic Ethiopian famine of 1984 and 1985. And, the former official asserted, these policies threaten to cause continuing starvation in the future.

title: Fodder Goes Best
description: A conservative looks at cuisines:

title: ENIGMATIC COACH STRUGGLES TO MOLD A NEW CHAMPION
description: In the last minutes of a recent exhibition match, when Italy's 2-1 victory over Austria was beyond doubt, the crowd started chanting, ''Enzo! Enzo! Enzo!''

title: Aquino Official Quits For 'Personal Reasons'
description: Deputy Information Minister Eduardo Zialcita resigned today, the first official to leave the three-month-old Government of President Corazon C. Aquino.

title: Best on the Block
description: The comparisons began in earnest this spring when David Robinson, the center from Navy, used 6 feet 10 inches of unmitigated skill to carry what was, without him, a below-average team to the brink of the Final Four. Robinson could score, and he could rebound, but most of all he could block shots.

title: A.M.C. Reaches Union Agreement
description: The American Motors Corporation said it had reached a general agreement with the United Automobile Workers union for contract changes at its Kenosha, Wis., plant, which would go into effect if the company built luxury cars for Chrysler. A.M.C.'s president, Joseph E. Cappy, also said planning for a new A.M.C. vehicle assembly complex and the future of its Toledo, Ohio, Jeep plant had been put on hold until the outcome of negotiations with Chrysler.

title: BALLET: 'MIDSUMMER NIGHT'S DREAM' AND 'LA VALSE'
description: THE unpredictability of love and the powers of the irrational were examined in two works by George Balanchine that the New York City Ballet presented Sunday at the New York State Theater.

title: Summit on Their Minds?
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union are next scheduled to meet in September in New York when the United Nations General Assembly opens its plenary session, and White House officials are cautiously predicting that the Russians at that time may be willing to engage in preparatory talks for a 1986 summit meeting.

title: Mayflower Rejects Offer by Laidlaw
description: Mayflower Group Inc., the nation's fourth-largest household moving company, said it had rejected as inadequate a sweetened offer of $29.25 share, or $225.2 million, from Laidlaw Transportation Ltd., an Ontario-based waste management and transportation concern.

title: Loan Arranged In Northwest Deal
description: Ten Japanese banks and one French bank have arranged a $500 million loan to help Northwest Airlines acquire Republic Airlines, according to Northwest officials. The remaining $384 million needed for the acquisition, which was announced in January, will come from a public securities offering or public sale of the debt, the officials said.

title: MUSIC: DON SHIRLEY, PIANIST
description: THE pianist Don Shirley's concert Sunday at Carnegie Hall was a harmless exercise in pretty, pompous, pseudoclassical mood music. Abetted by Juri Taht on cello and Kenneth Fricker on bass, Mr. Shirley tried to plunge 20th-century American composers - Duke Ellington, George Gershwin, Vernon Duke, the Rev. Thomas A. Dorsey - back into the overwrought European romanticism they had escaped.

title: NEW RUSSIAN IN CAPITAL: YURI VLADIMIROVICH DUBININ
description: When a local Spanish winery invited Yuri V. Dubinin to the annual Pamplona running of the bulls two summers ago, Mr. Dubinin, then Soviet Ambassador to Spain. accepted with enthusiasm.

title: Texas Storm Toll Is 6
description: The last boaters listed as missing after a fierce weekend storm that killed six people have now been accounted for, the authorities said today. A Houston couple called Polk County officials, ending the hunt for possible victims of Saturday's storm at Lake Livingston. Thousands of people taking part in a fishing tournament and a sailing race were at the lake, 70 miles north of Houston, when the storm hit.

title: DEMOCRATS IN PENNSYLVANIA DECIDE HEATED RACES
description: Robert P. Casey, a Scranton lawyer who was once State Auditor General, tonight won the Democratic nomination for Governor of Pennsylvania.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, MAY 21, 1986
description: The Economy

title: Enough Mexico-Bashing
description: It's Mexico-bashing time in Washington again. On this occasion, though, the consequences of the United States' public browbeating of its southern neighbor could get out of hand. Recent Administration statements and actions directed against Mexico go beyond anything seen in the past, and Mexico is far more vulnerable than ever before to American swipes at its officials and institutions.

title: Submarine Is Successful In Launching a Missile
description: The crew of the nuclear submarine Will Rogers fired a Poseidon missile today in the first successful launching here since January.

title: ALAMCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss includes a loss of $5,750,000 related to the acceleration of notes receivable in connection with the sale of 116 wells.

title: PENTAGON REPORT IRKS STATE DEPT.
description: The State Department assailed the Defense Department today for issuing a report expressing skepticism that the Contadora negotiations in Central America will produce a verifiable peace treaty.

title: Advertising; All-Female Agency Wins Lotion Account
description: Lotas, Minard, Patton, McIver, the new, all-female ad agency that has taken up residence in the Chrysler Building, has just announced its first client, S. C. Johnson, which has assigned it Curel, a moisture lotion for the derma.

title: DEMOCRATS GIVE THE NO.2 SPOT TOP ATTENTION
description: Faced with a two-week deadline, Governor Cuomo and Democratic leaders are stepping up efforts to choose a candidate for lieutenant governor, a selection with unusual significance because of the possibility that the Governor will run for President in 1988.

title: BEHIND THE COLOR
description: THE bright, sunny color of carrots, cantaloupes and other yellow-orange fruits and vegetables is telling you something. That appealing color means the produce is full of beta-carotene, a substance scientists call a precursor of vitamin A. Simply put, the body converts beta-carotene into vitamin A. While vitamin A is good for you, large doses are toxic. Large amounts of beta-carotene, however, have not been shown to be toxic, since it is converted to vitamin A only when needed.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report on dance in the Critics' Choices column of The Guide last Sunday gave an incorrect date for a performance by Bebe Miller and Company at the Whitney Museum branch at Philip Morris, Park Avenue at 42d Street. The dancers will appear tomorrow at 12:30 P.M., not today.

title: SCIENTISTS WEIGH RESULTS OF METEORITE EXPLOSIONS
description: Specialists assessing the probability of the earth being struck by a large object from space warned today that the most likely disaster would result from the explosion in the atmosphere of a medium-sized meteorite.

title: July Divorces
description: To the Editor:

title: ABBAS INTERVIEW IN ALGERIA
description: United States Government sources said today that Mohammed Abbas, facing murder and kidnapping charges in the hijacking of the cruise ship Achille Lauro, was on a secret visit to Algeria when he said in an American television interview this month that President Reagan had become ''enemy No. 1.''

title: FOOD NOTES
description: The Japanese Touch You won't find quiche or tortellini salad at Akemi, a Japanese catering shop at 1128 Third Avenue (66th Street). But you may be enticed by the unusual display of beef dumplings with sweet and sour sauce ($6.50 a pound), fried tofu balls traced with strips of seaweed ($7 a pound), mushrooms wrapped in fried bean curd ($1.50 each), darkly exotic hijiki salad ($7 a pound) made of strands of seaweed, or deliciously tangy fried butterfish in a vinegar and vegetable marinade ($2 a serving).

title: NORTHEAST UTILITIES reports earnings for Year to April 30
Protection Shifts Costs From One Worker to Another
description: To the Editor:

title: Stock Offered By Texas Air
description: The Texas Air Corporation, a Houston-based holding company that agreed in February to acquire Eastern Air Lines Inc., is offering four million common shares at $32.25 a share through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert.

title: Verbal Agility
description: A rhetorical match for Mayor Koch? Consider this exchange yesterday in the Mayor's office between Mr. Koch and the choreographer Antony Tudor.

title: FROM A TO B AND MORE
description: It is not literally true that before the Great Restaurant Renaissance began here about 1970, the dining-out possibilities in downtown Philadelphia ran the gamut from Arthur's steakhouse to Bookbinder's seafood. There were plenty of ethnic restaurants around town, mainly Italian and Chinese, and plenty of steak-and-chicken family spots.

title: TOP TRIAL LAWYER
description: John J. Wilson, the combative and outspoken trial lawyer who represented two top Nixon Administration aides in the Senate Watergate hearings in 1973, died Sunday at his home here. He was 84 years old and had been suffering from a heart ailment.

title: A 'SMART' BUILDING RISES FOR SMALL-OFFICE TENANTS
description: Since the advent of computer-based office operations and telecommunications systems, basic space has come to mean more than just a floor, four walls, heating and air-conditioning. Basic space also means access to the new technology, and most developers of the ''smart'' buildings providing such access have been catering only to large space users.

title: ICOT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: b-Includes tax credits of $660,000 and $1,615,000 for quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: GUGGENGEIM DRAMATIZES SPACE WOES
description: The Guggenheim Museum threw open its jam-packed basement storage rooms yesterday in an effort to show its need for more art space that it says a proposed annex will provide.

title: CONCERT: LOS ANGELES PHILHARMONIC
description: THE Los Angeles Philharmonic's second New York concert under Andre Previn showed how quickly its new music director has managed to transfer his tastes and style to a different set of musicians. This Avery Fisher Hall event Sunday afternoon offered some English music (Elgar's ''Enigma Variations''), a boisterous, brightly lighted 20th-century symphony (the Prokofiev Fifth) and even a little something by the conductor himself - Mr. Previn's ''Reflections'' for English horn, cello and orchestra.

title: Bridge: To Avoid Taking a Finesse, Bold Measure May Pay Off
description: If player knows that a finesse is doomed, then he may resort to desperate measures to avoid taking it. And if the defenders are not alert he may get away with it.

title: Dow Gains 25.80 in Light Trading
description: A decline in interest rates and a drop in oil prices helped Wall Street score a big gain yesterday, but trading volume remained light as investors were apparently not fully convinced that the recent market downturn was over.

title: Vote Count Resumes In Dominican Republic
description: Responding to a television appeal by President Salvador Jorge Blanco, electoral officials late tonight resumed counting of the votes cast in the presidential election here last Friday.

title: Mortgage Issues Yield Up to 10.15%
description: The Home Mortgage Access Corporation is offering $174.5 million of collateralized mortgage obligations through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. The obligations, rated triple-A by Moody's and S.&P., are backed by pools of pass-through securities of the Government National Mortgage Association and the Federal National Mortgage Association.

title: ENERGY OIL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GOTTI IS EXPECTED TO RUN MOB GROUP FROM FEDERAL JAIL
description: Law-enforcement officials said yesterday that they expected John Gotti to continue to run the Gambino crime family from jail with the help of subordinates.

title: ALTERNACARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income includes a tax credit of $31,000.

title: First Armed MX Missile Is to Be Deployed Soon
description: The first armed MX missile to be deployed will be lowered into a silo in southeastern Wyoming within 30 days, according to the Air Force.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL METS (NL) - Recalled Doug Sisk, pitcher, from Tidewater of the International League. Sent Terry Leach, pitcher, to Tidewater.

title: SHATNER IN 'BLOOD SPORT'
description: DECENT, dogged, down-to-earth Sgt. T. J. Hooker, the television cop, takes a shot at a two-hour adventure tonight, on Channel 2 at 9 o'clock. ''Blood Sport'' takes him to Hawaii to keep watch over an ambitious senator who is campaigning against terrorism (''We gotta hit the terrorists where it hurts'') and expects retaliation. The Senator (Don Murray) is an old college pal of Hooker's (William Shatner), but the years have come between them. Hooker remains decent, but his old pal has turned into a philanderer, a cynic and a political opportunist. ''Winning is always worth it,'' says the Senator, for whom politics is a blood sport. ''I'm beginning not to like what I see,'' says down-to-earth Hooker, talking like a television reviewer.

title: BLESSINGS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 19
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split to be paid June 2.

title: SCHOOL AID LINK URGED AS TOOL TO FIGHT DRUGS
description: The Secretary of Education advised Congress today to consider withholding Federal funds from schools that do not demonstrate a serious commitment to combating students' use of illicit drugs.

title: COMMUNIST PARTY RAIDED IN JORDAN
description: The Government was reported today to have arrested the leadership of Jordan's Communist Party in a move widely seen here as an effort to fix blame for a recent student protest that was violently put down by the police.

title: U.S. Spurns Chernobyl Offer
description: The State Department said today that it had turned down a Soviet invitation to send a diplomat to visit the area around the Chernobyl nuclear plant. A spokesman said that instead of a person without technical background, the United States would prefer to send a specialist to monitor contamination first-hand.

title: AMERICAN MEDCENTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: TO THE BURGLAR WHO SHUNS GRIEG Marilyn, Leontyne, Joan and Sherrill; Carlo and Franco, Placido, Bob Merrill. You skillfully jimmied the lock on my Honda - No more dodging the traffic to ''La Gioconda.'' A crook who swipes opera! A classical thief! Why not rob Winston? Arpels and Van Cleef? You left works by Grieg, perhaps to console me? Why not Turandot, Tosca, Don G. or Salome? Insurance I've got, but no ''Cielo e mar'': Next time leave the tapes; just take the car.

title: FOR ONE TOWN, JUST A RIPPLE OF MANILA SEA CHANGE
description: For the first time in 12 years, Armando Racelis did not lead the parade at the Fiesta of San Isidro this week. He sat at home with a few friends, within earshot of the brass band and the shouting.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: MOST of the Italian names for the different pastas are colorful and fun - it feels good just saying them. But they can be highly descriptive as well. Spaghetti, for example, derives from the word ''spago,'' for string or twine. Spaghetti, then, is a ''length or bundle of strings.'' Cannelloni, in turn, means ''large reeds,'' cappeletti means ''little hats'' and conchiglie are ''conch shells,'' all the names being apt descriptions of the shapes.

title: AFTER A DECADE, AN ADVENTURE IN DINING OUT
description: WHILE residents of Philadelphia have always had a rich assortment of cultural and historical flags to wave proudly, restaurants were not one of them. Until recently, the city's gastronomic claim to fame rested largely on a sandwich made with fried strips of beef heaped on a bun and smeared with Cheez Whiz. No longer.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: Batus Inc., Louisville, Ky., holding company, appointed Jay Baker president and chief executive of Thimbles, a women's clothing retailer with 35 stores in Eastern and Middle Western shopping malls.

title: Strength and Length Of Radiation Dose
description: To the Editor:

title: ANGELES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $321,000 from a reversal of a tax credit, an oil and gas investment adjustment charge of $4,800,000 and a tax benefit of $3,107,000. c-Includes tax benefits of $1,812,000 for the quarter and $2,509,000 for the 9 months. d-Includes an oil and gas investment adjustment charge of $4,800,000 and a tax benefit of $2,065,000.

title: Beirut Gunmen Seize U.S. Embassy Guards
description: At least five Lebanese guards at the American Embassy were held for eight hours by unidentified gunmen today.

title: BRONX LANDLORD OWES $125,000 IN SANITATION FINES
description: A Bronx landlord has failed to pay more than $125,000 in sanitation fines dating back to 1980, according to city records, and city officials said yesterday that they were unable to do anything about it.

title: CORRECTION
description: A paragraph yesterday introducing textual excerpts from the Supreme Court decision on affirmative action characterized the opinion of Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. incorrectly. Justice Powell, who announced the Court's decision, spoke for a plurality, not for a majority.

title: Advertising; Y.&R. Joint Venture
description: Young & Rubicam, a leader in multinational joint venture activity, has now got involved in a joint venture with its joint venture.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: IT is known as Lou Gehrig's disease, for the Yankee slugger whose career was cut short in 1939 by its destructive effects on the neuromuscular system. It has afflicted other famous individuals as well, among them the late actor David Niven and the late Senator Jacob K. Javits - which is about the only time most people hear about it. Yet, this progressive and nearly always fatal disorder is four times more common than muscular dystrophy and at least as common as multiple sclerosis.

title: Crude Oil Prices Slump To About $16 a Barrel
description: Crude oil prices slumped sharply on the world market yesterday, falling back to around $16 a barrel after climbing above $17 on Monday.

title: DIONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SOUTH AFRICAN PRESIDENT DEFENDS RAIDS ON 3 NEIGHBORING NATIONS
description: President P. W. Botha today congratulated the troops who carried out raids into Botswana, Zambia and Zimbabwe and said he took full responsibility for their actions.

title: DAYTON HUDSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Wall St. Sees Sperry Merger
description: Although animosity between the Sperry Corporation and the Burroughs Corporation has intensified, Wall Street apparently still thinks the two concerns could combine.

title: NIKI-LU INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary tax credit of $145,207. c-Net loss.

title: CAMPAIGN GIFTS TO SENATOR TIED TO CREDIT UNION
description: A 1984 primary campaign by State Senator Martin Markowitz of Brooklyn was financed largely by the Hyfin Credit Union, which was closed last month because of fraud charges, and by people linked to Hyfin, according to state records.

title: Once Is Not Enough
description: Of all the players now engaged in the final round between Calgary and Montreal, only two - John Tonelli, the former Islander, and Doug Risebrough, previously with the Canadiens - have ever won the Stanley Cup with a franchise other their current one. Tonelli and Risebrough, both now with the Flames, wouldn't be breaking any new ground, though, should Calgary prevail. More than 50 players in N.H.L. history have won the cup with at least two franchises, and only 17 years ago Larry Hillman won it with a third team (Montreal), having already skated to triumph with Detroit and Toronto. Here, in addition to Hillman, are the multifranchise success stories of the last 20 years (number of cups won in parentheses): 1st Team, 2d Team Billy CarrollIslanders (3), Edmonton (1) Mark NapierMontreal (1), Edmonton (1) Pat HughesMontreal (1), Edmonton (2) Ted HarrisMontreal (4), Philadelphia (1) Frank MahovlichToronto (4), Montreal (2) Mike WaltonToronto (1), Boston (1) Dick DuffToronto (2), Montreal (4) Terry SawchukDetroit (3), Toronto (1) Marcel PronovostDetroit (4), Toronto (1) Red KellyDetroit (4), Toronto (4)

title: Tense Moments
description: The swearing-in ceremony was ''more nerve-racking than a free throw down the stretch,'' but the Dallas Maverick guard Rolando Blackman is now a United States citizen.

title: BALLET: A NEW 'REQUIEM' BY KENNETH MacMILLAN
description: THE theater may not have replaced the church as a place of worship, but certainly there has been an increase in religiously inspired music in ballet.

title: AMERICAN CYTOGENETICS INC reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: AFTER 60 YEARS, DR. SEUSS GOES BACK TO HIS ROOTS
description: Like the Cat in the Hat, Dr. Seuss came back today, back to the schools, libraries, streets and parks of this New England factory town where he was born 82 years ago.

title: FLORIDA EXECUTES SECOND MAN FOR MURDER OF A STORE OWNER
description: A man convicted of beating and stabbing to death a store owner who refused to give him a job was executed today in Florida's electric chair, the second man to be put to death for the crime.

title: 'RIGHT TO KNOW' ON 31
description: ''R IGHT TO KNOW'' isn't a bad idea: take three controversial people, all bursting to tell us something we wouldn't otherwise hear, and allow them free rein to expression. The idea breaks down, however, when no one has much to say. There's just no getting around it. ''Right to Know,'' on Channel 31 at 9:30 tonight, isn't tendentious; it's tedious.

title: New Mexico Blast Kills 2; Fireworks Suspected
description: Explosions and a fire destroyed a cinder block building and killed at least two people here Monday evening.

title: FEDERATED DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $13,077,000 from the sale of a department store division.

title: IN SEATTLE, TUGBOATS LINK THE CITY TO THE SEA
description: Afterward, the surface of Elliott Bay looked as if broaching whales had been playing in it. But out of the crashing swells and the din of horns, klaxons and sirens, the Polar Merchant moved in today to win the annual Puget Sound tugboat race.

title: SOVIET APPOINTS NEW ENVOY TO THE U.S.
description: Yuri V. Dubinin, a Soviet career diplomat who was named only two months ago as the chief delegate at the United Nations, was appointed today as the new ambassador to Washington.

title: DELMED INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income includes a loss from discontinued operations of $462,000 and a gain on the sale of assets of $3,458,000.

title: A Return to Gorky, And a Nobel Speech
description: Today is Andrei D. Sakharov's 65th birthday. My husband is celebrating it alone in Gorky. In two weeks, I will return to him and again share the ordeal of exile. The six months I have spent in America since I arrived for medical treatment have convinced me that my husband and his fate will be remembered here. I hope that some of the ideas that he expressed in his 1975 Nobel Peace Prize address will be remembered as well. - Yelena G. Bonner

title: Two Tied at 70 In Dodge Open
description: Russ Helwig, head pro at Essex Fells Country Club, and Mike Burke Jr., an assistant pro at Edgewood, tied for the lead today in the opening round of the 23d annual Dodge Open Charity Classic. Each scored 70, two under par, for the Rockaway River Country Club.

title: JOHNSON'S MISSION: TO RALLY LAKERS
description: When Earvin Johnson joined the Los Angeles Lakers nearly seven years ago, he was brimming with enthusiasm. Always smiling and ever joyful, he gave new meaning to the high-five and infused an entire team with his effervescence - particularly an aging center who was then believed to be at the end of his career.

title: NAVY'S PLAN FOR S.I. PORT IS SET BACK IN CONGRESS
description: The Navy's plan to build a new port on Staten Island suffered a major setback today when the Senate Armed Services Committee failed to approve the release of funds, according to Congressional and Navy sources.

title: Advertising; B.B.D.O. Gets Apple Computer
description: BATTEN, BARTON, DURSTINE & OSBORN has won the shootout with Chiat/Day for the domestic business of Apple Computer, reported to bill $50 million.

title: Continued Cuts At British Rail
description: Britain's state-run railway company, British Rail, said it could cut as many as 5,000 mechanics' jobs in the next three years as part of a restructuring program. It said this was in addition to cutting 2,650 mechanics' jobs, a move planned for this period.

title: DREXLER TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
description: b-Net income

title: 5 Gimbel Executives Said to Be Job Hunting
description: Five top executives of Gimbel department stores in four cities are entertaining or seeking offers for new jobs, reliable sources in the retailing industry said yesterday. The reports are the latest indication that the 144-year-old Gimbels chain will soon disappear from the retail scene.

title: CONCERT: QUILAPAYUN, CHILEAN BAND
description: THE Chilean band Quilapayun brought songs, poems and skits to McMillin Theater at Columbia University Sunday. Quilapayun, an eight-man band, was one of the first Latin American Nueva Cancion (New Song) groups, mixing traditionalist music and current political lyrics; the group was associated with the poet-songwriter Victor Jara until he was arrested and killed in 1973.

title: Morton Thiokol Has Cooperated Fully With Challenger Inquiry
description: To the Editor:

title: THE CHEESE STEAK: AN ORIGINAL
description: IF you want to get a Philadelphian's intellectual juices running, simply ask who makes the best cheese steak in town.

title: Kilrea May Not Return
description: Amid speculation that Brian Kilrea, the Islanders' assistant coach, will not be rehired, Bill Torrey, the team's general manager, says he will make no plans about his staff until he and Al Arbour, the head coach, complete their player evaluations. Both Kilrea and Torrey were in Montreal last night for Game 3 of the Stanley Cup finals. Asked about Arbour's annual indecision about returning as head coach, Torrey said he assumed Arbour would be back behind the bench next season ''until he tells me otherwise.''

title: ALATENN RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GLOBAL NATURAL RESOURCES PROPERTIES LC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $672,000.

title: Whom to Appoint?
description: Lots of professional and political observers have predicted from time to time whom President Reagan will next appoint to the Supreme Court, assuming a vacancy occurs before he leaves the White House. But few authorities have been asked whom they would name to the High Court if they were President, so the ABA Journal canvassed ''a cross-section of the American legal community and other prominent citizens'' on that presumably less political question.

title: YANKEES BEATEN IN NINTH; METS 2, GIANTS 1
description: The Mets handed Mike LaCoss his first loss of the season tonight when they rallied with single runs in the seventh and eighth innings and defeated the San Francisco Giants, 2-1.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Oakland Athletics, at Yankee Stadium, 7:30 P.M. Oakland's prize rookie, Jose Canseco, is third in home runs and second in runs batted in.

title: AFRICA RAIDS: WHAT GOAL?
description: Some South African commentators suggested today that with the raids Monday against three black-governed nations to the north, South African authorities seemed ready to forfeit any hope of international sympathy and support in pursuit of limited domestic goals drawn from the politics of the white minority.

title: FIRSTCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Dance: San Francisco Moving Co.
description: THE San Francisco Moving Company, a modern-dance troupe directed by Ellen Bromberg, made its New York debut over the weekend at the Riverside Dance Festival with works by Miss Bromberg and Della Davidson, the troupe's associate director.

title: Bombers Black Out Much of Chile
description: Bombs destroyed three utility towers tonight, blacking out much of Chile, after army troops in the capital crushed a planned protest march against the military Government.

title: CELTICS AND ROCKETS NOT IDEAL MATCHUP
description: Surprise over the Houston Rockets' play against the Los Angeles Lakers is not limited to the basketball world. The folks at CBS Sports may go into shock.

title: Flirting With the Teamsters
description: Secretary of Labor William Brock surprised the teamsters with his blunt convention speech Monday night warning the union to clean up its act. In doing so, he also issued notice that the Reagan Administration may be cleaning up its own act after shamelessly courting this corruptly led union for years. It's a welcome change, and if he means it, let Mr. Brock now follow up with measures to give the union a dose of democracy.

title: ALL-LIGETI BILL TO OPEN HORIZONS '86 FESTIVAL
description: The third and last of the Horizons new-music festivals sponsored by the New York Philharmonic and directed by Jacob Druckman as composer in residence will get under way tonight at Avery Fisher Hall. This may be the last Horizons, but it promises to be the most ambitious in terms of budget ($800,000), number of concerts (seven) and overall scope.

title: PRESIDENT JOINING SENATORS TO FIGHT TAX BILL CHANGES
description: President Reagan and most members of the Senate Finance Committee agreed today to oppose Senate amendments to the tax-revision measure the committee approved two weeks ago.

title: COUNTING STEPS, NAMING NAMES
AN EARLY-APRIL START FOR DAYLIGHT SAVING IS BACKED BY SENATE
description: The Senate today approved a three-week extension of daylight time, making it likely that the daylight time period will be lengthened next year, for the first time since the energy crisis of the mid-1970's. The House has approved a similar bill.

title: U.S. DELAYS TEST OF A GENE-ALTERED PESTICIDE
description: The Environmental Protection Agency said today that it would not permit the Monsanto Company to conduct a field test of a genetically engineered pesticide until additional safety tests were completed.

title: ROZELLE CITES OFFER FROM THE U.S.F.L.
description: Pete Rozelle, the commissioner of the National Football League, testified in Federal District Court yesterday that in 1982, before the United States Football League began operation, U.S.F.L. officials offered him the job as commissioner.

title: Dominican Democracy Quakes Again
description: Democracy is again at risk in the Dominican Republic. Only eight years after the Carter Administration used diplomatic pressure to uphold an election, a presidential vote is again in bitter dispute.

title: THE PLUMBER'S GAME
description: The top Reagan officials are miffed these days when they read leaks in the press about what they're doing in private, and you can't blame them.

title: BEYOND BREAD AND GRAPE JELLY
description: THERE is more to the adult peanut butter market than spreads for white bread with jelly. Desserts by David Glass, sold in fancy food shops, has added peanut butter chocolate mousse balls to its line of rich confections.

title: Profits Down 4.9% in Quarter
description: After-tax corporate profits fell 4.9 percent in the January-March quarter, the biggest decline since the last recession, the Government reported today.

title: Gibson Works Out
description: Kirk Gibson, the Detroit slugger who has been out because of a sprained left ankle since April 22, showed up at Tiger Stadium and took his first batting practice since he was injured.

title: THE FIGHT TO SAVE BETHLEHEM
description: Walter F. Williams has long been surrounded by signs of his company's decline, but every now and then the reminders have been especially agonizing.

title: ANGELICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 26
PEANUT BUTTER: AN ENDURING AMERICAN PASSION
description: PEANUT butter, the pate of childhood, is the passion of many adults. They eat it in the morning, snack on it at night and, in between, mix it with everything from jellies to exotic spices in recipes that tax a peanut butter lover's inventiveness - and sometimes patience. Some 600 million pounds of peanut butter are eaten annually in what is a $700 million retail market; that's eight pounds of peanut butter per person per year.

title: HOME DEPOT INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
U.S. STEEL PLANNING FURTHER STAFF CUTS
description: The United States Steel Corporation will reduce its management staff by 10 percent to 15 percent this year in its steel operations and at its headquarters, the company's chief executive, David M. Roderick, said.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: In the city neighborhood in which I live, stoop sitting is the primary summer spectator sport. One night, I found myself doing it with my father. Together we looked out on the vista of brick row houses, 10-family tenement buildings and dozens of other stoops filled with other families. Across the street three elderly women were watching from their windows, pillows cushioning the sills; a group of men were fixing the transmission of a beaten-up Plymouth, and a whiffle ball game was under way with pieces of corrugated cardboard box serving as bases.

title: MORGAN GUARANTY CITES $6 MILLION IMPROPRIETY
description: The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company said yesterday that a former top officer in New York ''may have made unauthorized withdrawals'' of $6 million from customer accounts in Brazil.

description: BUSINESS, academic and political leaders at this first meeting of the Trilateral Commission in Spain have used it as an occasion to hail the emergence of Spanish democracy and the entry of Spain into the European Community and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: AMC ENTERTAIMENT reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
STAGE: ENSEMBLE STUDIO'S MARATHON
description: THE ephemera of fashion are an amusing running motif in Evening B of the Ensemble Studio Theater's Marathon '86. Although none of the four plays are as fully realized as Horton Foote's ''Blind Date'' in Evening A, they are more evenly balanced. Each has something to offer - an attitude, an idea or an intriguing situation. As usual in this annual festival, the work is fueled by fine acting and directing. However, many of the sets are cluttered and slow scene changes add to the already overlong duration of both evenings.

title: ECONOMIC GROWTH AT 3.7% RATE
description: The economy grew at a sound annual rate of 3.7 percent in the first quarter as it began reaping the benefits of the cheaper dollar, less expensive oil and lower interest rates, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: All-Round Game
description: Bill Walton, on why he loves basketball: ''Everyone has to do everything - rebound, score, pass, play defense. There aren't any place-kickers or relief pitchers.'' ''

title: G.M. Plastic Van
description: The General Motors Corporation plans to build a front-wheel-drive plastic-body mini-van for sale later this decade by Chevrolet and Pontiac dealers, a spokesman said today. The vehicle will be assembled in Framingham, Mass., where G.M. now builds the Chevrolet Celebrity and Oldsmobile Ciera.

description: By official proclamation, it was Mom and Pop Day in Brooklyn, celebrating the importance of small businesses to the economy of borough. But things did not go quite as expected.

title: WINE TALK
description: I HAVE always been of two minds about wine courses. Yes, they encompass a lot of wine knowlege in a small amount of time. Yes, they provide an opportunity to taste more wines than most people could afford on their own. Yes - well, you get the idea. There is a lot to be said about wine courses. I've even given a few myself.

title: HOWARD C. CLARK Jr.
description: Howard C. Clark Jr., director of promotion and public affairs of the New York State Department of Agriculture and Markets, died of leukemia Monday at the Albany Medical Center in Albany. He was 49 years old and lived in Loudonville, N.Y.

title: SWANS KEEP STRETCHING ROCK-AND-ROLL'S LIMITS
description: THE SWANS, who will be at the Ritz on Friday, have been praised by many reviewers for ''taking rock as far as it can go.'' Michael Gira, the group's songwriter and vocalist, considers this an insult. ''Saying the music can't go any further implies that we don't have much imagination,'' he says. ''But we do have imagination, and the music will keep on changing.''

title: PATRICK PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Nuclear Bomb Tested
description: A nuclear weapons test was held today in the Nevada desert, and officials said the operation, the 11th announced test since the Soviet Union announced a unilateral test moratorium last August, went off without incident. The test, code-named Panamint, was the fourth announced shot at the Nevada Test Site this year. It carried an explosive force of less than 20,000 tons of TNT.

title: CONFLICT THREATENS WITHERSPOON MATCH
description: A snag has developed in the negotiations for the Tim Witherspoon-Frank Bruno match, which was to have been the next fight in HBO's heavyweight unification series. The impasse, it turns out, involves the sale of delayed television rights to Britain, Bruno's home turf. The series' promoters, Don King and Butch Lewis, had sold the rights for the entire series to ITV, an independent British network. However, Mickey Duff, representing Bruno's manager, Terry Lawless, has a longstanding commitment to the BBC for his fighters. Seth Abraham, HBO's senior vice president of program operations and sports, indicated that the conflict would cancel the match if not resolved by the end of this week, which he did not think likely.

title: N.C.A.A. Adding 2 Investigators
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association, in a move designed to keep closer watch on how schools are complying with its regulations, today announced an expansion of its enforcement department.

title: DEROSE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A Smokescreen of Courtesy
description: If courtesy were king in New York City, its citizens would not be so adept at stealing cabs from one another. The dog owner would scoop the poop simply because he cared about his fellows' feet, and the pedestrian would have no need to fear the demon cyclist, or the bus rider the moody driver. The elderly and infirm might even be able to get seats on the subways.

title: Coming Soon: Even Less for Your New York City Subway Buck
description: To the Editor:

title: No Time for Books
description: In 1924, in the Hoover Administration, the American Booksellers Assocation discovered that the White House had no library and donated 500 books to begin one. Every four years since then, except in the two Reagan Administrations, it had donated an additional 250 books. The association, which is meeting next weekend in New Orleans, says the White House has not been able to schedule time for a presentation ceremony to accept the books.

title: Perry Must Reduce
description: According to the Chicago Bears' plans, there will be less of William (The Refrigerator) Perry next season but the 6-foot-2-inch defensive lineman will be doing more things with what is left. Perry reported to a minicamp at Lake Forest, Ill., at 330 pounds, but Coach Mike Ditka wants him to shed 30 pounds for the summer training camp starting July 14 and to open the National Football League season at 295.

Some professionals smooth over the texture by troweling on a thin layer of spackling compound, but this could lead to chipping or flaking later if not expertly done.

description: The Pan Am Corporation is considering a public stock offering stock in one of its profitable subsidiaries, Pan Am World Services, and in a new subsidiary it plans to set up for its shuttle service at La Guardia Airport.

title: GROUND COVERS THAT OUTDO PACHYSANDRA
description: I CAN'T think of any other class of plants that's quite as iffy as ground covers. The literal meaning of the word takes in far more territory than the plants it usually denotes. Pachysandra, vinca and English ivy are the three canonical ground covers, the ones that spring most easily to mind and those most likely to grow in almost anyone's garden, especially those who have shade and think they have problems. (Actually, most of the ground covers that do well in semishade, not absolute darkness, also grow happily in the sun.) But considered without prejudice, chickweed and crab grass do indeed cover the ground, lots of it, and they are a potent duo, since chickweed flourishes when it's cold and crab grass when it's hot.

title: NUCLEAR LIABILITY MEASURE GAINS
description: A measure that would increase the limits of accident liability of the nuclear power industry to $6.5 billion for any accident was cleared today by the House Interior Committee.

title: GENE FOUND IN AIDS VIRUS MAY BE KEY TO DISEASE
description: Scientists have discovered that the AIDS virus has a hitherto unknown and unexpected gene that may be a key to the virus's complex effects on the human body.

title: How to Make Terrorists Think Twice
description: Is there a way to proceed forcefully against terrorism without resorting to expensive military action? The Libyan episode raises that question.

title: A BLEND OF TECHNIQUES
description: FOR the last five years, Howard Crouch, left, has been developing furnishings that combine painting and sculpture. From the Spiral Trellis and Planter, left center, $600, to a multilegged coffee table, far left, $600, and his ''Chairs Made of Two Circles and Four Lines,'' with fabric by his wife, Chazz Levi, below left, the pieces combine rational construction techniques with freer, more expressive painted surfaces. Mr. Crouch's Human Nature Design studio is at 115 Avenue A, between St. Marks Place and Seventh Street. He can be reached at 212-505-6067.

title: The Best Candidate
description: The Democratic candidate for governor of Nebraska is the child of Greek immigrants; the Republican candidate's ancestors were Swedish. Both have worked their way up the political ladder - one to become Mayor of Lincoln, the other to become state Treasurer.

description: United States-Soviet arms talks continued today, with a regular weekly session between negotiating groups on long-range strategic nuclear weapons.

description: A plan by Mack Trucks Inc. to switch production of chassis and drive-train parts to the Dana Corporation of Toledo, Ohio, will cause layoffs of as many as 1,000 Mack employees in Pennsylvania, Maryland and Ontario, the company said.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a dispatch yesterday from Starke, Fla., about the execution of a murderer, misattributed a statement. A defense lawyer, not Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr., said the Justice needed additional time to study the case because of ''lingering doubt'' about the defendant's guilt.

title: Sluggers, Enshrined And Otherwise
description: Will Dave Kingman make it to the Hall of Fame someday? Fittingly enough (since his career strikeout ratio of 27.7 per 100 times at bat is tops in major league history), he has a number of well-noted strikes against him: a career batting average of only .239, unforgettable ineptness with the glove before he found refuge as a designated hitter and alienation of countless baseball writers, some 400 of whom cast Cooperstown ballots annually. Still, his total of 415 home runs places him in a can't-miss category: Of the 16 players who have hit 400 or more homers and been retired for the five-year minimum, only Billy Williams (426) is lacking enshrinement, and he's regarded as a cinch to make it next year. Among all players eligible for the Hall of Fame but never elected, these are the home-run leaders:

title: FORD IN TALKS FOR ALFA ROMEO STAKE
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it was negotiating with the Italian automobile company Alfa Romeo about acquiring as much as a controlling interest in Alfa's stock.

title: PANEL ENDS HEARINGS ON GROSS
description: A state panel, completing two days of hearings, said yesterday that it would not rule for at least 10 days on whether a state investigative committee acted improperly last year in recommending that charges of professional misconduct be brought against Dr. Elliot M. Gross, the Chief Medical Examiner of New York City.

title: CITY DROPOUT PROGRAM REPORTS 0.8% INCREASE IN ATTENDANCE
description: Attendance has increased by less than 1 percent at New York City high schools receiving extra money for dropout prevention, school officials said yesterday. But they described the small rise as ''very substantial progress.''

title: ARCHITECTURE: TWO RICHARD MORRIS HUNT SHOWS
description: RICHARD MORRIS HUNT has not, in our time, been as celebrated a name as Stanford White or Henry Hobson Richardson. This is not so terrible an injustice, for he was not as great an architect as they were. But Hunt, who was born in 1827 and died in 1895, was a very gifted architect indeed, one of the most potent forces ever to affect American architecture. He was the first American to study at the Ecole des Beaux-Arts in Paris, and in this sense he was a spiritual father to a whole generation of architects who followed him, men like Charles McKim, Stanford White himself, and Cass Gilbert, architects whose eclectic buildings shaped so much of the American landscape in the years before and after the turn of the century.

title: S.E.C. PAPERS SUGGEST TRAIL OF INSIDER TRADES
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday provided the most detailed picture yet of the scheme through which Dennis B. Levine is accused of reaping more than $12 million in illegal trading profits.

title: WILLIAM L. KEADY
description: William L. Keady, an industrialist who was chairman of the board of the Advalloy Corporation, died of congestive heart failure Sunday at his home in Menlo Park, Calif. He was 92 years old.

title: Award for Robertson
description: Alvin Robertson of the San Antonio Spurs, who had been named the National Basketball Assocation's defensive player of the year, has also been voted the winner of the league's new most-improved-player award.

title: Houston Water System Bonds
description: A $193.6 million issue of revenue bonds for Houston's water system is being offered with a maximum yield of 8.20 percent for bonds due in 2106 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Medical School Seeks Closer Ties to Church
description: The board of trustees of New York Medical College voted yesterday to ''strengthen its affiliation'' with the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York. But the college stopped short of changing its name or ending its status as a nonsectarian institution.

title: Topics; Frank/Candid; Watch This Space
description: Greeting cards, ever more varied in purpose and design, are also becoming more sophisticated in message. Several companies now offer expressions of fine-tuned emotion.

description: The Economy

title: N.H.L. Is Seeking Mandatory Testing
description: At a luncheon today to honor the sport's exemplary athletes, John Ziegler, president of the National Hockey League, announced that the league had proposed a mandatory drug-testing program for all players.

title: BALLET: A TUDOR EVENING OF HONORS AND 4 WORKS
description: ANTONY TUDOR, one of the few truly distinguished choreographers of this century, has lived his creative life modestly and without fanfare. He has not always been eager to accept proffered honors.

title: PANEL ACTS ON RENT BIAS AGAINST CHILDREN IN CITY
description: City legislation that would bar landlords and real-estate agents from turning away families because they include children was approved unanimously yesterday by a City Council committee.

title: BACK HOME, SHIP'S CREW DESCRIBES A NIGHTMARE
description: The days were ''barely tolerable,'' the nights were ''hell.'' But eight crew members of the sunken schooner Pride of Baltimore held on to a life raft and to one another for four days and seven hours, and came home today to Maryland.

title: PAIN VICTIMS' CARE FAULTED BY PANEL
description: A Federal advisory panel today called for improved treatment of pain after hearing testimony that millions of Americans are cared for inadequately.

title: A STRONG THATCHER ALLY RESIGNS FROM CABINET
description: Sir Keith Joseph, a hard-line Conservative and one of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's staunchest supporters in the party, stepped down as Education Minister today. Mrs. Thatcher appointed a more centrist Conservative in his place.

title: RED SOX OUTLAST RAIN DELAYS AND WIN
description: Steve Lyons doubled and scored Boston's first run in the sixth inning and then drove in the go-ahead run with a single in the seventh tonight, rallying the Red Sox to a 3-2 victory over the Minnesota Twins after two long rain delays.

OFFICIAL IN JUSTICE DEPT. CONTENDS CITIZENS ABUSE RACKETEERING LAW
description: The Federal racketeering statute is being abused by private citizens suing corporations and the Government in civil fraud cases that have nothing to do with organized crime, an Assistant Attorney General contended today.

title: PASQUA POWERS YANKEE ROUT
description: The two-run home run and the two-run double that Dan Pasqua swatted against Eric Plunk last night should have come as no surprise to Oakland's rookie pitcher. Plunk saw Pasqua hit 35 of his first 37 professional home runs and produce 147 of his first 151 runs batted in.

title: NEW HEAD FOR OPERA GUILD
description: The Metropolitan Opera Guild has announced that Alton E. Peters will become the organization's ninth president. He will succeed Katherine T. O'Neil, who has served as president for the last seven years. Thomas J. Hubbard has been elected the guild's new chairman; he will replace Laurence D. Lovett.

title: A Lottery
description: The National Republican Congressional Committee is running a lottery, and the winner is not likely to be Representative Bill Alexander, Democrat of Arkansas.

title: ROBERT WOOD, FORMER HEAD OF CBS TELEVISION NETWORK
description: Robert D. Wood, the former president of the CBS television network who ushered in television's ''era of relevancy'' in the 1970's, died of a heart attack Tuesday in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 61 years old and lived in Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: THE TYSON-BIGGS COLLISION COURSE
description: He sat in the fourth row ringside, watching Mike Tyson differently than anybody else was. Lou Duva wasn't there Tuesday night just to see the 19-year-old gladiator justify his sudden stature as the youngest heavyweight to headline a Madison Square Garden card. And the longtime trainer with the face of a clenched boxing glove certainly wasn't there just to be seen. No, he was there to study. To find the flaws in the hope of the heavyweight division who has a 21-0 record after a 10-round pounding of Mitch (Blood) Green.

title: ATLANTIC MONTHLY PRESS IS SOLD BY ZUCKERMAN
description: The Atlantic Monthly Press, one of the dwindling number of independent book publishers, has been purchased from Mortimer Zuckerman by Carl Navarre Jr., a 34-year-old businessman and writer from Chattanooga, Tenn.

title: HAYES-ALBION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $2,162,000.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I don't believe that there is anyone going hungry in America simply by reason of denial or lack of ability to feed them; it is by people not knowing where or how to get this help.'' -President Reagan. [ A1:2. ]

title: New York Air Shifting Flights
description: New York Air said yesterday that it would shift some flights from La Guardia to Newark International Airport, creating a shuttle service there that will compete with People Express.

title: Hutton Staff Addition
description: E.F. Hutton & Company said yesterday that Melvin B. Taub, 42, would become its executive vice president, capital markets operations and systems development. He will oversee the provision of information services to the capital markets group and the development of information systems.

title: Restore World War II System for the Joint Chiefs; CARTER DOCTRINE
description: To the Editor:

title: CONGRESS PASSES BILL ON SAFE DRINKING WATER
description: The Senate today approved and sent to President Reagan a five-year extension of the Federal law intended to assure the safety of the nation's drinking water. The vote was 94 to 0. The compromise, the product of a House-Senate conference committee, also expands the scope of the law and requires stricter enforcement by the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: COURT HEARS OF TRUMP CONTACT
description: In his fifth straight day on the witness stand, Pete Rozelle, the commisioner of the National Football League, said yesterday that Donald Trump, the New York real-estate developer, had tried to buy the Baltimore Colts in 1983 only to be told by Rozelle, through an intermediary, that it was ''a waste of time.''

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: ARTS AND CRAFTS SHOW
description: Arts and Crafts Fair, Route 299W and Libertyville Road, New Paltz, N.Y., 914-679-8087.

title: GREENWOOD RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains from the restructuring of long-term debt of $250,000 for the latest quarter and $229,000 for the year-ago period.

description: To the Editor:

REAGAN CONSIDERS EASING FEDERAL RULES ON GENE ALTERED MICROBES
description: President Reagan today began considering proposed rules for developing and marketing the products of biotechnology that could significantly reduce Federal oversight of an important group of living, genetically engineered microbes.

title: SIKES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Wish Fulfilled
description: Julie Clifton, 17 years old, arrived in New York yesterday, but on no ordinary visit. She has cystic fibrosis, and she was taken to the city by the Children's Wish Foundation, which grants wishes to terminally ill children.

title: PANEL FINDS ARMY MISMANAGED TESTS ON VEHICLE
description: Pentagon officials failed to provide adequate supervision of Army tests of an armored troop carrier, leaving the military open to charges that the tests were designed to hide the vehicle's vulnerabilities, according to a forthcoming Congressional report.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BOSTON (AL) - Recalled Rob Woodward, pitcher, from Pawtucket of the International League. Placed Al Nipper, pitcher, on the 21-day disabled list.

title: ANSWERS EMERGING ON SENATE TAX BILL
description: As more details of the Senate Finance Committee's tax revision plan emerge, new questions have been raised by individuals trying to grasp the impact of the sweeping proposal.

title: STUDY SAYS MORE FAMILIES MUST BEG FOR FOOD
description: An annual report on hunger in New York City has found an increase in the time that applicants for public assistance spend not knowing where their next meal will come from and in the numbers of families begging or asking for food.

title: The U.N. Today: May 22, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Disarmament Commission - 10:30 A.M.

title: BIO-MEDICUS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: INSUFFICIENT EVIDENCE ENDS KOHL'S PERJURY INQUIRY
description: A West German prosecutor announced today that he had ended a three-month political corruption investigation of Chancellor Helmut Kohl because of insufficient evidence.

title: PIANO: ARMINDA CANTEROS IN RECITAL
description: THE pianist Arminda Canteros's 75th-birthday concert at Alice Tully Hall Sunday afternoon had much to recommend it. Miss Canteros's playing has a gentle strength and a distinct, expansive personality.

title: Two Police Supervisors Said to Misuse Officers
description: A police captain and a sergeant were suspended yesterday for purportedly assigning on-duty officers to work as plainclothes security guards at a discotheque run by a friend of the captain.

title: Shift at Financial News
description: Financial News Network Inc. said yesterday that Paul Steinle, president and chief operating officer, would step down this summer to start his own company, Steinle Communications Inc. Mr. Steinle, 47 years old, joined the network in 1983 as vice president for programming and production, and was named president in 1984. A spokesman for the company said that Mr. Steinle would remain a director of Financial News, a cable network specializing in financial news and information that reaches 21 million households.

title: AIDE DEFENDS U.S. ROLE IN NURSING HOME CARE
description: A Reagan Administration health official today strongly defended the Government's role in enforcing health care standards in nursing homes against a Senate committee's charge that his agency had permitted widespread squalor and neglect.

title: ADMINISTRATION FAULTED FOR CURBING COMMENT ON CHERNOBYL
description: The Reagan Adminstration, which criticized the Soviet Union for withholding details of its reactor accident, is itself being criticized for ordering curbs on comments to the press about the disaster April 26.

title: Accounts
description: * California Cooler to Burrell Advertising, Chicago, for the black consumer market

title: TELE-COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
R.S. Barnaby, Ex-Glider Pilot
description: Ralph S. Barnaby, a retired Navy captain and glider pilot, died May 14 at his home in Philadelphia. He was 93 years old.

title: CONSUMER PRICES FALL 0.3%
description: The Consumer Price Index, continuing to reflect the collapse in oil prices, fell three-tenths of 1 percent in April, the Labor Department reported today.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET EXCHANGE LATIN VIEWS
description: Senior Soviet and American officials held talks about Central America in Moscow this week, but made no progress toward resolving differences, Western diplomats said today.
