description: The year-ago figures were restated for an accounting change.

title: COMGEN TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SHORT INTEREST ON BIG BOARD AND AMEX AT RECORDS
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest rose 13.1 million shares, or 4.1 percent, in the month ended May 15, to a record 331.4 million shares. The previous high of 318.6 million shares was set in March. The short interest for the period a year earlier was 220.6 million shares.

title: JUSTICE INVESTMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Apollo Industries, Toledo, Ohio, a diversified corporation with divisions in automotive specialty and packaging, elected its chairman of the board, Joe Lewo, to the additional position of president and chief executive, succeeding Morris Fruchtman, who resigned to pursue other business interests.

title: Bonn Has Secret Talks With Albania on Ties
description: West Germany said today that it had held secret talks with Albania on establishing diplomatic ties and indicated that the two sides had resolved a 40-year stumbling block over Albanian demands for war reparations.

title: Advertising; DFS-Dorland
description: DFS-Dorland Worldwide, formerly Dancer Fitzgerald Sample, has won a five-agency fight for the $10 million account of the North American Philips Lighting Corporation.

title: OFFICIALS REPORT STORE DETAINED IRAN DIPLOMAT
description: The chief Iranian delegate to the United Nations was detained for two hours at Alexander's midtown department store two weeks ago after a store detective accused him of shoplifting a raincoat, the police said yesterday.

title: Technology; More Efficient Cogeneration
description: FOR several years, industrial and commercial concerns around the country have been cutting millions of dollars from their utility bills by producing their own electric and thermal energy, using power plants that harness waste heat that would otherwise escape into the air.

title: LED IN BLUE BABY OPERATION
description: Dr. Helen Brooke Taussig, a Johns Hopkins pediatrician who was the founder of pediatric cardiology, a co-developer of the first successful ''blue baby'' operation and one of the early leaders among woman in American medicine, was killed in an automobile accident Tuesday near her home in Kennett Square, Pa. She was 87 years old.

title: FCP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a $35,000 tax benefit. c-Net income includes a tax benefit of $107,000. Sales figures for the latest 6 months and year-earlier period were unavailable.

title: DEMOCRATIC RIVAL ASSAILS PACKWOOD
description: Jim Weaver, the Democrat who was nominated Tuesday for United States Senator, charged today that his Republican opponent, Senator Bob Packwood, has shaped his votes to fit the interests of contributors to his campaign fund.

description: b-Net income This company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: CONCERT: 'DIVINE ORLANDO'
description: THE modern concert format conspires against the music of the Renaissance. Thus we know of Orlando di Lasso's greatness and have access to it on records, but find it infrequently in the concert hall. Orlando's rich and complex music requires highly trained, often small, vocal ensembles. It is not the kind of performing entity that easily mixes with an evening of Chopin or the Requiem of Brahms at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: TRIMEDYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
C.D. Yields Up Slightly
description: Yields on certificates of deposit were up slightly, while bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were down narrowly for the week ended yesterday.

Goldome Selects Vickers & Benson
description: Goldome, the Federal savings bank based in Buffalo, may have considered a couple of New York agencies but when push came to shove it decided on the Vickers & Benson Companies, Canada's biggest agency, which is in Toronto, a mere 95 miles away.

title: RATES ARE LITTLE CHANGED
description: Interest rates were little changed yesterday, though securities dealers said that demand from speculators and investors was noticeably improved from early this week.

title: 3 TIED FOR DODGE OPEN LEAD
description: As the rain stopped and the sun poked through the clouds, playing conditions improved and scores dipped below par today in the second round of the 23d annual Dodge Open Charity Golf Classic. Seven players were under par after two rounds on the Rockaway River Country Club course and four more were at par.

title: IN THE DRUG CAPITAL OF MEXICO, TOP SUSPECT IS THE GOVERNOR
description: A few months ago, say residents of this city of 600,000 in western Mexico, the country's most-wanted drug trafficker came to town on a Saturday afternoon for the coming-out party of a 15-year-old girl.

title: It Takes Two to Contadora
description: The quaintest news of the week describes the Reagan Administration as ''divided'' about the terms of peace with Nicaragua. How could anyone say divided, the White House asks, just because the Pentagon and C.I.A. are at odds with the President's special envoy to Central America while the State Department disputes the Pentagon, the Pentagon disputes State, and the President and Secretary of State are still reserving judgment?

title: Geers Gross Wins Pie Fillings Account
description: Geers Gross Advertising is going to be doing advertising for the pudding and pie fillings of the Comstock and Thank You divisions of Curtice-Burns of Rochester. There will be $3 million in fillings billings, thank you.

title: INTERNATIONAL THOMSON ORANISATION LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company reports its results in pounds sterling, and the figures have been translated at the March 31 exchange rate of $1.48 to one pound.

title: HERS
description: IT was a sunny, dry September Sunday - the kind of day that can convince an unsuspecting stranger that New York is a wonderful place to spend the summer. I was fresh off the plane from Israel. It was only my second day in the United States, but my friends here had made the shocked discovery that I had never even seen a baseball diamond. So they took me out to the ball game. Thurman Munson had been killed in a plane crash a few weeks before, and the Yankees weren't going to be in any World Series that year. But this particular Sunday had been declared Catfish Hunter day. Ole Catfish was retiring, and New York had turned out for him.

description: Sometime over the forthcoming Memorial Day weekend, President Reagan will sign the grant of a Federal charter to the Vietnam Veterans of America.

description: A recently discovered hormone may play a role in depression and the eating disorder anorexia nervosa, scientists reported today.

description: The number of Americans practicing safety at home and on the road has increased, but most Americans do not avoid high-cholesterol foods and a clear majority are overweight, according to a recently released Harris Poll on health and safety habits.

title: REAGAN, DEFENDING BUDGET, SAYS AID IS AVAILABLE TO ALL THE HUNGRY
description: President Reagan today strongly defended his Administration's budget priorities by asserting that America's hungry were suffering not from the unavailability of assistance, but from a lack of knowledge of where or how to get help.

title: CITY TO USE OLD WAY TO REBUILD ICE RINK AFTER NEW WAY FAILS
description: The Koch administration plans to scrap its five-year effort to rebuild the Wollman Memorial skating rink in Central Park and try again with a whole different system.

title: ANALOG DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
PAINTINGS ARE STOLEN IN IRELAND
description: Thieves stole 17 paintings worth up to $45 million, including works by Vermeer and Goya, from a mansion in Ireland early today. The seven least valuable paintings were found near an abandoned van within hours.

title: SEACO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and includes a $3.5 million profit on the sale of assets.

title: Jets' Haight Is an Achiever
description: Mike Haight, Ron and Angela Haight's eldest boy, has brought some joy to Dyersville, Iowa, this spring. Like so many other Middle West farm communities, Dyersville is suffering from mortgage foreclosures, unemployment and gloom.

title: Ralph Evinrude Dies; Made Outboard Motor
description: Ralph Evinrude, the former head of the the Outboard Marine Corporation, which made the outboard boat motor used by millions, died today at the age of 78.

title: INMED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Isuzu-Grumman Deal
description: Isuzu Truck of America said it had agreed with the Grumman Corporation to produce a new walk-in delivery truck. Isuzu is to provide the chassis onto which Grumman's Grumman-Olson division will place its truck body, Jerry Burwell, an Isuzu spokesman, said. No dollar value was put on the agreement.

title: CRIME REPORTS SPOIL ATLANTA'S PRIDE IN RAPID TRANSIT SYSTEM
description: It was a clear bright Sunday, almost 1 in the afternoon, when Jane Davis finished teaching her Sunday school class at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, crossed the street, started down the steps of the subway station, and felt the cool blade of a razor on the back of her neck.

title: Milk Flows on Nicosia Roads
description: Farmers poured milk on the main streets of Nicosia today to protest Government agricultural policies. At least one car skidded and crashed as cow-breeders in convoys protested what they call the Government's failure to take action on rising milk surpluses.

title: FRIEDMAN AND LAZAR CAN KEEP THEIR ATTORNEYS
description: A judge yesterday rejected a prosecution attempt to disqualify two lawyers from representing Stanley M. Friedman and Michael J. Lazar on Federal charges of corruption in the city's Parking Violations Bureau.

title: MUSICAL HOUR WITH KIRI TE KANAWA
description: ''KIRI AND FRIENDS,'' which will be shown tonight at 8 o'clock on the Arts & Entertainment network, is a sort of celestial vaudeville.

Philadelphia Club Drops All-Male Restriction
description: The all-male Union League, faced with declining membership, rising costs and pressure from the City Council, has voted to drop its 63-year-old ban on women as members.

title: People
description: * Jack Krayson has been appointed senior vice president of Scali, McCabe, Sloves.

title: FOREST LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $413,000 for the quarter and $896,600 for the year.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: ROOM air-conditioners often operate for years without much trouble, but this does not mean that they should be ignored. Cleaning the unit and attending to simple maintenance chores at the beginning of each season will help to prolong the life of the machine, insure that it is operating at peak efficiency and usually save on electric bills.

title: PRESSER WINS 5-YEAR PRESIDENCY AT JUBILANT TEAMSTERS' CONVENTION
description: Jackie Presser was re-elected president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters by an overwhelming vote today, with delegates demonstrating boisterous support for the teamster leader, who faces Federal charges of embezzlement and racketeering.

title: Sea-Land Sets Restructuring
description: The Sea-Land Corporation has announced a corporate restructuring, In addition, it said three new lawsuits had been filed against it over its $742 million acquisition by the CSX Corporation.

title: PHILIPPINES SEIZES A BIG CORPORATION
description: A Philippine Government commission charged with recovering the assets of Ferdinand E. Marcos and his associates has taken control of a large corporation, saying that a friend of the former leader may have been behind a takeover bid.

title: OPENING THE HOUSE: SURPRISES IN STORE
description: MEMORIAL Day weekend represents the classic beginning of the season for summer homeowners. It is a time of rediscovering sun, country air and a relaxed way of life. It is also a time of more daunting discoveries. Rare is the homeowner who has not driven out for the first weekend wondering what surprises weather, vandals, bugs, beasts or developers have in store for them.

title: ENVOY TO VATICAN DENIES AN OUSTER
description: William A. Wilson met with reporters today and dismissed suggestions that his resignation as United States Ambassador to the Vatican had been forced.

title: Gift From Paterno
description: Joe Paterno, the Penn State football coach, who is known for the emphasis he puts on college academics, has put his wallet where his mouth is with a gift of $150,000 to help build Penn State's library collection and to provide scholarships for minority students. ''As a coach, I have always emphasized the importance of a quality education, and this was a chance to support that belief,'' Paterno said yesterday. Paterno, who has been head coach at Penn State since 1966 after serving 16 years as an assistant under Rip Engle, is currently active in a new role as a fund-raiser for the university. He is a vice chairman of the Campaign for Penn State, a $200 million fund drive for academic enhancement. The campaign is now in the advance gifts phase. ''I'm repaying an obligation and a debt that I owe to Penn State,'' Paterno said. ''Like many families, we saved for years to educate our five children. As it turned out, the first four decided to attend Penn State, where our costs were far less because of my being on the faculty.'' The Paternos' two daughters, Diana Lynne and Mary Kathryn, are Penn State graduates. One son, David, is enrolled in the engineering school, and another son, Joseph Jr., will enter Penn State's new School of Communications in the fall. The other son, George Scott, is in the seventh grade. Paterno said he talked over the plans for the gift with his wife, Sue, and the children.

title: BGS SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
INTERNS HELPING AT HISTORIC SITES
description: AFTER singlehandedly obtaining landmark status for the railroad depot in Wellesley, Mass., in February, Matthew Kierstead began seeking a larger mission. ''Historic preservation isn't just poring over moldy ledgers,'' said Mr. Kierstead, a freshman specializing in art history at Framingham State College in Massachusetts. ''It's field work and writing, and it's fun. So I applied for a Yankee internship in historic preservation.''

title: MANILA PANEL SEEKING MARCOS ASSETS IS FAULTED BY SOME OVER ITS LAWYERS
description: A controversy has erupted over whether the political views of a New York lawyers' group will adversely influence its efforts on behalf of the Philippine Government to recover money and property taken by former President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: House Raises Loan Ceiling
description: The House voted, 398 to 0, today to raise the Veterans Administration home loan-guarantee ceiling for the second time this year to help the program keep up with the heavy demand for mortgages. The ceiling would go to $38.3 billion, from $17.4 billion.

title: SOVEREIGN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $67,862.

title: SCOTT INSTRUMENTS CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
C.I.A. WEIGHS ACTION ON WASHINGTON POST ARTICLE
description: The Central Intelligence Agency is considering whether to take action against The Washington Post for an article about a classified intelligence-gathering operation involving American submarines, the White House said today.

title: A PLEA FOR THE REVIVAL OF MUSICAL WARHORSES
description: JOSE FEGHALI, the most recent winner of the Van Cliburn Piano Competition, has come in for a fair amount of criticism. Understandably, though perhaps unjustly, the weight of widespread dissatisfaction with the competition process and the values it promotes has landed for the moment on his shoulders.

title: Sri Lankan Planes Bomb Tamil Rebels
description: Government planes bombed Tamil separatist rebels on the Jaffna Peninsula today, guerrillas blew up a factory and six civilians were killed in a brawl with soldiers in Colombo.

title: Don't Punish Times Square
description: The revelations of corruption in New York City have been a great boon for critics of the city government. The Times Square redevelopment project, in particular, came in for a barrage of new criticism, when Michael J. Lazar, a developer involved in the project, was indicted on charges wholly unrelated to it. This is unfair and unreasonable. Even if the indictment involved the 42d Street project, it would in no way detract from the merits of this important effort to give new life to our city.

title: Amoco Plans Cuts
description: The Amoco Corporation plans to cut about 400 people from the work force in its staff departments by the end of the year, the company announced. Each department will develop its own timetable for staff reductions, but the cuts, which will not be across the board, will be made between now and Dec. 31.

title: Kean Planning to Reappoint Jersey Supreme Court Chief
description: Governor Kean announced today that he would reappoint Chief Justice Robert N. Wilentz of the State Supreme Court, despite the urging of a group of Republican lawmakers to appoint a member of their party to the job.

title: COUSINS HOME FURNISHINGS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a writedown of $750,000 on the value of the company's warehouse facility in Portland, Ore. for the quarter and 9 months, and gains from the sale of discontinued operations of $416,000 for the quarter and $8,148,000 fot the 9 months. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $339,000 for the quarter and $1,076,000 for the 9 months. d-Includes a charge from the cumulative effect of an accounting change of $1,405,000. Sales figures for the latest 9 months and year-ago 9 months were unavailable.

title: Market Place; Japan Holdings Bolster Funds

title: NEW TV RATINGS METHOD POSTPONED
description: The A. C. Nielsen company, the research organization that measures television audiences for the networks and advertisers, has agreed to network requests that it delay full implementation of its new ''people meters'' - a method of measuring audiences. Early testing of the devices showed that fewer people than had been believed were viewing network television.

It simultaneously moved to resuscitate its computer business by unifying its huge communications and information systems divisions.

title: Columbia U. Creating Japanese Culture Center
description: Columbia University is creating the Donald Keene Center for Japanese Culture, named for the Columbia scholar considered the leading interpreter of Japanese literature to the Western world. Its establishment has been made possible by a gift of $1 million by the Shincho Foundation for the Promotion of Literature.

title: Scrutiny of Deal Seen
description: Alfa Romeo, which has recorded 13 years of consecutive losses, has been looking for a healthy partner to help revive its fortunes for several years, but market analysts said today that the announcement of a potential marriage with Ford had come as surprise.

title: Topics; Frank/Candid; Nail That Mail
description: ''A golden entitlement program'' -that's what Senator Dan Quayle, Republican of Indiana, calls the large and growing sums Congress appropriates each year to pay the postage on its members' newsletters and other mailings to constitutents.

title: WOLF FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings for 1985 are not available because of the acquisition in December of F.N. Wolf & Co. for 2.8 million common shares. The company said the transaction was accounted for as a reverse purchase acquisition by F.N. Wolf & Co. using the purchase method of accounting.

title: Lobbying Shift Gets Support
description: Administration officials told Congress today that they supported tighter restrictions on lobbying, but with civil sanctions, not criminal penalties.

title: OPERA: WELSH COMPANY'S 'OTELLO'
description: In recent years, the Welsh National Opera has become about the most hospitable forum for vanguard stage direction in the conservative Anglo-American operatic world. The East German opera director Joachim Herz has worked here often, as has Liviu Ciulei, who has a new ''Wozzeck'' here tonight. Andrei Serban directed his first opera here, and now the Welsh have another de facto operatic debut, this time by the West German stage director Peter Stein.

title: PARSONS SUMMER: DESIGN FROM JEWELRY TO FLOWERS
description: The basics of designing beaded jewelry and marketing tips for those interested in selling their creations will be explored in a workshop offered this summer at the Parsons School of Design.

title: AMERICAN LIST CORP reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
DARLING, SHAKY BUT GOOD, GOES 5-0
description: Ron Darling pitched three-hit ball for seven innings today and won his fifth straight game as the Mets defeated the San Francisco Giants, 7-4, and won their third straight. But, despite his success, Darling once more was reminded that Dwight Gooden is an exceptionally tough act to follow.

title: DANCE: SAEKO ICHINOHE JENNIFER DUNNING
description: SAEKO ICHINOHE AND COMPANY celebrated the group's 10th anniversary in a program performed on Tuesday at the Marymount Manhattan Theater. It wasn't a joyous birthday party. After the first sections of an opening piece - Miss Ichinohe's ''Niwa (Japanese Garden),'' a statement of artistic intent and a signature work that incorporates Asian traditional movement and Western modern dance - the dances tended toward an uncomfortable blend of heaviness and insubstantiality.

title: Chinese Ease One-Child Rule
description: Some Guangdong province couples will be eligible for an exemption from the Chinese policy limiting families to one child, the English-language China Daily said today. The province's People's Congress freed from the one-child rule urban couples whose first child was disabled by accident or nongenetic disease, couples who adopted after an incorrect diagnosis of sterility, couples who are both only children, and couples in which one mate worked in an underground mine for more than five years.

title: WALDHEIM CONDEMNS BIGOTRY
description: Kurt Waldheim, under attack for his role with Hitler's army, condemned Nazi crimes today and urged fellow Austrians to fight anti-Semitism.

title: AARON RENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ESSEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: SANDSPORT DATA SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The company had its initial public offering in January.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: FOLK ART ''Muffled Voices: Folk Artists in Contemporary America,'' an exhibition of 49 paintings and sculptures by 20th-century folk artists, is on view at the Paine Webber Art Gallery. Some of the pieces come from the collection of the Museum of American Folk Art, others from private collections. The impact of modern life is seen in the work of the 28 self-taught artists in the show. Their visual vocabularies are similar to those of academically trained artists and their work often reflects many sensibilities of modernism.

title: MOFFETT WON'T GIVE UP RACE AGAINST O'NEILL
description: Former United States Representative Toby Moffett said today that he would press on with his campaign to force Gov. William A. O'Neill into a statewide Democratic primary election on Sept. 9 despite a disputed loss Tuesday in Waterbury that left him short of his goal.

title: Income and Spending Increase
description: Unusually large Government subsidy payments to farmers lifted the overall incomes of Americans by 1.2 percent in April, the biggest increase in two years, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Sears to Create 2 Apparel Units
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's largest retailer, said it would divide its apparel buying and marketing division into two units.

title: Embassy Row; Signals From Moscow
description: By naming as its new Ambassador to Washington a diplomat who speaks little English and has never served here before, the Soviet leadership seems to be sending a signal that relations will no longer be the same.

title: ISRAELI ENVOY ASKS SHULTZ TO RESUME HIS MIDEAST ROLE
description: A special Israeli envoy sought today to win a commitment from Secretary of State George P. Shultz to make a trip to the Middle East to ease Israeli-Egyptian tensions and revive the effort to bring peace to the region.

title: BIOASSAY SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CAREY IS LISTED AS HAVING HELD CITISOURCE STOCK
description: Several prominent political figures - former Gov. Hugh L. Carey, Assemblyman Sheldon Silver and Murray Lewinter, secretary of the Bronx Democratic Committee - were among the investors in Citisource Inc., the company that has been implicated in the scandal in the city's Parking Violations Bureau.

title: Centerbanc Sold To Kinder-Care
description: Kinder-Care Learning Centers Inc., the nation's largest operator of day care centers, has acquired Centerbanc Savings Assocation of St. Petersburg, Fla., for $35 a share, or $37.5 million.

title: BROOK'S SECRET: HE'S RELAXED
description: Hubie Brooks figures his season can only get better. ''I usually start hitting my peak around July and finish real well,'' said Brooks, the shortstop for the Montreal Expos.

title: Esme Hammond, 66, A Prominent Socialite
description: Esme O'Brien Hammond, long a prominent member of New York society, died of pneumonia Monday at New York Hospital. She was 66 years and lived in Manhattan.

title: T.J. Ross in Merger
description: T.J. Ross & Associates, a venerable public relations firm, has reached a merger agreement with Vigderhouse & Osborn, a mere four years old. For starters, at least, both firms, whose combined income will be about $1 million, will operate as they are under the T.J. Ross Group of Companies. Thomas M. Little, who acquired the Ross firm in March, will be chief executive.

title: ENERGY VENTURES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SUNSHINE MINING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ETHIOPIAN LEADER URGES U.S. TO SOFTEN ITS ENMITY
description: The leader of the Marxist Government here says that Ethiopia wants to improve its strained relations with the United States, but that the Reagan Administration must first curb its ''anti-Ethiopia stance.''

title: MAY ENERGY PARTNERS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $4.6 million related to valuation adjustments to the book value of oil and gas properties. c-Net income

title: TECHNOGENETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Coming Soon: Even Less for Your New York City Subway Buck
description: To the Editor:

title: UNITED INNS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income c-Includes 10 cents a share from non-recurring gains for the quarter and 6 months.

title: CONCERT: JANE IRA BLOOM
description: JAZZ melted into performance art in Jane Ira Bloom's ambitious concert Tuesday at Symphony Space. Miss Bloom, a soprano saxophonist with a warm, airy tone, worked with elaborate electronic setups, lighting effects and a dancer as well as a jazz ensemble; the music encompassed Latin-jazz and sustained new age-style pieces.

title: Jersey Bars Schoolboys From Girls' Athletics
description: Boys may not play on girls' high school athletic teams in New Jersey, even though the prohibition seems to violate state laws against discrimination, the State Education Commissioner has ruled.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Richard F. Corbisiero Jr. has been unanimously appointed chairman of the New York State Racing and Wagering Board by the State Senate. He replaces John Van Lindt, who retired at the end of March to resume his law practice. . . . Gary Zimmerman, an offensive lineman, was signed by the Minnesota Vikings after a deal was worked out to releaase him from any obligation to the Memphis Showboats of the United States Football League.

title: Good Connection
description: Directory assistance: In Houston, Akeem Olajuwon's marketing and management company can be reached by dialing 650-DUNK.

title: FMI FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes loss from discontinued operations of $334,000.

title: CITY IS SETTING UP NEW DRUG SQUAD
description: An undercover unit of 101 narcotics officers is being established by the New York City Police Department to arrest the sellers of crack and break up ''crack houses,'' where the potent form of cocaine is smoked, Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward announced yesterday.

title: CONTINUING CARE ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: POP: KAREN MASON, SINGER
description: KAREN MASON is a cabaret performer who favors an ''elevated'' approach to pop music. The singer, who moved to New York from Chicago five years ago, has a voice that is almost of light-operatic caliber and has a preference for ballads that lend themselves to broad, histrionic interpretation.

title: Beating Redbirds No Minor Thing
description: The Louisville Redbirds of the American Association are leading all minor league teams in attendance this year, which is nothing new. The Redbirds have ruled the roost at hinterland turnstiles in every season since they winged their way to Kentucky from Springfield, Ill., four years ago, and in 1983 they even drew more than a million paying fans, a feat that the minors had never seen before and haven't seen since.

title: IF IT'S EXPENSIVE, CHANCES ARE THAT GRANDPA WILL PAY
description: ITEM: Last year Pittsburgh's Duquesne University, which projects a 7 percent annual increase in its current tuition of $5,000 a year, let alumni prepay - at a discount - four years of tuition for children who are not anywhere near college age. For a 1-year-old child, the total cost was $4,500 in cash; for a 16-year-old, $14,500. Kenneth P. Service, vice president of university relations, says that 55 out of the 482 people who took advantage of the offer -well over 10 percent - were paying for grandchildren.

title: TELEVISION TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: VICTORIAN HOME LIFE: DETAILED, IDYLLIC VIEW 2:3.4>
description: THEY are the sentimental visions of life in the American family of a century ago, images that may still be shaping today's expectations about the ideals of home and hearth: The portrait of the perfectly attired Victorian mother at play with her spotless child; the picture of the genial father welcomed home from work by a fawning family; the depiction of a happy new bride embraced by her husband's multigenerational household.

title: Bache Staff Changes Announced
description: Accelerating its efforts to become a major player in the lucrative investment banking field, Prudential-Bache Securities has hired Theodore V. Fowler from First Boston Inc. to head its international investment banking operations, its chairman, George L. Ball, said yesterday.

title: MISSILE BACKERS ARE RE-ELECTED IN NETHERLANDS
description: The Prime Minister of the Netherlands, facing what polls had predicted would be a narrow defeat in parliamentary elections, carried his center-right coalition to triumph today.

title: PUBLICKER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a provision of $375,000 in connection with the resignation of the company's former president on March 31 and a loss of about $552,000 due to costs relating to the closure of the company's contract packaging division. The company said that on March 31 it announced the sale of its idle industrial alcohol facility in Philadelphia for $3 million and the proceeds were used to retire secured debt under its domestic term-loan agreement.

title: CONTROLLER SHIFTS OVERLAP IN CHICAGO AIRPORT TEST
description: Reacting to a near-collision on a runway at a Chicago airport Saturday, the Federal Aviation Administration has begun tests of a new system for providing an ''extra set of eyes'' after shift changes by traffic controllers in the Chicago tower.

title: Fields Issue Is 84% Unsold
description: The record stock flotation of Mrs. Fields Inc., a Utah-based cookie maker, proved too much for London's unlisted securities market to absorb.

title: STIFF CHALLENGE SEEN IN PENNSYLVANIA SENATE RACE
description: By winning the Democratic nomination to the United States Senate on Tuesday, Representative Bob Edgar has posed a strong challenge to Arlen Specter, the Republican incumbent, politicians and political analysts said today.

title: Reintroduction Set for Contac
description: Contac, a popular cold medicine pulled from store shelves in March because of tampering, will return to the market in tamper-resistant caplets and capsules, the manufacturer said today.

title: Pennsylvania
description: A $141 million issue of Pennsylvania general obligation bonds was offered yesterday through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets with yields ranging from 4.40 percent for bonds due in 1987 to 6 percent in 1991, 7 percent in 1996, 7.50 percent in 2001 and 7.65 percent in 2005. The bonds are rated A-1 by Moody's and AA- by S.&P.

title: KOREAN STUDENTS VANDALIZE U.S. BUILDING
description: South Korean students rampaged through a United States Government building in Pusan today, smashing furniture and windows.

title: '84 REACTOR SHUTDOWN CALLED WORST FRENCH NUCLEAR EVENT
description: Nuclear safety officials said today that a reactor shutdown at the Bugey power station in 1984 - which was cited in a satirical newspaper - was the most serious in France's extensive nuclear power program, but they insisted it was very far from a serious accident.

title: ENVIRODYNE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $200,000 for the latest quarter and $711,000 for the earlier period. Latest quarter results include Viskase Corp., acquired Feb. 14, 1986.

title: State Studies Tax Changes
description: New York State officials are studying possible changes in the state tax code if Congress votes to revise the Federal tax system, according to Roderick G. W. Chu, the State Commissioner of Taxation and Finance.

title: DRIVE TO RESCUE 30'S BRITISH HOME FAILS 4:2.6>
description: Monkton, the Surrealist house in West Sussex that some experts have judged the most sophisticated and imaginative example of 20th-century interior decoration surviving in Britain, will now almost certainly not be opened to the public.

title: CUOMO IS SAID TO OFFER CONGRESSMAN NO. 2 SPOT
description: Representative Stanley N. Lundine of Jamestown, N.Y., told Congressional colleagues yesterday that Governor Cuomo had asked him to be his running mate for lieutenant governor. But, the colleagues said, Mr. Lundine had told them he was unsure whether to accept.

title: FOUNDERS FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a capital gain of $161,492. c-Net income includes a capital gain of $36,748.

title: Jockeying Liberals
description: The Coalition for the Homeless received $5,250 from an unusual source the other night - 10 percent of the proceeds of a fund-raising dinner sponsored by the Liberal Party faction headed by Raymond B. Harding.

title: 'Catch the Spirit'
description: For the first time since the Bicentennial 10 years ago, the Travel and Tourism Administration has produced a film encouraging international tourists to come to the United States. The film, ''America.

title: Seeing the Light
description: To help give a boost to ailing harness tracks, the State Racing and Wagering Board this year authorized afternoon harness racing on weekends and holidays, and, in a special concession to Roosevelt Raceway, allowed it to hold afternoon sessions on five Tuesdays, the day the state's major thoroughbred meeting - at Aqueduct, Belmont or Saratoga -shuts down.

title: Periodic Ratings
description: Timing, comedians say, is everything. The same might be said by, and about, politicians.

title: AEGON INSURANCE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Dollar figures are translated from Dutch guilders at the rate 2.613 guilers to the dollar.

title: Tektronix Plans Employee Cuts
description: Tektronix Inc., a supplier of instruments and computer graphics products based in Beaverton, Ore., said it would cut its work force by about 2,000, first through voluntary means, then by layoffs, if necessary.

title: Advertising; At U.J.A., A Focus on Awareness
description: ''W E have a heritage of taking care of our own,'' said Seymour Zises, corporate marketing director of Integrated Resources. He was not talking about his business, but rather about the business of the United Jewish Appeal-Federation, which is out to raise $150 million for Jews in need worldwide.

title: WEST EUROPEANS MARK SAKHAROV'S BIRTHDAY
description: West Europeans marked the 65th birthday of Andrei D. Sakharov today with appeals to the Soviet Union to free the Nobel Peace Prize-winning scientist from internal exile and let him live as he chooses.

title: BUDGET CUTBACKS SEEN LEADING TO WIDER CRISIS OF HOMELESS IN U.S.
description: Substantial Federal cutbacks and a lack of planning by state and local governments could lead to a greater crisis in homelessness than the nation has experienced in recent years, according to a report issued yesterday.

title: Developer Cleared of Perjury In Midtown Demolition Trial
description: A real-estate developer, Sol Goldman, has been acquitted of perjury charges in connection with the illegal overnight demolition of four buildings on West 44th Street last year.

title: Suspect in 14 Slayings Pleads Not Guilty
description: A suspect in a series of slayings and assaults in California pleaded not guilty today to 14 murder charges and 31 other felony charges.

title: Marathon Incentive
description: As a sort of present for the Yonkers Marathon, which will celebrate its 50th running on Sunday, the top 500 finishers in an expected field of more than 700 runners will gain automatic entry into the New York City Marathon, which will be held Nov. 2.

title: PRESIDENT VETOES EFFORT TO BLOCK ARMS FOR SAUDIS
description: President Reagan today vetoed a Congressional resolution that sought to block his request to sell advanced missiles to Saudi Arabia.

title: RULES BAR MANY POOR FROM FOOD AID, STUDY SAYS
description: Government red tape prevents as many as 15 million poor Americans from receiving Federal food stamps, according to a Harvard University study.

title: Continental Illinois Stake
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today that it had retained Morgan Stanley & Company to advise it on selling its large stake in the Continental Illinois Corporation, the Chicago-based bank holding company that the F.D.I.C. helped save from collapse in 1984 with a $4.5 billion rescue plan.

title: Hijacked Plane From Taiwan Starts Its Flight Back Home
description: A Taiwan cargo jet that was flown to China by a defecting pilot arrived in the southern Chinese city of Canton from Peking today on the first leg of its trip back to Taiwan.

title: CALNY INC reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $811,000 from the sale of restaurants and a pre-tax loss of $692,000 on the write-off of costs incurred in the development of potential restaurant sites which the company chose not to develop.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN PRESIDENT WARNS OF FURTHER RAIDS
description: President P. W. Botha warned today that South Africa would strike again against the outlawed African National Congress ''if necessary.''

title: DOUBTS ABOUT AN ELITE BANKER
description: While Antonio Gebauer was a senior banker at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, he dazzled colleagues with his outward wealth, holding lavish parties at his estate in East Hampton, L.I., entertaining the business elite at his expansive Park Avenue apartment in Manhattan and dashing off on the Concorde to buy jodhpurs in a London riding shop for his two sons.

title: Taylor to Join Giants Today
description: On Thursday, Lawrence Taylor will make his first appearance with the Giants since his recent treatment for substance (believed to be alcohol and cocaine) abuse. Coach Bill Parcells said today he did not expect the all-pro linebacker to discuss the subject publicly, and in fact, would probably advise him not to.

title: 17 KILLED IN CHRISTIAN-MOSLEM FIGHTING IN BEIRUT
description: Christian and Moslem militiamen clashed today in their heaviest artillery battle across the Green Line here in four months. The police said 17 people were killed and at least 60 wounded.

title: DEL-VAL FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
LEINER, P NUTRITIONAL PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
RETIREMENT LEAVES POLICE DEPARTMENT WITHOUT A KEY LEADER
description: The retirement of Patrick J. Murphy as the city's No. 2 police official will leave the department without the man who has essentially run its day-to-day operations, and law-enforcement authorities said yesterday that they were uncertain who would fill the post.

title: BRIEFS
description: Amerada Hess Corp. has asked the British Government for permission to delay development of two British North Sea oilfields because of the fall in oil prices.

title: FLAKEY JAKE'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
OCCIDENTAL AND DREXEL IN JOINT BID
description: In a move to bolster its operations outside the troubled oil sector, the Occidental Petroleum Corporation said today that it and Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. had signed a letter of intent to purchase the Diamond Shamrock Chemicals Company for more than $800 million.

title: GIFT GEYSER RAISES TUMULT OVER ROOSEVELT I.
description: For much of its lifetime, the southern tip of Roosevelt Island was a forgotten piece of weed-strewn real estate, but that was before it was blessed with two unusual pieces of philanthropy - the world's tallest man-made geyser and a cluster of 55 pine trees. The trees were donated by residents of Sutton Place, who were motivated in part by a desire to improve their views across the East River.

title: Chemical Offers $5
description: In the latest salvo in the war by New York banks to win consumer dollars, Chemical Bank has offered to pay $5 to any customer who waits more than five minutes for a teller. Chemical said it was offering the reward in seven branches on Manhattan's East Side, and that there was no plan to expand the test to the entire Chemical system. It said it had installed digital clocks in the branches to help customers time their wait.

title: GUILTY PLEA DUE IN CREDIT UNION FRAUD
description: A former counsel for the defunct Hyfin Credit Union will plead guilty today to Federal charges that he helped to siphon $3.7 million from the Brooklyn financial institution for illegal real-estate investments, a prosecutor said yesterday.

title: FIRESTONE TIRE & RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $66,000,000 for the latest 6 months and $1,000,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: FIRST CITY INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $696,000 for the latest quarter and a gain of $383,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: Disaster's Aftermath
description: Two spectacular sets of accidents this year are bringing gradual but possibly far-reaching changes in the international climate. Initial reaction to Chernobyl and the series of American space launch disasters focused on causes and remedies.

title: Guerrillas in Ecuador Seize a High Official
description: The Government said today that guerrillas had seized a member of a constitutional tribunal.

title: Relief Planes Drop Supplies To Solomons Cyclone Victims
description: Relief planes dropped food and other emergency supplies today to victims of a tropical cyclone that slashed through the Solomon Islands in the South Pacific, leaving tens of thousands of people homeless.

title: CITY COUNCIL COMMITTEE APPROVES 3 BILLS FOR STRICTER ETHICS
description: Bills to strengthen New York City's financial disclosure laws, restrict lobbyists and limit campaign financing were unanimously approved yesterday by a City Council committee.

title: Justice Dept. Backs RCA's Sale to G.E.
description: The Justice Department today endorsed the General Electric Company's proposed purchase of the RCA Corporation for $6.28 billion, raising no objections to the two companies' overlapping electronics business.

title: WAR'S SAD TOLL: THE DIVIDED HOUSES OF NICARAGUA
description: On warm summer weekends 25 years ago, Arturo Jose Cruz would pack up his young nieces and nephews and take them for overnight outings to the family ranch in the rural province of Carazo.

title: Freddie Mac
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation is offering $200 million of 8 1/4 percent subordinated capital debentures due in 2016 at a price of 97.30, to yield 8.50 percent, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. The debentures, which are non-callable before maturity, yield about one percentage point more than 30-year Treasury bonds.

title: Dow Drops by 8.81 in a Slow Day
description: Trading activity remained very slow yesterday on Wall Street, where stock prices turned moderately lower after interest rates inched up.

title: CONSERVATIVE RABBIS AFFIRM MOTHER ALONE IS IDENTITY KEY
description: The nation's Conservative rabbis have reaffirmed the principle that Jewish identity stems from the mother alone and have called for sanctions against rabbis who perform marriages or bar mitzvahs for a person whose mother is not Jewish.

title: MUSIC: 'LIGETI IN 'HORIZONS' OPENING
description: PERHAPS no composer of the generation that came of age in the 1960's had a greater impact on the music of that unruly period than Gyorgy Ligeti. His ''Atmospheres,'' which appeared in 1961 at the avant-garde festival in Donaueschingen, was one of the first important works to break out of the straitjacket of rigid Serialism that constrained most of his European colleagues. Shortly thereafter came his ''Aventures'' and ''Nouvelle Aventures,'' a pair of phantasmagorical theater pieces that exploited the voice in arrestingly novel ways and which continue to hold fascination today, when most music of the period is as outdated as the Nehru jacket.

title: FROM FUNCTIONAL TO SCULPTURAL: SHOW OF 3 CERAMISTS 4:2>
description: The frontier between a functional vase or teapot and a ceramic sculpture may be the few centimeters that elongate a neck or a spout. The works of Carolyn Chester and Barbara Diduk, currently on display at the Departure Gallery, straddle the line. The third ceramist of the show, Joy Brown, produces vessels in traditional Japanese forms and, on the nonfunctional side, spirited small figures that swing about on mobiles.

title: 'DINING IN FRANCE' ON 13, 'GOURMET TOUR' SERIES
description: FOR what would have cost a considerable fortune in a glossy advertising campaign, the French have deftly snared, perhaps for profit, the promotional equivalent in ''Dining in France,'' a weekly series of 13 half-hours that gets under way tonight at 7 o'clock on WNET/Channel 13. Offering a ''comprehensive gourmet tour'' of France, the series is a co-production of CEL Communications and the Initial Groupe, a Paris-based company, in association with FR3 French Television and KQED/Golden Gate Productions of San Francisco. Even outright puffery demands complicated production machines these days.

title: WORLD AIRWAYS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a pretax gain of $20,638,000 from the early return of aircraft. c-Net loss and includes a pretax gain of $1,592,000.

title: FORSCHNER GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $14,000. c-Net loss includes losses from discontinued operations of $333,000 for the quarter and $287,000 for the 9 months and provisions for losses on discontinuance of business divisions of $2,522,000 for the quarter and 9 months. d-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $11,000, a provision of $638,000 for a loss on discontinuance of business divisions and a tax loss carryforward of $814,000.

title: Equal Opportunity Nominee Is Rejected by Senate Panel
description: A Senate committee has rejected President Reagan's nominee for chief enforcement officer at the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission after hearing civil rights activists criticize the nomination.

title: DISTRIBUTED LOGIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
DATAVISION INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
UPDATING THE TRADITIONS OF BRITISH DECOR
description: David Mlinaric, one of Britain's leading traditional interior decorators, views his craft with the kind of simplicity and clarity that characterize his work. ''Decoration should be in response to the architecture,'' Mr. Mlinaric says emphatically. ''People very often overstate the case. So much of decoration is just over the top.''

title: Wollman Rink: Years of Delay
description: 1950 - Rink built during the tenure of Parks Commissioner Robert Moses. 1980 - Rink closed after its concerte floor buckles. New rink, projected at $9.1 million, is to open for 1981-1982 season. 1984 - As new rink is about to make its debut, workers find refrigeration coils are corroded and riddled with leaks. 1985 - Rink still closed, with cost of renovation up to $1 million. City Department of Investigation opens inquiry into delays. 1986 - Mayor Koch says city plans to rebuild rink with a new refrigeration system.

title: Bridge: Feigus to Compete Saturday In His 58th Goldman Pairs
description: What is believed to be the world's longest participation streak in any competitive activity is about to get a little longer.

title: FIFTH AVENUE CARDS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes gains on the sale of assets of discontinued operations of $18,000 for the quarter and $868,000 for the 9 months, and losses from discontinued operations of $302,690 for the quarter and $439,407 for the 9 months. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $76,655 for the quarter and $255,919 for the 9 monhts.

title: CARSON PIRIE SCOTT & CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: b-Net income

title: HI-PORT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: LORIMAR PURCHASING 7 TV STATIONS
description: The Lorimar-Telepictures Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire seven television stations, six of them network affiliates, for $1.85 billion.

title: BETHLEHEM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ROCKETS WIN ON SAMPSON SHOT, 114-112
description: The challenge of defending the National Basketball Association title has not been easy, and tonight, in stunning fashion, the champion failed to retain its crown for the 17th consecutive season.

title: PARAGUAY REGIME BUFFETED BY UNREST
description: Paraguayan opposition groups have begun taking to the streets to challenge the country's long-ruling dictator, Gen. Alfredo Stroessner. The Government has been swift to respond, denouncing ''subversive agitators'' and sending policemen and paramilitary thugs to club and tear-gas demonstrators. But over the last two months more than a dozen protest marches have nonetheless taken place.

title: SENIORS AT ANNAPOLIS ARE TOLD THE WORLD HAS BEEN IMPROVING
description: The nation's top military officer today admonished 1,015 graduates of the Naval Academy to keep an open mind, learn to laugh at themselves and not pay too much attention to prophets of doom.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday its latest report of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchange.

title: ALL ABOUT LEAKS
description: The anonymous passing of information from Government to journalist, or what is sometimes called ''the leak,'' may be the most misunderstood activity in the pursuit of power and policy-making.

title: Farm Fund Chief Moving to Wall St.
description: Peter J. Carney, the man responsible for raising the billions of dollars that the Federal Farm Credit System lends to farmers, said yesterday that he was resigning to take a job with a Wall Street firm.

title: Nevada Copter Crash Kills 1
description: An Air Force helicopter carrying Army Rangers on a training mission crashed and burned on the Nellis Air Force Base range early today, killing one serviceman and injuring 21 others.

title: When Courts Decide On Quality of a Life
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC: THE DEL-LORDS
description: TWANGING, stomping rock- and-roll bands like the Del-Lords aren't supposed to come from New York City, where rock often gets tied to arty, exotic or glamorous images. But the Del-Lords played a set of definitive New York rock Friday, when they returned to their hometown to perform at the Ritz. With songs from their two albums, ''Frontier Days'' and the new ''Johnny Comes Marching Home,'' the Del-Lords showed what they've gotten from New York: grit, pugnacity and a firsthand look at hard times.

title: FORWARD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: REXNORD INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $6,313,000 from an accounting change.

title: MEASURE IS INTRODUCED TO STIFFEN U.S. SANCTIONS AGAINST PRETORIA
description: A bipartisan coalition of members of the House and the Senate proposed today that the United States impose stiffer economic sanctions on South Africa.

title: FRANK McMAHON, AN INDUSTRIALIST
description: Frank McMahon, a Canadian industrialist and sportsman known to thoroughbred racing fans in the United States and in Canada, died yesterday at his home in Bermuda. He was 83 years old.

title: ENDOWMENT INQUIRY SOUGHT
description: A Republican Representative from Colorado asked the Justice Department today to look into possible conflicts of interest by two registered foreign agents who have participated in deciding how to spend millions of dollars in Federal funds to promote democracy overseas.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ''D AY-O!'' That's all Harry Belafonte had to sing to have the sedate, black-tie audience in the Waldorf-Astoria ballroom squealing like a bunch of teeny-boppers. Dressed in formal calypso attire - a loose-fitting black shirt, open halfway down his chest and trimmed with gold and silver beads - Mr. Belafonte performed at a benefit that raised $1.1 million for the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center.

title: The U.N. Today: May 23, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Disarmament Commission - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: DURABLES ORDERS FALL A 3RD MONTH
description: Orders to factories for big-ticket durable goods fell for the third consecutive month in April, to eight-tenths of 1 percent, the Commerce Department said today.

title: HALLDORSON SHOOTS 65 TO LEAD TOURNEY
description: On the same afternoon last month that Jack Nicklaus created the latest and possibly greatest of thrills in golf by winning the Masters at age 46, Dan Halldorson went comparatively unnoticed as he won the Deposit Guaranty Golf Classic in Hattiesburg, Miss. That event was an official PGA Tour tournament for those not invited to the Masters.

title: New Preferreds Spread
description: New issues of preferred stock whose dividend is adjusted at auction every seven weeks continue to proliferate, with four new issues this week totaling $300 million.

title: Rebuilding Approved At 2 Hospitals in City
description: Two financially distressed hospitals serving poor areas of the city, Bronx Lebanon and Jamaica, received state approval yesterday to begin large-scale rebuilding.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Marvin H. Koslow of Bristol-Myers has been elected president of the World Federation of Advertisers.

title: BPI SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $124,000. c-Net loss

title: ROAD REPAIR AND LOWER GAS PRICE POINT TO SUMMER OF TRAFFIC JAMS
description: For motorist and traffic engineer alike, it is likely to be a Dickensian summer: the best of times, the worst of times.

title: TOYS R US INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: WESTCHESTER
description: The Memorial Day weekend offers indoor and outdoor pleasures for visitors this year, from Victorian Age exhibitions in Yonkers and some role playing at Jay Gould's Lyndhurst mansion in Tarrytown to hiking at the new Rockefeller State Park Reserve in Pocantico Hills and soaring in a roller coaster at Rye's Playland.

title: U.S.-Canada Talks Conclude
description: The United States and Canada concluded their opening round of negotiations on free trade today with the chief negotiators emphasizing that both countries should benefit from the elimination of bilateral trade barriers.

title: Advertising; Survey Shows Drop In Client Payments
description: The trend of larger advertisers decreasing their compensation to their ad agencies is continuing, according to an Association of National Advertisers Survey.

title: CONSECO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes gains from investments of $266,499. c-Includes $40,111 from investments and $522,665 from the sale of operations.

title: SHULTZ HAS PRAISE FOR SOVIET COURAGE AT CHERNOBYL
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz today praised the Soviet people for showing courage and sacrifice in the aftermath of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster.

title: RENT-A-CENTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in March 1986.

title: Chairman of Ingersoll Is Building on Tradition
description: Someone interested in a publishing career might feel intimidated if his father had been publisher of Time magazine, managing editor of The New Yorker and a major influence in founding Life and Fortune magazines. Not Ralph Ingersoll 2d. Mr. Ingersoll is chairman of the Ingersoll Publications Company, a concern that his father started in 1957 but which the younger Ingersoll built into an empire of 114 small daily and weekly papers. On Wednesday, Ingersoll Publications paid $170 million in cash to outbid several competitors, including the Hearst Corporation, Newhouse Newspapers and Affiliated Publications, which owns The Boston Globe, for the two family-owned New Haven papers.

title: An Economic Stick
description: To the Editor:

title: Paul Bley, Pianist
description: The pianist Paul Bley and his quartet - with John Abercrombie on guitar, Glen Moore on bass and Barry Altschul on drums - will perform tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (242-1785). Sets are at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M; there is a $10 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: BLOWOUT CAUSES FOUR-CAR CRACKUP
description: A four-car chain reaction in the pit area that began when one car lost a wheel while going 190 miles an hour sent mechanics and spectators dashing for safety today. But despite flying debris and hurtling machines, no one was seriously injured.

title: SUSPECT IN MORMON PAPERS CASE BOUND OVER FOR TRIAL IN 2 KILLINGS
description: Judge Paul G. Grant of the Circuit Court announced today, after a long hearing, that Mark W. Hofmann, 31 years old, would be tried on two counts of first-degree murder, three homicide charges and 25 counts of forgery and fraud involving historical documents.

title: Queens Community-Access TV Wants to Be Ready for Cable
description: To the Editor:

title: ANGLING INSTRUCTION ON SHELTER ISLAND
description: More than 20 years ago, a band of dedicated saltwater fly fishermen met in Toms River, N.J., and formed the Salt Water Fly Rodders of America. That organization disbanded several years ago after it turned over its record-keeping role to the International Game Fish Association. But local and state organizations devoted to the sport continue to flourish.

title: HOUSE UNIT BILL WOULD EXPAND ROLE OF AUDITORS
description: Seven Congressmen introduced legislation today that would require auditors to report immediately to Government authorities suspicions of fraud or other illegalities raised in auditing a company's books.

title: E.P.A. MOVES TO REDUCE DDT CONTAMINATION
description: The Environmental Protection Agency took action today to reduce DDT contamination of streams and lakes in the South and West by directing manufacturers to change the formulation of a widely used insecticide containing the outlawed chemical.

title: 46 IN SENATE WOULD SCALE BACK SPACE SHIELD
description: In a blow to the Reagan Administration's top military priority, 46 members of the Senate urged today that the budget for the President's advanced missile defense program be held to an increase of 3 percent this year, far below the 77 percent requested.

title: ABOUT THE STOLEN VERMEER
description: Jan Vermeer's ''Lady Writing a Letter With Her Maid'' is far and away the most important of the paintings stolen Wednesday from Russborough House in Ireland. Although the collection of Sir Alfred Beit, assembled by his father, Otto, in the 1920's and 1930's, includes first-rate paintings by Peter Paul Rubens, Diego Velazquez and Jacob van Ruisdael, the Vermeer is the most celebrated and the most valuable.

title: BOSTON FANS' HOPE HAS A BITTER EDGE
description: Louise Scott said it would happen ''between now and the All-Star Game.''

title: Panel Recommends 3 To Become Taxi Chief
description: A special mayoral committee has recommended three possible successors to Jay L. Turoff as chairman of the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission.

title: Pianist to Make Debut
description: The pianist Cyprien Katsaris will make his New York debut at Alice Tully Hall tonight at 8 o'clock.

title: DYNATECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain on the sale of subsidiaries of $4,001,000 for the quarter and year.

title: MUSIC: A 4-HOUR OPERA, 'ORPHEUS,' BY BIRTWISTLE
description: In the 1950's Harrison Birtwistle was part of a group of young British composers and musicians that included Peter Maxwell Davies and Alexander Goehr. Mr. Davies went on to become the best-known British composer of his generation. Mr. Birtwistle, now 52, is not unknown; he made a splash in the late 60's, and since then he has composed an occasional notable piece (''The Triumph of Time,'' 1972) and, as music director for the National Theater, contributed some evocative stage music for Peter Hall's production of ''The Oresteia.''

title: YANKS TOP A'S, 4-3, IN 11
description: Rickey Henderson passed Babe Ruth on the Yankees' career base-stealing list last night, but his feet did not execute the most significant baserunning feat of the game.

title: TURNER BROADCASTING SYSEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the increased loss in the latest quarter resulted primarily from increased interest expenses generated by the purchase of MGM Entertainment Co.

title: COUNCIL REBUFFS EFFORT TO CHANGE S. AFRICA STAND
description: A bill that would allow the city to put aside its anti-apartheid law in certain circumstances to protect up to $400 million in Federal transportation aid ran into unexpected opposition yesterday in the final moments of a roll call.

title: PAUL HARRIS STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: Share earnings reflect a distribution of one Class B share for each share of common stock.

title: Abzug Reaches a Decision
description: Bella S. Abzug has told friends that she has decided to run for the House of Representatives again, this time from the 20th District in Westchester County. She plans to make the announcement in a week or so and will face at least three other Democrats for the party's nomination.

title: AUCTIONS
description: A MONUMENTAL ancient Egyptian sculpture of the lioness-headed goddess Sekhmet of Memphis, acquired in the mid-1970's by John Lennon, who placed it in the garden of his home in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., will be auctioned from his estate next Friday at Sotheby's. Believed to have been made for the Temple of Mut in Thebes during the reign of Amenhotep III (1403-1365 B.C.), the enthroned figure is one of very few colossal Egyptian works to be auctioned in recent memory, according to Richard M. Keresey, Sotheby's antiquities specialist.

title: Choice of Downwind or High-Altitude Radiation
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Orders Expulsion Of 2 Nicaragua Envoys
description: The State Department said today that two Nicaraguan diplomats had been ordered to leave the United States by Friday in reprisal for charges by the Sandinista Government that four United States diplomats in Managua were spies.

title: His and Her Circumstance
description: When De Pauw University invited Representative Philip R. Sharp of Indiana and his wife, Marilyn, a mystery novelist, to make this year's commencement address together, some delicate political negotiations were required. The couple decided to divide the 20 minutes into two separate but equal halves, rather than alternating stereophonically.

title: LETHAL-GAS PLAN BACKED BY NATO
description: Despite deep reservations from several Western allies, NATO defense ministers today formally approved a Reagan Administration plan to resume production of chemical weapons for the first time since 1969.

title: Boeing Jet Order
description: Lufthansa German Airlines says it will buy up to 15 Boeing 747-400 jetliners in an order valued at about $2.1 billion.

title: Tax Returns Bring Surplus
description: The Federal Government enjoyed a rare $9.93 billion budget surplus in April as a flood of last-minute tax returns swelled Government coffers, the Treasury Department said today.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Competitors and spectators alike will find plenty to do over the Memorial Day weekend in New Jersey.

title: South African Silence
description: To the Editor:

title: Changes for Caterpillar
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company said today that it had formally changed its name to Caterpillar Inc. The Peoria-based manufacturer of earthmoving construction equipment and engines also switched its legal incorporation from California to Delaware.

title: CONCERT: BAROQUE SONGS
description: BAROQUE music for double chorus was the subject of the New Amsterdam Singers' concert at Merkin Concert Hall on Tuesday night. For the event, Clara Longstreth, the conductor, had put together a program featuring Bach's ''Singet dem Herrn ein neues Lied'' and Carissimi's ''Jephte'' and including lesser items by Purcell, Charpentier and Morago.

title: CORRECTION
description: The column ''At the Movies'' in Weekend last Friday misstated Robert Wise's connection with the film ''Wisdom.'' He is executive producer.

title: Company and Goldin Criticize Rink Decision
description: The Koch administration may have been too hasty in its plan to scrap the existing - and not yet functioning -refrigeration system at the Wollman Memorial Skating Rink in Central Park, the City Comptroller and the system's manufacturer said yesterday.

title: 71 Dead in Worst Storm To Hit Solomon Islands
description: Typhoon Namu, the worst storm in history to hit the Solomon Islands, has killed at least 71 people and left about 90,000 homeless, and rescue workers said today that the toll was expected to go much higher.

title: LONG ISLAND
description: Lights, music and action are the dominant themes of this Memorial Day weekend on Long Island.

title: BOSTON FIVE CENTS SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $411,000 from stock distribution by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp.

title: AUTODESK INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
TAFT BROADCASTING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a writedown of $8.8 million in the value of certain children's programs, a non-cash charge of $22.6 million associated with the dilution from the purchase of Gulf Broadcast Corp., and a net gain of $7.9 million from the sale of certain assets, including Taft radio stations in the Tampa-St. Petersburg, Fla. area. c-Net income

title: Bridge; Eastern Event Opens Today In New Home, Javits Center
description: After 57 years in hotels, the world's oldest tournament, the Eastern Regionals, has a new home starting today. Play will be at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, 34th Street and 11th Avenue in Manhattan, with this schedule: Today - Men's pairs and women's pairs, 2 P.M. and 8 P.M. Tomorrow - Newcomers pairs, 1 P.M.; Goldman

title: President Retires At National Steel
description: The National Steel Corporation said yesterday that its president and chief operating officer, Robert D. McBride, had announced his retirement to pursue personal interests.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: HERE BE MONSTERS. By Anthony Price. 255 pages. The Mysterious Press. $15.95. JUNE 1984. Maj. Thaddeus

title: THE DRUG TRADE IN COLOMBIA PROSPERS, CRACKDOWN OR NO
description: Colombia is playing a strangely contradictory role in the war against narcotics, officials here acknowledge.

title: PRESTON L. SUTPHEN Jr.
description: Preston Lee Sutphen Jr., owner of the Seaharvest Fishing and Trading Corporation of Sag Harbor, L.I., died of a heart attack Wednesday at Beth Israel Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived in Sag Harbor.

title: PLESSEY CO PLC reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $11,075,000 for the latest year and $3,921,000 for the year-earlier period. The extraordinary items in the latest year include the costs of defending the bid by General Electric, which amounted to $5.92 million, and the loss on the disposal of a printed circuit business. Plessey said translation of both years' figures from pounds sterling into dollars is at the rate of $1.48 to the pound, the approximate rate of March 28. Share earnings are in American Depository Receipt (A.D.R.).

title: Advertising; 'Dogs' Get Their Say About Food
description: UP to now the involvement of most dogs in dog food commercials has been eating, barking, tail wagging, paw waving and other inarticulate pursuits.

title: Economic Scene; Global Appeal Of Capitalism
description: THE most remarkable development in the century-long struggle between capitalism and socialism is the growing recognition among many socialist leaders that capitalism delivers the goods of economic development. While this does not necessarily imply a surrender of socialist ideology, it does often mean a willingness, even an eagerness, to work with capitalists and let the winds of change blow through their countries.

title: TOWER PROPOSED TO RISE OVER METROPOLITAN CLUB
description: A 39-story residential tower would rise over a portion of the landmark Metropolitan Club on Fifth Avenue and 60th Street under a proposal announced yesterday by the club and a developer.

title: In the War on PAC's
description: Philip M. Stern, the Washington writer and liberal activist, has taken the offensive again in his war against political action committees. A lawsuit filed in Federal District Court in New York this week contends that campaign contributions by these groups are not made to elect lawmakers favorable to the donor but, illegally, to buy the favor of lawmakers who are likely to be elected.

title: Perry Mason Is Back, Defending a Nun
description: We hear the familiar ''Perry Mason'' theme music, the camera moves in on an empty courtroom, and we're instantly set for what's ahead - a first-rate mystery with the added charm of actors we've known in these roles for years. Raymond Burr is full of his old stern authority as Perry Mason and Barbara Hale thoroughly commonsensical as Della Street, in ''Perry Mason: The Case of the Notorious Nun,'' on NBC Sunday night at 9. In this television movie - a sequel to last year's top-rated ''Perry Mason Returns,'' as well as the long-running weekly series - Mason defends a wholesome young nun (Michele Greene) accused of murdering a priest (Timothy Bottoms) who had been investigating financial fraud in the diocese. It doesn't help Sister Margaret's case that she was found with Father O'Neill's body in his hotel room.

title: Congress; The Importance of WHERE Pros Play the Game
description: ''You have to understand,'' said Senator Arlen Specter, ''I'm still mad about the Brooklyn Dodgers.''

title: TIRE BLAMED IN MEXICO CRASH
description: A fire caused by the explosion of a tire in the landing gear was the cause of the crash March 31 of a Mexicana Airlines Boeing 727 in central Mexico, which killed all 167 people aboard, the Mexican Government said tonight.

title: ENCORE COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 26
Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's 360 money market mutual funds rose $2.34 billion, to $226.85 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: New Execution Date Set For Killer in Florida
description: Gov. Bob Graham signed a new death warrant today for Theodore Bundy, who was convicted of killing two sorority sisters and is a suspect in a number of murders around that country that were depicted in a recent television movie.

title: IRISH REPORT NO PROGRESS IN FINDING STOLEN ART
description: The authorities were on the alert at airports and docks today for the valuable paintings stolen from a mansion south of Dublin, but news reports suggested that the works, among them a Vermeer and a Goya, might have already been taken out of the country.

title: Space Panel Envisions Shuttles to Mars Base
description: The National Commission on Space released a report today on America's future in space that said interplanetary shuttles could be traveling to a base on Mars early in the next century.

title: THE SCREEN: 'RONJA'
description: ALL those kids in New York who have been longing to see a movie in the original Swedish can now throng to the 23d Street Triplex, where ''Ronja Robbersdaughter'' opens today. The adventures of Ronja, the spunky daughter of the leader of a medieval band of rovers, or, more plainly, robbers, and Birk, the son of the leader of a rival band, have reportedly been seen by a quarter of the Swedish population, which must mean every prepubescent in the land.

title: Dr. MELVIN S. SCHWARTZ
description: Dr. Melvin S. Schwartz, research professor of environmental medicine at the New York University Medical Center, died of heart disease May 16 at University Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived in New York City.

title: ART: GARY STEPHAN SHOW AT BOONE AND WERNER
description: THE gallery is Mary Boone and Michael Werner, at 417 West Broadway, between Prince and Spring Streets -no mystery there. But the show is ''Gary Stephan 1966 1986,'' and the missing dash is not typographical whimsy, for the 16 paintings on view come from one or the other year, except for the six that were done in 1985. So the question is why these particular years?

title: Best Pulses On the Hill
description: While Congress is debating the subject of professional sports franchises, many lawmakers are taking to the playing field as active amateur athletes in a wide range of endeavors.

title: A NEW TANGO WITH A BOOGIE-WOOGIE BASS?
description: ''IN Argentina,'' says the composer Astor Piazzolla, ''you can change the Government, you can change the literature, you can change the architecture. But if you change the tango, there is trouble.''

title: Rooney Fine Ordered
description: The Rooney, Pace Group said Wednesday that a New York Stock Exchange arbitration panel had ordered it to pay one of its former employees $1.1 million because ''a trade was made by senior management in the employee's account.'' The award will reduce its fourth-quarter profits.

title: WEDTECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes $450,000 of severance costs. c-Includes a tax benefit of $194,000.

title: Breslin Visits Park Ave.
description: ''I was looking for an excuse to hold a party for Jimmy,'' Sterling Lord said Tuesday evening in an apartment house still under construction on Park Avenue. ''It's been a marvelous spring for him, with the book and the Pulitzer.''

title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES
description: The legend grows about the pheenom, in the storied tradition of such marvels who one day appear as if newly fallen from the sky.

title: OUT AND ABOUT ON MEMORIAL DAY
description: OUTDOOR enticements abound this Memorial Day weekend, from guided meanderings, a feast and parades to a plunge back five centuries.

title: Game Wardens Arrest 100 as Poachers
description: State game wardens arrested more than 100 people today in raids on fish markets and meat and fur dealers. Officials said the arrests were part of a crackdown on poachers who supply sturgeon, turtles and other wildlife as gourmet foods.

title: AN AVID BRITISH HORSEWOMAN BEGINS QUIET BLUEGRASS TOUR
description: Queen Elizabeth II, an avid horsewoman, began a private, five-day visit to Kentucky today, where she will inspect thoroughbred farms and a number of mares she keeps in the area.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday LEAVE IT TO POIROT The Apple Corps Theater Company introduces its seventh annual Mystery Festival this week with the New York premiere of Agatha Christie's ''Black Coffee,'' a 1934 murder mystery featuring Hercule Poirot, the Belgian detective. This production, which is directed by John Raymond, runs through June 22. From July 9 to Aug. 17, the company will present a second mystery evening of three Christie one-act plays - ''The Patient,'' ''The Rats'' and ''Afternoon at the Seaside.'' This weekend's performances of ''Black Coffee'' are tonight at 8 o'clock, Saturday at 3 P.M. and 8 P.M. and Sunday at 3 P.M., at 336 West 20th Street. Tickets are $15 for evening performances and $13.50 for matinees. Information: 944-9300.

title: 1,108 MORE APARTMENTS FOR ROOSEVELT I. VOTED
description: Plans for the first housing development on Roosevelt Island since the sliver of land in the East River opened to residents more than 10 years ago were approved yesterday by the Roosevelt Island Operating Corporation.

title: SAMPSON SENDS ROCKETS SOARING
description: For much of Ralph Sampson's three-year pro career, he was labeled as the league's tallest unfulfilled promise. Yet for nearly four minutes at the Forum Wednesday night, he was everything the Houston Rockets wanted him to be, and more than they could have hoped for.

title: NEW BEIRUT SHELLING LIFTS TOLL TO 40 DEAD, 110 HURT IN 2 DAYS
description: Artillery duels continued to raged across residential areas here today. Ten more people were reported killed and 30 wounded, bringing the toll to 40 killed and 110 wounded since the clashes began on Wednesday.

title: RECOGNITION EQUIPMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $478,000.

title: BOSCOBEL CELEBRATING ANNIVERSARY
description: Elizabeth Corne Dyckman was a stubborn woman.

title: ACCO WORLD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SCREEN: DOCUMENTARY REVIEWS KEROUAC'S LIFE
description: ''What Happened to Kerouac?'' was shown as part of this year's New Directors/New Films series. Following are excerpts from Walter Goodman's review that appeared in The New York Times April 16. The film opens today at Cinema Studio 2, 66th Street and Broadway.

title: Perry Ellis Is Hospitalized
