description: The fashion designer Perry Ellis was reported in serious but stable condition at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center early today. According to spokesmen for the hospital and Mr. Ellis's company, Perry Ellis International, the designer is suffering from encephalitis, a viral inflammation of the brain and spinal cord. Mr. Ellis, 46 years old, has been ill for several months and made only a brief appearance earlier this month at the preview of his fall and winter collection.

title: HOUSE, 295 TO 115, VOTES TO TIGHTEN TRADE REGULATION
description: The House of Representatives brushed aside President Reagan's stern warnings today and decisively adopted a wide-ranging revision of the nation's trade laws.

title: WESTERN STEER-MOM 'N' POP'S reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
description: Share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid in February.

title: Quotron Said To Yield on Bid
description: Quotron Systems Inc., the target of an unsolicited $680 million tender offer by Citicorp, has indicated it will not oppose the bid, despite its rejection of an identical offer last month.

title: STOCKS POST BEST GAIN IN A MONTH
description: A powerful combination of professional buying programs and newly found optimism about interest rates sent stock prices sharply higher yesterday, giving Wall Street its best gain in more than a month.

title: SUSPECTED LIBYA INFORMER SLAIN IN EAST BERLIN
description: A former Libyan diplomat was killed this month in an East Berlin park, officials here said today, and there was speculation that his death may have been tied to an investigation into terrorist attacks in West Berlin.

title: DUPLEX PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 26
Demolition of Trees
description: Driving down Atlantic Avenue in the Boerum Hill section of Brooklyn on Monday, Julius Speigel realized something was wrong. What were all those fresh stumps between Bond and Hoyt Streets?

title: F.A.A. OPPOSES CLOSING 2 EXITS ON BOEING'S BIG JET
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said yesterday it would propose a rule change that would bar the closing of two over-wing exits on Boeing 747 airliners.

title: Border Lines
description: The most fascinating Congressional invitation of the month was received the other day by Representative Morris K. Udall, Democrat of Arizona, from Harold W. Ezell, Western regional commissioner of the Immigration and Naturalization Service. Mr. Ezell asked the Congressman to tour the United States-Mexico border near San Diego over Memorial Day weekend with him to observe his contention that ''we have lost control of our southern border.''

title: Africans to Get Business Help
description: A plan to provide technical, financial and management services for small- and medium-size businesses in Africa was announced today by the International Finance Corporation, the private-sector financing arm of the World Bank.

title: Taking Over, Part II
description: Jim Fitzgerald and Dan Finnane have completed arrangements to buy the Golden State Warriors.

title: Joyner's Knee Is Injured
description: Wally Joyner, the California Angels' rookie slugger, suffered a severe bruise below his left knee today when he was struck by a ground ball in the first inning of a game against the Baltimore Orioles.

title: JUSTICE DEPT. SAYS OPINION NARROWS JOB EQUALITY RULE
description: The Justice Department said today that a new Supreme Court decision requires repeal of portions of an executive order under which many Government contractors set numerical goals for hiring blacks, women and Hispanic people.

title: King Loses in Court
description: Don King has lost a decision in Manhattan Supreme Court, where Justice Martin Stecher ruled against the promoter's legal efforts to halt the nontitle heavyweight fight between Gerry Cooney and Eddie Gregg, scheduled for San Francisco on May 31. King contended that he had an exclusive contract with Gregg, but the judge called it an ''unduly harsh and one-sided contract.'' Gregg reportedly received only $12,500 in his last two bouts for King, which Justice Stecher noted put the fighter at the national poverty level.

title: U.S. SAYS MANES INSTIGATED BRIBERY PLAN AT CITY AGENCY
description: Federal prosecutors said for the first time yesterday that Donald R. Manes had initiated and for six years directed the multimillion-dollar scheme to obtain bribes from collection agencies to maintain lucrative contracts with the city's Parking Violations Bureau.

title: KEY SERIES FEATURE A BUSY WEEKEND
description: There will be no Triple Crown winner this year, following Ferdinand's victory in the Kentucky Derby and Snow Chief's in the Preakness, but three other three-race series are about to begin amid a busy Memorial Day weekend of racing.

title: The U.S. Responded Poorly to Chernobyl
description: We all agree that the Soviet Union was irresponsible in not informing the world immediately and fully about the nuclear accident at Chernobyl. What we overlook is that the United States did not fulfill its responsibilities nearly as well as it should have.

title: History on Ice
description: Hello, hockey fans, here we are in the middle of another historic Stanley Cup final, this time between the legendary Canadiens from Montreal and the upstart Calgary Flames, marking the very first time that a team from Calgary has made it to a Stanley Cup final. As . . . Psst. Mister, oh, mister . . . Shut up, kid. Yes sir, folks, real history. Just think, in the whole entire absolute history of the N.H.L., this is the first time - yes, the only time - a team from Calgary has played for the . . . I don't think sooo. . . . Look, kid, the Flames didn't move to Calgary from Atlanta until 1980, and they haven't even gotten a good look at the Stanley Cup since then. Before the Flames, Calgary never had a team in the National Hockey League, not one. You could look it up. Ottawa had a team. Hamilton had a team. But Calgary, before the Flames, nada. Nineteen twenty-four. Nineteen twenty-four?

title: SMITHFIELD FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,682,000 related to the termination of certain pension plans, a gain of $411,000 as a result of adoption of Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No. 87, and a charge of $4,533,000 related to the repurchase and retirement of notes.

title: Divestment Is a Declaration on Human Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: On the Festival Front
description: Sperryville, out in the Virginia orchard country at the foot of the Blue Ridge, wants to make sure that its spring festival this weekend is not confused with any others, so the brochure listing the craft shows, demonstrations and antique sales identifies the 200-year-old village as ''The Little Apple.'' Observable at the bake sale or quilt bazaar may be some of the Washingtonians with nearby country homes, such as David Brinkley of ABC television, former Senator Eugene R. McCarthy and James J. Kilpatrick Jr., the columnist and television personality.

title: Donald Bruce White, New York Caterer, Dies
description: Donald Bruce White, one New York's best-known caterers, died of cancer Wednesday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: ELIZABETH TAYLOR: DIET TIPS ON HOW TO BECOME A SIZE 6
description: Elizabeth Taylor sat propped on a pillow the other day in a pink-peony-laden $1,800-a-day suite at the Plaza Athenee, one of her magni-carat diamond rings saddled prominently to a left knuckle, two private secretaries within earshot and a pack of menthol cigarettes poised on her lap.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: A front-page picture on May 13 showed the President and Nancy Reagan greeting winners of the Medal of Freedom, the nation's highest civilian award. As the caption reported, there were seven winners, including former Ambassador Walter H. Annenberg, but Mr. Annenberg was not pictured.

title: 3 DIE IN CRASH OF PLANE AT JERSEY YOUTH CAMP
description: Three people, including the owner of an aviation company, were killed last night when a single-engine airplane crashed and exploded in a youth camp in the Wawayanda State Park in northwestern New Jersey, authorities said.

title: GOODEN ROUTED AS METS LOSE
description: When Dwight Gooden pitches and doesn't win, it's news. When he pitches twice and doesn't win, it's probably big news. When he pitches three times and doesn't win - well, whatever it is, it happened today in Candlestick Park.

title: TRADERS UNCERTAIN, WITH RATES MIXED
description: Interest rates were mixed yesterday as credit market participants waited for developments in the domestic economy or overseas that would cause rates to rise or fall.

title: Crash of Navy Jet Kills 2 Crewman and Motorist
description: A Navy bomber crashed on takeoff today, skidded along a country road and slammed into a station wagon, killing the plane's two crewmen and a woman driving the vehicle.

title: Production Deal With Stallone and U.A.
description: Sylvester Stallone's production company will finance and produce 10 pictures over the next six years to be distributed by Kirk Kerkorian's new United Artists film company. Mr. Stallone is scheduled to star in at least five of the movies.

title: KNEPPER WINS, 4-0, FOR HIS 8TH
description: Bob Knepper pitched a seven-hitter today to become the first eight-game winner in the major leagues, andthe left-hander also drove in a run to lead the Houston Astros to a 4-0 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: Allied Stores Corporation appointed Donald F. Dunn to the new position of director of profit development.

title: JUDGE CONTINUES FREEZE OF FUNDS IN INSIDER CASE
description: A Federal district judge in Manhattan yesterday granted a request by the Securities and Exchange Commission for an order that bars Dennis B. Levine from future violations of the securities laws and keeps a freeze on his assets.

title: ITALY SEES NO PROOF OF OFFICIAL SYRIAN LINK TO AIRPORT ATTACK
description: High-ranking Italian officials affirmed today that their investigation of a terrorist attack on the Rome airport in December had found that the gunmen had come from Syria and had had contacts there. But they said Italy had no proof of direct Syrian Government involvement in the attack, which took 17 lives, including five Americans, and left 80 people wounded.

title: Sugar Bowl Time Is Changed Again
description: The Sugar Bowl, which has moved its starting time from New Year's Day to New Year's Eve and then to New Year's night in the past decade, is going back to its original daytime schedule.

title: TWO JEWELERS SAY GUNMEN SEIZED THEM AND $1 MILLION
description: Two brothers who operate a jewelry concern in the midtown diamond district told the police yesterday that they surrendered $1 million in gold and diamonds to kidnappers who blindfolded them, drove them around at gunpoint for hours and threatened to harm their families.

title: Studies Show Marijuana Impairs Skills
description: To the Editor:

title: US SHOE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
3 Die as Mine Explodes Near Ulster Border
description: A British major and two police constables on foot patrol near the border of the Irish Republic were killed today when a large land mine exploded.

title: CHEMLAWN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $10,626,000 for the quarter and $30,464,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes tax benefits of $9,878,000 for the quarter and $27,528,000 for the 6 months.

title: Burke Wins Dodge Open With 276
description: Mike Burke Jr., assistant pro at the Edgewood Country Club, shot a pair of four-under-par 68's today to overtake Rick Vershure and win the 23d annual Dodge Open Charity Golf Classic. It was his first important victory as a professional.

title: Roseanne Leto Becomes a Bride
description: Roseanne Leto, the director of program development for prime-time programs at CBS in New York, and Robert James Broadwater, an associate in corporate finance at E.F. Hutton, also in New York, were married yesterday. Peter Leavitt, the town justice of New Castle, N.Y., officiated at his office in Chappaqua, N.Y.

title: BROADWAY
description: THERE are people who don't like the way things - most things - are going and aren't thrilled with what life has handed them. Still, these same people would do anything to hold onto whatever it is they aren't happy about.

title: YANYAN AND ERICA: 2 CHILDREN ENGAGE IN CHINA-U.S. TALKS
description: Erica Rosenfeld is 10 years old and lives on the Upper East Side. Her mother is a lawyer, her father an investment banker. Erica likes Mexican food, Agatha Christie mysteries and the Rolling Stones. When she grows up, she wants to be a biochemist.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: ZAPATA CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a $42.5 million writedown of oil and gas properties. c-Net income

title: AIDS EXPERIMENTS PROVIDE NEW CLUE
description: Researchers have prevented the AIDS virus from invading and infecting human cells in a test tube. The laboratory technique, described in the May 30 issue of the journal Science, being released today, could eventually become a basis for immunization against the deadly disease, the researchers said.

title: Israeli Official Says He Would Try Waldheim
description: Justice Minister Yitzhak Modai said today that Israel had enough evidence to put the former General Secretary of the United Nations, Kurt Waldheim, on trial for aiding in the commission of Nazi war crimes.

title: WYLE LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $76,000.

title: 3-State House Vote On Trade Bill
description: Following are the positions of Representatives from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut when the House approved sweeping trade legislation calling for sharp import curbs. A ''yes'' vote was a vote for the bill; a ''no'' vote was a vote against the bill; an ''xxx'' denotes a member not voting.

title: WARD APPOINTS A STATE OFFICIAL AS TOP DEPUTY
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward yesterday named Richard J. Condon, a former police commander with an extensive anticorruption background, to be the department's No. 2 official.

title: MUSIC: THREE PREMIERES ON 'HORIZONS' PROGRAM
description: ALTHOUGH the theme of the New York Philharmonic's ''Horizons'' concerts this year is ''Music as Theater,'' most of the works presented last night at Avery Fisher Hall in the second program of the series fell outside that roomy category. Two of the five pieces could be classified as stage works, in fact as dance pieces: Mauricio Kagel's ''Pas de Cinq'' and Morton Gould's ''Tap Dance Concerto.'' The other three, all New York or United States premieres, might have turned up on any conventional program of modern music anywhere.

title: Illinois Congressman Is Out
description: Representative John E. Grotberg, Republican of Illinois, who is recovering from the effects of a coma he suffered earlier this year, is withdrawing his bid for re-election, an aide announced today. On Friday, Representative George M. O'Brien, Republican of Illinois, also withdrew a re-election bid, citing severe health problems, including prostate cancer.

title: Kunitz Observance Set
description: A poetry reading marking the birth date of the poet Stanley Kunitz, who will be 81 this July and who received a Pulitzer Prize in 1959, is planned tonight at 8 o'clock at the Westside Y.M.C.A., 5 West 63d Street.

title: It Would Be a Mistake To Bar Waldheim
description: To the Editor:

title: RUTGERS GRADUATES URGES TO CARE ABOUT POOR
description: The president of the Children's Defense Fund, Dr. Marian Wright Edelman, urged the graduating class of Rutgers University today to help turn America's priorities from weapons to help for the needy and the hungry.

title: ELAN CORP reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: Dollar figures are translated at the rates of $1.29 a Irish pound for the year ended March 31, 1986, and $1.01 a Irish pound for the year ended March 31, 1985.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in Metropolitan Report on Wednesday misstated the number of schoolchildren from China who arrived in New York for a cultural exchange. There were 56.

title: CONTRAS DEBATE HOW TO WIDEN GROUP'S APPEAL
description: Top Nicaraguan rebel leaders are debating how to broaden their political appeal in light of a widespread perception that their movement is dominated by those loyal to the deposed dictator, Anastasio Somoza Debayle, according to several rebel and Congressional sources.

title: Carney Quits House Race
description: Representative William Carney of Suffolk County announced yesterday that he would not seek a fifth term. The 43-year-old Congressman, who was the only Conservative Party member of the House until switching to the Republicans last year to avoid challenges in a primary, was denied the endorsement of Republican and Conservative leaders in Suffolk in the last few days. They said they were fearful that Mr. Carney's support of the Shoreham nuclear power plant made him vulnerable.

title: SCREEN: 'SCREAMERS'
description: ''GIRLS SCHOOL SCREAMERS,'' which opens today at the Times Square Theater, is one of those all-fall-down murder movies made for summer, when school is out and the kids are looking for something to do. Why should they swim and sun, the feeling is, when they could be watching a bunch of kids their own age die horrible, blood-curdling deaths?

title: Allen Boretz, 85, Playwright And Hollywood Screenwriter
description: Allen Boretz, a playwright, Hollywood screenwriter and co-author of the play ''Room Service,'' died of cancer Wednesday at the Branford (Conn.) Hospice. He was 85 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: JAMESWAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
ADOBE RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss restated for an affiliate's change to successful efforts method of accounting effective Jan. 1. The effect on Adobe was a reduction totaling $734,000 from the previously reported first quarter 1985 amount. The latest first quarter net was reduced by preferred dividend requirements to a loss per share. The latest quarter reflects the consolidatin of Madison Resources Inc. and Adobe Oil & Gas Corp., on Oct. 31, 1985.

title: CHARTER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $1,134,000 for the latest quarter and $1,828,000 for the year- earlier period. The year-ago period is also after a loss of $6,921,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. Charter attributed its latest first quarter loss to a $26,987,000 writedown of its interest in an oil-producing concession.

title: TENNESSEE TRAIN LINKS TOURISM AND TRADITION
description: Two and a half hours before the 10-car Tennessee Homecoming Special pulled into the old brick depot here, Willie Avent and her husband, Walter, were waiting by the tracks, camped out in folding chairs and dressed in their Sunday finery.

title: CITY U. CHIEF SAYS 150 STUDENTS AT A BRONX COLLEGE ARE HOMELESS
description: The Chancellor of the City University, Joseph S. Murphy, said yesterday that 150 students at Bronx Community College were homeless.

title: BRAZIL BANKING CUSTOMS CITED IN MORGAN CASE
description: Brazilian banking clients of Antonio Gebauer may have given him discretionary authority over the money the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company suspects he diverted from their accounts, a source familiar with the matter said yesterday.

title: YEN PINCHING A JAPANESE CITY
description: This is a city that feels under siege - the siege of the strong yen. Its cabdrivers sigh when asked how things are going. Its exporters talk of lost orders and impending crisis. Its politicians speak bitterly of betrayal by the national Government.

title: CONSOLIDATED STORES reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: b-Includes a non-recurring tax benefit of $200,000, or 2 cents a share. Share earnings are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid in November.

title: 'Lov'd I Not Honor More'
description: The posthumous publication of the love letters between Mrs. Wallis Simpson and King Edward VIII call to mind three moments in which the Windsors, as they came to be called, touched my life.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Michele Hendricks, West End Cafe, Broadway near 114th Street (666-8750). Michele Hendricks got her training singing in the family group led by her father, Jon Hendricks, which also included her stepmother. It was very demanding training because the group's vocal style was based on Lambert, Hendricks and Ross, the vocal trio in which Mr. Hendricks sang with Dave Lambert and Annie Ross in the late 1950's, and, like that group, featured Mr. Hendricks's tongue-twisting lyrics. Michele Hendricks's appearance tonight and tomorrow at the West End Cafe is her New York cabaret debut as a solo performer. Since leaving the family act, she has toured Japan and played theater dates here and in Washington with David (Fathead) Newman. Shows tonight and tomorrow are at 9 and 10:30 P.M., midnight and 1:30 A.M. There is a $5 cover and a $6.50 minimum tonight and a $6 cover and $7.50 minimum tomorrow night.

title: ART: GERMAN DRAWINGS OF 20's AT GUGGENHEIM
description: ONE of the most instructive exhibitions of the season, and from time to time one of the most haunting, is the show of ''German Realist Drawings of the 1920's'' that can be seen through July 6 at the Guggenheim Museum. No one ever thought of the Guggenheim's ramps as a good place to show drawings, but as a matter of fact they turn out to be as supportive of the German realists as they are hostile to the small but all too numerous drawings by Enzo Cucchi that have been broken out like measles lower down the slopes.

title: 3 Charged With Fraud In Ammunition Sale
description: A Virginia company, two of its officers and a Salvadoran were indicted today on charges of selling El Salvador $4.7 million in inferior Yugoslav ammunition while depicting it as having been made in the United States.

title: Wang to Buy All of Intecom
description: Wang Laboratories said today that it had agreed to buy the 80 percent of Intecom Inc. that it does not already own in an exchange of stock valued at about $156.6 million.

title: 7-Eleven to Test Fast-Food Sales
description: The Southland Corporation, the owner of the 7-Eleven store chain, said it would begin selling the products of Church's Fried Chicken and Hardee's restaurants in some of its stores to test an expansion of its ready-to-eat food sales.

title: CANADIENS TAKE 3-1 LEAD IN SERIES
description: The game itself was a marvel of defensive restraint, with both the Montreal Canadiens and Calgary Flames attempting to execute with caution. But that restraint was abandoned after Montreal's 1-0 victory tonight at the Forum as the teams engaged in a 10-minute brawl that resulted in nine players being penalized. Some may face fines and suspensions.

title: MUBARAK AND HUSSEIN DISCUSS GAZA
description: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and King Hussein of Jordan recently discussed a proposal for Egyptian-backed Palestinian self-rule in the occupied Gaza strip, Arab and Israeli officials said today.

title: EXAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Shootings in Punjab Kill 11 and Wound 7
description: Six assailants thought to be Sikh extremists fired automatic weapons from jeeps into crowds at a shopping district today, killing 11 people and seriously wounding 7, the police reported.

title: Nassau County Insured Bonds
description: Nassau County, L.I., is offering about $78.5 million of insured general obligation bonds, through underwriters led by Chemical Bank.

title: CUSTOM ENERGY SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $1,361,820 for the quarter and 9 months related to the sale of certain assets.

title: SUBARU OF AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Share earnings reflect an 8-for-1 stock split paid in March 1986.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, MAY 23, 1986
description: International NATO backed chemical-weapons production by the United States. Several countries were sharply critical, but defense ministers approved a list of American goals that include an end to a 17-year ban on production of the weapons. [ Page A1, Column 3. ] Nicaraguan rebels are debating how to broaden the appeal of their movement and to assure civilian control of military guerrilla units, according to rebel and Congressional sources. The debate is spurred by the perception that the main rebel army is dominated by former soldiers of the country's deposed dictator, Anastasio Somoza Debayle. [ A1:5. ] A former Libyan diplomat died in a slaying this month in an East Berlin park, officials in Bonn said. There were unconfirmed reports that the man was acting as an informer for the authorities investigating terrorist attacks in West Berlin. [ A1:4-6. ] Artillery duels raged in Beirut for the second straight day. Officials said the clashes between Moslem and Christian gunners brought casualties to 40 killed and 110 wounded since the fighting, termed the worst civil warfare in the city in months, erupted Wednesday afternoon. [ A9:1. ] Egypt and Jordan leaders discussed the Gaza strip in a recent meeting, according to Arab and Israeli officials. They said the countries' chiefs studied a proposal for Egyptian-backed Palestinian self-rule in the occupied territory. [ A3:1-3. ] National The House voted to revise trade laws despite President Reagan's opposition. The bill, passed by a vote of 295 to 115, would require the President to take more vigorous actions against trading partners that subsidize imports to this country or prevent American goods from entering their own markets.

title: Guitar Solos and Duets
description: The guitarists Sharon Isbin and Carlos Barbosa-Lima will present a program of duets and solo works from Brazil, Cuba and the United States tomorrow afternoon at 4 o'clock at the Guitarreria Orozco, 155 Avenue of the Americas (near Spring Street). There is a suggested contribution of $5. The number for information is 691-8620.

title: ALFIN FRAGRANCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
AGENCY WOULD PROHIBIT SMOKING IN MOST PARTS OF FEDERAL BUILDINGS
description: Federal officials proposed stringent new rules today that would prohibit smoking in most areas of 6,800 Federal buildings around the country.

title: HISTORY OF MILITARY MAKING COMEBACK ON U.S. CAMPUSES
description: Military history is growing intellectually fashionable again on American campuses. Such a development would have been unthinkable during the Vietnam War, and it has evidently surprised many historians even in the relatively conservative atmosphere of the past few years.

title: HOUSE PANEL AND CANADIANS COOPERATE ON THEIR DEAVER INQUIRIES
description: Investigators in the United States Congress and the Canadian Parliament have joined to examine the lobbying activities of Michael K. Deaver, the former White House deputy chief of staff.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Bo Diddley, the Lone Star Cafe, 61 Fifth Avenue, at 13th Street (242-1664). The Bo Diddley beat is one of rock's basic rhythms. It's the rock extension of African rhythms and Latin clave; it has also been the pulse that links Mr. Diddley's ''Mona'' to Buddy Holly's ''Not Fade Away'' to Bruce Springsteen's ''She's the One.'' Mr. Diddley, who was born Elias McDaniel in 1928 in Mississippi and grew up in Chicago, was a part of that city's blues explosion in the 1950's, but his songs were different. Set to his trademark beat, they were often playful dialogues with his maracas-playing sidekick, Jerome Arnold. Mr. Diddley, with his eyeglasses and square guitars, still takes the Bo Diddley beat on the road every year. He will be at the Lone Star tonight and tomorrow, alternating sets with the Carter Brothers, who begin at 9:30 P.M.; Mr. Diddley will appear at about 10:30 P.M. and 1 A.M. Tickets are $12.

title: 'SLEEPS SIX,' A BBC PLAY, ON A&E
description: FOR the past few Fridays at 8 P.M., cable's Arts & Entertainment Network has been presenting a collection of seven plays called ''Oxbridge Blues.'' They were produced for the BBC in 1984. The writer adapting his own short stories is Frederic Raphael, whose previous credits include the films ''Darling'' and ''Two for the Road'' and the television series ''The Glittering Prizes.'' As is evident in ''Sleeps Six,'' tonight's final installment in the series, Mr. Raphael is an uncommonly keen observer of English manners, both elegant and nasty.

title: PHOTOS POINT TO WIND BURST SINKING TALL SHIP
description: Satellite pictures taken the morning the Pride of Baltimore sank last week have led some weather specialists to suspect that the vessel was overturned by a sudden burst of wind of a type that has been associated with airline accidents on landing and takeoff.

title: WHITHER G.O.P.-TEAMSTER ALLIANCE?
description: Ten years ago, Labor Secretary Walter J. Usery, appearing on behalf of the Ford Administration, went before a convention of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and declared an alliance between the union and the Republican Party.

title: Iranian Envoy Denies Trying to Shoplift Coat
description: Iran's chief delegate to the United Nations denied charges today that he was trying to shoplift a raincoat from a Manhattan department store two weeks ago and suggested that an F.B.I. agent tried to use the incident to blackmail him.

title: AGENCY RENT-A-CAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Fairness Now for Retirement Later
description: Many working Americans have concluded, hastily and wrongly, that tax reform would sabotage their retirement security. The reason is that the Senate Finance Committee reform bill would restrict tax deductibility of contributions to I.R.A. accounts. Yet the public should applaud, for this bill would have the opposite effect and make retirees far less likely to be stranded without pensions. The key is a little-understood idea called five-year vesting.

title: Kodak Introduces New Battery Lines
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, as part of its continuing efforts to diversify beyond its basic photographic business, yesterday introduced the first 9-volt lithium battery for mass consumer use along with a full line of alkaline batteries.

title: PRESIDENT YVES MONTAND? NOT EVERYBODY SCOFFS
description: Yves Montand, France's pre-eminent singer, actor and entertainer, has long been active in political causes. Lately French political commentators have begun to speculate about whether he might have political ambitions of his own.

title: TORO COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
Bronx Arts Ensemble
description: The Bronx Arts Ensemble will present an unusual Memorial Day tribute at the Woolworth Chapel of Woodlawn Cemetery in the Bronx Sunday afternoon at 2.

title: AMERICAN REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $10 million of the sale of the Williamsburg Hospitality House.

title: BELDEN & BLAKE ENERGY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a $4.1 million charge from the writedown of oil and gas-related assets. c-Net income

title: CHARTWELL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $164,000, or 13 cents a share, for the latest quarter and $60,000, or 5 cents a share, for the year-ago period.

title: MANAGEMENT CITED AS KEY TO SAFETY AT U.S. NUCLEAR REACTORS
description: Members of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission today listed the best and worst nuclear power plants in the United States and said the differences were mainly a result of management, not equipment or design.

title: HUDSON VALLEY
description: Visitors to the Hudson Valley this weekend will be able to take part in two tricentennial celebrations as well as a variety of less-historic events.

title: 3 MIDRISE STRUCTURES ADD TO HOUSING ON UNION SQ.
description: On the east side of Union Square, the formidable Zeckendorf Towers project is rising, obliterating memories of the S. Klein department store that once stood there. With its four residential towers above a five-story base of 300,000 square feet of office space, the Zeckendorf development is expected to become the anchor for a broader transformation around Union Square.

title: JAMES E. MURPHY
description: James E. Murphy, a retired justice of the Connecticut Supreme Court, died of cancer May 12 at the Connecticut Hospice in Branford, He was 89 years old and a lifelong resident of Bridgeport.

title: Wind and Thunder
description: Wind and Thunder, a group that mixes jazz and non-Western music, will perform tonight and tomorrow at 8 P.M. at JAM Gallery, 503 Broadway, below Spring Street (874-4153). The group includes Bill Cole on Middle Eastern and Far Eastern winds, Julius Hemphill on saxophones and flute, Joe Daley on tuba and Hafiz Shabazz on percussion; tickets are $6.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: ONE of the delights and challenges of reviewing restaurants as opposed to books, movies or art is that the subjects of the critiques are alive and forever changing. A movie, for instance, may be enjoyed slightly more or slightly less a second time, but the subject matter is immutable. Restaurants, though, grow and mature, like children - some develop diligent work habits and make something of themselves, while others slough off and invariably ''come to no good,'' as my parents used to say.

title: THE STAGE: 'OLYMPUS,' A 30's STYLE MUSICAL
description: FROM its firecracker-like opening number, ''Welcome to Greece,'' in which a smirking Greek chorus of three men - ''Tom, Dick and Horace'' -and a doll-faced, out-of-step chorus girl, ''Delores'' (Faith Prince), arrive to set the scene, the new musical ''Olympus on My Mind'' percolates with an old-fashioned sense of naughty musical-comedy fun. Delores's ineptitude, it turns out, is part of the merriment. Periodically throughout the evening, she models the wares of the show's fictional producer, Murray the Furrier, whose name glows in lights at the rear of the stage.

title: CORRECTION
description: A front-page article on Tuesday about the planned sale of two Louisville newspapers to the Gannett Company misstated the date of the announcement. It was Monday.

title: GARVEY CONTRADICTS ROZELLE
description: Ed Garvey, the former executive director of the National Football League Players Association and now a candidate for the United States Senate in Wisconsin, offered testimony in Federal District Court yesterday that contradicted many points made earlier by Pete Rozelle, the N.F.L. Commissioner. As a witness in the United States Football League's antitrust suit against the N.F.L., Garvey said that in 1982 the N.F.L. had put forward ''specific proposals'' that he thought ''dealt directly'' with the U.S.F.L., the formation of which had just been announced.

title: The Worm and the Apple; Roll Those Billboards Off the Road
description: Blame the Europeans, who thought up the idea, for those eye-catching, street-clogging trucks bearing billboards through the densest New York traffic. And serve giant worms on the entrepreneurs who thus prey on public discomfort. City officials should run them off the road.

title: Swans at the Ritz
description: The Swans will perform tonight at the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street (254-2800). Tickets are $13.50 in advance; Ritual Tension opens at about 11:30 P.M., with the Swans at 1 A.M.

title: IT'S A HAPPY TIME FOR THE MOTORIST
description: Plentiful gasoline, at sharply lower prices, will make this Memorial Day weekend, the traditional start of the peak summer driving season, one of the least worrisome for motorists in recent years, according to oil industry experts and motoring groups.

title: New Post for Brooks?
description: Herb Brooks, who recently withdrew his name from consideration as coach of the Winnipeg Jets, will be named next week as the hockey coach at St. Cloud State University in Minnesota, according to a report by WUSA, a television station in Minneapolis. Brooks, coach of the 1980 gold medal United States Olympic hockey team and coach of the Rangers for more than three seasons, has indicated when mentioned for available coaching positions that he preferred to stay close to his home in the Minneapolis-St. Paul area. St. Cloud, currently operating a National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III hockey program, was encouraged to move to Division I in three or four years by Brooks when he was asked to act as a consultant.

title: SCREEN: JOBETH WILLIAMS IN SEQUEL, POLTERGEIST II'
description: MAKING a sequel to a hit movie is always a gamble. When the original has the signature of a giant talent, and the sequel doesn't, it's a long shot. ''Poltergeist II: The Other Side'' finishes out of the money - at least artistically.

title: Market Place; Lorimar Faces New Challenge
description: THE Lorimar-Telepictures Corporation has fared well on Wall Street. Since October, when the merger between Lorimar and Telepictures was first announced, the latter's stock has risen from $17 to $31. (The union of Telepictures and Lorimar was accomplished by the issue of more Telepictures shares.) Now the company, by its expensive acquisition of seven TV stations, is taking on fresh challenges.

title: Benchmark Decisions
description: Having spent a season learning how to do things by the seat of their pants, the nation's high school basketball coaches will be allowed to loosen their belts a bit next fall.

title: BALLET THEATER: 'MURDER' BY GOREY AND GORDON
description: BOTH Edward Gorey, the artist and author of mock Gothic stories, and David Gordon, the experimental modern-dance choreographer, have been largely known as cult figures.

title: RIGHTISTS BREAK UP RALLY IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha was forced to cancel a rally by the governing National Party tonight after the police lobbed tear-gas at hundreds of right-wing white militants who besieged the meeting hall.

title: Diner's Journal
description: A TRIM little French bistro has opened on Lexington Avenue near 65th Street that, based on a recent sampling, is capable of offering solid and satisfying fare at reasonable prices for this expensive neighborhood. The five-month-old Sel & Poivre is the latest venture of Barbara Mora, formerly of Bistro Bamboche on York Avenue. The dining room has a warm and congenial feeling with its white walls and dark wood wainscotting, candlelight, decorative wall beams and cozy bar. It seems to be attracting largely a genteel neighborhood crowd at the moment, but as word spreads that could change dramatically - let's hope not for the worse.

title: FRIENDS OWE US THEIR VOTES
description: The United States has a few steadfast friends in the United Nations. Yet many countries to whom we dispense foreign aid continue to thumb their noses at us on important issues. The result is that despite our prominence on the international stage, we remain isolated in the world's most visible international forum.

title: ART: JASPER JOHNS PRINTS ON SHOWS AT THE MODERN
description: IT would be hard for ''Jasper Johns: A Print Retrospective'' not to be fascinating. Johns has one of the sharpest minds and most distinct sensibilities of any living artist. The prints may not have the density of his paintings, but their individual and collective impact is nevertheless considerable. The prints also clarify the paintings and shed light on how this seductive and elusive artist thinks.

title: IN THE NATION
description: Which of the two nations most involved - the United States and Nicaragua - wants the Contadora treaty less?

title: D. B. Cooper Money Split
description: Brian Ingram, who found $5,800 of a ransom paid to the plane hijacker D. B. Cooper, will get to keep $2,760.

title: Mattingly's Masters
description: Don Mattingly's career batting average is now up to .324 - the last New York ballplayer to retire with a higher one was Joe DiMaggio, at .325 when he hung 'em up 35 years ago - but not every pitcher has fallen frequent victim to him. Among all active hurlers whom Mattingly has faced at least six times, these have fared the best (L denotes left-hander):

title: Taking Over, Part I
description: The Chicago Bulls have called a news conference for today to announce that Doug Collins will fill the coaching vacancy created when the club dismissed Stan Albeck. ''I would not have taken it if I didn't get a fair shake,'' said Collins, who was reportedly seeking a three-year contract.

title: 2 Landlords Get a Year For Harassing Tenants
description: Two landlords were sentenced yesterday to one to three years in prison for threatening and harassing tenants into moving out so they could upgrade their buildings and get higher rents.

title: F.A.A. CHIEF BACKS STIFF SAFETY FINES
description: The head of the Federal Aviation Administration today defended his agency's airline inspection program and its stiff fines for safety violations, suggesting that past agency policies had led to insufficient penalties.

title: AVERY ROCKEFELLER, INVESTMENT BANKER AND CONSERVATIONIST
description: Avery Rockefeller, co-founder and former chairman of the board of the New York investment banking firm of Schroder, Rockefeller & Company, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Overhills, N.C. He was 82 years old and also had a home in Greenwich, Conn.

title: OIL'S PLUNGE DRAGS GAS DOWN
description: After oil prices plunged last January, the San Diego Gas and Electric Company stopped buying natural gas for the first time in years and substituted lower-cost fuel oil to fire up its electric generators.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. California Angels, at Yankee Stadium, 7:35 P.M. Reggie Jackson, who turned 40 last Sunday, comes in with the Angels for the first time this year.

title: ALBERTSON'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
LIVELY AT 75, THE LIBRARY THROWS A PARTY
description: Outside, the stone lions sported silk satin top hats and black bow ties, as befits a diamond jubilee. Inside, a glittering dinner-dance last night celebrated the 75th anniversary of the New York Public Library at Fifth Avenue and 42d Street. There were place cards for some 1,500 guests, a great many of whose well-known names could also be found somewhere in the library's 88 miles of stacks - if not printed on book spines, then in ''Who's Who in America'' or the Social Register.

title: ENGINEERED SUPPORT SYSTEM reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, MAY 23, 1986
description: The Economy

title: MARTIN GABEL, ACTOR, DIRECTOR AND PRODUCER, IS DEAD AT 73
description: Martin Gabel, whose career as an actor, director and Broadway producer spanned four decades, died of a heart attack yesterday. He was 73 years old.

title: AFRICA AID: NEED FOUND GROWING
description: African countries will need twice as much annual foreign aid as they now receive and sweeping internal policy changes that free private initiative if they are to pull themselves out of an economic crisis, according to a study issued today by the Committee on African Development Strategies.

title: CASE UNDERLINES PSYCHIATRIC ISSUE: TO KEEP CONFIDENCES OR REPORT THREATS
description: Last November Billy Gene Viviano walked from his psychiatrist's office into a legal tangle.

title: CLASSIFIED FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a loss on realized investments of $893,000.

title: HONDURAN DOUBTS NEARNESS OF CENTRAL AMERICAN TREATY
description: The President of the Honduran Congress said today that he doubted that a Central American peace treaty was imminent or that Nicaragua would comply with a treaty if one were signed.

title: Advertising; A Saatchi Purchase Makes a Purchase
description: Now here's another Saatchi & Saatchi acquisition.

title: ARLINGTON REALTY INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CITY WILL ASSIST UNION IN STUDY OF PAY EQUITY
description: City officials and the city's largest municipal employees union ended years of dispute yesterday by agreeing to go forward with a study on whether women and minority employees are being paid less than their white, male counterparts.

title: Plea From the British
description: A sign of the times:

title: Ralph Goldstein Dies; Queens Assemblyman
description: Assemblyman Ralph Goldstein, a Queens Democrat who served in the Legislature since 1976, died Wednesday at Albany Medical Center Hospital after suffering a heart attack Tuesday night. He was 64 years old.

title: A 1491 Hebrew Book Is Sold for $176,000
description: A rare copy of the first printed Hebrew book, Ibn Sahulah's ''Meshal ha-Kadmoni,'' an illustrated collection of fables and allegories in rhymed prose printed in Brescia, Italy, in 1491, was sold yesterday at Christie's for $176,000. It was the highest price ever paid at auction for a Hebrew printed book.

title: HOW TO FIND THAT SAND AND SURF
description: MEMORIAL DAY weekend means summer is unofficially here, and with its coming, urban fantasies turn to glistening sands, sea breezes and ocean waves. While surf and sand are probably not the first things that come to mind when one thinks of New York City, there are 14.9 miles of city beaches within an hour or so of midtown Manhattan, as well as beach areas within the Gateway National Recreation Area and the popular Long Island strands of Jones Beach and Robert Moses State Park.

title: A RETROSPECTIVE OF WELLES FILMS AT THE REGENCY
description: ''Citizen Kane'' and ''The Magnificent Ambersons,'' two masterpieces of American film, form a double bill that opens an important Orson Welles retrospective Sunday at the Regency Theater.

title: Dining Out Guide: From the Grill
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. BATONS, #62 West 11th Street (473-9510) -

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''Congress has sent a historic message: that the people of the United States will no longer stand by and watch American industry be replaced by foreign industry.''

title: G.M.'S SALES TO PRETORIA
description: The General Motors Corporation may be preparing to stop selling cars and trucks to police and military units in South Africa, according to sources close to the situation.

title: YORK INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: York became an independent corporation on April 9 as a result of a tax- free spinoff from Borg-Warner Corp. c-Net income

title: The Worm and the Apple; An Apology
description: We apologize to Representative Michael Barnes for erroneously stating yesterday that Representative Barbara Mikulski is Maryland's Democratic candidate for the Senate. They are competing for the nomination in a September primary.

title: REAPPOINTMENT OF SAFETY BOARD HEAD IS UNCERTAIN
description: The reappointment of James E. Burnett Jr. as chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board appears uncertain. The White House has let his term expire without notice to Congress of its intentions, and several lawmakers said today that they had been advised that other candidates were being considered.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: LOOK for David Jacobs, the creator of television's ''Dallas'' and the executive producer of ''Knots Landing,'' to turn his hand to directing independent feature films beginning next year.

title: CONNECTICUT
description: Memorial Day weekend in Connecticut will be marked by lobster festivals, parades, car races, fiddle-playing contests and railroad tours.

title: U.S. AIDES CALL LIBYAN PLOTS UNDETERRED BY RAID
description: Government officials said today that American intelligence had detected evidence that some of the reported terrorist plots cited as justification for the raid against Libya were still in motion.

title: PROFESSOR URGES ACADEMIC LIFE TO CITY U. CLASS
description: The Harvard University economist Dr. Henry Rosovsky yesterday welcomed the City University's newest recipients of advanced degrees to ''the company of scholars'' and invited them to consider among their career options ''the pleasures and virtues of academic life.''

title: Libya Halts English Classes
description: Libya has halted the teaching of the English language at ''all educational stages,'' the official press agency Jana reported today. Russian is being taught instead, the two-sentence dispatch said. It gave no other details.

title: PATIENT WINS MORPHINE PLEA: TRANSFER TO NEW FACILITY SET
description: Elizabeth Bouvia, the quadriplegic cerebral palsy victim who has spent years fighting the hospital system from her hospital bed, today won a court battle against county physicians who were seeking to wean her from morphine.

title: CARPENTER MISSES GIANTS' MINICAMP
description: May 22 - When the Giants' veterans joined the rookies at minicamp today, there was one missing starter - Rob Carpenter. The 31-year-old fullback is unsigned and therefore a free agent not required to be here.

title: TOP REAGAN AIDE ON SCIENCE QUITS
description: The top White House science official is resigning Friday, continuing an exodus that has depleted the top ranks of the small science office that is supposed to advise the President and his senior staff on critical technical issues.

title: FREE AIR TIME INCLUDED
description: Viacom International Inc. yesterday repurchased nearly 17 percent of its outstanding stock from the New York investor Carl C. Icahn, who said he had offered to take over the entertainment company but instead ended up with a profit that various Wall Street experts estimated would total $17 million to $35 million.

title: Advertising; Agencies and Clients Talk About Each Other
description: Nancy L. Salz, author of ''How To Get the Best Advertising From Your Agency,'' has also done a survey of advertisers and has thrown in some agency responses for good measure.

title: An Evening of Songs
description: Marion Brasch and Maurice Edwards will present an evening of songs by Bertolt Brecht, Kurt Weill, Hanns Eisler and Jacques Prevert at the TOMI/Terrace Theater, 23 West 73d Street, tonight and tomorrow at 8 and Sunday at 3 and 7.

title: The Right Response to Irish Terror
description: The seven democracies agreed at the recent summit conference in Tokyo to tighten their extradition treaties to seal the escape routes of terrorists. For mostly bad reasons, just such a measure continues to languish in the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Johnny Podres, the former Dodger pitcher, underwent successful open-heart surgery yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital in Manhattan. He was listed in stable condition and was expected to remain hospitalized for a week to 10 days.

title: Cable Venture
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and telephone companies in Canada, Britain, France and Spain said they had signed a contract to build a fiber optic cable under the Atlantic Ocean. The cable, the ninth under the Atlantic, is expected to be in service carrying telephone calls and data transmissions by 1991. It is expected to have twice the capacity of the last fiber optic trans-Atlantic cable.

title: Giants' Taylor Avoids Press
description: Lawrence Taylor reported to the Giants' minicamp yesterday, and true to his word, the all-pro linebacker refused to discuss his treatment for substance abuse - or anything else for that matter - with reporters.

title: FARAH MANUFACTURING CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $7,440,000.

title: MATERIALS RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: b-Net income

title: Nomenclature
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato added a twist to the old story he often tells, about how he came to be named Alfonse.

title: AN ACTOR, WRITER AND SAILOR
description: Sterling Hayden, the handsome blond actor who played wholesome leading-man movie roles in the 1940's and 1950's and later weathered into a rough-hewn solid character actor in films such as ''Dr. Strangelove'' and ''The Godfather,'' died yesterday at his home in Sausalito, Calif.

title: Rare Woodpecker Sighted on Mainland
description: To The Editor:

title: TRIANGLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $114,000.

title: CONVENIENT FOOD MART INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 20
2 Hope to Go With Bonner
description: Two Congressmen have applied for visas to accompany Yelena G. Bonner, the human rights activist and wife of the Soviet dissident Andrei D. Sakharov, when she returns to Moscow after six months in the West, one of the legislators said today. Representative Barney Frank, Democrat of Massachusetts, said he and Representative Dan Lundgren, Republican of California, had been asked to go with Miss Bonner, who is leaving for Europe this weekend and is to arrive in Moscow on June 2.

title: TII INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U.S. and Britain Veto U.N. Move on Pretoria
description: The United States and Britain tonight vetoed a Security Council resolution that would have strongly condemned the South African raids on three neighboring nations and imposed sanctions on South Africa.

title: FEDERAL HOME LOAN MORTGAGE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflect preferred stock. The common stock is not listed, but latest first quarter net equals $43.44 a common share, compared with $34.86 a common share for year- ago period.

title: Ecuador Police Trap Rebels Said to Be Holding an Official
description: Hundreds of policemen and army troops surrounded a house in a Quito suburb today where leftist guerrillas were believed to be holding a kidnapped Government official and demanding the resignation of President Leon Febres Cordero.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 46.. 1. This was a short flight for an old bird. Explain. 2. The White House yielded on 800 Stingers. What are Stingers and what were the circumstances? 3. ''That is probably because of a lack of knowledge on the part of the people as to what things are available,'' said President Reagan. To what was he referring? 4. Brian Skrudland's winning goal in Game 2 of the Stanley Cup final series between the Montreal Canadiens and the Calgary Flames set a National Hockey League record. What was special about that score? 5. ''I don't have a crystal ball,'' was the politician's reply. Who is he and what was the question? 6. The Supreme Court ruled that governmental investigators must have warrants to conduct aerial surveillance of fenced yards of private homes. True or false? 7. In a highly unusual direct criticism of another agency, a State Department spokesman said a Defense Department study ''has no standing as a United States Government document.'' What did the study conclude? 8. Inside one New York City landmark, the lights went out for nearly 18 hours. Outside another, the lights went on for the first time in 45 years. Identify the buildings and explain. 9. A suit in Oklahoma City, which some experts expect to be the turning point in health litigation against the tobacco industry, concerns a tobacco product whose sales are steadily rising.

title: ECI TELECOM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: SAVE THE POST OFFICE!
description: One fall day, 20 years ago, I was in Senator Robert F. Kennedy's office in Washington, working on a documentary about him and his expected try for the Presidency. In the middle of filming, an aide slipped into the room and whispered to me. ''There's a phone call for you. It's Theodore White.'' ''I'll call him back,'' I answered. The aide shook his head. ''He says it's a matter of life or death.''

title: THE DELAYED APPROACH TO SODIUM LABELING
description: More than five years ago Dr. Arthur Hull Hayes, then the Commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, told a Congressional hearing that if companies did not voluntarily label packaged products soon with their sodium content he favored forcing them to do so. Asked later what he meant by ''soon,'' Dr. Hayes said ''within six months.''

title: Comings and Goings
description: Bob Bourne, the Islander forward, has signed a one-year contract with the club with no option year. . . . Don Slaught, the Texas Ranger catcher, underwent surgery to repair a fractured cheekbone and nose suffered when he was hit by a pitch thrown by Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd of the Boston Red Sox last Saturday. Slaught may be able to resume workouts in about three weeks.

title: QUANTRONIX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax benefit of $140,000. The latest year results include an after-tax gain of about $190,000 on sales of 1.25 million shares of LFM stock, net of a reserve against uncollected LFM receivables and inventory of $262,000. The prior year figures include an after-tax gain of about $346,000 on sales of 240,000 shares of LFM stock.

title: IF ONLY TV NEWS DELIVERED THE NEWS
description: In Poland, where I grew up, the television news generally consisted of the latest estimates of the grain or potato harvest or, if it happened to be winter, of the production results from coal mines and steel mills. These were invariably the headlines, and night after night images of the same brave miners, farmers or steel workers crowded out virtually everything else on the TV screen. We used to joke that the Warsaw TV station ought to dig a little mine on its premises and save the state all the money spent on transporting newscasters out to the coal fields.

title: ADVANCED TELECOMMUNICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
British Banks Cut Rates
description: Britain's other main banks today followed Thursday's move by National Westminster, cutting their base lending rates by half a percentage point, to 10 percent.

title: Memphis Told of Penalty
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association notified Memphis State University today that it plans to place the school's men's basketball program on probation for two years and will require the return of almost $1 million from basketball tournament proceeds. The proposed N.C.A.A. sanctions were outlined in a letter delivered to the university president, Thomas G. Carpenter, today.

title: Winner of the Liberty Race
description: ''This really helped win the race,''

title: INMED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: DIAGNOSTIC-RETRIEVAL SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $187,000 for the quarter and year.

title: Ban on Pretoria Coins
description: Britain today banned the import of all South African gold coins, including the recently issued protea, the Foreign Secretary, Sir Geoffrey Howe, said. Britain, along with many other countries, prohibited imports of South Africa's best-known gold coin, the Krugerrand, last year. Pretoria's recent issue of the protea was seen as an attempt to circumvent the ban.

title: 2 Under Consideration As U.S. Science Aide
description: Dr. Robert O. Hunter Jr., a San Diego research executive, has emerged as a leading candidate for the job of White House science adviser, a senior official of the Reagan Administration said today.

title: ZURN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an after-tax charge of $2,518,000 for deferral of previously recognized income and revisions in cost estimates on certain long-term contracts undergoing renegotiation, and includes gains of $1,171,000, or 19 cents a share, from the sale of a division and $427,000, or 7 cents a share, from a change in the method of accounting for pension costs. c-Includes gains of $1,705,000, or 28 cents a share, from the adoption of new pension costs accounting standards for the latest year, and $2,700,000, or 46 cents a share, from the elimination of deferred taxes because of a tax law change for the year- ago period.

title: BAYLY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Larger Loss for Turner
description: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. attributed its $6.9 million loss for the first quarter of 1986 primarily to expenses associated with its takeover of the MGM/ UA Entertainment Company and its purchase of the Omni International complex in Atlanta.

title: U.S. and Polish Artists To Open Summerfare
description: Drama and dance from the United States and Poland will open the first weekend of the seventh Pepsico Summerfare on July 11 at the State University of New York at Purchase, on Anderson Hill Road in Purchase.

title: Talks on Afghan War Suspended in Geneva
description: The Foreign Ministers of Pakistan and Afghanistan suspended negotiations on the Afghan conflict today, sharply divided on how to schedule a withdrawal of some 120,000 Soviet troops from Afghanistan, a senior United Nations official said.

title: MUSIC: THE Y CHORALE
description: Amy Kaiser's 28-voice Y Chorale is one of the best local choruses, and Tuesday's program at the 92d Street Y, ranging over five centuries, upheld its reputation handsomely, even though one might dissent from some aspects of the choral style cultivated by the group.

title: CONGRESS BEGINS INQUIRY OF A FORMER U.S. AIDE
description: Congress has begun investigating the activities of a former Government official who helped formulate Federal textile policy and then went to work advising Hong Kong on textile negotiations.

title: Altiero Spinelli Dies in Rome; Champion of European Unity
description: Altiero Spinelli, an Italian member of the European Parliament and a longtime campaigner for European unity, died in a Rome clinic today. He was 78 years old.

title: Palo Alto Restaurants Thrive on Nonsmoking
description: To the Editor:

title: Turnesa, Murphy Win Wilson Golf
description: Jim Turnesa and Steve Murphy of Knollwood registered 10 birdies en route to a 135 to win the 15th annual Wilson Cup today at the Scarsdale Golf Club.

title: ON WEST SIDE, BARRIO LIFE IS VANISHING
description: All Antonio Raposo and his family had to do was give up their three-bedroom, $300-a-month rental apartment at 115 West 96th Street. In exchange, he said, the landlord handed them $30,000 last July.

title: RECITAL: ELIZABETH RICH, PIANO
description: In Elizabeth Rich's piano recital at Alice Tully Hall Wednesday night, intelligence, care and concentration were never in question, though some of the evening's basic premises were.

title: WHITSON STARS IN RELIEF AS YANKS DOWN ANGELS
description: The cheers were familiar to Ed Whitson. He heard them in the third inning last night, just as he heard them last season in the rare happy times he experienced at Yankee Stadium.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. California Angels, at Yankee Stadium, 1:20 P.M. (Television -Channel 4, 1:15 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 1:15.) Mets vs. Padres, at San Diego, 10:05 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 10 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 10 P.M.) Cardinals vs. Atlanta Braves, at St. Louis. (Television - WTBS, 8:05 P.M.) Indians vs. Toronto Blue Jays, at Cleveland, 1:30 P.M. The CBS radio network baseball broadcasts are starting up a week earlier than expected. (Radio -WCBS 880, 1:20 P.M.) College: National Collegiate Athletic Association Northeast Regional Championships at the University of Maine, Orono. St. John's and Rutgers are in this double-elimination tournament, in which the two losers from yesterday play at 11 A.M. and the two winners at 2:30 P.M. Hockey Flames vs. Montreal Canadiens, at Calgary, Alberta, the fifth game of the Stanley Cup final. The Canadiens can capture the cup with a victory. (Television - ESPN, 8 P.M.) Lacrosse North Carolina vs. Johns Hopkins, 12:30 P.M., and Syracuse vs. Virginia, 3:30 P.M. N.C.A.A. semifinals at the University of Delaware, Newark. Johns Hopkins has won the national title for the past two years, and Syracuse won it in 1983. The winners play each other for the title Monday at the same site. (Radio -WNYE-FM 91.5, 3:30 P.M.) Running America's Race, 10-Kilometer Super Run, at Lake Tahoe, Nev. Limited to one man and one woman from each of the 50 states, the top male and female finishers will get $500,000 each.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, MAY 24, 1986
description: International

title: Jurors Who Favor the Death Penalty Are Fairer
description: To the Editor:

title: Conservatives Lose Dartmouth Trustee Vote
description: In a mail-in election among Dartmouth College alumni, two incumbent trustees defeated challengers supported by a conservative alumni group that mounted its campaign in response to a perceived lack of direction on the board after a tumultous winter term.

title: Net Jumps At Macy's
description: R. H. Macy & Company, one of the nation's largest retailers, yesterday reported a 48 percent rise in net income for its third quarter, ended May 3, over the similar quarter a year ago. The department store chain, which is involved in a management buyout proposal, posted a 5.3 percent increase in sales over the 1985 period.

title: OPEC Sees Cutbacks
description: The oil ministers of Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Venezuela, Indonesia and Nigeria met here today to take stock of efforts to enlist cooperation of non-OPEC producers in helping to stabilize the world oil market.

title: CACHE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
The Arms-Control Messages From Chernobyl
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

MACY, R.H. & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: b-Includes a gain of $9,100,000, or 17 cents a share, from the sale of certain assets of the company's Midwest division for the quarter and 9 months.

title: BEN & JERRY'S HOMEMADE reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CATCHER GUNNING FOR MAJORS
description: The men brought their lawn chairs to Red McEwen Field, and their stopwatches, and the guns that track the velocity of baseballs. At times this season, the Basebulls of the University of South Florida have played before crowds that have seemed to include as many major league scouts as fans. And Scott Hemond, the junior catcher they were all here to see, has introduced a new purpose for their equipment.

title: WALKER TELECOMMUNICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BIOSEARCH MEDICAL PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax loss carryforward of $124,000.

title: U.S. OUSTS ATTACHE OF SOUTH AFRICA TO PROTEST RAIDS
description: The United States today ordered the expulsion of South Africa's senior military attache in this country in response to South African raids on Monday against targets in Zambia, Zimbabwe and Botswana.

title: THE BIG SHAKEOUT ON 7TH AVE.
description: In the two years since United Merchants and Manufacturers, a textile and plastics company, acquired the financially troubled Jonathan Logan, one of the apparel industry's largest producers, the new owners have closed three of the company's factories and discontinued one of its largest divisions.

title: ORMAND INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CLINI-THERM CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: DATAFLEX CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss The company is listed on the Boston Stock Exchange.

title: SHOWBOAT INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Radio Troubles Snag Flights
description: Flight operations stopped for an hour today at Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport when a malfunction put air traffic controllers out of radio contact with all flights, officials said. Norm Scroggins, manager of the airport's tower approach control, said all planes in the vicinity of the airport remained in contact with controllers at the Federal Aviation Administration's Fort Worth center, which was unaffected by the 7 A.M. malfunction.

title: TARTAN'S LUCK IS CHANGING
description: There was a Freudian slip at the start of yesterday's fourth race at Belmont Park, and Jan Nerud howled.

title: A JUDGE ORDERS L.I. TEEN-AGER TO SEE AUTOPSY
description: A Suffolk County judge has sentenced a teen-ager in a drug case to witness autopsies of two drug-overdose victims, but has been rebuffed by the county Medical Examiner.

title: William Moncrief Dies at 90; Wildcatter in Texas Oilfields
description: William Alvin Moncrief, a philanthropist who was one of four famous Texas wildcat oil drillers, died Wednesday in his office here. He was 90 years old.

title: VIRCO MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $1,306,000.

title: Memorial Day Closings
description: Stock and commodity markets in the United States will be closed Monday in observance of Memorial Day. Government offices, banks and many businesses will also be closed. The Government's weekly Treasury bill auction will be Tuesday.

title: Delta to Buy Part Of Smaller Line
description: Delta Air Lines said that it had decided to buy 20 percent of the voting stock of Atlantic Southeast Airlines, a commuter carrier that is a major feeder of travelers to Delta at its hub in Atlanta.

title: 3 Enter Pleas of Guilty In Murder of a Witness
description: Three reputed members of a narcotics distribution ring called the Vigilantes pleaded guilty yesterday to murdering a key witness in a murder trial two and a half years ago.

title: CENTURY BUSINESS CREDIT reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
'Lie of the Mind' to Close
description: The play ''A Lie of the Mind,'' which was written and directed by Sam Shepard, will close after the matinee on June 1 at the Promenade Theater. It will have played 185 performances and 13 previews.

title: VISHAY INTERTECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ELIZABETHAN MANUSCRIPT TO BE SOLD
description: What British scholars believe to be the only rough copy in the hand of a prominent Elizabethan playwright - a sheet of paper used as ordinary wrapping for the documents of a titled British family - will be auctioned here June 20.

title: VOIT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,007,635 from the sale of 9 bowling centers.

title: GAMING & TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $62,000 for the quarter and 9 months. c-After a credit of $239,000 representing the cumulative effect of an accounting change. The company said the 9 month results are not comparable because of the acquisition of Omega Enterprises Inc. on Jan. 1, 1985.

title: Woman Injured as Man Tries To Hijack Jetliner in Chicago
description: A man ran onto a Swissair DC-10 as passengers were boarding at O'Hare International Airport tonight and held a knife to a woman's throat for about 30 minutes, the authorities said.

title: CRESTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: ADDITIVES IN FOOD A CONCERN
description: Earlier this month, Massachusetts adopted regulations that will prohibit processed apple products, including apple juice and applesauce sold by baby-food makers, from containing a carcinogenic farm chemical.

title: A Journalism Junkie
description: Daniel Schorr, the television reporter known for his sharp questioning of Presidents, will be 70 years old next Aug. 31 and a few days ago was honored by the Ford Hall Forum of Boston for what he called ''my first 50 years in journalism.'' Accepting the tribute, Mr. Schorr observed that ''honoring me for service to journalism is like honoring a junkie for drug addiction.''

title: DOW ADDS 16.99 TO END A BIG WEEK
description: Wall Street yesterday made its second consecutive big gain, and its third this week, as the Dow Jones industrial average finished at its best level this month. The market seemed to overcome the fear that interest rates would stop declining.

title: HURCO COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
description: b-Includes a charge of $549,000 for foreign currency exchange losses and a charge of about $100,000 from employee termination costs. c-Includes a charge of $2,977,000, primarily due to asset writedowns.

title: Resignation Under Fire
description: A few weeks after his draft selections were severely criticized by Buddy Ryan, the new head coach, Lynn Stiles resigned as the director of the Philadelphia Eagles' scouting staff, the smallest in the National Football League. Stiles had held the scouting post since 1982 after serving as the Eagles' administrative assistant and coach of tight ends and special teams. He will be replaced by Joe Woolley, the former scouting director of the New Orleans Saints.

title: AFTER A 4-YEAR DROP, CRIME IN CITY IS RISING, LEAVING EXPERTS PUZZLED
description: Major crime is on the rise again in New York City after nearly four years of general decline, Police Department figures show. Law-enforcement officials and criminologists who had predicted continuing decreases say they are puzzled by the trend and are unsure how to cope with it.

title: Bridge; 22d U.J.A.-Federation Game Reaches Records for Growth
description: The world's most successful charity bridge event continues to grow. In play Thursday night at the Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th Street, a record total of 78 tables took part in the 22d U.J.A.-Federation game, raising $60,000, which was also a record.

title: HEICO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Louisville TV Bids Reported
description: At least four communications companies are bidding for WHAS-TV, one of the media holdings being sold by the Bingham family. Four WHAS executives also submitted a bid by Thursday's deadline, according to The Courier-Journal newspaper.

title: BARTON VALVE CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: WESPERCORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Simon, 52, to Be Oldest 500 Driver
description: Fifty-two-year-old Dick Simon realized his dream today: He will be the oldest driver ever to compete in the Indianapolis 500.

title: RMS ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: SCULPTURE BLOOMS IN THE ZIMBABWE COUNTRYSIDE
description: For the most part, tobacco grows here. But down a yellow gravel road, under the low-limbed mahobohoba and msasa trees, smooth stones that have been fashioned into solemn owls and moon-shaped faces, lumbering tortoises and anguished women sprout from the sandy soil.

title: PAUL B. ZEISLER
description: Paul B. Zeisler, a New York investment adviser, died of cancer Thursday at White Plains Hospital. He was 56 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: U.P.S. WILL PUT UP $500,000 TO RESOLVE PARKING TICKET FIGHT
description: United Parcel Service has agreed to pay $500,000 to New York City as an ''advance good faith payment'' toward its tens of thousands of outstanding parking tickets, city officials announced yesterday.

title: A Warning From Bundy
description: A race between the United States and the Soviet Union to develop space weapons poses a prospect ''more serious than any new event we have confronted since the emergence of the hydrogen bomb and the ballistic missile,'' McGeorge Bundy, a former White House official, said today.

title: Harold Mabern
description: Harold Mabern is playing piano solos tonight and tomorrow at Burgundy, 467 Amsterdam Avenue, above 82d Street (787-8300). Music begins at 9 P.M.; there is a $10 minimum at tables, a two-drink minimum at the bar.

title: Mayor Again to Seek A Residency Measure
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he would again seek a law to require new city employees to live within the city.

title: Progress Report
description: The pianist James Williams will lead his quintet, Progress Report, tonight and tomorrow at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, below 11th Street (255-4037). Sets begin at 9:30 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $10 cover and a one-drink minimum.

title: TOP BRASS ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: b-Net loss

title: Howe's Manager Fined
description: For allowing Steve Howe to pitch in a minor-league game after being ordered to bench the former Los Angeles Dodger pitcher because of a positive result in a drug test, Harry Steve was fined $500 and suspended for two weeks as manager of the San Jose Bees. The penalties were announced by Joe Gagliaradi, president of the California League, after Steve ignored the instructions from John Johnson, president of the National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues, the governing body for minor-league baseball.

title: BRAE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $2,549,000 for the quarter and $2,720,000 for the year. c-Net income includes gains from discontinued operations of $25,280,000 for the quarter and $28,883,000 for the year.

title: New York City Is to Blame for Scandalous School-Board Election
description: To the Editor:

title: FESTIVAL SPONSORS SEEK JULY 4TH VENDOR CONTROLS
description: The private Harbor Festival Foundation would control the selection and location of all outdoor vendors in much of lower Manhattan during the Fourth of July celebration, under a bill the Koch administration sent to Albany yesterday.

title: MANHATTANITES' MEMORIAL DAY RACES
description: Harvey Kaplan, mild-mannered Manhattan psychotherapist, leaped into a sporty black Thunderbird with red pin stripes yesterday at Budget Rent-A-Car.

title: Shanties and Countershanties
description: Shanties: on many American campuses, they are the symbol of the school year now coming to a close. These makeshift structures are meant to symbolize the cruelty of apartheid and the poverty inflicted on South African blacks. They also challenge the stereotype of college students as self-absorbed and pragmatic. With commencement visitors at hand, college administrators seem to regard the shanties as points of embarrassment; points of pride would be more like it.

title: MORGAN KEEGAN & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Louisiana House Defeats New Orleans Casino Bid
description: The Louisiana House of Representative today killed Gov. Edwin W. Edwards's proposal to legalize casino gambling in New Orleans.

title: AMERICAN MAGNETICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $607,000.

title: MID-MAY CAR SALES EDGED DOWN 2.4%
description: Sales of new domestically built automobiles edged downward by 2.4 percent in the May 11-20 selling period from the corresponding period last year, the major auto makers reported today.

title: KROY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: b-Net loss

title: Ceco Buyout Bid Withdrawn
description: Ceco Industries said today that a buyout group led by senior management had withdrawn a $185 million bid to take the company private because it was unable to reach an agreement with a special committee of five board members.

title: AQUINO SEES REBELS ON THEIR GROUND
description: President Corazon C. Aquino traveled today to this center of Communist insurgency, where she met with a group of rebel returnees and later outlined a hard-line policy on a proposed cease-fire.

title: Ford Acquisition
description: The Ford Motor Company said it had completed the second phase of the acquisition of the Sperry Corporation's New Holland agricultural equipment unit.
