title: BEKER INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $5,626,000.

title: TEMPLETON ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Col. Gen. Leonid Goncharov, Chief of Soviet Air Academy
description: Col. Gen. Leonid Goncharov, chief of the Vasilyevsky Air Defense Military Academy, died in the line of duty Wednesday, the military newspaper Krasnaya Zvezda said today.

title: KING OF THE COUNTRY CLUBS
description: When Robert H. Dedman, the world's largest owner and operator of private clubs, visited the Far East this month, there was one thing he wanted on his itinerary that he could not have: a Dedman-owned country club in China. But if history is any guide, it will not be long before he gets one.

title: INTEGRITY FINANCIAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After net realized investment gains of $23,000 and an extraordinary tax credit of $199,000, or 3 cents a share.

title:
PATENTS;
Robot Makes Parts
description: A robot that performs machine operations, such as drilling or riveting, at several places on a piece of work, under the direction of a controller, was patented this week by a team of six inventors for the United Technologies Corporation, Hartford. The robot is being used to manufacture helicopter parts. Patent 4,590,578 was granted John J. Barto Jr. and five staff associates.

title: BARDEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $1,765,000, or 99 cents a share, on the sale of land and a building by the company's English subsidiary.

title: A Jazz Tribute
description: A jazz ensemble including the pianist Hilton Ruiz and the trumpeter Bill Hardman will pay tribute to the music of Rahsaan Roland Kirk tonight at 9:30 and 11 o'clock at the Jazz Center of New York, 380 Lafayette Street, below East Fourth Street (505-5660). Tickets are $10.

title: SOSTRE, INMATE ACTIVIST, IS SEIZED AS A FUGITIVE
description: Martin Sostre, who became a national symbol of prisoners' rights in the 1960's and 70's and who has been wanted by the police for attempted murder since 1984, was arrested Thursday night while studying at a law school library in lower Manhattan.

title: Postgame Brawl Brings $42,000 in Fines
description: The pride of the National Hockey League, the Calgary Flames and the Montreal Canadiens, who are playing for the prize of the N.H.L., the Stanley Cup, were harshly criticized by league officials today for a brawl that broke out immediately after the game Thursday night at the Forum.

title: Your Money; Retirement Before Age 65
description: DECIDING whether to retire before the ''normal'' retirement age of 65 - a step taken by almost two-thirds of all new retirees - has many emotional and family implications that cannot be easily quantified. But the various financial considerations can certainly be weighed in detail.

title: AN ACCORD ON CHINA JEEP PLANT
description: The American Motors Corporation's troubled joint venture in China will continue producing Jeeps after negotiations averted a threatened A.M.C. abandonment of what has been one of the largest and most heavily publicized American investments in China.

title: Harness Driver Dies of Injuries
description: David Dunckley, who was involved in a four-horse pileup at Roosevelt Raceway last Friday night, died today from injuries suffered in the accident, Mike Cowen, a track spokesman said. Dunckley was 47 years old.

title: PARAGUAY RADIO STATION IS LONELY VOICE OF DISSENT
description: What most surprised Humberto Rubin about the mob attack on his radio station last month was not the crash of breaking glass or the crack of shots being fired into the air. Rather, it was the sound of musical accompaniment.

title: 'Comparable Worth' Is Unfair to Women
description: In 1927, my grandmother graduated first in her medical school class. She went on to practice medicine for 50 years, while rearing four children. My grandmother's two younger sisters became doctors, too. But if comparable worth had been around, perhaps they all would have become nurses instead.

title: CORRECTION
description: An editing error changed the meaning of Senator Arlen Specter's opening sentence in an article published Thursday. It should have read: ''Is there a way to proceed forcefully against terrorism without extensive military action?''

title: Gramm and Budget Cuts
description: Few in Washington take any pleasure in the belt-tightening aspects of the budget-balancing law, but one lawmaker who may gain some solace from it is Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, one of its authors.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: UNIVERSAL SOUNDS Bill Cole, an ethnomusicologist, chairs the Dartmouth College music department and has made a speciality of Indonesian, Ghanaian, Indian and native American music. Hafiz Shabazz is a faculty colleague who has studied in Africa and the Caribbean with drummers and folklorists. His specialty is non-Western percussion instruments.

title: U.S. SHELTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Jurors Who Favor the Death Penalty Are Fairer; Peremptory Challenges
description: To the Editor:

title: EARTHWORM TRACTOR reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: So Long, Scenic Merritt
description: The Connecticut Legislature took action to murder the Merritt Parkway a few weeks ago. It voted to eliminate tolls on one of the nation's handsomest parkways, opening it to a vicious cycle of greatly increased traffic that in turn stimulates an inevitable demand for expansion.

title: Warriors Name Karl
description: The Golden State Warriors, who have just changed ownership, now have a new coach as well. George Karl, who was dismissed in March as coach of the Cleveland Cavaliers, was named yesterday to succeed John Bach as the Warrior coach.

title: Hughes to Cut 4,100 Jobs
description: The Hughes Aircraft Company, the nation's seventh-largest military contractor, said today that it plans to eliminate about 4,100 jobs, or 5 percent of its 82,000 workers, by the end of the year.

title: Flyspecks and Flaws at the M.T.A.
description: Quibbles are doubly dismaying when they distract from valid criticism. The recent report of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority inspector general contains both. Its review of the authority's own two-year report is blurred by a fog of trivial numerical differences. Yet behind the fog looms an account of a genuinely troubling practice - how the M.T.A. has, in midstream, changed its own standards for judgment in the important categories of car performance and fire control.

title: ITALY SAID TO DECIDE TO ASK FOR WARRANTS FOR SYRIANS IN RAID
description: An Italian newspaper reported this morning that Italian magistrates had decided to seek arrest warrants against ''about 20'' Syrians for complicity in the attack Dec. 27 at Rome's Fiumicino airport.

title: U.S. Agency Clears Bid by Burroughs
description: The Justice Department, in an unusually speedy approval of a proposed merger, said yesterday that it had no objections to Burroughs Corporation's attempts to acquire a rival computer maker, the Sperry Corporation.

title: ATTENDANTS PRESSING EFFORT DESPITE END OF T.W.A. STRIKE
description: The end of a bitter strike by flight attendants against Trans World Airlines has left about 5,000 of the striking union members without jobs but vowing to continue their battle with the company through court actions and legislative remedies.

title: Dominican Candidates Agree to Resume Count
description: The two front-runners in the presidential election held last week have agreed to a completion of the vote count that has twice been suspended, to be followed by a recount of all two million ballots.

title: Fotomat Bid
description: The Konishiroku Photo Industry Company of Japan, which already owns 60 percent of the Fotomat Corporation, said yesterday that it had raised its bid for the remaining shares of Fotomat and begun the tender offer.

title: BARUCH-FOSTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: BUELL INDUSTIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Share earnings are not adjusted for the 100 percent stock dividend which will be distributed on May 30.

title: 2 Are Named by Koch As Chiefs of Agencies
description: Two city officials were named yesterday as heads of the city's Public Development Corporation and the Office of Business Development.

title: HALE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $52,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net income and includes income of $2,211,000 from discontinued operations.

title: MEESE DISAVOWS ATTACK ON MEXICO BY U.S. OFFICIALS
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d believes that United States officials' denunciations of drug trafficking in Mexico and their public accusations of official corruption there do not reflect the Reagan Administration's view, a Justice Department spokesman said today.

title: Funds Voted for Rink Design
description: An engineering concern will be hired to redesign the refrigeration system for the trouble-plagued Wollman Memorial Skating Rink in Central Park under the terms of a contract approved early yesterday by the Board of Estimate. In a 9-to-2 vote, the board authorized spending up to $130,000 to hire St. Onge, Ruff/Associates Inc. of York, Pa., to redesign the system. Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin cast the negative votes, in what a spokesman called ''a protest against the unseemly haste with which the item was being pushed.''

title: CELINA FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an investment gain of $1,000. c-Net loss includes an investment loss of $45,000.

title: YANKEE COS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit from the termination of a pension plan of $550,000. c-Includes an extraordinary credit from a Federal Home Loan Board stock dividend of $298,000. Latest quarter results include the operations of Eskey Inc., acquired in December 1985.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, MAY 24, 1986
description: International

title: 4 Nigerian Students Reported Slain at Protest
description: The Nigerian radio said law enforcement officers shot and killed four students and seriously wounded 15 during demonstrations today at Ahmadu Bello University in northern Nigeria.

title: 2 Soviet Units Link in Space
description: The Soyuz TM, an unmanned version of a new model of the Soviet space capsule Soyuz, docked with the Mir space station Friday, the official press agency Tass said.

title: GWYNN HOME RUN IN 9TH DOWNS METS
description: The malaise that has afflicted Dwight Gooden spread to other members of the Mets' staff tonight when Tony Gwynn hit a three-run home run off Jesse Orosco with two down in the ninth inning and the San Diego Padres overpowered the Mets, 7-4.

title: Hiram Walker President
description: Hiram Walker Resources Ltd., the big Canadian liquor and energy company taken over last month by the Reichmann family of Toronto, said yesterday that it had named M. A. Cohen president.

title: FED TRIED TO QUASH RATE-CUT HOPES
description: The Federal Reserve became worried last month that the financial markets had come to expect more easing of monetary policy than it was prepared to deliver. As a result, it sought to quash hopes that it would move quickly to make another cut in its discount rate.

title: Boxer Defies Doctor
description: Ignoring the advice of his doctor, Wilfredo Gomez of Puerto Rico will defend his World Boxing Association junior-lightweight title tonight in San Juan against Alfredo Layne of Panama.

title: Paris Taxis Marshal
description: To the Editor:

title: CHINA RETURNS HIJACKED JET AND 2 CREWMEN TO TAIWAN
description: A Taiwan cargo jet and two crew members hijacked to China three weeks ago were turned over to Taiwan airline officials here today amid all the formality of a prisoner-of-war release.

title: Sculpture of Amity
description: The inspiration came to Nathan Rapoport eight years ago, while watching the signing of the Camp David peace accord between Egypt and Israel. He was working on a maquette at the time, to be a sculpture of two brothers embracing.

title: G.M. CUTS ITS SALES TO PRETORIA
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that it would stop selling cars and trucks to police and military agencies in South Africa in response to complaints about that country's racial policies.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: 1864 HERO GETS GRAVE AND HONOR
description: After more than a century in a pauper's grave in Queens and an eight-year effort by his great-grandson, Capt. James Smith, a Medal of Honor winner from the Civil War, will join his fellow heroes at Arlington National Cemetery.

title: Woman in School Blast Believed Killed by Bullet
description: The woman who died with her husband as they held an elementary school hostage with a gasoline bomb last Friday was not killed by the bomb's accidental blast but by a bullet to the head, the authorities said today.

title: CAR BOMB KILLS 11 IN EAST BEIRUT IN WORST WEEK OF WAR IN MONTHS
description: An especially powerful car bomb exploded in Christian East Beirut today, killing 11 people, wounding 84 and setting several buildings afire, the police said.

title: JAVITS CENTER SWELTERED AFTER PAPERWORK FROZE
description: The air-conditioning failure at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center last weekend occurred after the center's funds ran out and contractors removed workers, including some of those responsible for the air-conditioning.

title: SOVIET PROTEST BARS ORWELL PLAY FROM FESTIVAL
description: A stage production of George Orwell's ''Animal Farm'' scheduled as part of Theater of Nations, an international festival to be held in Baltimore next month, has been canceled because Soviet officials protested its inclusion in the festival.

title: Ave Atque Cuomo
description: Dog bites man is not news and neither is Governor Cuomo announcing he will run for a second term. This is why I didn't attend the Governor's news conference Monday.

title: Leaseway Vote
description: The Leaseway Transportation Corporation said the management slate won a proxy fight concerning nominees to a committee to revitalize the company. Leaseway said the vote was 56 percent to 44 percent. The company had said previously that it expected to win the vote.

title: KIDDIE PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BUILDING THE BODY: AEROBICS TO GYMNASTICS
description: ''I've been looking for a place like this, one that isn't just one-two-three-kick,'' Bill Freeborn said as he exited, hair and body dripping perspiration, from an exercise class at Body by Jake.

title:
PATENTS;
Phone Aids Talks on Hostages
description: A TELEPHONE system intended for use in hostage negotiations was patented this week for Security Systems Internationale Inc. of Lanham, Md. The company supplies the equipment to police and Federal agencies, including the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and provides training in its use.

title: VELCRO INDUSTRIES N V reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AMERICANA HOTELS & REALTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: FMC Approves Recapitalization
description: The FMC Corporation's shareholders have approved a recapitalization plan that increases insider control of the chemical and machinery concern. Preliminary results showed that about 17 million shares, or 66 percent of the total outstanding, were voted in favor of the plan at the company's annual meeting, FMC said.

title: PROPERTY CAPITAL TRUST (BOSTON) (A) reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Quotation of the Day
description: ''We trust that this action will make clear to the South African Government that the United States cannot tolerate disregard of the sovereignty of South Africa's neighbors.'' - The State Department, in announcing the expulsion of a South African attache. [ 1:6. ]

title: BTR REALTY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings adjusted for a 2-for- 1 stock split distributed April 23.

title: ELAN CORP reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: Dollar figures are translated at the rate of U.S.$1.29 per Irish pound for the year ended March 31, 1986, and U.S.$1.01 per Irish pound for the year ended March 31, 1985. The latest year revenue figure is corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: TECHAMERICA GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a loss from a minority interest of $51,083, two non-recurring writeoffs totaling $1,777,858, a pretax loss on disposal of $660,994, and an inventory writeoff totaling $1,116,864. c-Includes a loss of $16,095 related to a minority interest.

title: TRINITY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $13.6 million, or 85 cents a share, resulting from a pension plan accounting change. c-Net loss The company said the latest quarter and year results include writedowns of $6.1 million in the company's marine segment, $2.3 million in its structural segment and $200,000 in other segments.

title: POLICE ADOPT POWERFUL WEAPONS TO BATTLE WELL-ARMED CRIMINALS
description: LOS ANGELES, May 23 -

title: COMMUNITY SHARE LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BONE MARROW NETWORK PLANNED BY THE NAVY
description: The Navy intends to establish a national network of 100,000 bone marrow donors next month to help doctors treat such diseases as leukemia as well as to respond to a possible nuclear accident, a Navy official said today.

title: BILL RATES FINISH DAY LOWER
description: Bond prices drifted in a narrow range yesterday in very light trading as dealers prepared to depart for the long Memorial Day weekend.

title: CONGRESSIONAL CHALLENGE PLANNED ON NEW U.S. CHEMICAL WEAPONS
description: The chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee said today that he would lead a fight to revoke funds for new chemical weapons, arguing that the Administration had failed to comply with a Congressional mandate requiring prior approval of NATO's governing political body.

title: EXPOS SET BACK GIANTS, 4-3
description: Hubie Brooks and Tim Wallach hit two-run homers, and Floyd Youmans won his fourth straight game tonight as the Expos beat the San Francisco Giants 4-3.

title: WHITE HOUSE ORDERS BROAD INQUIRY ON DISCLOSURE OF SECRETS
description: The White House has instructed the National Security Council to begin a systematic Government-wide investigation into disclosing of sensitive intelligence information to determine if additional preventive measures are needed, senior White House officials said today.

title: REAGAN BEING URGED TO BACK MORE AID FOR AFRICAN NATIONS
description: An independent organization of 59 prominent Americans called on President Reagan today to pledge new financial programs to help solve Africa's economic crisis.

title: Life and Fiction
description: EXPENSIVE HABITS. By Maureen Howard. 298 pages. Summit Books. $17.95.

title:
PATENTS;
308 New Plant Varieties
description: The Plant Variety Protection Office of the Department of Agriculture in Beltsville, Md., is considering 308 applications for new plant varieties. In the first quarter of 1986 the office issued 18-year certificates covering 72 new varieties, from alfalfa to wheat.

title: Unhappy Marshall Leaves Giant Camp
description: Leonard Marshall, the 24-year-old Pro Bowl defensive end, stayed away from the Giants' minicamp today because of a contract dispute.

title: MR. STEAK INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $114,000 for the quarter and $133,000 for the 6 months. The quarter's loss was also after an extraordinary charge of $67,000.

title: GIVING UP: A FILIPINO REBEL'S ORDEAL
description: Rose is proud of the calluses on her right palm from carrying her rifle and on the soles of her feet from walking jungle trails with the 52 guerrillas she commanded.

title: GENEALOGY, NEW YORK TO VIRGINIA
description: In 1862, when Gen. James S. Wadsworth of Geneseo, N.Y., was in charge of the defenses of Washington, a Virginia farmer was brought before him on charges of spying for the Confederacy.

title: FOR MEXICANS, TORTILLA PRICES OUTPACE PAY RISES
description: The Government announced this week that it was taking steps that would nearly double the price of tortillas, and labor leaders denounced the step today as a blow to a scheduled 25 percent rise in the minimum wage.

title: DYNATECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $2,917,000 from the sale of subsidiaries for the quarter and year. The 1985 figures were restated to reflect acquisitions during fiscal 1986 accounted for on a pooling-of-interests basis. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 10. 1. A radio-controlled plastic replica of a pterosaur, a flying reptile that became extinct 65 million years ago, crashed in its first public demonstration. 2. Stingers are advanced portable antiaircraft missiles that the Administration cut from a proposed $354 million arms sale to Saudi Arabia to avert a major Congressional defeat. 3. Mr. Reagan said the nation's hungry were suffering not from an availability of assistance but from a lack of knowledge about where or how to get help. 4. It came after only 9 seconds of overtime, the fastest overtime goal in league history. 5. Governor Cuomo was asked if his decision to seek a second term precluded all chances of his being a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1988. 6. False. 7. The study by the Pentagon expressed skepticism that the Contadora negotiations in Central America would produce a verifiable peace treaty acceptable to the United States. 8. A blackout temporarily cut off power at Grand Central Terminal. Lights were turned on at the top of the Woolworth Building, illuminating it for the first time since the beginning of World War II. 9. Smokeless tobacco, or snuff. 10. The White House sought NATO approval of a plan to resume production of chemical weapons for the first time since 1969 because Congress had linked its approval of the weapons to consultations with the NATO allies. 11. Theodor Geisel, who is better known as Dr. Seuss, the author of best-selling children's books, returned to his native city of Springfield, Mass., the setting of his first book, ''And to Think That I Saw It on Mulberry Street.'' 12.

title: TOURISIM BOOM AT GRAND CANYON: THE TOUGH PART IS FINDING AN ELEVATOR
description: Bonnie Lovejoy of Sacramento, Calif., rushed into the visitor's center at National Park Headquarters here in the Grand Canyon. ''I want to report a forest fire,'' she said to a ranger.

title: XL-DATACOMP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Letter: On Auditing; Over Potholes, With Deliberate Speed
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 California Banks Fined
description: The Security Pacific and Wells Fargo banks have agreed to pay civil fines of $605,0000 and $75,000, respectively, for violating a law requiring large currency transactions to be reported.

title: Boy, 5, Is Brain Dead After Bullet Hits Him
description: A 5-year-old Brooklyn boy playing on the front porch of his house was shot and reported brain dead late last night after being struck in the head by a bullet, the police said.

title: Hawkins's Drug Tests
description: The Senate Rules Committee this week turned down a request from Senator Paula Hawkins, Republican of Florida, to reimburse her discretionary office account for $468 spent to give urine tests to 69 members of her office staff.

title: Heyerdahl Heard From
description: Thor Heyerdahl, the Norwegian explorer who gained fame in 1947 when he sailed from Peru to Polynesia across 4,300 miles of open sea on the balsa-log raft Kon-Tiki, maintains that another famous sailor, Christopher Columbus, was well aware of Norse settlements in Greenland and would never have made it to the New World without that knowledge.

title: Browns Acquire Pagel
description: Mike Pagel, the quarterback for the Indianapolis Colts who became expendable after the acquisition of Gary Hogeboom from the Dallas Cowboys and Jack Trudeau of Illinois in the college draft, was traded to the Cleveland Browns for an undisclosed draft choice. Earlier this spring, Coach Rod Dowhower said Pagel would not be with the Colts next season, but Robert Irsay, the owner, said he did not want to trade away an experienced quarterback.

title: SENATE MOVE SAID TO IMPERIL RESEARCH ON MISSILE DEFENSE
description: A sudden move in the Senate to curtail growth in the research program for a defense against nuclear missiles could force a major restructuring of the program's main experiments, Reagan Administration officials and opponents of the research plan agreed today.

title: LEARNING TO NAVIGATE IN CITY'S ROUGH SEAS
description: Among those scheduled to visit New York for the Statue of Liberty centennial celebration on the July 4 weekend are 17,000 American and foreign sailors, many of them young, eager and perhaps not ready for the city's surprises - its delights and its rough shoals.

title: Shift Gives Reagan D.C. Circuit Majority
description: In the annals of the Federal judiciary, this will go down as a historic week.

title: ENERGY CAPITAL DEVELOPENT reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Omar Telmessani Dies; Cairo Fundamentalist
description: Omar Telmessani, leader of the outlawed Moslem Brotherhood, died Thursday of liver failure and circulatory problems. He was 81 years old. Mr. Telmessani had been the head of the brotherhood, a fundamentalist group, for 12 years and had served as editor of its magazine, Al Daawa.

title: EXPERTS ASSAIL REAGAN OVER PROBLEMS OF HUNGRY
description: Experts on hunger in the United States asserted today that the Reagan Administration was unsympathetic to the needs of America's poor people. They said the number of hungry people was growing and described as naive the President's assessment this week that lack of knowledge was the principal cause of hunger.

title: NICKLAUS SINKS BIRDIE FOR TIE
description: Jack Nicklaus is threatening to make the 46th year of his life the most memorable to date - a year when this once young, strong, heroic golfer makes middle age a time of even bigger heroics.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Advanced Telecommunications Inc., Atlanta, said it had agreed in principle to acquire Satelco Inc. for about $8.7 million.

title: BROOKLYN TURNING OFFENDERS INTO HELPING HANDS
description: A black youth accused of harassing a rabbi is sentenced to help residents of Borough Park, a predominantly Hasidic section of Brooklyn, fill out paperwork to obtain social services.

title: FRANCE AND IRAN MEET TO IMPROVE TIES
description: France and Iran have made progress toward easing their strained relations after a two-day visit here by a high-level Iranian delegation, French officials said today.

title:
PATENTS;
24-Hour Time Release In Drug Dosage System
description: A controlled time-release dosage system for drugs and vitamins, which can keep them at work for as long as 24 hours, was patented this week by Choong-Gook Jang for the Tech Trade Corporation, New Brunswick, N.J.

title: GORBACHEV GIVES CRITIQUE OF SOVIET FOREIGN POLICY
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev convened senior foreign-affairs officials and Soviet ambassadors from around the world today for what the official press agency indicated was a sharp critique of Soviet foreign policy.

title: REAGAN DECIDES TO JOIN HANDS ACROSS AMERICA
description: President Reagan, in a change of plans, decided today to join ''Hands Across America'' on Sunday. The project seeks to help raise money and demonstrate compassion for the nation's hungry and homeless.

title: Mayflower's Plan On Takeover Bids
description: Mayflower Group Inc., which is the target of an unsolicited $29.25-a-share, or $225 million, takeover offer from Laidlaw Transportation Ltd., said it has adopted a plan to guarantee that shareholders receive at least $33 a share in a takeover.

title: U.S. SUBMARINES MEET AT POLE
description: Three nuclear-powered submarines surfaced together this month at the North Pole on a mission that signaled a reinforced United States submarine presence under the Arctic ice pack, Navy officials said today.

title:
PATENTS;
Safer Training Missile
description: A lightweight rocket-powered training missile that minimizes danger to personnel and damage to property upon its impact has been invented for the Navy.

title: MULRONEY 'FURIOUS' AT REAGAN APPROVAL OF LUMBER TARIFFS
description: Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, who has spoken of his friendship with the United States, today unleashed a barrage of criticism at President Reagan, accusing him of engaging in ''pure protectionism'' against Canada.

title: Affirmative (to Most People) Action
description: Even in striking down a layoff plan for Michigan teachers, the Supreme Court has given affirmative action a welcome affirmation. Yes, we ought to do more than stop discriminating now, it says. Society ought to try, with great care, to undo damage inflicted over generations. The Court's humane message contrasts acutely with the viewpoint of William Bradford Reynolds, the Administration's civil rights chief. He would now rush to negate affirmative action policies in place for 20 years.

title: Bears Drop Receiver
description: The Chicago Bears said they have waived the wide receiver James Maness after he tested positive for cocaine use this week.

title: Is a Twinkie a Bribe? A Politician Worries
description: An unsuccessful City Council candidate, George L. Belair, has been charged with violating a state campaign law by distributing Twinkies and other snacks to senior citizen groups in an attempt to influence votes.

title: FILM: SYLVESTER STALLONE AS POLICEMAN, IN 'COBRA'
description: ''Cobra,'' Sylvester Stallone's film about a tough big-city cop who specializes in finding - and eliminating - psychopathic killers, is a disturbing movie from many points of view: disturbing for the violence it portrays, the ideas it represents and the large number of people who will undoubtedly go to see it and cheer on its dangerous hero.

title: WORLD BANK AND I.M.F. HIT BY WALKOUT ON PAY
description: Employees of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank - including several hundred professional economists earning upward of $100,000 tax-free - walked off their jobs today in a wage dispute.

title: WORLDWIDE ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a $7 million non-cash writedown of the capitalized costs of the company's U.S. oil and gas reserves, reflecting an average domestic oil price of $11.43 a barrel as of March 31. c-Net income and includes a tax credit of $377,000.

title: Theater Preservation
description: To the Editor:

title: Petty Out of Hospital
description: Richard Petty, the legendary stock car driver, has added to the legend. Petty, who has a string of 433 consecutive starts in Winston Cup races, was released from a hospital in Charlotte, N.C., yesterday after treatment for a mild concussion and bruised leg suffered during a practice session Friday for today's Coca-Cola 600 race in Harrisburg, N.C. The accident knocked Petty cold, but it apparently didn't shake his sense of humor or his resolve to return to the races.

title: Tippoo's Tiger
description: To the Editor: In the article ''Family Guide to Museums in London'' (Travel, March 23) the Victoria and Albert Museum is described without mentioning Tippoo's Tiger. We think Tippoo is absolutely the best thing there. My son visited him once a month from the age of 1 until we came to Washington when he was 4.

title: Alabama Resignation
description: The head track coach at the University of Alabama has resigned and an athlete has lost her eligibility following an in-house investigation into possible National Collegiate Athletic Association rules violations, Ray Perkins, the athletic director, said. In addition to losing longtime track coach, John Mitchell, and Liz Lynch, a runner, Perkins said the university was offering to forfeit all meets in which she competed, including the 1986 N.C.A.A. Women's Indoor Championship, which the Tide won.

title: SMALL BUSINESSES ARE STUDIED
description: MOST of the small businesses in Connecticut need help with management problems, but few of them realize that there are state agencies that might help them, according to the results of two recent surveys.

title: Marion Coughlin Wed To John K. Twyman Jr.
description: Marion Elizabeth Coughlin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Coughlin of Larchmont, N.Y., was married yesterday to John Kennedy Twyman Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Twyman of Cincinnati. The Rev. Edward M. Roos performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Augustine's Church in Larchmont.

title: STAGE: KOBO ABE'S 'MAN WHO TURNED INTO A STICK'
description: THE sly humor underlying the three enchanting one-acters by Kobo Abe in the Pan Asian Repertory's presentation of ''The Man Who Turned Into a Stick'' at Playhouse 46 is characteristic of the drama, and much of the fiction, of this Japanese author. The boundaries between humans and nature, tangible and spiritual, animate and inanimate dissolve in his work: people find their imaginations producing reality or themselves becoming objects. These transformations inevitably victimize some people, and it is Mr. Abe's ability to make his audience smile as he draws it into the bewilderment of victims (who themselves are usually a little amused by their plight) that makes his work unique.

title: Postings; Victorian Offices for Southport
description: Conforming with the surrounding residential neighborhood of late 19th century houses, a development group in Southport, Conn., is constructing a three-story clapboard office building with many Victorian design elements.

title: A RIP IN THE WINDOW SCREEN? IT'S NOT TOO HARD TO REPAIR
description: THE arrival of warm weather also signals the arrival of mosquitoes, flies and other flying pests, so almost everyone installs screens on windows and doors to keep these unwelcome visitors out.

title: BERLIN SENIOR SETS HOME-RUN RECORD
description: WHENEVER Pam Wallace of Berlin feels she needs some extra work on her hitting, she drives about 10 miles to Southington and spends an hour or so in a batting cage, pumping away at softballs ejected from a pitching machine.

title: GLISTENING TORSOS
description: CHASING THE GILDED SHADOW A Tale of the Time of James IV of Scotland. By Hunter Steele. 379 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $16.95.

title: PASSION AND PRECISION CLASH
description: HIGH on everyone's lists of countries favored to win the World Cup are France and Argentina, and high among the reasons are the team captains, Michel Platini and Diego Armando Maradona, two players who vie for the unofficial title of the world's best. Two players who - like so many of the world's top stars -have left their native lands to play in the soccer El Dorado that is Italy. There they each earn salaries of close to $1 million a year and employ agents and business managers to handle their affairs. Lucrative affairs indeed: Platini is estimated to have earned nearly $2 million from commercial contracts and investments in 1985.

title: THE COST OF BROKEN PROMISES
description: There is further deterioration between the Reagan White House and Congress. The coming Congressional elections are one reason, particularly on the protectionist trade bill.

title: VIETNAM VETERANS HONORED BELATEDLY
description: ALTHOUGH she has never been here to view the Vietnam Veterans Memorial, Gloria Philhower of Denville had always assumed her son's name one of those etched on it. She was wrong.Her son, Charles Albert Philhower, a fireman's apprentice in the Navy, died outside the Presidentially approved war zone and was not included among the 58,022 names on the black granite wall.

title: CAN WRITING BE TAUGHT IN IOWA?
description: THIS WEEKEND, AS VETERANS and high school bands all over America are marching to the local war memorial with wreaths of tribute for those fallen in our wars, more than 300 writers have come together in Iowa City to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the Iowa Writers' Workshop. Graduates of the nation's first creative-writing establishment, they have convened with former teachers and, much like the rest of the working world, are talking shop. There are commemorative T-shirts, an Iowa Writers' Workshop cookbook, beer and barbecue, a Workshop Ball, but much of the talk - actually organized panel discussions - might seem far-fetched at a down-home Memorial Day picnic or, for that matter, at any other college reunion. The workshop crowd is holding forth on: The Care and Nurture of New Writers; Renaissance of the Short Story; and Beyond Minimalism, Beyond Modernism, Beyond Realism. Toasting the golden years and looking around, the poets, novelists and short-story writers might, indeed, feel like veterans - a few of them heroes, many more casual-ties - of the battlefield of American writing.

title: SUSAN FOLLANSBEE WED TO NICHOLAS CAVATARO
description: Susan Jane Follansbee, an exercise physiologist at Pro-Fitness Inc. in White Plains, and Nicholas James Cavataro, an aquatics and swimming coach at Iona College, were married yesterday at St. Paul's Lutheran Church in Rye Brook, N.Y. The Rev. Henry Brau, a Lutheran minister, and the Rev. John Edmund, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: LYN DUNN IS MARRIED TO RICHARD G. FOWNES
description: Carolyn E. Dunn, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James P. Dunn of Summit, N.J., was married yesterday to Richard G. Fownes, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Fownes of Sarasota, Fla. The ceremony was performed aboard the Entrepreneur, the bridegroom's yacht, in New York Harbor by the Rev. Charles A. Weinrich, a Lutheran minister.

title:
ART;
LANDSCAPES AND WEAPONS FRAME A SCULPTURE SHOW
description: NOW in its second season, the nonprofit East Hampton Center for Contemporary Art is a lively showcase for both East End and New York City artists.

title: NEW CASSETTES: BY DE SICA, SUTHERLAND AND THE ROYAL BALLET
description: Whoopi Goldberg Direct From Broadway Directed by Thomas Schlamme Vestron Video 75 minutes. $59.95 In two years, Whoopi Goldberg has gone from fringe performance artist to Hollywood movie star.

title: BARBARA IRENE FRAWLEY BECOMES BRIDE OF DAVID MELVILLE ROSS IN BEVERLY HILLS
description: Barbara Irene Frawley, an associate at the Chase Manhattan Capital Markets Corporation, and David Melville Ross, an associate at Bankers Trust Company, both in New York, were married yesterday in Beverly Hills, Calif. Msgr. Peter Healey performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Good Shepherd Church, assisted by the Rev. Arthur X. Leone.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
CONSUMERS UNION IS 50
description: ''THE Siren from H. S. Kress - Best Buy - 50 cents a pair. Can be bought individually, at 25 cents a stocking.'' That's what Consumer Union Reports, a publication of Consumers Union, wrote in May 1936. This month, the magazine (now known simply as Consumer Reports) and Consumers Union, both based in Mount Vernon, are celebrating their 50th anniversary with a reception and dinner.

title: FAWN SHARI BRENNER WED
description: Fawn Shari Brenner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Simon Brenner of Rockville Centre, L.I., was married there yesterday at Temple B'nai Shalom to Brian Alan Rich, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman E. Rich of Hallandale, Fla.

title: Furloughs Foiled
description: As a result of a lawsuit by the American Federation of Government Employees and an opinion by the General Accounting Office, the Agriculture Department has abandoned a plan to furlough 7,000 meat and poultry inspectors without pay for the Memorial Day holiday tomorrow.

title: NANCY KUNIHOLM WED TO CRAIG T. ARONHALT
description: Nancy Church Kuniholm, a commercial credit analyst for the Wilmington Savings Fund Society, and Craig Thomas Aronhalt, an account executive at Dean Witter Reynolds, both in Wilmington, Del., were married yesterday. The Rev. Donald J. Hannan 3d performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenville, Del.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
KONWISSATIONS WITH A KAT
description: George Herriman is an authentic American genius, one of the enduring figures in the art of the comic strip. His only equal in visual inventiveness is the cartoonist Winsor McCay, who drew ''Little Nemo in Slumberland.'' McCay's effects are lush alongside Herriman's imaginative austerity, but no one even approached Herriman for verbal ingenuity until Walt Kelly, a Herriman admirer, turned up with Pogo after World War II. Herriman experimented with a number of strips between 1902 and 1932, but it is ''Krazy Kat'' - which appeared from 1913 until Herriman's death in 1944 - on which his fame rests. Herriman worked many splendid variations on the basic plot which finds ''that nice 'kop,' Offisa Pupp'' attempting to keep Ignatz Mouse from beaning Krazy with a brick, which Krazy always receives as an emblem of love. The adventures of this unlikely trio are only the dramatic spine for satiric comment, philosophical rumination and Herriman's gentle display of affection for the eccentricity of human beings.

title: CELTICS VS. ROCKETS: A CLASH OF BIG MEN
description: Ever since the big, strong Boston Celtic front line of Larry Bird, Kevin McHale and Robert Parish was put together for the 1980-81 season, and augmented this year with the addition of Bill Walton, it has provided opposing coaches with serious matchup problems.

title: LEIGH WHITTINGHAM EXCHANGES VOWS WITH JOHN RUSSELL ERSKINE RUHL JR.
description: Leigh Ann Whittingham, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Arthur Whittingham of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married yesterday to John Russell Erskine Ruhl Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ruhl of Asheville, N.C. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Robert Paul Mohan, a Roman Catholic priest, in the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in Manhattan.

title: WALKER LIVES UP TO HIS STAR BILLING
description: WHEN a verdict depends heavily on the testimony of a single witness, there comes a time when that witness goes on trial along with the defendant. A case in point: the espionage proceedings against Jerry A. Whitworth, which for the last few weeks temporarily became a trial of the Government's star witness, John A. Walker Jr. Mr. Walker, who has acknowledged spying for 17 years and recruiting his son and older brother to steal military data that he sold to the Soviet Union, did not have a trial of his own. He pleaded guilty to espionage along with his son, Michael L. Walker, in Baltimore in October. His brother, Arthur J. Walker, did not take the stand at his own brief trial in which he was convicted in Norfolk, Va., in August.

title: Johns Hopkins Student Charged in Firebombing
description: A junior at Johns Hopkins University was charged with three counts of attempted murder and arson today for allegedly firebombing a campus shanty built to protest South Africa's policy of strict racial segregation.

title: Irish Senate Approves Divorce Referendum
description: The Senate approved a referendum today on whether to lift the ban on divorce and set the vote for June 26.

title: SEEING CHINA LIKE A CAPITALIST
description: From the inside of a 23-foot 3-inch-long blue-black Fleetwood Brougham Cadillac stretch limousine with a 5-liter V-8 engine, vinyl roof, whitewall tires, air-conditioning, push-button (and tinted) windows, color television, AM-FM radio, dual refrigerators, bar stocked with Gorham lead-filled crystal glasses, lace antimacassars on the backs of the red plush seats, driven by a young chauffeur in a new blue uniform with bright brass buttons, the Peoples' Republic of China seems like a different country.

title: Tippoo's Tiger
description: To the Editor: One of the most delightful museums in London for children - and children at heart - is Pollock's Toy Museum, 1 Scala Street, behind the Goodge Street Underground station. Pollock's is slightly off the beaten track, but a nice respite from tourist London.

title: YANKS, WIN DESPITE 6 ERRORS
description: The afternoon lacked artistic excellence. It was, as far as the Yankees were concerned, a day full of untimely blunders: six errors that led to three unearned runs by the California Angels. But there was also redemption. Mike Pagliarulo, who made two errors at third base and dropped a ball that helped the Angels tie the game in the top of the ninth inning, hit a decisive single through the right side of the infield in the bottom of the ninth that lifted the Yankees to a 7-6 victory yesterday at the Stadium.

title: The Senate Finance Panel's Tax Bill, I.R.A.'s and Capital Gains
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIAN MICHAEL JAY IS WED TO KATHLEEN JEAN WARFORD
description: The wedding of Kathleen Jean Warford to Bryan Michael Jay took place yesterday at Our Lady of Angels Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn.

title: Ignorant About Hunger
description: ''I don't believe that there is anyone going hungry in America simply by reason of denial or lack of ability to feed them,'' President Reagan said to visiting high school students last week. ''It is by people not knowing where or how to get this help.''

title: On Language; Dry My Bier
description: BACK IN THE NIXON era, I remember going to a Redskins football game with Henry A. Kissinger, then national security adviser. We sat in Edward Bennett Williams's box with Earl Warren, who had retired as Chief Justice, all rooting cheerfully until an egregious interference decision was made by a referee that called back a home-team touchdown.

title: VISITING A TIBETAN MONESTARY
description: Along a dusty road 30 miles east of the Tibetan capital of Lhasa, one first sees Ganden Monastery, a stark silhouette high and nearly hidden on a far-off ridge. A mile or two more up a road that switches tortuously along the side of a mountain and one is there, amid what, were it not in the Himalayas, might be a collection of Greek ruins. Only a few of hundreds of rooms have been restored; the rest of the monastery is hollowed shells of stone, jagged pillars and clumps of dirt. Ganden is old and in ruins, but these are not old ruins: This 15th-century monastery, the third largest in Tibet, was destroyed only 17 years ago.

title: ON A WORKING VISIT TO ITALY AND THOUGHTS ON BOXING
description: I GOT the assignment to referee my first world title fight in Italy shortly after the bombing of Tripoli. The fight was between Reyes Cruz and Gary Hinton for Aaron Pryor's abdicated International Boxing Federation title. Friends and others warned of the dangers of the trip. People will always tell you what you can't do. They used to advise me of the ills of my profession when I was a young boxer. The plane carrying the officials left New York at 8:30 P.M. on a Wednesday, bound for another place and another time.

title: NEW CASSETTES: BY DE SICA, SUTHERLAND AND THE ROYAL BALLET
description: The Bicycle Thief Starring Lamberto Maggiorani, Lianella Carell, Enzo Staiola, Elena Altieri; directed by Vittorio De Sica, 1949 Corinth Films 90 minutes. $69.95 Though Vittorio De Sica tended toward flamboyance as an actor, he was a director of rigorous simplicity in his early, neo-realist films.

title: CRANKING UP A POWERFUL 'HAMLETMACHINE'
description: The plays by Heiner Muller are as dense as they are brief - shell fragments fired into our collective psyche. This East German playwright subscribes to the theory that ''theater is a laboratory for the social imagination,'' and, in ''Hamletmachine,'' he deconstructs Shakespeare in order to contemplate and comprehend the disintegration of civilization. Hamlet's madness becomes Muller's obsession, and he sees in it, in particular, a reflection of Germany today. For the author's English translator, Carl Weber, ''Hamletmachine'' is ''probably Muller's most complicated text, and the most difficult to decode.'' It is also, one might add, almost impossible to stage. What do you do, for example, with a stage direction that says that Hamlet ''steps into the armor, splits with the ax the heads of Marx, Lenin, Mao. Snow. Ice Age''?

title: UNCERTAINTY ON FUNDS THREATENS CHANNEL 21'S GAINS
description: SAMUEL J. FRANCIS, general manager of Channel 21, keeps his fingers crossed a lot these days. Money is at the heart of his worries.

title: Statue Would Honor Women's War Role
description: A group of women who are veterans of the war in Indochina has announced plans to place a bronze statue of an American military nurse on the grounds of the Vietnam Veterans Memorial on the Mall.

title: PENNY WATRAS IS THE BRIDE OF ROBERT B. DANA ON L.I.
description: Patricia Ann Karoline Watras, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Watras of South Huntington, L.I., and Delray Beach, Fla., and Robert Bristol Dana, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Dwight Dana of Appleton, Wis., were married yesterday at St. Elizabeth's Roman Catholic Church in South Huntington. Msgr. Arthur Kane officiated.

title: A FRESH TASTE OF MEXICO
description: THE few Mexican restaurants in Connecticut tend to follow a borderline fast-food pattern of similarity. What a pleasant surprise, then, to find Cafe de Olla in Winsted.

title: Headliners; A Federal Case
description: Iran's chief delegate to the United Nations had some explaining to do last week. Said Rajaie-Khorassani, accused of trying to walk out of Alexander's department store with a $99.99 raincoat on May 7, said he was returning it to the rack and had only tucked the price tags in the pocket to get them out of the way while he was feeling the fit. Mr. Rajaie-Khorassani, who has diplomatic immunity from prosecution, appeared forgiving toward Alexander's but said that the F.B.I. had taken every advantage of the situation. An agent summoned to the store pressed him for information, Mr. Rajaie-Khorassani said - probably to ''later on use the situation for blackmail.'' The Iranian mission was more direct, describing the incident as ''a total set-up'' by the F.B.I.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Auto Racing Indianapolis 500. Danny Sullivan, the defending champion, will be carrying one of the three race television cameras from his No. 2 position on Row 1. Although ABC has been televising the race for the last 22 years, this is the first time it will be shown live. (Television -Channel 7, 11 A.M.) $700,000 Nascar Coca-Cola 600, at Charlotte, N.C. (Television - MSG, 2 P.M. live and 8 P.M. tape.) Formula I Grand Prix of Belgium. (Television - ESPN, 10 A.M. Two-hour tape delay.) Baseball Yankees vs. California Angels, at Yankee Stadium, 1:35 P.M. (Television -Channel 11, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 1:30 P.M.) Mets vs. Padres, at San Diego, 4:05 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 4 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 4 P.M.) Cardinals vs. Atlanta Braves, at St. Louis (Television - WTBS, 2:05 P.M.) College: N.C.A.A. Northeast Regional Tournament, at the University of Maine, Orono, Me. Noon and 3 P.M. Bicycling The Tour of Nutley, N.J., 1 P.M. The Men's National Criterium Championships at 50 miles gets under way at 2 P.M., and the headliner is the Olympic silver medalist, Leonard (Harvey) Nitz. In the 20-mile women's race, at 1 P.M., Rebecca Twigg, also an Olympic silver medalist, will compete. Running Yonkers Marathon, at Gorton High School, Lake and Morningside Avenues, Yonkers, 9 A.M. In addition to the prize money of $1,000, $500 and $300 apiece to the first three male and female finishers, the first 500 eligible finishers over the 26.2-mile course will get automatic acceptance into the New York City Marathon Nov. 2.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
CELEBRATION OF MUSIC
description: There will be jazz bands, choral and string ensembles, woodwind quintets, vocal and instrumental soloists and an exhibit of 155 works of art in a wide range of two-dimensional mediums.

title:
IN NEW JERSEY;
MODERATE-RENT UNITS RISE IN HACKENSACK
description: IN Hackensack, many high-rise condominiums have been developed over the last decade on Prospect Avenue, which stands on a ridge overlooking the city. But few rental apartments were built there or elsewhere in the city, and of those few, most have been converted into condominiums.

title: CHILDREN PONDER CHERNOBYL
description: I ARRIVED later than I had expected from the meeting. A spring storm slowed down traffic and I was glad to be in my snug house and safely out of the drenching downpour.

title: Briefing; Next Stop, Moscow
description: Alexander Shalnev, the Tass White House correspondent who has come to symbolize the smoother, more Westernized approach of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, is being recalled to Moscow.

title: GENERAL ELECTRIC'S AMAZING MONEY-MAKING MACHINE
description: ''WE'RE not a bank,'' says Robert C. Wright, president of the General Electric Credit Corporation, with a note of disdain in his voice for banks. But perhaps the man protests too much. In the era of deregulation, G.E. Credit is emerging as a tough and innovative competitor for much more familiar giants of banking and finance such as Citicorp, Merrill Lynch and American Express. Consider its ingenuity:

title: NEW BARD IN A NEW McCARTER
description: TO SAY that ''As You Like It'' was recently unfurled at the McCarter Theatre here is apt indeed.

title: HISTORY OF STATE'S TRAINS TOLD WITH LOVE IN BOOK
description: THE first comprehensive history of railroading in Connecticut - the work of three railroad buffs who as boys fell in love with the whistle of locomotives and their spiraling plumes of black smoke - will be published next month by the Connecticut Historical Society.

title: REAGAN JUDGES GET LOWER BAR RATING
description: The quality of Reagan Administration nominees for Federal appeals courts has dropped significantly in President Reagan's second term, according to ratings compiled by the American Bar Association.

title: DELACROIX AND INGRES CONTINUE THEIR DUEL OF FIRE AND ICE
description: Two old enemies have sneaked into town. Jean-Auguste-Dominique Ingres, fearless defender of line, ideal beauty and the classical tradition, has 50 drawings at the Frick Collection through June 15. Eugene Delacroix, embodiment of the color and passion of Romanticism, is sharing the Salander O'Reilly Gallery with Jean-Baptiste-Camille Corot through June 28. These are not the exhibitions to evoke the 1820's and 30's in Paris, when Ingres and Delacroix all but divided the capital of the art world into armed camps. But a concurrent New York visit by these 19th-century giants is almost unheard of, and even in limited exhibitions their punch is evident.

title: BALLET: 'REQUIEM' RECAST
description: SIR KENNETH MacMillan's new ''Requiem,' presented by the American Ballet Theater on Thursday at the Metropolitan Opera House, is a nightmare tapestry through which are woven suggestions of love, loss and redemption. The ballet's 28 dancers might be moving through a wartime landscape, crowded with dim figures who serve as chorus, some fleetingly suggesting images of kindness or hostility. The children are like the doomed young Cambodian boy and his sister of Andrew Lloyd Webber's ''Requiem,'' to which the ballet is danced. But this is a tightly woven tapestry with many repetitions of pattern. Shapes and the stage picture are what seems most important about ''Requiem.''

title: FARMERS' SLIPPING SHARE OF THE MARKET
description: HARD times on the farm and political backlash from farmers in an election year have stirred new militancy in United States agricultural trade policy. Against a backdrop of mounting farm debt, price-depressing crop surpluses and shrinking land values, the Reagan Administration has moved closer to combat with some of its most valued foreign allies.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Topics; Mirror Images; Seeing Red
description: ''Information about the capitalist world is monotonous,'' a Soviet commentator wrote recently in Pravda, criticizing Soviet television's coverage of the West. ''Journalistic cliches [ like pictures of protests ] migrate from broadcast to broadcast.''

title: MARTHA PEARSALL TO BE WED TO ROBERT CHARLES SATROM
description: Martha Jeanne Pearsall and Robert Charles Satrom plan to be married late in June, according to the announcement made by Mr. and Mrs. Peter D. Reichenbach of Voorhees, N.J., the future bride's mother and stepfather. Mr. Satrom is a son of LeRoy M. Satron of Kent, Ohio and the late Grace E. Satrom.

title: THE DEFICIT
description: To the Editor:

title: Wire-Fox Terrier Best
description: An Irish-bred wire-fox terrier, Ch. Galsul Excellence, owned by William MacKay and Ruth Cooper, was named today as best of 1,334 dogs at the 57th annual show of the Monmouth County Kennel Club at Wolf Hill Farm.

title: Postings; Monroe Grows
description: The last time Monroe, N.Y., a small town in southeastern Orange County, drew wide attention was in 1976 when a group of Hasidic Jews from Brooklyn chose the community as the site for a new village.

title: The Victorious Personality
description: I came to the United States in 1975, at the age of 14, as a political refugee from South Vietnam. I quickly learned to speak English and graduated from high school in three years, receiving awards for outstanding senior in math and sciences.

title: THATCHER IS FIRST BRITISH PREMIER IN ISRAEL
description: Margaret Thatcher arrived in Jerusalem tonight on the first visit to Israel by a British Prime Minister.

title: CLARISSA BULLITT, ERIC BETTELHEIM PLAN TO BE WED
description: Clarissa Wardwell Bullitt and Eric R. Bettelheim plan to be married in the fall, according to the announcement of their engagement made by Mrs. Frank Seidner of Washington and John C. Bullitt of New York, parents of the prospective bride. Mr. Bettelheim is the son of Dr. Bruno Bettelheim of Berkeley, Calif., and the late Mrs. Bettelheim.

title: 5-YEAR-OLD, HIT OUTSIDE HOME BY OBJECT, DIES
description: A 5-year-old boy who was struck in the head Friday night by an unknown object outside his Brooklyn home died yesterday afternoon at Brookdale Hospital Medical Center as the police sought to determine how he had been injured.

title: Architect Leaving Mark on Westchester
description: SEVERAL of the major new office buildings in Westchester County bear the stamp of one architect, Michael Harris Spector. Mr. Spector has designed five buildings in the past few years that rank among the largest in Westchester, with a total of 2,345,000 square feet built or under construction in highly visible locations. He is working on designs for 1.5 million more square feet of offices and condominiums.

title: Central America Leaders Start 2 Days of Talks
description: Five Central American Presidents began two days of meetings here today in what promises to be a difficult effort to seek consensus on resolving their region's conflicts.

title: Focus: Baltimore; Waterfront Upgrading In Ripples
description: WITH the redevelopment of the downtown waterfront near Harborplace and the National Aquarium nearly complete, developers are now pushing farther out along the harbor, transforming abandoned industrial property into a glittering string of expensive housing, restaurants and marinas.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: A PIECE OF MY HEART: The Stories of 26 American Women Who Served in Vietnam. By Keith Walker (Presidio, $18.95.) This oral history recounts the experiences of a minority tucked experiences of a minority tucked away within another minority -American women who went to Vietnam in the military or as volunteers or entertainers.

title: Elizabeth Hollister Weds R. L. Jackson in Brooklyn
description: Elizabeth Louise Hollister, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Hollister of Brooklyn and Voluntown, Conn., was married yesterday to Robert Lee Jackson, the son of Edith Jackson of Colorado Springs, Colo., and Harold Jackson of Sullivan, Mo. The Revs.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: BERNARDO BERTOLUCCI. By Robert Phillip Kolker. (Oxford University, $17.95.) Robert Phillip Kolker says that ''this study is a critical one in all senses of the word.

title: Social Events; Evenings on the Town
description: Party Indoors and Out - May 27 - Yo-Yo Ma, Roberta Flack and the Harlem Blues and Jazz Band will perform at a benefit for the Children's Storefront, an independent school that provides year-round, tuition-free education for some of Harlem's most deprived youngsters. There will be a street party in front of the Storefront at 57 East 129th Street from 5 to 7 P.M. Then the party moves indoors for a dinner-dance at All Saints Church next to the school. Tickets, $35 for street party alone, $250 for street party and dinner-dance and $125 for those 35 years old and under, from 212-628-2208 or 212-879-3977. July 4 Preview May 27 - There will be cocktails at 7 P.M., dinner at 8 and then entertainment with Theodore Bikel as host of a preview of some of the July 4 weekend activities. The evening at the Water Club at the East River and 30th Street benefits the Ethnic Folk Arts Center, a nonprofit group dedicated to the research and performance of music and dance of the nation's urban immigrant communities. Tickets, $150, from 212-691-9510. Movie Preview May 28 - Founded in 1974 to serve the needs of Chinatown and Asians in the New York area, the community group Equality is renovating a building on Eldridge Street with state aid. With $1 million raised, $500,000 more is needed, prompting a benefit preview of ''A Great Wall,'' billed as the first feature film shot by an American company in China.

title: GRANDMOTHER GETS THE BILL
description: The first person ordered to pay child support under a state law holding grandparents liable for their teen-age children's offspring says it is hard to teach children right from wrong these days.

title: A Producer's Woes
description: To the Editor:

title: TREATING AN OUTBREAK OF PATIENT DUMPING IN TEXAS
description: TEXAS is renowned for its hospitality and its entrepreneurial spirit, but not for the munificence of its programs to help the down and out. Yet Texas is a pioneer among the states in insuring that the indigent are not treated shabbily when they get sick. Strict guidelines - the first of their kind in the nation -regulate the transfer of patients from one hospital to another. The new rules, which went into effect April 1, are meant to cut down on what critics call the ''dumping'' of patients on public hospitals by private for-profit and voluntary nonprofit hospitals.

title: WHEN EXECUTIVES SHOUT 'EUREKA!'
description: The Intuitive Manager, by Roy Rowan. Little, Brown & Co., Boston. 188 pages, $15.95. IT is hard to imagine today's often-overeducated managers letting intuition replace marketing surveys and computer models. Yet Mr. Rowan, a member of Fortune magazine's board of editors, makes a compelling case for the old-fashioned hunch.

title: CASINOS CAMPAIGN IN TRENTON FOR ALL-DAY GAMING
description: Casino executives testified last week that the time has come to relax New Jersey's law requiring casinos to close every night.

title: HOW CHERNOBYL ALTERS THE NUCLEAR EQUATION
description: THE Soviet nuclear plant disaster at Chernobyl is casting a deepening shadow over reactors in the United States. Already, politicians and critics concerned about the ability to evacuate people in a major accident are taking steps to delay the operation of some of the 15 nuclear plants that are complete or nearly complete but not yet licensed for full power. Those plants, whose total investment is about $50 billion, include Shoreham on Long Island, Seabrook in New Hampshire and Commanche Peak in Texas.

title: FAIR-HOUSING AMENDMENT FACES FIGHT IN THE STATE SENATE
description: GOVERNOR KEAN and the Republican leadership in the Legislature have agreed on a proposed constitutional amendment designed to prevent the State Supreme Court from ordering any more housing in the suburbs for the poor.

title: Tax Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: City Drafts Formal Rules for Living in Artists' Lofts
description: TO live in one of the 3,500 lofts in SoHo or NoHo, residents must be artists - and they are supposed to prove it to the Department of Cultural Affairs, which recently drafted regulations based on the informal procedure it has used since 1971.

title: EXOTIC OPERAS VIE FOR PUBLIC FAVOR
description: Even in the absence of many popular new operas, our operatic repertory is expanding. The public demands novelties, and aside from new singers, conductors, directors and designers, what better way than unfamiliar operas?

title: The Senate Finance Panel's Tax Bill, I.R.A.'s and Capital Gains
description: To the Editor:

title: LINDA BRYAN ENGAGED TO DR. ALAN ALMOND
description: Sir Arthur Bryan and Lady Bryan of Barlaston, Staffordshire, England, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Linda Bryan, to Dr. Alan Almond, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Almond of Tollerton, Yorkshire, England.

title: The Deficit
description: To the Editor:

title: IN MEMORY OF 4 YOUNG MEN, A MASK OF FRIVOLITY COMES OFF
description: In memory of John, Paul, Thomas, Walter and all young men and women who gave their lives in Vietnam and elsewhere for our country.

title: LAROUCHE CONCERN TO CONTEST ORDERS
description: A company linked to the political extremist Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. will contest orders from three states to stop issuing unregistered promissory notes, the company's attorney says.

title: Goldie and Reneberg To Meet in Tennis Final
description: Dan Goldie of Stanford and Richey Reneberg of Southern Methodist won semifinal matches today to advance to the singles final in the National Collegiate Athletic Association men's tennis individual championships to be played Sunday.

title: DANIEL RECOVERS TO LEAD GOLF BY 2
description: Beth Daniel considered her double bogey on the 13th hole today a turning point - for the better.

title: Youth in Critical Condition
description: A teen-age boy rescued Friday afternoon from the the waters of Rockaway Beach remains in critical condition, a spokesman at Peninsula Hospital Center in Far Rockaway, Queens, said yesterday. The youth, Persand Tameshwar, 15 years old, of Brooklyn, swam too far from the shore and was pulled from the water by lifeguards who were preparing to open the beach. A second youth, Mahin Budhran, also 15, was listed in stable condition, the hospital spokesman said.

title: MARY CALOTTA, EXECUTIVE AT BANK, BECOMES BRIDE
description: Mary Kay Calotta, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Calotta of Suffern, N.Y., was married yesterday to Campbell Black, a son of Mrs. Ernest A. Whitfield of Lord Howe Island, New South Wales, Australia, and James W. Black of Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. Eugene G. Connolly performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: THE CLOCK IS TICKING ON THE CONTADORA TREATY
description: THE presidents of five Central American nations held a rare meeting this weekend in Guatemala to seek consensus on the Contadora regional peace treaty being considered by their nations: Nicaragua, El Salvador, Honduras, Costa Rica and Guatemala. And as the June 6 deadline for signing the treaty approached, ideological hard-liners in both Washington and Nicaragua were already complaining of a sellout. Such complaints are an indication of the obstacles to reaching an accord that would replace threats with concessions.

title: A COOL EYE IN A PARCHED LANDSCAPE
description: OUT OF INDIA Selected Stories. By Ruth Prawer Jhabvala. 288 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $16.95. TO anyone who admires and honors Ruth Prawer Jhabvala's writing - and who does not? - the most interesting part of this book of her chosen short stories, choice though they are, is her introduction. It may be she has told before something of what lies behind her work, but I do not remember it, as, surely, I would have done.

title: BENEFITS AWARD DISPUTED
description: A PERSONNEL policy that will enable the retiring City Manager here to collect $246,000 for unused sick leave and vacation time has infuriated taxpayers and led to an investigation of the legality of the payments.

title: RECENT ISSUES FEATURE POSTAL CARDS AND A COPMMEMORATIVE FROM ISRAEL
description: The United States Postal Service is enjoying success with its new postal cards.

title: Office Development Surges in Suburbs
description: LAST month, Paine Webber, the big financial-services company based on the Avenue of the Americas, decided to consolidate part of its scattered back-office operations in Manhattan and move them across the Hudson River into a million square feet of new office space in Weehawken, N.J.

title: THE EXECUTIVES WHO PLY NEW YORK'S RIVERS
description: ''IT'S pure escape,'' said Kurt F. Teske of the Harold Friedman Consortium, producers of television commercials.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: THE EGG AND I - THE adoption center at Bellport High School was jumping. Students raced in between classes to cajole a teacher, Nancy Stouffer, for ''just one more'' new son or daughter.

title: THE FIERCE THREE-WAY BATTLE FOR THE MORNING TV AUDIENCE
description: Al Choate, a farmer, was with his dog, Tango, on live national television. Tango had saved Al from an angry cow and was named Dog of the Year for his efforts. Joan Lunden, the interviewer, asked what might have happened to Al had Tango not intervened. ''I guess that would have been the end of me,'' said Al. ''Hmm,'' reflected Miss Lunden. ''A real life-and-death situation.'' Life and death, cows and dogs. That's the stuff of morning television, although it doesn't always come in such neat packages as the above sample from a recent edition of ABC's ''Good Morning America.'' For two hours every morning, the news-and-information shows on ABC, NBC and CBS compete for viewers with a mix of everything from ''breaking international news to dog of the year,'' as ABC's David Hartman, a practitioner of the form put it.

title: 6 Die in Sri Lanka Attacks
description: At least six civilians were killed and eight were wounded when Tamil separatist guerrillas attacked three Sinhalese villages in Sri Lanka's eastern Trincomalee district, military sources said today. They said guerrillas armed with AK-47 rifles stormed the villages of Serunuwara, Kallar and Gomarankadawala Friday night. The attacks came hours after military officials said troops had successfully swept through the northern Jaffna Peninsula in a six-day operation to clear roads and secure areas controlled by Tamil guerrillas.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: CODE EZRA. By Gay Courter. (Houghton Mifflin, $18.95.) Like the divided Middle East, which provides much of its backdrop, ''Code Ezra'' has conflicting loyalties that are unresolved.

title: Indian Museum At Crossroads
description: FOR more than a decade, the Museum of the American Indian had sought to move from a too-small site in a seedy section of the Upper West Side, at Broadway and 155th Street, to a more appealing place where it could show its entire collection to visitors. There was hope last year that a solution was near.

title: SOVIET REVISES RULES OF OPERATION FOR NUCLEAR PLANTS AFTER DISASTER
description: The Soviet Union's top atomic power official has disclosed that the Government issued new ''operating instructions'' for all its nuclear stations as soon as the Chernobyl disaster occurred last month.

title: THE CURSE OF WAR
description: There is no more beautiful ceremony here in the flowering spring than the decoration of the graves in Arlington National Cemetery on the banks of the Potomac.

title: Pamela G. Harris, Investment Executive, to Wed
description: Dr. Joseph T. Harris of Metuchen, N.J., and Boca Raton, Fla., and Betty Harris of Cliffside Park, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Pamela Gwen Harris to Charles Andrew Heffner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard D. Heffner of New York and Putnam Valley, N.Y. A February wedding is planned.

title: WHEN FACTS DON'T ADD UP TO THE TRUTH
description: ''What is truth?'' Pilate asked the question but, being the sort of man he was, he didn't bother to supply an answer when no hands went up. In ''Rashomon,'' Akira Kurosawa denies the possibility of any fixed, universal truth by offering four, equally plausible explanations for the same act of violence. Truth is only as reliable as each person's perception of it. It's also the raw material for fiction, which, as processed in the minds of artists, becomes something quite other - a free exercise of the imagination that demonstrates its own logic and truth.

title: JAZZ: PAUL BLEY QUARTET
description: The Paul Bley Quartet, which is at Sweet Basil (88 Seventh Avenue South) through Sunday, gives its repertory the jazz equivalent of a CAT scan: examining each tune inside and out, in a series of cross-sections from every imaginable angle.

title: SOME FRESH IDEAS FROM THE SHELVES OF THE GREENGROCER
description: FARM stands laden with fresh, attractive produce are not a new phenomenon in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. Indeed, they have long represented one of the joys of suburban and country living. Even their urban counterparts, the green markets or installations like the Jamaica Farmers Market in Queens have become an established part of the cityscape. Farm-fresh produce now receives deserved appreciation everywhere.

title: STAGE: A SATIRICAL REVUE, 'PROFESSIONALLY SPEAKING'
description: ''THIS business isn't what it used to be - the Surgeon General won't let them smoke!'' complains an overwrought physician, resentful that America's health-consciousnesss might be denying him patients. Working himself into a lather of indignation, he clambers onto his desk to beseech the heavens, ''Oh pretty please! I need disease!'' Performed by David Ardao, ''A Doctor's Lament'' typifies the acerbic mood of ''Professionally Speaking,'' a revue made up of more than two dozen satirical songs about doctors, lawyers and teachers, at the Theater at Saint Peter's Church. Written by Peter Winkler, Ernst Muller, and Frederic Block and performed by a cast of six, the material displays a frisky verbal energy as it takes a bleak, cold-hearted view of the professions.

title: A FORMER STUDENT ACTIVIST RUNS UP THE FLAG
description: MEMORIAL DAY 1985 found me with three children under the age of 4, a house on Long Island and doing pretty well. College in the 60's had prepared me for many things. That Memorial Day was not among them. The war in Indochina, colleges clamping down on student rights, demonstrations for equality; the 60's weren't a time that you loved the Stars and Stripes just because it was the American flag. My peers were wearing it; some were burning it.

title: OUTRAGEOUS, YES, BUT NOT SO FUNNY
description: Perhaps it is only a matter of Lenny Bruce being stretched to logical conclusions, but contemporary comedy is becoming downright unsettling. From Martin Short to Bob Goldthwait, a good many of the newer comedians are pushing the limits of outrageousness in routines that reach for questionable laughs. Among other things, they look like they're having a nervous breakdown in public or being mentally retarded or simply being obnoxious brats. Consider ''On Location: Howie Mandel,'' an hourlong special being carried on the Home Box Office pay-cable service (future playdates are May 28 and June 2). Mr. Mandel has been playing Dr. Ficus on the NBC series ''St. Elsewhere,'' and he supplied the cuddly voice for Gizmo in the film ''Gremlins.'' Last year, he did a half-hour special for pay cable's ''Cinemax Comedy Experiment'' series. In short, since launching his career as a comic in Hollywood clubs six years ago, Mr. Mandel has been moving along as promisingly as any agent could wish.

title: BROKEN-BAT HOMER BRINGS METS' LOSS
description: They didn't have Dwight Gooden to kick around this time. But they did a pretty good job on Sid Fernandez and Jesse Orosco.

title: FRESH AIR FUND ALUMNI RECALL SUMMER JOYS
description: John Ryan fondly recalls a summer afternoon almost 40 years ago when he went exploring the countryside near Saranac Lake and discovered a fish pond that looked promising. When he returned home with a full catch, the family he was visiting told him the pond was his own discovery: it had not been fished for years.

title: FEATHERED ART FROM ANCIENT PERU
description: Feathers give flight to birds and send men's minds soaring. Some ravishing evidence of the latter can be seen through June 18, in an extraordinary exhibition of ancient Peruvian plumage at the Edward H. Merrin Gallery, 724 Fifth Avenue, at 57th Street.

title: Recent Sales
description: Glen Rock $225,000 14 Hillman Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 2-bath, 38-year-old colonial; new family room *2*with fireplace, skylights, french doors; taxes $2,937. Livingston $146,900 73 Fellswood Drive *2*3-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old ranch; aluminum siding, *2*1-car attached garage, new bathroom; taxes $2,125. Morris Township $135,000 27 Lake Valley Road *2*3-bedroom, 1-bath, 38-year-old Cape; Cod; family room with *2*fireplace, attached garage, on 1 acre; taxes $2,303. Smoke Rise $290,000 613 Mountain Road *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 5-year-old contemporary; skylights, *2*3 decks, family room; taxes $3,966. Wayne $200,000 18 Rillo Drive *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 25-year-old bi-level; den, family room, *2*new kitchen and deck; taxes $2,900. West Orange $243,000 2-4 Burnett Terrace *2*5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 60-year-old Tudor; renovated bathrooms *2*and kitchen, slate roof, rec room; taxes $3,886. OTHER AREAS Patchogue, L.I. $70,000 1 Willow Walk *2*3-bedroom, 1-bath, 50-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, *2*enclosed porch; taxes $980. Armonk, N.Y. $285,000 9 Evan Place *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 10-year-old colonial; *2*2 fireplaces, deck, landscaping, 2 acres; taxes $4,092. Canton, Conn. $145,000 297 Gracey Road *2*3-bedroom, 2 1/2 bath, 5-year-old contemporary; *2*solar hot-water panels, 1 acre; taxes $2,468.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
CANCER SCREENING
description: Even before President Reagan's surgery last summer, the American Cancer Society had targeted colorectal carcinoma as the cancer about which the general public had the least accurate information.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Moises Alou, the son of the former major leaguer Felipe Alou and nephew of two other former major leaguers, Jesus and Matty Alou, has been signed by the Pittsburgh Pirates. The 19-year-old, 6-foot-3-inch Moises was Pittsburgh's first-round selection in the regular phase of the free-agent draft out of Canada Junior College in California. . . . The Dodgers have released the pinch-hitter Terry Whitfield, who had only one hit in 14 times at bat this season, and replaced him on the roster with Len Matuszek, who is coming off the disabled list after surgery on his right shoulder last January. . . . The linebacker Mike Green of the San Diego Chargers, the team's top defensive player in 1984, was released after failing his physical.

title: U.S. IS SAID TO OPPOSE U.N. POST FOR EAST GERMAN
description: The United States has decided to try to block the appointment as chairman of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights of an East German official who Israel says was a Nazi Party member, according to a prominent Jewish figure.

title: ST. ANTHONY'S WINS BOYS, GIRLS TITLES
description: A double victory by Derrick Comma in field events led St. Anthony's of Huntington, L.I., to the team title yesterday in the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association Boys' Outdoor Track and Field Championships at St. John's University.
