On Friday night, the St. Anthony's girls' squad won the C.H.S.A.A. crown at Mitchel Park in Uniondale, L.I., with 53 points.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: DEAD AIR. By Mike Lupica. (Villard, $15.95.) If Henny Youngman, who apparently holds the record for the most jokes delivered in one minute, decided to write like Raymond Chandler, he might conceivably come up with ''Dead Air,'' a first novel by Mike Lupica, a sports columnist for The Daily News.

title: Missouri Picked for Census
description: The Census Bureau has selected St. Louis and 14 Missouri counties to test its system for the 1990 national census, a spokesman for Senator John C. Danforth, chairman of the Commerce Committee, said Friday. The committee, which has jurisdiction over the Census Bureau, said the bureau was notifying its offices in Missouri that St. Louis and the counties, Boone, Camden, Cole, Cooper, Franklin, Gasconade, Howard, Laclede, Maries, Miller, Montineau, Morgan, Osage and Pulaski, had been selected.

title: EX-LAWMAKER WARNS OF CUTS FOR SCHOOLS IN TEXAS SPEECH
description: Texas must not sacrifice its educational standards to cut state spending, former Representative Barbara Jordan said in prepared remarks prepared for delivery at the University of Texas graduation ceremonies tonight.

title: PICKING YOUR WAY AMONG NEW ISSUES
description: THE new issues game is a seductive one. Winners can pocket big rewards. Take, for example, the lucky investors who put their money in last year's best-performing initial public stock offering, Instructavision, a company that develops educational software. Between August and December, shareholders saw the stock more than 300 percent from its offering price of $1.50 a share - heavy investors could have hit the jackpot.

title: OUT OF STEP WITH PROSPERITY, VETERANS SEEK JOBS
description: There are powerful economic currents swirling around America today, set loose by investment wizards who plot corporate takeovers and mergers.

title: REAGAN IS REPORTED NEAR DECISION TO APPROVE A NEW SPACE SHUTTLE
description: President Reagan is reported to be nearing a decision to build another space shuttle, but a vigorous debate is likely to continue inside the Administration over precisely what kind of shuttle operations there should be and how to pay for them.

title: OUT OF CHINA COMES A COMEDY OF CLASHING CULTURES
description: ''The research scientist and a good artist - in a way they're doing the same thing,'' says Peter Wang. ''The only difference is that for a scientist, the result has to be repeatable. For an artist, it's a no-no.''

title: Busy Enclave
description: One of Long Island's newest communities, Islandia, a 2.48 square-mile enclave of 2,500 people near Hauppauge in Suffolk County, is the site of some of the area's strongest growth.

title: SCHOOLCHILDREN FROM COUNTY AND CHINA ARE JOINING IN DANCE
description: PUBLIC schoolchildren from the county will meet their counterparts from the People's Republic of China this week as they dance together at Edgemont High School in Scarsdale. It is part of an international cultural exchange arranged by the National Dance Institute, a nonprofit organization devoted to introducing children to the arts by offering dance classes at public schools within the regular school day.

title: Poll on Families: Small Is Best
description: An increasing majority of Americans prefer small families to large ones, according to a new Gallup Poll.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE DECLINE OF POWER 1915-1964. By Robert Blake (Oxford University, $19.95.) Robert Blake, the author of a biography of Disraeli, has written a thoroughly readable political history in this volume in the Paladin series on the history of England.

title: BRIDAL PLANS FOR MISS FELL
description: Mrs. Robert L. Stott Jr., of New York and Southhold, L.I., and John R. Fell Jr. of Locust Valley, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathleen Howell Fell, to Thomas Charles Connor, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Robert Connor 3d of Essex, Conn., formerly of Old Greenwich, Conn. An October wedding is planned.

title: HAS THE NEED FOR SEPARATION BEEN OUTGROWN?
description: HAS American craft outgrown the need for support by institutions that keep it separate from both the present art mainstream and its own history?

title: 11 TO BE WHITE HOUSE FELLOWS FOR 1986-87, REAGAN DECIDES
description: President Reagan has announced the selection of 11 people as 1986-87 White House Fellows.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
DAY AT THE RACES
description: THEY look a little like students, hunched over some exam. The papers are spread out in front of them, in neat rows; their writing utensils are poised. One half expects to hear a voice instructing: Sharpen your No. 2 pencils.

title: ON AN ASIAN ROAD LINKING WORLDS AND AGES
description: To stand at the pinnacle of this pass is to wonder at the accomplishments of man.

title: UNIVERSITY AND 4 HOSPITALS INCORPORATE
description: THE state-supported University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey and its four main teaching hospitals have formed a nonprofit corporation to market a range of health-care services, including the kind of highly sophisticated medical care that many New Jerseyans now seek at academic health centers in New York or Philadelphia.

title: Verbatim; Smokers and City Hall
description: Mayor Koch has proposed what he calls the country's most stringent antismoking law to date. It would ban smoking in city stores, taxicabs, public-hearing rooms, restrooms, waiting lounges and semiprivate hospital rooms; require restaurants, sports arenas, convention halls and employers to set aside nonsmoking sections, and impose civil penalties for violators.

title: ITALY EXPECTED TO IMPLICATE SEVERAL FROM MIDEAST IN THE AIRPORT RAID
description: Italian judicial and Government officials said today that magistrates investigating the killings at the Rome airport in December are expected to announce this week that several Lebanese, Palestinians and Syrians were involved in the attack.

title: 62 POLLING PLACES ARE TERMED ILLEGAL
description: THE recent decision by the Harrison Town Board to move two Election District polling places away from the State University campus in Purchase has unleashed a chain of events that could make voting more difficult for thousands of Westchester voters.

title: The Rajiv Generation
description: My husband and I returned to India for a visit last December, and I would like to offer a few personal glimpses of the changes that Rajiv Gandhi has invoked (''The Rajiv Generation,'' by Steven R. Weisman, April 20). In my parents' generation, the most dependable (and respectable) career opportunities for young middle-class men were government service (both civil and military), medicine and engineering.

title: Jennifer S. Luce Is Married in Rye
description: The wedding of Jennifer Susan Luce, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dudley Gordon Luce Jr. of Rye, N.Y., to William Wilson Taylor, a son of the Rev. and Mrs. Walter Hamilton Taylor of Darien, Conn., took place yesterday. The Rev. Dr. Joseph P. Bishop performed the ceremony at the Rye Presbyterian Church, assisted by the Rev. Kevin Bean, an Episcopal priest.

title: CREATURE COMFORT TILL THE COWS COME HOME
description: WHEN I first came to Westport in the 50's, it was referred to as ''going to the country.'' I rented a primitive little cabin for $300 for the summer, and as far as I was concerned, confined as I had been for most of my young life to the unforgiving streets of St. Louis and New York, Westport was indeed ''country.''

title:
MUSIC;
SYMPHONY IN NEW ROLE
description: FOR THE first time, Unity Concerts and the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra will be partners in a contemporary music venture, ''Soundings '86.''

title: ALLISON HALL AFFIANCED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harry R. Hall of Yonkers have announced the engagement of their daughter Alison Joan Hall to Lawrence David Goldman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Warren Goldman of River Vale, N.J. The wedding is planned for June 28. Miss Hall, a graduate of Alfred University with a master's degree in special education from Boston University, is a special education teacher at Monticello (N.Y.) High School. Mr. Goldman, who attends Ramapo College, is the printing services manager for Royal Oxford Stationers in Fairfield, N.J.

title: IS GOLD HEADED FOR A FALL?
description: The gold market may be about to lose some of its luster. According to two investment advisers, the price of the precious metal, which began the year around $330 an ounce and rose as high as $357 in March, is looking vulnerable. Last week on New York's Comex, futures contracts for current delivery were trading around $340 an ounce.

title: A Battle Over Lethal Chemicals
description: The Reagan Administration wants to resume the production of chemical weapons, halted in 1969, as part of the NATO defense system for Western Europe. The weapons are needed, the Administration says, as a deterrent against similar Soviet stocks and Russian soldiers equipped to use them.

title: A Stay-At-Home Economy
description: This weekend signals the start of the summer holiday season, and - with more tourists expected to vacation on American shores - it may also herald an improved economy by Labor Day.

title: Nell Willis Engaged to A. C. Twining
description: Dr. and Mrs. Hugh Hiter Willis Jr., of Chatham, Va., have announced the engagement of his daughter, Nell Morris Willis, to Alexander Catlin Twining, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kinsley Twining of Old Lyme, Conn. A July wedding is planned.

title: Q. & A. With Realty Board Chief
description: Steven Spinola, president of the city's Public Development Corporation for the past three years, was recently named president of the Real Estate Board of New York - the trade group that represents major developers and property owners in Manhattan. He assumes that position June 1.

title: Syria Is Playing a Dangerous Game
description: There has been much talk in the last few weeks about the possibility of another Middle East war, between Israel and Syria. As an Israeli citizen and longtime observer of the military situation in the Middle East, I have no doubt that Israel would go to war immediately if that were necessary - in response to a major terrorist attack or other provocation - but I myself do not believe that Israel would initiate a confrontation or that it is planning a war.

title: Stop Religious Persecutions of Voodoo in Haiti; An Inspiration to Art
description: To the Editor:

title: APOLOGIES TO THE PRIMATES
description: SILENT PARTNERS The Legacy of the Ape Language Experiments. By Eugene Linden. 247 pp. New York: Times Books. $17.95. ONLY in the peaceable kingdoms of art and Eden are the relationships of humans and animals innocent and harmonious; here and now they are complex, uneasy, often cruel and always profound. City dwellers, seeing only people plus an occasional Peke or pigeon, can pretend that nothing on earth matters but us; but if we want to eat or breathe, our dependence on nonhuman life is absolute and immediate, although mostly unexamined. When we use animals, as work partners, for food, or in laboratories, the ethics of the relationship become both urgent and obscure. In the matter of the use of animals in laboratory experiment, some extremists confuse use with misuse and demand a total ban, while others justify means by ends and demand that atrocities be condoned. The subject is what might be called a hairy one - and in ''Silent Partners'' Eugene Linden has picked a particularly tangled but fascinating aspect of it to explore in his third book about the apes used in language experiments. His earlier books are ''Apes, Men and Language'' and ''The Education of Koko.''

title: CORPORATE WOMEN MEASURE SUCCESSES
description: THE signs on the tall, metal stands in the center of each of the round tables at the Sheraton Hotel's ballroom in Stamford last Thursday evening read like a compendium of America's foremost corporations - I.B.M., G.T.E., A.T.& T., Champion International, Shearson Lehman Brothers.

title: TROOPERS BATTLE HIGHWAY SPEEDERS
description: Circling high above Interstate 91 in a state police airplane, Trooper Joe Davis adjusted his sunglasses as a red van headed south in the left lane. ''That's a good candidate,'' he said.

title: JENNIFER KIM RIE MARRIED TO MICHAEL VAN DER LINDEN
description: Jennifer Kim Rie, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Louis Rie of White Plains, and Michael Roderick van der Linden, a son of Mrs. Holbrook Bugbee and Septimus Strathern van der Linden, both of Westport, Conn., were married yesterday in the Church of St. Joseph of Arimathea in Greenburgh, N.Y. The Rev. Donald Cutler performed the Episcopal cermeony.

title: Lotka, 9-1 Shot, Captures Acorn Stakes
description: Woody Stephens did not run a 3-year-old in the Kentucky Derby this year for the first time since 1982, and he probably does not have one good enough to give him a fifth consecutive Belmont Stakes winner on June 7. The bettors at Belmont Park yesterday must have figured that the 71-year-old trainer had hit the skids, and they let his star 3-year-old filly, Lotka, go off at 9 to 1 in the Acorn Stakes.

title: RECITAL: MORDECAI SHEHORI
description: MORDECAI SHEHORI'S piano recital at Merkin Concert Hall on Thursday night demonstrated a technique of crushing power - a power that sometimes served the music at hand, sometimes acted to its detriment.

title: AMERICA IN THE MIND OF ISRAEL
description: FOR ISRAEL'S FOUND-ing fathers, America was supposed to be a benign distant giant, and the Jewish state was supposed to become self-sufficient, independent and so attractive that Jews from all over the world, including the United States, would flock there. Israel was going to be the center of the world, with its own original Hebrew culture, and America, in the mind of Israel, was going to be little more than an afterthought. But now, as a recent hit song in Israel puts it, ''Everyone is dreaming about America.''

title: THE BUSES THAT BIND MEXICO
description: A Tarascan Indian woman, standing alongside a dusty road that meanders through the craggy peaks of Mexico's Sierra Madres, waved down a creaky country bus. She climbed aboard, rested her heavy packages beside the driver, stooped before a yellowed and peeling decal of the Virgin of Guadalupe and crossed herself.

title: CHINA AND TAIWAN ARE AS FAR APART AS EVER
description: JUST as a family feud can bring out the worst in all concerned, so China and Taiwan displayed some of their less admirable characteristics last week as they struggled over the disposition of the Taiwanese jumbo jet diverted to the mainland May 3.

title: ANDREA LEE LOSHIN PLANS TO MARRY MICHAEL COLBY
description: Mrs. Jerome Loshin of White Plains has announced the engagement of her daughter, Andrea Lee Loshin, to Michael Elihu Colby, a son of Mrs. Sidney Colby of New York and the late Mr. Colby. The wedding is planned for July.

title: WHAT'S NEW ON THE EXECUTIVE BOOKSHELF
description: MORE than a few months back, Bantam Books published a book promising to reveal ''What They Don't Teach You at Harvard Business School.''

title: THE SENATE FINANCE PANEL'S TAX BILL, I.R.A.'S AND CAPITAL GAINS
description: To the Editor:

title: LAVISH TASTES FROM THE TANDOOR
description: MOGHUL feasts have been whetting Long Island appetites lately. Akbar, at Roosevelt Field in Garden City, is one of the newer Indian restaurants, open about a month. It is a branch of a restaurant by the same name on Park Avenue in Manhattan.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY
description: Andrew Bush's color photographs of interior domestic spaces are more traditional than much recent photography, but their charms are nonetheless compelling. The rooms he shows us - a kitchen, a hallway, a formal living room - are bathed in a warm, golden glow that invites the eye to linger.

title: Umpire Calls Right Play
description: The situation was right for an ugly incident Friday night at Arlington Stadium, but the home plate umpire, Ken Kaiser, nipped it as the Boston Red Sox nipped the Texas Rangers, 2-1.

title: DANCE: BRAHMS QUARTET
description: LIKE many of George Balanchine's works, ''Brahms-Schoenberg Quartet'' is a plotless ballet reflecting the score to which it is set: in this case, Johannes Brahms's First Piano Quartet in G minor (Op. 25), as orchestrated by Arnold Schoenberg. What helps make it unusual is the fact that although the score's four movements are all implicitly dramatic, they are disparate in mood. If the ballet's four choreographic sequences are therefore akin to acts of a play, each act could come from a different play.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: DEFYING THE ODDS AT INDY
description: THE DOORS REMAIN closed because A. J. Foyt prefers them that way.

title: Malaria Kills 200 in India
description: More than 200 people have died of malaria in three weeks in the northeastern Indian state of Assam, and the epidemic is spreading rapidly. An Assam political leader, Tarun Gogoi, state chief of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's Congress Party, said today that 1,000 new cases were reported Friday near Tamulpur.

title: DEMOCRATS ATTACK REJECTION OF WOMEN'S BOARD NOMINEE
description: LAST week's vote by the County Board of Legislators, in which the Republican majority rejected a nominee for the Women's Advisory Board, has angered women's rights groups and led some Democratic legislators to accuse their colleagues of ''McCarthyism.''

title: IN BASEL, THE HERITAGE OF ERASMUS
description: In the nearly 500 years since Erasmus first went to Basel, Switzerland's second city has been an intellectual beacon, attracting scholars and gathering art treasures with the kind of energy that has also made it a center of business and finance. The city's chemical industry, its port on the Rhine and its celebrated trade fairs are keys to its strength, but in Basel the past and its learning are always present. This spring and summer the city is paying tribute to one of the towering figures of the Renaissance, and to itself. Erasmus of Rotterdam, who is being honored, was a Baseler by adoption.

title: AN IDENTITY CRISIS, IN NAME ONLY
description: ONCE upon a time, I was the only Jessica in the world. Not as far back as when dinosaurs trod the earth, but long enough ago so that my name was unheard of, at least among my peers.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: I WAS in the middle of the Island, driving home from the North Shore on one of those wet, superatmospheric-disturbance nights that play tricks with your car radio. North of Mineola I had a jazz program going, and it was great: Duke Ellington himself, without the band, was playing piano solos.

title: JAZZ: DOROTHY DONEGAN
description: DOROTHY DONEGAN reaches New York so infrequently that each time she arrives she creates a sense of surprise. Over the years she has left such a firm image of flamboyance - virtuosic flamboyance, to be sure - that one tends to forget the subtlety and sensitivity that are also part of her virtuosity.

title: WHAT'S THE POINT AND PENALTY OF TENNIS SUSPENSION?
description: JIMMY CONNORS has been on a winning streak of sorts. In recent weeks, Connors has beaten Kevin Curren, Stefan Edberg, Mats Wilander, Aaron Krickstein and Bjorn Borg (three straight times). None of these victories at events in Tulsa, Tokyo and New Orleans can rival the French Open, which starts tomorrow in Paris, or Wimbledon next month. And Connors's activity is almost certain to further confuse many sports followers: After all, he is currently serving a 70-day suspension for outrageous behavior in a Grand Prix tournament in February in Florida.

title: INDICTMENT OF F.B.I. AGENT RAISES QUESTIONS
description: One morning last August, Robert Friedrick, an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, met with Justice Department officials to answer questions about the bureau's relationship with Jackie Presser, the teamsters' president.

title: Another Devotee Of Jogging Joys
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: BUILDING A BUSINESS AND A THICK SKIN
description: The Start-Up Entrepreneur, by James R. Cook. Truman Talley Books/E.P. Dutton, New York. 306 pages, $18.95. WRITTEN to inspire readers to build their own companies, this book is put together in true how-to fashion. Chapter headings include ''Three Keys to a Successful Start-Up,'' ''How to Diversify Your Growing Enterprise,'' and ''What to Consider Before You Decide to Step Down.'' Much of the advice is derived from the personal experiences of the author, the founder of Investment Rarities Inc., which started out trading in precious metals and is now a diversified group of Minneapolis companies.

title: Coping With the Crush
description: THE deluge of loan applications that has flooded the desks of mortgage lenders as rates have fallen is slowing approvals for home buyers and making some miss their contract closing deadlines.

title: The Right Wins An Election In Netherlands
description: The ''Lubbers Effect,'' as it is known in Dutch political parlance, prevailed in the parliamentary elections last week in the Netherlands. , Although his defeat in the elections had been predicted in polls, the popularity and power of Prime Minister Ruud Lubbers, proved strong enough to lead his center-right coalition to victory in the 150-seat Parliament.

title: JOBS ABOUND AT HIGHER PAY FOR SUMMER
description: BY ALL accounts this should be a good summer for young people to find a job on Long Island.

title: R. S. FELDMAN TO WED DR. VALERIE VERIDIANO
description: Gen. and Mrs. Juanito Veridiano of Manila have announced the engagement of their daughter Dr. Valerie B. Veridiano to Randy Steven Feldman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Feldman of Peekskill, N.Y. A June 21 wedding is planned.

title:
GARDENING;
FERTILIZER: TOO LITTLE OR TOO MUCH IS BAD
description: CONSUMERS spend large sums of money on fertilizer each year. In some areas, notably Long Island, excessive fertilizer application is threatening the water supply by contaminating it with nitrogen. Is it necessary to fertilize lawns and gardens, and, if so, how does one go about it in a reasonable way?

title: LOVE, LIFE AND DEATH IN BALLET
description: The last 40 years have accustomed us to the idea that theater dancing is about dancing. Is something different now creeping into the kind of choreography increasingly on view? There are two tendencies to consider. One attempts to tackle the Big Questions - love, life and death. The second would appear the opposite - to treat intensely personal events. Very often, they are one and the same.

title: JAYNE JAMISON PLANS TO WED JAN BROWNE
description: A fall wedding is planned by Jayne Ellen Jamison and Jan Philip Browne, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Sydney Jamison of Glendale, Pa., have announced. Mr. Browne is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry W. Browne of Forest Hills, Queens.

title: DEBORAH SURNAMER TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Martin M. Surnamer of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Deborah Jane Surnamer to Richard Goldhair, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Goldhair of White Plains. An August wedding is planned. Miss Surnamer, a graduate of Goucher College and Lesley College, where she received a master's degree, is a financial supervisor at Ogilvy & Mather Promotions in New York. Mr. Goldhair, a graduate of the University of Cincinnati, is president of Milton Goldhair Associates Inc., an office products and printing concern in Manhattan that was founded by his father.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: MIRROR OF LANGUAGE: The Debate on Bilingualism. By Kenji Hakuta. (Basic Books, $18.95.) At a time when the proponents of bilingual education in America find their programs under attack it is useful to consider Kenji Hakuta's ''Mirror Of Language.'' Mr. Hakuta, who teaches psychology at Yale University, debunks the myths suggesting that bilingual children suffer from cognitive deficits and he presents evidence suggesting that educating children, at least initially, in their native language can be beneficial.

title: Questions Raised On Horse Drugs
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
FERTILIZER: TOO LITTLE OR TOO MUCH IS BAD
description: CONSUMERS spend large sums of money on fertilizer each year. In some areas, notably Long Island, excessive fertilizer application is threatening the water supply by contaminating it with nitrogen. Is it necessary to fertilize lawns and gardens, and, if so, how does one go about it in a reasonable way?

title: JENNIFER T. JACKSON IS WED TO DWIGHT RANDELL DAVIES
description: The wedding of Jennifer Tillson Jackson to Dwight Randell Davies took place yesterday in the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Bryn Mawr, Pa. The Rev. Timothy Pickering performed the ceremony.

title: 'Sleaze' and Strategy
description: Encouraged by the extensive news coverage being given to allegations of influence-peddling by former Reagan aides, the Democrats will try again in elections this year to revive the ''sleaze factor,'' this time tying it to the issue of trade deficits.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:We are interested in a rail cruise within the United States. Would you furnish the names of companies who sponsor such trips? -J. G. O'T., Pittsburgh Answer:A major organizer of rail tours, one with about 20 years' experience, is Four Winds Travel (175 Fifth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10010; 212-505-0901 or 800-248-4444). Its Americana Rail Cruises consist of seven itineraries, four in the United States and three combining the United States and Canada.

title: If Mr. Waldheim Were Cross-Examined
description: There's a middle ground approach to the Kurt Waldheim affair that promises to break the logjam over whether the former Secretary General of the United Nations was or was not a war criminal.

title: COUNTERACTING THE 'PREMIERE SYNDROME'
description: Most orchestras and performers shy away from contemporary music but are reluctantly willing to play an occasional premiere for prestige or a place in the history book. Then, too often, the piece, no matter its worth, sits on the shelf forever, without a second hearing. This has come to be known as the ''premiere syndrome,'' and it has become so prevalent that the composer Ralph Shapey once proposed a Society for Second Musical Performances. Now the A.T.& T. Foundation has chosen the Philadelphia Orchestra and the Los Angeles Philharmonic to help fight the ''premiere syndrome.'' A new program, entitled ''A.T.& T. American Encore,'' will underwrite performances of 20th-century works that have been given their premiere and are deserving of repeated, wider exposure.

title: LIFE REARRANGES ITSELF, THEN KILLS YOU
description: THE CONGRESSMAN'S DAUGHTER By Craig Nova. 301 pp. New York: Seymour Lawrence/ Delacorte Press. $16.95.

title: CATHERINE CONNOR IS WED TO MICHAEL D. TIMMENY
description: Catherine Connor, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Connor of Annandale, Va., was married yesterday to Michael D. Timmeny, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Timmeny of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y. The Rev. Paul Murray performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Washington.

title:
DINING OUT;
PROMISE REVIEWED IN CROTON FALLS
description: IT is always a pleasure to return to a restaurant obviously full of potential to find that it has begun to fulfill, or, in the case of Mona Trattoria, refulfill its promise. In our review more than a year ago, we lamented that the food no longer reflected the careful preparation that was once the hallmark of this kitchen. To judge from four recent visits, however, we find that while dishes still fall short of consistent superiority, the kitchen seems to have made something of a comeback; quite a few items deserve superlative praise.

title: OXNARD, CALIF.: A BUMPER CROP OF DEVELOPMENT
description: FOR decades, this coastal town of 127,000 residents midway between Los Angeles and Santa Barbara billed itself as the ''Lima Bean Capital of the World.'' One of several farming communities that comprised a mid-sized agricultural region, Oxnard was known to coast highway travelers as a good place to stop for fresh produce.

title: Celtics Benefit From Rest
description: After seven days of rest and relaxation (and a little practice), the Boston Celtics resume their quest for a 16th National Basketball Association title when they oppose the Houston Rockets tomorrow afternoon at Boston Garden in the opener of the four-of-seven-game championship series. After completing a sweep of the Milwaukee Bucks last Sunday, Coach K. C. Jones gave his players Monday and Tuesday off before two days of light conditioning.

title: 21 COUNTIES IN TEEN ARTS FETE
description: FOR the first time, the annual State Teen Arts Festival of the New Jersey State Teen-arts Program will include the works and performances of young writers, musicians, film makers, actors and artists from cultural and heritage commissions in all 21 counties.

title: SUTTON'S 66 FOR 203 LEADS BY 3 STROKES
description: Hal Sutton eagled the par-5, 15th hole with a 25-foot putt today and followed with birdies at the 16th and 17th. The strong finish enabled the 28-year-old Louisiana pro to score 6-under-par 66 for a 54-hole total of 203 and a three-shot lead in the 11th Memorial Tournament at Muirfield Village Golf Club.

title: SYDNEY
description: It's easy to be seduced by Sydney's center. Unlike some other places, it looks just as good in reality as it does on postcards. But the high glass towers and wide streets on the edge of the deep-blue harbor, the girdered arc of the Harbour Bridge and the spinnaker-like roofs of the Opera House are only a small portion of metropolitan Sydney. Outside the shopping malls and office blocks, the State Parliament and other government buildings, much of the city's life goes on elsewhere. Sydney, like New York, is a vast patchwork of separate neighborhoods whose boundaries are defined by subtle shifts of prosperity, ethnic origins or topography. Paddington Despite the intrusion of glass-fronted shops and determinedly modern house renovations, Paddington's narrow streets and rows of Victorian terraced houses decorated with elaborately worked, wrought-iron railings have managed to retain their traditionally Bohemian and village-like ambiance.

title: THE WOMAN WHO LOVED MEMORY
description: OCEAN OF STORY The Uncollected Stories of Christina Stead. Edited, and with an afterword, by R. G. Geering. 552 pp. New York: Viking. $19.95.

title: NEW YORK CITY OFFICIALS CITE 52 FOOD OUTLETS FOR VIOLATIONS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 52 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: OVERNIGHT RIVER RACE - There may still be time to enter the 14th annual Sunfish Connecticut River Classic Race-Cruise beginning at 8:30 A.M. Saturday in Riverside Park in Hartford, and ending mid-afternoon June 1 at the Pettitaug Yacht Club in Essex. Only 100 of the sailboats are permitted, and the entry fee is $75.

title: Living a 'Dream' On the Run
description: FOR 40 years, a German soldier who escaped from a prisoner-of-war camp in New Mexico during World War II lived, as he put it, ''my own version of the American dream.'' He assumed a new name, married and became upwardly mobile as a ski instructor, tennis pro and contractor.

title: Ending a Bias Against Families
description: About half of all rental housing in the nation has some kind of restrictions against children; about a quarter of it forbids them entirely. An official of New York City's Human Rights Commission estimated that similar proportions applied in the five boroughs, but perhaps not for long.

title: The Senate Finance Panel's Tax Bill, I.R.A.'s and Capital Gains
description: To the Editor:

title: DRUGS IN THE WORK PLACE: EFFORTS GROW TO STEM ABUSE
description: WHEN Guy was 19 he was apprenticed to the Westchester Carpenters Union and started using heroin. ''Only at night and weekends,'' he said, ''I never used it on the job.'' But gradually he began using both heroin and cocaine on the job and the quality of his work declined ''100 percent.'' But, he said. ''I thought I was doing great work. Cocaine gives you a feeling of superconfidence.'' He added:

title: A MARTYR TO MODERATION
description: THE VANISHED IMAM Musa al Sadr and the Shia of Lebanon. By Fouad Ajami. 228 pp. Ithaca, N.Y.: Cornell University Press. $17.95.

title: SOUTH AFRICA STRIKES OUT ACROSS THE BORDER
description: LIKENING it to the Reagan Administration's bombing of Libya, President P. W. Botha defended South Africa's attack on three black-ruled capitals last week as ''legal'' reprisals against the African National Congress. But the White House wasn't buying it.

title: REPORTS REFLECT VARYING ASSETS OF CONGRESSMEN
description: Some members of Congress from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut give lots of speeches, others travel a lot and some have received gifts ranging from golf equipment to a loan of Adolfo dresses, according to annual financial disclosure reports released by the House of Representatives last week.

title: MANILA LABORS TO PAY FOR UNUSED ATOM PLANT
description: Standing almost deserted by the side of the glittering South China Sea is the only nuclear power plant in the Philippines, an unwanted giant that may never go into operation, but which has placed the new Government in one of its most irksome quandaries.

title: MARYLAND THEATER FESTIVAL, FINLAND IN A DAY
description: THE TROUPES DESCEND UPON BALTIMORE - When mid-June comes to Baltimore, 20 theater companies and individual performers representing 13 countries will display their talent in the first United States presentation of the biennial Theater of Nations.

title: POP: YOKO ONO IN CONCERT
description: ''WE'RE on the threshold of the dawning of the age of wisdom - we're going to make it!'' announced Yoko Ono at her Beacon Theater concert on Thursday evening. The event, which kicked off the East Coast leg of her international ''Starpeace'' tour, was an unabashedly sentimental affair in which Miss Ono alternately sang -backed by a strong six-member rock band - and reminisced and philosophized in childlike utopian slogans.

title: Sculpture Goes Public
description: In ''Sculpture Goes Public'' (April 27), Douglas C. McGill describes the rationale for what is, in fact, the contribution of modern three-dimensional design to contemporary architecture.

title: WHITNEY HOUSTON - POP'S NEW QUEEN
description: In the last three months, Whitney Houston, the 22-year-old singer from Newark, has grown from pop music's new kid on the block into a phenomenon for the history books. The facts speak for themselves. Miss Houston's debut album has logged more than 60 weeks on Billboard's Pop Album chart, with nine of those weeks spent at No. 1. The album has sold more than 5.2 million copies, including 900,000 in April alone. It has also yielded four top-10 singles, three of which have reached No. 1 on Billboard's pop singles chart.

title:
DINING OUT;
WALDWICK: IT'S ALL IN THE FAMILY
description: ANDREA'S is that rare kind of cozy neighborhood ristorante with food so good that one is tempted to move into the neighborhood. Tucked into a row of shops in the Bergen County community of Waldwick, it was opened just over a year ago by the Sicilian-born Mansueto family.

title: At Last, Victory Over Vermin?
description: Among New Yorkers - for whom cockroach cohabitation is an all-too-common denominator - the news is being spread in tones of awe and disbelief. Maybe it is possible, after all these years and all those approaches, to get rid of roaches.

title: DIANA L. SCHMERMUND IS MARRIED IN FAIRFIELD
description: Diana Lynne Schmermund, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gary L. Schmermund of Fairfield, Conn., and Huntington, L.I., and Mark David Shoemaker, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Wayne Shoemaker of Columbus, Ohio, were married yesterday at the Greenfield Hill Congregational Church in Fairfield. The Rev. Gary Ritts officiated.

title: 24TH SEASON IN THE SUN FOR BROOKLYN LIFEGUARD
description: Beach season officially opened yesterday along the 2.4 miles of sand that stretch across the foot of Brooklyn, from Coney Island to Brighton Beach. There was sun (hazy), surf (gentle) and Billy Weintraub (resplendent in lifeguard orange).

title: TUNING IN ON CITY STUDENTS WHO DROP OUT
description: A COUPLE of days a month, a 16-year-old student at Bushwick High School in Brooklyn would turn up for classes. He then would disappear, and no one at the school knew why. In fact, the boy's stepfather had died of cancer and his mother, irrationally blaming her son for the death, had thrown him out of the house. The student was working full time to support himself.

title: THEATER: NEGRO ENSEMBLE'S 'LOUIE AND OPHELIA'
description: IN dozens of scenes that take place over a period of about one year but seem to last an eternity, Gus Edwards tells the pathetic story of ''Louie and Ophelia,'' a mismatched couple that never realize how different one is from the other. Perhaps if the author had removed every other scene, one might have had more patience with the characters.

title: MEMORY OF VIETNAM: A LESSON
description: NOT long ago my wife and I took a trip to Washington with our 9-year-old son. As luck would have it, we lost our way for a time after entering the District and ended up driving through what seemed a maze of residential streets before suddenly coming upon the Capitol, its columns and dome resplendent in the midafternoon sunshine.

title: IDEAS FOR THOSE NOT-SO-LAZY DAYS OF SUMMER
description: WITH the start of school vacations just around the corner, parents and children are turning their attention to how the young people will spend the approaching summer days.

title: A Car Condominium
description: Finding a parking space in New York's popular neighborhoods can be an agony. It involves tedious circling through the streets in search of a piece of empty curb that is large enough to snuggle up to and that also is bare of signs forbidding occupancy. And then, when the search is successful, the driver often finds that the space is covered by alternate-side parking regulations and it has to be surrendered by 8 o'clock the next morning.

title: ANTHONY COLAVITA'S SKILLS FACE TEST ON LARGER STAGE
description: WHEN New York State Republicans gather in Syracuse this week for their quadrennial convention to select statewide candidates, rank-and-file members will get their first chance to see close up what Anthony J. Colavita has been up to for eight months.

title: WANDERING KINGS
description: To maintain unequivocally that ''the king is a fighting piece,'' as Wilhelm Steinitz did, is just plain silly.

title: Racing Restrictions
description: Jean-Marie Balestre, the president of the International Auto Sports Federation (FISA), has announced that the organization would order major cuts in engine power following the death last week of Italian driver Elio de Angelis during practice for a Grand Prix race.

title: CARAMOOR: A CENTER OF ONGOING ACTIVITY
description: THE opening of the Caramoor Festival, the jewel of Westchester's summer music making, is more than a month away, but another concert series has just concluded at the estate in Katonah, and on Saturday, Caramoor plays host to 300 county students of music and art.

title: SHERRI TRIGOBOFF WEDS
description: Sherri Paige Trigoboff, a registered nurse at Community General Hospital in Syracuse, N.Y., and James Nellis Arkerson, a civil engineer for Niagara Mohawk Power of Syracuse, were married last night at the Hampshire House in New York by the Rev. Dr. Melvin A. Hawthorne, a Baptist minister, and Cantor Robert Bloch. Mrs. Arkerson, a graduate of Russell Sage College, is the daughter of Martin Trigoboff of New York and Myrna E. Trigoboff of Deerfield Beach, Fla. Mr. Arkerson, a graduate of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, is the son of Mr. and Mrs. James Arkerson of Syracuse.

title: OPERA: U.S. SPOLETO FESTIVAL OPENS
description: This gentle, antiquated coastal city is throwing its annual party. On Friday, the Spoleto Festival USA opened its 10th season here, and talk of opera, dance, mime, and theater has supplanted the traditional subjects of gardens, squalls, Civil War and she-crab soup. This year, the festivities have an additional impetus; 1986 is the year that Gian Carlo Menotti - the composer, director, librettist, Spoleto founder and resident guru - turns 75.

title: RODINO IN A FIGHT FOR RENOMINATION
description: Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr. did not miss a beat Thursday when a report of a fire in the Federal office building that bears his name forced him to leave his 14th-floor office and begin walking downstairs.

title: Eduardo Gonzalez Gallarza; Was Air Minister for Franco
description: Lieut. Gen. Eduardo Gonzalez Gallarza, an early aviator who was Air Minister in the Franco regime, died today of an intestinal hemorrhage, his family said.

title: U.S. Defends Support For 10 Exits on 747's
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has denied that politics and public pressure rather than safety factors caused the agency's head to oppose the removal of two emergency exits from Boeing 747 jetliners.

title: Higher Rate Applies Only to Part of Income
description: To the Editor:

title: ROCKETS IN SYRIA STIRRING NEW FEAR
description: Military analysts are increasingly worried about the introduction of highly accurate tactical missiles into Syria, calling them a new factor that could push either side into war at a time of high tension between Syria and Israel.

title: THE MOVIE RATINGS: IT'S TIME FOR A FADE-OUT
description: ONE OF the most frustrating incidents I've ever been involved in was when a group of friends and I tried to get into the film ''St. Elmo's Fire,'' supposedly a ''teen'' movie but, unfortunately, rated R. We did our best to look old and self-assured as we tried to breeze past the ticket seller, but he gave us a suspicious look and asked for I.D.'s.

title: LAURA J. SHAPIRO IS WED IN BOSTON
description: Laura Jean Shapiro, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eli Shapiro of Boston and Truro, Mass., was married yesterday to Neal B. Dowling Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dowling of Phoenix. Justice of the Peace Milton Wolk performed the ceremony at the Boston home of the bride's parents.

title: Brighter Evenings in the Offing
description: TENNIS players, backyard barbecuers and the Chicago Cubs won a victory last week when the Senate approved a bill to begin daylight time three weeks earlier. The House has passed a similar bill, making it likely that we will be moving clocks forward an hour on the first rather than the last Sunday in April.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: O'CLOCK. By Quim Monzo. Translated by Mary Ann Newman. (Available Press/Ballantine, Paper, $4.95.) Oppressive boredom and a terror lurking at the heart of everyday routine grip the perverse, disaffected characters in these tales by the gifted young Catalan writer Quim Monzo.

title: SOLID GROWTH MAY MASK WEAKNESSES
description: The economy grew at a 3.7 percent annual rate in the first quarter, a figure interpreted variously as weak and strong. Some economists said the trade deficit will start to improve as the weaker dollar encourages purchases of American products abroad, but others noted that the benefit of cheaper oil is masking underlying weaknesses in manufacturing. Indeed, durable goods orders fell eight-tenths of 1 percent in April, although most analysts see an improvement soon. Inflation stayed away: consumer prices fell three-tenths of 1 percent in April, the third drop in a row. But most economists expect an increase in consumer prices as oil climbs back up. (Oil futures traded above $17 a barrel last week for the first time in three months.) Personal income and spending increased in April, although little of the money went for big-ticket items.

title: AGNES VARDA: SHE AIMS TO UNSETTLE
description: ''Can helping someone do any good?'' the French film maker Agnes Varda asked with intensity. She was posing one of the many questions that led her to make ''Vagabond,'' winner of the top prize at the 1985 Venice Film Festival. ''I wanted to create a stimulating or bracing discomfort whereby the spectator shapes a portrait from fragments, and realizes the film has no answer.''

title: CITY AGENCY URGING STUDY OF SELLING SOME WATERFRONT PARKS
description: The city's Public Development Corporation will ask the city to study the possible sale of as many as 25 ''sparsely used'' tracts of waterfront parkland to builders, the agency's outgoing president said Friday.

title: CALCULATING RISK IS A RISKIER BUSINESS NOW
description: TO hear the liability insurance industry tell it, a civil court system gone wild is pushing underwriters deeper into the red and some clients out into the cold, uninsurable against the potential financial penalties of damage suits. Gentler skeptics say the industry brought its grief on itself by overpricing and bad management. Rougher doubters argue that the insurance companies are simply trying to protect hidden profits made investing premiums at the high interest rates of the late 1970's and early 1980's.

title: CECILY KAHN WED TO A FELLOW ARTIST
description: Cecily Kahn, a daughter of Emily Mason and Wolf Kahn of New York and West Brattleboro, Vt., was married yesterday to David Kapp, the son of of Mr. and Mrs. Ira B. Kapp of New York. Algernon D. Black, leader emeritus of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, performed the ceremony at the New York home of the bride's parents.

title: 'THE WINNER IS...'
description: MY daughter tore open the envelope, Academy Award-style, and screamed, ''I made it!''

title: NEW CASSETTES: BY DE SICA, SUTHERLAND AND THE ROYAL BALLET
description: La Fille Mal Gardee The Royal Ballet, featuring Lesley Collier, Michael Coleman, Brian Shaw, Leslie Edwards, Garry Grant; choreography by Sir Frederick Ashton Thorn EMI/HBO Video 98 minutes. $39.95 Sir Frederick Ashton's choreographic version of a ballet first produced in 1789 is one of the treasures of the Royal Ballet's repertory.

title: Popping Plugs and Patience
description: WHEN we arrived at Wasque Point, nearly all of the three dozen anglers already there were leaning against their four-wheel-drive vehicles, waiting.

title: SHALIT'S SAVE-THE-GAME PLAN
description: CHARLES O. FINLEY, the man who brought softball suits to major league baseball, has revealed to The Times his seven suggestions for improving baseball. Among them:

title: FEEDING BODY AND SOUL ON A GALLERY EXCURSION
description: Basel has been a distinguished center of art since the Reformation, when the city was a place of refuge for Protestants from all over Europe fleeing persecution. Painters and writers, philosophers and theologians went there to live and took with them taste, culture and a love of art. They created a climate that continues to this day, fostered by the many private collectors and by the sponsorship of bankers and leaders of industry, but not by these alone.

title: THE CONSTITUTION IN DANGER
description: CITIZENS of New Jersey, of whatever political philosophy, ought to be concerned over efforts in our Legislature to petition Congress to call for a constitutional convention.

title: THE CARE AND FEEDING OF A PC
description: ONE of the more expected, but nonetheless startling, developments in personal computing has been the evolution of these sophisticated machines into commodity items. Although the personal computer is far more complicated than a toaster, the purchase and maintenance of the two devices have to a certain extent come to parallel one another.

title: SOCIAL TIES OF ELDERLY STUDIED
description: Nine out of 10 elderly people who live by themselves manage to maintain social contacts that can help them to a longer life, a Government study indicates.

title: The Senate Finance Panel's Tax Bill, I.R.A.'s and Capital Gains
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS IN COLLISION: THE CONTINUING CASE OF SACCO AND VANZETTI
description: THE case of Sacco and Vanzetti has been solved. Again. Twice.

title: NEW CASSETTES: BY DE SICA, SUTHERLAND AND THE ROYAL BALLET
description: Hooters: Nervous Night CBS/Fox Video 42 minutes. $19.98 The five-member Philadelphia band that backed Cyndi Lauper on her debut album ''She's So Unusual'' plays streamlined meat-and-potatoes rock-and-roll seasoned with the Melodica (a hybrid keyboard harmonica) and mandolin.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: COMMERCE and art, especially home-grown art, belong together, says Martin Sukenick of Little Falls.

title: THE WORLD IS WATCHING
description: THIS was at the Ritz Hotel in Barcelona in June 1982. The cocktail lounge was dark except for a huge television screen at the far end.

title: SPACE DEFENSE AND THE RETALIATION FACTOR
description: STAR WARS Suicide or Survival? By Alun Chalfont. Illustrated. 169 pp. Boston: Little, Brown. $16.95. BEFORE he received his title, Lord Chalfont was a professional army officer and then defense correspondent of The Times of London, under the name of A. Gwynne Jones. He certainly has the background for his purpose in writing ''Star Wars,'' which he says is not ''to make judgements about the science and technology of the Strategic Defence Initiative [ but ] to place 'Star Wars' in the broader context of the strategic framework within which it was conceived.'' That he summarizes as trying to give ''future world leaders a calculus of international relations which does not depend upon the threat of nuclear annihilation.'' But his book is not the sober, objective analysis that the description of his aim suggests. Rather, it is an argument in favor of President Reagan's program and against its critics, cooler and less florid than much of the Administration's rhetoric on behalf of ''Star Wars'' but nonetheless a brief for the idea.

title: INSURER CHARGED WITH BIAS AGAINST HOMOSEXUALS
description: Homosexual men here say that some health insurers are discriminating against them in issuing insurance and evaluating claims because of the prevalence of AIDS among homosexuals.

title: Texas Thunderstorms Result in 4 Deaths
description: Violent, fast-moving thunderstorms with winds up to 75 miles an hour dumped nearly 4 inches of rain today, caving in part of the roof of a crowded bowling alley.

title: AIDS OUTBREAK GROWING ON L.I.
description: CHRIS PRIESTLY and Mary Smith have come home to Long Island - not to live where they were born and raised, but to die.

title: A PARIS TABLE IN CLASSIC STYLE
description: Next best to traveling on a great ocean liner might be boarding the two-century-old restaurant in Paris known as Ledoyen. If Ledoyen is about nostalgia and leisure, privacy and ceremony, it is also about old-fashioned cooking and, possibly, respite from the peapod proclivities of the no-longer-so nouvelle cuisine.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: THE state's Department of Environmental Protection, maintaining that the microbial insecticide it has been using for the last two years is not effective enough, is testing a new chemical insecticide against the gypsy moth this spring. But some environmentalists contend that the new chemical's safety is still unproven.

title: SOLOMONS AIDE SEES TYPHOON RECOVERY TAKING OVER 5 YEARS
description: A Government official was quoted as saying today that it would take years for the Solomon Islands to recover from devastation wreaked by Typhoon Namu. The storm left a third of the population homeless and wiped out most of the archipelago's crops.

title: Elizabeth Irwin Becomes a Bride
description: The Community Unitarian Church in White Plains was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Elizabeth Barrett Irwin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. Irwin of Chappaqua, N.Y., to James Farber Friedlander, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Friedlander of New York and East Hampton, L.I.. The Rev. Shannon Bernard performed the ceremony.

title: SCHLEMMER'S NONCOMMITTAL MUSE CAME TO LIFE ON STAGE
description: Among the thousands of intelligent lay observers who throng the Museum of Modern Art, year in and year out, not one in a hundred has a firm hold on the achievement of the German painter, sculptor, draftsman, teacher and dance-deviser Oskar Schlemmer (1888-1943). The retrospective exhibition of more than 100 of his works that can be seen through July 5 at the I.B.M. Gallery on Madison Avenue at 56th Street may not, therefore, have the immediate pulling power of Manet or Monet or van Gogh.

title: Blockbuster Quiz Amplified
description: To the Editor:

title: JULIE KAY BALL IS MARRIED TO JOHN GLASS, A TEACHER
description: Julie Kay Ball, a public relations executive, and John Edward Glass, a teacher, were married yesterday at the Church of the Angels in Pasadena, Calif. The Rev. Robert J. Gaestel officiated at the Episcopal ceremony.

title: LANGUAGE - LYING AND TREACHEROUS
description: DEATH SENTENCE By Maurice Blanchot. Translated by Lydia Davis. 81 pp. Barrytown, N.Y.: Station Hill. Cloth, $10. Paper, $5.95.

title: Vatican Envoy Is Coming Home
description: William A. Wilson is an old California friend and adviser of Ronald Reagan, who appointed him Presidential envoy and, later, United States Ambassador to the Vatican. Mr. Wilson resigned from that post last week, however, amid concern, Administration officials said, about unauthorized dealings he had had with Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader.

title: Lesley Williams Douglass Wed to Jules A. Webster
description: Lesley Williams Douglass, a deputy commissioner and the counsel to the New York State Department of Commerce in Albany, and Jules Antwon Webster, an engineer for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, were married yesterday at St. Peters Lutheran Church in New York. The Rev. John Gensel officiated.

title: SOVIET SPY TRIAL HEARS EVIDENCE OF BIG CASH DEALS
description: Nine weeks into the espionage and tax fraud trial of Jerry A. Whitworth, prosecutors have begun detailing vast amounts of evidence as to the financial dealings of the defendant in an attempt to prove he received $332,000 in exchange for stolen Navy cryptographic data.

title: Tony Eligibility
description: To the Editor:

title: 2-YEAR DRAMA NEARS THE END: ITALY OPENS AGAINST BULGARIA
description: THE WORLD CUP, soccer's premier event, which stirs most of the world's sporting passions every four years, opens at majestic Azteca Stadium in Mexico City Saturday afternoon. Italy, the defending champion, meets Bulgaria in the first match, and the 24-nation tournament - actually the culmination of a 110-nation extravaganza that began two years ago - will conclude there on June 29, with the crowning of the champion.

title: MENTAL-HEALTH UNIT HONORING MALLACH
description: AS she reflects on her 25 years with the Mental Health Association of Westchester County, executive director Esther D. Mallach concludes that timing and luck have been important factors in the development of the agency and her contributions to it.

title: Rosenbergs' Sons Lose An Appeal
description: A Federal appellate panel has ruled that the Federal Bureau of Investigation and other Government agencies made a good-faith effort in searching their records and supplying documents to Michael and Robert Meeropol, two sons of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, who were executed as spies for the Soviet Union in 1953.

title: Topics; Mirror Images; The Frog's Message
description: Two young Oklahoma women met a frog on the street. ''Kiss me,'' the frog said, ''and I'll turn into an independent oil man.''

title: U.S. GIVES WARNING ON MOSCOW MILK
description: The United States Embassy advised pregnant American women and infants in Moscow today not to drink Soviet milk because of a sharp increase in radioactivity readings in milk distributed in the Soviet capital.

title: RETAIL CHAINS SAY STATE'S STRONG POINTS HELP GROWTH
description: SOPHISTICATED consumers with money to spend, an adept work force and a favorable business climate have combined in Connecticut to nurture three of the most dramatically growing retailers in America.

title:
NATURE WATCH;
PARASOL MUSHROOM
description: Lepiota procera - Size: 6 to 12 inches tall; 2 1/2 to 6 inches wide.

title: SUFFOLK ACTS ON PRIVATE LANDFILLS
description: SUFFOLK COUNTY is moving to crack down on illegal dumping at private landfills because the state lacks the money and manpower to do so, officials say.

title: I WAS A TEEN-AGE INTELLECTUAL
description: THE ADRIAN MOLE DIARIES By Sue Townsend. 342 pp. New York: Grove Press. $14.95.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: CHAGALL, MATISSE - Many of the county's landmark sites of one sort or another are braced for an influx of visitors this holiday weekend. Today, from 2 to 5 P.M. would be a good time to view the Matisse and Chagall stained-glass windows, commissioned as memorials by the Rockefeller family at the Union Church of Pocantico Hills.

title: Blockbuster Quiz Amplified
description: To the Editor:

title: I.R.A.'S REALLY DO SPARK NEW SAVINGS
description: SENATOR Bob Packwood and the Senate Finance Committee have produced a tax bill that would gut many of the tax shelters that waste resources and challenge common conceptions of fairness. In going after real estate interests, raising capital gains taxes and imposing a corporate minimum tax, the Packwood bill does both the hard thing and the right thing.

title: A BOROUGH'S GROWTH, AT BRONX ARTS MUSEUM
description: LESS than a century ago, the Bronx was a sleepy northern suburb of New York City dotted with farms, country estates and small towns. Between 1890 and 1940, however, its population expanded from 90,000 to 1.5 million, a spectacular growth that did not come about in an altogether haphazard way; it sprang from the interplay between planning on a comprehensive scale and the response to an ever-increasing demand for housing in the city.

title: THE FLUTE SELLER OF VARANASI
description: I bought the flute in Varanasi, India, the ''eternal city'' once known as Benares -older than Babylon, Athens or Rome.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: RIVERA IN PHILADELPHIA - With earth tones and bold, flat forms derived from pre-Columbian art, Diego Rivera celebrated the working class of his Mexican homeland, depicting the daily tasks of men and women and allegories of Mexican history.

title: MANY BICYCLISTS ARE GOING AGAINST THE CITY'S GRAIN
description: WHILE muggers and assorted other thieves still pose a danger on the streets of New York City, of course, in recent years a new threat has emerged, speeding along on two wheels. The number of reported accidents involving pedestrians and bicyclists in the city has doubled in the last five years, according to the police, who acknowledge that they have trouble doing much about it.

title: REUNION BUSINESS A BUSY ONE
description: IN the spring, a not-so-young person's fancy often turns to thoughts of the ''glory days'' of high school. And for two former New Yorkers (Jamaica High School, Class of 1965), nostalgia among aging baby boomers has been the wellspring of a burgeoning business.

title: HANNAH ROCKWELL WEDS D. P. BRION
description: Hannah Rockwell, a sales promotion specialist, and David Palmer Brion, a cartoonist and illustrator, were married yesterday at the chapel of St. Saviour's Episcopal Church in Old Greenwich, Conn., by the Rev. Robert J. Miner. Elizabeth Anne Rockwell was maid of honor for her sister.

title: Surgery for Arcaro
description: The former jockey Eddie Arcaro, a legend in horse racing, underwent two open-heart surgical procedures simultaneously and remained in serious condition in intensive care at a Miami hospital yesterday, his doctors said.

title: THEORY VS. PRACTICE
description: The Cavendish Club Invitational Pairs Championship played in Manhattan two weeks ago had an unusual feature. In a two-day event in which it was possible to win 200 international match points or more on a deal, the final margin of victory was 8 points. The gap between second and third was two points. It was like a marathon in which a yard covered the first three runners.

title: The Senate Finance Panel's Tax Bill, I.R.A.'s and Capital Gains
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on May 11 about the A.L. Williams General Agency misstated the agency's administrative costs for each $1,000 of life insurance in force at the end of 1985. The cost is about 38 cents per $1,000, compared with more than $3 at several life insurance companies.

title: RUTH UDELL PLANS AUGUST WEDDING
description: Plans for an August wedding of Ruth Ann Udell to Christopher T.W. Kunstadter have been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Udell of Elkins Park, Pa. Mr. Kunstadter is a son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Kunstadter of New York and London.

title: BLUE JAYS OVERPOWER INDIANS, 9-6
description: George Bell hit a three-run home run to cap a four-run fifth inning today and Lloyd Moseby drove in four runs to lift the Toronto Blue Jays to a 9-6 victory over the Cleveland Indians.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE DEVIL AT HOME. By Oliver Lange. (Stein & Day, $16.95.) Oliver Lange thinks to go Hannah Arendt one better, inflating her observation about the banality of evil into an observation about the universality of evil.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''The aim is to enable the police to remove from the community those involved in the unrest for a sufficient time in order to normalize the situation.''

title: THEATER PRESERVATION
description: To the Editor:

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: All Sorts of Lighting With Distinction - Distinction is the name of a lighting-fixture retail shop in Hartsdale providing imported hand-blown and handcrafted glass and crystal, both traditional and modern, and currently promoting 50 percent reductions storewide on overstock worth $200,000.

title: OPERA AS GODZILLA AND OTHER MATTERS OF NOTE
description: It is that time again, the twinkling instant between spring and summer seasons when the critic's ''Miscellaneous'' folder must be cleaned out to make room for the next wave of clippings, memos-to-himself, unanswered or unanswerable letters, enigmatic jottings and, he must have thought at the time, legitimate ideas for articles. Before the file is pushed overboard, a few items seem, for various reasons, worth perusing.

title: PSYCHIC SUED FOR TELLING TRUTH
description: BIGFOOT DREAMS By Francine Prose. 280 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $16.95.

title: INEFFECTIVE PITCHING KEEPS BLUE JAYS IN A LOSING PATTERN
description: FINDING last season's division champions in this season's standings requires some extra-duty searching. They range from the middle of the divisions to the bottom. The Toronto Blue Jays, the American League East champions, who could not win the pennant after taking a three-games-to-one lead over Kansas City, have resided at the bottom of their division the longest of any of the four defending champions. The Blue Jays settled into seventh April 29 and apparently have grown accustomed to the place.

title: POP: BOB STEWART AND DUO
description: BOB STEWART was one of that last generation of singers who learned their craft with big bands and then, just as they were becoming established, found that the big bands had disappeared. Thirty years later, after having weathered rock and fusion as captain of a fishing vessel, Mr. Stewart has returned to his singing career, but without a band.

title: 2 THEATER GROUPS IN VENTURE
description: CAN two theatrical organizations that appear to be on tenterhooks help each other survive by joining forces? The question will be raised, if not resolved, next weekend when ''The House in the Woods,'' a new musical-in-progress, will have three tryout performances at Tarrytown's Music Hall.

title: Dog Earns Hero Honor at 13
description: She is a black-and-white mutt, part border collie and part Australian collie, and she is 13 years old, an age when most dogs are doing little else but eating and sleeping.

title: Sculpture Goes Public
description: Sculptor Scott Burton states that ''. . . the world is now in such bad shape that the interior liberty of the artist is a pretty trivial area.''

title: A MOVE FROM 'MAYHEM' BRINGS SUCCESS TO PLAYWRIGHT
description: TINA HOWE had to prove she could be conventional so she could do what she really wanted to do, which was to be outrageous.

title: Reagan Names Envoys To Egypt and Sudan
description: President Reagan has announced the nominations of two career diplomats as the United States Ambassadors to Egypt and the Sudan.

title: IN MILLER'S 'JOURNEY,' THE AUDIENCE ENDS UP PLAYING THE FOOL
description: To the Editor: The only conclusion one can reach after seeing the new production - one cannot call it a revival so much as a rejection - of ''Long Day's Journey Into Night'' is to conclude that Jonathan Miller despises Eugene O'Neill. That the greatest play in our literature had to be reduced to three hours, when ''Cats'' and ''Biloxi Blues'' are not that much shorter, suggests something even worse: a distrust of the theatergoing public which apparently the producers share, as evidenced from the radio ads promising a production that is ''young, fresh and even short.'' Last fall, Jose Quintero did not feel the need to shorten ''The Iceman Cometh''; but then, Mr. Quintero understands O'Neill better than any other director. He also understands audiences.

title: The Victorious Personality
description: To divide the human race into people with ''victorious personalities'' and those without is merely a polite way of labeling people ''winners'' and ''losers.''

title: L.I. ARTISTS TAKE 7 PRIZES IN SHOW
description: THE opportunity to achieve recognition motivates artists to enter juried exhibitions. It is a chance to have work displayed, perhaps reach a new audience and possibly even win an award. For their part, the sponsoring organizations feel they create a fair, democratic system that gives needed exposure to talent.

title: To Let Commanders Command
description: If the Russians were poised to invade Australia, the American commander in Honolulu would prepare to fight them. But before he could meet any adversary, the commander in chief Pacific would face daunting problems to the rear. Congress aims at last to lift these handicaps by overhauling the Defense Department.

title: VALERIE MINTON IS WED TO A NAVY LIEUTENANT
description: Valerie Haven Minton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dwight Church Minton of Princeton, N.J., and Lieut. James Gillis Webster 4th, U.S.N., a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Gillis Webster 3d of Englewood, N.J., were married yesterday at Trinity Church in Princeton.

title: WHY, MISS SCARLETT, HOW WELL YOU'VE AGED
description: WHEN Harriet Beecher Stowe, the author of ''Uncle Tom's Cabin,'' was taken to call on President Lincoln at the White House, he said to her, ''So this is the little lady who made this big war.''

title: LYNDA CAROLYN LOW TO BE WED IN JULY
description: Dr. and Mrs. Paul R. Low of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of his daughter, Lynda Carolyn Low, to Russell S. Reynolds 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Reynolds Jr. of Greenwich. The future bride also is the daughter of Joan G. Low of Burlington, Vt.

title: DARIO FO, ITALY'S POLITICAL CLOWN, PAYS A VISIT
description: The Italian actor and playwright Dario Fo was a choirboy in his youth. As he tells the story in his solo piece, ''Mistero Buffo,'' he also learned the blues under the tutelage of black American soldiers after World War II. But when he tried to bring this new style to bear on the liturgy, his priest did not appreciate the innovation.

title: THE CASE FOR VERBAL THRESHOLD INSURANCE
description: THE 13-year debate over New Jersey's auto-insurance laws continues in the Legislature. In January, Republicans in the Assembly fulfilled a campaign promise and passed a bill to reform no-fault statutes by limiting suits for pain and suffering.

title: PAMELA K. DEJAGER TO WED MARK C. SMITH IN OCTOBER
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bruce DeJager of Naples, Fla., and Highlands Falls, N.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter Pamela Karan DeJager to Mark Christopher Smith, the son of Mr. and Mrs. G. Emmett Smith of Dallas.

title: OPERA: BRITISH 'OBERON' IN SOUTHEASTERN FRANCE
description: That John Eliot Gardiner, one of the leading lights of the English early-music movement, is also music director of the Opera de Lyon is of interest on two counts. The notion that an Englishman should occupy an important administrative and artistic position at a leading French opera company is unusual enough. But in assuming responsibility for the full range of operatic repertory, Mr. Gardiner is clearly positioning himself to move into the conductorial mainstream - as Neville Marriner, Raymond Leppard, Nikolaus Harnoncourt and Christopher Hogwood have done, with varying success.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK;
Houston: Urban Motels In Small Towns
description: DESPITE the overabundance of comfortable hotel and motel lodgings in most major cities, travelers through small-town America often must settle for a few older accommodations offering the barest of amenities.

title: A YANKEE IN A HURRY
description: IN the hours before a game, baseball players usually stroll calmly into their clubhouse the same way other people arrive at work - wondering what will happen next, but not in any particular hurry to find out. Friday night, most of the Yankees had reported to Yankee Stadium early, as ballplayers usually do. Many were already in their pinstriped uniforms, sitting at their lockers or out taking early batting practice when Dan Pasqua arrived. But unlike the others, his brow and his blue sport shirt were damp with perspiration. Hurrying to his locker, he glanced at the clock on the wall above the door.

title: Dance
description: Modern dancers love innovation, yet they also borrow from other cultures. Take ''Noh Body,'' which Sarah Skaggs will present Thursday through next Sunday at St. Mark's Church.

title: GETTING SHIPSHAPE FOR SPRING SAILING
description: THE congealed white glob at the tip of his spatula had the consistency of hardened cream cheese and a vaguely chemical odor. Gerard Koeppel thoughtfully studied the gummy substance for a moment, then smeared it into a crack on the hull of his 30-foot racing boat, which was drydocked at the Nichols Yacht Yard in Mamaroneck.

title: Ethiopia's Chief Has His Say
description: The leader of Ethiopia's Marxist Government, Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam, said last week that his country wants better relations with the United States. But first, he said, the Reagan Administration must curb its ''anti-Ethiopia stance.''

title: IN LONDON, CROWNING JEWELS
description: London is aglitter this season with a special menagerie of lizards and crustaceans that would appear to have escaped from the Natural History Museum but for their sparkling marcasite or diamante bodies that instead seem to slither or crawl or generally enliven the latest and more classic styles of dress. Jewelry as an accessory based on good and unusual designs rather than simply on costly materials has become a serious rage in this city where individual boutiques are selling vintage pieces as well as manufacturing new designs. Gathering their wares from Continental and American Art Deco collections, the stores also reflect a long tradition of English interest in costume jewelry.

title: AN L.I. CAST FOR STATE G.O.P.
description: LONG ISLANDERS will be playing a major role at the Republican State Committee designating meeting that opens Tuesday in Syracuse.

title: E. R. BERGER 3d TO WED GEORGINA LAIDLAW
description: Georgina Arianne Laidlaw, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Laidlaw of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Everett Raymond Berger 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Berger Jr. of Wilmington, Del. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. S. Mark Browne at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Darien, Conn., assisted by the Rev. Peter Church, a Baptist minister.

title: PAINTINGS BY 1940'S SPECIAL ARMY UNIT SHOW MANY SIDES OF WORLD AT WAR
description: IN many of the tank attacks, amphibious landings, parachute drops and other combat situations of World War II, photographers were not the only noncombatants taken along to document the battle: often there were artists, sketchbooks in hand, struggling to capture the action. Throughout the war, a group of 45 artists, many of whom belonged to a special Army unit of painters, produced more than 3,000 oil paintings, watercolors and drawings of war scenes in the Pacific and in Europe.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: We Read to Die?

title: MISS STIFEL TO WED PETER BRITTON
description: Christ Church in Summit, N.J., was the setting yesterday for the wedding ceremony of Stephanie Elizabeth Stifel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry G. Stifel of Short Hills, N.J., and Stratton Mountain, Vt., to Peter Mills Britton, a son of Audley Clarke Britton of West Hartford and Kent, Conn., and the late Mr. Britton. The Protestant ceremony was performed by the Rev. Allen A. Tinker, a Baptist-Congregational minister.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THANK YOU, QUEEN ISABELLA. By John Works. (Texas A&M University, $12.95.) Garland Wyatt has a problem. The unemployed law graduate is obsessed with the increasing disorder of his life in Dallas and of the cosmos in general.

title: From Dobrynin to Dubinin
description: There may be some initial confusion when the new Soviet ambassador, Yuri V. Dubinin, arrives in Washington. After all, he will replace Anatoly F. Dobrynin.

title: DANCE: FERRI AND BISSELL IN 'ROMEO AND JULIET'
description: CHOREOGRAPHERS who create ballets to Prokofiev's ''Romeo and Juliet'' respond to different things in the score. Sir Kenneth MacMillan emphasized its orchestral richness in his adaptation of Shakespeare's tragedy, which returned to American Ballet Theater's repertory on Friday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Data Bank: May 25, 1986
Prosecutors Say It All Began With Manes
description: Federal prosecutors said last week for the first time that Donald R. Manes, using trusted associates as middlemen, initiated and directed a multimillion-dollar scheme to obtain bribes from private collection agencies serving the city's Parking Violations Bureau. In an affidavit opposing a defense motion to have the case split into separate trials, the prosecutors said they had evidence of ''an integrated racketeering enterprise'' instigated by Mr. Manes, who resigned as Queens Borough President Feb. 11 and killed himself March 13.

title: The Fate of Newborns
description: To the Editor:

title: CHASING RETURNS IN DIFFERENT CURRENCIES
description: Attracted by booming stock markets and strong returns abroad - and the prospect that worldwide diversification will reduce risk -corporate and public pension funds have put a hefty $35 billion chunk of their $1.5 trillion hoard of assets under the guidance of international investment advisers. But, surprisingly, in selling their expertise to American pension funds, many of the 100 or so advisory firms that specialize in international investments have soft-pedaled one potential benefit: The chance to cash in on shifts in currency values.

title: U.S Dispute on Drugs in Mexico
description: The Reagan Administration was divided last week over what to say and think about drug trafficking as well as charges of political and economic mismanagement and official corruption in Mexico. Some State Department officials have criticized Mexico sharply and William von Raab, the head of the United States Customs Service, has testified that the governor of one Mexican state was growing marijuana and opium on his own farm.

title: Sailor Awaits Goodwill Games in Soviet
description: Buzz Reynolds, a champion Finn Class sailor, has a history of broken dreams when it comes to international competition. When he heard news of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster, it came at first as one more crimp in his sailing career. He was sure that the Goodwill Games planned for the Soviet Union this summer would never survive the fallout.

title: U.S. JEWISH GROUP SHIFTS ON SOVIET
description: The principal American organization for Soviet Jews has drafted a new policy statement supporting for the first time a ''step by step'' easing of United States trade restrictions on the Soviet Union if Moscow begins to relax curbs on Jewish emigration.

title: Brooklyn Man, 81, Kills Son, Then Stabs Himself 2 Times
description: An 81-year-old man fatally stabbed his emotionally disturbed son and then critically wounded himself with the knife early yesterday in what the police called an apparent murder and attempted suicide at the Brooklyn home of the men.

title: Publishers Sue Meese's Panel
description: ''I'm afraid there is a train marked 'censorship' which has just left the station,'' an American Civil Liberties Union spokesman said last year when Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d set up a commission to study pornography. To hear some publishers tell it today, that train is getting close to its destination.

title: Crown Heights Feels the Force of the Drop in Rates
description: ALL along Eastern Parkway and the populous residential streets around it in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn, the evidence of property rehabilitation abounds. New double-pane windows on walk-up buildings half a century old are the most visible outward sign.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: UP FROM JERICHO TEL By E. L. Konigsburg. 153 pp. New York: Atheneum. $12.95. (Ages 8 to 12) YOUNG children generally have a good sense of humor, which tends to desert them as they reach the self-absorbed years of adolescence. ''Up From Jericho Tel'' by E. L. Konigsburg should reawake a mood of fun and games in even the sulkiest of preteen-agers. The novel is at bottom your basic fairy tale, involving Malcolm and Jeanmarie, two isolated children unpopular at school, latchkey kids who live in the Empire Estates Mobile Homes Park somewhere on Long Island. They encounter the spirit of a famous old actress called Tallulah while burying some dead animals in a graveyard in the woods. The name they have given this secret place is Jericho Tel. (Jeanmarie is nothing if not pretentious. She and Malcolm are both convinced they are going to be famous.) These early pages of the book are faintly reminiscent of the great French movie ''Forbidden Games'' and give the same feeling of two children's secret alliance against the world.

title: Battling Hooky: 2 Approaches
description: TRUANCY was high at Memorial Junior High School in San Diego when the principal tried a desperation gambit in 1980 - a cash bonus for every pupil who showed up for school.

title: YACHT RUNS AGROUND ON EAST RIVER SHORE ON A DINNER CRUISE
description: About 350 diners aboard a commercial yacht cruising in the East River last night got an unscheduled close-up view of Brooklyn when the vessel lost power and temporarily ran aground next to the Manhattan Bridge.

title: The Economy Looks Rosy, Relatively
description: Last week's report of 3.7 percent economic growth in the first three months of the year - half a percentage point more than earlier estimated - was distinctly more positive than the dismal record of the previous quarter. But it was full of the usual anomalies, and as usual private analysts were more cautious in their interpretations than was the White House.

title: Hinckley Heard From
