description: John Hinckley Jr., who has been confined to a mental institution for four years after trying to assassinate President Reagan in 1981, has taken up the cause of defending inmates like himself against public ridicule.

title: BONNER STARTS HER JOURNEY BACK TO SOVIET
description: Yelena G. Bonner left the United States tonight to return to her husband, Andrei D. Sakharov, and their life in internal exile in the Soviet Union.

title: Starling Protests Bout
description: Don Bowers, the manager of Marlon Starling, has officially protested Starling's loss of the United States Boxing Association welterweight title to Johnny Bumphus of a technical decision. After an accidental collision of heads in the sixth round, it was ruled Bumphus could not continue.

title: PRETORIA, IN REPLY TO U.S., INTENDS TO OUST ATTACHE
description: South Africa announced today that it intended to expel the senior United States military attache in the country.

title: Judith S. Kessler To Wed June 29
description: Mr. and Mrs. Nelson S. Kessler of Swampscott, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Judith Sandra Kessler to Lee Michael Arthurs, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Arthurs of New York and Summit, N.J. A June 29 wedding is planned.

title: Chicago: New Tower for Shoppers' Row
description: FOUNDATION work has begun on a 66-story apartment-retail-office tower on fashionable North Michigan Avenue that will cover virtually an entire city block and include this city's first Bloomingdale's store and its second Four Seasons Hotel.

title: AID HOMELESS CHILDREN, FORDHAM CLASS IS URGED
description: A leading advocate for the homeless urged graduating students at Fordham University yesterday to work to ease the suffering of homeless children.

title: DIPLOMATIC DOLDRUMS IN THE MIDEAST
description: THESE days in Washington, the Middle East peace process is being discussed largely in the past tense. Officials, diplomats, Middle Eastern visitors and academic specialists have been conducting post-mortems on the failed effort, undertaken from February 1985 to February 1986, to launch negotiations between Israel and a Jordanian-Palestinian delegation on the future of the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Each party blames another, of course, for missing the ''window of opportunity'' that followed the fragmentation of the Palestine Liberation Organization after Israel's 1982 invasion of Lebanon. The window slammed shut in February, when talks failed between King Hussein of Jordan and Yasir Arafat, the P.L.O. leader. Since then, United States diplomatic activity has been in something of a lull.

title: INDY RACES INTO FUTURE AT MODEL T PACE
description: Every year, the members of a club from St. Louis arrive at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway and camp out on the infield grass in vans and trailers and other recreational vehicles.

title: MINNESOTA TRANSCENDENTALIST
description: SELECTED POEMS By Robert Bly. 213 pp. New York: Harper & Row. Cloth, $18.95. Paper, $8.95.

title: HE FOUND HIS VOICE IN PRISON
description: SHCHARANSKY Hero of Our Time. By Martin Gilbert. Illustrated. 467 pp. New York: Elisabeth Sifton/Viking. $24.95.

title: England Tops Canada In Warm-Up for Cup
description: Mark Hateley knocked in a rebound at close range off a direct free kick today to give England a 1-0 victory over Canada in a World Cup soccer warm-up match.

title:
ON LONG ISLAND;
CONCERN OVER AFFORDABLE HOUSING GROWS
description: EARLIER this month, Anthony and Sandra Sturchio and their three small children moved into a new three-bedroom high ranch in Medford that they purchased from the Town of Brookhaven for $65,000.

title: AQUINO HAS PRAISE FOR 'MY SOLDIERS'
description: President Corazon C. Aquino told a rally here today to forget the past abuses of the military, and she indicated at a news conference that she might be ready to grant an amnesty to some of the soldiers who had committed human-rights violations.

title: HOUSTON AIMS AT WEAPONS IN SCHOOL
description: In what officials here say is an unfortunate first, the Houston School District has established a program to deal with the increasing problem of students who bring guns and other weapons to school.

title: THE GARDNER SISTERS PLAN THEIR WEDDINGS
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ben Gardner of Great Neck, L.I., have announced the engagements of their daughters, Rhona and Pamela Gardner, to Rick Meyer and Kenneth Olson. The weddings are planned for June 21 and November. Mr. Meyer is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Seymour Meyer of Kings Point, L.I. Mr. Olson is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Olson of Queens Village, Queens.

title: Piquet Gains Pole Spot For Belgian Grand Prix
description: Nelson Piquet of Brazil, in a Williams-Honda, ended a ''very confusing qualifying session'' today with a record lap that took the pole position for the Belgian Grand Prix.

title: HART SAYS HE'S ASSUMING CUOMO WILL SEEK THE PRESIDENCY IN 1988
description: Senator Gary Hart said last week that he assumed Governor Cuomo would seek the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1988 and would start as the party's best financed candidate.

title: TUCKAHOE
description: WHEN the New York and Harlem Railroad extended its line north nearly 150 years ago, one of the first new stops was Tuckahoe. That was for the convenience of quarry owners who had sought the new rail transportation to ship huge blocks of white marble.

title: LORRAINE FRASER IS MARRIED TO J. A. SEMPLINER, PAINTER
description: Lorraine Ann Fraser, a medical journalist, and John Alexander Sempliner, a painter, were married yesterday at the Parish Church of St. Mary in London by Canon Jorgen Simonson.

title: ROUND AND ROUND THEY GO IN NEW EGYPT FOR CASH AND GLORY
description: THE sign pops up out of nowhere, breaking the rural monotony of Route 539 where lush farmlands and then the Pine Barrens line the way from Trenton to the Shore.

title: FM STEREO STRIVES TO INCREASE ITS REACH
description: When radio and I were young, the main aim of listeners was to pull in stations from as far away as possible. It didn't matter how dim and crackly they sounded. The idea was to log distance. Living in Vienna during those years, I distinctly remember my father's triumphant delight at being able to milk the noisy sky for faint voices speaking exotic languages like English or Rumanian, coming all the way from London or Bucharest, respectively.

title: The Victorious Personality
description: I was moved by Gail Sheehy's description of people who have survived tremendous obstacles to lead productive lives (''The Victorious Personality,'' April 20). In each example she gave of children who struggled with hardship, their individual heroics were aided by an adult, outside the family, who served as a friend and acted as a good Samaritan.

title: Viewers Could Judge Abu Abbas for Themselves
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, MAY 25, 1986
description: International

title: PIANO: CYPRIEN KATSARIS IN RECITAL
description: STANDING ovations are not rare, probably not as rare as they ought to be. But it is still unusual to see the whole hall rise in quick unison as the last chord is played, and that is what happened Friday when Cyprien Katsaris finished his program at Alice Tully Hall. The response was prompted by an extraordinary program. Mr. Katsaris, a French pianist known to pianophiles in America by a long series of recordings, built this debut concert around the theme ''Liszt and Beethoven: Death and Heroism,'' and his playing had the intellectual, rhetorical and technical substance to hold one engaged without the traditional care over variety or contrast.

title: NEW TECHNOLOGY LINKING HANDS ACROSS AMERICA
description: Long before any hands could come together this weekend in an attempt to form a human chain across the country, a vastly greater nationwide network of technology had to be formed to coordinate the event.

title: Johns Hopkins, Syracuse Out
description: The top teams in the national intercollegiate lacrosse tournament, Johns Hopkins and Syracuse, were both beaten today, the Blue Jays losing to North Carolina, 10-9, in overtime and the Orange to Virginia, 12-10.

title: CONCERN GROWING AMONG U.S. AIDES ON MEXICO FUTURE
description: More and more senior United States Government officials are coming to believe that Mexico's political and economic problems have grown so severe that Mexico could become one of this nation's most important foreign policy problems, many officials say.

title: FAUBUS RUNS AGAIN FOR GOVERNOR OF ARKANSAS
description: Two men whose careers have symbolized the poles of Southern politics are seeking the Democratic nomination for Governor in the Arkansas primary Tuesday, while in another race a national Republican organization has provided support to a Democrat who seeks to unseat a Congressman from eastern Arkansas.

title: THE CUOMO BRAND OF DEEP-POCKET POLITICS
description: POLITICAL money follows political success, and Mario M. Cuomo - who had raised less than $1 million at this time four years ago - had at least $8 million in the bank when he announced his candidacy for a second term last week.

title: IN BLACK AND WHITE: PHOTOGRAPHS, LITHOGRAPHS AND DRAWINGS
description: THE CAUSE of black and white is well served by shows now at the Montclair Art Museum (corner of South Mountain and Bloomfield Avenues) and the Kornbluth Gallery (7-21 Fair Lawn Avenue, Fair Lawn).

title: TANGO: ASTOR PIAZZOLLA AT THE PUBLIC THEATER
description: BY breaking every tango convention, Astor Piazzolla reveals some essence of the tango - the sense that, at any moment, a gust of strong emotion can rip through any form, any artifice. Mr. Piazzolla is a meticulous composer who has thought hard about the modernist harmonies, shifty rhythms, contrapuntal devices and structural extensions he has added to the tango. But at the Public Theater Friday, he never let sophistication take the place of heart.

title: WATER: THE SEASON'S PLAYGROUND
description: FORTUNATE are the water-loving folk of Connecticut, within whose 5,009 square miles are 253 miles of shoreline, 8,400 miles of rivers and streams and 6,000 lakes and ponds. As summer approaches, visions of outings at the shore or the lake, romps in the town pond, river cruises, sailing, water-skiing, fishing and dips in the old swimming hole, come rushing into focus.

title: THE UNTUCKED LOOK IS NEWS IN SHIRTS
description: THE out shirttail is very in this year, especially among younger people. Good old-fashioned rebellion may have something to do with it, but more likely it's the influence of a couple of very up-to-the-moment pace-setters - the designer Claude Montana and the ''Miami Vice'' television series.

title: Yankee Coach in Incident
description: Gene Michael, the Yankees' third-base coach, and John Shulock, the third-base umpire, got into a minor shoving incident yesterday after the Yankees' 7-6 victory over the California Angels.

title: ROAD PROJECT SPLITS 2 GROUPS
description: A DISPUTE between two civic associations over a proposed four-lane road that Suffolk County has been planning to build for 15 years in Brookhaven Town has put the project on hold.

title: MISS MEDLIN, A NURSE, IS WED TO A PHYSICIAN
description: Elizabeth Anne Medlin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Medlin Jr. of Lincolnton, N.C., was married yesterday to Dr. Charles A. Mangano Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Mangano of Tuckahoe, N.Y. The the Rev. James English performed the ceremony at St. Francis of Assisi Roman Catholic Church in Raleigh, N.C., assisted by the Rev. Paul Hamilton, a Methodist minister.

title: WHEN PICASSO USED FILM FOR A PALETTE
description: Pablo Picasso's sketchbooks are not the only new additions to the seemingly endless supply of artworks and artifacts left by the 20th-century's most influential artist. We now have the opportunity of seeing a dozen photographs taken by Picasso in the years 1912 and 1913. They are small, no bigger than playing cards, yet they are remarkable for what they tell us about Picasso's art in particular and about the impact of photography on painting in general.

title: Movie Music
description: To the Editor:

title: FORUMS FOR PUBLIC CONCERNS - FROM AGING TO AIDS
description: Although Manhattan's cable franchises are principally known as conduits for programming, frequently these days they also produce public-affairs work that is ambitious, elaborate and catholic in appeal. A case in point is ''Still Growing After All These Years,'' a 30-minute documentary sponsored by Manhattan Cable - which services the southern part of the borough -that will be shown Thursday night at 9:30 on Channel L. The film, produced by Johanna Cooper, features interviews, performances and exhibitions by an irrepressible corps of New York musicians, painters, sculptors, poets and actors who happen to be over age 60, in an exploration of the ways in which retirement can be used for personal development and fulfillment. Included are conversations with Betty Friedan, who is currently working on a book about misconceptions regarding the elderly; the composer Otto Leuning, now 85, and gerontologists from Columbia University's Brookdale Institute on Aging and Adult Human Development.

title: BILL LIMITING INVESTMENTS IN NOTHERN IRELAND IS SENT TO CUOMO
description: After months of impassioned lobbying by Irish-American groups, the Assembly has given final passage to a bill that sets standards for state investments in American companies doing business in Northern Ireland.

title: HERCULES AND THE SNAIL DARTER
description: LAW'S EMPIRE By Ronald Dworkin. 470 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The Belknap Press/ Harvard University Press. $20.

title: GIVING THE ESPIONAGE LAWS A NEW LOOK
description: THE issue of the hour was spies and their relentless assault on the national defense.

title: PRETORIA READIES TOUGH NEW LAWS TO COMBAT UNREST
description: The South African authorities are preparing tough new legislation that will enable them to crack down on opponents in areas of unrest and detain them without charge or trial for six months.

title: A RECOUNT LEAVES O'NEILL AHEAD
description: A recount here today upheld Gov. William A. O'Neill's narrow victory over his challenger, Toby Moffett, last Tuesday in a key local primary to choose delegates to the Democratic state convention in July.

title: SOCCER FEVER A RESPITE, NOT A MALADY
description: THE FEVER is filling the air here and all of Mexico is but a hair's breadth away from seemingly complete soccer mania.

title: NEW CASSETTES: BY DE SICA, SUTHERLAND AND THE ROYAL BALLET
description: Fraggle Rock, Volume 1: Beginnings Written by Jerry Juhl; produced by Duncan Kenworthy; directed by Jim Henson, 1982 Thorn EMI/HBO Video 30 minutes. $24.95 Here it is, that first episode, the one that tells everything you always wanted to know about Fraggle Rock and couldn't ask HBO, which has been broadcasting this children's entertainment on pay television since 1983.

title: HOSPITAL PROJECTS: TRENTON PROPSES NEW RULES
description: THE statewide moratorium on hospital building and renovation would be lifted temporarily this fall under interim rules recently proposed by the state's Health Care Administration Board.

title: MORTON GOULD: COMPOSER, CONDUCTOR AND, NOW, EXECUTIVE
description: In January, Morton Gould - at 72 - was elected to the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters, filling the vacancy left by Roger Sessions's death. In April he was elected president of Ascap, the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers, the oldest performing rights organization in the world. Elected unanimously by its 24-member board of directors, Mr. Gould succeeds Hal David, the lyricist for ''Raindrops Keep Falling on My Head,'' who had six years before succeeded Stanley Adams, the lyricist for ''What a Difference a Day Makes.''

title: PHILADELPHIA PARK FIGHTING OFF DECAY
description: In the American Revolution, Benjamin Franklin's daughter lived in a Georgian country home above the silvery Schuylkill, where she spent her time writing letters to her father and stitching bandages and clothes for wounded soldiers.

title: FIGHTING DRUGS ON NEW YORK BLOCKS
description: To a stranger, the block looks like any other in the northwest Bronx, a narrow street of brick apartment buildings with rusting fire escapes, a few two-family houses, a very few trees.

title: Waldheim Rally Is Disrupted By Demonstrators in Vienna
description: A presidential campaign rally for Kurt Waldheim was disrupted today by about 20 chanting demonstrators who held banners protesting the former United Nations Secretary General's candidacy.

title: Matter of Principle
description: He was there to get an honorary degree, but when Drew Lewis, the former Secretary of Transportation, got a standing ovation last week, it was for handing his purple doctoral hood back. Invited by Haverford College to receive an honorary Doctor of Laws degree, he learned that 28 faculty members had signed a letter protesting his role in the Reagan Administration's decision to fire the air traffic controllers who went on strike in 1981.

title: A BOUNTIFUL HARVEST, GROWN WITHOUT PESTICIDES
description: I never met an evangelist I liked, until I called on Farrell Freeman.

title: The Victorious Personality
description: The examples of victorious personalities described by Gail Sheehy were very moving. However, they are also very rare. The great majority of survivors emerge from their ordeals as psychic cripples, beset by nightmares, fear, ''guilt,'' suspicion.

title: Oil Spill Damages U.S. Study Of Coral-Reef Life in Panama
description: A 55,000-gallon oil spill from a refinery tank failure in Panama has caused extensive damage to a large coral-reef biological reserve, the Smithsonian Institution has reported.

title: EXPOS DEFEAT GIANTS BY 7-4
description: Hubie Brooks hit a home run and drove in three runs today to lead the Montreal Expos past the San Francisco Giants, 7-4.

title: MARTHA GRAHAM RETURNS TO HER ROOTS
description: ''I don't believe in nostalgia,''

title: Poland Indicts A Solidarity Figure
description: A military prosecutor has indicted Tadeusz Jedynak, a Solidarity underground leader, on a charge of plotting to overthrow Poland's Communist system by force, according to a published report.

title: GROUP FAULTS CITY POLICY ON BURIAL OF POOR INFANTS
description: Almost half the infants who died in New York City from 1981 to 1984 are buried in unmarked graves in Potter's Field, according to a study released yesterday by an advocacy group for the homeless.

title: MASSACHUSETTS TRIES TO UPDATE BEACH LAWS
description: Memorial Day marks the official opening of most New England beaches, and lawmakers in Massachusetts are turning their attention to a problem beachgoers in this state have endured for centuries.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a transmission error, two words were dropped from Cynthia Ozick's review May 18 of ''The Bloody Crossroads'' by Norman Podhoretz. Miss Ozick wrote: ''Nevertheless, Mr. Podhoretz's pre-eminent strength is that he will not allow indignation over Soviet and Soviet-subservient totalitarianism to fade out or die down or diminish to platitude in our intellectual universe.''

title: CABARET: LAMPOON'S 'CLASS OF '86'
description: IN the final skit of the National Lampoon's ''Class of '86'' at the Village Gate theater, President Reagan, asleep in the Oval Office, dreams of riding his horse off to rescue a woman from the clutches of Libyan leader Muammar el-Qaddafi. In general, the targets of the satire here will be familiar to the readers of the Lampoon, and those who recall the 1973 Lampoon hit, ''Lemmings,'' also staged at the Gate, will recognize some old themes. ''Class of '86'' also has some of the same faults as the earlier show. They were not faults to the audience in those days but they were new faults then, and they aren't new now.

title: L.I. ACTOR STARS IN AIDS FILM
description: ONE year ago, as the public became aware of the rising concern about AIDS, Arthur J. Bressan Jr., an independent film maker, began making ''Buddies,'' a dramatization of the relationship between a homosexual man who becomes a ''buddy'' to a man dying of the incurable disease.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a computer entry error, the hardcover fiction best seller list on page 22 of The Times Book Review today reverses the ranking of two books. ''I'll Take Manhattan,'' by Judith Krantz (Crown), should be No. 1. ''A Perfect Spy,'' by John le Carre (Knopf), should be No. 2.

title: FOR SWIMMERS AND SPLASHERS, IT'S BACK TO THE BEACH
description: EAST HAMPTON is expecting an invasion of wind-surfing Europeans. Long Beach has built its own sand dunes. The Fire Island National Seashore will have a new pizza parlor. And Long Island's premier location for fun in the sun, Jones Beach State Park, which had 13 million visitors last summer, is set to show off its newly refurbished West Bathhouse.

title: Barthes: His Dates and Uses
description: To the Editor:

title: Ambiguity on Affirmative Action Plans
description: The Supreme Court struck down one school district's program for protecting minority teachers' jobs last week, but the decision nonetheless signaled that affirmative action is very much alive.

title: Making It Big: More for the List
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: AMANDA H. BOE WEDS IN DARIEN
description: Amanda H. Boe, a daughter of Deon W. Boe of Stamford, Conn., and Roy L. M. Boe of Westhampton, L.I., and William F. Faulkner, a son of Mrs. Thomas C. Taylor of Rochester and Dwight F. Faulkner of New York, were married yesterday at St. Luke's Church in Darien, Conn. The Rev. Kevin D. Bean officiated at the Episcopal ceremony.

title: CONGRESS IS TAKING EXCEPTION TO REAGAN'S FOREIGN POLICY AGENDA
description: DURING his first term, President Reagan used his considerable political skills to have his way generally on foreign policy, and Congress went along with the dispatch of American troops to Beirut and the sale of advanced radar planes to Saudi Arabia. But in recent months, Mr. Reagan has had more trouble getting what he wants from Congress on foreign issues. And last week, the struggle between the White House and the Congress over control of the nation's foreign policy intensified as Mr. Reagan's policies in several areas were challenged on Capitol Hill.

title: Arthur Rubloff Is Dead at 83; Developed Chicago Projects
description: Arthur Rubloff, a real estate developer whose projects reshaped the face of Chicago and who gave millions of dollars to artistic and charitable endeavors, died at his home today. He was 83 years old.

title: 'SIN' LEVIES ONLY ADD TO ALCOHOL'S ALLURE
description: IN the current political climate, the push to control drinking behavior is getting out of control. This pursuit is manifesting itself now in the cry for increased taxes on alcoholic beverages. Apparently 4,000 years of repressive laws have taught our social engineers nothing. They still believe that drinking behavior can be controlled through legislation.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Sports of The Times column last Sunday about the Goodwill Games in Moscow this summer reported incorrectly the duties for which Edwin Moses, the American hurdler who will compete at the games, will be paid. He will receive a fee only for his work as a television commentator with the Turner Broadcasting System, which helped arrange the games.

title: COYOTES' ARRIVAL IN RURAL VERMONT PROMPTS STUDY
description: Somewhere in a field here, Guinevere and Lancelot met nightly to walk in the moonlight, to lie in a leafy bower, to munch on small rodents.

title: A PAMPHLETEER TACKLES THE CHANGING PROBLEMS OF SOCIETY
description: IN September 1960, while on a sabbatical and thinking about what she wanted to do next, Adele Braude was called by an acquaintance who asked her to take a six-month job, planning the forthcoming 25th anniversary observances of an organization called the Public Affairs Committee Inc.

title: A STRATEGY OF AGGRESSIVE INNOVATION
description: Innovation, by Richard Foster. Summit Books, New York 316 pages, $19.95. UNLIKE Roy Rowan, Richard

title: PRIMARY VOTES FAIL TO CLARIFY CANDIDATES IN G.O.P.
description: BY now, with two months to go before the Republican State Convention, party leaders had figured to have a clear reading on which of their four contenders for governor was building the strongest candidacy.

title: MUSIC
description: One of the truly heartbreaking activities for composers is finding musicians to play their work. Concert opportunities are not that many; presenters tend toward the conservative; and prior reputation is usually a deciding factor.

title: CAMARADERIE, COMPETITION AT TRYOUTS
description: RONY SEIKALY and Reggie Williams have met several times during the last three years, but never once on what might be termed a social occasion. Their meetings, rather, were more work-related. And it was the kind of work that allowed them to find out much about the other.

title: MOHM PAT IN AMERICA
description: SPIRIT OF SURVIVAL By Gail Sheehy. Illustrated. 400 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $17.95. IN her wildly successful book, ''Passages,'' Gail Sheehy, a New York journalist, seemed to capture a fragment of the self-interested, self-absorbed 1970's and make stages of personal growth understandable to readers who found their lives in flux. Her new book, ''Spirit of Survival,'' is a far less structured and very personal account of lives in crisis that may even baffle Miss Sheehy's most faithful admirers.

title: U.S.-YEMENI OFFER REPORTED
description: A report published here today said that the United States had promised to provide opponents of the Soviet-backed regime in Southern Yemen with military aid and other asistance to help them seize power.

title: THE TEAMSTERS THROW A PARTY FOR THEIR PRESIDENT
description: THE delegates to the International Brotherhood of Teamsters' convention were crowded into a lavish party at Caesars Palace, where any drink could be had for the asking and the extension of a hand, and table after table was laden with comestibles: caviar, shrimp, crab, cheese, ham, beef, fruit, cakes, pies.

title: HALPIN SETS HAMMER RECORDS
description: Poor Gary Halpin. Four weeks ago, he put his right arm through a plate-glass door, needed five stitches and lost two weeks of training. Once he resumed training, he strained a tendon in front of his right hip joint, and it hurt so much that it wiped out the last half of his competition today.

title: Dorothea Dickerman, Lawyer, Weds
description: Dorothea Wilhelmina Dickerman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Dickerman of Potomac, Md., and Richard K.A. Becker, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Becker of Philadelphia, were married yesterday. The ceremony was performed at the National Presbyterian Church in Washington by the Rev. Louis H. Evans, assisted by the Rev. Joseph Currie, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE enormous, glittering atrium with its elegant glass enclosures and dramatic staircase quickly alerts a visitor to expect captivation by the new $24 million WOR-TV building on Meadowlands Parkway in Secaucus.

title: A CYNICAL ENGLISH COMEDY AIMS LOW
description: ''SHUT Your Eyes and Think of England,'' now at the Arena Players Repertory Theater in East Farmingdale, is a broad comedy that will appeal to those whose taste runs toward ''Animal House'' and ethnic jokes.

title: SUMMER CARE FOR BETTER PHOTO FARE
description: FOR some photographers, the beginning of summer is like New Year's eve. Resolutions are made that during the coming summer new and better pictures will be taken. There is a pledge to learn more about the technique of photography and how to get the most out of color film.

title: THE DANCE: 'JUNGLE,' BY LEMON
description: THE aura of an ancient legend, magically transferred to the stage almost intact, permeated the Bessie Schonberg Theater on Friday. The occasion was the presentation of a new work by Ralph Lemon, ''And The Jungle Will Obliterate The Shrine/ Seasons,'' which is set to a varied and atmospheric score by C. Hyams-Hart and unfolds in a sensuously colorful world designed by Kay Bloss and Jane Townsend. We seem to be watching a creation fable, as Mr. Lemon's seven vivid and skillful dancers move dreamily, at the beginning and end, in gauzy blue-green suits that seem to be made of water.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Mennonites Try Reconciling Eras - THE Mennonites, a prominent religious group in Lancaster County and other parts of Pennsylvania, have never been quite as strict and reclusive as the Amish. Some are restaurateurs and entrepreneurs serving the tourist trade in the Pennsylvania Dutch country, and more than a few are well off. Nevertheless, the transition from the old ways of simplicity to the modern world of business and financial success can demand difficult religious and ethical decisions.

title: 74 Protesters Arrested At Nuclear Plant's Gates
description: The police arrested 74 antinuclear activists who staged a sit-in today outside the gates at the nearly complete Seabrook reactor.

title: RESERVE FOR SHORE BIRDS DEDICATED
description: STATE officials from New Jersey and Delaware last week dedicated the first migratory shore-bird reserve in the Western Hemisphere, an area along the lower 25 miles of Delaware Bay.

title: U.S. WANTS TO ENHANCE ENFORCEMENT ON ALIENS
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service has drafted a bill that would sharply enhance the Government's power to prevent, detect and punish violations of immigration law.

title: EFFECT OF BIAS SUIT ON YONKERS BUDGET WEIGHED
description: A PROPOSED $284 million budget in Yonkers for the next fiscal year would raise property taxes 12.65 percent to improve services, hire new city workers and pay for a major capital-improvements program.

title: SEWAGE TERMED THREAT IN SOUND
description: THE county shoreline suffered little damage as a result of Hurricane Gloria's visit last October or from natural erosion over the winter. But boaters who traverse the waters of the Port Chester Harbor in northern Westchester may detect the effects of a sewage system there that each day dumps about seven million gallons of mostly untreated waste into the Long Island Sound.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: 'CANDIDE' IN MILLBURN - ''Candide,'' Voltaire's tale adapted by Hugh Wheeler and set to music by Leonard Bernstein, with lyrics by Richard Wilbur, has opened at the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn.

title: BEST SELLERS: MAY 25, 1986
description: $ Weeks This Last on Week Fiction Week List 1 A PERFECT SPY, by John le Carre. 1 5 (Knopf, $18.95.) The tale of Magnus Pym, a British secret agent, and his father, Rick, a flamboyant con man. 2 I'LL TAKE MANHATTAN, by Judith Krantz. 2 5 (Crown, $18.95.) Rich, beautiful Maxi Amberville conquers the world of magazine publishing. 3 THE BOURNE SUPREMACY, by Robert Ludlum. 3 12 Random House, $19.95.) The hero of ''The Bourne Identity'' foils a plot to seize Hong Kong and bring China into conflict with the West. 4 LAKE WOBEGON DAYS, by Garrison Keillor. 4 39 (Viking, $17.95.) Yarns about life in a small Minnesota town. 5 THE MAMMOTH HUNTERS, by Jean M. Auel. 5 27 (Crown, $19.95.) Ayla continues her adventures in the prehistoric world. 6 BREAK IN, by Dick Francis. 6 10 (Putnam, $17.95.) The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores in every region of the United States, statistically adjusted to represent sales in all bookstores. In Advice and How-to, five titles are listed because, beyond that point, sales in this category are not generally large enough to make a longer list statistically reliable. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the bookselling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: 'AIN'T MISBEHAVIN'' IN DARIEN: A BOUNTIFUL MUSICAL REVUE
description: WHAT is so endearing and enduring about ''Ain't Misbehavin' '' is that it is virtually indestructible. It all looks so easy. Start with a concept - here, the music of Fats Waller - and spark it with high-voltage energy. Why, then, do so many similar revues based on a composer's body of work fail, whereas this one, unfailingly, works?

title: CONCERT: MOZARTEUM QUARTETT
description: SOMETHING extraordinary happened at the conclusion of the Mozarteum Quartett Salzburg's performance of Mozart's Quartet in D minor (K. 173) at the Symphony Space on Thursday night. The players, dismayed by what was admittedly a less than polished rendition of the final movement, apologized to the audience and played it again.

title: WORKSHOP FOCUSES ON USES OF HUMOR
description: LATELY, everyone from company presidents to salesmen are using humor to sell products, a trend that worries Dr. Vincent Rogers, who says using humor in business is not ''just relying on a bag of jokes'' but is a way of looking at life from a realistic perspective.

title: NUCLEAR NAVY A FACTOR IN SHAPING U.S. FACILITIES
description: IN the hundreds of articles that have recently been published about the differences between the nuclear electric-power programs in the United States and the Soviet Union, one major factor has been overlooked - an institution that has shaped its philosophy of operation for the last 30 years.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: MAY 25, 1986
description: Fiction

title: West German Arson Kills 7
description: An arson fire raced through a 19th-century villa early today, killing 7 people and seriously injuring 13 others. All the victims were attending a birthday party, authorities said. Investigators said an incendiary device that started the fire was left on the villa's stairwell, blocking the escape of about 25 guests on the third floor.

title: OTTERS AND SEA LIONS IN STEINBECK COUNTRY
description: A lot has happened since 1945 when John Steinbeck published his affectionate stories about life along Cannery Row in Monterey, Calif.

title: DROP IN OIL COSTS GIVES HOPE TO STRUGGLING GRAIN FARMERS
description: Bruce Wilkinson raises corn and soybeans on rolling hills here about 50 miles north of Kansas City. Bill Turrentine grows wheat on the level plains near Garden City, out in western Kansas. But both have a lot in common this year.

title: Sundstrom and Gomez Gain Final in Florence
description: Henrik Sundstrom of Sweden, rebounding from a two-year slump, upset Emilio Sanchez of Spain today to join top-seeded Andres Gomez in the final of a $100,000 men's Grand Prix tournament.

title: YOUTHS RUN TOWN'S AMBULANCE SERVICE
description: WHEN Karen Schell had to help deliver a baby earlier this month in an ambulance on Interstate 95, she knew what to do. A member of Explorer Post 53, Darien's volunteer ambulance service, Miss Schell has assisted victims at such medical emergencies as shootings, stabbings, car accidents, drug overdoses and heart attacks.

title:
GARDENING;
FERTILIZER: TOO LITTLE OR TOO MUCH IS BAD
description: CONSUMERS spend large sums of money on fertilizer each year. In some areas, notably Long Island, excessive fertilizer application is threatening the water supply by contaminating it with nitrogen. Is it necessary to fertilize lawns and gardens, and, if so, how does one go about it in a reasonable way?

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: MEDIEVAL HOUSEHOLDS. By David Herlihy. (Harvard University, Cloth, $30. Paper, $11.50.) The modern family is a medieval institution, so argues David Herlihy, in ''Medieval Households.'' Mr. Herlihy, Henry Charles Lea Professor of Medieval History at Harvard University, finds that the family as we know it left little record in ancient times.

title: RESERVE DUTY FOR ISRAELIS: A WAY OF LIFE
description: An Israeli Chief of Staff, Gen. Yigael Yadin, once said that in Israel ''the civilian is a soldier on 11 months' annual leave.''

title: VETERANS CEMETERY WILL BE DEDICATED
description: NEW JERSEY, which lost its only National Veterans Cemetery when plots in nearby Beverly were exhausted 21 years ago, will get a replacement in this Burlington County village Friday.

title:
RAISING THE COST OF DRINKING;
HIGHER TAXES SAVE LIVES AND CUT ABUSE
description: TAKE your pick. Either kill programs like the Small Business Administration, Medicare or school lunches for children or raise excise taxes on alcoholic beverages. That is a choice Congress may have to make during the continuing debate on the budget.

title: SAILING TO CITY FESTIVAL, TALL SHIP REACHES U.S.
description: A towering, three-masted ship from Indonesia, two-thirds of the way on an 18,000-mile voyage to New York, sailed into San Diego Harbor today, becoming the first of the international flotilla of tall ships bound for the July 4 Statue of Liberty centennial to make landfall in the continental United States.

title: CABLE TV
description: One durable joy of home-screen film watching is the cavalcade of cameo players - some familiar, some not. Take ''The Gold Rush'' (1925), Charlie Chaplin's classic Klondike caper, and the hirsute, explosive villain, a hulking actor named Mack Swain - Monday at 10 A.M. and 8 P.M., Thursday at 8:30 A.M., Friday at 6:30 A.M.

title: About Men; A Touch of Vanity
description: AND THERE I AM in my third-grade class picture, the girls in white blouses and felt skirts, the boys in striped jerseys and cotton chinos - except for the curly-haired kid in the gabardines, white shirt, bow tie and (oh my god!) suspenders. ''You look like a little twit,'' announced my dear wife, Marilyn. I guess I do, but I recall feeling quite dashing at the time. Those other boys would have fought that outfit to the death. I had picked out the suspenders.

title: CHRISTINA VOTH DILLENBECK WEDS RICHARD S. WOOD
description: Christina Voth Dillenbeck, a daughter of Suzanne Dillenbeck of Locust Valley, L.I., and Richard R. Dillenbeck of Summit, N.J., was married yesterday to Richard Sands Wood. He is a son of the Rev. and Mrs. Hubert S. Wood Jr. of Johnson City, N.Y. The ceremony was performed at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley by the Rev. Charles G. Newbery and the bridegroom's father.

title: L.I. Town Is Proposed As Garbage Plant Site
description: Town officials in North Hempstead, L.I., have proposed a former Port Washington sand pit as the site of a plant that would burn garbage and generate electricity.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: MAPP AND LUCIA, by E. F. Benson. (Perennial/ Harper & Row, $5.95.) E. F. Benson's ''Lucia'' novels, in which the imperious socialite Emmeline (Lucia) Lucas lords it over a retinue of sycophants in two small English villages, garnered an enthusiastic cult following in the 1920's and 30's and now are the basis of a public television series. ''Mapp and Lucia'' (1931), the fourth of the six novels, pits Lucia against the malignant Elizabeth Mapp in a vigorous struggle for social supremacy. When the collected novels were reissued in 1977, Auberon Waugh wrote in The Book Review that Lucia is ''a superbly ridiculous woman'' and that Benson's comedy ''is as exquisite, in its way, as anything in English humorous literature.'' FINAL CUT: Dreams and Disaster in the Making of Heaven's Gate>, by Steven Bach. (Plume/New American Library, $8.95.) In 1980, Michael Cimino's $44 million film ''Heaven's Gate'' was such a monumental flop that it was withdrawn from exhibition; a shorter version fared no better, and the disaster brought down United Artists, which was taken over by M-G-M the following year.

title: PORTER PRESENTATION IS TRIAL'S EXHIBIT A
description: Almost every day in the trial of the United States Football League's antitrust suit against the National Football League, someone refers to an exhibit that is now known as the Porter Presentation.

title: SPRING'S BITTER DELIGHT
description: DANDELIONS HAVE an almost mystical place in the memories of all of us who collected and ate them as children. Now these ancestral favorites are finding wider popularity as a new generation of inventive chefs discovers the dandelion's unique taste and texture.

title: HARRY CHAPIN'S LEGACY: A HUNGER FOR LIFE
description: HARRY CHAPIN, I'm convinced, could have been anything he wanted to be in this life.

title: LYONS HAS SEEN A GHOST
description: UNHEALED WOUNDS France and the Klaus Barbie Affair. By Erna Paris. Illustrated. 252 pp. New York: Grove Press. Cloth, $17.50; Paper, $7.95.

title: COLLEGE GETS FOOD SERVICE PROGRAM
description: EARLY in the day, as students make their way to classes at Passaic County Community College here, the tantalizing aromas of hot biscuits and other baked goods permeate the corridors.

title: A NEW ZIP TO BOTTLED WATER SALES
description: WHEN George T. Rowan delivers bottled water in the financial district here, he likes to point out that the product he sells, at a little more than $5 for a five-gallon jug, now costs more than gasoline. While this surprising statistic reflects the precipitous drop in oil prices, it also indicates the surge in demand for bottled water, which has become the fastest-growing segment of the beverage industry.

title: NEW CASSETTES: BY DE SICA, SUTHERLAND AND THE ROYAL BALLET
description: Joan Sutherland in Concert Accompanied by Richard Bonynge Kultur 49 minutes. $39.95 Since her rise to world prominence some 25 years ago, the soprano Joan Sutherland has proved a remarkably durable artist.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Weekend on Friday misstated the time for the ceremonial relighting of the Fire Island Lighthouse today. The relighting will take place at 9 P.M.

title: DEBATE GROWS ON PAYING FOR SHOREHAM
description: THE State Public Service Commission's new guidelines on how electricity consumers would pay for the Shoreham Nuclear Power Station look markedly different depending on where one stands in the debate over nuclear energy and the future of the Long Island Lighting Company.

title: FROM CRUSADE TO CAMPAIGN IN MICHIGAN
description: WHAT began in Michigan as the first test of strength between Vice President Bush and Representative Jack F. Kemp of New York is now being closely watched for another, at least as significant result: the ability of the Rev. Pat Robertson to mobilize thousands of evangelical Christians as a statewide political force. If his drive here is successful, it could have major implications not only for the 1988 Presidential race but for the future of the Republican Party.

title: CANADIENS DEFEAT FLAMES TO CAPTURE STANLEY CUP
description: The Montreal Canadiens, the team that had been touted as the next Stanley Cup champion even before this series with the playoff upstart Calgary Flames began, won the 1986 National Hockey League championship tonight at the Saddledome with a 4-3 victory. That gave the Canadiens their 23d Stanley Cup.

title: Stop the Religious Persecutions of Voodoo in Haiti
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan Prime Minister Urging Consumption
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone called on the Japanese people today to step up domestic comsumption and give President Reagan ammunition to prevent a protectionist trade bill from passing through Congress.

title: Reagan: A Hand For the Hungry
description: Once again, President Reagan made it clear last week that his main answer to hunger is charity. America's hungry, Mr. Reagan said, suffered not from a lack of aid but from a lack of knowledge about where to get it.

title: Succession To a Lease
description: To the Editor:

title: Elizabeth Nay Plans Winter Wedding
description: Dr. and Mrs. Howard Riley Nay of Tenafly, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Denby Nay to Robert Harrison Schwengel, a son of Franklin D. Schwengel of Santa Monica, Calif., and the late Lynn Kenworthy Schwengel. A January wedding is planned.

title: PAUL J. MAZZILLI IS WED TO SHARON L. PICKETT
description: Sharon L. Pickett, president of Cognitive Concerns Inc., a marketing concern in Scarborough, N.Y., and the owner of Briarpatch, a toy shop in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., was married yesterday to Paul J. Mazzilli, a vice president in the investment banking division of Morgan Stanley & Company in New York. The Rev. Paul Zahl performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Mary's Church in Scarborough.

title: Tia Maggio Weds Kim H. Sperduto, A Law Associate
description: Christina Barrett Maggio, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Maggio of Brooklyn and South Egremont, Mass., was married yesterday to Kim Hoyt Sperduto, a son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Theodore C. Sperduto of Annandale, Va. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Charles A. Bevan Jr., and the bridegroom's father, a Presbyterian minister, at St. John's Episcopal Church in Salisbury, Conn.

title: MORE BANKS ARE SELLING STOCK TO BUILD UP CASH
description: SIX Connecticut savings banks have applied to convert from mutual to stock corporations this year, more than in the first three years such conversions were allowed.

title: WHAT DEMOCRATS MUST DO TO REINSPIRE THE STATE'S VOTERS
description: THE Democratic Party in America is coming to grips with its mission, but not before experiencing major electoral setbacks on the national, state and local levels.

title: ARE INSURERS CAUGHT IN A SQUEEZE OR PUTTING IT ON?
description: WHETHER it has been artifically induced or is the natural product of changing times, there is certainly a liability insurance crisis.

title: Q and A
description: Interim Lease Question: I am considering buying an unoccupied apartment in a rent-stabilized building being converted to cooperative ownership. The sponsor offers interim leases to purchasers of unoccupied apartments who want to move in before the building is converted. But the sponsor disclaims any obligation to renew the interim lease at the end of its term if the plan does not go through. Assuming the building has been under rent stabilization, are such interim leases governed by rent regulations? What are my rights, if any, to a renewal lease? . . . F. D., Roslyn, L.I. Answer: Until the black book is issued the sponsor may not offer the units for sale and therefore may not make an agreement to purchase a condition of rental. After the plan has been accepted for filing, however, it is legal for the sponsor to allow those who have signed purchase agreements to rent their units. If the plan does not go through, the unit would remain under rent-stabilization and the supervision of the state housing agency. David Fishlow, a spokesman for the Attorney General's office, said that as the stabilized tenant you would have the right to a lease renewal.

title:
ART;
OLD MASTERS AND CONTEMPORARY REALISTS AT YALE GALLERY
description: THE featured exhibition at the Yale University Art Gallery strikes one, at first glance, as a tranquil sea of muted colors. One sees black or brown ink washes firmly etched or in free, loopy lines; or, for contrast, white chalk on blue or brown paper. The show bears the prosaic but august title ''Old Master Drawings,'' and ringing in one's ear is the warning, ''a little learning is a dangerous thing.''

title: The Yen's Worth
description: To the Editor:

title: STAMFORD CONDUCTS 4 MODERN WORKS
description: THE end of May is traditionally a quiet time in the world of music, with most of the regular orchestral and choral groups already on vacation and the summer season not yet begun. What welcome news it is, then, that the few concerts on the schedule in the next two weeks bring us music of more than usual interest.

title: KEEPING THE PARTY GOING AT FAST-PACED PEPSICO
description: WHEN D. Wayne Calloway became president of Pepsico Inc.'s Frito-Lay subsidiary in 1976, the Dallas-based company was already flying high. It dominated the snack food industry, boasted a strong management team and had recorded eight consecutive years of profit growth.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: OUR AGING SOCIETY: Paradox and Promise. Edited by Alan Pifer and Lydia Bronte. (Norton, $22.95.) For some time now we have been put on notice that our nation will soon be blundering into demographic terra incognita.

title: HELEN COXE IS A BRIDE
description: Helen Eyre Coxe, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Osborne Coxe of Brunswick, Me., was married yesterday to Edward Drew Cheney, a son of Mrs. Edward Rice Cheney of Bethesda, Md., and the late Mr. Cheney.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''We've broken the back of the trade deficit, at least in the sense that it's not going to go up any more.'' - Richard Peterson, chief economist, Continental Illinois.

title: MISS HORSEY WED TO E. E. BIDDLE, OFFICER OF A BANK
description: Philippa Ridgely Horsey, a daughter of Justice Henry Ridgely Horsey of Dover, Del., and Alexandra Leigh-Hunt of Sag Harbor, L.I., was married yesterday to Edward Elliot Biddle, a son of William Whelen Biddle of Seattle and Barbara Noyes of Durham, N.H. The Rev. Gregory Howe performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Dover, assisted by the Rev. Michael Mayor and the Rev. Craig Biddle 3d, an uncle of the bridegroom.

title: A Producer's Woes
description: To the Editor:

title: Koch Delays Decision On a Rights-Law Curb
description: In an unusual move, Mayor Koch held a bill-signing ceremony Friday but then postponed his decision to sign or veto one of the bills, an amendment to curb the power of the city's homosexual rights law.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: SUZANNE GEER MELHADO AND PHILIP BOLDUC TO WED
description: Suzanne Geer Melhado, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Anderson Melhado of Dorset, Vt., and Philip Bolduc, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Bolduc of Armonk, N.Y., were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents by the Rev. Cass Gilbert 3d, a Methodist minister.

title: DR. POPPE WEDS MARK TREMALLO, BOSTON LAYWER
description: The Memorial Church at Harvard University was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Dr. Wellner Anne Poppe, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Walker Poppe of Huntington, L.I., Durham, N.C., and Acapulco, Mexico, to Mark Van Bael Tremallo. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Gene Tremallo of Exeter, N.H. The Rev. John Boles, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Philippine Bus Crash Kills 23
description: A bus fell from a 50-foot cliff in the southern Philippines, igniting an explosion that killed 23 people, officials said. Sgt. Rolando Geroche, a military spokesman in Iloilo Province, said the accident occurred Friday near the village of Igbugacay in Antique Province, 260 miles south of Manila. Fifteen passengers were injured, he said.

title: KAREN UPTON PLANS TO WED NEXT MONTH
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald Allen Upton of Lunenburg, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Karen Marie Upton to James Kendrick Noble 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James Kendrick Noble Jr. of Bronxville, N.Y. A June 21 wedding is planned.

title: POLISHING THE APPLE'S IMAGE
description: FOR Roscoe Crist, a snowy haired apple grower in New York's Hudson Valley, the first weekend in May was an unusually frightening one. Temperatures plunged below 30 degrees, threatening to ruin the fluffy, delicate blossoms that covered the apple groves like a pinkish-white blanket. Growers wandered all night through their orchards, hooking up rows of heaters on the ground and hovering overhead in helicopters to force the warm air earthward.

title: COLOMBIA PICKS CHIEF TODAY AFTER LONG CAMPAIGN
description: Colombians will vote Sunday to pick a successor to President Belisario Betancur after a lengthy campaign.

title: THE COST OF CANCELING
description: With bookings for Europe and the eastern Mediterranean way down in the wake of terrorist attacks and threats, this spring has been notable for widespread cancellations of tours and cruises there, sometimes sorely disrupting the plans of Americans who still want to go. In most cases refunds have been available for payments already made although many operators have tried to avoid them by offering alternative departure dates for the same tour or incentives to travel with the same company to someplace else. If a passenger decides, however, to drop out of a tour that is operating as scheduled, or to cancel hotel or transportation arrangements that have already been paid for, substantial financial penalties may be imposed.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
IT'S A LONG TRADITION
description: The British Royal Mint will commemorate a long coinage tradition with a special exhibition in London. The month-long exhibition will mark the completion of 1,100 years of government minting. One of the star attractions will be an example of the coin that started it all: the famous ''monogram penny'' of Alfred the Great.

title: THINKING THE UNTHINKABLE: NO GARDEN
description: TO sow or not to sow - that is the question.

title: AIRLINES OFFER MANY ENTICEMENTS TO LURE TRAVELERS ABROAD
description: Free tickets, champagne, caviar and increased security against terrorists are a few of the enticements airlines are using to lure reluctant Americans to travel abroad.

title: Just Unfunded Is Justice Undone
description: Our judicial system has come a long way since the age of Solomon, when justice was meted out by an omniscient judge based upon his intuitive feelings of fairness. Today, the Federal judiciary is a well-oiled machine that depends on thousands of support personnel to justly resolve disputes. This sophisticated apparatus safeguards the liberties vouchsafed us by the Bill of Rights, reviews legislative decisions that affect our lives and protects the community from terrorists and mobsters.

title: A Close Encounter In Connecticut
description: Former United States Representative Toby Moffett's race for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination in Connecticut ran into trouble last week in Waterbury. Under the state's complex rules, Mr. Moffett fell just 48 votes short in his effort to force a statewide primary against Gov. William A. O'Neill.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: COLONIAL FURNITURE Dipping into its packed vaults, the East Hampton Historical Society opens its summer season today at the Clinton Academy with ''William E. Wheelock: Legacy of a Colonial Revival Mind.'' Wheelock was a turn-of-the-century collector intent upon creating and maintaining an idyllic country home steeped in objects that revealed the romantic virtues of the past, a simpler age free of industrialization and urbanization. He assembled a wide array of furniture and decorative art objects that remained in his East Hampton home until his son, the poet John Hall Wheelock, donated the lot to the society in 1977. The exhibition can be seen at the academy, 151 Main Street, from 1 to 5 P.M. weekends through June and then daily, except Mondays, through August. Admission is $1, 75 cents for senior citizens, and 50 cents for children.

title: Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: SENATE

title: Flynn to Leave Senate After 20 Years' Service
description: A tearful State Senator John E. Flynn of Yonkers announced today that he would not run for office again, ending a 20-year political career in Albany and opening the way for a struggle over what he had established as a safe Republican seat.

title:
GARDENING;
FERTILIZER: TOO LITTLE OR TOO MUCH IS BAD
description: CONSUMERS spend large sums of money on fertilizer each year. In some areas, notably Long Island, excessive fertilizer application is threatening the water supply by contaminating it with nitrogen. Is it necessary to fertilize lawns and gardens, and, if so, how does one go about it in a reasonable way?

title: MISS GEBHARDT WEDS
description: The marriage of Elisabeth Reading Gebhardt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Evans Gebhardt of Sewickley, Pa., to Thomas William Turner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. R. Melvin Turner of Salem, Va., took place yesterday. The Rev. George Wirth performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Church of Sewickley. The bride is an assistant to the director of admissions at Hollins College of which she is an alumna. Mr. Turner, territorial manaager for Stop In Food Stores Inc., in Roanoke, Va., attended Virginia Polytechnic Institute.

title: JOHNSON & JOHNSON GIFT FINANCING MEDICAL-TECHNOLOGY WORK
description: SOME of the $7.5 million that Johnson & Johnson, the New Brunswick-based health-care products company, donated to medical research and public-interest projects last month to mark its 100th anniversary already is paying for sophisticated technology programs.

title: 'Bigfoot Dreams'
description: In the murky gloom of much contemporary fiction, one seems always to be following the fate of an aging, alcoholic writer, an unfulfilled Manhattan wife or a troubled survivor of the 1960's. Francine Prose offers lively alternatives. In six previous novels, she has set out exuberantly onto roads less taken, winding between myth and reality, exploring the legends with which people give meaning to their lives. In ''Judah the Pious'' (1973), a rabbi unravels an unpredictable tale of dreams and disguises. In ''Hungry Hearts'' (1983), a capricious dybbuk possesses the heroine. Invoking the supernatural with humor and sympathy, Miss Prose reveals the wonder at the heart of everyday life. As someone ruefully remarks in ''Household Saints'' (1981), ''Maybe the burning bush was burning all the time and Moses didn't notice. Maybe the miracle is when you stop and pay attention.''

title: CABARET: SONGS OF THE 1920'S
description: FOR Cathy Chamberlain, her performance at Upstairs at Greene Street Thursday evening was both an introduction and a nostalgic look to the past. It was her first formal engagement in the company of the pianist Dick Wellstood.

title: PRO AND CON: SETTING LIMITS ON LAWSUITS AND LAWYERS
description: Under the Administration's liability package, the Federal Government and its contractors would be protected against awards for pain and suffering and punitive damages greater than $100,000. Private companies would be similarly protected for harm caused by their products by the setting of the first national standards for product liability. Fees for plaintiffs' lawyers would be limited. Richard K. Willard, Assistant Attorney General for the Civil Division, and Robert Hunter, president of the National Insurance Consumer Organization and former Federal Insurance Administrator, discussed the plan and its implications recently. Excerpts follow.

title: Daniel Nelson Adams Jr. Is Wed to Camilla Siglow
description: Camilla Sloat Siglow, a marketing vice president of the Learning Pyramid, a consulting firm in Redding, Conn., and Daniel Nelson Adams Jr., the company's president and founder, were married yesterday at Christ Church in Redding. The Rev. Stephen Parker officiated at the Episcopal ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Leland Hunt.

title: SHARED PATIENT ROOMS IN HOSPITALS SHOULD BECOME A PRACTICE OF THE PAST
description: WOULD any sensible person in good health accept a motel room if he were told at the check-in desk that he would be sharing a room with a stranger, a member of the same sex, matched by no acceptable method, and that the stranger might snore, smell, cough and smoke, be uncouth or obnoxious - or, perhaps all those things?

title: Renata Soltys Is Married to an Investment Banker
description: Renata Anna Wypijewska Soltys, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dionizy Wypijewski of Chicago, was married yesterday to Count Guillaume Pascal de Dalmas, the son of Mrs. Roger Lehideux of Paris and the late Jean de Dalmas, at a Roman Catholic church ceremony in St. Barthelemy, the French West Indies.

title: BEYOND RIOJA
description: LIKE SPAIN, WHOSE TER-rain seems linked to the Continent as an afterthought, Spanish table wine occupies a distant corner of awareness. Rioja, the consumer knows, is there somewhere. But Catalonia, Ribera del Duero, Rueda? Virtually terra incognita.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: HER NATIVE COLORS. By Elisabeth Hyde. (Delacorte, $15.95.) In one of Aesop's fables, a country mouse visits a city mouse for dinner; his friend's hectic urban life gives the country mouse indigestion and he abruptly leaves, vowing to be content with the familiar comforts of his own hole.

title: THE PHONE RINGS. IT'S 2 A.M. 'HI, MOM?'
description: IT has come to my attention that parents aren't quite as sad as they used to be when grown children leave home. Oh, mothers and dads wring their hands, wipe their eyes and open doors to vacated rooms with nostalgia, but it just doesn't strike me as being as genuine a loss as it was in the past.

title: WENDY TEMPRO WED TO GEORGE VAN AMSON
description: Wendy Alicia Tempro, a nutritionist, and George Louis Van Amson, a vice president of Goldman, Sachs & Company, were married yesterday at Riverside Church in New York by the Rev. Fanny Erickson, a Presbyterian minister.

title: LITERARY AGENTS: ROLE IS CHANGING
description: ONE OF the major changes in the book business in the last 20 years has been the increasing role of literary agents; more and more publishers and editors have come to rely on them to develop new talent.

title: MOWATT IS RETURNING TO FORM
description: Last August, against the Pittsburgh Steelers in the final preseason game, Zeke Mowatt of the Giants suffered torn ligaments in the right knee. He underwent surgery and missed the entire season, and only now is regaining the form that had made him one of the National Football League's premier tight ends.

title: Sculpture Goes Public
description: Douglas McGill's article on public sculpture failed to mention that Susan Child, a Boston landscape architect, was an equal, third partner in the South Cove project at Battery Park City, along with Mary Miss (sculptor) and Stan Eckstut (architect). In fact, Mr. McGill's article ignored altogether the enormous impact of landscape architecture on current developments in public sculpture.

title: BRADLEY AIRPORT POINTS WITH PRIDE TO ITS NEW TERMINAL
description: ON Wednesday, Robert F. Juliano hopes to prove the skeptics wrong.

title: Atlanta: Plan to Unearth Underground
description: BEGINNING in the late 1960's, tourists, conventioneers and local residents made Underground Atlanta one of the nation's most popular urban entertainment districts. Set amid an abandoned railroad and warehouse district near downtown that had been covered over by highway viaducts in the 1920's, the area drew thousands of people nightly to its rows of 19th century brick-front restaurants, shops and bars.

title: CANCER UP IN CITIES, NEW ATLAS SHOWS
description: CONNECTICUT'S cities have a significantly higher per capita incidence of cancer than do rural areas, according to the Connecticut Cancer Atlas, the first compiled in the state.

title: Sunday Observer; Breakfast Visitors
description: HERE ARE THE newspaper movie ads on a typical May morning in New York.

title: Working Profile: Robert M. McGlotten; Pacing the Corridors for the A.F.L.-C.I.O.
description: It is evening in the Capitol, and Robert M. McGlotten, chief lobbyist for the A.F.L.-C.I.O., emerges briskly from a closed meeting with Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Ways and Means Committee chairman.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: A FUNNY thing has happened to status. Ask anyone sporting Paloma Picasso earrings, a Chanel bracelet, a Bulgari neck ring, a Cartier pen, a Mark Cross handbag and Maud Frizon shoes, and they'll tell you they actually don't give a fig about status, what's in and out, or any of that nonsense.

title: BARRIER SCIENCE & TECHOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Dr. Willa Hsueh Wed in California
description: Dr. Willa Ann Hsueh, the daughter of Chao Wong Hsueh of Cincinnati and Greta Yu of Columbus, Ohio, was married yesterday to Dr. Orrin Marshall Troum, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Nathan F. Troum of Wayside, N.J. Rabbi Zvi Dershowitz performed the ceremony at Temple Sinai in Westwood, Calif.

title: Kathryn C. Dickinson Is the Bride of John F. Istel
description: Kathryn Clegg Dickinson, the daughter of Mary Eugenia Dickinson of Worthington, Ohio, and the late Dr. Beeford Dickinson, was married yesterday to John Francis Istel, the son of Yves-Andre Istel of New York and Maureen Congdon of WiltonConn.

title: WINSTON MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued opereations of $59,000.

title: STAGE: FROM SHANLEY, 'WOMEN OF MANHATTAN'
description: It is the blindest of dates. A man and a woman meet in a cafe at midnight. He is black, she is white. He is a handsome womanizer, she has a problem relating to heterosexual men. The matchmaker, his former mistress, is also one of her best friends. The two begin by being antagonistic but are soon hitting it off romantically. The playwright, John Patrick Shanley, has written the scene succinctly with a certain off-the-wall humor. It is surrounded, however, by other scenes that are off-the-wall, but with less humor.

title: BAKER COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DANZIG CONNECTION IS WINNER
description: Danzig Connection and Clear Choice ran head and head for almost every step of the Peter Pan Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday before finishing three-quarters of a length apart in that order. Danzig Connection's triumph gave his sire, Danzig; Woody Stephens and Henryk de Kwiatkowski their second Grade I stakes victory in two days, and may have provided Stephens with a small chance at winning a fifth straight Belmont Stakes.

title: DEFIANCE PRECISION reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
CARE PLUS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
LIKE DYNASTY DAYS FOR TWO OLD PROS
description: WHEN the game ended and the Stanley Cup, which they had sensed but never predicted would return to Montreal this year, was theirs, Larry Robinson and Bob Gainey searched for each other in the crush of bodies celebrating on the ice.

title: INDY IS A TALK SHOW
description: THE finish was the closest in the history of the Indianapolis 500, with Gordon Johncock edging Rick Mears. Thrilling - and four years old. What was to be the first live network telecast of the nation's premier auto race became instead television's longest pregame show yesterday as rain delayed, delayed and, finally, forced a postponement of this year's race. For more than five and one-half hours, ABC Sports tried gamely to make a go of it, showing us fresh faces and old tapes, before race officials announced the postponement, until today, at about 4:40 P.M.

title: CHARLOTTE CHARLES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CONSOLIDATED HYDRO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: There are no comparable figures because the company went public on March 18, 1986.

title: BALLET THEATER: 2 CASTS IN 'ROMEO AND JULIET'
description: Sir Kenneth MacMillan's ''Romeo and Juliet'' was decently danced and capably acted by the American Ballet Theater in two performances on Saturday, led in the afternoon by Bonnie Moore and John Turjoman, and in the evening by Leslie Browne and Ross Stretton.

title: TRIANGLE MICROWAVE INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Shifts Sought At Latin Bank
description: THE Reagan Administration is still playing hard ball with the Inter-American Development Bank, the principal lender of development funds to Latin America. The Administration wants the bank to make its loans conditional on market-oriented policy shifts, such as more divestment of public enterprises, faster deregulation and greater liberalization of trade policies.

title: TV: MAORI ART AND CULTURE ON 31
description: When ''Te Maori'' opened its American tour at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in September 1984, it was apparent that this was not a conventional show. A group of Maoris - the indigenous people of New Zealand -arrived at the museum at dawn, some in tribal dress, and enacted a ceremony to protect and inaugurate the exhibition. Their presence and concern discouraged any attempt to approach the objects in esthetic terms alone.

title: SBE INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $98,000 and $167,000 for quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $67,000 and $108,000 for quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: BOOK CONVENTION ACCENTUATES POSITIVE
description: Hope may not spring eternal in the breasts of the nation's booksellers and publishers, but at least once a year it breaks loose at the exuberant four-day convention of the American Booksellers Association, which began Saturday.

title: YALE UNIVERSITY: LAST SPEECH FOR GIAMATTI AS PRESIDENT
description: In his last formal words as president of Yale University, A. Bartlett Giamatti addressed a baccalaureate ceremony today marked by protest pickets and urged graduating students to beware the ''tyranny of group self-righteousness.''

title: BIOTECHNICA INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company's stocks are traded on the Boston Stock Exchange.

title: TIME IS RIPE FOR ROOKIES
description: GENE MAUCH says he has neither the time nor the intelligence to figure it out, but he would like someone who has both to investigate his germ of an idea about why baseball is enjoying the greatest influx of impressive rookies in memory.

title: Kitty B. Hanna Is Married To John Hunt Marshall 3d
description: Kitty B. Hanna, a photographer, and John Hunt Marshall 3d, an antiques dealer and restorer, were married yesterday at Apple Knoll Farm in Millis, Mass. Abbott Jon Aidan of St. Andrews Abbey in Santa Fe, N.M., an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: NOVUS PROPERTY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
YANKEES AGAIN OVERCOME ERROR TO TOP ANGELS
description: The scenario threatens to become a daily affair, but the Yankees would prefer taking their victories with slightly more ease.

title: URANIUM MINING Vs. GRAND CANYON
description: Until recently uranium mining seemed about as promising a business here on the Colorado River plateau as grazing steers in Central Park, but the discovery of some rich uranium ore deposits along the border of the Grand Canyon National Park is changing that.

title: CONTINENTAL VISIONARY: KENNETH ALLAN KRAGEN
description: For Ken Kragen, the talent manager and promoter who orchestrated the Hands Across America event, staging spectacles for charity is nothing new. Mr. Kragen also headed USA for

title: PAMELA TOBEY, ARTIST, MARRIES R. S. DUNHAM
description: Pamela Ann Tobey, a graphic artist for The Washington Post, and Richard Scott Dunham, a reporter in the Washington bureau of The Dallas Times Herald, were married yesterday at Cliveden, a Colonial manor in Philadelphia. Thacher Longstreth, a Philadelphia city councilman, officiated at the Quaker ceremony.

description: International

title: A Boy Is Killed in Fall From Stalled Elevator
description: A 5-year-old Brooklyn boy plunged to his death in an elevator shaft in an apartment building last night when the elevator car stalled between the fourth and fifth floors and he tried to climb to the lower floor, the police said.

SYSTEMS ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30

What if an Army Were Camped Along Our Border?
description: To the Editor:

title: Memorial Day Closings
description: All United States stock and commodity markets are closed today in observance of Memorial Day. Banks, Government offices and many businesses also will be closed. The Government's weekly Treasury bill auction will be Tuesday.

title: Now, That's Loyalty
description: Longtime Washington observers will certify that even the most serious cause can sometimes produce an unpredictable ardency among its constituents. A driver passing the Pentagon the other day spotted a white Corvette bearing a bumper sticker that read: ''I H Defense Spending.''

title: 1,000 CHURCHES RISE IN POLAND ADDING GRACES OF AVANT-GARDE
description: Amid the state-built housing and office blocks of Poland, there are now close to a thousand new, innovative buildings rising, spiraling and sprawling. And all of them are Roman Catholic churches.

title: SI HANDLING SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Year to March 2
description: b-Includes a tax credit in foreign subsidiaries of $374,000. c-Includes an extraordinary credit of $657,000 from termination of a salaried pension plan.

title: MARYMOUNT COLLEGE: CUOMO SPEAKS UP FOR NEEDY
description: Governor Cuomo urged 260 graduating seniors at Marymount College today to enjoy the fruits of their success, but not to forget those less fortunate.

title: MAXXAM GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and includes an extraordinary tax credit of $200,000, or 2 cents a share. The company said it had investment income in the latest first quarter of $26,948,000, compared with $4,963,000 in the year-ago quarter. This latest quarter's investment income includes pre-tax gains of about $21 million on the sale of significant holdings of common stock in two public companies. The latest quarter also reflects interest expense and amortization of financing costs of $28,447,000, principally in connection with the indebtedness incurred in the acquisition of Pacific Lumber Co.'s forest products division.

title: Lilac and Other Memorials
description: Living veterans have their holiday in mid-November but will be marching today with high school bands in tribute to servicemen and women who didn't come back. Originally Memorial Day commemorated the dead of the Civil War - which still ranks as our most traumatic because at no other time in the past century and a half have American civilians experienced war at first hand - and it comes at the ripest moment of spring when all the birds have returned, from the earliest killdeer to the tardiest bobolink, and when the vegetable kingdom (as children might say) is in frantic adolescence. Spring, which began as a circle of thawing bare ground around the base of maple trees, is heavy with lilac scent and manic with red-eyed vireos, birds crying out 20,000 times in a day.

title: WICHITA INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax writedown of oil and gas revenue of $5,550,000 The year-ago results were restated to reflect disposal of a segment.

title: TV: 'ROANOAK,' 3-PART SERIES, ON 13
description: The three-part series ''Roanoak,'' beginning tonight at 9 on WNET/Channel 13, is an admirably ambitious project that has had the good sense to work imaginatively within its production limitations. There are no stars. Filming was done on only two locations: near Myrtle Beach, S.C., and in Richmond, where a restored Tudor house, Agecroft Hall, became the English estate of Sir Walter Raleigh. The budget, put together through a dizzying list of grantors and underwriters, is clearly modest. Yet, ''Roanoak'' is quietly, consistently compelling as it sets about telling the story of a village that, in the late 16th century, vanished from the face of the earth.

title: Thurmond's Flexibility
description: Flexibility is one of the major secrets of survival in American public life, so it shouldn't surprise anyone that Senator Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, at 83 years of age, has been proving remarkably politically agile of late. After all, he is the only man ever to serve as Democratic Governor and Senator, run for President on a third-party ticket (carrying four states), switch parties and serve as a Republican Senator for more than 20 years.

title: FITCH FINDS OLD HABITS HARD TO BREAK
description: MOST coaches are creatures of habit, often to humorous extremes. Bill Fitch, for example, learned some time ago that if something works, no matter how eccentric or inane it seems, then stick with it.

title: VISUAL TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A Standout Stepper
description: Nothing quite prepared Virginia Reed for the reaction she got when she took up race-walking last year and, in training excursions around her Upper West Side neighborhood, adopted the sport's exaggerated, hip-swiveling gait with its long, bent-elbow arm swings. ''Kids think it's a riot,'' she says. ''Teen-agers mimic me. And even babies in carriages react; they're used to runners, but when they see me they lift their arms.''

title: NEWSPRINT OUTLOOK UNCERTAIN
description: Although several newsprint companies are reported to be considering price rises for this fall, slow growth in demand at newspapers, increased foreign competition and widespread price cutting may delay any increases by North American producers in the near term.

description: Among the major problems facing Soviet authorities in the aftermath of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster is the future of tens of thousands of people displaced by the accident.

description: Some say it is about 86 years too late, but on July 1 the University of Rochester will open a women's studies center named for Susan B. Anthony, who in 1900 forced the university trustees to begin to admit women.

description: President Corazon C. Aquino today named 45 people from diverse political and religious groups to a body that will draft a new Philippine constitution.

Autopsy Shows Bullet Killed Brooklyn Boy, 5
description: A 5-year-old boy who died Saturday after being struck in the head by an object outside his Brooklyn home was killed by a bullet that lodged in his brain, according to the results of an autopsy released yesterday by the city Medical Examiner.

title: Eduardo Gonzalez Gallarza; Was Air Minister for Franco
description: Lieut. Gen. Eduardo Gonzalez Gallarza, an early aviator who was Air Minister in the Franco regime, died Saturday of an intestinal hemorrhage, his family said.

Arcaro Surgery
description: Eddie Arcaro, the former jockey, remained in serious condition today while recovering from a five-hour operation on his heart, officials at the Heart Institute said. Arcaro, 70 years old, underwent surgery on Friday and is expected to be hospitalized for at least two weeks. He was described as awake and alert in the intensive care unit.

title: WEST GERMAN STEEL REVIVES
description: After several tough years, West Germany's powerful steel industry is in the midst of a remarkable comeback.

title: OPEC Ends Strategy Talks
description: Six ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries formally ended talks here today, and Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani of Saudi Arabia said they had reached an agreement to be announced during a full session of the 13-nation organization next month.

title: Taiwan Landslide Kills 14 And Buries About 25
description: A landslide crashed down on about 120 Taiwanese tourists in a scenic gorge in central Taiwan today, killing 14 of them, burying about 25 others and injuring 28, the police reported.

title: PENN STATE TAKES TRACK MEET BY A POINT
description: Villanova started the day trailing Penn State, 49-0. Still, the host Wildcats had an opportunity to win the team title as the 110th annual IC4A outdoor track and field championships ended. Instead, Villanova threw it away, and Penn State won by a point.

title: CITY BALLET: 'WHO CARES?'
description: When the New York City Ballet danced George Balanchine's ''Who Cares?'' on Saturday afternoon at the New York State Theater, a new cast of soloists took over the leading roles in this suite to orchestrated songs of Gershwin. The performance's pleasures included those of watching unfamiliar dancers in familiar roles and of seeing the company preserve a continuity of tradition.

title: 20 MILLION RUN TO RAISE MONEY FOR THE STARVING IN AFRICA
description: With 200,000 Londoners setting the pace, more than 20 million runners in 76 countries ran today in Sport Aid, a global benefit to raise money for the starving of Africa.

title: Outstandingly Wins
