Outstandingly finished a head in front of La Koumia, with the favored Estrapade another head back in third.

title: Knight Absent
description: Ray Knight flew home to Georgia on Saturday to join his wife, Nancy Lopez, the golfing star, who was expecting their second child. He planned to rejoin the Mets on Tuesday. . . . Gary Carter, who had caught in 35 of the team's 37 games, got a day off to rest his knees.

title: HE'S NOT DR. L
description: ROGER CRAIG, the manager of the San Francisco Giants who as a Mets right-hander in 1963 lost 18 consecutive games, can't understand the commotion. Up in the big bullpen in the sky, neither can Clifton Curtis, who lost 23 straight games with the Boston Braves from early in the 1910 season through early in the 1911 season. Neither can Bob Groom of the 1909 Washington Senators and John Nabors of the 1916 Philadelphia A's, who each lost 19 straight.

Vinia Tsopelas, Pianist
description: The pianist Vinia Tsopelas will make her New York recital debut on Tuesday at 8 P.M. in Alice Tully Hall.

title: Jonathan Mark Is Wed To Kathleen Munguia
description: B. Kathleen Munguia and Jonathan I. Mark, both graduates of the Columbia University School of Law who practice in New York, were married yesterday at La Mansion del Rio Hotel in San Antonio. Tom Vickers, a judge in Bexar County, Tex., officiated.

title: 'TIE THAT BINDS' ONE TROUBLED TOWN
description: For days before the actual events of today produced a broken line but a triumph of the family spirit, the feeling about joining Hands Across America had been growing in the rich farmland around this county seat, 15 miles east of the Mississippi.

title: ISRAEL DEBATES CHARGING 'SENIOR AIDE'
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's visit to Israel was overshadowed today by a dispute between Prime Minister Shimon Peres and Attorney General Yitzhak Zamir over whether to prosecute an unidentified ''senior official'' of the Israeli Government.

title: FOLLOWING IN MOTHER'S FOOTSTEPS
description: If one is 6 years old or younger, very few things beat an outing with Mom. It gives a small person a chance to look at the world in good company, to hold hands with someone special and, once in a while, to dress up.

title: BELLWETHER EXPLORATION COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Under Ervin's Table
description: At least six eavesdropping devices were installed under tables in the Senate Dining Room when the committee headed by Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. was investigating the Watergate burglary and the involvement of President Nixon and his aides, according to a witness who has now come forward. One of those bugs was hidden under the table at which Senator Ervin customarily took meals.

title: AT CARNEGIE, OLD PAPERS AND DEBRIS
description: Seen through a fog of plaster dust, the most prominent objects on Carnegie Hall's august stage Friday morning were two empty cardboard boxes. The hall has been closed a week - the first of 28 set aside for restoration of this historic concert auditorium. Not only are the seats already gone, but the vinyl tile and wood foundation below them as well. Now only the ribs show, to be covered eventually with a new wooden floor and refurbished seating.

title: 'Why Me?' And, 'Why Them?'
description: ''Why me?''

title: Sooner Summer for Fun and Profit
description: Sales of charcoal briquettes could glow brighter by $42 million and golf ball sales would bounce up about $25 million. Dealers in shrubs, plants and lawn food predict a lush growth of $250 million and 7-11 convenience stores think they can sack an additional $15 million.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday: Memorial Day. Tuesday: None. Wednesday: None. Thursday: Leading Indicators...April.

title: HEALTH INFORMATION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NO REST YET ON SNOW CHIEF'S SCHEDULE
description: When Snow Chief goes to the post in the Jersey Derby at Garden State Park today, it will be his third start this month and his 13th in a row without a vacation from racing. If he wins, he will stay in training and may make as many as seven more starts this year, then go right into the Strub Series for older horses at Santa Anita next winter.

title: BAYOU RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
20 REPORTED SLAIN IN SRI LANKA RAID
description: Witnesses and army officials said today that Tamil guerrillas had killed 20 Sinhalese settlers in this jungle hamlet, including 10 children, many by gunshots at point-blank range.

title: Cityfed Mortgage Promotes 2 Officials
description: Youth is being served at the senior echelons of the Cityfed Mortgage Company. On Friday the company elected John W. Delaney, 38 years old and currently its president and chief executive, to be chairman and chief executive. Jonathan P. Gabriel, 32, was named president and chief operating officer.

title: PICCASO'S DOCUMENTED IMAGINATION
description: Like any form of art, notebooks provide a way of preserving something - an idea, a dream, a phrase overheard on the street, a glimpse of a stranger or a friend. They provide a way of appropriating something from the physical world - and by saving and perhaps rearranging its elements, making it one's own. W. H. Auden used his commonplace book (published as ''A Certain World'') as a sort of manual of inspiration, hoarding quotations and observations there, as though, like Proust's famous madeleine, they might later serve to unlock all sorts of memories and sensations. E. M. Forster, on the other hand, used his notebook more as a confessional, confiding to it his own worries, crotchets and fears; while F. Scott Fitzgerald seems to have used his as a bank vault for future projects, filling its pages with outtakes from abandoned stories, ideas for possible novels.

title: Anti-Nuclear Protesters Freed in New Hampshire
description: The state police today released 74 antinuclear demonstrators who had been arrested in protests Saturday at the Seabrook nuclear power plant.

title: Mark Lundy, Law Student, Wed to Lisa Beth Brinberg
description: Lisa Beth Brinberg, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Simeon Brinberg of Roslyn, L.I., and Mark Harris Lundy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Lundy of Bay Harbor Island, Fla., were married yesterday.

title: ADVANCED TOBACCO PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago sales figures are not applicable because the company hadn't begun marketing its product.

title: COLGATE UNIVERSITY: CAREY OPPOSES PROPOSED CUT IN STUDENT AID
description: Former Gov. Hugh L. Carey told 630 Colgate University graduates today that proposed Federal cutbacks in student aid were ''unconscionable'' and would hurt about 3 million of the 5 million current aid recipients.

title: OPERA: 'LORD BYRON' AND 'RENARD' AT FESTIVAL
description: ''Lord Byron's Love Letter'' is something of an anomaly among operas, in that it is better known for its librettist than its composer. If ''Lord Byron'' is dicussed at all it is usually as the ''Tennessee Williams opera'' - the only libretto the playwright produced in his long career. All of which is somewhat unfair to the composer, Raffaello de Banfield, who deserves equal credit for the work's obscurity. For ''Lord Byron,'' while obviously the work of two gifted men, is a pretty bad opera.

title: MECHTRON INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
METS DEFEAT PADRES, 4-2, IN 11
description: The Mets ended an 11-game four-city trip to the West Coast today by beating the San Diego Padres, 4-2, in 11 innings. And they did it with a strange mix of tricks that symbolized their ability to scrounge, and that included three walks, three stolen bases, two squeeze bunts that went foul and one wild pitch that won the game.

title: PRETORIA DIVESTMENT QUICKENS
description: The pace of withdrawal from South Africa by American companies has quickened, as some of the biggest corporations in the United States reconsider doing business in the economically and politically troubled country.

title: BIRD WILL FIND A WAY
description: ON the night of April 29 when Roger Clemens of the Red Sox struck out 20 Seattle batters to establish a major-league record, Larry Bird said, ''I could get a hit off him.''

title: DOLLAR'S RALLY HAS SKEPTICS
description: Recent upticks in interest rates and some signs that the pace of economic activity may be quickening in the United States have helped to bolster the dollar lately, but most foreign exchange traders and international economists do not expect the recent rally to last more than a month or so.

title: VIDEO LIBRARY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
UNIMED INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

description: b-Net income

title: BIRDIES HELP SUTTON CAPTURE MEMORIAL
description: Hal Sutton was never seriously threatened during the final round of the 11th annual Memorial Tournament as Jack Nicklaus staged a thrilling six-birdie charge on the back nine that proved to be too little too late.

title: MEESE CRITICIZES CUSTOMS CHIEF OVER MEXICO
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d sharply criticized the head of the United States Customs Service today for charging Mexican Government involvement in drug trafficking.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: HARBOR MASTER - On the last day of a three-day holiday weekend there are few if any offbeat cultural events, few out-of-the-way gems. What predominates are if-you're-in-the-neighborhood nuggets. Strolling through the South Street Seaport? At the museum, 207 Front Street, 55 years of New York harbor history are depicted in the exhibition ''Harbor Witness: The Lithographs of John A. Noble.'' Between 1928 and 1983, Mr. Noble recorded the harbor's changes. He saw sails replaced by steam and schooners give way to container ships.

title: MET-PRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Elizabeth Laporte and Carl Oshiro, Lawyers, Wed
description: Elizabeth Duncan Laporte and Carl Kiyoshi Oshiro, both public-interest lawyers in San Francisco, were married yesterday at Lyford House in Tiburon, Calif. The ceremony was performed by Federal Judge Marilyn Hall Patel of the Northern District of California, for whom the bride was a law clerk in 1983.

title: TAX SETBACK IS FEARED BY COMMODITY TRADERS
description: Commodity traders, long a powerful lobbying force in Washington, may suffer a setback if the Senate Finance Committee's version of tax revision becomes law.

title: Tripoli Raid of 1815 Was Libya Precedent
description: To the Editor:

title: RINKER WINS BY 3
description: Laurie Rinker shot a 66 and took advantage of a collapse by Beth Daniel today to come from five strokes back and win the $250,000 Corning Classic by three strokes with a 10-under-par 278 total.

title: 30,000 ARE ROUTED FROM THEIR HOMES NEAR CAPE TOWN
description: As many as 30,000 people are said to have been made refugees in their own land and more than 30 have died in a week of violence pitting conservative black vigilantes against loyalists of radical black leaders in this squatter camp near Cape Town.

title: Chief Resigns At Clark
description: James R. Rinehart, chairman and chief executive of the Clark Equipment Company, has resigned his positions at the troubled truck and agriculture machinery maker, which is undergoing a restructuring program.

title: BIG CHANGES LOOM IN FINAL TAX BILL, LAWMAKERS AGREE
description: Leading members of the Senate and House of Representatives agree that the Senate Finance Committee's tax-revision bill will be changed substantially before it can become law.

title: Must Bikini's Veterans Be Outcasts?
description: Everyone knows that at the Bikini bomb tests of 1946, American ships and sailors took a bath, a real hot tub of atomic radiation. Forty years later, the Government is still trying to wipe away the memories. What most people don't know is that we Bikini veterans -those with possible atomic bomb diseases - are outcasts. We are refused admission to Veterans Administration hospitals. We are denied any disability pensions. We can't even get at our records - most were lost, so the story goes, in a warehouse fire in St. Louis.

title: SUBWAY SCHEMES; Beaver Pride
description: In lower Manhattan, however, the Transit Authority and Committee for Astor Place, a group of local merchants and civic leaders, demonstrate the enlightened approach to subway renovation. Shiny apples all around.

title: TO-FITNESS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
VARI-CARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
S&M COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Buyout Group Stock Offering
description: The first public stock offering of a company specializing in leveraged buyouts has been announced by the Prospect Group, which is offering 10 million shares at $9.75 a share, through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc.

title: In Sunglasses, Darkness Is Not Enough
description: To the Editor:

title: WHEN A SIBLING IS DISABLED
description: ONE day, when she was only 8 years old, Marilyn Jaffe-Ruiz remembers becoming so irritated with her mentally retarded younger brother, Joel, that she screamed at him, calling him an ''idiot.'' Her anguish was compounded when her parents scolded her for the outburst.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, MAY 26, 1986
description: The Economy The Senate Finance Committee's tax bill faces major changes before it can become law, Senate and House members agree. Conferees from the House will have at least as much say in shaping the final product as those from the Senate, they say. [ Page 1. ] Commodity traders could suffer a setback because of a provision in the bill that would affect a taxation system Congress set up in 1981 especially for the commodity business. [ 31. ] The dollar's recent rally will be short lived, most foreign exchange traders and international economists say, pointing to continued American trade deficits. [ 27. ] Federal Reserve and Treasury officials are in disagreement over whether commercial companies, other than bank holding companies, should be permitted to own banks. The dispute has been heightened by a $100 million lawsuit against Sears. [ 27. ] The insider-trading case against Dennis B. Levine has entered a lull as both sides gather information to support their cases. [ 29. ] Newsprint companies may delay price increases because of slow growth in demand and increased foreign competition. [ 29. ] International The pace of withdrawal from South Africa by American companies has quickened. [ 27. ] West Germany's steel industry is in the midst of a remarkable comeback after several tough years of recession. [ 27. ] Entrepreneurs in sub-Saharan Africa will receive help from a new international organization to find financing. [ 30. ] Albert Frere, the Belgian financier, is fashioning an international network of banking and industrial operations.

title: Pan American Rechecks Repair Work on 6 Jets
description: At the request of the Federal Aviation Administration, Pan American World Airways is double-checking maintenance work done overseas on six jumbo jet engines, an airline official, James A. Arey, said Saturday.

description: The first day of play Friday at the Eastern Regional Championships in Manhattan blended some past greatness with some present inconvenience.

description: If the election for Mayor were held now, the city's blacks and whites would probably be as racially polarized in their choices as they were in 1983, according to a poll to be released this week.

MUSIC: SUZANNE VEGA, SINGER
description: ''Some days I wish I were Lou Reed,'' said Suzanne Vega at the Bottom Line on Friday evening in her first local concert in many months. The most talented singer-songwriter to have emerged out of the New York folk music scene in recent years, Miss Vega shares some striking similarities with the godfather of punk-rock.

title: East-West Intrigue
description: THE CHINA CARD. By John Ehrlichman. 523 pages. Simon & Schuster. $18.95. John Ehrlichman's ''China Card'' is a suspense thriller about the rapprochement between the United States and China that was effected by President Nixon and his national security adviser, Henry A. Kissinger, in 1971 and 1972. Where, you may wonder, is the suspense in this, since we know from the outset that Mr. Nixon will end up going to Peking? Where is the thrill?

THE CHALLENGE OF WHITE-WATER CANOEING
description: MY friend's invitation was to join a group from Boston, an Appalachian Mountain Club group, for white-water canoeing on the West River in Vermont. We were to close out the spring season a couple of weekends ago because a lack of rain has lowered the water level. And close it out we did.

title: Collision at British Air Show
description: Two vintage jets collided in the air today before more than 100,000 spectators at an air show here, killing two British airmen.

title: Another French Connection For the Statue of Liberty
description: All sorts of French connections are being trotted out for the centennial of the Statue of Liberty.

description: The Software Publishing Corporation, the fifth-largest producer of personal-computer software, said Friday that it expected to lose $2.5 million to $3 million in its third quarter ending June 30. The announcement comes after three quarters of declining sales and earnings for the company, which is based in Mountain View, Calif.

description: Required summer reading lists of classic literature are no longer educationally fashionable or effective, according to public school officials, librarians and publishers in New York City and its suburbs.

title: G. A. White Wed To Alison Brown
description: Alison George Brown, a daughter of Justice and Mrs. Frederick L. Brown of Belmont, Mass., was married yesterday to Gregory Athelston White, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore White of East Orange, N.J. The Rev. Norman Helm, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony at the Memorial Church at Harvard University, of which the bride is an alumna and from which the bridegroom received an M.B.A. degree.

title: Stunt Plane Crashes, Killing 2 From NASA
description: A stunt plane crashed while performing maneuvers Saturday, killing an astronaut candidate and a NASA engineer, officials said.

title: Majority Wrongs in Zimbabwe
description: When Zimbabwe was Rhodesia, a minority white regime waged a brutal bush war against black rebels, killing, torturing and imprisoning their leaders without charges. After six years of black majority rule under Prime Minister Robert Mugabe, most of the country is at peace and whites who had fled to South Africa are trickling back. But the bush war goes on, against a black minority in Matebeleland. And Mr. Mugabe flatters his white predecessors by using their methods - indeed, their laws - against his political opponents.

title: Elder Takes Tourney
description: Lee Elder birdied the 11th hole for a 1-under-par 71 in the final round today and led all the way to win the $230,000 Coca-Cola Grand Slam senior golf tournament by six strokes.

description: A chicken farmer in Zimbabwe is looking for advice on where to buy chicks and how to finance them. A small company in Ghana is planning to invest in agricultural processing but is uncertain which equipment to buy.

description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $57,045.

title: LEECO DIAGNOSTIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TALKS TO BRIDGE LATIN CONFLICTS END IN A SPLIT
description: Five Central American Presidents appeared today to have failed to reach agreement on a common approach to resolving the conflicts that have troubled their region.

title: The Diploma That Life Confers
description: It's the week before finals and I'm swamped with all the work that didn't get done the first time around. So let's just say that I'm not in a good frame of mind. The word ''frantic'' occurs to me. But ''desperate'' seems about right. Even after adjusting for the season - allowing for less sleep, more work, strange hours - it's still pretty awful if I think about it, which I don't. Not voluntarily, at least. That's not my style. Thinking about my work is not what I call ''a good time.'' But then, each of us has a different strategy for dealing with pressure.

title: Bonner Arrives in Paris
description: Yelena G. Bonner, the Soviet human rights activist and wife of the dissident Dr. Andrei D. Sakharov, arrived in Paris today, en route back to the Soviet Union after a six-month stay in the West for medical treatment.

title: MILLIONS JOIN HANDS ACROSS U.S. TO AID THE HOMELESS AND HUNGRY
description: The line twisted through 4,150 miles of America, through city streets, across bridges, through deserts and mountain passes.

title: INQUIRY IS SAID TO AFFECT 9 BOSTON-AREA POLICE UNITS
description: A well-organized group of police officers stole Civil Service examinations and were able to raise the scores of their friends and block the promotion of their rivals in at least nine Massachusetts police agencies, according to sources familiar with a growing state and Federal investigation of the case.

title: They Were Expendable
description: ''Can we renounce the good and worthy ideals for which these Nicaraguan patriots shed their blood,'' rhetorically asked Ronald Reagan last week as he urged support for the contras, ''and believe the freedom lost there may not one day be lost here as well? Some say yes. I say never.''

title: A FADED SUMMER PLACE WITH HOPES OF REVIVAL
description: ''Welcome,'' says the Chamber of Commerce sign near the Cross Bay Bridge tolls approaching the Rockaways, announcing that this remote corner of Queens is celebrating its 300th birthday. ''Reckouwacky''- ''the place of our own people,'' - is what the Canarsie Indians called the 11-mile peninsula, hence the Rockaways, according to popular history. And 300 years after its sale by the Indians to the English, its people include more than 55,000 whites, more than 30,000 blacks, more than 11,000 Hispanic people and about 180 American Indians.

title: BKW SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Postgame Looting
description: Vandals overturned cars and damaged or looted 40 downtown stores Saturday night in wild street celebrations after the Montreal Canadiens' Stanley Cup victory.

title: Minor Quake Hits California
description: An earthquake registering 4.0 on the Richter scale, capable of causing slight damage, was reported near Lake Isabella today, but the authorities said there was no damage or injuries.

title: TECHNALYSIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Kohl's 'Driving Force' On the Road to Buyout
description: Last January when Batus Inc. announced it would sell Kohl's Department Store and several other retail holdings, Kohl's chairman and chief executive, William S. Kellogg, received telephone calls from several potential buyers who wanted information about the chain, which is based in Brookfield, Wis.

title: ACA JOE INTERCON reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: The company began operations on June 3, 1985.

title: SCHOLAR TO INNKEEPER, VIA MANY BYWAYS
description: In a big old-fashioned Vermont kitchen, a bearded man is making pancakes on a sunny Sunday morning. Right now he is feeding only two people. But henceforth his Sunday brunch schedule will require him to concoct pancakes for up to a hundred - not to mention scrambled eggs with Monterey jack cheese and green peppers, baked grits with garlic and cheese, country sausage with apple slices, Canadian bacon with apricot glaze, creamed chicken on hot biscuits, sauteed cinnamon bananas, pecan and molasses scones, Vermont maple sticky buns and brandied pumpkin soup.

title: Reynolds Assessment of Ruling Is at Issue
description: The Justice Department's response to the Supreme Court decision last Monday on affirmative action provided a revealing example of the department's approach to complex and ambiguous legal rulings on issues about which its top officials feel strongly. The Court found unconstitutional a Michigan school board's policy of laying off white teachers before minority-group teachers with less seniority.

description: b-Net income

description: A bitter labor-management dispute has reached across the Atlantic Ocean to West Germany from this sun-baked community on the Mississippi River.

title: THRONG IN MANILA MARKS DAY 'PEOPLE POWER' TRIUMPHED
description: Tens of thousands of Filipinos gathered today to mark the day three months ago when a military revolt and ''people power'' propelled Corazon C. Aquino to the presidency.

description: Nigel Mansell of Britain drove his Williams to victory in the 44th Belgian Grand Prix today, finishing almost 20 seconds ahead of Ayrton Senna of Brazil in a Lotus.

description: Fourteen years and nine months after his alleged crime, Stephen M. Bingham has begun his defense in a trial that could send him to prison for life.

title: GIANTS ROUT EXPOS BEHIND LaCOSS
description: Mike LaCoss went 4 for 4, including a two-run double, and allowed four hits over eight innings today to lead the San Francisco Giants to an 11-3 rout of the Montreal Expos.

Farm Trade Surplus Falls
description: The traditional surplus in United States agricultural trade, once a measure of American strength in world markets, is slumping toward its lowest level since 1973, the Government said Thursday.

title: The Worm and the Apple; Subway Schemes; Transit Blues
description: The New York City Transit Authority is spending $4.5 million to repaint and refurbish 100 subway stations and make them less vulnerable to graffiti. What's wrong with that? Only the new color schemes.

title: CUOMO SAYS REGENTS FAIL THE SCHOOLS
description: Governor Cuomo has begun a broad attack on the Board of Regents, accusing it of having failed to improve the state's education system and of sometimes acting in its own political interests rather than in the interests of students.

title: A Happy Discovery
description: Congress spends much of its time on the budgets of the rest of Government but is not used to downward adjustments in its own.

description: Hope and sorrow mingled outside the Soviet Mission Saturday as 20 writers gathered on the corner of Third Avenue and 67th Street to read the poetry of Irina Ratushinskaya.

title: CANADIENS PROVE PATIENCE PAYS OFF
description: The Montreal Canadiens were not expected to win the Stanley Cup. They were the seventh-best of the National Hockey League's 21 clubs when the regular season ended and were, with the exception of the veterans Larry Robinson and Bob Gainey, a somewhat undistinguished crew so far as renown is concerned.

title: HOTEL VACANCIES SEEN AS JULY 4 NEARS
description: For months, callers requesting reservations at Windows on the World for Operation Sail and the fireworks on July 4 have been told that the place has been fully booked for private parties.

title: FLORIDA PIG FARM POSES AIDS RIDDLE
description: Following a hunch, two medical researchers looking for clues to the riddle of why a small Florida migrant center has so many cases of AIDS went deep inside a sugar cane field outside the town. What they found there earlier this month is now a matter of dispute.

description: b-Net income

title: Rookie Goes Home Again
description: The rookie came home in style, as promised.

description: b-Includes tax credits of $82,904 and $86,791 for latest quarter and year- ago period, respectively.

title: VASSAR COLLEGE: CARTOONIST GIVES SOBER TALK ON 'STAR WARS' AT EXERCISES
description: At Vassar College's outdoor amphitheater today, the cartoonist Garry B. Trudeau urged the graduating class to question the rationale of the Strategic Defense Initiative as a matter of ''simple duty.''

title: Ecuador Judge Freed As Rebels Surrender
description: Judge Enrique Echeverria, kidnapped last week by leftist guerrillas, was freed unharmed tonight after the rebels surrendered in exchange for the promise of a fair trial, officials reported.

title: HOME-BASED WORK GRIEVANCE
description: When the California-Western States Life Insurance Company offered some of its claims processors the chance to work at home instead of in the office a few years ago, it seemed like an attractive opportunity.

title: SERVED IN 4 ADMINISTRATIONS
description: Chester Bowles, an adviser to four Democratic Presidents in a public career that spanned three decades and included service as an ambassador, Congressman and Governor of Connecticut, died yesterday at his home in Essex, Conn. He was 85 years old.

title: Amy Potts Is Bride
description: Amy Beth Potts, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Efrem M. Potts of Baltimore, and Paul B. Knapp, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Knapp of Teaneck, N.J., were married yesterday by the bride's grandfather, Dr. Louis L. Kaplan, at Beth-Am Synagogue in Baltimore. Mrs. Knapp is a graduate of the State University of New York at Plattsburgh. Mr. Knapp, a partner in the law firm of Meron & Knapp in Plattsburgh, graduated magna cum laude from Fairleigh Dickinson University and received his law degree from Albany Law School.

title: MUSIC: DAVID RUDDER, SOCA
description: At this year's Carnival in Trinidad, David Rudder was crowned Calypso Monarch, Road March King and Junior Calypso Monarch simultaneously - a first. His performance Saturday at the Tilden Ballroom in Brooklyn proved he is far more than the latest soca (soul-calypso) singer of uptempo party tunes.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's about time we put something into our own country,'' - Tony Veschio, standing in the Hands Across America Line in Santa Monica. [ 6:4. ]

title: COLOMBIANS ELECT CENTRIST PRESIDENT IN LANDSLIDE
description: Virgilio Barco Vargas, the candidate of the opposition Liberal Party, scored a landslide victory in the Colombian presidential election today.

title: CITY PARKING SCANDAL CAUSES RE-EXAMINATION OF INSPECTOR GENERAL SYSTEM
description: In the spring of 1982 the Inspector General of the City Department of Transportation met with an official who was upset about a fraud he believed was being perpetrated against the city.

title: Pagliarulo Hitting
description: Pagliarulo drove in four runs in his first three games of the season, then only five in the next 33 games. In his last four games he has knocked in eight runs while hitting three home runs and raising his average to .208, marking the first time since May 6 he has been at or over .200. . . . Holland, permitting no earned runs in two innings, gained his first victory since May 11, 1985. . . . Guidry retired 14 batters in a row in the first five innings, but the Angels finished him in the seventh with no-out singles by Jackson, Bobby Grich and Schofield. Jerry Narron singled across a run against Fisher, and Pettis followed with his first sacrifice fly...The An-gels have called up the pitcher Charles (Chuck) Finley, age 23, a left hander from their Quad City af-filiate and released Ken Forsch, a 15-year veteran.

title: Jails Crowded Too, Study Says
description: Large local jail systems are packed with inmates and yet are being forced to take more convicts from other overcrowded correctional facilities, a Justice Department report issued today concludes.

COMPUTERIZED BUYING NETORK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Penn Wins At Regatta
description: The University of Pennsylvania's heavyweight varsity crew, winner of the Eastern Sprint title last Sunday, extended its domination of this 1986 rowing season, capturing the Joseph Burk Cup in a dual regatta with Northeastern University today.

title: Taiwan's Trade Protest
description: Taiwan says the trade bill passed by the House on Thursday violates free-trade principles. Vincent Siew, director of the board of foreign trade, told reporters Saturday that Taiwan would lobby against the measure, which would force Taiwan, Japan and West Germany to cut trade surpluses with the United States by 10 percent for four years or face retaliation.

title: WILSON BROTHERS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $103,000 for the latest quarter and includes a tax credit of $102,000 for year-ago period.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Hoechst Corp., Somerville, N.J., a maker of polyester fibers, biochemical, serological and immunological diagnostic reagents, elected Gerald P. Elden executive vice president.

title: STEPS WEIGHED TO LIMIT ACCESS TO U.S. SECRETS
description: The Reagan Administration is considering reducing the number of officials with access to classified documents as part of a broad effort to control the unauthorized disclosure of sensitive national security information, Administration sources said today.

title: NEW FLU VACCINE PREPARED BY U.S.
description: Federal health researchers are recommending that a new vaccine against influenza be used next winter because the widespread Type B flu appears to be evolving into a new strain.

title: FOR NATION'S DEFENDERS, FLOWERS AND TINY FLAGS
description: Not long after sunrise last Thursday, several hundred soldiers fanned out over the hills of Arlington National Cemetery, moving quietly and methodically through the morning mist. They were planting American flags, one of the first and most enduring rituals of the Memorial Day observance in the nation's capital.

title: HOME INTENSIVE CARE reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $5,221 for the quarter and $28,021 for the 6 months. c-Net loss

title: LAWSUIT AGAINST SEARS FUELS BANKING DEBATE
description: A $100 million private antitrust suit filed against Sears, Roebuck & Company's savings bank has added fuel to a growing dispute here between the Federal Reserve Board and the Treasury Department as to whether commercial companies, other than bank holding companies, should be permitted to own banks.

title: BELGIAN FINANCIER PLANS GLOBAL ROLE
description: When Albert Frere made his first foray into international financial dealings in 1981, he snatched a prize that infuriated the newly elected French Government and drew lasting attention to the businessmen behind the legendary escapade.

title: CONTROL LASER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
VAC-TEC SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss

title: CERBERONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;
Cincinnati Sluggers
description: The Reds are off to a miserable start this year, but not all of Cincinnati is suffering a baseball depression. As usual, the town is producing a stable of prospects, and foremost among them is Ken Griffey Jr., son of the Yankee outfielder.

title: A HOLIDAY FOR COOKOUTS AND TEACHING A CHILD TO RIDE A BIKE
description: Two barbecue grills? Check. Three bags of charcoal? Check. Chicken, ribs, steaks and salads? Check. Baseball bats, gloves, tennis racquets and balls? Check. Did somebody grab a radio? Check. With the essentials accounted for, the Thompson, Long, Wilkerson and Cook families set out from their homes in Queens Village and Jamaica, Queens, and the Bushwick section of Brooklyn yesterday to converge on Flushing Meadows-Corona Park for their annual Memorial Day weekend family get-together.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Auto Racing Indianapolis 500. Rick Mears, Danny Sullivan and the rest of the 33-car field will try again after rain forced a postponement Sunday. (Television - Channel 7, 11 A.M.) Baseball Yankees vs. California Angels, at Yankee Stadium, 1:35 P.M. Joe Niekro (5-2) and Mike Witt (3-4) will pitch. (Television - Channel 11, 1:30 P.M. Radio -WABC, 770; 1:30 P.M.) Pirates vs. Atlanta Braves, at Pittsburgh. (Television - WTBS, 1:05 P.M.) Basketball Celtics vs. Houston Rockets, at Boston, opening game of N.B.A. championship final round. (Television -Channel 2, 3 P.M.) Cycling The Tour of Somerville, N.J., 1 P.M. The women's 25-mile national criterium championship is the feature, with the Olympic silver medalist Rebecca Twigg challenging the defending champion Sophie Eaton, of Renfrew, Pa., and Rebecca Daughton, of Carmel, N.Y., who was second last year. Tennis French Open, at Paris, opening round. The first of the year's Grand Slam tournaments opens on the Roland Garros courts. The respective defending men's and women's champions are Mats Wilander and Chris Evert Lloyd, but the top-seeded players are Ivan Lendl and Martina Navratilova. (Television - ESPN, 9 A.M.) Thoroughbred Racing Belmont Park, 1:30 P.M. The $250,000-added Metropolitan Mile, first leg of the handicap triple crown, is the feature. (Television - ESPN, 5 P.M., live. SportsChannel, 6:30 and 11 P.M., tape.) Garden State, 1 P.M. The $1 million-added Jersey Derby, for 3-year-olds at a mile and a quarter, is the feature. Among the favorites are Snow Chief, the Preakness winner at 7-5, Tasso at 7-2 and Fobby Forbes at 9-2.

title: OF STRAYS, BILLBOARDS AND TRUTH
description: Officials of Lambert, Miss., recently told residents they were resorting to an old but proven remedy to deal with complaints about wild and stray dogs roaming the town's streets: The police are going to shoot them.

title: Pakistan Says 4 Outposts Were Shelled by Afghans
description: Afghan Government forces have heavily bombarded four Pakistani border posts in an area where an Afghan jet was reported shot down recently, the Pakistani Foreign Ministry said today.

title: BankAmerica Bad-Loan Plan
description: The Bank of America is planning to consolidate its efforts to deal with roughly $1 billion in nonperforming loans in California, a bank official said Friday. The company plans to appoint a senior executive to oversee the actions of seven special units, spread around the state, that were formed in the last 15 months to work on the bad loans.

title: CIRO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Zambia-U.S. Food Deal
description: Zambia and the United States signed a $10 million agreement Friday for the United States to deliver 37,000 tons of wheat and 6.9 million tons of vegetable oil.

title: SYRIA DENIES TERRORISM ROLE AND SEEKS TALKS WITH U.S.
description: Syria has sent several messages to the United States in recent days denying complicity in terrorist activity and seeking a constructive discussion to resolve differences and misunderstandings, Administration officials said today.

title: Maine to Play St. John's Today
description: Mike Dutil hit a two-run homer in the ninth inning to lead top-seeded Maine to a 5-1 victory over Rutgers in the opening round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I Northeast Regionals yesterday in Orono, Me.

title: UNIVERSAL MEDICAL BUILDNGS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: TSENG LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NONCERTIFICATE STOCKS
description: The London Stock Exchange said that share certificates, pieces of paper used for centuries to prove equity ownership, would become vestiges of the past under a new computerized share-processing system. The exchange announced it had approved development of the new system, named Taurus, which would allow shareholders to hold British and Irish stocks in noncertificate form. Shareholders would continue to appear on company share registers when the system becomes operative in early 1989, the exchange said.

title: Vehicle Output Drops in Japan
description: Japan's production of cars, trucks and buses fell during April from a year earlier for the first time in 19 months, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said Friday.

title: INTELLIGENT COMMUNICAIONS NETWORKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
An Oil Drilling Rig In the Harlem River?
description: Metro-North Commuter Railroad riders have noticed an unusual sight as their trains cross the Harlem River. ''It looks like an oil drilling rig right in the middle of the river,'' said Lincoln Diamant, a commuter from Ossining.

title: Patricia Eydt Married To Robert F. Vance Jr.
description: Patricia Ann Eydt, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred J. Eydt of New Canaan, Conn., and New York, was married yesterday to Robert F. Vance Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Vance of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Roland M. Jones officiated at the ceremony at St. Mark's Episcopal Church in New Canaan.

title: COLLEGE OF NEW ROCHELLE: WIESEL DEPLORES FANATICISM
description: Elie Wiesel, the author and Holocaust survivor, deplored the rise of fanaticism in the world and exhorted graduates of the College of New Rochelle today to ''be sensitive to all groups, to all injustice.''

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Willie Randolph of the Yankees recently ended a streak in which he had reached base in 28 straight games. Who holds the record for reaching base safely the most consecutive times and who has done it the most times in a season?

title: Oerter Takes Discus
description: Al Oerter, a four-time Olympic gold medalist and now 49 years old, captured the discus throw with a toss of 189 feet in the Metropolitan Athletic Congress track and field championships today at Mitchel Park.

title: Iraq Hits a Supertanker Sailing in Persian Gulf
description: An Iraqi missile hit a supertanker loaded with Iranian oil this weekend, ending a two-week lull in attacks on shipping in the Persian Gulf.

title: Boxing for Glory
description: Boxing has long been seen - even saluted - as a stepping stone to wealth for impoverished young men, but Michael Bent has never quite fit the stereotype of the destitute fighter struggling against odds. As a 20-year-old student at Queensboro Community College and the son of a cement mason in Cambria Heights, Queens, he's just too much middle class.

title: INDY 500 IS RESET FOR TODAY
description: It rained on the 500 today, sending 400,000 fans, 33 drivers, and the first live network-television audience back to their trailers, homes, motels and other programs to wait until Monday.

title: TEECO PROPERTIES L.P.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said results of operations between the two periods are not comparable since the partnership's principal objective is to sell or otherwise dispose of its assets and distribute the proceeds to its unitholders.

title: OVER JULY 4TH WEEKEND, A WORLD OF FOLK MUSIC
description: To celebrate America's folk and immigrant music during the Statue of Liberty centennial on the Fourth of July weekend, folk-music organizations will join in a different American tradition - deficit spending. To represent the full spectrum of American music, the producers say, may leave them $250,000 in debt.

title: ENESCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
INSIDER STOCK CASE IS ENTERING A LULL
description: With a Federal district judge's granting of a preliminary injunction against Dennis B. Levine last Thursday, the Government's insider trading case against the former investment banker enters a lull of perhaps as much as three weeks.

title: UNIVERSITY OF MASSACHUSETTS: AN EARNED DEGREE FOR DR. J., PLUS AN HONORARY DOCTORATE
description: Julius Erving, the Phildelphia 76ers star, finally got his college degree today, to the delight of his mother and thousands of other new graduates at the University of Massachusetts.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Cyanamid Co., Wayne, N.J., appointed Iain A. Forsythe president of its Jacqueline Cochran Inc. subsidiary, which manufactures men's and women's fragrances and skin care products.

title: British Visitors View Fire-Damaged Palace
description: Hampton Court, one of England's finest palaces, opened its south front to the public today for the first time since fire ravaged part of the palace two months ago.

title: Pacific Group Meets on Oil
description: Twelve member nations of the South Pacific Forum have rejected a World Bank recommendation to set up a regional petroleum buying agency, a spokesman for the group said today.

title: Youth and Suicide
description: While the recorded rate at which Americans commit suicide has risen only slightly over the last three decades, the victims are increasingly younger, according to a report from the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

title: Taxing Dilemma For Boosters
description: The Internal Revenue Service, which knows about controversy, got a landmark dose of it two years ago when it issued a ruling that, collegiate officials howled, posed a threat to tens of millions of dollars in annual contributions to athletic programs at the major schools. Recently the I.R.S. provided a clarification that leaves the situation just as controversial - and more cloudy than ever.

title: STARS RIDE AND ROPE IN 'WILDEST WEST SHOW'
description: ON CBS tonight at 9 o'clock, ''The Wildest West Show of the Stars'' takes a batch of television and movie performers and sets them to playing games with one another. Bob Stivers, the executive producer, is also the creator of those other name-filled specials called ''Circus of the Stars.'' In the circus, your favorite performers get to swing on trapezes and ride elephants. In this Wild West show, they enter sharpshooting contests and ride jackasses.

title: STEPHEN B. SWEENEY
description: Dr. Stephen B. Sweeney, founder of the Institute of Local and State Government at the University of Pennsylvania, now the Fels Center of Government, died of congestive heart failure Wednesday at his home at Crosslands Retirement Community in Kennett Square, Pa. He was 86 years old.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, MAY 27, 1986
description: The Economy

title: Clemens Examined
description: Roger Clemens of the Boston Red Sox, who on Sunday pitched hitless ball for seven and two-thirds innings against the Texas Rangers as he won his eighth decision without a loss, yesterday was flown back to Boston from Cleveland as a precaution because of a swelling on the middle finger of his pitching hand. Clemens, the 23-year-old right-hander who set a major league record with 20 strikeouts against the Seattle Mariners on April 29, lost his bid for Boston's first no-hit game since 1965 when Oddibe McDowell singled with two out in the eighth inning. Clemens, who wound up with a two-hitter, will be examined today in Boston by Dr. Arthur Pappas, the team physician, and is expected to make his next scheduled start on Friday against the Twins in Bloomington, Minn.

title: CLASSES DEBATED FOR 4-YEAR OLDS
description: As public schools in New York City and thousands of other districts across the country move to open their doors to 4-year-olds, a national debate is developing over how such young children should be taught.

title: St. John's Reaches Finals
description: Tony Pellegrino and Mike Palladino combined to drive in seven runs, and Owen Kelly gave up nine hits in a complete-game victory as St. John's routed Rider, 16-3, yesterday in Orono, Me.

title: LENDL AND LLOYD WIN IN PARIS
description: Ivan Lendl, the top-seeded player, and Chris Evert Lloyd, the defending women's champion, scored straight-set victories today on the first day of the French Open.

title: Bond Mutual Funds Surging
description: Although some economists began warning months ago of higher interest rates and declining bond prices later this year, individuals are still attracted to bond mutual funds offering higher yields than are available elsewhere.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE LIFE AND LEGEND OF JAY GOULD. By Maury Klein. Illustrated. 595 pages. The Johns Hopkins University Press. $27.50. THERE were no opinion polls in the 19th century, but if there had been, they would probably have shown that Jay Gould was the most hated American of his time. Regularly execrated by the press while he lived, unmourned at his death, he has come down to posterity as a symbol of the robber barons at their worst - a pure predator, wholly unscrupulous and unrestrained in his greed.

title: Eyes on Ethics at White House
description: It is the newspaper cartoons that hurt the most, White House aides say, the ones depicting the President's advisers on ethics as a group of Pygmies, or his former aides selling off the White House column by column. Nor do the aides appreciate what they consider unrelenting news reports of widening scandals or critical commentary or Congressional attacks on the issue.

title: OIL PRICE RISE VIEWED AS TEMPORARY
description: The recent spurt in crude oil prices, primed by strong demand for gasoline in the United States, signals only a temporary gain for the battered oil industry and prices will decline again before fall, many industry experts and analysts say.

title: FOCUS ON LATIN FLIGHT OF CAPITAL
description: The investigation of Antonio Gebauer and his handling of Brazilian accounts at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company has focused new attention on the broader question of capital flight from Latin America, an issue that has assumed increasing importance in the context of the region's four-year-old debt crisis.

title: SAMPSON'S PRESENCE FELT - AFTER GAME
description: The first time Ralph Sampson made his presence felt today, he was fully dressed, stylishly in beige pants and a white shirt, and standing inside the visitors' locker room here at the Boston Garden. The problem, at least for his team, the Houston Rockets, was that it was more than 20 minutes after they were routed by the Boston Celtics in a contest in which Sampson, a 7-foot-4-inch center, was barely seen and hardly heard from.

title: PRESCRIPTIONS TO COUNTER SUMMER DUST AND HEAT
description: ALL sorts of strange things can happen to a personal computer system in the summer.

title: IVORY QUOTAS REDUCE POACHING OF ELEPHANTS
description: A new ivory-export quota system and other potection programs are significantly reducing the number of elephants killed illegally in Africa for highly prized tusks, according to a United Nations official.

title: O'Connor at Georgetown U.
description: Associate Justice Sandra Day O'Connor of the Supreme Court said today that rising costs have put legal services out of the reach of many Americans and urged law school graduates to devote some of their time to representing the poor.

title: Mayflower Chairman Is Fighting Takeover
description: About two years ago, John B. Smith, chairman and chief executive of Mayflower Group Inc., the nation's fourth-largest moving company, decided to tap the $5 billion market in contract school busing.

title: Ever So Humble
description: The most disparate set of post-mortems so far this year sprang forth in a joyous Houston locker room after the Rockets had eliminated the defending champion Los Angeles Lakers last week.

title: 'A MATTER OF THE MIND' LOOKS AT THE MENTALLY ILL
description: ''FRONTLINE'' looks tonight at the mentally ill, a project more sensitive than it may seem. Mental illness, after all, is a fact, although doctors, lawyers and courts have difficulty defining its perimeters. The ''Frontline'' documentary, ''A Matter of the Mind,'' on WNET/Channel 13 at 10 P.M., explores it from the point of view of those who are afflicted.

title: TENTATIVE ACCORD REACHED IN TALKS AT BETHLEHEM STEEL
description: Negotiators for the Bethlehem Steel Corporation and the United Steelworkers of America reached a tentative contract settlement today that would, if approved, cut wages and benefits for 30,000 workers in return for a stock and profit-sharing plan.

title: A PARIS PRISONER FLEES BY COPTER
description: A woman and a pistol-wielding associate flew a helicopter into a prison here today, lowered a cable and carried away a prisoner who had been serving an 18-year sentence for armed robbery.

title: 'TOP GUN:' INGENIOUS DOGFIGHTS
description: Near the end of ''Top Gun,'' currently one of the nation's top-grossing movies, there is a spectacular aerial dogfight in which United States Navy pilots, in peacetime, shoot down four Soviet MIG fighters over the Indian Ocean.

title: INDY 500 IS RESET FOR SATURDAY
description: They ran out of sunshine, they ran out of hot dogs, and people ran out of town today as the Indianapolis 500 - which had started on time each race since the 1915 event - was postponed by rain for the second straight day. The race is now scheduled for Saturday.

title: WOMAN, 87, UNHORSES PURSE-SNATCHING BICYCLIST
description: To the bicycle-riding purse-snatcher on the Upper East Side of Manhattan yesterday afternoon, 87-year-old Vera Tucker must have looked like an easy target.

title: Memorial Day Closings
description: Stock and commodity markets in the United States were closed yesterday in observance of Memorial Day. Government offices, banks and many businesses were also closed. The Government's weekly Treasury bill auction will be held today.

title: RECITAL: CAROL LIAN, PIANIST
description: IMPROVISATION is an art which both frees and limits.

title: 'Amerika' Props Stolen From Nebraska Storage
description: An estimated $8,560 in equipment and props were taken from a warehouse storing items for ''Amerika,'' a television mini-series being filmed in Nebraska, according to the police.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, MAY 27, 1986
description: International African countries seek more aid from the developed world. They are asking for an increase of $80 billion to $100 billion in aid and debt relief over five years. The request will be considered at a special five-day meeting of the 159-member United Nations General Assembly that is opening today. [ Page A1, Column 6. ]

title: Pirate Shuffle
description: Although they announced on Sunday that they were sending Trench Davis, an outfielder who is hitting .136, to the Hawaii Islanders of the Pacific Coast League and purchasing the contract of Barry Bonds from the Islanders, the Pittsburgh Pirates learned that Davis is out of minor league options and must clear waivers before he can join Hawaii. Yesterday the team announced that it would take three days for Davis to clear waivers and that Bonds would work out with the Pirates until he can be activated on Friday. Bonds, the 21-year-old son of the former major league outfielder, Bobby Bonds, and Pittsburgh's No. 1 choice in the free agent draft last June, was batting .311 with seven home runs and 37 runs batted in in 44 games for Hawaii .

title: Advertising; Unionmutual to Mullin
description: Mullin Advertising, situated since December in the old William Loeb mansion in Prides Crossing, Mass., has a new client that has managed to find its way through the thick stand of trees surrounding the place.

title: ONE PERSON DIES AS A FIRE SWEEPS 15 PLANTS IN COMPLEX IN KEARNY
description: One person was killed late last night when an explosion at an aluminum manufacturing plant ignited a fire that spread through an industrial park in Kearny, N.J., authorities said.

title: Bonner Is Meeting French Political Figures
description: Yelena G. Bonner, the human rights activist and wife of the Soviet dissident Andrei D. Sakharov, began a round of meetings today with French political leaders.

title: Symbol of Struggle Visits Fifth Ave.
description: ''I haven't seen anything like this,''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Finally, you are touched. Every time a name is added here it is a victory for these men.''

title: 1,050 U.A.W. Workers Locked Out in Dispute
description: The Sundstrand Corporation locked out 1,050 members of the United Auto Workers after last-minute talks failed to produce a new contract today, company and union officials said.

title: WHEN COLOR ENTERS PICTURE, COMPLEXITY GROWS
description: TO the beginner, the most comforting component of a personal computer, at least in appearance, is probably the monitor. After all, it's nothing but a television set, right?

title: COLOMBIAN VICTOR: VIRGILIO BARCO VARGAS
description: In the final stages of Virgilio Barco Vargas's successful bid for the Colombian presidency, local wits had it that the candidate was at last relaxing: When he ended speeches with three ''vivas'' to the Liberal Party, they said, he read two of them and improvised the third.

title: Negotiator To Testify
description: The National Football League's chief labor negotiator is expected to testify today, as the United States Football League's antitrust case against the N.F.L. enters a third week in Federal District Court in lower Manhattan.

title: Policy And Perception
description: Heresy is seldom welcomed by orthodoxy. It wasn't when two articles in this space, on Feb. 4 and 7, argued that the Federal budget deficit was not as dangerous as proclaimed and did not necessarily warrant Draconian budget cuts or a big tax increase, much less the indefensible Gramm-Rudman-Hollings Act.

title: New York City Is for Bird Lovers
description: To the Editor:

title: Garthorn Takes Metropolitan
description: With a clocking that equaled the second fastest ever run in the event, Garthorn closed strongly yesterday to post a 1 1/4-length victory in the Metropolitan Handicap at Belmont Park.

title: EAST GERMANS ADD BORDER CONTROLS AT THE BERLIN LINE
description: East German border guards today turned back West German diplomats trying to cross to West Berlin, and advised diplomats from other NATO countries that measures would be enforced Tuesday to enlarge East Germany's legal authority on its side of the divided city.

title: SMALL PUBLISHERS TAKING BIG STEPS
description: At a small booth among a group of other small publishers and book distributors, Lawrence and Deborah Freundlich, the publisher and managing editor, respectively, of Freundlich Books, have been quietly counting the orders coming in for the most important book in their company's four-year history.

title: TUROFF'S TIE TO MEDALLIONS IS UNCLEAR
description: After two months of investigation, Federal and state officials say they have not found a reason why the city's former taxi chief, Jay L. Turoff, helped a taxi fleet owner obtain 123 free taxi medallions.

title: NEW VACCINE DESIGNS HOLD HOPE AGAINST DEFIANT DISEASES
description: THE first testing in humans has begun with a genetically engineered vaccine against malaria, one of the world's most devastating unconquered diseases. Doses of the vaccine were given recently to healthy volunteers at Walter Reed Army Institute of Research in Washington. And tests are to begin now with another malaria vaccine of somewhat different design that was developed through research at New York University. This vaccine is entirely synthetic, made from off-the-shelf chemicals.

title: FOR EVENINGS IN THE FALL, A TIMELY CHANGE OF PACE
description: Fashion designers, including those better known for their sportswear, have paid more attention to their evening clothes for fall and winter, with spectacular results. They have expanded the fabric range, added festive separates and given the knee-baring skirt or dress more prominence for night than for day.

title: Voyager Flight Set
description: Two pilots have set Sept. 14 as the date they will begin a flight that will take them around the world without landing or refueling in midair.

title: BUTTERFLIES' MEMORIES ARE FOUND TO BE FLITTING
description: AN experiment with butterflies has demonstrated the importance of learning in their feeding behavior, but also the strict limits to their memory. It explains, too, why butterflies observed in the wild tend, like many bees, to feed almost entirely from flowers of the same species even when flitting among nectar-sweet blossoms of varied types that could be exploited with less travel. ''In a field of 20 different plants, a butterfly sticks with the blossoms it knows,'' says Alcinda C. Lewis, a behavioral ecologist at the University of Colorado.

title: Bridge: Two From Manhattan Win Goldman Pair Eastern Title
description: After four sessions of play at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, the Goldman Pairs title was won Sunday night by Allen Kahn and David Rosenberg of Manhattan. Second were John Lowenthal of Manhattan and Chuck Lamprey of White Plains.

title: AN INDIVIDUALIST AND A BENEFACTOR
description: At the age of 79, Adolph Sipporta keeps busy by giving away his money.

title: HANDS ACROSS AMERICA HEAD SAYS PROJECT WAS SUCCESSFUL
description: The organizer of Hands Across America said Sunday's human chain, which cost more than $12 million to organize, achieved its aim of fighting hunger and homelessness even though the chain had several gaps.

title: REFORM DRIVE TURNS TO CLASSROOM ITSELF
description: THE recent announcement by the Carnegie Corporation of New York that it will set up a voluntary national system to certify primary and high school teachers is a sign that the school improvement effort of recent years is now moving into what educators are calling a ''second generation'' of issues.

title: ANGUISH OF A CAPE TOWN EDUCATOR
description: THE annual report by Dr. Stuart Saunders, vice chancellor and president of the University of Cape Town, begins, ''Nineteen eighty-five was a traumatic year for South Africa, and the University of Cape Town was deeply affected by the anguish which was experienced by South African society.''

title: CHERNOBYL CLOUD PASSES, BUT CHILL IN ITALY LINGERS
description: Marcella Senni, a secretary and mother of four, found that the Soviet nuclear disaster had complicated birthday plans for her 13-year-old daughter.

title: What Price Efficiency?
description: When the President's Council on Integrity and Efficiency was set up in 1981, it promised to reduce Government waste by establishing hot lines for people to report suspected fraud and mismanagement to inspectors general in 18 Government agencies.

title: Europe Sees 3.7% Inflation
description: Annual inflation for countries in the European Community fell below 4 percent for the first time, despite a slight monthly increase in April, the community's statistics office, Eurostat, said today.

title: Texas Air Official Ends Brief Tenure
description: Gerald L. Gitner, who joined the Texas Air Corporation only five months ago as its president, has resigned to pursue other business interests, the company said late last week.

title: RENT RISES SEEN UNDER TAX PLANS
description: Dramatic changes in the cost and supply of housing in America could be expected if the tax incentives that have long helped nourish real estate investment are curtailed as proposed by Congressional tax revision plans.

title: Moderate Week for Treasury Issues
description: Treasury auctions this week consist of today's sale of new three-month and six-month bills, followed by a five-year note issue tomorrow.

title: Advertising; Administrative Chief at Bates
description: Even though it has the reputation of being a well-managed company, Ted Bates Worldwide, on the verge of becoming part of publicly held Saatchi & Saatchi of London, has appointed its first chief administrative officer, John Hoyne.

title: Dr. Paul Diamond Wed To Dr. Suzanne Holroyd
description: Dr. Suzanne Holroyd, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William McGinnis Holroyd of Springfield, Va., was married yesterday to Dr. Paul Thomas Diamond, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Monroe Thomas Diamond of Chappaqua, N.Y. Rabbi Harold White performed the ceremony at Collingwood-on-the-Potomac, a historic property in Alexandria, Va.

title: 1,800 DEGREES ARE CONFERRED AT BROWN'S COMMENCEMENT
description: The president of Brown University, Howard R. Swearer, told the members of the Class of 1986 this morning that today's common attitude of '' 'me first' must give way to the more generous response of 'others, too.' ''

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: WITH American music (John Philip Sousa and Leon Redbone) and American food (fried chicken and apple pie), the Fashion Group hailed what it called ''the best American collections in history'' Friday. Nearly 4,000 fashion professionals filled the New York Hilton's ballroom for two runway shows spotlighting fall trends: trumpet skirts, swing dresses, styles the moderator said were ''for the woman whose bank account is equal to her self-assurance,'' belts (''the accessory of the year''), velvet, gray (''the new black''), boots and big coats.

title: Chess: DeFirmian Proves Ranking At Tourney in SanFrancisco
description: Nick DeFirmian was the only grandmaster entered in the San Francisco International Tournament, as he demonstrated by taking the first prize. The 30-year-old Oaklander came across the bay to score 9-3 in the round-robin competition staged at Miz Brown's Restaurant.

title: West Virginia Prisons Told to Bar New Inmates
description: Gov. Arch A. Moore Jr. today ordered corrections officials to refuse new inmates at West Virginia prisons, saying poor conditions persist because of overcrowding.

title: Pivotal People
description: When Patrick Ewing was named the National Basketball Association's rookie of the year last week, he became the 12th center to win the award since its inception in 1953. Among the dozen, he ranks fifth in first-year scoring average but last in rebounding. The roll call, from most recent to most distant:

title: RISE OF A CAROLINA PLANT SETS OFF NUCLEAR NERVES
description: The congregations of both the Baptist churches in this old crossroads farming town sat up far past a country bedtime last Tuesday night, listening as county and state officials tried to assure them that they would be safe if an accident occurred at the Shearon Harris Nuclear Power Plant, three miles up the road.

title: The Liability Panic, And How to Cool It
description: It is called the liability insurance crisis, and crisis it is. Rates are so high and insurance so hard to get that some doctors are avoiding dangerous aspects of their profession, some companies are quitting the manufacture of litigation-prone products and some cities are setting up self-insurance pools.

title: Detailed Descriptions In Pornography Report
description: The report of the Attorney General's Commission on Pornography will include so many graphic descriptions that it will be a guaranteed best seller, the American Civil Liberties Union said today.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: There is a space in Manhattan called Exxon Park. It is west of the Avenue of the Americas between 49th and 50th Streets, near the Exxon Corporation's headquarters. On Tuesdays and Thursdays, until Aug. 28, Rockefeller Center is sponsoring a lunchtime series of free concerts, ''City Celebrations in Exxon Park.''

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Binghams Sell Another Unit
description: An Atlanta businessman paid the Bingham family more than $20 million for the Standard Gravure Corporation, which prints Sunday magazines and advertising supplements for newspapers, the company said Friday.

title: FOR MISS LIBERTY, A NEW GRANDEUR
description: In an age in which the restoration of monuments and major works of architecture has become commonplace, the restoration of the Statue of Liberty nonetheless stands as an extraordinary event.

title: TWO KILLED IN A BROOKLYN DRAG RACE
description: To some residents of the East New York section of Brooklyn, it was only a matter of time before the illegal drag races on Vandalia Avenue resulted in tragedy.

title: S.I. AIDE'S SON HELD IN ATTACK
description: The 17-year-old son of the Staten Island Borough president, Ralph J. Lamberti, was arrested last night and charged with assaulting a black teen-ager with a hammer in what police described as a racially motivated attack.

title: The Postwar Dollar Bought Fewer Yen
description: To the Editor:

title: OFFICIAL IN ISRAEL FOCUS OF INQUIRY IN '84 COVER-UP
description: The Attorney General of Israel has asked the police to examine evidence that the head of the domestic intelligence organization covered up the involvement of his agency in the beating deaths of two Palestinian bus hijackers two years ago, Israeli officials and press reports said today.

title: MARY TYLER MOORE TO GET ANOTHER CHANCE ON CBS
description: It is unusual for the star of a failed series to be immediately offered a second chance, but CBS still views Mary Tyler Moore as easily worth the gamble.

title: Haymarket Martyrs and the First May Day
description: To the Editor:

title: The Towers Under Siege
description: In launching the Houston Rockets into the National Basketball Association championship final, Akeem Olajuwon and Ralph Sampson combined for an average of nearly 50 points a game. But in limiting the Twin Towers to a total of only 35 points, only 2 by Sampson, in yesterday's 112-100 victory, the Boston Celtics used what Coach K. C. Jones described as ''Plan A and Plan B'' on defense. On offense, the Celtics used the whistle.

title: How U.S. Science Got To China Before '79
description: To the Editor:

title: BIOLOGICS' HISTORIC PRODUCT
description: For years, it was widely expected that the first living, custom-designed, gene-altered product would come from Boston or San Francisco, the two main centers of research and spending by companies in biotechnology. So last January, when the Agriculture Department issued the historic first license for a genetically engineered product to a virtually unknown Nebraska animal health-care company called the Biologics Corporation, its executives were exuberant.

title: NAKASONE WINS AN ACCORD ON ELECTIONS, AND HIS STOCK RISES
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone won an important victory today when leaders of Japan's governing party ended weeks of political wrangling and agreed to hold elections in both houses of Parliament this summer.

title: Lightning and Terrorism
description: Leading experts on international terrorism, including one with firsthand experience, will lead a two-day seminar beginning today to advise travel industry executives on practical ways to deal with terrorism and to reassure the traveling public.

title: SCIENTIST CORRECTS AN OLD ERROR ON HALLOWED SPEED OF SOUND
description: A CANADIAN scientist has discovered that the speed of sound in air is nearly a half mile per hour slower than physicists, acousticians and aerodynamic engineers have thought for four decades. The finding, confirmed by acousticians who have studied it, reveals a small but significant error in modern calculations of one of nature's most venerable benchmarks.

title: Inflation's Down, Not Out
description: Not since 1949 have consumer prices declined so rapidly as in the last three months. Any decline feels like a new experience for most Americans, who had come to think that prices grow higher each month as surely as everyone grows older. Any break in this psychology and in the damaging economic behavior it produces is welcome. But a closer look at what's really been happening is sobering. Inflation has been tamed but it's alive and threatening to break out again.

title: Soviet and China in Accord
description: The Soviet Union and China signed an accord today to expand exchanges in science, culture, health, sports and other areas, the Tass press agency said. The agreement was signed here by Mikhail S. Kapitsa, a Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, and by Li Zewang, the Chinese Ambassador.

title: Why the Governor's Mansion Needs Fixing Up
description: To the Editor:

title: Coast Guard Studying Circle Liner Accident
description: The Coast Guard is investigating the crash of a Circle Line sightseeing vessel that hit pilings at the Willis Avenue Bridge Sunday, a Coast Guard spokesman said yesterday. About 15 people were injured in the crash, one seriously.

title: THOUSANDS GATHER TO REMEMBER 1.2 MILLION WAR DEATHS, PLUS 110
description: With friends and family members looking on, 110 American servicemen were belatedly honored today at the Vietnam Veterans Memorial for giving their lives in the Vietnam War.

title: EX-PRESIDENT HOLDS EDGE IN LATEST TALLY OF DOMINICAN VOTE
description: Former President Joaquin Balaguer appeared today to have won the presidential election with a margin of more than 43,000 votes.

title: PATH Recalls Early Years
description: Travel by rail to New Jersey will require more travel on foot through Manhattan beginning next Monday, when PATH closes the downtown platform at 14th Street and the entire station at Christopher Street for a three-month facelift.

title: 9.9% DROP IN MACHINE-TOOL ORDERS POSTED IN APRIL
description: New orders for American-made machine tools dropped 9.9 percent in April from March's level, according to a report that will be released today by the National Machine Tool Builders' Association.

title: BANGLADESH SHIP, 1,000 ABOARD, SINKS
description: A double-decked river ferry capsized in a storm south of here Sunday night, and at least 80 people were known dead and more than 500 were missing, according to reports from the scene.

title: N. CAROLINA TAKES LACROSSE TITLE, 10-9
description: Gary Seivold, a tireless 155-pound attackman who often sets up his teammates' goals, scored the winning one today as North Carolina won the national collegiate lacrosse championship.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: SUCCESS OF POOR LINKED TO CONFIDENCE
description: Self-confidence is more important than mental ability in determining whether male students will later get the jobs they want, according to a 14-year study of impoverished students in the rural South.

title: Lebanese Christian Chief Blames Syria for Bombs
description: The chief of the main Christian militia, Samir Geagea, accused Syria today of carrying out a series of bombings in Christian areas of Lebanon.

title: Baltimore Man Named President of Montefiore
description: The head of Sinai Hospital in Baltimore, who is a national authority on hospital management and medical education, has been appointed president of Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx.

title: Adena Burnstein Becomes a Bride
description: Adena Burnstein and Avi Saperstein, who expect to receive medical degrees from New York University next month, were married yesterday. Rabbi Dr. Benjamin Helfgott, the bride's grandfather, Rabbi Melvin Burnstein, the bride's father, and Cantor Yochanan Burnstein, the bride's brother, performed the ceremony at La Perville, a catering hall in Brooklyn.

title: LONGEVITY OF BOOM IN DOUBT
description: The housing boom appears vigorous at the moment, but experts are split about how long it can be sustained.

title: Of Robb and Nunn
description: Charles S. Robb, the former Virginia Governor who is continuing an active role in Democratic politics, is telling friends privately that his personal choice for the party's 1988 Presidential nominee is Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia. Which is not ideologically surprising since Mr. Nunn has long exemplified much the same strong-defense/moderate-domestic posture that Mr. Robb is presenting in his speeches these days.

title: Advertising; Burger King's Campaign
description: BURGER KING will break its new national advertising campaign from J. Walter Thompson next Tuesday. And that should put an end to rumors that the Pillsbury subsidiary is switching to Needham Harper Worldwide, McDonald's old agency.

title: I.M.F. Representative Not Haiti Bank Boss
description: To the Editor:

title: Portuguese Stage Strike
description: Portugal's World Cup players, angered by the refusal of team officials to double their tournament bonuses, decided today to go on strike and boycott training sessions through the start of the tournament.

title: Advertising; From Promoting Name To Everything but
description: How is this for a proper mix of assignments? Biederman & Company is going to be promoting a new name and image for the former Libbey-Owens-Ford.

title: INSIDER WITNESS TELLS OF 'COVER STORIES'
description: Bruno Pletscher, the Government's key witness in the insider trading case against Dennis B. Levine, has presented the Securities and Exchange Commission with 28 typewritten ''cover stories'' that he says Mr. Levine helped produce to hide his activities when he discovered that the S.E.C. was on his trail last summer.

title: Lemieux Wins Award
description: The National Hockey League's Lester B. Pearson Award, which had been won for the last five seasons by Wayne Gretzky of Edmonton, yesterday went on a vote of N.H.L. players to Mario Lemieux of the Pittsburgh Penguins. The award, named for the late Canadian Prime Minister and Nobel Peace Prize winner, is given to the player who in the opinion of his peers, has done the most for hockey.

title: Miami Police Chief Releases Papers Requested by F.B.I.
description: The Miami Police Department has released cabinets full of records to the Federal Bureau of Investigation, which is pursuing an investigation of the department.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Metropolitan Report yesterday about commencement ceremonies at Yale University misattributed a quotation about the complexities of life and the quest for understanding. It was A. Bartlett Giamatti, the president of Yale, not Mayor Andrew Young of Atlanta, who said: ''Salvation does not come through simplicities, either of sentiment or system. The gray, grainy complex of existence and the ragged edges of our lives as we actually lead them defy hunger for a neat, bordered existence and for spirits unsullied by doubt or despair.''

title: Charlotte Curtis; The Soviet Connection
description: THERE'S no stopping the indefatigable Armand Hammer.

title: Careers; A Supply Officer's Navy Life
description: THE head of the Navy's Supply Corps, Rear Adm. Edward K. Walker, has a supply problem of his own: finding anywhere from 350 to 375 men and women a year to become new officers in the service's purchasing arm.

title: HOUSING BOOM IS CONTAGIOUS
description: A boom in home construction across much of the country is spilling into other sectors, stimulating an otherwise languid economy, economists say.

title: CECIL BEATON'S WORLD OF FAME AND FASHION
description: The work of Cecil Beaton, best known for his photography of fame and fashion, is being shown in copious quantity in a lavish exhibition in London's Barbican Center.

title: A MARCOS DEFECTOR JOINS CHARTER PANEL
description: The commission set up to draft a new Philippine constitution will include an opposition group headed by a former Cabinet minister who broke with Ferdinand E. Marcos, the Government announced today.

title: Brooklyn Museum Names Semi-Finalists
description: Ten architects and architectural teams have been announced as semi-finalists by the Brooklyn Museum in its competition for the design of a master plan to guide the museum's expansion over the next two decades. The expansion, which will nearly double the size of the building and will link the museum to the adjacent Brooklyn Botanic Garden, is expected to cost between $50 million and $100 million.

title: CELTICS BEAT ROCKETS, 112-100
description: Without Ralph Sampson, the Houston Rockets held their own today. Without Akeem Olajuwon, the Boston Celtics overwhelmed them, 112-100, in the opening game of the National Basketball Association finals.

title: CITY BALLET: 'LA SOURCE' AND 'CONCERTO' PERFORMED
description: THE New York City Ballet presented the sort of program and dancing on Sunday at the New York State Theater that might easily have convinced dan=cegoers that they had died and gone to heaven. The tone of the afternoon was set by an exquisite performance of George Balanchine's ''La Source,'' led by Kyra Nichols, Sean Lavery and Lisa Hess in dancing that stood out for its playfulness, easy classicism and breathtaking delicacy of phrasing. In an exhilarating change of pace, ''La Source'' was followed by the edgy, astringent ''Concerto for Two Solo Pianos,'' a ballet by Peter Martins that is second only to ''Calcium Light Night'' in the Martins repertory. ''Symphony in C'' provided a grand finale, a light-filled sumptuous ceremony of a ballet that never seems to show its age, despite its status as a venerable Balanchine masterwork.

title: Bail Set in Hopkins Bombing
