description: Judge John Themelis of District Court today set bail at $50,000 for a student charged with arson and attempted murder in the firebombing of a shanty town built on the Johns Hopkins University campus to protest South Africa's system of racial separation. The 20-year-old student, Russell Abrams of Riverdale, N.Y., was apprehended shortly after the attack Saturday morning by students sleeping in adjoining shanties. One student was hurt in the fire, and State's Attorney Kurt Schmoke said his office would investigate the firebombing as a serious crime.

title: Ban AIDS Blood Tests
description: Governor Cuomo has proposed a bill that would not only create a substantial tax savings for New York residents but would avert much anguish for an estimated 500,000 people in the state who have been exposed to the AIDS virus and who may or may not have the disease.

title: DANCE: DOUGLAS WRIGHT PRESENTS FOUR WORKS
description: DOUGLAS WRIGHT does not merely choreograph dances, he choreographs power plays. This was evident Sunday night at the Field of the Pineapple Dance Center when Douglas Wright and Dancers offered four works by Mr. Wright, a member of the Paul Taylor Dance Company who has also choreographed for the enterprising group called Limbs in his native New Zealand.

title: DOCTORS CITE STIGMA OF AIDS IN DECLINING TO REPORT CASES
description: The man who died was 32 years old, a nurse, never married, a resident of a section of San Francisco that is predominantly homosexual. His death occurred within weeks after serious respiratory problems developed, and his body was cremated.

title: I.R.A.'s for Middle-Income People
description: To the Editor:

title: ENOUGH DITHERING ON CHILE
description: Proclaiming its opposition to ''tyranny of the right'' as well as of the left, the Reagan Administration has distanced itself from Gen. Augusto Pinochet Ugarte and endorsed a gradual return to democracy in Chile. But unless the United States pressures the Chilean armed forces to oust General Pinochet and rapidly restore democracy, it may find that it has encouraged the violent revolution that is wishes to prevent.

title: Boxer Is Killed In Truck Crash
description: Donald Perry Shiver, a junior middleweight boxer with a 22-1 professional record, was killed early today after he lost control of his pickup truck and crashed on Interstate 75, the police said.

title: OROSCO HOLDING ON
description: Sometimes, when the winning run isn't 90 feet away and the mob at Shea isn't yelling for a strikeout and Davey Johnson isn't glowering from the dugout, sometimes, when he passes an art supply store and maybe there's a picture in the window that he likes, Jesse Orosco will go inside and buy some art pencils and a drawing pad.

title: REACTOR DEATH TOLL IS NOW 19
description: The Soviet Union raised the death toll in the Chernobyl nuclear disaster to 19 today, and a Soviet scientist said there was the ''theoretical possibility'' of further danger from the reactor core.

title: AFRICANS WILL ASK WEST FOR MORE AID AT THE U.N. TODAY
description: The United Nations General Assembly will open a special five-day session today aimed at finding ways to solve the chronic economic problems of Africa.

title: ANGOLANS SAY PRETORIA KILLED 53
description: The Angolan Defense Ministry said today that South African troops had taken up positions inside Angola to support rebels fighting the Angolan Government and had killed at least 53 soldiers.

title: Advertising; Bulova Watch Assigns
description: McCaffery & Ratner has become agency for the watches and clocks of the Bulova Watch Company, which is promising a seven-digit budget. The previous agency was Sherwood & Schneider, a subsidiary of Della Femina, Travisano & Partners.

title: TRUTH, PRECISION AND SEDUCTIVE NUMBERS
description: CERTAIN kinds of numbers are so seductive that we wolf them down like salted peanuts. Batting averages, stock prices, vote tallies, accident deaths: we want them correct to the last decimal place, because our instincts tell us that precision is the soul of truth.

title: Shame Can't Cure College Sports
description: When it comes to sacrificing academic standards to big-time sports, Tulane is hardly the worst offender. It was properly embarrassed last year by a basketball payoff and point-shaving scandal and looked seriously at the compromises that energetic recruiting of athletes requires. That effort makes all the more instructive the contortions now decreed for a new set of admission ''standards.''

title: ULTIMATE SURVIVAL: DESERT DREAMERS BUILD A MAN-MADE WORLD
description: ON a high plateau in the Arizona desert, construction has begun on a $30 million project designed to test the feasibility of self-sustaining manned bases on the Moon or Mars - or on an earth ravaged by nuclear war.

title: Market Place; Trading Pace Under Scrutiny
description: THE huge trading volume that helped to fatten the bull market in recent months has slimmed down sharply in May. John A. Mendelson, one of Wall Street's leading technical analysts, considers that an ''early warning'' signal.

title: SNORING IS CALLED POTENTIALLY SERIOUS HEALTH RISK
description: Snoring, once considered little more than an amusing social nuisance, is now increasingly recognized as a sign of serious medical problems in some snorers, according to experts who addressed a scientific convention here today.

title: Business and the Law; Soul-Searching On Salaries
description: WHEN Cravath, Swaine & Moore announced last month that it was raising its compensation for starting lawyers to $65,000 -more than $10,000 higher than last year's going rate - other major law firms were caught by surprise.

title: Need a Consultant?
description: Washington probably has more people who advertise themselves as ''consultants'' than any other community in the world: lawyers anxious to avoid wills and courtrooms, lobbyists, public relations practitioners, self-proclaimed political advisers and others with even more amorphous credentials.

title: McDonald's Stock Split
description: The McDonald's Corporation said Friday that its board had approved a 3-for-2 stock split and an increase in the quarterly cash dividend to 16.5 cents for each common share on a post-stock-split basis. The new quarterly cash dividend will be 10 percent higher than the current level of 15 cents a share and is payable on June 12 to common shareholders of record as of June 3, McDonald's said.

title: Warm Welcome
description: Joe Dudek, the record-shattering running back from little Plymouth (N.H.) State, after flying into Denver to sign with the Broncos and being met at the airport by a full battery of minicams and microphones: ''I didn't know who they wanted. I kept on walking. I thought the President was behind me.''

title: Sockers Capture M.I.S.L. Title
description: Brian Quinn scored two goals and assisted on another tonight as the San Diego Sockers beat the Minnesota Strikers, 5-3, to win the Major Indoor Soccer League championship.

title: MET MUSEUM'S NEXT CONCERT SEASON
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art has announced its 1986-87 concert season, a mix of world-famous artists and ensembles as well as newly discovered talent and programs of music not readily found on the New York scene.

title: NORDSTROM MOVES EAST WITH ITS RETAILING STYLE
description: Nordstrom Inc. had a bit of an identity problem when it expanded into California in 1978. ''A marketing poll showed that more people thought we were a refrigerator than a store,'' said John N. Nordstrom, co-chairman of the Seattle-based retailer of shoes and apparel.

title: HEAVY SPENDING MARKS THE CALIFORNIA G.O.P. SENATE PRIMARY
description: In the final days of a crowded, often bitter campaign for the Republican senatorial nomination in California, the question most frequently asked is: Can an outpouring of campaign contributions from business interests turn a relatively obscure Congressman into a winning statewide candidate?

title: Florida Fines British Airline
description: Florida has fined British Airways $2,000 and threatened to bar the airline's ''Go for It America'' contest for failing to get state approval to give away plane tickets and other prizes. British Airways announced the $8 million campaign last week.

title: A Founder of Giorgio Tries a Solo Venture
description: Ever since she was a little girl growing up in New York, Gale Hayman has had a passion for fragrances.

title: AIR CRASH KILLS EX-DETECTIVE, WIFE, SON AND PILOT
description: A former New York City police detective, his wife, his 6-year-old son and an upstate pilot were killed yesterday afternoon at the start of an aerial sightseeing flight over the Catskills when their plane apparently developed engine trouble on takeoff and crashed, the state police said.

title: BASCO: UPDATING THE CLASSICS
description: The men behind Basco aren't high-fashion types. Lance Karesh and Gene Pressman wear Weejun penny loafers, white socks and casual shirts under only slightly Italian jackets.

title: Iran Says It Shot Down An Iraqi Warplane
description: Iranian antiaircraft batteries shot down an Iraqi plane today and naval units damaged an Iraqi warship, the Teheran radio said.

title: PROJECT MANAGER BATTLES DEADLINE
description: It is 7:19 A.M. and E. Lawrence Bellante is already back from his daily run. He has awakened George Evans, a construction supervisor with whom he shares an Upper West Side apartment. He has the coffee brewing, the toast browning and the cantaloupe quartered.

title: Veterans and the Homeless
description: Every year, the audience has grown for a variety show put on by the Vietnam Veterans Ensemble Theater Company. ''And that's pretty depressing,'' the company's artistic director, Tom Bird, said.

title: ITALIAN ISLE, SITE OF U.S. BASE, IS FEARFUL OF QADDAFI'S ANGER
description: This barren and dusty island of sheer cliffs and waters so clear that the fish can stare up at the fisherman would like nothing better than to be out of the news.

title: WARNER: WILL HE FAVOR MORE NAVY PORTS OR NOT?
description: The scene was a closed meeting of the Senate Armed Services Committee last week. The subject was the Navy's ''strategic home-porting'' plan to disperse its fleet, expanding old ports and building new ones.

title: SNOW CHIEF ROMPS TO JERSEY VICTORY
description: Snow Chief, who has never been beaten after getting the early lead, took over soon after the start and cruised away from nine opponents to score a two-length victory over Mogambo in the $1 million Jersey Derby today at Garden State Park.

title: School Volunteers Are Providing Free Tutoring
description: To the Editor:

title: Actors in Politics
description: Ben Jones, who played the rustic Cooter character on the long-running television series ''The Dukes of Hazzard,'' is running for the House of Representatives as a Democrat in Georgia's Fourth Congressional District, the second video actor to announce he would like to change roles this year. Fred Grandy, who plays Gopher on the ''Love Boat'' series, has announced he is a Republican candidate in Iowa's Sixth.

title: It's a Girl
description: A second daughter, Arinn Shea Knight, who weighed in at 9 pounds 12 ounces, was born to Nancy Lopez, the professional golfer, and her husband, Ray Knight of the Mets, at 12:38 P.M. yesterday in Albany, Ga. The couple are also the parents of another young daughter, Ashley. Knight, who missed two games to be with his wife for the birth, is expected to be available for tonight's game against the Los Angeles Dodgers at Shea Stadium.

title: The U.N. Today: May 27, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets on African economic crisis at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. TRUSTEESHIP COUNCIL

title: Operaworks Company Plans 3 Modern Works
description: The chamber opera company Operaworks will present three 20th-century works in repertory in September, at Symphony Space, Broadway and 95th Street, the company has announced.

title: 47 U.S. Banks Have Failed
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation reported last week that banks in Colorado, Florida and Texas, with assets totaling more than $263 million, have failed recently, bringing the number of failures this year to 47.

title: AFRICA FACING A MULITITUDE OF AILMENTS
description: For the vast majority of African countries, the 1980's have been a decade of declining agricultural production, widespread ecological destruction, soaring debt and an uncontrolled expansion of population.

title: YANKEES LOSE TO ANGELS ON JOYNER'S HOMER IN 9TH
description: As Dave Winfield stood at first base with two out in the ninth inning yesterday, Wally Joyner, the California first baseman, turned to him and said, ''Are you guys going to pull another rabbit out of the hat?''

title: Agency Criticizes Pesticide Labels
description: Pesticides may carry some long-term health risks, but little or no information about those risks is available to homeowners and weekend gardeners, a Government agency reports.

title: Yakima Canutt Dies; Stunt Man in Movies
description: Yakima Canutt, an Oscar-winning stunt man who doubled for John Wayne and other stars in dozens of movies, died Saturday at the North Hollywood Medical Center. He was 89 years old.

title: Paraguay Springs to Life
description: The news from Paraguay is that there is news from Paraguay. For 32 years the political life of this South American nation has been muzzled by its dictator, Gen. Alfredo Stroessner. So repressive has been his grip that protest virtually vanished from the streets. The last major independent voice, the daily ABC Color, was silenced two years ago.

title: W. VIRGINIA EASES LAW AFTER INSURERS' THREAT
description: In a special session called to avert cancellation of thousands of malpractice and liability insurance policies, the West Virginia Legislature overwhelmingly approved a measure that eases new restrictions on insurers.

title: 3 Die in Small Plane Crash
description: A small plane crashed into a residential neighborhood as it took off tonight, killing all three people aboard, a fire official said. The plane was leaving College Park Airport when it crashed and exploded about 7:15 P.M. in the front yard of a house in this suburb four miles east of Washington, the Prince George's County Fire Department said. The identities of the victims were not immediately released.

title: Kaiser Reports Larger Loss
description: The Kaiser Steel Corporation reported a $9.9 million loss for the first quarter, sharply wider than the $1.8 million net loss the company reported in the first quarter of last year.

title: Hewlett Profit Sharing
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company said Friday that it had distributed profit-sharing checks totaling about $50.9 million to about 79,700 eligible employees worldwide.

title: Homers Help Red Sox Win 8th Out of 9
description: Don Baylor hit a two-run homer and Bill Buckner hit one with nobody on today as the Boston Red Sox beat the Cleveland Indians, 5-3, for their eighth victory in the last nine games.

title: Quarterback to Indians
description: After spending two seasons as a quarterback for Montreal in the Canadian Football League and suffering a series of concussions, Turner Gill has been advised by doctors to end his football career. So the former backfield star at the University of Nebraska is turning to baseball and has signed a contract to play shortstop for the Cleveland Indians' Class A team at Waterloo, Iowa.

title: THEATER: '1951,' A REVUE ON HOLLYWOOD BLACKLIST
description: IF it strikes you that the Hollywood blacklist is a peculiarly unpromising subject for a musical, your hunch is resoundingly confirmed by ''1951,'' now playing at the Perry Street Theater. Is the unhappy episode to be treated as tragedy or farce, as sentimental melodrama or political morality tale? This ''music-theater piece,'' conceived and directed by Anne Bogart, tries them all and produces confusion.

title: EXPERT DOUBTS COMPUTER SYSTEM FOR U.S. MISSILE SHIELD IS FEASIBLE
description: An expert in computer programs who was asked to advise on research into defense against long-range nuclear missiles says he is skeptical that a reliable computer system to control such a defense can ever be devised.

title: In Pursuit of Stock Cheats
description: Everyone suspected it. Now, with the arrest of Dennis Levine, a successful investment banker, suspicions are hardening into certainty. Insider trading, the illegal use of nonpublic information about corporate maneuvers for personal profit, seems as commonplace on Wall Street as myocardial infarctions and stretch limousines. The good news is that the Levine arrest and a spate of other recent cases suggest the Government finally has the capacity and will to crack down.

title: Advertising; Doctors Are Learning To Market Themselves
description: And now for more good news - the physician's house call may be coming back.

title: A PROSECUTOR IS PICKED TO RUN WITH O'ROURKE
description: Andrew P. O'Rourke, the unchallenged Republican candidate for governor, picked a political newcomer yesterday - an assistant district attorney in Westchester County - to run with him for lieutenant governor.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Los Angeles Dodgers, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. The Mets open a 10-game home stand - the Dodgers, then the Giants and the Padres.

title: Dollar Dips; Gold Up a Bit
description: The dollar closed marginally lower against European currencies and up against the Japanese yen and Canadian dollar today. Gold was up slightly.

title: GAVIN NAMED ARCO OFFICER
description: John Gavin, who plans to leave his post as the United States Ambassador to Mexico at the end of this month, was named yesterday as a vice president of the Atlantic Richfield Company, effective next Monday.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Los Angeles Dodgers, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. Dwight Gooden will try to break out of his recent slump.

title: Finally, Africa Looks to Itself
description: The rains have returned and Africa's recurring nightmare of death and famine has ended, at least temporarily, but the underlying conditions that triggered the 1984-85 famine and caused more than one million deaths remain.

title: EXPLOSION THAT KILLED 2 IS TRACED TO BOILER ROOM
description: The thunderous explosion and fire that ravaged a square-block industrial complex here early today, killing two workers at an aluminum-bat company, began in a building housing a boiler and two smelting ovens, fire officials said.

title: BANK OF MONTREAL (CALIFORNIA) reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: All figures are in Canadian dollars. The bank is listed on the Montreal Stock Exchange.

title: Francis Coppola's Son Killed In a Motorboating Accident
description: The son of the movie director Francis Ford Coppola was killed and the actor Ryan O'Neal's son was injured when their motorboat ran under another boat's tow line, officials said today.

title: SUFFOLK POLICE OFFICER IS SHOTGUNNED IN CAR
description: A Suffolk County police officer was shot and critically wounded last night by a motorist whom he had routinely stopped on Main Street in Center Moriches, L.I., the police reported.

title:
BRIEFING;
A Phone Call to Casey
description: It has been widely reported that William J. Casey, Director of Central Intelligence, recommended to the Justice Department early last week that NBC be prosecuted for airing information relating to strategic United States communications systems.

title: NICARAGUAN LEADER IN OFFER ON ARMS
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra said today that Nicaragua was prepared to seek ''concrete agreements on arms control'' in an effort to resolve a deadlock over a Central American peace treaty.

title: THATCHER FINISHES UP A 3-DAY VISIT TO ISRAEL
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said today after winding up talks with Israeli officials and Palestinian leaders that she would ''have a lot more to talk about with the King'' when King Hussein of Jordan visits London in three weeks.

title: Snow Chief Skips Belmont
description: Snow Chief, who won the Preakness Stakes May 17 and the Jersey Derby Monday, will not run in the Belmont Stakes on June 7 after all, his handlers decided yesterday.

title: BALTIMORE PAPER ENDS PUBLICATION
description: The News-American, the smaller of Baltimore's two afternoon newspapers, ceased publication yesterday with the front-page headline, ''So Long, Baltimore,'' after efforts to find a buyer who would keep it in operation proved fruitless.

title: The Appeal of Artichokes
description: DURING summer, I often serve steamed fresh artichokes with lemon butter as appetizers. They are easy to make, light and nutritious.

title: SOVIET CHALLENGES U.S. MILK WARNING
description: A leading Soviet newspaper today challenged a recent United States Embassy recommendation that pregnant American women and infants in Moscow should not drink milk because of increased radioactivity readings.

title: Creepy Feely Folk
description: These are the feelgood days. In Washington we have President Feelgood. In New York's Feelgood Street (formerly Wall) feelgood guys and feelgood girls greet each other every morning with ''Have a nice $25 million day.''

title: Memphis Markets Revenue Bonds
description: Memphis is offering $134.3 million of electric system revenue bonds, with a maximum yield tentatively set at 7.98 percent for bonds due in 2006, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: CHARLES BIERER WRIGHTSMAN, PHILANTHROPIST, IS DEAD AT 90
description: Charles Bierer Wrightsman, a retired oil executive, art collector and philanthropist whose many gifts enriched the Metropolitan Museum of Art, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 90 years old and also maintained homes in Palm Beach, Fla., and London.

title: Park Service Rejects a Limit Of Grand Canyon Flight Times
description: The National Park Service has rejected proposed limits on days and times of flights around the Grand Canyon, but banning planes below the canyon's rim is among the noise-reduction plans still under study.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: TORMENTED IN ELMHURST DEAR DIARY:

title: PRACTICE SET AT INDY FOR FRIDAY
description: Sitting around is not their style, and some of the Indianapolis 500 drivers were cheered today when they learned the track would open on Friday for a special 30-minute practice session to prepare for Saturday's rain-delayed race. They have not been in their cars since last Thursday's Carburetion Day.

title: Cleveland Utility's $125 Million Issue
description: The Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company is offering $125 million of 10 1/4 percent bonds, due in 2016 and priced at par, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: CANADA SET FOR TARIFF RETALIATION
description: Prime Minister Brian Mulroney told Parliament in Ottawa today that Canada would retaliate against the United States for putting a tariff on imports of some cedar wood products, but he did not disclose the steps agreed upon by Cabinet ministers.

title: QUINCY COOPERATIVE BANK reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The year-ago per share earnings were unavailable. The bank converted to stock ownership in November 1985.

title: BANK OF NOVA SCOTIA reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The bank is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, MAY 28, 1986
description: Companies

title: U.S. SAYS FIGURE IN SPY CASE TOLD OF EAVESDROPPING EFFORT
description: Ronald W. Pelton told the Soviet Union that the United States was eavesdropping on some of its highest-level communications, according to testimony in the opening day of his trial on espionage charges.

title: Portuguese Halt Boycott of Cup
description: Portuguese players decided today to abandon their boycott of World Cup preparations, and team officials said the players gave up their demands for higher bonuses for the championship tournament.

title: SUMNER RULON-MILLER
description: Sumner Rulon-Miller Jr., an insurance and real-estate consultant, died of a heart attack Friday at Moore Memorial Hospital in Pinehurst, N.C. He was 73 years old and lived in Pinehurst.

title: Vols' House Not a Home Yet
description: At the University of Tennessee, where superlatives come easy - the 91,000-seat Neyland football stadium, for example, is one of the largest in the country - a double superlative is shaping up: The new Arena and Assembly Center, with 25,000 seats, would be the largest arena ever built primarily for college basketball. It will also surely be one of the most-built and longest-built arenas ever built.

title: BROCK SAYS HE CLEARED WARNING TO TEAMSTERS
description: Labor Secretary Bill Brock said today that the White House had in effect cleared his recent speech urging teamsters to purge their union of criminal influences.

title: KEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 20
U.S. TO STRESS FREE MARKETS AT U.N. MEETING ON AFRICA
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz says that he hopes the special United Nations session on Africa will ''mark a historic turning point'' by promoting bold economic measures to stimulate free market and individual initiative.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Metropolitan Report yesterday about the choice of a running mate for Andrew P. O'Rourke, the unchallenged Republican candidate for Governor of New York, misstated his appraisal of the ticket. Mr. O'Rourke said that the difficult search for a running mate was not a signal that the ticket was weak.

title: YANKS SEND FISHER TO COLUMBUS CLUB
description: Dave Righetti was hoping no one would mention the word ''Columbus'' loud enough for Brian Fisher to hear. ''Yeah, we've thought about it; you have to think about it,'' Righetti said after the Yankees lost to California Monday. ''But I hope no one mentions the possibility to Brian. I hope he's naive enough to think he's going to just keep pitching here. I'd hate to see them do it.''

title: INDEPENDENT COUNSEL TO BE NAMED TO STUDY DEAVER'S LOBBYING ROLE
description: A special three-judge Federal court will appoint an independent counsel to investigate conflict-of-interest charges against Michael K. Deaver.

title: RED SOX AND FOG THWART INDIANS, 2-0
description: Mike Brown and Steve Crawford combined on a six-hitter and Bill Buckner and Jim Rice hit consecutive run-scoring singles in the first inning tonight, leading the Boston Red Sox to a 2-0 victory over the Cleveland Indians in a game called after five and two-thirds innings due to heavy fog.

title: TYSON VS. BERBICK IS ON THE HORIZON
description: If he keeps winning, Mike Tyson is expected to step into HBO's heavyweight unification series - possibly before the year is out.

title: U.S. AIDE CLARIFIES SIGNAL TO MEXICO
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d did not intend to imply that the United States was unconcerned about Mexico's political and economic troubles when he telephoned the Mexican Attorney General to apologize for comments made at a Senate hearing, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: DRIVE ON FOR SENATE APPROVAL OF JUDICIAL NOMINEE
description: The Reagan Administration has begun a top-level campaign to win Senate confirmation for a judicial nominee whose legal background and conservative political views have come under attack by Democratic lawmakers.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Joe Lefebvre, a 30-year-old outfielder for the Philadelphia Phillies who had been playing with Portland in the Pacific Coast League, announced his retirement because of a chronic problem with his right knee. . . . The Green Bay Packers signed Jim Zorn, quarterback, to a one-year contract and placed Mike Douglass, veteran linebacker, on waivers. . . . Henry Bibby was named head coach of the Springfield Fame of the United States Basketball League.

title: TUTTI-FRUTTI: PERFECT SUMMER PRESERVE
description: IT is hard to assign tutti-frutti a hierarchy of virtues. Should the rich, liquorous flavor come first, the way each fruit tastes of itself yet contributes to and partakes of the whole? Or should top marks go to the ease of its preparation? Here, after all, is a homemade preserve that requires no tedious boiling, stirring and sealing of jars.

title: PRAXIS PHARMACEUTICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bridge: The 3 Top Seeds Are Ousted In the Reisinger Team Event
description: The first day of play in the Reisinger Knockout Team Championship Monday was marked by the disappearance of the three top-ranked squads from the field of 33 teams.

title: ALLIED CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Includes realized gains of $3,259,400 in the latest year and $2,987,000 for the previous year. Share earnings are adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split paid Feb. 28, 1986.

title: Congressional Research Service; How Your Tax Dollars Help Do Term Papers
description: When Terri Bower, a high school junior from Finksburg, Md., needed help with a paper on the Soviet Union, she asked her history teacher where to look. He told her to write to Congress.

title: Net Cost Is Low
description: For a major-college varsity team that receives not a penny of financial support from the administration, the athletic department or the student government - and that offers no athletic scholarships - the Iona College water-polo squad casts a wide and effective recruiting net. It's so effective, in fact, that in their third varsity season last fall, the Gaels won 23 of 34 matches, were ranked 18th nationally and narrowly missed gaining a berth in the eight-team national championship tournament.

title: SAHLEN & ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $80,000 and $190,000 for quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss

title: U.S. AND JAPAN TO SHARE SECURITIES FRAUD DATA
description: The United States and Japan today jointly announced their intention to share surveillance and investigative information in cases relating to securities fraud, such as the manipulation of stock prices and illegal insider trading.

title: THEATER: 'HEARTBREAK,' PRISONERS IN VIETNAM
description: THE ''Place Called Heartbreak'' of Robert S. Stokes's play is a room in which American prisoners of war are tortured by the North Vietnamese. We never enter it, but to judge by the testimony and actions of the characters we meet, a painfully effective operation goes on there. The goings-on at the Harold Clurman theater are a bit painful, too.

title: HOSTS HOPE TO DESERVE THE INVITATION
description: When Mexico's national soccer team is practicing at its training center here, the giant Aztec Stadium looms dimly half a mile away through Mexico City's famous air pollution.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: WHILE preparing a recent dinner to be shared with friends, I realized that once again I was playing with flavors and combinations of flavors I might not have considered 10 or so years ago. The meal consisted of broiled tuna marinated in freshly grated ginger, lemon and oil and was served with a traditional Provencale sauce with its blend of tomato, red wine vinegar, garlic, basil and more.

title: STATEX PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a $1,750,000 writedown of oil and gas properties for quarter and 6 months. c-Net income and includes tax credits of $34,000 and $240,000 for quarter and 6 months, respectively. Preferred dividend payments exceeded net income for the year-ago quarter and 6 months.

title: WEARY NYSTROM IS ELIMINATED IN PARIS
description: Joakim Nystrom of Sweden paid the price at the French Open today for too much success and too little planning.

title: HANDS ACROSS AMERICA GETS SILVER-SCREEN TWIST
description: A 6-year-old New York girl who was chosen as the first link in the Hands Across America chain because her family had been homeless signed an acting contract through benefit organizers three weeks before the event, it was disclosed yesterday.

title: ALLIED DIPLOMATS DEFY EAST GERMAN CONTROLS
description: Diplomats from the United States, Britain and France defied an East German demand today that they show their passports while crossing from East to West Berlin or back again. But other diplomats complied with the measure, which the West has denounced as an attack on Berlin's delicate postwar status.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, a dispatch yesterday from Nairobi, Kenya, about African economic problems misstated the role of Morocco at the United Nations General Assembly conference on Africa. The country is a participant.

title: BANCTEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: b-Includes a reduction of a tax loss carryforward benefit of $194,000. c-Includes a gain of $400,000, or 6 cents a share, from the effect of a change in the method for inventories at a subsidiary. d-Net loss includes a gain of $405,000 from the sale of land.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, MAY 28, 1986
description: International

title: 'STAR WARS' SPLITS 2 FRENCH LEADERS
description: President Francois Mitterrand, countering a statement by France's neo-Gaullist Prime Minister, reiterated his opposition today to French participation in the American research program on space-based anti-missile systems.

title:
BRIEFING;
Leotards at an Exhibition
description: For aficionados of the arcane, the Smithsonian's National Museum of American History has a new exhibit, ''The History of Women's Gym Suits, or the Late Bloomers and How They Blossomed and Died.'' The exhibit, which will run through July 27, can be found in the west corridor of the museum's first floor.

title: Marketplace Offers No Disaster Shelter
description: To the Editor:

title: Teacher Salaries Are an Educational, Not a Bargaining, Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: CELEBRITIES TAKE ON NEW ROLES AS RESTAURATEURS
description: A RAPIDLY growing number of stars from stage, screen and sports are out and playing to new audiences in restaurants across the nation. The connection is a natural: today's restaurant is theater on a grand scale. But nowadays celebrities are pouring money into eating establishments as if they were also the best investments on Wall Street, rather than risky businesses, at least half of which will fail.

title: NASA CHIEF ARGUES FOR REPLACING SPACE SHUTTLE
description: The chief of the space agency said today that he had told the White House that building a redesigned space vehicle based on advanced technology would take 10 years longer than replacing the lost space shuttle with a similar craft.

title: Putting Life on Hold
description: Paul Girard of Sharon, Mass., recently begged for someone to donate a liver to save the life of his son, who needed a liver transplant. He called local newspapers, television stations and, eventually, the White House.

title: IT'S LONELY AT THE TOP FOR 'KING OF CALL-IN CONTESTS'
description: Stuart Denning complains that there are those trying to make him out as some sort of hog, calling him that very thing on the radio and charging that he is hogging all the prizes from radio call-in contests.

title: AMERICAN MONITOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: WHEN DIPLOMACY BEGINS AT HOME
description: WHEN Mikhail Gorbachev and Ronald Reagan signed their cultural agreement in November, many Americans chuckled. To them, the two leaders were merely putting their stamp of approval on a thawing of relations that had been going on at the citizen level for years. ''The summit didn't cause the improved climate - the people's desire for communication caused the summit,'' said Christopher G. Senie, a 32-year-old Connecticut lawyer.

title: WINE TALK
description: WHERE is the best pinot noir made? France, where it is the only grape that, by law, can be used for red Burgundy? California, where the vintners have been trying to emulate Burgundy for decades? Or Oregon, where the wine makers have made impressive progress in producing Burgundy-style wines in recent years?

title: SUN PROTECTION, TRAVELER'S AID
description: 1. Beyond Tanning Lotion For sun worshipers who are protective of their skin, the makers of the Teledyne Water Pik have come out with the Ultraviolet Sensor.

title: THEATER: 'THE CURE,' BY RICHARD FOREMAN
description: FOR 18 years, Richard Foreman has been exploring and annotating his dreams, creating scores of plays that have led him from small SoHo lofts to major theaters and festivals. Once again he is in SoHo, at the Performing Garage with a new dream play called ''The Cure'' - and the evening is filled with the playwright-director's fanciful esoterica.

title: PANEL REPORTS EVIDENCE OF BRIBES IN A STATE LEASE INVOLVING LAZAR
description: The State Commission of Investigation said yesterday that it has found evidence indicating that a real-estate company in which Michael J. Lazar was a major partner paid $47,000 in bribes in return for a state contract to lease a Queens office building for $33 million over 10 years.

title: AUDIO CASSETTES A HIT AT BOOKSELLERS' MEETING
description: Books have been on display everywhere here at the convention of the American Booksellers Association, but books on cassettes have also been turning up in dozens of places.

title: CLAIRE'S STORES reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: The year-ago first quarter share earnings were adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split in October 1985.

title: Market Place; Carpet Makers Draw Attention
description: C.H. MASLAND & SONS is so small that Nelson's Directory of Wall Street Research does not list a single securities analyst who follows the carpet manufacturing company based in Carlisle, Pa. But small can be beautiful in the stock market. Last week, Masland's little-noticed shares proved this by jumping $29.25, to close at a record price of $68.375, on the American Stock Exchange.

title: U.S. TO TEST FLORIDA HERD FOR SWINE FEVER
description: The Department of Agriculture dispatched a team of inspectors today to collect blood samples from 125 pigs on a Florida farm and quarantined the animals after scientists found evidence that one of the pigs might have been exposed to African swine fever, a deadly swine disease.

title: HECHINGER CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: The company announced a 5-for-4 stock split in the form of a stock dividend on both its class A and class B common stock. The new shares will be issued on June 20, to shareholders of record on June 11.

title: A Central Park 'Aida' Begins Met's Series
description: The Metropolitan Opera's 20th annual summer series of free concerts in New York City parks will begin on June 17 with ''Aida,'' on Central Park's Great Lawn. Aprile Millo, James McCracken, Grace Bumbry and Louis Quilico will sing the principal roles, and Nello Santi will conduct.

title: Japan Chip Tariff Voted
description: The United States International Trade Commission imposed stiff tariffs today on imports of a type of Japanese computer memory chip that is a major component in computers and communications equipment. The decision, on a 4-to-2 vote, upheld an earlier ruling by the Commerce Department that held Japanese concerns were ''dumping'' the chips, 64K dynamic random access memory chips, in this country at below-fair-value prices. Computer chips are the tiny silicon circuits that serve as the crucial elements in many electronic products.

title: Council in Capital Votes Bill on AIDS Insurance
description: The District of Columbia City Council unanimously approved legislation today that requires life insurance companies to provide coverage to people exposed to the virus that can cause AIDS.

title: RAVEN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
PERFECTDATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CHARMING SHOPPES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid April 25.

title: A SAMPLER OF CINEMA 16'S BEST
description: A WARNING ought to precede ''Homage to Cinema 16,'' which opens today at the Film Forum. Something of this sort: ''A few scenes from the nine short movies that follow are guaranteed to turn some stomachs.'' With that bow to the fastidious or squeamish, the show can proceed, and a powerful show it is.

title: Ethiopia's Other Drought
description: Hard truths are emerging at last about Ethiopia's disastrous inability to feed itself. ''We called it a drought problem, but it was more of a policy problem,'' says Dawit Wolde Giorgis, who once directed that nation's food relief effort. ''Drought only complicated the problem. If there is no change in our policies, there will always be millions of hungry people in Ethiopia.''

title: ROSS STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: The results include income tax credits of $5,367,000 for the latest first quarter, compared with $2,875,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: Askew to Leave
description: Vincent Askew, a starter on Memphis State University's basketball team, said, ''I'm leaving,'' after a meeting with university officials yesterday. Askew, a 6-foot-6-inch, 210-pound guard, said he did not know yet where he wanted to play his final two years of college eligibility.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: REAGAN DECLARES U.S. IS DISMANTLING TWO NUCLEAR SUBS
description: The White House announced today that President Reagan had decided to dismantle two old Poseidon submarines, which would keep the United States in step with the provisions of the unratified 1979 arms treaty when a new Trident goes to sea on Wednesday.

title: CENTRAL SPRINKLER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
THAI ARMY CHIEF OUT; COUP RUMORS QUIETED
description: Thailand's Prime Minister dismissed the commander of the army today, touching off rumors that a coup was imminent.

title: Islamic Scholar and Wife Slain in Pennsylvania
description: An Islamic scholar and his wife were stabbed to death early today and their daughter was seriously wounded.

title:
ADVERTISING;
New Ball Partnership
description: Michael Ball, who has built a network of seven agencies in the Pacific Basin for the Ogilvy Group, has now acquired a majority interest in them. They will be renamed the Ball Partnership. The offices, which have collective billings of $35 million, are in Hong Kong, Singapore, Bangkok, Kuala Lumpur and Sydney, Melbourne and Hobart in Australia.

title: DANCE: MARTHA GRAHAM OFFERS WORLD PREMIERE
description: LIKE Shakespeare, Martha Graham has always been a great entertainer. And nowhere has her ability to communicate with the groundlings of the world been traced so strikingly as in the extraordinary new program that opened the Martha Graham Dance Company's season last night at the City Center with Miss Graham's new ''Temptations of the Moon.''

title: Republic Bank Offering Notes
description: The Republic National Bank of New York is offering $50 million of 8 1/2 percent depository notes due in 1996 at a price of 99 7/8 to yield 8.52 percent through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: COMPUTRAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
ALAMCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss includes a tax benefit of $5,040,000.

title: No Troops Need Go
description: To the Editor:

title: Pennzoil Curtails Natural Gas Sales
description: The Pennzoil Company said it would discontinue the sale of more than 225 million cubic feet of natural gas a day on the spot market, or about half its current level.

title: Checking Up on Ads
description: Broadcast Advertisers Reports periodically monitors the advertising on network and spot television to let the advertising community know if its advertising is running as requested and how much the competition is doing. Now it has begun to check on the activity on syndicated television. In its first report, it said that 194 advertisers spent $139.4 million in the first quarter this year, with the top advertisers being Procter & Gamble, Philip Morris, R. J. Reynolds, Nestle and Mars.

title: DEBBIE ALLEN'S 'CHARITY': COACHED BY THE ORIGINAL
description: Debbie Allen gets up from the table at a midtown restaurant. ''It's the finger tips on the hat, the shoulders that move, one and then the other - this is Fosse and Gwen working together,'' she says.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Who Is Eating What Steak remains the nation's No. 1 choice for a dinner entree in ''fine dining'' restaurants, according to the 1985-86 Gallup Annual Report on Eating Out, recently released; 19 percent of the survey's respondents said they ordered it the last time they dined in a restaurant. But that was not enough to make beef the leading menu item in this country, the survey found. Only 31 percent of the more than 1,000 people sampled by telephone said that beef of any kind was their most recent dinner choice. The top choice was seafood, which was cited by 39 percent of the sample. Chicken trailed with 11 percent.

title: CAROLYN BEAN PUBLISHING reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ROCKING HORSE CHILD CARE CENTERS OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SET OWN PACE, U.S. TELLS LATIN CHIEFS
description: The Administration expressed satisfaction today that the leaders of democracies in Central America were not being ''forced into action'' on a peace agreement that might fall short of a desired goal of more democracy in Nicaragua.

title: U.S. REJECTS ACCORD AT RIGHTS MEETING, CALLING IT TOO WEAK
description: A 35-nation meeting called to review human-rights provisions under the Helsinki accords of 1975 ended its six-week session here today after the United States blocked adoption of a final set of recommendations as too ''weak and modest.''

title: Union Leaders Support Bethlehem Steel Accord
description: Presidents of union locals from Bethlehem Steel Corporation mills in four states approved a contract today that would cut wages and benefits for 30,000 workers by $1.96 an hour.

title: COSMOPOLITAN CARE reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
JONES FINDS A WINNING WAY
description: K. C. Jones has a split personality: an entertainer off the court, serious and low key on it.

title:
BRIEFING;
One Who Came Back
description: Old members of Congress often fade away to the practice of law, the consulting business or to the nether reaches of the think tank.

title: A VICTORIOUS VICTIM TAKES IT ALL IN STRIDE
description: In her 40 years in New York, Vera Tucker, an 86-year-old Englishwoman, says she has moved freely about the city, undeterred by the fear of crime. ''I go wherever I want,'' she said, adding that she often walks home alone to her luxury apartment on East 66th Street after neighborhood outings with friends.

title: Banner Art for Liberty
description: A huge yellow banner lay on the concrete floor of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center. Hundreds of youngsters were about to attack with paintbrushes.

title: AMERICAN TRAVELLERS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company went public May 6.

title: Infoquest at A.T.&T
description: I found it very, very exciting,''

title: OPTICAL RADIATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Monumental In Aegon Deal
description: The Monumental Corporation, a life insurance holding company based in Baltimore, said yesterday that it had executed a definitive agreement to merge with Aegon N.V., in a deal valued at $56 a share, or a total of $361 million.

title: A TEE FOR MATTINGLY
description: Don Mattingly's enthusiasm for slugging baseballs doth bubble over, which is the reason for some dissatisfaction with himself so far this year.

title: PETROLITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
VIRTUES OF BUTTERMILK
description: CONTRARY to what many people believe, buttermilk is not milk to which butter has been added. Originally, it was the liquid remaining after butter was made. Naturally fermented, it made a tangy, refreshing drink.

title: President Names a Scientist To Interim White House Post
description: President Reagan named an astrophysicist, Richard Johnson, as interim director of the White House science office pending announcement perhaps later this week of a permanent science adviser.

title:
BRIEFING;
For Women in the House
description: The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee has started a major drive, through its Women's Congressional Council, to raise $200,000 for women running for the House of Representatives. That would be double the amount raised by the group for such candidates in 1984, a spokesman said, and it reflects a heightened interest in women seeking state and Federal office this year.

title: PT Components
description: PT Components Inc., a leading maker of power transmissions, bearings and other motor parts, said it had entered into a merger agreement with a group of investors to take the company private for $132.3 million.

title: S.E.C. ASKS ROLE ON BROADCASTERS
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission voted unanimously today to ask Congress for legislation that would for the first time classify broadcasters that primarily give advice on securities as investment advisers and subject to the nation's anti-fraud laws.

title: SOVIET TELLS U.S. IT WILL ALLOW 117 TO REJOIN FAMILIES
description: The Soviet Union has informed the United States that it will resolve 36 cases of divided families by allowing 117 Soviet citizens to emigrate, the State Department said today. It called the Soviet move ''a significant step.''

title: Molson Golden Duo To Be Heard, Not Seen
description: Fans of the couple who have been making those wonderfully relaxed Molson Golden Beer and Ale radio commercials will hear that the brand is testing television advertising and think they will at last get the opportunity of seeing their camera-shy hero and heroine. Forget it.

title: Reagan's War on Poverty
description: Imagine that Government workers appeared in Harlem and Watts tomorrow morning, tacking up this message: ''Notice: Special bonus for poor families. Extra $700 to family of four. Inquire, Internal Revenue Service.''

title: POLISH ACTIVIST TO FACE A MILITARY TRIAL
description: Czeslaw Bielecki, a Solidarity activist who has been force-fed in prison since last October, will be tried by a military court on charges of planning to overthrow the state by force, the Government said today.

title: SANITY OF CONFESSED SLAYER AT ISSUE IN SEATTLE TRIAL
description: A drifter went on trial today for the murder of the Charles Goldmark family, a crime that sent shivers through Seattle's governing class.

title: A Plumbing Company In Queens Is Indicted
description: A State Supreme Court grand jury yesterday indicted the president of a Queens plumbing company that holds two contracts from the city Board of Education for failing to disclose to school officials that he was under Federal indictment for obstructing justice.

title: Senate Floor Tax Outlook
description: Bob Dole, the Senate majority leader, predicts that no major amendments -including restoring deductions for Individual Retirement Accounts - will pass when the full Senate begins debating tax overhaul next week.

title: People
description: * Brian Meredith has been named executive vice president/creative director for the Earle Palmer Brown Co., Philadelphia.

title: Steven Brill Buys Legal Times
description: Steven Brill, who founded The American Lawyer and who has bought nine other legal newspapers across the country in the last few months, said yesterday that he had bought one of his biggest competitors, The Legal Times, a 6,000-subscription paper based in Washington. Mr. Brill declined to disclose the price of the paper, which he bought from Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. He said he would follow the same pattern as he did with his other purchases. ''We will try very intensively to upgrade the already high quality of the product,'' he said, and ''ultimately the subscription price will reflect that.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I was very happy they got the fellow. I wanted to go up and hit him some more.''

title: COBB RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $55,000 for the quarter and $218,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes tax credits of $149,000 for the quarter and $557,000 for the 9 months.

title: Thrift Figure Pleads Guilty
description: Jeffrey A. Levitt, whose ouster as president of the Old Court Savings and Loan last year sparked a run on Maryland's privately insured thrift industry, pleaded guilty today to theft and misappropriation of almost $15 million of depositors' funds.

title: DRUGS AND MEXICO GOVERNOR: WAS HE WRONGLY ACCUSED?
description: There appears to be no evidence to back up an American official's allegations that the Governor of the northern Mexican state of Sonora is growing marijuana or opium poppies on ranches near this town, according to information gathered here.

title: BURROUGHS, IN CHALLENGE TO I.B.M., TO ACQUIRE SPERRY FOR $4.8 BILLION
description: Two of the world's largest computer makers, the Burroughs Corporation and the Sperry Corporation, agreed yesterday to merge in an effort to create the most potent competitor to the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: Real Estate; Schwarz's Short Move On 5th Ave.
description: IT remains unclear why the Christiana Corporation, a real estate company that owned F.A.O. Schwarz for a short time in 1984 and 1985, gave up a lease that guaranteed the toy retailer 20 additional years at a moderate rent in 745 Fifth Avenue at 58th Street, one of New York City's most desirable retail locations.

title: GREAT LAKES SHORE DWELLERS RETREAT BEFORE RISING WATER
description: When a 25-foot chunk of Frank Lundell's yard tumbled into Lake Michigan not long ago, he did what 12 of his neighbors had already done. He hired someone to move his house safely away from the shore.

title:
BRIEFING;
Now Hear This
description: The nominations are in. According to the International Platform Association, 17 men and women, living and deceased, have been proposed for induction into the Orators Hall of Fame, established in 1982.

title: Corestates to Buy New Jersey National
description: In a major push into the lucrative New Jersey banking market, the Corestates Financial Corporation of Philadelphia said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the New Jersey National Corporation once interstate banking between New Jersey and Pennsylvania becomes legal.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Getty Petroleum Corp., Plainview, L.I., an independent marketer of gasoline and petroleum products, promoted Stephen Salzman to senior vice president.

title: FOUR AIRLINE OFFICES IN PAKISTAN BOMBED
description: Bombs ripped through four closed airline offices here today, killing an airline guard and injuring four other people, officials said.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: THE arrival of warm weather is often a signal to relax. But if you have small children in the house - or expect to have them visiting - now is the time to be most vigilant.

title: CUOMO SET TO NAME LUNDINE FOR SLATE
description: Governor Cuomo has chosen Representative Stan Lundine of Jamestown as his running mate for lieutenant governor, according to politicians close to both men.

title: Frank B. Hall
description: Frank B. Hall & Company, the troubled insurance concern based in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., said it had reached a $45 million settlement with the Protective National Insurance Company of Omaha, the Central National Insurance Company of Omaha and the Commissioner of Insurance for Nebraska.

title: Mitterrand Meets Bonner
description: President Francois Mitterrand met today with Yelena G. Bonner and promised to do everything in his power to help her husband, the dissident Soviet physicist Andrei D. Sakharov, obtain release from internal exile in Gorky. The President told Miss Bonner that he would be visiting Moscow in July but did not spell out how he would pursue the matter. Miss Bonner, who arrived here on Sunday from the United States, said Mr. Mitterrand had made no concrete promises, but she added, ''I am sure he will continue his efforts.''

title: OPTICAL COATING LABORATORY INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss c-After net gain of $4,055,000, or 69 cents a share, on the sale of discontinued operation.

title: FREER FOOD POLICY GIVES CHINA VIGOR
description: THE scene at the night market along Donghuamen Street in the bustling center of Peking one recent spring evening was a grazer's paradise: Two dozen or more food stalls, some as simple as an oilcloth-covered counter, others virtual restaurants in miniature, each offering enticements.

title: CONVEST ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AIDE TO GOLDIN PLANS TO WORK ON WALL STREET
description: A city official who questioned the ethics of the hiring of the city's Sanitation Commissioner by Lazard Freres & Company has decided to take a job with another Wall Street investment house that does business with the city.

title: How the California Condor Can Be Saved
description: To the Editor:

title: BIG B INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 10
A TEARFUL LOOK BACK
description: THE 90-minute ''Program for Vietnam Veterans . . . And Everyone Else Who

title: D'AMATO WINS RENOMINATION BY STATE G.O.P.
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, who was rejected by Republican Party leaders when he first ran for the Senate six years ago, was renominated today for a second term by acclamation by the Republican State Committee.

title: JUSTICES BAR INSURING OF STANDBY LETTERS OF CREDIT
description: The Supreme Court, reversing a Federal appellate decision, ruled today that a standby letter of credit was not insured as a ''deposit'' under the Federal deposit insurance program.

title: Irving Trust Hires Survivor of Bailout
description: David G. Taylor, who is credited by analysts with playing a key role in keeping afloat the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company during some of its roughest days, is leaving the bank to become a vice chairman and director of the Irving Trust Company in New York, Irving announced yesterday.

title: LOWE'S COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a one-time writeoff of about $1 million from the liquidation of inventory from four stores that were closed in Houston on Jan. 31.

title: BOROUGH CHIEF'S SON ARRAIGNED IN ATTACK DURING BRAWL ON S.I.
description: James Lamberti, the 17-year-old son of the Staten Island Borough President, Ralph J. Lamberti, was arraigned yesterday in the assault Sunday on another teen-ager that at the time the police said was racially motivated.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: WE were teaching assistants together in college, and we met for the first time in 10 years at our class reunion. She was a professor of political science. I was a newspaper columnist. We condensed the past, looked it over, had a few laughs. And all the time I was thinking, ''She's a professor?'' And all the time she was thinking, ''She's a columnist?'' And all the time we both were thinking, ''Where are the grown-ups? Who handed the keys to the kingdom over to the kids?''

title: ULSTER'S BITTER POLICE: A BATTERING ON BOTH SIDES
description: Like their father and grandfather before them, the Gracey brothers are all members of the Royal Ulster Constabulary, a police force that has been toughened and tempered in the flames of unremitting sectarian conflict. Like 90 percent of their fellow officers, they are Protestants.

title: U.S. Trust Announces Promotion of Schwarz
description: The United States Trust Company of New York, a bank that caters to the well-to-do, yesterday named H. Marshall Schwarz president.

title: ABRAMS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Maine Crushes St. John's, 21-8
description: Bill Reynolds, the catcher, hit four consecutive home runs and drove in a total of nine runs yesterday to lead Maine to a 21-8 rout of St. John's in the finals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I Northeast Regionals at Orono, Me.

title: Economic Scene; Israeli Growth And Inflation
description: HOW can Israel get back on a higher path of economic growth without losing its still-unfinished battle against inflation?

title: Books: Swift of Sports
description: RED: A BIOGRAPHY OF RED SMITH.

title: 'My Glance of Summer Fire'
description: It has been a bountiful New York spring - wonderful backyard forsythia, splendid flowering trees in Central Park, heavy blossoms on the locusts along the Henry Hudson Parkway. And to judge by scattered reports from bird lovers, there are more orioles around than usual. Flocks of the brilliant birds have been seen in gardens, and people sauntering along suburban roads hear more of them singing, or at least singing more loudly.

title: STATE U.-BUFFALO'S SPORTS PLAN AT ISSUE
description: At a time when big-time college sports is facing intense criticism nationwide, the administration, faculty and students at the State University of New York branch here are trying to strengthen their school's athletic program and move to the top levels of N.C.A.A. competition.

title: MUSIC: SCHUBERT SOCIETY OFFERS DEBUT CONCERT
description: FOR all of its dark majesty, the Cathedral of St. John the Divine has less than ideal acoustics. It is the largest Gothic cathedral in the world, a cavern so vast that a given note will sound and resound for nearly 10 seconds before dissipating into air.

title: Son for McEnroe
description: Tatum O'Neal and John McEnroe are the parents of a boy named Kevin John McEnroe who weighed 8 pounds 11 ounces when he was born in good health on Friday at St. John's Hospital in Santa Monica, Calif. On Monday the 22-year-old actress and the 27-year-old tennis star brought the child to their home in Los Angeles. McEnroe, who has not played on the pro tour since the Masters Tournament in January, will return to competition in time for the United States Open in late August, according to his father, John McEnroe Sr.

title: Bechtel Planning Reorganization
description: The Bechtel Group Inc., a major engineering and heavy construction company based here, said its two principal operating companies would be replaced by five new companies. Senior executives will also be changed under the reorganization scheduled for July 1.

title: How to Regain Face in Space
description: President Reagan has promised to build an $8 billion space station and a trillion-dollar missile defense system in space but at the moment the United States can scarcely launch a moonbeam. Dreams have so far outrun means that urgent national needs, like the ability to launch military reconnaissance satellites, are in jeopardy.

title: Fire Damages a House Designed by Wright
description: A one-story stone house designed by the architect Frank Lloyd Wright was severely damaged by fire just before dawn Monday, the authorities said.

title: Flames Honored
description: About 125,000 people, or one-fifth of Calgary's population, lined downtown streets yesterdfay for a parade to thank the Flames for their first appearance in the Stanley Cup final.

title: Rape Victims' Privacy and Courtroom Cameras
description: To the Editor:

title: Spurs Name Weiss
description: Bob Weiss, a 6-foot-3-inch guard for six National Basketball Association teams from 1965 to 1977, yesterday was named head coach of the San Antonio Spurs. He succeeds Cotton Fitzsimmons, who was dismissed April 28 after the Spurs completed a 35-47 season and were eliminated from the playoffs in the first round by the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: Warning on 15 Lab Monkeys
description: A Federal agency has one week to decide whether to turn over 15 monkeys to an animal rights group or face public censure from ''a lot of very angry Congressmen,'' says Representative Robert C. Smith.

title: Politics; Laxalt Looks at Geography and Money
description: When faced with a major personal decision, Senator Paul Laxalt likes to retreat to the splendid isolation of what was once his father's sheep ranch at the end of a 10-mile-long dirt road high in the Sierra Mountains of Nevada.

title: PHONE ROLE OF STATES IS UPHELD
description: The Supreme Court today rejected an effort by the Federal Communications Commission that would have led to more rapid rate increases for intrastate telephone service in many states.

title: BLOCK DRUG CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DEVELOPERS ARE FLOCKING TO THE MOVIES
description: Having shaped and been shaped by New Yorkers' discerning and exotic tastes in cinema, the movie houses of upper Broadway are now being reshaped by the developers who are rebuilding the West Side.

title: RANGAIRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title:
ADVERTISING;
Minority Recruitment
description: Among black advertising agency executives the poor performance of general agencies in minority recruitment in the professional area is a continuing cause for concern.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: READINGS AND WRITING - One of the most successful programs at the Symphony Space (864-5400) center for the performing arts has been the series ''Selected Shorts,'' in which performers read from classic and contemporary short stories. Today, the series concludes its second season. The author Toni Morrison will comment on stories she has selected for the program and will introduce the readers. The actress Ruby Dee will read ''Sweat,'' by Zora Neale Hurston. Morgan Freeman will read Jean Toomer's ''Esther.'' And Toni Cade Bambara's ''Gorilla, My Love'' will be read by Hattie Winston.

title: Foreign Journalists Named To Study as Nieman Fellows
description: Eight foreign journalists have been named to join 12 Nieman fellows from the United States who were announced earlier this month, the Nieman Foundation at Harvard University announced today.

title: Genesis
description: One way of fully appreciating just how long baseball's over-40 gang has been around is to glance at a list of other players who were there in the beginning. For example: 1.

title: 3-MONTH BILL SOLD AT 6.15%
description: Interest rates fell modestly in quiet trading yesterday, as many market participants continued to wait for fresh clues from the economy or the Federal Reserve about the direction of rates.

title: HANDCUFFED MAN SHOOTS 2 OFFICERS, THEN IS KILLED
description: A suspect who was handcuffed behind his back pulled a concealed gun yesterday afternoon and shot the two police officers who were driving him to a Brooklyn station house, police officials said. One of the officers was seriously wounded.

title: If Democracy Is Declining, It's Not on Campus
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: * Atlantic Richfield Co., Los Angeles, said its board had declared a dividend distribution of common stock purchase rights intended to protect stockholders against any unsolicited takeover.

title: PROFESSORS DENY INTENT TO HARM U.S.F.L.
description: Two professors from the Harvard Business School who developed a seminar for National Football League executives have testified that their presentation was intended to ''suggest'' and ''recommend'' ways to deal with the United States Football League, not to devise strategy to ''conquer'' it.

title: FOREIGN PARTNERS EASE PUBLIC TV STATIONS' COSTS
description: Faced with sharply rising production costs, public television stations are increasingly turning to Europe and Japan for help in financing programs.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: BEACHMASTERS. By Thea Astley. 185 pages. Viking. $14.95.

title: The Class of 1986
description: This year's college graduation ceremonies were marked by an unusual event. At Georgetown University's Law Center here, Justice Sandra Day O'Connor of the Supreme Court made a speech that lasted no more than five minutes. This confirmed my long-held conviction that the hope of the world depends on the women.

title: PROSECUTOR IN ISRAEL AFFIRMS HIS RESOLVE IN COVER-UP INQUIRY
description: Attorney General Yitzhak Zamir said today that the struggle between him and the Cabinet over whether to investigate the head of Israel's domestic intelligence agency ''is the gravest, most complicated problem of principle ever faced by an attorney general since the founding of the state of Israel.''

title: Rochester Council Approves Measure on Alien Sanctuary
description: After three hours of public debate, the Rochester City Council approved a resolution last night recognizing the city as a sanctuary for aliens seeking political asylum.

title: Compelling Resignation
description: John Mitchell, who built the University of Alabama's track program into a national contender in the course of 17 years, said he felt compelled to resign after his misunderstanding about a rule cost one of his athletes her N.C.A.A. eligibility. ''Alabama has had a spotless record, and because of my mistake the track team and the school have been embarrassed,'' said Mitchell, who resigned over the weekend and was replaced by an assistant, Wayne Williams.

title: U.S. BECKONS NEW 'JEEVESES'
description: Armed with striped pants and a home computer, Paul Raybould is trying to revive a distinctively British but dying profession -that of the butler.

title: HIGH COURT TO HEAR APPEAL ON CURB IN USE OF GRAND JURY EVIDENCE
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to hear the Justice Department's appeal of a ruling that kept Government lawyers from using some grand jury evidence in a subsequent civil suit.

title: I.B.M. Buyback
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said it would buy back up to 10 million shares of its own stock over an unspecified period.

title: 29.74 RISE PUTS DOW AT 1,853.03
description: The stock market continued its recent surge yesterday as blue-chip issues lifted the Dow Jones industrial average by more than 29 points, to within 3 points of its highest close.

title: EVANGELIST MAY LEAD IN PRELUDE TO MICHIGAN RACE
description: The Rev. Pat Robertson, a television evangelist who is considering a Presidential bid in 1988, appeared to score a major breakthrough yesterday in Michigan's delegate-selection process.

title: ALDEN H. SULGER Jr.
description: Alden H. Sulger Jr., executive vice president of the advertising agency of Ogilvy & Mather Partners, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 58 years old.

title: Advertising; Alfa Romeo Focuses On Power
description: POWER. That's the name of the game. Power as reflected in an executive behind his desk. Several more watching a presentation. A man firing a pistol. Another leaping in the long jump. A baseball player hitting the long ball. A shot-putter. More big operators on the phone. Film snippets of all of these events appear in a 45-second strip that the Bloom Agency in New York created to identify the target audience of the cars that its client, Alfa Romeo, wants to sell.

title: F.M.R. Gets O.M. Scott
description: O. M. Scott & Sons, Marysville, Ohio, an ITT Corporation subsidiary, has named Fallon McElligott Rice of Minneapolis as its agency after a six-way competition.

title: WINANS CONVICTION UPHELD
description: A divided Federal appeals court yesterday upheld the securities fraud conviction of R. Foster Winans, a former reporter for The Wall Street Journal. He was found guilty last June of trading on the basis of his advance knowledge of what was to appear in the newspaper's ''Heard on the Street'' column.

title: After 9 Years, Bridgemarket Plans Change
description: Already on the drawing board nine years, a plan to turn the Manhattan side of the Queensboro Bridge into a combination farmer's market, open plaza and restaurant may stay on the board a bit longer.

title: Japan Is Top Creditor
description: Japan has become the world's largest creditor nation, surpassing Britain and other industrialized nations, the Finance Ministry said in an annual report today. The country's assets in other nations at the end of 1985 totaled $437.7 billion, while liabilities amounted to $307.9 billion. That left Japan with net assets of $129.8 billion, almost twice the amount at the end of 1984.

title: Mayor of Chicago Wins Court Ruling
description: Mayor Harold Washington won an important battle over opposition aldermen today when a circuit judge ruled that the City Council properly approved 25 mayoral appointments.

title: U.N. OPENS SESSION ON AID FOR AFRICA
description: President Abdou Diouf of Senegal opened a special General Assembly session on Africa's economic crisis today with a call for African and donor nations to make ''an act of faith'' in developing the world's poorest continent.

title: CONDON'S AND GULLIVER'S ARE SET FOR A REPRISE
description: THE names of two of the best-known jazz clubs in the metropolitan area - Eddie Condon's, which closed at the end of July 1985, and Gulliver's, which closed three years ago - will be back in lights next month.

title: SLAM BY FOSTER POWERS METS
description: It took just one quick turn on a fastball thrown across the letters. With it George Foster accomplished the following: He gave Ron Darling and the Mets a big lead, he completely tore at the composure of the Dodgers and he turned a cool, quiet evening at Shea Stadium into a rollicking, explosive affair. The old slugger can still have his say.

title: Illinois Issues Warrant For LaRouche Backer
description: A judge issued an arrest warrant today for Janice Hart, the Democratic nominee for Illinois Secretary of State, who is a supporter of the political extremist Lyndon H. LaRouche. when she failed to appear for a hearing.

title: New York State Bonds Climb to A-1 at Moody's
description: On the eve of today's $340 million bond sale, the rating of New York State's general obligation bonds was raised to A-1 from A, Moody's Investors Service announced yesterday.

title: The U.N. Today: May 28, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. TRUSTEESHIP COUNCIL

title: FORWARD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: PERSISTENCE PAYS OFF IN BURROUGHS DEAL
description: Ten minutes before the board of the Sperry Corporation was to begin an 11 A.M. meeting at the company's Manhattan headquarters yesterday, an envelope arrived, carrying a $76.50-a-share acquisition offer from the Burroughs Corporation.

title: MURDOCH GIVES PRINTERS $75 MILLION 'FINAL OFFER'
description: The publisher Rupert Murdoch has made a $75 million ''final offer'' to end his dispute with striking print unions.

title: CORRECTON
description: An article on the Washington Talk page yesterday, about the Reagan Administration's ethical standards, incorrectly described a reprimand given Joseph R. Wright Jr., deputy director of the Office of Management and Budget, over his contact with a regulatory agency about an oil company in which he had an interest. He was reprimanded by James C. Miller 3d, the budget director, for ''the creation of an appearance of a conflict of interest in the minds of the general public.''

title:
BRIEFING;
Saluting Pendleton
description: The American Conservative Union is planning a reception in honor of Clarence M. Pendleton, chairman of the Civil Rights Commission, who is an outspoken proponent of the Reagan Administration's ''color-blind'' philosophy on civil rights.

title: 'BARGAIN' STOCK OFFER CITED BY EX-CITY HOSPITALS CHIEF
description: The former president of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, who was indicted last month on bribery charges, told investigators last summer that he had been offered a ''bargain'' on a stock purchase because a lawyer for the company ''thought that I would be going somewhere, whether in public life or in hospital administration, and that this would be a favor well made.''

title: Times Mirror Company Buys Publisher of National Journal
description: The Times Mirror Company said today that it had bought the company that publishes The National Journal, a weekly magazine covering the government and national politics.

title: PINNACLE PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: OH, THE SWEET INTRIGUE OF THE ARTICHOKE
description: OF all the fresh vegetables available for springtime culinary adventure, the artichoke is, hands down, the most intriguing. To begin with, it has the distinction of being the unexpanded flower of a thistlelike plant that grows to a height of four feet or more.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I had a brick patio constructed in my yard about two years ago. Even though a bed of stone dust was placed under the bricks, algae and moss are growing in the cracks. How can I remove this and treat the bricks to prevent recurrence? A. I'm not sure what you mean by a ''bed of stone dust,'' but brick is usually laid on sand or gravel for adequate drainage. You seem to have a drainage problem, although the soil itself may not drain well.

title: MACY MANAGER GROUP SEEKING 19%
description: The 300 to 350 members of senior management involved in the proposed leveraged buyout of R. H. Macy & Company will put up less than 6 percent of the cash to acquire an eventual 19 percent of the surviving company, according to a proxy statement released yesterday for the June 19 stockholders meeting.

title: Bridge: The Reisinger Semifinalists Include One Veteran Team
description: One team of established stars and three teams of rising younger experts survived the quarterfinal stage of Reisinger Knockout play at the Beverly Club, at 130 East 57th Street in Manhattan, Tuesday night.

title: Fast Start for Cowley
description: Joe Cowley of the Chicago White Sox became the first major league pitcher since 1900 to strike out the first seven batters in a game when he achieved that against the Texas Rangers tonight. But both Cowley and the White Sox slowed down, and Texas won the game, 6-3.

title: SLIGHT RISE SEEN IN MEDICARE RATE
description: The Administration will soon propose an increase of one-half of 1 percent in Medicare payments to hospitals for the treatment of elderly or disabled patients, Federal health officials said today.

title: Soviet Account No. 904, and Ours
description: Never underestimate the allure of a fad. The Soviet Government has blessed the staging of a Live Aid-style rock concert for the victims of Chernobyl. The proceeds will go to ''Account No. 904,'' which is also the name of the concert, to be held tomorrow in Moscow's Olympic stadium. By coincidence, this Soviet expression of trendy moral hygiene occurs as the United Nations ponders the desperate plight of sub-Saharan Africa. That account's number is $100,000,000,000 - the amount of debt relief and aid sought by 44 of the world's neediest countries.

title: ROCK MUSIC: SIMPLE MINDS AT RADIO CITY
description: THANKS to a hit single, ''Don't You (Forget About Me),'' from the soundtrack of ''The Breakfast Club,'' the longtime cult band Simple Minds, from Scotland, finally crossed over into the rock mainstream. And on Tuesday, the quintet, led by the hoarse-voiced singer and lyricist Jim Kerr, filled Radio City Music Hall with its brand of modal, exhortatory rock.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL MILWAUKEEE (AL) - Signed Bob Sobczyk, catcher; Terrence Brown, outfielder; Jose Samaniego, shortstop, and William Rabb, outfielder, in free agent draft.

title: CONTRAS IN PACT GIVING CIVILIANS GREATER POWER
description: After almost three weeks of hard bargaining here, the leaders of the main Nicaraguan rebel organization were reported today to have reached an accord under which civilian officials will be given greater control.

title: EXECUTIVES
