description: * American Maize-Products Co., Stamford, Conn., named Leslie C. Liabo to the new position of vice chairman and said John C. McCormick would succeed him as president and chief operating officer.

title: SPARTECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
Group to Buy TV Station
description: The Christian Science Monitor Syndicate announced today that it had agreed to purchase WQTV, an independent Boston television station, to use as a base to start a national nightly newscast.

title: Americans Go to Court Believing They'll Get Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRYSLER PROPOSES MASERATI TAKEOVER
description: The Chrysler Corporation announced plans today that may eventually lead to the taking over of Maserati S.p.A., the Italian luxury car maker.

title: Service for Chester Bowles
description: A memorial service for the late Chester Bowles will be held on Friday, June 6, at 11 A.M. at the Battell Chapel at Yale University, a family spokesman said. Mr. Bowles, 85 years old, died here Sunday of complications arising from his long struggle with Parkinson's disease. Mr. Bowles, a Democrat, was a former Connecticut governor, Congressman, ambassador and adviser to four Presidents. In lieu of flowers, the spokesman, Lise Stone Heintz, said, donations can be made to organizations seeking ''peace, economic justice and human dignity here and abroad.''

title: Technology; Customized Crop Plants
description: AFTER years of development, the nation's plant biotechnology companies, using a host of test tube-based techniques for altering the characteristics of crop plants, are moving a new generation of custom-designed grains, vegetables, fruits and ornamental shrubs to the market.

title: U.S. SUSPENDS PLAN FOR NUCLEAR DUMP IN EAST OR MIDWEST
description: The Administration said today that it had indefinitely postponed studies on a possible site for a nuclear waste dump in any of 17 states in the East and Middle West.

title: U.S. AGENT GIVES PELTON'S VERSION OF SECRET DATA HE GAVE TO SOVIET
description: An agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation testified today that Ronald W. Pelton had admitted selling secrets to the Russians that were ''enormously costly'' and ''harmful'' to the United States.

title: DELTAK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: STAGE: DARIO FO'S 'MISTERO BUFFO,' A ONE-MAN SHOW
description: AFTER years of denied visas, Dario Fo is finally performing in America. With all the controversy surrounding him, by now one might expect him to wear a label, ''Warning: dangerous to one's health.'' Happily, the opposite turns out to be true in his celebrated one-man show, ''Mistero Buffo,'' which opened Tuesday at the Joyce Theater. Let the label read: ''Take Fo for fun, and to restore one's comic equilibrium.''

title: Fuji Will Market Disposable Camera
description: The Fuji Photo Film Company, the top Japanese photo film maker, said it would soon market a throwaway camera -a pack of color film with a built-in plastic lens and a shutter.

title: PRESIDENT SELECTS NEW CHIEF OF NAVAL OPERATIONS
description: President Reagan has selected Adm. Carlisle Trost to be the next Chief of Naval Operations, officials in the Reagan Administration said today.

title: CITICORP BID ON QUOTRON ADVANCES
description: Citicorp now looks more likely than ever to succeed in acquiring Quotron Systems Inc., securities analysts and other investment professionals said yesterday.

title: Nisson Alpert, 58, a Scholar At Rabbi Elchanan Seminary
description: Prof. Nisson Alpert, a noted rabbinical scholar at the Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary, an affiliate of Yeshiva University, died of cancer Monday at his daughter's home in Queens. He was 58 years old and lived in Far Rockaway, Queens.

title: Sam Goldaper on Pro Basketball; Ramsay Dismissed by Blazers
description: Citing ''a need to change direction,'' the Portland Trail Blazers today dismissed Jack Ramsay, the National Basketball Association's coach with the second-best career record, and replaced him with Mike Schuler, who was an assistant coach with the Milwaukee Bucks for the last three seasons.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF TAPES PLAYED FOR JURORS
description: Following are transcripts prepared by the Federal Bureau of Investigation from tapes of two telephone calls that were played for the jury Tuesday by the prosecution in the espionage trial of Ronald W. Pelton:

title: LATEST HOT TICKET: A FLOATING SEAT FOR THE 4TH
description: A lot of people have been calling Malcolm Forbes lately to ask - as innocently as possible - what he's doing on the Fourth of July. Some merely have their secretaries place a casual call to his secretary.

title: Crum Offered Post?
description: Denny Crum, who guided Louisville to the national collegiate basketball championship, will coach the United States team in the 1987 Pan American Games, according to a report in yesterday's Courier-Journal in Louisville. Crum declined to confirm the story, deferring to an official announcement expected later this week.

title: Deere's Dividend Cut to 12 1/2 Cents
description: Deere & Company, the nation's largest farm machinery manufacturer, said it was cutting its quarterly dividend in half, to 12 1/2 cents a share, from 25 cents. Robert A. Hanson, Deere's chairman, cited ''current pressure on the company's operating result and the need to conserve cash for investments in cost reduction and new products.''

title: Papandreou Faults U.S.
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou, toasting President Assad of Syria at a dinner here Tuesday night, indirectly criticized the United States position on international terrorism.

title: ARMEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $200,000.

title: STEVENS, J P & CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: b-Net loss and includes income from discontinued operations of $729,000. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $19,486,000.

title: A Star's Choice: Stay or Play
description: Norris Coleman may be either the latest victim of the David Thompson rule or its biggest beneficiary.

title: AS CBS LOBBYIST, DEAVER SOUGHT MEETING WITH F.C.C.'S CHAIRMAN
description: As a lobbyist for CBS Inc., Michael K. Deaver, invited the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission to lunch to discuss an aspect of the agency's review of Ted Turner's attempt last summer to take over the network.

title: NEW YORKERS SIGN SOVIET TEST PACT
description: The Soviet Union said today that it was prepared to allow American nongovernmental scientists to staff stations in the Soviet Union to monitor underground nuclear tests. The arrangement is contingent on Washington's approval for Russians to monitor tests in the United States.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: What the Bugs Do and How to Stop Them
description: PEST: Ants (carpenter) - Black, one-half to three-quarters inch long. Very common to Eastern and Midwestern United States.

title: New York's Scandals and Mr. Anderson
description: Since only Democrats in New York City are being indicted for political fraud, why rush to respond with state legislation? So says the Republican Senate leader, Warren Anderson, as he wastes a precious moment of opportunity to improve the campaign financing laws.

title: FLEETWOOD ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
PT Components Chief Restores Profitability
description: Five years ago, an investment group led by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company bought PT Components Inc., a leading maker of power transmissions, from the FMC Corporation in a $125 million buyout. At the time, PT, which is based in Indianapolis, was in its worst shape ever, incurring a $4 million loss on sales of $213 million in the 1982 fiscal year.

title: COOPER UNION: SURPRISE AT COMMENCEMENT
description: In a surprise move at the 127th commencement exercises at the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art, the chairman of the college's board of trustees announced he would resign from his position after serving 15 years.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: WEST SIDE STORIES The Yivo Institute for Jewish Research (535-6700) and Ansche Chesed Temple (865-0600), a 100-year-old synagogue at 251 West 100th Street, are today observing the 70th anniversary of the death of Sholom Aleichem as he requested: by reading his works aloud. The humorist asked that such anniversary readings be a monument to him. This program, the second in the institute's series on Jewish humor, will feature the Golden Peacock Players - Rita Karin, David Rogow, Suzanne Toren and Leonard Wolf - performing in Yiddish and English tales by Mr. Aleichem. Janet Leuchter, a guitarist and singer, will perform songs written for Mr. Aleichem's works.

title: STAGE: A MIXED ARRAY OF DRAMAS IN LONDON
description: As far as new plays are concerned, the West End is in the same fix as Broadway: No major new drama has excited either city's commercial theater district since Michael Frayn's ''Benefactors.'' In the West End's case, that means a two-season drought - ''Benefactors'' has long since come and gone here - but the London theatergoer, like his New York counterpart, satisfies the hunger for fresh writing at fringe and institutional companies. As always, the National Theater and Royal Shakespeare Company mix the classics in their repertory schedules with contemporary scripts of nearly every esthetic and ideological persuasion. No doubt some of these new plays will eventually travel to our own institutional theaters - or even Broadway - though past experience suggests that they could be either substantially sharpened (''The Real Thing'') or bruised (''A Map of the World'') in transit.

title: Advertising; Accounts
description: Pace Foods, San Antonio, to Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt for Woody's cooking sauces.

title: REDMAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
description: b-Net income

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, MAY 29, 1986
description: International The main Nicaraguan rebel leaders were said to have agreed to give civilian officials increased authority. The agreement came after nearly three weeks of hard negotiating in Miami. Rebel sources said the accord seemed likely to resolve a long power struggle that threatened to split the rebel front, the United Nicaraguan Opposition. [ Page A1, Column 5. ]

title: TV STATIONS LOBBYING OVER MUSIC ROYALTIES
description: The nation's local televison stations are waging an intense campaign on Capitol Hill for a sweeping change in music copyright law that the bill's opponents contend could cost composers and lyricists millions of dollars each year in performance royalties.

title: ARBOUR RESIGNS AS COACH, CITING NEED FOR CHANGES
description: The Islanders, a franchise that has been resistant to change and controversy in its 14-year history, held a news conference today at which Al Arbour, the coach for the last 13 seasons, announced his resignation.

title: 2 STATES TO LOSE HIGHWAY AID FOR VIOLATIONS OF SPEED LIMIT
description: For the first time since the Federal speed limit of 55 miles an hour was adopted more than a decade ago, the Department of Transportation has decided to withhold Federal highway funds from states found to have inadequately enforced the speed limit. Two states were affected by today's decision.

title: GOVERNMENT PACT IS AIM
description: The director of the Natural Resource Defense Council, John H. Adams, described his group yesterday as an ''honest broker'' working toward a governmental pact for on-site inspection.

title: SHIP HIT AND SUNK OFF FALKLANDS
description: An Argentine naval ship fired on two Taiwanese fishing vessels today, setting one ablaze, and chased a third just outside the 150-mile exclusion zone set by Britain, a Taiwan official said.

title: Step by Step
description: Mark Salas, the Minnesota catcher, explaining his decision to have surgery for a bone spur on his right foot: ''I felt it was time to do something after three doctors told me I shouldn't be walking.''

title: H. Harvard Arnason, Art Historian, Is Dead
description: H. Harvard Arnason, an art historian and a former administrator at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in New York City, died yesterday at the Florence Nightingale Nursing Home in Manhattan. He was 77 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: COUNTRY: LAYERED SUMMER PERENNIALS
description: AT 7:30 in the morning, the nine staff members of Galen Williams's landscape design company begin their day in her East Hampton, L.I., driveway, which is a holding pen for the hundreds of plants being transported to the gardens she has designed in the area. Seen en masse, her selections have a cooling effect, because the landscape designer stresses interesting combinations of foliage with only subtle accents of bloom.

title: SERVO CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
HOW TO CHECK CREDENTIALS WHEN HIRING EXTERMINATORS
description: WHEN recommended pesticides have been used and an insect problem remains, it is time to consult an exterminator or pest control applicator, as they prefer to be called.

title: Royal Ballet Appoints American as Conductor
description: Britain's Royal Ballet Company at Covent Garden said today that it had appointed its first American conductor, Isaiah Jackson.

title: JAZZ: MILT JACKSON'S QUARTET
description: THE vibraphonist Milt Jackson and his quartet, at the Village Vanguard through Sunday, take on blues tunes and ballads with soulful elegance.

title: BRAZILIAN MINISTER QUITS IN DISPUTE WITH LEADER
description: President Jose Sarney accepted the resignation today of the Minister for Agrarian Reform and Development, Nelson Ribeiro, in what political sources described as a dispute over redistribution of land.

title: Mississippi Judicial Races Postponed by Judge
description: Judge William H. Barbour of Federal District Court has indefinitely postponed the Chancery and Circuit Court elections set for June 3 after State Senator Henry Kirksey and others argued that Mississippi's at-large voting system makes it inordinately difficult for blacks to be elected.

title: Expert Witnesses
description: To the Editor:

title: SOUTHLAND ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
description: The company changed its fiscal year-end to Jan. 31 because of equity reporting requirements of its 20 percent-owned affiliate, Marine Transport Lines Inc. The company had a loss of $244,028 on revenue of $4,288,247 for the year ended Oct. 31, 1984.

title: 1,000 Radiation Cases Now Reported in Soviet
description: A Soviet press agency indicated today that as many as 1,000 people, including residents of the immediate area around the Chernobyl nuclear plant, had suffered radiation in the accident last month.

title: HERS
description: SOME questions are simple enough. ''Where are you from?'' for example. That's an easy one for most people, its answer the starting point of identity. But for me it has become a mine field. London, Jerusalem, New York. . . . I have too many answers and none of them sufficient. Even my bylines reflect the confusion. I may be a British psychologist or an Israeli journalist or a British-Israeli writer based in New York; it depends on the subject or on something as trivial as how many words can be used to identify me.

title: PELTON CASE CALLED EXAMPLE OF BIG SPYING PROBLEM
description: Some of this country's most sensitive secrets are in the hands, and heads, of thousands of servicemen, junior government workers and low-paid employees of contractors who are vulnerable to the entreaties of foreign intelligence agents.

title: Topics; Pet Projects; Six Years on Ice
description: Gliding to music on a crisp winter day against the backdrop of the Manhattan skyline and Central Park used to be one of the supreme New York experiences - for anyone who, after six years, can remember it. That's how long it has taken to rebuild the Wollman rink, and the job isn't finished yet.

title: Trial Put Off 2 Weeks In Comedian's Death
description: Cathy Evelyn Smith's trial on charges of murdering the comedian John Belushi was postponed today for two weeks.

title: MUSIC: TOOTS THIELEMANS
description: THE unclassifiable Toots Thielemans manages to squeeze an amazing display of his versatility into the span of a single set at Carlos I, on Avenue of the Americas near Ninth Street, where he is leading a quartet through Sunday.

title: C.I.A. DISPUTES WHITE HOUSE ON SOVIET ANTIMISSILE GAINS
description: In a sharp contradiction to Congressional testimony by the Reagan Administration, a Central Intelligence Agency report released yesterday says the Soviet Union would have to conduct further underground nuclear tests before it could deploy an X-ray laser, an advanced antimissile weapon.

title: CERTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: HOW TO CONTROL THE HORDES
description: INSECTS have been around longer, much longer, than humans have, and no household is going to win the war against them. But with the right tools and a little knowledge, individual battles can be won.

title: BOLOSHOI'S 'SWAN LAKE' ON CABLE ARTS NETWORK
description: AUDIENCES love to watch it. Ballerinas love to dance it. Choreographers love to tinker with it. ''Swan Lake'' is magic. Ballet fans will be able to fall under its spell tonight at 8 o'clock when the Arts & Entertainment Network offers a complete production by the Bolshoi Ballet of Moscow. A repeat starts at midnight.

title: C.D. Yields Off Slightly
description: Yields on certificates of deposit and bank money market accounts fell slightly, while the average yield on money market mutual funds was unchanged in the week ending yesterday.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Los Angeles Dodgers, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. Fernando Valenzuela of the Dodgers goes for his eighth victory.

title: AS RIVALS MERGE, I.B.M. WAITS IN WINGS
description: The Burroughs Corporation's acquisition of the Sperry Corporation could prompt Sperry customers to abandon the company's products for those made by the International Business Machines Corporation, several users said today.

title: NO SYRIANS ARE INCLUDED IN NEW ITALIAN WARRANTS
description: Despite strong suspicions that Syria was involved in the terrorist attack on the airport here in December, Italian magistrates investigating this and other terrorist activities have decided for now not to take steps against any Syrian officials.

title: A Television Accord
description: A threatened postponement of the heavyweight title bout between Tim Witherspoon, the World Boxing Association champion, and Frank Bruno, a British challenger, was avoided when an independent network in England, ITV, and the British Broadcasting Corporation agreed to share the delayed telecast rights to the fight. Witherspoon is to meet Bruno July l9 in Wembley Stadium, a 78,000-seat facility in London. The match is part of the American-based Home Box Office heavyweight unification series. . . . Livingstone Bramble's World Boxing Association lightweight title defense against Terrance Alli, scheduled for June 15, has been postponed because Bramble suffers from tendinitis in his right arm.

title: Silent Spring
description: Spring in Italy, and no artichokes. No lettuce, no asparagus, no spinach. All were taken off the market for weeks after fallout from Chernobyl drifted over Italy.

title: The Choice of Causes
description: The big cause on campuses at the end of this college year is South Africa. Oberlin is no exception. About half the graduates receiving their degrees wore ribbons in the red-black-green colors of the African National Congress, or badges reading ''No Divestments? No Donations.''

title: AP and Conus Form A TV News Service
description: The Associated Press and Conus Communications today announced the formation of a video news service covering events in Washington.

title: CONCERT: COMPUTER MUSIC
description: NEIL B. ROLNICK, a computer-music composer who teaches at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Troy, N.Y., gave a short concert Tuesday night as part of the latest music and dance series of the Whitney Museum of American Art at Philip Morris, Park Avenue at 42d Street.

title: Harvard Professor And N.F.L. Trial
description: Michael Porter, a professor at the Harvard Business School, found himself a factor in the continuing Federal court trial of the United States Football League's antitrust suit against the National Football League in New York this week.

title: UNITED STOCKYARDS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The year-ago quarter and 6 months revenue figures were restated to include investment gains and real estate fees and both year-earlier share earnings figures were restated to reflect a 10 percent stock dividend declared Dec. 23, 1985.

title: Compassion Without Bankruptcy
description: The White House public-relations apparatus is in full swing. Its message is that a bunch of wild-eyed Democrats is conspiring to lead this country to bankruptcy. But a dispassionate analysis of the budgets approved by the Senate and House suggests a remarkable degree of bipartisan unity on two crucial points: that the nation has an obligation to maintain basic social services and that it is equally obliged to raise the money to pay for them.

title: SPY TRIAL BRINGS WARNING ON NEWS
description: The Director of Central Intelligence and the head of the National Security Agency today warned news organizations against reporting on the implications of the declassified information disclosed at the trial of Ronald W. Pelton.

title: Ogilvy to Buy Adams & Rinehart
description: Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide said it had agreed to acquire Adams & Rinehart Inc., a public relations concern, for an initial payment of $6.8 million, plus future payments based on earnings over the next three years.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: CAULKING compound is one of the least expensive yet most effective materials to protect the house against the weather and to save energy. Properly applied, a good compound will keep water from seeping in and causing paint to peel or wood to rot. Even in masonry, water that seeps into joints or cracks can cause structures to deteriorate quicker, particularly when freezing alternates with thawing.

title: OFFICER'S SHOOTING TIED TO TICKETS
description: The man who shot a Suffolk County police officer in the face with a shotgun Tuesday night told the police, ''I wanted to kill him because he gave me some traffic tickets,'' the police said today.

title: HONDURAN SEES PROBLEM IF U.S. ENDS CONTRA AID
description: The President of Honduras said today that his country would face ''an extremely serious problem'' if Congress did not renew United States aid to the Nicaraguan rebels fighting from Honduran bases.

title: Saving a Church Tower On Central Park West
description: The sight of scaffolding on a landmark, as with a spider's web entwining a victim, often means demolition and is usually greeted with regret.

title: FLIERS' KIN LOSE JURY AWARDS
description: A Federal appeals court today overturned awards to the families of four men killed in military air crashes, ruling that the military contractors involved were immune from liability.

title: THE METS' THREE-CARD MONTE DEALER
description: He won six games for the Mets before Dwight Gooden did, before Ron Darling did, before Sid Fernandez did. With his change-of-speed pitches, Bob Ojeda provides what Davey Johnson, the Mets' manager, calls a ''different wrinkle to what we feature,'' alluding to the flaming fastballs of the other starters. As a pitcher, the 28-year-old left-hander is the Mets' version of the three-card monte dealer who flim-flammed him on his first visit to New York five years ago as a Boston Red Sox rookie out of the Visalia, Calif., farms. During a midtown stroll that day with another Red Sox left-hander, Bruce Hurst, they stopped to gape at the Empire State Building.

title: FIVE INDICTED IN LATEST INSIDER CASE
description: A Federal grand jury in New York indicted four Wall Street professionals and a customer yesterday on charges of trading in securities on the basis of inside information.

title: UNCERTAINTY AT GENERAL CAMP
description: Across the river from where the United States Football League's future was being determined in an antitrust suit against the National Football League, the Generals opened a three-day minicamp at Giants Stadium today.

title: Human Errors?
description: His reflexes may not be what they were when he was winning six straight Gold Gloves at second base in the 1970's, but Kansas City's 35-year-old Frank White wasn't slow in his reaction time Tuesday night. No sooner had he got to the clubhouse after a 9-1 loss to Milwaukee than he was sounding off about Royals Stadium's official scorer, Del Black, and warning that if Black crossed him again, the reaction would be even quicker.

title: Cavanaugh's 69 Leads L.I. Open
description: Randy Cavanaugh, one of the last players to finish in the late afternoon, scored 69 today to lead the first round of the Long Island Open by one stroke.

title: UTILITY WILL BUY DRUG CHAIN
description: The Pacific Lighting Corporation said today that it was acquiring the Thrifty Corporation, the biggest operator of drugstores in the West, in a stock exchange valued at $886 million.

title: A PRAGMATIC NEW FACE IN AFRICAN POLITICS: ABDOU DIOUF
description: For participants in this week's United Nations General Assembly discussion of Africa's economic crisis, the quiet words of President Abdou Diouf of Senegal have set the tone for the session.''Africa's problems are complex,'' said Mr. Diouf, ''so one cannot apply simple solutions.''As the leader of the Organization of African Unity, the 6-foot-5-inch, 50-year-old Mr. Diouf has emerged as the spokesman for a new generation of more pragmatic African leaders, a moderate who advocates long-term programs to repair his continent's wrenching economic problems.

title: A Higher Alcohol Tax Will Reduce Drinking
description: To the Editor:

title: Sikma Seeks Trade
description: Saying he is tired of the Seattle SuperSonics' losing ways, Jack Sikma, has told the team he wants to be traded. ''The main thing is I'd like to be in a position of playing with a possible contending team right now,'' said Sikma, who is 30 years old and has four years left on a contract estimated to be worth $1.5 million a year.

title: HELPING THE ELDERLY LIVE ON THEIR OWN
description: AN innovative state-sponsored housing program for the elderly has been expanding steadily in New York State in the last year.Known as Enriched Housing, it is tailored to people not in need of the full regimen of services typically offered in nursing homes, but who require some care. Clients of enriched housing projects, while unable to live independently, can, in large measure, take care of themselves.

title: The U.N. Today: May 29, 1986
description: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets at 11 A.M. on renewal of mandate of United Nations Disengagement Observer Force. >GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. >TRUSTEESHIP COUNCIL Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Belgium Cuts Key Rate
description: Belgium's central bank is lowering its key lending rate by half a point, to 8 percent. This is the fourth cut since the April 16 European Monetary System realignment, which raised the value of the Belgian currency.

title: TRANSPORTATION PANEL SAYS MORE CONTROLLERS ARE NEEDED AT O'HARE
description: Alarmed by two recent near-colli sions at Chicago's main airport, a Government board yesterday urged immediate assignment of two extra tower controllers when intersecting runways are in use.

title: SEMINARS DEFENDED BY DONLAN
description: In a long day of testimony - some of it sharp, some of it humorous - the National Football League's chief labor negotiator tried yesterday to explain that various seminars, letters and memos that the United States Football League charges constituted a pattern of anticompetitive behavior were normal business practices, designed to combat a sudden escalation in player salaries.

title:
BRIEFING;
Kemp's Unfund
description: Representative Jack F. Kemp has not been coy about his Presidential aspirations, but he and his staff are taken aback by a letter seeking $50 to $500 donations for something calling itself Kemp's First Fund.

title: EVENTS: SEPHARDIC FAIR
description: Sephardic Fair, Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue, 8 West 70th Street, 212-873-0300.

title: SHONEY'S SOUTH INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 20
NO CHARGES FILED IN FAULTY SEARCH
description: The police officers who failed to detect a second gun a suspect later used to shoot two other policemen Tuesday will not be charged with violating the department's standard operating procedures, police officials said yesterday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We all agree that Africa needs resources, but those resources must be well used.

title: Refugee Girl Is Guest For Liberty Weekend
description: An 11-year-old Vietnamese refugee who was unable to claim her prize in a Statue of Liberty essay contest because it would have disqualified her family from receiving public assistance will get a free trip to New York for Liberty weekend, officials said yesterday.

title: KEY SHOWDOWN IN LUMBER
description: The Weyerhaeuser Company sawmill has operated here since 1917, when it first started turning out wooden parts for World War I aircraft. And for most of that time, workers have considered it a generous employer, offering good wages and job security. But they are not saying that now. In a move to slash its costs, the giant lumber company is insisting that its 8,000 unionized employees accept cuts of 20 percent or more in wages and benefits.

title: FEARS GROW AS EROSION ON A L.I. BEACH WORSENS
description: When William Yankus bought his ocean-front home here 10 years ago, he had a front yard many people dream of - 150 feet of sand and beach sloping down to the Atlantic Ocean.

title: RED SOX ROUT INDIANS, 13-7, FOR 4 IN ROW
description: Jim Rice drove in five runs and Don Baylor knocked in four, including three with his 10th homer, to spark the Boston Red Sox to a 13-7 triumph over the Cleveland Indians tonight.

title: Pasadena's Place in Space
description: A faint asteroid orbiting between Mars and Jupiter has been named Pasacentennium in honor of Pasadena's centennial celebration, the California Institute of Technology, which is situated here, announced Tuesday. The asteroid was named by its discoverer, Eleanor F. Helin, a planetary scientist at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory.

title: DOW GAINS 25.25 AND HITS RECORD
description: Stock prices catapulted into record territory yesterday on a wave of institutional buying and another blue-chip rally.

title: James H. Driscoll, 76, Advertising Executive
description: James H. Driscoll, president of the Driscoll Advertising Company, died of cancer Saturday at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Manhattan. He was 76 years old. Mr. Driscoll, a resident of Manhattan, was the founder and president of the company at 45 John Street.

title: GORBACHEV PROMISES SYRIANS ARMS SUPPLIES WILL CONTINUE
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev told a visiting Syrian leader today that the Soviet Union would continue to supply military aid, according to the Government press agency Tass.

title: MUNICIPAL BOND INSURER EXPECTED TO OFFER STOCK
description: The Financial Guaranty Insurance Company, the fastest-growing insurer of municipal bonds last year, is expected to announce today plans for a public stock offering.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: 42D ST. STATIONS ARE HIGHEST IN CRIME
description: Four subway stations on 42d Street in Manhattan were the most crime-ridden in the system in 1985, the transit police reported yesterday.

title: YANKEES STRUGGLE, DESPITE 4 HOME RUNS
description: Their pitching troubles continued tonight, but at least the Yankees can take comfort in an offense that produces runs as if they were coming off an assembly line.

title: POPE CONSIDERS BETTER SOVIET TIES
description: Pope John Paul II is considering new efforts to improve ties between the Vatican and the Soviet Union, Vatican officials said today.

title: Nuclear Emergency Plan Opposed in N. Carolina
description: The Chatham County Board of Commissioners voted Tuesday night to withdraw from the emergency plan developed for the Shearon Harris nuclear power plant in nearby New Hill.

title: CORNELL MEDICAL SCHOOL: GOOD OLD DAYS ARE DERIDED
description: At the 89th commencement exercises yesterday, graduates of the Cornell University Medical College were told not to pay attention to those who hark back to the old days of medicine.

title: 9 1/2% Ralston Issue
description: A $300 million issue of Ralston Purina Company 9 1/2 percent debentures due in 2016 was offered yesterday at a price of 97.60 to yield 9.75 percent, through underwriters led by the First Boston Company. The debentures, which are not refundable for 10 years, are rated Baa-1 by Moody's and A- by S.&P.

title: LOGICON INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Market Place; A.M.A. to Own Fund Manager
description: MOVE over Dreyfus, Vanguard Group and Fidelity Investments. The American Medical Association is going into the mutual fund business. The A.M.A. plans to acquire the stock of PRO Services Inc., a mutual fund management company based in Blue Bell, Pa., for $3.5 million in cash and $500,000 in notes.

title: ONSET OF AIDS AFTER TRANSFUSION FOUND TO LAG AVERAGE OF 5 YEARS
description: The average time lag between infection with the AIDS virus and the onset of acquired immune deficiency syndrome has been at least five years among people who developed the deadly affliction after receiving contaminated transfusions, according to a Federal study.

title: AIM TELEPHONES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $122,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and $233,000, or 8 cents a share, for the year. c-Includes an extraordinary loss of $3,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $53,000, or 3 cents a share, for the year.

title: Baker Doubts Inflation Gain
description: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d said today that he saw little evidence that the decline of the dollar would revive inflation anytime soon. But, characterisically, he avoided saying whether he thought the dollar should decline more to help American exporters and dampen the protectionist attitudes in Congress.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Mort Scharfman has been named senior vice president/creative director of Doyle Dane Bernbach, San Francisco.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Fedders Corp., Peapack, N.J., said it was considering a plan to spin off its Nycor unit by offering shares in the company as a dividend to shareholders. Nycor said the decision would depend on how taxes would affect the transaction.

title: ESTERLINE CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The latest second quarter and 6 months figures reflect adoption of Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No. 87, which resulted in an increase in net income of $93,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $183,000, or 2 cents a share, for the 6 months.

title: ALAS, POOR HAMLET! OR SOMETHING'S ROTTEN
description: IN a lecture at Cambridge University, as recently reported in Plays and Players magazine, Tom Stoppard discussed various historical revisions of Shakespeare - attempts, he said, ''to save Shakespeare from himself.'' By this he meant the odd twists and happy endings cavalierly appended to the tragedies: Nahum Tate's rewrite of ''King Lear,'' which closed with Cordelia marrying Edgar; Romeo and Juliet revived from the dead for a reconciliation scene; the Garrick version of ''Hamlet,'' in which Hamlet stabs Claudius after Claudius threatens to send him to England (anything to keep from going to England). Reading Mr. Stoppard's wry comments reminded me of more modern mischief perpetrated on Shakespeare, in particular on ''Hamlet'' -alterations that make the recent Liviu Ciulei production seem far less eccentric.

title: Marcos's Bill at Base Is Put at $206,000
description: Ferdinand E. Marcos and the nearly 90 people who fled from Manila with him ran up a bill of more than $206,000 for personal expenses, including $2,552 for shoes, during the month they stayed at United States Air Force bases, a Congressional report said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article and a picture caption in The Living Section yesterday about celebrities as restaurateurs gave an incorrect address for Positano. The restaurant is at 250 Park Avenue South.

title: SUPERMARKETS GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
Advertising; MCA Sets Purchase Of Ally & Gargano
description: MCA Advertising, a subsidiary of the Marketing Corporation of America, has agreed to merge with Ally & Gargano after 10 months of negotiations. The combined subsidiary, to be named Ally Gargano/MCA Advertising Ltd., will have annual billings of $300 million - $170 million from MCA and $130 million from A.&G. With $12 cash being paid for each outstanding A.&G. share, the deal totals $26.65 million.

title: Sellers's Daughter, 21, To Aid in Drug Inquiry
description: The 21-year-old daughter of the late Peter Sellers, the actor, and Britt Ekland, the actress, has pleaded guilty to a charge stemming from her knowledge of a violent, international cocaine ring and will testify for the Government, court documents unsealed today disclosed.

title: STERLING ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: b-Includes a loss from relocation costs of $70,700. c-Net income

title: Reagan 'Legitimizes' Botha
description: When President Botha of South Africa last week raided three of his southern African neighbors because he said they harbored terrorists, the sound amidst the gunfire was the sound of President Reagan's Libyan chickens coming home to roost.

title: HUSSEIN TO SEE REAGAN
description: President Reagan and King Hussein of Jordan will meet here June 9, the White House announced today. King Hussein will be in the United States for the graduation of two of his children from high school.

title: Anti-Apartheid Rally Planned for June 14
description: More than 200 labor, political, religious and student organizations are joining to sponsor an anti-apartheid rally June 14.

title: CONCERT: ALL-PELOSI PROGRAM
description: RATHER than wait for performers to discover their work, more and more composers are becoming their own impresarios. On Tuesday night at Merkin Concert Hall, Louis Pelosi presided over an evening of his music, with the help of the pianist Eliza Garth, the violinist Dale Stuckenbruck, the mezzo-soprano Mihal Shiff, the cellist Michael Rudiakov, the clarinetist Laura Flax, the conductor Morris Rosenzweig (who shared podium duties with the composer) and several other musicians.

title: Interest Rates Show Increases
description: Interest rates rose and prices declined for short- and long-term Treasury issues yesterday, though securities dealers noted that there was good investor demand early in the day for outstanding notes due in five to 10 years.

title: EXERCISE GROWING AS A FAMILY ACTIVITY
description: AT the young age of 4, Jeffrey Lowenstein is, like his parents Kenneth and Ronnie, an outdoors enthusiast. He goes backpacking for three hours at a stretch in the Catskill Mountains. ''I hike to find animals - chipmunks, lizards and frogs,'' he said.

title: Topics; Pet Projects; Disclosing Cats
description: On his financial disclosure form last year, Representative Andy Jacobs of Indiana listed his Great Dane puppy, Friend, as a liability. This year, however, Friend became an ''invaluable asset.''

title: P.A.L. Essay Winner
description: Adrian J. Kuduk does not want to be a police officer when he grows up. But he has given some thought to the relationship between the Police Department and the city's youth, as part of a class essay assignment.

title: FROM A PRISON OFFICE, INMATES ANSWER TELEPHONES FOR PAY AND SELF-RESPECT
description: For four hours each workday, when she is sitting at her desk and answering one of 33 constantly ringing telephones, Sandra Mitchell takes a psychological trip outside the red brick walls of the Bayview Correctional Facility in Manhattan, where she is imprisoned.

title: GOODEN WINS 6TH, STRIKING OUT 10, TO END MILD SLUMP
description: Sweat dropped from his chin on the warm night, his eyes wide, his face revealing no troubles, only calm. His fastball had the old movement and the curve was delectably pinpoint. Spread the word. Nothing is wrong with Dwight Gooden.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Cabaret-Law Target Was Wild Strangers
description: To the Editor:

title: AIR FORCE ACADEMY: BUSH WARNS ON TECHNOLOGY
description: The Air Force Academy Class of '86 graduated today, and its members included the son of the commander of the ill-fated space shuttle Challenger and the first woman chosen as outstanding cadet.

title: PHILANTHROPIST BACKS ARCHIVE IN MONTREAL
description: In some quarters, they call Phyllis Lambert Joan of Architecture, a sobriquet bestowed with affection and respect. Mrs. Lambert, an architect, writer, photographer and passionate urban preservationist, is a daughter of Samuel Bronfman, the Canadian distillery giant, and the woman responsible for having Ludwig Mies van der Rohe design the great International Style landmark in Manhattan, the Seagram Building.

title: THROW RUGH WITH A DIFFERENCE
description: HIS first work was for himself - a rug cut from a sheet of 1950's linoleum.

title: HOWARD S. GREENWALD
description: Howard S. Greenwald, a former executive vice president of Manhattan Industries, apparel manufacturers and retailers, died Monday at his home in Glen Rock, N.J. He was 65 years old.

title: DAMSON ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain from the early extinguishment of debentures of $1,491,000 and attributable primarily to a writedown of about $62.5 million on the partnership's oil and gas properties. c-Net income

title: DYCOM INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Help for Women, Old and Young
description: A man of 45 years old is presumed to be hitting his prime. Not so his female counterpart. According to a study by the Older Women's League (OWL) of the 40 million women who are 45 and over, the mid-40's often mark the beginning of downward mobility. The study makes clearer than ever the need, beyond Social Security and Federal medical aid, to help women help themselves.

title: Advertising; 9 Gold Awards Won By Fallon McElligott
description: It was the kind of night to make New York ad agencies bow their heads in shame.

title: '20/20' REPORT ON M.I.A.'S
description: ARE there still American prisoners of war in Vietnam? It is a ''haunting question,'' as ''20/20'' says, a question that declines to be dismissed. It lingers because families want to believe that husbands, fathers and sons are still alive; it lingers because of unresolved issues. ''20/20'' explores the question of prisoners on ABC at 10 o'clock tonight.

title: 4 Armenians Are Murdered In Moslem Section of Beirut
description: Four Armenians have been murdered in Moslem West Beirut in the last 24 hours.

title: TRADE CURBS BY U.S. AGAINST SANDINISTAS ARE CALLED A FAILURE
description: President Reagan's trade sanctions have inflicted relatively modest economic losses on Nicaragua and have been a ''tactical mistake'' politically, according to two Washington research institutes.

title:
BRIEFING;
That Alexander Lottery
description: In the wake of a hard-fought Democratic primary victory in Arkansas's First Congressional district, Representative Bill Alexander has asked state party officials to consider filing a complaint about a campaign lottery sponsored by the National Republican Congressional Committee.

title: Sherrill Milnes to Open Queens College Season
description: A performance on Oct. 18 by Sherrill Milnes, the Metropolitan Opera baritone, will open the 1986-87 season at Queens College's Colden Center for the Performing Arts, Kissena Boulevard and the Long Island Expressway in Flushing.

title: SHULTZ CONDEMNS EAST GERMANY'S STEP
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the NATO allies ''cannot tolerate'' East Germany's apparent effort to impose passport controls on diplomats seeking to travel from East to West Berlin.

title: EVANGELIST'S DRAW STINGS G.O.P. RIVALS
description: The Rev. Pat Robertson's success in mobilizing the religious right as a new force in Republican politics in Michigan deprived two of the party's major Presidential hopefuls of a clear victory in their first test of strength, according to political professionals and party strategists.

title: U.S. REFUSES PERMIT TO BURN TOXIC WASTES IN THE ATLANTIC
description: The Federal Environmental Protection Agency today refused to grant a permit to incinerate toxic wastes off the Atlantic Seaboard on a test basis.

title: State U. Trustees Vote For Sports Scholarships
description: The trustees of the State University of New York voted yesterday to allow individual campuses of the state college system to grant athletic scholarships and to raise their levels of sports competition.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: New York State and California yesterday offered two large new bond issues totaling $600 million, through underwriters led by Chase Manhattan Bank. Underwriters said that demand for the new bonds was very strong, with heavy buying by institutional investors.

title: MAN RIDING A BICYCLE ON CONEY I. IS BEATEN AND STABBED TO DEATH
description: A 20-year-old man who was riding a bicycle on a Brooklyn street early yesterday was fatally beaten and stabbed by a group of at least six men who then took his bicycle and fled in automobiles, the police said.

title: NBC Wins Ratings On Strength of Reruns
description: On the strength of reruns, NBC soared to the top of the weekly prime-time ratings and led by the third biggest margin since September, figures showed yesterday.

title:
BRIEFING;
That Race in Maryland
description: Kathleen Kennedy Townsend will make it official today, announcing her candidacy for Maryland's Second Congressional District seat against the incumbent, Helen Delich Bentley, a Republican. Mrs. Townsend will outline her campaign at Towson American Legion Post 22, in that suburb of Baltimore.

title: Required Reading; The Passport Business
description: Excerpt from testimony of Joan M. Clark, Assistant Secretary of State for Consular Affairs, before the House Foreign Affairs Subcommittee on International Operations, May 15:

title: THE RISE OF A BALTIMORE INSTITUTION
description: The first issue of The Sun appeared in Baltimore on May 17, 1837, as a one-cent tabloid. ''Baltimore was not impressed,'' according to an official history written a century later.

title: Grace to Sell Retail Stores
description: W. R. Grace & Company agreed in principle to sell the balance of its retail stores, including its home improvement and jewelry outlets, to an investor group led by Bernard R. Kossar, senior vice president of Grace's retail group, the Citicorp Capital Investors Group and Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

title: Airline Deal Gets Backing
description: The Transportation Department's public advocate has recommended that Northwest Airlines be allowed to buy Republic Airlines, contending the $884 million acquisition would not cause higher fares or reduced services by reducing competition.

title: Gorbachev Attends Meeting Of Internal Security Agency
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev attended a meeting of the K.G.B. on Tuesday and today.

title: FIFA Head Stays On
description: Joao Havelange, the president of FIFA, the international soccer federation, said that since no other candidate had come forward, he would serve another four-year term as the president of soccer's world governing body. Havelange made the announcement in Mexico City at a meeting of the federation's executive committee held in conjunction with the World Cup, which begins here Saturday in Aztec Stadium with opening ceremonies and a game between Italy, the defending champion, and Bulgaria.

title: MUSIC: PIANO RECITAL BY TSOPELAS
description: VINIA TSOPELAS, the Greek pianist who gave her first local recital Tuesday at Alice Tully Hall, is qualified to play Beethoven's sonata ''Appassionata,'' (Op. 57), in that she has the capacity to become impassioned during a public performance. There was a sense of engagement with the music (its predominant characteristic, in her interpretation, was a kind of pregnant mysteriousness), and this involvement proved characteristic; thus one heard her program with pleasure even though her skills are not extraordinary ones.

title: Bethlehem's Chief Adds Job
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said yesterday that Walter F. Williams, its president and chief executive, had been elected to the additional post of chairman.

title: Cyanide Taint Feared in Texas
description: A 24-year-old man who died May 22 may have taken an Anacin-3 capsule that contained cyanide, the authorities said today. Officials of the Walgreen drug store chain said the product has been ordered off store shelves.

title: CONEY I.: SYMBOL OF FUN IS NOW ONE OF DESPAIR
description: Toward the western end of Coney Island, the sight of the Parachute Jump is the only reminder that this place once meant pleasure and recreation. Now, it is nothing but a slum by the sea, where violence is common, the homeless abound and the chief concessions of Surf Avenue involve drugs and prostitution.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: LIONEL TRILLING AND THE FATE OF CULTURAL CRITICISM. By Mark Krupnick. 207 pages. Illustrated.

title: AMERICAN SCIENCE & ENGIEERING reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax loss carryforwards of $109,000 for the quarter and $363,000 for the year. b-Net loss

title: BURROUGHS WILL COURT KEY SPERRY EXECUTIVES
description: The Burroughs Corporation said yesterday that it will try to enter into new five-year employment contracts with 26 key Sperry Corporation employees before the merger of the two companies is completed in about two months.

title: APARTHEID'S REFUGEES LOSE GROUND TO BULLDOZERS
description: Just before the bulldozer came, the woman swathed in a blanket darted forward and tugged at a piece of corrugated zinc sheeting. She pulled it from the debris as if salvaging an item of great value - gold, say, from a sunken clipper.

title: U.S. Envoy to China Takes Look at Trade
description: When a Holiday Inn opens in Tibet soon, it will represent a high-water mark in ''the astounding success story'' of United States relations with China, the newly appointed United States Ambassador to Peking said today.

title: SPERRY'S SKILLED AND DOGGED PURSUER
description: W. Michael Blumenthal, the chairman of the Burroughs Corporation, loves to negotiate. He has studied the art of negotiating, and practices his skill whenever he can, even, on occasion, entertaining friends by trying to negotiate discounts at restaurants.

title: 'GREEN CARD,' A 2-YEAR WAIT
description: FOR working parents - or people responsible for their own ailing and elderly parents - finding the right domestic help may be a matter of survival.

title: Cuomo Picks Lundine As His Running Mate
description: Governor Cuomo named Representative Stan Lundine of Jamestown as his running mate yesterday, saying he wanted a lieutenant governor ''who was competent to be governor immediately.''

title: Advertising; G.M. Puts Stress on Efficiency
description: The General Motors Corporation, which spent $978 million last year for advertising worldwide, wants to use the clout of those dollars across media lines and national boundaries to get the lowest prices from the media.

title: WAYS SOUGHT TO BLOCK USE OF A TAX WINDFALL
description: A senior Treasury official said today that the Administration might recommend moving up to next Jan. 1 the drop in personal and corporate income tax rates proposed in Congress. This would prevent a revenue windfall that would result from the first year of tax revision being used to help balance the budget.

title:
BRIEFING;
Bats, Capital Style
description: It is softball season in Washington, and the daily scramble for the limited number of playing fields on the mall in front of the Capitol is under way. To obtain a grassy field, as opposed to a muddy swamp or hilly infield, most Congressional offices dispatch interns to the mall in mid-afternoon to sit for hours in the hot sun and stake out territory for the evening game.

title: SUN NEWSPAPERS OF BALTIMORE WILL BE SOLD TO TIMES MIRROR
description: The owners of The Sun and The Evening Sun, the celebrated Baltimore newspapers that were home to H. L. Mencken and the winners of 12 Pulitzer Prizes, said yesterday that they would sell the papers to the Times Mirror Company, the Los Angeles-based communications conglomerate.

title: Broken Hill Bid Falls Short
description: Robert Holmes a Court's latest bid for control of the Broken Hill Proprietary Company again came up short, but the Perth investor is not expected to abandon his long-running battle for Australia's biggest company.

title: LUCKY SOVIET KIN INCLUDE MANY JEWS
description: About half of the 117 Soviet citizens told they could join families in the United States are Jews, the State Department said today.

title: POISONINGS ARE AVOIDABLE BY FOLLOWING INSTRUCTIONS
description: SAFETY is the most important consideration when a pesticide is used, either by a householder or a professional exterminator.

title: Memphis State Decision
description: Saying, ''We don't really blame the N.C.A.A., we just had a difference of opinion,'' Dr. Thomas Carpenter, president of Memphis State, announced that the university would accept a two-year probation and return almost $1 million in basketball tournament proceeds.

title: REDKEN LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Share earnings are restated for a 10 percent stock dividend paid in the latest quarter.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report on Tuesday in the Briefing column of the Washington Talk page misstated the Senate tenure of the actor George Murphy. He served one term and was defeated for re-election in 1970.

title: Just Grand
description: George Foster's bases-loaded homer for the Mets on Tuesday night brought him within two of the grand-slam leader among all active major-leaguers, Dave Kingman.

title: FRETTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
VARIETY IN TIEBACKS
description: THE curtain tieback is an alternative to the braided cord and decorative tassel to hold back draperies. Tiebacks are often used by those who want a simpler look than that of the fancy cord, by those who want to add metal -such as brass or wrought iron - to their decor and by those copying a period design.

title: 'LIZA IN LONDON' PRESENTED ON HBO
description: EVEN devoted fans of Liza Minnelli might be forgiven for approaching ''Liza in London'' with some trepidation. For one thing, the prospect of listening to her belt ''Cabaret'' and ''New York, New York'' still once again can seem daunting. For another, watching her perform at the London Palladium inevitably triggers memories of her mother's triumph there decades ago. And despite the physical and aural echoes, Liza Minnelli is not Judy Garland. Yet, for all that, Miss Minnelli gets out there on the stage and does the kind of star turn that, more's the pity, is fast disappearing from show business. ''Liza in London,'' on Home Box Office's pay-cable service tonight at 7:30, is an exciting and almost poignant reminder of what we may be losing in a glitzy new world of mammoth stage sets and music videos, a world in which performers seem interchangeable.

title: WHEN A BARN BECOMES A HOME, THE FIRST RULE IS TO KEEP IT SIMPLE
description: ALTHOUGH the success of many buildings resides in their architectural details, the very appeal of barns may be that they have none. Rough and cavernous, barns are magnificently free of small, meticulous joints and fine materials carefully worked. Most barns were built by farmers, not professional builders, and their charm lies not in their refinement or subtlety, but in their directness and informality.

title: FESTIVAL'S BAN ON ORWELL GETS MIXED REACTION
description: Producers, publishers, actors and others involved in the arts responded with a mixture of anger and resignation at the decision to withdraw a stage production of George Orwell's ''Animal Farm'' from an international theater festival in Baltimore.

title: Honor Switched From I.L.G.W.U. to Jazz
description: A cryptic line at the end of an announcement from the Queens Borough President's office tells much about how local heroes change.

title: LENDL, NAVRATILOVA WIN
description: Top-seeded Ivan Lendl and Martina Navratilova moved easily into the third round of the French Open today and Steffi Graf of West Germany stretched her winning streak through a 22d match.

title: A New Wrinkle In Farm Bonds
description: The Federal Farm Credit System successfully introduced a new wrinkle in its regular monthly financings, selling bonds due in three months.

title: PATIENT WAIT FOR GUERRERO
description: The gray baseball shirts with the blue numerals and white trim had been hung in the stall of nearly every Dodger in the visiting team clubhouse at Shea Stadium. The exception was a player who had been out chatting while his teammates were taking batting practice. He wore warm-up pants and a sleeveless blue T-shirt as his teammates went about their routine. Pedro Guerrero talked to friends, and talked to fans, and posed for a picture, and signed autographs.

title: CITY: GREEN PLANTINGS SHADE A PATIO
description: AMONG the many backyard gardens that flourish in Greenwich village, Daniel D. Stewart's is something of a standout. It ought to be, because Mr. Stewart is a landscape architect whose interests include city garden design.

title: Mutual Shares Buys Mesa Stock
description: The Mutual Shares Corporation, a New York-based investment firm, said it held 5.3 percent of the Mesa Petroleum Company's 66.9 million shares outstanding. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mutual said it had bought the Mesa shares ''as part of their ordinary course of business'' and added that it had ''no plans to acquire control'' of the company.

title: Don't Deny Aid to a Democratic Pakistan
description: To the Editor:

title: WESTVACO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
U.S. AND JAPAN NEAR A PACT ON CHIPS
description: The United States and Japan have drawn up the broad outlines of an agreement aimed at reducing the United States deficit in semiconductor trade after nine months of negotiations.

title: DANCE: 'DON QUIXOTE' RETURNS TO ABT
description: EVERYBODY was agog on stage at the Metropolitan Opera House on Tuesday night. Fans were snapped, tambourines were thumped, goblets and guitars were hurled right and left. ''Don Quixote'' has returned to the repertory of American Ballet Theater.

title: AFRICANS UNHAPPY ON REPLIES AT U.N. AID SESSION
description: Many African delegates expressed disappointment today at the failure of the industrialized donor countries to commit themselves to specific financial targets requested by African nations at the General Assembly special session on the African economic crisis.

title: DOCTORS CHALLENGING CITY HOSPITALS BOARD ON CLOSED MEETINGS
description: A union representing doctors at New York City hospitals charged yesterday that the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation had adopted a new policy of meeting behind closed doors in violation of the state's open-meeting law.

title: Congress; Down and a Little Out On $75,100 a Year
description: The Lungren family of Vienna, Va., and Long Beach, Calif., is about to start its summer scramble.

title: Compensation Flaws
description: To the Editor:

title: CITY IS ORDERED TO DEPEND LESS ON FOSTER CARE
description: A Civil Court judge ordered New York City yesterday to take more action to keep children out of foster homes and with their natural parents.

title: SYRIAN IS 'CERTAIN' FRENCH HOSTAGES WILL BE FREED
description: Syria's Defense Minister said today that his Government was negotiating with the groups holding French hostages in Lebanon and that he was ''certain'' that Syria would gain the captives' release.

title: Staten Island Is Tired of Short End of City's Stick
description: To the Editor:

title: 16 Hurt When B Train Stops
description: Sixteen subway riders were injured yesterday when a crowded B train leaving the Pacific Street station in downtown Brooklyn for Manhattan jerked to a halt during the morning rush hour, throwing passengers to the floor. The injured were taken to hospitals, where all were treated and released. The Transit Authority said that the accident was being investigated and that the reason the train came to a sudden halt was not yet known.

title: JUSTICE IN IMPEACHMENT INQUIRY QUITS IN RHODE ISLAND
description: After two weeks of public testimony in an inquiry into whether he should be impeached, Chief Justice Joseph A. Bevilacqua of the Rhode Island Supreme Court resigned today.

title: Betting Inquiry Reported
description: The National Football League is investigating whether the wide receiver Irving Fryar and other members of the New England Patriots bet on football games last season, according to a published report.

title: Signal Capital Gets First Asset-Based
description: The Signal Capital Corporation said it had acquired First Asset-Based Lending Group Inc. from the First National Bank and Trust Company of Oklahoma City for about $65 million. First Asset-Based is a commercial lender that makes loans to companies against their inventories and accounts receivable.

title: Write-Down Seen At NL Industries
description: NL Industries, a major oil services company, said it expected to write down its petroleum service assets by at least $250 million in the second quarter because of sharp cuts in exploration, which have led to a decline in domestic drilling.

title: Point Well Taken
description: White's blow-up may have been nothing more than a result of the world champion Royals' disappointing record. Told by a reporter after an earlier loss to Milwaukee that several factors in that game had pointed to victory, Manager Dick Howser said: ''Yeah, that's why I never point.''

title: COMMERCIAL SHEARING INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
DAVID ELLIN
description: David Ellin, a leading actor in the Yiddish theater who also appeared on the Broadway stage, died Tuesday at Lenox Hill Hospital after suffering a heart attack. He was 61 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: CUOMO PROPOSES PERIODIC REVIEWS FOR ALL DOCTORS
description: All physicians in New York State would have to pass periodic competency reviews to keep their licenses, under a rule proposed yesterday by Governor Cuomo.

title: Urylee Leonardos Memorial
description: A memorial service will be held Monday at 7 P.M. at St. Malachy's Church, 239 West 49th Street, for the actress and singer Urylee Leonardos. Miss Leonardos played leads and featured roles in such Broadway musicals as ''Carmen Jones,'' ''Lost in the Stars,'' ''Wildcat'' and ''Porgy and Bess,'' in which she alternated as Bess with Leontyne Price in the Blevins Davis and Robert Breen revival in the 1950's. Miss Leonardos, who was 67 years old, died of cancer April 25 at her home in Queens.

title: U.S. MILITARY ACADEMY: WEINBERGER ADVISES CADETS ON THE NEED FOR LEADERSHIP
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger told 973 graduating cadets of the United States Military Academy today to dedicate themselves to leadership for a war he hoped they would never have to fight.

title: Comings and Goings
description: A Superior Court judge in Los Angeles has upheld an arbitrator's decision to award the former defensive back Pat Thomas his entire $200,000 salary for the 1983 season when he was sidelined by a knee injury. Judge Jerry Fields rejected claims by the Raiders and the Rams, who traded Thomas to the Raiders in July 1983. He passed the Rams' physical, but flunked the one administered by the Raiders. . . . Herb Brooks, the former coach of the Rangers, confirmed last week's report and became head coach of St. Cloud State in his native Minnesota.

title: U.S. SAYS IT LACKS EVIDENCE ON MEXICO DRUGS
description: The Treasury Department said today that it had no evidence that the Governor of the Mexican state of Sonora, knew of the cultivation of marijuana and opium poppies on ranches he owns.

title: Checkpoints Do Not Prevent Drunken Driving, Study Says
description: Random checkpoints where motorists are stopped are not an effective way to prevent drunken driving, the American Bar Association says.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, MAY 29, 1986
description: Companies

title: Hewlett-Packard Computer Debut
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company, based in Palo Alto, Calif., introduced the first computer in its technical series that uses new architecture based on the principles of reduced-instruction-set computing.

title: CONCEPTS REVISED ON SPACE TRAVEL
description: Rapid advances in extremely powerful lasers and directed particle beams, such as the ones being developed for the Administration's advanced antimissile shield, are leading to new ideas about interstellar communication and space travel, scientists reported here today.

title: Working Profile: Herbert J. Miller; A 'Farm Boy' Representing Deaver
description: Herbert J. (Jack) Miller takes the tough cases.

title: SURPRISE G.O.P. CANDIDATE LEAVES RACE
description: Two days after she became the Republican leadership's surprise candidate for lieutenant governor, Jeanine F. Pirro said today that she would not run, throwing a well-orchestrated state committee nominating meeting into confusion.

title: Advertising; Addendum
description: * Golf Digest is raising its rate base 2 percent, to 1,225,000, and its rates 2 percent with the September issue.

title: COMTECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $31,000, a loss of $6,000 from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $58,000. c-Net income includes a loss from discontinued operations of $744,000, a gain on disposal of discontinued operations of $5,933,000 and a tax credit of $2,600,000.

title: Recital at Merkin Hall
description: The flutist Rie Schmidt and the guitarist Benjamin Verdery will present a recital of music by composers as diverse as J. S. Bach, Francois Couperin, Toru Takemitsu, and Jimi Hendrix at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street, tomorrow night at 9. Tickets are $8. Information: 362-8719.

title: Canada Eases Stand on Trade
description: American trade negotiators told their Canadian counterparts today that the United States did not owe Canada any trade concessions as a result of last week's Presidential decision to increase import duties on certain Canadian lumber products, officials of both countries said today.

title: Jaki Byard, Piano
description: Jaki Byard is playing piano solos tonight through Sunday at Burgundy, 467 Amsterdam Avenue, above 82d Street (787-8300). Music begins at 9 P.M.; there is a $10 minimum at tables, a two-drink minimum at the bar.

title: CITY GAS CO OF FLORIDA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MORE DEATHS EXPECTED
description: An American doctor who is treating the victims of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster said here today that the number of deaths from radiation exposure had risen to 21.

title: RYMER COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to April 26
description: b-Includes tax credits of $387,000 and $673,000 for quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $903,000 and $2,080,000 for quarter and 6 months, respectively. The company reported that results in the latest quarter and 6 months include those of Murry's Steaks Inc., acquired in October.

title: 11 AT REFUGEE CAMP IN THAILAND KILLED, 40 HURT IN SHELLING
description: Artillery shells hit a rebel-controlled Cambodian refugee camp just inside Thailand today, killing at least 11 people and wounding as many as 40, officials reported from the camp. Several of those reported dead were children.

title: OFFICIAL FAVORS A TEST PROGRAM TO CURB AIDS
description: Dr. James Curran, one of the top Federal officials in the fight against AIDS, said yesterday that he would support a test program to give clean hypodermic needles and syringes to drug addicts to help curtail the spread of the disorder.

title: LEADING INDICATORS CLIMB 1.5%
description: Interest rates on short- and long-term Treasury securities rose sharply yesterday in response to signs that economic activity is strengthening and is likely to continue to improve.

title: SYNTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $118,000 for the quarter and $2,927,000 for the 9 months plus a gain on the sale of discontinued operations of $153,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes a gain from discontinued operations of $258,000 plus a gain on the sale of discontinued operations of $16,157,000.

title: INTERPHASE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Sudan Aide at U.N. Asks For Global Africa Aid
description: The Deputy Prime Minister of the Sudan said today that Africa recognized that ''a mighty national effort'' was needed to carry out its plans for economic recovery, but felt it was ''the duty'' of the international community to provide necessary financial backing.

title: Pipeline Planned
description: The Consolidated Natural Gas Company of Pittsburgh announced plans to build a pipeline system that would deliver attractively priced Canadian gas to the New York City area.

title: New O'Grady Plea
description: Deane Beman, commissioner of the PGA Tour, has turned down Mac O'Grady's appeal of the $5,000 fine and six-event suspension imposed by the commissioner last month for what Beman called action ''unbecoming a professional golfer.''

title: MANHATTAN: RENOVATING IN OLD AREA
description: The Washington Heights section of northern Manhattan is graced with blocks of solid, prewar apartment buildings, many displaying marble staircases and delicate tiled floors.

title: Not-So-Vital Statistics On Senator Packwood
description: Senator Bob Packwood, a 53-year-old Republican, has represented Oregon in the Senate since 1967 and, as chairman of the Finance Committee, recently oversaw the evolution of a tax revision bill that many, including the Senator himself, at first gave little chance of succeeding. After months of work, however, the committee unanimously approved the bill just after midnight May 8, and it appears likely to pass when the full Senate, in televised debate, takes it up next Wednesday. Some insights into Mr. Packwood, as provided by the Senator: Height - 5 feet 11 inches. Weight - 180 pounds.

title: HUNTER COLLEGE: TUTU AGAIN URGES SANCTIONS FOR SOUTH AFRICA
description: Bishop Desmond M. Tutu of South Africa yesterday renewed his call for the imposition of economic sanctions against the South African Government, saying it was ''the last nonviolent option left'' in the campaign against apartheid, the nation's policy of racial separation.

title: SCREEN: ROB NILSSON DIRECTS 'SIGNAL SEVEN'
description: ''SIGNAL SEVEN,'' which opens today at the Waverly, is an unusual, touching, intelligent film. It helps to prove the case, argued notably by such recent gems as Horton Foote's ''1918'' and ''On Valentine's Day,'' that excellent movies can be made without big stars and mega-budgets. In ''Signal Seven,'' a bunch of very talented people with a good dose of artistic integrity have managed - for about $150,000 - to turn out a film whose haunting theme will linger long after many more expensive films are forgotten.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Computer Horizons Corp., which provides customized softwear services, named Edward S. Fleury to the new position of senior vice president, corporate development, with responsibility for acquisitions.

title: A Diamond Merchant Is Robbed at Sheraton
description: More than $200,000 in diamonds was stolen from a Belgian diamond merchant about to enter his room at the Sheraton Centre Hotel in midtown yesterday morning by a robber who assaulted the merchant and handcuffed him to a bed, the police said.

title: NATO FAULTS U.S. ON INTENT TO DROP 1979 ARMS TREATY
description: Britain, West Germany, Canada and other NATO allies expressed alarm today over President Reagan's decision to stop adhering to the terms of a 1979 strategic arms accord unless there is a major change in Soviet policy.

title: The U.N. Today: May 30, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. >TRUSTEESHIP COUNCIL Meets at 10:30 A.M.

title: Wilander Overcomes Krickstein
description: Mats Wilander of Sweden, the defending champion, beat Aaron Krickstein today, 6-1, 3-6, 5-7, 6-3, 6-4, at the French Open championships. Wilander, seeded No. 2, needed every shot he could muster to turn back Krickstein, who was unseeded and ranked 36th in the world.

title: Casey Gives Data on Finances
description: William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, released a list of his assets and income today, but it only included a small portion of his multimillion-dollar wealth.

title: THE OLD AND THE NEW
description: In Mexico, the past and the present are never far apart. In the upscale El Presidente Chapultepec hotel, there are rooms and boutiques and restaurants catering to affluent visitors to the World Cup of soccer, which begins tomorrow.

title: LIFETIME COMMUNITIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $192,710 and $349,560 for quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: AMERICAN STORES CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes after-tax LIFO charges of $3,250,000 for the latest quarter and $3 million for the year-ago period.

title: U.S. Emergency Fund Called Nearly Depleted
description: With the start of the six-month hurricane season only three days away, the Federal Emergency Management Agency says it is running millions of dollars short of what it may need to provide emergency relief assistance to local communities.

title: COMMONWEALTH SAVINGS & LOAN OF FLA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
INTEREST RATES UP SHARPLY
description: The Government index designed to predict the course of the economy surged 1.5 percent in April, its third strong gain in as many months, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE OXFORD DICTIONARY OF POPES. By J. N. D.Kelly. 347 pages. Oxford University Press. $24.95. WHO exactly was St. Silverius? ''Born at Frosinone, son of Hormisdas, he was, unprecedentedly, only a subdeacon when, news of Agapitus I's death at Constantinople having reached Rome, Theodahad, last Ostrogothic king of Italy (534-6), terrorized the clergy into electing him pope.'' Within less than a year, however, he was deposed by the Emperor Justinian's General Belisarius and sent into exile, dying not long afterward as a result of his sufferings.

title: Diner's Journal
description: THE Hudson River waterfront from the West Village down to SoHo is becoming a berth for all sorts of funky new restaurants catering to a young, budget-minded crowd. One of the latest is a kaleidoscopic night spot called Sunset Strip, at 95 Horatio Street. Sunset Strip looks as if a couple of tipsy house painters were set loose with their brushes for an afternoon - the walls are splashed with pastels and the bar is covered with brush strokes of black on white. Add to this purple banquettes overlaid with black and white cowhides, paint-dabbled floors and - well, you get the picture.

title: Potholes in New York, A Hardy Perennial
description: To the Editor:

title: SCREEN: 'BIG TROUBLE,' WITH ARKIN AND FALK
description: LEONARD HOFFMAN (Alan Arkin) is a successful Los Angeles insurance salesman, but not successful enough to be able to afford the $42,000 tuition fees to send his three musically gifted sons - triplets - to Yale. Yale has accepted the boys but hasn't come forward with any financial assistance.

title: TELOS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes losses of $98,000 and $465,000 from discontinued operations for quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes losses of $116,000 and $150,000 from discontinued operations for quarter and year, respectively.

title: Kodak Sensor
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said it had developed a new solid-state electronic imaging sensor is placed behind the lens of a camera to translate an image into an electronic signal, which can be relayed to a video monitor to be converted back into a picture.

title: WILLIAMS-SONOMA INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
HAMBURGER HAMLETS INC reports earnings for Year to March 30
Another Rain Forest Survives in the U.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: SECTION OF SUBWAY LINE SHUT AFTER WATER BREAK
description: On June 14, 1885, steam engines of the Brooklyn Elevated Railroad Company inaugurated a new line running from Gates Avenue toward Queens.

title: THOR INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in March 1986.

title: THE VEILED WAYS AND BYWAYS OF SANDINISTA LAND
description: The first things to learn about this capital are the places that are not there.

title: CITY PROPOSES SEPARATE HOUSING OF HOMELESS WITH SPECIAL NEEDS
description: The Koch administration has proposed an $82 million plan to provide separate housing for homeless people who are mentally ill, drug or alcohol abusers, elderly or young.

title: Standing Arrow Singers
description: The Standing Arrow Singers and Dancers, a group from the Akwesasne Mohawk reservation on the New York-Canada border, will present a program called ''Music and Dance of the Iroquois and other Native American Nations'' at the Washington Square Church, 135 West Fourth Street, tomorrow night at 8. Tickets, $10 each, will be available at the door, beginning at 6:45 P.M. Information: 362-3366.

title: SOVIET SAID TO TIE SAKHAROV'S FATE TO BONNER
description: The Soviet authorities have been pleased with Andrei D. Sakharov's recent statements in Gorky on the Chernobyl disaster and disarmament, but his wife's behavior in the West has harmed his chances of being allowed to settle again in Moscow, an informed Soviet journalist said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Washington dispatch yesterday on sites for nuclear waste repositories misidentified Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine. He is a Democrat.

title: Player Wins Damages
description: Sexto Benitez, the former George Washington High School football player who suffered a neck injury during a kickoff in a game against John F. Kennedy High in 1983 and required surgery for a fractured vertebra and slipped disc, has won his lawsuit against the New York City Board of Education.

title: ATTACKS CUOMO RECORD
description: Andrew P. O'Rourke, the Westchester County Executive, was formally designated the Republican candidate for governor today and pledged to unseat Mario M. Cuomo by running on the issues of crime, corruption, taxes and government spending.

title: VORNADO INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 26
