description: b-Includes tax credits of $1.2 million, or 36 cents a share, and $1,960,000, or 56 cents a share, for latest quarter and year-ago period, respectively.

title: U.S.F.L. ASSERTS SCHEME
description: The United States Football League tried hard yesterday to prove that the National Football League conspired to keep a U.S.F.L. team out of New York.

title: Leucadia National Sells GATX Stake
description: The Leucadia National Corporation said it had sold its entire 8.9 percent stake of the GATX Corporation's shares outstanding. The sale represents the end of Leucadia's attempted takeover of GATX, which was halted in late March after Leucadia refused to sign a definitive agreement on its offer of $40 a share in cash and securities, valued at $544.8 million, because of what it termed ''new information that was significant from a financial point of view.''

title: TEXAS TAKES HARD LOOK AT TAXES AND ITS FUTURE
description: The oil tremors shaking Texas have set off the beginning of a reluctant reappraisal of the state's budget priorities that will shape the state's development over the rest of the century.

title: Guilty Plea on Drugs
description: A former Syracuse University basketball star, Tony Bruin, has pleaded guilty in Onondaga County Court to a felony drug charge stemming from two 1984 cocaine sales to an undercover police officer, authorities said. In a plea-bargain arrangement, Bruin pleaded guilty to a reduced charge of attempted third-degree criminal possession of a controlled substance, a felony carrying a maximum penalty of up to 15 years in prison. But Judge William J. Burke agreed that if a probation department's pre-sentence report recommends jail, he will sentence the former star at Mater Christi High School, Astoria, Queens, on July 10 to no more than one year in prison.

title: Dr. King Sculpture Protected by Planks
description: William Tarr once dreamed that his monument to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. - a 30-foot-high cubic sculpture outside the high school that bears Dr. King's name -would endure forever.

title: ITT to Sell Off Abbey Life
description: The ITT Corporation, fulfilling a goal to divest itself of at least $1.7 billion of its assets by 1987, said yesterday that it would sell its remaining 51.8 percent interest in the Abbey Life Group P.L.C.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Milt Jackson, at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, between West Eleventh and Perry Streets, 255-4037. Milt Jackson's instrument, the vibraphone - a double row of mellow bars struck with mallets - can't be cajoled into the sort of slurred, bent phrasing that is the emotional currency of blues and jazz. Yet Mr. Jackson has been one of the music's outstanding blues interpreters since the mid-40's, and a player whose ballads are distillations of the purest beauty. Like the greatest jazz pianists, he casually and consistently does the impossible; he makes his instrument sing. And the Vanguard seems to bring out the best in him. Sets will begin at around 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M. tonight and tomorrow and at 10 and 11:30 on Sunday. Admission is $10, with a $5 mimimum.

title: On Nicaragua, First Things First
description: Bitter squabbling has again erupted over Nicaragua. A leaked Defense Department report questions the idea of reaching a negotiated settlement. The State Department denounces the report, asserting that it has no standing as policy. And Representative Jack Kemp suggests that President Reagan fire his special envoy, Philip C. Habib.

title: FRYAR DENIES GAMBLING STORY
description: The agent who represents Irving Fryar of the New England Patriots said yesterday that Fryar has denied a published report that he placed bets on National Football League games.

title: ART PEOPLE
description: MATTA, the Surrealist painter who was a leader of the New York avant-garde scene in the 1940's, was back in the city the other day and was, as ever, pushing back the boundaries of art and propriety.

title: FOUR CELEBRATIONS OF ONE-ACT PLAYS
description: IF you had gone to the Ensemble Studio Theater's annual festival of one-act plays in previous years, you might have seen works by such playwrights as Christopher Durang, David Mamet, Wendy Wasserstein, Michael Weller and Tina Howe.

title: 'SHAKER DESIGN' AT WHITNEY MUSEUM
description: A leanly conceived wheelbarrow at the entrance to ''Shaker Design,'' which opened yesterday at the Whitney Museum of American Art, aptly expresses the religious sect's joy in work and its skill at transforming ordinary tools into extraordinary objects. And it accomplishes this well, as can be seen in any of the 140 objects assembled in this show, one of the most comprehensive exhibitions ever assembled on the subject.

title: Open Beethoven Sing
description: The 92d Street Y School of Music will present an open sing of Beethoven's Symphony No. 9, with the ''Ode to Joy'' finale, performed by the Y Symphonic Workshop under the direction of Yaacov Bergman, on Sunday afternoon at 3.

title: FILM: 'JAKE SPEED,' ADVENTURE SPOOF
description: IN ''Jake Speed,'' which opens today at Embassy 1 and other theaters, a fictional hero from a pulp novel comes to life to help a woman who is in desperate, not to say ridiculous, straits. Her sister has been kidnapped by white slavers in Paris, transported to Zimbabwe and sold to what appears to be rich Arabs - a rough situation from any point of view, not to mention jet lag and culture shock. Jake Speed rescues the kidnapped victim, wins the heart of her sister and, with bullets whizzing, packs them safe and sound aboard yet another airplane headed for home in the U.S.A.

title: DANCE: MARTHA GRAHAM PRESENTS 'PART DREAM'
description: THE Martha Graham Dance Company has revived ''Part Real - Part Dream'' this season for the first time since 1969. It is the kind of exotic-erotic fantasy that appears pure Graham and yet, oddly, is atypical of most of her repertory.

title: ALLIED RESEARCH ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: AS TOURIST TRAFFIC PLUMMETS, BRITISH PLEAD FOR U.S. VISITORS
description: Last year at this time, when the deluge of American tourists coming to London traditionally begins to reach flood levels, the press commentary here was filled with foreboding at the onslaught.

title: Why Don't Educational Reformers Ask the Teacher?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Spousal Burden in Politics
description: There's no law in New York requiring a candidate for state office to disclose a spouse's financial resources or obligations. But there should be one, as Jeanine Pirro recognized in declining the Republican nomination for lieutenant governor. Mrs. Pirro, an Assistant District Attorney of Westchester County, properly withdrew because her husband, an attorney, had ''private reasons'' for not revealing his clients or their businesses and investments.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: IT is impossible to be dispassionate about Palm, the archetypal New York steakhouse that opened as a restaurant and speak-easy in 1926. Judging from the clamorous, standing-room-only crowds at the bar nightly, one might think these fervid Palmists somehow missed news of the 21st Amendment that made it possible to have cocktails before dinner elsewhere.

title: LAWYERS REST CASES IN JOHNSON TRIAL
description: Both sides in the Johnson estate trial rested their cases yesterday amid reports that an out-of-court settlement was being negotiated.

title: SEYMOUR, ONCE PROSECUTOR HERE, IS NAMED TO HEAD DEAVER INQUIRY
description: A three-judge Federal court today named Whitney North Seymour Jr., a former United States Attorney in Manhattan, as an independent counsel to investigate conflict-of-interest charges against Michael K. Deaver.

title: SSC&B Loses A Citibank Job
description: After a five-year relationship Citibank is moving its northeast division account, which is consumer advertising, out of SSC&B:Lintas USA. The account bills some $8 million and the bank is now deciding on its future agency.

title: TEXT OF STATEMENT ON PRESS AT TRIAL
description: The following is the text of the statement issued Wednesday by William J. Casey, Director of Central Intelligence, and Lieut. Gen. William E. Odom, director of the National Security Agency:

title: Crash Kills 5 Aboard An Air Force Helicopter
description: An Air Force helicopter providing security for a missile maintenance ground convoy crashed today, killing five of the six people on board, military officials said.

title: Police Seek Motive in Killing Of a Bicyclist in Coney Island
description: Detectives were questioning possible witnesses yesterday in the fatal beating and stabbing of a 20-year-old man who was riding a bicycle early Wednesday in the Coney Island section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: SHULTZ CONSIDERING MIDEAST TRIP
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz is giving active consideration to making his first trip to the Middle East in more than a year if it would provide momentum to stalled diplomatic efforts in the region, his top aides said today.

title: 8 INDICTED BY U.S. IN TERRORIST ACTS
description: Five men and three women were accused by the Federal authorities today of taking part in a nine-year pattern of bombings, murder and bank robberies by two terrorist groups.

title: Time Off
description: Manager Whitey Herzog explains why yesterday's open date is unlikely to reverse the direction of his slump-ridden St. Louis Cardinals: ''We've had off days before. We've had off days on days when we played.''

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Dorothy Donegan, Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street (758-2272). Technically virtuosic, with a broad vaudevillian sense of humor, the Chicago-born jazz pianist and protege of Art Tatum is still in fine shape after more than 45 years. Classically trained, Miss Donegan can play with a late Romantic lushness, then segue abruptly into a section of lusty foot-stomping stride. Her improvisations are full of quotes and parodies of other musicians. As an occasional singer, she offers tart caricatures of other pop and jazz vocalists. In her current engagement, which runs through June 7, she leads a trio that includes Arvell Shaw on bass and Bobby Durham on drums. Shows are 9:30 and 11:30 P.M., and there is a $10 cover charge and a two-drink minimum.

title: Duvalier to Move To French Riviera
description: The ousted Haitian leader Jean-Claude Duvalier and his family will leave Grasse today or Friday and move to Cannes on the French Riviera, real estate agents said.

title: Natural Gas Pricing Vote
description: The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission voted unanimously in principle today to raise price ceilings on most of the nation's supply of so-called old natural gas.

title: Phillips Platforms
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company said the Norwegian Petroleum Directorate had approved Phillips's proposed $286 million project to elevate six offshore production platforms in Norway's Ekofisk oil and gas field in the North Sea to compensate for a sinking seabed.

title: D H HOLMES CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: b-Net income

title: Levy, Flaxman Wins An Oldsmobile Account
description: Levy, Flaxman & Associates has won the $6 million Oldsmobile Dealers Association, Philadelphia account, also known as the ''Olds Connection,'' after a six-week, three-way competition.

title: Pact Seen on Debt Of Dome Petroleum
description: More than 50 creditors of beleaguered Dome Petroleum Ltd. are to sign a document Friday in Calgary, Alberta, allowing Dome to avoid most interest and principal payments on debt of $6.2 billion (Canadian), or about $4.5 billion (United States), until Oct. 29, banking sources and investment analysts said today.

title:
BRIEFING;
On Frumps and Flash
description: Washington's women may be on the cutting edge of politics, government and other serious-minded pursuits, but they are not generally considered trend-setters in the world of fashion. ''W,'' the society and fashion newspaper based in New York, highlighted this observation in a recent article rather bluntly titled, ''Frumpy Washington,'' accompanied by 20 pictures of prominent Washington women out on the town.

title: Saatchi & Saatchi Posts Rise in 6-Month Profits
description: Saatchi & Saatchi Company yesterday released its half-year earnings, ended March 31, which shows revenues of $260.36 million, up 49.2 percent from $174.47 million in the comparable period last year. Earnings per share were up 20 percent, to $1.08, from 90 cents, on a greater number of shares outstanding in the latest period. Net income rose to $18.6 million, up 39.2 percent from $13.39 million in 1985.

title: Productivity Up by 3.6%
description: Business productivity climbed 3.6 percent in the first three months of the year from the last quarter of 1985, the Labor Department said in revised figures released today.

title: Cyanide Death in Texas Is Ruled Homicide
description: The death of a former chemistry student last week from cyanide in an Anacin-3 capsule has been ruled a homicide.

title: ART: 'SEVEN SPANISH REALISTS' AT CLAUDE BERNARD
description: WITH the term ''new young artist'' now a cliche, you don't have to be perverse to wish for the occasional roundup of talents billed as not so young and not especially new. ''Seven Spanish Realists'' may be such a show, even though it arrives at the Claude Bernard Gallery, 33 East 74th Street, with no promotion at all and with most of its participants new to American viewers. It is also a reminder of the adage about being careful what you wish for.

title: CONTINENTAL FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
2 Dead in Golden Nugget
description: Security guards at the Golden Nugget casino hotel found two youths from northern New Jersey dead Wednesday afternoon in a room registered to someone else, authorities said today.

title: PRESIDENT ASSAILS HOUSE TRADE BILL AS 'DESTRUCTIVE'
description: President Reagan today denounced efforts in the House of Representatives to revise the nation's trade laws as an exercise that could ''send our economy into the steepest nose dive since the Great Depression.''

title: AUCTIONS
description: THOUSANDS of collectors, dealers and the merely curious have traveled this week by car, train and helicopter to view the extraordinary contents of West Dean, an 11th-century castle in Sussex, south of London, where Christie's will hold a five-day auction of the Edward James collection next Monday through Friday. The bizarre and beautiful artworks and furnishings up for bidding - 2,679 offerings valued at about $4 million -were inherited or acquired by Mr. James, a collector of Surrealist art who was the heir to several American fortunes in lumber, metals, mining and railroads. At his death at the age of 77 in 1984, virtually all of his estate was bequeathed to the Edward James Foundation, which manages West Dean College, a school of crafts and conservation.

title: For Shakespeare Festival
description: In an effort to recreate Central Park inside the cavernous Seventh Regiment Armory, organizers filled doorways with leafy trees and placed picnic baskets on tables. But you could hardly see the decor for the people -2,000 people from the theater, magazine publishing and advertising who had arrived for a tribute to Joseph Papp, founder of the New York Shakespeare Festival.

title: Soviet Accused Again On Chemical Weapons
description: The Reagan Administration today repeated allegations that the Soviet Union waged chemical warfare in Southeast Asia and Afghanistan five years ago, saying that a Canadian Government study that seemed to refute the accusation referred to another time period.

title: N.R.A. JOINS CORE IN DRIVE
description: The National Rifle Association yesterday joined a civil-rights group in establishing an anticrime program in Brooklyn.

title: SPECIAL COUNSEL RESIGNS POST
description: The independent counsel investigating a withholding of Federal documents from Congress has resigned to avoid the appearance of a conflict of interest, a special court announced today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The liberty notion is stirring to anyone, and to attach negativism to the renovation of a statue proclaiming liberty is not my interest.

title: COLLEGE ACTS AS GATEWAY IN THE BRONX
description: The kindest description of the campus would be nondescript - two plain brick buildings, a brick and granite building and three trailers. But these buildings making up Hostos Community College are symbols for many students of a two-year passage to self-sufficiency.

title: Doctors in Ontario Strike Over Fee Curbs
description: Most Ontario doctors began a two-day strike today as part of an effort to stop the provincial government from limiting physicians' ability to collect fees.

title: KOCH CHOOSES PROFESSOR TO RUN TAXICAB AGENCY
description: Mayor Koch yesterday selected a professor at the University of North Carolina who is a leading analyst of the nation's taxi industry to be chairman of the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission.

title: FERNANDEZ GETS DODGER SWEEP
description: Another victory, another big winning streak is theirs, so it is easy to overlook the small moments that are making the Mets' season spectacular.

title: ZAB'S BACKYARD HOTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
10b-5 Vs. The Arbs
description: ''The 'arbs' used to perform a stabilizing function,'' says Felix Rohatyn, the investment banker who helped merge Sperry and Burroughs this week. ''But now, more often they're destabilizers.''

title: 2 INVESTMENT FIRMS BID FOR ANDERSON, CLAYTON
description: Anderson, Clayton & Company, a consumer products concern whose shareholders are to vote next week to restructure the company, received a surprise $655 million acquisition offer yesterday from Bear, Stearns & Company and Gruss & Company, two New York investment firms.

title: Money Fund Assets Fall
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds fell $1.43 billion, to $225.41 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, marking the first time all categories have reflected a decrease since Oct. 25, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: The Worm and the Apple: Urban Relief; Serving Youth
description: Although tennis can now be played in clothes that are not entirely white, its aura as a game for mannered aristocrats fades slowly. Doing much to make the game's conditioning and fun available to city children is the New York Junior Tennis League.

title: WASHINGTON LAWYER AND AIDE TO J.F.K.
description: Mitchell S. Cutler, a prominent Washington lawyer who was a special assistant to President John F. Kennedy, died Tuesday after suffering a heart attack in his office. He was 53 years old.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Washington dispatch on Tuesday about the Vietnam Veterans Memorial misidentified an Air Force technical sergeant, Gene A. Lauer, one of 110 war dead whose names were added to the memorial. He was the brother, not the son, of Robert Lauer of West Haven, Conn.

title: ART: WOODBLOCK PRINTS FROM JAPAN AT THE MET
description: ANYONE who wants to spend an amusing hour in the Metropolitan Museum before the dog days strike need look no further than the exhibition of Japanese color woodblock prints that were given to the museum by Lincoln Kirstein around 25 years ago and are only now - so it would seem - being put on view.

title: TORONTO-DOMINION BANK (CANADA) reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The bank's stocks are traded on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: The Worm and the Apple: Urban Relief; Mooring Moore
description: Henry Moore's ''Two Piece Reclining Figure: Points,'' a gift to New York from George and Virginia Ablah, has had a berth in Central Park's Duck Pond since 1984. But the ducks loved it to death and then a rainstorm floated it into a big mud puddle.

title: 'MASTERPIECE THEATER' OFFERS 'THE IRISH R.M.'
description: RETURNING to a seemingly topsy-turvy universe of sly servants and baffled masters, public television's ''Masterpiece Theater'' is presenting - on Sundays at 9 o'clock on Channel 13 - further adventures of ''The Irish R.M.,'' a series made by Britain's Channel 4 in association with Ulster Television. The R.M., or Resident Magistrate, was a familiar British Empire figure around the turn of the century, sent from London to such foreign lands as Ireland or India in order to, as Alistair Cooke puts it, ''try and bring something like justice to the locals.'' Invariably, of course, the locals have their own ideas about justice and, at least in these fictions, the R.M. rarely triumphs.

title: Ohio City Alters Punctuation
description: The City Council voted 5 to 1 Wednesday to add an exclamation mark to this town's name to attract attention, and possibly new industry and jobs. City Manager Jack Becker said he believed the city of 64,000 in southwest Ohio was the first in the country with an exclamation point in its name.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: SUMMER arrived early this week - and that was just dandy for at least two groups of party-givers and party-goers on Wednesday. That was the night of the Museum of Modern Art's annual Party in the Garden and of the second annual Boat House Ball in Central Park.

title: BANK LEU STUNS THE BAHAMAS
description: Even for the Bahamas, where banking secrecy is a way of life, Bank Leu International is regarded as having gone too far.

title: Boom-Boom Blyleven
description: Maybe it's his advance toward middle age, maybe it's the fact that he now pitches in the Metrodome, maybe it's a livelier ball - home runs in the majors are up by almost 20 percent this year -and maybe it's a combination of the three. Whatever it is, the Twins' 35-year-old Bert Blyleven, who has never yielded more than 24 homers in a season, has already served up 19 this year, a pace that would give him a 1986 total of 67 and a major-league record by far. Here's the top of the ladder that Blyleven has started to climb:

title: GRAY & CO PUBLIC COMMICATION INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
ZYMOS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After interest expenses of $468,000 for the quarter and $844,000 for the 6 months. c-After interest expenses of $305,000 for the quarter and $478,000 for the 6 months.

title: ORIOLES' WIN, 8-6, FOR 15TH IN LAST 18
description: Larry Sheets hit a pair of two-run home runs and Cal Ripken Jr. added a two-run homer today to lead the Baltimore Orioles to their 15th victory in their last 18 games, an 8-6 triumph over the Oakland A's.

title: C.I.A. ROLE REPORTED IN CONTRA'S FALL
description: A man known to Nicaraguan rebels as an official of the Central Intelligence Agency induced six senior commanders to desert the insurgent leader Eden Pastora Gomez, according to officials of rival rebel factions.

title: Orchestra Union Strikes After Negotiations Fail
description: The union representing Radio City Music Hall's 35-member orchestra began a strike yesterday after negotiations broke down in April over work guarantees in the proposed three-year contract. The last contract ended May 14, and union members voted to strike on Tuesday.

title: Why Don't Educational Reformers Ask the Teacher?; Blind Leading Blind?
description: To the Editor:

title: HAZARD OF DIOXINS ASSAILED IN STUDY
description: Highly toxic airborne dioxins constitute an ''unacceptable'' and uncontrolled threat to public health, according to a paper presented to the American Academy for the Advancement of Science.

title: WIENER ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
NO-FRILLS BLOCK PARTY FOR A HARLEM SCHOOL
description: ''It's a real old-fashioned benefit with everything donated and absolutely no overhead,'' said Liz Fondaras. ''The decorations on each table cost about $4, the neighborhood women baked the desserts and even the young people serving are volunteers. We're not paying them a penny.''

title: Moscow Promotes 2 Aides To Deputy Foreign Minister
description: Two senior Foreign Ministry officials, Anatoly L. Adamishin and Vladimir F. Petrovsky, have been promoted to Deputy Foreign Minister, the Soviet Union announced today.

title: Good Deal for Alaskan Oil
description: Big Oil has long wanted to drill in the waters off Alaska. Environmentalists, native fishermen and others want to prevent it. The Interior Department and the state of Alaska are caught in between. The scene was set, in other words, for a protracted court battle in which legal skill and staying power were more important than the broad public interest. Yet thanks to an unusual and promising privately negotiated accord, the fate of at least some Bering Sea drilling areas probably won't be decided that way. The procedure won't be easy to duplicate in other disputed leasing areas, but it does offer hope for salvaging a rational policy for offshore drilling from the ruin of litigation.

title: GERBER SCIENTIFIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Vershure Wins L.I. Open by 8
description: Rick Vershure, the assistant pro at the Woodmere Club, shot a four-under-par 68 in the morning round and a 70 in the afternoon today to win the Long Island Open by eight strokes at the Cherry Valley Club.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, MAY 30, 1986
description: The Economy

title: Layoffs at Cessna
description: The Cessna Aircraft Company will lay off 900 employees - about 16 percent of its work force - and suspend piston-engine airplane production for more than a year. Cessna, which is owned by the General Dynamics Corporation, is one of the world's largest makers of light planes. Cessna's chairman, Russell W. Meyer Jr., said enormous increases in product liability insurance premiums were a major factor in the decision.

title: Convergent Cites Falling Shipments
description: Convergent Technologies said that it could lose money in its second quarter of this year because of declining shipments of computers to its major customer, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Chevron Corporation is offering $300 million of 9 3/8 percent debentures due in 2016 at a price of 98 5/8, to yield 9.514 percent, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: RUSS TOGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $434,000.

title: One for the Viewers
description: Anheuser-Busch Companies Inc. plans to experiment with commercials on this weekend's World Cup soccer telecasts, permitting viewers to follow the action during its Budweiser beer commercials. Under one approach, a Budweiser commercial will frame the continuing action of the soccer match.

title: Exchanges Will Meet
description: Federal regulators and officials of the nation's stock and commodities exchanges will meet in Washington on Friday to weigh proposals aimed at curbing the impact on stock prices when stock index futures and options contracts expire simultaneously. Brandon C. Becker, assistant director in the Division of Market Regulation for the Securities and Exchange Commission, said the principal item at Friday's meeting would be a New York Stock Exchange plan that would base the settlement price of expiring futures and options on the opening prices of shares on expiration day, rather than the closing prices.

title: ONEIDA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: b-Net loss

title: FLUOROCARBON CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $98,076 from discontinued operations.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: THEATER: 'RUSH RIFE,' BY THE RUSSELL FAMILY
description: WE meet the Russell family, creators and performers of ''Rush Rife,'' as they are rousing themselves for another bustling day in New York to the sounds of a radio weather report. Father, mother and their two young daughters go about their morning routines and ablutions. When father opens an imaginary door, we hear the snap of the locks; when he brushes his teeth at an imaginary sink, we hear the sounds of brushing and rinsing; we hear the buzz of an imaginary electric razor, the flush of an imaginary toilet and more.

title: DANCER AND CHOREOGRAPHER RESTORE LOST SOLO
description: ''EPISODES'' was considered a novelty when first performed by the New York City Ballet in May 1959. Planned as a collaboration between Martha Graham and George Balanchine to be set to the difficult music of Anton Webern, the dance developed into separate works presented in sequence on the same program. Miss Graham's was a stark costume piece about the final moments of Mary, Queen of Scots. Balanchine's ballet was felt at the time to be breaking ground for the choreographer, with its most startling element a strange and frighteningly anomic solo for Paul Taylor, then a member of the Graham company. Tonight, that solo will be performed again as part of ''Episodes,'' for the first time since it was dropped from the ballet in 1961. Peter Frame, a City Ballet soloist, will dance the role as taught to him by Mr. Taylor.

title: Sims Set to Retire
description: Billy Sims, the leading ground-gainer in the history of the Detroit Lions, will apparently retire because of an injury to his right knee that forced him to miss most of the last two seasons. Sims, 30 years old, has filed a claim to collect on a $2 million insurance policy he took out with Lloyd's of London in the event he was physically unable to play football.

title: F.B.I. AGENTS BACK COLLEAGUE ENTERING PLEA OF NOT GUILTY
description: Amid a strong show of support from colleagues, an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation pleaded not guilty today to charges that he had made false statements to the Government about his dealings with Jackie Presser, the teamsters' union president.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, MAY 30, 1986
description: International

title: REAGAN AND ARMS TREATY: A SHARP SHIFT IN POLICY
description: President Reagan's latest statement that the United States will no longer be bound by the provisions of the second strategic arms treaty in making future decisions on deploying strategic weapons marks a sharp break with the Administration's stated policy on the 1979 agreement.

title: If Territorial Toes Get Stepped On, Look Out
description: If there is one thing that can persuade legislators to set aside their partisan differences, it is a bare-knuckled battle over turf.

title: New President At Homestake
description: The Homestake Mining Company today elected David I. Fagin president, chief operating officer and a director.

title: 31 SENATORS CALLED SET TO FIGHT TAX AMENDING
description: Bob Packwood, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, said today that he now had a coalition of 31 senators who have pledged to defeat all amendments to the committee's tax-revision bill that are offered on the Senate floor.

title: SCREEN: 'AT CLOSE RANGE' WITH PENN AND WALKEN
description: BRAD WHITEWOOD JR. (Sean Penn) is both a character and a social condition.

title: TESTIMONY HEARD IN ZACCARO CASE
description: A former undercover state trooper testified today that John A. Zaccaro Jr., son of Geraldine A. Ferraro, the 1984 Democratic Vice-Presidential nominee, had sold cocaine last winter at his Middlebury home.

title: STRAWBRIDGE & CLOTHIER reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the latest first quarter earnings reflect a pre-tax charge of $1.7 million for its defense against a tender offer by Berry Acquisition Co.

title: Box-Office Figures Lag On Memorial Weekend
description: Receipts for 25 top-grossing movies were off 18 percent from last year for the four-day Memorial Day weekend, with only six of the top 10 bringing in more than $1 million, a mark nine passed a year ago.

title: Bridge: Play Resumes in Semifinal Of the Reisinger Knockout
description: Play in the semifinal stage of the Reisinger Knockout resumed last night at the Beverly Club, 130 East 57th Street, with teams headed by Bruce Rogoff of Bayside, Queens, and Michael Rosmarin of Jamaica, Queens, apparently en route to victory.

title: Foreign Accent
description: Tim McCarver, the Met broadcaster, sizes up the Dodgers, whose roster includes Alejandro Pena, Cesar Cedeno and Alex Trevino: ''They lead the league in tildes.''

title: U.S. SEEKS DELAY IN CORRUPTION TRIAL
description: Federal prosecutors asked yesterday for a three-week delay to give them time to prepare their case against Stanley M. Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader, and five others on charges relating to the bribery-extortion scandal in the city's Parking Violations Bureau.

title: Consoling Hostages' Relatives
description: John H. Adams, a career diplomat, is on call at the State Department 24 hours a day, every day, serving as counselor, confidant, bearer of grief and source of hope for the families of five Americans still missing in Lebanon.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Living Section on May 21 about peanut butter misstated the estimate of schoolchildren's peanut butter sandwich consumption. From kindergarten through 12th grade, according to the Peanut Advisory Board, an industry trade association, a youngster eats approximately 1,500 such sandwiches.

title: CONTRAS SEE A LONG-TERM NEED FOR AID
description: Nicaraguan rebel leaders, formally announcing a unity accord, said today that they would seek continued assistance from the United States and elsewhere even if a regional peace treaty is signed by the nations of Central America.

title: AIR FORCE ONE BUZZES THE CITY, POSING
description: The baby-blue and white four-engine jet with the Presidential seal on the fuselage and the American flag on the tail came sweeping out of the Queens sky yesterday morning and flew low over the Brooklyn Bridge.

title: BANK BUILDING & EQUIPMENT CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
TEXFI INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: b-Net income and after tax credits of $152,000 for the quarter and $178,000 for the 6 months.

title: 2 CAREER MEN WHO WORKED THEIR WAY TO THE TOP OF NAVY AND AIR FORCE: CARLISLE ALBERT HERMAN TROST
description: Adm. Carlisle A. H. Trost was nominated by President Reagan today to become chief of naval operations. In his working career, he has been a commander of submarines and fleets, a political scientist and student of German, a Washington bureaucrat and budgeteer. He also shares with Mr. Reagan the nickname ''Dutch.''

title: PAINTER'S STROKES HELP HIM IN SQUASH
description: ''I wish I could hit the squash ball as well as I can swing the brush,'' Frank Stella said. Stella's prowess with the paint brush is beyond debate. For the last quarter-century he has ranked as one of America's major artists. This week he will be exercising another of his passions - squash racquets.

title: HOME-GROWN SILK FOR A ROYAL WEDDING
description: Robert Goodden strolls by the big bug case and gently taps the glass. ''They're ravenous creatures,'' he declares, gazing at a flock of baby silkworms eagerly gnawing mulberry leaves.

title: DISNEYLAND EASING LIQUOR BAN TO LURE PARTIES
description: After 31 years, it is now possible to get a drink at Disneyland.

title: SHAER SHOE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
SHAMIR ROLE IN 1984 CASE IS DISPUTED
description: A controversy has arisen here over whether Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir had a role in a reported cover-up of the beating deaths of two captured Palestinian terrorists.

title: Article 661486 -- No Title
description: Basic telephone rates for homes and small businesses will rise by $1 a month on Sunday. But as local rates increase, some long-distance rates are falling.

title: INTELLIGENCE CHIEFS ASK JOURNALISTS' COOPERATION
description: The Director of Central Intelligence and the head of the National Security Agency asked journalists today to cooperate in efforts to reduce disclosures of sensitive information they said had cost lives and billions of taxpayer dollars.

title:
BRIEFING;
Dept. of Power Couples
description: To the ranks of Washington power couples, add another with a bipartisan twist.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: ZYTEC COMPUTERS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss The company is listed on the Vancouver Stock Exchange.

title: XYTRONYX INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said it had no sales figures because it was in a product development stage of operations.

title: THE SCREEN: 'A GREAT WALL,' FROM PETER WANG
description: ONE hates to say it about the first American feature movie made in China, but ''A Great Wall'' leaves one hungry. The people in it, without exception, are agreeable. The scenes of life in China are colorful - from a bathhouse to a tryout for fashion models to a dance featuring American folk songs with a Chinese beat to an outdoor television viewing of an opera by the whole neighborhood (Now, that's public television). What's lacking is a story to keep up the interest between incidents.

title: No Fanfare For Travelers
description: A number of American sports teams have been led to cancel European trips this summer because of the threat of terrorism, but the Yale soccer squad is not among them. Twenty of the Elis' 25 players - five opted to remain home - have just returned from a tour of matches against Dutch and West German clubs that was marked by two victories, two losses, one tie and nothing unpleasant.

title: AMWEST INSURANCE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
KURT WEILL, JANE SIBERRY AND JACKSON BROWNE
description: THE chances are that at this weekend's most interesting pop music events - the 92d Street Y's concert presentations of Kurt Weill's and Maxwell Anderson's ''Lost in the Stars,'' Jane Siberry's shows tonight at the Bottom Line and Jackson Browne's sold-out concerts Saturday and Sunday at Radio City Music Hall - there will be almost no overlap among audiences that might otherwise enjoy all three.

title: HOSPITALS CHIEF AND DOCTOR TUSSLE
description: The chairman of the city's Health and Hospital Corporation, Victor E. Botnick, and the president of a union that represents doctors filed charges against each other last night after a shoving match that led to a hasty adjournment of a meeting of the corporation's board.

title: Vice Adm. H. Karo, 82, Dies; Headed U.S. Geodetic Survey
description: Vice Adm. H. Arnold Karo, a former director of the Coast and Geodetic Survey, died of respiratory failure May 23 at Georgetown Hospital, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration announced today. He was 82 years old.

title: One Presidency, One Primary
description: Since 1980, when the Democrats officially created a ''window'' for primaries and caucuses in the second week of March, the number of states selecting Presidential convention delegates that week or the next, often for both parties, has grown sharply. From four in 1976, it went to 11 in 1980, to 22 in 1984. Now, several Southern states are threatening to set up a ''Southern regional primary'' to be held during that period.

title: Treasury to Stop Issuing Certificates
description: The Treasury Department announced that as of July it will stop issuing engraved certificates to all buyers of Government notes and bonds and instead record such purchases through an electronic system.

title: Economic Scene; Overhauling Israeli Banking
description: IN the wake of the worst banking scandal in its history - a scandal that stemmed from, and seriously aggravated, inflation - Israel is facing the need to reconstruct its financial system.

title: LIBERTY GALA STIRS MIXED EMOTIONS FOR BLACKS
description: For at least some American blacks, the Fourth of July Statue of Liberty centennial celebration evokes mixed feelings and emotions well short of enthusiasm.

title: MINI MARATHON OFFERS A BIG STEP FOR ROE
description: The 8,000 or so women who have entered the L'Eggs Mini Marathon in Central Park tomorrow include 174 lawyers, 107 accountants, 64 physicians, 10 architects, 7 members of the clergy, 6 dentists, 4 mathematicians, 3 security guards and a New Zealander who is just returning from the racing junkpile.

title: NATIONAL BANK OF CANADA reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: BRADLEY TRIES FOR GRAND SLAM
description: Pat Bradley, who two weeks ago became the first woman to reach the $2 million mark in golf earnings, began reaching today for another goal: the major victory she needs to become the first woman to achieve a grand slam of golf.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: ''THIS is the biggest endorsement we have received from the commercial public,'' said Ismail Merchant.

title: SPEIZMAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: b-Net income

title: Advertising; A Global Focus for Ad Session
description: The caliber of panelists who opened today's session of the International Advertising Association World Congress was a testimonial to the growing status of the association.

title: 2 CAREER MEN WHO WORKED THEIR WAY TO THE TOP OF NAVY AND AIR FORCE: LARRY DEAN WELCH
description: Gen. Larry D. Welch, who entered the Air National Guard fresh out of high school in 1952, was nominated today to be the new chief of staff of the Air Force.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. San Francisco, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. The Giants only won the finale of a three-game series at home against the Mets last week.

title: S&K FAMOUS BRANDS reports earnings for Qtr to April 26
description: The company said the improved results are after additional interest and depreciation expenses of $73,000, or 4 cents a share, which reflect the investment in a new corporate headquarters.

title: New McGuigan Foe
description: Steve Cruz of Fort Worth has agreed to replace Fernando Sosa of Argentina in the World Boxing Association featherweight title bout against Barry McGuigan of Ireland on June 23 at Las Vegas. Cruz, ranked No. 9, was invited to challenge after Sosa suffered detached retinas in both eyes. . . . A tooth infection and lower back problems have forced Marvin Johnson to withdraw from a June 7 defense of his W.B.A. lightheavyweight championship.

title: Treasury Move On Libya Curb
description: The Treasury Department today put the strength of law behind a call by President Reagan for American oil companies to close their Libyan operations by the end of June.

title: DOW AT NEW HIGH OF 1,882.35
description: Stock prices overcame weak early trading yesterday to rise to a record for the second consecutive day, but advancing stocks outnumbered declining issues by only a narrow margin.

title: A.T.&T. OFFICER PICKS 4 IN MERGING OPERATIONS
description: Randall L. Tobias, who last week was named a vice chairman of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and head of its merging long-distance telephone and computer operations, disclosed plans yesterday for combining them.

title: Crews in Long Island Sound Raise Sunken Fuel-Oil Barge
description: A barge containing 840,000 gallons of fuel oil has been recovered from Long Island Sound, where it sank in 185 feet of water last Nov. 22, about a mile and a half south of Fishers Island, N.Y.

title:
BRIEFING;
Eyes on Iacocca
description: A few Democrats have been quietly exploring strategies for drafting Lee Iacocca, the Chrysler Corporation chairman, as a Presidential contender.

title: Banned From Bali, but Not a Bit Abject
description: To the Editor:

title: BROADWAY
description: IT'S hard to quarrel with people who say there's no such thing as a lovable drunk -but if such a possibility existed, the most endearing of the species would probably be ''Arthur,'' a character played by Dudley Moore in the motion picture of the same name. By the time the movie was finished, Arthur was a reformed character, but he'll be back boozing again if Joseph Billone and Bruce Michael have their way.

title: BUILDING TRAILS AND TOURING
description: If occasional tennis games, cocktail parties and languorous do-nothing days at the beach have lost their appeal, or if you'd like to visit a faraway spot but haven't the funds, you might wish try a new approach to summer vacationing.

title: THEATER: FRANCA RAME
description: WHILE Dario Fo is regaling theatergoers with his ''Mistero Buffo,'' his wife, the actress-author Franca Rame, is exhorting them with ''Tutta Casa, Letto e Chiesa (It's All Bed, Board and Church).'' Miss Rame's one-woman show opened Wednesday at the Joyce Theater, where it is running in repertory with ''Mistero Buffo.''

title: COMPACT VIDEO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit from utilization of net operating loss carryforwards of $59,000. c-Net loss

title: Market Place; Institutions Tilt To Data Stocks
description: DATA processing stocks dislodged the oil and gas group during the first quarter of 1986 in total dollar value of shares held by institutional investors, according to the Vickers Stock Research Corporation. This subsidiary of Argus Research Group Inc. derives its findings from 3,600 portfolios ranging from banks, insurance companies and mutual funds to foundations, colleges and closed-end investment companies.

title: How to Save the Volunteer Fire Departments
description: To the Editor:

title: 55 CUBANS RIOT IN BUS TRAVELING TO ATLANTA PRISON
description: Fifty-five Cubans accused of starting a melee at the Krome Avenue detention center here rioted today aboard a special security bus while being transferred to the Federal penitentiary in Atlanta, the authorities said.

title: TESTIMONY ON U.S. SPYING FORBIDDEN AT PELTON'S TRIAL
description: Federal prosecutors today stopped a witness from giving details about the operation of a highly secret project to intercept Soviet communications. The situation arose in the espionage trial of Ronald W. Pelton after his lawyer tried to elicit the details.

title: Crude Oil Prices Slump To a Three-Week Low
description: Crude oil prices slumped to the mid-$14 range on the world oil market yesterday, their lowest level in three weeks.

title: VISUAL GRAPHICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $160,000 and a non-recurring gain of $547,000 from the sale of real property and other assets for quarter and year.

title: UNIVERSAL COMMUNICATION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes insurance proceeds of $1,418,871, or 20 cents a share.

title: Walt Disney Ice Shows Won by Bloom Agency
description: The Bloom Agency/New York, which worked on the Walt Disney Ice Shows on a project basis last November, has been given the entire $6 million account by the ice shows' producer, Irvin Feld and Kenneth Feld Productions Inc. of Barnum & Bailey Circus.

title: Texas Instruments
description: Texas Instruments Inc. has signed a three-year agreement with a subsidiary of Japan's third-largest trading company to distribute the company's artificial intelligence computer in Japan, officials said. The Century Research Center Corporation, a unit of C. Itoh & Company, will distribute the Explorer work station, a computer that has become the focal point of the company's growing emphasis on artificial intelligence products, officials said.

title: CHILD WORLD reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
Oklahoma Bonds' Top Yield Is 8 1/4%
description: The Oklahoma Municipal Power Authority is offering $77.2 million of revenue bonds through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers with a maximum yield of 8 1/4 percent for bonds due in 2023.

title: Information on Crack
description: Awareness of crack, the potently addictive form of cocaine, is seeping into the affluent Upper East Side - thanks to widespread press coverage and information efforts by the police.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Aluminum Co. of America, Pittsburgh, said it would increase aluminum beverage-can body stock prices by about 7 percent on shipments beginning July 1.

title: FRIEDMAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
5 WHO MAKE UP NEW YORK G.O.P. SLATE
description: Alfonse M. D'Amato First elected to the Senate in 1980 in a three-way race with 45 percent of the vote and a 1 percent margin of victory . . . Won the Republican nomination that year despite the opposition of party leaders by defeating the late Senator Jacob K. Javits in a primary . . . Featured his mother in campaign advertising . . . Serves on Appropriation and Banking Committees and Select Committee on Small Business . . . Campaigned as a conservative but has challenged President Reagan on local issues . . . As the only New York Republican in the Senate, has the major say in Federal patronage here . . . Began political career in Nassau County as protege of Joseph Margiotta, the former county chairman . . . Served 16 years in local government, including two terms as Presiding Supervisor of the Town of Hempstead and majority leader of the Nassau County Board of Supervisors . . . An attorney . . . Born in Brooklyn Aug. 1, 1937 . . . Raised in Island Park, L.I. . . . Attended Roman Catholic parochial schools . . . Earned a degree in business administration and a law degree from Syracuse University . . . A sailing enthusiast . . . Enjoys playing piano . . . Has four children . . . Lives in Island Park with wife, Penelope. Andrew P. O'Rourke

title: A LINK TO DOMESTIC TERROR IS SEEN
description: The Government of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou has shaken up the leadership of the nation's intelligence and security agencies.

title: U.S. WEIGHS REQUEST TO EXPAND SWINE FEVER TESTS
description: The Department of Agriculture said today that it was considering expanding an emergency surveillance program for detecting African swine fever beyond Belle Glade, Fla., to farms in other states.

title: GERBER SYSTEMS TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income The company reported that results in the latest year include an $84,000 tax benefit from the use of foreign operating loss carryforwards.

title: 3 SEEN AS ISLANDER PROSPECTS
description: When Al Arbour, who led the Islanders to four Stanley Cups in his 13-season tenure, announced his resignation Wednesday, neither he nor Bill Torrey, the team's general manager, gave any indication that they had any ideas about a replacement.

title: LEADERS TO DEBUT AT SWEET BASIL
description: THE Leaders, who are making their New York debut playing at Sweet Basil through Sunday, have every right to call themselves an all-star band. Each of the six musicians has an enviable reputation as a band leader, composer and recording artist in his own right. Arthur Blythe, Lester Bowie and Chico Freeman, the three hornmen in the front line, and the band's rhythm section of Kirk Lightsey, Cecil McBee and Don Moye are among the leading exponents of their respective instruments, and they are players who are helping chart the evolution of jazz as a whole.

title: Oil Pipeline Decontrol Bid
description: The Justice Department today urged an end to Federal regulation of most of the nation's interstate oil pipelines, saying that consumers would not be hurt by deregulation and competition between companies would continue.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday about space travel gave an incorrect figure for the radius of the planet Mercury. It is approximately 1,515 miles.

title: Boys Choir of Harlem
description: The Boys Choir of Harlem will present a benefit concert of classics, pop, jazz and spirituals at Alice Tully Hall Sunday night at 8.

title: ART: 'ENGAGING OBJECTS,' AUDIENCE PARTICIPATION IN CULTURAL ZOO
description: ''ENGAGING OBJECTS: The Participatory Art of Mirrors, Mechanisms and Shelters'' is one of the more unusual shows of the season. The subject is what Tom Finkelpearl, the coordinator of the Clocktower Gallery and curator of the exhibition, calls ''audience-activated'' art. What this means is art that is set in motion by our physical presence or movement - like sitting on it, talking into it, rocking it or wearing it.

title: FREY ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: PACIFIC UTILITY CHIEF CITES TAKEOVER GOAL
description: For Paul A. Miller, chairman and chief executive officer of the Pacific Lighting Corporation, its acquisition of the Thrifty Corporation is a logical expansionary step.

title: Repeating the Past
description: Since Ronald Reagan took office in 1981, the gross public debt has more than doubled, from $930 billion to $1.9 trillion, reflecting huge annual Federal deficits that reached $212 billion in fiscal 1985.

title: Why Don't Educational Reformers Ask the Teacher?; Classroom Experience
description: To the Editor:

title: 5 HUDSON PIERS TO BE OFF LIMITS ON THE FOURTH
description: Concrete barriers and metal fences will be erected to block access to five old wooden piers on the Hudson River in lower Manhattan that were expected to be vantage points for thousands during the Fourth of July festivities.

title: WICKES COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 26
description: b-After an extraordinary tax credit of $4,816,000. c-Net loss includes net from discontinued operations of $855,000 and an extraordinary credit of $128,000. Results for the latest quarter include the operations of the Consumer & Industrial Products Group, acquired in September 1985.

title: RARE GLIMPSE OF A SECRET AGENCY
description: In three days of testimony in the espionage trial of Ronald W. Pelton, the Government has provided an unusual glimmer of insight into the workings of the National Security Agency while illustrating just how sensitive intelligence is about revealing its secrets on monitoring foreign communications.

title: Masland Turns Down Offer
description: C. H. Masland & Sons, a leading carpet maker for cars and homes, yesterday rejected an unsolicited offer of $68 a share, or a total of about $109 million, from Burlington Industries.

title: 'Manifesto,' From 1848, Is Sold for $39,811
description: An 1848 copy of Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels's ''Communist Manifesto'' was sold Wednesday at Sotheby's in London for $39,811, to the Valmadonna Trust, a private British collection of Hebrew and Jewish books and manuscripts.

title: QUANEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: PROBLEMS FOR G.O.P.
description: The New York Republican Party demonstrated this week that it still has not come out of the post-Rockefeller doldrums, many Republicans agreed today as they put the finishing touches on the state ticket and platform.

title: Poor, Sick and Uninsured: Who Pays?
description: The union worker's contract once covered everything from his little girl's corrective shoes to his own blood-pressure medicine. Laid off, he now works for an exterminator who offers him no-frills health coverage but requires an extra premium that he can't afford to cover his family . . . The single mother earns barely enough to support herself and a baby son, but too much to qualify for welfare or Medicaid; only half in jest, she warns the baby not to get sick . . . The bicycle messenger makes good money, but all in cash, without other benefits. Should a reckless swerve between taxicabs lead to injury, he'd have no way to pay a hospital bill.

title: 2 Divisions Set For Smith Race
description: The Red Smith Handicap at Belmont Park will be run in two divisions tomorrow because the race drew 19 entries yesterday and had to be split.

title: Barbados Vote Won By Opposition Party
description: The opposition Democratic Labor Party, led by former Prime Minister Errol Barrow, won a sweeping election victory, according to official election results today.

title: Piano Double Bill
description: The pianist Geri Allen will play her own compositions, and the pianist Bross Townsend will play standards and blues with the singer Carrie Smith in a double bill Sunday at 2:30 P.M. at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 104th Street (722-8223). Tickets are $6, $3 for students and over 65's, or $12 for a family of two adults and up to four children.

title: Growth Linked to Cheap Oil
description: Falling oil prices offer the leading industrial nations a chance to achieve much faster growth and to end a decade of disappointment, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said in a report that was released today.

title: Bumper Car
description: If the highways of Pittsburgh were a football field, yellow flags would be flying every time Chris Brown made the scene. Indeed, when it comes to being clipped while behind the wheel, he must hold the N.F.L. record.

title: ERNIE KOVACS: ZANY INFLUENCE ON TV COMEDY
description: THE antics of Ernie Kovacs in the early days of television remain etched in the brains of aficionados, who like to trade classic moments.

title: SOVIET PROMISES A CHERNOBYL ACCOUNTING
description: The Soviet Union has promised a detailed accounting of the accident at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant at an international forum this summer, probably in July, according to a senior American nuclear official.

title: EATON FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ALASKA STATEBANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Reagan to Visit Carolinas
description: President Reagan will visit Marine recruits at Parris Island, S.C., on Wednesday and then fly to Greensboro, N.C., to attend a fund-raising event for James T. Broyhill, a Senate candidate, the White House announced today.

title: CELTICS TAKE 2-0 SERIES LEAD
description: The Houston Rockets tried to stop the Boston Celtics tonight by using three big men to slow them down and then by using three small men to run with them. But those strategies, plus everything else that Coach Bill Fitch threw at the team he once led and helped put together, were not enough.

title: PICKING EXPERTS FROM OUT OF TOWN
description: Mayor Koch's appointment of an out-of-towner as head of the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission is the latest of several appointments in which he has chosen people who have experience in their field, but not necessarily in the intricacies of the city or its government.

title: Jazz Cultural Theater
description: The saxophonist Charles Davis will perform with the pianist Jack Wilson and his trio at the Jazz Cultural Theater, 368 Eighth Avenue, above 28th Street (502-4300) tonight and tomorrow. Sets are at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; admission is $8, $5 for students and over 65's.

title: TEMCO SERVICE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $198,400 for the quarter and $296,700 for the 6 months. c-Includes a tax benefit of $49,050.

title: MCCALL PATTERN CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
IRT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: YANKEES SHUT OUT MARINERS
description: The Yankee offense rested tonight, but the pitching thrived. Dennis Rasmussen, whose career has been marked by his inability to throw complete games, came within one out of getting one, finally settling for a 2-0 victory over the Seattle Mariners at the Kingdome.

title: Dining Out Guide: Sushi
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. CHIKUBU RESTAURANT, #12 East 44th

title: 3 ARMS EXPERTS CRITICIZE REAGAN ON 1979 TREATY
description: Several leading arms control experts said today that President Reagan's new arms policy could multiply the difficulties of developing an effective defense against long-range missiles.

title: ROCKWELL LAYOFFS VIEWED AS A TREND
description: In an action that may become increasingly common in the aerospace industry in the next few years, the Rockwell International Corporation said today that it will lay off 6,800 workers in the next five months as production of the B-1 bomber winds down.

title: CATHOLICS FIND MONEY LACKING FOR CARE OF OLD NUNS AND PRIESTS
description: The nation's Roman Catholic religious communities may fall short by $2.5 billion to $3.5 billion in providing for the retirement of aging members, a church study has found.

title: Exit for Old Tokens Is Set for Next Week
description: Starting Monday, subway riders in New York City will be able to use only the new ''bull's-eye'' tokens.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday GARDENS OF SOUND Just as composers organize notes to create music, audio artists organize sounds to create a novel art form. They might, for instance, set the sharp crack of breaking ice against the dull rhythm of a rumbling train or let the wind knock two hard plastic balls on a string against hollow steel rods. ''Sound Wave N.Y.C.,'' an audio art series mixing ''sound gardens,'' gallery exhibits and live performances, continues this weekend with shows tonight through Sunday at Performance Space 122, 150 First Avenue, at Ninth Street. Tonight at 9 o'clock, the performers include David Garland, who sings and plays everything from a toy piano and a piece of Styrofoam to the medieval psaltery; Linda Fisher, who reads texts inspired by mythology and feminism against electronic music, and Yoshimasa Wada, known for bagpipe-like instruments fashioned out of plumbing fixtures and powered by an air compressor. Frankie Mann and Sher Doruff, Nigel Rollings and Ellen Fullman will perform tomorrow at 9 P.M., and David Behrman, Andrew Culver and Brooks Williams will appear Sunday, also at 9. Tickets are $6 for each night's performance. Information: 477-5288. An exhibition of ''sound sculptures'' is also on display at the Bronx River Art Center at 1087 East Tremont Avenue, one block east of Boston Road. It is open from 1 to 6 P.M. today and tomorrow. Admission is free. Information: 589-5819.

title: ARCHIE VAN WINKLE
description: Col. Archie Van Winkle of the Marine Corps, who won the Congressional Medal of Honor in 1950 for helping turn back an attack by North Korean troops, died of unspecified natural causes on May 20.

title:
BRIEFING;
Reagan's Bacon and Arms
description: President Reagan has invited all 100 Senators to breakfast at the White House next Thursday. The meeting was originally planned to signal renewed White House involvement in the tax revision legislation pending in the Senate.

title: PURCHASERS' SURVEY FINDS GAINS
description: The pace of economic activity has picked up markedly this month, following a sluggish April, a closely watched business survey showed yesterday.

title: DRUG CASE TESTS CRICKET
description: England's leading cricketer, who has admitted in print that he occasionally smoked marijuana, was banned from the playing fields, if only briefly, as punishment for his behavior.

title: Girl Dies After Aid Is Refused on Bus
description: A 9-year-old girl with a pacemaker who died early today was suffering convulsions on a city bus when a driver refused to take her to a nearby hospital, witnesses said.

title: Potholes in New York, A Hardy Perennial
description: To the Editor:

title: TEST IS DUE TODAY ON GENE ALTERING
description: A biotechnology company will begin today to conduct the first field test of a plant altered by genetic engineering, the company said yesterday.

title: Keenan Gets New Pact
description: The Philadelphia Flyers have extended the contract of Coach Mike Keenan, but they did not disclose any terms of the agreement, including the length of the extension. In his first season as coach, Keenan led the Flyers to the Stanley Cup final with 53 victories, the most in the club's history, and was named the National Hockey League's coach of the year. This past season, the Flyers again had 53 victories and again captured the Patrick Division title, but they were eliminated in the first round of the playoffs in five games by the Rangers.

title: OFFICIAL TERMS PELTON MATERIAL A BOON TO SOVIET
description: The material that Ronald W. Pelton is charged with providing to the Soviet Union offers a detailed account of this country's successes, and failures, in intercepting many of the communications networks in the Soviet Union, a senior official of the National Security Agency testified today.

title: METS WIN ON ERROR IN 10TH
description: This is how hot the Mets are in these heady days of spring: In the top of the 10th inning in Shea Stadium last night, the San Francisco Giants broke a 6-6 tie when the rookie Robby Thompson hit a home run off Jesse Orosco. Thompson, who jumped from the Texas League to the National League this year, had no history of power hitting.

title: Anderson, Clayton Persists in Its Plan
description: Anderson, Clayton & Company said yesterday that it had decided to go ahead with a plan to reorganize, but it also agreed to meet with a Bear, Stearns partnership to discuss uncertainties about that group's bid for the consumer products company.

title: Lieberman Joins Pros
description: The former college basketball star Nancy Lieberman yesterday signed with the Springfield Fame of the United States Basketball League, saying she is confident she can compete with male professional athletes. The 27-year-old Miss Lieberman signed a one-year no-cut contract for an undisclosed sum, then went off to practice with her new teammates.

title: Why the Pitched Battles on Policy?
description: One recent Sunday morning on a television news program, Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d was discussing narcotics trafficking in Mexico when, much to the surprise of many listeners, he referred to the head of United States Customs Service as ''one of the those unfortunate people.''

title: Smoking Restriction in New York Is Good for the Public Health
description: To the Editor:

title: INTEGRATED CIRCUITS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
THE THIRD WORLD LOOKS AT CONSUMERISM
description: Fledgling consumer groups from developing countries met at a conference in Riverdale, the Bronx, this week to set modest goals to protect consumers in their countries.

title:
Patents;
A Device That Traces Nuisance Phone Calls
description: A telephone user will be able to have a nuisance call traced, using a device patented this week for Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, N.J. The invention has been undergoing field trials in three cities.

title: Caught In the Hype Line
description: Now suddenly I am supposed to love France. The Statue of Liberty, you know. It was a gift from France. And on July Fourth a huge media event having to do with the statue will occur in New York.

title: INDY DRIVERS TAKE FINAL PRACTICE RUN
description: Some drivers took in a final few laps of practice for peace of mind. Others were looking for specific problems. Others, confident their cars were race-ready, did not even show up.

title: FLORIDA TESTS SHOW NO SWINE FEVER
description: The Department of Agriculture said today that tests of blood serum taken from 87 swine in Belle Glade, Fla., did not contain any evidence that the animals were infected by African swine fever, an incurable viral disease in pigs.

title: John G. Martin Dies; Popularizer of Vodka
description: John G. Martin, the man who made vodka popular in the United States, died Thursday at his home in Naples, Fla. He was 80 years old.

title: LEADER OF TEAMSTERS PLEADS NOT GUILTY
description: With his back to a crowded courtroom, Jackie Presser, the president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, pleaded not guilty today to Federal embezzlement and racketeering charges.

title: MCDERMOTT INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $2,789,000, or 8 cents a share, for the quarter and year. c-Net loss d-After an extraordinary gain of $11,687,000, or 32 cents a share, for the quarter and year.

title: Dome's Lenders Accept Extension
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd. said its 54 lenders had agreed to at least a five-month extension of an interim plan to defer a substantial amount of principal and interest payments on $5.3 billion (Canadian) of a $6.27 billion debt. The plan is effective immediately and scheduled to end next Oct. 28 or Feb. 28, 1987, if extended.

title: RATES RISE IN LIGHT TRADING
description: Interest rates rose moderately in light trading yesterday, particularly in the longer-term bond market, after much sharper increases on Thursday for both long- and short-term Treasury issues.

title: NEW LOOK PAYS OFF FOR FORD
description: The early returns are in, and the Ford Motor Company's $3 billion Taurus gamble appears to be paying off.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, MAY 31, 1986
description: International The U.S. will bypass the 1979 treaty on nuclear arms with the Soviet Union in deciding what nuclear weapons are needed for its security, Secretary of State George P. Shultz said. In a news conference at the end of a contentious two-meeting of the NATO foreign ministers in Halifax, Nova Scotia, Mr. Shultz announced a policy ''shift of gears'' and said nuclear weapons would be chosen on miitary grounds and no longer on ''the technicalities '' of the 1979 treaty. That accord, which was never ratified by the Senate, sets limits on the numbers of offensive long-range missiles and bombers in the Soviet and American arsenals. [ Page 1, Column 6. ] A papal encyclical scorns Marxism and other forms of philosophical materialism as ideologies that portray ''God as an ememy of his own creature.'' The 141-page document, the fifth encyclical issued by Pope John Paul II, contains many references to Satan and to the coming of the third millennium. It seeks to focus attention on the Holy Spirit, the mysterious third person of the Trinity. [ 1:1. ] Political corruption charges against Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany were dropped by the Bonn prosecutor's officer after two-month investigation. The announcement came nine days after a prosecutor in Coblenz had halted a similar inquiry for lack of evidence. Investigators in Bonn had been looking into the possibility that the Chancellor had lied to a parliamentary inquiry into political party financing. [ 3:5. ] A benefit rock concert in Moscow raised $125,000 to help victims of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster, according to the official press agency Tass.

title: Khan Advances In Squash Event
description: Top-seeded Jahangir Khan of Pakistan opened the $50,000 Swan Laser Die U.S. Pro Squash Softball Championships yesterday with a 9-3, 9-2, 9-0 victory over Ned Edwards of New York.

title: STANDARD BRANDS PAINT CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
QUEENS COLLEGE: 'HIGHER PRIORITY' IN EDUCATION
description: Terrel H. Bell, the Education Secretary during President Reagan's first term, declared yesterday that both the President and Governor Cuomo could do more to make education a ''higher priority'' in the United States.

title: Cherry Bowl Order
description: The organizers of the Cherry Bowl have been ordered by the postseason committee of the National Collegiate Athletic Association to pay a minimum of $400,000 to both Syracuse and Maryland for participating in the postseason football game last winter. Mike Lude, the chairman of the committee, said the payment would have to be made by June 30 or the Cherry Bowl would face loss of certification.

title: 2 SIDES CITE ALUMINUM STRIKE FEAR
description: The nation's two largest aluminum companies and their unions agreed yesterday that a strike, threatened to begin at 12:01 A.M. tomorrow, would have dire consequences on the companies if it lasted long.

title: Kerryn King, 68, Dies; Ex-Manager at Texaco
description: Kerryn King, a former senior vice president of Texaco Inc., died May 23 at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, after a long illness. He was 68 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: DANCE: REVIVAL OF GRAHAM'S 'HERETIC'
description: ''Heretic,'' as uncompromising a work of art as any, was choreographed by Martha Graham in 1929, danced by Miss Graham and her first major company, and then never performed again in New York after 1931.

title: HAWKINS CHEMICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid March 14.

title: CO-FOUNDER OF RANDOM HOUSE
description: Donald S. Klopfer, who co-founded Random House almost 60 years ago, died of a cerebral hemorrhage yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan, and although he officially retired from the company in the 1970's, he continued to come into the office almost every day.

title: DOW DECLINES 5.64, CLOSING AT 1,876.71
description: The Dow Jones industrial average came tantalizingly close to the 1,900 level yesterday before profit taking, and perhaps concern about recently rising interest rates, pulled stock prices lower for the first time in the last six sessions.

title: INTERNATIONAL POWER MAHINES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

BRIEFING;
Kemp's Foes Are Busy
description: While Representative Jack F. Kemp crisscrosses the country laying the groundwork for the Republican Presidential sweepstakes, the Democrats are trying to lay some diversionary land-mines for him at home.

title: BURKHART PETROLEUM reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a provision of $225,000 for uncollectable receivables from oil and gas programs. Latest first quarter results also include operations of Henderson Petroleum Corp,. acquired Dec. 31, 1985.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THUNDERING HOOFBEATS, ETC. - Lo and behold! Radio is fit for a museum. At least the Museum of Broadcasting (752-4690), at 1 East 53d Street, thinks so. Today it is presenting a special program from 10:30 A.M. to noon to introduce radio to children, mostly those from 7 to 11 years of age. Of course, the presentation will note the museum's radio-program collection, but it will also show the audience how radio serials were created. Describing, for example, how sound effects - including the squeaking doors, hoof beats and marching feet - were made.

title: Sri Lanka Bombs Kill 26; Rebels Are Blamed
description: Twenty-six people were killed today in bomb explosions at a soft-drink bottling plant and in a military convoy, the authorities said.

title: JAPAN TAKES NEW YEN STEPS
description: The Japanese Government today adopted a second package of emergency measures to counter the effects of a strong yen.

title: JEWISH HUMOR FROM ROTH TO RIVERS
description: An 80-year-old widow goes on a blind date to a drive-in movie with an 80-year-old widower. When she comes home, her daughter asks how it went.

title: CROCKER ABSORBED INTO WELLS FARGO
description: The Crocker National Corporation, a bank with roots stretching to the early days of California, ceased to exist today as it was merged into Wells Fargo & Company in the biggest acquisition in banking history.

title: CENTURY PAPERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: YANKEES LOSE TO A'S BY 6-3
description: The loss was one thing. But certainly the Yankees were more concerned tonight with the condition of Mike Pagliarulo, who was struck on the bridge of his nose in the seventh inning, than by their 6-3 loss to the Oakland A's.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Auto Racing Indianapolis 500. (Television - Channel 7, 11 A.M.) Baseball Mets vs. San Francisco Giants, at Shea Stadium, 7:05 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 7 P.M. Radio -WABC 770, 7 P.M.) Yankees vs. A's, at Oakland, Calif., 4:05 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 4 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 4 P.M.) Reds vs. St. Louis Cardinals, at Cincinnati (Television - Channel 4, 1:15 P.M.) Cubs vs. Atlanta Braves, at Chicago, 4 P.M. (Television - WTBS, 4:05 P.M.) Royals vs. Texas Rangers, at Kansas City, Mo. (Radio - WCBS 880, 7:50 P.M.) College World Series, at Omaha. Miami vs. Oklahoma State and Indiana State vs. Florida State (Television - ESPN, 5 P.M. and 8 P.M. live). Boxing Gerry Cooney vs. Eddie Gregg, 10 rounds, heavyweights, at the Cow Palace, San Francisco. (Television - Channel 7, 4:30 P.M.) Running L'eggs Mini Marathon, at Central Park, 10 A.M. (Television - Channel 7, 4:30 P.M., tape. Radio -WABC 770, 9:30 A.M. live). Soccer Italy vs. Bulgaria, at Mexico City. Opener of the month-long World Cup, 2 P.M. Italy is the defending champion. (Television - Channel 41, 1 P.M. live, opening ceremonies, followed by the game at 2 P.M., live commentary in Spanish. Channel 4, 4 P.M., tape). Tennis French Open, at Paris. (Television - ESPN, 9 A.M.) Thoroughbred Racing Belmont, 1 P.M. Since there are 19 horses entered in the fifth running of the Red Smith Handicap, the turf race has been split into two divisions, each worth $125,000.

title: Replacement Ordered For Destroyed Satellite
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has ordered a replacement for the $250 million satellite lost in the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger.

title: Bridge; Rogoff and Rosmarin Teams Meet in the Reisinger Final
description: Teams led by Bruce Rogoff of Bayside, Queens, and Michael Rosmarin of Jamaica, Queens, clashed last night in the final of the Reisinger Knockout Team Championship at the Beverly Club, 130 East 57th Street in Manhattan.

title: THE WAY TO HELP TEEN-AGERS
description: Society does not pay much attention to adolescents until they cross a pathological line into violent crime, teen-age pregnancy, psychiatric distress, running away or suicide attempts. Then we focus on attempts to fix the problem.

title: NEW MEXICO & ARIZONA LAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Volvo, Fermenta Fined in Sweden
description: The Stockholm Stock Exchange fined Volvo A.B. and threatened to delist the shares of the biotechnology company Fermenta for failing to report plans to link the companies earlier this year.

title: RECITAL: STEVEN MASI, PIANO
description: Steven Masi's recital at Merkin Concert Hall on Wednesday night ended with an impetuous account of Stravinsky's Three Movements from ''Petrouchka'' after the pianist had played Book I of Debussy's Etudes with panache and devoted himself earlier in the evening to Beethoven's Sonata in A flat (Op. 110) and Schubert's Three Piano Pieces (D. 946).

title: MACDERMID INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BEAMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
description: Share earnings reflect a 100 percent stock dividend paid July 25, 1985.

title: Australian Says U.S. Sought Haven for Nazi
description: The United States wanted Australia to resettle Klaus Barbie, who is accused of war crimes in France, according to a Liberal Party senator who says he obtained documents in the case.

title: 'Good Enough' Isn't
description: The first national symposium on ''Schooling for 4-Year-Olds,'' recently sponsored by Yale's Bush Center in Child Development and Social Policy, came none too soon. About 1,500 of the nation's 15,000 school districts already educate 4-year-olds and more will inevitably do so as the number of working women increases.

title: WORLD CUP PLAY STARTS TODAY
description: The eyes of the soccer world will be on Aztec Stadium in Mexico City today when Italy plays Bulgaria in the opening game of the 13th World Cup, the quadrennial championship of the planet's most popular sport.

title: CAMPANELLI INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income and includes a tax credit of $58,490.

title: The U.N. Today: May 31, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 3 P.M.

title: Speakes's Father Dies
description: Harry Earl Speakes, father of the chief White House spokesman, Larry Speakes, died of cancer today at King's Daughters Hospital in Greenville after a long illness. He was 80 years old.
