Mr. Speakes had been manager of the Marigold Branch of Cleveland State Bank from 1937 to 1980 and was vice president of the bank.

title: How to Crack Down On 'Crack' Dealers
description: When spring arrived in our Greenwich Village neighborhood with the sweet chirping of birds, it also brought something new and frightening. ''Mommy, they're smoking crack downstairs,'' said our 7-year-old son. ''Mom, they offered me crack today,'' announced our 13-year-old son.

title: SHULTZ SAYS NEED, NOT THE '79 PACT, WILL DECIDE ARMS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the United States, in a policy ''shift of gears,'' would decide what nuclear weapons were needed for its security on military grounds and no longer on ''the technicalities'' of the 1979 arms treaty with the Soviet Union.

title: Smoking Restriction in New York Is Good for the Public Health
description: To the Editor:

title: Three Students Indicted In Shanty Firebombing
description: Johns Hopkins University has suspended three students following their indictment on charges of arson, conspiracy and assault with intent to murder in the firebombing of an inhabited shanty built as a protest against South Africa's racial segregation, officials say.

title: CLYDE BERNHARDT, 80, A JAZZ TROMBONIST IN TOP SWING BANDS
description: Clyde E. B. Bernhardt, who played jazz trombone and sang in the bands of King Oliver, Fats Waller, Claude Hopkins and many others, died May 20 at St. James Hospital in Newark. He was 80 years old and lived in Newark.

title: 41 Accused of Smuggling Cocaine Throughout U.S.
description: Forty-one people were accused by the Federal Government today of operating a drug ring that smuggled and distributed cocaine throughout the United States.

title: Britain Condemns Argentina for Sea Attack
description: Britain has condemned Argentina for attacking Taiwan fishing trawlers near the Falkland Islands and said it called earlier this week for an end to harassment of the vessels.

title:
Patents;
A Wristwatch Alarm To Ward Off Attack
description: A panic alarm wristwatch patented this week can sound a warning when the wearer is attacked.

title: Farragut at Home
description: It has been besieged by the elements, defaced by vandals, eroded by acid rain and coveted by the Metropolitan Museum of Art. But the statue of Admiral Farragut looked undaunted when it was returned yesterday to its gray granite pedestal in Madison Square Park.

title: A TOP POSTAL AIDE ADMITS TO FRAUD
description: The vice chairman of the United States Postal Service's Board of Governors pleaded guilty today to taking illegal payoffs in exchange for trying to steer a $250 million postal contract to a Dallas company.

title: GREGG GETS HIS BIG CHANCE
description: In a plaza just outside the Hyatt Regency Embarcadero, a crowd sang ''Happy Birthday'' to Eddie Gregg today.

title: Bolling Leads In Kemper Open
description: Charlie Bolling shot a 70 today for a 137 total, seven under par, and a one-stroke lead over four golfers after two rounds of the $500,000 Kemper Open. Bobby Clampett, Mike Reid, Larry Mize and Leonard Thompson each finished at 138.

title: MICHAELS STORES reports earnings for Qtr to May 4

BRIEFING;
Calling All Liberals
description: Americans for Democratic Action, which calls itself the oldest and largest multi-issue liberal organization, will hold its 38th convention next Thursday, with its theme the future of liberalism among young people.

title: BOB EVANS FARMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 25
21 YEARS OF MILES TAKE TOLL ON TOES
description: She thought the problem was just a bruise. The time was approaching for Francie Larrieu-Smith to defend her championship in the L'Eggs Mini Marathon, the 6.2-mile event that has become part world-class road race through Central Park, part party with more than 7,000 guests, and part personal celebration of achievement. As that day - today - approached, the sensation in her feet made her feel less and less capable of being involved in anything but the party. ''It was just there,'' she said. ''I could feel it, but it didn't hurt.''

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a Washington dispatch yesterday about criticism of President Reagan's new arms-control policy misattributed an assertion that the policy could make it harder to develop a defense against long-range missiles. The assessment came from experts working on Mr. Reagan's Strategic Defense Initiative, not three former high-ranking Government officials.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: CANADA SOUTHERN PETROEUM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: All figures are in Canadian dollars. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: NEW LANDMARKS POLICY URGED BY MAYORAL PANEL
description: The city's Landmarks Preservation Commission should conduct an immediate inventory of potential landmarks and should be empowered to protect those sites from demolition or alteration while the commission determines whether to designate them as landmarks, a mayoral panel recommended yesterday.

title: SECRET SNACKS OF TOP CHEFS
description: When our city's most sophisticated chefs and restaurateurs want a snack, they often choose the kinds of things their patrons would never admit to eating.

title: CORRECTION
description: A brief article in Weekend yesterday about the Boys Choir of Harlem gave an incorrect date for the choir's concert at Alice Tully Hall. It will take place on June 8, not tomorrow.

title: 2 TRADE BLAME FOR ALTERCATION AT CITY MEETING
description: Victor E. Botnick, a top aide to Mayor Koch, and Dr. Barry Liebowitz, president of the union representing city doctors, each blamed the other yesterday for an altercation that broke up a meeting of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation on Thursday night.

title: NEW-HOME SALES FALL SLIGHT 3.5 %
description: New-home sales declined by a relatively slight 3.5 percent in April but were still 33 percent above their rate of a year ago, the Commerce Department said today.

title: CONCERT: PHILHARMONIC IN NEW-MUSIC PROGRAM
description: The third of the New York Philharmonic's Horizons '86 new-music programs Wednesday night at Avery Fisher Hall entered realms of meditational mysticism and attracted a healthy audience as a result. Not everyone was similarly entranced: there were boos as well as cheers after every piece. But in today's fatally polite world of contemporary music, a little controversy can hardly hurt.

title: CITY OPENING OFFICES TO GIVE AID ON FINES
description: Starting Monday, it may be easier for New Yorkers to clear up mystery parking tickets.

title: CLOUD OF CHERNOBYL CHILLS A LUSH KIEV SPRING
description: More than a month after the Unit 4 reactor at the Chernobyl atomic power station erupted with a plume of radioactive dust, Kiev and its 2.5 million people are learning to live with the invisible threat that stirs with strong south winds - the ''dust,'' as people call it.

title: U.S. to Give Information To Mexico on Trafficking
description: The United States Customs Commissioner has agreed to give Mexican authorities intelligence information about the purported involvement of Mexican police officers and public officials in narcotics trafficking, delegates to a conference of legislators from the two countries were told here today.

title: Looking Ahead At Funerals
description: A FUNERAL may very well be one of the most expensive single outlays for individuals and their families. The latest statistics from the Federated Funeral Directors of America show that the average selling price for an adult's funeral is $2,656, excluding items such as special transportation and clothing. And the cost can run much, much higher.

title: 3 DRAFT CHOICES SIGNED BY GENERALS
description: Despite the uncertainty over the United States Football League's first fall season, the Generals have signed three of their 39 draft choices, an improvement over last year when they signed only one, Doug Flutie, and barely tried for the others.

title: PROSECUTOR IN BONN REJECTS CHARGES AGAINST CHANCELLOR
description: The Bonn prosecutor's office announced today that after a two-month investigation, it had decided that it would not bring political corruption charges against Chancellor Helmut Kohl.

title: Deputy to Shulman Named
description: Peter Magnani, a 47-year-old city planner, was appointed Deputy Borough President of Queens yesterday by Borough President Claire Shulman. He will fill the $75,000-a-year post that Mrs. Shulman held before taking over for the late Donald R. Manes, who resigned as Borough President Feb. 11. Mr. Magnani, a Jackson Heights resident and an architect, has been director of the Queens office of the City Planning Department for the last six years.

title: 19 DEAD, 22 INJURED IN BUS CRASH IN SIERRA NEVADA
description: A tour bus carrying residents of a retirement home careened at high speed off a twisting mountain road and plunged into a swift, icy river today, killing 19 people and injuring 22, the authorities said.

title: BLACK HEAD COACH IN N.F.L.
description: Fritz Pollard, the only black head coach of a National Football League team and a member of the National Football Foundation Hall of Fame for college players, died May 11 in Silver Spring, Md., after a short illness. He was 92 years old.

title: Hortense Calisher Is New PEN President
description: Hortense Calisher, the author of 10 novels, a memoir and several collections of short stories, has been elected president of the American Center of International PEN for 1986-88.

title: The Price of Sports in SUNY
description: A football Saturday on campus is much more than the game. It also means tailgate parties, alumni strolling the grounds, the marching band pumping out fight songs - much that promotes an intangible school spirit, which has more tangible fallout in publicity and fund-raising.

title: AMFESCO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income Results for the latest quarter include Chapter 11 expenses of $435,000. The latest 9-month results include non-recurring charges of $14,170,000, inventory writedowns of $13,095,000, and Chapter 11 expenses of $714,000.

title: CUCOS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 6
description: b-Net income

title: No Opponent for Tyson
description: The undefeated heavyweight Mike Tyson will fight a 10-round match June 28 in Troy, N.Y., against a yet-to-be selected opponent, according to Loraine Miller of Tri-City Promotions. Miss Miller said ''a guy with a very good record'' would eventually be selected as an opponent for Tyson, who is also scheduled to face Reggie Gross June 13 at Madison Square Garden. . . . The former heavyweight champion Larry Holmes said he would sue the International Boxing Federation if the organization failed to overturn his April 19 loss to Michael Spinks. ''What they have to do is tell Michael they made a mistake, and then apologize to me for making a mistake and give me my title back,'' Holmes said.

title: D'AMATO TESTIFIES FOR THE U.S.F.L.
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato testified in Federal District Court yesterday that he had been led to believe for a time by Leon Hess, the owner of the Jets, that the Jets would return to New York City in time for the 1989 National Football League season to play in a new domed stadium in Flushing Meadows, Queens.

title: ASTRO-MED INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
EXCERPTS FROM POPE'S ENCYCLICAL, 'THE LORD AND GIVER OF LIFE'
description: Following are excerpts from Pope John Paul II's encyclical, ''Dominum et Vivificantem'' (''The Lord and Giver of Life''), which was made public today by the Vatican:

title: ROCKETS FACE TOUGH TASK
description: Four men in a hotel coffee shop this morning were discussing the Boston Celtics' 117-95 rout of the Houston Rockets Thursday night in the second game of the National Basketball Association championships.

title: JARRYD IS UPSET
description: Ivan Lendl and Martina Navratilova continued to win with ease at the French Open tennis championships. Not so for Anders Jarryd of Sweden, the fifth-seeded player, who was upset today by his fellow Swede, Ulf Stenlund, 6-4, 6-2, 6-3.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 10. 1. Students at a butlers' school in London put glasses on their heads to learn good carriage. 2. Margaret Thatcher made the first visit by a British Prime Minister to Israel. 3. The names of 110 servicemen were added to the Vietnam Veterans Memorial. Because the deaths occurred outside the Vietnam war zone, the names were omitted when the memorial was dedicated in 1982. 4. With her silver-handled umbrella, Mrs. Tucker hit a purse snatcher in Manhattan and successfully detained him until a passer-by and a police officer came to her aid. 5. Sport Aid. 6. Lampedusa, a small Italian island in the Mediterranean, is the site of a United States Coast Guard station. Libyans have threatened to blow up not only that installation, but also the entire island, which it says is a base for attacks by the United States and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. 7. The seven states have been eliminated as potential sites for the nation's first nuclear waste dump. The three Western states are potential sites of the repository. 8. Slower. 9. The Grand Canyon. 10. The road, connecting China and Pakistan, has been opened to nationals of other countries for the first time since its completion in 1978. 11. The Federal speed limit of 55 miles an hour. 12. Carnegie Hall. 13. Representative Lundine was selected as Governor Cuomo's running mate on the Democratic ticket. Mr. Kavanaugh was named as the Republican candidate for lieutenant governor after Jeanine F. Pirro withdrew from the ticket. 14.

title: EVANS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 1
STORM OVER 'ANIMAL FARM' DISPUTE
description: Wole Soyinka, the Nigerian playwright, and Sir Peter Hall exchanged sharp accusations yesterday over Mr. Soyinka's decision to drop Sir Peter's production of ''Animal Farm'' from a theater festival in Baltimore because of Soviet objections.

title:
Patents;
An Apparatus to Help Orientation in Space
description: Apparatus to enhance the stability of a spacecraft with respect to an astronomical body, such as the earth, was patented this week for the Ford Aerospace and Communications Corporation, Detroit.

title: ANALYSIS & TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Debt Rating Cut On Burroughs
description: Credit ratings for the Burroughs Corporation were reduced by Moody's Investors Service because of the increased debt and financial risk Burroughs will incur by acquiring the Sperry Corporation. Ratings for Sperry's outstanding debt issues were also reduced.

title: Peter DeNunzio, Sharon D. Kistler Exchange Vows
description: Sharon Drew Kistler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Drew Kistler of Pittsburgh, and Peter Dwight DeNunzio were married yesterday. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Dwight DeNunzio of Riverside, Conn.

title: Egyptian Sculpture Sets Record High at Auction
description: A monumental ancient Egyptian sculpture of the lioness-headed goddess Sekhmet of Memphis was sold at Sotheby's yesterday from the estate of John Lennon for $742,500, a record at auction for Egyptian art that doubled the previous high.

title: MOSCOW ROCK CONCERT AIDS CHERNOBYL VICTIMS
description: For three hours tonight, the public image the Soviet Union presents to the world was replaced by a rock-and-roll vision.

title: The 'Andromeda Strain' Is Still Science Fiction
description: To the Editor:

title: DRUG TEAM OFFICER STRUCK BY A GUNSHOT AFTER MAKING ARREST
description: An officer on the Police Department's new anticrack unit was shot in the leg last night in front of a West Harlem apartment building after a group of officers made drug-related arrests, the police said.

title: INTERNATIONAL TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said share earnings for fiscal 1985 are after preferred dividends of $1,080,000. The results for both years reflect the company's acquisition of McKittrick Mud Co., which was accounted for as a pooling of interest.

title: Texas Dairy Shuts Plant That Had Bacteria
description: The Schepps Dairy has voluntarily recalled milk from schools and stores and announced a $500,000 remodeling project at the Dallas plant where health officials found a deadly bacteria on the floor near a filling machine, its officials said today.

title: SYLVAN LEARNING CORP reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Net loss Share earnings have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split effective Jan. 31, 1986. Comparative results are not applicable because the company went public in 1985.

title: Flatten the Hump in Tax Reform
description: The Senate Finance Committee's tax reform bill brims with good features - and a few abominations. One is the unfairness created by a tricky hump in tax rates on income between $75,000 and $145,000.

title: KELLWOOD CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $148,000 for the quarter and $1,794,000 for the year. c-After a gain from discontinued operations of $731,000, or 11 cents a share. d-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,110,000.

title: BONNER SAYS SAKHAROV FILMS ARE K.G.B.'S WORK
description: Yelena G. Bonner said today that recent films purporting to portray the views of her husband, Andrei D. Sakharov, were part of a disinformation campaign by the K.G.B.

title: SQUARE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes a gain of $553,000 from the sale of land.

title: CANDIDACIES ANNOUNCED BY ABRAMS AND BADILLO
description: Attorney General Robert Abrams formally declared his candidacy for a third term today. And Herman Badillo declared that he was running for state comptroller with the backing of Governor Cuomo.

title: Lurene Tuttle, 79, an Actress In Films and on Radio and TV
description: Lurene Tuttle, a radio, movie and television actress who starred in the 195O's television series ''Life With Father,'' died Wednesday in Encino, Calif. She was 79 years old and lived in West Hollywood.

title: Don't Make Worker Exploitation Easier
description: To the Editor:

title: 94 degrees Temperature Sets A Record for May 30
description: A temperature record tumbled in the metropolitan area yesterday as the mercury reached 94 degrees in Central Park at 2:22 P.M. The temperature was two degrees above the previous record for the date, set in 1942.

title: OSHAMAN'S SPORTING GOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BLOCK DRUG CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings for the years ended March 31, 1986 and 1985, as well as the fourth quarter ended March 31, 1985, are restated to reflect stock dividends declared November 1985 and October 1984.

title: GENE-ALTERED TOBACCO IS PLANTED IN WISCONSIN
description: In a significant step for the biotechnology industry and agriculture, scientists and technicians planted genetically engineered tobacco on a Wisconsin farm today to begin the first outdoor test of plants modified by artificial manipulation of their genetic structures.

title: Plan Aids Projects in State
description: Embedded in the completed version of the Senate Finance Committee's tax-revision plan are several tax favors that would save millions of dollars in taxes for projects in New York State.

title: CARDINAL DISTRIBUTION INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: The company said that the latest quarter results include its John L. Thompson Sons & Co. unit acquired in January.

title: Alamito Accord On Legal Fees
description: The Alamito Company, an electricity wholesaler based in Tucson, Ariz., said that Osceola Energy Inc. had agreed to pay $936,372 in legal fees involving a class action lawsuit related to Osceola's merger agreement with Alamito.

title: Nonpresence in Vanuatu Of Cuba and Vietnam
description: To the Editor:

title: TRADE GAP NARROWED IN APRIL
description: The nation's trade deficit, measuring the excess of imports over exports, declined to $12.1 billion last month from $14.5 billion in March, the Government reported today.

title: CLERK ACCUSED OF POISONING DRUGS TO MAKE MONEY IN STOCK MARKET
description: A former clerk in a stock brokerage has been charged with putting rat poison in capsules of Contac cold medicine and two other drugs in an attempt to profit through stock trading.

title: LIBYAN AMBASSADOR MAKES A QUIET EXIT AT SPAIN'S REQUEST
description: The Libyan Ambassador to Spain, who was accused by suspected terrorists of having personally overseen their operations, has left Spain at the request of the Spanish Government, according to Libyan and Spanish officials.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, MAY 31, 1986
description: The Economy

title: A FIERCE FIGHT OVER THE SUN
description: Once upon a time, there was suntan lotion.

title: SOLITRON DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes a reduction of a tax credit of $223,000 for quarter and includes a tax credit of $1,317,000 for year.

title: Toots Thielemans
description: The guitarist and harmonica player Toots Thielemans will lead a quartet tonight and tomorrow at Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas, at Ninth Street (982-3260). Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M., with a 12:30 A.M. set tonight; there is a $10 cover and a $7 minimum.

title: Saga's Board Opposes Offer
description: The Saga Corporation said today that its board had recommended that shareholders reject the $34-a-share offer from the Marriott Corporation.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''What we are talking about here is a shift of gears from a form of restraint under a treaty that was never ratified and was being violated for that matter, and has been increasingly obsolete.

title: Seagram Buyback
description: The Seagram Company said that it plans to buy up to 4.7 million shares, or 5 percent of its common stock outstanding, on the open market over the period of a year.

title: DEBATE IS FOCUSED ON RESPONSIBILITY OF NEWS MEDIA
description: Senior Reagan aides are attempting to focus the debate over the news media's role in reporting national secrets on the media's responsibilities, Administration officials said today.

title: PERRY ELLIS, FASHION DESIGNER, DEAD
description: Perry Ellis, whose spirited sportswear for men and women made him one of the nation's top fashion designers, died yesterday at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was 46 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL TECTONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $224,000.

title:
BRIEFING;
Creatures II
description: Elsewhere in the animal kingdom, the Celebrity Invitation Dog Show and Fair, to benefit the Capital Children's Museum, will be held Sunday afternoon at the museum.

title: AMBRIT INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss There were no common share earnings for this year's first quarter after preferred dividend requirements.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on May 20 about the Cannes Film Festival awards incorrectly described ''The Mission,'' the movie that won the top prize. It concerns the Jesuit missions of Paraguay in the 18th century.

title: JEWS REJECT CHANGE ON SOVIET
description: Several leading American Jewish organizations issued a strongly worded statement today opposing any dilution of the Jackson-Vanik amendment, the 1974 law linking trade benefits for the Soviet Union to a relaxation in restrictions on the emigration of Soviet Jews.

title: FIRST AMERICAN HEALTH CONCEPTS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
ANDERSON JACOBSON INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
EUROPEAN ROCKET DESTROYED AFTER ENGINE FAILURE
description: Europe's Ariane rocket was blown up by mission control nine minutes after launching tonight when its third stage failed to fire, sending the unmanned rocket and a $55 million satellite payload tumbling into the Atlantic.

title: FIFTH AVENUE'S STONE IS A GEOLOGIST'S TREASURE
description: ''Look!'' yelped Sidney Horenstein, whipping out his trusty geological hand lens and pressing his nose to the limestone lining of Saks' doorway on Fifth Avenue. ''Colonial coral fossils!''

title: Moscow Said to Allow Wide Matisse Showing
description: Armand Hammer, who coordinated the exchange of Soviet and American Impressionist art exhibitions currently touring both countries, said today the Soviet Union would allow Matisse's ''Harmony in Red'' to be shown with the rest of the Soviet collection when the exhibition moves to Los Angeles and New York later this year.

title: PRICES PAID TO FARMERS UP BY 2.5%
description: The prices that farmers receive for their raw products rose 2.5 percent in May but remained 4.6 percent below the level of a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Democracy's Successes in Dominican Republic
description: To the Editor:

title: EX-OFFICIAL'S CASE IN NEBRASKA ENDED
description: The Nebraska Supreme Court today reversed the perjury conviction of former Attorney General Paul L. Douglas and ordered his case dismissed, ruling that he had been wrongly indicted and prosecuted.

title: REAGAN REITERATES SUPPORT FOR LIABILITY SUIT LIMITS
description: President Reagan today brought his proposal to limit liability damage awards to an audience that supports it, the American Tort Reform Association, an organization of business and professional groups seeking such limits.

title: INTERACTIVE TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $12,000 and $24,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $104,000 and $216,000 for quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: WHITES IN PROTEST AGAINST PRETORIA
description: The police, using whips and tear gas, arrested more than 50 people today as college students, both white and black, staged anti-Government protests in South Africa's two biggest cities.

title: Interest in Islanders
description: All three candidates believed to be likely successors to the former Islander coach Al Arbour have expressed interest in the position. Two are currently coaching minor league clubs, Fred Creighton with the Islanders' Springfield farm club and Terry Crisp with Calgary's top minor team in Moncton, New Brunswick, and the third, Terry Simpson, is without experience at the N.H.L. level. Simpson, 42, has coached the Prince Albert Raiders, a leading junior club in the Western Hockey League, for the last 15 seasons, and he coached the Canadian Junior Team to gold and silver medals in their last two seasons of international competition.

title: ON S.I., A BRAWL RENEWS UNEASY DEBATE ON RACIAL TENSION
description: During a brawl at a Staten Island park last weekend, someone stood over William Galloway, black and 14 years old, and screamed racial epithets while hitting him on the head with a hammer. Just who did this is still not clear, but the event has troubled a community deeply divided along racial lines.

title: OF FRIENDS AND MONEY: CAMPAIGN IN SAN DIEGO
description: A popular bumper sticker here reads, ''Welcome to San Diego - but please don't stay,'' echoing a growing sentiment that the nation's eighth largest city need advance no further in closing its population gap with Los Angeles.

title: HORIZONS RESEARCH reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said that effective March 31, 1985, it acquired 100 percent of the outstanding common stock of Metalphoto of Cincinnati Inc. Metalphoto is a wholly owned subsidiary, and the results of its operations are included in the operating results for the latest quarter.

title: COMPUTER TRANSCEIVER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
Okamoto of Japan Has 3-Stroke Lead
description: Nine years ago, Chako Higuchi won the 23d Ladies Professional Golf Association championship at North Myrtle Beach, S.C., and Pat Bradley was one of three who tied for second.

title: SECURITY AGENCY OFFICIAL OFFERS A LESSON ON SPYING
description: Jurors in the espionage trial of Ronald W. Pelton Jr. listened raptly today as a top official of the National Security Agency gave them a lesson in the secret art of intercepting signals.

title: Jewish Body Releases Waldheim Document
description: The World Jewish Congress yesterday produced a copy of the United Nations War Crimes Commission document that accused Kurt Waldheim of being a war criminal who should stand trial for murder and putting hostages to death.

title: SOVIET AIDE DOUBTFUL ON SUMMIT
description: A senior Soviet official cast doubts today on the likelihood of a Soviet-American summit meeting later this year if the Reagan Administration does not alter its attitude toward arms control.

title: CITY COLLEGE: 1,700 URGED TO SHAPE FUTURE
description: The Mayor of San Antonio, Henry G. Cisneros, urged the 1,700 graduates of the City College of the City University of New York yesterday to learn to be ''masters of diversity'' in order to successfully deal with the ''relentless change'' in the world.

title: American Dreamers
description: SUCCESS STORIES. By Russell Banks. 183 pages. Harper & Row. $15.95. In his last book, ''Continental Drift,'' Russell Banks created a visionary epic about innocence and guilt, and in doing so, he also set down a shattering portrait of contemporary American society. His story of one man's doomed attempts to reinvent his life became a dark mirror of the American dream: As we watched Bob Dubois set off for Florida with entrepreneurial visions of glamour dancing in his head, then witnessed the smashing of all his ambitions and his hopes, we were made aware of the terrible consequences that the false promises of success can have on the lives of ordinary workingmen.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The owner of the Golden State Warriors denied a report on CBS at halftime of Thursday night's telecast of the Celtics-Rockets game that the team was considering trading Chris Mullin, the former St. John's star. ''It's just hogwash,'' Jim Fitzgerald, the owner, told The Oakland Tribune. . . . Mary Decker Slaney, the track star, gave birth yesterday to a 7-pound 5-ounce girl in Eugene, Ore. The baby will be named Ashley Lynn Slaney.

title: JOHN PAUL, ISSUING FIFTH ENCYCLICAL, ATTACKS MARXISM
description: Pope John Paul II issued the fifth encyclical of his papacy today, denouncing Marxism and other forms of philosophical materialism as ideologies that portray ''God as an enemy of his own creature.''

title: CITY BARS CONTRACTS WITH A QUEENS COMPANY
description: A city panel found yesterday that a Queens plumbing and heating contractor whose owner faces criminal charges and has purported ties to an organized-crime leader was ''not a responsible bidder'' and barred the company from doing business with the city for three years.

title: REMOVAL OF GROUPS IN CHARITY DRIVE BARRED
description: Federal District Judge Joyce Hens Green today barred the Federal Government from removing political and legal advocacy groups from the $120 million annual Federal charity drive, saying the Reagan Administration may be illegally excluding the groups with liberal views.

title: 'GODMOTHERS' CUDDLE AILING INFANTS
description: David is overcoming the drug addiction he inherited from his mother. The newborn infant is fretful, restless and difficult to comfort. He and a half-dozen other drug-dependent babies in the neonatal intensive care unit at Beth Israel Medical Center cry almost ceaselessly.

title: Bidding on a Facelift
description: It takes a certain sang-froid to bid in public for a facelift. But several supporters of the New York City Opera did just that at an auction Thursday at the National Academy of Design on Fifth Avenue.

title: ON THE TRAIL OF ARAB TERROR: FOOTPRINTS IN BERLIN
description: On two days in March, Ahmed Hazi told the police, he lugged a cardboard box full of explosives supplied by the Syrian Embassy in East Berlin to the German-Arab Friendship Society here. There, he placed it on a balcony.

title: CORRECTION
description: An art review in Weekend yesterday gave an incorrect closing date for Robert Mason's show at the CDS Gallery, 13 East 75th Street. It closes next Saturday, not today.

title: MMI MEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $474,000.

title: DATA DIMENSIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: UNIVERSAL SECURITY INSTRUENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $74,638 for the quarter and $308,362 for the year. c-Net loss

title: Get OTB Out of Dinginess
description: The New York City Off-Track Betting Corporation is missing a terrific chance to build a new image and reverse the decline in its revenues - revenues that go directly to the city. It is time for OTB to move out of its dingy downtown storefronts and into a new kind of facility - a place more like the casinos at Atlantic City, where New Yorkers from all walks of life would feel safe and comfortable while they bet.

title: Contract for Carew
description: Rod Carew, who was unable to land a job in the major leagues last season, has called a news conference for Monday to announce he has agreed to a one-year contract with a big-league club. Carew, who has been coaching his daughter's softball team while waiting for an offer, last night would not reveal the club with which he has come to terms.

title: TOUR, VENTURING OFF BEATEN TRACK, DISCOVERS 'CITY' OF BROOKLYN
description: They came from as far away as Singapore and as nearby as Greenwich Village, and they looked attentive as Justin Ferate announced the news.

title: OF GRAFFITI AND MISS LIBERTY
description: After more than a year of painstaking labor, with 12-hour days that often started at 6 A.M., the ironworkers who installed 1,800 new stainless steel armature bars inside the Statue of Liberty wanted a little immortality.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 13. 1. Students in classes like these have glasses atop their heads as part of a job training program. Explain. 2. A plane fitted with special devices to deflect surface-to-air missiles carried a traveler to a historic visit. Who traveled where, and why was the trip historic? 3. In a Memorial Day ceremony, 58,022 formally became 58,132. Explain. 4. ''Listen, I've been through two wars, with bombs flying all around me,'' said 86-year-old Vera Tucker, after more recent combat. What happened? 5. Millions of hands and feet aided the hungry and homeless. According to estimates by sponsors of the two events, which drew more participants, Sport Aid or Hands Across America? 6. Some people fear that Lampedusa will be blown up. What is Lampedusa and what are the circumstances? 7. Georgia, Maine, Minnesota, New Hampshire, North Carolina, Virginia and Wisconsin are no longer under consideration, according to the White House, but Nevada, Texas and Washington are. What is at issue? 8. The speed of sound in air is nearly a half mile an hour (faster/ slower) than had been thought, according to calculations of a Canadian scientist. 9. The discovery of rich uranium ore deposits near (the Grand Canyon/the Great Salt Lake/Monument Valley/Yellowstone National Park) is luring mining companies to the area. 10. Although the 795-mile Karakoram Highway has reduced a journey of months for camel trains to 36 hours of Jeep driving, it remains as arduous a road as can be found anywhere in Asia.

title: COMCOA INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 20
SAFEGUARDS ON BABY FORMULA
description: Six years ago, after two brands of deficient baby formula caused widespread illness, Congress passed a law strengthening Federal regulation of the contents and manufacture of the formula. The law was unusually specific, identifying 29 nutrients that had to be included in all baby formula and requiring manufacturers to use ''periodic'' testing to make sure that a specified level of each nutrient was present.

title: Milt Jackson
description: The vibraphonist Milt Jackson and a quartet featuring Cedar Walton on piano will perform tonight and tomorrow at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, below 11th Street (255-4037). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $10 cover and a one-drink minimum.

title: Exxon Closes Last Center For Free Road Maps
description: The last motorists to glean free maps and directions drifted into the Exxon Touring Service yesterday.

title: CHARLES SCOTT KING
description: Charles Scott King, a news anchorman for WINS, an all-news radio station in New York, died Monday at St. Joseph's Hospital and Medical Center in Paterson, N.J., after a long illness. He was 56 years old and lived in Glen Rock, N.J.

title: FASHION INSTITUTE OF TECHNOLOGY: MORE AID FOR SCHOOLS URGED
description: Addressing graduates of the Fashion Institute of Technology yesterday, the Chancellor of the State University of New York, Dr. Clifton R. Wharton Jr., questioned the Government's practice of spending more money ''on military hardware than on student software.''

title: 'NOT MANY' REBELS, A FILIPINO ASSERTS
description: Jaime Cardinal Sin, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Manila, said today that he thought the scope of the Communist insurgency in the Philippines had been exaggerated.

title: SOUTHEASTERN PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $374,000 for the quarter and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $512,000 and an extraordinary gain on insurance recovery of $456,000, both for the year. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $315,000. d-Net income

title: DEAVER SEEN LOSING CANADA CONTRACT
description: Canada is not expected to renew its $105,000 annnual contract with Michael K. Deaver, the former White House aide whose subsequent activities as a lobbyist have come under investigation in Washington.

title: HANDYMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 19
description: b-Net income and includes an after- tax gain of $2.6 million on the sale of real estate. Both quarters represent 16-week periods.

title: U.S. READY TO CHARGE ISRAELI IN SPY OPERATION, AIDE SAYS
description: An Israeli military officer is expected to be charged in the next several days with participating in an espionage operation in the United States, a Reagan Administration official said today.

title: Misguided Mischief for Ulster Investors
description: Misguided legislation in half a dozen states, including New York, seeks to capitalize on the disinvestment protests against apartheid by blaming a few American companies in Northern Ireland for discrimination against Roman Catholics there. By demanding that the managers of public pensions use their leverage to influence the companies' hiring policies, these laws draw too facile a parallel with South Africa. By further increasing the difficulties of investing in Ulster, they risk more of the poverty that breeds the discrimination they deplore.

title:
BRIEFING;
Creatures I
description: The White House Press Secretary, James Brady, who remains partly paralyzed from a bullet wound suffered five years ago when John Hinckley tried to assassinate President Reagan, is scheduled to officiate today at an unusual retirement party.

title: A MATTER OF INFRACTING
description: It is a rare day when there isn't some announcement adding evidence of the game that the colleges and the N.C.A.A. enforcement agency play with each other.

title: TELEVIDEO SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: b-Net loss

title: TRUMP OFFERS TO REBUILD SKATING RINK
description: Donald J. Trump has offered to take over reconstruction of the trouble-plagued Wollman Memorial Skating Rink in Central Park, to have it open by this winter and to operate it at no profit to himself.

title: For Holocaust Survivors, 40 Years of New Life
description: Forty years ago this month, I was a member of the first group of Holocaust survivors to immigrate to the United States. At first glance, the passengers on the Marine Perch, which reached New York harbor on May 24, 1946, were like any other newcomers to America. We came here seeking freedom and a new life.

title: Democrats May Press For an Inquiry on Pirro
description: Democrats on the Westchester Board of Legislators said they would decide Monday whether to seek formation of a nonpartisan committee to investigate whether Jeanine F. Pirro should continue as an assistant district attorney if she continues to refuse to disclose family business interests.

title: AIR SHUTTLE SERVICE: MORE FLIGHTS, MORE FRILLS
description: In a scramble for passengers, the airline shuttles that link New York with Washington and Boston are making changes this summer that are some of the most extensive since Eastern Airlines began the service in 1961. The changes - and the competition - will intensify on Oct. 1 when Pan Am World Airways adds its own shuttle, making it a four-way race with Eastern, New York Air and People Express Airlines.

title: SMALLEY'S SWITCH HOMERS STOP RED SOX
description: Roy Smalley knocked in four runs with two home runs, including one in a five-run third inning, to lift the Minnesota Twins to a 13-5 victory over the Boston Red Sox tonight.

title:
PATENTS;
Magnetic Particles Vs. Disease
description: DR. ROBERT T. GORDON, a young surgeon and inventor, was granted a patent this week on the use of magnetic particles for the treatment of disease and sterilization of surgical instruments.

title: DISTRIBUTION OF TAX CUTS OULINED IN SENATE PLAN
description: The smallest share of the tax cut proposed by the Senate Finance Committee, in total dollars, will go to people with incomes of $75,000 to $200,000, according to details contained in the completed version of the panel's tax-revision plan that was published today.

title: MEDICARE-GLASER CORP (o) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a pretax charge of $375,000 related to the company's medical information services business. c-After a pretax charge of $295,000 for the closing of a store. d-Net income

title: Sinatra Won't Attend Ceremony on July 6
description: Liberty Weekend, the four-day celebration of the Statue of Liberty centennial, is more than just an event or a series of events.

title: SCREEN: 'DEMONS,' BY BAVA
description: Blame it on Nostradamus. According to somebody in ''Demons,'' the made-for-music-video blood gusher that opened yesterday at United Artists Twin and other theaters, the 16th-century prophesier wrote: ''Demons are instruments of evil.

title: ROSARIO'S TESTS RAISE A CONFLICT
description: That boxing is a mysterious, Byzantine world unto itself was demonstrated again yesterday as reports, denials, charges and countercharges erupted over the health of Edwin Rosario, a former lightweight champion, who is scheduled for a bout in Madison Square Garden in two weeks.

title: Donald J. Gormley, 70, Ex-Art Panel Secretary
description: Donald J. Gormley, the executive secretary of the New York City Art Commission from 1959 to 1979, died Wednesday after suffering a heart attack at his summer home in Elizaville, N.Y. He was 70 years old.

title: SPEC'S MUSIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
RAX RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
